title: Harvard's Black Alumni
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: The Selling of New Jersey, and Its Difficulties
description: The inflatable rabbit robot cruised the aisles at the Hyatt Regency playing an electronic version of ''It's A Small World.''

title: The Maximum Security Adolescent
description: Margaret Talbot's article (Sept. 10) was gripping. As a parent of two teenagers, I found the real-life stories gut-wrenching. How can a civilized society permit the lives of children not yet old enough to drive to be destroyed by a criminal justice system so blindly focused on the deed and not the doer? I support the ''tough on crime'' dogma, but the logic of applying adult sentences to kids under 16 doesn't make sense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEEHAN, JANE C.
description: MEEHAN-Jane C. On September 29, 2000, at age 93. Beloved sister of the late Marion, Jack, Charles and Henry Meehan and Georgette Livingston. Loving aunt of 17 nieces and nephews and 20 grandnieces and nephews. Friends may call at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday, 2-6 PM, with funeral mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th St., Monday, October 2, 10 AM. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: The Silver Lining in Chernobyl's Cloud
description: After reading Matthew Brzezinski's article (Sept. 3), I actually threw the magazine to the floor and uttered a prayer for the Aniskin family. Leonid Aniskin is knowingly sacrificing his life for an apartment, a decent job and a chance for his kid to have a good life. That the Aniskins chose Slavutich knowing the dangers is an index of their economic desperation. This has got to be one of the most God-awful human tragedies in recent memory, and a lesson in political pragmatism run amok in full view of the world community.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: William Mulholland and the Rise of Los Angeles

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERGER, WILLIAM
description: WEINBERGER-William. On September 29, 2000. Beloved husbnd of Ida. Loving father of Barry and the late Dr. David Weinberger. Devoted father-in-law of Linda. Dear brother of Irving. Adoring grandfather of Laura. Service Sunday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Bookend; The Bad Boys of Summer
description: IN 1946, Joe DiMaggio published a book called ''Lucky to Be a Yankee.'' It was a pretty standard baseball autobiography of its time, telling with unfailing modesty the story of DiMaggio's rise from humble roots to stardom. The dedication was indicative of the book's tone. DiMaggio dedicated ''Lucky to Be a Yankee'' to, among others, ''all the ballplayers in both leagues, a clean bunch of fellows and all grand sports.''

title: God, Man and Whale
description: The Collected Poems

title: South Carolina Wrestles With Lottery
description: Last year, the churches and businesses of South Carolina rose up as one to help drive the electric jangle of video poker from the state. But now, as pastors work to rouse their congregants against a proposed state lottery on the November ballot, they are finding a bit less sympathy in the pews and the state's corporate offices.

title: Lesson on How Not to Play A Hypermodern Defense
description: The hypermodern openings that made their debut after World War I stressed holding back the center pawns with the intent of lining up pieces for a concentrated attack to demolish the enemy pawn center, which had been allowed to expand without restraint. But to hold back without a plan to undermine White's center is to invite disaster. Black's position can end up in self-destructive passivity with a cramped formation.

title: E-ZPass Unveiled on New Jersey Turnpike
description: After years of delay, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority introduced the E-ZPass toll collection system at 120 of the turnpike's 344 toll lanes yesterday morning.

title: Online Delivery Sites Finding That Manhattan Can Be a Hard Place to Make It
description: Kozmo.com, which strives to be the 7-Eleven and Blockbuster of online delivery companies, started in Manhattan. Urbanfetch.com, one of its main competitors, has one of the strongest presences in the city. YourGrocer.com, an online supermarket that serves much of the New York region, gained its first footholds in TriBeCa and Greenwich Village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERBER, RUTH
description: FERBER-Ruth. Beloved wife of Dr. Robert. Devoted mother of Dr. Alan and Sandy Ferber and Judith and John Lubrano. Cherished grandmother of Dr. Michael Ferber, Robyn Ferber, Casey Ferber, Rosanna Lubrano and Mikel Lubrano, and great-grandmother of Nadia Lubrano. Graveside services Monday, 1 PM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: An Arms Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: Sept. 24-30; Median Income Tops $40K
description: The Census Bureau reported that median household income rose in 1999 to top $40,000, the fifth consecutive annual increase. The increase was fueled by relatively large increases in household incomes for the poor: 11.8 percent of the population was living below the poverty line, defined as $17,029 for a family of four, the lowest poverty rate since 1979. More than 2.2 million fewer people were considered poor last year, and 81 percent of that decline occurred in inner cities, suggesting that prosperity has begun to trickle down. Steven A. Holmes

title: The Debates Begin
description: The elusive aura of electoral inevitability once possessed by Gov. George W. Bush, and then captured for a time by Vice President Al Gore, has vanished from the presidential race. The latest polls show Mr. Bush ahead, Mr. Gore ahead or a tie. The only things that seem inevitable now are that the Election Day result will be close -- perhaps as narrow as the Kennedy-Nixon race of 1960 and the Ford-Carter race of 1976 -- and the series of presidential debates that begins Tuesday will be pivotal. The swing voters are entering their decision phase.

title: Diane Weathers, Ronald Smothers
description: Diane Marie Weathers and Ronald Smothers were married yesterday at Riverside Church in Manhattan. The Rev. James A. Forbes Jr. performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Californias Freeway to Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Streetscapes/1 Beekman Place; A Rockefeller Co-op and Its 460-Foot-Long Garage
description: FEW people ever noticed the anonymous one-story building running along the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive from 49th to 51st Streets, its southern end at the foot of the majestic co-op at 1 Beekman Place, which was built by the Rockefeller family. Now the unusual structure -- a 460-foot-long garage whose origins reflect a Civil War-era height restriction -- is largely demolished. And the co-op has hired the architects Fox & Fowle, otherwise known for their new Times Square skyscrapers, to rebuild it.

title: Susan LaMontagne, Lawrence LaRose
description: Susan Michele LaMontagne and Lawrence Clifford LaRose were married yesterday in East Hampton, N.Y. The Rev. Paula M. Peterson, an interfaith minister, officiated at East Hampton Point, a restaurant.

title: The Maximum Security Adolescent
description: We tell kids to keep out of gangs, stay away from drugs and then, when they get into trouble, we put them into a society of gangs and drugs. Adults are not rehabilitated in jail; how can a child be? When children really need help, when they need the guidance of an adult, we give them murderers and drug dealers to serve as their guides in the prison system.

title: Riding the Tiger
description: THUNDER FROM

title: Saddam's Bomb
description: The Wal-Mart on Route 3 in Spotsylvania County, Va., about 50 miles south of Washington, is not the sort of place where you would expect even a whiff of Middle Eastern intrigue. Yet one humid morning in August, Khidhir Hamza, once a high-ranking Iraqi nuclear physicist and now a defector, experienced a moment there as chilling as anything out of a Hitchcock movie. As he picked through a stack of shirts, Hamza looked up to see before him two people he knew from Baghdad, the wife and daughter of a senior official on the Iraqi Atomic Energy Commission.

title: Courtney Weaver, Simon Frankel
description: Courtney Weaver, a writer, and Simon James Frankel, a lawyer, were married yesterday at their home in San Francisco. Judge Pierre N. Leval of the United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan, for whom the bridegroom had been a clerk, officiated.

title: The Supreme Court And the Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Location, Location, Commutation
description: ABOUT the time Lisa and Michael Gallo began thinking seriously about starting a family, they also thought about moving to the suburbs from their rental apartment on the Upper West Side. Since both worked for securities firms in Manhattan, they were looking not only for an affordable house in an attractive community but also for a convenient commute.

title: The Clothes That Make The Inmate
description: THINK of jail, and a vivid image comes to mind of surly convicts clad in black-and-white striped uniforms. Yet those distinctive outfits, a staple of Jimmy Cagney movies and Halloween parties, are actually relics of a time that had vanished with the ball and chain.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Into the Tangle of Friendship

title: Low-Wage Jobs Leading Gains In Employment
description: New York City's rebounding economy has produced a record number of jobs, but a new study shows that the number of low-wage jobs, those paying less than $25,000 a year, is growing much faster than the number of middle- or high-wage jobs.

title: At Crucial Point in Race, Lazio Retooling Upstate Strategy
description: The cheers echoed through the ballroom of the Best Western Carriage House Inn here. White ''Lazio 2000'' buttons gleamed from shirts and blouses and, as they always do, those in the crowd laughed at Representative Rick A. Lazio's favorite joke about New York subsidizing Arkansas.

title: In an Apartment Turned Museum, a Dominican Trove
description: Isaias Amaro made his first carnival mask out of a school notebook when he was 5, and from the looks of his living room walls he's been making them ever since. Tomorrow, that living room, the dining room and one bedroom in his first-floor apartment at 507 West 176th Street will cease to exist, replaced by New York City's newest attraction: the Museum of the Dominican Folkloric Carnival.

title: Napster, With a Fee
description: What's up with the emo-alternative band The Get Up Kids (below), charging admission to their Napster-sponsored concert at Rutgers?

title: Suiting Up on Sundays To Play Football for Fun
description: THE contrast is as subtle as a blind-side tackle. When professional football sweeps across the television sets of America every Sunday afternoon during fall and winter, millions of viewers enter a world of not only yards and points but also bucks and megabucks.

title: Oakland Clinches A.L. West
description: OAKLAND, Calif. - Tim Hudson earned his 20th victory and the Oakland Athletics clinched the American League West by beating Texas 3-0 Sunday for their first playoff appearance since 1992.

title: PULSE; A New Beauty Crop
description: It's harvest season, time to reap the beauty products. Cosmetics companies are now using ingredients that conjure up the bucolic simplicity of indulgent rustic getaways. Napa Valley Fragrances makes Cielo, a scent that contains real Napa grape leaves and a northern California shrub called Daphne odora to evoke American wine country. Napa's latest scent, Boheme, $80 for three ounces, lists rosewood, jasmine and honey among its ingredients (both at Aedes de Venustas and Bergdorf Goodman). Aesop, an Australian-based line, packaged in apothecary jars and popular with celebrities, distills virgin olives of northern Tuscany for its new Fabulous Face Cleanser, to relieve dry skin ($35 for a 6.5-ounce bottle at Barneys). Fresh, the Boston-based company, just introduced Rice Formula, Japanese-inspired products made from rice grains. Sold at all Fresh stores, they include a humble rice bran face wash, $35 for 0.6 ounce, and a luxurious sake bath, $75 for 14 ounces, based on the beauty treatments of the geisha. Serve cold or hot. ERICA SCHACTER

title: Deals and Discounts
description: SCOTTISH SPRING -- CIE Tours International wants travelers to look ahead, in this case to the spring in Scotland, with savings of $419 to $439 on one-week escorted trips with air fare. Departures are April 7, 14, 21 and 28, with stops including Loch Lomond, the Isle of Skye, Fort William, Loch Ness, Glasgow and Edinburgh. Rates of $1,455 a person, double occupancy April 7 and 14, $1,475 April 21 and 28 (versus $1,894 in summer), include air fare from New York, Boston or Baltimore and daily breakfast, six dinners, bus and guide, admissions and local taxes. Typical hotels are the Hilton Grosvenor in Glasgow and the Ardoe House in Blairs. Call (800) 243-8687; www.cietours.com.

title: Tree Blocking Sign Could Have Been Saved
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Data Mine, There Is Seldom a Pot of Gold
description: AFTER eight years of publication, one of the investment newsletters that I monitor called it quits over the summer. The newsletter, named Beating the Dow, was one of several that recommend stocks known as the Dogs of the Dow -- those among the Dow Jones industrials that offer the highest yields.

title: Sizing up Children's Museums...Sending In Pint-Size Critics; At a Mall, Digging Dinosaur Facts
description: OUR 2-year-old daughter, Una, has been to malls and to museums, and she thinks she knows the difference. So she was puzzled when we pulled into the parking lot of the South Hills Mall in Poughkeepsie. ''That not a mooseeum,'' she insisted.

title: A Virtual Battlefield Helps Keep Japan Alert
description: During a recent violent rainstorm, about 300 soldiers from Japan's self-defense forces were hastily dispatched to Mount Fuji, where 100 or so heavily armed invaders had seized control of the scenic summit.

title: Sept. 24-30; Everyday Campaign Strategies
description: Vice President Al Gore has invited 13 everyday people to help him bone up for the first presidential debate on Tuesday. Well, not just any everyday people. It just so happens they hail from Michigan, Ohio, Illinois, Florida, Pennsylvania, New Mexico and a few other swing states.

title: Victorian-Era Hospital Edges Toward Life as Luxury Housing
description: The abandoned, chateau-style former Towers Nursing Home, opened as a cancer hospital in the 1880's by John Jacob Astor, has moved closer to becoming part of a luxury apartment complex. But those who are campaigning to put a museum of American medicine in the fortresslike and fire-scarred building have not given up their effort, even against increasingly long odds.

title: California's Freeway to Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: For the First Time in 32 Years, No Gold for American Freestyle Wresters
description: SYDNEY, Oct. 1 - Dan Gable won a gold medal in freestyle wrestling at the 1972 Summer Olympics and coached the United States team to six golds at the 1984 Los Angeles Games.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-01-00: Questions for Charlene Barshefsky; The Negotiator
description: Q: You've conducted trade negotiations all over the world, in places with widely varying social mores. Have any of your counterparts in other countries ever had difficulty accepting a woman as a legitimate government authority?

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A High-Density Project in a High-Tech Area
description: AFTER a long struggle, a 1,000 acre residential development aimed at middle-income workers in nearby high-tech and service companies has begun to emerge within former woodlands three miles east of this major corporate center.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Pakistan Newspaper Inspection Is Seen as Effort at Intimidation
description: Civil libertarians and journalists have reacted angrily and warily to a surprise government inspection of electrical hookups at the headquarters of the Dawn Group of Newspapers, a visit by engineers and armed soldiers presumed to be an effort by the military government to intimidate the press.

title: Brooklyn Journal; The Suits Put Up Dukes Ali's Old Boxing Gym
description: Friday night at the fights usually means rich guys at ringside watching a couple of street toughs battle it out. But once a month at Gleason's Gym in Brooklyn, it's the other way around.

title: California's Freeway to Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  THURMAN, BARRY LEO
description: THURMAN-Barry Leo. Feb. 11, 1956 to Oct. 1, 1987. Time has not diminished my love and respect. Arthur Williams and Friends

title: A Dark Gucci's Sunshine
description: TO Sara Gay Forden, the most compelling character in her new book ''The House of Gucci'' (William Morrow) may well have been the one that got away. Ms. Forden's labyrinthine tale of familial corruption, betrayal and greed in the renowned Italian luxury empire spans the decades from 1921, when Guccio Gucci founded the company, to the present.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILLS, THOMAS A.
description: SILLS-Thomas A. On September 26 at age 86. Beloved husband of the late Jeanne Reynal, a mosaicist. Devoted father of Kenneth and Michael, grandfather of Arvis and Dawn and brother of Anne McMurray. A gifted artist, who was a member of the New York Abstract Expressionist movement and then later in life turned to collage as a medium to create surreal works of unusual power and beauty. Lawrence Campbell wrote in Art News, ''There is a novel and unique strangeness to his work. He flirts with a language which has taken thousands of years to evolve.'' Memorial services Monday evening, 6 PM, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: 2 New Trains in the Subways: Catch Them if You Can
description: The spiffy new subway trains were unveiled to much fanfare in July. By late next year, they are expected to replace the city's oldest fleet of trains, known as the Redbirds, which have been operating since the 1950's.

title: Insiders Unflinching Look at Corsican Rebels
description: GIANNUCCIO, Corsica  The setting is reassuring enough: a weathered stone house near a mountaintop on the island of Corsica, the Mediterranean glistening in the distance. Behind the windows are lace curtains and sepia portraits of grandparents on the wall.

title: What's Entertainment? That Depends ...
description: REMEMBER what fun it was rushing Snowball to the vet after he gulped down a badminton birdie? Hey, you protest, that was not fun. Nevertheless, that's entertainment, according to the United States government.

title: Those Clothes: So Mysterious. So Powerful. So Dark.
description: NEVER mind what you read in Vogue, see traipsing down the runways in Paris or observe on the fashionistas on ''Sex and the City.'' Black remains the perennial favorite color of New York women.

title: Claudia Taylor, Gunnar Overstrom III
description: Claudia Maria Taylor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everard Sinclair Taylor of Vienna, Va., was married yesterday to Gunnar S. Overstrom III, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Overstrom Jr. of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Susannah R. Smith performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. James in New York.

title: On the Paper Mill Stage, It's 'Anything Goes'
description: AT Paper Mill Playhouse, ''Anything Goes'' might as well represent a flippant stage direction, or an arbitrary state of mind. But a focused representation of a musical perennial, it is not.

title: Nora Odendahl, David Searls
description: Dr. Nora Vivian Odendahl and Dr. David Burdette Searls were married yesterday by the Rev. Christine Reed, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at Prospect House, the Princeton University faculty and staff club.

title: Sports of The Times; With a Fourth Gold Medal, Edwards Can Finally Retire the Right Way
description: In the United States' Olympic women's basketball team media guide, there is a team photo from the 1984 Los Angeles Games, where the Americans won all six games and the gold medal. The picture of youth, Teresa Edwards stands in the second row, far left corner, with a hairstyle she doesn't wish to remember and a set of clothing she won't forget.

title: Wide Open and Aggressive
description: Randall Godfrey was a Dallas Cowboys linebacker for the last four seasons, and he played against the Giants twice a year. When Godfrey jumped as a free agent to the Tennessee Titans last Feb. 16, he left behind the National Football Conference Eastern Division and those annual Cowboys-Giants rivalries.

title: Tiverton Smith, Austin McClintock
description: Tiverton Stewart Smith, the daughter of Dr. Judy Reed Smith and Normand F. Smith III of Boston, was married yesterday to Austin Coolidge McClintock, a son of Alexandra Tana Kantor of Alameda, Calif., and Kelly McClintock of Sherborn, Mass. The Rev. Colin Leitch performed the Episcopal ceremony at Keene Valley Congregational Church in Keene Valley, N.Y. The Rev. Van Santvoord Merle-Smith, a Presbyterian minister and grandfather of the bride, took part in the service.

title: Cityscapes by Father and Son
description: THE work of Eddie Earl Cato (1941-1980) and his son, Nicholas Evans-Cato (who was born in 1973) pays homage to the Gowanus Canal and the once-thriving industrial center around it. Mr. Cato studied at Brooklyn College and later worked there; Mr. Evans-Cato was born in Brooklyn and still lives in the borough. Their work is on exhibit at the Prospect Park Tennis House in ''Thirty Years of the Gowanus: Two Generations of Cityscapes.'' (Mr. Evans-Cato's oil ''Palazzo'' is above.) He will also lead a walking tour through locations depicted in the paintings, joined by Dan Wiley, an urban educator, who will discuss the neighborhood's future. The events are presented by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANZ, FRED
description: FLANZ-Fred. The Trustees, Medical Staff and Employees of Jamaica, Brookdale, and Flushing Hospitals extend their sincere condolences to our esteemed colleague, Bruce J. Flanz, Executive Vice President, on the passing of his father, Fred Flanz. Our heartfelt thoughts are with the Flanz family. David P. Rosen, President & CEO

title: Conductors in Hartford, Choirs, Chamber Music and More
description: WHEN the Hartford Symphony takes the stage at the Bushnell this season, the programs may very well produce more than music. One of the eight guest conductors of the subscription programs will likely become the symphony's new music director. Edward Cumming was at the podium last weekend, while Andre Raphel Smith, the assistant conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, arrives Oct. 17 and 18. Other conductors in the series include James Paul, Steven Smith, Leslie Dunner, Derrick Inouye, Enrique Arturo Diemecke and Ransom Wilson. Perhaps, however, the music director will be chosen from conductors coming into town for other parts of the symphony's season: Martin Fischer-Dieskau, in charge of two pops evenings; Peter Sacco and Randall Craig Fleischer, presiding over family matinees; Angel Gil-Ordonez and Joseph Silverstein, leading concerts by the Hartford Symphony Chamber Orchestra. The number to call for a list of programs and guest soloists is (860) 244-2999.

title: Buying Low In High Times
description: THIS year is shaping up as a record for the cruise industry, officials say, with the number of passengers possibly exceeding 7 million, well above the record 5.8 million in 1998. A major reason, according to the cruise industry trade group, the Cruise Lines International Association, is the many low fares this year, which some industry observers have described as ''the best prices since 1980.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURR, ERNESTINE B.
description: DURR-Ernestine B. Died peacefully at home at age 95 on August 24, 2000. Memorial Service at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue at 61st Street, Manhattan, on Saturday, October 14, 2000, at 11:00 A.M. Memorial donations may be made in her name to St. Peter's Lutheran Church of Manhattan, 619 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10022, or to The Wartburg Foundation, Wartburg Place, Mount Vernon, NY 10552.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I was concerned that when I hit the straightaway, my legs were going to say, 'No more, Marion, no more.' They didn't.''

title: A Fond Farewell From Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 1  After the commercial excesses and failures of technology and transportation in Atlanta, the Sydney Games revived the idea that the Olympics can be organized smoothly on a vast scale and that they remain within the reach of ordinary people.

title: A Marketplace of Bulls and Bears Faces a New Bottom Line: Snakes
description: When garter snakes slithered through the lobby of a Wall Street office building early last month, workers were understandably terrified.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCULLOUGH, DONALD F.
description: McCULLOUGH-Donald F. Former Chairman of Collins & Aikman. Died Tuesday, September 26, 2000. He is survived by his wife Louise and children Gregory, Sally, Tracey and Nina Williams. Memorial service will be at the First Congregational Church, 108 Sound Beach Ave., Old Greenwich, CT, Tuesday, October 3, 11 AM. Family requests donations be made to the American Lung Association, 1740 Broadway, NY, NY 10019.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLANDER, PHILIP
description: ENGLANDER - Philip. Beloved husband of Betty, loving and devoted father of Robert and Rita, cherished grandfather of Adam, Alex, Jessica, Hillary and Drew, loving and devoted father-in-law of Nancy and Jeffrey, passed quietly on September 29, 2000. Founder of the Intercollegiate Press in 1935 and Publisher until 1999. His sense of humor and devotion to his family will forever be remembered and treasured.

title: A Traffic Jam at the Wharf
description: IN the Caribbean, cruise lines are seeking new ports as competition grows for space in this prime winter destination. The larger ships, unable to dock in many ports, take another tack, concentrating on the ship itself as the main destination and visiting fewer ports.

title: Melissa McCann, Robert Santangelo
description: Melissa Christina McCann, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William P. McCann of Andover, Mass., was married yesterday to Robert Anthony Santangelo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel P. Santangelo of Garden City, N.Y. The Rev. Fritz Cerullo performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Cecilia in Boston.

title: Le Provocateur
description: Michel Houellebecq's blend of anomie, Stalinism, sexual hedonism, sensory-deprivation and reported homophobia is full of contradictions (Emily Eakin, Sept. 10). His approval of Stalin's murder of anarchists is a case in point. Perhaps ''le provocateur'' should contemplate the meaning of a bullet in the back of the head. Joseph Stalin would have had no problem liquidating Houellebecq's acute case of anomie.

title: Mets Ponder Who Will Pitch Playoffs Game 1
description: Bobby Valentine gathered his coaches together with General Manager Steve Phillips before the start of Friday's game to discuss the composition of the team's postseason roster, figuring who would fill out the final spots of the 25-man roster, how many pitchers they would keep, and perhaps most important, who would be handed the ball to start Game 1 of their National League Divisional Series.

title: A Ruling That's Sure to Roil the Waters
description: A case that seemed like small potatoes -- a court decision preventing the Village of Huntington Bay from restricting the Huntington Yacht Club's plans to add another 14 floating boat slips -- has cast doubt on the validity of decades of decisions by Long Island villages regarding the development of waterfront properties.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Best

title: Gardner Will Carry U.S. Flag at Closing
description: Rulon Gardner, whose victory over Aleksandr Karelin in Greco-Roman wrestling provided one of the biggest upsets of the Sydney Games, will carry the flag for the United States in today's closing ceremony.

title: The Maximum Security Adolescent
description: There is too little discussion of the reasons for juvenile crime and the use of graduated punishment and creative treatment options to address the problem. The successes enjoyed by such strategies never get as much publicity as one graphic and isolated crime. Instead, critical decisions affecting the structure of the juvenile justice system, and the lives of thousands of children with unique treatment needs, have been fueled by Colombine-type incidents and other rare but easily exploited episodes of particularly violent conduct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODGERS, SYLVIA ADLER
description: RODGERS-Sylvia Adler. Devoted mother to Marc, Kenneth and Rand. Adored grandniece to Minnie Cohan. Loving sister to Abner and Howard. Childhood and lifelong friend to Margery Aronstein.

title: For Mets and Giants, Home Field Could Be Key
description: The last time the Mets began a series at Pacific Bell Park, Bill Pulsipher was their starting pitcher, Rickey Henderson was the controversy of the moment and the San Francisco Giants were hopeless at their new home.

title: Bryn Williams, Drew Fox
description: Bryn Blair Williams, a daughter of Marlie R. McRoberts of Lexington, Ky., and Stephen G. Williams of Berwyn, Pa., was married yesterday to Drew Dickinson Fox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reeder R. Fox of Ardmore, Pa. The Rev. Georgia A. Snell, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE DAY LAID ON THE ALTAR By Adria Bernardi. Middlebury College/University Press of New England, $24.95.

title: Togetherness in Music
description: The concerto takes its name from a word meaning together, as, in concert. In most concertos, togetherness is furnished by a soloist with an orchestra, whose combined artistry makes or breaks the performance. But togetherness in Beethoven's Triple Concerto involves not one soloist but three. The solo trio for this concerto, with which the Westfield Symphony Orchestra opens its 10th season Saturday, was chosen from the roster of the Arbor Chamber Music Society, based in Summit.

title: The Phantom of the Pension Fund
description: PAUL J. FROMMERT, 61, works for Xerox as a quality and safety manager in Webster, N.Y. He has been with the company for 36 years. His retirement account is worth about $1 million and should provide him with a retirement income of about $5,000 a month.

title: Consultants Say Olympics Will Add $3.6 Billion to Australias Gross Domestic Product
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 28 -- They call Australia the lucky country, and there may be no better example of its good fortune than the unexpected windfall Sydney is reaping at the end of these Olympics.

title: Americans Win the Gold By Beating an Upstart
description: One by one, the options kept fading for Lauren Jackson. Worn down on the inside, barely able to get free on the perimeter, Jackson, the young star of the Australian team, resorted to the only move she had left against the Americans, a move straight out of a heated schoolyard:

title: Seafaring Smuggler Awaits His Freedom
description: The first time that Amir Humuntal Lumban Tobing, an Indonesian mariner, was washed up into the American legal system, it was in a wave of international notoriety.

title: Britain Rethinks Costly Millennium Projects
description: THINK of Britain's ambitious Millennium projects and the tendency is to focus on the ill-fated Dome, the inverted-wok edifice at Greenwich that provided so little bang for its billion-plus public bucks.

title: Feng Shui and Swing for the Not-Busy-Enough
description: SOME people just can't get enough of school, no matter how old they are.

title: Americans Come From Behind to Win Sailing Medals
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 1 -- On Saturday afternoon, as the gun fired to begin the final, deciding race in the Star-boat class in the Olympic sailing regatta, the United States skipper Mark Reynolds crossed the starting line too early, a victim of his own aggressiveness.

title: Access to Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Is 7 Train Good or Bad? It Depends on the Measure
description: To the Editor:

title: Minnesota Welcomes Wild as a Prodigal Son
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 30  Seven years after the North Stars left the state where kids grow up on skates and a hockey pickup game can be found on every corner, Minnesota finally has a National Hockey League team to call its own again.

title: Where to Get Information
description: ABERCROMBIE & KENT INTERNATIONAL, 1520 Kensington Road, Suite 212, Oak Brook, Ill. 60523; (800) 323-7308, fax (630) 954-3324; Web site: www.abercrombiekent.com

title: IN BRIEF; Great Neck Residents Backing Tax Increase
description: More than 500 Great Neck residents crammed into Great Neck House on Tuesday evening to testify publicly that they are willing to pay an increase in taxes to extend the shoreline of Steppingstone Park in the Village of Kings Point.

title: Expanding Debt Relief
description: Debt relief for the world's poorest nations is an idea with moral urgency and strong bipartisan support. People in these countries, most of which are in Africa, suffer needlessly because their governments use 40 percent or more of their national budgets for interest on a foreign debt that will never be repaid. This leaves little for pressing social needs, including improved health care, and better schools and universities. The Clinton administration and most members of Congress back a program to forgive the debts of impoverished nations that can show they have sensible economic policies and will use the money to help their poor citizens. Uganda has used its debt relief to reduce school fees. Mozambique is planning to stock health clinics with badly needed medicines.

title: Article 2000100190011859082 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Finding Freedom in Free-Form Rock
description: TRANS AM: 'RED LINE'

title: Telling America's Story Through America's Music
description: WHEN the documentary filmmaker Ken Burns announced his plans for a series on jazz, Matt Glaser, a violinist who had played on the soundtracks of Mr. Burn's ''Civil War'' and ''Baseball,'' started pestering him about being included in the new film. Mr. Burns ignored him. Mr. Glaser insisted. Finally he came to Mr. Burns's apartment one night and pressured him into hearing his spiel about one of Louis Armstrong's recordings of ''Lazy River.''

title: Strike Fears Grip Hollywood As Unions Flex New Muscle
description: For decades Hollywood was a town run by a few moguls. Films were churned out like autos on an assembly line. Labor negotiations in the 1930's and 1940's were often resolved through the strong-arm tactics of dynastic studios. By the 1960's, with the power of studios ebbing, the unions and film studios as well as television networks placed labor negotiations in the hands of the town's top broker, Lew R. Wasserman, then the chairman of MCA Inc.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about complaints by AIDS patients about poor service at the Bronx office of the Division of AIDS Services and Income Support, an agency that has been placed under federal oversight, misidentified the neighborhood where the Bronx AIDS center is located. The center, known as the Kingsbridge Office, is at 260 East 161st Street in the Concourse Village section of the Bronx. It is not in the Kingsbridge section.

title: Kate Mattingly, Clayton Moran
description: Kate George Mattingly, a daughter of Catherine S. Mattingly and George E. Mattingly of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Clayton Frederick Moran, a son of Kate J. Moran of New York and Frederick A. Moran of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. James J. Greenfield performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Washington.

title: Nemesis
description: The Avengers

title: Sizing up Children's Museums...Sending In Pint-Size Critics; Where Low Tech Gets a High-Five
description: ADULTS impressed by space-age gadgetry might expect the most popular draw at a children's museum to be the computer-based attractions. But for children, low-tech can be way cool.

title: Texas Resort Combines Work and Play
description: Westin Hotels and Resorts' latest property is made for mixing business and pleasure. The Westin Stonebriar Resort in Frisco, Tex., which opened Sept. 5 just north of Dallas, is what the company calls an ''urban resort,'' offering modern business facilities and country club amenities -- most notably a golf course by the designer Tom Fazio, scheduled to open Nov. 1.

title: The Goldman Sachs Bunch: Where the Women Went
description: It is called 85 Broads. It is a networking group, created by women who worked at Goldman Sachs and named for its address.

title: Residents Seethe at Big Rigs Idling Near Busy Highways
description: The intersection where the Cross Bronx Expressway meets the Bronx River Parkway has never been free of noise, traffic or pollution. But in the last six months, residents of the Bronx River section of the Bronx, which is ringed by these two big highways, have realized just how unpleasant life can be when trucks idle for hours along residential streets.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last week about the military service of United States presidents included an incomplete list of those who served as officers. James Monroe was a lieutenant colonel under George Washington, John Tyler a captain in the Virginia militia, and Jimmy Carter a lieutenant in the Navy. Millard Fillmore served as a major in the New York Home Guard during the Civil War, but only after he left the presidency.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 1, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Lara Spencer, David Haffenreffer
description: Lara Spencer, a television reporter, and David Huffard Haffenreffer Jr., a television news anchor, were married yesterday in Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Peter M. Larsen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Dune Church.

title: Stony Brook Museum Changing Name
description: The Museums at Stony Brook said last week it was changing its name to more clearly identify collections and programs, and would now be known as the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages.

title: The Nation; Breaking All the News That's Fit to Frighten
description: WHEN child advocates and entertainment industry lobbyists met in 1997 to devise a television ratings system that would include ''V'' for violence and ''S'' for sexual content, one category of programming was notably exempt: the news. So too this campaign season.

title: The Goldman Sachs Bunch: Where the Women Went
description: It is called 85 Broads. It is a networking group, created by women who worked at Goldman Sachs and named for its address.

title: Hanging a Portrait of Welles In a 'Citizen Kane' Frame
description: JUST before Orson Welles died, as the scene is presented in ''War of the Worlds,'' a new biographical drama that opens the Next Wave festival on Wednesday in the Harvey Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, he uttered a last word that could be taken as the key to his whole personality.

title: A Star Mezzo Role Finds a Mezzo Star to Sing It
description: THE American mezzo-soprano Susan Graham has for the better part of a decade impressed audiences with her creamy singing and chiseled characterizations, sharing the stage with stars like Renee Fleming, Thomas Hampson and Dawn Upshaw, and consistently earning reviews as strong as theirs. In December, Ms. Graham gained new prominence in John Harbison's ''Great Gatsby'' at the Metropolitan Opera. Now she is ready for her close-up, at the center of another new work, Jake Heggie's ''Dead Man Walking,'' which opens on Saturday at the San Francisco Opera.

title: Serbian Opposition Says Strike Will Close Belgrade on Monday
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Oct. 1 -- Pressing a strategy of legal challenges and popular pressure to get President Slobodan Milosevic to concede that he lost last weekend's elections, Serbia's opposition vowed to shut Belgrade and the country down on Monday in what would be the first general strike in this country since World War II.

title: Offering Chinese With a Korean Twist
description: DORY is different and difficult to decipher. Call this new Asian restaurant at 1087 Jericho Turnpike in Commack (631-543-6790) and you will be told it serves Korean-style Chinese food, yet the sign out front identifies it as a ''Chinese restaurant'' and the menu given to me listed only Chinese golden oldies like egg rolls, won-ton soup, lo mein, fried rice and moo goo gai pan. Our waiter (who like the rest of the staff was long on hospitality but short on English) said Dory serves Chinese-American and Chinese-Korean dishes. When I said, ''would you please point to a Chinese-Korean dish on my menu,'' he reached for my wife's instead. So there are actually two different menus. No one told us that, nor does either menu have a heading (the gold covers are Chinese-American, and blue covers are Chinese-Korean). Order from the latter; that's what was done by the large family groups of Koreans, happily engaged over their bowls of noodles, rice and soup. Anyway, why order standard Chinese preparations at a place that specializes in Korean-style creations?

title: A New Port of Call, in Panama
description: LIKE children with their noses pressed up against a candy-store window, Panamanian tourism officials had watched with longing and frustration as cruise ships full of tourists glided tantalizingly through the canal on their way to the Caribbean or South America. But starting this month, vacationers who would have seen Panama only from a ship's railing finally will be able to go ashore when Panama inaugurates Colon 2000, a $45 million cruise ship port on the Caribbean entrance to the legendary canal.

title: Death Toll Rises in Mideast, Dimming Prospects for Peace
description: JERUSALEM -- Rock-throwing Palestinians battled Israeli troops for a fourth day, striking Arabs shut down shops and schools, and leaders on both sides traded recriminations Sunday amid the worst surge of violence in four years.

title: Article 2000100191678949334 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Beyond the Finish Line, Where Should Fans Gather?
description: Come the first Sunday in November, the New York City Marathon will funnel some 30,000 runners over the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, through 26 miles of city streets and into Central Park near the Sheep Meadow. Draped in silvery blankets, these runners will then spill out of the park and find their friends and families waiting at the reunion area, which will be situated a stretch of Central Park West from 74th to 85th Streets.

title: Take That, Catwoman
description: Anya Hindmarch, a British designer, has taken a cue from 1960's television for a line of Pop Art-style accessories that any Batgirl would kill for. Her ''Whaam! Boom! Kpow!'' collection of sequined handbags, $580, and Jimmy Choo for Anya Hindmarch mules, $660, right, explodes with the comic-book-style exclamations of the era's ''Batman'' series. ''My younger brother was obsessed with the show, and I was forced to watch it,'' Ms. Hindmarch said last Tuesday from London. The designer, 32, said the kitschy combination of vibrant color and groovy graphics are chic because ''fashion is quite whimsical at the moment.''

title: A Fishing Skeptic Who Took the Bait
description: FISHING, I recently discovered, is about more than, well, fishing. Of course, seasoned fishermen know this, but my experience with a rod can be counted on as many fingers as a trout has.

title: Lara Schmidt, Remy Trafelet
description: Lara Elizabeth Schmidt and Remy White Trafelet were married yesterday by the Rev. Richard A. Burnett at Trinity Episcopal Church in Columbus, Ohio.

title: A Suggestion Box For United Airlines
description: To the Editor:

title: The Perfect Intermission
description: You've cherry-picked surprisingly low-priced Burgundies at an Acker Merrall & Condit auction. Wine is about sharing, so you've invited novices and aficionados to sample a dozen; after an hour, the bottles will hop to the dinner table. But frustration lies ahead: Your guests will find successive wines harder to appreciate as tannins, acidity and alcohol accumulate on their palates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HOWARD
description: COHEN-Howard. Age 75, of Somers, NY, formerly of Bayside, NY. Beloved husband of Ellin. Loving father of Stuart and Gail, Barry and Irene and Susan and Michael Schapiro. Adored grandfather of Jamie, Evan, Tyler, Colby, Jason and Michelle. Brother of Shirley Riback. Funeral service at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, Monday, 12:30 PM. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery in Emerson, NJ.

title: A Suggestion Box For United Airlines
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Lucky Gourd Shop By Joanna Catherine Scott. MacMurray & Beck, $25.

title: Surcharge on Fuel Raises Air Fares in U.S.
description: Domestic round-trip air fares rose $20 in early September when all of the major airlines except Southwest imposed a surcharge that the industry said is necessary to offset the recent increase in the price of jet fuel.

title: Bluestocking Blues
description: According to your article, polls show that white women favor Hillary Clinton's opponent by 5 percentage points. Clinton mishandled health care reform and has been linked to illegal activities involving Whitewater land deals. Could it be that white women are less concerned about sexual politics than Clinton's record? I, for one, would not vote for a man or a woman who had bungled major policy reform or had been investigated for illicit activities.

title: The Favorite Word In His Vocabulary Is Undermine
description: ARTISTS all over the world, in the late 1950's and early 1960's, began scouring the streets and newsstands of Tokyo, Dusseldorf, Paris, Moscow, New York and San Francisco for junk materials or pop motifs. Everything that the stringent rules of Modernism had pronounced unworthy of artmaking seemed newly alluring: comic books, trash, an old quilt, a tarnished spoon, a stuffed goat, words on a page. Artists and critics called this work anti-art, Fluxus, neo-Dada, Beat, Nouveau Realisme, Gutai. The artists' aim was to sabotage any accepted definition of art and vandalize its boundaries. As Robert Rauschenberg once put it, they wanted to work in the gap between art and life.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN; San Juan
description: With the elections Nov. 7, it is not surprising that the question on most Sanjuaneros' minds is who is going to be the next governor. Given the emotional campaign issues, such as corruption in public agencies and the United States Navy's possible withdrawal from the island of Vieques, some of the recent transformations in this capital city have been barely noticed, it seems. There is construction everywhere. The biggest projects include a new coliseum and a light rail system.

title: Ammann Provides a Lift, and His Teammates Are Grateful for It
description: Mike Ammann stood in front of his locker after the MetroStars' 2-0 victory over the Chicago Fire tonight and faced a crowd that was larger and closer than anything he had seen in front of the goal during the game. Walking past, defender Mike Petke laughed and said, ''Now, Ammann comes back and he's the savior.'' He walked a few more steps and turned back, nodding and acknowledging, ''Yeah, he is.''

title: Just Click on a Name
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Widens Investigation Into Debate Leak
description: Officials with the Bush campaign said today that they did not believe that an employee of the campaign's advertising firm, who has drawn the attention of F.B.I. investigators, was involved in sending confidential debate-preparation materials to the Gore campaign.

description: Weeks

title: Generation Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RICH, BENJAMIN
description: RICH-Benjamin. 9/30/90. Dad, it has been 10 years since you left us. Your sons will always keep you in their hearts. Evan and Dan

title: Ethiopia Establishes Tradition in Mens Marathons
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 1 - With winds gusting to 40 miles an hour, Gezahgne Abera of Ethiopia tucked into a pack of 10 runners on the Olympic marathon course. At 10 1/2 miles, though, his feet became tangled and he fell down, scraping his knee and shoulder.

title: INSIDE
description: Dream Team Wins Gold; Jones Adds Two Medals

title: Tempus Fudge It
description: Deadlines are estimable things. For one, they are a universally respected excuse for brusqueness in dismissing distractions: ''Sorry, can't talk now. I'm on a deadline.'' For another, the visceral fear of missing a deadline motivates so powerfully that many people in high-pressure occupations say they have trouble accomplishing much without one. And where would Americans be without April 15?

title: They Talk, but What Are They Saying?
description: We stand on the threshold of a new century big with the fate of many nations. It rests with us now to decide whether in the opening years of that century we shall march forward to fresh triumphs, or whether at the outset we shall cripple ourselves for the contest. Is America a weakling, to shrink from the work of the great world-powers? No. The young giant of the West stands on a continent and clasps the crest of an ocean in either hand. . . .''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTUW, GLADYS (NEE KALMAN)
description: OSTUW-Gladys (nee Kalman). On September 16, 2000 in Hollywood, FL. Formerly of Woodmere, N.Y. Devoted wife of the late Jack Ostuw. Loved and respected by her son and daughterin-law, Richard and Lois, her sister and brother-in-law, Shirley and David Chernow and her friends. Her love of the arts led to her participation in the Five Towns Music and Art Foundation. She was in at the inception of the organization, served as Vice President, Secretary and Treasurer for many years. She will be remembered for her many attributes, her sense of humor and especially her integrity.

title: Israel Seeks to Uncover Fate Of 11 Jews Lost Fleeing Iran
description: In her immaculate apartment here, Farahnaz Rabizade, an Iranian immigrant, was tempted to set an extra place at the Rosh Hashana table for her missing husband. But she did not let herself be that maudlin, she said, because she did not want to upset her children, who have been waiting four years for their father to show up in Israel for the Jewish New Year.

title: Sizing up Children's Museums...Sending In Pint-Size Critics; An Invitation: 'Do Touch, Please'
description: BEFORE you enter the Garden State Discovery Museum in Cherry Hill, there is no need to give a stern lecture about how this building is full of items that are just to look at and not to touch. Here, you are invited and encouraged to look, touch, pick up and play.

title: EXPEDITING PERMITS
description: Developers who want to build in already populated areas will have their building permits fast-tracked by the state Department of Environmental Protection, Governor Whitman said last week. The new rules, which should be in place by the beginning of next year, are aimed at supporting the State Plan, which directs development into urban centers and away from open spaces. Karen DeMasters

title: For the Cheney Family, the Motto Is 'All for One'
description: As campaign props, political spouses and children have long held a place somewhere beside red, white and blue bunting, yard signs, buttons and balloons. But this year, perhaps more than most, presidential politics has become a family affair.

title: Sept. 24-30; Deal on Food Sales to Cuba
description: After months of bitter negotiations that pitted the American farm lobby against enemies of President Fidel Castro of Cuba, Congressional Republicans agreed to allow the sale of food products to Cuba. The deal, which was brokered by Representative Roy D. Blunt, Republican of Missouri, would allow Cuba to buy American grains, pork and other products by paying cash or arranging financing through a third country. In a nod to Mr. Castro's critics, however, the arrangement ruled out American financing for such purchases, and Cuban products will not be sold in the United States. Christopher Marquis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEER, LAURA H
description: BEER-Laura H. Died September 22, 2000. She lived a mindful, simple life in the West Village. She was a social worker who respected the wisdom of her clients, a gospel chorus member who offered her voice joyfully with her peers, a mother who loved and dazzled her children and a citizen with a daily commitment to living ethically and lovingly as a member of her community. She loved scholarship that affected people's lives, nature that was available to everyone and grassroots political efforts. She is survived by her children Elizabeth and Andrew, their spouses Kevin and Eleanor, her grandchildren Nuala, Orla, Tea and India and many loving friends and extended family. We are left poorer from her loss, but are grateful to have loved her mind, humor, gaze, gestures, generosity and courage while she was here. She moved us all in gentle and radical ways and we will miss her every day. A memorial will be held Wednesday, October 4, at The Boat House in Central Park at 9:30 AM.

title: Article 2000100191141093962 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Made for Each Other
description: Zoboo the leaping lemur, above, and the Kratt Brothers discover that plants and trees are living things, too, on the season premiere of ''Zoboomafoo'' (Tuesday at 3:30 p.m. on Channel 13)

title: Footnotes
description: 1. More than just paintings, Delia Brown's artwork is a modern happening. After setting up a scene, she has it photographed paparazzi-style and then renders the glamorous sequence of events in watercolors. Neither brush nor camera shy, Brown always includes herself in the picture -- a task made infinitely easier with Nikon's new Coolpix 990 digital camera with remote self-timer. ($999.95 at Alkit Pro Camera). Satisfying the same itch is Givenchy's new Miroir lipstick, with a mirror embedded in the tube. ($21 at Sephora.)

title: Playoff Scenarios Pointing Due West
description: The Yankees' players had many questions for reporters today, asking for help in sorting out the many playoff possibilities. Finally, one player asked another: ''So, let me get this straight. Where do we go if the Bengals win?''

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Lives; Enlightenment Thinking
description: It was the ultimate acid flashback, courtesy of that modern route to the promised land -- the Internet.

title: Word for Word/Test-Marketing R-Rated Films; Hey, Kids, Wasn't That Cool When The Robot Rips the Guy's Arms Off?
description: IF it's possible to buff tinsel, the nation's top movie studios tried gamely to polish Hollywood's tarnished image last week.

title: Bluestocking Blues
description: I am often dumbfounded that intelligent women can begin a conversation by lamenting the lack of female representatives in government and then conclude it with a catty comment about Hillary's hair, home or husband that serves to dismiss her. It is distressing that this treatment of powerful women hasn't changed in over 100 years, as Shulevitz demonstrates in her comparison of Hillary to the bluestocking, Henrietta Stackpole.

title: 12 Again, Learning Hebrew
description: DAVID HAYS, founder of the Theater of the Deaf, set designer for 30 Balanchine ballets and 40 Broadways plays and musicals, intrepid Dad who took his son sailing around Cape Horn in a fearsomely small boat, then wrote about it in ''My Old Man and The Sea,'' has a new book out on Thursday, called ''Today I Am A Boy'' (Simon & Schuster).

title: LAB ADMITS GAS FRAUD
description: A Linden testing lab agreed last week in federal court to pay $1 million in fines for releasing substandard fuel to gasoline dealers in the tri-state area. Three company supervisors pleaded guilty to fraud and conspiracy charges and face possible fines and jail time. By forging documents, Caleb Brett USA Inc. permitted nearly 300 million gallons of fuel that did not meet the Environmental Protection Agency's pollution standards to be sold throughout the tristate area, according to the Environment and Natural Resources division of the Justice Department. John Holl

title: Still Seeking Justice In a Brother's Death
description: Dolly Filartiga's days of medical training are long behind her. She was studying to be a doctor in Paraguay in 1976 when her brother Joelito, 17, was tortured and killed because their father opposed the repressive government. Ms. Filartiga dropped her studies to seek reprisal. Today, living in Forest Hills, Queens, she said full justice continued to elude her.

title: Jones Math: Endurance Plus Speed Equals No. 5
description: They were not all gold, as she had hoped, but Marion Jones became the first woman to win five medals in track and field in the same Olympics today. The measure of her greatness as a sprinter was most evident by her withering speed and endurance in the 400 meters, a race she hardly ever runs.

title: CONFEDERATE FLAG BANNED
description: Students at Warren Hills Regional High School will be prohibited from wearing the Confederate flag on their clothing starting this week, Superintendent of Schools Peter Merluzzi said last week. Several recent bias-related incidents, including distributing racial jokes and waving the flag in hallways, have changed the flag from decoration to a symbol of prejudice, Mr. Merluzzi said. Because of that, he said, the school district attorney has determined the flag can be banned. Karen DeMasters

title: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
description: August 25, 2000 Go to article

title: Remembering a Boarding School for Black Students
description: The former campus of the Bordentown Manual and Training School, a residential school for black high school students in Burlington County, is now owned by the state. Some of the buildings, dating to 1886 when the school was founded, are used by the Department of Corrections to house juvenile offenders, but most are vacant and sinking into disrepair. The current condition of the school belies the impact it had on black education in New Jersey and beyond. Thomas C. Guy Jr., who has made a number of documentaries on black history topics, talked about a video documentary he is making about the Bordentown school. He is still searching for people with connections to it; he can be reached at tcgjr@aol.com

title: Some Movies You Won't Find at the Multiplex
description: THE New Jersey Film Festival at the Rutgers University Co-op/New Jersey Media Arts Center certainly is not lacking for themes. There will be French classics like Godard's ''Alphaville'' and new French releases like ''Beau Travaille'' based on Melville's ''Billy Budd.'' There will also be films with Jewish themes, films with gay themes, films from Iran and of course, films from American independents including a retrospective of the work of the experimental filmmaker Bruce Baillie.

title: If Notre Dame Is in the Game, Expect the Score to Be Close
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 30  Two plays from being undefeated, one from being 1-3. Notre Dame is disappointed and relieved to be 2-2 after starting the season against four Top 25 teams.

title: The Lasting Allure Of 'All About Eve'
description: FIFTY years ago this month, the movie ''All About Eve,'' starring Bette Davis as Margo Channing -- a quintessential actress, both celebrated and temperamental -- opened at the Roxy in New York and became an instant classic. The film won six Academy Awards, including two for Joseph L. Mankiewicz, as screenwriter and director (the same prizes he had won the previous year for ''A Letter to Three Wives'').

title: Home Loss For Rutgers Is Worst Since 1888
description: Miami limbered up for its game against Florida State by squashing Rutgers tonight, 64-6. Amazingly, the Hurricanes said they used a basic game plan but still got valuable contact work by gleefully mobbing each other in the end zone after each touchdown.

title: Crow's-nests at home
description: To avoid getting stuck on the wrong ship, it pays to do some online research before booking a cruise. The cruise lines' own sites offer plenty of information about their own products -- you've got to love the live-from-the-bridge feeds at the Princess Cruises site (www .princess.com) -- but for impartial reviews from both experts and the public, you need to go elsewhere.

title: Lori Flanagan, James Vincent
description: Lori Aeryn Flanagan, the daughter of Gloria and Edward W. Flanagan Sr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to James Burton Vincent, a son of Sue Vincent and Dr. Joseph Vincent of Santa Barbara, Calif. The Rev. John Vigilanti performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALLEE, SUZANNE D.
description: SALLEE-Suzanne D. 92 years old, Lake Worth, FL died Monday, September 25 at her residence. Born in New York City, former resident of Cold Spring Harbor, NY graduated from Rosemary Hall, and attended Bennett Jr. College where she later served on the Board of Trustees. Mrs. Sallee and her husband, George, retired to Key Biscayne, FL in 1967. He died in 1985 shortly after their 50th wedding anniversary. Mrs. Sallee moved to West Palm Beach, FL in 1989. She is survived by her son, John C. Sallee of Manila, the Phillippines; her daughter, Mrs. Clifford Slater of Pacific Palisades, CA; and her five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, October 3, at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the Sea, Palm Beach, FL. Graveside service Thursday at the Memorial Cemetery of St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the Alzheimer's Association, Greater Palm Beach Area Chapter, Inc., 1325 S. Congress Ave., Suite 203, Boynton Beach, FL 33426.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGASHIMA, HIDEO, M.D.
description: NAGASHIMA-Hideo, M.D. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center and the entire Montefiore community are deeply saddened by the death of Hideo Nagashima, M.D. An esteemed member of our Department of Anesthesiology for more than 4 decades and director of Anesthesiology Research, Dr. Nagashima was highly regarded as a pioneer in the use of anesthesia during open heart surgery. A revered teacher, he founded a fellowship program which for 30 years trained many of the leaders of academic and anethesiology in Japan. Dr. Nagashima will be remembered by his colleagues, students, patients and friends as a man of warmth and grace who fulfilled the highest tenets of medicine. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Sachiko; his sons, Robert, Hidalgo and Richard, his grandchildren and entire family. Spencer Foreman, M.D., President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Respect for Buckeyes Might Take a While
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 30  Ohio State is doing its best to prove a point: forget about last year.

title: Poet and Favorite Son
description: A birthday bash in in honor of Wallace Stevens, a favorite son, poet and insurance executive of his adopted hometown of Hartford, will feature a talk by Richard Howard, Pulitzer Prize-winning poet, critic and translator. His subject will be ''Even in Paris: Wallace Stevens and French Culture.''

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE best-known exchange in DINNER AT EIGHT (1933) is between Marie Dressler, as a grand stage actress of an advanced age, and Jean Harlow, as a plantinum blond bimbo in a backless dress. Harlow has read recently that ''machinery is going to take the place of every profession.'' Dressler quickly replies, ''Oh, my dear, that's something you need never worry about.'' The scene comes at the end of the film, but there's a lot of wonderful business leading up to it. Based on Edna Ferber and George S. Kaufman's play and directed by George Cukor, the movie merited major star power, including two Barrymores (John and Lionel), Wallace Beery as a nouveau riche opportunist and Billie Burke (with her Glinda the Good Witch trill put to good use) as the panicked Park Avenue hostess. For her, the evening is a disaster; for moviegoers, it's old Hollywood at its comic-drama best - Sunday at 6 p.m. on TCM.

title: Sandra Mancini, Peter Yu
description: Sandra Katherine Mancini and Peter Michael Yu were married yesterday at the Episcopal Chapel of the Transfiguration in Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming. The Rev. Lynn Wright, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Carl Beavers, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: FORDLANDIA

title: The Autumn Run in Montauk Has Begun
description: Bang!

title: Kate Barzun, Bryan Adams
description: Helen Kathleen Barzun, a daughter of Dr. Kathleen and Dr. James Barzun of Harvard, Mass., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Bryan George Adams, a son of the Rev. Hope Eakins of Essex, Conn., and Daniel N. Adams Jr. of West Redding, Conn. The Rev. William Eakins, who is the bridegroom's stepfather and the rector of Trinity Episcopal Church in Hartford, performed the ceremony.

title: Gino's Spirits Continues Winning Ways
description: The program at Belmont Park said it simply: ''Fictitious. Chestnut filly, 4 years old, owned by Her Majesty the Queen.''

title: Lazio's Campaign Coffer Surpasses Mrs. Clinton's
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio has surpassed Hillary Rodham Clinton in fund-raising, according to unofficial figures released by the campaigns today, a feat accomplished after just four months as the Republican Senate nominee and as the camps enter the crucial last month of the race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINN, ELEANORE
description: ZINN-Eleanore. 87, beloved wife of the late Oscar Zinn, passed away peacefully September 28, 2000. She gracefully devoted her life and love to her family and to the honoring of Jewish traditions in the home. She is the cherished mother of Victor and Douglas Zinn and the late Harold and Richard Zinn; and the dear sister of David Forrest and Shirley Wilburne. She is also survived by grandchildren Adam, Omar, Joshua, Eric and Melissa Zinn and great-grandchild Jacob Zinn. Services will be held at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 Station Plaza North, Great Neck, NY on Monday, October 2, 2000 at 12:30 P.M.

title: The Maximum Security Adolescent
description: Children and adolescents possess neither a constituency nor political power, and it shows. Far too many live in poverty and many more receive inadequate and substandard educations. Now this vulnerable population has been forsaken by the criminal justice system, in a bow to political expediency, to appear tough on crime. It is a crime (or should be) to throw away the opportunity to reclaim these young people by locking them up in adult prisons and throwing away the key.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWINBURNE, JOHN KNOWLES
description: SWINBURNE-John Knowles. The Long Island Plastic Surgical Group is deeply saddened by the passing of John Knowles Swinburne, M.D. This gifted and dedicated individual lost his valiant battle against cancer on September 26. His creativity and ability to see complex problems from a fresh and novel vantage point will be sorely missed. His gentleness and seemingly unbounded patience will always be remembered and cherished by his patients. His partners, colleagues, friends and family mourn the loss of his graciousness and gentility, and will always hold fond the memories of their own special times with him. He found beauty in life's simple pleasures and taught this truism to any who listened. He has slipped from earth's surly bonds and touched the lips of God. We will miss you, John.

title: The Nation; What Uncle Sam Needs Now Is a Few Good Page-Turners
description: ALTHOUGH members of the United States military are barred from partisan political activity, holding and sharing opinions on issues that affect them directly is another matter. If you know where to look, you can get a pretty good idea how officers feel about overseas commitments, military spending and their civilian masters. It's available in the military reading lists.

title: Not a Machiavellian
description: To the Editor:

title: From a Web Site, A Way to Measure Risk
description: By conventional measures, the Red Oak Technology Select fund has been one of the best performers this year, ranked 12th by Lipper among all funds as of early September. But when one examines the risk that its managers took, Red Oak's position was a less-stellar 27th. By contrast, Fidelity Select Natural Gas ranked 10th by the usual yardstick but did better when adjusted for its risk, rising to 6th.

title: A Younger Audience Goes to the Symphony
description: MAYBE the orchestra members are wearing color-coded T-shirts so one can tell the strings from the woodwinds. Or maybe the program opens with an opportunity for the audience a chance to try out different instruments. The concert is short and sweet: nobody has to be persuaded to come back after intermission because there isn't one.

title: When They Ask for a Raise, Show Them This, and Laugh
description: Members of Congress write the darndest bills.

title: Off the Rez
description: THE HEARTSONG

title: In the Region/Long Island; KeySpan Ponders the Future of 500 Riverhead Acres
description: KEYSPAN ENERGY, the giant gas and electric concern formed two years ago by the merger of Brooklyn Union Gas and the Long Island Lighting Company, is preparing to divest itself of more than 500 acres of farmland, woods and Long Island Sound shorefront in the Town of Riverhead, potentially with an eye toward preservation, its officials said.

title: Holiday Poinsettia
description: If you saved last year's poinsettia and expect the bracts to develop color for the holidays, give it 14 hours of darkness and 10 hours of bright light every day. That means put it in a dark closet for 14 hours and do not open the door or turn on the closet light.

title: Giants Hoping to Stay Home
description: PHOENIX, Sept. 30  The San Francisco Giants moved one step closer to clinching home field advantage in the playoffs, something their manager thinks can help make them champions.

title: The Producer
description: ''If you had told me a year ago that I would own not one, but two pairs of blue jeans with gold sparkles on them, I would've said you were crazy,'' said Jane Long, who moved last winter from New York to Los Angeles, to be a producer for Radical Media, a multimedia production company. Still, Ms. Long said, ''the L.A. mentality of dressing like Barbie is pretty fun. You can't be too serious about your clothes out here, when half the people you meet are wearing board shorts.''

title: Greene Says It Again: He's Sorry
description: A day after a preening celebration of his team's victory in the 4x100-meter relay race, Maurice Greene of the United States acknowledged today that he had received some negative reaction to the display and reiterated an apology he had first issued after the race.

title: Beyond the Ubiquitous Three Ground Covers
description: SOMETIMES the simplest answer for a difficult area is ground cover.

title: Photographic Evidence
description: AN EMPIRE OF WOMEN

title: Line Is Disconnected on the Bus
description: Nearly every commuter has a favorite cell phone story.

title: Sept. 24-30; Denmark Rejects the Euro In Blow to European Unity
description: In the first popular test for Europe's common currency, Denmark voted to reject the euro 53.1 percent to 46.9 percent. The rejection suggested that the euro was likely to remain weak and dealt a blow to the political project of European unification behind the currency. With Britain and Sweden, the other two European Union states not inside so-called Euroland, now unlikely to adopt the euro any time soon, the European Central Bank faces the daunting task of forging confidence in a currency that has no single government or unified fiscal policy behind it. Roger Cohen

title: Neither
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Not a Back Lot, It's Northvale
description: Considering its occupant has a big title, the office doesn't have much of a view.

title: For Dirt Dishing or Bread Baking, There's Cable
description: WHILE fans all over the country spent this summer obsessed with the last ''Survivor,'' the latest ''Millionaire'' and all manner of television that had nothing to do with their lives, some Westchester residents were tuning in to Channel 73 and watching a Rye police officer, Gary Olivier, cook sausage and peppers while chatting about the news in their hometown.

title: Tech Quarterback Doesn't Just Get Mad, He Gets 210 Yards
description: Michael Vick had not put up the statistics that matched the superlatives he inspired before the season. He knew it, and it frustrated him. Today, he demonstrated what a quarterback can accomplish when he is angry and determined. Unstoppable.

title: Delayed? Take Out Frustration at the Airport Gym
description: LUCKY GOLD, who makes 30 or more business trips a year, says that being able to work out using a treadmill and free weights while on the road is crucial to his well-being.

title: BENEFITS
description: Open Houses

title: A Younger CBS Is the Talk of the Town
description: THE network television business continues to undergo enormous change, but how strange is this: the hot network of the fall season looks to be CBS.

title: One Bad Cop
description: The case that would eventually spark the most damaging scandal in the history of the Los Angeles Police Department began early on the afternoon of Nov. 26, 1996, when Javier Francisco Ovando was wheeled on a gurney into a downtown courtroom of the Los Angeles County Hall of Justice for a pretrial hearing. ''He was emaciated, frail, such a little man,'' recalled Tamar Toister, the public defender who was assigned his case, one of seven she would have that day. Ovando was charged with assaulting Rafael Perez and Nino Durden, two Los Angeles police officers, with a semiautomatic weapon. Since the Honduran-born Ovando then spoke no English and the Israeli-born Toister didn't speak Spanish, they conversed through an interpreter. But Ovando could barely talk in any language. A month and a half earlier, on Oct. 12, Perez and Durden, the two officers he was accused of assaulting, had shot him in the neck and chest. Through the interpreter, Ovando softly asserted his innocence and said he did not remember much of what happened except that ''bad cops'' had tried to kill him.

title: Even After His Perfect Start, Groh Striving to Be Better
description: Al Groh confronted the first public crisis of his head coaching tenure last week, and he handled it with perfect Parcellsian pitch. He refused to disclose even the most minute details of his meeting with Vinny Testaverde last Tuesday. He blasted the news media. And then, in a normal bit of coaching logic, he insisted -- the meeting with the quarterback notwithstanding -- that there had never been a problem in the first place.

title: Costly Prescriptions: One Issue That Fits All
description: Brian Schweitzer, a peppermint, alfalfa and cattle farmer running for the Senate in Montana, holds up a pair of pill bottles for the camera and declares, ''I bet you'd be surprised to find out that veterinarians prescribe the exact same medicine for dogs, and charge half as much.''

title: Amy Olt, Stephen Dolan
description: Amy St. Clair Olt and Stephen Frederick Dolan were married yesterday at St. Pius X Church in Fairfield, Conn. Msgr. Edward J. Scull performed the ceremony.

title: Following Up: Seafaring Smuggler Awaits His Freedom
description: The first time that Amir Humuntal Lumban Tobing, an Indonesian mariner, was washed up into the American legal system, it was in a wave of international notoriety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYSON, DR. ANNE E.
description: DYSON-Dr. Anne E. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the untimely passing of Anne Dyson, a member of the board since 1990. We extend our sincerest sympathy to the members of the Dyson family, who have been generous friends of The Metropolitan Opera for so many years. Mrs. Gilbert W. Humphrey, Chairman Emeritus Bruce Crawford, Honorary Chairman James W. Kinnear, Chairman Paul M. Montrone, President

title: Artwork That Doubles As Homes for the Homeless
description: An artist who designs inflatable plastic shelters that kept a number of street people warm and dry last winter plans to step up his work this winter.

title: Ukiah Journal; Illicit Weed May Find a Legal Home
description: No one can say for sure when the first seeds were planted, or how things reached the point where marijuana became Mendocino County's No. 1 cash crop and claim to fame.

title: Sept. 24-30; No Trial for Netanyahu
description: In a ruling laced with scathing language for the ''improper'' behavior of former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel's attorney general said that a six-month review failed to turn up enough evidence to prosecute him on charges of conspiring with a contractor in an illegal kickback scheme, of stealing gifts to the state and of obstructing justice. Mr. Netanyahu said he was ''relieved, relieved, relieved.'' It is unclear whether he will seize the moment to re-establish himself at the head of Israel's right wing, which has splintered since he stepped down after his overwhelming defeat in May 1999 by Ehud Barak.

title: Considerations in Choosing
description: The best reason for drinking a Long Island wine is that it is demonstrably competitive in quality and price with its peers. The worst reason is local chauvinism; the psychodynamics of chauvinism are not conducive to high standards.

title: On the Trail of History in New Canaan
description: A VISIT to the New Canaan Historical Society transports visitors to a particularly pretty part of a town. Across from God's Acre, a lush greensward and former burial ground, and adjacent to St. Michael's Lutheran Church, the society owns five buildings with seven museums on two rolling acres, and each museum has its own historical focus.

title: A Tenement's Tenants, Evicted by the City, Beg for Help
description: During the last several years, tenants at 181 East Houston Street said, they have endured cascading leaks, unstable stairs and rats. On Tuesday, their problems got worse when police officers and city workers told them to leave the building immediately because it was in imminent danger of collapse. The distraught tenants wondered where they would spend the night.
