title: BACKTALK; Don't Be So Quick to Prejudge All That Power
description: My mother always said, ''If you don't have anything nice to say, don't say anything at all.''

title: In Kingsbridge, a Sycamore Faces an Unwelcome Neighbor
description: Can a tree be a local celebrity?

title: A Case Sounds a Warning About Pension Safety
description: WORKERS who think that their pensions are secure because the government guarantees them, and that their 401(k) money is safe once it goes to an investment house, may want to follow closely a case in Portland, Ore., that has cost 100,000 people some major chunks of their retirement income.

title: Alexandra Holberton, William Wight Jr.
description: Alexandra Holberton, the daughter of Gale Russell Nash of McLean, Va., and Philip V. Holberton of Lincoln, Mass., was married yesterday to William Needles Wight Jr., a son of Deborah Wight and William N. Wight of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. E. Bevan Stanley performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church in Short Hills.

title: 'Arming America'
description: To the Editor:

title: ART; Museum Official's Dismissal Brings Tension, but Few Specifics
description: BEHIND the four Ionic columns of the Montclair Art Museum are a 15,000-piece art collection, a massive hole in the parking lot ready for a pricey new wing and a yet-to-be-resolved controversy that began in the summer with the dismissal of the museum's executive director by its board of trustees.

title: SCOOTER LAWS PROPOSED
description: The death of a 6-year-old boy in Elizabeth and an increase in injuries nationwide has fueled efforts by state and local officials to require children to wear helmets while riding kick scooters. The boy, Andy Alex Pino, died from head injuries late last month after being hit by a car while riding his scooter. He was the first child and the second person in the country to die in a scooter-related accident, according to the National Consumer Product Safety Commission. Even before the death, officials in Elizabeth and Jefferson Township had begun discussing local helmet requirements, and Assemblyman Gary Guear of Mercer County began drafting an amendment to the state helmet law to include scooters. Steve Strunsky

title: Danielle Dell'Olio, Robert Elder Jr.
description: Danielle Nancy Dell'Olio, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Dell'Olio of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Thomas Elder Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elder Sr. of Apex, N.C. The Rev. Michael J. Walsh, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Give Us a Break
description: To the Editor:

title: Ukraine Appoints a New Foreign Minister
description: KIEV, Ukraine, Sept. 30  President Leonid Kuchma was quoted today as saying he would name a longtime diplomat, Anatoly Zlenko, as foreign minister. The report was taken as a sign that the country would try to maintain its delicate balance between Russia and the West.

title: Diary: Ready, or Often Not, to Provide Elder Care
description: Adult children are often expected to care for aging parents who become frail or ill, but a new survey has found that many may not be completely prepared for the task.

title: Where to See 'Maisie'
description: To the Editor:

title: Athens to Get Ready for 2004
description: SYDNEY, Oct. 1 - The hand-off looked seamless. On the stage of Stadium Australia Sunday night, the Olympic flag passed from Sydney to Athens.

title: HISTORIC REGISTER
description: Palace Amusements in Asbury Park, known for the grinning painted face of Tillie, took a step toward protection from demolition last week when the State Review Board for Historic Sites unanimously recommended its listing in the New Jersey Register of Historic Places. Asbury Park sought to demolish the structure late last year, but held off after an engineering firm said it could be saved. The State Office of Natural and Historic Resources must decide within 90 days whether to list it. Inclusion in the register means developers would have to consult with the state before beginning any construction that could affect the site. Abhi Raghunathan

title: After Premier, Refund Routes
description: ON Sept. 14, with 2,800 passengers aboard five vessels in the Bahamas, Cozumel, Mexico, and Nova Scotia, Premier Cruises was shut down.

title: Saris Lose Their Luster As Western Look Takes Over
description: For thousands of years, Indian women have moved through daily life wearing vividly colored, gracefully flowing saris. Given the quixotic world of fashion, where trends may last for a season at most, that might be a record.

title: A DeLorean Second Hand (Hour, Too)
description: The creator of the stainless-steel gull-winged sports car is trying a comeback. John Z. DeLorean declared personal bankruptcy last year and then was evicted from his 434-acre estate in New Jersey hunt country after it was sold at auction. Now that he is finally close to settling with creditors for the DeLorean Motor Company, Mr. DeLorean, 75, is starting a new online retail company, DeLorean Time.

title: Sizing up Children's Museums...Sending In Pint-Size Critics; At a Mall, Digging Dinosaur Facts
description: OUR 2-year-old daughter, Una, has been to malls and to museums, and she thinks she knows the difference. So she was puzzled when we pulled into the parking lot of the South Hills Mall in Poughkeepsie. ''That not a mooseeum,'' she insisted.

title: For a Great Neck Synagogue, Another First
description: FEW people would probably be surprised to learn that the teenage boy who liked to spend his time studying the Torah ended up becoming a rabbi. Unless, of course, the boy happened to be Japanese.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEAVY, JOSEPHINE BREAKSTONE
description: LEAVY-Josephine Breakstone. June 28, 1895-October 1, 1920. A brief life of love enduring through the generations of her descendants. Eternal life shine upon her. Stan

title: Selling Tea as Serenity, Not Snobbery
description: WHEN it rains on one, it pours on us all.''

title: The Greatest Generation (Revised)
description: The Golden Age

title: Gore Assembles 'Debate Camp' Of 13 Citizens
description: Vice President Al Gore met with a couple of his hand-picked ''real people'' today to begin preparing for Tuesday's debate with Gov. George W. Bush in Boston -- what he called, in President Clinton's phrase, a ''job interview'' with the American people.

title: 3 Injured in Subway Rampage Shooting
description: Two people were seriously injured and another victim was shot in the leg in a rampage-like shooting that began on a southbound N train early Sunday morning and turned into pandemonium at the 59th Street station in Midtown.

title: This Smile Warmed Martha's Heart
description: ON a Saturday in early October 1789, George Washington powdered his graying brown hair, donned a yellow waistcoat, lace cravat and the blue uniform with gold epaulettes that he had worn as commander of the Continental Army and set off to meet John Ramage, the most popular miniaturist in America. He probably went to Ramage's studio on Williams Street in Lower Manhattan, 10 blocks south of where he was staying on Cherry Street. And there Ramage painted his portrait, the first produced of Washington since he had become president five months earlier. That night, he recorded the event in his diary, writing, in his idiosyncratic way, ''Sat for Mr. Ramage near two hours to-day who was drawing a miniature Picture of me for Mrs. Washington.''

title: Now It's Women's Turn to Make It in the Ring
description: BOXING has always provided an apt metaphor for films about struggle and redemption. The troubled young man from the poor background is locked in the frame with his adversary, the sweat flies, there are close-ups of agonized faces and the architecture of oiled and muscled bodies. As more and more women, including Muhammad Ali's daughter, Laila, and Joe Frazier's daughter, Jacqui Frazier-Lyde, take up the sport, it is almost inevitable that films about women who box should follow, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, IRENE
description: EISENBERG-Irene. Died on September 27. Survived by sister, Muriel Garnice, and nephews, Michael and Eric. (732) 536-2179.

title: In Case You Didn't Notice
description: The urge to decorate oneself with fashion accessories is back in focus, after being banished during the 1990's minimalist putsch. Roses are blooming on shoulders, hoop earings are dangling, and strings of rhinestones form belts. Even the late-1940's fedora with a veil made the scene during the first week of autumn. ''Sex and the City'' is a big influence on the trend, but it actually started three years ago in Italy, when the design team Dolce & Gabbana decorated dresses with butterflies and when designer handbags like the Fendi baguette appeared, signaling the rise of accessories as the star of fashion.

title: It Appears the United States Will Not Win a Gold Medal for the First Time Since 1948
description: The United States boxing team began these Olympics hoping to be favorably compared to the 1976 United States Olympic team that won five gold medals.

title: How 47,000 Volunteers Rescued Their Olympics
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Everybody has a favorite last memory of the Sydney Summer Games, now over. Mine will forever be the sight (and sound) of a Swiss lawyer named Francois Carrard breaking into song.

title: On the Mississippi, Over the Top
description: ''When I was a boy there was but one permanent ambition among my comrades in our village on the West bank of the Mississippi River. That was to be a steamboatman.'' -- Mark Twain, ''Life on the Mississippi.''

title: Rat Rock Continues To Live Up to Its Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; Lonely Passion Of Hillary
description: It was a tip-top Tipper moment.

title: Synagogue Acquires A Torah Rich With Meaning
description: The city's oldest surviving synagogue building, a Gothic Revival structure at 172 Norfolk Street that reopened as a house of worship last year after a quarter-century of disuse, is acquiring a central piece of its past, a Torah with possible deep roots in the synagogue's history.

title: An Excerpt; Inside Saddam's Court
description: The Egyptian belly dancers jiggled across the stage, shaking like bowls of crme brle. A quartet of clarinet players wailed themselves into a dither. The drummer thrashed his cymbals and snares. It was a typical night at the Hunting Club, the private cabaret for Baghdad's elite. With a difference: normally the band had the audience on its feet, clapping and whistling. But not tonight. On Thursday nights we sat glued to our seats, sipping our drinks and checking our watches. We were waiting for Saddam.

title: Princeton Rallies Past Columbia
description: Princeton's Taylor Northrop kicked a 24-yard field goal in overtime to cap a stirring comeback and a 27-24 victory over host Columbia yesterday in the Ivy League opener for both teams.

title: The Nation; When the Military (Ret.) Marches to Its Own Drummer
description: IT is a singular aspect of military life that men and women in uniform give up some of their basic rights as American citizens, starting with those protected by the First Amendment. The Uniform Code of Military Justice makes it a crime to criticize superior officers and prohibits troops from uttering ''contemptuous words'' against civilian leaders -- say, members of Congress, the secretary of defense, or the president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COYLE, EILEEN JANE (NEE TUOHY)
description: COYLE-Eileen Jane (nee Tuohy). Unexpectedly on September 28, 2000. Beloved wife of Daniel Edward. Adored mother of Patricia K. Coyle, M.D., Eileen Dana Flood, Daniel Edward Coyle, Jr., Claudia Coyle, Mary Jane Herkenham, and Christopher Coyle. Loving grandmother of Danny, Peter, Billy, Eileen, Mackenzie, Laura and Katie. Her early career was as a fashion designer, her later career was a wife and mother. Visiting Saturday 2-5 and 7-9 and Sunday 25. Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave, 212-475-2024. Services Monday, 10 A.M., at Epiphany Church, New York. Interment at Holy Sepulchre Cemetery in Coram, Long Island. Any donations to Long Island Chapter National MS Society, Hauppauge, New York.

title: Candleabra and Crayons: Fine Dining With Children
description: FIRST, a confession. David C. (his real name) and his wife once took two young children to dine in a fancy restaurant.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Buzzwords

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Raymond De Felitta and Michael Rispoli; Swizzling Up a Storm
description: THE talk Thursday night, on a barhopping jaunt through Midtown was: bars we have known and loved, bars we have worked in, bartenders we miss, bars we miss, drinks we miss, bars where we fell in love, oh, yes, and this movie.

title: School Board Questions Fitness of Book Because of Bomb Diagram
description: WHEN the Port Washington Board of Education met last month, one of the issues on its agenda was the review of two books proposed for use in the high school English curriculum. While the board enthusiastically approved ''Clear Light of Day'' by Anita Desai for an advanced-placement English course, several members raised concerns about the second book, ''In the Time of the Butterflies'' by Julia Alvarez, proposed for a 10th grade literature and composition class.

title: Habitats/Copake, N.Y., in Columbia County; Couple From Manhattan Build Their Dream House
description: STEPHEN AND MARGE HOPPE say their friends thought they were crazy to build their own country house. Why didn't they just buy one?

title: Stinky, Spitty and Gunter
description: WHAT SHE SAW . . .

title: How Bridges Begin And Skyscrapers End
description: As a child living in England, without a television to watch and largely dependent on himself for entertainment, David Macaulay began erecting bridges, skyscrapers, even cable car systems, out of homemade materials on his living room floor. Forty years later, as a writer and illustrator living in the United States, he has turned the science of engineering into a source of entertainment.

title: A Workshop's Bounty: Fellowship, Feedback
description: WHAT separates playwrights from novelists, poets and artists? Chilton Ryan, the president of the Theater Artists Workshop of Westport, says it is collaboration.

title: Taking A Chance On Takeover Candidates
description: THE triple threat of big-league corporate earnings warnings, signs of an economic slowdown and elevated oil prices has made the stock market an exceedingly frustrating place of late. What's an investor to do?

title: Man Against (Ready. Aim. Fire.) Nature; As the Line Separating the Suburbs and the Countryside Blurs, the Wildlife Gets Squeezed. Or Worse.
description: AH, wilderness. A 100-year-old Tudor mansion hidden away. An under-construction faux Tudor mansion rising behind a ribbon of fresh asphalt. A broad green lawn to mow. A place to fire up the grill -- or have someone fire it up for you. For half a century, such has been the lure of New Jersey for waves of former city dwellers.

title: Hitching a Vintage Ride to the Past
description: THERE are two kinds of car people,'' Jan Voboril told me as we climbed into his 1916 Lancia convertible. ''One likes to polish them, one likes to drive them. I think it's much more fun to drive. Wouldn't you rather cook than do the dishes?''

title: Yugoslav Opposition Preparing for a Risky Showdown
description: Aleksandar Djurkovic's mother, 65, has been tending the flowers on her balcony for nearly two years. On Friday, when high school students marched past her window to a rally against the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, she ripped off the blooms and tossed them down, on to their heads.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Violet Pigskins

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIETA, HENRIETTA E. COUNTISS
description: VIETA-Henrietta E. Countiss. Peacefully at home on September 28, 2000. Beloved wife of the late John O. Vieta, M.D. Loving mother of Dr. Paul, Frances, Jona. Dearest mother-in-law of Leila Vieta and Richard Larm. Cherished grandmother of Kathryn, Amy, Paul, Laura, Robin, and Jonathan. Dear sister of Barbara Lee of Denver, Colorado. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Friday, October 6, at 5:00 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the John O. Vieta Memorial Lecture, care of Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 E. 77 St., NYC 10021.

title: New Season Comes Not a Moment Too Soon
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 1  The longtime Yankees Paul O'Neill and David Cone shagged fly balls together one sunny morning last March and shared their dreams for the coming season, chatting freely about trying to become the first team in 26 years to win three consecutive championships.

title: To His Gritty World Add an Ink-Stained Wretch
description: DICK WOLF eschews the expensive sports clothes and open-necked shirts that are de rigueur for rival television kings like Steven Bochco and David E. Kelley. Instead, with his slicked-back hair, cuff-linked off-white shirt, expensive tie and sleek suit, Mr. Wolf resembles a very successful businessman.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Habitat for Humanity Is Putting Up More Houses
description: ON the corner of Porach and Walnut Streets, in an area of well-kept but modest homes, a small group of volunteers for Habitat for Humanity is busy putting in the foundation for two houses, one of which will be the home of the Diaz family, who live nearby and have been closely following the progress of the construction.

title: The Supreme Court and the Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Delays Its Sanctions Against U.S. Over Trade
description: The United States persuaded the European Union yesterday to delay imposing billions of dollars in sanctions stemming from a dispute over tax laws, providing at least a short reprieve while both sides seek to cut through a thicket of trade tensions.

title: An Illness Can Have a Positive Effect
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 30  Wherever he is, Derrick Kennedy, a senior defensive tackle for the University of Louisville, is ready with a joke or a smile. At class, on the practice field, in the weight room.

title: U.S. Wrestler Rulon Gardner: From Wyoming to Hollywood, via Sydney
description: SYDNEY,Australia, Oct. 1 - Eight or so minutes of fame on a wrestling mat with the Meanest Man in the World must be worth something on the free market, and Rulon Gardner is about to find out just how much it's worth.

title: Bluestocking Blues
description: John F. Kennedy, whom Bill Clinton greatly admired, was not dissuaded by the charge of nepotism from appointing his brother attorney general. One wonders why Clinton did not name his wife to that post, rather than let her lurk around the fringes of the administration attempting to push her agendas without the accountability that would come with a formal position.

title: Americans Dominate Medal Count
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 1 - It began with a surprise, on a Saturday morning nearly 20 miles west of downtown Sydney in an agricultural area known as the Cumberland Plain. American Nancy Johnson won the first gold medal of the 2000 Olympic Games, and did so in an upset at the 10-meter air rifle event.

title: Beware of Fuzzy Insurance Argot
description: JENNA died two weeks ago, so the thoughts of her parents, Theresa and Bruce Gudin, are not as preoccupied by their insurance carrier as they once were.

title: As Slide Continues, Yankees Hope They Can Turn It Around in Playoffs
description: It is too late for the Yankees to reverse their horrible slump before the playoffs begin, too late to recapture their sense of invincibility. They were routed again tonight, losing to the Orioles, 9-1, as Manager Joe Torre rested many of his regular players, the day after the team clinched the American League East.

title: Sept. 24-30; Clues to a Solar Mystery
description: The sun's atmosphere, called the corona, is hundreds of times hotter than its surface, and astronomers have been trying to figure out why for more than 50 years. They have long suspected that powerful magnetic fields sprouting from the solar surface are involved. By taking the sharpest pictures ever of gases clinging to those fields, a NASA satellite has tightened that connection. The pictures show what amount to pillars of fire at the base of the field lines. But scientists still haven't figured out what sets off the fires. James Glanz

title: Mr. Spaceman
description: Buzz Lightyear, the lantern-jawed hero of the ''Toy Story'' films, battles intergalactic evildoers in his own animated action comedy series, ''Disney/Pixar's Buzz Lightyear of Star Command,'' beginning tomorrow on Channel 9, where it will be shown weekdays at 7 a.m. and Sundays at 10:30 a.m. Saturday broadcasts begin Oct. 14 at 10:30 a.m. on ABC.

title: Mary Kate Wynperle, James Moriarty
description: Mary Catherine Wynperle, a daughter of Mary and William Wynperle of Great Neck, N.Y., was married yesterday to James John Moriarty, a son of Josephine and Thomas Moriarty of East Atlantic Beach, N.Y. Msgr. James Kelly, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Jean Baptiste in New York.

title: Genentech: Survivor Strutting Its Stuff
description: WHEN Genentech Inc. was founded here nearly 25 years ago, it created a model for a new industry based on biotechnology, the premise that biological discoveries would lead directly to breakthrough drugs. Since then, more than 1,200 biotechnology companies have sprung up around the world.

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; A Spec Office Builder Near Princeton Thinks Bigger
description: THIS month backhoes will begin tearing into 17 acres here for an office building that, like others in recent years in the flush office market along the Princeton Route 1 corridor, will be built on speculation.

title: Where to hitch up to a freighter
description: Until a few years ago, it was relatively easy to cross the Atlantic on a freighter, but more and more lines have stopped taking passengers on that popular route. There are, however, still some freighters available between North America and Europe.

title: Sept. 24-30; Defense of Wen Ho Lee Case
description: After weeks of criticism, Attorney General Janet Reno and Louis J. Freeh, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, admitted at a Senate hearing that the government had made mistakes in its handling of the case against the nuclear scientist Wen Ho Lee. But they expressed no regret for the criminal prosecution of Dr. Lee, which collapsed earlier this month when Mr. Lee pleaded guilty to a single count of mishandling atomic secrets. As Ms. Reno put it, ''Dr. Lee is no hero.'' David Johnston

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ARGUING THE WORLD

title: The Post-Rock Band
description: Radiohead is a significant band at a bad time for significant bands. Radiohead took its name from a song by Talking Heads, which says something about Radiohead's aspirations, and something too about how self-conscious and historically freighted any aspiring band cannot help being now. Radiohead is making music at a moment when the epoch of bands would seem to be coming to a close, a moment when what is novel in popular music is being made not by groups of young men playing guitars and writing and singing their own songs but rather by individual D.J.'s and one- or two-person production teams using turntables and computers and assorted electronic gadgets. It's a moment that has the feel of a mainstream-music paradigm shift -- away from pop-rock and toward hip-hop, dance music and what gets called electronica. It's a moment nearly 40 years removed from the last big paradigm shift, secured by the advent of the first significant band, the Beatles, whom the members of Radiohead seem to talk about all the time.

title: Corrections
description: The Dining Out column on Sept. 17, about Coolfish, a new restaurant in Syosset, misstated its hours. They are 11:30 a.m. to 10 p.m. Monday through Thursday; to 11 p.m. on Friday; 5 p.m. to 11 p.m. on Saturday; and 5 p.m. to 9 p.m. on Sunday.

title: The World; In Poor Countries, High Oil Prices Cost Even More
description: PRESIDENT HUGO CHAVEZ of Venezuela, speaking to leaders of the OPEC countries in Caracas last week, urged crybabies lamenting the high price of oil to direct their anger at national taxes or, in the case of the poorest countries, at the failure of the rich to grant them debt relief. The big oil producers, Mr. Chavez said, were on the side of the people. Nice try, but that's not the way it looks from Rwanda, or just around the corner from Caracas in the Caribbean and Central America, or in faraway Asia.

title: How a Passion for Tarot Cards Led to a Full-Time Business
description: STUART KAPLAN used to buy and sell coal and copper mines for a living. That was before a 1968 visit to the Nuremberg Toy Fair in Germany, the largest toy fair in the world. Ostensibly he was shopping for presents for his five children, but Mr. Kaplan, an inveterate collector of stamps, coins, matchbook covers, old books and baseball cards, among other things, found the atmosphere irresistible.

title: Two Workers Injured in a Fire at Newark Airport
description: One electrical worker was critically injured and another was scarred after they were burned in an explosion and fire yesterday in a FedEx building at Newark Airport.

title: If It's Out There, It's In Here
description: THE Talmud and

title: Joy in the Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Armstrong Cared Enough to Be in Games
description: LANCE ARMSTRONG did not have to be here. These Olympic races had nothing to do with the Tour de France, the European circuit, where he makes his very considerable living.

title: Swiss Tolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: On Essex County As Literary Inspiration
description: To the Editor:

title: Accused of Threat, Erxleben Is Arrested
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 30  Russell Erxleben, the former National Football League kicker convicted of securities fraud, has been jailed after a former investor said Erxleben had threatened his life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STREETEN, DAVID H. P., M.D.
description: STREETEN-David H. P., M.D., D.Phil. F.R.C.P., F.A.C.P. Age 78, died Friday, September 29, at University Hospital, Syracuse, NY. Dr. Streeten was born in Bloemfontein, South Africa. Beloved husband of Dr. Barbara Streeten, and father of Robert, Elizabeth and John Streeten. Funeral services will be held at 11 AM at St. Paul's Cathedral in Syracuse, NY, Tuesday, October 3. Dr. Streeten was beloved in his role as teacher, lecturer and physician by his students and a large number of patients for whom he cared. He was also a very productive contributor to medical research, publishing over 200 research papers, and serving on the editorial boards of five clinical and research journals. He had a special interest in orthostatic disorders of the circulation, publishing a book with this title in 1987, and reported original descriptions of several new syndromes in this and related areas.

title: The Trials of 'Branding' Locally Grown Produce
description: WENDING her way through the Hayground Market in Bridgehampton one recent afternoon, Kathi Cavanaugh stopped to scoop string beans into her plastic bag. ''I always pick fresh produce here, rather than going to the supermarket,'' said Ms. Cavanaugh, who lives in Sag Harbor. She was standing beneath a handwritten sign proclaiming ''Local String Beans.''

title: Lieberman, Twice
description: To the Editor:

title: Ready, or Often Not, To Provide Elder Care
description: Adult children are often expected to care for aging parents who become frail or ill, but a new survey has found that many may not be completely prepared for the task.

title: For Hungry Bulls And Bears
description: 14 WALL STREET RESTAURANT

title: Andrea Gurwitt and Adam Eidelberg
description: WHENEVER Andrea Faith Gurwitt and her mother, Nissa Simon, go out to dinner together, they usually sit in total silence, eyes glazed over, busy eavesdropping on their fellow diners.

title: Ancient Aqueduct, New Image
description: Built in the early part of the first century, the 150-foot-high Pont du Gard spanning the Gardon River between Nimes and Avignon crowns a stunning engineering feat. The stone aqueduct supplied water from the source of the Eure at Uzes to the thermal baths and fountains of the Roman colony of Nimes, more than 31 miles away, until the early fifth century.

title: Article 2000100190011754239 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Unexpected Glory for Yugoslavian Vollyball Team
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 1 -- Victory gave Yugoslavia's Ivan Miljkovic wings. After he hit the winning shot against Russia final on Sunday, the 6-foot-9 Miljkovic stuck his long arms out like a huge child imitating an airplane. While he completed a loop-the-loop round the court, his team-mates pogoed for joy, mouths open as wide as they could in yells of disbelief. Arms which spent all afternoon reaching for blocks now stretched upward to grab nothing but the rarified air of unexpected glory.

title: Cuba Cruises to Third Straight Gold
description: The thick gray hair of the Russian coach, Nikolai Karpol, bounced as he barked at his blank-faced players, and his thick eyeglasses slid down his nose while he shook his fists at them.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-01-00; What They Were Thinking
description: Jeffrey Newland, Plumas National Forest, near Belden, Calif., Aug. 22, 2000

title: If the Show Almost Didn't Go On? Tales to Tell
description: DOES anyone really know why the show must go on? Is it because the tickets have been sold? Because the actors must be paid? Or is the reason more intangible, rooted in the notion of art itself?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about Heike Drechsler's victory in the Olympic women's long jump referred incorrectly to her participation in the 1996 Games. She did not win the event that year, but missed the Games with an injury.

title: The Mets Receive a Boost From a Farmhand
description: The tension has disappeared. The Mets are playing carefree and spirited baseball for the first time in a month. It is happening immediately after they clinched the National League wild card, and that is not a coincidence.

title: Academic Gains Pay Off for Teachers and Students
description: Several times a month, in preparation for a statewide math exam later this school year, the opening minutes of every 9th and 10th grade class at Northwest Cabarrus High are devoted to math, no matter whether the class is Latin, history or physical education.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in this section last Sunday with an article about televised presidential debates misidentified the one shown. It was the last of four between John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon in 1960; it was not their first, which was the first televised presidential debate.

title: Atlantic Beach in Void Over Zoning Power
description: THE Nassau County executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, vetoed a measure last week that would have given zoning powers to the village of Atlantic Beach, even though the Nassau County Legislature twice passed bills in favor and the state attorney general's office expressed its approval last month.

title: Shore Music for a Cause
description: For more than two decades, Southside Johnny Lyon and the Asbury Jukes have epitomized the mix of rock 'n' roll and blues that made the New Jersey shore music scene famous. Some of the best musicians from in and around Asbury Park have honed their skills with the Jukes and gone on to develop regional, and even national, followings of their own.

title: One Home's Unplanned Addition: A Courtroom
description: BE had done all the right things. We checked the record of the home improvement contractor with state regulators and the Better Business Bureau. We inspected the contractor's jobs in progress. We checked references. And we wrote and signed a detailed contract and an additional written agreement that the contractor would forfeit $100 for each day the job ran late. If the work didn't go smoothly, we thought, we were covered.

title: Top Names No Gamble For Casinos
description: THE perception of casino entertainment as sleazy lounge acts has greatly changed in recent years. Today, casinos like Foxwoods in Mashantucket and Mohegan Sun in Uncasville offer a wide array of musical acts that once would never have dreamed of playing a casino.

title: Fiedler Tries to Fill Marinos Shoes
description: MIAMI, Sept. 30  The line is long, 10 or 12 fans deep waiting to stand next to the bronze statue outside the stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, GLORIA (NEE BIERFREIND)
description: STEIN-Gloria (nee Bierfreind). Of Boynton Beach, FL. for the past sixteen years, and formerly of Pomona, NY. Died on September 25, 2000 in Boca Raton, FL. Mrs. Stein was the loving mother of Michael Stein and Hara Stein; cherished sister of Sheila (Philip) Gatto and adored aunt and great-aunt.

title: REMOTE VOTING
description: A bill that would allow ill state legislators to participate in house and committee meetings and vote on legislation through unspecified ''remote electronic means'' passed through the Senate State Government Committee this week. The bill would permit ill members to be considered fully present and would count their presence toward determining a quorum. Anne Ruderman

title: POSTINGS: They're Part of a New 19-Story Condo at 351 East 51st Street; Saving 1893 School's Facades
description: The two 1893 facades of the onetime Public School 35, which a neighborhood coalition successfully fought to preserve, are to form a four-story Romanesque Revival base around the Beekman Regent, a new 19-story luxury condominium at 351 East 51st Street scheduled to be completed next summer.

title: A Play Date for Playwrights Who Meet in a Weekly Workshop
description: LIKE most playwrights, Doug Michaels realizes that his is a solitary craft. That's why he decided six years ago to start a weekly playwright's workshop at the Schoolhouse in Croton Falls.

title: Two World Travelers Bringing It All Back Home
description: SOONER or later, most world travelers reach the same realization: you can't leave yourself behind. In the most distant locales and unlikely situations, you still carry a lifetime of habits and memories. Yet with any luck, you'll bring back something lasting: a new perspective on space and light, on how people interact and how ideas fit together.

title: Virginia Seabring, Henry Watts III
description: Virginia Nash Seabring, a daughter of Ellen and Robert Seabring of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Henry Miller Watts III, a son of the late Barbara and William Watts, who lived in Ardmore, Pa. The Rev. Dr. William Steele performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church of Bronxville.

title: California's Freeway to Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: After Another Near-Death Experience, U.S. Wins Gold
description: When Antoine Rigaudeau stepped up and knocked down a 3-pointer with 4 minutes 26 seconds left this afternoon, another alleged cakewalk in the men's basketball tournament turned into riveting theater at the Super Dome in Olympic Park, the unthinkable again on the minds of the 14,883 in attendance.

title: Corrections
description: The main front-page article in this section last Sunday, about efforts to revitalize John Jay High School in Park Slope, Brooklyn, misstated the school's location. It is on Seventh Avenue between Fourth and Fifth Streets, not Third and Fourth.

title: Sept. 24-30; Fewer Lack Insurance
description: President Clinton took office promising health insurance for all Americans, so he was distressed by the steady increase in the number of uninsured from 1993 to 1998. But finally the trend has been reversed. The Census Bureau reported that the number of people without insurance dropped last year by 1.7 million, to 42.6 million. The number of people with employment-based insurance rose 3.4 million, to 172 million. Robert Pear

title: Ideas & Trends; A Slight Judeo-Christian Warming Trend
description: THE Jewish New Year, which began on Friday evening, serves as an annual reminder for American Jews that in a predominantly Christian society, they are a tribe set apart by their own calendar, rhythms and rituals.

title: Science Fiction
description: The title of THE TELLING (Harcourt, $24), Ursula K. Le Guin's new novel, may reveal more about the book's virtues and flaws than she realizes. Its protagonist, Sutty, is an Indo-Canadian who becomes an Observer for the Ekumen, the benign organization that looks after the varied worlds settled by humans.

title: Out of the Trunk
description: THE MAP OF LOVE

title: Park and Ride And Ride and Ride and . . .
description: WELCOME to Newark International Airport from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, transmitting on highway advisory radio 530-AM. Please be advised that monorail service has been suspended at all stations and that despite the exhaustive guidance I'm about to give you in this radio announcement, coming here today may turn out to be the biggest mistake you have ever made. We sincerely regret any inconvenience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZORN, LILLIAN R.
description: ZORN-Lillian R. On September 30, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Lewis E. Adored mother of Richard and beloved mother-in-law of Franny. Loving grandmother of Danny and Katie. Her loving and supportive spirit will always be remembered by her family.

title: Sept. 24-30; A Victory for Microsoft
description: Microsoft won a significant skirmish in its appeal of the landmark antitrust case that resulted in an order by a federal district judge to break the company in half. The Supreme Court rejected the government's plea to hear the appeal, instead sending the case to be reviewed by seven judges on the federal appeals court in Washington. That court sided with Microsoft two years ago in a related proceeding. The decision leaves the supervision of the federal case in the hands of the next administration, which Microsoft executives hope will be open to reconsider both the merits of the lawsuit and the order to break up the company. Stephen Labaton

title: Nadia Holubnyczyj, Marco Ortiz
description: Nadia Holubnyczyj and Marco Vinicio Ortiz were married yesterday by the Rev. Barry Andrews, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, at the Swan Club in Glenwood Landing, N.Y.

title: BACKTALK; Confidentiality Is the Cornerstone
description: Ever since the news broke in Sydney that the world champion shot-putter C. J. Hunter had tested positive for elevated levels of the chemical substance nandrolone, the governing organizations of international sport have been falling all over themselves to call for USA Track & Field and its chief executive, Craig Masback, to release information about those tests and to divulge the names of other American athletes whose cases are in its administrative hearings process.

title: Little Sippers
description: Models and other fashion insiders have been nursing miniature bottles of Champagne for years, backstage at fashion shows and at chic parties and promotions. Cashing in on the cool appeal of casually sipping bubbly from a hand-held bottle, companies like Moet & Chandon, Veuve Clicquot and Pommery are marketing the minis, or splits, to the general public. Piper-Heidsieck has packaged its Baby Pipers (about a glass and a half) in eye-catching red bottles and distributes them to restaurants like Brasserie 8 1/2 and Flute ($15 a pop), which serve them right in the bottle, like beer.

title: PALLONE WITHDRAWS
description: Representative Frank Pallone, who had publicly considered seeking the Democratic nomination for governor, announced last week that he would not. The Monmouth County Democrat, who said he would support Mayor Jim McGreevy of Woodbridge in the primary, said he wanted to devote all of his time to running for Congress now and to Congressional reorganization in early 2001. Karen DeMasters

title: Titans Bring Giants Back to Reality
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn. - The Tennessee Titans played keepaway to keep their perfect record intact at Adelphia Coliseum.

title: Sept. 24-30; Faithful's Window of Opportunity
description: To a casual passer-by, the second-floor window overlooking Washington Street in Perth Amboy, N.J., is filled with nothing more than smudgy streaks of pale white, reddish-orange, light gray and green.

title: The Nation: Debatable; What to Do With All That Money
description: THE presidential debates of 1960 are best remembered today for the contrast between a tanned, youthful-looking John F. Kennedy and a pasty, sweaty-looking Richard M. Nixon.

title: Ever Onward
description: In support of the arts and the fight against drug and alcohol abuse.

title: FIRST PERSON; Mind if I Join You?
description: I HAVE always felt a compulsion to join groups, whether they suit me or not. Living in New York, I have needed to escape the throngs of strangers in those ''huddled masses,'' and looked to more intimate cliques. But just as I began to revel in acceptance and belonging, I inevitably encountered expulsion.

title: Openness Can Be A Two-Way Street
description: SUNSHINE is healthy. But it can burn.

title: A Diner's Latest Incarnation, With Children's Fare Too
description: The Purity Diner is reopening in Park Slope, Brooklyn, this time at 289 Seventh Avenue (at Seventh Street). The restaurant, which offers standard diner fare like Belgian waffles, eggs, sandwiches, salads and burgers, as well as a children's menu, was at 100 Seventh Avenue (at Union Street) from 1929 until the end of last year. (It was originally called the Purity Restaurant and was named the New Purity Restaurant in 1986.)

title: Funds Watch: From a Web Site, a Way to Measure Risk
description: By conventional measures, the Red Oak Technology Select fund has been one of the best performers this year, ranked 12th by Lipper among all funds as of early September. But when one examines the risk that its managers took, Red Oak's position was a less-stellar 27th. By contrast, Fidelity Select Natural Gas ranked 10th by the usual yardstick but did better when adjusted for its risk, rising to 6th.

title: The 19th Century Revisited: Turning a Public Street Private
description: More than a century ago, the stately little street known as Montgomery Place was a private walkway, gated at both ends and lined with decorative lampposts.

title: The Nation; Now, Another Pill Promises a Revolution
description: FOR both medical and political reasons, the Food and Drug Administration's approval Thursday of the abortion drug mifepristone, or RU-486, is the most significant abortion-rights triumph since the Supreme Court's 1992 reaffirmation of Roe v. Wade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLMAN, HELEN SLATER
description: ALLMAN-Helen Slater. Age 93, of Ridgewood, NJ, and formerly of Ronan, Montana, on September 27, 2000. Wife of the late Charles A. Allman. Loving mother of Phoebe A. MacGillivary of Ridgewood, NJ, and Leesville, NY, and Willard S. Allman of Wyckoff, NJ. Adored grandmother of Stefanie Alison Allman. Services are private.

title: When Baby Makes Three, It Begins. When Does It End?
description: When I was a child I did not know that the circus had an intermission. The moment the break came in the show, my mother would stand up and say, ''Well, wasn't that wonderful?'' and sweep us toward the exit of Madison Square Garden faster than you could say ''Ringling, Barnum and Bailey.''

title: A Pickle Juice Drinker Finds Validation
description: To the Editor:

title: Tipper's Dance
description: Tipper Gore hopped off a New Orleans streetcar and boogied her way through the crowd, shimmying all alone to the music of a Dixieland band. Wacky, fun-loving Tipper was at it again. Just as in Los Angeles, where she had jammed on stage at the Democratic convention. Which was nothing compared with her performance four years ago in Chicago. That time, she jumped into Lake Michigan with her clothes on. Officially, she's the antidote to her stuffy husband, Lucy to his Ricky Ricardo, forever mugging and angling to play with the band. What will she think of next? Today, it's a one-woman line dance outside the local party headquarters, where she's supposed to cut a ribbon and give a speech. But there is something a little off, a little forced about the gaiety swirling around the laughing woman who is dancing as fast as she can while a small herd of TV camera guys closes in. It doesn't look like fun.

title: Peru Turning a Colder Shoulder
description: President Alberto K. Fujimori's surprise two-day visit to Washington momentarily froze a deteriorating political situation here in which all the most important buttresses of his power appear to be cracking. The opposition is on the march, truck drivers have staged crippling protests against rising fuel prices and even Mr. Fujimori's own prime minister has tacitly conceded that the military is restive.

title: BUSINESS; In the Oakland A's, Some Lessons for Silicon Valley
description: AT the beginning of the baseball season, the San Francisco Giants embodied everything happening in the ever-growing Bay Area: a beefed-up $55 million player payroll, a new $319 million stadium and a giddy, price-is-no-object optimism.

title: California's Freeway to Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Relays Reveal The Most About Jones
description: FOUR years ago, had you told Marion Jones that in the 2000 Games she would win five medals, most likely she would have been ecstatic. Some runners train a lifetime to reach the Games, competing but never winning a medal. Their careers are defined by simply getting there.

title: DEATH TOLL RISES
description: Violent clashes between Palestinians and Israeli troops left at least 12 Palestinians dead and hundreds wounded in the third day of fierce fighting set off by the defiant visit on Thursday of a right-wing Israeli leader, Ariel Sharon, to the steps of the ancient mosques atop Jerusalem's Old City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, JOHN D.
description: MORAN-John D. A pressman for The New York Times for 17 years from 1967 to 1984 passed away Saturday, September 23, 2000. He is survived by his wife, Margaret, two daughters, Agnes and Therese; one son, John. His daughter Adelaide died in 1983. Adelaide's son, Michael Bonomo was raised by John and is now in his senior year at Hunter College. John was a 4th Degree Member of the Daniel J. Bradley Council of the Knights of Columbus, Baldwin, NY and the presentation of colors was made at his wake on Tuesday evening, September 26, 2000. He was a kind, gentle and friendly man, loved by many.

title: Guides: Cappuccino-Free Bookstores, Cafes With Big Ears
description: GUIDEBOOKS to New York City are always in demand in a place where advice can quickly become outdated. Here is a sampler from some recent volumes:

title: Bluestocking Blues
description: It is not the perception of Hillary Clinton as a ''bluestocking'' that concerns women (The Way We Live Now: Judith Shulevitz, Sept. 10). In fact, one of the few things we may have in common with the first lady is the experience of being perceived as opinionated or aggressive, particularly those of us who have worked in male-dominated professions. What concerns us is her willingness to remain in a marriage in which she was demeaned. And what concerns us even more is the very public support she gave to her husband, support that was in large part responsible for his ability to remain in office. This undermined women by legitimizing the notion that men can be expected to cheat and that women should, nonetheless, stand by them.

title: Sara Krause, Souheil Inati
description: Sara Skidmore Krause, a medical student, and Dr. Souheil James Inati, a physicist, were married yesterday at the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, R.I. The Rev. Richard Manzelmann, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Jennifer Shook, Kenneth Matthews
description: Jennifer Lynn Shook, a daughter of Linda and Merrick Shook of Mechanicsburg, Pa., was married there yesterday to Kenneth Craig Matthews, a son of Carol and Craig G. Matthews of Chatham, N.J. The Rev. Chester P. Snyder performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GASTER, SANFORD (SANDY)
description: GASTER-Sanford (Sandy). Dear friends, relatives, colleagues, students, we would welcome your presence at a memorial service for Sandy on Tuesday, Oct 3, at Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 33 Spring Street, NYC 11AM-12noon. Harriet & Jo-anne Gaster

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLANN, MARIE (OLYVE) WARNER
description: GOLANN-Marie (Olyve) Warner. On September 28, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Irwin Golann. Loving mother of Steven Golann, Robert Golann, & Janet Dickstein. Survived by her six grandchildren: Jason, Zachary, David, Lora, Nathan, and Douglas. Interment at Greenwood Cemetery.

title: For Players, Mah-Jongg (Recall Bam, Crak, Dot?) And Bridge and Chess
description: WHEN it comes to games, it seems there are those who do and those who don't -- enjoy playing them, that is.

title: Southern Exposure
description: WHILE Edison has many restaurants featuring the wheat-based fare of North India -- puffy naan bread served with tandoori chicken -- few offer the rice-based vegetarian cuisine of the Spice Coast in South India, a place where steaming idlis, crunchy dosas and pillowy uttappam reign.

title: Nameless Now, a Neighborhood Seeks to Be 'Rosehill' Again
description: The Rosehill Community Association is trying to put its neighborhood on the map. Literally.

title: The Scooter Menace
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-16

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARVARO, BESSIE
description: VARVARO-Bessie. Age 91, of Brooklyn. Wife of Steven, mother of Arnold Neiderbach, sister of Lillian Caivano, and beloved grandmother and great grandmother. Services are 11 AM, Monday, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Average Age, 64.1
description: IT was tempting. Six cities in 12 days, unpacking only once? Add two days in London and it was even more inviting. Especially since this tour-cruise to four Scandinavian capitals, St. Petersburg and an optional side trip to Berlin was for ''experienced travelers.'' Make that ''mature,'' the brochure amended, using an adjective that describes me better than ''experienced.''

title: Club Noise Draws Criticism, But Partyers Say It's Cultural
description: When two nightclubs on Jamaica Avenue close at 4 a.m. on weekends, revelers continue to party in the streets. And many of the neighbors are furious.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-01-00: Salient Facts: New Subway Cars; Notes From the Underground
description: You can see it on passengers' faces along the No. 6 and No. 2 lines: their customary mass-transit masks melt into cautious smiles as they register the changes in the environment. From lighting to flooring, the R142 trains currently being tested set a new standard for subway comfort and civility.

title: Haunted and Redeemed by a Jewish Heritage
description: WHEN 88-year-old Nicholas Pogany and his wife, Margaret, 77, gathered recently with their three children, six grandchildren and other family members for the traditional Jewish wedding of their oldest grandchild, it was more than an ancestral ritual. It was a celebration of an American family that almost never was.

title: Memories of Tennis On Special Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Time
description: The boy band 98 Degrees (right) and the newcomer Hoku, the teenage daughter of Don Ho, take the stage, then travel behind the scenes to their respective hometowns, Cincinnati and Honolulu, in the Disney Channel's ''In Concert'' series, Saturday at 8 p.m.

title: Economic Outsiders
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-01-00: On Language; Left Coast
description: 'If she was wearing a revealing top,'' wrote The Los Angeles Times in a guide to the geographic origins of guests at a Conga Room party during the Democratic National Convention, ''a short, tight micro-mini and strappy stilettos, if she had that come-hither look, she was definitely Left Coast.''

title: The Mundane Transformed, As Exotic Objects
description: Five years ago, Linda Pagan opened the Hat Shop at 120 Thompson Street (between Spring and Prince Streets). After leaving a job on Wall Street, she began vacationing in countries like Kenya and India and brought back handmade merchandise that did not exactly fit the mandates of her first shop; they were not hats, nor were they made by New York artisans.

title: Another Attack Ad, but Criticism Goes Awry
description: AS state Republicans see it, the mistake in their soft-money television commercial targeted at Steve J. Israel, the Democratic candidate for the Second Congressional District seat, was just an innocent error. As the Israel campaign sees it, the ad was evidence that the Republicans don't know Suffolk County.

title: Ecuador's Electricity Meets Global Power
description: THIS is a story about the search for corporate citizenship, and a cautionary tale of money, influence and the limits of American power.

They were on their way to Riverside Park. ''It is the quietest street I've lived on in New York,'' he said of Riverside Drive, where he has spent four years.

This past off-season, Al Groh -- the now undefeated Groh -- thought his chances of becoming a head coach were so minuscule that he strongly considered leaving professional football and coaching in college again.

title: FUEL-PROOF PROSPERITY
description: Two Rutgers economists, speaking at their annual seminar for state officials and lobbyists in Trenton last week, said that soaring energy prices will not end the state's economic boom. Joseph Seneca, vice president of academic affairs at Rutgers and chairman of the Governor's Council of Economic Advisors, and James Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, acknowledged that high energy prices historically touch off a recession. But ''the New Jersey economy and national economy are much less dependent on energy than they were a decade ago and two decades ago,'' Mr. Seneca said.

title: In Japan, Pathfinders Romancing The Camera
description: EAST is East, and West is West, and never the twain shall meet'' may be good poetry, but it's a limited world view. Eastern and Western religions, cultures and arts have mixed and married and traded ever so profitably with each other for centuries. (And then, of course, there's actual trade, where meeting means less than money.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, ROBERT W., SR.
description: MARSHALL-Robert W., Sr. Of Summit, New Jersey, whose career with Bell Laboratories spanned more than four decades, died on Friday, September 29, 2000 at Overlook Hospital after a long illness. He was 87 years old. Marshall, who retired from Bell Laboratories in 1977, was a patentee of various radar and underwater tracking systems and devoted much of his career as an electrical engineer in research, development, and quality assurance of integrated circuitry. He worked in the Whippany, Murray Hill, and Holmdel labs. Marshall was detailed to the U.S. Department of Defense during World War II. During the post-Korean War years Marshall served with the U.S. Army Air Corps' Intelligence forces in the North Atlantic. A contributor to several professional journals, Marshall was a member of IEEE and the American Society of Engineering Education. He was also a very active member of Central Presbyterian Church in Summit, NJ serving for many years as Superintendent of the Church School and as an Elder. He was also a member of the Board of Development at Princeton Theological Seminary. During his retirement Marshall was much involved in the Old Guard of Summit, serving as Program Chairman for several years. A native of Minneapolis, Marshall graduated from the University of Minnesota School of Engineering in 1934. He received an M.S. with honors from Columbia University in 1936 and was inducted into the Sigma Xi Honor Society. He was married to the late Alexandra Babcock Marshall for 54 years. Marshall is survived by his children, Robert W., Jr. and his wife Karen of Newtown Square, PA, Carlile Babcock Marshall of Summit, NJ and Ann Kelsey Marshall of Alexandria, VA. A Service of Celebration will be held at the Central Presbyterian Church on Thursday, October 5, 2000 at 11 o'clock am.

title: Sara Naison-Phillips, Malik Russell
description: Sara Naison-Phillips, the daughter of Elizabeth Phillips and Mark Naison of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Malik Naki Russell, the son of Dawn Russell of Brooklyn. Rabbi Miriam S. Ancis is to officiate at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Taking Care Working With Stone
description: WORKING with natural stone can be a rewarding experience because a project finished in stone has a rustic charm that is unmatched in any other building material. Stone is easy to work with because it requires minimal dressing and shaping, although gathering and positioning stones calls for a lot of muscle and sweat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEITRICK, JOHN E., SR., M.D.
description: DEITRICK-John E., Sr., M.D. The Boards, Faculty and Staff of Weill Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences of Cornell University and New YorkPresbyterian Hospital are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend, Dr. John E. Deitrick, Sr., who served as Dean of Cornell University Medical College from 1957-1969. During his long and distinguished career, Dr. Deitrick was one of the leading figures in American medical education. He joined The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in 1934 as a resident in medicine and subsequently became a member of the Medical College faculty in the Department of Medicine. In 1949, he took a leave of absence from the Medical Center to direct a comprehensive survey of medical education for the Association of American Medical Colleges and the American Medical Association, which published his landmark report: ''Medical Schools in the United States at the Mid-Century.'' In 1957, Dr. Deitrick returned to New York-Cornell to become Dean of the Medical College. Among his many accomplishments was a significant increase in the ration of faculty to students, with the number of faculty increasing by 43% during his deanship. From 1962 to 1969, he served as a Trustee of Cornell University, representing the faculty of the Medical College. In 1969, when he retired from the Deanship, he became Professor Emeritus of Medicine. In 1982, Dr. Deitrick received New York-Cornell's highest honor, the Maurice R. Greenberg Distinguished Service Award, in recognition of his exceptional and longstanding service. We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Dietrick's children, Sara, John, and William, and their children.

title: FILM; A Poet of Middle-Class Life, Played Out in Taiwan
description: THE Taiwanese director Edward Yang, who accompanied his film ''Yi Yi'' (''A One and a Two'') to the Telluride Film Festival last month, was almost through answering questions after a screening when a middle-aged woman took the floor.

description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 30  Beginning on Sunday, the dealers and manufacturers of every new handgun sold in Maryland will have to give state police a spent shell casing carrying the weapon's ballistic fingerprint.

description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 30  There were times this year when the Iron Man looked like an old man.

title: In an Ex-Soviet Land, High Hopes Are Ebbing
description: The factories built as part of the great Soviet industrialization undertaken for Stalin, Georgia's native son, stand empty. The ugly concrete apartment houses for the workers are crumbling. The shops display few wares, and every traffic light is off to save electricity.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE FEELING OF WHAT HAPPENS: Body and Emotion in the Making of Consciousness, by Antonio Damasio. (Harvest/Harcourt, $15.) A neurologist, drawing on the experiences of patients over many years, explains the difference between intelligence and consciousness and the central role of emotion and feelings in forming consciousness. His account, chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 1999, is ''a must-read book . . . on one of the greatest unsolved mysteries,'' William H. Calvin wrote in these pages.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-01-00: The Ethicist; To the Point
description: As part of our training in acupuncture, we students practice on one another for two years prior to becoming student clinicians. I have been hurt many times by fellow students and have seen situations that breach the bounds of ''do no harm.'' Is it unethical to make us guinea pigs for inexperienced fellow students? Would I betray my profession if I sued my school for the harm done to me and to stop this dangerous practice? -- Anonymous

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELLER, ROBERT G., ESQ.
description: SHELLER-Robert G., Esq. Died peacefully on September 26, 2000 at the age of 93. Husband of the late Helen Reiser Sheller. Father of Elly Sheller Rufer and the late Ed Sheller. Grandfather of Alexandra and Christopher Sheller, Daniel and Kate Rufer. Brother of the late Frances Snyder and uncle of Joan Steiner and Martin Snyder. Father-in-law to John Rufer. Brother-in-law to the late Florence Reiser Shultz. Litigator extraordinaire! He was a force in the courtroom for over 60 years. Avid card player: from casino with his grandchildren, to weekly bridge games with the ladies. We will always miss his amazing intellect, his incredible wit and his pragmatic approach to life. As requested, no services will be held. Donations may be made in his memory to the Summit School, 187-30 Grand Central Parkway, Jamaica Estates, New York 11432.

title: Introduction
description: Many readers of our cover article on teenagers doing time in adult prisons were shocked at the thought of hardened criminals serving as stand-in parents for these adolescent inmates. And Hillary Clinton a bluestocking? Some said that she has clouded rather than illuminated feminist issues.

title: A Family That Tried to Be Both Rich and Good
description: THE new season's crop of television shows is transmitting an oddly puritanical message: the pursuit of wealth breeds immorality -- or, at the very least, extreme vulgarity. On ''Bull,'' the new TNT series, the founder of a prosperous investment banking firm is a manipulative, coldhearted schemer who doesn't flinch from organizing an illegal trade -- and then foisting responsibility on somebody else. The young hotshot stockbrokers in ''The Street'' on Fox break up their day with quickies in the bathrooms and amuse themselves by urinating prankishly in coffee cups. On NBC's ''Titans,'' the latest nighttime soap opera from Aaron Spelling, an heir to an aeronautics fortune discovers that his former lover is about to become his stepmother -- and she's pregnant with his baby.

description: The National Football League career of Minnesota center Matt Birk changed dramatically last Feb. 15 when his former teammate Jeff Christy, a five-time Pro Bowl selection, signed as a free agent with the Vikings' division-rival Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: Brains and the Bus
description: ''It's O.K. to Be Smart'' is not your standard graffito. But that's what's written on the yellow Brain Quest Bus, which will visit New Jersey for six weeks starting Oct. 10. The bus, which promotes the popular question-and-answer card game, will hold Brain Quest Challenges for children in second through fifth grades at various schools. All participants will get a prize -- a T-shirt, mouse pad, stickers or tattoos -- whether their answers are right or not. The winners at each school become that school's team, and face teams from other county schools. The winning school gets $500 worth of library books from Workman, which puts out Brain Quest. The bus will visit Camden County Oct. 10 to 14; Middlesex County Oct. 16 to 21; Morris County Oct. 23 to 28; Essex County Oct. 30 through Nov. 4; and Bergen County Nov. 6 through 11. The full schedule is available on the Web at www.brainquest.com by clicking on the yellow bus. After the bus rolls on, the stops will be memorialized in a diary on the site.

description: THEY don't write, they don't call, and they don't wait for an invitation to make themselves comfortable in your home.

description: THINKING about starting a coin collection? You probably already have. Just pull the change out of your pocket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOREHOUSE, EDWARD J.
description: MOREHOUSE-Edward J. Of Chappaqua, died Thursday, September 28, 2000, at Northern Westchester Hospital. He was born on December 8, 1920, in San Francisco, CA, to the late Edward C. and Katherine (Kerwin) Morehouse. He was 79. Mr. Morehouse was a graduate of UC-Berkeley. He worked for 25 years as an executive vice president of HarrimanRippley and retired as a vice president for Merrill Lynch in 1985. He was a former member of the Campfire Club and a devoted fisherman as well as as an avid turkey hunter. During WWII, Mr. Morehouse served in the US Navy in the Pacific. He held the position of Executive Officer on the submarine Pomfret. He married Martha Jean Bernstein on October 26, 1946, in Kingston, NY. She died in May of 2000. He is survived by three sons, John, Peter, and Stephen; a daughter, Margaret; one brother, Vincent; and his sister, Jean Ritchie. He was grandfather of six. His son Jeffrey died earlier. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 7, at 11 AM, at Bedford Community Church, 160 Bedford Center Road, Bedford Hills, NY. Interment was private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to the American Cancer Society, Westchester Division, Inc., 2 Lyon Place, White Plains, NY 10601 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; After the Last Picture Show
description: The boarded-up movie theaters in Michael Putnam's SILENT SCREENS: The Decline and Transformation of the American Movie Theater (Johns Hopkins University, $39.95) wear their faded glamour like battered hats. Putnam's photographs, taken with an 8 by 10 view camera, are starkly formalistic: the boxy, Art Deco theaters are largely shot head-on and centrally placed in the frame, making the viewer conscious of minute variations in detail and texture. The stylized neon marquees that read ''Ritz,'' ''Lux'' or ''Judy'' contrast with the blank, peeling facades, as if we can see the dream palace that once was and the shell it has become. In the two decades since he started the project, Putnam found the old theaters were disappearing like buffalo from the plains. The film historian Robert Sklar points out in his introduction that although local cinemas figure prominently in our national mythos, they actually were a secondary source of revenue for Hollywood. In a 1948 antitrust case, the Supreme Court ruled that the studios held a monopoly because of their control over the vastly more influential metropolitan first-run theaters, which constituted less than 1 percent of the 10,000 screens in the country. Larry McMurtry, who wrote the novel ''The Last Picture Show,'' says that the old theaters are ''structural Quixotes, exhausted and brought to rest by brute reality, yet retaining in the gaunt and stubborn angles of their facades a suggestions of the visions, cheap but romantic, that once rolled like great clouds across their screens.'' Eric P. Nash

title: River touring from the Nile and Irrawaddy to the Snake and Willamette
description: Barge operators in Europe traditionally shut down from about November to April, but travelers seeking river cruises then can find them in Egypt, where winter is prime season, as well as in China, Myanmar, the United States and South America.

description: The campaign debate over prescription drugs for the elderly has become a confusing muddle of partisan charges and countercharges, with both sides invoking the standard bogymen of health care debates, from ''big government'' to ''H.M.O. bureaucrats.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANKOW, ROBIN M.
description: RANKOW-Robin M. On Sept. 22, 2000. Professor Emeritus and Attending Surgeon, Head and Neck Surgery, Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons. Attending Surgeon, Yale University, New Haven Medical Center, 1979-1985. Authored surgical atlas, medical texts, numerous articles. Past President, American Society of Maxillofacial Surgeons; New York Chapter, Association of Military Surgeons. Colonel, U.S. Army Reserve, served in World War II with military commendations. Predeceased by his first wife, Elaine. Survived by his daughter, Leslie, of New York and by Jane Whitman, of Tuscon, Arizona. Private interment at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to Columbia University, C/O The Association of Alumni, 650 W. 168th St., NY NY 10032.
