description: On the eve of an election campaign some 30 years ago, Richard Nixon described himself as being ''tanned, rested and ready.'' Three decades along, on the threshold of yet another America's Cup crusade, the same could be said of Russell Coutts.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, LOTTIE
description: BERNSTEIN-Lottie. Four years have passed. Love forever. Beyond time and beyond space. George

title: In London, Ho-Hum Ends In Smash Finale
description: It was close to midnight on Wednesday in the old Gainsborough film studios when the last of the reporters and camera crews elbowed their way into the grim little corner where Hussein Chalayan waited. Mr. Chalayan is famously aloof, and at times his comments add up to mumbo jumbo, but there is nothing vague about his talent. It punches you in the nose with its audacity, and makes you feel grateful for the blow. Without Mr. Chalayan and Alexander McQueen here to deliver such jolts, the British spring 2001 collections would be as inconsequential as a baby's burp.

title: Pipe-Major Brian MacRae, Bagpiper for Queen, Is Dead at 58
description: Brian MacRae, who for 15 years was the Queen of England's personal bagpiper, died on Sept. 3. He was 58.

title: Rebels in Colombia Warn U.S. to Avoid Front-Line Combat
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 30  Marxist rebels have warned American soldiers based in Colombia that they will be declared a "military target" if they take any front- line combat role in the nation's long- running war.

title: Bon Voyage Doesn't Mean What It Used To
description: A TICKET for two passengers (Biglietto di Passaggio) on the Andrea Doria, sailing March 31, 1956, from New York to Naples, fluttered out of an old suitcase of mine the other day. Under ''Nome dei Passeggeri'' are our names: ''Mr. and Mrs. Maxime Furlaud.'' In another miscellany of forgotten letters and bills, I've found a blurry, distant photograph of Max and me looking over the rail as the liner eased away from the pier, to head slowly down the Hudson estuary to the sea. I am wearing glasses so I can see the friends on the dock who are taking the picture -- at least six of them, not counting my mother, who had come to see us off. Somewhere I have the picture Max took of these friends, waving heartily at us.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DURR, ERNESTINE B.
description: DURR-Ernestine B. Died peacefully at home at age 95 on August 24, 2000. Memorial Service at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue at 61st Street, Manhattan, on Saturday, October 14, 2000, at 11:00 A.M. Memorial donations may be made in her name to St. Peter's Lutheran Church of Manhattan, 619 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10022, or to The Wartburg Foundation, Wartburg Place, Mount Vernon, NY 10552.

title: Uncorking Chateau du Basement
description: HOME winemaking is a well-worn first step toward a commercial career, as Kip Bedell, the North Fork merlot master on Long Island, can attest. The hobby that began in his Garden City basement in 1970, when he made five gallons from riesling grape concentrate, culminated in February in the $5 million sale of Bedell Cellars. Not a bad return.

title: The Empty Booth
description: ON primary day last month, E. S. Dixon and Janet Ingram sat in the basement of a public housing project in north Brooklyn and stared at an empty voting booth.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TOLKIN, ISABEL
description: TOLKIN-Isabel. Four years gone, but a lifetime of memories to recall and remember, of a special lady, our Mom, Grandma and Great-grandma. Your Children, Grandchildren and Great-grandchildren

title: Businessman Pleads Guilty To Cheating His Workers
description: The owner of one Long Island company has pleaded guilty to cheating workers out of $300,000 in wages, and two officials at another company face similar charges that they underpaid workers by nearly $780,000, the authorities said today.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-01-00; Female Troubles
description: A new prescription drug from Eli Lilly has recently reached the market. Carefully packaged to appeal to consumers, the pill is a pretty pink-and-lavender capsule, available in a light blue box. It's sold under the liltingly soft name Sarafem, which sounds like the angels known for the quality of their spiritual love. Although the name sounds equally like Esperanto for a beleaguered husband's fantasy -- a serene wife. So -- a prescription for divine quietism and devotion, clothed to appeal to the woman who favors Monet hues? Hard not to smile at the transparency of the imagery, especially when you discover that the medication is for premenstrual irritability and bloating -- and that it isn't a new drug at all, only Prozac in drag.

title: QUICK BITE/Carteret; These Eyes Spy Cheese Fries
description: Wisconsin is synonymous with cheese, and for potatoes, you've got to go with Idaho. But when it comes to combining the two, New Jersey takes the cake. (I do not know which state takes the cake for cake.) I'm talking, of course, about cheese fries. You were thinking maybe potatoes au gratin? Sorry, mon ami; this is the New Jersey section, not Le Figaro. Driving along Roosevelt Avenue in Carteret, I believed I had stumbled across the Cheese Fry Holy Grail. Could it be -- a restaurant named Cheese Fries? With a 24-hour drive-through window? That's what it said on the bright yellow sign just off the road. But it was not to be. The establishment was, in fact, Burger Express. Had I approached from the other direction, I would have thought its name was Fried Chicken. Entering Burger Express was like stepping back in time, into my beloved world of 1970's fast food: dark wood paneling, rounded corners on rectangular windows. The ambience harked back to a simpler, pre-McNugget era, before environmental activists sprung the Quarter Pounder from its plastic foam cage. Alas, I was derailed from my retro reverie by an unmistakable train theme, with faded railroad photos on the wall, and a burger named The Locomotive ($3.84). I ordered a Big Broiler with cheese ($2.34), and admired some atypical fast-food menu items, such as grilled cheese with tuna ($3.04) and grits ($1.74). But let's face it, I was there for the cheese fries ($2.55). They came in a generous portion of crisp, hot crinkle-cuts, smothered in a hearty but not overpowering cheese sauce. Served in a plastic foam container, no less. To the young entrepreneurs out there: The restaurant name Cheese Fries is apparently still available. I am easily reached for consulting. JACK SILBERT

title: When Women Step Into the Ring
description: IT was largely the romantic obsession of male writers and moviemakers that first elevated boxing from barroom backwater to relative respectability early in the 20th century. From Damon Runyon's columns in The New York American, Hemingway's ruminations on the ''sweet science'' and Clifford Odets's play ''Golden Boy,'' to Norman Mailer's discourse on the Thrilla in Manilla, and Martin Scorsese's ''Raging Bull,'' boxing has long stood as a metaphor for male angst and aggression. The lawlessness of the boxing establishment -- still evident today -- invited riffs on exploitation and the corruptibility of the soul.

title: Homecoming for a Jazz Artist
description: The jazz artist Eric Alexander returns to his alma mater, William Paterson University, this afternoon.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Shearing the Flock
description: Wendell Berry's new novel, JAYBER CROW (Counterpoint, $25), is an observant and agreeably rough-hewn book that relates the life story of a young man who abandons his plans to become a minister and becomes the town barber instead. Like so much of Berry's fiction -- he has also written many volumes of poetry and acerbic social commentary -- Jayber Crow'' is set in the fictional small town of Port William, Ky. We suffer with Jayber as he watches the object of his affections, a young woman named Mattie, marry her high school sweetheart, Troy Chatham. Troy exploits her father's land and betrays her. Mattie's marriage to Troy becomes a metaphor for the dying prosperity of small southern towns like Port William, and for the withering of family ties. But as Jayber, a bachelor who is losing his hair, narrates his own tale of unrequited love, he reflects upon the stories he hears as he's giving a shave or a haircut -- and he is somehow buoyed. ''The world doesn't stop because you are in love or in mourning or in need of time to think,'' he says. ''And so when I have thought I was in my story or in charge of it, I really have been only on the edge of it, carried along.'' The novel's digressive structure makes for a slow start, but by the end this melancholy barber has won both our attention and our hearts. Gail Gilliland

title: A Month That Couldn't End Fast Enough
description: Investors hope that it's over now -- the punishing string of earnings warnings that has relentlessly pushed down stocks, especially the high-wire technology stocks. Apple, Intel, Sprint, Eastman Kodak, UAL and a host of other big names announced that they would disappoint Wall Street as the third quarter closed.

title: A Love Boat Is Rated G
description: FOR several years before their 50th wedding anniversary, my partner's parents, Frank and Lucy, knew exactly how they wanted to celebrate the occasion. ''In March of 2000,'' they would tell their children, their children's spouses and partners, and their grandchildren, ''we're taking all of you on a Caribbean cruise.''

title: THEATER; Thoughts on the Perfect Play in Rome's Colosseum
description: THE moment for ''Oedipus Rex'' has come round again. It popped up on Broadway in the late 1940's, when I, an eager student, saw the most acclaimed actor on the English-speaking stage, Laurence Olivier, portray the hapless young man who solves the riddle of the Sphinx, is rewarded with a kingdom and a queen, attempts to rid his land of a plague and discovers the truth.

title: Bush Tempers His Remarks On Abortion
description: Gov. George W. Bush told an annual conference of the Christian Coalition today that the country needed to place more value on ''the life of the unborn'' and that he would sign a law to ban late-term abortions.

title: CART Hires Recruiters to Find a Successor to Rahal as Chief
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 30  CART is trying a different approach in looking for a new leader.

title: Miriam Kim, Ming Chang Shih
description: Miriam H. Kim, the daughter of Huicha and Shinyol Kim of Basking Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday in Bernardsville, N.J., to Ming Chang Shih, the son of Joyce Chang Seprish of Rockaway, N.J., and Dr. Shawn Shih of Nei-Li, Taiwan. The Rev. Peter G. Hofstra performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Bernardsville.

title: Playing Field Can Be Level, Even Amid the Hype
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Even as the French basketball team was chiseling a few more cracks in the American men's basketball monolith, drawing within 4 points in the second half of the gold medal game yesterday, I was wondering how the Israeli kayaker was doing in the men's K1 500-meter sprint out in Penrith.

title: An Architect's Contribution
description: To the Editor:

title: You Can Take the State Out of Montclair
description: Montclair State University is -- as the name says -- a state school, with 13,500 students, most of them middle-class commuters. But between 8 and 9 p.m. tonight, it will be ''a prestigious school on the other side of the tracks, populated by kids who act as if they're on top of the world that they own anyhow.''

title: Fay Alexander, Circus and Movie Daredevil, Dies at 75
description: Fay Alexander, who soared to stardom as one of the few trapeze artists to execute a triple somersault and who performed the aerial maneuvers for movie characters played by Tony Curtis, Doris Day and others, died on July 16 at his home in Sarasota, Fla.

title: The World: Naked Power; The Emperor of Serbia Runs Out of Clothes
description: SLOBODAN MILOSEVIC'S gift was an ability to persuade Serbs that someone was out to get them -- and that much of the world was in on the plot.

title: Shredding the Concept of 'Deadbeat Dads'
description: PAY, pay, pay. That's what divorced fathers are forced to do, said Sari Friedman, a matrimonial lawyer in Garden City with a mostly male clientele. Even divorced fathers who are nurturing, devoted and involved with their children's lives. They, too, are sometimes treated like wallets.

title: Choices Read Like a Culinary Map of U.S.
description: WHO is Mae Browne? She's the grandmother of Kathleen Zadrozny, the owner of a new Huntington Station restaurant. Her wedding photo (circa 1934) graces the foyer of this namesake restaurant.

title: INVESTING WITH: Jean-Pierre Conreur; Tocqueville Small Cap Value Fund
description: ALEXIS DE TOCQUEVILLE, the French historian and philosopher, visited the young United States in the early 1830's and wrote ''Democracy in America,'' concluding that the democratic system would indeed survive for the long term.

title: Corrections
description: An automobile review of the Mi tsubishi Montero last Sunday misstated the vehicle's towing capacity. It is 5,000 pounds, not 1,500.

title: A Zen Priest and the Art of Black Serenity
description: SHE was sitting in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden the other day, feeding a duck out of her hand. She looked serene, as befitted a soon-to-be-ordained Zen priest.

title: Our Towns; The Lonely Run of the Other Guy in Lieberman's Other Race
description: THE mayor of Waterbury?'' asked a commuter on the train platform. ''I thought he was in jail.''

title: Giants Try to Alleviate the Pressure on Collins
description: The words were blistering and seemed excessive. Kerry Collins, the Giants' quarterback, had failed to guide the team back from its first deficit last week against the Washington Redskins, and then stood behind a podium and told reporters the loss was his fault. Given a chance to share the blame, Collins repeated his admission of guilt.

title: Close Race For House Is So Polite
description: The House candidates in Michigan's Eighth Congressional District seem so committed to being nice that they have trouble explaining why people should vote for them and not the opposition.

title: The Client
description: RESCUING JEFFREY By Richard Galli. 194 pp. Chapel Hill, N.C.: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $19.95.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in this section last Sunday with an article about televised presidential debates misidentified the one shown. It was the last of four between John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon in 1960; it was not their first, which was the first televised presidential debate.

title: Yankees Confidence Is Shaken by Late-Season Slump
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 30  Everything on the periphery is disappearing and the Yankees are face to face with the most significant obstacle that could prevent them from winning the World Series for the third consecutive year: their own wretched slump.

title: Harry Paster, 74, an Adviser To Madison Avenue Executives
description: Harry Paster, who rose from a $60-a-week statistician to become a valued adviser to the most rich and powerful executives of Madison Avenue, died on Tuesday at his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 74.

title: The Supreme Court And the Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Native American Theater Takes Its Heritage Front and Center
description: THERE are easier things to do than run a community theater, especially one with a Native American theme. It's a concept that escapes most people, said Marty Black Eagle Carl, founder, president and producing artistic director of Algonkuin Theater Company in Hamden.

title: Fleeing Isolation for the Bonds of Humankind
description: TWO prisoners flatten themselves like salamanders against a chain fence in their climb to glimpse freedom. Wordlessly, their faces exchange impressions of life beyond jail before dissolving in rage and tears. Then one softly sings of dreams. It's a daring show of vulnerability that triggers a savage beating from the other, whose weapon is a bedspring that once served them as lovers.

title: PUBLISHER MOVING TO NEWARK
description: Last week, Matthew Bender, a leading legal publishing house, announced that it would move its headquarters from Manhattan to downtown Newark, taking offices in the National Newark Building. Gene McGovern, senior vice president of operations for Matthew Bender, said the company, a subsidiary of Lexis-Nexis Group, chose Newark for its ''dramatic cost advantage,'' and the ease with which its 250 employees, 80 percent of whom live in New Jersey and New York City, can reach Newark. He said the presence of two law schools, Seton Hall and Rutgers, also made Newark a logical choice. When Matthew Bender moves in, possibly by next spring, the National Newark Building, a 34-story neoclassical tower, will be 85 percent occupied, said Arthur Stern, chief executive of Cogswell Realty Group, the building's owner.

title: A Future In N.H.L., But Maybe No Present
description: Barring a trade, the future doesn't appear to be now for two 19-year-old Rangers.

title: Letters: Suggestion Box for United Airlines
description: To the Editor: Re "Righting United Airlines: Nine Flight Plans" (Sept. 10), in which airline experts, professors and consumer advocates offered their ideas for solving the carrier's labor and service problems:

title: A Matter of Degree? Not for Consultants
description: THERE was a doctor from Boston and a lawyer from Chicago, a philosopher from Australia and an engineer from France. There were people who had Ph.D.'s in mathematics, sociology and astronautics. In fact, in the tiered classroom filled with 50 clean-cut, casually dressed people in their 20's and 30's, there seemed to be just about every graduate degree imaginable, except one: the M.B.A.

title: Whether You Win or Lose, It Is Fun Playing Games
description: WHEN it comes to games, it seems there are those who do and those who don't -- enjoy playing them, that is. And then -- in a category all their own -- are those who take their games very, very seriously.

title: Sizing up Children's Museums...Sending In Pint-Size Critics; Newcomer Is Put Through Its Paces
description: THE Stepping Stones Museum for Children opened here in March after eight years of planning and fund-raising. Its one-story building in Mathews Park contains six galleries that offer about 40 different activities for children up to 10 years old.

title: Powerful Delbarton Trails at Halftime for a Change, and Has to Rally to Win
description: For two seasons, the Delbarton Green Wave had cruised into its locker room each week with a comfortable halftime lead.

title: The Nation: Lights, Camera ...; It's Not Only What You Say, but How
description: IF Al Gore and George W. Bush really want to win over millions of Americans in their first debate on Tuesday night, they might dispense with the briefing books, give their policy advisers the weekend off and get some tips from a pro: Mark Burnett, the executive producer of the megahit television show ''Survivor.''

title: A Refuge for Injured Wildlife
description: WHILE others in the state are debating whether to allow hunting of some of the 1,000 or so black bears that live in northern and western New Jersey, Tracy Nash Leaver is rescuing black bears, mostly injured or abandoned cubs, and caring for them while they recuperate or grow up.

title: Article 2000100190882205548 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHULMAN, NATHAN
description: SCHULMAN-Nathan. July 8, 1905September 27, 1984. In memory of our dear father, Nat Schulman. A very special man. Brenda and Evelyn

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the second day of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Sundays of Bluesy Jazz And Food
description: FOR the last 20 years, the region's jazz fans have faithfully circled the dates on their calendars: the second Sunday of each month from September through April.

title: Mets' White Squares His Feet
description: Rick White, the Mets right-hander who has struggled lately, studied videotape on Wednesday, searching for flaws. He and the pitching coach, Dave Wallace, went down the checklist of typical mechanical problems but could find nothing wrong.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Star Shining Brightly Amid a Regional Galaxy
description: JULY 6, 1996 was not your typical day at the Denver International Airport. A crowd of 200 jammed a United Airlines gate, drumming, dancing and singing to welcome 15 members of the Maasai tribe of Kenya. The Maasai, tall and proud in their traditional red plaid and beaded collars, bracelets and earrings, were met by their equally vivid hostess, Cleo Parker Robinson. Wearing a bright blue dress, auburn braids and inchlong crimson fingernails, Ms. Robinson led the group through the concourse to the shuttle train and, above the continuing din, surveyed the scene, beaming her megawatt smile. The Maasai's visit, the culmination of a cultural exchange between Ms. Robinson's Denver-based dance ensemble and its sister city counterpart in Nairobi, was Ms. Robinson's brainchild and another fulfillment of her vision of dance as a bridge between cultures, nations and people.

title: Bits of Latin. Pieces of Anglo. All Iconoclastic.
description: IF you're a pop musician, there are two ways of going through your parents' record collection. One way is to mimic whatever recent or distant past appeals to you, which is the way most North Americans do it. The second way, the route that more and more Latin Americans are taking -- with their built-in consciousness of mestizo culture -- is a sort of self-examination. It involves taking bits and pieces of the regional culture that your family has lived in and combining them with new music to make a portrait of who you are.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about the fiddler Randal Bays, with the fall arts calendar, misstated the date of his concert at Searing-Roslyn United Methodist Church in Albertson. It will be Oct. 14, not Oct. 16.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a security review at the State Department misstated the effect on promotions of some 200 officials. They have been frozen, not unfrozen, while the review is under way.

title: Galleries Where All Hands Help in Their Own Space
description: WHEN the guy wielding a broom to sweep up the front steps is the same guy who wielded a brush to paint the picture on the wall, it's a good bet that you've entered that corner of the art world known as the cooperative gallery.

title: College Without the Math
description: One of the biggest clouds over any parent's finances is the cost of college tuition -- and the long haul toward setting aside enough to cover it.

title: Cablevision's Chairman Named Richest Resident
description: Charles F. Dolan, the chairman of Cablevision, is Long Island's wealthiest resident, Forbes magazine says. Mr. Dolan, 73, who lives in Oyster Bay, is worth an estimated $3 billion, ranking him 80th on the magazine's list of the 400 richest Americans, published in the Oct. 9 issue.

title: Yale Takes a Different Path
description: Throughout the 1990's, pension funds and university endowments added to their domestic stock holdings to take advantage of the bull market. Not Yale University.

title: If Only It Delivered
description: Two centuries of stunning advances in communications and information technology have brought humanity at last to this. It is now possible, with a few clicks on your Web-enabled cellular phone or hand-held digital assistant, to instantly obtain a map of the shortest route from wherever you are in the world to the nearest Godiva Chocolatier outlet.

description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKAY, THOMAS J.
description: McKAY-Thomas J. of Orangeburg, NY, formerly of Old Tappan, NJ, on September 29, 2000. Beloved husband of Cynthia McKay (nee Habel). Devoted father of Jared and Vanessa McKay. Loving son of Frances McKay (nee Kelly) and the late Raymond. Dear brother of Cecelia Marceaux, Robert and Michael McKay. Funeral from Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kinderkamack Rd, Westwood, NJ, on Monday, October 2, 2000, at 8:45 AM. Funeral Mass at Sacred Heart R.C. Church, Tappan, NY, at 10 AM. Interment, Rockland Cemetery, Sparkill, NY. The family will receive their friends on Saturday from 7-9 PM, and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Memorial gifts to American Heart Association, NJ Affiliate Memorials Program, 2550 Route 1, North Brunswick, NJ 08902-4301, would be appreciated.

title: A Mania for Rock Lives in Video Trove
description: LARRY YELEN exists in two worlds. He is manager of rights and clearances, law and business affairs for VH-1, protecting musicians' copyrights. He is also a major collector of music audio and video recordings.

title: A Mover of Mountains for Womens Sexual Rights
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 29  When Nafis Sadik, an obstetrician from Pakistan, was hired by the United Nations Population Fund more than 20 years ago, family planning in the developing world was largely something bureaucrats foisted on poor women who were targets for meeting fertility-control quotas.

title: Let Them Eat Cake, and Listen to the Music
description: TAKEOUT meals, books on tape, mail order, even the much-abused use of the cell phone -- they're all ways to survive in a time-crunched society. Those employing all these tools and still finding it hard to fit in time for a good time, might try this approach to eating out: bring family or friends to the table and add entertainment.

title: Diary: If Only it Delivered
description: Two centuries of stunning advances in communications and information technology have brought humanity at last to this. It is now possible, with a few clicks on your Web-enabled cellular phone or hand- held digital assistant, to instantly obtain a map of the shortest route from wherever you are in the world to the nearest Godiva Chocolatier outlet.

title: A Mysterious Fall by Favor Hamilton
description: Suzy Favor Hamilton had the fastest time in the world this year in the women's 1,500 meters. Her career best of 3 minutes 57.40 seconds, run with a new assertiveness and an appetite for distance training, made her a favorite for a gold medal in the Sydney Games.

title: Security Deposit Deduction
description: Q After renting an apartment in a midtown co-op for four years, I asked to break my lease. Since the rent was still under the market rent, I thought they would be glad to get rid of me. However, I was told by the management company that I needed to find someone to sublet the apartment whom they would approve. I did that. The management company gave that person his own lease for a higher rent and immediately terminated my lease. The apartment was left in impeccable condition. When I received my security back, however, it was about $1,000 less than I expected. When I called to find out why, I was told that I was being charged for painting the apartment because I broke my lease. Can they do this? . . . Lisa Robin, Manhattan.

title: Aiming Lower on Priceline
description: PaineWebber has named its own price for Priceline.com, and it is a mere fraction of the previous target.

title: Suffolk Tax Revenues Rise Without Sales Tax
description: Despite eliminating its 4 percent sales tax on clothing under $110, sales tax revenues in Suffolk County have actually increased 8.2 percent so far this year, the county budget director announced last week.

title: The Price of Divorce
description: The Unexpected

title: Malena Mathiesen, David Belafonte
description: Malena Knopf Mathiesen, the daughter of Irmgard Mathiesen of Jyderup, Denmark, and the late Aksel H. Mathiesen, was married yesterday to David Michael Belafonte, the son of the singer Harry Belafonte and Julie Belafonte of New York. David N. Dinkins, the former mayor of New York, officiated at the Bryant Park Grill.

title: Palestinian Death Toll Climbs in More Rioting Against Israel
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Oct. 2 -- On the fifth consecutive day of violence originally sparked by a right-wing Israeli politician, Palestinian and Israeli officials today traded blame for the continuing conflict while the Palestinian death toll mounted from what occasionally looked more like war than rioting.

title: Reckonings; Oops! He Did It Again
description: It's confession season on the financial news. With many companies admitting that profits won't measure up to market expectations, programs like CNN's ''Moneyline'' have become painful to watch: night after night executives squirm as interviewers grill them about why earnings fell short of estimates. Needless to say, honest accounting is a given. After all, the interviewers do their homework -- they would pounce on any obviously wrong numbers.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2001 Honda Civic; Honda Nominates Yet Another Conservative Ticket
description: AFTER just three decades in the American auto market, Honda is poised to sell a million cars and trucks in the United States this year. And it was the Civic that built the franchise.

title: Sizing up Children's Museums...Sending In Pint-Size Critics; Where Low Tech Gets a High-Five
description: ADULTS impressed by space-age gadgetry might expect the most popular draw at a children's museum to be the computer-based attractions. But for children, low-tech can be way cool.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: LOWER MANHATTAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, ILSE
description: WARREN-Ilse. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother, Ilse died peacefully on September 28, 2000 after a courageous battle with cancer. She leaves her devoted son and daughter-in-law, Steven and Judith Katten, her cherished grandson, Daniel, and her dear sister and best friend, Irene (Reni) Rendsburg. A woman of grace and beauty, Ilse will be missed by all who knew her. Services at ''The Riverside,'' on Monday, October 2nd, at 12:45 P.M.

title: A Knee Injury Slows Longley
description: Luc Longley's plans of arriving at Knicks training camp with fresh legs and a new start backfired Friday night when the Australian team's 7-foot center hyperextended his left knee in a semifinal loss to France here at the Olympics.

title: MetroStars Save the Best For Their Last Chance
description: Faced with elimination tonight, the MetroStars played their best game of the season, if not their history, beating the Chicago Fire, 2-0, at Giants Stadium.

title: Strip Away The Pretense Of the Games
description: Dear Juan and Dick,

title: End-of-the-Season Dishes Made Easy With Corn and Tomatoes
description: THE calendar may say autumn, but summer lingers at produce stands. There's still time to enjoy fresh sweet corn and ripe tomatoes. And with them, the pungent seasoning provided by fresh cilantro is always welcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUINIER, DORIS I.
description: GUINIER-Doris I. Suddenly passed on September 28, 2000. She was a retired guidance counselor of the NYC Board of Education and a devoted, active participant in many community organizations. Beloved mother of Clotilde Y. Stenson, beloved grandmother of Lisa M. Stenson, Esq., and beloved matriarch of her family. Her wisdom, strength of character and energetic spirit will be deeply missed by family and friends, and she will live on in our hearts forever. Visitation will be held on Thursday, October 5, 4-8 PM, at J. Foster Phillips Funeral Home, Inc, 179-24 Linden Blvd, Jamaica, NY 718526-5656. Funeral service will be held on Friday, October 6, at 10:30 AM, at St. Albans Congregational Church, 172-17 Linden Blvd, St. Albans, NY. Interment will be held on Saturday, October 7, at 11 AM, at Oakland Cemetery, Sag Harbor, NY.

title: Debate Stakes Seen as Critical By Candidates
description: When Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore appear side by side in Boston on Tuesday before the largest single television audience of the presidential campaign, officials in both camps say, the stakes will be far greater than they had anticipated because the contest is so excruciatingly tight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMOND, BERNARD (BERNIE)
description: RICHMOND - Bernard (Bernie). Boca Raton, FL, formerly Lawrence, NY. Survived by wife, Shirley (Zone), son, James; daughterin-law, Cheryl; daughter, Barbara; son-in-law, Michael Brandeis; seven grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. After a long illness, rest in peace, be happy again.

title: Why Pay More? Go Ask The Germans
description: THE events I'm about to relate are almost too terrible to publish in a family newspaper. Nothing is being done to halt the abuse I'm about to describe, but somebody has to blow the whistle. So if you're the squeamish type, turn the page now.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: An Obvious Enchantment

title: Today's Sludge Tank, Tomorrow's Bucolic Pool?
description: Keith Rodan fell in love with the million-dollar view from the roof of his old apartment on Freeman Street, from which he could see the entire East Side of Manhattan spread out like a picture postcard. But there was a blight on the horizon.

title: Chateau du Basement: The '00 Vintage
description: HOME winemaking is a well-worn first step toward a commercial career, as Kip Bedell, the North Fork merlot master on Long Island, can attest. The hobby that began in his Garden City basement in 1970, when he made five gallons from riesling grape concentrate, culminated in February in the $5 million sale of Bedell Cellars. Not a bad return.

title: Art Nouveau to Star At the National Gallery
description: ''Art Nouveau, 1890-1914,'' which opens next Sunday at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, is, according to Paul Greenhalgh, curator of the exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum, among the most extensive collections of the style ever presented. The exhibit closed in London in July, and will travel on to Tokyo in April 2001.

title: Braves Blend to Take Ninth Division Title
description: John Schuerholz was beaming. He knew he was beaming. ''I'm beaming,'' he said.

title: Style; Tea and Strumpets
description: What's the modern-day equivalent of Mary Cassatt's Impressionist tea parties of cakes and chiffon? A Realist Champagne bacchanalia of Lee press-on nails and Doritos, perhaps? Inspired in part by the exclusionary gleam and faux intimacy of fashion shoots, as well as by Cassatt's scenes of social life, Delia Brown has been staging parties, inventing invitees and photographing them, then exquisitely painting the hedonistic results. Of course, she is always invited and In the Scene, one step beyond the 80's artists who used their celebrity to get On the List. In the group show for her graduate degree, she even created her own V.I.P. room with a Champagne party of hired actors cavorting behind velvet ropes while the cheap white-wine masses were kept at bay.

title: Picking Up a Path Trod by Sibelius And Even Haydn
description: AMONG the great crowd of composers working at the moment, the spotlight of current events falls just now on the brilliantly accomplished Magnus Lindberg.

title: FILM; Stretching Sound To Help the Mind See
description: IT disappeared long ago, but in 1972 the Window was still there, peering through milky cataracts of dust, 35 feet above the floor of Samuel Goldwyn's old Stage 7. I never would have noticed it if Richard hadn't suddenly stopped in his tracks as we were taking a shortcut on our way back from lunch.

title: TELEVISION: Track Records; As Thoroughly a Doctor as He Was a Cop
description: SO far, we've had kidney cancer, breast cancer, prostate cancer, leukemia and myelofibrosis,'' says Andre Braugher, reciting the dire list with remarkable equanimity. He is referring, fortunately, not to his personal medical history but to the ordeals undergone weekly by the patients of Dr. Ben Gideon, the hero of the new ABC hospital drama ''Gideon's Crossing,'' which has its premiere on Oct. 10. Playing Dr. Gideon, he says, involves ''a steep learning curve,'' and, judging by the professional coolness with which he is now rattling off the names of life-threatening diseases and risky, radical therapies, it appears that he's negotiating that daunting curve with ease: six weeks into production of ''Gideon's Crossing,'' Mr. Braugher sounds uncannily like a real doctor, able to speak the unspeakable trippingly on the tongue.

title: Truer Than History
description: Since 1972, Gore Vidal has split his time between Ravello, in Italy, and a house in the Hollywood Hills -- which means, he likes to say, that arguably he no longer lives in the United States. He was here for the conventions, however, and returned last month for the revival of his play ''The Best Man'' at the Virginia Theater. The following conversation took place, by phone, when he was briefly back in Italy.

title: Cal Ripken of Suffolk Politics Steps Down
description: DOMINIC J. BARANELLO is something of an institution in Suffolk County politics.

title: Article 2000100190593920015 -- No Title
description: The College Search Game, Spam Included

title: First Arrest Using Cameras In Livery Cabs
description: A Queens teenager has been charged with robbing a cabdriver in what is believed to be the first arrest making use of digital cameras that were placed in thousands of livery cabs after a series of killings this year, police officials said yesterday.

title: Silver Medalists Do Much Agonizing in Defeat
description: Sammie Henson could not contain his anguish tonight. Moments after losing the gold medal flyweight freestyle wrestling match to Namig Abdullayev of Azerbaijan, 4-3, Henson rushed from the stage and under the bleachers of the exposition hall. Wailing and screaming, he raced past stunned spectators in a 5-foot-4 blur, then fell to the floor sobbing inconsolably and rocking on his back.

title: Chemical Bonding With Martini Formulas
description: In this age of synthetics, it seems that nobody wants to bond.

title: Antoinette Yeh, Marc Genovese
description: Antoinette Yeh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tsun-Cheng Yeh of Ardsley, N.Y., was married yesterday to Marc Justin Genovese, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Genovese of Avon, Conn. The Rev. Robert J. Allmen, a priest of the American Catholic Church in the United States, officiated at Oheka, the Otto Kahn house in Cold Spring Hills, N.Y.

title: TELEVISION: Reassessments; It May Be Timely, but It's Way Past Its Prime
description: ON Oct. 18, when Dianne Wiest replaces Steven Hill as ''Law and Order's'' district attorney, the entire cast from the original season will finally be gone. It has been a lingering death, and the ultimate blow will not be a severe one: Adam Schiff, the character played by Mr. Hill, did little these past few seasons beyond muttering ''Make it go away'' whenever he was confronted by the weekly murder-cum-political-headache. Ms. Wiest will almost certainly be an improvement. But her salutary appearance will not be enough to reverse a sorry decline.

title: Discovering Dance in New Jersey
description: The traditions and life in the legendary land on the border between China and Korea are the basis for a dance work, ''White Mountain, Black Water,'' choreographed by Nai-Ni Chen and performed by the Nai-Ni Chen Dance Company, one of the consortium of professional dance companies that make up Dance/New Jersey.

title: Trees to Cabinets, Kitchens to Museums
description: WHEN John Hein sees a beautiful piece of wood, he has the urge to frame it like a picture. When he does, the fact that a usable cabinet or table is built in the process is almost beside the point.

title: Loss of Face At Lockerbie
description: If anything suffered at the Lockerbie trial this week as much as the star witness who withered under cross-examination, it seemed to be the credibility of the American intelligence community.

title: A Much Calmer Life After Oracle
description: FOR an eight-year run as president and chief operating officer of the Oracle Corporation, the world's second-largest software publisher, Ray Lane was the un-Ellison. While Larry Ellison flew his fighter jet, won yacht races, glowered on magazine covers and, as founder and chief executive, served as Oracle's swashbuckling public persona, Mr. Lane was the accessible, old-school corporate veteran back at the office.

title: Oxford Pays a Price for Its Rebound
description: NORMAN C. PAYSON has done it again, almost.

title: Roche: Drug Giant Stubbing Its Toes
description: MARTIN EBNER has a reputation for pushing the giants of Swiss industry and finance to change their ways and pay more attention to shareholder value. But for Mr. Ebner, a maverick investor who is a kind of Swiss Warren Buffett, Roche Holding was a special case. As recently as 1997, shares in Roche, the pharmaceutical giant based here, accounted for 92 percent of Mr. Ebner's profitable Pharma Vision fund, which rose 24 percent a year, on average, through the 1990's.

title: The Cost of the American Dream
description: BANDAGED and bruised, one of the two Mexican immigrant workers from Farmingville who were recently lured to an abandoned building and then attacked was afraid to show his face. ''I guess that's the price you have to pay for the American dream,'' he was quoted as saying about the attempt to murder him.

title: Basketball Gods Come Home, a Bit More Humble
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 2 -- They left before the closing ceremonies, flying to Honolulu for fuel and then onto Los Angeles, where varied connections did them part: Allan Houston to New York. Alonzo Mourning and Tim Hardaway to Miami. Vince Carter to Toronto. Off to their own worlds.

title: The Founding Villains
description: The Creation of America

title: Sept. 24-30; Plan Nears on Everglades
description: The Senate voted to approve a $7.8 billion project intended to restore the Everglades and its ailing ecosystem, a plan supporters called the most ambitious environmental restoration effort ever undertaken. The Everglades has been dying since 1948, when the Army Corps of Engineers rerouted its water flow. Fixing the problem would take 40 years, and Florida would pay half the cost. But the legislation must pass the House, where its prospects are uncertain. Lizette Alvarez

title: Where the Shows Are (or Will Be)
description: The new television season is arriving later than ever; for the rest of this month it will keep falling into place. Here is what prime time is scheduled to look like on the six major broadcast networks once all the shows have found their homes. (Keep in mind that some of the new shows may not last that long.) The Times's television critics, Caryn James and Julie Salamon, have selected 14 shows - some new, some old - that they'll be watching with particular interest.

title: Company Is Silent But Keeps Struggling
description: LESS than two years after winning a Tony Award as outstanding regional theater, the Crossroads Theater Company, in New Brunswick, is struggling to survive.

title: Sept. 24-30; Vatican and China Square Off
description: Beijing and the Vatican have feuded since the Communist victory in China in 1949, but tempers have flared anew over events from the distant past. After the Vatican announced it was canonizing 120 Roman Catholics, including 87 Chinese and 33 Europeans, who were killed in China between 1648 and 1930, angry Chinese officials charged that many were colonial oppressors who ''committed monstrous crimes against the Chinese people.''

title: Lazio's Island; Congressman's Roots Mean Senate Contest on Long Island Will Be Over the Margin, Not the Outcome
description: THE children packed inside the auditorium at the Pulaski Street elementary school in Riverhead on a recent afternoon might have yawned or fidgeted when the man in the suit strode in. Instead they raised the rafters with screams of excitement.

title: Keeping the Day Job While Still Heeding The Call of the Stage

title: Graft in China Flows Freely, Draining the Treasury
description: Gleaming and new, yet hollow and unused, the 28-story Water Resources Administration Building in southwest Beijing stands as a mocking monument to the problems plaguing farmers like Liu Guangyue, whose rice crop has failed this year because of the lack of water.

title: Olympian Narratives
description: Race walking provided the most riveting Olympic moment for television viewers in Mexico. Danes were mesmerized by badminton, South Koreans by their men's field hockey team. Chinese and Swedish fans watched an epic battle between two longtime rivals for table-tennis gold. In the Netherlands, these Olympics were mostly about swimming. In Cameroon, they were about soccer.

title: Yes, She's a Vampire Slayer. No, Her Show Isn't Kid Stuff.
description: THOUGH it's popular with high school and college audiences and has a small following among older viewers, WB's ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' has yet to be taken seriously -- to be removed from the status of cult entertainment. Yet the show is a knockout: as much as ''The West Wing,'' which dominated the recent Emmy Awards, it demonstrates what television can accomplish.

title: Corrections

Robert Ornato owns the restaurant with Nino Antuzzi, not with Michael Christy, who is the executive chef. The report also misstated the price range of Red's wines. They are $20 to $200 a bottle, not under $20.

title: Sept. 24-30; Suharto Case Dropped
description: Indonesia's democratically elected government suffered a setback in its attempt to restore credibility to the rule of law when its corruption case against former President Suharto was dismissed. Doctors said three strokes had left Mr. Suharto unfit to stand trial. The decision touched off street clashes; at least one person was killed. The government of Abdurrahman Wahid had charged Mr. Suharto with embezzling $590 million during his 32-year rule; he and his family are believed to have stolen billions. Mr. Suharto's youngest son has been sentenced to 18 months for corruption.

title: Ideas & Trends: Fewer Strings Attached; The World's Bankers Try Giving Money, Not Lessons

Wolfensohn, respectively the new managing director of the I.M.F. and the World Bank president, stood at an outdoor ceremony with fixed smiles on their faces.

title: A Buffet Line of Cultures in Las Vegas
description: I'D heard that Las Vegas had gone upscale, but I wanted to see for myself. I liked it the old way: gaudy and like nowhere else in the world. Now it seems as if each huge new resort deliberately mimics some other place, wrapping itself in the veneer of an older, more elegant culture: Egypt of the pharaohs, Venice of the doges, Paris, even New York. I wanted to see if Las Vegas had lost its sense of itself.

title: TELEVISION: A Special Section; To Get the Best View of Television, Try Using a Wide Lens
description: A FEW years ago, a party to celebrate the start of a cable arts channel was held at the home of an art collector. The walls were lined with canvases by Jasper Johns and other contemporary painters whose work museums would be happy to have. Yet any idea that this event signaled an easy coexistence of high art and mass media was short-lived. When it was time for a toast, the hostess announced without a trace of irony or self-consciousness, ''We're not television people, my husband and I, but we figure it's not going away so we might as well support an arts channel.''

Their job was reading every word of Playboy Magazine, then offering miniversions of social commentary and media criticism, addressed principally to J. Edgar Hoover.

title: Havana Meets New Orleans On a Syncopated Journey
description: Cubanismo declared Havana and New Orleans ''sister cities'' when it performed on Tuesday night at S.O.B.'s. Old Havana and New Orleans share crumbling, pastel-washed colonial architecture, steamy temperatures and infusions of African culture, from a love of syncopation to clandestine worship of the voodoo and Santeria pantheons of African deities.

title: The Politics of Fuel
description: The sharp rise in oil prices over the last few months has given energy issues new and unexpected prominence in the presidential campaign. But what ought to be a serious debate has been marred by unedifying accusations about who deserves blame for allowing America to sink further into ''dependence on foreign oil.'' Gov. George W. Bush says the Democrats have inhibited oil exploration with their environmental and tax policies. Vice President Al Gore says the Republicans have allowed ''big oil'' to put profits ahead of the American consumer. All this has diverted attention from two inconvenient truths about America's energy problem.

title: Issues for the Supreme Court; Mr. Rehnquist's Dilemma

In a brief statement, Mr. Rehnquist explained that he had decided not to disqualify himself from participating in the court's deliberations on Microsoft even though his son, James Rehnquist, is part of a team of lawyers defending Microsoft against rival companies in a private antitrust case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGASHIMA, HIDEO, M.D.
description: NAGASHIMA-Hideo, M.D. Professor Emeritus at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, died on September 29 at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 70. He was predeceased by his first wife Olga and is survived by his second wife Sachiko; his three sons, Robert, Hidalgo, and Richard; a brother, Yasuo of Tokyo, Japan; and his grandchildren Arthur and Carson. Dr. Nagashima, a pioneering anesthesiologist, helped to develop the careers of countless young Japanese anesthesiologists. He acted as mentor and ''father'' to many young anesthesiologists coming from Japan who had spent one or more fellowship years at Montefiore. Dr. Nagashima was born in Yokosuka City, Japan, on September 9, 1930. He completed his medical degree at Yokohama University School of Medicine in 1957, and that year came to New York, where he began an internship at Fordham Hospital. After completing his internship in 1958, he began his residency training and fellowship at Montefiore Hospital in anesthesiology, beginning a 42-year career there. In 1962, he joined the Montefiore Hospital attending staff and was appointed as an Instructor in Anesthesiology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in 1964. In 1979, Dr. Nagashima achieved the rank of Professor, and was elected membership in the prestigious Association of University Anesthesiologists. He has had a distinguished and fruitful career at Montefiore Hospital. He has been loved and admired by his colleagues, friends, and especially his family. We are deeply saddened, and he will truly be missed. He was a true gentleman in every sense of the word. A ceremony honoring his memory will be held on Wednesday at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, Inc., 491 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605, (914-949-7777) at 4:30 PM, with visiting hours from 46. An additional memorial service will be held at Montefiore Hospital and will be announced at a later date.

description: By the end of the year Texas will likely have set a record for executing people. The number of inmates marched into the death chamber in Texas this year is expected to reach 40 by New Year's Eve. That would be the highest number of prisoners put to death by one state since officials began compiling death penalty statistics from across the country some 70 years ago.

title: Choose Your Partners, and Art Will Be the Winner
description: There's talk, talk and more talk about this being the age of artistic collaboration. It's certainly a time when art forms, genres and media technologies cohabit: theater uses film, video and journalism; dance uses narrative and poetry; and fairly new terms like ''performance art'' and ''music-theater piece'' abound, while old terms like ''opera,'' ''musical'' and ''play'' undergo reconstruction.

title: Working for Women's Sexual Rights
description: When Nafis Sadik, an obstetrician from Pakistan, was hired by the United Nations Population Fund more than 20 years ago, family planning in the developing world was largely something bureaucrats foisted on poor women who were targets for meeting fertility-control quotas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULTE, MAURICE, D.D.S.
description: SCHULTE-Maurice, D.D.S. Peacefully on September 30, 2000, at the age of 94. He was a man of gentleness and humanity, a dedicated professional with a lifelong commitment to social justice. He is mourned by his daughter and sonin-law Marjorie and Michael Engber, his grandsons Benjamin and Daniel, and three generations of nieces and nephews. A memorial gathering will be announced at a later date.

title: Debussy's Bombs Explode In Space
description: Debussy's opera ''Pelleas et Melisande,'' which was revived at the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday, tells us at once not enough and too much. There is no clear information about time, place or even the precise relationships within the family of wandering solitaries that is being observed. And much of what they say is vague or off the point. It is the power of Debussy's music, though, to reveal how remarks that seem stray and almost meaningless, or questions that appear idle, can be tight little burning bombs, fired by one person at another with exact control in games of love and cruelty.

title: Turkish Parliament Convenes, But Generals Remain in Power
description: For four centuries, the imperial council of the Ottoman Empire met in the divan at Topkapi Palace in Istanbul to debate the affairs of the far-flung realm. Shielded behind a grilled window above the exquisitely tiled chamber, the sultan observed the proceedings and dictated his instructions by summoning the grand vizier.

title: Weapons Lab Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Roads: One Goes to the White House
description: As a Yale freshman George W. Bush was the only pledge in his fraternity who could stand up and recite the names of the other 49 pledges. In his first year at Harvard Al Gore was knocking on doors and shaking hands while running for freshman council. In ''The Choice 2000,'' a joint biography of the presidential candidates, these differences still define the men and their campaigns: Mr. Bush's cult of personality and Mr. Gore's marathon of perseverance.

title: U.S. Is No.1, but Parity Follows
description: The American success began with a surprise, on a Saturday morning nearly 20 miles west of downtown Sydney in an agricultural area known as the Cumberland Plain. Nancy Johnson won the first gold medal of the 2000 Olympic Games, and did so in an upset at the 10-meter air rifle event.

title: Investment Banks Rebound in 3rd Quarter
description: Stock prices may be volatile, but somehow investor jitters have not had much impact on the underwriting business. After some rockiness in the spring, the market for debt and equity offerings rebounded in the third quarter, meaning brisk business for the investment bank that bring those offerings to market.

title: Lazio Supports Abortion Pill, Opposing Bush
description: Rick A. Lazio declared yesterday that he supported the F.D.A.'s approval of the abortion-inducing drug RU-486, breaking from the position taken by his party's presidential nominee, George W. Bush. But the Republican candidate for Senate in New York said he opposed allowing the government to pay for the drug for poor women.

description: FleetBoston Financial Corporation, the eighth-largest United States bank, has agreed to buy Summit Bancorp, New Jersey's largest bank, for $7 billion in stock to expand beyond New England.

title: Amid public outrage over oil prices, how much progress on alternatives to fossil fuels? Alas. . . .
description: WITH the price of home heating oil and gasoline near 10-year highs, President Clinton recently released 30 million gallons of oil from the nation's strategic reserve, saying he was concerned about cost and supply over the coming winter. Those developments once again prompt questions about alternatives to fossil fuels. Are we any closer to substitutes for crude oil? Has someone invented a car that runs on water?

title: Already, Knicks' Challenge Is Uphill
description: When General Manager Scott Layden declared 12 days ago that the Patrick Ewing trade would be the Knicks' last before training camp, his words were met with disbelief, not only among those attending that day's news conference at Madison Square Garden, but also among the Knicks' 28 competitors in the National Basketball Association.

Bongard at Blemont Park by five-and-three-quarter lengths over the favorite, Backstreet Blues.

After all, experts argued, the French were used to scandals over the financing of political parties and Mr. Chirac had survived being mentioned in connection with such activities before.

title: Issues for the Supreme Court; The New Term's Docket
description: The new Supreme Court term, which opens today, has no high-profile cases to match last session's tangles over partial birth abortion, gays in the Boy Scouts and organized prayer at high school football games. But even shorn of the Microsoft case, this season will not lack for suspense or importance. The court's docket includes cases that, depending on their outcome, could significantly bolster or weaken environmental protection, federal civil rights, freedom of the press and the Fourth Amendment's shield against unreasonable searches and seizures.

Johnson, Mr. Valenti's political patron and hero.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, THOMAS P.
description: MURPHY-Thomas P. Age 77, of Highlands, NJ, died Saturday, September 30, 2000 at Monmouth Medical Center, Long Branch. He was a retired Circulation Manager of The New York Times and President of The Newspaper Guild, retiring in 1988. After retiring from the paper, he worked for 10 years with the Monmouth Park Racetrack. Mr. Murphy was a communicant of Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church in Highlands. He was also a member of the Lions Club of Highlands, VFW of Highlands, the American Legion Post 143, President of the ''Gravelly Point Beach Association,'' the Knights of Columbus in Brooklyn, and a former Councilman of Highlands. He served his country during World War II in the Navy. Born in Manhattan, he lived in Brooklyn for 20 years where he started the first block association in Bay Ridge before moving to Highlands 31 years ago. Anyone whoever encountered him will always remember that the only thing bigger than his smile was his heart. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Mary Murphy; son Michael Murphy; daughter-in-law Carol Murphy, son George Murphy; daughter Patricia Murphy, all of Highlands; brother James Murphy of Ridgefield Park, NJ; six grandchildren and 14 great grandchildren. Funeral services will be held 11 AM, Tuesday at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, 141 Navesink Ave, Highlands, where a Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated. Interment will be in Fairview Cemetery, Red Bank. The family will receive their friends 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Monday, at John P. Condon Funeral Home, 804 State Highway 36, Leonardo.

title: After Near-Death Experience, U.S. Wins Gold
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sunday, Oct. 1  When Antoine Rigaudeau stepped up and knocked down a 3-pointer with 4 minutes 26 seconds left this afternoon, another anticipated cakewalk in the men's basketball tournament turned into riveting theater at the Super Dome in Olympic Park, the unthinkable again on the minds of the 14,883 in attendance.

title: The Meanest Man vs. Mr. Fingertips
description: When Aleksandr Karelin lost his bid for his fourth consecutive gold medal, it was a struggle for commentators to resist hyperbole. When describing Karelins dominating career, the phrase best wrestler of all time was mentioned repeatedly. After all, Karelin had not lost a single Greco- Roman match since 1987, winning nine world championships to go along with his three Olympic golds. But this is not baseball or football. In wrestling, all time goes back a long way.

title: Taking On 'Turandot' Under Scrutiny
description: The American dramatic soprano Alessandra Marc has an ardent contingent of fans who believe that she has not received her due from the critics and the public. So there was much anticipation before her performance on Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera in the title role of Puccini's ''Turandot,'' its first presentation this season. Ms. Marc, who made her Met debut as Verdi's Aida in 1989, had been scheduled to sing Turandot later this month. But because of the illness of Sharon Sweet, who was to have sung the role on Saturday, Ms. Marc's return to the Met came earlier than expected.

title: Ernst & Young Plans a Training Spinoff
description: The accounting firm of Ernst & Young said it would spin off its online corporate-training operations this week as part of a strategy to become a dominant player in the crowded online corporate-training industry.

title: Is 'Flack Whacking' Good Public Relations?
description: Journalists and public relations people have a bipolar relationship. They need each other, and they often hate it.

title: Vietnamese Refugees In New Orleans Find a Little Peace
description: The Virgin Mary, cast in smooth, white concrete, stands watch in many of the small yards in New Orleans East, her arms spread wide, palms out, as if to signal that this is a good spot to stop, to stay. Two, sometimes three to a square block in the neighborhood, the statues are heavy, permanent, and the plain, tiny houses they guard are brick, built to last. The journey to get here was too hard to even think about moving again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDT, HENRY
description: BRANDT-Henry. On September 30, 2000, at age 77. Beloved husband of Roxanne. Loving father of Pamela Jackson and Jonathan Brandt and father-in-law of Thomas Jackson. Adored grandfather of Natalie. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Monday, 7-9 PM, with service Tuesday, 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Riverside Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to the National Parkinson Foundation, Inc, 1501 N.W. 9th Ave, Bob Hope Road, Miami, FL 33136-1494.

title: 3 Killed in Brooklyn Car Crash
description: Three people were killed and four others were injured when two cars collided early yesterday at a busy intersection in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, the authorities said. The police said they suspected one of the cars ran a red light, but some residents said the light had been broken for two days.

title: Cadbury in Talks To Buy Orangina From Pernod
description: Cadbury Schweppes, the soft-drink company that has agreed to buy Snapple for $1.45 billion, said Friday that it was in talks to buy Pernod Ricard's Orangina.

description: The College Search Game, Spam Included

description: At first glance, the Supreme Court term that opens on Monday figures to be a pale imitation of the blockbuster term that concluded in June.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRYGIER, BEN (BINEM)
description: KRYGIER-Ben (Binem). Died September 29, 2000, at the age of 76, in New York at Sloan Kettering Memorial Hospital. He had battled for many years with great courage and dignity. He will be sorely missed by those who loved him. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, October 3, in Kfar Shmaryahu, Israel.

title: Games Can Go Home: Athens in 2004
description: The handoff looked seamless. On the stage of Stadium Australia tonight, the Olympic flag passed from Sydney to Athens.

title: Bickering and Sputtering, Bucs Lose Second Straight
description: Warren Sapp's demeanor was about as pleasant as a beehive that had just been sprayed with water. Beginning in the second quarter, the Tampa Bay defensive tackle shifted up and down the Washington Redskins' offensive line, giving out equal-opportunity bashings, fighting through double and triple teams and several times body-slamming quarterback Brad Johnson to the ground, sacking him once.

title: SAS Institute Patient With Stock Offering
description: This may be the antithesis of Internet time.

title: A Crime Story of the White-Collar Kind
description: THE INFORMANT

title: Mary Shepard Dies at 90; 'Mary Poppins' Illustrator
description: Mary Shepard, the modest illustrator whose line drawings of Mary Poppins brought to life the ultimate British nanny in a series of seven books by P. L. Travers published from 1933 to 1988, died in London on Sept. 4. She was 90.

title: A Return to Australia Returns Swimming to a Higher Level
description: Ian Thorpe, the young Australian with size- 17 flippers for feet, led a charge of high- promise swimmers into the Sydney Games. And they did not disappoint. In all, 15 world records were set in the 32 events. Fast pools, fast suits and drug use were among the reasons offered for such an increase in swimming performances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, I. JOSEPH
description: HARRIS-I. Joseph. On September 30, 2000. Beloved husband of Hilda. Loving uncle of Harriet DavisKram, Ellen Werther and Martin Kaufman. Dear great-uncle. Services Monday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A picture last Monday with an article about family choices that can blunt the effect of video violence carried an incorrect credit. The picture, of Brian and Osiris Garcia, who play video games in their room, was by Giorgio Palmisano for The New York Times.

title: Yankees Draw Oakland, Young Team on the Rise
description: Like a lot of friends gathering on a Sunday to watch a big game, the Yankees surrounded a television in their clubhouse here this evening. But they were all dressed in coats and slacks and ready to travel. The outcome of the games would determine where they would start the playoffs.

title: Parity, Equality or Mediocrity? It's Your Call
description: The dictionary definition of parity and the one invoked in today's sport culture are rarely the same. In my edition of Webster's, the word means the state or condition of being the same in power, value, rank, etc.; equality. When commissioners of professional leagues, or their surrogates -- that is, television executives -- use the word, it's usually in response to dwindling fan interest, low ratings or the unexpected decline of a powerhouse or two.

title: Metro Matters; Polls Count, But Could Use A Closer Look
description: THE Polls as Good.

title: New York Olympic Stadium Plan Masks Shaky Political Coalition
description: Proposals for a stadium on the far West Side of Manhattan seem to emerge every year as the solution to a problem, like a way to keep the Yankees in town or to get the Jets back from out of town.

title: Quandary for Sather: Where Does Rookie Go?
description: Coach Ron Low singled out the rookie defenseman Mike Mottau again for his play as the Rangers ended their preseason schedule with a 2-1 victory over the Islanders today at the Hartford Civic Center.

title: About the Tables
description: Beginning tomorrow and continuing through Dec. 29, Business Day will include a second section, World Business (Section W), on Tuesdays through Fridays. That section will consist of international business news as well as the tables for the United States exchanges plus preferred stocks.

title: Abera Resurrects a Proud Ethiopian Tradition
description: With winds gusting to 40 miles an hour, Gezahgne Abera of Ethiopia tucked into a pack of 10 runners on the Olympic marathon course. At 10 1/2 miles, though, his feet became tangled and he fell down, scraping his knee and shoulder.

title: Accounts
description: * Orkin Pest Control, Atlanta, part of Rollins Inc., to Doner, Southfield, Mich., to handle its direct marketing account, which had been at the Atlanta office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. Thompson Atlanta continues to handle the Orkin advertising account.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, RUDDICK C.
description: LAWRENCE - Ruddick C. Of Bronxville and Shelter Island, NY, on September 30. Beloved husband of Cherry McDonnell Lawrence. Devoted father of Dana Lawrence, Sara Engelhardt, Jean Lawrence, Ruddick Lawrence, Jr., Daniel Lawrence, and the late Megan Lawrence, and stepfather of Leslie Tawfik and Caroline Blydenburgh. Loving grandfather to 14 grandchildren. Service Saturday, October 7, 10:30 AM, at Christ Church, Bronxville. Donations in lieu of flowers may be sent to Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St, Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

title: Equity Offerings Scheduled for Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: SYDNEY 2000: Sports of The Times; Marion Jones Feels An Odd Emptiness
description: ALITTLE less than 24 hours after winning her fifth and final Olympic medal, Marion Jones was still searching for the word to describe a feeling of emptiness.

title: 3 Shot at Subway Station After Clash Over Camera
description: A member of a street gang, angry because he thought a fellow subway rider had videotaped him, ignited a desperate struggle inside an N train early yesterday that continued onto a platform at East 59th Street in Manhattan, where three people were shot, the police said.

title: Burnett USA Names New Chief Executive
description: Brad W. Brinegar, chief operating officer at Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, part of Leo Burnett Worldwide, has been named chief executive, effective on Jan. 1. Mr. Brinegar, 45, will succeed Linda Wolf, 52, who was named last week as the next chairwoman and chief executive of Burnett Worldwide, also effective on Jan. 1.

title: Bylines are becoming more than a badge of authorship.
description: HI. I'm your reporter. My name is Felicity. This is my editor, Dave. We're going to serve you reports on the media today. Do you want to chat about them? Do you want to recommend something that's not on the menu? Just let us know.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIALE, CHESTER W.
description: VIALE-Chester W. Died on September 28, at the age of 81. ''Chet'' is rememberd fondly by his loving wife Rita of 55 years, his devoted nephew Chris Torelli and sister-inlaw Vera Torelli, and his many other nieces and nephews. Viale was Senior Executive Administrative Partner of L.F. Rothschild & Co. until he retired in 1981. He guided and built the national and international presence of the investment banking and brokerage firm. He brought the firm to prestigious status as a managing and leading underwriter of municipal bonds. He will be missed by his peers and colleagues, his partners, associates and the staff of L.F. Rothschild & Co., all beneficiaries of his creativity, generosity and fidelity. Calling hours are 6-8 PM, on Monday, October 2, at Scobee, Ireland, Potter Funeral Home in Delray Beach, FL. Services will be held there on Tuesday, October 3, at 11 AM, with interment following. In lieu of flowers. the family suggests donations to the Bethesda Memorial Fund, Box 461, Delray Beach, FL 33447.

title: George M. Rood, 65, Times Staff Editor
description: George M. Rood, a staff editor at The New York Times for 38 years, died of cancer on Saturday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 65 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGFAN, HILDA
description: LANGFAN-Hilda. Died at her home in Houston, TX, on September 28, 2000, at the age of 85 after a long illness. She was a native and longtime resident of New York City. Beloved wife of the late Rubin Langfan and devoted mother of the late Judith Shilling. She is survived by her children Lorraine and Alex Dell; her grandchildren Steven and Marci Dell, Michael and Susan Dell, Adam Dell, Leah and Louis Recchia, Mitchell, Susan, and Joel Shilling; her precious greatgrandchildren Jordan, Kira, Madeline, Alexa, Olivia, Zachary, Juliette, Amy and Joseph; her dear sister Eva Rebhun, and her brother-in-law William K. Langfan; sonin-law Wayne Shilling; nieces and nephews Robin and Jay Hammer, Mark Langfan, Dayna and Larry Langfan-Heller, Bonnie and Alfredo Gironella. Hilda was a devoted mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother-an inspiration to her entire family. She had a wide circle of friends, a keen intellect and many interests. She will be greatly missed by all whose lives she touched. Service Tuesday, 2 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Expressions of sympathy may be sent to Amit Women or the Dell Jewish Community Center of Austin, TX, 73 Hart Lane, Austin, TX 78731.

title: Clearing the Air
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: More Options, and Decisions, for Men With Prostate Cancer
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York decided on a treatment for his prostate cancer, which was diagnosed in April, after months of private deliberation and public speculation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, BRITA DIGBY
description: FRIED-Brita Digby, age 88, died peacefully on October 1 at her home in East Hampton, following a series of strokes over the past few years. She is survived by her husband, Walter J. Fried, her daughters Allison Blinken and Ingrid (Mimi) Einstein and her grandchildren Anna Lonergan, Ingrid Blinken and Nicholas, Elizabeth and Abigail Einstein. In accordance with her wishes, there will be no funeral service.

title: Abortion Drug Requires Access
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Bridgestone/Firestone Tire Inquiry
description: Bridgestone/ Firestone Inc., a unit of the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan, said tonight that it had made 27.5 million Firestone Steeltex tires, the brand that federal regulators began investigating last Friday after receiving 169 complaints of tire failure. The tires were made from 1991 to 2000 in Aiken, S.C.; Decatur, Ill.; Joliette, Quebec; Lavergne, Tenn.; and Wilson, N.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTELLO, HARRY J.
description: COSTELLO-Harry J. On September 30, 2000. Beloved husband of Marie. Loving father of Diane, Laura, Mark, and Lisa. Adored grandfather of seven. Army Air Corp. Captain in the Pacific Theater, WW II. ''May flights of angels sing you to your rest.'' Donations to the Cabrini Hospice would be appreciated.

title: Low Pay Cited For Small Size Of Police Class
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani partly blamed low salaries yesterday for the shortage of recruits in a Police Academy class that is more than 350 people shy of the number the department had planned.

title: At Arms Again, Suddenly
description: Last week, Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, were having a garden party, breaking pita bread and trading jokes in the yard of Mr. Barak's private suburban home in Israel.

title: Article 2000100390685198004 -- No Title
description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

title: GIRLS SITE CLOSING
description: Kibu.com, a five-month-old Web site for teenage girls that received an impressive first round of financing early this year, said yesterday that it was shutting down and returning its remaining capital to investors. Despite signing on some notable sponsors, the company, based in Redwood City, Calif., said it could not drum up enough corporate support. In February, Kibu announced it had raised $22 million in venture capital from sources like James H. Clark, co-founder of Silicon Graphics and Netscape, and Tom Jermoluk, chairman of Excite@Home. Laurie J. Flynn

title: Police Say Videotape May Lead to Killers of a Man in Queens
description: The police released a videotape yesterday that they hope will lead to the people who killed a father of four with a cobblestone after following him into the lobby of his Queens apartment building.

title: CHINA ISSUES INTERNET RULES
description: China has published new regulations that require all companies providing Internet content to apply for licenses within two months. The rules also say that the proportion of foreign investment in Chinese Internet concerns must conform with laws and administrative regulations, implying that much of the foreign investment in Chinese Internet ventures is illegal. Those laws ban all foreign investment in the industry and restrict foreign ownership to 49 percent of Chinese Internet ventures after the country joins the World Trade Organization. But many Chinese Internet companies already have a majority foreign ownership. Craig S. Smith

title: White Sox vs. Mariners
description: Here is a scouting report on the division series between the Chicago White Sox and the Seattle Mariners. During the regular season, the White Sox won seven of twelve games between the two teams. A scouting report on the Mets-San Francisco Giants series will appear tomorrow.

title: Brookhaven Lab to Get $170 Million From U.S.
description: Brookhaven National Laboratory is slated to receive $170 million in federal money, including $5 million for an accelerated cleanup of environmental hazards, under a bill approved by the Senate today. The money is expected to allow the lab to take on additional projects.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Vice President Al Gore's performance in past debates referred incorrectly to strategy for the coming ones. It is Mr. Gore, not Gov. George W. Bush, who is trying to bat down the impression that the vice president is the more accomplished debater.

title: Seasoned Debater of Varied Styles vs. Upbeat but Less Experienced Opponent
description: Down a wooden sidewalk and behind a pressed-tin facade, the Jackson Hole Playhouse -- with an adjoining saloon that has stuffed elk heads on the walls and leather saddles for bar stools -- looks like the kind of place John Ford might have chosen to film a gunslingers' brawl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAER, MITCHELL
description: GRAER-Mitchell. On October 2, 2000. Beloved husband of Sherry, devoted father of Joseph Ian. Loving son of Leon and Selma, dear brother of Ellen Winkler and Stuart. Services Tuesday 12:30 at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.
