description: EBNER-Gertrude. Dear mother of Marian Marsh and Judith Ebner. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Service at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Bdwy, Hewlett, L.I., 11:30 AM Tuesday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: ASM LITHOGRAPHY TO BUY A RIVAL
description: ASM Lithography Holding a Netherlands-based company that makes equipment used to fabricate integrated circuits, agreed to buy the Silicon Valley Group, a rival based in San Jose, Calif., in a stock deal valued at 1.8 billion euros, or $1.6 billion, the companies said yesterday. Silicon Valley's stock rose $7.38, or 28 percent, to close at $33.69. The acquisition will create the largest maker of lithography equipment used by semiconductor manufacturers in the world, the companies said. ASM had sales of $1.3 billion in 1999 and said the acquisition would immediately increase its earnings per share, but its stock fell $2.44, or 7.5 percent, to $29.88.

title: Report Gives Nassau Weeks To Fix Budget
description: In a withering report, a state board monitoring Nassau County's fiscal crisis said today that the county executive had failed to balance the budget in his new four-year rescue plan. The report urged county officials to come up with a sound proposal by the end of the month. If they fail, they face a state takeover.

title: Connecticut Holding Inquiry Into Priceline
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 2  The Connecticut state attorney general is investigating Priceline.com , the Internet name-your-own-price company, after receiving more than 100 complaints from consumers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MARGETT, HON. CHARLES
description: MARGETT-Hon. Charles October 2, 1997. In loving memory always. Your family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITT, EVELYN
description: WITT-Evelyn. On October 2, 2000 at age 90. Beloved wife of the late Ira. Loving mother of Stuart and grandmother of Jenny. Former Executive Secretary to Dean Mathey. As a Gray Lady during WWII, she comforted the troops when they returned from battle. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday, October 4th, at 12 Noon.

title: Pomp Propels Bush Toward Contest of Words
description: Confetti swirled, fireworks thundered and men with parachutes floated down from the clouds. The rally on the banks of the Ohio River here this afternoon was bolder and louder than a typical campaign event, but then it was Gov. George W. Bush's send-off for one of the most important appointments of his political career.

title: Lieberman Expected to Set Tone
description: RICHMOND, Ky., Oct. 2  A big unanswered question as the vice- presidential debate approaches is which Joe Lieberman will show up. Will it be the genial, grandfatherly lawmaker or the relentless, focused attacker?

title: Hyundai Will Build Auto Plant in U.S.
description: Seeking a greater piece of the world's largest market for automobiles, the Hyundai Motor Company plans to invest more than $1 billion to build its first production plant in the United States.

title: Martin Stresses Defensive Goals With the Nets
description: The Nets' Kenyon Martin, the top overall pick of the 2000 draft, did not think about the sharp teeth digging into his shooting hand today.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The yen dropped on speculation that a business confidence survey would not prompt the Japanese central bank to raise interest rates. In New York, the dollar settled at 108.84 yen, up from 108.02 on Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Joseph A. Ball, who was a senior counsel to the Warren Commission, which concluded that Lee Harvey Oswald killed both President John F. Kennedy and J. D. Tippit, a Dallas police officer, misstated the order in which the two were shot. Officer Tippit was shot after President Kennedy.

title: Drought Portends Famine for Tajikistan
description: Standing on toasted earth where the wheat crop failed this summer and no seeds are left for planting this fall, Hokim Ulimov pointed to the scattered piles of stones that are all that remains of his family home and said, ''I don't remember a time in my life when it was this bad.''

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices' Decisions Shape New Course for U.S. Sentencing
description: The Supreme Court opened its new term today where it left off in June: directing a potential revolution in federal criminal sentencing.

title: She Made Gay Rights Opponents Flinch
description: AS a gay rights lawyer, she has argued -- in baggy trousers -- a workplace discrimination case during which one judge swiveled in his chair and turned his back on her, and another took notes on her summation only to reveal a page of doodling he balled up and lofted toward the wastebasket as if shooting hoops. Lost the case? Yes. Lost her temper? Not in court.

title: A 12-Year-Old Boy, Killed in Gaza
description: To the Editor:

title: Thompson to Handle New Beauty Line
description: Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that it had named J. Walter Thompson in New York, part of the WPP Group, as agency of record to help introduce Becoming, a line of beauty products to be sold at J. C. Penney and Sears, Roebuck stores.

title: Foreign Affairs; What a Mess!
description: There is only one thing to say about Indonesia today: If you can't take a joke, you shouldn't have come.

title: Metro Business; A Project in Harlem Advances Quickly
description: Last year, Gov. George E. Pataki announced that an $85 million retail, office and hotel complex called Harlem Center would be built on state-owned land at Harlem's crossroads, 125th Street between Malcolm X and Adam Clayton Powell Boulevards.

title: Surging A's Prepare for Sinking Yanks
description: The Oakland Athletics are baseball's youngest team, certainly old enough to sip Champagne, yet by major league standards too inexperienced to celebrate. Yet here they are, American League West champions, and on a tear that should worry the struggling Yankees.

title: CAIRNS OUT 4 WEEKS
description: The Islanders will begin the regular season Friday without defenseman Eric Cairns, who is out for at least four weeks with a fractured left wrist.

title: A Measure of an Infant Skull's Strength
description: Anyone who has ever tenderly held a young baby is familiar with the instinctive desire to protect the child's head from harm.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Boston

title: Wrestling Federation Calls Foul on Its Heavyweight Agency
description: World Wrestling Federation Entertainment Inc., whose roster of mat-slamming stars includes Stone Cold Steve Austin and The Rock, has filed a lawsuit accusing the William Morris Agency of trying to exploit an unfair contract with the company.

title: Metro Business; Wine Distributorship Sold
description: The House of Burgundy, a fine wine importer and distributor since 1934, spun off the distribution side of its business yesterday and sold it to Eber Brothers/Paramount Brands, a wholesaler in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Helping Pandas Survive
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, WALTER S.
description: FREEDMAN-Walter S. Of Delray Beach, Florida, formerly of New York City & Danbury, Connecticut. Died October 1, 2000 after a lengthy illness. Beloved husband of the late Jacqueline Mond Freedman. Proud father and father-in-law of Cathy and Jerry Gollub. Cherished grandfather of Michael, Allison and Matthew. Son of the late Abraham and Florence Freedman and brother of the late Lillian Katz, Mary Rubin and Sheldon Freedman. Graduate and lifetime supporter of CCNY. Retired as Executive Vice-President and CFO of Alexander's, Inc., and served as a member of its Board. Services Wednesday, October 4th, at 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' Amsterdam at 76th Street.

title: Why What Goes Up Doesn't Fall Down
description: Small wonder the American Society of Civil Engineers has endorsed ''Building Big,'' PBS's five-part documentary series about bridges, domes, skyscrapers, dams and tunnels. These terrific programs trumpet the scientific derring-do of the creators without ignoring their equally compelling quixotic foolhardiness. There's even more bravado and pathos here than in the just-finished Olympics.

title: Xerox Releases Warning About a 3rd-Quarter Loss
description: The Xerox Corporation, citing lower sales at a time of rising costs, warned investors yesterday that it would report a third-quarter loss of 15 cents to 20 cents a share.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They've stolen everything -- our lives, history and now the elections. But we will not allow them to do this. This time we have caught him with his hand in our pockets. There will be no second round. The elections are over.''

title: For the Vaccine-Wary, a Lesson in History
description: Most parents now raising questions about the safety and wisdom of childhood immunizations have never seen a case of whooping cough, polio, measles or mumps. Parents now in their 20's and 30's grew up in an era when they and all their schoolmates were protected against such serious infections by a series of vaccinations administered early in life.

title: Ford Motor Cutting Prices in Britain
description: Ford Motor, Britain's best-selling carmaker, has cut British list prices for cars and trucks and canceled cash-back offers, saying it wants to make vehicle prices easier for buyers to understand.

title: Cummings Retires After 18 Seasons
description: Terry Cummings, 39, of the Golden State Warriors, one of eight players to play at least 18 seasons in the National Basketball Association, retired after a career in which he scored 19,640 points and played for 7 teams in 18 seasons.

title: Virtual College Fairs for Students
description: Aseries of virtual college fairs kicking off later this month will allow high students to chat with potential colleges from their homes or school computer labs rather than trudging through a crowded gymnasium.

title: Sydney Anticipates Long-Term Boon
description: They call Australia the lucky country, and there may be no better example of its good fortune than the unexpected windfall Sydney is reaping at the end of these Olympics.

title: Nuclear Testing Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUINIER, DORIS
description: GUINIER-Doris. The members of the Brooklyn Museum of Art Community Committee are deeply saddened by the sudden death of Doris Guinier, a devoted member and dear friend. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Edith Gothelf, President Community Committee

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER TO SELL MASONITE FOR $523 MILLION
description: The International Paper Company, the biggest maker of forestry products and paper, agreed yesterday to sell its Masonite Corporation building-products unit to Premdor Inc. of Canada for $523 million. Masonite, based in Chicago, makes door facings and siding products. Premdor is a doormaker based in Mississauga, Ontario, near Toronto. International Paper is selling assets to pay for its June purchase of the Champion International Corporation. Masonite's net asset value was $558 million at the end of June.

title: Trial Opens for Doctor Accused of Killing Wife
description: Prosecutors argued yesterday that a miserable marriage, ending in a flashpoint of rage, led a plastic surgeon to kill his wife 15 years ago and dump her body from an airplane. Defense lawyers called this just a theory -- no better or worse than any other -- to explain the disappearance of the doctor's wife, whose body has never been found.

title: Songs in the Same Key With Just a Few Guitar Licks
description: Boubacar Traore

title: Long After His Arrest, His Car Is His Again
description: The police made him an example of what they called their get-tough policy on people who drove while drunk. Civil libertarians cited him as an example of a victim of a flawed city policy that was too aggressive.

title: U.S. Selects a New Encryption Technique
description: After a three-year worldwide search for a new encryption technique powerful enough to earn the official endorsement of the United States government, the Commerce Department yesterday named a winner: Rijndael.

title: How the Poll Was Taken
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Wednesday through Sunday with 1,462 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,131 said they were registered to vote.

title: The Birth, Death and Rebirth of a Novel Disease-Fighting Tool
description: Richard Belmont, an airline pilot, went to the emergency room on Christmas Eve in 1989 for what he thought was a pulled abdominal muscle. It turned out to be non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a usually incurable cancer. ''I think it's your last Christmas,'' Mr. Belmont recalled being told by the doctor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RINDNER, RICHARD
description: RINDNER-Richard. Of Fair Lawn, N.J. Husband of Ilana. Father of Marc and Janette (Sheldon), beloved grandfather of Alison and David. Services are 1PM today, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4, Paramus, N.J.

title: Early Warnings on Diabetes Dangers
description: Diabetes affects some 16 million Americans and for many, the consequences can include blindness, kidney disease and heart disease.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: When Black America Triumphed in France; An Exhibition Revives the Excitement Of Josephine Baker's 1925 Paris Revue
description: Nineteen twenty-five was a vintage year for American art on both sides of the color line. The white fiction writers who published included Dreiser (''An American Tragedy''), Fitzgerald (''The Great Gatsby''), Cather (''The Professor's House''), Hemingway (''In Our Time''), Sherwood Anderson (''Dark Laughter'') and Anita Loos (''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes''), and some of the best journalists of the day were being recruited for a fledgling magazine, The New Yorker.

title: Schedule Causes Confusion
description: The Mets and Yankees may both be playing playoff games this Saturday in New York City, something that's never happened before in the same city on the same day in major league baseball. The only problem is that at this point, it's not clear whether the Yankees would be playing early in the afternoon or in the evening or if the Mets would be playing early in the afternoon, late in the afternoon or in the evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, SAMUEL
description: WEINBERG-Samuel. Peacefully, in his sleep on October 1, 2000. Born March 28, 1908, son of Bertha Katz and Morris Weinberg. Attorney-at-law, senior partner at Sperry, Weinberg & Cohen. Loving husband of the late Mildred Wolton Weinberg. Beloved father of Ladd and the late Michael. Caring father-in-law of Catherine. Adored grandfather of Gillian Ladd and Joanna Weinberg. Devoted brother of Sophie Karp and dear uncle of Marilyn Silverman and Martin Karp. Fond friend of Carol Cohen. We are all richer for having shared his warmth and long life. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Tuesday, October 3, 7:00-9:00 PM. Services to be held Wednesday, October 4, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 381 Park Ave. South, New York, NY 10016.

description: Comparing Tax Cut Plans

title: Gun Battle Halts Mideast Cease-Fire
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 3 - A cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians crumbled within hours today when intense rioting and gun battles flared once more throughout the West Bank and Gaza Strip and in Arab towns inside Israel.

title: But Enough About You, Now Look Only at Me
description: The Brazilian singer Marisa Monte -- a million-seller in her own country and a chic, arty and lesser-known artist here -- does her best to reconcile pop entertainment and the intellect. During her tour, which stopped at the Beacon Theater on Saturday night, she was presenting songs for the audience to regard from a distance and coolly analyze.

title: Playoff Time
description: There is some unusual geographical symmetry attached to the baseball playoffs that begin today. Both New York teams open their quest for a world championship in northern California. The Yankees play the Athletics tonight in Oakland. Tomorrow afternoon the Mets play the Giants in San Francisco. If the Yankees and Mets prevail in these best-of-five matchups, they will keep alive the idea of an all-New York subway series. If Oakland and San Francisco prevail, they will keep alive the idea of an all-BART (Bay Area Rapid Transit) series. There are four other playoff teams with World Series ambitions -- St. Louis and Atlanta in the National League, Seattle and Chicago in the American -- but right now people on both coasts are dreaming big.

title: Hunted Man Is No Rockefeller, but Plays One in Hamptons, the Police Say
description: He cut a wide swath through the Hamptons this summer. His name was sterling: Christopher Rockefeller. His pitch was gold: ''I can double your money in a month.'' Women threw themselves at his feet; men threw cash.

title: Study Finds Winners and Losers For Bush and Gore Tax Proposals
description: For months now, Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore have been arguing on the campaign trail over whose tax plan would help particular families more. Often the candidates actually introduce families they say would do better under their plan.

title: Assembly Speaker Quits Race for Governor
description: Assembly Speaker Jack Collins, who had been a leading contender for the Republican nomination to succeed Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, abruptly quit the 2001 governor's race today, leaving his counterpart in the State Senate, Donald T. DiFrancesco, the likely front-runner.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Stock Volatility Declines, but So Do Prices
description: Maybe peace and quiet are not things to be cherished in the stock market.

description: The College Search Game, Spam Included

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOORHEES, FLORENCE E.
description: VOORHEES-Florence E. Of Jersey City, New Jersey on Saturday, September 30, 2000. Loving daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John J. Voorhees, Jr. and step daughter of Emma Louise Tompkins Voorhees. Cremation services were held privately. For information McLaughlin Funeral Home, 625 Pavonia Ave, Jersey City, NJ 07306. There will be no visiting at the funeral home. Contributions in Florence Voorhees' memory may be made to the Boys and Girls Club of Hudson County.

title: Strikes Threaten Milosevics Power
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Oct. 3  The Serbian government issued a harsh warning to the democratic opposition today, promising "special measures" and prosecutions against those organizing a spreading general strike in Serbia intended to oust Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Parties Squabble on 10th Anniversary Eve : Germans Trade Barbs Over Who Owns Unity
description: FRANKFURT  On the eve of Germany's 10th anniversary of reunification, Berlin's political debate has degenerated into a finger-pointing squabble over who deserves credit or blame for the monumental events of 1990.

title: Article 2000100393632053241 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Officials Say Millions Embezzled From Catholic Church in Forest Hills May Never Be Traced
description: As a criminal investigation into financial irregularities at a large Roman Catholic church in Queens gained momentum, law enforcement officials said yesterday that some questions might never be answered, including precisely how much money was missing, where it had gone and how many people were culpable.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about George M. Rood, a staff editor at The New York Times for 38 years, omitted the surname of a surviving daughter. She is Amy Brokering.

title: Big News Is Just a Guy Named Joe
description: It's been a whirlwind news week for Joseph Austin, newly minted celebrity. He has been profiled in not one, not two, but three Albuquerque-area daily papers since Friday. His name is a sudden staple on the wires; he has sat for satellite interviews with two of Albuquerque's television stations and shot the breeze with a bevy of New Mexico radio talk show hosts.

title: CANADIAN ENERGY ACQUISITION
description: In a further consolidation of Canada's energy sector, Gulf Canada Resources has agreed to buy Crestar Energy for 1.74 billion Canadian dollars ($1.16 billion) in cash and stock. Combining the two Calgary companies creates Canada's fifth-largest independent oil and gas producer. Gulf Canada's natural gas production will increase almost 60 percent. Timothy Pritchard

title: American Air Orders 6 Planes
description: American Airlines, the second-biggest United States carrier, has exercised rights to buy six more planes from Boeing as part of a plan to increase international and transcontinental flights.

title: Gambling on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: M.L.S. Semifinals Go Down to Wire
description: While three of the four quarterfinal series in the Major League Soccer playoffs were sweeps, both semifinals will require a third and deciding game for the right to play in M.L.S. Cup 2000 on Oct. 15 in Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington.

title: Microsoft Seeks an Extended Appeals Process
description: The Microsoft Corporation asked a federal appeals court today to allow more than five months for the filing of documents in the appeal of the antitrust ruling against the company, and to permit a brief four times as long as usual.

title: What to Look For as Bush and Gore Debate; Mikes and Lecterns
description: To the Editor:

title: Conflagration in the Middle East
description: The violence that has convulsed the Middle East since late last week has given Israelis and Palestinians alike a frightening replay of the bloodshed that scarred the region for so many years. The question now is whether the fighting will prove to be a temporary setback in the drive to make peace or a terminal point in negotiations. The recent experience of Northern Ireland suggests that violent outbursts need not upend a determined effort to settle a prolonged conflict, but heroic work will be required by Israeli, Palestinian and American leaders to save the Middle East peace talks. That can begin at the planned meeting in Paris on Wednesday of Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel, Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright.

title: Groups at Risk Get Flu Shot Priority
description: Delays in the production of flu vaccine have led federal health officials to recommend that the drug first go to people at greatest risk, like the elderly.

title: In Dark Days, the Human Hyena Has the Last Laugh
description: A FRIEND OF THE EARTH

title: Connecticut Holding Inquiry Into Priceline
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 2  The Connecticut state attorney general is investigating Priceline.com , the Internet name-your-own-price company, after receiving more than 100 complaints from consumers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAGNALL, WILLIAM (BILL)
description: BAGNALL-William (Bill). Died at his home in Boston, on September 29, 2000. His family and friends will sorely miss his glorious one-liners, loyalty, & love, his grandchildren the butterfly kisses.

title: 2 Join to Purchase Brazil Utility Stake
description: The AES Corporation, the largest United States power-plant developer, and Electricite de France have agreed to buy Reliant Energy's stake in a Brazilian electric utility, for $430 million, Reliant said today.

title: TOWER TO CUT JOBS IN MICHIGAN AND WISCONSIN
description: Tower Automotive Inc. said yesterday that it would phase out its heavy truck rail manufacturing in Milwaukee by March and close its stamping operation in Kalamazoo, Mich. The moves will affect ''fewer than 800'' employees, Tower said. The company, which had 12,000 employees last year, said it wanted to put more focus on its light vehicle and modules businesses. Tower said it planned to take a $140 million charge in the fourth quarter for the moves. It also warned that its third-quarter earnings would fall short of Wall Street estimates. The company said it expected to earn 20 cents to 25 cents a share for the third quarter. Analysts had expected Tower to make 42 cents a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISMAN, FLORENCE
description: WEISMAN-Florence, age 81. Of Harrison, N.Y. passed away on September 30, 2000. Cherished mother of Susan and Barry Weisman and dear sister of Ruth. Adored grandmother of Elana.

title: BAY AREA MEETS BIG APPLE
description: First thing first. If the Yankees had any class, they would withdraw from the playoffs and not foist an embarrassing team on Major League Baseball's brightest time of the year. Where is George Steinbrenner when an apology is really needed, not just to the people of New York (see 1981 World Series) but to all of baseball?

title: WORLD BUSINESS: Energy on Ice; Rising Oil and Gas Prices Revive Interest in Russia's Arctic Fields
description: The far north of Russia is an inhospitable sheet of ice and snow more than half the size of the the 48 contiguous United States. But to Russian and foreign energy companies hungry for new supplies, the lure of profits has started to make the region inviting.

title: Accounts
description: Topp Telecom, Miami, a subsidiary of TelMex, to Bernstein-Rein Advertising, Kansas City, Mo., to handle the account of Tracfone, a prepaid cellular telephone service, which had been at Integer Dallas, part of the Integer Group unit of the Omnicom Group. Spending was estimated at more than $7 million.

title: Russia Hardens Its Positions Along a Tajikistan Border
description: Russia is laying antipersonnel mines and reinforcing its defensive positions along the border between Tajikistan and Afghanistan, as Taliban fighters have moved their forces within artillery range of the Russian Army, which protects the gateway to Central Asia.

title: Defending Champions Have Much to Prove
description: The two-time defending World Series champions took batting practice at Oakland Coliseum yesterday and should have felt like a team on parole. The Yankees were pensive and showed little swagger, which is typical for them and which should be routine behavior for a team that switched between being invisible and inferior for the last three dreadful weeks.

title: Fox and NBC Renege on a Debt
description: How times have changed. Forty years ago CBS, NBC and ABC broadcast the first-ever televised presidential debate, and that tense contest between Richard Nixon and John Kennedy was seen as not only the pivotal moment of the election, but a harbinger of how television would enhance democracy.

title: Unilever Outlines Plans for Plant Closings
description: Unilever, the largest maker of food and soap products, plans to close about 25 plants this year and next at a cost of about $1.1 billion, a co-chairman, Antony Burgmans, said today.

title: Dazzling Tomb Found in Syria Leaves Archaeologists Puzzled
description: A 4,300-year-old tomb excavated this summer at the site of an ancient city in Syria has the discovering archaeologists excited but deeply puzzled. The arrangement of the bodies, accompanied by gold, bronze and ceramic grave goods, seems to defy ready explanation.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILIS, SUSAN
description: BAILIS-Susan. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a highly respected leader of the Jewish community, the beloved sister of Stephen D. (and Elsa) Solender, Board member of our Wurzweiler School of Social Work. Mrs. Bailis championed health care for the elderly, social work education, and breast cancer research. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to her husband, Lawrence; children, Kathryn and David; father, Sanford Solender; brother, Peter (and Susan) Solender; sister, Ellen (and Harvey) Hirsch, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jeruslem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Sports of The Times; Bonds's Desperate October
description: IF Barry Bonds is voted the Most Valuable Player in the National League this year, he will be the first major leaguer to win it four times. And with career totals of 494 homers and 471 stolen bases, Bonds, the San Francisco Giants' left fielder, is the only player in baseball history with more than 400 in each category.

description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia Man Is Pardoned In a Murder; DNA Is Cited
description: Acting on the basis of DNA evidence, Gov. James S. Gilmore III of Virginia granted an ''absolute pardon'' yesterday to Earl Washington Jr., 17 years after Mr. Washington was convicted for the rape and homicide of a Culpeper County woman.

title: How to Speak in Alphabet Soup; Course Helps Small Firms Obtain Government Contracts
description: There are billions of dollars in government contracts out there. But before the ambulette company that Ingrid Sevieux works for could get some of that business, she had to learn a foreign language:

title: Money Needn't Win
description: Americans are increasingly alienated from their own democracy because they believe their votes and money can never match the power of special interests or personal fortunes. Those who participate do so keenly aware of the way the process is distorted by the need to raise huge sums just to run for office.

title: Messing Up As Only A Moliere Fool Can
description: ''L'Etourdi'' or ''The Bungler,'' an early Moliere comedy, his first in verse, is a hoot, a nutty 17th-century sitcom about a manservant, proud of his gift for dissembling and manipulation, trying to help his dimwitted master win the girl of his dreams away from the rich old man to whom she is indentured, as well as a variety of other suitors.

title: BRITISH INSURANCE DEAL
description: A big British insurer, the Royal London Mutual Insurance Society, will buy the Scottish Life Assurance Company for $:1.1 billion ($1.63 billion) in the latest in a string of British insurance company mergers. In winning Scottish Life, Royal London, which will gain access to new distribution channels, including important independent brokers, beat out several other suitors, including GE Capital. The combined entity will have income of $:1.9 billion ($2.81 billion) and manage funds worth nearly $:30 billion ($44.31 billion).

title: In Silicon Valley, Candidates Seek Both Money and 'Cool'
description: By many political calculations, Silicon Valley should be Al Gore country. After all, the vice president has championed high-technology issues, and eight years of a strong economy has created an unimaginable level of wealth here. Moreover, this academic region is a magnet for young college graduates who often gravitate to Democrats.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES

He succeeds Francis Barton, who is assisting Mr. Rivet during the transition.

title: A Mad Max in Her Own Future Thunderdome
description: Before he sent Kate Winslett overboard to shiver and turn blue in the ocean of ''Titanic,'' James Cameron directed movies whose heroines were as tough on the outside as they were in. Sigourney Weaver in ''Aliens'' and the pumped-up Linda Hamilton in ''Terminator 2'' were female versions of the primary Cameron character, Arnold Schwarzenegger in ''The Terminator.'' In ''Dark Angel,'' the captivating futuristic series created by Mr. Cameron and Charles Eglee, Max is a 19-year-old heroine who shares a bit of all these characters.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEIDEN, ROBERT T.

title: PNC TO SELL HOME MORTGAGE UNIT TO WASHINGTON MUTUAL
description: PNC Financial Services Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its residential mortgage business to Washington Mutual Inc., the country's largest savings and loan, for $605 million. Pittsburgh-based PNC, formerly called PNC Bank, put its mortgage business up for sale in July, saying it would rather use the capital from the business to expand its asset management and private banking divisions. The deal will make Seattle-based Washington Mutual the nation's third-largest mortgage originator and fourth-largest servicer of home mortgages.

title: Corrections

description: Xerox Is Predicting a Loss; Shares Tumble After Hours

description: New York City officials are considering a temporary cut in the 4 percent local sales tax on heating oil to ease the pain on homeowners and businesses who have been hit by the continuing surge in fuel prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGFAN, HILDA
description: LANGFAN-Hilda. AMIT is deeply grieved by the passing of our most devoted longtime former president of the AMIT B&P Chapter. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Sondra Sokal, President Hilda Savitsky, President AMIT B&P Chapter Marvin Leff, Exec Director

He was 66.

title: Mrs. Clinton Lunches, and Raises Hackles
description: As far as campaign speeches go, the one on breast cancer delivered here today by Hillary Rodham Clinton was tame. No name calling. No partisan exaggerations. No whipping up the crowd. Apart from a couple of personal references to the Senate, it was the kind of responsible talk you would expect from any first lady.

title: Passionate Playing of a Briton
description: Thomas Bowes and Eleanor Alberga, a violin-piano duo from Britain, gave a recital at Weill Hall on Sunday evening built around three strong works from the decade between 1915 and 1924: Szymanowski's ''Three Myths,'' Bartok's Second Sonata and Ravel's ''Tzigane.'' The last two of these were written for Jelly d'Aranyi, a violinist remarkable, according to the program note, for her ''passionate and fiery playing.'' Mr. Bowes was passionate and fiery on his own terms, which were thoroughly musical.

title: Yanks Try to Forget Any of This Ever Happened
description: The Yankees' distinct tradition is strangely blurred as they prepare for the first two games of the American League division series, where they will reveal themselves as fading champions caught in a horrible and irreversible slump, or as a team with extraordinary mental toughness.

title: Where to Get Debates on Radio and TV
description: WASHINGTON  All three presidential debates, plus the one vice presidential debate, will be covered live by radio, television and Internet outlets available around the world, and transcripts will be made available almost instantly.

title: New Personnel but Old Approach As Van Gundy Plans for Season
description: The roster seems to beg for Coach Jeff Van Gundy to toss out his old playbook and let the Knicks break free, outrun their opponents rather than out-pound them in the halfcourt. No one can dominate in the low post, but there are three high-scoring wing players and one lanky power forward who can flourish in the open court. There are at least five guards who deserve to play significant minutes but not a single player who possesses the height, brawn and ferocity to discourage opponents from attacking the basket.

title: September Orders Fall To 2-Year Low
description: Manufacturing declined in September for the second consecutive month as orders slumped to a two-year low, a sign that higher borrowing and energy costs caused factories to cut back.

title: Corrections

title: New Tactic on College Drinking: Play It Down
description: In recent years, colleges have spent millions of dollars on scare tactics aimed at reducing binge drinking -- posters showing students covered with vomit, displays of cars wrecked by drunken drivers -- yet student drinking rates have remained unchanged.

title: DANISH BANK MERGER

The deal will make Danske the second-biggest bank in Scandinavia, after Nordic Baltic Holding of Sweden. The deal values RealDanmark at 445 kroner ($52.44) a share. Alan Cowell

description: Several agencies have opened for business.

description: SHERMAN-Mabel. Dear wife of the late Irving. Loving mother of Robert (Mimi). Caring grandmother & great-grandmother. Services Wednesday, 11:30AM at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Milan Casting Call: Novice Models Test Walks and Nerves
description: It lasts just a moent, no longer than a mayfly hatch on a remote Montana river. The Discovery Channel hasn't documented the phenomenon yet, but it should, because, for three or four days each fall, a circuit of small and sinuous streets in Milan is suddenly overrun not with the usual tourists slogging from one luxury store to another, but with a herd of unbelievably beautiful beings.

title: People
description: Jonathan Cranin, executive vice president and chief creative officer for North America at McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, New York, was named to the additional new post of chief creative officer for Africa, Europe and the Middle East. For his added duties, he will divide his time between London and New York. McCann is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Cheerleading Changes, and Injuries Increase
description: Cheerleading is not what it used to be. While in the past, cheerleaders were little more than overcaffeinated dancers in itty-bitty skirts, these days they are athletes, real athletes. The head cheerleader is no longer the woman with the cutest smile and shapeliest legs, but the one with the best executed X-out double full twist. (Hint: don't try this at home.)

title: Jellyfish Damage in Gulf Is Raising Concern for Aquatic Life
description: Swarms of jellyfish consumed so many fish eggs and larvae in the Gulf of Mexico this summer that some scientists are talking about the potential for serious future threats to commercial and recreational fisheries in the northern Gulf.

title: Big Hospital Manager to Pay a Fraud Settlement of $95 Million
description: The Quorum Health Group, the nation's largest hospital management company, has agreed in principle to pay $95.5 million in civil penalties to settle two lawsuits that accused it of defrauding federal health care programs like Medicare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNURE, ANDREW
description: SCHNURE-Andrew. On October 1, 2000. Survived by brother, Dr. Joel, niece Stacey, nephews, Adam and Eric, many very loving and close friends, aunts, uncles and cousins. Esteemed executive of United Federation of Teachers. Services held on Monday at Sherman's Funeral Parlor. Buried at Mount Golda Cemetery.

title: Taco Bell's Core Customers Seem Undaunted by Shell Scare
description: Meet Jaime Troche, fast-food devotee. The native New Yorker eats from one chain or another at least once a day. He has recently been laid off from his job, and worries about money. He is 19 years old, and likes big piles of food. By all accounts, he is the model Taco Bell customer.

title: A Law That Helps the Disabled, but Not in New York
description: This is a 30-second commercial that went on the air during the weekend promoting a law that Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican Senate nominee, sponsored that allows the working disabled to continue to receive government health benefits even after finding a job, under certain conditions. But New York State is not participating in the program, so its residents cannot get the benefit.

title: SOCCER TEAM'S PROFIT DROPS
description: With players costing more and ticket receipts falling, Manchester United, the world's wealthiest soccer team, said its full-year profit fell 22 percent, to $17.5 million. Manchester United said the amortized cost of buying players had risen 29 percent, to nearly $20 million, while ticket sales at its Old Trafford stadium were lower, at $53 million. Alan Cowell

description: To the Editor:

title: New Efficiency Standards Proposed for Appliances
description: Central air-conditioning and heat pumps would have to do the same amount of work on 20 percent to 30 percent less electricity under standards that will be proposed on Tuesday by the Energy Department as part of a broad effort to reduce consumption by appliances to cut air pollution, fuel use and strain on the electric system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLOGGIAMENTO, ALBERTO
description: ALLOGGIAMENTO-Alberto, on September 29, 2000, at age 64. Beloved husband of Nancy. Dear brother of Attilio (Al). Adored sonin-law of Ruth Thomas and brother-in-law of Gary, Penny and Jim Thomas, and Toni and Ann Alloggiamento. Cherished uncle of Christine, Thomas, Arthur, Paul, John, Florence, Arlene, Mark, Matthew, Shannon, James and Jillian. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Tuesday, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. John Evangelist Church, 348 East 55th Street, on Wednesday, 10:30 AM. Interment St. John's Cloister, Middle Village, NY.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

Vieta Memorial Lecture, care of Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 E. 77 St., NYC 10021.

title: A Robust Sound Over the Centuries
description: Viviane Hagner, violinist

title: Metro Business; A Focus on Internet Law
description: The New York State Bar Association has formed a committee to help lawyers better advise clients who do business over the Internet.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Joseph A. Ball, who was a senior counsel to the Warren Commission, which concluded that Lee Harvey Oswald killed both President John F. Kennedy and J. D. Tippit, a Dallas police officer, misstated the order in which the two were shot. Officer Tippit was shot after President Kennedy.

title: What to Look For as Bush and Gore Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Ulster Town's Memories: Healing and Hurting
description: Sylvia Crawford is still haunted by the image of the sign from her shattered bridal shop -- Joyful Occasions, it said -- being used as a stretcher for the dying. For Mary Logue, perhaps the worst memory is of scrabbling through rubble, looking for her daughter but knowing in her heart that she was already dead.

title: Cell Phones Most Popular in Ireland
description: Ireland has more cell phone lines than traditional phones for the first time, with just under 50 percent of the population, or 1.86 million people, now owning cell phones, Ireland's telecommunications regulator says..

title: How the Poll Was Taken
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Wednesday through Sunday with 1,462 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,131 said they were registered to vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDT, HENRY
description: BRANDT-Henry. On September 30, 2000, at age 77. Beloved husband of Roxanne. Loving father of Pamela Jackson and Jonathan Brandt and father-in-law of Thomas Jackson. Adored grandfather of Natalie. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Monday, 7-9 PM, with service Tuesday, 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Riverside Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to the National Parkinson Foundation, Inc, 1501 N.W. 9th Ave, Bob Hope Road, Miami, FL 33136-1494.

title: NAVISTAR SHARES RISE ON WORD OF PURCHASE OFFER
description: Shares of the Navistar International Corporation jumped yesterday on a report that the company, the third-largest truck maker, received a conditional purchase offer from Paccar Inc., but Paccar later said it ''has not made a bid.'' Navistar climbed $6.56, to $36.50. Paccar, the maker of Peterbilt trucks, offered to buy Navistar's truck, bus and engine assets, according to a report in Stark's Truck & Off-Highway Ledger. Navistar declined to comment. Navistar investors who held as much as 30 percent of the shares outstanding have urged the company this year to consider ways to improve the stock.

title: Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged, Warns of Potential Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Reassured by signs that economic growth is moderating to a sustainable pace, the Federal Reserve voted today to hold interest rates steady, but warned that low unemployment and high oil prices could still lead to a jump in inflation.

title: Public Interests; The Debate Prep
description: George W. Bush is really psyched for tonight. ''I view this as a chance for people to get an impression of me on a stage debating my opponent,'' said the Republican nominee, summarizing the situation as only he can. His advisers have been very busy lowering expectations, and have pretty much convinced the nation that Mr. Bush will be the winner if he avoids referring to tariffs and barriers as ''terriers'' again.

title: Braves vs. Cardinals
description: Here is a scouting report on the division series between the Atlanta Braves and the St. Louis Cardinals. During the regular season, the Cardinals won four of seven games between the two teams. A scouting report on the Mets-San Francisco Giants series will appear tomorrow.

title: MUSICMATCH UPGRADES ITS JUKEBOX
description: While the music file-sharing service Napster fights a battle over the legality of its software in a courtroom in San Francisco, MusicMatch, a San Diego company that makes software for storing and playing music on home computers, is waging a different kind of battle over market share. The company is releasing a new version of its jukebox software today that gives users the ability to customize their selections. MusicMatch, which claims 10 million users, is fighting to gain market share from RealNetworks, whose RealJukebox software has 45 million users, as well as from Microsoft, whose Windows Media Player comes installed on many new PC's. Susan Stellin

title: PFIZER WILL SELL ITS FEED ADDITIVE BUSINESS
description: Pfizer Inc., the world's second-largest drug company, said yesterday that it was selling its medicated feed-additive business to the privately held Philipp Brothers Chemicals for about $155 million. Palladium Equity Partners L.L.C., a New York-based investment firm, will also take a stake in the feed-additive business with a Philipp Brothers subsidiary, Phibro Animal Health. The deal will make Phibro the world's third-biggest producer of medicated feed additives. The product lines to be sold include drugs meant to promote growth in swine and treat intestinal parasites in livestock. Philipp Brothers' business focuses on four core product groups: animal nutrition and health, industrial chemicals, crop protection and electronics and metal treatment.

title: BIG CONTRACT FOR NORTEL
description: The Canadian fiber optics equipment maker Nortel Networks won a contract totaling 950 million [pounds] ($1.4 billion) to upgrade the systems of Cable and Wireless P.L.C. over 10 years. The project involves integrating voice and data services over the Internet on a single network. Nortel, based in Brampton, Ontario, will upgrade assets in Europe and the United States, build a new switching platform and transfer existing customers. Cable and Wireless plans to offer additional services like videoconferencing and call and message centers.

title: Safety Agency Will Rate Vehicles for Rollover Tendencies
description: Government regulators have tested more than 100 automobile models for their tendency to roll over and found that sport utility vehicles like the Ford Explorer tend to be the least stable, particularly when fully loaded, while cars are the most stable.

title: CANDIDATES GIVEN HIGH MARKS IN POLL ON FITNESS TO LEAD
description: On the eve of the first presidential debate here, most Americans say Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore are strong leaders, but they consider Mr. Gore far more prepared for the White House and better qualified to deal with world leaders and members of both parties in Congress, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Abortion Drug Requires Access
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged, Warns of Potential Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Reassured by signs that economic growth is moderating to a sustainable pace, the Federal Reserve voted today to hold interest rates steady, but warned that low unemployment and high oil prices could still lead to a jump in inflation.

title: Article 2000100391673501596 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Panel Gives Nassau Month to Fix Budget
description: In a withering report, a state board monitoring Nassau County's fiscal crisis said yesterday that the county executive had failed to balance the budget in his new rescue plan.

title: John Espey, 87, Author and Teacher
description: John Espey, a writer and teacher whose first books were devoted to his childhood in China, died on Sept. 26 in Los Angeles. He was 87.

title: Touring Many Styles, but Ending Up His Own Way
description: Ben Harper does not suffer from generational anxiety. The 30-year-old guitarist and singer-songwriter is famous for channeling the wisdom of his elders, particularly baby boom stars from Jimi Hendrix to Cat Stevens. His Thursday show at Roseland, the second of a two-night run, blended many influences without pointing too strongly at any one. Its main focus was the category-leaping that makes Mr. Harper his own man.

title: Napster Case: Hard Queries On Copyrights
description: Three federal appeals judges today pointedly questioned lawyers for the record industry about their argument that Napster, the Internet music service, is liable for contributing to copyright infringement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, HARRY L.
description: BLOCK-Harry L. Of Hackensack, New Jersey. Adored father of Alison. Beloved son of Nita and Burt. Cherished brother of Beth. Services on Wednesday, 1:00 PM, at ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey.

title: Ann Doran, 89, Character Actress
description: Ann Doran, a character actress who appeared in hundreds of movies and television shows over the course of a career that began during the silent film era and lasted into the 1980's, died on Sept. 19 in Carmichael, Calif. She was 89.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIZZURRO, MARGARET ELIZABETH HOLTKAMP
description: PIZZURRO-Margaret Elizabeth Holtkamp, beloved wife of Joseph C. Pizzurro and mother of Joseph, Peter, Virginia, Mary (Esposito), Elizabeth (Ossoff) and Catherine (Hliboki) and grandmother of ten died September 30, 2000 following a short hospitalization. Her two sisters, Sr. Catherine Mary and Esther (Wenzel), and her brother Edward also survive her. Mrs. Pizzurro was born in Kalida, Ohio on December 21, 1924, the second daughter of Edward and Mary Holtkamp. Mrs. Pizzurro attended Mary Manse College of Toledo, Ohio and in 1946 was awarded a B.A. in Chemistry. She earned a M.S. degree from the University of Detroit in Biology in 1948, a notable achievement for a woman at that time. Mrs. Pizzurro is remembered by her friends and family as a woman of unfailing grace and kindness. She was extensively involved in church and charitable activities. She had a lifelong love of music, which she shared through the piano, her singing and work in amateur musicals. Her strength and inner beauty will be cherished by her family and all those whose lives she touched. She was an active parishioner at Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Ardsley for over forty years and most recently attended St. Augustine's parish in Ossining. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 7 to 9PM Monday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Wednesday, Oct. 4 at 10AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her name for Alzheimer's disease research to the Mayo Foundation, 200 First Street SW, Rochester, Minnesota 55905.

title: Old Anger of Israeli Arabs Finds Vent
description: Ferrying wounded from the rubble-strewn battleground at the entrance to this Israeli Arab town today, honking cars sped up a road to a clinic besieged by an angry crowd.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SANDERS, MOLLIE NAYER
description: SANDERS-Mollie Nayer. May 19, 1900-October 3, 1980. My beloved mother is always remembered with love

title: 'A Tyrannical Situation'; Farmers Caught in Conflict Over Illegal Migrant Workers
description: The sun rose majestically over one side of Mark Rice's hilltop field, and a brilliant harvest moon lingered over the other, as Mr. Rice warmly greeted the 70 Mexicans who had gathered to pick his 900 acres of apples. ''The trees,'' he said in a halting Spanish, ''are heavy with fruit.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, ABRAHAM
description: FELDMAN-Abraham. Age 83, of Danbury, CT. Died Saturday, September 30, 2000 at Danbury Hospital. He was the husband of Fay E. (Cohen) Feldman. Mr. Feldman was a self-employed member of the Natl. Electrical Contractor's Assoc. He is survived by his son William Feldman, daughters Heidi Spiegler and Candace Feldman, brother Jack Feldman, sisters Miriam Kravitz and Eleanor Rosen, and four grandchildren. Services were held Monday at Cedar Park Cemetery in Westwood, NJ.

title: The Week in Science: A Busy Week on the Medical Front
description: This was a busy week for medical news, seasoned by incipient scandals in anthropology and engineering.

title: Police Brutality Revisited, But Not on Federal Ground
description: When Bradley McCallum, a former artist in residence of the New York Civil Liberties Union, conceived of a public art project focusing on police violence, he anticipated trouble getting the city's permission to display the project.

title: Ruddick Lawrence, 88, Market Executive
description: Ruddick C. Lawrence, a former vice president for public relations at the New York Stock Exchange and chairman of the board of Sarah Lawrence College, died Saturday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 88.

title: Inexplicably, Bucs Not Giving Ball to Johnson
description: Keyshawn Johnson walked alone from the locker room on Sunday evening, a scowl on his face replacing that perfect smile. The Tampa Bay Buccaneers, once a Super Bowl favorite, had fallen to the Washington Redskins for their second consecutive bitter loss of the season. The offense was so bad that Buccaneers guard Frank Middleton had these indelicate words for it: ''We stink.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSHMAN, BEATRICE COHEN (NEE WEXLER)
description: OSHMAN-Beatrice Cohen (nee Wexler), on October 1, 2000, three days before her 94th birthday. Widow of Benjamin Cohen and Harry Oshman. Devoted mother of Sara Fuchsman and Martin H. Cohen. Beloved mother-in-law of Arline Cohen and Alan Fuchsman. Loving grandmother of Ellen Fuchsman Ford, Eric Fuchsman and Bruce, Paul and Adam Cohen. Adoring great-grandmother of Carolyn, Katelyn and Alyson Cohen and Ryan Ford. Services today, October 3, 11 AM, at Schwartz Bros. Funeral Home, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY, 718263-7600. Burial at United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island, New Yokr. Contributions may be made in her memory to Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center, 68 Happauge Road, Commack, NY 11725-4403.

title: Article 2000100391488197933 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, DR. GERALD ''LEFTY'' A.
description: FOSTER-Dr. Gerald ''Lefty'' A., 72, of Milwaukee, WI, died Wednesday, September 27, 2000 from complications of congestive heart failure. He was born August 31, 1928 in Colby, WI. His professional experiences included Associate Professor of Psychology at Indiana State University (Terre Haute); Associate Professor Indiana University (Bloomington); Director of Counseling, Testing and Psychological Services at Atterbury Job Corps Center (Edinburg, IN); Assistant Director of Education and Training with AVCO (Washington D.C.) working with the Bureau of Indian Affairs; Psychological Consultant to Management, RH & R International (Boston, MA); Corporate Psychologist for C.N. FLagg & Co. (Meriden, CT); Psychologist for U.S. Army Alcohol & Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Program (Germany). He was published three times. Gerry is dearly loved by his wife of 27 years, Alessandra (Lucci-Brewer) and by his seven children and their spouses. A Funeral Mass will be held at 10AM on Saturday October 7, 2000 at the Cathedral of St. John the Evangelist, 802 N. Jackson, Milwaukee, WI. There will be no burial services. Dr. Foster's wish was that his body be donated to science. Gerry Foster faced life with great humor and unwavering optimism, turning even the greatest adversity into an adventure. He was an inspiration for all who met him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENNARO, PETER
description: GENNARO-Peter. The Board of Directors of The Actors Company Theatre wish to express our deepest sympathy to the family of Peter Gennaro.

title: A Hip Audience Packs the Hall to Hear Hip Works
description: The Dutch composer Louis Andriessen is hard to categorize, and that's the way he wants it. Though he is a leader of the musical avant-garde in Europe, he has a background in jazz and has worked in theater and film. His rhythmic style has been influenced equally by the metrical vigor of Stravinsky and the lulling repetitions of Minimalism. And he boldly mixes electronic and traditional instruments in his works.

Tippit, a Dallas police officer, misstated the order in which the two were shot. Officer Tippit was shot after President Kennedy.

title: Athletics Beat Yankees in Opening Game
description: OAKLAND, Calif. -- Even the comfort of the postseason couldn't break the New York Yankees out of their deep funk.

title: MITSUBISHI MOTORS IS FINED
description: A Tokyo court has ordered Mitsubishi Motors to pay a fine of 4 million yen, or about $37,000, the maximum penalty, for failing to report repairs of defective automobiles to the Transport Ministry and failing to disclose the cases to the public. The company eventually recalled 620,000 cars and trucks.

title: Troubled Shoe Designer Hires an Adviser
description: Steven Madden Ltd., a women's shoe designer whose chief executive has been charged with securities fraud, said yesterday that it had hired an investment bank, Bear, Stearns, to explore its alternatives.

title: Debate Rises Over a Quick(er) Climate Fix
description: A sharp new debate has sprung up among atmospheric scientists over where to aim efforts to stave off the prospect of global warming from the buildup of heat-trapping greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Some say the main target should be carbon dioxide, the most common greenhouse gas, while others say the most practical solution is to focus first on less common, but more powerful, substances possibly influencing climate, like methane, ozone and soot.

title: Arizona Fires Showalter as Managers Start to Exit
description: Buck Showalter, gone. Jack McKeon, gone. Gene Lamont, gone. Larry Rothschild . . . staying.

title: Childhood Asthma and Urban Geography
description: Federal studies have found a 20 percent higher incidence of asthma in black children than in whites.

description: CARACCI-Josephine (nee Culcasi). On September 30, 2000, of Bay Terrace, NY. Beloved wife of Frank. Adored mother of Joseph and Philip and their spouses, Debora and Yvonne. title: Passing Along the Diet-and-Binge Habit
description: People who constantly diet but give in to temptation at the first sight of some rich food learn the hard way that this is a singularly ineffective way to control weight.

title: Bush and Gore Clash Over Tax Cuts in First Debate
description: BOSTON, Oct. 3  Facing his opponent for the first time in the presidential campaign, Vice President Al Gore repeatedly hammered away at Gov. George W. Bush for a tax cut proposal that he said would disproportionately benefit the "wealthiest 1 percent" of Americans. Mr. Bush, in turn, argued that it was time for a "different kind of a leader" who could end the partisan standoff between their two parties in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUSTADT, ETTA
description: NEUSTADT-Etta. 97, of Mamaroneck, N.Y., on October 2, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Jack and his wife, Rhena, and Paul and his wife, Zelda. Cherished grandmother of Beth Figman and husband Scott, Mark Neustadt & his wife, Rachel Friedman. Devoted great grandmother of Jordan & Ted Figman, Chelsea Sage Figman, Noah Daniel Figman and Isaac Nathaniel Neustadt. Last surviving sibling of Al Gottlieb, Max Gottlieb, Rose Gottlieb Christiano, Mollie Gottlieb Blau, Louis Gottlieb, Moe Gottlieb and Leon Gottlieb. Truly a woman of valor, loved by her children, grandchildren, great grandchildren, and many nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be today, October 3, 1:00 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ. Donations made to Sarah Neuman Nursing Home, Mamaroneck, New York, Greenberg Hebrew Center, Dobbs Ferry, NY, and Fort Lee Jewish Center, Fort Lee, New Jersey.

description: BIALKIN-Robert. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons notes with sadness the passing of Robert Bialkin, beloved brother of our Honorary Trustee Kenneth Bialkin. title: Dresden Journal; An Uneasy Celebration, as Germans Take Stock
description: With its rediscovered national symbols, its gracious statuary and grim wastelands, its crumbling Communist apartment blocks and chic cafes, this city on the Elbe provides a fitting emblem of the ambiguities of Germany on the 10th anniversary of its unification.

title: La Russa Throws a Curve: Ankiel to Start Over Kile
description: In many ways, the St. Louis Cardinals have enjoyed a surprising season. So it was fitting that their manager, Tony La Russa, made a surprising announcement today.

title: Times Official Adds Technology Posts
description: Michael G. Williams, a vice president and the chief information officer of The New York Times, has been promoted to the same posts at the newspaper's parent company. He will also retain the positions at the newspaper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENKEN, COOPER, SADIE NEE SHEINGOLD
description: MENKEN - COOPER - Sadie nee Sheingold. Widow of Irwin Menken & Irving Cooper. Beloved mother of four, grandmother of nine, great-grandmother of eleven. Accomplished musician. Her strength, wisdom and devotion to family will be always remembered and ever missed.

title: Franks Record Displays Skill In Legislative Deal Making
description: For nearly two weeks now, Jon S. Corzine has been blasting his Republican opponent for the Senate, Representative Bob Franks, as a Newt Gingrich puppet and right-wing Grinch who tried to steal old people's Medicare entitlements.

Mr. Bush, in turn, argued that it was time for a ``different kind of a leader'' who could end the partisan standoff between their two parties in Washington.

description: As a general strike hit much of Serbia, President Slobodan Milosevic went on national television today to implore his citizens to reject the designs of what he called a traitorous opposition and to re-elect him.

title: A Rule of Thumb That Unscrambles the Brain
description: A new breed of animal, dubbed the ''sand mouse,'' has been added to the annals of biological science, and it has become the subject of a scientific challenge.

description: GREENE-LOWTHER-Susan M. On September 30,2000. Beloved wife of Richard. Loving daughter of James and Brigitte Greene. Dear sister of the late Thomas M. Greene. description: Scatting Around So Playfully

title: STOCK HURT BY PROFIT WARNING
description: In a new sign that the business-to-business e-commerce market may be cooling off, shares in Project Software and Development fell about 28 percent yesterday after the company said fourth-quarter results would fall short of expectations. Project Software, which is based in Bedford, Mass., and whose clients include companies like General Motors and Eli Lilly, said it expected earnings to be less than the 16 cents a share forecast by financial analysts, and substantially less than the 22 cents a share the company earned in the period a year earlier. The company said reduced demand for its products in Asia had hurt sales. Simon Romero

title: Bush to Appear Again on Letterman
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas will make a return appearance on the ''Late Show with David Letterman,'' but it will not be for a debate with Vice President Al Gore.

title: Olympic TV Commercials Win Few Gold Medals
description: Maybe it was a blessing in disguise that viewership of the Olympics on NBC never reached the high levels the network had anticipated. That shortfall kept consumers from being more fully exposed to the generally dull and disappointing commercials that ran constantly during the broadcasts.

title: As Arabs and Israelis Fight On, Albright Seeks Talks
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel said on Monday that peace talks were now ''on the shelf'' and Yasir Arafat called for an emergency Arab summit meeting as violence tore through Israel and the Palestinian territories for the fifth straight day.

title: Letters: Nuclear Testing Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: ALZA EXERCISES OPTION TO PURCHASE CRESCENDO
description: The Alza Corporation said yesterday that it had exercised its option to buy the Crescendo Pharmaceuticals Corporation, a former Alza unit used to finance research and development through outside investors, for $100 million in cash. Alza, which makes improved versions of drugs already on the market, agreed to pay Crescendo shareholders $20.27 a share, slightly less than the $20.50 closing price of Crescendo shares on Friday. Crescendo was formed through a spinoff of an Alza unit in 1997. Alza said in July that it was evaluating exercising its option to buy Crescendo. Both companies are based in Mountain View, Calif.

title: White Sox, Second Team in Second City, Take Rare Turn in Spotlight
description: For most of the season, the Chicago White Sox have been successful but hiding in plain sight, drawing attention to themselves only occasionally and drawing far fewer fans than the struggling Cubs.

title: Congressional Dos and Don'ts
description: Congress is planning to adjourn in two weeks so that members can do some last-minute campaigning before Election Day in November. Before it leaves, it ought to pass some important legislation that should not be allowed to spill over into a new administration and a new Congress next year, thus robbing the bills of legislative momentum. At the same time, Congress should refrain from its traditional end-of-session mischief. Here is an abbreviated list of good legislation that should be enacted, followed by some bad legislation that should be made to vanish.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday misstated the day of a chamber concert by Composers Concordance at the Frederick Loewe Theater at New York University, 35 West Fourth Street, in Greenwich Village. It is today, not Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLDUC, REV. MONSIGNOR NORMAN P. JR.
description: BOLDUC-Rev. Monsignor Norman P. Jr., Chancellor of Manchester, NH Diocese, by accident September 30th in New Hampton, NH. Son of Norman & Cecile Bolduc Sr., Laconia, NH, brother of Richard, of Barnstead, NH, James and John, both of Laconia, NH, Karen Burke, Sanbornton, NH, Terry Roberts & Kathleen Moynihan, both of Belmont, NH. Funeral mass October 5th, 11 AM in St. Joseph Cathedral, Manchester, NH. Interment in Sacred Heart Cemetery, Laconia, NH. For info Simoneau & Lambert 603-524-1424.

title: Boy's Death Prompts Inquiry by Agency
description: Five days after a 3-year-old was murdered in Florida, resulting in charges against his prospective foster father, the commissioner of Connecticut's Department of Children and Families today admitted that her agency should not have sent the boy to live with the man and his wife.

title: Bakery Deal in Canada
description: The Onex Corporation, an investment company based in Toronto, said today that it had acquired Pennant Foods through its SC International Services unit to add Pennant's line of baked goods and mixes. Terms were not disclosed. The closely held Pennant has annual sales of about $176 million. Pennant makes bakery mixes, dough for bread, thaw-and-serve muffins and puff pastries for use by food service operators and distributors, retail in-store bakeries and commercial accounts. The company, based in Lisle, Ill., has factories in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Minnesota and Georgia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGASHIMA, HIDEO, M.D.
description: NAGASHIMA-Hideo, M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the loss of our distinguished Professor Emeritus of Anesthesiology. A member of our faculty since 1964, he was a skilled and caring physician who also made important contributions to the advancement of anesthesiology through his pioneering research. A beloved mentor to several generations of students and residents, he exemplified the highest ideals of academic medicine in all of his endeavors. He will be greatly missed by all who had the privilege of knowing him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Sachiko and the entire family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University.

title: A 12-Year-Old Boy, Killed in Gaza
description: To the Editor:
