description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefings
description: INTERNET

title: Q & A
description: Freezing Water

title: A Mission To Redirect Money Used For Defense
description: Under a radiant autumn sky, a bus with a sign identifying it as the ''Moneymobile'' pulled into the College of St. Benedict, a Roman Catholic institution near here. The bus's five young occupants emerged and inflated nine large balloons, which assumed a form both festive and esoteric -- billowing, multicolored pie charts and bar graphs representing federal spending.

title: Fassel, in Fury, Commands Giants to Keep Faith
description: His face still red, his scowl still in place, Jim Fassel had not lost today any of his anger about the Giants' game on Sunday.

title: Low Supply of Heating Fuel Lifts Crude Oil Prices 4.3%
description: Crude oil prices rose more than 4 percent yesterday on expectations that heating oil supplies at United States refineries, now down more than one-third from levels a year ago, will still be low when cold weather spurs demand in the weeks ahead.

title: About the Tables
description: Beginning today and continuing through Dec. 29, Business Day will include a second section, World Business (Section W), on Tuesdays through Fridays. That section consists of international business news as well as the tables for the United States exchanges plus preferred stocks.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Move to Save Wildlife Snags Spending Bill
description: The three oddly named species two birds and a fish -- are unfamiliar to most people. But the piping plover, the least tern and the pallid sturgeon have emerged as central players in the drama surrounding passage by Congress of a $23.6 billion spending bill for energy and water projects.

title: Cruise Line Orders 2 Ships
description: Carnival, the world's largest cruise operator, said today that its Costa Crociere unit would buy two new ships for about $800 million. Costa Crociere, Europe's largest cruise line, with seven ships, will buy the 2,720-passenger ships from the Italian shipyard Fincantieri Cantieri Navali. The 105,000-ton vessels will be delivered in late 2003 and 2004. The move is part of Miami-based Carnival's plan to expand in Europe. Carnival operates 49 ships and has 16 on order.

title: Brooklyn School District Exceeded Spending Caps for Conferences, Audit Says
description: A Brooklyn school district failed to request competitive bids for three staff conferences at hotels in the last two years and then greatly exceeded Board of Education spending limits, according to an audit released yesterday by the city comptroller.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, IRVING
description: BECKER-Irving. Beloved husband of Millie. Devoted father of Elaine Margolies, Susan Becker Spiegel and Nancy Becker Cope and father-in-law of Michael, Jeff and Steven. Cherished grandfather of Eric, Craig, Isabel and Dylan. Loving brother of Bill and Joe Becker. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: A World of Strife
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: In a Concrete City, Dreams of Light and Air
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Fence, But Not at the End
description: When Najee Ali converted from the Baptist faith to Islam eight years ago, his family was shocked.

title: A MAKER OF CHASSIS FOR MOTOR HOMES FIRES 100 WORKERS
description: Spartan Motors Inc., a maker of chassis for motor homes and buses, said yesterday that it had laid off 100 employees, or 17 percent of its workforce, and would discontinue its Carpenter Industries school-bus unit. Spartan Motors said the layoffs were part of a consolidation that includes closing one of four operations at its headquarters in Charlotte, Mich., because of a slowdown in the recreational vehicle chassis market. The company could lay off as many as 200 additional workers, unless the Carpenter unit is bought. The company said the consolidation would save $2 million in 2001.

title: Tenet Healthcare's Profit Up by 20%
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the No. 2 United States hospital chain, said today that fiscal first-quarter profit rose 20 percent as its hospitals admitted more patients and charged health insurers higher prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, BRITA DIGBY.
description: FRIED-Brita Digby. Age 88, died peacefully on October 1 at her home in East Hampton, following a series of strokes over the past few years. She is survived by her husband, Walter J. Fried, her daughters Allison Blinken and Ingrid (Mimi) Einstein and her grandchildren Anna Lonergan, Ingrid Blinken and Nicholas, Elizabeth and Abigail Einstein. In accordance with her wishes, there will be no funeral service.

title: 2 Candidates, Identical Images
description: Dr. Jonathan Gallen thought there was so little difference between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas in their debate tonight that he said the two candidates were like two identical cans of tuna, with different brand names.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about fighting between Israelis and Palestinians in Jerusalem included an erroneous identification from The Associated Press for a wounded man shown with an Israeli policeman. He was Tuvia Grossman of Chicago, an American student in Israel, not an unidentified Palestinian. In some copies the caption also misidentified the site where Mr. Grossman was wounded. It was in Jerusalem's Old City, but not on the Temple Mount.

title: Major League Baseball Selects Agencies
description: Major League Baseball said yesterday that it would consolidate various advertising assignments, with billings estimated at $20 million to $30 million, by naming the San Francisco office of FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications, to handle those tasks for the 2001 season.

title: Putting Franks on the Side of Government's Enemies
description: This 30-second commercial, titled ''Dismantle,'' was released yesterday by Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for the Senate from New Jersey. It is being broadcast on television stations in New York City and Philadelphia.

title: Taking the Guesswork Out of 'Cook Until Done'
description: There are a number of ways to determine whether fish has reached the proper degree of doneness. Cooking it 10 minutes for every inch of thickness is an old standby, as is prodding it to see if it flakes. But both methods often guarantee overcooking. Now there's Captain Quackenbush's Fish Cooking Testers, plastic-coated sensors that are briefly inserted in the fish and turn green when it reaches 140 to 145 degrees, the temperature the Agriculture Department considers safe. The testers are not for cooks who like their tuna rare or their salmon somewhat underdone: both will be thoroughly cooked if you wait for the green. But the testers are fine for cod and striped bass. You can also use them to test chicken breast or pork chops (cut a little slit so the tester slips in), or to signal a medium hamburger. A package of six is $1.99 at Citarella stores.

title: Half-Gone, But Not Forgotten
description: Half-used onions are often the orphans of the refrigerator, languishing in the corners of crispers. But now they -- and their grapefruit and tomato cousins -- have their own cozy plastic containers called Forget-Me-Nots. They are five inches across and come in blue or green, with a handy hook so they can hang on a refrigerator shelf; $10 a pair from Tupperware: www.tupperware.com or (888) 887-9273. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: A New Season, but the Same Old Yanks
description: Even the Yankees who made mistakes tonight in Game 1 of the playoffs kept repeating the same words. We played well, Jorge Posada said. We played well, Luis Sojo said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, LOWTHER, SUSAN M.
description: GREENE-LOWTHER-Susan M. On September 30,2000. Beloved wife of Richard. Loving daughter of James and Brigitte Greene. Dear sister of the late Thomas M. Greene. Reposing at Simonson Funeral Home, Inc., 119-04 Hillside Avenue (corner of Lefferts Boulevard), Richmond Hill, NY. Mass of Christian burial Friday 9:30AM at Church of The Holy Child Jesus. Cremation to follow at Fresh Pond Crematory, Middle Village, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the National Cystic Fibrosis Foundation would be appreciated; PO Box 96305, Washington, DC 20090-6305

title: TWO WEB COMPANIES CHANGE THEMES
description: Two dot-com companies that advertise a lot are starting campaigns with new themes. ''Onward. Upward'' is the new one for the Hotjobs.com job search site, based in New York, replacing ''The hottest hand on the Web.'' The campaign is the first from the new Hotjobs.com agency, Weiss Stagliano Partners in New York. Hotjobs.com has advertised in the last two Super Bowls. And the E*Trade online brokerage firm will begin using ''It's your money,'' to replace ''It's time for E*Trade,'' in a new batch of humorous commercials by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group. Brandweek reported that E*Trade planned for the second consecutive year to sponsor the Super Bowl halftime show, but Kim Brooks, a spokeswoman, said it was ''too early'' to discuss such plans. Stuart Elliott

title: Queens Man Sought in Loss Of Church Cash
description: Detectives were seeking a Queens man yesterday for questioning in the investigation into missing money from a prominent Roman Catholic church in Forest Hills.

title: Article 2000100492672773132 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Goring Excoriates Isles
description: With the season opener only one day away and the Islanders coming off an 0-5-1 record in the preseason, Coach Butch Goring went on a stick-pointing, profanity-laced tirade yesterday morning after a spotty practice session at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Actors on Strike: Support From the Many
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Searching for Their Lost Running Game
description: The Giants were stuffed on their first play from scrimmage, and the game at Tennessee went downhill from there. Tiki Barber took a toss and swept to the right, but before he could turn the corner, he was met by a wall of Titans. He tried to dance out of trouble before he was smothered by Jevon Kearse and Samari Rolle and thrown for a 3-yard loss.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN RISES. Corn rose on signs that farmers are collecting less grain per acre than expected, fueling speculation about a lower crop forecast. In Chicago, corn for December delivery rose 4.25 cents, to $2.035 a bushel.

title: U.S. Seeks Faster Filing Schedule in Appeal of Microsoft Case
description: Trying to demonstrate that the appeal of the Microsoft verdict can be handled quickly, the Justice Department proposed a schedule for the filing of documents in the case today, two days earlier than scheduled, and called for a filing period half as long as the one Microsoft proposed on Monday.

title: HUD Takes Over Agency In East Texas, Citing Bias
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development seized control of a public housing authority in Texas today, saying the agency had demonstrated a pattern of discriminatory abuses dating to the 1960's.

title: AFFYMETRIX FORMS UNIT TO FOCUS ON GENETIC VARIATIONS
description: Affymetrix Inc., a maker of DNA chip technology used by medical researchers, said it formed a unit to identify and analyze genetic variations in humans for developing and testing drugs. The unit, Perlegen Sciences Inc., plans to use about $100 million in financing from an unidentified source to hire scientists and begin processing DNA samples. Perlegen will buy Affymetrix's DNA chips, or glass slides with millions of genetic fragments attached, to analyze genetic variations and build a database of 50 human genetic profiles. It then plans to offer the information to companies interested in developing drugs by studying how genetic variation and the interaction of genes play a role in disease. Affymetrix is based in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: FAILED DRUG IS REPRISED
description: The biotechnology concern Isis Pharmaceuticals will resume clinical trials of its drug for Crohn's disease, 10 months after the drug failed to show effectiveness in patients with the serious intestinal inflammation. Isis, based in Carlsbad, Calif., is expected to announce today that data from the failed trial actually showed that patients with higher levels of the drug in their blood showed a statistically significant improvement over the group receiving a placebo. The new trials, using a higher dose, are expected to take about three years. Isis stock lost two-thirds of its value in a single day last December when the failure of the trial was announced. Andrew Pollack

title: SPANISH UTILITY EXPANDS IN MEXICO
description: Spain's third-largest power company, Union Electrica Fenosa S.A. is to invest $600 million to build and operate a third power station in Mexico, bringing the company's total capacity there to 1,500 megawatts and making it Mexico's leading private supplier of power. Fenosa won a 25-year contract to manage the natural-gas-fired generator in Veracruz state and is already building two other plants in the state of Sonora. The power company earns $1 billion annually from operations in Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean. Benjamin Jones

title: G.M.'s Sales Are Off, but Ford and DaimlerChrysler's Are Up
description: General Motors' United States auto sales fell last month as overseas rivals had gains and DaimlerChrysler offered deep discounts to move an aging minivan line.

title: Circumventing An Oil Crisis; This Time, Policy Makers Take a Hands-Off Approach
description: It seems like an echo of another era.

title: Four-Batter Nightmare Puts Mets in a Hole
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4  There was no need to start running. Ellis Burks had crushed Mike Hampton's fastball, and it would either land foul or be a game-turning home run. It certainly had the distance.

title: The Sophisticated Series: Mets vs. San Francisco
description: Season series: Giants won 5 of 8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPARITO, LOUIS
description: SAPARITO-Louis. On October 3, 2000. Loving father of Peter, and the late Louis and Thomas Saparito, grandfather of six. Brother of Catherine Sellian. Reposing George T. Davis, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle, NY, on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Friday A.M.

title: Son Conceived To Provide Blood Cells For Daughter
description: For the first time, genetic tests have been used to help parents have a baby with the exact traits needed to provide a cell transplant to treat a desperately ill sibling.

title: Saying No to Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: DELTA PETROLEUM WILL BUY INTO WELLS IN THE SOUTHWEST
description: The Delta Petroleum Corporation, an oil and natural gas exploration company based in Denver, agreed to buy stakes in 680 wells in Texas and New Mexico from the Saga Petroleum Corporation for $49.5 million in cash and stock. Delta paid $500,000 in cash and 289,583 restricted common shares as a deposit and plans to pay most of the rest by Dec. 1, the company said. Delta said it did not yet have financing needed to complete the purchase. The wells produce 1,750 barrels of oil and gas a day.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile on Aug. 26 about Bawa Jain, general secretary of the Millennium World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders, held at the United Nations, referred incorrectly to David Finn, whose company helped organize it. He is a co-founder of Ruder Finn public relations, with William Ruder -- not the sole founder. A reader's letter dated Sept. 13 pointed out the error; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Judge Allows School to Raze Poe's House
description: A State Supreme Court justice has dismissed a lawsuit that tried to prevent New York University from tearing down a block in Greenwich Village that includes a house where Edgar Allan Poe once lived.

title: Rangers Leave Quintal Dangling on Waiver Wire
description: The Rangers trimmed their roster today for the season opener on Saturday, and it was no surprise that Pavel Brendl, Manny Malhotra and Jamie Lundmark were cut. The real shocker was not announced by the team.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday showing the effect of the presidential candidates' tax plans on 12 hypothetical individuals and families misstated the taxes for one case -- a single parent with three children and an annual income of $29,000. That family would be due a rebate of $1,210 under current law, $2,218 under the Bush plan and $3,462 under the Gore plan; it would not owe those amounts.

title: Parole Is Denied For Killer Of Lennon
description: Mark David Chapman, who shot and killed John Lennon 20 years ago, was denied parole today after a 50-minute hearing at Attica state prison.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Takeover of Johns Manville Fails to Generate Enthusiasm, or Cash
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst and Bear, Stearns are having trouble financing their $2.9 billion takeover bid for the building materials manufacturer Johns Manville, according to bankers close to the transaction. The bankers said they expected Manville to report disappointing earnings for the third quarter, making it tough to generate enthusiasm in the capital markets to lend money to the buyout.

title: Metro Business; Space.com Cuts 22 Jobs
description: Space.com, a New York multimedia company that bundles astronomy-related content, eliminated 22 jobs, or about 22 percent of its work force, on Friday as a part of a plan to make the company profitable next year.

title: Metro Business; Con Ed Merger Plan Advances in Albany
description: The staff of the New York State Department of Public Service agreed with Con Edison and several consumer groups yesterday on a proposal to reduce electricity rates by up to 17.3 percent, and recommended that the state approve Con Ed's plan to merge with Northeast Utilities of New England.

title: Arafat and Barak Reportedly Reach Deal to End Violence
description: PARIS - Middle East peace talks in Paris agreed on Wednesday on steps to curb Arab-Israeli violence that has rocked the region for almost a week, an Israeli official said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORSCH, GEORGE
description: DORSCH-George. The History of Art Department at F.I.T. is grieved to announce the death of our friend and colleague, who was born July 2, 1936 and died on September 15. A beloved and inspiring teacher at F.I.T. since 1968, Professor Dorsch served as chairperson of the department from 1990 to 1994 and oversaw its growth from its inception in 1989, particularly fostering the areas of East and West Asian art, modern architecture, and medieval art. He opened these and other worlds to many students who will mourn him as deeply as do the members of the department and the F.I.T. community.

title: Love Finds a Way in Iran: 'Temporary Marriage'
description: For five years, Maryam, the hairdresser, and Karim, the home appliance salesman, carried on a love affair, meeting secretly at the house where Karim lived with his parents. The young couple's relationship was officially sanctioned by Iran's Islamic Republic, even though unmarried couples who have sex or even date and hold hands can be arrested, fined, even flogged. That is because Maryam and Karim were married.

title: Rangers Sign Mottau to a 2-Year Pact
description: The Rangers challenged Mike Mottau to come to camp without a contract and prove he deserved a better offer. Mottau did exactly that, and yesterday the 22-year-old rookie defenseman was rewarded with a two-year deal that included a signing bonus of $575,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAGNALL, WILLIAM
description: BAGNALL-William (Bill). Died at his home in Boston, on September 29, 2000. His family and friends will sorely miss his glorious one-liners, loyalty, & love, his grandchildren the butterfly kisses.

title: Actors on Strike: Support From the Many
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption in Science Times yesterday with an article about a newly excavated tomb in Syria referred incorrectly to a lapis lazuli artifact found there. It represents an ibex, not an ibis.

title: COMDISCO CUTS PRISM SERVICE LOOSE
description: The technology services company Comdisco said yesterday that it would stop financing Prism Communications, its New York-based high-speed communications business, and take a charge for the fourth quarter. As a result, Prism said it would curtail its Red Connect operations immediately. The company provides digital subscriber lines to 2,000 customers in Manhattan, Philadelphia and parts of northern New Jersey. The company said it would continue to serve them until it could hand them off to another service carrier by the end of the year. Catherine Greenman

title: Born in a French Cafe, Growing Up in New York
description: WHILE French restaurant and country cooking have been thoroughly examined by American home cooks, somewhere between the two styles lies a branch of cuisine that has been almost entirely missed: France's bar and cafe food. This is the realm of snacks like tartines and rillettes, salads and savory tarts, and one of most delicious of all: the croque-monsieur.

title: Judge Upholds F.D.A. Policy On Genetically Altered Foods
description: A federal judge has upheld the Food and Drug Administration's policy on genetically modified food, throwing out a lawsuit by biotechnology opponents that sought to require that such foods be labeled and tested for safety.

title: Chicken Salad Gets The International Treatment
description: MOST takeout spots offer just one chicken salad. Pando's Poultry in the Market at Grand Central Terminal goes them 11 or 12 better.

title: Folk Museum Gets Works of a Self-Taught Artist
description: The Museum of American Folk Art has announced an important 20th-century acquisition: a large group of paintings and all the manuscript books of Henry Darger (1892-1973), a Chicago recluse whose imaginary world centered on a tribe of sometimes androgynous child-warriors led by seven angelic sisters called the Vivian Girls.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a film review on Saturday and its list of credits misspelled the original title of a movie that was screened at the New York Film Festival on Saturday and Monday. The film, directed by Nagisa Oshima and being released commercially on Friday as ''Taboo (Gohatto),'' was first called ''Gohatto,'' not ''Gohatta.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, SAMUEL
description: WEINBERG-Samuel. Peacefully, in his sleep on October 1, 2000. Born March 28, 1908, son of Bertha Katz and Morris Weinberg. Attorney-at-law, senior partner at Sperry, Weinberg & Cohen. Loving husband of the late Mildred Wolton Weinberg. Beloved father of Ladd and the late Michael. Caring father-in-law of Catherine. Adored grandfather of Gillian Ladd and Joanna Weinberg. Devoted brother of Sophie Karp and dear uncle of Marilyn Silverman and Martin Karp. Fond friend of Carol Cohen. We are all richer for having shared his warmth and long life. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Tuesday, October 3, 7:00-9:00 PM. Services to be held Wednesday, October 4, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 381 Park Ave. South, New York, NY 10016. WEINBERG-Samuel. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, Samuel Weinberg. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire family. James M. Dubin, President Martin Lowy, Secretary

title: Transcript of Debate Between Vice President Gore and Governor Bush
description: Following is a transcript of the presidential debate last night in Boston between Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Vice President Al Gore, as recorded by The New York Times. The moderator was Jim Lehrer of PBS.

title: Thomas Suffers Power Failure as Sox Lose
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4  In a team sport, an individual star often gets credit for the success of the group. When the team fails, blame is usually more dispersed. But as the Chicago White Sox have lost twice to the Seattle Mariners in the first round of the baseball playoffs, it has been hard to overlook the performance of Frank Thomas, the veteran slugger who led the Sox to the best record in the American League this season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOW, EVELYN
description: LOW-Evelyn. The Board of Directors of the United Hebrew Geriatric Center mourn the passing of Mrs. Evelyn Low, beloved mother of Barbara and Robert S. Savin and Frieda and Robert Low, and widow of Max M. Low. As the esteemed Chairmen and Past Presidents of our Board, both Robert S. Savin and Max M. Low have been ardent supporters, benefactors and valued friends for many years. Among their many contributions was the endowment of the Low-Savin Residence for Seniors on our campus. Our heartfelt sympathy and prayers are extended to the beareaved family. Donald Duberstein, President Malcolm Lazarus, Chairman Rita C. Mabli, Executive Vice President LOW-Evlynne. In her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Robert and Frieda, and Barbara and Robert Savin. Adored grandmother of Debi and Steve Scoggan, Scott Savin, Gary and Nancy Low, Caren and Glen Coben and Warren Low. Cherished great-grandmother of five. Service on Thursday, 11:15AM, Westchester Jewish Center, Palmer and Rockland Avenue, Mamaroneck, NY. Contributions to your favorite charity or the United Hebrew Geriatric Center. 60 Willow Dr., New Rochelle, NY. For information, call Plaza Memorial Chapel, 212-769-4400.

title: CINTRA BREAKUP ORDERED
description: Mexican antitrust authorities announced that they would order the breakup of Cintra, the nation's airline monopoly and the holding company of its two largest carriers, Mexicana and Aeromexico. Fernando Sanchez Ugarte, president of the Federal Antitrust Commission, said the decision would allow more competition in the airline industry and should result in lower domestic airline fares. Unions representing pilots and flight attendants threatened to stage protests or strikes if the government followed through with the decision. Graham Gori

title: Confidence Surges in Japan But Optimism Is Tempered
description: Japan's large manufacturers turned markedly more confident about business conditions the last three months despite adverse foreign exchange rates, rising oil prices and a weakening stock market, a widely followed quarterly Bank of Japan survey showed today.

title: Personality Counted in Showalters Dismissal
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 3  Buck Showalter's firing came down to personalities.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS TO PAY $30 MILLION TO SETTLE
description: The American Home Products Corporation will pay $30 million to settle federal complaints about substandard manufacturing conditions at plants in Marietta, Pa., and Pearl River, N.Y. The Pennsylvania plant produces flu vaccines and the Food and Drug Administration said the settlement should not interrupt vaccine production. The company will also be subject to stepped-up inspections for at least four years. The settlement was announced after the close of trading. American Home shares fell 63 cents to close at $56.06.

title: Crowds Fill Montreal Streets for Pierre Trudeau's Funeral
description: Canada held a state funeral for former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau today, ending five days of national mourning for the flamboyant intellectual who led the country through one of its most tumultuous periods.

title: Enter the Mets and the Giants, Two Teams on an Upswing
description: In every postseason, Mike Piazza said, there is a moment of clarity that takes away all the pressure. Last year, the Mets' catcher said, he felt it when the Mets and the Atlanta Braves staged two extra-inning thrillers to close out the National League Championship Series.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ELIAS BROTHERS CORP., Warren, Mich., a franchiser of Big Boy restaurants, said it would close two restaurants in St. Clairsville, Ohio, and three in New Martinsville, Moundsville and Clarksburg in West Virginia. The company will try to find jobs in other Big Boy restaurants for some of the workers in those affected restaurants.

title: Yanks Head Home With Series Tied
description: OAKLAND, Calif. - Andy Pettitte's near-flawless pitching and a radically revamped lineup allowed the New York Yankees to temporarily delay obituaries for the two-time defending World Series champions.

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees Only Raise More Questions
description: LIKE Alice in Wonderland, the Yankees suddenly found themselves in a weird place last night. That is, leading in a game. After all, they hadn't been ahead in a ball game for what must have seemed to them like 40 years, though it was only since Sept. 25, when they briefly went ahead of the Tigers.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Told to Come Together, Nassau Officials Remain Far Apart
description: Ideally, all three leaders of Nassau County's embattled government say, they want to clean up the county's fiscal mess together and restore its pride. The trouble is, they have yet to sit in a room -- just the three of them -- to discuss it.

title: The Electoral Vote: Make It Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Skewering' The Politicians
description: One of the guests bounded through the door with a bag of lollipops. ''Suckers,'' Bobby Milstein, the host, announced with a gleam in his eye. ''Suckers and skewers.''

title: Cumulus Media Gets 35 Radio Stations
description: The radio broadcasting company Cumulus Media Inc. said today that it had completed the acquisition of 35 radio stations in nine markets from Connoisseur Communications of Westport, Conn., for $257.8 million.

title: Suharto's Son Admits Guilt In Maneuver To Stay Free
description: Stepping up pressure on the government, the youngest son of former President Suharto admitted today that he was guilty of corruption and asked for clemency to avoid serving an 18-month prison sentence imposed by the Supreme Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEMEL, LILLIAN S.
description: SEMEL-Lillian S. The Partners and Staff of Goodkind, Labaton, Rudoff & Sucharow, LLP express their deepest sympathy to their partner Betty M. Semel on the passing of her mother Lillian; we extend our condolences to her daughter, Rita and to her grandchildren. Goodkind Labaton Rudoff & Sucharow LLP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, ABRAHAM

title: Arafat Places Conditions on Mideast Talks in Paris
description: PARIS -- The focus of Middle East peacemaking efforts shifted Wednesday to Paris, but Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat demanded two things before he would agree to meet with Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak: a guarantee of protection for his people and an inquiry into the causes of violence that have swept the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Arafat told reporters after meeting with French President Jacques Chirac that a three-way meeting that had been planned with he, Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and Barak, was not a sure thing. "The meeting (with Barak) will depend on the one I will have with Albright," said Arafat. Asked what his conditions were, he said, "Protection and an international inquiry commission." A senior Palestinian official has said an international inquiry into Israel's actions would be a condition of reviving the peace talks. But Barak's office has said he "totally rejected the call for an international investigation." "I think that, if there are questions and if there are queries, we can answer them ourselves. We don't need a committee biased against Israel to investigate things," Justice Minister Yossi Beilin told Israel radio Wednesday. Albright arrived at the U.S. ambassador's residence in Paris on Wednesday to start the talks aimed at stopping six days of violence that have left at least 58 people dead in Israel, Gaza and the West Bank, and salvage the already-stalled Middle East peace process. She met with both Barak and Arafat Wednesday separately. At about the same time, Chirac met with Barak, who was accompanied by his most senior military adviser, Danny Yatom. Fighting broke out last week after an Israeli hardline leader, Ariel Sharon, visited one of Jerusalem's most hotly contested holy sites, a spot revered by both Jews and Muslims. State Department spokesman Philip Reeker, speaking in Washington, said CIA director George Tenet planned to join Albright in Paris. Reeker said Tenet will take part in discussions on security issues. As diplomatic efforts gained momentum, there were no signs of the violence abating. Two Palestinians were shot dead early Wednesday in the West Bank, and three Israeli military outposts in the Gaza Strip came under attack overnight. In northern Israel, a large forest fire raged Wednesday, one of more than 100 blazes that police believe have been set by Arab arsonists. Most have been extinguished. Europe has pointed the finger of blame at Sharon, who visited a shrine, known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as Al Haram As-Sharif, or Noble Sanctuary. The dispute over who will control the site is the main obstacle to a peace agreement. Chirac has blamed the violence on an "irresponsible provocation" -- a clear reference to Sharon's visit to the holy site. Sharon, notorious among Palestinians for launching the bloody war against Arafat's forces in Lebanon in 1982, said he bore no responsibility. After the Paris talks, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, a key player in the Middle East peace process, is planning a leadership summit on Thursday. Barak and Arafat have both agreed to come, Mubarak said Tuesday. Officials said the Paris talks would not just be a bid to stem the tide of violence. "The meeting ... is a step in the direction of the renewal of the negotiations and not just the end of violence here," Israeli Acting Foreign Minister Shlomo Ben-Ami told Israel radio. A diplomatic drive, led by Clinton, to forge an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement had lost momentum even before the recent violence, stalling after a July summit in Camp David.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MIRIAM WOLFF

In the caring presence of her son Michael and friend Lanie. After a lengthy, determined and exhausting battle with breast cancer, she finally rejoins her late husband John Forrest Mackay Ross. A small, private gathering of family and friends will be held. Donations to Dying with Dignity, 55 Eglinton Ave East, Suite 705, Toronto, Ontario, M4P 1G8, will be gratefully acknowledged, as both Miriam and John strongly supported choice in dying.

title: ROCHE REJECTS GENENTECH SALE
description: The Swiss drug giant Roche Holding refused the demand of a major shareholder that it sell its majority stake in Genentech Inc., the California biotechnology pioneer. The shareholder, Martin Ebner, the Swiss investment manager whose Pharma Vision fund controls 16.2 percent of Roche voting rights, proposed last week that Roche sell its 59 percent of Genentech to clarify Roche's value to investors and provide them with a clear choice between a pharmaceuticals company and a biotechnology concern. Franz B. Humer, above, Roche's chief executive, rejected the idea, telling the Swiss newspaper Neue Zurcher Zeitung in an interview that ''agreeing to Ebner's demand is unthinkable'' given Roche's present strategy of linking biotechnology research with the diagnosis and treatment of illnesses. John Tagliabue

title: OM GRUPPEN EXTENDS OFFER
description: OM Gruppen, the Swedish technology company that runs the Stockholm stock exchange, said it had extended its offer to acquire the London Stock Exchange to Oct. 23. As of Monday, the original closing date of the offer, OM Gruppen said that it had received acceptances representing 300,000 London Stock Exchange shares, or about 1 percent of the shares outstanding. OM Gruppen urged shareholders of the exchange to vote in favor of lifting a restriction that limits holdings in the exchange to 4.9 percent; the vote is set for an Oct. 19 meeting. The restriction would have to be removed before OM Gruppen, or any other bidder, could win control of the exchange. Suzanne Kapner

title: Survey Finds Parents Favor More Detailed Sex Education
description: As a mother and librarian at a suburban high school outside Washington, Susan Madden holds few illusions about the sexual innocence of teenagers. She has overheard girls chattering in the corridors about condoms, shuddered at the scantily dressed stars on music videos and come across students' notes that read like intrepid dispatches from between the sheets.

title: Resuming an Interrupted Conversation
description: The classic girl groups brought a crucial element into rock 'n' roll: the exuberant sound of women's conversation. In the 1980's the all-woman band the Bangles, whose reunion tour came to Irving Plaza on Monday night, resurrected that hidden dialogue in the new, more open-ended context of underground rock. Even more than the Go-Go's, that era's other hugely famous female group, the Bangles forged a link between women's history in pop and their future, showing how a girl group could take charge and become not just a girl band but a rock band, no gender appellations needed.

title: MINNESOTA MINING WILL BUY ELECTRONICS MAKER

Robinson shareholders will get $19 in 3M stock for each share, a 14 percent premium over Monday's closing price. Robinson had $93 million in sales in its fiscal year that ended in June. Shares of 3M, which is based in St. Paul, rose $2.31 to $94. Shares of Robinson, based in New Albany, Ind., rose $1.69 to $18.31.

The question for caviar lovers is, was it worth the wait? And what about the prices, as much as 50 percent higher than for other caviars?

title: Balkan Machinations
description: Slobodan Milosevic is not relinquishing power easily. Ten days after voters decisively elected Vojislav Kostunica as Yugoslavia's new president, Mr. Milosevic continues to bluster and threaten, proceeding with plans to hold a meaningless runoff vote this Sunday. Mr. Kostunica and his allies are right to disparage the runoff and insist on immediate recognition of his victory. Foreign governments, especially Russia's, must persuade Mr. Milosevic to yield power without further delay.

title: The Name Says It All, Quietly
description: IT'S hard to think of a blander name for a restaurant than the Dining Room. The Warholian blatancy of it seems almost subversive, and it's tempting to scrutinize the menu and decor to tease out conceptual layers within layers.

title: Supreme Court Considers the Use of Sobriety Checkpoints to Search for Drugs
description: It has been 10 years since the Supreme Court upheld the use of drunken-driving checkpoints on city streets, and nearly twice that long since the court ruled that the airport police could use drug-detecting dogs to sniff passengers' luggage. So it was perhaps inevitable that the justices would be confronted with the question they considered today: Can the police, by adding a trained dog, turn a sobriety checkpoint into a constitutionally permissible way of checking motorists for drugs?

title: Bush Fails to Stir Tough Crowd of 3
description: A married couple watched the debate here with a friend from Franklin Lakes over a dinner of ziti and sausage pizza, switching now and then to the Yankee playoff game.

title: THE CHEF
description: POTATO gratin is an unbelievably easy dish to prepare. Unfortunately, most recipes miss its breathtaking simplicity. Gratins are usually loaded down with butter and cheese, which can overwhelm the potatoes. That's the last thing I want to do -- especially at this time of year, when the potatoes are freshly dug and incredibly flavorful.

title: Steinbrenner Is Humming A New Tune
description: George Steinbrenner was cloistered in a Manhattan hotel suite working on undisclosed business yesterday, instead of sitting behind the first base dugout here watching the Yankees search for themselves. Steinbrenner declined to explain why he was not with his enigmatic two-time defending champions, but he was adamant about defending them after their three-week drought.

title: How to Juice Up Fruit Compote
description: To American moviegoers, a jujube is the colorful jellylike candy that sticks to your teeth. But a jujube is also a smooth-skinned, walnut-size subtropical fruit that is used in Chinese and Indian cooking.

title: Restoring Wolfe
description: Unlike most newly published novels, ''O Lost: A Story of the Buried Life'' comes with an introduction, a discussion of the manuscript and typescript, and a brief essay on editorial policy. That is because ''O Lost'' is the original version of Thomas Wolfe's ''Look Homeward, Angel,'' which first saw print in 1929 -- without any mention of its editor, Maxwell Perkins, or of the editorial policy at Scribners, where Perkins worked. It is hard to say how much two versions of a novel have to differ before they can be called different novels. But from a historical perspective, as well as an aesthetic one, these are indeed distinct works.

title: Archbishop's Appointment Signals Focus on Finances
description: Signaling that fiscal management is a top priority, the new archbishop of New York, Edward M. Egan, has hired a longtime former aide who helped overhaul the finances of his former diocese.

title: DELTA BAGGAGE HANDLERS VOTE AGAINST UNION MEMBERSHIP
description: Baggage handlers and ramp workers at Delta Air Lines Inc. again voted against joining the Transport Workers Union, giving the Delta, the third-largest carrier, a continuing cost advantage over rivals. About 18.8 percent, or 1,845 of the 9,804 eligible workers, voted in favor of joining the T.W.U. or another union, the National Mediation Board said. The union needed a majority of votes to win representation, and cannot file for another vote by the baggage and ramp workers for at least another year. Only Delta's pilots and a small group of dispatchers and flight instructors are unionized.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORGASH, SYLVIA
description: FORGASH-Sylvia. The Board of Directors, Administration and Staff at Just One Life, Inc. (USA and Israel) record with profound sorrow the passing of Sylvia Forgash, beloved mother of its founder and chairman, Jack Forgash. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire family: children, Jack and Carole Forgash; Phyllis and David Bruder; and grandchildren, Elliott and Cindy, Stuart, Matt and Sarah, Natan and Lisa, and great-granddaughter Chloe. Shiva will be observed through Sunday morning. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Joel Gold, President, USA Hillel Weinberger, Chairman, USA Steve Adelsberg, VP, USA Rabbi Martin Katz, Exec VP USA Rabbi Solomon Sharfman, Honorary Chairman, Israel Rabbi Macy Gordon, Honorary President, Israel Steven Esses, Chairman, Israel Dr. David Ribner, Chairman, Israel Madelaine Gitelman, Executive VP, Israel FORGASH-Sylvia. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a highly respected member of the Jewish community, beloved wife of the late Isaac Forgash and mother of Jack (and Carole) Forgash, founding member of the Board of Yeshiva College and the newly established Board of Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to daughter, Phyllis (and David) Bruder; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees FORGASH-Sylvia. The National Jewish Outreach Program (NJOP) mourns the passing of Sylvia Forgash, beloved mother of Jack (and Carole) Forgash, distinguished supporters of NJOP, who have played a crucial role in NJOP's efforts to assure a Jewish future for American Jewry. Condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir

title: Slump Allowed Players To Heal
description: Maybe the only good thing that happened to the Yankees over the last few weeks is that they nursed their wounds. The Yankees finished the regular season dropping 15 of their last 18 games and seven in a row, but left fielder David Justice rested his strained groin regularly, Bernie Williams's strained rib cage seemed to heal and right fielder Paul O'Neill's hip pointer improved.

title: The Electoral Vote: Make It Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Both Senate Candidates Blame Palestinians for New Violence
description: On the eve of peace talks aimed at ending a spasm of violence between Israelis and Palestinians, the Senate candidates from New York both staked out positions critical of the Palestinians yesterday, in a nod to the influence of the Jewish vote.

title: A Bear of a Wine Has a Cuddlier Sibling
description: BRUNELLO di Montalcino is a brooding Tuscan monster of a wine, requiring years of aging to release an inner core of dark, concentrated fruit from its wrapping of steely tannins.

title: Coach Righetti Cites An Unlikely Legacy
description: To think that Art Fowler's legacy lives on in the San Francisco Giants. That's Art Fowler, as in the old pitcher who in his post-playing life became Billy Martin's confidant, drinking buddy and pitching coach, a pitching coach who was perceived to be more drinking buddy than coach, a pitching coach of whom George Frazier, the former Yankees pitcher, said: ''I've been Fowlerized. I know how to throw a spitball now.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, HARRY L.
description: BLOCK-Harry L. Of Hackensack, New Jersey. Adored father of Alison. Beloved son of Nita and Burt. Cherished brother of Beth. Services on Wednesday, 1:00 PM, at ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey.

title: The Greening Of the Martini
description: THE long, sticky summer of the chocolate martini is at last behind us. Its replacement is a crisp new cocktail made from vodka and some variety of apple spirit, with a Granny Smith slice floating on top.

title: Suit Could Delay World War II Memorial
description: A suit filed in United States District Court here could delay the groundbreaking ceremony of the proposed national World War II memorial, plaintiffs in the case said today.

title: MILOSEVIC PLEDGES HARSH CRACKDOWN ON STRIKE LEADERS
description: The Serbian government issued a harsh warning to the democratic opposition today, promising ''special measures'' and prosecutions against those organizing a spreading general strike in Serbia intended to oust President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.

title: The Basic Principles of Civility Cubed
description: It was the snap of nail clippers from the adjoining cubicle that finally got to Jeanine Smartt. Her colleague at the Manhattan public relations firm made a habit of grooming his hands on the job, and she could not concentrate on her work until he finished.

title: Of Taiwan's Bourgeoisie and Its Affecting Charms
description: Midway through ''Yi Yi,'' a morose, skeletally thin teenager (whose nickname is Fatty) tells his date: ''Movies are lifelike. That's why we like them.'' In his view, movies don't only resemble the world we live in -- they expand it. ''We live three times,'' he declares, his passion overwhelming his arithmetic. ''Two times as much life at the movies!'' After watching this lovely, absorbing film you'll be inclined to agree. In exchange for three hours of your time, ''Yi Yi'' will give you more life.

title: LUCENT NAMES CHIEF OF NEW UNIT
description: John Young, a board member and former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, was named by Lucent Technologies as chairman of its microelectronics business. Mr. Young, 68, led Hewlett-Packard from 1978 to 1992, and was credited with leading the company into selling computers and printers. Lucent, in Murray Hill, N.J., plans to spin off the yet-to-be renamed microelectronics division to shareholders, next year and sell 20 percent of its shares in an initial public offering. The unit makes communications chips and fiber optic components like lasers. The spinoff is part of a broader strategy at Lucent, the world's largest telephone-equipment manufacturer, to focus on potentially faster-growing areas like broadband communications and the mobile Internet. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITT, EVELYN
description: WITT-Evelyn. On October 2, 2000 at age 90. Beloved wife of the late Ira. Loving mother of Stuart and grandmother of Jenny. Former Executive Secretary to Dean Mathey. As a Gray Lady during WWII, she comforted the troops when they returned from battle. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday, October 4th, at 12 Noon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVMAN, CELIA
description: BRAVMAN-Celia (nee Kahn). Beloved wife for 67 years of the late Moses, adoring mother of Irving (Rose), treasured Oma to Elizabeth (Jonah), cherished GreatOma to Noah, Sarah, Rebecca, Daniel and Gideon, sister of Rosel Schwarzenberger and Senta Eulau. A truly pious women who died on Rosh HaShana after a very full life; she remains a role model to the three generations she leaves behind.

title: Florida Appeals Court Rules In Favor of Voucher Program
description: A Florida appellate court ruled today that the state could use taxpayer-financed vouchers for students in poor-performing schools who could not afford private school tuition.

title: More Shock Waves Over the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANCINI, AMALIA
description: MANCINI-Amalia. On October 2, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Carmine, devoted mother of Maria DeLozier and Enrico, and son-inlaw Raymond. Also survived by one granddaughter, Karen. Mass Thursday, St Frances DeChantal R.C. Church, 9:30 AM. Reposing Ralph Aievoli & Son, 1275 65 Street, Brooklyn. Visiting hours are 2-4:30 PM and 7-9:30 PM.

title: Beijing Journal; China's Little Gladiators, Fearsome in the Ring
description: ''You need to look at the legs and examine the jaws, and you need to see if the lines on the head are straight,'' Meng Yu was saying, admiring the animals before him like any connoisseur of fine breeds.

title: Across the Country, the Audiences Settled In, Waiting to Be Swayed
description: MERCER ISLAND, Wash., Oct. 3  If the presidential nominees had radar to find the small percentage of undecided voters, it would lock in on people like Amy Rudolf, a 42-year-old mother of three who turned on tonight's debate waiting to be convinced.

title: Mailer Tells a Lot. Not All, but a Lot.; His Longest Love Affair Is With the U.S.
description: At the age of 77, Norman Mailer spends three hours every day at his beachfront home in Provincetown, Mass., writing a big novel that may -- or may not -- be his last.

title: Candidates' Positions Reflect Party Stances
description: On several issues in the debate, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush stood on principles that have divided their parties for decades.

title: Take a Big Chef. Add Tasty Pictures.
description: THE audience for cookbooks by celebrity chefs is usually limited to people who buy them just to look at the pictures, to the lucky few who consider cooking mainly a hobby and especially to those hobbyists who live in large cities. That is, places where one can easily buy special mushrooms like cepes, chanterelles and mousserons; cod with the skin on; and ingredients like elderflowers. You get the drift.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Plummets 3.2%; Other Gauges Are Mixed

title: Like Father (a Writer), Like Son (an Actor), and Neither Is Likable
description: Near the end of Theresa Rebeck's bilious new play ''The Butterfly Collection,'' Sophie, a young woman who has spent several weeks as the assistant to a Nobel Prize-winning novelist, finally gives literal voice to the complaint that the play itself seeks not only to address but also to avenge.

title: Food Stuff: Before Ordering Surf, Read About Turf
description: The National Audubon Society, which is concerned about the finned as well as the feathered, has published the Seafood Lover's Almanac, a colorful guide ($19.95) to the habitats of various fish, crustaceans and mollusks and the methods used to catch them. There are also some cooking tips and recipes. Each species is rated, from green to yellow to red  with red being the worst  on the Audubon Fish Scale, a gauge of whether it is endangered and whether harvesting methods cause pollution or threaten other species. Among the imperiled are the Patagonian toothfish (a k a Chilean sea bass) and swordfish. (King mackerel, above, gets a green.) To order: (888) 397-6649.

title: What Women Need to Know About Starting Up
description: Perhaps it is not surprising that venture capitalists, most of whom are men, mostly shower their riches on men.

title: Candidates' Positions Reflect Party Stances
description: On several issues in the debate, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush stood on principles that have divided their parties for decades.

title: Elections for Winners
description: To the Editor:

title: New Alliance to Take on Managed Care
description: An association representing 22,000 social workers in New York State announced yesterday that it was forming an alliance with New York City's largest health care union in an effort to give both groups a louder voice in Albany to push for changes in managed care.

title: Nader Blocked at Debate Door
description: BOSTON, Oct. 3 (AP)  Ralph Nader, who was excluded from tonight's presidential debate, managed to get a ticket anyway  but was turned away at the door.

title: Life Opens the Law Firm's Doors
description: I'm a part-time model, and one of my first jobs was to be a secretary behind a desk, phone in hand. Another time, I played a secretary on the stage in a repertory theater. So, when my son asked me to fill in for his legal secretary while she was on sick leave, I thought, ''This will be a piece of cake.'' How wrong I was. Keeping one toe on your Dictaphone machine and answering the phone while drafting a divorce complaint is the kind of gymnastic activity that takes practice. Even so, eight years later, I am still at it.

title: Germany Celebrates a Decade of Unity With 'a Bit of Pride'
description: Germany celebrated a decade of unity today with speeches that dwelled on the country's place at the heart of a unifying Europe. But the day was marred by a firebomb attack on a synagogue in Dusseldorf.

title: Neuberger Shares At Record High
description: Neuberger Berman Inc. shares jumped 5 percent to a record high on speculation that the company, a money manager that caters to wealthy people, could be bought in what would be the latest in a series of acquisitions of fund companies.

title: Lazio and Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Rookie Gives Team a Scare
description: The Nets' top draft pick, Kenyon Martin, rolled his right ankle in practice yesterday morning after he and the free agent Kevin Freeman became entangled during a three-on-one drill. Everyone on hand seemed to gasp.

title: Text of the Parole Board's Decision
description: Parole is denied. You murdered the victim, John Lennon, when you fired a .38 special caliber Charter Arm revolver filled with hollow-point bullets. You discharged all five chambers and hit Mr. Lennon as many as four times. Mr. Lennon was returning to his residence and was in the company of his wife when you committed this murder. This act was calculated and unprovoked. You had planned this crime for a protracted period of time, and it is apparent that you were obsessed in causing fatal harm to John Lennon. In addition to being an international celebrity, Mr. Lennon was a husband and a father of two young children.

title: Giants Trace Success to Their Happy New Home
description: Ellis Burks, the 36-year-old right fielder, was among the first players in the Giants' clubhouse today, arriving early to enjoy the perks of what may be the strongest home-stadium advantage in Major League Baseball.

title: GREEN MOUNTAIN ENERGY TO RECEIVE BACKING FROM NUON
description: The Green Mountain Energy Company said yesterday that it would receive as much as $53.5 million from Nuon N.V., the Netherlands' largest utility, to help finance its expansion in deregulated markets in the United States. BP Amoco invested about $50 million in Green Mountain Energy in May. Based in Austin, Tex., the company sells electricity generated from windmills, solar panels, hydroelectric dams and natural gas in California, Pennsylvania and New Jersey.

title: Times Promotes Executive
description: Virginia P. French, who has overseen arts and entertainment advertising sales and marketing for The New York Times since 1996, has been promoted to vice president for advertising, the newspaper said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIALKIN, ROBERT
description: BIALKIN-Robert. The Jerusalem Foundation notes with sorrow the passing of Robert Bialkin, brother of esteemed Vice Chairman Kenneth J. Bialkin. We extend condolences to Ken and his family. Teddy Kollek, Int'l Chairman Ruth Cheshin, Int'l President William Ackman, Chairman Sandra Rubin, Exec Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, THOMAS P.
description: MURPHY-Thomas P. The Newspaper Guild of New York notes with great sadness the death of Thomas P. Murphy who served with great distinction as President of the local from 1972-1978. Barry F. Lipton, President William J. O'Meara, Secretary-Treasurer Peter Szekely, Local Chairperson

title: Christie's Ordered to Answer in Antitrust Suit
description: The federal judge hearing a civil antitrust lawsuit against Sotheby's and Christie's yesterday questioned Christie's good faith in refusing to answer questions posed by one of the defendants and ordered the auction house to respond or face possible sanctions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, JEANETTE LILLIAN,
description: HOROWITZ-Jeanette Lillian, nee Jacob, who would have been 90 on November 29, died at the Salem Lutheran Home Skilled Nursing Facility in Oakland, CA. on October 3, 2000. Mrs. Horowitz was a teacher in New York City for over 35 years and lived in the Bronx, NY, Boonton, NJ, and Walnut Creek, CA. She was predeceased by her husband of 54 years, Robert. She is survived by her son, Alexander Horowitz, MD of Livingston, NJ, her twin daughters Roslyn Kleinsinger of Oakland CA. and Paula Horowitz-Engle of Berkeley, CA, and nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in Oakland, CA. at a later date.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: When Mold Ruins a Cheese

title: Vietnamese Refugees in New Orleans Find a Little Peace
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 30  The Virgin Mary, cast in smooth, white concrete, stands watch in many of the small yards in New Orleans East, her arms spread wide, palms out, as if to signal that this is a good spot to stop, to stay. Two, sometimes three to a square block in the neighborhood, the statues are heavy, permanent, and the plain, tiny houses they guard are brick, built to last. The journey to get here was too hard to even think about moving again.

title: Sports of The Times; On the Trail of the Reality Behind the Boxing Legend of Jack Johnson
description: THE Summer Games were over now, the Olympic ''family'' was splitting up and going in hundreds, thousands, of directions.

title: Police Investigate 5 Incidents for Ties to Strife in Mideast
description: The New York Police Department is investigating whether at least five recent incidents in the city are related to the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians in the Middle East.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWASSER, RUTH
description: ROSENWASSER - Ruth (nee Schwartz). Passed away peacefully in New York. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Emanuel Rosenwasser. Cherished mother of Judge Joseph K. Rowe, adored aunt of Jane Gevirtz and Beth Hess. Services private.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-20

title: In Opposing Parole, Ono Cites Safety
description: Following is the text of Yoko Ono's letter to the New York State Division of Parole on Mark David Chapman's request for parole in the killing of her husband, John Lennon:

title: RATINGS RISE IN INDONESIA
description: Standard & Poor's raised its ratings on Indonesia's foreign currency debt after $850 million in syndicated bank loans to the government were rescheduled. The long-term ratings rose to B- and the short term to C, both from selective default. The new loan agreements are not altogether good news for the lenders since the terms extend the repayment period, but the accords do reduce the risk that Indonesia might default on the loans. Wayne Arnold

title: A Challenge to Bilingual Programs in Teaching English
description: On a crisp September morning, the lesson of the day in a beginning class in English as a second language at International Middle School in Brooklyn was on greetings.

title: STEEL MAKER ORDERED TO LIQUIDATE
description: Philippine regulators ordered the liquidation of the country's largest steel maker, the National Steel Corporation, after the company's Malaysian owner rejected plans to refinance roughly $330 million in overdue debts. Malaysia's debt-restructuring agency controls 82.5 percent of the company on behalf of one of its own debtors. National Steel shut down in November, blaming the Asian financial crisis and a flood of cheaper imports for its debt problems. Wayne Arnold

title: Business Briefs
description: Con Ed Merger Plan Advances in Albany

title: Random House to Aid Holocaust Memoir Project
description: Random House has pledged $1 million to the Holocaust Survivors' Memoirs Project set up by the World Jewish Congress to find and publish the written accounts of those who suffered under the Nazis during World War II.

title: Dell Warns Its Third Quarter Sales Hurt by Europe
description: NEW YORK - Dell Computer Corp. , the world's No. 2 personal computer maker, said Wednesday its third quarter sales were coming in about 3 percent below what it expected due to weak demand in Europe.

title: Don't count on next year's air fare increases holding to the 5% that has been projected.
description: IN the preliminary 2001 business-travel forecast it released last month, American Express predicted that typical business air fares would increase about 5 percent next year. With airlines wailing about oil prices and slapping on fare increases and surcharges, the question now for corporate travel departments is: Will the number hold?

title: Candidates' Positions Reflect Party Stances
description: On several issues in the debate, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush stood on principles that have divided their parties for decades.

title: Metro Business; Expansions on Long Island
description: Carousel Foods of America, a producer of desserts, says it will buy and renovate a 22,000-square-foot building next to its site in Farmingdale, N.Y., in an expansion expected to add 150 jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILBERT, ARTHUR H., MD.
description: MILBERT-Arthur H., MD. On September 29, 2000. Prominent Urological Surgeon of North Bergen, NJ. Dear uncle of William Mauskopf. Great Uncle of Eric and Susan. Cherished brother of the late Ann Wiener, Edith Mauskopf, and Joseph Milbert. Graveside services will be held on Wednesday, October 4, 2000 at 2:30 PM at Riversville Cemetery, Glenville, CT. For information contact: Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ.

title: The Boss: Born to Be Bruised
description: When the Soviet Union was collapsing, I came up with the idea of a stunts company. We had been involved in auto rodeos and in lots of action films, which the Soviet government financed. But by the early 1990's, we had to think of other ways to make a living. Now we have the biggest stunt operation in Russia.

title: Dell Warns Its Third Quarter Sales Hurt by Europe
description: NEW YORK - Dell Computer Corp. , the world's No. 2 personal computer maker, said Wednesday its third quarter sales were coming in about 3 percent below what it expected, due to weak demand in Europe.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When people asked how I felt about the killer of my husband, I have always told them that I didn't think about that day anymore. I wanted to look to the future, and not to remember that horrible moment. But in actual fact, the memory of that night has never left me for the last 20 years.''

title: Pardoned Inmate's Lawyers Attack Virginia Evidence Law
description: Lawyers for Earl Washington Jr., the former death row inmate who was pardoned in Virginia on Monday after 17 years of imprisonment, say their long struggle to prove his innocence through DNA evidence was necessary because the state has the most severe limits in the nation on submitting new exculpatory evidence.

title: American Bard in Paris Stokes Poetic Home Fires
description: Legion are the young American novelists who have moved to Paris in the belief that this muse-city would release their innate talents. And for a good number of them it did. Far fewer, though, are the American poets who have settled here, almost as if they were fearful that this city's legendary powers of seduction would erode their identity as Americans, perhaps even weaken their resolve to become poets.

title: Miso's Ready To Become A Player
description: NOT long ago, miso was found almost exclusively in Japanese markets and health food stores. It was used in not much more than soup.

title: Nets Dealing With Injuries To 2 Backups
description: On the first day of the preseason, before the first practice of the new feel-good era, the Nets were twice visited by the injury curse today like a somber rite of fall.

title: Suffolk Restricting Cell Phones in Cars
description: The Suffolk County Legislature voted to make it illegal to drive while talking on a hand-held cell phone. The law is based on the conviction that the phones are distracting and likely to precipitate accidents. Suffolk is believed to be the nation's first county to adopt such a law.

title: Striking Serbian Coal Miners Maintain Solidarity
description: Here in the coal-black heart of Serbia's revolt against Slobodan Milosevic, miners in overalls milled nervously around their idle machinery today, smoking and chatting. There is solidarity, anxiety and contempt for Mr. Milosevic's effort to cling to power.

title: A Bad Night for O'Neill, In the Field and at Bat
description: Ramon Hernandez lashed a liner to right field and Paul O'Neill darted to his left, hoping to reach the ball and save Roger Clemens from a delicate situation in the sixth inning. But O'Neill churned and churned and never made it. He finally slowed down as the ball bounced about five feet behind him to deliver the tie-breaking run for the Athletics.

title: A Merger of 2 Medical Device Makers
description: The Thoratec Laboratories Corporation said today that it would buy the rival medical device maker Thermo Cardiosystems Inc. for $572 million in newly issued stock.

title: I.B.M. Introduces Top of Line In New Family of Computers
description: Entering a new phase in its three-year-old effort to adapt to the growing role of the Internet in business computing, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its new computers from large mainframes down to personal computer-sized servers would all be marketed under a single family name -- eServer.

title: TV Notes
description: Web Site, Meet Checkout Line

title: Serbian Police Abandon Posts at Yugoslav Coal Mine
description: KOLUBARA, Serbia, Oct. 4 -- Hundreds of Interior Ministry police, many in riot gear, swooped in to break a protest strike today at the Kolubara mines, which produce the coal for half of Serbia's electricity.

title: Kelly Returning To Manage Twins
description: Tom Kelly agreed yesterday to a one-year contract extension to return for a 15th season as manager of the Minnesota Twins. Kelly, who has the longest tenure among active major league managers, led the Twins to World Series titles in 1987 and 1991, but has also managed Minnesota through eight straight losing seasons.

title: F.C.C. Suspends Last Elements of Broadcast Fairness Rules
description: The federal government today suspended two long- established rules that had required television and radio broadcasters to provide free reply time for opponents of political candidates endorsed by the stations, and for candidates and others whose integrity is attacked on the airwaves.

title: Officials Disagree on How Lab Scientist Became Spy Suspect
description: Former government officials disagreed at a Senate hearing today over whether Wen Ho Lee became the subject of an espionage investigation because of his ethnicity, while scientists debated the significance of the nuclear information he downloaded from the computer system at the Los Alamos National Laboratory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOOCK, BETTY
description: KOOCK-Betty (nee Geffen). Of Copley, Ohio, on Monday October 2, 2000. Beloved wife of Julian C. Devoted mother of Marjorie and Charles Isroff and Kenneth and Cristine Koock. Loving grandmother of Bradley and Jason Isroff, Jessica Koock and Felisa and Michael DiSanto. Adoring greatgrandmother of Phaelan Koock. Graveside service Thursday, October 5, at 1 P.M. in the Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodridge, N.J. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to B'Nai Brith women.

title: Tough New Rules Don't Faze Chinese Internet Start-Ups
description: Chinese Internet entrepreneurs and their foreign backers expressed only mild concern today about the potential impact of new rules that, if enforced, could markedly slow development of the young industry here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHELSON, GERALDINE
description: RICHELSON-Geraldine. Loving wife of the late Sigmund Richelson died at her home October 1. She is survived by her sons Andrew and Eric, her grandchildren Emily, Silas and Caleb, and her brother Melvin Popper. Mrs. Richelson, a graduate of Hunter High School and Hunter College, authored children's books and greeting cards and co-authored the bestselling book, ''Burnout''. Services Thursday at 1:30 PM at Riverside Chapel in Mt. Vernon, New York.

title: As Truce Fails, Fighting Rages In Middle East
description: A cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians crumbled within hours today when intense rioting and gun battles flared once more throughout the West Bank and Gaza Strip and in Arab towns inside Israel.

title: Franks Ally Comes Up With First Ad Attacking Corzine
description: After a month of advertising on television with no rebuttal from the other side, Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for the Senate from New Jersey, came under attack today for the first time on television, in a commercial paid for by a Republican with close ties to Representative Bob Franks.

title: Botanical Garden Is Seeking $300 Million
description: It is considered one of the world's most prominent botanical gardens, but its 80-year-old greenhouses -- where thousands of plants are meticulously cared for -- have a heating and cooling system that is considered uncontrollable. The gift shop operates out of a tent. And the 15 miles of roadways at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx are marked with potholes and cracks.

title: Layoffs at Missouri Plant
description: Mallinckrodt Inc. said this week that it would close its oxygen concentrator operations in St. Charles, Mo., and would lay off 140 employees. The company, based in St. Louis, makes and distributes health care products. It said it would stop making its Puritan Bennett 590 series oxygen concentrators. The move is part of a manufacturing and distribution agreement with Invacare.

title: ONLINE AD SPENDING RISES
description: Advertising spending on the Internet grew robustly in the second quarter compared with the year-earlier period, the Internet Advertising Bureau said yesterday, though the growth rate slowed markedly from the first quarter. The bureau, along with PricewaterhouseCoopers, reported that ad revenue from April through June totaled $2.1 billion, up 127.3 percent from the second quarter of 1999, but up just 8.8 percent from the first quarter of 2000. ''We looked at the market correction in the dot-com world as a cause for concern,'' said Rich LeFurgy, chairman of the bureau, adding that ''the traditional advertisers have stepped in to fill the gap'' from the loss of ads from online marketers. He said Internet ad revenue for the full year could total $8 billion to $10 billion, compared with $4.6 billion in 1999. Stuart Elliott

title: Before Ordering Surf, Read About Turf
description: The National Audubon Society, which is concerned about the finned as well as the feathered, has published the Seafood Lover's Almanac, a colorful guide ($19.95) to the habitats of various fish, crustaceans and mollusks and the methods used to catch them. There are also some cooking tips and recipes. Each species is rated, from green to yellow to red -- with red being the worst -- on the Audubon Fish Scale, a gauge of whether it is endangered and whether harvesting methods cause pollution or threaten other species. Among the imperiled are the Patagonian toothfish (a k a Chilean sea bass) and swordfish. (King mackerel, above, gets a green.) To order: (888) 397-6649.

title: When the Real Thing Just Isn't Enough
description: Is that caviar on my plate, or are you just trying to amuse me? If today's caviar prices are too high, one can pretend to spoon it up daily with whimsical plates that trick the eye.

title: 6-Run First Off Maddux Gift-Wrapped for Cards
description: The tone for today's playoff opener at Busch Stadium was set in the first inning, when the Atlanta Braves performed like impostors.

title: Single-Family Home Sales Fell in August
description: Sales of new single-family homes dropped in August but remained on course to register the second-best year on record, government figures showed today.

title: Toy Giant Announces Japan Net Plans
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. announced its Internet strategy in Japan today, including a new Japanese-language e-commerce site and a potential linkup with the online retailer Amazon.com Inc.

title: Plastic Bags, Rats' Silver Platters
description: With officials citing an alarming increase in New York's rat population, a City Council committee was told yesterday that the main culprit might be as simple as the ubiquitous plastic garbage bags that have eclipsed metal cans at the curb. Pest control executives said the bags, and the food they contain, are potluck for vermin.

title: The Electoral Vote: Make It Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: A beer importer sponsors a series of concerts, but is keeping the tickets under tight control.
description: THE San Francisco band Third Eye Blind -- which produced the hummable tune ''Semi-Charmed Life'' in 1997 -- has sold millions of records and attracted legions of fans, including the decision makers at the company that imports Beck's beer into the United States. They are using the band in a new marketing campaign.

title: The Wonk, er, Woman Behind Mrs. Clinton
description: THERE is, among the grubby temp offices and junk-food cartons of every campaign, the smart kid, a k a the policy wonk, and if you think she's going to go into detail about her job, telling how hard she worked to make sure the candidate knew the stats and the issues, recalling the time she saved the candidate by catching this error or that in a speech, forget it. That would not be smart.

title: New Jersey Ranks Poorly On Medicare
description: A federal study has ranked New Jersey 48th in the country in terms of meeting standards for treatment of Medicare patients.

title: Hopping the Globe to Tend the Grapes
description: THERE are lots of flying winemakers, but only one is supersonic. His name is Michel Rolland, and he lives here in one of the more famous wine communes of the Bordeaux region. That is, he lives here now and then.

title: Across the Country, the Audiences Settled In, Waiting to Be Swayed
description: If the presidential nominees had radar to find the small percentage of undecided voters, it would lock in on people like Amy Rudolf, a 42-year-old mother of three who turned on tonight's debate waiting to be convinced.

title: $25 and Under; At Sundown, the Anchovies Sneak Off to the Kitchen
description: BY day, Sapori d'Ischia is a bright and thriving Italian specialty market in Woodside, Queens. Scattered among its attractive assortments of meats, cheeses, pastas and condiments are a dozen tables, where workers from the neighborhood sit cheek-by-cheese with hanging provolones and wheels of Parmigiano-Reggiano, eating heaping platters of rustic dishes like sausage and peppers, or veal with mushrooms, served at the counter for $4.50 each.

title: Nader Blocked at Debate Door
description: BOSTON -- Ralph Nader thought he had at least a seat in the audience at Tuesday's presidential debate -- thanks to a college student who gave his ticket to the Green Party nominee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODGERS, TERRY
description: RODGERS-Terry (Lila) of Terry Rodgers Antique and Fine Jewelry of New York City passed away on Tuesday Morning, October 3, at approximately 10:30 AM, on a bright, beautiful, sunny day. Her adoring and adored husband Jesse was at her side. She is also survived by her beloved daughter Melody, grandson Cameron and son-in-law John. Terry, a remarkable woman, will be greatly missed by her loving family, cherished friends, fellow members of F.A., and all who had the great fortune to have known her. The Rodgers family resides in Englewood, New Jersey, and services will be conducted at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Hackensack, NJ at 12 noon on Thursday, October 5. Terry is now in magnificent company in her rightful place at the head of the Round Table.

Visitation Thursday. Funeral Friday at Taylor & Modeen Funeral Home, Jupiter, FL. Memorials to First United Methodist Church, 815 Indiantown Road, Jupiter, FL. 33477.
