title: Treasury Prices Drop as Federal Reserve Holds Rates Steady
description: Treasury bond prices fell yesterday after Federal Reserve policy makers left interest rates unchanged and warned that high oil prices would increase the risks of faster inflation.

title: AstraZeneca Ulcer Drug Is Close to Approval
description: The Food and Drug Administration is nearing approval of Nexium, a new ulcer treatment by AstraZeneca P.L.C., the agency said.

title: ANOTHER DOUBLECLICK ACQUISITION
description: The Internet advertising company DoubleClick said yesterday that it would acquire NetCreations, a provider of e-mail marketing services, for about $191 million. NetCreations stockholders will receive 0.41 share of DoubleClick common stock for each share of NetCreations common stock, representing a price of $12.15 a share. The deal serves as something of a double play for DoubleClick, which last week agreed to purchase AtPlan, an online market research company, for $120 million in stock and cash. The New York-based DoubleClick provides technology and services that allow publishers and advertisers to manage and track their Internet advertising campaigns. Susan Stellin

title: Offering Students A Hand to Move Up
description: WE like to believe this is a nation of great social mobility. Study and work hard, and you will rise above your parents' status to join the middle class.

title: The Chef: Potato Gratin
description: POTATO gratin is an unbelievably easy dish to prepare. Unfortunately, most recipes miss its breathtaking simplicity. Gratins are usually loaded down with butter and cheese, which can overwhelm the potatoes. That's the last thing I want to do  especially at this time of year, when the potatoes are freshly dug and incredibly flavorful.

title: Jets Look in the Mirror And See the 1-3 Steelers
description: Even while they lounged on their sofas this weekend, the Jets won.

title: Accord Is Elusive in Talks to Quell Mideast Fighting
description: PARIS, Thursday, Oct. 5  After more than 12 hours of stormy talks and with clashes continuing in the Middle East, the Israeli and Palestinian leaders and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright struggled into the early morning today to find a way to stop the violence but failed to reach an overall agreement, a senior Clinton administration official said.

title: Silicon Valley Candidates Both Run Against the G.O.P.
description: Both candidates in a critical House race here seem to be running against the Republican Party as well as each other.

title: When It Comes to Knicks Talk, An Absent No. 33 Is Easily No. 1
description: They spoke respectfully about being stunned when they first heard that Patrick Ewing had been traded, about how odd it was not to see his nameplate above his old locker at their practice facility, and about how great a player he had been during his 15 years with the Knicks franchise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABER, IRVING
description: RABER-Irving. The Board of Directors of the American Friends of David Yellin College of Education mourn the loss of Vice President Irving Raber, loving and devoted husband of Naomi, father of Patty and Michael and special mentor and friend to his grandchildren. Irving served for many years as treasurer of the American Friends of David Yellin College of Education and tirelessly worked as a committee member for all events. Irving was a vibrant Jewish leader who touched and enriched the lives of many. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire Raber family. Elias Strum, President Marjorie G. Price, Executive Director The American Friends of David Yellin College of Education

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on Saturday about fighting between Israelis and Palestinians in Jerusalem included an erroneous identification from The Associated Press for a wounded man shown with an Israeli policeman. He was Tuvia Grossman of Chicago, an American student in Israel, not an unidentified Palestinian. In some copies the caption also misidentified the site where Mr. Grossman was wounded. It was in Jerusalem's Old City, but not on the Temple Mount.

title: The First Presidential Debate
description: After sparring for months from a safe distance, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush confronted each other last night in an intense, sometimes barely polite televised debate over health care, tax cuts, defense spending, campaign finance and other issues at the center of their presidential race. At times viewers may have felt lost in a blizzard of details, but certain overriding impressions came through. Mr. Gore came across as a candidate with ambitious government solutions who looked more confident and knowledgeable on the attack, and Mr. Bush as a Washington outsider who hopes to stir public resistance to what he said was the vice president's partisan, big-government approach.

Contributions can be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: CHIEF RETIRES AT TRAMMELL CROW, A REAL ESTATE COMPANY
description: The Trammell Crow Company, one of the largest commercial real estate services companies, said yesterday that its president and chief executive, George Lippe, had retired and was succeeded by Robert Sulentic, the chief financial officer. Mr. Lippe joined Trammell Crow in 1978 and had been president and chief executive since January 1996. He will continue as a director and will ''remain as an employee'' to help with a smooth transition, the company said. Mr. Lippe oversaw the growth of Trammell Crow's revenue from $250 million in 1996 to an expected $750 million in 2000.

title: Golota vs. Tyson A Clean Fight?
description: Andrew Golota and his handlers said yesterday that the heavyweight was ready to fight a clean fight against Mike Tyson on Oct. 20 at the Palace in Auburn Hills, Mich. No low blows. No biting. No dirty business. As long as Tyson behaves, so will Golota.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTTRELL, HELEN ELIZABETH.
description: COTTRELL - Helen Elizabeth. Died October 1, 2000. She was 88 years of age and resided in Mystic, CT. Helen was a graduate of the College of Mt. St. Vincent 1931 and Columbia Law School 1934. She was admitted to the Bar in both New York and Connecticut and worked with the US Attorney's office in NYC. During World War II she worked in Washington, DC with the Marketing Law Survey and the Office of Price Administration. She is survived by her sister Leone C. Birdsall and seven nieces and nephews. Private graveside service for the family will be in Westerly, RI at the River Bend Cemetery where she will join her parents Leone Balfe and Edgar H. Cottrell in the family mausoleum.

title: Disney to Deter Children From Some Areas of Its Web Sites
description: The online arm of the Walt Disney Company said yesterday that it would take steps to deter children from wandering into areas of its Web sites that contain inappropriate material.

Beloved husband of the late Jacqueline Mond Freedman. Proud father and father-in-law of Cathy and Jerry Gollub. Cherished grandfather of Michael, Allison and Matthew. Son of the late Abraham and Florence Freedman and brother of the late Lillian Katz, Mary Rubin and Sheldon Freedman. Graduate and lifetime supporter of CCNY. Retired as Executive Vice-President and CFO of Alexander's, Inc., and served as a member of its Board. Services Wednesday, October 4th, at 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' Amsterdam at 76th Street.

description: SIGMAN-Carl. The Board of Directors and members of the National Academy of Popular Music/ Songwriters' Hall of Fame regret the passing of Carl Sigman, a wonderful songwriter and an honored inductee in the Songwriters' Hall of Fame. Hal David, Chairman

title: The Faint Taste Of a Lost Harvest: Native Chestnuts
description: COMING across fresh chestnuts in a farmers' market is like spotting an opossum in Central Park. By all rights, they shouldn't be anywhere near New York. But there they are, as real as pigeons.

title: SWISSCOM TOLD TO LOWER RATES
description: The Swiss telecommunications regulator ordered Swisscom A.G., the country's largest phone company, to cut the price it charges rivals to lease its lines by as much as 63 percent. The ruling came in response to a 1998 complaint brought by a small Zurich-based provider, Commcare Communications A.G., that the price charged by Swisscom, a former monopoly, was not based on costs incurred. Swisscom said it was considering an appeal. Elizabeth Olson

title: Former Sothebys C.E.O. Pleads Guilty to Antitrust Violations
description: After a three-year investigation into the multibillion dollar auction business, Diana D. Brooks, the former president and chief executive of Sotheby's, has agreed to plead guilty today to conspiring to violate antitrust laws in collusion with archrival Christie's, people close to Ms. Brooks and the government said yesterday.

Mr. McVeigh was elected to The NYU Medical Center Board of Trustees in 1962. He served with distinction as Secretary of The Board and most recently as a Life Trustee of The Mount Sinai/NYU Board of Trustees. We extend our sincerest condolences to his family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman, Board of Trustees Mount Sinai/NYU Health Barry Freedman, Acting President & CEO Mount Sinai/NYU Health Theresa Bischoff, President, NYU Medical Center

title: Philip Glass and Friends Wrap Everything Into a Symphony
description: Since the early 19th century symphonists have tried to wrap music around transcendent ideas, from the concepts of heroism or universal brotherhood (in the Beethoven Third and Ninth Symphonies, respectively) to the mystical aspects of fate, death and resurrection, or heaven and the afterlife (in much of Mahler). Implicit in these works is a notion that is as old as the Psalms and that runs through medieval and Renaissance motets and Bach Masses: that music has a direct, emotional power that can magnify any idea, however mundane or profound.

title: Britain's Legal Barriers Start to Fall
description: Isabelle Terrillon has sued her former employer, Nomura International, asserting that her superiors at the bank instructed her to wear short, tight skirts to work. Once, the lawsuit attests, they ordered her to strip to her underwear and give a man a massage during a business meeting.

description: Through Dec. 29, Business Day is including a second section, World Business (Section W), on Tuesdays through Fridays. That section consists of international business news as well as the tables for the United States exchanges plus preferred stocks.

title: Serbian Strikers, Joined by 20,000, Face Down Police Encounter at Coal Mine
description: KOLUBARA, Serbia, Oct. 4  If the regime of Slobodan Milosevic breaks and Vojislav Kostunica takes office as Yugoslavia's president, it could be because of what happened at this gritty coal mine here today.

title: Tunisian Olive Oil From a Belgian Bakery
description: Alain Coumont liked the Tunisian extra virgin olive oil he was using in his Pain Quotidien chain of bakeries so much that he decided to sell it by the bottle. The delicate fruity-tasting oil, from Les Moulins Mahjoub, a century-old company near Tunis, is made from organic olives crushed between granite millstones, then cold-pressed in layers of straw mats.

Cherished grandmother of Nicole, Lauren and Nicholas D. Cyprus. title: Yugoslav Protesters Set Parliament on Fire
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Oct. 5  Supporters of the political opposition here seized control of the federal parliament building, media outlets and other government institutions today, moving closer to pushing President Slobodan Milosevic out of power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUDOIN, CHARLES H.
description: BAUDOIN-Charles H., October 4, 2000. Loving husband of Suzanne. Caring father of Patsy, Jean-Yves, Marina and Bettina. Grandfather of Christina, Patrick, Alexander, Daniel and Paul. Father-in-law of Madge, Ellen, Harry and Henri. He will be remembered by family and friends for his love of life and friendship, for his sense of humor, his wisdom, and his courage, as well as his contribution to the French Resistance. BAUDOIN-Charles H. It is with a profound sense of loss that Thanks To Scandinavia notes the passing of a truly exceptional and honorable human being Charles H. Baudoin. A person of unyielding faith in the goodness of mankind, he devoted much of his adult life to humane causes that enriched the lives of thousands. As a Vice President and a member of the Thanks to Scandinavia Board of Directors, he was a motivating source instrumental in the educational organization's recent affiliation with the American Jewish Committee. He was dedicated to the moral imperatives of Thanks To Scandinavia in reminding current and future generations of the heroism and bravery of the people, the governments and churches of Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden in rescuing persons of the Jewish faith from the Holocaust and in expressing America's gratitude to the Scandinavians through its perpetual program of scholarship awards to Scandinavian students and doctors. The nobility and sense of humane purpose exhibited by Charles Baudoin throughout his long and fruitful life stands as a beacon to all who mourn his passing today. Victor Borge, National Chairman Richard Netter, President Michael D. Beinner, Vice President BAUDOIN-Charles H. The American Jewish Committee is deeply saddened by the death of Charles H. Baudoin, a vice president of, and vital force behind, Thanks To Scandinavia, an organization with which AJC is proud to have joined in affiliation. Having survived the Holocaust as part of the French Resistance, Mr. Baudoin's affection for, and dedication to, this group that honors the unique role of Scandinavian countries in the rescue of Jews during World War II was a natural outgrowth of who he was and what he stood for. He was a brave and gentle man, and an inspiration and a friend. We send our sincere condolences to his wife and chidren. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Exec Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELDZAELER, HORTENSE.
description: GELDZAELER-Hortense. Of Toronto, Canada, on October 4, 2000 in her 103rd year. Beloved mother of Emily L. Grant (Eugene) of Mamaroneck, NY, Alfreda Henry, and the late Phyllis Weisfeld of Toronto; devoted grandmother of Barbi Weisfeld, David Weisfeld, Robert Henry and Carol Henry of Toronto; Terry Grant of Charlottesville, VA, Andrea Grant and Carolyn Grant of Boulder, CO; and doting great-grandmother of Jordana, Andrew and Alexis Klarfield, Leslie and Brett Henry, and Jamie Weisfeld of Toronto; and Samantha Grant Pardee and Jordan Grant-Krenz of Boulder, CO. Born in NYC in 1897, she became an accomplished pianist and singer, working with music publishers in Tin Pan Alley. In WW I, she served with a USO troupe entertaining Canadian and American troops departing for overseas, and met a young Canadian officer, the love of her life, the late Bernard Geldzaeler of Toronto, Canada, whom she married on his return from Europe. An effervescent personality and a superb entertainer, Hortense was an active leader at Holy Blossom Temple, Toronto, for many years. She was an elegant and charming presence throughout her life and brought untold happiness to all who knew her. Funeral services at Holy Blossom Temple, Toronto, Canada will be held at 10:30 A.M. on Friday, October 6th. GELDZAELER-Hortense. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Hortense Geldzaeler of Toronto, beloved mother of Emily L. Grant, a cherished leader in the Jewish community. Emily and her husband, Eugene M. Grant are admired and respected for their extraordinary leadership, commitment and philanthropy on behalf of UJA-Federation and many other organizations worldwide. We extend our sincerest condolences to Emily and Eugene; to Mrs. Geldzaeler's other daughter, Alfreda Henry; her seven grandchildren; her seven great-grandchildren; and her entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Factory Orders Rose Modestly In August After Plunge in July
description: Factory orders rose in August, bouncing back a bit from the largest monthly drop ever, as the Boeing Company sold more aircraft and demand picked up for electrical equipment, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Teacher Is Accused of Duping Boy to Make a Sexual Video
description: It seemed to be a risque online relationship between a high school boy and an older woman that had spiraled out of control. The woman demanded that the boy make a sexually explicit home video of himself, or else she would distribute images, doctored to show him engaged in sexual activities, to his classmates at Salesian High School here.

title: Pseudo.com Bankruptcy
description: Pseudo.com, a Silicon Alley content company, filed for bankruptcy in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Tuesday, two weeks after it laid off its 175 employees.

title: Priceline Pulls the Plug on Grocery, Gasoline Discounts
description: One of the most ambitious efforts to use the Internet to transform a big business, Priceline.com's system to let consumers bid for groceries and gasoline, was abandoned today because the company could not raise enough money to stay in business.

title: Miriam Wolfe, Vocally Adroit Actress, 78
description: Miriam Wolfe, whose long acting career embraced radio, television and the theater, died on Sept. 29 at her home in Toronto. She was 78.

title: Evil Anew In a Return Of 'Screw' By Britten
description: For his operas, Benjamin Britten was drawn toward stories in which malevolence lurks beneath mundanely straightforward social surfaces, with those dark forces invariably breaking through to wreak havoc in the lives of innocents. Recent biographies have explored the degree to which Britten's works reflect issues that he grappled with personally, most notably his relationships with the young boys who performed in them. But it is one of Britten's strengths as an opera composer that he was able to address these matters, again and again, in works that are as musically and dramatically compelling as they are disturbing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIZOWY, CHARLOTTE.
description: RIZOWY - Charlotte. American Friends of The Hebrew University deeply mourns the passing of Charlotte Rizowy, wife of our esteemed colleague Dr. Carlos G. Rizowy, Senior Development Director for the Midwest. On behalf of AFHU, we extend our deepest condolences to Carlos, their children, Brian Isaac, Yael Deborah, Michal Evie and the entire family. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President Todd S. Lundy, President, Chicago Chapter Lawrence E. Glick, Chairman, Chicago Executive Committee

description: It is the Satur day evening news, and Aleksandr I. Saliy 50-ish, stiff in a vaguely Soviet way, looking every bit the Parliament member and Tatarstan Communist Party boss that he is -- is reciting the shortcomings of President Vladimir V. Putin's cabinet. It is a television ritual, the sort of numbing boilerplate party bosses can deliver to a camera in their sleep.

title: Robert Allen, 73, Whose Songs Were Sung by an Array of Stars
description: Robert Allen, the composer of songs that included ''Chances Are,'' ''Moments to Remember'' and ''Home for the Holidays,'' died on Sunday at his home in Quogue, N.Y. He was 73. The cause was colon cancer, his family said.

description: Following are excerpts from an interview today with Vice President Al Gore on foreign policy issues, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Claims About Safer Cigarette Are Disputed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)  Antismoking groups said today that they wanted the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company to stop test-marketing an experimental cigarette it has promoted as safer than ordinary cigarettes. The groups said an independent study found that the new cigarette posed many of the same health risks as current ones.

title: Official Warns of Danger on Subway Lines
description: The inspector general of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that several subway lines were ''potentially in danger of experiencing a train collision, derailment or serious delays'' because supervisors failed to make hundreds of inspections of signal equipment.

title: TYCO TO ACQUIRE INNERDYNE FOR $180 MILLION
description: Tyco International Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the medical device maker InnerDyne Inc. for about $180 million in stock to add to the company's line of surgical instruments sold to hospitals. InnerDyne shareholders will receive $7.50 in Tyco common stock for each share held, a 5.2 percent premium over the closing price on Tuesday. InnerDyne makes instruments that help make the tiny incisions for so-called minimally invasive surgery, which is less traumatic for patients than traditional procedures. Shares of Tyco rose 94 cents, to $52.06. InnerDyne fell 22 cents, to $6.91.

title: Lender Accused of Deceptive Practices
description: The First Alliance Corporation, one of the nation's largest lenders to people with spotty or little credit, was charged by federal regulators with deceiving home equity loan borrowers.

title: Bolt Problem Scraps Shuttle Launch
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- NASA called off Thursday night's launch of space shuttle Discovery because of last-minute concerns over bolts on the external fuel tank.

title: Avalanche and Stars Tie in Opener
description: The Dallas Stars and Colorado Avalanche played to a 2-2 tie last night in a penalty-filled season opener matching two of the National Hockey League's best goalies and the teams that played in the last two Western Conference finals.

description: The antiques dealer Eric Philippe has a reputation as the first to catch trends. His T. H. Robsjohn-Gibbings show, closing this weekend, is the first solo exhibition of Robsjohn-Gibbings's work since his death in 1976. Most pieces came from Casa Encantada in Bel Air, Calif., and sold immediately. The pillars, right, were $100,000 a pair. Eric Philippe, 25 galerie Vero-Dodat, 011-33.142.33.28.26; also by fax, 011-33.1.42.21.17.93; or e-mail, ericphil@worldnet.fr.

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales for September
description: U.S. automakers reported an increase in seasonally adjusted vehicle sales for the fourth consecutive month in September. Analysts say the industry is on a pace to reach a record 18 million sold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OKIN, ROBERT (BOB).
description: OKIN-Robert (Bob). Bob passed away on October 3, 2000. Born to Deborah and Harry Okin on February 20, 1917 in Bronx, NY, he was a graduate of Ohio University and St. John's School of Law. Bob was a founding member of the Atlantis Yacht Club in Sea Bright, NJ and a former Executive Vice President and Board member of Faberge. Father of Kenneth and Dennis Okin, beloved grandfather of Peter, Elizabeth, Samuel and Catherine Okin, Bob was preceded in death by his loving wife Babette Slotkin Okin. Business advisor and friend for over fifty years to George Barrie. A loving friend, father and grandfather who will be greatly missed by all. Graveside services will be held Friday, October 6, 2000, 11AM at Riverside Cemetery in Saddle Brook, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The American Diabetes Association. For information, please call Louis Suburban Chapels (201) 791-0015.

title: The Setting Is Morocco
description: When two friends from Miami asked Pierre de Gastines, a Paris designer, to do a tableware collection inspired by Moroccan classics, Yzza (pronounced E-zah) was born. Mr. Gastines, born and raised in Morocco, created a modern yet timeless collection perfect for everyday use but special enough for a more formal setting. Among the pieces are a streamlined tagine cooker (large one shown, $135; small pair also shown, $35), plates decorated with a single Arabic letter (set of six, about $190) and simple vases with a Moorish cutout in slate blue, moss green, sand and taupe (large, $190, small $122). Vase and tagines are available at Barneys New York, and the entire line at Dean & DeLuca. Wholesale, www.yzza.com.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOOG
description: HOOG The Department of Romance Languages at Princeton University mourns the loss of its colleague, Armand Marc Francois Hoog, Pyne Professor of French, who died on September 10, 1999. A commemoration will be held in 106 McCormick Hall on Saturday, October 7 at 2 PM.

title: Justices Questions Congress's Limits on Legal Aid Arguments
description: The Supreme Court has permitted Congress to attach many strings to the use of federal money over the years. But pointed questioning by the justices today indicated that in restricting the type of legal arguments that lawyers in the federally financed legal services program can make on behalf of welfare clients, Congress might have gone too far.

title: Israel's Doomed Peace
description: In the last few years I have watched a curly-haired, wide-eyed Palestinian girl named Balqis, the child of a family I am close to, grow into a cheerful kindergartener in a refugee camp in Bethlehem. Four days ago, Israeli soldiers entered the area and suddenly fired near her school. Three children in the schoolyard were injured. Balqis was shot in the chest and now lies in the hospital in stable condition. Palestinians blame the Israelis; the Israelis blame Yasir Arafat; everyone blames Ariel Sharon for his decision to visit the site in Jerusalem that Muslims call Noble Sanctuary.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: All That Dancing

title: Weak Euro, Expensive Oil Prompts Central Bank to Raise Interest Rates
description: PARIS, Oct. 5  Treading a thin line between higher inflation and stifled growth, the European Central Bank made a surprise decision today to raise interest rates, reflecting its concern over rising prices caused by the weak euro and expensive oil.

title: Rethinking Police Dept. Recruitment
description: LAST week, Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik, facing a crisis in attracting police recruits, especially among blacks and Latinos, relaxed some standards. Applicants can be 21 years old instead of 22, and more of them may use work credits in place of college credits.

title: 11 Companies Buy Crude Oil From Reserve
description: The Energy Department sold 30 million barrels of crude oil yesterday from the country's Strategic Petroleum Reserve to 11 companies, defying predictions that refiners might boycott the sale and buoying a White House campaign to replenish low stocks of heating fuel in the Northeast.

title: Taking Time for Movies
description: To the Editor:

title: Tech-Shy TV Producer Extends Hit Shows to Web
description: HE does not own a computer. He still writes scripts by hand on a yellow legal pad. He has seen only one Web site, when an employee carried a laptop into his office and turned it on.

title: Former Sotheby's Chief Is Said To Be Planning to Plead Guilty
description: After a three-year investigation into the multibillion-dollar auction business, Diana D. Brooks, the former president and chief executive of Sotheby's, has agreed to plead guilty today to conspiring to violate antitrust laws in collusion with Sotheby's archrival, Christie's, people close to Ms. Brooks and the government said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the cultural impact of ''La Revue Negre,'' in which Josephine Baker made her debut in Paris 75 years ago, misidentified the composer of both the show's music and a standard of the day, ''I Ain't Got Nobody.'' He was Spencer Williams, not Clarence Williams. The two composers and pianists worked together sometimes but were not related.

title: KINDER MORGAN UNIT TO BUY GAS DIVISIONS FROM PARENT
description: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners L.P. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a natural gas pipeline, a gas-processing system and stakes in two other gas businesses from its parent, Kinder Morgan Inc., for $300 million in cash and partnership units. Kinder Morgan Energy will get Kinder Morgan Texas Pipeline Inc., a 2,600-mile pipeline that runs along the Gulf Coast to Houston, and Casper/Douglas, a gas-gathering and processing system in Wyoming. Also included in the purchase are stakes in a Colorado gas system and another one in Wyoming. Half of the purchase will be in cash and half in units of Kinder Morgan Energy. Kinder Morgan Inc. said it would use the proceeds to pay off $150 million in debt. The companies are based in Houston.

title: Scientists Find Planet-Sized Balls
description: WASHINGTON (AP) -- Scientists are rethinking some basic theories about planets after astronomers found 18 planet-sized gas balls drifting free in a star field some 1,200 light years from Earth.

title: Arming a Computer Against Trojan Horses
description: Q. What are Trojan horses and how can I keep from getting them on my computer? Is there any software that scans for Trojan horses and removes them?

title: From Pong to Today's Multibillion-Dollar Industry
description: VIDEO GAMES: BEHIND THE FUN

title: New TV Season in Review; Are They Paranoid Or Just Plain Realistic?
description: 'The Trouble With Normal'

title: Finding the Right College
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: All E-Mail, All the Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Time for Movies
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush vs. Gore, Round 1: Now the People Debate; Children 'at Risk'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KENNER, MORTON
description: KENNER-Morton. Happy Birthday, Darling. I miss you. Edythe

title: I.R.S. Agents Seize Records From a New Jersey School Board
description: Federal tax agents have seized seven years' worth of financial records from the headquarters of the school board in this affluent suburban community as part of an investigation into possible money laundering, corruption and budget irregularities, officials said today.

title: In Test, F.C.C. Lifts Requirement On Broadcasting Political Replies
description: Challenging broadcasters to open the airwaves to more robust political debate, the federal government today suspended two long-established rules that had required radio and television stations to provide free reply time for opponents of political candidates endorsed by the stations and for candidates and others whose integrity is attacked.

title: Visor Goes Wireless With New Modules
description: It's an unwritten law in the computer industry that when any new gadget is available, it takes about a year before the developers start releasing useful add-ons. The year is up for Handspring's Visor, and the floodgates have opened with the availability of interesting -- and not so interesting -- Springboard modules. (The Springboard is the name for a Handspring expansion slot.)

title: Realty Group Starts Its Own Listing Site
description: Concerned that Manhattan's biggest real estate firms had joined forces to publish their listings on the Web, a group of smaller brokerage firms unveiled its own Web site yesterday to compete head-to-head in cyberspace.

title: Word's Not Perfect
description: To the Editor:

title: Accord Ends 3 Days of Highway Blockades by Spanish Truckers
description: After a three-day strike aimed at forcing concessions from the government and shippers, Spanish truckers reached an agreement today on higher rates and a tax break to offset rising fuel prices and began dismantling their blockades of border crossing points.

title: MEDICINE MERCHANTS/Cultivating Alliances; With Quiet, Unseen Ties, Drug Makers Sway Debate
description: Elizabeth Helms arrived on Capitol Hill on a warm Tuesday afternoon in July with a simple message for Congress: Drug stores, not drug makers, are to blame for the high cost of prescription medicines.

title: Corrections
description: The Design Notebook column last Thursday, about annoyance over cryptic Olympic pictograms and other icons, misstated the meaning of a red traffic light in China. It means stop. During the Cultural Revolution 30 years ago, an effort was made to change the meaning to ''go,'' but the idea did not take hold.

title: TV Audience for Debate Is Smaller Than Expected
description: The debate on Tuesday night between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush was watched by at least 46.6 million people, a fairly meager audience for a presidential debate, data from Nielsen Media Research shows.

title: NO DEAL REACHED IN TALKS TO QUELL MIDEAST FIGHTING
description: After more than 12 hours of stormy talks and with clashes continuing in the Middle East, the Israeli and Palestinian leaders and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright struggled into the early morning today to find a way to stop the violence, but failed to reach an overall agreement, a senior Clinton administration official said.

title: Math Panel To Consider City's Tack In Teaching
description: Worried that New York City students are ill equipped to meet new graduation requirements in mathematics, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has appointed a panel to study how the subject is taught in city classrooms and to recommend changes by spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARSON, DANIEL
description: PARSON-Daniel. Age 78. Beloved husband of Grace. Passed away September 16. Interment private in New Jersey. Memorials to any animal rights organization appreciated. For info. 630 469-0032.

title: A Day in the Life of the Wired School
description: THE noise level in Jen Butler's fifth-grade language arts class in Viola Elementary School in Suffern, N.Y., was more fitting for a gymnasium than a class dedicated to reading and writing. But seven days into the school year, the children could not contain their excitement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAVANAGH, DORIS V.
description: CAVANAGH-Doris V. (Ret. NY Telephone Co.). Beloved wife of Gerard. Devoted mother of Barbara Cavanagh-Farley and son-inlaw, Thomas G. Farley. Reposing Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joan of Arc R.C. Church, Friday, 9:30 AM. Visiting Thursday 2-5 and 7-10 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to the Alzheimer's Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODGERS, LILA (TERRY).
description: RODGERS-Lila (Terry). To lose you was very sad, but to have been your friend was a tremendous joy. Connie and Burt

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTNER, MOSHE
description: ETTNER-Moshe. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons notes with sadness the passing of Moshe Ettner, beloved grandfather of Gali Ettner-Levkovitz, the wife of Assistant Rabbi Levkovitz. We extend our deepest condolences to Gali and her family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: NETSCAPE REDESIGNS ITS SITE
description: Netscape Communications, a unit of America Online, has redesigned its Web site for easier navigation and for more seamless interaction with Netscape 6.0, the company's browser update. ''It's an evolution of the home page from our core mission of serving the business professional,'' said Susan Minert, vice president for programming. Catherine Greenman

title: World Business Briefings
description: EUROPE TELEFONICA SEEKS MEXICO WIRELESS BUSINESS Spain's telephone company, Telefonica S.A., is in talks to purchase Motorola 's stake in several Mexican mobile phone companies. It would be Telefonica's first move into Mexico. Telefonica said a subsidiary, Telefonica Moviles, would acquire the Motorola shares and that a final agreement was expected within the next two weeks. No price for the shares was disclosed by Telefonica, but Spanish media reports said that the purchase would be worth about $2.6 billion and the companies involved were Movitel , Portatel , Cedetel , Baja Celular and Norcel . The transaction would be the first since Cesar Alierta, above, took over as chairman and Fernando Abril-Martorell as chief executive after Juan Villalonga resigned in July. The deal would give Telefonica Moviles about 1.3 million new cell phone customers.

title: A Net or a Snare?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIGMAN, HOWARD
description: SIGMAN-Howard. On October 2, 2000. Beloved husband of Judy and loving son of Seymour. Funeral service Friday, 12 noon at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Mets Dangle a Gift, but Then Take It Back
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Jay Payton's quiet little single was bigger than J.T. Snow's dramatic pinch-hit homer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RICHARD G.
description: MILLER-Richard G. 74, of Brookfield, CT, died September 29, 2000. Retired Senior Patent Counsel for Union Carbide Corporation, Graduate of West Virginia University and George Washington Law School. Honorably discharged from U.S. Navy. Survived by his mother, Gertrude H. Miller of Massachusetts, two nieces, Donna Brindley of MA, and Barbara Mahana of Idaho, and nephew, John Stacey of Oklahoma.

title: Company News Column
description: TYCO TO ACQUIRE INNERDYNE FOR $180 MILLION Tyco International Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the medical device maker InnerDyne Inc. for about $180 million in stock to add to the company's line of surgical instruments sold to hospitals. InnerDyne shareholders will receive $7.50 in Tyco common stock for each share held, a 5.2 percent premium over the closing price on Tuesday. InnerDyne makes instruments that help make the tiny incisions for so- called minimally invasive surgery, which is less traumatic for patients than traditional procedures. Shares of Tyco rose 94 cents, to $52.06. InnerDyne fell 22 cents, to $6.91. (Bloomberg News)

title: Mexico Ends Asylum Case, Sends Official Back to Cuba
description: A longtime Cuban intelligence official who had broken with his government and sought political refuge here was arrested by armed immigration agents on Tuesday night and deported to Cuba this morning, government officials and human-rights advocates said today.

title: Free-Form Roundup of Design Award Winners
description: DESIGN being used as a marketing tool? Hardly shocking. In the 1980's, Chrysler, now DaimlerChrysler, got a leg up on the competition by making design history with its minivan; this year it was the company's bulbous retro PT Cruiser with the getaway-car fenders. Chrysler also came up with the Chrysler Design Awards in 1993, dedicated to sussing out innovators in the fields of architecture, environmental design, electronic media and graphic and industrial design. The winners, announced this week, each receive a trophy and $10,000.

title: New TV Season in Review; A Marriage Made In Vegas, or Somewhere
description: 'Nikki'

title: Congressional Missteps; Boundless Secrecy
description: American government officials can go to jail for disclosing certain kinds of classified information. It is a crime to reveal secrets about nuclear weapons, codes and intelligence communication or the names of covert agents. It is also a crime to leak information that could injure national defense, although this is seldom prosecuted. But a bill passed on Monday by the Senate would criminalize the disclosure of all ''properly classified'' information. It is an overly broad proposal that would deprive the public of information vital to national debates on serious issues.

title: SHARP DROPOFF IN ONLINE TRADERS
description: Many online stock traders found something else to do after technology stocks took a steep dive last spring, according to survey results released yesterday by Jupiter Media Metrix. About 20 percent fewer people visited online trading sites on the World Wide Web in the second quarter, and those who did spent about half as much time there, said Rob Sterling, a senior analyst at Jupiter. The dropoff was most pronounced at brokerage firms like the E-trade Group that have no branches, and among women and people with high incomes, he said. ''These people got scared after the market behaved poorly,'' Mr. Sterling said. Patrick McGeehan

title: J.F.K. Restaurant Deal
description: A division of Restaurant Associates, which owns the Sea Grill at Rockefeller Center and the Brasserie at the Seagram Building, has won a contract to operate the restaurants and food kiosks at the $1.2 billion terminal now under construction at Kennedy International Airport.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Edison, N.J.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Spinach by Another Name

title: Corzine Assailed on Spending
description: This 30-second commercial, titled ''Ain't Buying It,'' is the first released by Representative Bob Franks, a Republican of New Jersey, in his campaign for the Senate against Jon S. Corzine. It began running yesterday on television stations in Philadelphia.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Christopher Rocancourt, who is sought by authorities on suspicion of having bilked the well-to-do out of millions of dollars by impersonating a Rockefeller, misspelled the surname and misstated the nationality of a painter whose work he boasted of knowing. The painter was Camille Pissarro, not Pissaro. Although born in the Danish West Indies, Pissarro moved to France and was considered French; he was not Spanish.

title: Full text of the Vice-Presidential Debate, Part 1
description: Following is the full text of the vice-presidential debate Thursday night (Oct. 6, 2000) in Danville, Ky., between Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut and Dick Cheney, as recorded by The New York Times. The moderator was Bernard Shaw of CNN.

title: Oracle's Stock Falls Again, But It Maintains Forecasts
description: As the Oracle Corporation's stock price dropped for the second consecutive day, company officials scrambled to clarify remarks made earlier in the week by an executive that apparently led to the selloff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAINES, NATHANIEL
description: GAINES-Nathaniel. On October 3, 2000. Beloved husband of Beatrice (nee Mordkoff) Gaines. Loving father of Marc , and Roberta Gaines, Steven Caine and Susan Caine. Also survived by three grandchildren Alyssa, Jesse and Melissa. 9:45 service today at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Pl, New Rochelle. Contributions would be appreciated to the Parkinsons Foundation or the American Heart Association. GAINES-Nathaniel. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: Piracy a Concern as the China Trade Opens Up
description: The Chinese government has promised long and loud to protect intellectual property rights as a member of the global trade world. But now, the Communist Party itself has fallen victim to copyright pirates: a party-sponsored anticorruption film is available across the country in illegal digital and celluloid versions.

title: 2 G.O.P. Lawmakers Offer Bill Limiting Access to Abortion Pill
description: The day after Gov. George W. Bush said he thought he would have no authority as president to overturn the Food and Drug Administration's approval of the abortion pill, two anti-abortion lawmakers today introduced legislation restricting access to it.

title: BOWATER TO CUT PULP PRODUCTION 10% IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: Bowater Inc. said yesterday that it would cut the production of pulp sold to other paper companies by 10 percent in the fourth quarter, a sign of slowing demand for the main ingredient used to make paper. The company, which is based in Greenville, S.C., and is the nation's biggest maker of newsprint, will cut production by at least 25,000 metric tons. The pulp inventories of paper makers are increasing while shipments of paper have leveled off, according to government figures. Falling demand for pulp and too much production have led to increased inventories that probably will result in lower fourth-quarter prices, analysts said. Bowater's shares rose $1.88, to $49.31.

title: New Procedure for Handling Sexual Misconduct Charges at Columbia University Is Challenged
description: When Columbia University approved new procedures for handling sexual misconduct complaints against students earlier this year, the changes were widely praised on campus despite some concerns that accused students could no longer confront their accusers or have lawyers represent them at hearings.

title: 8 Protesters Arrested At Campaign Offices
description: Eight AIDS advocates were arrested inside the campaign headquarters of the Senate candidates Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick A. Lazio yesterday after they staged simultaneous protests at the sites, criticizing the two candidates for their lack of attention to AIDS-related issues, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about ''Building Big,'' a new book and television series that explains large-scale engineering projects, incorrectly dated the hurricane that led Red Cross officials to plan an evacuation of Midtown and, by implication, misstated the year an engineering flaw was discovered in the construction of the Citicorp Building. The hurricane was Ella in 1978, not the one in 1962.

title: Return to Glory? No, but Yankees Win
description: His juggernaut had stalled and Joe Torre figured it was time for change, and there was nothing conventional about the decisions he made tonight other than to rely, again, on Andy Pettitte.

title: Time Warner, EMI Abandon $20 Billion Merger
description: LONDON -- EMI Group PLC and Time Warner Inc. said Thursday they had withdrawn their proposal to combine EMI Music with Warner Music Group in the face of opposition from the European Commission, but would continue talks on some kind of joint venture.

title: Bush vs. Gore, Round 1: Now the People Debate; Each Camp's Favorite
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big Tax Loophole for Insurers Prompts a Review on Capitol Hill
description: A loophole in American tax law that allows insurance companies to stop paying income taxes simply by opening a small office in Bermuda is causing deep concern on Capitol Hill amid signs that a number of companies are preparing to exploit it.

title: Mr. Lieberman's Job Program
description: While the vice-presidential debate scheduled for this evening will focus on national issues, Senator Joseph Lieberman, the Democratic nominee, remains at the center of a vital matter affecting voters in his home state and members of his national party. Since being nominated for vice president this summer, Mr. Lieberman has refused to take his name off the ballot for the United States Senate in Connecticut. Thus he is running for two offices at once, a fail-safe approach that almost certainly guarantees him a Senate seat in case the Democratic presidential ticket loses. The problem is that this dual candidacy is unfair to his constituents at home and undercuts his own image as a person who puts principle above political convenience.

title: Schools and Computers: Debate Heats Up
description: WHEN it comes to assessing the relative benefits of computers in their children's lives, parents don't have it easy. The signals are decidedly mixed. As computer manufacturers and software companies promote computers as indispensable educational tools, some educators agree, but certain scholars and technology skeptics denounce the reliance on the machine. Sorting through the arguments is no small task.

title: Analog Meets Digital TV
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPANSION BY BILLITON
description: The British mining and metals company, Billiton P.L.C. said it won the battle for the Canadian mining concern Rio Algom Ltd., after Noranda Inc., a rival Canadian concern that owns 5.4 million shares of Rio Algom, abandoned a competing offer. The deal values Rio Algom at about $1.13 billion, or $27 a share. At the same time, Billiton joined Anglo American P.L.C. and Glencore International A.G. in a consortium that bought the Columbian government's 50 percent stake in the Cerrejon Zona Norte coal mine for $384 million. The consortium will now form a joint venture with Intercore, a subsidiary of the Exxon Mobil Corporation, to manage the mine.

title: Lucent Spinoff of Avaya May Offer Clues for AT&T Proposal
description: According to recent news accounts, AT&T is considering spinning off its residential long-distance business to its shareholders in a move that would free the company to focus on faster-growing areas. The question naturally arises as to whether investors would benefit from such a strategy.

title: CONSUMER CONFIDENCE FALLS IN FRANCE
description: French consumer confidence fell at the steepest pace in five years in September as soaring fuel prices eroded shoppers' purchasing power. An index balancing positive and negative responses to questions about personal finances and spending fell to minus 8 from a revised record high of 2 in July, the national statistics office, Insee, said. That is the lowest level since July 1999 and the first negative reading in six months. A tripling in the cost of crude oil since early last year has been amplified throughout the 11-country euro region by a weaker currency. French consumer spending fell in August at the steepest pace in four years.

title: Turning Twin Passions Into an Eclectic Hit
description: Emmanuelle Fouks, a fashion designer, never paid much attention to her mother's shop, Maison de Vacances, known for its simple but chic white and beige bedding. She was too busy designing fashion collections and being paid as a trend spotter for Japanese clients. Two years ago, after having a baby, Ms. Fouks suddenly noticed her mother's business. ''I saw the potential to merge two of my passions -- fashion and home furnishings,'' said Ms. Fouks, right, who added color (raspberry, orange, fuchsia, khaki, purple) and texture (velour, mohair, rabbit fur, alpaca) to the natural linen that had been the Maison de Vacances trademark. ''When you buy a pair of shoes, you don't buy them thinking you will keep them for 10 years,'' she said. ''I think home furnishings should be the same.'' At recent trade fairs buyers snatched up her first collection: velour house slippers, above, $60 a pair, and cushions ($70 to $350) and bedspreads ($340 to $650) in velour and linen, mohair cable and jersey knit, and rabbit fur and linen. Available soon at Roberta Freymann, 23 East 73rd Street, (212) 585-3767; A La Maison, 1078 Madison Avenue (near 81st Street), (212) 396-1020; Ad Hoc Softwares, 136 Wooster Street, at Prince, (212) 982-7703; and in January, Bloomingdale's.

title: Justices Consider Limits of the Legal Response to Risky Behavior by Pregnant Women
description: There was little dispute at the Supreme Court today about what actually happened at the Medical University of South Carolina during the height of the crack epidemic of the late 1980's: the university's public hospital in Charleston tested the urine of selected maternity patients and turned evidence of their cocaine use over to the police. Thirty women were arrested, some taken from their hospital beds in handcuffs directly after giving birth.

title: Mueller's Pasta Line Sold
description: The American Italian Pasta Company, North America's biggest maker of dry pastas, agreed to buy the Mueller's pasta brand from the Bestfoods unit of Unilever. The price, to be paid in cash and stock, was not disclosed. American Italian, based in Kansas City, has manufactured the Mueller's line for Bestfoods since 1998. The company said that marketing the brand itself would bring cost savings and aid promotions. American Italian's chairman, Horst Schroeder, said the deal should add to company profit in 2002. Unilever has completed its $24.3 billion acquisition of Bestfoods, which is based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., Other Bestfood brands include Hellmann's mayonnaise and Skippy peanut butter. American Italian shares rose $1.13, to $19.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Bestfoods rose 12.5 cents, to $72.94.

title: Ground Zero, an agency founded on the West Coast, is now expanding to New York.
description: A creatively focused Los Angeles agency is opening in New York with ambitious plans for the new outpost to someday be much larger than the home office.

title: A Partner Leaves Frierson Mee & Kraft
description: Neil Kraft, a well-known figure in fashion and fragrance advertising, is opening his own agency, KraftWorks in New York, after leaving Frierson Mee & Kraft in New York, which he joined in 1998 as a partner and creative director.

title: A Film About Saving Life Is Suddenly Shadowed by Death
description: Eight years ago Claire Marie Panke set out to make a film about the daily drama inside the intensive care unit for newborns at St. Vincents Hospital in Greenwich Village, where nurses and parents struggle to save and nurture sick, fragile and underweight babies.

title: On the Ice, Suhonen and Hlinka Bring New World Order From the Old
description: The new man behind the Chicago Blackhawks' bench, Alpo Suhonen, respects the accomplishments of other hockey coaches. But he also admires the work of William Shakespeare, Anton Chekhov, Samuel Beckett, Sam Shepard and Tennessee Williams. Between hockey jobs, Suhonen was the artistic director of the theater company in Turku, Finland. He said there are similarities between people who play between the boards of the hockey rink and those who perform on the boards of the stage.

title: Nick Fatool, 85, Drummer Who Kept the Beat for Swing-Era Bands
description: Nick Fatool, a swing-era drummer who played with many of the most popular big bands in the 1940's and 50's, died on Sept. 26 in Los Angeles. He was 85 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Sexual Abuse Reported at an Immigration Center
description: The Justice Department is investigating complaints from women held at an immigration detention center near Miami who said they had witnessed or were victims of sexual assaults by Immigration and Naturalization Service guards.

title: Article 2000100591877958863 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Article 2000100591272622889 -- No Title
description: this is top sevenday index/knews_data/promos/ technology/sevendayindex/sevenday.html

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELLAYOCANO, NICHOLAS
description: DELLAYOCANO - Nicholas (Broadway Nick). Died in Clove Lake Nursing Home of natural causes October 3, 2000, age 89. Born in New York City, moved to Staten Island in 1970. Retired mailer from the New York Times, Local 6 Union. He was the Sergeant of Arms for many years. Grandpa enjoyed traveling. His granddaughter said, ''He had a passion for life, family and friends and Grandpa will be missed by all.'' ''Thank you for the wisdom and knowledge you have given us over the years.'' Survivors are his daughter Annabell, his son Anthony, his sister Edith. He has six grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. Funeral is from 2-4 and 7-9:30 PM on Wednesday at Richmond Funeral Home, Staten Island. Funeral Mass is at 11 A.M. on Thursday at St. Ann's Church. Burial is at Calvary Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: First Bonds Gets the Call, And Then He Gets the Mets
description: Barry Bonds's reputation preceded him when he came to bat in the third inning at Pacific Bell Park today. That is what the Mets thought, at least, after a borderline pitch went Bonds's way and nothing was the same in the opening game of their division series with the Giants.

title: Jakarta Won't Pardon Suharto Son; Orders Militia Chief's Arrest
description: Trying to send a message that widespread violence and corruption will no longer be tolerated in Indonesia, President Abdurrahman Wahid refused today to pardon the convicted son of Suharto, the former dictator, and ordered the arrest of the country's most notorious militia leader.

title: Bonnie Wiley, 90, Path-Blazing Reporter
description: Bonnie Wiley, who in the last months of World War II became The Associated Press's only female war correspondent in the Pacific, died on Sept. 23 in Honolulu. She was 90.

title: New TV Season in Review; Close Encounters Of the Supernatural Kind
description: 'Freakylinks'

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BOEING CO., Seattle, the jet maker, said it won an order from Air France worth about $2 billion for 10 long-range 777-300 passenger jets.

title: In America; Gore Piles On
description: If he can somehow force himself to stop sighing and interrupting and behaving condescendingly in front of the television cameras, Al Gore may yet get elected president.

title: Shoddy Pass Defense Is Hurting the Giants
description: The Giants continued yesterday to reassemble the pieces from two consecutive losses with an eye on the Atlanta Falcons. In both losses -- especially in Tennessee last Sunday -- the Giants found an array of leaks that need plugging.

title: A Collection Is Born, in Installments
description: ''It's the story of a home,'' the architect and designer Florence Fabiani-Baudoux, above, said of her maiden furniture collection, Oom. The first Oom pieces -- a sofa, low table, lamp, rug and key chain; yes, a key chain -- are for the living room. ''In January, I will present the bedroom and so on and so forth until the collection, the house, is complete in two years,'' she said. A khaki felt sofa with a few stripes, above, and a low table divided into three lacquer trays have a contemporary feel with French refinement. Ms. Fabiani-Baudoux is known in Paris for her architectural and design work on residential projects. She is now doing her first home in the United States. Information, www.luma-oom.com; fax, 011-33.1.45.49.37.36.

title: Pressman Punished For Post Slowdown
description: The New York Post, which is in the midst of a heated price competition with The Daily News, has disciplined one of its pressmen for ''his role in fomenting the deliberate slowdown of operations,'' according to a memorandum last Friday from the newspaper's publisher, Ken Chandler.

description: MANES-Jeanette Etta. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Jeanette Etta Manes, beloved mother of our devoted member Michael Manes. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

description: Tuesday was an evening of biology as destiny, genetically groomed specimens caught up in a battle over prescription drugs, the gulf between rich and poor, and apocalyptic pronouncements about the fate of the post-millennial world.

title: Treasuries Are Mixed; Analysts Focus on Oil and Job Outlook
description: Bond prices were mixed yesterday, a day after the Federal Reserve left short-term interest rates unchanged but reaffirmed its belief that low unemployment and high oil prices could lead to higher inflation.

title: MP3 Jukebox Tries to Replace Just About Everything
description: If you have not yet been swept up in the digital music explosion, either by choice or indifference, you pose a tempting target for an increasing group of companies determined to develop devices that will make you forget all about your old stereo system.

title: Residential Sales

title: Stepping Past The Wolves On Jesus' Path Toward Death
description: The Passion Play here, depicting the last hours and resurrection of Jesus, has been delighting Christian believers and incurring increasing controversy over its anti-Semitism, however grudgingly modified in recent decades, for nearly 400 years. But this year's installment, which began on May 21 and ends Oct. 8, has had a curious pendant, which in its own understated way has made a comment on that anti-Semitism that has passed largely if not entirely unnoticed in Germany.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the continued fighting in Israel misidentified Prime Minister Ehud Barak's army chief, Shaul Mofaz. He was the man standing at right; the man who was pointing was an unidentified officer in the Israeli Army.

title: Flash Points In West Bank And Gaza Ignite Again
description: About 2 this morning, neighbors say, Mahmoud Ibrahim Abu-Khalil and nine or more other members of the local Fatah militia here crept out on a rocky ridge overlooking a highway crossing and an Israeli military post and opened fire with their Kalashnikovs.

title: Essay; Bush Wins by Not Losing
description: Because he surprised the undecideds by fighting his more experienced debate opponent to a draw, George W. Bush won Round One.

title: FULLER ACCOUNTING IN JAPAN
description: The Ministry of Finance plans to release a ''national balance sheet'' intended to clearly show how the country's assets compare with its rising debts, which are partly a result of government spending to stimulate the economy. Publication of the balance sheet, scheduled for next week, is part of a government effort to be more open about the nation's finances and raise awareness of its long-term fiscal problem, which already has made Japan the world's largest debtor nation. The Nihon Keizai Shimbun, the leading economic newspaper in Japan, published what it called a draft of the balance sheet, which showed that Japan's liabilities, including pension obligations for the nation's aging population, are more than double its total assets of 660 trillion yen, or about $6.1 trillion. Miki Tanikawa

description: BRUDER-Evelyn, 90. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. Devoted mother and mother-in-law of Joan and Stuart Danoff, and Patricia and Charles Debrovner. Cherished grandmother of Nancy, Susan, William, Diane, and Caroline. Adored great-grandmother of Alexandra, Claire, Stephen, Michael, Abigall, William, & Amelia. Services will be held on Friday, October 6, at 9:45 AM at Gutterman's Inc., 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY. The family will be at home at 181 Blackheath Road, Lido Beach, on Sunday, October 8, from 11 AM to 4 PM.

title: Nasdaq Climbs 67 Points As Technology Shares Rally
description: Buoyed by Oracle's reaffirmation of strong prospects, the Nasdaq composite index climbed nearly 2 percent yesterday after losses in eight of the nine previous sessions, a downturn that had dropped the technology-heavy gauge back to the levels of late May.

title: Three-Dimensional Space Is the Next Frontier for the Internet
description: STEVE KASH is living in his own little world, but guests are welcome to drop in for a chat. Flyby's Hangar is the three-dimensional structure Mr. Kash calls home on the World Wide Web. Visitors can circle the music room, then scoot up a set of stairs and take an elevator to the roof garden, where a brook burbles loudly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, GEORGE QUINTARD.
description: PALMER-George Quintard. Died Thursday, September 15, 2000 after a short illness. He was a long time NY resident before moving to England. Mr. Palmer graduated from St. Marks School, Princeton University Class of 1947. He served with the Army in the South Pacific during WW II. Survivors include three sisters, Isabelle Dunning Palmer of Warwick, NY, Ruth Palmer Blanke of St. Louis, Mo. and Warwick, and Katharine Palmer Bailey of Westwood, Mass. Three children William and George Palmer and Isabel-Diana Palmer Carr-Smith. He will be sadly missed by his family, many friends and his companion, Patricia Simmons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFFER, HANS A.
description: SCHAEFFER-Hans A. On Wednesday, October 4, 2000. Hans A. Schaeffer of Bethesda, MD, formerly of Linden, NJ. Beloved husband of Lilo Schaeffer; devoted father of Barbara (William) Dagger, Monica (Mitchell) Gorochow and Edward (Liza) Schaeffer; seven grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Friday, October 6 in Rockville, MD. Memorial contributions may be made to the United Jewish Appeal and U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum. Edward Sagel Funeral Direction, Inc., Rockville, MD, 800-217-9403.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURFEIN, LOUIS
description: GURFEIN-Louis. The officers, directors and membership of the DMIA were deeply saddened to learn of the passing of their former president and esteemed colleague. We extend our sincere condolences to his family and his many friends. Diamond Manufacturers & Importers Association of America Jeffrey Fischer, President Ben Kinzler, Counsel

title: Congressional Missteps; Preserve the Spirit of Service
description: In an extraordinary outpouring of bipartisan support, 49 of the nation's governors -- including George W. Bush of Texas and his brother Jeb Bush of Florida -- sent a joint letter to Congress last month calling on lawmakers to approve a five-year reauthorization of Americorps, President Clinton's signature national service program. The letter was a well-deserved tribute to the program's approximately 40,000 volunteers, who receive a $4,725 educational stipend in exchange for an intensive year performing valuable work like cleaning up dilapidated parks, tutoring at-risk children and helping communities to recover from natural disasters.

title: Serbian Police Use Tear Gas Against Protesters
description: BELGRADE, Oct 5 -- Serbian police used tear gas and batons against protesters who tried to enter the Yugoslav parliament building in central Belgrade on Thursday, witnesses said.

title: Finding the Right College
description: To the Editor:

title: New Hostility in Mideast Echoes in a Brooklyn Neighborhood
description: Along Eighth Avenue in Brooklyn's Sunset Park, Hasidic Jews and Palestinian Muslims cross paths at every corner. Women with unmistakable Yiddish accents shop in Islamic markets, alongside Arabic women in head scarves. In the evenings, Jewish fathers pass Muslim fathers clutching the Koran, each on the way to pray to God or to Allah. A few return home to the same blocks.

title: SERBIAN STRIKERS, JOINED  BY  20,000, FACE DOWN POLICE
description: If the regime of Slobodan Milosevic breaks and Vojislav Kostunica takes office as Yugoslavia's president, it could be because of what happened at this gritty coal mine here today.

title: SAVOS IN DEAL WITH KOREAN COMPANY
description: South Korea's leading wireless communications carrier, SK Telecom, has agreed to acquire technology for its network from Savos, a New York wireless services provider, the companies are expected to announce today. SK Telecom will hold a trial run among Seoul customers first to introduce the Savos wireless audio portal technology, which allows users access to streaming audio content from the Internet on mobile phones. The contract is one of the first examples of a transaction between a large foreign wireless carrier and one of Silicon Alley's fledgling wireless applications companies. ''We plan to use this deal as a platform to expand in other parts of Asia,'' Nathaniel Brochin, the president of Savos, said in an interview. Simon Romero

title: A Carom Sends Bell Hobbling To Bench
description: His right leg was propped up on a folding chair, his ankle was bandaged and Derek Bell's heart, it seemed, was heavy. The Mets' right fielder did not want to talk -- ''I'm in pain right now; I don't want to talk,'' he said -- and he may not do much playing anytime soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, HORACE B.B.
description: ROBINSON-Horace B.B. The Society of Colonial Wars in The State of New York regrets the passing of it devoted member, and former Treasurer, on October 3, 2000. M. David Sherrill, Deputy Governor James B. Gardiner II, Secretary
