description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Mexico Deports Cuban

title: Man or Woman: Does It Matter?
description: Read of love and the emotions arising from it, and suddenly and surprisingly you realize that mostly you are reading novels written by men, not women, or so it seems. Now I'm not talking of fantasy romances -- dashing executives and swooning young women -- or bodice rippers, but of the mazy pleasantries and miseries of average people in common settings who unite, sometimes briefly, in triumph and tragedy. That's the ''love story'' genre.

title: John T. Patterson Dies at 72; Helped to Rally South Bronx
description: John T. Patterson Jr., who founded a development corporation that helped lure both businesses and capital to the struggling South Bronx of the 1970's, died Sept. 26 near Munich. He was 72.

title: 3 Carnegie Hall Executives Leave Amid Complaints About Leader
description: In the third departure in a week of a top executive from Carnegie Hall, the director of artistic planning resigned yesterday.

title: Bush vs. Gore, Round 1: Now the People Debate; Unfair to Nader
description: To the Editor:

title: Coffins, Urns and Webcast Funerals
description: THE spirit of Barbara Anne Frederiksen Pingree could be found floating around the Internet one day last July. Some people gasped. Others cried. Ms. Pingree had died less than a week earlier of lung cancer at age 69.

title: Senate Rivals Both Praised As Promoting Conservation
description: The board of the New York League of Conservation Voters, an environmental group, is deeply divided over whom to endorse in the Senate race, because its members say both candidates have strong positions on the environment.

title: SWISS PHONE DEAL
description: Switzerland's leading phone company, Swisscom A.G., will sell its satellite communications division to Verestar, a unit of American Tower Operations, which provides communications services to cruise ships. No price was disclosed for the sale, which will include a satellite ground station. Swisscom, however, estimated that selling its 25-year-old satellite business would save about $58 million over the next decade and allow it to concentrate on undersea cables or other providers for its international traffic.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dell Warns That Its Sales Will Not Meet Estimates

title: School Improvements Are Cited in California
description: In the first year of a California program that ties academic performance to financial rewards for public schools and educators, two-thirds of the state's public schools showed improvement on tests that provide the basis of the program, officials announced today.

title: Runoff Election Canceled
description: A Yugoslav court annulled parts of the recent presidential election, a decision the government will use to cancel a runoff on Sunday and call a new vote. Page A6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABER, IRVING R.
description: RABER-Irving R. Loving husband and companion of Naomi of 54 years. Beloved father of Michael (Hila) and Patricia Max (Ken). Caring grandfather of Jesse and Maia Raber, Lindsey & Benjamin Max. Dear brother of Murray (Lila). He will live in our hearts forever. Services at Beth El Synagogue, Northfield Road, New Rochelle, Thursday at 11 AM. RABER-Irving. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Irving Raber, a longtime friend and generous supporter of our Westchester Campaign. We extend our sincere condolences to his beloved wife, Naomi; his children, Patty and Michael; his grandchildren; and the entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect Barry Effron, Chair, Westchester General Campaign John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO RABER-Irving R. The Chinatown Community mourns the loss of Irving R. Raber, founder of the Irving R. Raber Company, Inc. on Canal Street. Mr. Raber has been developing the Chinatown area since 1940 and has helped improve the face of Chinatown. From the Bowery to Broadway, Mr. Raber has helped the Chinese Community to expand in immeasurable ways. He will be greatly missed by all of his associates and his employees at The Irving R. Raber Co. RABER-Irving. Beth El Synogogue of New Rochelle mourns the loss of our longtime devoted member an Honorary Trustee. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Russell Fayer, President

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Pop Life; Iran's Shadowy Tape Man, Spreading What's Forbidden
description: On a Wednesday at 5 p.m., a certain house in the Shemiran district of northern Tehran bustles with activity. Friends are called, the final minutes of videocassettes are hurriedly watched, and lists are drawn up. The tape man is on his way for his weekly appointment.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose against the yen on expectations that United States interest rates would continue to be more attractive than those in Japan. In New York, the dollar settled at 109.38 yen, up from 108.86.

title: Making a Dent In the Price of Gas
description: ONE day last week, I went undercover. Parking inconspicuously in front of the Minimally Invasive Surgery Center in my town, I slouched behind the wheel and surveyed the action unfolding across the street. I wished I had worn dark glasses. I wished I had stopped at Starbuck's to get a cup of hot joe.

title: In Turnaround, McCain Does Ad Urging Background Checks for Buyers at Gun Shows
description: In what gun-control proponents consider a major boost for their cause, Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, has begun appearing in television commercials promoting ballot initiatives in Colorado and Oregon that would require people who buy firearms at gun shows to undergo criminal background checks.

title: Wired Glasses Called eShades Offer Floating-Web Trick
description: So far, wearable computing has been for the highly technical and the very strange. But Inviso, a company with headquarters in Sunnyvale, Calif., would like to change that with eShades, a head-mounted computer display device that looks like a pair of oversize sunglasses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARASH, FRANCES (NEE COHAN).
description: BARASH-Frances (nee Cohan). Age 50 of Sunrise, FL. Survived by husband, Harvey; son, Andrew Schuster; parents, Stewart and Betty; and sister, Irene. Died October 3. Services Friday in Florida.

title: Camby Is Looking to Stay Healthy (and Put)
description: He will not lead the Knicks in scoring, but Marcus Camby could make a big impact this season. If he is healthy -- as he was during the playoffs in 1999 -- Camby could help catapult the Knicks toward a long postseason run. If he is hobbled by injury -- as he has been for most of the last eight months -- Coach Jeff Van Gundy's perimeter-heavy team could be in for a bottom-rung playoff seeding.

title: Windows Without Wincing
description: THE first computer system that I bought for my personal use came with 8 megabytes of RAM and took up a sizable portion of the available space atop the cheap kick-together Swedish desk I had at the time. It was 1994, and I thought I was living large.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, GERALD
description: FISHER-Gerald. Beloved husband of Annette. Loving father of Susan and Steven. Former vice president of Reeves International, Inc. of NYC. Mr. Fisher was well known in the toy industry and will be missed by all who knew him. Service Friday, 1:30 PM at Riverside, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIETA, HENRIETTA E.
description: VIETA-Henrietta E. Countiss. Peacefully at home on September 28, 2000. Beloved wife of the late John O. Vieta, M.D. Loving mother of Dr. Paul, Frances, Jona. Dearest mother-in-law of Leila Vieta and Richard Larm. Cherished grandmother of Kathryn, Amy, Paul, Laura, Robin, and Jonathan. Dear sister of Barbara Lee of Denver, Colorado. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Friday, October 6, at 5:00 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the John O. Vieta Memorial Lecture, care of Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 E. 77 St., NYC 10021.

title: BRAZIL AGAIN SETS BANESPA AUCTION
description: Brazil's central bank announced that it planned to sell 66 percent of the voting capital of the Sao Paulo state bank, Banespa, for at least $1 billion in a privatization auction on Nov. 20. Brazil plans to auction 11.2 billion ordinary shares of Banespa, which represents 33 percent of the bank's overall capital. Four local and five foreign banks, including the FleetBoston Financial Corporation and Citigroup, have qualified to bid. An additional 1.2 billion shares will be sold to employees for a minimum price of $52.6 million. The government made several previous attempts to auction Banespa, but trade unions and bank employees blocked the sale. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Scottish Court Allows Diary of Lockerbie Defendant Into Trial
description: PARIS, Oct. 5  Conceding that a defendant's 1988 desk diary had probably been illegally seized, judges in the Lockerbie trial still allowed it to be entered as evidence today.

title: Malcolm Todd, 87, a 'Father' Of Federal Medicare System
description: Dr. Malcolm C. Todd, a former president of the American Medical Association who helped develop a precursor of the Medicare program, died on Monday at Long Beach Memorial Medical Center in California. He was 87.

title: Thomas Suffers a Power Failure as the Sox Lose
description: In a team sport, an individual star often gets credit for the success of the group. When the team fails, blame is usually more dispersed. But as the Chicago White Sox have lost twice to the Seattle Mariners in the first round of the baseball playoffs, it has been hard to overlook the performance of Frank Thomas, the veteran slugger who led the Sox to the best record in the American League this season.

title: One Judges Opinion: Delete Should Mean Delete
description: The geniuses who designed the modern world's computers probably thought they were doing mankind a favor when they decided that nothing, in fact, would ever be deleted when a computer user presses the Delete button. At least one prominent jurist, however, thinks Delete should mean just that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMPSON, RITA (NEE BRACH)
description: SIMPSON-Rita (nee Brach). Of Ft. Lee, NJ, on October 3, 2000. Beloved wife of Henry. Devoted mother of Brach B. Simpson, Scott B. Simpson and Burt Ray Simpson. Loving grandmother of seven grandchildren. Services will be held at Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, New Jersey on Thursday, October 5, 2000 at 11 AM. For more information call ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Playing War, but With a New Set of Rules
description: I STARTED looking forward to computer war games the day my mother conquered Russia with a car door. And with the release of Combat Mission: Beyond Overlord, I've started looking forward to them all over again.

title: A Day After the Big Debate, No One Boasts of a Big Night
description: For all the buildup of the first presidential debate as a make-or-break moment for Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore, Republicans and Democrats alike conceded today that the overall dynamics of the race did not seem to have changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, MARY C.
description: FLYNN-Mary C. Of Rockville Centre, N.Y. on October 4, 2000. Dear mother of Robert (Rosemary), William (Kathleen). Proud grandmother of Ryan, Tara, Kevin, Erin, Kiera, Kerry and the late Colin. Cherished sister of William F. Nolen and his wife Gloria. Reposing at Macken Mortuary Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, N.Y. Thursday and Friday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Saturday 9 AM St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment Mount St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y. In lieu of flowers friends may make contributions to the American Cancer Society, 839 Stewart Avenue, Garden City, N.Y. 11530.

title: Word's Not Perfect
description: To the Editor:

title: WASH YOUR HANDS
description: Wonder where your keyboard has been? A BBC report says that computer keyboards accumulate up to 2 grams (about 0.07 ounces) of dirt every month. A study undertaken by AOL of Britain found that 56 percent of the nasty stuff came from food, but the study also found insects, dead skin and hair.

title: Steep Budget Rise Saves Project to Use Lasers for Nuclear Tests
description: A mammoth laser project at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory will apparently not have to be halted, as proponents had feared, after Congress this week nearly tripled its original budget for the 2001 fiscal year to cover large cost overruns and construction delays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCK, ERIC
description: FRANCK-Eric. Age 79 of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of West New York, NJ, died suddenly on October 3, 2000. He is survived by his wife, Paula; his daughter, Michele; and granddaughters, Sharon and Daniella. Contributions may be made in his memory to either The American Heart Association or The American Cancer Society.

title: Word's Not Perfect
description: To the Editor:

title: Bishop in Exile Prays for Panama's Poor
description: A rough ink sketch of Moses, encircled by prayers and petitions, covers the small window in the living room of Bishop Romulo Emiliani, a prominent Roman Catholic cleric in Panama who has ministered to a rugged jungle diocese along the border with Colombia. It is a fitting image these days as he ponders his own hurried exodus from the country he loves.

title: PepsiCo Taps Successor to Chief Executive Who Is Stepping Down at the End of 2001
description: Roger A. Enrico, 55, the chairman and chief executive who transformed PepsiCo from an expansive and rather cumbersome conglomerate into a streamlined packaged-foods company, announced yesterday that he would retire by the end of next year.

title: BROADCOM ACQUIRING ELEMENT 14
description: The semiconductor maker Broadcom said yesterday that it would acquire Element 14, a British developer of high-speed communications chip sets, for $594 million. The privately held company makes low-power digital subscriber line chip sets and other network technology. Element 14, a year-old company with 68 employees, is based in Cambridge, England. Broadcom said that the acquisition would help expand its local and wide-area network offerings with a full range of DSL technology for home and enterprises. As part of the deal, Broadcom will issue 2.65 million shares of its common stock in exchange for all of Element 14's stock. Laurie J. Flynn

title: A Mother and Daughter, Both With Growing Pains
description: The mother is 32. The daughter is 16. Do the math.

title: Hometown Still Loves Its Stalin
description: Even the Darth Vader of the evil empire is beloved in his hometown.

title: Paris Biennale: Where U.S.A. Meets F.F.F.
description: THIS is just a little pied-a-terre,'' said Susan Gutfreund, the New York hostess and aspiring decorator, thus stretching the credulity of more than 40 attentive American interior designers ogling the palatial splendor of her triplex in the chic Seventh Arrondissement.

title: Pushing Pills With Piles Of Money; Merck and Pharmacia In Arthritis-Drug Battle
description: Before the Olympic Games opened in Sydney last month, the aging gold medalists Bruce Jenner, Dorothy Hamill and Bart Conner were talking more about their arthritis than the coming events.

title: People
description: Kathy Tierney was named president at Addis, Berkeley, Calif., and San Francisco, succeeding Storey Hayden, who remains on the Addis board. Ms. Tierney had been president and chief operating officer at Smith & Hawken, Novato, Calif.

title: Time Warner-EMI Deal Off, Plan Faced Stiff Opposition
description: PARIS, Oct. 5  Faced with the opposition of European antitrust regulators, Time Warner and the EMI Music Group of Britain today withdrew their plans for a $20 billion joint venture to link their music businesses.

title: Bush vs. Gore, Round 1: Now the People Debate; Third- Party Exclusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Rewarding the Wealthiest
description: Of all the contentious issues in their debate Tuesday night, none underscored the differences between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush more than taxes. Repeating himself relentlessly, Mr. Gore asserted that the Texas governor's proposed tax cuts would award more money to the wealthiest 1 percent of taxpayers than the amounts Mr. Bush would set aside for education, health and defense combined. Mr. Bush accused the vice president of using ''fuzzy numbers,'' but never refuted the basic charge. In fact, Mr. Gore's formula was on target, illustrating a stark choice between the two candidates' approaches on the tax issue.

title: Nader Wants Apology From Debate Panel for Turning Him Away
description: Ralph Nader saw it as bad enough that he was barred from participating in Tuesday night's presidential debate. But to be barred from even attending it? Even in a secondary hall separate from the actual debate? When he even had a ticket, albeit one passed on to him by a supporter?

title: Yes, We Have No Bronx Pandas; The Bears Seem to Be Everywhere Except New York
description: Suddenly, there are pandas everywhere. In 1996 the San Diego Zoo got two, which thrilled animal lovers last year by producing America's first successful panda birth. Zoo Atlanta got its panda pair last year. The National Zoo in Washington is scheduled to get a couple in prime breeding age, perhaps as early as this month.

title: Senator Jeffords on Firm Ground for Re-election Bid
description: In a year when Vermont's political landscape has been thrown into turmoil over the state's new law granting gay partners legal marriage benefits, Senator James M. Jeffords remains on firm ground in his bid to win a third term in the United States Senate.

title: Article 2000100593012477241 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: ELECTRIC CAR'S JOURNEY STALLS
description: The bid to drive an electric car from Hawthorne, N.Y., to Detroit without recharging to show off the capabilities of its novel zinc-air power system, ended Monday evening in central Pennsylvania. Evonyx, the technology company that cobbled together the car, ended the attempt when night-driving conditions became hazardous as its vehicle was averaging just 45 miles an hour on the heavily traveled Interstate 80. The company said that data collected from the 1,075 fuel cells on board suggested that it could have reached its goal even though more than 300 of the cells did not work properly. A tandem car quit earlier with mechanical problems unrelated to the power system.

title: With Two Key Hits, Bonds Has Last Word
description: With a .200 career batting average in the playoffs, Barry Bonds was particularly sensitive about his past. He was testy toward the Mets, too, opening the National League division series today with two key hits and sparking the San Francisco Giants to a 5-1 victory.

title: Economic Scene; Don't blame deregulation for airline problems. Blame not enough deregulation.
description: AIR travel is no fun, especially for people who do a lot of it.

title: Vodafone Moves to Grab a Place in China's Cell-Phone Market
description: HONG KONG  Vodafone, the world's largest mobile phone company, announced an alliance Wednesday with the largest cell-phone operator in China, moving to tap a potentially vast market as it prepares to join the global economy.

title: Martin Gives Nets A Scare at Practice
description: The Nets' top draft pick, Kenyon Martin, rolled his right ankle in practice yesterday morning after he and the free agent Kevin Freeman became entangled during a three-on-one drill. Everyone on hand seemed to gasp.

title: Ferocity of Mideast Clashes Ebbs After U.S. Mediation
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank -- A fragile U.S.-brokered truce appeared to take hold Thursday, as Israel rolled back tanks from sensitive positions near several West Bank cities. But one Palestinian was killed in a clash near the West Bank town of Bethlehem, and another died at a Gaza Strip crossroads.

title: Taking Up Where Debate Left Off, Bush Assails Gore on Spending
description: Gov. George W. Bush rode out of the first presidential debate today accusing Vice President Al Gore of being ''the biggest spender we've seen in decades'' while defending his own $1.3 trillion tax cut against Mr. Gore's assertion that it favors the very wealthy.

title: Word's Not Perfect
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Aides See Slips by Bush After Tallying Debating Points
description: A day after his first debate with Gov. George W. Bush, Vice President Al Gore seemed far removed from the thrust and parry of forensics.

title: Article 2000100593472235414 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: ASIAN INTERNET INVESTMENT
description: GigaMedia Ltd., one of Taiwan's largest Internet service providers, and Satellite Television Asia Region Ltd., a unit of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, said they would invest more than $100 million in a new venture that will enable Taiwan's 4.8 million cable subscribers to order goods and services through their television sets. Most of the financing to upgrade existing networks to digital will come from Star. The joint venture provides Star with a bigger outlet for its services and GigaMedia with the money to upgrade its operations. The venture is a blow to Pacific Century CyberWorks Ltd., Asia's No. 2 Internet company.

title: Bush vs. Gore, Round 1: Now the People Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Kill Me? But I Have This Great Story . . .
description: Oh, what wonders are to be beheld on the stage of the New Victory Theater.

title: U.S. DETECTS BIAS IN POLICE SEARCHES
description: A federal investigation of the New York Police Department's Street Crime Unit has determined that its officers engaged in racial profiling in recent years as they conducted their aggressive campaign of street searches across the city, officials said.

title: In Albuquerque, Highly Touted Debate Fails to Impress
description: Dawn had yet to peek through the pitch-black curtain of a New Mexico morning when Nancy Laflin, a reporter for KOAT's Action 7 News, hit the streets to find out what waking thoughts the city had about the presidential debate.

title: Dell Warns About Third-Quarter Slowdown in Sales
description: The slowdown in the personal computer industry has hit one of its most successful companies, Dell Computer, which told analysts yesterday that its third-quarter sales would fall short of expectations.

title: Warner to Close Flagship
description: Four years after it doubled the size of its flagship on Fifth Avenue, Warner Brothers is closing the studio store.

title: Suitors for EMI Emerge After Time Warner Merger Called Off
description: LONDON, Oct. 5  The decision today by EMI Group and Time Warner to withdraw a plan to merge their music businesses may open the door to a new partner for EMI.

title: A MEDICAL DEVICE MAKER WARNS OF A QUARTERLY LOSS
description: Aspect Medical Systems Inc., a maker of an anesthesia-monitoring device, said it would report third-quarter revenue that would be significantly below analysts' estimates, resulting in a loss for the period. Revenue will be a lower-than-expected $7 million to $7.3 million, leading to a loss of 14 cents to 16 cents a share, the company said. Aspect, of Newton, Mass., had been expected to earn 2 cents a share by analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Aspect's shares fell $1.38, to $9.88. The Food and Drug Administration approved a competing product by Physiometrix Inc. in July and that has caused some customers to delay orders longer than anticipated to evaluate the new devices, Aspect said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''During the NATO war, we worked four shifts, including Sundays, and the government called us heroes. I was here and saw the missiles flying over my head. Now the government calls us enemies. But we are victims. Their victims.''

title: Reflections of a Museum Outdoors
description: Built on the relics of Roman baths in the 15th century, the elaborate medieval cloister of the Musee Cluny, the French national museum of the Middle Ages, has made a 21st-century addition, a garden meant for education and relaxation. ''In the Middle Ages, man was in communion with nature,'' one of the garden's architects, Eric Ossart, said. Mr. Ossart and Arnaud Maurieres, working in tandem on the project, used the museum's rich collection as the principal inspiration. The garden's wood catwalks allow visitors close to the plant beds, which are divided into four groups: plants for cooking (cabbage, garlic, onion); medicinal plants (sage, hyssop, mint); flowers (roses, iris, violets), and a love garden (topiaries, perfumed grass). The Musee National du Moyen Age is at 6 place Paul-Painleve, at Boulevards St. Germain and St. Michel; 011-33.1.53.73.78.00; www.musee-moyenage.fr

title: Unapologetic, Sharon Rejects Blame for Igniting Violence
description: Palestinians and some Israeli liberals have said that it was the well-publicized and intensely guarded visit to the area of the Al Aksa Mosque on the Temple Mount by the rightist leader, Ariel Sharon, that has touched off nearly a week of deadly fighting.

title: Article 2000100594001512867 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOOMIS, WILBER D.
description: LOOMIS-Wilber D. Age 75. On September 30. Beloved husband, father and friend. We will cherish his memory always. Service Saturday, 3 PM at Church of the Ascension, 5th Avenue and 10th St.

title: Word's Not Perfect
description: To the Editor:

title: About the Tables
description: Business Day is including a second section, World Business (Section W), on Tuesdays through Fridays through Dec. 29. That section consists of international business news as well as the tables for the United States exchanges plus preferred stocks.

title: Yugoslav Protesters Set Parliament on Fire
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Oct. 5  Supporters of the political opposition here seized control of the federal parliament building, media outlets and other government institutions today, moving closer to pushing President Slobodan Milosevic out of power.

title: Seahawks Switch Quarterbacks
description: Seattle Seahawks Coach Mike Holmgren has benched quarter-back Jon Kitna in favor of Brock Huard for Sunday's game at Carolina.

title: Ethics Rebuke Goes to Shuster, Head of House Transport Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5  In a punishment that sounds harsher than it is, the House ethics committee criticized Representative Bud Shuster, the chairman of the House Transportation Committee, for improper links with a lobbyist who once worked for him, and for other misbehavior.

title: Bush vs. Gore, Round 1: Now the People Debate; All Debate, All the Time?
description: To the Editor:

title: Full Text of the Vice-Presidential Debate, Part 2
description: SHAW: Senator Lieberman, this question to you. Once again in the Middle East peace talks on the one hand, deadly confrontations on the other and the flash point Jerusalem. And then there's Syria. Is United States policy what it should be?

title: $60 Million Gift Is Made To Library of Congress
description: The Library of Congress has just received the largest single donation in its history, $60 million, and Dr. James H. Billington, the librarian, is eagerly preparing to spend it repairing relations between ''the thinkers and the doers,'' between a resident panel of visiting senior scholars he plans for the library and the politicians across the street in the Capitol.

title: Bush vs. Gore, Round 1: Now the People Debate; No Winner Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Reggie Kray, the last survivor of a three-brother gang that ran London's underworld in the 1950's and 1960's, misstated the condition of the city's East End docklands at the time of his birth. The area was intact, not ''blitz-blighted'' in 1934. The bombing known as the blitz did not occur until World War II.

title: Toyota Distributors Name West Wayne
description: The Southeast Toyota Distributors L.L.C., representing 25 local Toyota dealer groups in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, North Carolina and South Carolina, has consolidated its account by naming West Wayne in Atlanta as its new agency of record. Billings were estimated at $70 million.

title: From Many, Two
description: SEPTEMBER 1997 Bill Higgins, the husband of Barbara Corcoran, the chairwoman and founder of the Corcoran Group, buys the domain name nycmls.com.

title: Technology Briefings
description: HARDWARE

title: Word's Not Perfect
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: U.S. Bancorp to Be Acquired By Firstar for $21 Billion
description: The Firstar Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire U.S. Bancorp in a $21 billion stock deal that unites two large regional banks led by brothers.

title: Going Out a Winner?
description: Jeff Kent might consider retiring should the Giants win the World Series. The subject came up when the second baseman was asked about the most valuable player award.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOW, EVLYNNE
description: LOW-Evlynne. In her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Robert and Frieda, and Barbara and Robert Savin. Adored grandmother of Debi and Steve Scoggan, Scott Savin, Gary and Nancy Low, Caren and Glen Coben and Warren Low. Cherished great-grandmother of five. Service on Thursday, 11:15AM, Westchester Jewish Center, Palmer and Rockland Avenue, Mamaroneck, NY. Contributions to your favorite charity or the United Hebrew Geriatric Center. 60 Willow Dr., New Rochelle, NY. For information, call Plaza Memorial Chapel, 212-769-4400. LOW-Evlynne. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the passing of Evlynne Low. The Low and Savin Families are dedicated Benefactors of The Hebrew University. Among the projects benefiting from the generosity of Evlynne and her late husband, Max, are the Evlynne and Max M. Low Medical Research Building at The Hebrew University Hadassah Medical School; the Harry S. Truman Research Institute for the Advancement of Peace, of which they were Founders; the Otto Stieber Chair for Cancer Research; and the Avraham Harman Chair in Modern Jewish History. We extend our deepest condolences to her children, Barbara Low Savin and her husband, Robert S. Savin, AFHU National Vice President; Robert K. Low and his wife, Frieda; grandchildren, great-grandchildren and the entire family. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menachem Magidor, President Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, Rector Yigal Arnon, Chairman of the Board of Governors American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President LOW-Evlynne. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University deeply mourns the passing of its long-time friend, esteemed Benefactor and beloved wife of the late Max, who was a member of our Board of Overseers. The adored mother of Robert and Frieda Low and Barbara and Robert Savin, Mrs. Low was the matriarch of the distinguished philanthropic family that named the Low Residence Hall on our Jack and Pearl Resnick Campus. A woman of compassion, she will be greatly missed by all who had the privilege of knowing her. We offer our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Yeshiva University Dr. Norman Lamm, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dr. Dominick P. Purpura The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: Europe Finds Abortion Pill Is No Magic Cure-All
description: Even before she got to the Broussais Hospital clinic here last month, the 28-year-old woman knew that she wanted to have a drug-induced abortion.

title: All Politics Are Local, but Look at These Stakes
description: As she runs for Congress here in Ohio's principal battleground district, City Councilwoman Maryellen O'Shaughnessy takes care to maintain her role in the family funeral home on East Town Street that has been the downtown anchor for generations of Democratic politicking by her kin.

title: Bush vs. Gore, Round 1: Now the People Debate; Specifics Counted
description: To the Editor:

title: Cardinals Chase Glavine Early
description: ST. LOUIS - Another of the Atlanta Braves' golden arms left Busch Stadium badly tarnished, putting the St. Louis Cardinals within one win of the NL championship series.

title: Article 2000100591806169587 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: An Essential and Immeasurable Victory for Yankees
description: Cursory answers, glazed expressions, awkward silences and sudden changes. Those are the elements of a spiraling team, and that is how the Yankees looked and acted for most of the past two days. They were numb and they almost seemed done. Their season could have been over tomorrow night.

title: When Card Competition Stands for Accord
description: At a major bridge tournament the journalists usually concentrate on the players who are in contention for the title. That was not entirely true at the Transnational Mixed Teams played last month at the World Championships in Maastricht, the Netherlands.

title: Braves, Still Confident, Are Relying on Glavine
description: October is a bad time to play bad baseball, and the Atlanta Braves have paid the price.

title: The Cleveland Shows It Means Business
description: It is the time of grand openings and season renewals. The New York City and Metropolitan Operas have reintroduced themselves, also the New York Philharmonic. The fourth shoe to drop was heard at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night when the Cleveland Orchestra, Christoph von Dohnanyi and Maurizio Pollini played to a gala audience of first-nighters ready for art but happy as well to contemplate the food-and-drink festivities that accompany such events.

title: GULFSTREAM ELIMINATES 2% OF ITS WORKERS TO CUT COSTS
description: The Gulfstream business jet unit of the General Dynamics Corporation laid off about 200 employees, or 2 percent of the operation's work force, last month as part of a plan to cut costs and increase efficiency. Most of the workers were in management and administrative positions at Gulfstream's headquarters in Savannah, Ga., said Keith Mordoff, a Gulfstream spokesman. He declined to estimate the cost savings. The layoffs came as demand for business jets was declining from recent record levels and competition was increasing, said Paul Nisbet, an analyst with JSA Research Inc. in Newport, R.I.

title: Sarah Burroughs Retires at Burrell
description: Sarah Burroughs, president and chief operating officer at the Burrell Communications Group in Chicago, has retired, the agency said, after 26 years at Burrell and 36 years in the advertising industry. Ms. Burroughs, 56, is one of the best-known top executives in the field of agencies that specialize in campaigns aimed at black consumers. No successor to Ms. Burroughs is being named at this time as Burrell considers changes in its management structure. Burrell is 49 percent owned by the Publicis Groupe S.A.

title: U.N. SEES $1 TRILLION IN GLOBAL INVESTMENT
description: Foreign direct investment worldwide, fueled by cross-border mergers and acquisitions, is expected to increase to $1 trillion this year, up from $865 billion in 1999, the United Nations trade and development agency said. In its World Investment Report the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development said industrialized economies led by the United States received the largest share of investment inflow, with $276 billion, more than all developing countries combined, at $208 billion. Elizabeth Olson

title: Coaches Seek Edge From Rival's Misfortunes
description: Their New York experiences have been eerily similar. Both came to the Giants with reputations as passing gurus only to deal with quarterback controversies. Both earned coach-of-the-year honors in their first season with the Giants. And after two mediocre seasons, each entered his fourth year with his job security in doubt.

title: Bush vs. Gore, Round 1: Now the People Debate; Foreign Policy Wonk?
description: To the Editor:

title: MAXTOR BUYING QUANTUM DISK
description: The maker of lowpriced hard disk drives Maxtor said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Quantum's hard disk drive group for about $1.3 billion in stock, creating the world's largest computer hard drive manufacturer. Maxtor will exchange 1.52 of its shares for each share of Quantum HDD. Shares of Maxtor fell 4 percent, to $9.38 yesterday, while Quantum jumped 38 percent, to $13.25. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about the performances of Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas in their first debate referred imprecisely in some copies to a criticism of the candidates. The observation that they took ''too much time niggling over details'' was a paraphrase of comments by former Mayor Pete Flaherty of Pittsburgh, not a quotation.

title: Building Malls And Selling Art
description: A. Alfred Taubman . . . a shopping mall magnate who never finished college . . . born Jan. 31, 1925 in Pontiac, Mich. . . . transformed strip malls into upscale shopping centers . . . in 1971, opened the nation's biggest mall in Schaumberg, Ill. . . . rescued a bloated Sotheby's from corporate raiders in 1983 and turned it into a retail center for art . . . axiom: selling art is not too different from selling root beer . . . infused Sotheby's with 80's glamour, has homes in Palm Beach and Southampton . . . resigned as chairman on Feb. 21, 2000, after Christie's, Sotheby's rival, announced it was cooperating with a criminal antitrust investigation . . . still the controlling shareholder of the auction house.

title: Bush vs. Gore, Round 1: Now the People Debate; Expertise Preferred
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; One Analyst's Grim Telecommunications View
description: The stock prices of networking equipment companies like Cisco Systems and Nortel Networks sometimes seem as if they are priced for perpetual success. But shares of the phone companies that buy that equipment have spelled failure so far this year. Now, one analyst is warning investors in the equipment makers that this difference may not last much longer.

title: Lazio and Mrs. Clinton Put Schools at the Forefront
description: With New Yorkers citing education as a critical concern -- and with some voters still undecided in the Senate race -- Representative Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton are spending a lot of time in classrooms as Election Day approaches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, BRITA DIGBY.
description: FRIED-Brita Digby. Age 88, died peacefully on October 1 at her home in East Hampton, following a series of strokes over the past few years. She is survived by her husband, Walter J. Fried, her daughters Allison Blinken and Ingrid (Mimi) Einstein and her grandchildren Anna Lonergan, Ingrid Blinken and Nicholas, Elizabeth and Abigail Einstein. In accordance with her wishes, there will be no funeral service. FRIED-Brita D. The law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson offers its deepest condolences to esteemed retired partner Walter J. Fried on the loss of his beloved wife, Brita. We extend our sympathy as well to her daughters and her grandchildren on their great loss.

title: Jets' Game Plan Against Steelers Requires Double Effort
description: The Jets may not know which half of Pittburgh's two-headed quarterback they will face until game time on Sunday. But does it matter?

title: Shapes in Plaster for Just the Right Touch
description: Anne Severine Liotard made her mark on decorating in 1994 with her Brancusi-inspired collection of multiwick wax candles, with their zigzagging columns and oversize circular or oval shapes. (Those sparked a candle mania, repercussions of which we still see in stores today.) What next? Ms. Liotard, a former fashion magazine editor, found the answer in smooth, sensual plaster forms in which art meets decoration. ''Plaster is volatile and ethereal, yet feminine and soft,'' she said. ''I love its whiteness.'' A fine sandpaper will rub out finger prints from hands that could not resist touching. From $1,150 to $1,800 at Galerie Joelle Mortier Valat, 13 rue des St. Peres; telephone, 011-33.1.42.60.28.30; fax, 011-33.1.42.60.28.16.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Bush vs. Gore, Round 1: Now the People Debate; So Who Won?
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Company Buys Distributor
description: The Biovail Corporation, a Canadian maker of generic drugs, agreed to buy a closely held distributor, DJ Pharma Inc., for $162.5 million.

title: Microsoft Says Government Is Trying to Curtail Its Court Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5  The Microsoft Corporation shot back at the Justice Department today, saying in an Appeals Court filing that the government wanted to curtail the company's right of appeal of the antitrust ruling against it.

title: Vodafone in $2.5 Billion Deal With Chinese Mobile Concern
description: In a case of the big getting help from the bigger, Vodafone AirTouch said today that it would invest $2.5 billion and strike an alliance with China's largest wireless phone company, China Mobile Hong Kong Ltd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, WILLIAM
description: GOLDSTEIN-William. On October 4, 2000. Loving husband to the late Ida. Devoted father of Paula (Shimon), Alan (Karen), Resa (David). Cherished grandfather and greatgrandfather. Services will be held today, 1 PM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAKSIMA, DOROTHY
description: PAKSIMA-Dorothy. On October 4, 2000 of Fort Salonga, N.Y. Beloved wife of Ali. Loving mother of Jamila, Suzanne and Ali David. Cherished grandmother of Alexandra and Daria Schwab. Dear daughter of Rachel. Fond sister of Nancy, Thomas, Lois and John Vitale. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th St., Garden City 2-4 & 7-9PM Friday. Religious service at The Garden City Community Church 1:30 PM Saturday. Interment Roslyn Cemetery. Donations to the American Diabetes Associated appreciated.

title: Altered Lineup A Change For Better
description: On his way to lunch today, Yankee Manager Joe Torre met up with Don Zimmer, his bench coach, and Torre showed Zimmer an altered lineup he was considering for Game 2. As Torre pulled out a slip of paper, Zimmer produced a few suggestions he had jotted down.

title: Furniture With Dual Personalities
description: GOOD-LOOKING and multitalented. Sleek, with a sense of humor.'' If a stool, table or chair could write a personal ad, that's what these pieces would say. They are space-savers that can do double duty, making a small place more comfortable and fun. But generally speaking, this will not be a cheap date.

title: The Bickering Over, A Soccer Game Is On
description: After 10 days of bickering among officials of the Connecticut Junior Soccer Association and the two team coaches, it appears the 10-year-old boys of the Avon Soccer Club will play Fairfield United after all.

title: Protesters Rally in Belgrade to Oust Milosevic
description: BELGRADE, Oct. 5 -- Yugoslavia's political crisis came to a head on Thursday when the Constitutional Court ruled that the disputed presidential election should be held again and police used tear gas on protesters at the parliament building.

title: Belgrade Court Annuls Vote That Was Milosevic Setback
description: In a decision that seems designed to buy time for President Slobodan Milosevic, Yugoslavia's highest court tonight annulled parts of the Sept. 24 presidential elections, according to the official news agency, Tanjug.

title: Gore Defends Civilian Uses of Military
description: Vice President Al Gore today intensified a foreign policy argument with George W. Bush that began during their debate on Tuesday, arguing that his vision of using the American military to build new democracies after peace is won has its roots in the Marshall Plan that rebuilt Western Europe after World War II.

title: Bush vs. Gore, Round 1: Now the People Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Franks's Cash-Short Campaign Finally Puts Its First Ad on TV
description: Trailing in the polls and struggling to raise money, Representative Bob Franks, the Republican candidate for United States Senate, began running his first television commercial today after a month in which his wealthy Democratic rival, Jon S. Corzine, had the medium all to himself.

title: The Reality Of War, Traffic Jams And All
description: Twenty-seven years ago tomorrow, Egypt and Syria launched a surprise attack against Israel. The brief, intense war that followed -- called the Yom Kippur War, after the Jewish holiday on which the fighting started -- is the subject of Amos Gitai's new film, ''Kippur,'' which will be shown tonight at the New York Film Festival. The battlefield action in the film is bloody and relentless; Mr. Gitai is working in the close-to-the-ground, hyper-realist mode of Sam Fuller's ''Big Red One'' and the opening battle sequences of Steven Spielberg's ''Saving Private Ryan.'' War, according to this style of filmmaking, is an existential rather than a political event. The causes -- and even, in this case, the outcome -- of the conflict matter less than the experiences of the men who fight.

title: Interior City: Hotel As the New Cosmopolis
description: DESIGN euphoria finally has a New York home. Ian Schrager's new hotel, the Hudson, contains a thousand guest rooms, a suite of public rooms and an outdoor garden, but the main attraction is the imagination with which Mr. Schrager and Philippe Starck have redesigned the face of the cosmopolitan idea. For the city of strangers, they have proposed an aesthetic of strangeness. It's a match.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Article 2000100591465326849 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CITRIN, SYLVIA LEAH.
description: CITRIN-Sylvia Leah. On Sunday, October 1, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Harry Citrin. Devoted mother of Cynthia Janis and the late Linda Lederman. Loving grandmother of Howard & Lauren Janis and Steven and Kenneth Lederman. Great-grandmother of Abby Louise Janis. Graveside service was held on Wednesday, October 4 at 1:00PM at New Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N.J. Expressions of sympathy in her memory may be made to American Cancer Society &/or American Heart Association. Danzansky Goldberg Memorial Chapel, phone 301-340-1400

title: Just as They Did in '99, Mets Send a Signal
description: A year ago a year ago today, to be precise -- Edgardo Alfonzo slugged a two-out grand slam in the ninth inning of a tied postseason opener, catapulting the Mets to a stunning 8-4 victory in the Arizona Diamondbacks' ballpark and igniting a scintillating playoff run that would be derailed two victories short of the World Series.

title: Yanks End Drought; Mets Fall in Opener
description: On one side of the bay, the Yankees finally got back on track with a 4-0 victory in Oakland to even their playoff series, 1-1. On the other side, the Mets never got untracked and lost their opener in San Francisco, 5-1.

title: TELEFONICA SEEKS MEXICO WIRELESS BUSINESS
description: Spain's telephone company, Telefonica S.A., is in talks to purchase Motorola's stake in several Mexican mobile phone companies. It would be Telefonica's first move into Mexico. Telefonica said a subsidiary, Telefonica Moviles, would acquire the Motorola shares and that a final agreement was expected within the next two weeks. No price for the shares was disclosed by Telefonica, but Spanish media reports said that the purchase would be worth about $2.6 billion and the companies involved were Movitel, Portatel, Cedetel, Baja Celular and Norcel. The transaction would be the first since Cesar Alierta, above, took over as chairman and Fernando Abril-Martorell as chief executive after Juan Villalonga resigned in July. The deal would give Telefonica Moviles about 1.3 million new cell phone customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNKIN, SOL R
description: DUNKIN-Sol R. Retired Justice of the New York State Supreme Court. Beloved husband of Leonore. Loving father of Amy and Ellen. Father-in-law of Lawrence Kraftowitz and Joseph Michaeli. Devoted grandfather of Ari, BJ, Noah, Eli and Jonah. Services Thursday 1 PM, at Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard & 76 Road, Forest Hills. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Parkinsons Disease Foundation, 650 West 168 St, New York, New York 10032.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALISCH, JACK
description: SALISCH-Jack. Son of the late David and Ethel. Predeceased by sister Audrey. Survived by a niece, a nephew and several cousins. 82 year resident of Kew Gardens, N.Y. A sweet and gentle man. Graveside service at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, October 5, 1PM. Family will gather at Schwartz Bros. Forest Park Chapel, 12:30PM prior to the service.

title: Sports of The Times; The Trade Never Made Still Golden
description: IT was right at the trading deadline, at the end of July of last year, and the news had leaked. The Yankees were about to deal one of their top pitchers. Andy Pettitte, who had been struggling, was about to change uniforms, swapping the Bronx Bomber pinstripes for the Phillies' candy stripes.

title: Pilgrims Have Landed On World Wide Web
description: The Web site of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania (www.sail1620.org) offers a look at the 102 English colonists who landed in Massachusetts in 1620. The site features the text of the Mayflower Compact, pages for children, information about the Pilgrims and links to other Mayflower societies. There are also biographies of famous Mayflower descendants like Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, Grandma Moses, Humphrey Bogart and a number of presidents. SHELLY FREIERMAN

title: Moving Heaven With Earth
description: DAN KILEY trudged slowly up the hill and across the green meadow. ''We just cut the hay,'' he said. ''It was this high.'' His hand floated just above his hip. ''Of course, it's a lot of work. Next year, I'm going to mow a path close to the woods, and just let the rest go.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDSON, WILLIAM J.
description: RICHARDSON-William J. The members of the Reveille Club of NY mourn the loss of our beloved member. Bill was a devoted member, loving husband and father. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Gertrude and family. Livingston S. Francis, President The Reveille Club of NY

title: Lieberman and Cheney Meet in Debate
description: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

title: Oedipus Wrecks
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Courtly Discussion
description: In an encounter characterized by polite, almost amiable disagreements, Senator Joseph Lieberman and former Defense Secretary Dick Cheney defended the men at the top of their tickets, while carefully avoiding the personal attacks of the presidential debate earlier this week. In substance, the candidates echoed the disagreements of Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush, but with a muted tone that seemed aimed at reassuring the public about their respective commitments to civility. Mr. Lieberman sounded almost sorrowful in criticizing the Republican tax cut proposal, while Mr. Cheney hammered calmly at the vice president's alleged love of big government. Although almost refreshingly low key, the debate seemed unlikely to have an immediate impact on the polls.

title: A Mideast Peace, Derailed Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Trump and Others Accept Fines For Ads in Opposition to Casinos
description: Donald J. Trump and his associates have agreed to pay $250,000 in fines and to issue a public apology because they failed to disclose to the state lobbying commission that he had secretly financed newspaper advertisements opposing casino gambling in the Catskills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAPENA, HARVEY V.
description: DELAPENA-Harvey V. Husband of Joanne (Young). Father of Stephen & Bradford Delapena & Susan Cava. Also survived by 3 grandchildren & a sister Mimi Turner. Visiting hours Sunday 2-5 pm in John-Lawrence Funeral Home, Marstons Mills, MA. Memorials in his name to C-O-MM Rescue Squad, 1875 Falmouth Rd., Centerville, MA 02632.

title: Panel Approves Bill On Auto-Safety Issue
description: A bill that would give government auto-safety regulators more power to get information about defective products was approved 42 to 0 by a Congressional committee. The full House will vote on the bill as early as next week.

title: MetroStars Seeking a Repeat Performance
description: The MetroStars have a simple formula for success going into the third and deciding game of their second-round Major League Soccer playoff matchup against the Chicago Fire tonight: repeat their performance from their last game when they played the best game in their five-year history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTNER, JANE ELLEN ON OCTOBER 5, 2000
description: ORTNER-Jane Ellen on October 5, 2000. Beloved wife of Charles. Loving mother of Amy and Eric. Devoted sister of Ann and Dr. Michael Rosen and Dr. Jeffrey and Margo Gold. Cherished daughter of the late Dr. Theodore and Belle Gold. Proud aunt of Dana, Barrie, Seth, Alexander and Julia. Jane was a dedicated, passionate and inspiring teacher and friend. Service Friday 1pm, Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd, Scarsdale. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Jane Ortner Multiple Myeloma Research Fellowship, c/o Clyde B. Jones III at Weill Medical College of Cornell University, 525 E. 68 St, Box 123, NYC 10021.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend last Friday about ''Remember the Titans'' misattributed a line of dialogue spoken by a member of the Titans football team at a high school in Virginia. It is Cook (played by David Jefferson Jr.), not Petey (played by Donald Faison), who says, ''There's too much male bonding going on here.''

title: Barak and Arafat Order Their Forces to Pull Back
description: Deadly clashes in Israel and the Palestinian territories slowed but did not stop today, even as the Palestinian and Israeli leaders issued orders to curb the violence and both sides continued talks on how to end the rioting that has spilled over the region for a week.

title: Alcoa Expects Weaker Demand
description: Alcoa Inc., the world's biggest aluminum maker, posted a 42 percent increase in third-quarter profit today but said that it expected fourth-quarter results to be hurt by higher energy costs and weaker demand from the transportation and construction industries.

title: Hurricane Fades as It Hits Mexico's Gulf Coast
description: A hurricane that has lashed four nations for a week struck Mexico's gulf coast with 90-mile-an-hour winds today, after killing at least a dozen people, driving tens of thousands from their homes and causing close to a quarter of a billion dollars in damage, the National Hurricane Center in Miami said.

title: In Something of a Surprise, Europeans Raise Rates Early
description: Treading a thin line between the risks of higher inflation and stifled growth, the European Central Bank made a surprise decision today to increase interest rates, reflecting its concern over rising prices caused by the weak euro and expensive oil.

title: Gore and Bush Make Their Pitches to Parents
description: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush both courted parents and swing voters in battleground states of the Midwest today.

title: Curbs Sought On Abusive Tax Shelters
description: Leaders of the Senate Finance Committee proposed tough new laws yesterday to crack down on abusive corporate tax shelters and to impose hefty penalties on those who promote sham transactions to evade taxes.

title: Sojo Gives Yanks Boost With Bat, and His Feet
description: The slump that started in September hung on the Yankees like an anvil, threatening to pull them over the precipice that exists in every playoff. But they got a toe-hold and dug in and won Game 2 of the division series against Oakland on Wednesday, and now that they are stabilized, the Yankees are in a much better frame of mind to attempt that long climb to a third straight World Series championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUERRERO, ROXANE P.
description: GUERRERO-Roxane P. was the youngest of four, after Elisabeth, Margaret, and William. Daughter of William W. Pollock, politically liberal appraiser/journalist, and college educated free thinking, Elisabeth Philbrook Pollock, Roxane began a fifty year journalism career at the Evening Public Ledger, and the Philadelphia Record. During World War II Roxane was in the South Pacific and Europe with the Red Cross. She wrote for ''Overseas Woman'' and covered the Nuremberg Trials. Roxane met Spanish painter Jose Guerrero in Rome, whom she married in Paris, 1949. They spent the next forty-two years together in New York, he was at the forefront of the Abstract Expressionist Movement; she, at Life Magazine. In Spain, they were deeply involved in the post Franco art movement. After Jose's death in 1991, Roxane lived between Barcelona and State College, PA. She is survived by her daughter Lisa (Pep) of Barcelona; son Tony (Deb) of State College, PA; and four grandchildren, Allegra, Lucas, Pilar, and Daniel. She was instrumental in creating ''El Centro de Arte Jose Guerrero'' with the Diputacion de Granada, inauguarated June, 2000. She died peacefully with her children on October 2, 2000. Roxane was loved and appreciated for her curiosity, generosity, loyalty, sense of humor and her love of life. Her family and many dear friends will greatly miss her. A service will be held at the Chapel of the Good Shepherd, General Theological Seminary, 175 9th Avenue on Sunday, October 8 at 3:00 PM.

title: Digitalizing Those Dinos
description: Ten percent of anything isn't much, but when it comes to DVD, the slice grows all out of proportion. Distributors say that the new format, now in about 10 percent of households and spreading fast, is becoming so popular that it has not only started to compete with VHS, it is also helping the videocassette by rekindling interest in all home video.

title: GERMAN UNEMPLOYMENT AT FIVE-YEAR LOW
description: Unemployment in Germany, Europe's largest economy, fell to the lowest level in five years last month, reflecting a surge in exports because of the weakness in the euro, Europe's unified currency. The jobless rate fell to 9.4 percent, the lowest level since July 1995, from 9.5 percent in August, and the number of unemployed fell by 18,000, the 11th decline in 12 months, the federal government said. Christian Baumgaertel (NYT)

title: New Jersey Will Seek Licensing Reforms
description: New Jersey state gaming officials recommended sweeping changes yesterday in the way boxers, managers and promoters are licensed in the state, in the wake of a federal investigation into bribes for boxing rankings and the death last year of a Brooklyn fighter with an unclear medical history.

title: A Mideast Peace, Derailed Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Triple Whammy Hits Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5  Bill Mueller, the Giants' third baseman, has spent a career being overlooked and underappreciated, lacking the power and statistics associated with most players at his position. Heading into spring training, he also faced the prospect of being unemployed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, ROBERT
description: ALLEN-Robert. With profound sorrow, the entire Beth Israel Medical Center family mourns the passing of Robert Allen, beloved husband of our dear friend and long time Beth Israel supporter Patty Allen. Our sympathy is extended to Patty, her family and loved ones. Morton P. Hyman Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew E. Fink, MD President and CEO Anthony C. Cahan, MD Physician-in-Charge Robert and Helen Appel Comprehensive Breast Service

title: Public Interests; Crunching Numbers
description: When Americans look back on this presidential campaign, they may remember it as the moment in which the specter of International Communism was replaced by the horror of ''fuzzy math.''

title: I.N.S. Inspectors Are Judge, Jury and Deporter, Report Says
description: Richard Riley arrived at Kennedy International Airport two years ago a carefree college freshman, just back from a Christmas break visit with his mother in Jamaica. He left the airport 12 hours later shackled, accused of trying to enter the country with falsified documents.

title: A High-Tech Workout for Your Eyeballs
description: ''Cyberworld'' offers 55 minutes of unabashed, and often quite diverting, technological overkill. It combines the skull-rattling, eyeball-straining gigantism of the Imax format with the latest in computer animation: 3-D computer animation. With its vertiginous free falls and swoops, and all manner of creatures popping up right in front of your face, it's as much a theme park thrill ride as a showcase for the latest technical ingenuity.

title: SHARES OF BSB BANCORP FALL AFTER MERGER IS SCRAPPED
description: BSB Bancorp shares fell 23 percent yesterday after NBT Bancorp called off its proposed $251 million purchase of BSB. BSB, based in Binghamton, N.Y., also said it expected a third-quarter loss of about $1.7 million because of a higher loan loss provision and merger expenses of about $2 million. BSB's shares fell $4.97, to $16.25, while NBT's shares rose $1.63, or 14 percent, to $12.88. NBT, based in Norwich, N.Y., called off the acquisition after BSB said it had significantly increased its provisions for loan losses.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Big, beautiful Serbia has risen up just so one man, Slobodan Milosevic, will leave.''

title: Copyright Extension Stifles Creativity, Lawyer Tells Court
description: A lawyer challenging a recent law that extends copyrights told a federal appeals court here today that the extension restricted an artist's First Amendment right to draw on works from other artists, thus stifling creativity and competition.

title: Gore's Name Doesn't Take the Swing Out of Tennessee
description: Since the Civil War, this state, this county and this small northwest Tennessee town have been evenly split between Republicans and Democrats, swinging unpredictably from candidate to candidate. And in the last few weeks, it has become increasingly clear that Vice President Al Gore's presence on the ballot as a native son is not going to change that division much, if at all.

title: BAXTER GAINS APPROVAL TO EXPAND PRODUCTION OF A DRUG
description: Baxter International said yesterday that it had won approval from the Food and Drug Administration to expand production of its blood-clotting drug to treat hemophilia. The treatment, a genetically engineered protein, is produced at Baxter's plant in Thousand Oaks, Calif. The company, based in Deerfield, Ill., said demand for the therapy, known as recombinant Factor VIII, had almost doubled in the last five years. Bruce Cranna, an analyst for ABN Amro, said the expanded production could mean $200 million to $240 million in new annual sales. Baxter's recombinant Factor VIII had 1999 sales of about $450 million, he said. The company is the biggest maker of the drug. Baxter shares rose $5.44, closing at $82.13.

title: A Porous Underbelly In a Gritty Boot Camp
description: In Robert Altman's ''Player,'' a filmmaker played by Richard E. Grant is repeatedly seen pitching a death-row drama called ''Habeas Corpus,'' which he promises will be raw and real, with ''no stars'' and no happy ending. ''Because that's the reality,'' he insists. ''Innocent people die.'' When ''Habeas Corpus'' finally sees the light of day, its ending features Bruce Willis breaking into the gas chamber to save a fainting Julia Roberts, whom he carries to safety through the fumes as the audience cheers.

title: G.O.P. Buys Ad for Lazio, Despite Pact On Financing
description: The opening scene of a new commercial promoting Representative Rick A. Lazio's record displays the standard text saying that it was paid by Mr. Lazio's campaign. Or at least, that is the commercial that the campaign released to reporters.

title: Some Retailers Can Celebrate Monthly Gain
description: After enduring three months of waning consumer interest and rising oil prices that had sent fashion purchasing into a spiral, some of the nation's merchants received a glimmer of good news in September.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, RUDDICK C.
description: LAWRENCE - Ruddick C. Of Bronxville and Shelter Island, NY, on Sept. 30. Beloved husband of Cherry McDonnell Lawrence. Devoted father of Dana Lawrence, Sara Engelhardt, Jean Lawrence, Ruddick Lawrence, Jr., Daniel Lawrence, and the late Megan Lawrence, & stepfather of Leslie Tawfik and Caroline Blydenburgh. Loving grandfather to fourteen grandchildren. Service Saturday, October 7, 10:30 AM, at Christ Church, Bronxville. Donations in lieu of flowers may be sent to Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, New York 10707.

title: A Former Child on the North Shore
description: By 6:15 a.m. my friend Lou and I were stumbling out of the Clark Currier Inn and driving the few miles to Plum Island on the North Shore of Massachusetts. Our headlights cut through the fog as we followed the road along the Merrimack River toward the sea. Plum Island is a natural barrier beach, a nine-mile-long spit of sand, dune grasses, trees and tidal marsh -- and beach plums, hence its name -- that attracts huge numbers of migrating birds in the spring and fall.

description: Fights over the huge federal spending bills often reflect deep ideological divisions or sharp partisan differences. In the case of James R. Lyons, they seem to reflect personal pique.

description: The presidential debate moved some undecided voters in Missouri. Women said they were now leaning toward Al Gore, men toward George W. Bush. Page A26.

Robinson, on October 3, 2000. As Chairman of the Foundation's Investment and Law Committees for many years, he provided dedicated leadership which will be sorely missed. Jodie Z. Bernstein, director of the commission's bureau of consumer protection, said the agency was exploring civil complaints over deceptive or unfair trade practices by game makers or other entertainment companies that market adult content to children. She did not say criminal charges might apply.

title: Mrs. Clinton Says Attending a West Bank Ceremony With Mrs. Arafat Was a Mistake
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton moved to fortify her standing with Jewish voters yesterday, saying that she had made a mistake in attending a ceremony with Suha Arafat on the West Bank, and urging that the administration release classified documents in the case of Jonathan Pollard, the convicted Israeli spy seeking clemency.

description: Directed by David Maquiling

title: Devils, Minus 2 Stars, Hope They Haven't Lost the Magic
description: The Devils will open their National Hockey League season Friday with a great deal of excitement when their Stanley Cup championship banner is raised at Contintental Arena before their game against the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Serbian Opposition Supporters Revel in the Streets of Belgrade
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- As euphoric, all-night street celebrations of Slobodan Milosevic's apparent political demise wound down, Russia on Friday sent its foreign minister on a delicate mission said to include planned talks with the Yugoslav president in his secret hideout.

title: Siemens to Cut 1,800 Jobs
description: Siemens A.G., Germany's biggest electronics company, said today that it would eliminate about 1,800 jobs in two units to increase competitiveness amid concern that rising interest rates might slow economic growth and corporate earnings. About 1,200 jobs, including 550 at home, will be cut in the large-drives division of its Automation and Drives Group. Poor business conditions were blamed Wednesday for 600 job cuts at the Shared Medical Systems Corporation, which it bought this year. The company, whose businesses include factory automation and mobile phones, is shedding jobs amid concern on earnings growth. The European Central Bank raised interest rates again today, an action that may slow demand further.

title: Silva and Kagwe To Run Again
description: With the New York City Marathon just a month away, organizers announced yesterday that two of the race's most storied competitors will give it another try.

title: Four Natural Gas Utilities Seek Emergency Rate Increases
description: Citing sharply higher wholesale costs on the eve of the winter heating season, New Jersey's four natural-gas supply companies are seeking emergency rate increases of 16.7 percent to 31.9 percent.

title: Giuliani Defends Police Against Federal Finding of Racial Profiling
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani angrily defended the New York Police Department yesterday against a federal finding of racial profiling, saying a Justice Department investigation into police tactics was politically motivated and based on flawed analysis of stop-and-search statistics.

description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Bethlehem, Pa.; Wilmington, Del., and Baltimore

title: Generations Gifted in The Blarney
description: Benjamin Madigan, the sitcom character played by the Irish actor Gabriel Byrne, is that rare commodity: a handsome man who is oblivious to his own good looks. ''You have a gift and you're wasting it,'' says a colleague with disgust, when Madigan ignores an attractive women who is ogling him.

title: In Civil Clash, Cheney and Lieberman Reinforce Tickets' Sharp Differences
description: With a studied civility, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman and Dick Cheney spelled out their tickets' differences on taxation and foreign policy last night in a vice-presidential debate that more resembled an academic seminar than the political warfare typically expected when understudies cross swords.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADDEN, DANIEL MICHAEL
description: MADDEN-Daniel Michael. A retired Lieutenant, U.S. Navy, died September 15, 2000 in his Phoenix, Arizona residence. The son of the late Thomas P. Madden and Anna Hanlon Madden was predeceased also by his wife, Huan Wilson Madden. He is survived by his sister, Rose Mary Noonan and niece, Maureen E. Noonan, of Southport, nephews Brian of New Haven; Thomas of Stratford and nieces Dr. Patricia Walsh of Dublin, Kathleen Charlton, R.N. and Mary Meunier of San Francisco; 11 grandnieces and nephews and one great - grandnephew, Matthew Thomas Fischetti of New York; also a cousin, Catherine Hanlon Knapp of Sandy Hook and several cousins in Derry, Ireland. He had been a reporter for the Yorkville Advance and a writer from Europe for American editors and publishers primarily in Catholic Digest, Columbia, and travel articles in The New York Times some accompanied by his photographs; also America, Saturday Review and Sign. He was the author of several books. Funeral will be at the convenience of the family in Phoenix, handled by GreerWilson Funeral Home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLOUSIS, LOU
description: GALLOUSIS-Lou. The Faculty and Staff of Mt. Sinai School of Medicine and The Mt. Sinai Hospital of Mt. Sinai NYU Health are profoundly saddened by the sudden passing of Lou Gallousis, Founder and President of the Louis Green, Evelyn Green Davis Childcare Center which serves the children of Mt. Sinai employees. ''Papa Lou'' as he was fondly called, joined the Mt. Sinai family as President of Innovative Learning Centers, Inc.-a childcare project in 1984. Opening in 1989 with less than 20 children, the Center now provides quality care for a capacity of 90 children. Thru his 20 year career in hospital personnel services, Lou recognized the increasing need for childcare. His company proudly provides a nurturing environment at 10 early childhood centers in the tri-state area. A caring, generous man who led by example, Lou will be sorely missed. We extend our sympathy to his wife, Virginia, and his children Christopher and Dina. Helene L. Kaplan, Chair, Mt. Sinai School of Medicine Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean Mt. Sinai School of Medicine Barry R. Freedman, President, The Mt. Sinai Hospital and Acting President, Mt. Sinai NYU Health

title: HUGHES ADDS 450,000 DIRECTV CUSTOMERS
description: The Hughes Electronics Corporation said that its DirecTV satellite-television unit signed up 450,000 customers in the third quarter, 6.3 percent more than it added a year earlier. DirecTV, the No. 1 U.S. satellite TV provider, has nine million customers. Hughes expects third-quarter revenue of $1.65 billion to $1.7 billion, a company statement said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEEVE, HARRY, AGE 84, ON OCTOBER 3
description: SEEVE-Harry, age 84, on October 3. Beloved husband of the late Zelda and devoted father of Marsha Rolston and Leonard Seeve and the late William Seeve. Brother of Moses Seeve and grandfather of Michael, David, Eric, Matthew, Brian and Sean. He was a fund raiser for the UJA and founder of Seeve Enterprises, a New York based real estate firm. Services will be held on Friday, October 6, at 10am at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 76th St & Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Fire Kills 2 Children and Injures 4 Other People
description: Two children were killed and four other people were injured yesterday morning when a fire tore through a two-story duplex in Brooklyn, fire officials and witnesses said.

title: Sometimes, the Best Ideas Are Copied From Others
description: Considering that the Yankees have won the last two World Series and three of the last four, the Mets could pick a worse example to copy. So copy the Yankees the Mets did last night. Up to a point, that is. The plan broke down somewhere in the ninth inning, and from then on, they had to improvise.

title: WORLD BUSINESS: A Local Liquor Catches On; But Export Outside Brazil Has Been Fragmented
description: When Frederico Spezia was a child, the men of Luis Alves traveled 20 miles over unpaved roads to buy the liquor that would warm their bellies at night. Necessity soon bred invention, though, and the first bootleg stills started dotting the secluded valley in the 1940's and 50's, brewing up a traditional liquor called cachaca (ka-SHA-sa).

title: National News Briefs
description: Drugmaker Recalls Arthritis Medication

title: Irish Agency Knew of Risks In Blood Sales, Tribunal Says
description: An official inquiry into the infection of more than 200 Irish hemophiliacs with H.I.V. and hepatitis C has confirmed that the government's Blood Transfusion Service Board knowingly put them at risk throughout the early 1980's.

title: Murdoch Puts Son in News Corp.'s No. 3 Slot
description: The News Corporation said yesterday that Lachlan Murdoch, the oldest son of the company's chairman, Rupert Murdoch, had been named deputy chief operating officer, the No. 3 position at the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUTKA, LEONARD M.
description: DUTKA-Leonard M. Of Pound Ridge, N.Y. and Carlsbad, Calif. Died on October 4. Retired President of Dynarex Corp and former President of IPCO Hospital Supply. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Devoted father of Elaine, Mark and Richard. Loving father-in-law of Irene. Doting grandfather of Annie B. and Zoe C. Brother of Seymour and Robert. Fighting against insurmountable odds in his battle with Lou Gehrig's Disease, he displayed the courage, selflessness and dignity that typified his entire life. A devout humanist, family man, proponent of social justice, our ''Rock'' and inspiration, he will be sorely missed. Contributions to the ALS Association 818-880-9007 or the Rick Dutka Memorial Fund c/o the Tides Foundation 415561-6400. Services on Sunday at 10:30AM at the Jewish Family Congregation, South Salem, N.Y. 914-763-3028. Interment immediately following at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, N.Y.

title: Putin Joins India in Vow On How to Use Atomic Plants
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia today took a high-profile tour of India's leading nuclear research center, where reactors and bombs are designed, and promised to work with India in developing peaceful uses for atomic energy while encouraging India to sign the nuclear nonproliferation and test ban treaties.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Addicted to Drugs and Drug Rituals
description: In ''Requiem for a Dream,'' the director Darren Aronofsky's adaptation of Hubert Selby Jr.'s lower-depths novel, Jared Leto has lost so much weight he looks like another person altogether. As the junkie Harry, a wasted pretty boy, he seems kept aloft by his eyelashes, the only substantial thing on his frame. Superficially, it might be easy to confuse the protagonists of '''Requiem'' with the models in a Calvin Klein Jeans ad of a few years ago. But make no mistake: there is plenty of meat on its bones.

title: Workfare Exemption For Students Who Intern
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has signed legislation that will allow workfare exemptions for college students on welfare if they are involved in internships or work-study programs.

description: And the winning bid for 15 original light fixtures from Grand Central Terminal offered on eBay? A search warrant.

title: IVAX SUIT ACCUSES 2 COMPANIES OF BLOCKING COMPETITION
description: The Ivax Corporation said it sued Bristol-Myers Squibb and American BioScience, accusing them of illegally blocking generic competition to Bristol-Myers' cancer treatment Taxol. The suit opens a new front in the legal battle over Ivax's effort to bring a generic version of Taxol to the market. The companies are already tangled in litigation in federal courts in Washington, New York and California. Ivax, based in Miami, said the suit it filed in a Florida state court asserts that Bristol-Myers and American BioScience are violating the state's antitrust and unfair trade practices laws and have committed fraud.

title: All in the Family, Creatively
description: Live music helped add vitality to ''Autumn Engravings,'' the program Cherniak Dance presented on Sunday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio.

George W. Bush of Texas. As written, the article said the confrontation took on greater significance because the contest was ''disturbingly close for both candidates.''

title: French Political Class Smothers Yet Another Scandal
description: PARIS  Last week, the republic was described as in danger, and French political life as stained dark with discredit. Sounding aghast, Philippe Seguin, the Gaullist candidate for mayor of Paris, insisted that France looked "like a banana republic."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIERFASS, SARAH
description: BIERFASS-Sarah. Beloved mother of Martin Biers, mother-in-law of Elizabeth Biers & grandmother of Eric, Carl and John Biers and grandmother-in-law of Carolyn & Nina. Passed away Oct. 5. Funeral service at Hebrew Institute of White Plains, 10:30AM, October 6. In lieu of flowers, contribution to your favorite charity.
