title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILLS, NATHANIEL L., 93 YEARS.
description: SILLS-Nathaniel L., 93 years. Devoted husband of the late Ruth, father of Larry and Susan, Arthur and Sarah, Peter and Susan, grandfather of Deborah and Adam, Eric and Leah, Matthew, Dylan, Daniel and Noah, greatgrandfather of Jacob, Eli & Laila. He was Chairman of the Board of Standard Motor Products but his main passion was his family. He had a profound influence on all of us. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Forest Hills. title: 'Luminarias'
description: Directed by Jose Luis Valenzuela

title: One Judge's Opinion: Delete Should Mean Delete
description: The geniuses who designed the modern world's computers probably thought they were doing mankind a favor when they decided that nothing, in fact, would ever be deleted when a computer user presses the Delete button. At least one prominent jurist, however, thinks Delete should mean just that.

title: The Big City; After Ocean Trip, Leif's Descendant Says Vikings Were Here
description: THE year is 1008. Now that you've braved the Atlantic Ocean to reach a new continent and fathered the first European child on those shores, what are you going to do?

title: 'Year One,' a Conceit for the Millennium
description: Until now the prospect of the 21st century and third millennium had not evoked much comment at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Whitney Museum of American Art and the Museum of Modern Art have gone all out, with two- and three-part exhibitions of the last 100 years or so of modern art. In its own all-museum effort, ''1900: Art at the Crossroads,'' the Guggenheim looked back to the preceding fin de siecle, showing a cross section of academic and advanced art of that moment.

title: How He Found America
description: JANUSZ KAMINSKI can close his eyes and conjure up the picture of a teenager sitting in the hushed hours after midnight in the living room of a small apartment in Wroclaw, Poland. A television set is on, bathing both the room and the boy in a flickering glow. The young man, of course, is himself. He must have been about 16 at the time, he thinks, though he's not really sure. Certainly it is sometime in the late 1970's, when the Communist world was approaching twilight, not that anyone knew it.

title: Convict Costume Leads to Warnings
description: Trick-or-treating is still weeks away, but a realistic-looking prison costume has already tricked the New Jersey Department of Corrections and prompted the store chain selling the outfit to issue a warning to those who buy it.

title: Defendant's Diary Is Admitted as Evidence in Lockerbie Trial
description: Conceding that a defendant's 1988 desk diary had probably been illegally seized, judges in the Lockerbie trial still allowed it to be entered as evidence today.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page TK.

title: DE BEERS SWEETENS ASHTON BID
description: The seesaw struggle for Ashton Mining of Australia was extended as De Beers raised its offer by 45 percent, trumping a bid by its rival, Rio Tinto. De Beers offered 2.28 Australian dollars, about $1.23, a share, for a total of $400 million. Rio Tinto had offered 1.85 Australian dollars. De Beers, the world's largest miner and marketer of diamonds, covets Ashton, which holds a 40 percent stake in the Argyle mine in Australia. Argyle, which yields the low-quality stones used for cutting and grinding, is the largest deposit of diamonds in the world. Rio Tinto holds the remaining 60 percent of Argyle. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Burstyn Past And Present
description: Two Ellen Burstyns can be seen on New York screens this week. There is the 1973 Ellen Burstyn, starring in ''The Exorcist: The Version You've Never Seen,'' a reissue of the horror classic with scenes restored by the film's screenwriter, William Peter Blatty. And then there is the Ellen Burstyn of 2000, starring in a different kind of horror movie: ''Requiem for a Dream,'' a tough-minded independent film about a Brighton Beach boy (Jared Leto) and his house-bound mother (Ms. Burstyn), who become involved with drugs in different but equally dangerous ways (review, Page 27).

title: Gaborone Journal; Africa Rejoices as a Wandering Soul Finds Rest
description: To stuff and exhibit a dead human, one taxidermist advised in a practical guide published in the 1830's, ''it is necessary to make a circular incision around the fingertips and peel back the skin as if it were a glove.''

title: Sports of The Times; Leiter Keeps Composure To Set Tone
description: LAST Sunday, Manager Bobby Valentine announced that Mike Hampton, and not Al Leiter, would be his starting pitcher when the Mets opened their division series against the Giants on Wednesday. They had similar strong records for the Mets over the course of the season, but Leiter had pitched in league championship and World Series games before. Hampton did not have that experience. Shouldn't Leiter be the guy to start the series, to get the Mets off on the right track to withstand the pressure?

title: Private Horror Made Public
description: The smothering sense of solitariness gets to you from the very beginning, that feeling of being helplessly on your own within a crowd. There he stands, the leader of a nation, so confident, so brisk, so firm of purpose as he speaks to his supplicating subjects. And also, clearly, so very very alone. The saddest part is that he doesn't even seem to know how alone he is. He will before the evening is over, of course. His name is Oedipus.

title: OPENTV ASSERTS 'ONE-CLICK' SHOPPING CLAIM
description: An interactive media systems company, OpenTV, has filed a claim to broaden one of its patents to include ''one-click'' shopping and set-top storage of personal data, which the company says may supersede the patent that Amazon.com is trying to assert against Barnesandnoble.com. OpenTV asked the federal Patent and Trademark Office to expand the scope of its original patent to include the TV commerce technology. OpenTV said because of the early filing date of its original patent, and the publication of the European equivalent patent application, ''Amazon could be precluded from using its patents against'' anyone else using the technology. Amazon.com has filed suit against Barnesandnoble.com, saying that its one-click ordering system infringed on a patent it was awarded in September. ''One-click'' systems store users' billing and shipping information so they do not have to be re-entered on each visit.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the number of people who watched the televised debate on Tuesday between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas referred incorrectly in some copies to Ronald Reagan's opponent in 1980, when the largest audience for a presidential debate was recorded. He was Jimmy Carter; Walter F. Mondale ran for vice president that year, and for president four years later.

title: Benjamin Orr, 53, Rock Musician Who Was a Founder of the Cars
description: Benjamin Orr, a bassist, vocalist and founding member of the rock group the Cars, died on Tuesday in his home in Atlanta. He was 53.

title: Michael Smith, 68; Won Chemistry Nobel
description: Michael Smith, who shared the 1993 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing one of the basic tools of genetic engineering, died on Wednesday at Vancouver General Hospital in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 68.

title: Jets' Focus Is to Stop Bettis's Forward Roll
description: Jerome Bettis, tagged the Bus because of his build, rolls into the Jets' consciousness this week, but the team will try to put the brakes on him without its most important roadblock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELDZAELER, HORTENSE
description: GELDZAELER-Hortense. Of Toronto, Canada, on October 4, 2000 in her 103rd year. Beloved mother of Emily L. Grant (Eugene) of Mamaroneck, NY, Alfreda Henry, and the late Phyllis Weisfeld of Toronto; devoted grandmother of Barbi Weisfeld, David Weisfeld, Robert Henry and Carol Henry of Toronto; Terry Grant of Charlottesville, VA, Andrea Grant and Carolyn Grant of Boulder, CO; and doting great-grandmother of Jordana, Andrew and Alexis Clarfield, Lesley and Brett Henry, and Jamie Weisfeld of Toronto; and Samantha Grant Pardee and Jordan Grant-Krenz of Boulder, CO. Born in NYC in 1897, she became an accomplished pianist and singer, working with music publishers in Tin Pan Alley. In WW I, she served with a USO troupe entertaining Canadian and American troops departing for overseas, and met a young Canadian officer, the love of her life, the late Bernard Geldzaeler of Toronto, Canada, whom she married on his return from Europe. An effervescent personality and a superb entertainer, Hortense was an active leader at Holy Blossom Temple, Toronto, for many years. She was an elegant and charming presence throughout her life and brought untold happiness to all who knew her. Funeral services at Holy Blossom Temple, Toronto, Canada will be held at 10:30am on Friday, October 6th. Eugene and Emily Grant

title: Serbia's Reluctant Revolutionary Calmly Looks Beyond the Chaos
description: Vojislav Kostunica had just made a rousing speech from the balcony of City Hall to several hundred thousand roaring supporters, who had just made him a revolution, and as he slouched in a leather chair, as aides and politicians rushed about, he had trouble believing that it was really his own life that was being transformed.

title: Of Family Names, Lucky Breaks and Politics
description: REBECCA LIEBERMAN, the famous man's daughter and the newest $75,000-a-year employee at the New York City Board of Education, had been thinking about doing a book about fathers and daughters. This is the kind of concept that could become a best-seller when you're the eldest daughter of the first Jewish candidate for vice president from a major party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, CLAIRE
description: RAND-Claire. Continually devoted mother of Larry and Debbie, Carol Rand and Bob McCluskie, and Mitchel and Dr. Laura. Loving grandmother of Benjamin, Jeremy and Kyle. Cherished sister of Dr. Richard and Lila Nachtigall, adored aunt and great-aunt and loyal friend. She will be sorely missed. Funeral Friday, October 6, at 10 AM, Weinstein Memorial, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Foundation for Women's Wellness, 251 East 33 St, NYC 10016.

title: Strong Earthquake Hits Western Japan
description: TOKYO, Oct 6 - A strong earthquake with a magnitude of 7.1 on the open-ended Richter scale rocked broad areas of western Japan on Friday, the country's biggest since the deadly Kobe earthquake in 1995, the Meteorological Agency said.

title: Residential Real Estate; Home Building Project in Brooklyn, Halted Since 1984, Is Being Revived
description: For more than a decade, 11 shuttered and abandoned buildings have stood among the neat single-family homes on Dean Street in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. And behind them along Bergen Street and Underhill Avenue a blanket of too-tall grass hides crumbling foundations of houses once begun but never completed.

title: Harris Drury Cohen Shifting Executives
description: Harris Drury Cohen in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is reorganizing top management.

title: Louise Fishman
description: Cheim & Read

title: Article 2000100690797892968 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Putin Meets Aides, but Takes No Stand
description: Striking a cautious tone, President Vladimir V. Putin has refused to take a position on the leadership struggle in Yugoslavia.

title: Article 2000100693297666622 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Retracing a Poet's Journey to Despair
description: Julian Schnabel's film ''Before Night Falls'' belongs to what might be called the life-is-but-a-dream school of biographical cinema in the way it hovers ethereally over its subject and conjures up fragments of his consciousness in brilliant, disconnected flashes. Adapted from a memoir by the exiled Cuban poet and novelist Reinaldo Arenas, this haunting film portrays that homosexual dissident writer as a desperate unfulfilled searcher for a lost heaven on earth that he experiences only briefly as a very young man. No sooner has he tasted the ecstasies of this pagan paradise than it is snatched away by the punishing, gray-faced Communist revolution.

title: Album of the Week
description: TOM TOM CLUB: "The Good, the Bad and the Funky" (Rykodisc). The female bass player is a fixture in countless punk and indie bands. But the stereotypical role owes its existence to real pioneers, especially Tina Weymouth of the Talking Heads and the Tom Tom Club.

title: Promoting the Madame Tussaud's in Times Square.
description: THE longtime appeal of wax museums has been in the resemblance between famous people and their life-size replicas. But a campaign to promote the first New York outpost for the Madame Tussaud's wax museum eschews the familiar faces for objects from slippers to spectacles.

title: Tendency to Embellish Fact Snags Gore
description: For years, his political opponents have groused that Vice President Al Gore has trouble with facts. They pounced on statements he made about his service in Vietnam, about his record in Congress and even about the price he has to pay for his dog's arthritis medicine.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Armani Hammers Chaos Into Order in Final Touches on His Fashion Palace
description: Workers erected a perimeter fence of fresh-cut oak branches along the Via Manzoni, Milan's main shopping street, preparing for Wednesday's party celebrating the opening of Giorgio Armani's long-awaited new flagship store. Mr. Armani himself stood on the sidewalk at 10 a.m., tearing apart a window display.

title: Business Briefs
description: Burberry Planning A Retail Expansion

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest yesterday about Dell Computer's announcement that its sales growth could slow in the third quarter misstated its projection. Dell predicted a revenue increase to about $8.2 billion -- 3 percent below estimates -- not a decrease of $8.2 billion.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE HOUSE

title: South Korea's Central Bank Increases Key Interest Rate
description: Alarmed by four consecutive months of rising inflation, South Korea's central bank raised interest rates today, breaking with a government policy of keeping the cost of borrowing low to help troubled businesses reduce their debts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Metro Briefing column yesterday about the robbery of $100,000 from an armored truck at the main post office in Montclair, N.J., misstated the number of people shot in a 1995 robbery at a nearby postal annex. It was five, not four.

title: Engineers Work on Glitch as Cassini Snaps Picture of Jupiter
description: PASADENA, Calif. -- NASA's Cassini spacecraft, en route to a 2004 rendezvous with Saturn, snapped its first image of the giant planet Jupiter as engineers worked to understand a communications problem with a companion probe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONSINGER, LEROY VERNON
description: HONSINGER-Leroy Vernon, Rear Admiral, died at the Masonic Geriatric Healthcare Center in Wallingford on Sunday, October 1, 2000 after a short illness. Recently turned 95, he had lived at 4303 Ashlar Village for the last eight and one-half years. He also had lived in Southbury, CT for eighteen years. Admiral Honsinger was born September 5, 1905, the second of five children of Dr. Frederick S. and Evalina Vernon Honsinger. Named for his maternal grandfather, he was widely known by the nickname given by his father-Mike. He graduated from the United States Naval Academy in 1927 and received the Master of Science degree in naval architecture from MIT in 1932. As a young naval officer he served a tour of duty in Panama and, in his long life, he transited the Panama Canal fifty-four times. During World War II Honsinger was deeply involved in battleship and LST (Landing Ship Tank) construction in the Norfolk, VA Navy Yard, in repairing British warships damaged in the Battle of the Atlantic, and in aircraft carrier construction at Newport News Shipbuilding Company in VA. Sent to Europe the last year of the war, he served as Acting Chief of the United States Technical Mission responsible for investigating German shipyards and their shipbuilding programs and bringing back their secrets. Admiral Honsinger served several tours of duty in the Bureau of Ships in Washington, D.C., including detailed responsibility for the Navy's shipbuilding program during the Korean War. After a tour as Commanding Officer of the Navy shipyard at Long Beach, CA, he was promoted to rear admiral and sent back to the Bureau of Ships for four years, first as Division Head of Ship Design, Construction, and Repair, and then for two years as Deputy Chief. Honsinger was associated early, and for many years, with the nuclear submarine program. He completed his thirty-nine-year naval career as Commanding Officer of the Mare Island Naval Shipyard, whose mission at that period was building nuclear submarines. Honsinger retired from Mare Island in 1962 with the Legion of Merit. Honsinger was president of the American Society of Naval Engineers and also of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers. After retirement Admiral Honsinger spent ten years with Todd Shipyards Corporation in New York City, eight of those years as Vice President for Shipbuilding. In his later years he was a Trustee and Vice Chairman of World Education, an organization set up to support the literacy work of his aunt, Dr. Welthy Honsinger Fisher. Always civic minded, Admiral Honsinger was active in church work wherever he lived and for many years was an active Rotarian, including one year as President of the Tribury Rotary Club in Southbury, CT. He developed great interest in environmental issues and in his eighties made himself an expert on recycling efforts. Admiral Honsinger married his childhood sweetheart Norma Chapin in 1930 and the couple had just celebrated their seventieth wedding anniversary, September 6, 2000. In addition to hie wife, he is survived by a son, retired Captain Vernon Chapin (Chip) Honsinger of Lexington, VA, a daughter, Valerie Kirkpatrick Joiner of Atlanta, GA, a sister, Helen Halstead of Peru, VT, five grandchildren and six great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 12, 2000 at the Activities Room at Ashlar Village, Cheshire Road, Wallingford. Burial will be private at the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, MD. There are no calling hours. It is suggested that gifts in his memory be made to the Ashlar Village Grants and Aid Fund, Post Office Box 70, Wallingford, CT 06492. Please call the B.C. Bailey Funeral Home at 273 South Elm Street in Wallingford for information.

title: SHARP DROPS FOR RAZORFISH AND MARIMBA
description: Shares of Razorfish and Marimba plunged in extended trading last night after the two Web-dependent companies issued separate warnings about their third-quarter performances. Razorfish, which advises companies on Internet strategy and Web-page design, said third-quarter earnings would decline from the previous quarter because of a larger-than-expected slowdown at European businesses. The stock fell $2.75, or 31 percent, to $6 after the 4 p.m. New York close of regular trading. Meanwhile, Marimba, which makes software that lets users deliver and update personal computer programs over the Web, fell $4.88, or 44 percent, to $6.25. It said third-quarter revenue would fall to about $10 million, from $12.1 million in the second quarter.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a phrase was omitted in some editions on Wednesday, altering the meaning, in a front-page article about the debate between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. As written, the article said the confrontation took on greater significance because the contest was ''disturbingly close FOR BOTH CANDIDATES.''

title: Hudson Ready to Face Yanks, if Not News Media
description: Tim Hudson has never pitched in Yankee Stadium or in the postseason, so the only questions about the 25-year-old ace of the Oakland Athletics' pitching staff were how he would respond to the pressure-filled assignment. But if part of the pressure comes from the craziness of New York, where the glare of the news media is larger than it is in Oakland, or just about anywhere, Hudson missed that last night.

title: In Plea, Sotheby's Ex-Chief Points to Her Superior
description: Speaking in a low, controlled voice, Diana D. Brooks, the former president and chief executive of Sotheby's auction house, pleaded guilty in a federal courtroom in Manhattan yesterday to fixing commission fees with the company's archrival, Christie's, and pointed the finger at A. Alfred Taubman, Sotheby's former chairman, whose orders she said she was following.

title: Federal Inquiry Opened Over Suspect's Death
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have opened a criminal investigation into the actions of a police officer who threw his radio at a fleeing suspect who later died, according to lawyers involved with the case.

title: GENENTECH SAYS IT WILL SPLIT ITS STOCK TWO FOR ONE
description: Genentech Inc., the world's oldest biotechnology company, said yesterday that it would split its shares two for one. Genentech said that on Oct. 24 it would issue one share for every share owned by shareholders of record as of Oct. 17. Genentech had 262.2 million shares outstanding as of Sept. 30, the company said. Genentech split shares in December after the stock quadrupled in the previous 12 months. Its stock price is up 28 percent this year. Shares of the company, based in South San Francisco, fell $1.38, to $171.06.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HOLIDAY RV SUPERSTORES, -- Fort Lauderdale, Fla., the only publicly traded chain of recreational vehicle and boat dealerships in the United States, agreed to buy four dealerships from Emerald Coast RV Center, to expand in the Southeast. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Bush vs. Gore: Debate Aftermath
description: To the Editor:

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Sorting It Out: Tax Cuts and Spending
description: RICHARD W. STEVENSON

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AMERICAN URBAN NETWORKS, -- New York, named Vernon S. Wright, vice president and general manager for SFX Radio Networks, as senior vice president for marketing and sales.

title: Microsoft Renews Call for Longer Appeal Process
description: The Microsoft Corporation shot back at the Justice Department today, saying that the government wanted to curtail the company's right of appeal of the antitrust ruling against it.

title: REIT Considers Closing
description: Laser Mortgage Management Inc., a mortgage real estate investment trust, may close after trying to find a buyer for two years. The company, based in Short Hills, is preparing a plan to sell its $292 million mortgage securities portfolio. The portfolio consists mainly of mortgage pass-through securities, said Charles Howe, secretary of Laser. Laser had hired Lehman Brothers in August 1998 to find a buyer after it fired its chairman and chief executive, Michael Smirlock. ''Nobody came up with an offer that was anywhere near the right price,'' Mr. Howe said. Laser rejected an offer of $4.30 a share from the Ellington Capital Management Group, managed by Michael Vranos, in December. Shares of Laser closed at $3.19, up 13 cents.

title: After Bottoming Out Last Season, Islanders May Be on the Upswing
description: New owners, new players, a new sense of optimism -- call them the renewed New York Islanders.

title: Status Symbols For the Rich, Then and Still
description: In 17th- and 18th-century Europe a mirror was the ultimate status symbol. Louis XIV set the example by installing the spectacular Hall of Mirrors in Versailles. After that, displaying a mirror was a mark of refinement, power, wealth and self-confidence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMALEWSKI, DIANE OF BROOKLYN, NY, SUDDENLY ON OCTOBER 3, 2000
description: ROMALEWSKI-Diane of Brooklyn, NY, suddenly on October 3, 2000. Devoted daughter of Helen(Linda) and Anthony Romalewski; beloved sister of Alice Tuminello, Thomas and Steven. Adored aunt of Michelle Tuminello; loving life partner of Gregory Coburn. Friends may call at Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Av., Wantagh, L.I., Friday October 6, 2-5 PM and 7-10 PM. Funeral Mass Saturday morning, St. Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church, Hicksville, L.I. Interment to follow. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Archbishop Molloy H.S. Endowment Fund, 83-53 Manton Street, Briarwood, NY 11435 or Polish American Folk Dance Company, 1001 Lorimer St, Brooklyn, NY, 11209. For further information call 516-731-5550

title: Review/Fashion; In Milan, Specters and a Suspicion
description: Someone once said that the first casualty of war is truth, and to the extent that fashion shows resemble a kind of sensory ground assault, with hundreds of outfits coming at you and the big houses frankly demanding oaths of loyalty from editors and retailers, hardly any of them will tell a designer his show was a dud. Instead, they resort to such stock backstage laurels as ''You've done it again!'' or the always enigmatic, ''Unforgettable.''

title: Mariners Clicking at the Right Time
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 5  Since baseball instituted preliminary playoff rounds in 1969, only five teams have taken leads of two games to none before losing a three-of-five- game series. It happened last fall, when Boston eliminated Cleveland. And many of the Seattle veterans remember the time before that, in 1995, when the Mariners came back to defeat the Yankees.

title: Perez Making Most of Chance
description: Leading off and playing right field for the Mets tonight was Timo Perez, the 23-year-old September call-up whose energetic play and background have drawn comparisons to last year's October hero, Melvin Mora.

title: U.S. Voices Concern for Cuban Whom Mexico Sent Back to Havana
description: The State Department expressed concern today about the fate of Pedro Riera Escalante, a former Cuban intelligence official who sought political asylum here but was forcibly repatriated to Havana on Wednesday.

title: AFFYMETRIX RISES ON PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: Affymetrix shares rose as much as 20 percent after the company said it expected to break even or turn a profit by the end of the year, earlier than analysts expected, as it sells more gene-research chips. Shares rose $8.50, to $61.25. The stock earlier touched $63.38. Affymetrix dominates the market for DNA chips, which are slides with millions of genetic fragments attached. The company said it hoped to double its sales of GeneChips this year to 200,000, compared with last year. In an analysts' meeting yesterday, company officials said Affymetrix would continue improving its chips and lowering their cost.

title: Priceline's WebHouse Club Abandoned as Investors Balk
description: One of the most ambitious efforts to use the Internet to transform a big business, Priceline.com's affiliate that lets consumers bid for groceries and gasoline, was abandoned yesterday because it could not raise enough money to stay in business.

title: What's a Nice Girl Like You Doing With Him?
description: You may have noticed how few couples actually behave like matched pairs. And those who do -- who can complete each other's sentences and use the word ''we'' with absolute confidence to describe their cozily congruent tastes -- usually seem to be missing something. For the outsider, being a third party around such a closed system can be insufferable, for it means being outvoted, two to one, whenever there's a disagreement.

title: President Puts Himself in Progressive Company
description: Opening a Princeton University conference today on the Progressive Era, President Clinton likened his presidency to the far-reaching reforms enacted under Theodore Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALINSKY, EDITH
description: PALINSKY-Edith. On October 4, 101. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Max Palinsky. Loving mother to Trudy Solin and husband, Jerry, and the late Samuel. Devoted grandmother of Seth and wife, Janet, David and wife, Judy, and the late Nina and Alexa. Caring greatgrandmother to Serena, Alana and Julia. Never was there a woman more full of grace.

title: Bush vs. Gore: Debate Aftermath; 'Fuzzy Math'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIANCHI, DORIS BALIN
description: BIANCHI-Doris Balin, aged 68. Loving mother of Diana & Peter, beloved ''Gran'' to Josh, Elliott and Lilly, adored sister to Herbert, died on October 4th, 2000 after a valiant fight that rarely slowed her down. She was a faculty member of the Department of Speech & Theater at Montclair State University for over 25 years. She will always be remembered for her love of family, her many dear friends, travel, the fine arts & everything British. She died as she lived, on her own terms with great dignity and independence. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 7th, at 2 PM at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Ave. at 80th St.; reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Doris Bianchi Senior Award, C/O Montclair State University Foundation, 1 Normal Ave., Upper Montclair, NJ 07043. ''The show must go on.''

title: A Hoedown, a Masked Ball And a Mystery, All on Ice
description: Ice Theater of New York, which seeks to make ice-skating look choreographically imaginative as well as virtuosic, was charming and elegant and occasionally mysterious in the program it presented on Tuesday night in the Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers.

title: Triple Whammy Hits Giants
description: The crack of J. T. Snow's bat in the ninth inning tonight was as chilling and eerie to the Mets as the fog that had rolled into Pacific Bell Park and enveloped them. Trailing by 4-1 and sensing their home-field advantage slipping away, the Giants rallied to force Game 2 of the National League division series into extra innings.

title: LUCENT GETS $1 BILLION SUPPLY PACT WITH SBC
description: SBC Communications agreed to buy more than $1 billion in equipment, software and services from Lucent Technologies in a five-year deal that makes Lucent SBC's main supplier. SBC will use Lucent equipment as it moves into 30 new markets, including Atlanta, Baltimore, Boston, Philadelphia and Seattle. SBC is the nation's second-largest local telephone company and has been aggressively adding long-distance and high-speed Internet connections to increase its customer base. Besides the SBC contract, Lucent said yesterday that it had signed a $180 million contract with Eletronet, a Brazilian company, to provide optical networking systems in several states in Brazil. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: A Clue for Designing Safer Anxiety Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (Reuters)  Researchers said today that they had found a possible way to design drugs that work as well as popular anxiety medications, but without side effects.

title: So You're the Lunkhead Who Wants Daddy's Girl
description: Robert De Niro's scowl has entered the cultural shorthand that generally presages entry into the Smithsonian, where it can lie in state next to the Fonz's jacket, Archie Bunker's chair and Cher's hair. Alec Baldwin's quick assumption of that martial frown in a ''Saturday Night Live'' sketch brought the house down a few years ago. It's as if Mr. De Niro recognized that his own wattage rises in direct proportion to his glower; when his face cracks into a wide-open grin, he looks like an insanely happy 6-year-old, and he couldn't be more harmless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, MARGUERITE (NEE MURPHY).
description: McCABE-Marguerite (nee Murphy). On October 4, 2000, at age 89. Beloved wife of Robert Dale McCabe; Devoted mother of Maureen and Patricia; Cherished grandmother of Christopher, Timothy, Kevin, Robert, Andrew, Matthew and Stephen Brown, Mary Ellen Hunter and Marguerite Phaneuf; Great-grandmother of Sarah, Meghan, Conor, Kaitlyn, Stephen, William, Taylor, Grace, Anne Marie and Sydney. Visitation Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM at Dimiceli & Sons Funeral Home, 182 Lexington Ave, NYC. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10:30 AM at The Church of Our Saviour. Interment at Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers friends may make donations in Marguerite's name to Father Frank Pavone, Priest's For Life, Staten Island, New York.

title: Correction
description: A Sept. 26 article erred in stating that national SAT scores have dropped in the past decade. In fact, the scores have risen slightly.

title: To-the-Wire Fighting for U.N. Seats; U.S. Tries to Block Sudan
description: An unusually intense battle is being fought over three of the five Security Council seats open for election this year, with three European nations vying for two places and an American-backed African candidate trying to derail a bid by Sudan for the third. The two other seats are not being contested.

title: Dr. Eugene Borowitz, 71, Adviser on 'Genius Grants'
description: Dr. Eugene Borowitz, a psychiatrist who had a key role in developing the anonymous system that the MacArthur Fellows Program uses to identify potential recipients of its stipends known informally as ''genius grants,'' died on Tuesday in a hospital in Chicago. He was 71 and lived in Chicago.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: European Central Bank Increases Interest Rates

title: Palestinian Security Prevents Violent Confrontation in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM -- Angry Palestinians threw stones after midday prayers Friday at the Al Aqsa mosque compound in Jerusalem, but Palestinian security quickly stepped in to prevent a confrontation with Israeli forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFFER, HANS A.
description: SCHAEFFER-Hans A. Formerly of Linden, NJ, passed away October 4, 2000 at home in Bethesda, MD., with his wife by his side. His wife, Leilo, his three children, Barbara Dagger of Woodstock, VT, Monica Gorochow of Patomic, MD and Edward Schaeffer of Wellesley, MA & seven grandchildren survive him. Born in Berlin, Germany, Mr. Schaeffer began his education in chemistry at the Technical University of Berlin. He was very fortunate to escape Germany in 1939 and move to London, England where he further developed his knowledge in chemistry, pharmacology and toxicology at London University. In 1947 he moved to the U.S. where he settled in Linden, NJ working at E.R. Squibb and completing graduate courses at Rutgers University in NJ. He continued his careerworking for such well-known pharmaceutical and personal care companies as Block Drug and J.B. Williams Co. He retired in 1982 from J.B. Williams to form Hans A. Schaeffer Associates. For 18 years working with companies such as Beecham Products, Whitehall Laboratories and BectonDickinson, he dedicated himself to developing innovative and advanced technological products for the personal care industry. He held numerous patents including the original patent on Mentadent Toothpaste. He will long be remembered for his innovation and contributions in commercializing raw materials for the cosmetic industry. Mr. Schaeffer's loss will be strongly felt within the personal care and pharmaceutical industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, MURIEL
description: HOFFMAN-Muriel. At age 91, of Queens, NY. Beloved wife of the late Max. Loving mother of Mona Paster. Adored grandmother of Marla. Great-grandmother of Jacqueline & Sam. Graveside services on Friday, 1 PM, Beth David. She was a woman ahead of her time. She will be greatly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRISCHLING, ANNA
description: FRISCHLING-Anna. Died at home in Florida after a long illness at age 86. Beloved wife for 66 years of Irving. Devoted mother of Rosely, Carl and Adele, Steven and Ruth, and the late Eleanor. Loving grandmother of Nica and Rob, William and Amy, Amos, James, Teddy, Estee, Menucha, Yael, and Sholom. Caring great grandmother of Jake, Stevie, and Robert. Private family graveside services. Receiving family and friends Friday, October 6, 12:303:30 at 92nd Street Y, Room 101.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARIS, SAMUEL L.
description: PARIS-Samuel L. 3 yrs since you left our lives, we miss you very much. Your spirit lives on within us we think of you everyday. Love Shirley, Children & Grandchildren.

title: Sierra Leone to Try Juveniles Separately in U.N. Tribunal Plan
description: The Security Council got a blueprint today for a war crimes tribunal for Sierra Leone, the fourth such special court to be established in the last decade of world civil conflict.

title: Knoblauch Waits For Second Chance
description: Chuck Knoblauch spoke in a whisper, his voice a faint mixture of sadness, bitterness and rebellion as he wondered how he fits in with the Yankees anymore. Actually, Knoblauch's words had a tinge of resolution, too, because he realizes he might not fit in at all this October.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page contents entry yesterday about a Cuban intelligence official who was seeking refuge in Mexico misstated his relationship to the Cuban Embassy in Mexico City. He was a consul there from 1986 until 1991, not recently.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: $3 Million Award in Police Brutality Case
description: A federal jury awarded $3 million yesterday to a Bronx woman who said she had been beaten by an undercover New York City police officer when she was mistakenly arrested in a drug case in 1998.

title: Rangers' Remake Will Take More Time
description: When Glen Sather was hired as Rangers president and general manager last summer, he inherited a team overstocked with so many highly paid veterans, Broadway looked more gray than blue.

title: Nicole Eisenman
description: Jack Tilton

title: Where the Apple Doesn't Fall Far From the Tree
description: THE FAMILY ORCHARD

title: Even in the Harshest Conditions, Precious Life Somehow Prevails
description: ''Distant Voices IV: Images of the Other America,'' at the Puffin Room in SoHo, is a show that wears its heart on its sleeve. The subjects of these photographs are the Macuxi Indians in the Serra do Sol, a remote grassland of the Amazon basin in northern Brazil, and the Mayans in Guatemala and in the state of Chiapas in southern Mexico.

title: Searching for Welles as Welles Searched for Kane
description: ''I have spent a lifetime listening to 'I don't understand,' '' Orson Welles complains as the narrator of his own life story, the deconstructed subject of ''War of the Worlds'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. ''It's as plain as day. It's about the frame, you see. It's all about the frame.''

title: Tory Leader Says British Now Reject Labor as Just a Fad
description: Buoyed by a recent lift in Conservative poll numbers, William Hague, the leader of the party, said today that it now had broader appeal to Britain's middle class than Labor and was fully prepared to run the country.

title: A Lead-Paint Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Indians Show Influence in Montana
description: American Indians constitute such a small voting bloc in national elections, about one million people, that the Census Bureau does not track their participation rates as it does for whites, blacks and Hispanics.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOOG
description: HOOG The Department of Romance Languages at Princeton University mourns the loss of its colleague, Armand Marc Francois Hoog, Pyne Professor of French, who died on September 10, 1999. A commemoration will be held in 106 McCormick Hall on Saturday, October 7 at 2 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWNEY, MARJORIE
description: DOWNEY-Marjorie. On October 5, 2000, peacefully, at home, at age 71. Loving sister of Ralph Fields. Interment private. A memorial service to be announced. Contributions in her memory may be made to Belgravia Foundation, c/o Martin Felcher, 18 East 48 Street, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10017.

title: Yes to Year-Round High Schools
description: New York City's public high schools have responded to drastic overcrowding by doing away with the double instructional periods that poorly prepared students and new immigrants commonly require to become fluent readers and writers. The system is also offering abbreviated course schedules that provide six classes per day, one short of the state-mandated minimum. With the crowding getting steadily worse, the Board of Education has had little choice but to propose that it run some of its high schools on a year-round schedule, with some students attending school while others are on vacation. This sensible plan deserves prompt support in the State Legislature, which must first act to make year-round schooling fundable under state law.

title: CHAIRMAN OF UGLY DUCKLING BIDS FOR REMAINING SHARES
description: The Ugly Duckling Corporation, a used-car dealer that sells to people with troubled credit histories, said its chairman and principal shareholder had offered about $63.8 million to buy all the shares outstanding he does not already own. The chairman, Ernest C. Garcia, who holds about 40 percent of the shares, has offered to pay $8.50 in cash and debt for each share, Ugly Duckling said. That is a 48 percent premium over the company's closing price of $5.75 on Wednesday. The company's shares fell 6 cents, to $5.69.

title: Knicks Must Deal With Spare Parts
description: The president of Madison Square Garden, Dave Checketts, pulled up a chair today and watched the unorthodox team he had assembled go through practice. He saw three evenly matched point guards vying for one starting spot; three high-scoring swingmen shooting for the limited minutes at two other positions; and a collection of injury-plagued centers with no legitimate starter among them.

title: Serbian Opposition Supporters Revel in the Streets of Belgrade
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- As euphoric, all-night street celebrations of Slobodan Milosevic's apparent political demise wound down, Russia on Friday sent its foreign minister on a delicate mission said to include planned talks with the Yugoslav president in his secret hideout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARAH, JOSEPH JOHN
description: FARAH-Joseph John. On October 5, 2000 of Newark, NJ. Beloved husband of Awatif (nee Sadaka). Beloved father of Jeffrey Farah & Monica Farah-Stapleton. Beloved brother of Philip Farah and Rose Farah. Dear grandfather of Alexandra Farah. Funeral from the Galante Funeral Home, 17 Pacific St. at Walnut St. Newark, NJ on Saturday at 10AM. Funeral Mass at St. James Church, Newark, NJ at 11 AM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Visitation Friday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. In lieu flowers, donations to the American Heart Association N.J. Affiliate Memorials Program, 2550 Rt. 1 North Brunswick, NJ 08902-4301, would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page contents entry yesterday about a Cuban intelligence official who was seeking refuge in Mexico misstated his relationship to the Cuban Embassy in Mexico City. He was a consul there from 1986 until 1991, not recently.

title: UTILICORP AGREES TO BUY SIX POWER PLANTS FROM GPU
description: The Aquila Energy unit of UtiliCorp United agreed yesterday to buy stakes in six power plants and an electricity project from GPU Inc., a utility owner based in Morristown, N.J., for $225 million. The stakes amount to about 500 megawatts of capacity, enough to light 500,000 homes. Two plants are in New York and two are in Florida, with one each in New Jersey and Georgia. The project, proposed for Mississippi, will produce 715 megawatts. UtiliCorp, based in Kansas City, Mo., is adding power plants for its trading arm, which buys and sells electricity. GPU will post a gain of $60 million to $80 million on the sale. Proceeds will be used to reduce debt, GPU said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTOS, DON FLORIANO
description: SANTOS-Don Floriano. The members of Loeb Block and Partners mourn the loss of their dear friend, Don Floriano Santos, of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. For more than thirty years we shared joys and sorrows together. A big man with an even bigger heart, respected businessman, loving father and grandfather. His presence will be missed.

title: European Court Overturns Ban On Tobacco Ads
description: The European Court of Justice, Europe's highest court, today overturned a ban that would have phased out tobacco advertising across Europe.

title: Out of Work and Low in Spirits? Let's Put on a Show!
description: Halloween may still be a few weeks in the future, but too many ghosts are hanging around ''Bootmen.''

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Playing Drill Sergeant for Teenage Drivers
description: AT 16, boys are fascinated by a lot of things. Cars, for instance, and the birds and the bees. We had the cars and went in search of a bee -- specifically, an 800-pound fiberglass likeness described as the ''world's largest bee'' in an off-the-wall travel guide.

title: Article 2000100691414392827 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Most restaurants are moving targets. Chefs change. Menus change. It's hard to keep up. Arizona 206 is a special case. In October 1998 it changed its name to Bolivar, transformed its menu from Southwestern to nuevo latino and began picking up favorable reviews. End of story? No.

title: Nicola Constantino
description: 'Human Furrier'

title: Milosevic Concedes Election Defeat
description: BELGRADE, Oct 7 - Slobodan Milosevic, who presided over the destruction of Yugoslavia, on Friday accepted election defeat at the hands of president-elect Vojislav Kostunica in what appeared to be a bloodless transition of power.

title: Hernandez Leads Yankees Past Athletics
description: NEW YORK -- The New York Yankees used Orlando Hernandez's playoff experience and Oakland's lack of it to move within one win of the AL championship series.

title: Meg Webster
description: Paula Cooper Gallery

title: Miscellany
description: Towne Silverstein Rotter, New York, is being renamed Rotter Kantor Inc., to reflect the recent hiring of Robert Kantor as co-chairman.

title: SARA LEE SAYS IT IS CONSIDERING SALE OF SOME BUSINESSES
description: The Sara Lee Corporation's chief executive, C. Steven McMillan, said yesterday that the company might sell some of its global food and European apparel businesses to winnow the collection of products amassed over the last 25 years. Mr. McMillan said that Sara Lee had received bids for food companies with about $300 million in annual sales. The company is also considering the sale of clothing units in Europe with as much as $150 million in sales. He did not name the units. Sara Lee said in May that the company would sell shares in its Coach leather goods unit and its food-service business, PYA/Monarch, to the public, and find a buyer for its Champion sportswear unit.

title: ONLINE MORTGAGES MAY GROW FAST
description: Half of all Americans expect that most home mortgages will be handled over the Internet within five years, making it easier to compare lending options and to reduce discrimination in the borrowing process, a new survey has found. The study, by Fannie Mae, a government-chartered corporation that buys home loans from banks and other lenders, found that nearly 30 percent of those polled would ''definitely or probably'' use the Internet to apply for a mortgage, up from 20 percent in 1996. Still, the Internet remains largely an information resource, as only 2 percent of recent homebuyers completed the entire mortgage approval process using the Web.

title: April Gornik
description: Edward Thorp

title: Mrs. Clinton's Primary Opponent Backs Lazio
description: Campaign officials for Representative Rick A. Lazio teased journalists that a key endorsement was imminent. They rolled out his campaign bus, playing patriotic and pop music. Party faithful, including the state Republican chairman, William D. Powers, were summoned.

title: DIABETES DRUG APPROVED
description: Novartis A.G. of Switzerland and Merck of Germany have won their first regulatory approval to sell the diabetes medicine, Starlix. Swiss regulators have approved the drug for use alone or with Merck's Glucophage, the world's best-selling noninsulin diabetes treatment. Novartis, Europe's third- largest drug maker, will now seek approval from regulators in the United States to begin marketing Starlix in the first quarter of 2001.

title: Congress Addresses Importing Medicine and Exporting to Cuba
description: Meeting into the night, House and Senate negotiators agreed today on separate measures to allow imports of low-priced prescription drugs and to lift four-decade-old sanctions on the sale of food to Cuba but with severe restrictions on financing and travel.

title: Yugoslavia's Fate, and Europe's
description: Slobodan Milosevic's fall in Serbia can extinguish the last vestiges of the Communist Party in Eastern Europe that began with Red Army occupation in 1945. Though Tito's Yugoslavia broke with the Soviet Union in 1948, Yugoslav Communists in the Republic of Serbia did not succumb to the counterrevolutionary wave of 1989 that swept away other Communist regimes around them.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: The Vice-Presidential Debate; Excerpts From the Debate Between the Vice-Presidential Candidates
description: Following are excerpts from the vice-presidential debate last night in Danville, Ky., between Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut and Dick Cheney, as recorded by The New York Times. The moderator was Bernard Shaw of CNN.

title: Starr Aide Is Acquitted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The former spokesman for the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr was acquitted this afternoon of trying to hide his role in leaking information about Mr. Starr's investigation of President Clinton.

title: Anxiety in Book Business Over Barnes & Noble Snag
description: A snarl at a Barnes & Noble distribution center set off a wave of anxiety in the book business this week. The company says the problem has been resolved, but some publishers are not so sure.

title: Hospitals Fear U.S. Rule Would Curb Fund-Raising
description: Not long after a stay at the Cleveland Clinic, most patients receive a letter telling about the clinic's good works -- and seeking a contribution.

title: Sports of The Times; 'Joe and Cash Are a Good Combination'
description: WHILE several pinstriped employees on his $112 million payroll took batting practice or shagged balls in the outfield, George Steinbrenner wore a royal blue warm-up suit with a small white USA logo and white sneakers as he sat in the cloudy chill of the Yankee dugout.

title: Crude Oil Price Drops 2.9% On Sale From U.S. Reserve
description: Crude oil prices fell almost 3 percent yesterday as the United States sold 30 million barrels of reserve oil it had offered, easing concern of a supply crunch in the months ahead.

title: In Bethlehem, New Generation of Teenage Foes Renews Ritual of Bloodshed
description: Juggling stones in his hands, Muhammad Ibrahim, 17, reported for his afternoon shift in the seven-day-old street war of what he thinks of as the second, and final, Palestinian uprising.

title: Yugoslavs Claim Belgrade for New Leader
description: As the federal Parliament burned and tear gas wafted through chaotic streets, vast throngs of Serbs wrested their capital and key levers of power away from Slobodan Milosevic today, bringing his 13-year reign to the edge of collapse.

title: The End? The Fall of the House of Poe
description: To the Editor:

title: Owens Corning Has Filed For Bankruptcy Protection
description: Owens Corning, facing a cooling of its markets as asbestos-related litigation is heating up, said yesterday that it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: A Hole in the Collection Plate; From Smudge on Ledger to Embezzlement Inquiry
description: In July 1999, accountants from the Diocese of Brooklyn arrived at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Queens. They had heard reports from the parish that the pastor, Msgr. Thomas J. Gradilone, had been acting irrationally, and the accountants wanted to see the books. They exchanged pleasantries with the monsignor and turned their attention to the numbers.

title: Reno Says She'll Seek Release of U.S. Study on Los Alamos
description: Attorney General Janet Reno has told a group of Asian-American community leaders that she would seek to make public a highly classified Justice Department report said to be critical of the investigation and prosecution of Wen Ho Lee, the former scientist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory who was accused of mishandling nuclear secrets.

title: Walker Evans
description: 'Polaroids'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, JOHN PATRICK JR.
description: MURRAY-John Patrick Jr., on October 3, at the age of 73, of Princeton, NJ and Hobe Sound, Florida. Beloved husband of almost 50 years of Mary Tietje. Devoted father of Ellen Kelsey, Greenwich, CT, Elizabeth Hosea, Princeton, NJ, John P. III, New York City, W. Stephen, Greens Farms, CT, M. Timothy, Stuart, FL, R. Scott, Plymouth, NH and nine grandchildren. He was predeceased by sons, J. Michael and Peter C. He served in the United States Navy during World War II. He graduated from Indiana University, Class of 1949 and was elected to their Academy of Alumni Fellows and Business School Hall of Fame. In his 50 year business career, he was President/ CEO of The Atlantic Products Corporation, President/CEO of the Prince Tennis Corporation, and Chairman/CEO of Wilson Sporting Goods. He served as a Director on the boards of a number of companies and philanthropic organizations including The New Jersey National Bank, CoreStates Financial Corporation, ChesebroughPonds Inc. and the Recording for the Blind where he served as National Chairman. He was Director of The International Tennis Hall of Fame, The Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association, The United States Tennis Association and The Golf Manufacturers Association. He served as a Commissioner to the town of Jupiter Island, FL. He was founder and Chairman of the Murray Foundation, whose focus is research to save sight and other medical interests. Jack Murray will be remembered by his family and friends as an enthusiastic sportsman who was particularly devoted to the tradiitons and game of golf. He was Founding President of the Bedens Brook Club, Princeton, NJ, a long time member of The Pine Valley Golf Club, where he was a Trustee, Seminole Golf Club and The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews. There will be a private family service. Contributions in his memory may be made to: The Medical Center at Princeton Foundation, 253 Witherspoon Street, Princeton, NJ 08540 or Jupiter Medical Center Foundation, 1210 South Old Dixie Highway, Jupiter, Florida 33458.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABEDON, MARSHA
description: ABEDON-Marsha. Hillel: The Foundation For Jewish Campus Life extends its heartfelt condolences to the family of Hillel Treasurer Julian Sandler on the passing of his sister, Marsha Abedon. May the Sandler and Abedon families be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Hillel International Board of Governors Edgar M. Bronfman, Chairman Charles Schusterman Co-Chairman Michael Steinhardt, Co-Chairman Chuck Newman, Chairman, Hillel Board of Directors Richard M. Joel President and Internat'l Director

title: Article 2000100690028744096 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Man Dies After Falling Off the Empire State Building
description: NEW YORK -- A man died after falling off the Empire State Building Thursday night, police said.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Good Lesson In Improvisation

title: Just 'Peanuts,' But Still Gold
description: After weeks of watching the Olympics, it's easy to forget that one of the most endearing (and enduring) heroes of American popular culture is a perennial loser. Impossible? Then you're overlooking Charlie Brown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUDOIN, CHARLES
description: BAUDOIN-Charles. A compassionate, wise and gentle man who was a much valued member of the Board of Trustees of the Ackerman Institute for the Family. We were indeed most fortunate to have his involvement and committment to helping families. Sincerest condolences to his loving family. Arthur Maslow, Board Chairman Peter Steinglass, MD, Exec Dir

title: EATING OUT
description: The Month for Beer

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: NAPSTER USE CONTINUES AT TORRID PACE
description: Despite being embroiled in a court battle with record companies over its use of technology that allows users to trade musical recordings free online, Napster3 has become the fastest-growing home software application ever, according to the Web research firm Media Metrix. Napster had 6.7 million users in August, up more than 500 percent from 1.1 million in February, the firm reported yesterday. Also yesterday, Napster officials denied a news report that they had held talks about selling the business.

title: Milosevic Concedes Defeat; Yugoslavs Celebrate New Era
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Oct. 6  Bowing to a vast popular revolt against him, a pale Slobodan Milosevic resigned tonight as Yugoslavia's president, ending 13 years of rule that have brought his country four wars, international isolation, a NATO bombing campaign and his own indictment on war crimes charges.

title: Presidential Debate Swayed Some Independent Minds in St. Louis
description: Like any hyperscheduled mother of two with a full-time job, Toni Caracciolo does not have time to spend 90 minutes sitting still. So on Tuesday night she tuned in and out of the debate between Al Gore and George W. Bush while giving her young daughters a bath. Still, Ms. Caracciolo, a Republican, saw enough to consider doing something that she never has before and that would appall her husband: casting her vote for a Democrat.

title: Time Warner And EMI Halt Venture Plan
description: Faced with opposition from European antitrust regulators, Time Warner and the EMI Group of Britain withdrew their application today for a $20 billion joint venture to link their music businesses and said they would work to submit a revised plan.

title: Tom Burckhardt and Frank Gonzalez
description: Caren Golden Fine Arts

title: Race Is On To Decode Genome Of Mouse
description: With the work on the human genome essentially complete, the National Institutes of Health and others said today that they would spend $58 million to decode the genome of the mouse by February.

title: MERIDIAN INSURANCE STOCK JUMPS AFTER ANNOUNCEMENT
description: Shares of the Meridian Insurance Group rose 28 percent after it said it was considering ways to increase shareholder value. Meridian, which has been fending off a hostile takeover from a dissident shareholder, said it had hired A.G. Edwards & Sons to advise it. It said the options included going private, repurchasing shares, entering into a ''business combination'' with another company or remaining independent. Meridian shares rose $3.88, to $17.75. Last month, Meridian rejected a takeover offer from the American Union Insurance Company and its chairman, Gregory M. Shepard.

title: Liberating Yugoslavia
description: The long tyranny of Slobodan Milosevic was crumbling in Belgrade yesterday. In a tumultuous day reminiscent of the anti-Communist revolutions of 1989, the leading symbols of Yugoslav government power, like the Parliament and the state television station, fell to opposition demonstrators as police resistance melted away. Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets and, refusing to be intimidated, demanded that the recent election of Vojislav Kostunica as president be respected. Their courage and determination impressed a watching world.

title: Some Other Contenders For Rich EMI Repertory
description: The decision by the EMI Group and Time Warner to withdraw a plan to merge their music businesses may open the door to a new partner for EMI.

title: States' Drug Subsidy Programs Have Troubles of Their Own
description: Pennsylvania has one of the nation's largest state-run drug-subsidy programs for its older low-income residents. So it seemed natural for Gov. George W. Bush to choose it last month as the place to announce his program to help states ease drug costs for those on Medicare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAKE, KAREN NELSON
description: DRAKE-Karen Nelson. Age 67, of Rutherford, NJ died peacefully at her home on Tuesday October 3, 2000. Beloved wife of the late John G. Drake and loving daughter of the late Mayor Martin P. and Florence H. Nelson. She is survived by her beloved sister Margot N. Carey, her brother-in-law J. Raymond Carey and loving nephew Nelson L. Carey. Mrs. Drake was a retired manager with NYNEX. She was a graduate of Rutherford High School, Centenary College Hackettstown and received her Bachelor of Science Degree from Hiram College in Ohio. Mrs. Drake was a trustee of Centenary College, Past-president of its alumni association and class correspondent. She was the first recipient of the VanWinkle Distinguished Alumni Award from the college. She was a member of the Order of the Eastern Star in Rutherford, former officer of the First Presbyterian Church of Rutherford and past president of the Rutherford Women's College Club. Donations to the Karen Nelson Drake Memorial Fund of the First Presbyterian Church of Rutherford, 1 East Passaic Avenue, Rutherford, N.J. 07070, would be appreciated. A memorial service to celebrate Karen's life will be held at the First Presbyterian Church of Rutherford on Saturday, November 11, 2000 at 11:00AM. For further information, call Collins-Calhoun Funeral Home, 19 Lincoln Avenue, Rutherford, New Jersey.

title: Bolt Problem Scraps Shuttle Launch
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- NASA called off Thursday night's launch of space shuttle Discovery because of last-minute concerns over bolts on the external fuel tank.

title: Dr. Dain L. Tasker
description: Howard Greenberg Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUBENSTEIN, HENRY.
description: RUBENSTEIN-Henry. Henry dearest, the passage of years does not dim how much I miss you, how deeply I love you. Yours always, Beatric

title: About the Tables
description: Business Day is including a second section, World Business (Section W), on Tuesdays through Fridays through Dec. 29. That section consists of international business news as well as the tables for the United States exchanges plus preferred stocks.

title: Fraud Charges In Informix Case
description: The Informix Corporation's former top European sales executive was indicted by a federal grand jury on charges that he committed fraud by helping inflate the company's financial results in fiscal 1996.

title: The End? The Fall of the House of Poe
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, SOPHIA B.
description: CASEY-Sophia B. On October 5, 2000, of Roslyn Harbor. Beloved wife of the late William J. Casey, former Director of Central Intelligence. Loving mother of Bernadette Casey Smith and her husband Owen T. Smith. Dear sister of Lillian Kurz and Joseph Kurz. Loving aunt of Noel Glenn, Carol Murray, Thomas Langan and many loving grand-nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends at the Casey residency (Mayknoll) 12 Glenwood Road, Roslyn Harbor, Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 11:00 AM, St. Mary's RC Church, Roslyn Harbor. Interment, Holy Rood Cemetery. She was a Dame of the Order of St. Gregory and the Order of Holy Sepulchre.

title: Complicated Maneuvering on Utah Paper
description: For decades The Salt Lake City Tribune has been the largest newspaper in Utah without a connection to the Mormon church. Now the news of talks between a Mormon-owned newspaper company and The Tribune's corporate parent have raised fears inside The Tribune that its independent voice could be eroded.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: A Columbus Day Parade Has Denver on Edge
description: For the first time in eight years, Italian-Americans in the Denver area are organizing a Columbus Day parade, scheduled for downtown on Saturday. But the plans have met with such resistance from groups opposed to celebrating Columbus that Gov. Bill Owens says National Guard units will be available to assist the police if protests turn violent.

title: A Mideast Peace, Derailed Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABER, IRVING
description: RABER-Irving. The Trustees and staff of the Educational Alliance note with profound sadness the passing of Irving Raber, our devoted Trustee and friend. Irving joined the Board in November, 1988 and remained active until his death. He was involved with house and building issues and was a supporter and advocate of our agency's programs. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, son, daughter and their families.

title: As the Cat and Mouse Go Forth and Multiply
description: At the start, 37 years ago, ''The Fugitive'' must have seemed like a ludicrous idea for a series: send a man on the lam even though viewers know he can't possibly be caught or the show would be over. Where's the suspense in that? But the old ''Fugitive'' ran for four years and its finale drew the largest audience for a series ever, until someone shot J. R. on ''Dallas.''

title: Choice of Metaphors From Opposing Camps Takes Edge Off a Bit
description: DANVILLE, Ky., Oct. 5  The faux boxing posters, all over town, promoted the big debate tonight as "The Thrill in the 'Ville."

title: Accounts
description: Andrew Jergens Co., Cincinnati, part of the Kao Corp., to the Bozell Group, New York, part of True North Communications, as creative agency of record for the Ban line of antiperspirants and deodorants, a brand Jergens recently acquired from Chattem Inc. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $12 million.

title: INSIDE
description: Mets Even Series; Braves Are Reeling

title: The Running Mates Stick to Second Fiddle
description: The two vice-presidential nominees demonstrated their fitness for their political calling tonight by safely remaining one heartbeat away from committing any news whatsoever that might conceivably have upstaged their principals.

title: Giants' New Kicker Hoping Latest Stop Is His Last Stop
description: Jaret Holmes was greeted by strange stares at the gate at Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta as he awaited a flight home to Jackson, Miss. Don't we know you, the commuters seemed to imply. When Holmes was finally asked what line of work required him to be a regular on the Atlanta-Jackson route, he replied, ''I'm trying to make money playing football.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE MARTIN, PETER R.
description: De MARTIN-Peter R. Son of the late Peter DeMartin of Brooklyn, NY and the late Charlotte Dessilla of Cliffside, NJ, on September 30, 2000. Funeral and interment at Madonna Cemetery, Fort Lee, NJ will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations appreciated ''In memory of Peter R. DeMartin'' to Cabrini Hospice, attn: Mary Cooke, 227 East 19th Street, NYC 10003.

title: A Mideast Peace, Derailed Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, SYLVIA RUTKINS
description: POSNER-Sylvia Rutkins. Beloved wife of the late Harry B. Rutkins and the late Bernard Posner. Adored mother of Amy Davis Gold. Loving grandmother of Alison and Howard. Cherished sister of Dr. Edward Zornberg, Rose Goldberg and the late Ethel Spitalny, Bertha Richman and Monroe Zornberg. Service Friday, 10 am, Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECK, THEODORE H.
description: BECK-Theodore H. Of NYC and Nantucket Island. Age 81, in Sleepy Hollow, New York, on October 5. Ted served in the U.S. Army's spearhead division across the Rhine in WW II. His tank and crew were destroyed in a direct hit but he survived, minus one leg. Despite this disability, he lived a full and well-traveled life, once hiking deep into mountainous Rwandan jungle to visit rare silverback gorillas. Employed at Beck Engraving Co., he later taught English as a Second Language in Colombia. His great love was fishing, especially for ''blues'' off Nantucket's Great Point. As he wished, there will be no funeral service.

title: Women Who Are Definitely Going Somewhere, Maybe
description: ''Wyoming,'' a new play by Catherine Gillet, is a road story of sorts, except the map it follows consists of the twists and turns in the neurological back roads of the human mind.

title: A Brother Swept Into a Cycle of Death
description: There is a relentless circle trod by enraged Palestinian men in the Gaza Strip. They file from concrete hovels each day to the Netzarim intersection. There they clash with Israeli soldiers. Those who are shot are taken to the hospital. Those who die return home by nightfall draped in national colors on a wooden bier.

title: Seeking a Constant in the Many Styles of Lee Krasner
description: Did Lee Krasner (1908-1984) never find her true calling as a painter? Or was she a postmodernist before the fact? That is to say, did she reject the Abstract Expressionist myth of natural genius and deep authenticity and by working in a variety of styles over the course of her five-decade career realize the self as a field of socially constructed possibilities?

title: Metro Business; 110 Jobs in Queens Saved
description: A Queens company that makes furniture and equipment for beauty salons and barber shops will remain in Flushing and expand, rather than move out of state, preserving 110 jobs and adding about 20 more, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced

title: 'Two Family House'
description: Directed by Raymond De Felitta

title: 51 Dead After Torrential Rains in Vietnams Northern Mountains
description: HANOI, 0ct 6 - A total of 51 people have been confirmed dead in Vietnam's northern mountains after torrential rains sparked flash floods and landslides, officials said Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTIN, MAURICE
description: AUSTIN-Maurice, on Wednesday, October 4, 2000, in his 94th year. Devoted husband and beloved companion of Jennie Austin for 71 years; loving father of Alice and John Brumbaugh, Alan and Irene Austin; doting grandfather of Sharon Moser, Sheila Sybrant, Jonathan Austin, and Kathleen Austin; and great-grandfather of five. Distinguished scholar, lecturer, lawyer, and accountant, Maurice Austin, in his seventy-five years of practice, conducted himself with impeccable integrity and dignity. He brought to his clients, family, and friends the benefit of his extraordinary intellect, kind and generous spirit, and sense of humor. He was a recipient of numerous honors and awards, the most recent being the endowment for Maurice Austin Scholars established in his honor by The J.M. Kaplan Fund, Inc., at City College of New York. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to the Maurice Austin Research Fund at the National Jewish Medical and Research Center, 1400 Jackson Street, Denver, CO 80206.

title: Mets Have a Flair for the Dramatic
description: If Armando Benitez had worked out of the ninth inning without incident, and the Mets had taken a tidy victory back with them to Shea Stadium -- well, they would not be the New York Mets.

title: The Plan: He Steps Down, They Step Up, U.S. Lies Low
description: With televisions in the White House tuned to the images of protesters seizing the Parliament in Belgrade, President Clinton stepped into the Rose Garden today to encourage them on, at once offering American support while making it clear that the considerable American military presence in the region would not intervene.

title: Most Powerful Quake in 5 Years Hits Japan, but Damage Limited
description: TOKYO, Oct. 6  A powerful earthquake struck western Japan today, injuring at least 20 people, damaging many buildings and disrupting electricity and train service in the country's most violent tremor in five years.

title: Mariners Win Division Series Over White Sox
description: SEATTLE -- The Seattle Mariners used a squeeze to sweep.

title: Elegant Family Man
description: ART history, including recent American art history, has its share of stars who dropped from the radar screen. Edward Steichen, for decades the most celebrated photographer in the country, who died only 27 years ago at 85, has suffered a surprising decline in public recognition considering his onetime exalted fame. People these days confuse him with Alfred Stieglitz.

title: After the Lost Wars and the Ruined Economy, 'the Greater Slobo' Falls Silent
description: The Serbian nationalist hysteria that swept Slobodan Milosevic to power in the late 1980's evaporated long ago, leaving him an isolated figure ruling over a shrinking land. But with resilience, ruse and ruthlessness, he outmaneuvered his enemies, until at last the enemy became his own people.

title: Metro Business; Burberry Planning A Retail Expansion
description: Burberry, whose check-lined raincoats were once ubiquitous on fashionable city streets, recently bought the building next to its store on 57th Street and plans to expand its retail space, the company announced yesterday.

title: Showcasing Life's Sorrows and Humans' Ways of Bearing Them
description: Peter Hujar stamped his photographs with an uncommon sensibility that has not shown up often or consistently in photography. It was a sensibility both emotionally removed and tender, respectful of the compromised dignity of the least of his acquaintances, a trifle solemn, alert to signs of death and ruin, and constantly mindful of the delicate sorrows of the human condition.

title: A Vote for Me, Bush Says, Is, Well. . . .
description: Challenging an incumbent in times of peace and prosperity is not easy. And as Gov. George W. Bush of Texas campaigned across the Midwest today, he showed just how difficult it can be.

title: Prisons and Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Forces Storm Al Aqsa Mosque to Remove Palestinian Flags
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 6 - After a week of rioting and gun battles, Israeli and Palestinian authorities today struggled, with limited success, to keep the Friday prayers at al-Aqsa mosque in the Old City from ending in a bloodbath and further inflaming an already explosive Israeli-Arab conflict.

title: Amid Bats and Balls, Come Sticks and Pucks
description: The National Hockey League's 2000-2001 season opened with one game Wednesday night, picked up steam last night and gets into full swing this weekend. Here's a look at how the season may go, with teams listed in the predicted order of finish.

title: Trying On Blackface in a Flirtation With Fire
description: Spike Lee has grabbed a tiger by the tail in his scabrously risky new comedy, ''Bamboozled.'' The wonder is how long he succeeds in hanging on.

title: Congressman Draws Rebuke But No Penalty
description: Mixing harsh words with leniency, the House ethics committee has criticized Representative Bud Shuster, the chairman of the House Transportation Committee, for improper links with a lobbyist who once worked for him and for other misbehavior.

title: SOCCER STOCK OFFERING
description: The sports club BV Borussia 09 Dortmund said its shares would be traded for the first time on the Frankfurt stock exchange on Oct. 31 as it becomes the first German soccer club to stage an initial public offering. After the stock offering, 50 to 75 percent of Dortmund's stock will be freely traded, the company said. The club is worth more than 200 million euros ($175 million), Financial Times Deutschland reported earlier this week. Investors will be able to subscribe to the stock from Oct. 23 to Oct. 27. The soccer club will use the proceeds from the initial offering to acquire a major stake in its own stadium, to keep up with the international competition and to purchase players. (Bloomberg News)

title: Cards Shove Braves to the Edge
description: For two games, the Atlanta Braves have been ambushed at Busch Stadium, outplayed and overwhelmed by a team that looks intent on dethroning the defending National League champions.

title: Ball Park Brands Selects Two Agencies
description: Ball Park Brands in Southfield, Mich., a division of Sara Lee that sells the Ball Park line of meat products, has awarded its advertising and media planning accounts to two units of the B Com3 Group in Chicago. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YATES, CONGRESSMAN SIDNEY R.
description: YATES-Congressman Sidney R., 91, beloved husband of Adeline, nee Holleb, devoted father of Hon. Stephen (Debra) Yates, loving grandfather of Jonathan, Lauren and Carolyn. Services Sunday, 11:00AM at Temple Sholom, 3480 N. Lake Shore Dr., Chicago. Interment Memorial Park Cemetery, Skokie, IL. Memorials may be made to the A.L.S. Therapy Development Foundation and sent to The Stephen Yates Fund C/O A.L.S. Therapy Development Foundation, 44 Glen Ave., Newton, MA 02459. Messages may be sent: www.everlastingmemories.com. For information call The Piser Chapel, (888) 67-PISER (74737).

description: Amid a laser light show, the sellout crowd roared with delight as the Stanley Cup stood at center ice.

description: California's electricity market is not ''workably competitive'' and needs to be fixed, the California Power Exchange said in a draft report.
