title: Hole in Ozone Layer Stretches Over Chile
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 6  The hole in the ozone layer over Antarctica stretched over a Chilean city when it ballooned to a record size last month, scientists reported this week.

title: Masur's Own Epiphany in 'St. Paul'
description: From the day he arrived as music director of the New York Philharmonic in 1991, Kurt Masur wanted to present Mendelssohn's serenely beautiful oratorio ''St. Paul,'' an early masterpiece that seldom turns up on programs today. As a Mendelssohn champion who held the same post the composer once did, music director of the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra, Mr. Masur could not believe that the Philharmonic had never played the work.

title: Cyberscout: Bidding For a Trip Online
description: THERE is good reason why Internet auctions have sapped millions of working hours from businesses and chained otherwise attentive parents to their PC's on evenings and weekends. Not only can auctions yield bargains, but there are few other places where you can compete against a potential pool of hundreds of millions of people and emerge as the winner.

title: Article 2000100790980665816 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Engineers Work on Glitch as Cassini Snaps Picture of Jupiter
description: PASADENA, Calif. -- NASA's Cassini spacecraft, en route to a 2004 rendezvous with Saturn, snapped its first image of the giant planet Jupiter as engineers worked to understand a communications problem with a companion probe.

title: The Tenacity of Madeleine Albright
description: Washington tried out a succession of policies toward Slobodan Milosevic during his 13 years in power, courting him, cajoling him and finally opposing him with air strikes and economic sanctions. But Madeleine Albright, first as the representative to the United Nations and then as secretary of state, never wavered in her conviction that Mr. Milosevic was a dictator and aggressor and that only his departure from power would assure the triumph of peace and democracy in Southeastern Europe. Her own background as a refugee from tyranny in Czechoslovakia taught her that such men could not be appeased but must be opposed forthrightly. The events of the past few days in Yugoslavia have vindicated her persistence, and President Clinton's willingness to follow her instincts.

Not only can auctions yield bargains, but there are few other places where you can compete against a potential pool of hundreds of millions of people and emerge as the winner.

description: The civility was short-lived. At two rallies today celebrating Dick Cheney's performance in a debate with Senator Joseph I. Lieberman that was variously described as gentlemanly, mannerly and downright friendly, Republicans unleashed some of their strongest assaults yet on Vice President Al Gore's credibility.

title: Lingerie That Loves the Limelight
description: MILAN  Four years ago, the designer Petra Pistoletto created for the Florence Biennale della Moda a pale pink and white sleeveless wedding gown replete with train.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERESEY, JAMES F.
description: KERESEY-James F. Of Upper Brookville, NY on October 5, 2000. Age 74. Loving husband of Jane for 49 years. Devoted father of Michael, Virginia and Kevin. Brother of John, Ann and Diane. Grandfather of five. A U.S. Marine Corps survivor of Guam and Iwo Jima, past President of the Creek Club, member of Augusta National and the Links. Memorial service St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY, Tuesday, October 10th at 11 AM. Contributions may be made to the Marine Corps Law Enforcement Foundation, P.O. Box 37, Mountain Lakes, NJ 07046.

description: Marion Berry, a Democratic representative from Arkansas, has raised Congressional arrogance to a new level.

description: There is no future for small farmers in New York State. Everybody knows that.

description: Tuvia Grossman, 20, a Chicagoan who has been studying at a yeshiva in Jerusalem for two years, set out from school with two American friends on the High Holy Day of Rosh Hashana last week to pray at the Western Wall in the Old City.

title: INTERNET SERVICE COMPANY LOSSES
description: Burdened by an acquisition spree at home and abroad, one of Europe's biggest Internet service companies, Wanadoo of France, said its first-half net loss swelled to 66.9 million euros, or $58 million, on revenue of 456.3 million euros, compared with a net loss of 1.9 million euros in all of 1999. Wanadoo, which is controlled by France Telecom, raised 1.9 billion euros in July in an initial offering to the public. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: When to Ruff Partner's Ace (First, Be Sure You're Right)
description: Most defenders have enough to do in attempting to solve their own problems. On a higher plane altogether are those who foresee that partner is about to have a problem, and solve it for him by taking charge of the defense. The diagramed deal, an elegant example, was played in a league match in Sweden, long a power on the international bridge scene.

title: Lazio Reverses Stance on Ads Allies Paid For
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio last night repudiated his decision to use money from his Washington allies to buy commercials in the New York Senate race, trying to avoid damaging his credibility on an issue that has become a cornerstone of his candidacy.

title: Bush Says the Clinton Administration Waged a Lackluster War on Illegal Drugs
description: Gov. George W. Bush today accused the Clinton administration of fighting illicit drugs ''without urgency, without energy and without success'' and proposed $2.7 billion in new grants in the next five years to combat narcotics and provide drug treatment.

title: The Sure Thing: El Duque in October
description: Orlando Hernandez was in slacks and a leather jacket when he bumped into Yankees Manager Joe Torre in the basement hallway of Yankee Stadium a few minutes before midnight last night. Hernandez extended his hand. ''Todo bien,'' he said. All is well.

title: E.D.S. Wins Record $7 Billion Contract for Navy Computer Network
description: The largest information technology contract ever awarded by the government, worth nearly $7 billion, has been won by the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the United States Navy said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Sojo Leads Cashman's Cavalry
description: LUIS SOJO didn't trip last night. Instead, he tripped the Oakland Athletics, knocking in one run, scoring another and starting a flashy double play in the Yankees' 4-2 victory for a 2-1 jump in their American League division series.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Bowler Briefed in Torts, Not Retorts
description: On NBC's ''Providence,'' Tom Cavanagh played a recurring character called Dog Boy, a man who identifies with dogs. Maybe it's coincidental, but on NBC's new romantic comedy series, ''Ed,'' Mr. Cavanagh gets doggy again, playing a man with many canine qualities: his puppyish Ed Stevens is loyal, affectionate and eager to be loved.

title: Seminoles Are Next In Miami's Climb Back
description: The Florida State quarterback says he has recovered from a sprained left ankle, his coach isn't so sure, and the Miami Hurricanes are just sorry that any sort of subplot may diminish a game they believe they are due to win -- though they have lost the two teams' last five meetings by an average of 22 points.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Lazio's Refund
description: Representative Rick Lazio's decision to refund to the Republican National Committee the roughly $1.4 million he accepted from the party to help pay for television commercials touting his candidacy was a necessary act of damage control. Although accepting the money was legal, it violated the terms of the campaign financing agreement under which he and his opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, agreed not to use outside funding in their campaigns.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILLSTEIN, GEORGE S.
description: MILLSTEIN-George S. 10/7/25-11/ 20/95. Celebrating our 75th Birthday without you is very painful for me. I think of you and love you always. Your twin sister, Annie

title: WESTPOINT STEVENS PLANS TO CLOSE TWO PLANTS
description: WestPoint Stevens Inc., the biggest maker of bedding and towels in the United States, said it would close two plants in North Carolina and South Carolina and lay off 565 workers as it consolidates manufacturing to cut costs. One plant, which makes towels, is in Roanoke Rapids, N.C. The other, which makes bed pillows and mattress pads, is in Union, S.C., the company said. WestPoint Stevens will have 32 factories after the plant closings, which are part of a revamping plan announced in June. The company said then it would also seek to contract with other manufacturers to make some of its products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDERLIP, CAROLE ANN
description: VANDERLIP-Carole Ann (previously Cam Newell, nee McGillicuddy), sculptor and author, died September 19th at her home in Chelsea, England of brain cancer. She was well loved by her husband Kelvin, who can answer all inquiries at (011) 4420 7581-8344. A memorial service will be held on October 20th at 5:30 P.M. at Our Lady of Pompeii, Carmine Street. Family flowers only, please.

description: It would be ''make or break.'' It would be Kennedy-Nixon. Bush might drool. Gore might explode. At MSNBC, the breathless anchor predicted an audience ''as high as 90 million'' -- 10 million more than the record set by Reagan-Carter in '80. Democracy in action, baby!

title: Holidays on Monday
description: Columbus Day, actually Oct. 12, will be legally observed. Yom Kippur is also observed on Monday.

description: NEW YORK -- Olmedo Saenz quickly rocketed a three-run homer off Roger Clemens, and Barry Zito and Oakland's bullpen made sure the lead held up.

description: Bette Midler takes on a TV series playing perhaps the most challenging role of her career: herself. A report by Lynn Hirschberg in The Times Magazine.

description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 -- He thinks the slam-dunk has hurt basketball and should be banned. He believes that star players have overwhelmed the team spirit of the game. The purest basketball, he says, is being played by women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESLOW, HAROLD
description: BRESLOW-Harold. We will always remember Harold laughing and enjoying his sweet grandson Nate. Our hearts are with his beloved wife Bea, his daughter Lori and our dearest friends Ellen and Sam Newhouse and their children S.I., Ben and Nate. Sandra, Sam, Robert and Cary Wasserman

title: Charge in Stadium Case Dropped Against Father in Baby Death
description: A Queens judge agreed yesterday to dismiss the most serious charge from a Shea Stadium bottle-throwing incident involving Brian C. Peterson, who pleaded guilty in 1998 to manslaughter in the death of his newborn son.

title: 2 Held in Abuse of Boy, 7, on Bus
description: A school bus matron was on duty, along with the driver, in a van where the police say two Brooklyn boys sexually abused a younger schoolmate, officials said yesterday.

title: Studies Find Race Disparities in Texas Traffic Stops
description: Black and Hispanic motorists across Texas are more than twice as likely as non-Hispanic whites to be searched during traffic stops while black drivers in certain rural areas of the state are also far more likely to be ticketed, according to two studies examining possible racial profiling.

description: THE HOUSE

title: Jobless Rate Hits A 30-Year Low
description: The Labor Department said that the unemployment rate in September fell to 3.9 percent, matching a 30-year low, and that 252,000 nonfarm payroll jobs were created. The report sent stock prices down on fears that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates in the future and on expectations on Wall Street of weaker profit growth in the just-ended third quarter.

title: Prospects of a 5-0 Start May Prove Significant
description: If the Jets beat the Pittsburgh Steelers at Giants Stadium on Sunday to go 5-0, they are, historically speaking, virtually assured of going to the playoffs. In the past decade, 14 clubs opened at 5-0 -- 13 of those teams earned playoff berths, 11 won division titles, 7 reached the Super Bowl and 5 won it all.

title: Pitt Looks to Keep Turnaround Going Against Syracuse
description: Pittsburgh is perhaps a victory away from entering the national college football polls and about half a season away from moving into a new stadium. With a few more players like Rod Rutherford and Antonio Bryant, the Panthers might be close to returning to the good old days when Tony Dorsett and Dan Marino siphoned some attention from the city's main sports attraction, the National Football League's Steelers.

title: The Revolution Was the Easy Part
description: Let us all stand and cheer the people of Serbia. Though heavily drugged by Slobodan Milosevic's opportunistic nationalism, they have finally awakened from their nightmare and dispensed with the man who has so devastated the stability of the Balkans. This was a truly popular revolution, carried out with determination and in pursuit of noble goals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVITZ, SY
description: SAVITZ-Sy. On October 5, 2000 at age 74. Adored husband of Nita. Loving father of Jane and Tony Mangiaracina and Susan and Michael LaValle. Devoted grandfather of Bianca, Jayson, Michelle and Michael. Dear brother of Judy Rand. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, 11:30 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Neurological Research Fund, c/o Dr. Michael Fetell, Room 204, Columbia University, 710 W. 168th St., NYC 10032 or The Bertolli Brain Tumor Lab, c/o Dr. Jeffrey Bruce, Room 434, 710 W. 168th Street, NYC 10032.

title: Clinton Demurs on Drug Imports and Cuba
description: President Clinton expressed reservations today about Republican proposals to allow wholesalers to re-import low-cost American-made prescription drugs and to ease trade sanctions on Cuba, a day after House and Senate negotiators approved both proposals.

title: Keeping Shoes In the Family
description: MILAN  It was tourists from the beaches on the Adriatic coast coming inland to buy sandals from the local artisans that gave birth to San Mauro Pascoli's footwear industry. It eventually evolved into a production center of prestigious footwear, some of whose brands are known throughout the world.

title: Financial and Technology Stocks Send Markets Lower
description: Stocks plunged yesterday, led by declines in financial and technology stocks, as investors worried about corporate earnings disappointments and dismissed what was generally a positive employment report for September.

title: Ondieki Paces Fairleigh Dickinson
description: Steve Ondieki, a graduate student at Fairleigh Dickinson, successfully defended his title in 24 minutes 15.6 seconds for five miles to lead the Knights to the team crown with 23 points in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

title: Argentine Vice President Quits to Protest Scandal
description: Vice President Carlos Alvarez of Argentina resigned yesterday to protest a cabinet reshuffling that left two officials in place who have been implicated in the possible bribing of senators to pass a new labor code.

title: New Control Tower Being Rebuilt in Miami
description: The mark of a good air traffic control tower, say the controllers who guide the commercial jets on, off and across busy runways, is actually being able to see the planes.

title: Squeezed Out: Mariners Sweep Anemic White Sox
description: When the pinch-hitter Carlos Guillen of the Mariners shocked everyone by squaring around to bunt in the bottom of the ninth inning today, he pushed the ball past pitcher Keith Foulke, first baseman Frank Thomas and second baseman Ray Durham of the White Sox.

title: At Last, Recognition and Praise for the Resistance in Nazi Germany
description: When the British historian A. J. P. Taylor declared in the 1960's that German resistance to the Nazis was a myth, his was a widely held view. Even today many people in Germany and elsewhere believe there was little internal opposition to Hitler.

title: Touring Belgrade Ruins, in Pride and Sorrow
description: A perfume shop on one of Belgrade's main shopping streets, Terazije, is called Scandal, and it is owned by Marko Milosevic, son of Slobodan.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL PRICES RECOVER. For the first time in four days, prices of crude oil rose yesterday. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light crude oil for November delivery traded at $30.86 a barrel, up 33 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KHAZANEH, DR. ABBAS
description: KHAZANEH-Dr. Abbas. On October 6th, 2000 at age 74. Beloved husband of Rafat. Father of Amir, Manda, Ali and Mamad. Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday, October 12th, 3:00 PM.

title: Designers Move Into Aristocratic Havens : The Style Kings' Palaces
description: MILAN  From the outside, 7 Via San Damiano looks like just another austere Milan building, with nary a name accompanying either of the two buzzers on its gray facade. But beyond the heavy wooden door bursts a rococo extravaganza of crimson velvet-covered walls, multicolored Murano glass chandeliers, gilded mirrors and zebra-skin throw rugs  the private headquarters where the fashion designers Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana hold business meetings, entertain clients and eat lunch.

title: IRISH UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS
description: Irish unemployment fell to 3.8 percent in September, the lowest figure since 1981, according to figures released by the Central Statistics Office. The number of people receiving social welfare support from the government dropped 22 percent from September 1999, although the immediate decrease is partly because of the reopening of schools and universities.

title: Court Says Lab Rats Deserve Special Care
description: In what is seen as a significant victory for animal rights advocates, a federal court ruled yesterday that the most commonly used laboratory animals -- mice, rats and birds -- will have to be given care under the relatively stringent rules of the Federal Animal Welfare Act.

title: MetroStars Fume After Fire Advances With Late Goal
description: The third time was the charm for Chicago. The Fire edged the MetroStars, 3-2, in the third match of their Major League Soccer semifinal playoff series tonight, and clinched a berth in the M.L.S. Cup final on Oct. 15 in Washington.

title: Oakland Rookies Carefree Approach
description: With a sheepish grin, Oakland's Barry Zito admitted that the last big game of championship implications that he pitched was, well, in the Cape Cod League two years ago when he was 20. "That sounds like college," he said with a laugh, and quickly changed his answer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTNER, JANE ELLEN
description: ORTNER-Jane Ellen. On October 5, 2000. Beloved wife of Charles. Loving mother of Amy and Eric. Devoted sister of Ann and Dr. Michael Rosen and Dr. Jeffrey and Margo Gold. Cherished daughter of the late Dr. Theodore and Belle Gold. Proud aunt of Dana, Barrie, Seth, Alexander and Julia. Jane was a dedicated, passionate and inspiring teacher and friend. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Jane Ortner Multiple Myeloma Research Fellowship, C/O Clyde B. Jones III at Weill Medical College of Cornell University, 525 East 68 Street, Box 123, NYC 10021. Services were held.

title: CNA FINANCIAL SELLS LIFE REINSURANCE HOLDING
description: The CNA Financial Corporation, the second-largest business insurer in the United States, said yesterday that it agreed to sell its United States life reinsurance operations to a unit of Munich Re, the world's largest reinsurer, for an undisclosed price. The sale to Munich American Reassurance Company comes two months after the Chicago-based CNA took its life insurance business off the block after being unable to find a buyer at an acceptable price. Munich Re said the sale would double its life reinsurance business in the United States.

title: Sparks of Lyrical Meditation Fly From the Cutting Edge
description: Although it's risky to generalize about the nature of avant-garde cinema, it is reasonably safe to say that most experimental films are either exercises in perception or investigations of filmmaking technology. Often they are both. In tone and attitude, however, they still tend to fall into two types: personal, lyrical statements that invite us into private meditative worlds, and more abstract modernist works that affect an emotional detachment and aesthetic objectivity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCTAGGART, ALLAN
description: McTAGGART-Allan. A successful architect. Passed away on June 17, 2000 and is survived by a brother Cecil of Tennessee, son John of Vermont, daughters Wendy of Ontario and Leslie of Hawaii. There are also four grandchildren.

title: 2nd New Jersey Community Bans Cell Phones on the Road
description: Hoping to be part of a wave of local laws that will force the State Legislature to act, Carteret has become the second community in New Jersey to ban the use of handheld cellular phones while driving.

title: Democracies at U.N. Gather for First Caucus
description: In this truly multicultural organization, there are caucuses of almost every imaginable kind -- region, geographical classification (small islands, landlocked countries and so on) and even religion (Islamic nations). But until today, there was no caucus of democratic nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, SOPHIA B.
description: CASEY-Sophia B. On October 5, 2000, of Roslyn Harbor. Beloved wife of the late William J. Casey, former Director of Central Intelligence. Loving mother of Bernadette Casey Smith and her husband Owen T. Smith. Dear sister of Lillian Kurz and Joseph Kurz. Loving aunt of Noel Glenn, Carol Murray, Thomas Langan and many loving grand-nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends at the Casey residency (Mayknoll) 12 Glenwood Road, Roslyn Harbor, Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 11:00 AM, St. Mary's RC Church, Roslyn Harbor. Interment, Holy Rood Cemetery. She was a Dame of the Order of St. Gregory and the Order of Holy Sepulchre.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: School Finds Loaded Gun
description: School officials shut down a middle school in Suffolk County yesterday after a loaded handgun, apparently left during a security training session, was discovered in the building on Thursday night.

title: Republican's Unusual Gift: A Vote on the House Floor
description: For years, a measure to condemn the mass killings of Armenians in Turkey 85 years ago as genocide languished in Congress. That was before James E. Rogan's seat was in jeopardy.

title: Clinton Welcomes Rise of New Leader, and Promises to Help Lift Sanctions
description: President Clinton hailed the victory of Vojislav Kostunica today, stressing that it was a triumph for the people of Yugoslavia and promising to work with Europe to lift economic sanctions.

title: The Yanks Hope Fans Can Help Against the As
description: Derek Jeter finished packing Wednesday night in Oakland and then wrote a check to the attendant for the visiting clubhouse for the customary tip baseball players give for receiving a few days of food and services. Jeter walked across the clubhouse and handed the check to the attendant, who then cheerily said, "See you on Sunday." Jeter looked at the attendant and quickly said, "I hope not."

title: Art Athens, 61, Host of Radio Shows
description: Art Athens, a veteran New York radio correspondent and host whose broadcasts sometimes made the news as well as reported it, died yesterday near his home in Hudson, N.Y. He was 61.

title: The Forecast for Shea: Loud, With a Strong Chance of Drama
description: Darryl Hamilton, the Mets outfielder and a former Giant, was discouraged by the razzing he got from the fans at Pacific Bell Park in the first two games of the Mets-Giants division series.

title: China Rushes to Adopt Genetically Modified Crops
description: Until Monsanto introduced a genetically altered cotton plant here in the buckle on the Chinese Cotton Belt three years ago, farmers like Ma Yuzhuo sprayed their fields with tons of organophosphate pesticides to kill bollworms, grubs that feed on immature cotton bolls.

title: Most Powerful Quake in 5 Years Hits Western Japan, Injuring 100
description: The most powerful earthquake in five years struck western Japan today, injuring more than 100 people, damaging many buildings and disrupting electricity and train service to the region.

title: In Defense of Free Speech
description: Four years ago, facing the very real prospect that a hostile Republican Congress would put it out of business, the federal Legal Services Corporation agreed to accept a set of harsh restrictions on the sort of work that lawyers supported by the program could perform on behalf of their poor clients. That fateful bargain gave rise to an awkward showdown in the Supreme Court on Wednesday, as lawyers for the corporation and the Clinton administration tried to defend one of the more pernicious elements of the G.O.P.'s assault. That was the restriction limiting the kinds of arguments that Legal Services lawyers can make on behalf of welfare clients.

title: Suddenly, the A's Look Overmatched
description: Derek Jeter finished packing Wednesday night in Oakland and then wrote a check to the attendant for the visiting clubhouse for the customary tip baseball players give for receiving a few days of food and services. Jeter walked across the clubhouse and handed the check to the attendant, who then cheerily said, ''See you on Sunday.'' Jeter looked at the attendant and quickly said, ''I hope not.''

title: LOWE'S SAME-STORE SALES TO MISS FORECASTS
description: The Lowe's Companies said fiscal third-quarter same-store sales would miss forecasts because of lower lumber and building materials prices and the integration of the Eagle Hardware and Garden Inc. chain. Lowe's said sales at stores open at least a year would rise at a ''low-single'' digit percentage rate in the quarter ending Oct. 27, less than the 4 percent to 6 percent gain it previously expected. Sales were hurt as Lowe's converted the Eagle chain into its own stores. Lowe's, based in Wilkesboro, N.C., bought Eagle last year for $1 billion in stock. Sluggish sales at Lowe's, the nation's No. 2 home-improvement chain after Home Depot, come as rising interest rates and gasoline prices push consumers to slow spending, analysts said.

title: Man, 83, Dies in Collision With Police Car
description: An 83-year-old Staten Island man died early yesterday, hours after his car collided with an unmarked police car that had been responding to a shooting, the police said.

title: Court in Moxley Case to Hear Probation Report on Skakel
description: A juvenile court judge in Stamford, Conn., has scheduled a hearing later this month to discuss a biographical report on Michael C. Skakel, the Kennedy relative charged in the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley in Greenwich.

title: Undercutting the Notion Of Brazil as a Sex Symbol
description: Sergio Bianchi's ''Chronically Unfeasible'' is a blunt and mordant fist in the ribs of Brazil's middle class. Close in spirit to Luis Bunuel's attacks on the bourgeoisie's infatuated gazes at itself, the film has a big heart that's both in the right place and on its sleeve.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DOMINION RESOURCES INC., -- Richmond, Va., the top integrated electricity and natural gas company in the United States, agreed to sell $948 million in commercial loans held by its First Source Financial unit to GE Capital Commercial Finance, a unit of the General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn.

title: U.S. SEEKS MORE DATA ON BID MADE BY TRANSOCEAN
description: Transocean Sedco Forex Inc. said the Justice Department had asked for more information about the company's proposed $8.4 billion purchase of a rival oil driller, the R & B Falcon Corporation. The request was not expected to delay the transaction from being completed in the first quarter, the companies said. In August, Transocean agreed to buy R & B Falcon to create the world's largest fleet of offshore oil and natural gas drilling rigs. The Justice Department is studying the planned union to see how it might affect competition. Transocean shares rose $1, to $56.94, in early trading. R & B Falcon rose 63 cents, to $27.06. Both companies are based in Houston. (Bloomberg News)

title: Running Mates, Ready to Fight, Kept Gloves On
description: The day before his debate with Senator Joseph I. Lieberman in Danville, Ky., Dick Cheney said he hoped to set a ''pleasant and professional tone'' there. Nonetheless, he and his coaches made sure he went to the table armed with attack lines, just in case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENGROVE, SYLVIA M.
description: DENGROVE-Sylvia M. On October 5, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Jay L. and H. Bruce. Dear sister of Elaine Mendlowitz. Service Sunday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Protecting All Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTOS, DON FLORIANO
description: SANTOS-Don Floriano. The members of Loeb Block and Partners mourn the loss of their dear friend, Don Floriano Santos, of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. For more than thirty years we shared joys and sorrows together. A big man with an even bigger heart, respected businessman, loving father and grandfather. His presence will be missed.

title: Gonzalez Taps Boras as Agent
description: DETROIT, Oct. 6  Juan Gonzalez, the two-time American League most valuable player who spent a laregly unhappy season in Detroit, has hired Scott Boras as his new agent as he prepares to become a free agent, The Detroit Free Press reported yesterday.

title: MILOSEVIC CONCEDES HIS DEFEAT; YUGOSLAVS CELEBRATE NEW ERA
description: Bowing to a vast popular revolt against him, a pale Slobodan Milosevic resigned tonight as Yugoslavia's president, ending 13 years of rule that have brought his country four wars, international isolation, a NATO bombing campaign and his own indictment on war crimes charges.

title: Monitors Commend Police On Effort to End Profiling
description: The two monitors overseeing the New Jersey State Police Department's effort to end racial profiling commended the force yesterday for its first steps toward that goal.

title: Franks Defends Claims on N.R.A. and Labor Support
description: After keeping his Democratic opponent, Jon S. Corzine, on the defensive for weeks, Representative Bob Franks, the Republican candidate for Senate, suddenly found himself dealing with problems of his own making today.

title: Strahan Tight-Lipped About Coach's Remarks
description: An animated, emotional, fast-talking Michael Strahan finally responded today to the criticisms made by the Giants' defensive line coach. Or as close as he would get.

title: Bell to Miss Rest of Year, but Help Is Here
description: In Game 2, the Mets benefited from the continuing emergence of Timo Perez and the clutch contribution of Darryl Hamilton in the 10th inning. As the division series with the Giants continues, those contributions may be needed again because the Mets learned yesterday that right fielder Derek Bell would be lost for the postseason.

title: Aide to Starr Is Acquitted Of Contempt
description: The former spokesman for the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr was acquitted today of trying to hide his role in leaking information about Mr. Starr's investigation of President Clinton.

title: Modified Corn in Tacos
description: To the Editor:

title: Nearly 40% of Fourth Graders Fail Writing Test
description: New Jersey education officials revealed yesterday that nearly two-fifths of public school fourth graders failed the state's standardized writing test in 1999 and 2000, even after the results were adjusted.

title: Tehran Journal; The 2 Lives of a Newly Minted Cleric
description: The black cloak was draped over his shoulders, nearly covering his neatly pressed long gray robe. The white turban carried on a gladiola-covered tray was placed on his head. Grand Ayatollah Nasser Makarem-Shirazi, one of the most senior religious leaders in Iran, expressed confidence that the new cleric would carry on the work of his father, a beloved senior ayatollah from Shiraz who had died a few days before. The crowd of several thousand cheered, ''Praise be to God!'' over and over.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Page A6 last Saturday about fighting in Jerusalem gave an erroneous identification from The Associated Press for a wounded man shown with an Israeli policeman. He was Tuvia Grossman of Chicago, an American studying at a Jewish seminary in Jerusalem, not an unidentified Palestinian. In some copies the caption also included the news agency's erroneous reference to the site. The incident occurred in an Arab neighborhood of Jerusalem, not on the Temple Mount or elsewhere in the Old City.

title: Article 2000100794156619078 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Pataki Orders State Records On Doctors To Be Posted
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation today that requires the state to provide New Yorkers with extensive information about malpractice judgments and disciplinary actions against doctors practicing in the state.

title: A Version Of My Job, Made for TV
description: OLIVER PLATT, an engaging and intelligent actor, dropped by the newsroom a few months ago. He was preparing for his starring role as a newspaper columnist in ''Deadline,'' a new NBC series that got rolling the other night.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FISHER, STANLEY
description: FISHER-Stanley. Remembered every day. Deeply missed. Love, All Your Family

title: Bolivia Makes Key Concessions to Indians
description: The Bolivian government today agreed to a broad range of demands by Indian peasant leaders, buckling under the pressure of three weeks of road blockades that paralyzed the economy, caused food shortages and threatened to force the resignation of President Hugo Banzer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENTEN, MOLLY
description: ENTEN-Molly, age 96. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Adored mother of Judge Harold Enten (Barbara). Loving grandmother of Louise and Harry. Will be deeply missed. Services at Garlick-Riverside, 1439 Unionport Rd., Bronx on Sunday, October 8th at 10AM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, ESTHER L.
description: ROSENTHAL-Esther L. Died on October 7, 1999. I think of you everyday with love and gratitude. I miss you, Mommy. Love, Judy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILLS, NATHANIEL L.
description: SILLS-Nathaniel L., 93 years. Devoted husband of the late Ruth, father of Larry and Susan, Arthur and Sarah, Peter and Susan, grandfather of Deborah and Adam, Eric and Leah, Matthew, Dylan, Daniel and Noah, greatgrandfather of Jacob, Eli & Laila. He was Chairman of the Board of Standard Motor Products but his main passion was his family. He had a profound influence on all of us. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Forest Hills. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to American Parkinson's Disease Association, 650 West 168 St, NYC 10032.

title: The Heat Is on a Texas Town After the Arrests of 40 Blacks
description: On the morning of July 23, 1999, Billy Wafer, a forklift driver, was swept up in the biggest drug sting in local history: In this town of only 4,500 people, 43 suspects were arrested on charges of selling small amounts of cocaine. In some cases, hometown juries later meted out sentences ranging from 20 years to more than 300 years.

title: Debate Drew 28.5 Million
description: The vice-presidential debate on Thursday between Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut and Dick Cheney was watched by at least 28.5 million people, the second-smallest audience on record for a vice-presidential debate, according to Nielsen Media Research data.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARDAWAY, CHARLOTTE
description: HARDAWAY-Charlotte Cubberley, known to friends and birth family as ''Chickie'', died October 3, after a long illness, in Mesa, AZ. She was the daughter of Howard and Charlotte Cubberley (deceased), and summered with them and her sister Edna (d. February 10, 1999) for many years on Cape Cod. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, and Tenafly, NJ, Chickie had lived year-round on the Cape since 1969, following separation from her husband, Ben F. Hardaway (d. October 17, 1995). She was a graduate of Tenafly High School, and attended Bucknell University in her freshman year. She is survived by her children, Ben F. Hardaway IV of Manassas, VA; Charlotte E. Hardaway of Tucson; Anne H. Robinson of Glendale, AZ; Peter R. Hardaway of Wellfleet, MA, and six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

title: Sports of The Times; One More Time, Franco Is a Closer
description: Three thousand miles from where John Franco was staring at potential ruin to a baseball season, from a distance so much safer to make the call, Joe Gambuzza talked to the television as if it had ears and the ability to pull the string on Barry Bonds.

title: Article 2000100791499032369 -- No Title
description: Questions on Wired Schools

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Florida and Texas

title: As Affluent Nassau Faces Debt Troubles, All Sides Ask Why
description: Nassau County is attracting rubberneckers, and not just those crawling past accidents on the Long Island Expressway. Like a suicide in high society, the county, in its current fallen financial state, brings out a morbid curiosity among finance experts, academics, politicians and, closest to home, residents themselves.

title: For One Brief but Crucial Moment, Hudson Shows His Age
description: Oakland starter Tim Hudson, the team's 20-game winner in his first full major league season, will think about his second-inning misplay and want to rewind it in his mind.

title: Oliver Gets Much More But Not in a Cereal Dish
description: Ninety minutes into Masterpiece Theater's six-hour rendition of ''Oliver Twist,'' even people only vaguely acquainted with the Dickens novel may be asking themselves a basic question: where the heck is Oliver?

title: The Race for No. 2: A Debate With a Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: Jobless Rate Fell to 3.9% In September
description: Unemployment fell to 3.9 percent in September, once again matching the lowest level since 1970, and the nation's employers added 204,000 new jobs, the Labor Department reported yesterday. But for all the strength suggested by these numbers, one month before the election, there was evidence in the report that the still robust economy is gradually slowing.

title: Political Memo; Police Report Rekindles The Mayor's Fiery Side
description: The summer came and went with few confirmed sightings, but there was no mistaking it at City Hall this week. The combative, finger-pointing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was back, as the erstwhile gentler, friendlier mayor reasserted a style he had set aside last spring after his diagnosis of prostate cancer.

title: When 1980's China Went Pop, Discovering Pink Polyester and Spandex
description: The subject of ''Platform'' is nothing less than the social and cultural transformation of China in the 1980's, the slow waning of Maoist orthodoxy and the gradual arrival of Western popular culture and clothing styles.

title: Article 2000100790320360241 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Power Plant In Thailand Is Criticized
description: Thailand's national utility plans to sell to the public this month 40 percent of a power plant that is the exclusive customer of a natural gas project in Myanmar connected to the Unocal Corporation.

title: DE BEERS WANTS BAN LIFTED
description: For the first time since it began to reduce its diamond stockpile in a strategic shift, De Beers, the world's biggest diamond company, signaled publicly that it wanted talks with the United States Justice Department to lift a ban on trading in the United States. Antitrust regulators in the United States have accused De Beers of using its hold on the diamond trade to fix prices. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro drifted lower yesterday, but the damage was limited as dealers struck a cautious tone ahead of a long U.S. holiday weekend. In New York, the euro settled at 86.84 cents, down from 86.92.

title: Prosecutors Cancel First Appointment to Debrief Wen Ho Lee; No New Meeting Has Been Set
description: Three and a half weeks after the former Los Alamos scientist Wen Ho Lee entered a plea agreement that the government said would resolve urgent issues of national security, the government has not yet scheduled a meeting with Dr. Lee.

title: Isles Salvage Tie in Opener
description: If the Tampa Bay Lightning is any barometer, the Islanders are an improved team from last season. That's how Islanders Coach Butch Goring sees it. A year after losing to the Lightning in their regular-season opener, the Islanders tonight opened their season with a 3-3 tie before 20,686, a record for the Ice Palace.

title: CREDITORS WILL DIVIDE DAEWOO MOTOR
description: In an attempt to sell off ailing Daewoo Motor by a self-imposed Oct. 20 deadline, creditors of the company, South Korea's second-largest carmaker, said that they would break up the company and sell off the separate units to different buyers.

title: Cardinals Sweep Braves
description: ATLANTA -- The St. Louis Cardinals dealt Atlanta another postseason disappointment, sweeping the Braves out of the opening round of the playoffs with shocking ease.

title: Transportation Spending Bill Is Approved
description: Rebuffing for the moment an attempt to stiffen auto safety laws, Congress passed a $58 billion transportation spending bill today.

title: LTV, NO. 3 STEEL CONCERN IN U.S., IS GIVING UP 2 PLANTS
description: The LTV Corporation, the No. 3 steel company, said it would hand over two plants to USX-U.S. Steel Group, suspend its quarterly dividend and buy back shares. U.S. Steel said the transaction would cost it about $95 million in pensions, severance and other employee expenses. It plans to close one of the plants, in Aliquippa, Penn., that makes tin-coated steel for use in food cans, and to lay off 400 workers. It will keep open a similar mill in East Chicago, Ind. Cleveland-based LTV said it would take a $180 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings for the sale. The company is selling and shutting businesses to focus on steel making and processing after having losses for seven quarters, largely, it says, because of competition from low-price imports.

title: INSIDE
description: Yankees Lead Series; Seattle Sweeps Chicago

title: Tottering Through a Landscape Without Hope
description: The nicest way to put it might be that ''Eureka'' is a movie that takes its time. During the second half of this murky, dawdling three-and-a-half-hour meditation on trauma and healing, written and directed by Shinji Aoyama, the camera trails its four major characters as they drift around southwestern Japan in a large bus.

title: The Race for No. 2: A Debate With a Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: Arch Deal Moves Forward
description: Arch Wireless Inc., the second-largest paging company in the United States, came closer to closing its acquisition of a bankrupt rival, Paging Network Inc., by getting shareholders' approval for the deal today. The approval came a day after a federal bankruptcy court shot down the competing bid by Metrocall Inc. PageNet is based in Dallas, and Arch is based in Westborough. Shares of Arch fell 28 cents, to $4.09, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Times Square Marchers Protest Killing of Palestinians
description: Several thousand demonstrators gathered south of Times Square during the evening rush yesterday to protest the killing of dozens of Palestinians by Israeli soldiers in recent days and what they characterized as blind American support for Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACRI, ROSE A.
description: MACRI-Rose A. On October 5, 2000. Sister of the late Angie, Mary Lynch, Fanny Geraci and the late Edward and Frank Macri. Visiting Sunday and Monday 2-5PM and 79PM at M.J. Smith Sons Funeral Home, 248 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, New York. Mass of the Resurrection Tuesday 10AM at Holy Name Church. Interment at St. John's Cemetery.

title: E-ZPass Is Not Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: SmithKline Is Said to Bid for Block Drug
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. is a front-runner in the bidding for the Block Drug Company of Jersey City, the maker of Sensodyne toothpaste and Polident denture cleaners, a person close to SmithKline said today.

title: Remarks by Milosevic, Clinton and Key Serbs
description: Following is the statement by President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia accepting the election of Vojislav Kostunica to succeed him, as broadcast by CNN:

title: Insuring Children
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPEFRENCH ECONOMY EXPANDS The French econ- omy expanded 0.7 percent in the second quarter, the same pace as the first three months of the year. The slide of the euro aided exports, while rising oil and borrowing costs hurt consumer spending, which slowed to 0.2 percent. That was the smallest gain in spending in more than a year, and down from 0.8 percent in the previous three months. Surging oil prices have raised gasoline costs 27 percent in two years.

title: STOCK OF HYPERION SOLUTIONS, SOFTWARE CONCERN, DROPS
description: Shares of the Hyperion Solutions Corporation fell as much as 44 percent after the company, a software maker, said it had a fiscal first-quarter loss on lower-than-expected license revenue. Hyperion shares fell $7.38, or 38 percent, to $12. Earlier, they touched a 52-week low of $10.88. The plunge was the biggest percentage drop in the stock since the company first sold shares to the public in November 1995. The company, which makes programs that help large companies analyze data like sales results and payroll information, did not disclose the size of the loss. Officials at Hyperion, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., could not be reached for comment.

title: FRENCH ECONOMY EXPANDS
description: The French economy expanded 0.7 percent in the second quarter, the same pace as the first three months of the year. The slide of the euro aided exports, while rising oil and borrowing costs hurt consumer spending, which slowed to 0.2 percent. That was the smallest gain in spending in more than a year, and down from 0.8 percent in the previous three months. Surging oil prices have raised gasoline costs 27 percent in two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELDZAELER, HORTENSE
description: GELDZAELER-Hortense. Of Toronto, Canada, on October 4, 2000 in her 103rd year. Beloved mother of Emily L. Grant (Eugene) of Mamaroneck, NY, Alfreda Henry, and the late Phyllis Weisfeld of Toronto; devoted grandmother of Barbi Weisfeld, David Weisfeld, Robert Henry and Carol Henry of Toronto; Terry Grant of Charlottesville, VA, Andrea Grant and Carolyn Grant of Boulder, CO; and doting great-grandmother of Jordana, Andrew and Alexis Clarfield, Lesley and Brett Henry, and Jamie Weisfeld of Toronto; and Samantha Grant Pardee and Jordan Grant-Krenz of Boulder, CO. Born in NYC in 1897, she became an accomplished pianist and singer, working with music publishers in Tin Pan Alley. In WW I, she served with a USO troupe entertaining Canadian and American troops departing for overseas, and met a young Canadian officer, the love of her life, the late Bernard Geldzaeler of Toronto, Canada, whom she married on his return from Europe. An effervescent personality and a superb entertainer, Hortense was an active leader at Holy Blossom Temple, Toronto, for many years. She was an elegant and charming presence throughout her life and brought untold happiness to all who knew her. Funeral services at Holy Blossom Temple, Toronto, Canada were held held Friday, October 6th. Eugene and Emily Grant

title: VEECO INSTRUMENTS STOCK TUMBLES ON EARNINGS WARNING
description: The shares of Veeco Instruments Inc. tumbled yesterday after the company, a maker of disk drive components, warned that it would miss its third-quarter revenue and earnings estimates. After the financial markets closed Thursday, the company, based in Plainview, N.Y., said it expected third-quarter earnings of 18 cents to 22 cents a share. That projection was below its earlier guidance of 38 cents to 42 cents a share. It also forecast that sales for the third quarter would be $93 million, down from the $104 million expected. Veeco Instruments attributed the decline to a $7 million sales shortfall for its recently acquired CVC unit. It said the shortfall would reduce earnings for the quarter by 15 cents a share. Shares of Veeco Instruments were down $34.97, at $67.56.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   YATES, SIDNEY R.
description: YATES-Sidney R. 1909-2000 IN MEMORIAM TIRELESS ADVOCATE OF HUMANITY AND THE HUMANITIES Rabbi Irving Greenberg, Chair Ruth B. Mandel, Vice Chair Sara J. Bloomfield, Director United States Holocaust Memorial Museum 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place S.W. Washington D.C. 2002

title: Perennial Combinations That Add to Fall Colors
description: BLUE STARS, flowering spurge, bowman's root: there's no hint of autumn splendor in their names, and yet combinations of these native perennials provide powerful color boosts to fall gardens.

title: This Texan, Too, Has a Lot Riding on Bush's Campaign
description: THE State Capitol is quiet as Lt. Gov. Rick Perry ambles out of his corner office behind the Senate chamber and greets two visitors in the ornate hallway. He is heading ''out in the country'' for a fund-raiser later in the day, so he is wearing a white polo shirt and cowboy boots embroidered with the Texas flag.

title: The Race for No. 2: A Debate With a Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: British Telecom's Finance Director Resigns
description: British Telecommunications, which has been facing mounting criticism as its debt balloons, said today that its finance director was stepping down.

title: At a Crucial Moment, Hudson Shows His Age
description: Oakland starter Tim Hudson, the team's 20-game winner in his first full major league season, will think about his second-inning misplay and want to rewind it in his mind.

title: William P. Bundy, 83, Dies; Advised 3 Presidents on American Policy in Vietnam
description: William P. Bundy, who under three presidents was a central figure in Vietnam policy and who ultimately concluded that the war was ''a tragedy waiting to happen,'' died yesterday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 83.

title: WCBS-TV Charges for Debate Broadcast
description: Television station WCBS, which is the host of tomorrow's debate between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio, has asked radio networks that want to broadcast the event to help defray the costs of the production.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Using Bankruptcy As a Takeover Tool; Russian Law Puts Healthy Companies at Risk
description: The Novokuznetsk Aluminum Plant here turns out 276,000 tons of metal a year, more than 10 percent of Russia's total production and enough to build more than 3,500 Boeing 747's.

title: European Union, Congratulating the Serbs, Will Begin Lifting the Sanctions on Yugoslavia
description: Moving quickly to show support for the opposition leader Vojislav Kostunica, the European Union announced today that its foreign ministers would meet on Monday to begin lifting sanctions imposed on Yugoslavia in 1999.

title: Beliefs; A Vatican office attacks pluralistic relativism, and the resulting fallout is spread far and wide.
description: On Sept. 5, Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, who heads the Vatican's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, issued a document titled ''Dominus Iesus'' (''The Lord Jesus'') that condemned certain ''relativistic theories'' of religious pluralism. A month later, the dust has still not settled.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Thursday about Rhoda H. Karpatkin, the president of Consumers Union, gave an incorrect figure supplied by Consumers Union for the number of paid subscribers to its Web site. It is 475,000, not 350,000.

title: Abroad at Home; Milosevic and Bush
description: Just 36 hours after the first presidential debate came those unforgettable scenes in Belgrade as the Serbs reclaimed their destiny. They underlined what may be the most important question in our election: Could George W. Bush as president deal wisely with the crises of the world?

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Today's KEY GAMES

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I've just received official information that Vojislav Kostunica won the elections.''

title: Slimline Stallone, With a Bruising Touch and a Gentle Mutter
description: In its first few moments ''Get Carter'' worms its way into the small but select sub-phylum of vacuous and overdirected minor classics like ''Kalifornia'' and others that inhabit the recesses of the Movie Channel in the predawn hours on a weeknight. It's so minimally plotted that not only does it lack subtext or context, but it also may be the world's first movie without even a text.

title: Gore Campaign Sees Florida as Ripe for the Picking
description: The ''magic place'' that Vice President Al Gore was talking about today was Walt Disney World, but in political terms, it could easily have been the state of Florida, which is becoming increasingly central to a strategy that his campaign believes could give him a landslide victory in November.

title: MARCONI TO TRADE ON NASDAQ
description: Marconi, a British phone equipment maker, said it planned to list its shares on the Nasdaq the week of Oct. 16. Marconi also reported a 40 percent rise in half-year sales.

title: National Editor Named by The Times
description: The appointment of Katherine J. Roberts as national editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Joseph Lelyveld, the executive editor. It will take effect after Election Day.

title: Without Fanfare, Morning-After Pill Gets a Closer Look
description: Each month, at least one woman comes into Katterman's Sand Point Pharmacy in Seattle to ask for a prescription drug. None of the women have seen or spoken to a doctor but each says she needs the drug immediately.

title: The Race for No. 2: A Debate With a Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: Torre Hopes Coaches Get a Shot to Manage
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks asked for permission to interview the Yankees' hitting coach, Chris Chambliss, for their managerial vacancy, and similarly, Philadelphia will talk with the third-base coach, Willie Randolph, about the possibility of his replacing Terry Francona as the Phillies' manager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOSPER, DENA BROWN
description: VOSPER-Dena Brown. In Guilford, October 3, 2000, of 35 North St., Guilford CT. Wife of the late Richard Waynard Vosper. Mother of Dinah Hatfield Vosper of Guilford, CT. Sister of Dorothy Brown Fugate of Greenfield, MA. Also survived by three nieces, JoDean Fugate of Wilmington, DE, Judith Fugate-Bahiri of New York City, NY, and Jana Fugate Cummings of Greenfield, MA, and three great-nieces Christina and Colleen Kreisel of Wilmington, DE, and Emma Mae Cummings of Greenfield, MA. Predeceased by two brothers, Jack and Melvyn Brown. Mrs. Vosper was a former librarian at Yale University Department of Public Health and Epidemiology. Prior to Yale, she had been a librarian at Dartmouth College and she was also employed at the US State Department, during WWII. A Graveside Service will be held in Cornish, NH at the convenience of the family. Services in care of the Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church St, Guilford, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUTKA, LEONARD M.

Beloved husband of Charlotte. Devoted father of Elaine, Mark and Richard. Loving father-in-law of Irene. Doting grandfather of Annie B. and Zoe C. Brother of Seymour and Robert. Fighting against insurmountable odds in his battle with Lou Gehrig's Disease, he displayed the courage, selflessness and dignity that typified his entire life. A devout humanist, family man, proponent of social justice, our ''Rock'' and inspiration, he will be sorely missed. Contributions to the ALS Association 818-880-9007 or the Rick Dutka Memorial Fund c/o the Tides Foundation 415561-6400. title: Songs That Won't Be Written
description: Much of the discussion in this week's hearing in federal appeals court over whether Napster violates federal copyright law focused on how the online music service affects big record companies and recording artists. But they are not the only ones being hurt by Napster, which helps people share music on the Internet, and companies like it. Songwriters like me, who depend on the royalties they earn from the sale of their songs, are also being injured.

title: CANADA'S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE DROPS
description: The unemployment rate in Canada dropped to 6.8 percent in September from 7.1 percent in August, as 56,300 new jobs were created -- the largest number so far this year and twice as many as economists had expected. The biggest employment gains were in the service sector, but renewed strength was also evident in manufacturing and construction. Derek Burleton, senior economist at the TD Bank Financial Group, said monthly job increases of 25,000 to 30,000 in the final quarter would probably drop Canada's unemployment rate to 6.6 percent by the end of the year, matching the 24-year lows of early summer. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Barak Issues 48-Hour Ultimatum to Arafat
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 7 - At the end of a day in which the Israeli-Palestinian conflict spread into Lebanon and threatened to engulf the region, Prime Minister Ehud Barak issued Yasir Arafat a 48-hour deadline for restraining violent protests before Israeli troops would be authorized to use ``all available means'' to quell the riots.

title: Even Prison Can Be Fun If Walls Bend
description: The theme of imprisonment has been popular in French Canadian and European modern dance. The latest piece to go that route is ''Bagne,'' presented by PPS Danse of Montreal on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. There is no solid four-walled prison, though the title of the dance is said to translate colloquially to ''slammer.'' Bodies do slam against walls for much of this 70-minute duet. But, tellingly, those walls are made of metal mesh that gives with the impact. ''Bagne'' is one of the gentlest and least brutal prison pieces to career through New York. It has more on its mind than exploring a threadbare metaphor.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL TO TOUGHEN LAWS ON FORCED LABOR
description: The House overwhelmingly approved a wide-ranging measure today that toughens laws against the trafficking of women and children for prostitution and sweatshop labor and helps states and localities fight domestic violence.

Leonard (Lorraine) and Kenneth (Antoinette); grandmother of Paul, Jane Lewittes (Michael), Daniel, Jonathan (Sarah), Abigail, and Maayan; great grandmother of Joshua, Jack, and Sophie. Matriarchal aunt and teacher of generations of Shulamith school girls. Funeral services will be held at the Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51 St., NYC at 9:30 AM, Sunday, October 8.

Loving mother of Diana & Peter, beloved ''Gran'' to Josh, Elliott and Lilly, adored sister to Herbert, died on October 4th, 2000 after a valiant fight that rarely slowed her down. She was a faculty member of the Department of Speech & Theater at Montclair State University for over 25 years. She will always be remembered for her love of family, her many dear friends, travel, the fine arts & everything British. She died as she lived, on her own terms with great dignity and independence. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 7th, at 2 PM at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Ave. at 80th St.; reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Doris Bianchi Senior Award, C/O Montclair State University Foundation, 1 Normal Ave., Upper Montclair, NJ 07043. ''The show must go on.''

title: Dine Like Rabelais (Till the Bill Comes)

They were labeled ''poison for the king'' and ''poison for the dauphin.'' When the innkeeper found them after the meal, he immediately had Rabelais arrested and transported to Paris, where he was welcomed by the king with hearty laughter at the free trip and the bill-avoiding scheme.

title: Crime
description: Sunny Randall has some identity issues. Although she's not the wuss she was when Robert B. Parker introduced her in ''Family Honor,'' the newly minted Boston private eye has yet to develop a voice, let alone a personality, of her own. There are moments in PERISH TWICE (Putnam, $23.95), notably in polite but guarded conversation with pimps, hookers and hard guys, when she sounds just like Spenser. (''It's what I do,'' she tells a gangster who admires her style. ''I try to find out stuff. I like the work.'') The Spenserian air of amused detachment is hardly suitable, though, for this story about an assortment of women having emotional breakdowns because of troubled relationships, and when Sunny tries to be her own woman, she either freezes up or goes to pieces.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-08-00: Album; Portrait of a Failed Marriage
description: Two new books -- The Unexpected Legacy of Divorce,'' by Judith S. Wallerstein, Julia M. Lewis and Sandra Blakeslee, and ''The Case for Marriage,'' by Linda J. Waite and Maggie Gallagher -- have renewed the debate over the once-scandalous, now commonplace phenomenon of divorce. The first study suggests that children of divorce suffer more than we suspect, and the second suggests that the long-term benefits of staying together are greater than we realize. To those who choose to end their marriages, of course, sociological analyses are irrelevant; it is always a personal decision, and usually a painful one. Most who make that choice do so just a few years after marriage. But the seven people featured on these pages spent decades together before parting ways. One couple fell victim to infidelity, another came apart when one spouse realized he wasn't who he thought he was, a third simply drifted apart. Yet another -- overshadowed by the demands of work -- later managed to reconcile. Here, they talk frankly about why they made such a radical change after so many years together.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Quadrennial Madness
description: Evan Cornog and Richard Whalen's HATS IN THE RING: An Illustrated History of American Presidential Campaigns (Random House, $39.95) fills in the gaps of dimly remembered high school history classes. If you cannot recall what the Federalists stood for, or who Tippecanoe was, or when Wendell Willkie ran for president, then it will serve as an entertaining primer. Short chapters on each election convey basic historical information: who ran, who won, what issues mattered and how the campaigns were conducted. The text is illustrated by numerous prints, political cartoons and photographs, and peppered with primary sources and anecdotes. We learn, for example, that ''Franklin Pierce commissioned Nathaniel Hawthorne, his former classmate at Bowdoin College, to write a campaign biography. When Horace Mann heard about the project, he quipped that if Hawthorne succeeded in writing an inspiring biography of the undistinguished Pierce, it would be 'the greatest work of fiction he ever wrote.' ''Cornog, the author of ''The Birth of Empire: DeWitt Clinton and the American Experience, 1769-1828'' and an associate dean at Columbia University's School of Journalism, and Whalen, the author of biographies of Robert Capa and Alfred Stieglitz, discuss the enormous influence of the founding fathers; not only did they create a constitutional system, but they also established such a moral standard that for close to a century, politicians refused to campaign extensively, lest they appear more power-hungry than Washington or Jefferson. Even in 1900, observers considered William Jennings Bryan's whistle-stop tour of the country ''begging for the presidency as a tramp might beg for a pie.'' The authors even celebrate the gradual acceptance of campaigning and the decline of the stigma of self-interest, arguing that it creates at least the possibility of open contests and informed electorates. Douglas A. Sylva

Those dancers will perform the usual blend of the old, represented by a revival of Asadata Dafora's 1932 classic, ''Awassa Astrige/Ostrich,'' and the new, epitomized by ''Children of the Passage.'' title: PAROLE BOARD
description: Robert Egles, the executive director of the New Jersey Parole Board, returned last week to his $87,000-a-year post after a six-week medical leave, but he may not be there for long. Kenneth Connolly, who served as acting executive director in Mr. Egles' absence, said recently that there was no change in Mr. Egles' job status, but, he noted, ''His status is being reviewed and that final review could be complete any day now.'' Mr. Connolly said the review was not related to any investigation. ''He expressed an interest about doing something else on the board,'' said Mr. Connolly. ''It's a situation where there needed to be continued discussions and to figure out a place where to best use his talent.'' If Mr. Egles were to leave, he would be the second high-ranking official in the troubled state agency to vacate his position. In July, the board's chairman, Andrew M. Consovoy, resigned while under investigation by the state attorney general amid allegations he gave favorable treatment to several inmates with links to organized crime. George James

title: Despite Divorce, Children Need Both Parents
description: As the wife of a man who is a loving and devoted father to his two children by a previous marriage, I have watched in dismay as the courts and the system treat him as not much better than a criminal. It is assumed that he is guilty, negligent, delinquent and not interested in the children's welfare. As a feminist, I never imagined I'd be championing the rights of a group of men, but injustice and prejudice know no gender.

title: A Document By Cuban Spy Talks of Acts Against C.I.A.
description: When he was arrested by the Mexican government this week, a Cuban spy on the run from his government was carrying a document, parts of which were made public today, in which he outlined his career running operations against the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DISCOVERING THE BODY By Mary Howard. Morrow, $24.

title: Read My Tie: No More Scandals
description: EARLY this year, when Vice President Al Gore was ostensibly under the stylistic tutelage of the writer Naomi ''release-your-inner-alpha-male'' Wolf, he showed up in New Hampshire for a primary debate with Bill Bradley looking more like someone trying to sign Minnie Driver to a three-picture deal than a politician aiming to lead the free world. On Jan. 26, Mr. Gore wore a snug three-button suit that wasn't quite dark enough, a shirt of French blue that appeared at once too French and too blue, and a horizontally striped tie. The look brought a rejoinder from DNR, the men's wear trade journal, deploring ''fashion offenses bordering on the impeachable.''

title: The Flight From Fortress Salinger
description: DREAM CATCHER

title: Jillian Backus, Brendan Sullivan
description: Jillian Courtney Hubbard Backus, a daughter of Theresa Backus and Dennis L. Backus of Mill Neck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Brendan Patrick Sullivan, a son of Gene Sullivan and Dr. Gregory Sullivan of Upper Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Paul E. Gilbert performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, N.Y.

title: Walking on Air
description: EVERYONE strolls the Brooklyn Bridge, or should. The George Washington has its pedestrian devotees, as does the Williamsburg. But what about the other bridges in the city, a total of 2,027, according to The Encyclopedia of New York City? With the right P.R., might tourists be posing for their photos on the Queensborough, the Goethals, the Pulaski?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MISHKIN, HARRIET
description: MISHKIN-Harriet. On October 6, 2000 at age 61. Beloved wife of Edwin. Loving mother of Andrew and David. Dear sister of Samuel Furgang. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday 7-9 PM with service Tuesday 9:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: The Anchor
description: Giorgio Armani is considered an artist by those who covet his clothes, so it makes sense that his 25th anniversary as a designer will be commemorated with a retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum. The show, opening on Oct. 20, will feature sketches, photographs and over 300 garments by Mr. Armani, who is known for his classic lines and his Hollywood following. The designer is a mainstay of the power elite on this coast as well. Last Monday, the ''Good Morning America'' co-host Diane Sawyer wore Armani to the star-studded Project A.L.S. benefit at the Manhattan Pavilion. She was a beacon in a sea of black wearers (including Uma Thurman and Juliana Margulies) as she navigated the room in a hot pink satin suit. The 80's-inspired outfit, with its sleeveless tie-neck top, was glitzier than Armani's typical offerings, but Ms. Sawyer said that if she was of-the-moment it was only by chance. ''I'm a seriously sweat pants kind of gal,'' she said. ''Forget about the clothes. Why don't you write about the fact that I'm still standing at the end of the day? That's my greatest achievement.'' JENNIFER TUNG

title: Pamela Ferris, Keith Muller
description: Pamela Danielle Ferris, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Ferris of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Keith Edward Muller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Muller of Mahwah, N.J. Msgr. Thomas J. McDade performed the ceremony at the Church of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Franklin Lakes, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELDZAELER, HORTENSE
description: GELDZAELER-Hortense. Of Toronto, Canada, on October 4, 2000 in her 103rd year. Beloved mother of Emily L. Grant (Eugene) of Mamaroneck, NY, Alfreda Henry, and the late Phyllis Weisfeld of Toronto; devoted grandmother of Barbi Weisfeld, David Weisfeld, Robert Henry and Carol Henry of Toronto; Terry Grant of Charlottesville, VA, Andrea Grant and Carolyn Grant of Boulder, CO; and doting great-grandmother of Jordana, Andrew and Alexis Clarfield, Lesley & Brett Henry, and Jamie Weisfeld of Toronto; and Samantha Grant Pardee and Jordan Grant-Krenz of Boulder, CO. Born in NYC in 1897, she became an accomplished pianist and singer, working with music publishers in Tin Pan Alley. In WW I, she served with a USO troupe entertaining Canadian and American troops departing for overseas, and met a young Canadian officer, the love of her life, the late Bernard Geldzaeler of Toronto, Canada, whom she married on his return from Europe. An effervescent personality and a superb entertainer, Hortense was an active leader at Holy Blossom Temple, Toronto, for many years. She was an elegant and charming presence throughout her life and brought untold happiness to all who knew her. Funeral services at Holy Blossom Temple, Toronto, Canada were held on Friday, October 6th. Eugene and Emily Grant

title: 24-Hour Spots Are Attacked as Inconvenience Stores
description: Residents of College Point say a concentration of 24-hour convenience stores in the neighborhood are more of a nuisance than a convenience.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the retirement of Dominic Baranello, the longtime Democratic Party chairman of Suffolk County, misidentified the first Democratic presiding officer of the county Legislature. It was Floyd S. Linton in 1975, not Sondra M. Bachety in 1988.

title: Rodents Just Want A Nice Home: Yours
description: HAVE you been hearing strange sounds at night? Does your dog or cat get excited for no apparent reason? And what exactly was that you saw out of the corner of your eye?

title: Fairness of New York Condemnation Procedures at Issue in Property Owners' Lawsuit
description: Bill Brody says he would have challenged this village's condemnation of the four downtown buildings that he owned and had just renovated into office and retail space, and that Port Chester officials plan to turn over to a developer for a Stop & Shop supermarket.

title: The Unending Travails of Life Near a 'Sewage Chernobyl'
description: Living with foul odors is a way of life for Harlem residents who live near the North River Water Pollution Control Plant. But now the city plans to decrease environmental monitoring of the site, and residents are furious.

title: The New Guard
description: Clair Watson, Creative Consultant

title: Emelin Theater Offers Series of Cabaret Acts
description: THE Emelin in Mamaroneck gave theater a good run, with season after season of homegrown productions of plays. But the audiences weren't there.

title: A Little-Known Threat
description: WHEN mercury spilled in the basement of Frank and Susan Giampiccolo's home in Tarrytown in August during a routine pressure test of the gas lines, it became a homeowner's nightmare.

title: Diary: Keep Working and Stay Healthy
description: Americans are now expected to spend decades of their lives  not years  in retirement, and that may not be a good thing, according to a researcher at the International Longevity Center-USA, a nonprofit group in New York.

title: Food; Buried Treasure
description: At $1,500 a pound for fresh whites, truffles may be the most expensive food in the world. Considering their price, are they as overrated as all but three movie directors, the cleverness of Bruce Vilanch and any five minutes in the Hamptons? Or are they worth the money? The answer -- if they are perfectly prepared, as they are below -- is yes, thunderingly so.

title: Article 2000100892042327876 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Betting on the Old Economy Puts Three Managers Ahead
description: AFTER a wild ride during the third quarter, many mutual funds ended up about where they started. But some of the smallest and narrowest funds gained more than 20 percent.

title: In Evanston, Ill., a Downtown Revitalization
description: AFTER languishing for more than 10 years, downtown Evanston, Ill., is experiencing a threefold increase in development this year with an estimated $200 million worth of new residential and commercial projects under way.

title: College Mansion Tours Set
description: NOOKS and crannies, hidden staircases, secret hideaways -- just your typical 1930's Tudor-style suburban architecture.

title: Accents
description: To the Editor: It's a charming, and certainly appealingly counterintuitive, notion that the letter ''A'' does double duty as the name of a town, as well as serving as ''the last letter of the Norwegian alphabet'' (''In Norway, Cod, Caves and White Nights,'' Sept. 10). Unfortunately, that's not the case. As in most Western European languages, ''A'' is the first letter of the alphabet; the last letter is an A with a small circle over it (pronounced AW).

title: Sauna
description: To the Editor: Saunas may be relaxing, restful and invigorating, as Edmund L. Andrews suggests in his article about Finland, ''Sauna-of-the-Month Club'' (Sept. 24). But the absence of warning signs should not lead travelers to conclude that there are no risks.

title: The Monumental Shift In Parental Roles
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEATHERINGTON, FRANCES
description: HEATHERINGTON - Frances. Painter, died October 4, 2000. A memorial gathering will be held at her studio, October 11, 4 PM.

title: FILM; A Moment From the Past Recovers Its Sound
description: A STYLISHLY dressed man with a mustache plays a violin into a phonograph horn. Two other men waltz arm in arm beside him. Then a man wearing a visor ducks into the frame, as if to adjust a piece of equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILFILLAN, MARIJANE
description: GILFILLAN-Marijane. On October 6, 2000, at age 67. Longtime employee of the Village Voice. Loving sister of Sue Ann Converse. Aunt of Anthony and Alexander Converse. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Friends in Deed, 594 Broadway, NY, NY 10012.

title: Hostility Toward Israelis Resurfaces in a Wave of Violence
description: As violent clashes continued unabated today between Israelis and Palestinians, the anger that has churned across the Middle East since the violence began last week suggested that the polarization of Muslim opinion may have sharply reduced prospects for an overall peace settlement, even if the violence can be curbed.

title: Tests Detect Communications Problem in Craft Bound for Saturn
description: Three years out from Earth and almost four years away from Saturn, its destination, the Cassini spacecraft is undergoing a round of in-flight equipment and communications tests, and these have exposed one malfunction that could severely reduce the amount of science data received from the mission's probe of Saturn's moon Titan.

title: In Cumbria, Spotlight On an Ancient Kingdom
description: A grass-roof building, the largest in Britain, containing a large-screen theater has opened in the Lake District of England. Rheged, as the 80,000-square-foot center is called, is the name used to refer to the region's Ancient Kingdom of Cumbria, which existed between 400 and 700 A.D. The structure, which was designed by Jak Jones, a local architect, is in a natural hollow in the landscape. Sunlight enters through seven glass atriums; interiors include babbling brooks, limestone crags and waterfalls -- features found in the surrounding countryside.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 24 about the whitewater course at the Olympics in Sydney used an outdated name for the White Plains-based manufacturer of the six pumps that create the rapids. The company is ITT Industries, a successor to the ITT Corporation.

title: Boys and Girls of Every Age Want to Get Into the Act
description: LAST Sunday morning in a boxing gym here, a teenage girl was getting slapped around by an older boy. As they circled each other in the ring, she suddenly reared back and unleashed a flurry of punches and kicks.

title: Catherine Lewis, Dean Hamilton
description: Dr. Catherine Fiona Lewis and Dean Corning Hamilton were married yesterday by the Rev. Matthew H. Calkin, an Episcopal priest, at the Christ and Holy Trinity Church in Westport, Conn.

title: More Funds Using Outside Managers
description: Mutual funds are sold, not bought, the saying goes. That sales-driven philosophy is behind the growing number of companies using outside managers to run their funds.

title: On the Alert in Alaska for Salmon and Bears
description: Adozen half-eaten salmon lay scattered on a gravel bar, remnants of a grizzly bear's recent breakfast. Apparently, similar to the way humans approach a lobster, grizzlies prefer the meaty parts; heads and guts are left for the gulls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KHAZANEH, DR. ABBAS
