description: KHAZANEH-Dr. Abbas. On October 6th, 2000 at age 74. Beloved husband of Rafat. Father of Amir, Manda, Ali and Mamad. Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday, October 12th, 3:00 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DURR, ERNESTINE
description: DURR-Ernestine. The people of Saint Peter's Church a congregation of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, gives thanks to God for the life and witness of Ernestine Durr, who died on August 24, 2000. An active member and generous supporter of Saint Peter's Church for most of her life, Ernestine served as a member of the Parish Council of Saint Peter's and was particularly strong in her support and encouragement of the Jazz Ministry, which has earned Saint Peter's its designation as ''The Jazz Church''. Beloved benefactor of the Choir School of Saint Thomas Church, much loved by her friends in the Choir School and at Saint Peter's, she lived her life ''clothed with compassion'', and as a valiant and faithful servant of the Lord. A memorial Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated at 11:00 Saturday morning, October 14th at Saint Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue at 54th Street. A reception in the Living Room will immediately follow the Mass.

title: Albuquerque
description: To the Editor: Re your coverage of the Big I Reconstruction Project in Albuquerque, N.M., ''Road Work Could Slow New Mexico Tourists,'' (Aug. 20) by Catherine C. Robbins, we recommend that visitors stay on I-25 and I-40 whenever possible rather than using city streets to bypass the construction zone. Traffic on city streets is already congested. We also recommend that visitors allow an extra 15 to 20 minutes to reach their destinations.

title: Corrections
description: An automobile review of the Honda Civic last Sunday misidentified the models on which antilock brakes are available. They are standard on the most expensive Civic, the EX, but are not available on other models.

title: Ad on Gold Medal Precedes Coverage
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGANSTERN, SYLVIA
description: MORGANSTERN-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Leo, dearest mother of Susan, on Sunday, October 1. Sleep well.

title: The Accidental Vice President
description: Weeks before the 1980 Republican convention, Ronald Reagan asked me to vet the people he was considering for vice president. This occurred at a meeting in his suite at the Waldorf-Astoria. William Casey, campaign chairman, and Edwin Meese were also there. I remember Reagan saying how dismayed he had been by the spectacle of the parade of candidates to Plains, Ga., in 1976. He said that he wanted the process carried out with the greatest confidentiality.

title: Willeman Captures U.S. Young Rider Title
description: Sarah Willeman of Hamilton, Mass., scored 362 points in a four-rider showdown to win the United States Equestrian Team's young rider championship, the first leg of the equitation triple crown, yesterday in Gladstone, N.J.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Environmental-Bond Issues Are on 2 Towns' Ballots
description: THE Nassau County towns of North Hempstead and Oyster Bay have approved referendums for Nov. 7 on spending a total of $45 million for acquisitions of open space, environmental restoration, park improvements and ground and surface water protection.

title: Defending the Dutch
description: To the Editor:

title: For 'Smart Growth' Advocates, a Baptism by Fire
description: IN late February, over 500 people crowded into a downtown Huntington theater to spend the next four days discussing community development issues. This was neither a dry academic forum nor a boisterous antidevelopment rally.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-08-00: On Language; To No Avails
description: Because George W. Bush was frequently answering questions on a variety of subjects from reporters on his campaign plane, his aides noticed that their chosen message of the day at major events was not getting through. ''Because Gore wasn't doing avails like that,'' said Karen P. Hughes, ''the networks were using shots from his events.''

title: Fuzzy Morality
description: Every public opinion poll suggests that the Bush-Cheney ticket has no more loyal supporters than the millions of men and women of faith who care about family and life issues. How surprising, then, that those voters have had their hearts broken in two consecutive debates, as they watched first a lackluster defense of the sanctity of life, and then a surrender on the defense of traditional marriage.

title: PULSE; Red Hot Nets
description: Fashionistas who braved frigid weather with bare legs last winter are looking forward to a reprieve this season as stockings make a comeback. But not so fast. The happening hosiery right now is open weave stockings -- especially fishnets. Richard Tyler, Anna Sui, Vivienne Westwood and Helmut Lang had fishnets in their Fall 2000 shows. Wolford is carrying them in small and large stitch ($35 to $40) in nine colors for fall: off-white, honey, pink, lilac, mango, magenta, brown and the hue-of-the-moment -- red. The fishnets aren't meant to be trashy, a la Madonna in her ''Lucky Star'' video, but more as a kicky touch to the preppy woolens also in vogue. Christina Perrin showed fishnets with hot pants and miniskirts in her fall collection as well as a wide-windowpaned version with a ladylike suit. ''I find fishnets incredibly sexy, especially if they have a shimmer and great texture,'' she said. To incorporate the fishnet look into everyday fashion, and take the streetwalker out of it, Ms. Perrin suggests wearing red fishnets, for example, ''with boots, paired with something caramel.''

title: Together Again
description: It's a real shift for Chita Rivera, who is to make the transition from a sexy chanteuse on a luxury liner in a Cole Porter musical to an elderly madam in a seedy godforsaken town.

title: Introduction
description: Our special issue drew mail from former and native New Yorkers who said they, too, have stories to tell. A prosecutor offers a different perspective on a young felon. And prominent members of the 1980 Reagan campaign dispute that Gerald Ford was nearly chosen as ''co-president.''

title: Our Place in the Balkans
description: We once celebrated the Prague Spring; we now have the Milosevic Fall. After a little rejoicing over what seems to be the final political demise of Slobodan Milosevic, we should consider the broader meaning of his imminent departure. Does it vindicate, as some suggest, those arguing in this campaign season for peacekeeping interventionism?

title: From Cotton Fields To Dance Halls, An Outsider's Journey
description: ABOUT 25 years ago, I got a telephone call from my friend Mike, who asked me if I wanted to go to a party at Tom Luddy's house in Berkeley, Calif. I didn't particularly like Berkeley, and at the time Mr. Luddy was the head of the Pacific Film Archive; film was another thing I wasn't into. Then Mike said the magic words: ''Dewey Balfa will be there.'' He meant Dewey Balfa of the Balfa Brothers, the Cajun band that had introduced the folk scene to the wealth of astonishing music Southern Louisiana had to offer. ''I have to pick him up and drive him over there,'' Mike said. ''So be at my house at seven.''

title: Mariners Are Quick to Give Credit to a Calmer Piniella
description: Even after relocating to the mellow Pacific Northwest in 1993, Lou Piniella never seemed particularly pacifistic. When the Mariners' manager mimicked Mount St. Helen's, his temper tantrums created a cartoon caricature that clouded his success.

title: In a Co-op, Parking Is A Privilege
description: Q: A little more than two years ago, my wife and I bought two ground-floor co-op apartments and joined them together. We rented one parking space in the basement garage because the president of the co-op told us we could park our second car in front of a driveway adjacent to our terrace. (The driveway was chained off by the superintendent to prevent other cars from using it.) Some months later, we were advised that other residents would be allowed to park their cars in the driveway for up to 20 minutes -- when we weren't parked there -- to unload groceries from their cars. Now we are being told that we can only park our car in the driveway for 20 minutes to unload groceries. Does the co-op have the right to withdraw our parking privilege after two years? . . . Sidney G. Adler, Lawrence, N.Y.

title: Lazio Portrayed as an Ostrich
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign will begin broadcasting this 30-second commercial in upstate New York tomorrow.

title: A Little Guilt, in Season
description: I was parking my white rental car near the top of a high-end residential canyon in Los Angeles where I was staying last month with a friend. Opening the door, I left a tiny white dot on a neighbor's black Porsche. The next day, to my dismay, the same thing happened again, so there were two tiny white dots on the Porsche. I tried unsuccessfully to rub them off with my thumb. All week long, as I got in and out of my car, those two little white dots haunted me like a pair of eyes in the dark.

title: Forever Young
description: Cathy Rigby, a former Olympic contender and world champion in gymnastics, stars in a new musical version of ''Peter Pan,'' on A&E tonight at 8.

title: Chafee Legacy Central To a U.S. Senate Race
description: Some say there is a dead man running in the race for Rhode Island's United States Senate seat.

title: A. J. Croce, on Guitar
description: A. J. Croce is known for his piano playing and his ability to write distinctive, insightful blues and jazz songs. His work demonstrating those talents has filled three albums since he began a recording career in 1993.

title: The Big Island's Royal Enclave
description: LOOKING up, we saw shimmering water, backlighted by the sun, roaring over and in front of us. Below was a gaping green chasm, a 200-foot drop to a pool below. Beneath our feet, a rocky ledge four feet wide was all that protected us from free fall. It was heaven.

title: Plan to Muffle Rifle Noise Fails to Mollify the Neighbors
description: Barney, the 80-pound black-and-tan coon hound who lives on Tier Street on City Island, was a nervous wreck the other day. The bombs were going off again at Rodman's Neck, the police firing range across the water. Through the year, almost 41,000 officers, 216 a day, trek to the range to unload rounds from their handguns, punctuated by shotgun blasts, cracks from assault rifles and the baroque outbursts of the bomb squad detonating all the dangerous stuff found around the city.

title: Perennial Combinations That Add to Fall Colors
description: BLUE STARS, flowering spurge, bowman's root: there's no hint of autumn splendor in their names, and yet combinations of these native perennials provide powerful color boosts to fall gardens.

title: A Star Everywhere Else, a Stranger at Home
description: LITTLE wonder that Lucinda Childs is fluent in French these days. Her choreography may be quintessentially American, a product of her early training with Merce Cunningham, her years at the Judson Dance Theater and her long association with Robert Wilson, Philip Glass and John Adams. But when it comes to pursuing her career, this tall, striking New Yorker leaves her SoHo loft and invariably heads for Europe, usually France.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 24 about an exhibition at Art on Main Street/ Yonkers included an erroneous credit from the gallery for a photograph of a gated entranceway. The photographer was Susan Parslow, not Arnold Kastenbaum.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Speculative Warehouses Head South on Turnpike
description: THE development of big boxy warehouses continues its march southward along the New Jersey Turnpike, most recently arriving at Exit 6A, where an industrial park is under way that will ultimately contain eight million square feet of space.

title: Pipeline Route Change Draws Fire
description: EVEN statistics showing natural gas pipelines as the safest way to transport energy don't ease the worries of Neil Miller, a homeowner in Ossining.

title: Two Seminars to Aid Business Start-Ups
description: Arranging financing will be one of the topics at free seminars for potential business owners on Oct. 25 from 6 to 8 p.m. at the White Plains Library and on Oct. 28 from 10 a.m. to noon at the Katonah Village Library.

title: Homicide Charge in Parking Lot Dispute
description: A 27-year-old Bronx man was charged last night with killing a Midtown parking lot manager by punching him in the face during a dispute, the police said.

title: 90 Candles, and a Second Wind
description: IT'S 11 a.m., her private yoga session is over and she's dressed to the nines in a beige gabardine Oscar de la Renta suit and brown hat, a triple strand of pearls gracing her neck. The monogrammed handkerchief with which she occasionally dabs at sniffles is the only sign that she braved a cold rain the night before to attend the Rose Garden dinner-dance at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Over tea, she sits in the library of her Park Avenue apartment, examining a printout of her daily schedule. There will be lunch at Cafe Boulud, a trustees' meeting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and in the evening a Louis Armstrong concert at Carnegie Hall, followed by a benefit dinner where flashes will pop upon her arrival.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GENSER, SIDNEY
description: GENSER-Sidney. October 8, 1998. Love you and miss you. Take care of Mommy. Love, Barbara

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SITTNER, BEATRICE C.
description: SITTNER-Beatrice C. Of Yonkers, NY on October 3, 2000, at age 92. Born in NYC to Benjamin and Hattie Steckler Cohen, Bea was the wife of the late William Sittner. She was a cherished mother and surrogate mother, poet, editor of the newsletter at Nyack Manor Nursing Home, and member of the Ethical Culture Society of Riverdale. She was humble, funny, inquisitive, compassionate and passionate, devoted, and generous in giving of herself. Above all, she was much loved by many people. Bea leaves behind daughters, Barbara and Carol.

title: Idling Buses Leave a Stain of Pollution on a Jewel of a Park
description: People talk about Madison Square Park as though it were an elegant lady with awful taste in jewelry. They gush about her greenery, and they applaud the playgrounds and reflecting pools that are part of her continuing $5 million face lift.

title: SHOPPING WITH: Geena Davis; When the Emmy Dress Just Won't Do
description: SIZING up her quarry, a feathered corsage displayed on a counter of Bergdorf Goodman's main floor, Geena Davis circled, then swooped. ''This is flamboyant, all right,'' she said, plucking the piece off its perch and trying it on with a grin. She moved on, then, to a plumed headdress -- a tame variation on the avian headgear Busby Berkeley dancers used to wear.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Fighting Bob La Follette

title: Natalie Moore, Patrick Clavette
description: Natalie Hancock Moore, a daughter of Carol S. Robbins of Simsbury, Conn., and Franklin H. Moore of Eastham, Mass., was married yesterday to Patrick Louis Clavette, a son of Elaine and Conrad Clavette of Harwinton, Conn. The Rev. Joanne Neel-Richard, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Trinity College Chapel in Hartford.

title: A Plain Home With a Sense of Place
description: THE most notable physical feature of the home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra is plainness. It is less a ''concert hall'' than a large rectangular room. The floor is exposed wood. The downstairs seats, with their hard, thin upholstery, are removable. The gilt proscenium is topped by a medallion reading, ''Beethoven''; eight flanking medallions are blank. This is a functional space in which to hear music -- or at most, a spare church in which to worship it. Even the name is plain: Symphony Hall.

title: Options Seem to Be Coming Home to Roost
description: FOR years, stock options granted by the nation's fastest-growing companies have been capitalism's version of a free lunch. Now, with new-economy stocks tumbling, the bill for the meal may be coming due.

title: Clemens Staggers Again; Will Yankees Take a Fall?
description: Forty-five minutes before last night's first pitch, there was a wall of fans in blue and white descending upon Yankee Stadium and hoping to witness a celebration. So many people flooded across River Avenue that it did not matter if the traffic light was green or red. Everyone kept walking. There was a game to get to and a potential clinching to watch, so the fans acted as if the light were constantly green.

title: THEATER; Audiences Today Are Getting in on the Act
description: WHEN the revival of the cult musical ''The Rocky Horror Show'' begins previews on Broadway on Oct. 20, ticket holders may end up shouting and dancing in the aisles -- and that's before the curtain call.

title: FOR YOUNG VIEWERS
description: Devlyn Parker, front left, Jhaleh Akhavan and Charles Norman (back) are among eight intrepid teenagers who explore the Australian outback, and the meaning of teamwork, in four episodes of the weekly ''Outward Bound'' series (Saturdays at 11 a.m. on Discovery).

title: How Yeltsin Nearly Scuttled Democracy in Russia
description: In a new memoir, former President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia says that he had all but decided in 1996 to upend the democratic process in Russia by banning the Communist Party, dissolving Parliament and postponing presidential elections he seemed certain at the time to lose.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Out of the Fray, Onto the Sidelines

title: Q & A
description: Taking an Auto Plant Tour

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, HARRY
description: DAVIS-Harry. Beloved husband of Edna. Devoted father of Fern and Hersh Cohen and William Davis. Cherished grandfather of Joe and Ami Cohen, Susan and Herb Myers, Joshua and Amanda Davis and Jeremy Davis. Loving greatgrandfather of Lili and Jack Cohen and Benjamin Myers. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Sunday 12:30 PM.

title: Just Which Murdoch Will Become the Next Rupert?
description: THE announcement from the News Corporation last week was not exactly of the stop-the-presses variety: on Thursday, Rupert Murdoch, the company's founder and chairman, promoted his elder son, Lachlan. He received the title of deputy chief operating officer, a position just below that of the president and chief operating officer, Peter Chernin, Mr. Murdoch's trusted lieutenant, who has been at the company since 1989.

title: How to Quench a Thirst for Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Neighborhood Opponents of Milosevic Testify to Wild Abuses by His Son
description: Momcilo Veljkovic was one of Marko Milosevic's greatest foes here in his hometown, opposing his thuggish control, even at the cost of two severe beatings from Marko, Slobodan Milosevic's son, and his friends.

title: For Knicks' Strickland, No Challenge Too Large
description: Shaquille O'Neal was pulverizing a platoon of Dallas Mavericks centers during a game last season when the 6-foot-3-inch guard Erick Strickland got an idea. Though 10 inches shorter and 105 pounds lighter than the Los Angeles Lakers' wonder, Strickland marched over to his exasperated coach, Don Nelson, and asked to guard O'Neal.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2001 Nissan Pathfinder and Infiniti QX4; The Meek Inherit Some Muscle
description: WHEN Nissan Pathfinders roll off the slow boat from Japan, New York welcomes them with a hug. The Pathfinder is the most popular imported sport utility in the region; there seem to be at least a couple of them in every horn-blaring knot of congestion.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 17 about French Canadian directors who make films in English misstated the year of the ''October crisis'' in which Pierre Laporte, the Quebec labor minister, was kidnapped and killed by members of a separatist group. It was 1970, not 1974.

title: At Orient, Day in Park Winds Up in Arrests
description: ON the North Fork of Long Island, there is no more precious possession than knowledge of special outdoor places not yet overwhelmed by development, government regulation or humans at play. And by this measure boaters who knew about a splendid stretch of Orient shoreline called Long Beach counted themselves rich.

title: Finding a New Music Director the Old-Fashioned Way
description: CONDUCTOR searches are today a fixture of the North American symphonic scene; the New York Philharmonic, the Boston Symphony, the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Minnesota Orchestra and the Toronto Symphony are among the orchestras that need to find a new music director. Too often, the strategy of choice seems to be to land a celebrated maestro, then rely on him (or her) to shape (or not) the mission at hand. A better strategy, exemplified by Henry Higginson in the early days of the Boston Symphony, is to set the mission first, then find a conductor who fits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCH, DAVID
description: MARCH-David. 87 years old, died on October 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Belle. Devoted father of Janice and Steven Friedman, and Dr. Lewis and the late Kathy March. Cherished grandfather of Emily, Rebekah, Jacob, Erika, Aaron, Zachary and Benjamin. Dearest brother of Harold and the late William. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Prosecutors See Profiling By New York Police
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have told the Giuliani administration that they have found a pattern of racial profiling by officers on the New York Police Department's Street Crime Unit, which has been under intense scrutiny since the fatal 1999 shooting by four of officers of Amadou Diallo, an unarmed African immigrant in the Bronx.

title: Spanning Miles and Generations, 140 Family Members Celebrate Heritage
description: The four-story brownstone at 44 King Street was the center of life for the Di Fiores, a family of eight Sicilian brothers and sisters who packed up their dreams and followed one another from Bagheria, Italy, to Greenwich Village a century ago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17

title: POSTINGS: 35 Three-Family Town Houses in Melrose Commons; New Homes for South Bronx
description: On a vast, mostly vacant and formerly rubble-strewn expanse of the South Bronx, 35 three-family town houses, their two-tone facades set back behind modest gates and greenery, have been snatched up by eager buyers.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-08-00: Phenomenon; Crowning Miss Navajo
description: The Miss Navajo Pageant isn't about sex. It's about cultural preservation. That's why there's no swimsuit competition, and contestants spend about as much time in standard pageant-issue evening gowns as it takes to boil an egg. ''If there was a swimsuit competition, I would never enter,'' said 19-year-old Leslie John, one of the dozens of junior princesses and regional Miss Navajos who came last month to watch the five-day pageant in Window Rock, Ariz. ''I could have smelled like sheep, and it would have been fine.'' Indeed, the year before, contenders for the Miss Navajo crown had competed in sheep butchering. ''You need the hooves to hang it up with,'' recalled Floranda Dempsey, the only one of this year's four contestants who competed last year. ''But we cut their whole hooves off. We made a huge mess.'' She laughed. ''It was a female. We cut into the breast. Milk everywhere!''

title: Colleen Adams, Jesse Lawrence III
description: Colleen Ann Adams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Adams of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Jesse H. Lawrence III, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Jr. of Washington Township, N.J. The Rev. Earle Markey, a retired dean of the College of the Holy Cross, performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Ideas & Trends: Unprecedented; Legal Shortcuts Run Into Some Dead Ends
description: TO cope with a flood of cases, appeals judges across the country are increasingly taking shortcuts that critics say undermine the fairness of the justice system, including issuing decisions that don't count as precedent and deciding thousands of appeals with one-word rulings, like ''Affirmed.''

title: Traci Koenig, Samuel Wilk
description: Traci Beth Koenig and Samuel Lawrence Wilk were married last evening by Rabbi Eric Wisnia at Temple B'nai Tikvah in North Brunswick, N.J.

title: One Year. Fresh Arrivals. New York.
description: You paint a dispiriting portrait of New York today. Instead of brilliant eccentrics, outcasts and gritty personalities, we are treated to war tales from a woman in a failed relationship, a giddy candidate for ''the hippest person in Manhattan'' and a famous writer lost in a world of late-night parties.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Sept. 24 with the What's Doing column, about Dallas, included an outdated street name. Oakland Avenue was renamed Malcolm X Boulevard in 1998.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: HOTEL

title: Style; In a Tailspin
description: My name is Antonia Wasserstein, and I am mad as hell. I also happen to be drop-dead gorgeous. My grandmother was a champion Maine coon cat and my mother, according to family legend, was once on ''Regis and Kathie Lee.'' My namesake is Antonia Fraser, the English biographer. Attention must be paid to me.

title: The World: Cold War Echoes; Our (and Their) Man in Peru
description: IN recent years President Clinton has apologized for the C.I.A.'s training of death squad leaders in Guatemala and has made public once-secret files on the killing of leftists in El Salvador, Chile and Argentina. The aim was to show that democracy and human rights have a new importance in American policy in Latin America now that the cold war is over.

title: Political Briefing; Unmentioned in Utah: Democratic Labels
description: Democrats almost qualify as an endangered species in Utah, where Republicans outnumber them better than 2 to 1 and control just about everything. So when Democrats run, they often run without identifying themselves as Democrats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, FLORENCE
description: KAHN-Florence. Beloved wife of the late Murrey. Loving mother of Earl and Leslie. Cherished grandmother of Hillary, Joshua and Steven Kahn. Dear sister of Gloria Bryer. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Sunday, 11:30 AM.

title: Commercial Property; Deals for Small Spaces Add Up to Big Business
description: THE big deals, the ones that account for hundreds of thousands of square feet of office space at a time, are the ones that attract the most attention in the brokerage world. For the individuals involved, they bring the prestige that comes from persuading both a landlord and a tenant to make a major financial commitment, the possibility of recognition by professional groups and, of course, a handsome commission.

title: Sex Education Gets Parental Consent
description: With many parents citing the threat of AIDS, a recent survey by the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation has found overwhelming support among parents for sex education in America's high schools. A strong majority of parents surveyed wanted schools to cover not just the biology of reproduction and the dangers of sexually transmitted diseases, but also issues like abortion and sexual orientation.

title: Cards Display Their Punch, And It's a Quick Knockout
description: In their shockingly brief postseason, the Atlanta Braves never contained Jim Edmonds. They never played like the defending National League champions. And they never beat the impressive St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Imperiled Homeless Shelter Serves a Specific Purpose
description: To the Editor:

title: The Thing Dynasty
description: Jeffrey Bernett Studio B, New York

title: Islip Area Approves Library of Its Own
description: FOR years, residents of the Islip Town section of Hauppauge have been paying for the privilege of using libraries in other towns. Then, in an election last week, they were asked to vote on whether they wanted a library of their own.

title: Dying to Drop-Kick And Body-Slam, And Make It Pay
description: WHEN Lorenzo Papa was a boy, he loved professional wrestling, and so did his dad.

title: Without Fanfare, Morning-After Pill Gets a Closer Look
description: Each month, at least one woman comes into Katterman's Sand Point Pharmacy in Seattle to ask for a prescription drug. None of the women have seen or spoken to a doctor but each says she needs the drug immediately.

title: Airborne Amenities
description: Rapid innovation has not been a hallmark of commercial aviation in recent decades. But the European aircraft manufacturer Airbus Industrie is now seeking to revolutionize long-distance travel by developing a huge new triple-decker airplane that would resemble a cruise ship.

title: One Year. Fresh Arrivals. New York.
description: As a native New Yorker, I have often thought I would like to have been able to arrive in this city as a young adult and experience it, unfettered by a lifetime of memories. I know that a first-time experience in New York can be exhilarating as well as terrifying. I just wish that I could, even for a day, see it from that vantage point.

title: Joseph F. Haas, Lawyer, 89; Helped Secure Voting Rights
description: Joseph F. Haas, an Atlanta lawyer who played an important role in the Voter Education Project, which encouraged blacks across the South to register to vote in the 1960's, 1970's and 1980's, died on Tuesday in Atlanta. He was 89 and lived in Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENTHAL, ADAM J.
description: LEVENTHAL-Adam J., 42. A sculptor, died September 29, 2000 in Los Angeles. He is survived by his wife, Cindy Kolodziejski, his daughter, Olivia Moon, his parents, David and Ann Z. Leventhal of Hartford, CT, a sister, Amy, two brothers, Max and Seth, and eight nieces and nephews. There was a memorial service in Los Angeles. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Las Familias del Pueblo, 307 E. 7 St., LA, CA 90014.

title: IN BRIEF: Environment; YORKTOWN HEIGHTS AND RYE: HOUSEHOLD CHEMICAL DAYS
description: Residents have four opportunities this fall to dispose of unwanted household chemicals and tires: Oct. 20 and 21, at Franklin D. Roosevelt State Park in Yorktown Heights, and Nov. 3 and 4 at Playland in Rye. The Friday events will run from 1 to 3 p.m., the Saturday events from 9 a.m. - to 3 p.m. Most household chemicals in original or labeled containers are accepted as well as up to 10 automobile tires. Paint is not accepted. Elsa Brenner

title: Where's the Help For Hempstead?
description: Re the efforts of the Town of Hempstead's Republican leadership to insulate itself from voter anger over Nassau County's fiscal crisis [''G.O.P. Fights for Bastion of Its Power: Hempstead,'' Sept. 17]: the sister ship of the Titanic must not think itself unsinkable.

title: In Some Foreign Funds, a Way To Overcome the Strong Dollar
description: AMONG the world's major currencies, the dollar has reigned supreme this year, climbing 14 percent against the euro and 5 percent against the yen. While that has meant bargain travel for American tourists, it has generally meant miserable returns for Americans holding foreign mutual funds.

title: Lazio Denies Ad Violated Campaign-Financing Deal
description: With Senator John S. McCain at his side, Representative Rick A. Lazio declared yesterday that he had a ''complete commitment to campaign finance reform'' and had not breached his agreement with Hillary Rodham Clinton to restrict campaign spending by accepting $1.8 million from Washington Republicans for television advertisements.

title: Business & Investing; Finding Funds Online
description: THE Internet's usefulness in researching and, more recently, in buying and selling mutual funds is growing rapidly. Many mutual funds, including some once available only through middlemen, are becoming as easy to buy online as stocks.

title: The Software Doctor Is Out, But With a Healthy Wallet
description: Is Pavan Nigam ready for his next adventure with Jim Clark, the billionaire who founded Silicon Graphics, Netscape and Healtheon, now called WebMD? ''I'm going to try my best to resist any temptation for the next few months,'' Mr. Nigam, 41, a software engineering wizard who has labored to make Mr. Clark's dreams come true, said on Friday, a couple of days after resigning as WebMD's chief technology officer. Mr. Nigam's 6-year-old daughter asked why he was home one morning during the week answering e-mail in bed. Intent on spending more time at home, he has considered no new ventures with anyone.

title: When Six Figures Add Up to Zero
description: WHEN I was 10 years old, I would sit at my father's desk in his study, checking my math homework on his adding machine. One day, around tax time, I accidentally came across his pay stubs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COREN, ARNOLD S.
description: COREN-Arnold S. 4/8/22-10/12/97. Forever in our hearts. Miriam, Alice, Larry, George, Nancy and your boys

title: Bidding For a Trip Online
description: THERE is good reason why Internet auctions have sapped millions of working hours from businesses and chained otherwise attentive parents to their PC's on evenings and weekends. Not only can auctions yield bargains, but there are few other places where you can compete against a potential pool of hundreds of millions of people and emerge as the winner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTIN, MAURICE
description: AUSTIN-Maurice, on Wednesday, October 4, 2000, in his 94th year. Devoted husband and beloved companion of Jennie Austin for 71 years; loving father of Alice and John Brumbaugh, Alan and Irene Austin; doting grandfather of Sharon Moser, Sheila Sybrant, Jonathan Austin, and Kathleen Austin; and great-grandfather of five. Distinguished scholar, lecturer, lawyer, and accountant, Maurice Austin, in his seventy-five years of practice, conducted himself with impeccable integrity and dignity. He brought to his clients, family, and friends the benefit of his extraordinary intellect, kind and generous spirit, and sense of humor. He was a recipient of numerous honors and awards, the most recent being the endowment for Maurice Austin Scholars established in his honor by The J.M. Kaplan Fund, Inc., at City College of New York. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to the Maurice Austin Research Fund at the National Jewish Medical and Research Center, 1400 Jackson Street, Denver, CO 80206.

title: SUING H.M.O.'S
description: The Senate unanimously approved a bill last week that would grant patients the right to sue their health maintenance organizations for medical malpractice in denying or delaying care. The bill would also permit patients to bypass an independent appeals process before filing suit. The measure is a crucial part of a 24-point Health Care Reform package developed by the Senate Health Committee. It now goes to the Assembly. Anne Ruderman

title: DNA Evidence Prompts a Murder Pardon
description: On the basis of a DNA test, Earl Washington Jr., a Virginia farmhand with an I.Q. of 69, was finally pardoned last week for a grisly rape-murder he never committed. Across his 17 years of imprisonment, most of them on death row, pro bono lawyers have complained that the police concocted his confession. But they ran afoul of the nation's toughest evidence bar -- a narrow 3-week window for submitting new exculpatory evidence after a conviction.

title: Two Continents, Three Days
description: SPRAWLED elegantly along both shores of the Bosporus, in both Europe and Asia, Istanbul is a fabled amalgam of civilizations layered one upon the other across nearly 3,000 years. Its ancient Christian and Islamic monuments exist within a vibrant modern city, an intimate juxtaposition that makes Istanbul a fascinating place. The incandescence of this rich history amid a teeming metropolis, however, can leave even the most seasoned traveler too dazzled to truly appreciate one of the world's most splendid cities.

title: Salvadoran Immigrant Found Guilty in Fatal Arson
description: A 22-year-old immigrant from El Salvador was convicted last week of murder and arson for setting a fire that killed four people in an illegally converted and overcrowded apartment house in Huntington Station in May 1999.

title: A Bill of Rights in England
description: England made the European Convention on Human Rights part of domestic law, giving ordinary citizens their first American-style bill of rights ever. Civil libertarians praised the move as the most important change to the British constitutional system in more than 300 years, since the 1689 Bill of Rights limited the monarch's power in relation to Parliament. The new list, which spells out the freedoms of individuals rather than legislators, includes the right to privacy and the right to freedom of expression.

title: A Show So Dumb, It's Smart
description: WHEN ''V.I.P.,'' the syndicated series starring Pamela Anderson, made its debut two years ago, it was without the imprimatur of Viewers for Quality Television.

title: Sidney R. Yates Dies at 91; Congressman Supported Arts
description: Sidney R. Yates, a congressman from Chicago for nearly half a century who battled for government support for the arts, died on Thursday at a hospital here. He was 91.

title: The Plain Janes, at Center Stage
description: IN the stock market's new world order, boring is beautiful and the dazzlers have been dimmed.

title: More Kosher Than Thou in the Five Towns
description: FOR the first three weeks of September, the certificate in the window of Shula Babajanof's pizza shop in Cedarhurst indicated that the food was kosher under rules of the Vaad of the Five Towns and Far Rockaway. The certificate also noted that Ms. Babajanof was not shomer Shabbat, or a Sabbath-observant Jew.

title: RESPONSIBLE PARTY: DAVID McGRATH; Doubling Your Dolby
description: FOR those who want to hear music as clearly from their Discmans as they would in a recording studio, Dolby and Lake Technologies Ltd. have come up with what they call Dolby Headphone technology.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURNHILL, MICHAEL S., M.D.
description: BURNHILL-Michael S., M.D. Memorial services will be held on October 16, 6:30 PM at The Princeton Club of New York, 15 W. 43 Street.

title: Zito Keeps It Simple, And That Is Enough
description: Only when he found a seat in the dugout last night did the Oakland rookie Barry Zito look much like a nervous playoff newcomer. Between innings he would wrap a towel around his neck and quickly nibble at his nails, inspect them, then nibble at them again, as if he could not nibble enough.

title: Anna Rudnicki, Anthony Barbieri III
description: Dr. Anna Maria Rudnicki, the daughter of Dr. Joanna Rudnicki and Dr. Marek Rudnicki of Chicago, was married yesterday to Dr. Anthony Vincent Barbieri III, the son of Rosina Barbieri and Mr. Barbieri Jr. of Alpine, N.J. The Rev. Louis J. Mazza, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y.

title: Healthy Douglas In the Nets' Picture
description: Sherman Douglas has stormed into the Nets' training camp to start his 12th professional season, trim, grinning again and knowing all the plays. From two decades ago.

title: New Jersey Race Turns on the Question of Money
description: On the eve of the first of three televised debates, the race to succeed United States Senator Frank R. Lautenberg is coming down to a stark question: Will the Republican candidate, Bob Franks, have enough money to run a credible race against his Democratic opponent, Jon S. Corzine?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAUBER, BEATRICE
description: DAUBER-Beatrice. Wife of the late Isidore Dauber, died October 6 in her 89th year. Beloved mother of Drs. Leonard (Lorraine) and Kenneth (Antoinette); grandmother of Paul, Jane Lewittes (Michael), Daniel, Jonathan (Sarah), Abigail, and Maayan; great grandmother of Joshua, Jack, and Sophie. Matriarchal aunt and teacher of generations of Shulamith school girls. Funeral services will be held at the Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51 St., NYC at 9:30 AM, Sunday, October 8.

title: Boy Scout Policy Is Damaging to All
description: To the Editor:

title: A Master Returns to His Realm
description: THE 2000 New York Film Festival, as much as any in recent years, has been a celebration of Asian film: Edward Yang's ''Yi Yi''; Wong Kar-wai's ''In the Mood for Love''; Im Kwon-Taek's ''Chunhyang''; Takeshi Kitano's ''Brother''; ''Platform,'' by Jia Zhang Ke; and, of course, Ang Lee's ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,'' which takes him back to his Asian roots. Yet that list omits the least expected and perhaps most welcome offering -- the Japanese film ''Taboo'' (''Gohatto''), which marks the return to feature filmmaking of Nagisa Oshima after a 14-year absence.

title: A Good Thing That Won't Last
description: A glowing review propels you into a wine shop. I'm sorry, the manager says, we are out of the wine and can't get more. Another disappointment.

title: The Saloon Priest, Keeping an Eye on His Flock
description: There is a crowd sitting at a table near the window at Elaine's. One man is the port-a-potty prince of New York, the other is a nightclub owner. The club owner's wife is sitting there with him and she looks good. At the adjoining table is the Rev. Peter Colapietro, the saloon priest who, at 275 pounds, fills a chair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORO, VIOLET
description: TORO-Violet. Angels belong in heaven, so we try to understand that you had to leave. Only in looking forward to meeting with you one day again, eases our mourning. Your dear friends truly thank God for the time you spent with us and your love will always be kept deep in our hearts. There was so much to learn from you and now that you are gone it will live with us forever.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Little Tragedies

title: Medical Center Offers Program Tailored to Gay Patients
description: FINDING good health care can be a difficult and painful process for gay people, who are often forced to explain their sexuality to doctors who may be ignorant, unsympathetic or even hostile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDERLIP, CAROLE ANN
description: VANDERLIP-Carole Ann (previously Cam Newell, nee McGillicuddy), sculptor and author, died September 19th at her home in Chelsea, England of brain cancer. She was well loved by her husband Kelvin, who can answer all inquiries at (011) 4420 7581-8344. A memorial service will be held on October 20th at 5:30 P.M. at Our Lady of Pompeii, Carmine Street. Family flowers only, please.

title: One Year. Fresh Arrivals. New York.
description: I applaud your special issue describing the experiences of people who have moved to New York City (Sept. 17). Your writers did an excellent job of capturing the allure of the city as well as its pitfalls.

title: Jets' Twin Worries: A Possible Letdown and the Steelers' Defense
description: No sideshow. No stinging slights from a former coach. No taunts from a scorned teammate. What is this, a Jets football game without an attendant carnival?

title: Barber Hoping the Ball Is Not Such a Stranger
description: Tiki Barber is not one to show his frustration publicly, so when he shrank into an innocent bystander in the first half of the Giants' loss at Tennessee last Sunday, he seethed quietly on the sideline. Days later, while discussing his minor role in the Giants' second straight loss, Barber was again cautious. Yet he was the player who declared in August: ''There's big plays in me. It's just a matter of finding them.''

title: A New Fund Banks on Technology
description: Talk about fast out of the gate. The newly hatched Merrill Lynch Focus Twenty fund took second place in the performance rankings for the third quarter, with a return of 22.8 percent. So it is not surprising that Focus Twenty has already gathered $1.7 billion in assets.

title: Is Jersey City Too Alluring?
description: Twenty years ago, the word blighted aptly described the Jersey City waterfront.

title: Bellport Returns to Form, And East Islip Is the Victim
description: Bellport (3-1), the top-ranked preseason team in Division 2 in Suffolk County on Long Island, rebounded from its first loss of the season last week and defeated its archrival, East Islip (2-2), 33-13, yesterday.

title: Kristin Penta, Michael Arvanitis
description: Kristin Lucille Penta and Dr. Michael Louis Arvanitis were married yesterday by the Rev. Christ Kontos at St. George Greek Orthodox Church in Asbury Park, N.J.

title: Putting the Authentic in Indian Cuisine
description: JUST as there are Chinese-American and authentic Chinese restaurants, there are Indian-American and genuine Indian spots. The new India House in Hicksville's growing Indian enclave is the latter, the real thing. There's a fierce-looking turbaned, bearded chef in the kitchen turning out exotically spiced northern Indian dishes. Tiny framed silver figurines, musical instruments and pottery from the subcontinent are on the walls, the buffet luncheon is served from ornate Asian chafing dishes and there is a tray of licorice-tasting fennel seeds near the door for departing diners. Beveled rimmed silver charger plates, fresh flowers and the plaintive strains of minor key Indian music also set the mood at the spare, serene storefront at 19 Broadway (516-933-6501).

title: Say It Isn't So. What's Happening Here?
description: To the Editor:

title: Presidential Candidates Differ Sharply on Judges They Would Appoint to Top Courts
description: Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore are presenting voters with perhaps the starkest choice in decades over the kind of people they would select as judges for the federal bench, according to legal analysts and several of the candidates' closest advisers.

title: An Armchair Husband
description: YOU would think we'd have worked it out before the wedding. There were signs, of course. When Mark and I talked about time spent abroad during college, I rhapsodized over working in an Austrian ski hotel, following the path of Mad King Ludwig, losing myself in the Italian train system. He spoke of bunking with his big brother in Paris, playing basketball and working at the American College. Visiting friends in California, he found San Francisco unsettlingly citylike and hilly. He tended to return from overnight trips with a mild case of food poisoning and complaints of bad weather.

title: Habitats/Upper East Side; Adding Exercise Room And Subtracting Pounds
description: A VERY fit-looking man of medium build answered the door of a modern town house in the East 60's. Friends say he barely resembles the person he used to be, a guy with hair out to there, and a lot more bulk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWLING, MADLYN
description: DOWLING-Madlyn. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Madlyn Dowling, associated with The Times from 1962 until 1991.

title: Keep Working And Stay Healthy
description: Americans are now expected to spend decades of their lives -- not years -- in retirement, and that may not be a good thing, according to a researcher at the International Longevity Center-USA, a nonprofit group in New York.

title: Tessa Rowan, Gerrit Goss
description: Tessa Sinead Rowan, a daughter of Patricia C. Rowan of Clearwater Beach, Fla., and the late Dr. Patrick J. Rowan, was married yesterday to Gerrit Johnston Goss, a son of Representative Porter J. Goss and Mrs. Goss of Sanibel Island, Fla., and Washington.

title: Heidi Ginter, Nilesh Shah
description: Dr. Heidi Britt Ginter, a daughter of Debbe Cotter of Cockeysville, Md., and John Ginter of Burlington, N.C., was married yesterday to Nilesh Vinod Shah, a son of Ranjan and Vinod Shah of Irvington, N.Y. The Rev. William Bliss, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Elkridge Club in Baltimore.

title: Veteran Yanks Silence Upstart As
description: OAKLAND, Calif. - The New York Yankees, tired of being eulogized as fallen champions, broke out of their offensive malaise for a half-inning and then barely held on for a series-clinching win over the sleepy Oakland Athletics.

title: Academy in Shrub Oak Is Now on the Market
description: A 140-ACRE property atop a hill with views of parkland has gone on the market for $15 million. It is currently the Shrub Oak campus of Phoenix Academy, a substance abuse rehabilitation program for teenagers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUDOIN, CHARLES
description: BAUDOIN-Charles. On October 4, 2000. Memorial service Friday, 3 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Thanks to Scandinavia Foundation, the Ackerman Institute or to the charity of your choice.

title: House-Hunting Togetherness
description: A recent online survey adds a new wrinkle to the age-old question of who does what in a marriage.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Berthold Lubetkin has more listings to his credit with the preservation body English Heritage than any other architect of the last century. (A listing means that the building can't be torn down or restructured.) His Modernist legacy was forged mostly in London and its outskirts in the 1930's. Lubetkin retreated to Gloucestershire in 1939 to become a pig farmer and dropped from view, although he never stopped designing buildings. There was a resurgence of interest in his work in the early 80's after he received England's highest architectural accolade -- the Queen's Royal Gold Medal. Since then, his fellow architect John Allan has further consolidated Lubetkin's reputation with a monograph published by RIBA Publications in 1992.

title: After Distressing Stumble, Yanks Face Daunting Trip
description: The Yankees' dugout felt like a funeral, Derek Jeter exclaimed when he came off the field in the fifth inning last night. Funerals are for the dead, and the Yankees played the part perfectly in Game 4.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   YATES, SIDNEY R.
description: YATES-Sidney R. 1909-2000 IN MEMORIAM TIRELESS ADVOCATE OF HUMANITY AND THE HUMANITIES Rabbi Irving Greenberg, Chair Ruth B. Mandel, Vice Chair Sara J. Bloomfield, Director United States Holocaust Memorial Museum 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place S.W. Washington D.C. 2002

title: OPINION; Memories of Summer: Nail Guns
description: DO you, like me, ever think up harebrained names for those unforgettable seasons here on our little island paradise? Names like That Ice Winter for the time the world turned into a frozen banana peel and we relearned toddler steps in an attempt at self-preservation. Or something like That Endless Leaves Autumn when I realized that my new house sits at a meteorologically significant spot on the Island where all winds converge, giving me the pleasure of scratching other people's leaves into little piles in my yard, well into each new year.

title: Dennis Sandole, Jazz Guitarist And an Influential Teacher, 87
description: Dennis Sandole, a jazz guitarist and legendary teacher whose students included John Coltrane, died on Saturday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 87.

title: Diary: No Jokes, Please, About Working for Scale
description: Sweetly oblivious to the ichthyological metaphors so often heard in the workplace, a trade association for pet supply makers is trying to promote Wednesday, Oct. 25, as "Take a Fish to Work Day."

title: Article 2000100894191256502 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: By Water or by Land, Foliage on the Hudson
description: Travelers in the New York area can take their pick of transportation to view the autumn landscape along the Hudson River.

title: New Yorkers Like to Work Here, But Say the Living Isn't So Easy
description: Is life in the city getting better?

title: The World; How to Succeed in the Kidnapping Business
description: IN the security business, there is a technical term for the Muslim rebel kidnappers of the southern Philippines, draped in new gold chains, conspicuous in pristine Nike sneakers and Ray Ban sunglasses, racing around on -- and often falling off -- their new motorcycles. The term is ''decadent guerrillas.''

title: UConn Punter Will Remember a Debut to Forget
description: It is understandable that freshmen make mental mistakes or commit bad plays in their first game. But Adam Coles had not envisioned that his collegiate football debut would take such a bad turn.

title: Article 2000100893959828017 -- No Title
description: BY CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Grace Wong, Michael Donohue
description: Grace Wong, the daughter of Mimi Lai Ching Wong of Hong Kong and the late Joseph Cho Chuan Wong, was married yesterday to Michael Robert Donohue, a son of Barbara and Robert Donohue of Ridgewood, N.J. Msgr. Ronald A. Richardson performed the ceremony at the Queen of the Most Holy Rosary Church in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: The Software Doctor Is Out, but With a Healthy Wallet
description: Is Pavan Nigam ready for his next adventure with Jim Clark, the billionaire who founded Silicon Graphics, Netscape and Healtheon, now called WebMD? "I'm going to try my best to resist any temptation for the next few months," Mr. Nigam, 41, a software engineering wizard who has labored to make Mr. Clark's dreams come true, said on Friday, a couple of days after resigning as WebMD's chief technology officer. Mr. Nigam's 6-year-old daughter asked why he was home one morning during the week answering e-mail in bed. Intent on spending more time at home, he has considered no new ventures with anyone.

title: When the French Mediterranean Was Declasse
description: ONE of the most surprising and rewarding exhibitions of the new season is ''Mediterranean: From Courbet to Matisse'' at the Grand Palais. Its subject is the discovery, from 1850 to 1914, of the south of France as a place that was waiting for great new art to be born.

title: On Way to Perfection, Rams May Pass Dolphins
description: The St. Louis Rams, a point-scoring machine, have captured the attention of almost everyone associated with professional football. They have awed a hard-core league that has been there and done that. And no one is paying closer attention to the defending Super Bowl champions than the Hall of Fame Coach Don Shula.

title: Bumming's Always in Season
description: Summer may be over, but that never stopped a real beach bum. Those who fit the description can make use of three publications from -- what else? -- Beach Bum Press. ''The Beach Bum's Alamanac of the Jersey Shore'' ($4.95) by Yma Courbash (who put the extra a in almanac) includes a full calendar of weather wisdom and forecasts through next April, fish facts, moon modes, sea lore and cooking tips. ''The Beach Bum's Guide to the Boardwalks of New Jersey'' ($12.95) is by Richard Handschuch and Sal Marino, who say they walked every board in the state. ''The Beach Bum's Guide to the Jersey Shoreline'' ($5.95), also by Ms. Courbash, is subtitled ''The Book That Answers the Question -- What IS That?'' the ''what'' being shells, crustaceans, fish, birds, about 20 types of seaweed, shore and marsh plants, buoy and channel markers, storm flags, clouds and much more. Order from Currents Marketing and Communications, 2101 Central Avenue, Ship Bottom N.J. 09008; (609) 494 5556, currents@att.net. MARGO NASH

title: IN BRIEF: Government; GRANTS TO COMBAT VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN
description: The state has announced grants of $6.9 million to combat violence against women. Receiving grants in Westchester are the County Attorney, $76,000; the District Attorney's Office, $145,333 and $262,000; My Sisters' Place, $40,000; the Northern Westchester Shelter, $45,000; and Westchester Community Opportunity Program Victims' Assistance Services, $28,125. Elsa Brenner

title: Meta-Midler
description: Bette Midler does not watch television. She has never seen ''E.R.,'' watched ''Seinfeld'' only after she appeared on it and did not tune in to see her own astonishing performance as Johnny Carson's last guest on ''The Tonight Show.'' ''I always said I'd never watch anything stupider than me,'' Midler explains, sitting on the set of ''Bette,'' her television show that will have its debut on CBS on Wednesday night. ''And a lot of TV is really stupid. But movies are over for me. There's nothing there for me. It was so hard to get a picture. My agents could only get me these cameos and I said, What am I doing these cameos for? And I saw that all my compatriots, all the girls I had come up with -- I never say women, I always say girls -- were not doing so good. So rather than wait for the ax to fall completely, because I like to work and I think I have a lot to offer, I said, That's it. Let's try television.''

title: Mural From the 30's Is Given Rebirth
description: THE Colonial American hero General Israel Putnam is said to have slayed a vicious wolf in Pomfret, narrowly escaped a burning at the stake by Indians, led his militia in the Battle of Bunker Hill, and dodged the British in Greenwich by riding his white horse down a steep set of stone steps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHATTEN, ARLENE
description: SHATTEN-Arlene, age 75, of Atlanta, GA. Formerly of Cleveland, OH., and Naples, FL died Sunday September 24, 2000. She is survived by her husband Michael Shatten, daughter Jane Shatten Flowerree, both of Atlanta. In lieu of flowers the family requests a donation to the giver's favority charity. Cremation Society of the South. Please direct all correspondence to Cremation Society of the South, 770-941-5352.

title: A Confidence Drawn From a Charmed Life
description: WHEN it comes to directing, Cameron Crowe has a reputation for being unflappable. But one day, on the set of his latest movie, ''Almost Famous,'' he almost lost it.

title: So You Can Buy Love After All
description: I ADORE the Met, there's no question about that,'' Alberto W. Vilar said. ''I go into that place, and I get goose pimples. Wow, this is the Met! My rich friends laugh at me, because I sit in the same seat every night, in the first row. A101, that's my seat. I want to watch the conductor, the pit, the stage. Not only that, I hold court. My friends come up. They know where I am.''

title: In Armonk, Nostalgia and Meals
description: ALL he wanted was a place to go for breakfast. And when Michael Fareri, this town's most visible and prolific developer, decides he wants something here, it tends to happen. Moreover, it happens on an ambitious scale.

title: Article 2000100893751329280 -- No Title
description: Questions on Wired Schools

title: STATE EASES UP
description: The writing portion of the standardized state tests given to New Jersey's public school fourth graders for the past two years has been evaluated again with a kinder, gentler grading system. In most districts, scores improved for both 1999 and 2000 under the new system. In the last two years, the Elementary School Proficiency Assessment scores in writing were so low that a number of administrators, parents and teachers began to question the validity of the test. When the State Department of Education released scores in other subjects in August, it withheld the language arts scores because on some writing questions where students could score zero to four points, almost 75 percent got one point or less on several items. Debra Nussbaum

title: The Concrete Beneath His Feet
description: Salman Rushdie talks of all the ordinary people he gets to meet in New York (D.T. Max, Sept. 17). Then he mentions lunch with Thomas Pynchon and baseball games with Don DeLillo and Paul Auster. Hey, I write books, yet none of these guys have ever given me a call, and I've been living in the city 16 years!

title: Three Generations
description: To the Editor: The article ''All Together Now,'' by Rick Marin (Sept. 17), interested me a great deal because last February 10 of us, ages 9 to 92, three generations, traveled to Europe. We had two days in London, took the Channel Tunnel to France, and had two days in Paris.

title: IN BRIEF: Environment; FOR ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES ONLY
description: A separate court is being set up to hear environmental cases. The court will be a part of the State Supreme Court and will have a permanent judge and its own staff to concentrate on land-use and environmental issues. It is similar to other dedicated parts of State Supreme Court, which handle domestic violence, matrimonial and commercial issues. ''The key word here is expertise,'' County Executive Andrew J. Spano said. ''We want the judge and his or her staff to be immersed in environmental law.'' The court is expected to be operating by January. Robert Worth

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about vacant seats on the United Nations Security Council misidentified the country that is backed by Latin America and the Caribbean for one of two uncontested positions. It is Colombia, not Costa Rica.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERESEY, JAMES F.
description: KERESEY-James F. Of Upper Brookville, NY on October 5, 2000. Age 74. Loving husband of Jane for 49 years. Devoted father of Michael, Virginia and Kevin. Brother of John, Ann and Diane. Grandfather of five. A U.S. Marine Corps survivor of Guam and Iwo Jima, past President of the Creek Club, member of Augusta National and the Links. Memorial service St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY, Tuesday, October 10th at 11 AM. Contributions may be made to the Marine Corps Law Enforcement Foundation, P.O. Box 37, Mountain Lakes, NJ 07046.

title: Sticklers for Detail
description: Three years ago, Ou Baholyodhin, 34, a product designer, and his partner, Erez Yardeni, 36, a painter, were house hunting in London when they stumbled across a gem -- albeit an unpolished one. It was the penthouse apartment that the architect Berthold Lubetkin, the designer of such beloved modern landmarks as the Penguin Pool at the London Zoo, had built as his own home in the city's Highgate neighborhood soon after he arrived in England in the early 1930's. The property had been on the market for a year, with no sale in sight.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-08-00: The Ethicist; Recommendation Denied
description: I am a college professor, and one of my students has asked for a recommendation for a program sponsored by a group I find deeply offensive. I do not want to punish her for holding controversial political views, but I also do not want to support an education in what I consider hateful ideas. Must I write this letter? -- John Drabinski, Grand rapids, Mich.

title: Appearances; Working It
description: In the department store, after scouring racks and squinting into mirrors, you come away with a wardrobe that will define you as a woman of charm and discernment, or maybe you vow to return when your hips are slimmer and bank balance heftier. Whether laden with finds or empty-handed, you invariably drift to the cosmetics counter, where the makeup diva waits, eager not only to help you find the perfect lipstick for fall but also to reveal the secrets of beauty, if you will allow her to dab a little of this moisturizer on the back of your hand.

title: Blame in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Pro-Abortion Candidates Not Welcome, Bishop Says
description: Bishop James McHugh, the spiritual leader of Long Island's 1.4 million Catholics and the head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, said last week that candidates for political office who supported abortion would not be permitted to speak at candidates' forums held in church buildings.

title: October 1-7; Campaign Laugh Track
description: Graph shows a running tally ranking the most joked-about politicians in late-night network TV monologues: Friday night, Sept. 29, through Thursday night, Oct. 5.

title: A Decision on a Convicted Killer Looses a Rush of Musical Memories
description: ''Imagine all the people. . . .''

title: Landowners File Suit To Block Condemnation
description: Three Port Chester property owners who stand to lose their buildings under a downtown redevelopment plan have filed a federal lawsuit to overturn the state law that lets governments take over private property.

title: Queens Boy Injured By a Stray Bullet
description: An 11-year-old boy walking home from school on Friday was wounded by a stray bullet fired during a fight between two gangs on a major Queens thoroughfare, the police said yesterday.

title: Reese and Columbia Roll Over Lafayette
description: Columbia, led by tailback Johnathan Reese, scored early and often as the Lions coasted by Lafayette, 47-22, yesterday at Wien Stadium. The 47 points were the most scored by a Columbia team since the Lions hammered Brown, 50-0, in 1961.

title: Elizabeth Hall, Peter Thauer
description: Elizabeth Susanne Hall, the daughter of Suzan C. Hall and Charles B. Hall, both of Portland, Ore., was married yesterday to Peter Beck Thauer, the son of Nancy Thauer and Peter E. Thauer of Saddle River, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Edwin H. Cromey performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Episcopal Church in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: MISGIVINGS

title: How to Quench a Thirst for Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Gardiner Offutt, Nicholas Lapham
description: Elizabeth Gardiner Offutt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ellwood Offutt of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Nicholas Payne Lapham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. Lapham of Washington. The Rev. William P. Billow performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Northeast Harbor, Me.

title: Store Owners Silently Fight A War of Words With Signs
description: Two storeowners in Astoria have little to say to each other. Instead, they let their signs do the talking.

title: 'Fairness Doctrine' Rules Are Abandoned
description: With the national elections heading into the home stretch, the federal government suspended two old regulations that had required radio and television stations to provide free reply time to candidates and others attacked on the airwaves.

title: OBJECT FIXATION; Power Puff
description: Question: What do Jade Jagger, David Tang, Julie Christie, John Cleese, Bryan Adams, Ridley Scott, the Duchess of Westminster and John Galliano have in common?

title: Arab-Israeli Conflict Spreads to Border With Lebanon
description: As the Israeli-Palestinian conflict spread into Lebanon and threatened to engulf the region, Prime Minister Ehud Barak issued Yasir Arafat a 48-hour deadline for restraining violent protests before Israeli troops would be authorized to use ''all available means'' to quell the riots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESLOW, HAROLD
description: BRESLOW-Harold. On October 5, 2000. Beloved husband of Bea. Loving father of Lori and Ellen. Devoted father-in-law of John and Sam. Dear brother of Norman and Claire. Adoring grandfather of Nate, S.I., Ben, Jedidiah and David. We love you. Service Sunday, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: AN ACQUISITION
description: FleetBoston Financial Corporation earlier this month signed an agreement to acquire Summit Bancorp, New Jersey's largest bank, in a deal valued at approximately $7 billion. Summit, which is based in Princeton, has $39 billion in assets and more than 500 branches across New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut. Fleet, with assets of $181 billion, has about 1,200 branches in New England, New York and New Jersey. The transaction is expected to be completed next year. Anita Dennis

title: Puerto Ricans Seek Vote for President
description: An Election Day here, almost any Election Day, can cause dancing. ''We enjoy voting,'' said 62-year-old Ana Esther Diaz from behind the counter of a sundries shop in San Juan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, HORACE B.B.
description: ROBINSON-Horace B.B. The Society of Mayflower Decendents in the State of New York mourns the death of Horace B.B. Robinson, our passed Governor and present Elder. His perserverance, hardwork and devotion to duty were an inspiration to us all. We extend our sympathy to his wife and three sons. Walter R. Brewster Jr, Governor Catherine A. Brawer, Secretery

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Article 2000100890447683728 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LILLIAN LEVINE
description: GORDON-Lillian Levine, died May 9th, 2000, age 91 in Oakland, CA. A native New Yorker, she taught second grade in the NYC public schools and the Hillel school in Lawrence. A loving mother and wife. Preceded in death by her husband Max, 1994. Survived by her son Roy (Oakland), daughter Gail (Berkeley) and grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, SOPHIA B.
description: CASEY-Sophia B. On October 5, 2000, of Roslyn Harbor. Beloved wife of the late William J. Casey, former Director of Central Intelligence. Loving mother of Bernadette Casey Smith and her husband Owen T. Smith. Dear sister of Lillian Kurz and Joseph Kurz. Loving aunt of Noel Glenn, Carol Murray, Thomas Langan and many loving grand-nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends at the Casey residency (Mayknoll) 12 Glenwood Road, Roslyn Harbor, Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 11:00 AM, St. Mary's RC Church, Roslyn Harbor. Interment, Holy Rood Cemetery. She was a Dame of the Order of St. Gregory and the Order of Holy Sepulchre.

title: The Aesthete Goes On
description: For Mark Hampton, it was a pair of shutters he painted as a boy. For Mario Buatta, it was the experience of buying an 18th-century lap desk. What triggered Russell Bush's aesthetic epiphany was a magazine article extolling the town and country houses of the English photographer and dandy Cecil Beaton.

title: Julia Parker, Allen Benello
description: Julia du Pont Parker and Allen Carpe Benello were married yesterday by the Rev. William R. Hayward Jr., an Anglican priest, at St. Mark's Church in Smith's Parish, Bermuda.

title: A View of the Sound, a Flair for Seafood
description: THE most romantic dining along coastal Connecticut may well be at Capri Ristorante in Westport. The lemon-vivid one-story building overlooks Compo Cove, and at night, from large front windows, twinkling lights from the opposite side of the tiny cove are clearly visible.

title: The Girl Who Would Be James
description: QUARREL & QUANDARY

title: Lisa Parker, Adam Gorfain
description: Lisa Britton Parker and Adam Herschell Gorfain, producers at ''Dateline NBC'' in New York, were married yesterday on Nantucket Island. The Rev. James L. Burns, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Siasconset Union Chapel in Siasconset, Mass.

title: Doris Chen, Terence Zahner
description: Doris Wan Chen, the daughter of Teresa Chen and Dr. Patrick Chen of Chesterfield, Mo., was married yesterday to Terence Macken Zahner, a son of Loretta and Ernest Zahner of Glen Cove, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel Ulloa, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in Manhattan.

title: Proverbs: The Board Game
description: In 1991 Jordan Pine was a dentist studying for his law degree. Now he is a lawyer who has developed a board game, Proverbial Wisdom, in which players draw sketches to illustrate famous sayings while others try to guess the sayings.

title: The Blunt Appeal of Being Stupid
description: MODERN comedy, in the parlance of media cognoscenti, is wet: fast, verbal, canny and rude about the human condition. It has side-splitting laughter as its goal. Think of your favorite Mel Brooks movie. Modern comedy helps you accept your humanity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASCH, ALTHEA M.
description: RASCH-Althea M. On October 6, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Roland O. Devoted mother of Althea Eisler and R. Frederic. Fond grandmother of Elizabeth and Cynthia Eisler, Kimberly and R. Frederic Jr. Services private.

title: Eden White, Jed Morey
description: Eden White, a songwriter and singer, was married yesterday to Jed Ronald Morey, a radio executive. The Rev. E. Bonnie Goodwin, a Congregational minister, officiated at the Vanderbilt, a catering hall and concert venue in Plainview, N.Y., owned by the bridegroom's family.

title: TAKING THE HELM, YUGOSLAV LEADER FACES BIG DIVISIONS
description: Vojislav Kostunica, whose shoe-leather campaign and reputation for honesty made him the choice of a nation fed up with Slobodan Milosevic, was sworn in today as the new president of a deeply divided Yugoslavia.

title: Knoblauch Changes Routine
description: Chuck Knoblauch has been out of the starting lineup for the last three playoff games, and he has indicated that he accepts the decision of Yankees Manager Joe Torre. Meanwhile, his approach to pregame workouts has changed radically.

title: Clinton and Lazio Face Off in 2nd Televised Debate
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick A. Lazio condemned the United States yesterday for abstaining on a United Nations resolution implicitly blaming Israel for the violence in the Middle East. It was a rare moment of agreement in a debate during which Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Lazio argued over whether New York would be helped or hurt by having a Republican in the Senate next year.

title: TV, the Movies' Abused (and Abusive) Stepchild
description: BLACK people are frightening. Black people are criminals. Black people are violent. Black people are athletic. Black people are successful members of the professional class. Black people are drug addicts. Black people are great entertainers. Black people are loving members of big families. Black people are musical. Black people are funny. Black people are loud. Black people are sexy. Black people are angry. Black people are churchgoers. Black people are always in trouble. Black people are frightening.

title: Sarah Piel and Douglas McAlinden
description: UNTIL she started dating Douglas Gibbon McAlinden seven years ago, Sarah Harfield Piel was a confirmed bookworm who could often be found in her room, reading while eating burned toast (she likes it charred).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, NORMAN ALBERT
description: MILLER-Norman Albert. Tuxedo Park, New York. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 14, 2000 at St. Mary's-In-Tuxedo, Tuxedo Park, N.Y. at 10:30 A.M. for Norman Albert Miller who died August 2000. Smith, Seaman & Quackenbush, Inc. Funeral Home, Monroe, N.Y.

title: Julia Fuller, Yasuyuki Nakayama
description: Julia Kathleen Fuller, the daughter of Kathleen Fuller and Dr. Richard Fuller of Potomac, Md., was married yesterday to Yasuyuki Nakayama, a son of Hiroko and Shigeki Nakayama of Sagamihara, Japan. The Rev. Alida de Coster, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at Dumbarton House, a history museum in Washington.

title: Dobbs Ferry Cheers Return of Own Football Team
description: YOU can hear it in the elementary school here. ''Every Friday at noon the kids give a 'Go Dobbs' cheer,'' Jamie Block, a teacher, said. ''They try to make it loud enough to be heard at the high school a couple of blocks away.''

title: Alas! Uneasy Lies the Head That Tries the King's Gambit
description: The King's Gambit has been out of favor for a long time. In the 1858 match for world supremacy between Adolph Anderssen and Paul Morphy in Paris, it did not appear. But in their offhand games afterward it was played in each one of the six encounters. It was evident that the players enjoyed using it but did not trust it to a formal challenge.

title: Jane Timberlake, Taylor Walker
description: Jane Mills Timberlake, the daughter of Kate M. Timberlake and Terrill V. Timberlake of Burlingame, Calif., was married there yesterday to Taylor Scott Walker, a son of Diana H. Walker and O. Mallory Walker Jr. of Washington. The Rev. Stuart Coxhead Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Lives; After the Fire
description: I took care of my father in the last months of his life as he battled stomach cancer. I slept in the bedroom next to his, monitoring every hour of his day and night, and I treasured our closeness -- in large part because it came so late in his life. Before his illness, he always kept us all at arm's length. He was quick to anger if we challenged him, intolerant of scrutiny of any kind. And then, only weeks before I lost him forever, I learned why.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: TAKE a look at SOME classic films from midcentury and they seem almost cliched, just because they've been imitated so many times, often badly. But Vittorio De Sica's masterpiece THE BICYCLE THIEF (1949) is as fresh and powerful as ever. Lamberto Maggiorani is heartbreaking and yet strangely inspiring as a poverty-weary man who has finally found a job and manages to reclaim his pawned bicycle (a job prerequisite) only to have it stolen on his first day of work. The film, Italian neo-realism at its purest, is a portrait of the man's hope, desperation, determined responsibility and shaky dignity as he and his little boy (Enzo Staiola) search Rome for the missing bike -- Thursday at 8 p.m. on TCM.

title: Pennsylvania Is Hard Climb for Bush
description: Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania sounded unconvincingly exuberant when he introduced his colleague, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, in this fast-growing town west of Philadelphia on the morning after the year's first presidential debate.

title: What Price Luxury? A Pathfinder With $4,000 in Padding
description: IN the beginning, there were sport utility vehicles, and they were fun. The postwar Jeeps and Land Rovers, the International Scouts, the Ford Broncos -- you could drive them almost anywhere, or try to. And because they were rude and crude, the driver and passengers were very much part of the action.

title: Despite Divorce, Children Need Both Parents
description: I read the article about an advocacy group for fathers' rights [''Shredding the Concept of 'Deadbeat Dads,' '' Long Island Journal, Oct. 1] and recoiled at another approach that reinforces the wedge between divorced parents. That is the antithesis of what divorced families need! In my experience as a divorced mother, stepmother, developer of family mediation programs and director of Queens Peace, a parent education program for divorcing parents, one message resounds: children need and want both parents. Our obligation as parents is to ensure that our child is able to have a meaningful relationship with both parents.

title: Meagan McInerney, Daniel Johnson
description: Meagan Mary McInerney, a daughter of Maureen and John McInerney of Rockaway, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel George Johnson, a son of Margaret and Robert Johnson of Wallingford, Conn. The Rev. George Drury performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: Do Athletics Know The Way to San Jose?
description: A Bay Area World Series between the San Francisco Giants and the Oakland Athletics would be a tame preliminary to a turf battle between the owners of the two teams. That battle may never develop, but it simmers close to the surface.

title: What If a McMansion Sprang Up Next Door?
description: FIVE McMansions, priced between $680,000 and $775,000, are rising from lots that few in my neighborhood knew were available for building. They are unsightly structures, out of scale and out of character with their surroundings, although they will probably look less jarring once the insulating thermal paper is sheathed in wood and the scarred earth is landscaped.

title: Make 'Em Think
