description: To the Editor:

title: A Price He Didn't Name
description: Want to hire a dot-com spokesman cheap? Priceline.com seems to have gotten William Shatner for next to nothing in cash by paying him in stock options that have tanked. ''That's one way to look at it,'' said Brian Ek, a company spokesman. ''But I'm not going to touch that one.''

title: Copyrights Expire
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An excerpt in The Times Magazine last Sunday from the book ''Saddam's Bombmaker: The Terrifying Inside Story of the Iraqi Nuclear and Biological Weapons Agenda'' carried an incomplete credit. It is Copyright $; 2000 by Khidhir Hamza with Jeff Stein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, JOHN T. JR.
description: PATTERSON-John T. Jr. The officers and members of Black Agency Executives were deeply saddened to learn of the passing of one of their founders and esteemed colleague. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Horace W. Morris, President

title: BackTalk; Woman Accuses Duke of Going Wide Right of Title IX
description: As small and bald as many of his fans, Garo Yepremian scored 1,074 points during his 15-year National Football League career. He was not the first former soccer player with enough leg to place-kick, but his size and accent made the Armenian Cypriot a butt of nervous jokes. He was not a real football player, said some of the big boys on his team. And it was true that when it came to size -- Garo was 5 feet 7 inches tall -- he might as well have been a girl. The real players knew what they were really worried about -- girls.

title: In Princeton, A Scholar's Unseemly Dismissal
description: The Institute for Advanced Study here is the country's most rarefied of ivory towers, counting more than a dozen Nobel laureates among its past and present scholars. The faculty -- only 22 tenured professors -- is utterly free from teaching duties, spending time on research and mentoring 180 visiting scholars each year.

title: On the Trail of Antiques and Collectibles
description: WOODBURY remains a drawing card not only as a fine antiques center but also for its Saturday-morning Parisian-style flea market. And now there is a 210-year-old bed and breakfast born again as an inn.

title: POSTINGS: Zoning Vote on Church in Harrison, N.Y.; Mormon Plan Is Rejected
description: With its plans for a new temple in Harrison, N.Y., the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints seems to have aimed too high -- more than 14 feet too high.

title: The Wrong Messages In Private Counseling
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000100892562555069 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILLS, NATHANIEL L.
description: SILLS-Nathaniel L., 93 years. Devoted husband of the late Ruth, father of Larry and Susan, Arthur and Sarah, Peter and Susan, grandfather of Deborah and Adam, Eric and Leah, Matthew, Dylan, Daniel and Noah, greatgrandfather of Jacob, Eli & Laila. He was Chairman of the Board of Standard Motor Products but his main passion was his family. He had a profound influence on all of us. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Forest Hills. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to American Parkinson's Disease Association, 650 West 168 St, NYC 10032.

title: 'Seducing The Innocent,' The Sequel
description: THE evidence was gruesome, the delivery impassioned, the message dire: a generation of American youngsters being lured into crime and psychological troubles by large doses of violence and sex; juvenile crime turning ever more vicious, inspired by the horrendous tales and pictures being peddled to tens of millions of vulnerable children; efforts to safeguard the young being blocked by adult greed, ignorance and politics.

title: The Pope Sends A Message to China
description: Pope John Paul II canonized 87 Chinese believers and 33 European missionaries killed in China between 1648 and 1930, and it was clear that he wanted to send a message to those Chinese Catholics who remain loyal to Rome and are often persecuted. The Chinese government reacted fiercely, described the Vatican's martyrs as imperialist spies and ''evil-doing sinners.'' The pope said he did not seek to make judgments about history, but that did not appease Beijing, which warned that the Vatican's quest to normalize relations had been severely hampered. Alessandra Stanley

title: Reckonings; Create And Destroy
description: Hold your horsemen! Last week the market guru James J. Cramer, once famed for his boundless optimism about tech stocks, declared himself, yes, disillusioned with the sector. He detailed his disappointment with the ''four horsemen'' of tech: Dell, Microsoft, Intel and Cisco.

title: Into the Unknown, by Choice and Otherwise; Battered Crossroads Cancels Its Season
description: THE curtain -- after looming for some time -- came down Monday on a season that had not yet even begun at the Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick, as board members canceled the company's entire season, furloughed its small staff and changed the locks on their building.

title: Chess, Anyone? Well, Someone Took Pieces
description: MAYBE they should check down the rabbit hole.

title: Refuge Inside Arctic Circle Is Also in the Middle of U.S. Energy Debate
description: Roughly 250 miles north of the Arctic Circle, hard by the icy Beaufort Sea, this tiny Eskimo village is unlikely to be a stop on the presidential campaign trail.

title: Who Lost Russia?
description: FAILED CRUSADE

title: Goodbye, Pests
description: Webs at the ends of branches on a variety of trees signal the presence of fall webworms. Since these pests feed just before leaf drop, they have little impact on a tree's overall health: prune out nests to aid appearance -- unless you prefer a Halloween effect.

title: Melissa Meyers, Wilbur Foster Jr.
description: Melissa Caroline Meyers and Wilbur Frank Foster Jr., lawyers in New York, were married yesterday in Hilton Head, S.C. Dr. Lewis W. Johnson, the brother-in-law of the bride and a notary public, officiated at the Crown Plaza Hotel.

title: Down the Years, a Slippery Foe Frustrated the U.S.
description: In the mid-1990's, when the United States was trying to end the war in Bosnia and then enforce the peace, Washington's contacts with Slobodan Milosevic were frequent, volatile and very much in person.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Backdoor Route To Wine Auctions
description: A small, rundown shop at 95 Trinity Place in Lower Manhattan is undergoing extensive renovations. It is probable that its former name, G's Wines and Spirits, meant little at the American Stock Exchange, across the street. The new name, Aulden Cellars, may ring a bell there.

title: Emma Mead, Antonio Melo
description: Emma Elizabeth Mead, the daughter of Nancy Mead and the Rev. Andrew C. Mead of New York, was married yesterday to Antonio Melo, a son of Gloria Melo and Dr. Julio C. Melo of Louisville, Ky. The bride's father, who is the rector of St. Thomas Episcopal Church on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, performed the ceremony there. The Rev. Kevin D. Robb, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Still at Sea in a Tempest-Tossed Market
description: After a stormy week, analysts saw little in the near-term to soothe the jarred psyches of investors, who watched both the upstanding Dow drop and the frontier-town Nasdaq get pummeled.

title: Torre Uses Short Pitching Staff
description: Bullet Joe Bush started one game and pitched in two others in the 1923 World Series, the first time the Yankees won a championship. Sad Sam Jones started Game 3 and relieved in Game 6, and Manager Miller Huggins used only three other pitchers: Herb Pennock, Bob Shawkey and Waite Hoyt.

title: National Parks Abuzz in Winter
description: WINTER, when crowds thin out, is a time for tranquillity in the national parks as well as reduced rates at lodges that remain open. But this winter may not be as serene as snowshoers, cross-country skiers and other visitors had hoped.

title: Obsessive? No, Just Looking for a Parking Space
description: AS a regular alternate-side parker, Janet MacAdam is likely on any given weekday to be hunkered down in her old Chevy wagon in the middle of the day, reading the daily papers or marking up book galleys as she awaits the end of street sweeping and preserves her claim on the curb. She is half of a somewhat bohemian couple, a chef and a writer, and they are the sort of veteran West Siders for whom paid parking is anathema.

title: Palestinians Destroy Israeli Site That Was Scene of Many Clashes
description: Ransacking a site considered sacred by some Jews, hundreds of Palestinians overran the site known as Joseph's Tomb today, hours after it was vacated by Israeli troops. The Palestinians burned the compound and tore it apart with pickaxes, sledgehammers and their bare hands.

title: The World; Arafat Always Seems to Survive. Peace May Not.
description: DESPERATE to halt the sudden wave of bloodshed threatening Middle East peace efforts, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright theatrically ran after Yasir Arafat last week as he stalked out of negotiations in Paris, and ordered the gates closed so the Palestinian leader could not get away.

title: The A Train Taken for a Ride?
description: CONTACT, or the hope of contact, was the operative notion when Simon Rattle conducted Duke Ellington at Carnegie Hall recently: two forces rushing toward each other, giddy with the prospect of embrace. Contact, real or imagined, existed on so many levels that there is hardly room to list them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACRI, ROSE A.
description: MACRI-Rose A. On October 5, 2000. Sister of the late Angie, Mary Lynch, Fanny Geraci and the late Edward and Frank Macri. Visiting Sunday and Monday 2-5PM and 79PM at M.J. Smith Sons Funeral Home, 248 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, New York. Mass of the Resurrection Tuesday 10AM at Holy Name Church. Interment at St. John's Cemetery.

title: Thermal Dynamic
description: Now that corporate offices have all but converted to casual dress, how can cool-chasing employees differentiate their informal wear from the phalanxes of nerdy oxfords and pleated khakis? Possibly by dressing up their underwear, specifically their long-sleeved thermal shirts. This winter, the thermal crew neck is stepping out in style, in luxury fabrics, body-hugging fits and decidedly nonunderwear colors like black, chocolate and navy. At Barney's New York, Marc Jacobs's heather blue cashmere long johns top ($650) and John Varvatos's gorgeous, feather-light merino wool crew neck in navy, brown and gray ($165) raise the humble undershirt to lofty new standards. At lower price points, sleek, dark fine-knit cotton pullovers by Banana Republic in black ($38) and thinner stylized thermals by Gap ($24.50) and Old Navy ($14.50) provide more affordable options. And Tommy Hilfiger offers a pin-dot thermal ($26.50), which can be worn untucked beneath a sport coat or under a short-sleeved T-shirt for that increasingly crossover street look. ELLEN TIEN

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 8, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Invisible? Sadly, Just the Opposite
description: THE setting was a dinner party on the Upper West Side. The talk turned to a new crime deterrent: a thumb-detonated electronic alarm system being tested on an Upper East Side block starting this month.

title: In the Sologne, Feasting On the Season's Game
description: THE Sologne is a vast, flat expanse lying south of the Loire just beyond Orleans. It stretches from the chateau of Chambord in the west to the hills of Sancerre in the east. A haunting landscape of forests and ponds, it is one of France's premier game regions and one of my favorites for downright good eating.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: CONDITIONS OF FAITH

title: Getting Its Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALTAGIRONE, VINCENT
description: CALTAGIRONE - Vincent. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Vincent Caltagirone, associated with The Times from 1929 until 1979.

title: Planning an Italian-Style Dinner for Fall
description: ITALIAN cooking is about letting ingredients speak for themselves. This light autumn dinner begins with a classic antipasto: fresh figs with prosciutto. But the figs are served in a salad made with chunks of buffalo mozzarella and whole basil leaves, sprinkled with a light lemon olive oil vinaigrette. The salad is arranged in the center of a serving platter, surrounded by thin slices of prosciutto. It's an unusual combination, but it works. You can use regular mozzarella, but the tangy taste of mozzarella made from the milk of water buffalo is even better, and it must be very fresh.

title: IN BRIEF: Transportation; COUNTY AIDS COMMUTERS
description: Westchester will help three local governments, two nonprofit agencies and a college provide better public transit.The county will lease eight 20-passenger vans for $1 a year up to five years to Tarrytown, for commuter service to the train station and historic sites; Dobbs Ferry, for a service to the train; New Castle, for shuttles between park-and-ride lots and the Chappaqua train station; Westchester Community Opportunity Program, to help people get to work; Westchester Community College, between the college and various downtown areas; and WestHab, to provide transportation to jobs and training sites. Elsa Brenner

title: Israels Barak Renews Ultimatum as Tensions Mount
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Faced with the worst assault on Middle East peace since he entered the White House, President Clinton asked the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, to convene an urgent summit meeting where Mr. Clinton could meet the leaders of Israel, the Palestinians and Jordan, a senior administration official said today.

title: Falun Gong Sect Persists Despite Chinese Pressure
description: Followers of the Falun Gong sect mounted their largest, most coordinated protests in a year on China's National Day, showing that their numbers may have been thinned by the government's year-and-a-half crackdown on the group but that their spirit has not been broken.

title: Europe to America: Ante Up
description: The Europeans brought their pie-charts (the French call them camemberts) to the United Nations to demonstrate how much the European Union gave to the organization's various budgets compared with the richer United States, and why Washington did not deserve the cut in dues demanded by Congress. European and American shares of the world's total gross national product, on which basic national dues are assessed, are about the same: 29 percent.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Gore Vidal; Enter Characters and an Author
description: IT is not so much that Gore Vidal entered the theater but that the theater entered him. Last week, he came to full attention at the back of the Virginia Theater to catch the last 15 minutes of ''Gore Vidal's 'The Best Man,' '' his 1960 satire of a political convention. When Spalding Gray, playing one candidate, delivered his comeuppance line, ''If I'm so unstable, why did you offer me the ambassadorship to Red China?'' Mr. Vidal reared back and laughed.

title: Erika Ryan, Thomas Oelkers
description: Erika deBoesche Ryan, a daughter of Fabienne and Robert Ryan of Orangeburg, N.Y., is to be married today to Thomas Gunther Oelkers, a son of Catherine and Thomas M. Oelkers of Maspeth, Queens. Msgr. William J. Belford will perform the ceremony at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Blauvelt, N.Y.

title: OUTDOORS WITH/Jonathan Kruk; Storyteller Observes 20th Year of Elfin Tours
description: FAIRY houses of bark, moss and fern fronds and leprechaun lairs in fields of blue asters are alive and well at Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Cross River, thanks to Jonathan Kruk, Hudson Valley storyteller.

title: Making 'It'
description: ON WRITING

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-08-00; What They Were Thinking
description: President Clinton: ''I was thinking the vice president should re-enact this scene at the convention in 2000. Actually, we were being briefed for the state arrival of Prime Minister Chretien [of Canada]. I was focused on making this visit a success. I wanted Chretien, an ally and a close personal friend, to feel good about it. Also, I had recently hurt my knee and wanted to make sure that the injury didn't cause any problems during the day. I had to be very careful by trying to minimize pain and discomfort and do two physical therapy sessions a day. At the same time, I was working on the balanced-budget agreement with Congress. I felt relieved that we had weathered the G.O.P. shutdown of the government and won the election, and was determined to work with Congress to get a good balanced budget.''

title: Footlights
description: Sister-to-Sister Chorus Meeting

title: On the Proper Education Of Actors (and Audiences)
description: THE actress Mary-Louise Parker and the director Joe Mantello have known each other since they were students at the North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem. Ms. Parker, who starred in David Auburn's play ''Proof'' last summer at the Manhattan Theater Club, resumes her role on Tuesday, when the production, directed by Daniel Sullivan, begins previews on Broadway at the Walter Kerr Theater, where it opens on Oct. 24. Mr. Mantello, who is currently directing Terrence McNally and Jake Heggie's ''Dead Man Walking'' at the San Francisco Opera, will direct the Roundabout Theater Company production of Noel Coward's ''Design for Living'' later this season in New York.

title: Now That I Have Your Attention
description: I MISSED you at our junior high school reunion.

title: The Nation; A Modest Poll Proposal
description: AND now for a modest proposal: Ban all political polling between now and Election Day.

title: Political Briefing; New Poll Gives Robb Good and Bad News
description: Political oddsmakers rate Charles S. Robb of Virginia the most vulnerable Democratic senator this year. In a state that Republicans have come to dominate, he is the last Democrat holding statewide office and he barely hung onto his seat when he ran for re-election six years ago.

title: Testaverde Hurt in Jets First Loss
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. (AP) - Kordell Stewart's composed, efficient play didn't earn him the job as starting quarterback for the Pittsburgh Steelers. What it did was hand the New York Jets their first loss of the season.

title: Saburo Sakai Is Dead at 84; War Pilot Embraced Foes
description: Saburo Sakai, a Japanese fighter pilot in World War II who said he shot down 64 Allied planes, including one of each type the United States flew, but who later befriended the Americans he once fought, died in Tokyo on Sept. 22. He was 84.

title: A Leading Man Tries TV in a Show About Men
description: GABRIEL BYRNE was walking past a newsstand one day, with its stacks and stacks of women's magazines, when the idea occurred to him for a television show about a neglected minority: men.

title: SOAPBOX; It's Brain Injury Month
description: OCTOBER is Brain Injury Awareness Month, but I do not need a calendar to be aware of the devastating impact of this often invisible injury. Since a BMW hit my Chevrolet in June 1994, I have been living with its insults.

title: From a Keyboard to a Tugboat
description: Eddie Layton likes playthings -- the organ at Yankee Stadium, the toy trains in his Queens apartment, the tugboat he sails on the Hudson.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NADELSON, ANDREW MITCHELL
description: NADELSON-Andrew Mitchell. 10/8/49-12/28/93. In loving memory on his 51st birthday. Mother and Jay

title: Likable Lawyer Buys Local Bowling Alley
description: A couple of years ago, Rob Burnett and Jon Beckerman decided they wanted to create a television show that deconstructed an Everyman's life. They wanted it to capture that moment when he looked at where he'd been and where he was heading, in order to make a midcourse correction and get back on track. They wanted the man to move back to his hometown to regain some real feeling in his life.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: AHAB'S WIFE: Or, The Star-Gazer, by Sena Jeter Naslund. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $15.) Inspired by a few brief passages about Ahab's young wife in ''Moby-Dick,'' this novel reworks Melville's whaling adventure from a female, liberal Protestant perspective, imagining a world ruled by compassion rather than obsession. ''Naslund is unstintingly reasonable, empathetic and kind,'' Stacey D'Erasmo wrote here last year, and her heroine ''is a deep and wayward creature.'' The same publisher has reissued The Disobedience of Water: Stories and Novellas ($13), in which mostly Southern characters struggle to make human connections through the power of memory. ''Naslund has an eye for odd, telling details and a gift for rendering (and respecting) this oddness in . . . sharp and precise'' language, Maud Casey said here in 1999.

title: For Hamptons Films, A Global Perspective
description: THE daytrippers have disappeared and at last it is safe to make a left turn on Montauk Highway. But ''the season'' is not over yet.

title: Miami Shows It's Back, With Upset of Florida State
description: The old quarterback, the 28-year-old from the defending national champions, was supposed to lead his team 48 yards in the final minutes and throw a game-winning touchdown pass. Florida State's Chris Weinke, bum ankle and all, did just that. Or at least it looked that way when he drilled a 29-yard pass to Atrews Bell with 1 minute 37 seconds left in the game to put the top-ranked Seminoles ahead of Miami for the first time today, 24-20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLTARSH, ELAINE
description: OLTARSH-Elaine. Beloved wife of the late Stuart Oltarsh died October 6, at home. Adored and loving mother of Lauren Oltarsh, mother-in-law of Chris Guarino, cherished Nana of Allison and Katie, loving sister of Harriet and Mervin, and dearest aunt to their children and grandchildren. Loved sister-in-law and best friend of Cherie Stahl and adored aunt to her children and grandchildren. She will be greatly missed by her many close friends. Service Sunday, October 8, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Elaine and Stuart Oltarsh Fund, Congregation Shearith Israel, 8 W. 70th St.

title: Hadley Gilman, David Goerk
description: Hadley Rowena Gilman, the daughter of Sondra Gilman Gonzalez-Falla of New York and the late Charles Gilman Jr., was married last evening to David Brian Goerk, a son of Coralie and Jay B. Goerk of Manasquan, N.J. Bentley Kassal, a retired judge who was with the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court in Manhattan, officiated at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Celso Gonzalez-Falla, in New York.

title: Susan Brady, Gregory Miles
description: Susan Jane Brady, a daughter of Jane and Gerald Brady of Bloomfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Gregory Lynn Miles, the son of Virginia Miles and Dr. Leland Miles of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Aldo J. Tos performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Kiera Scharfenberger, Ryan Branon
description: Kiera Amy Scharfenberger, the daughter of Joan M. Reilly of Centerport, N.Y., and Joseph M. Scharfenberger Sr. of Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., was married Friday to Ryan Matthew Branon, a son of Sarah T. Branon and Dr. Mark E. Branon Jr. of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Harold Ridley, the president of Loyola College of Maryland in Baltimore, performed the ceremony at the Loyola College Chapel.

title: Kitchen Confidential
description: In her Food column (Sept. 17), Molly O'Neill speaks of the ''legions of newly arrived immigrants working as dishwashers and runners'' who ''inform menus'' for the star chefs like Anne Rosenzweig. Everyone knows how much busboys and prep cooks earn. What extra money are they paid when their recipes are ''fused'' into a profitable restaurant's menu? Or do they just get a really big tip? I plan to make the spicy corn fritters ''adapted'' from Anne Rosenzweig's Lobster Club menu. But when someone asks me where I got the recipe, I'll say it's from an anonymous Bangladeshi chef.

title: HOME DESIGN: Fall 2000; Style Counsel
description: Brad Floyd is an architect, but he looks and acts like one of the laconic, downtown models in Andy Warhol's 1968 Factory film ''Lonesome Cowboys.'' Blue-eyed, wavy-haired and sideburned, Floyd, 44, is a Nashville native who studied at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn and has lived in New York for 24 years. A vegetarian and a kayaker who floats his boat on the Hudson River a couple of evenings a week, Floyd is standing in the living room of Grace Coddington's two-story apartment on West 11th Street.

title: Susan Sherrill, Frederick Canavan
description: Susan Leigh Sherrill and Frederick Canavan were married yesterday by the Rev. John Hartnett at St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church in Ridgewood, N.J. The bride's father, the Rev. Christopher R. Sherrill, who is the associate rector at Trinity Church in Princeton, N.J., assisted in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANACORE, NANCY (NEE LEPORE)
description: VANACORE-Nancy (nee Lepore). Of Palisades Park, NJ on October 6, 2000. Wife of Dominick Vanacore. Mother of Elizabeth Miguel, Stephen and the late Gennaro Vanacore. Also survived by three grandchildren and brothers and sisters. The family will receive their friends Sunday, 7-9 PM, and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Frank A. Patti and Kenneth Mikatarian Funeral Home, 327 Main St., Fort Lee, NJ. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10 AM, St. Nicholas R.C. Church of Palisades Park, NJ. For further information call 201-944-0100.

title: A Grand Creation That Crosses a Road
description: THE annual sculpture exhibitions at Storm King Art Center here have customarily featured works that are quite different from their setting, like most of the permanent works, which are angular and metal, set on and against the rolling fields that are especially green right now. The special exhibition this year is markedly different from its predecessors because it makes ample use of natural materials found on the Storm King property.

title: So, Who Wants Long Distance If Even AT&T Spurns It?
description: IN his heart of hearts, C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman and chief executive of AT&T, still probably wants folks to phone home. But if he has his way, they will do so on someone else's network.

title: Michelle Baez, Jason Asch
description: Michelle Ann Baez, a daughter of Carole Baez and Dr. Julio C. Baez of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jason Dmitri Asch, a son of Sherry Asch and Dr. Harvey Asch of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DURR, ERNESTINE B.
description: DURR-Ernestine B. Died peacefully at home at age 95 on August 24, 2000. Memorial Service at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue at 61st Street, Manhattan, on Saturday, October 14, 2000, at 11:00 A.M. Memorial donations may be made in her name to St. Peter's Lutheran Church of Manhattan, 619 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10022, or to The Wartburg Foundation, Wartburg Place, Mount Vernon, NY 10552.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEINFELD, FRANCES
description: SCHEINFELD-Frances. With much sadness we mourn the untimely passing of Frances Scheinfeld. To her husband, Al, & her children and grandchildren, we offer our condolences in this hour of their bereavement. She was a tower of strength loved by all. Her memory will be a blessing to everyone who knew her. Esther and Harry Walker

title: Meow Mix
description: Fashion is having kittens this fall. Not to mention Alsatian dogs and elephant bells.

title: Spending So Much to Sway So Few
description: Football fans are seeing more of Rick A. Lazio these days. Soap opera buffs can count on both Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mr. Lazio being part of the days of their lives for the duration of New York's Senate campaign. And anyone who watches news regularly will be at ground zero for the explosion of political advertising on television.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column on Sept. 10 about Lewis Arlt, artistic director of Fleetwood Stage in New Rochelle, misstated his role in a production of ''Deathtrap'' last winter at the Paper Mill Playhouse in New Jersey. He played a supporting role; the lead character was played by Jonathan Hadary.

title: Bypassing Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: Once Again, Protecting the Barrens From a House in the Bogs
description: Two months ago the New Jersey Chapter of the Nature Conservancy opened an office in the Pine Barrens, in Whitesbog, a hamlet where employees of the cranberry grower J. J.White Inc. lived until the 1940's. The building was the Arts and Crafts-style residence of Elizabeth C. White, whose family owned the business and were among the first to cultivate cranberries commercially in the Pine Barrens. She was also a conservationist and gardener. Now her house, called Suningive, nurtures the Conservancy's new effort to protect the 1.4 million acres of the Pine Barrens, which the Conservancy calls one of ''America's Last Great Places.'' Anne E. Heasly, assistant state director of the New Jersey Chapter of the Nature Conservancy and director of the group's Pine Barrens Program Office, spoke from the new quarters.

title: Ask No Questions, We'll Tell No Lies
description: I have children, so I know how irritating it can be to have people ask lots of questions. Can we have a dog? Why can't we? Are we there yet? Can we leave?

title: Bookend; O Rapture! A Word From Our Sponsor
description: Lady Warbones now felt herself much restored, having partaken of a goodly dollop of Drumsnab's Patented Extract of Whey, the elixir favored by 10 Crowned Heads and a Nabob for curing headache, the fantods and flutteriness of the humours. Lord Fleagle would appear at any moment -- should his new ''Glad Miles'' barouche, built by Hobstone & Bros., traverse the distance from Mealy House to her front door without incident, and, as Hobstone & Bros. All-English barouches were the only choice of the gentry, one could, on this matter at least, be quite delivered of fears. Young Phoebe now dispatched Lady Warbones's reverie. ''Ma'am, will Cook be using the everyday mustard for the Mutton Surprise?'' inquired the scullery maid, red of proboscis and sniffling. The silly girl could use a spoonful of Dr. Jolly's Arabian Crystal Vapors!

title: Kathryn Sullivan, Ryan Hanley
description: Dr. Kathryn Hartzel Martin Sullivan and Ryan Patrick Hanley were married yesterday at the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Eugene C. Bay performed the ceremony.

title: Ever the Foe of Market Guesswork
description: INVESTORS in index funds should circle Dec. 31 on their calendars.

title: Gunshots and Flying Debris Replace Residents' High Hopes
description: One day in 1968, state landscape architects stood on the banks of the Harlem River, then blighted by abandoned industry, and imagined River Park Towers. They dreamed of a place where renters could walk up gently sloping green lawns to the doors of modern high-rises.

title: A Techno Auteur Finds Rock-Like Success
description: FOR more than a year, ''Play,'' a genre-straddling collection of electronic dance songs by the techno auteur known as Moby, has been an oddity among the usual suspects -- teen idols, slick VH-1 stalwarts, rappers, R-and-B divos and divas, truculent frat rockers, Shania Twain -- hovering in the top half of the Billboard 200 album chart. The record is a big hit. It has sold one million copies in the United States, and has been on the Billboard charts for 59 straight weeks; overseas, where techno is more entrenched in the pop mainstream, ''Play'' has sold an additional three million copies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGINNIS, ARTHUR J.
description: McGINNIS-Arthur J. Chairman of Simmons-Boardman Publishing Corp, died of a stroke at age 89, on October 5. Mr. McGinnis graduated from Fordham University in 1932, and from Harvard Business School in 1934. His 60 year career culminated in his achieving control of the corporation which publishes numerous trade magazines in the shipping, marine, banking and railway industries, including ''Railway Age,'' the oldest railway trade publication in the United States. Mr. McGinnis is pre-deceased by his wife Roselind Diskon and his daughter Roselind (Mrs. Joseph) Mullen, and his brother Joseph McGinnis. He is survived by his children Arthur Jr., Carolyn and Patricia McGinnis, Kathleen (Mrs. Alfred Anthony) Stein. He also leaves seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. For funeral information call Buckley Funeral Home, 732-775-2455.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICKEN, ANNA ELEANOR
description: PICKEN-Anna Eleanor on October 5, 2000. Beloved wife of Robert. Reposing at The Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Boulevard, Jackson Heights, NY on Monday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass on Tuesday, 10AM at The Church of St. Mary the Virgin, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers donations to The Queens College Foundation.

title: The World; Sticks and Stones: A Deadly Brand of Child's Play
description: HAD a cameraman not been on hand when 12-year-old Muhammad al-Durrah and his father walked into a firefight last Saturday, the boy might just have been another faceless casualty. As it is, the image of Muhammad's death has become the latest totem in the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians.

title: China, Once a Supporter of Milosevic Against NATO, Sends Its Congratulations to Kostunica
description: Briskly adapting to the fall of Slobodan Milosevic, who was a close diplomatic ally, President Jiang Zemin today sent ''heartfelt congratulations'' to the newly elected president of Yugoslavia.

title: Captain of Cottage Industry
description: Growing up in Watertown, Mass., the youngest of six, John Derian was ''always collecting and arranging things to try to make my own little place,'' he explains. And he's still doing it: his store on East Second Street, the John Derian Company, is nothing if not his own little place -- a colorful haven filled with his handmade tableware, alongside antiques, flea-market finds and home furnishings gathered on his travels. The shiny plates he designs are arrayed brightly side by side, their lively faces as inviting as fresh flowers or candy. Pillows, straw bags, hat feathers, Chinese lanterns, vases and Derian's line of paper goods (note cards, postcards and wrapping paper) cover every surface. A wrought-iron bed is piled with richly colored Indian cotton spreads and reversible coverlets from France.

title: Ideas & Trends; Anthropology Enters the Age of Cannibalism
description: THE anthropologist Napoleon A. Chagnon has spent decades studying patterns of conflict and revenge among Yanomami Indians, deep within the Amazon Basin. He needn't have traveled so far to pursue his research. After all, anthropologists themselves are one of the most bellicose tribes on earth. The discipline's latest outbreak of infighting -- over accusations of ''ethnographic cleansing'' made against Mr. Chagnon in an upcoming book, ''Darkness in El Dorado'' -- may be its nastiest battle yet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVITZ, SY
description: SAVITZ-Sy. On October 5, 2000 at age 74. Adored husband of Nita. Loving father of Jane and Tony Mangiaracina and Susan and Michael LaValle. Devoted grandfather of Bianca, Jayson, Michelle and Michael. Dear brother of Judy Rand. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, 11:30 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Neurological Research Fund, c/o Dr. Michael Fetell, Room 204, Columbia University, 710 W. 168th St., NYC 10032 or The Bertolli Brain Tumor Lab, c/o Dr. Jeffrey Bruce, Room 434, 710 W. 168th Street, NYC 10032.

title: Article 2000100893517204348 -- No Title
description: this is top sevenday index/knews_data/promos/ technology/sevendayindex/sevenday.html

title: A Broadway Boyhood
description: From 1980 to 1993 Frank Rich was the chief theater critic for The New York Times. But his relationship with the theater began many years before. As a child in Washington, struggling with his parents' divorce and his mother's subsequent remarriage, Rich sought refuge in the stage. He would spend endless hours scouring the theater pages of The New York Times and Variety and playing the cast albums from ''Damn Yankees,'' ''The Music Man'' and ''Gypsy,'' transporting himself out of one life and into another. In this article, adapted from his coming book, ''Ghost Light: A Memoir,'' to be published by Random House later this month, a young Rich experiences his first night alone on Broadway.

title: The Greatest Hits of the Index King
description: WHAT keeps mutual fund executives awake at night?

description: WELL-FOUNDED FEAR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTNER, JANE ELLEN
description: ORTNER-Jane Ellen. On October 5, 2000. Beloved wife of Charles. Loving mother of Amy and Eric. Devoted sister of Ann and Dr. Michael Rosen and Dr. Jeffrey and Margo Gold. Cherished daughter of the late Dr. Theodore and Belle Gold. Proud aunt of Dana, Barrie, Seth, Alexander and Julia. Jane was a dedicated, passionate and inspiring teacher and friend. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Jane Ortner Multiple Myeloma Research Fellowship, C/O Clyde B. Jones III at Weill Medical College of Cornell University, 525 East 68 Street, Box 123, NYC 10021. Services were held.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Let Me Say This About That
description: THE ARROGANCE

title: Where Else to Gaze When a Star Falls to Earth?
description: FEW grins were brighter than Thomas H. Bailey's pearly-white wattage a year ago on the cover of Forbes magazine.

title: In a Productivity Surge, No Proof of a 'New Economy'
description: NOTHING has been harder for economists to explain than the prosperity that burst upon the United States with magical suddenness in late 1995. In the absence of explanation, there was phrase-making. A ''new economy'' had arrived, and the words became a banner for all sorts of optimism. Only now is a realistic definition of the new economy coming into focus.

title: Iona Runners Aim at Glory for Their College
description: NEXT month, in Ames, Iowa, Iona College has a shot at finishing in the Final Four. But this is the national championship in cross country, not basketball, the sport that usually draws all the attention at this small college on North Avenue here.

title: Turning Miles Into Money
description: FOR many of the tens of millions of Americans who participate in frequent-flier programs, it is feast or famine. Some road warriors have so many frequent-flier miles sitting in their accounts that they have no hope of using them up, or no desire to cash them in to spend even more time away from home, while other occasional fliers have too few miles to qualify for any travel award.

title: Viewing Brooklyn's Backyard
description: BEGUN in 1829 as a Sunday School festival, Anniversary Day (or Brooklyn Day) was transformed into a celebration of the founding of Brooklyn, and in 1959 the Board of Education extended the holiday to Queens. The holiday is usually celebrated the second Thursday in June. The celebrants pictured above are from a 1910 photograph by J. J. Levison, from the Prospect Park Alliance archives, that is part of the show ''A Park for All People.''

title: A Backward Glance
description: VICENTE WOLF, below. This is a den, and it was done close to 20 years ago for a couple in New Jersey, a doctor and his wife, with seven children, and the wife's parents lived there, too. This room became their ''live-all,'' the space where the whole family could gather. It functioned very well because it provided so much seating. It was leather, the kids could jump on it, but it didn't travel well with time. I've learned since then that the idea of having everything monochromatically ''designed'' makes a strong statement but forgets the humanity of the space. And yet, even then, when environments were hard-edged and modularly oriented, there was the commencement of an understanding of bringing in different periods. The crudeness of that wood table next to the smoothness of the leather yields a yin-yang quality. With today's perspective, I look at the coffee table and I see a very Zen type of surface. That table, which had looked so 80's, becomes contemporary: an Oriental pond of black in the middle of the space.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Highland Park, N.J.; Small in Size but Large in Diversity
description: THE tiny 1.8-square-mile borough of Highland Park in Middlesex County, N.J., has been taking on a cosmopolitan flavor in recent years. Eating establishments such as Jerusalem Pizza and Kosher Chinese, which reflect the Jewish character of Raritan Avenue, the main business street, have been joined by Pad Thai, the Seven Hills of Istanbul and a Chinese bakery. Although less than a mile long, Raritan Avenue has about two dozen places to eat.

title: Rangers Off to Unusual Start: With a Victory
description: Mark Messier donned his red, white and blue No. 11 Rangers sweater for real for the first time in four seasons tonight. He lined up with Adam Graves and Brian Leetch for the national anthem. And he assisted on the Rangers' first goal in a 2-1 victory over the Atlanta Thrashers.

title: Streetscapes/307-17 West 80th Street; Six Gothic-Style Row Houses That Date From 1894
description: THE houses at 307-17 West 80th Street are some of the most distinctive on the West Side, built in the last full decade of substantial row-house construction, when builders were seeking variety, not uniformity. The fronts of the buildings have changed little over the last century, but the interiors have continued to evolve with each new generation of owners.

title: A Hidden Empire in Turkey
description: MIST rose from the deep gorge that separates Turkey from Armenia on the day I toured the ruins of an ancient city that has nearly slipped from historical memory. Once this was the capital of a great empire and home to kings, bishops and 100,000 prosperous citizens. Today it is eerie and abandoned, the shells of its great churches and palaces conveying a deep sense of the impermanence of grandeur.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the financial prospects of Roche Holding, the Swiss pharmaceuticals company, misidentified the disease that Pegasys, one of its medications in development, is intended to treat. It is hepatitis C, not B.

title: Dawn Webb, Richard French III
description: Dawn Marie Webb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis R. Webb of Warwick, R.I., is to be married today to Richard Edward French III, a son of Mr. and Mrs. French Jr. of Harrison, N.Y. The Rev. Paul A. Keenan will perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in New York.

title: Corsican Rebel Whose Eyes Have Turned to Peace
description: The setting is reassuring enough: a weathered stone house near a mountaintop on the island of Corsica, the Mediterranean glistening in the distance. Behind the windows are lace curtains and sepia portraits of grandparents on the wall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMBERG, HILDA
description: BLUMBERG-Hilda. On October 5, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Gail Rise Retter. She will be deeply missed for the love and beauty she added to the lives of her family and friends. Service private.

title: This Could Be Last Chance for Roy and Sakic
description: Patrick Roy and Joe Sakic might have figured that the 1996 Stanley Cup would be the first of many titles they would win with the Colorado Avalanche. But no championships have followed, and now Roy and Sakic might be making their last run together.

title: Margaret Bernstein, Christopher Santana
description: Margaret Lewis Bernstein, the daughter of Ann L. Bernstein and Daniel L. Bernstein of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Michael Santana, a son of Marie and Robert Santana of Coral Gables, Fla. The Rev. Charles J. Minifie performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-08-00: Questions for Bono; Relief Pitcher
description: Q: Third world debt is not an inherently sexy issue. How did you find your way to it?

title: The Long View
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Reed Puts Past in Past, And Does Job for Mets
description: IN the bottom half of the second inning of a scoreless game yesterday afternoon, the Giants were threatening to score against the Mets, gray-suited San Franciscans standing on first and third with one out. It was Game 3 of the National League division playoffs, and a goodly portion of the crowd stood to cheer on the home team pitcher, Rick Reed.

title: In Larchmont, an Apollonian Experience
description: JUST when it seemed that the only restaurants to open were those serving Italian cuisine, Pascal's breezes in and sets up shop in the space last occupied by Hope and Anchor.

title: Anka Laszlo, William Paine
description: Anka Mira Laszlo and William Abbott Paine are to be married today by Kimberly A. Thompson, a California marriage commissioner, at the Andretti Winery in Napa, Calif.

title: Good Poets Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicole Artzer, John Weeldreyer
description: Nicole Kristen Artzer, a daughter of Joyce and Richard Artzer of Fort Worth, Tex., was married there yesterday to John Samuel Weeldreyer, the son of Janet Cornwell of Philadelphia and Dennis Weeldreyer of Hickory, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Nicholas V. Gamvas performed the ceremony at St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Church.

title: Houston Limps Out of Practice
description: The Knicks received a scare today when Allan Houston sprained his left ankle. Houston did not continue to practice but was able to walk back to the club's hotel and said he hoped to practice Sunday.

title: Central Islip Courthouse Upholds Dignity
description: In ''For Central Islip, A Renaissance,'' [Sept. 17] a Hauppauge resident was quoted as criticizing the design of the new federal courthouse for not being ''warm and fuzzy.'' As a co-architect of the building, I can assure the critic that it was designed to express the dignity and the authority of the federal government. When one is called to appear before a federal judge, it would be most inappropriate to expect to enter an environment that is ''warm and fuzzy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARESCA, HON. OREST V.
description: MARESCA-Hon. Orest V., on October 6, 2000. Beloved son of the late Vincentina and Michael. Dear friend of Mario Puppio, Charles Marin and Carmine De Sapio. Also survived by other relatives and many friends. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. (at 20th St.), NYC, Mon. 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial at Church of the Epiphany (at 22nd St. and Second Ave.) Tues., 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Who's Who?
description: MARTIN BAUMAN

title: Nonchalance Is Back
description: The daytime blouse worn without a jacket was part of the sportswear revolution of the late 1930's. The evening shirt was popularized by the Gibson girl circa 1900, when the man's shirt, recut, became an alluring style. This fall, the silk blouse, top row, is being embraced as a daytime look, and taffeta shirts, bottom row, are being worn for evening with long skirts or trousers, or sometimes as a jacket over a dress.

title: Clark Is Filling Big Shoes With Some Very Big Hits
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 7  As Will Clark was surrounded by reporters Friday in the St. Louis Cardinals clubhouse, Mark McGwire walked by to get something from his locker.

title: Q & A/Patricia Lucan; Mutual Respect: Teachers and Board
description: ON July 1, Patricia Lucan took office as president of the 1,650-member New Haven Federation of Teachers. Ms. Lucan, a 53-year-old native of New Haven who now lives in Hamden, began teaching in 1969 and (with nine years off to raise her own children) has spent her entire career as a language teacher in New Haven public schools, at Lee High School and at Sheridan Academy middle school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENGROVE, SYLVIA M.
description: DENGROVE-Sylvia M. On October 5, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Jay L. and H. Bruce. Dear sister of Elaine Mendlowitz. Service Sunday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: 3 Hospitals Join North-Shore-L.I.J. System
description: Peconic Health Corporation and three member hospitals serving the East End of Long Island signed an agreement last week to become affiliates of North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, the largest health system on Long Island.

title: Sequoias and a Hotel, A Natural Fit in Yosemite
description: MENTION a Yosemite expedition to most fans of the park and you will be directed to the standard glorious sites: El Capitan, Half Dome, Yosemite Falls. You may also be encouraged to stay at the Ahwahnee Hotel, whose soaring dining room, Native American murals and location in the heart of Yosemite Valley have long made it the park's most luxurious lodging.

title: Elizabeth Joy, Peter Conze III
description: Elizabeth Joy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard F. Joy of Glen Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Horst Conze III, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Conze Jr. of Providence, R.I. The Rev. Carl Hansen performed the ceremony at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Carmel, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 20 of the Travel section today about restaurants in the Sologne region of France refers incorrectly to the chef at La Solo gnote in Brinon-sur-Sauldre. The chef, Dominique Girard, is a man.

title: Laura Moffatt, Edmond Thompson
description: Laura Margaret Moffatt and Edmond F. Thompson are to be married today at St. Patrick's Church in Huntington, N.Y. The Rev. John J. Denniston, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Political Briefing; Buchanan Fights On, For a Future Election
description: Patrick J. Buchanan has a new plan.

title: Big Play Hurts Fordham, And Rekindles a Rout
description: Brown flanker Stephen Campbell, who made a team-record 19 receptions a week ago, had eight more yesterday against Fordham at Jack Coffey Field. But his biggest play of the day came on a kickoff that he ran back 83 yards for a touchdown in the third quarter.

title: One Year. Fresh Arrivals. New York.
description: Thirty years after we left New York for the suburbs, my wife and I have escaped back to Manhattan -- to an apartment a few blocks from where I lived when I first came to the city, in 1956. Of course, many things have changed. What hasn't is how I feel at 67: I'm a kid again, drinking in the city as if it were the first time. I have rediscovered Central Park, and it has never looked so beautiful.

title: High Standards In Corporate Accounting
description: To the Editor:

title: India Tries To Reassess Its Measure For Poverty
description: By nearly any economic measure, India is a country with multitudes of poor people, but precisely how many? The attempt to answer that question has sparked a vigorous debate in recent months among some of the country's leading economists.

title: Where Old Trees and Bushes Go to . . . Live
description: SOME people covet their ancestral sterling silver, others dote on old rugs, medicine bottles or superannuated spittoons. But only a few people really appreciate horticultural antiques. The members of the Scarsdale Women's Club are among those people.

title: Emily Baldwin, John Augustine
description: Emily Elizabeth Baldwin and John Douglas Augustine were married yesterday in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel Love performed the ceremony at Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: Welcome to the Dollhouse
description: Even though the design world is having a modern moment, the dollhouse world has been generally slow to respond -- until now. The Kaleidoscope House, which is manufactured by Bozart Toys and was designed by Laurie Simmons, an artist, and Peter Wheelwright, an architect, is a place a 21st-century doll can call home. Even better, it's filled with the efforts of a who's who of contemporary designers and artists.

title: A Crowded Collection Finds New Space
description: The Museum of the City of New York is taking advantage of free real estate in cyberspace.

title: Fans of Yankees and Mets Back Both Teams, for Now
description: It was beyond Clinton-Lazio. Higher than Wall Street. Deeper than Hamlet moralizing over dead Ophelia. It was a gorgeous autumn Saturday for baseball, the Yankees and the Mets were in town for crucial playoff games on the same day, and for New Yorkers dreaming of a Subway Series little else mattered.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We turned eastward but now I am confident we can turn westward and heal our wounds.''

title: Hints for Tenants in a Conversion
description: IN the last two years, there has been a flurry of conversions of rental buildings to co-ops or condominiums in New York City and the surrounding suburbs, according to the state attorney general's office. The office said there had been nine such conversions in New York City alone since the beginning of 1999.

description: Dr. Rachael Lynn Frandina and Dr. Joseph Michael Caiati Jr., physicians in New York, were married yesterday at St. Louis Roman Catholic Church in Buffalo. The Rev. Mark A. Connolly performed the ceremony.

title: Despite Protests, Denver's Columbus Day Parade Resumes
description: For the first time in nine years today, Italian-Americans in Denver bucked a tide of protest and staged a Columbus Day parade along a few city blocks of downtown.

title: From Brooklyn to Montauk, One Step at a Time; On a Nine-Day Hike, an Intimate 'Warts and All' Portrait of the Island Emerges
description: THERE are few things that Patty Ellis enjoys more than walking. She likes to walk along Jones Beach, and she walks regularly during her lunch hour at work. Walking gives her a chance to think, she says, and to quietly enjoy her surroundings.

description: NETZARIM, Gaza, Oct. 7  Muhammad Rayyan, 12, was ready when the Israeli soldiers fired, the bullets whizzing and cracking in unnerving waves overhead, forcing dozens of people to sprawl motionless on the ground and crouch behind sand piles.

description: MIDTOWN

description: To the Editor:

description: Vice President Al Gore, responding to intensifying Republican attacks on his credibility, said today that he did not have a problem with embellishment that should cause concern about his character, and he accused Gov. George W. Bush of waging personal attacks rather than focusing on issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARLOW, FRANCES (FRAN)
description: BARLOW-Frances (Fran). Wife of the late Meyer (Mac) Barlow. Beloved mother of Seldon and Lydia, Susan and Clive. Very loving grandmother to Paul, Mindy, Michael and Jessica Barlow, and Jill and Eric Sussman. Great-gandmother of Morgan, Aaron, Cori, Mitchell and Justin. Passed away on October 7, 2000. We will all miss her for her devotion to humanity and her dedication to the fight for making the world a safe and peaceful place for all. From her family and friends, from the poor and underprivileged, our last goodbye. Private graveside service on Tuesday.

title: Baltic Tours
description: To The Editor: Re the information in the Q & A column about trips to the Baltic region (Aug. 20): We have had the pleasure of traveling to Moscow and St. Petersburg with a tour group called Exeter International (formerly known as RussiaTours).

title: Jones Throws a One-Hitter, and Mets Advance
description: The New York Mets didn't need any more late-inning dramatics.

title: Wiring the Reservations
description: Several American Indian tribes are seeking to create or expand basic telephone service, a necessary step to increase Internet access on native lands, and the Mescalero Apache tribe of southern New Mexico has now become the latest to form its own telephone company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUTKA, LEONARD M.
description: DUTKA-Leonard M. Of Pound Ridge, N.Y. and Carlsbad, Calif. Died on October 4. Retired President of Dynarex Corp and former President of IPCO Hospital Supply. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Devoted father of Elaine, Mark and Richard. Loving father-in-law of Irene. Doting grandfather of Annie B. and Zoe C. Brother of Seymour and Robert. Fighting against insurmountable odds in his battle with Lou Gehrig's Disease, he displayed the courage, selflessness and dignity that typified his entire life. A devout humanist, family man, proponent of social justice, our ''Rock'' and inspiration, he will be sorely missed. Contributions to the ALS Association 818-880-9007 or the Rick Dutka Memorial Fund c/o the Tides Foundation 415561-6400. Services on Sunday at 10:30AM at the Jewish Family Congregation, South Salem, N.Y. 914-763-3028. Interment immediately following at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, N.Y.

title: Portland's New Space for Art of the Northwest
description: Collections of American Indian and Northwest art have a new home at the Portland Art Museum, which recently unveiled its 50,000-square-foot Hoffman Wing in a renovated 1969 building that once served as the museum's art school. The new wing expands the gallery space by 50 percent.

title: After the Curtain Near Lincoln Center
description: BRASSERIE AMERICAINE

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, JOHN D.
description: MORGAN-John D. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John D. Morgan associated with The Times from 1967 until 1984.

title: Riverside Drive And Grant's Tomb
description: To the Editor:

title: Extravagant Evil And the I.M.F.
description: FIRST Seattle, then Prague. The recurrent images of clashes between hooded demonstrators and police officers defending the barons of global capitalism have become a powerful motif for the protests and preoccupations of a new millennium.

title: More Elderly Living Options, at a Price
description: AFTER a three-year stint in Stamford, Conn., Ruth Zema is back in Yonkers. A widow in her mid-70's who was living alone at home, Mrs. Zema decided in 1997 that she needed senior housing. She had to go out of state -- to Stamford -- to find a residence she considered acceptable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MIRIAM WOLFF
description: ROSS-Miriam Wolff. Actor, director and writer, known to the stage as Miriam Wolfe. Peacefully at her home in Toronto, Friday evening, 29 September 2000, at age 78. In the caring presence of her son Michael and friend Lanie. After a lengthy, determined and exhausting battle with breast cancer, she finally rejoins her late husband John Forrest Mackay Ross. A small, private gathering of family and friends will be held. Donations to Dying with Dignity, 55 Eglinton Ave East, Suite 705, Toronto, Ontario, M4P 1G8, will be gratefully acknowledged, as both Miriam and John strongly supported choice in dying.

title: Among Men, It's Bush the Maserati by a Mile
description: When Gov. Gray Davis's political advisers want to take Californians' temperatures on the presidential race in voter focus groups, they ask a question that might sound goofy: if Al Gore and George W. Bush were cars, what would they be?

title: Sasha Boak, John Kelly
description: Alexandra Hamilton Boak, the daughter of Julia Clark Boak of Manhattan and J. Michael Boak of Brooklyn, is to be married today to John Thomas Kelly, the son of the late Catherine and John J. Kelly. The Rev. Dr. Ann Adams is to officiate at the First Presbyterian Church in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FERRARA, RONALD ANTHONY
description: FERRARA-Ronald Anthony. You are forever cherished and always missed. Love, Jane

title: Plan for Veterans' Monument Stirs Debate
description: THE needle of the Washington Monument pierced an almost cloudless sky and the geese outnumbered the tourists at the far end of the Lincoln Memorial's reflecting pool, but Christine McAdoo still acted claustrophobic when she was asked about plans to build a memorial to the veterans of World War II on this spot.

title: The Nation: Make Way for The Donkephant; The Bare-Knuckled Business of Bipartisanship
description: A VOTER had to listen closely (and tune out Vice President Al Gore's aria of sighs) to hear it, but there was something off-kilter about Gov. George W. Bush's references to Democrats during the debate on Tuesday night, something off-key in his tone.

title: Editorial Observer; The Unbearable Memories of a U.N. Peacekeeper
description: The story of Rwanda's genocide in 1994 has few heroes. It was mass murder carried out with machete and hoe, by neighbor against neighbor, with the complicity of the country's churches and elected leaders. The United Nations had a small contingent of peacekeepers in Rwanda before the genocide, but these troops were not allowed to act, and they were pulled out, not reinforced, as the mass killing began.

title: Pomodoro's New Offshoot: Think Small
description: CANTINA POMODORO, a tiny new spot in Huntington Village, is a niche restaurant. Diners with a sense of adventure, who love surprises and enjoy being coddled will find it a pleasure. Those who are finicky about food, have strong likes and dislikes, have dietary restrictions or food allergies might want avoid it.

title: Defining, and Redefining, American
description: AFTER its performances today in Morristown and next weekend in New Brunswick, American Repertory Ballet may want to rethink its name. The dances choreographed by its English-born director, Graham Lustig, are set to tangos by Astor Piazzolla, a Brazilian, to a piano piece by the English composer Michael Nyman, and to a concerto by Poulenc whose dance Mr. Lustig named ''Paramour.'' So, repertory of America, where are you now?

title: Environment Is the Loser In U.S. Energy Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: MetroStars Turn Attention To Matthaus and Stadium
description: The MetroStars' turnaround from worst in the league to a goal away from reaching the championship game of Major League Soccer can be attributed to the attitude and efforts of players and the team's new management.

title: OUT THERE: London; Sympathy for the Devil in a Sinless Club
description: IN an example of one of Britain's least likely trends -- an imitation of American-style healthy living -- Ron Wood of the Rolling Stones has opened a different kind of private club. There is no boozing until 4 a.m., as is common at London's other private clubs. Nor is there dancing into the wee hours, as is the fashion at Tramp and Annabel's -- two grand dames of the London nightclub circuit. The Harrington Club closes at midnight. Mick Jagger suggested turning a room into a disco. Mr. Wood vetoed it. ''It's not really a place you can make loud noise,'' he said, a sheepish grin spreading over his face.

title: IN BRIEF: Government; YONKERS: MUTUAL AID AT RISK
description: With 18 fire companies under his command and 15,000 emergency calls a year, Fire Commissioner Peter S. Guyett of Yonkers is changing the way his city aids neighboring communities. While Yonkers will still answer calls in emergencies, the city has told Eastchester and Mount Vernon that it will not send firefighters to sit in a firehouse as backup. ''We have our own emergencies,'' Mr. Guyett said. ''I can't afford to supplement their budgets on the backs of the citizens of Yonkers.'' He said the 38-year-old mutual aid agreement needs revamping. Elsa Brenner

title: IN BRIEF: Government; CARMEL: BIRD HABITAT
description: The state has designated 10,050-acres in Clarence Fahnestock State Park in Carmel as a Bird Conservation Area, the 11th one since 1997. The habitat, with large forest areas, is host to many birds, some considered at risk of extinction. Elsa Brenner

title: He Sells Fish Garnished With Blessings and Cheer
description: Abdul Muhammad smiles when he recalls the days when the milkman delivered fresh milk and eggs to everybody's front stoop in the morning.

title: Normandy
description: To the Editor: Thanks to Frederick Turner (''Autumn Is Mellow Deep in Normandy,'' Sept. 10) for reminding me of a visit, in 1976, to the splendid Calvados countryside and an overnight at the same Auberge du Vieux Puits in Pont-Audemer.

title: October 1-7; Number Crunchers Take the Gold
description: Forget that Russian gymnast and that Australian swimmer. The real winners in Sydney were Andrew Bernard and Meghan Busse, the business school professors who created a model to predict how many medals each nation would win at the 2000 Olympic Games.

title: Operating System
description: THE SECOND COMING

title: Footnotes
description: 1. The sight of a large piece of furniture being hoisted through the window of a New York City apartment is no big deal. The sight of an oil tank being airlifted by crane into a loft, however, might raise a few eyebrows. This was definitely the case when the 7,200-gallon tank from an oil truck arrived at Josh Morton's building just over a year ago (a, b). Can't live without a tank of your own? Morton acquired the rehabilitated tank for a mere $3,500 from Garafano Tank Service in Paterson, N.J. That's about $50,000 less than the cost of a new truck. And there's no need to worry about fumes or trace petroleum: each three-ton tank is meticulously steam-cleaned by Peter Garafano and his crew.

title: Easing of Some Restrictions By West Could Happen Soon
description: Disastrous civil wars, onerous sanctions and corrupt misrule turned Yugoslavia from the most open and developed nation in the old Communist orbit into the sick man of Central Europe, with a collapsed economy, plummeting living standards and a wretched inventory of bombed bridges, severed electrical lines and outdated factories.

title: Sports of The Times; Three Days' Rest and the '64 Phillies' Phlop
description: UNLESS the Yankees win tonight's decisive fifth game at Oakland to salvage their American League division series, they will be branded as having suffered the most colossal collapse in baseball history.

title: Justice for Women
description: To the Editor:

title: On Milosevic: What to Do?
description: Even revolutions have a day after. Serbia's came today beneath a pale sun that illuminated the giddying contradictions of the national soul -- uplifted by the overthrow of Slobodan Milosevic, disoriented by his long rule, alternately vengeful and compromising, angry and cowed.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: One Grape, Two Wines
description: Two gewurztraminers from one winery in one vintage is somewhat unusual on Long Island. Tom Drozd, the winemaker at Palmer Vineyards in Aquebogue on the North Fork, successfully undertook such an experiment a year ago.

title: Give Back the Gold
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Resources
description: A selective list of where to find the architects, designers and products featured in this issue.

title: Alexandra Lee, Richard Sohn
description: Alexandra Won Lee, the daughter of Suk Yung and Dr. Kie Bok Lee of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Hoon Sohn, a son of Ryang Sue Sohn and Dr. Jeung Ho Sohn of Hollis, N.H. The Rev. Jennifer McKenna performed the ceremony at the Second Presbyterian Church in Baltimore.

title: GROWTH VS. SPRAWL
description: The New Jersey Sierra Club reviewed more than 50 New Jersey development projects last week, highlighting the best and worst of recent development in an effort to commend good growth and call attention to the problems of suburban sprawl. The club cited the Metuchen Square development in Hoboken as the state's best project and Oakland's Ramapo River Reserve development as the state's worst, based on 30 positive and 20 negative criteria, such as location near mass transit, concern for endangered species and preserving greenways. The review is part of a 50-state survey conducted by the Sierra Club, ''Smart Choices or Sprawling Growth.'' Anne Ruderman

title: The World: Stare Down; Serbs Shed Their Fear and Make a Revolution
description: THE black plumes of smoke rising from Yugoslavia's federal Parliament building as a flag-waving throng storms the building will forever define the Serbian revolution that toppled Slobodan Milosevic. In its way, the image has the force of the photograph of a soldier planting the Soviet flag atop the Reichstag in Berlin in 1945. Both images are overwhelming in their glorious finality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENTEN, MOLLY
description: ENTEN-Molly, age 96. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Adored mother of Judge Harold Enten (Barbara). Loving grandmother of Louise and Harry. Will be deeply missed. Services at Garlick-Riverside, 1439 Unionport Rd., Bronx on Sunday, October 8th at 10AM.

title: Corrections
description: The picture caption with the Vows column last Sunday, about the marriage of Andrea Faith Gurwitt and Adam Charles Eidelberg, misstated the date of the event. As the column noted, it was Sept. 24, not Sept. 9.

title: Luring Back Concorde Passengers
description: Air France and British Airways are seeking ways to keep the loyalty of their most lucrative passengers, those who shuttled across the North Atlantic on the supersonic Concordes, which have been grounded since a July 25 crash near Charles de Gaulle Airport outside Paris that killed 113 people.

title: Behind the Experts' Smoke, There's More Smoke
description: PLEASE ignore most of what you read in this section.

title: Cheering On the Door-to-Door Troops
description: NESTLED between the factories and forklifts on Westmoreland Avenue here is a small office building with a small sheet of paper on its front door bearing the name E&G Communications.

title: Tell Us What You Really Think
description: Thomas Brown has never been one to mince words in his career as a Wall Street analyst and, more recently, as a hedge fund manager and proprietor of Bankstocks.com. But on his site last week, he outdid even his earlier barbs about banking executives and analysts.

description: Now that the Stanley Cup banner has been raised to the rafters at the south end of Continental Arena and all the emotion has dissipated, the Devils can go to work at what they do best: allowing as few goals as possible.

title: Europe Leads in Solheim Before Rain Puts Off Play
description: LUSS, Scotland, Oct. 7  Sophie Gustafson of Sweden and England's Trish Johnson stayed unbeaten in three matches as their European team won two fourball matches in the Solheim Cup today before rain washed out play for the day.

title: Left Bank Hotel
description: To the Editor: Regarding the Hotel Pont Royal (Travel Advisory, Sept. 17): before I even arrived at the hotel three months ago, there was a problem. No one at the hotel had checked the e-mail, and so they failed to make the restaurant reservations I had requested.

title: Christina Corbett, Robert McGinness

Corbett Jr., both of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Andrew McGinness, a son of Lucille McGinness and Robert E. McGinness of Wellesley, Mass. Frances A. Richards, a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's maternal grandfather, Christopher H. Phillips, in Ipswich, Mass.

title: Sarah Spencer, Beau Hurst
description: Sarah Coles Spencer, the daughter of Mary Randolph Spencer of Richmond, Va., and Harold Rennolds Spencer of Warrenton, Va., was married yesterday to Basil Leonard Hurst III, the son of Cordelia Harrison Ward, also of Richmond, and Mr. Hurst Jr. of Newport News, Va. The Rev. Robert G. Hetherington performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Richmond.

title: Music of the Heart
description: By profession, Yehuda Gilad is a conductor, not a marriage-maker. But the Colonial Symphony's Morristown season opens with a little evidence that Mr. Gilad is both. When Sheryl Staples, Saturday's soloist in the Beethoven Violin Concerto, came from Los Angeles four years ago to perform with the orchestra, its timpanist, Barry Centanni, was smitten. As casually as he could, he asked Mr. Gilad about Ms. Staples' life out west, and about her, er, husband. Learning from Mr. Gilad that she was, in fact, single, he managed to wait till the second rehearsal to approach her. Cut to the chase -- or to last April's wedding cake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, NORMAN

Cherished grandfather of Ali, Samantha, Deborah, Thomas, Heather and Brittany. Service Sunday 10:00 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel 21 West Broad St. Mount Vernon, NY.

title: From New York to Trenton, To Help Police Department
description: In the last few years, the Trenton police department has faced union troubles, discipline problems and a high-profile shooting that raised an outcry over the poor relationship between the police and the community. Now, the police director, with a mandate from the mayor's office, has hired the man credited with turning around New York City's mammoth police force to see if he can do the same for Trenton.

title: Holidays Tomorrow
description: Columbus Day, actually Oct. 12, will be legally observed. Yom Kippur is also observed tomorrow.

title: Paper Reinstates Writer Who Likened Politician to Hitler
description: Walter Sanchez, the publisher of The Queens Ledger, has reinstated a columnist who compared Terri Thomson, the Queens representative to the city's Board of Education, to Hitler. The writer, Frank Borzellieri, was suspended after a column with that comparison appeared in July.

title: John's Call The Warrior At Belmont
description: It was a memorable day at Belmont Park yesterday for Jean-Luc Samyn, the 43-year-old jockey: he rode the winners of both Grade I stakes, the Flower Bowl Invitational and the Turf Classic Invitational, each worth $750,000 plus the inside track on this year's turf championships.

description: WHEN I first came to New York, in 1985, a friend and I were sitting in what was then called the Kenny Scharf Room downstairs at the Palladium and this hip-looking old guy walked in with a gorgeous chick on each arm.

title: IN BRIEF: Sports; SHORT-LIVED SEASON
description: Tre Johnson, the Peekskill native who is a lineman with the Washington Redskins, started his season late and it appears to have ended early. The 6-foot-2, 326-pound guard, who served an opening-game suspension for striking an official last season, suffered a torn left-knee ligament in last Sunday's victory over Tampa Bay. Coach Norv Turner said he expected Johnson to need surgery and be lost for the season. ''It's what you have to live with,'' Johnson said early in the week. ''All I can do is what I can do.'' Chuck Slater

title: As Investors Worry More About Their Tax Bills, Managers Should, Too
description: UNTIL recently, mutual fund managers had little incentive to care about the tax consequences of their investments. After all, very few investors were choosing funds according to after-tax performance. Nor were any managers' reputations suffering because their shareholders' after-tax returns were so much lower than their pretax returns.

George, as much as we hate to admit it, even if we practiced for our entire lives we could never beat the Sundance Kid. From the DAC Squash Hackers

title: BackTalk; There's at Least One Fan Down Front Who Will Miss the Big Fella
description: I fall into the group that regrets seeing Patrick Ewing go. I clocked him, along with Walt Frazier, as one of the two greatest Knickerbocker players in the team's history. Like Frazier, he was home-grown, that is, a Knick drafted right out of college and not acquired in a deal. This is not to say the Knicks didn't get many fine athletes in trades. Dave DeBusschere, Larry Johnson and Bob McAdoo were great and of course Earl Monroe made the game art, but Frazier and Ewing began their professional lives here and that puts something extra into their pedigrees.

title: Exam Time at the Debates
description: The first presidential debate of campaign 2000 was testy and confusing. The meeting between the vice-presidential contenders was somber and informative. Now those debates are over, we can see the broad outlines of the political drama that will play out over the next four weeks. Voters will be trying to figure out whether the Republican nominee, Gov. George W. Bush, is knowledgeable enough to be president, and whether the Democratic candidate, Vice President Al Gore, is likable enough. To observe the personal nature of the choice between the candidates is not to denigrate the important role of issues like taxes, Social Security, health, education and defense. But anyone listening to the campaign dialogue on talk shows and at dinner tables has to be struck by the degree to which politically engaged people are focusing on the candidates' contrasting capabilities and personality traits.

title: In Defense Of Columbus
description: THROUGHOUT time, treasure has typically been measured in trinkets and pennyweights, coins and carats. But to William J. Connell, a historian at Seton Hall University, ''there's nothing more precious than a hard fact.''

title: Two Business Groups Considering a Merger
description: Harold E. Vogt is retiring after 30 years as president of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce, and the chamber is considering a merger with the county's other major business advocacy group, the Westchester County Association.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-08-00; Too Many Eyes On the Prize
description: In spite of its deep obsession with the spinoffs of technical research, from cell phones to DNA fingerprinting, the global culture operates with only the vaguest idea of where all this fascinating stuff comes from. It's not that laypeople are uninterested in the mysteries of pure research; they just can't navigate among them anymore -- nor can anyone, really, who does not belong to whatever subspecialty has produced the latest laser weapon or impotence drug.

title: Courtney Colodner, Seth Dallaire

The Rev. Jay Sidebotham, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Church in Manhattan.

title: A Company's Key: Subscribers Who Renew
description: ANY salesperson will tell you that it is easier and more cost-efficient to retain customers rather than to bring in new ones. In the business of running a small, professional theater, however, neither is a cakewalk. Stamford Theater Works, which started its 13th season recently with Russell Lee's serio-comedy ''Nixon's Nixon,'' has proven to be the little theater that could.

title: Broadcast Schedule; Senate Debates

Lazio will be held at the Broadcast Center of WCBS-TV (Channel 2) on West 57th Street. It will be shown live on Channel 2, CNN and C-Span. A tentative list of radio stations that plan to broadcast the debate includes WCBS-AM (880), Bloomberg's WBBR-AM (1130) and NPR's WNYC-AM (820).
