title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEENAN, MAURICE, C.M.G., Q.C.
description: HEENAN-Maurice, C.M.G., Q.C., former Attorney General of Hong Kong, died September 26 at the age of 87 at his residence ''Plane Trees'', 534 West Road, New Canaan, Connecticut. Educated in New Zealand, LLB, barrister & solicitor of Supreme Court of New Zealand 1937-40, Major, 2nd NZEF (Western Desert, Libya, Cyrenaica & Italy) 1939-45, Crown Counsel Palestine 1946-48, married in 1951 to Claire Cihova of Trencin, Slovakia (former Czechoslovakia). In 1966 he was invited to join the United Nations in New York as Deputy Director, General Legal Division, Offices of the Secretary General. In 1973 he was appointed General Counsel for the UN Relief & Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees in the Middle East. Member of The Hong Kong Club and The Country Club of New Canaan. He is survived by his wife Claire, his daughters Ingrid Heenan Hammond and Karen Heenan Pujol, and his grandchildren Ogden, Ingrid, John, Katherine and Alexa. London Times and news publications in Hong Kong, Beirut, New Zealand and Slovakia, please reprint.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRER, NORMA (NEE NASH)
description: BARRER-Norma (nee Nash). Of Ft. Lee, NJ, on October 7, 2000. Beloved wife of Jerome. Devoted mother of Peter Barrer, Carole Barrer, Nancy Barrer and Betty Barrer. Cherished grandmother of Joshua, Ira, Rachel, Jennifer and Samuel. Past President of NCJW, South Shore, LI, and Palm Beach, FL chapters. Past president of Hospital Escort Service of Yorkville. Services today, 11:15 AM, at United Hebrew Cemetery, Arthur Kill Rd., Staten Island, NY. Expressions of sympathy in her memory may be made to NCJW or the American Cancer Society. For information ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 1-800-522-0588.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-08-00: ShopTalk; Be It Resolved . . .
description: With the quadrennial ritual of presidential debates now under way, the discussion has turned, as ever, to tangential matters like which candidate seems more statesmanlike and which one is more telegenic. But what of the debate itself? Do the televised exchanges between the two front-runners bear any relation to the ancient rhetorical art that bears the same name? And if so, what advice do its most skilled practitioners have to offer? We asked Christopher Park, a star of the Harvard Speech and Parliamentary Debate Society, and Michael Horowitz, a recent graduate of Emory and winner (with Jon Paul Lupo) of the 2000 National Debate Tournament, to share some of the secrets of their skills.

title: Liberties; West Wing Chaperone
description: The Bushies kept telling me that, eventually, I would feel the Cheney magic. They said it would tingle ''like champagne,'' as one member of the clan put it.

title: With Son's Team on the Wane, A Father Takes Over as Coach
description: MY wife said I was being too pushy, too Type A, when I wanted our son, Jeremy, to try out for the traveling soccer team in second grade. I told her I could already see that our 8-year-old had talent in the sport.

title: Where The Life Enters The Work
description: MARY FRANK is a quintessential 20th-century artist forever on the brink of her own millennial revelation. So much was she shaped by midcentury modernist culture -- its seriousness and anxiety, its traumas and resurgent longings for transcendence -- that her work, which has moved people to tears and elicited rapturous critical praise, still wants exegesis today. Now two retrospective shows of her paintings -- at the D.C. Moore Gallery, 724 Fifth Ave., through Saturday, and the Neuberger Museum in Purchase, N.Y., through Jan. 7 -- provide an occasion.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about sound design for movies misstated Francis Ford Coppola's age when he founded the company American Zoetrope in 1969. He was 30, not 35.

title: N.Y.U. Plans a New Park, But Neighbors Feel Left Out
description: A plan to build a park on the waterfront between North Seventh and North Ninth Streets hinges on the support of New York University, which has promised money for the project. But some have questioned the role of the Manhattan university in this Brooklyn neighborhood.

title: In the Ninth, Rivera Stays in the (Strike) Zone
description: Don't bother asking Mariano Rivera about how tough he is to hit at this time of year. His eyes will widen, and he will start to laugh nervously.

title: Georgia Park Is to Hail 'Southern Spirit'
description: Surrounded by pine woods, the 825-foot high granite dome that looms over this suburb east of Atlanta is famous for many things: the Rushmore-esque relief of the Confederate leaders Robert E. Lee, Jefferson Davis and Stonewall Jackson; the birthplace of the modern-day Ku Klux Klan; and 3,200 acres of forest and lake that make Stone Mountain Park among the state's most popular tourist destinations.

title: Sign Right Here
description: Consumers have grown accustomed to buying books, records and more with the click of a mouse. But a home? On Oct. 1, the Electronic Signatures in Global Commerce Act went into effect, giving contracts signed by mouse, modem or other high-tech means the same legal weight as the ink-on-paper variety. The result could be increased convenience and cost savings for business and consumers alike, with the potential for increased security. The law, however, does not force consumers to sign on the dotted e-line. They can still opt for deals based on the paper variety. ''If you're not comfortable with closing a deal online, don't do it,'' advised Frank Torres, the legislative counsel at Consumers Union. John Schwartz

title: They Also Ran
description: As Election Day draws near, it is time to remember that this country has had a lot of presidential losers. In fact, Rutgers University has an exhibit about them, ''The Dust Bin of History: Presidential Losers, 1796-1996.''

title: COMPLAINTS ABOUT POLICE
description: The number of complaints filed against municipal police in New Jersey increased dramatically between 1995 and 1997, according to a survey of the years 1995 through 1998 done by the National Institute of Ethics, a leading provider of police ethics training based in Winter Park, Fla. The complaints reached a high of 9,025 in 1997 compared with 6,208 in 1995. In 1998, the number dropped to 8,688. Essex and Hudson Counties topped the list with the most complaints. The complaints ranged from excessive use of force to police

title: So, Three Doctors Walk Into a Fund Company. . .
description: IN the summer of 1999, Dr. Camilo Martinez was treating the working poor of the San Fernando Valley in a clinic north of Los Angeles. A year later, he was sitting in a courtroom in Boston, monitoring the health of a very different subject: the shares of Amgen, the biotechnology company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VLACHOS, ALICE M.
description: VLACHOS-Alice M. Died on September 29, 2000. Beloved wife and loving mother, she leaves behind her husband of 52 years, James, and her adoring children: her sons, Paul Vlachos and Nicholas Christopher, and her daughter-in-law, Constance Christopher. She was the joy and light of her family and her many friends. Memorial service was held on October 7 at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church.

title: SOAPBOX; Mourning a Humble Ailanthus
description: THANK God it was a cool summer. In 25 years of living in New York I can't remember another July when I reached for a blanket. But now that my tree is gone, there will be afternoons you can bake potatoes on the fifth-floor windowsills of my century-old tenement on Sullivan Street. The shade is gone and with it a part of the urban canopy.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Little Gloria, Free at Last
description: In his sprawling new novel, GLORIA (Soho, $27), which takes place among the country club set in West Virginia in the late 1950's, Keith Maillard gets the details right. The book, which owes a small debt to John O'Hara's fiction, is meticulous in its resurrection of period detail -- the fashions, the slang and the social and sexual mores of debutantes, cocktail-drinking executives and drum majorettes. The novel is set largely during the summer of 1957, a momentous one for Gloria Cotter. She is back home in Raysburg, W.Va. after graduating from college, and she has three months to make a big decision: Will she marry Rolland Spicer, her devoted and socially unimpeachable college sweetheart, as her family and almost everyone else expects? Or will she head instead for New York City, where an unknown world, as well as a graduate program in Renaissance poetry, await her at Columbia University? There are many stumbling blocks on the journey Gloria has to make that summer: the rigid conformism of Eisenhower society, her sorority sisters and her controlling parents; the unwanted advances of her father's brutish right-hand man; her distrust of her own sexuality; and, above all, her all-consuming need to fit in, which is at war with her streak of intellectual rebellion. ''Gloria'' is occasionally weighed down by its heroine's tendentious equation of literary criticism with religious salvation, and perhaps by one or two more references than are strictly necessary to the various contours and responses of her athletic body. But Maillard nevertheless succeeds in building a gilded, crinoline-draped labyrinth and watching his lithe, artful protagonist wiggle and reason her way to freedom. Jesse Browner

title: Why Are They Dying in Cinnaminson?
description: IT was Christmas night and the festivities at the Fisher house were winding down. Like any 18-year-old, Bobby Fisher was eager to go hang with his friends. He had argued with his girlfriend Lizzie, who was home from college, earlier in the day because they weren't getting together on Christmas. But she agreed that they would celebrate the following day.

title: The Autumn Of the Oligarchs
description: Vladimir Putin, president of Russia, looked down the gorgeous hall in the Kremlin of which he was now master. Seated before him, on a muggy summer day, were some 30 men who represented the better part of Russia's capitalist class. They were known as oligarchs, from the Greek-derived ''oligarchy,'' meaning rule of the few. In the Yeltsin era of the 1990's, so much power passed into their hands that the word had fit them like a glove. Putin -- a diminutive man who had made lieutenant colonel in the K.G.B. -- was here to tell them that their rule was over.

description: Gray shoebox-sized radio devices are fastened to light poles around the city, and Metricom, a California Internet company, wants you to feel good about them.

title: The Maximum Security Adolescent
description: In contrast to some in Margaret Talbot's article (Sept. 10), Jessica Robinson's case was hardly her first brush with the law. At the time she committed the offense against her grandparents, she was on juvenile probation for a violent crime. And Robinson attempted to rob an 80-year-old man at knifepoint a few weeks before she victimized her grandparents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, ALTON
description: BRODY-Alton. Of Boca Raton, FL, died peacefully October 6, at the age of 82. He is the beloved husband of Gloria Brody, loving father of Dr. Roberta Godbe and Stephen Brody, grandather of Michael and Zachary. He was a veteran, furniture distributor and sales executive and president of Furniture Wholesalers Inc. Al was a devoted father and exceptional husband. His major charitable contributions were to DWH for leukemia research and he was instrumental in reactivating the United Brothers Synagogue, serving as its first president. Services in Boca Raton, October 8 and a memorial service, United Brothers Synagogue, Bristol, RI on October 13, at 11 AM.

title: The Blood All Over
description: Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga, the president of Sri Lanka, is a virtual prisoner in the fortress of her official residence, locked away in a lovely, white-washed mansion from the suicide bombers who prowl the traffic-clogged streets of the capital, Colombo. They wait for a chance to blow themselves up and take her with them, all in the cause of a separate homeland for the country's ethnic Tamil minority. Even with parliamentary elections crucial to the future of her government looming on Oct. 10, Kumaratunga, a formidable, instinctive campaigner, has not appeared at public rallies because of fears she will be killed.

description: DEAR DIARY:

description: SYDNEY, Australia  After most athletes had flown home from here with their Olympic memories, Louise Sauvage was training hard for her gold medal races.

title: In a Weak Ruble, Strength for Russian Timber
description: UNTIL a few years ago, the small town of Sokol in the Vologda region of northwest Russia was largely idle. Now, thanks to a timber plant that was nearly bankrupt, Sokol is coming to life again. Logs are brought in constantly by rail. Large tractors haul loads of wood. Even more important, employees are paid real money for real work -- a not-so-common arrangement in Russia's economy.

title: Shooting the Messenger
description: Fashion feeds on the outrageous, the marginal, even the outright menacing. And it often draws vitality from the outlaw style embodied by New York's City's ubiquitous bicycle messengers. In ''Messengers Style'' (Assouline, $24.95), the photographer Philippe Bialobos and the fashion historian Valerie Steele look at the insolent, idiosyncratic get-ups created by those urban couriers on wheels. In their photos and text, the two identify the influence that members of this funky subculture wield on fashion at large. Ninja, pilot, punk, weird prophet -- these are just a few of the oddball personas messengers have assumed, and civilians have been quick to adopt their accessories, including chain belts and tinted aviator specs, studded wristbands stacked like bangles, cell phones and, of course, the trusty messenger bag.

title: Put Down This Newspaper And Turn On the Debate
description: One candidate is prone to getting lost in his own syntactical swamps, and staring into the camera as if someone just shut off the teleprompter. The other is a policy wonk, a sometimes evasive career politician, who runs the risk of coming across like a one-note scold.

title: Cell-Phone Cars For the L.I.R.R.?
description: Re cell phones on Long Island Rail Road trains [''Cell Phone Abuse Is Riding the Rails,'' Sept. 10]: there's a solution that I learned about while travelling this summer in England, where trains have designated ''quiet coaches,'' in which cell phones are banned. How about having one or two ''cell phone carriages'' on each L.I.R.R. train, and banning cell phone use on the rest? Let them enjoy one another's company, leaving the rest of us to peace and quiet.

title: Winning Belgrade

It was his unpretentious and somehow normal air that made him a perfect candidate for the presidential election, which became a referendum on Mr. Milosevic himself.

title: Jets Lose Testaverde and Perfect Record

The day got worse for the Jets (4-1) as the rest of the team sleepwalked through a mistake-marred 20-3 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: SmithKline Beecham to Buy Block Drug Company for $1.24 Billion
description: LONDON -- SmithKline Beecham PLC is to buy U.S.-based Block Drug Co. for $1.24 billion, the pharmaceutical giant announced Monday. SmithKline Beecham has made a cash tender offer for all outstanding Block common stock at $53 per share, the drug group said in a statement. Block Drug, based in Jersey City, New Jersey, manufactures Sensodyne toothpaste, Poli-Grip denture adhesive and other consumer health care products. The firm reported sales of $864.3 million in the year to March 31, 2000. SmithKline said it had received commitments from a majority of Block shareholders to tender into the offer. "This acquisition will significantly enhance SB's Consumer Health Care business, which is a key part of out strategy for corporate growth," said SmithKline Beecham CEO J.P. Garnier. SmithKline Beecham sold $4.1 billion worth of consumer health care products in 1999, a third of its total sales. The deal places SmithKline, which already produces the Aquafresh brand, among the world's top three toothpaste manufacturers. The company said it was too early to say what effect the takeover would have on jobs at Block Drug, which employs 3,000 people "In any merger or takeover, jobs are lost," said SmithKline Beecham spokeswoman Lynne Smith. "We will have a process that ensures we keep the best people ... There will be an effect in both companies." The deal, which must gain regulatory approval in the United States and Europe, is not expected to affect SmithKline Beecham's proposed merger with Glaxo Wellcome PLC, the statement said. That merger, which also is awaiting U.S. and British regulatory approval, is scheduled to be completed by the end of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLANE, ED
description: MULLANE-Ed, who continued as owner and operator of Mullane Ford and as President of the Ford Dealers' Alliance until his last days, died on October 7, 2000, at his home in Paramus, NJ. He died of pulmonary complications, the residual effects of polio, which had kept him hospitalized for a year as a youth over seventy years ago. The Captain of the Hackensack High School football team, Ed subsequently graduated from Fordham University in 1935, and successfully ran his own business for over sixty years. Mullane Ford in Bergenfield, NJ, has always been noted for the highest quality customer service, and has thrived on repeat business. He was known as a maverick and highly principled advocate for the independent dealer, creating and leading the Ford Dealers' Alliance (FDA) in order to promote dealer and consumer interests in dealings with Ford Motor Company. Over the years Ed gave speeches in every state and was known for his fiery rhetoric in promoting the FDA. He also testified before legislative committees at both the federal and state levels, and his comments on industry issues have been broadcast by all the networks and published in the N.Y. Times and other major news media. Through his efforts major changes were achieved to bring more equity for dealers with regard to warranty reimbursement rates, fleet subsidies, parts prices and other issues. While he was often at odds with Ford policies, he developed friendships with several top Ford executives, including Lee Iaococa and Ben Bidwell. As Bidwell said in admiration, ''After Ed was made, they threw away the mold.'' In 1977 he was awarded the Distinguished Service Citation by the AOT, a leading automotive trade association. He was honored as one of the most influential people in the automotive industry over the last fifty years. Ed often used great quotations in his speeches, and this one from Edmund Burke best captures Ed's spirit: ''The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing.'' This is how he lived his life; he believed one man could make a difference, and he succeeded in making that difference. Ed's wife Ruth passed away in 1996. He is survived by his brother Bill of Oradell, NJ, his daughter Mary Alice Hill and her husband Bob of Summit, NJ, his son Michael Mullane and his wife Sarah of Park Ridge, NJ. Adored grandfather of seven grandchildren, Susan, Paul, Jennifer, Ryan, Erin, Elizabeth and Liam. Also survived by one great-grandson Abraham. Family will receive friends at the Beaugard Funeral Home, 869 Kinderkamack Rd., River Edge, NJ 07661, on Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10 AM, at St. Mary's R.C. Church in Closter. Interment is at George Washington Memorial Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations are requested in Ed's memory to Interweave Center, 31 Woodland Ave, Summit, NJ 07901, or St. Mary's Parish School, 20 Legion Place, Closter, NJ 07624.

title: How to Recruit Police Officers

Besides increasing numbers, it needs to attract more officers from minority communities, building a police force that has more in common with the people it polices. But Police Commissioner Bernard Kerik's decision to relax the age and education requirements is a bad idea. Instead, the department should dramatically expand its recruiting and find creative new ways to attract and retain mature, well-educated candidates. For starters, the new effort should focus on the college-age population within the city itself, especially at the City University of New York.

The baby gaur, an oxlike creature that is native to India and Southeast Asia, is expected to be born next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUZON, EDWARD
description: KUZON-Edward. Of North Miami Beach, FL on October 6, 2000 in his 90th year. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia (Leff), wife of 65 years. Devoted father and father-in-law of Ronald and Susan of Scarsdale, NY. Loving grandfather of Tiffany, Jillian, Joshua, Ariel and Aaron. Born in Kiev, Russia, he came to America as a young child and settled in Springfield, MA, and eventually in Longmeadow, MA. Together with his wife, Sylvia, and her brother Morris H. Leff, they founded the Bradlees department store chain which was sold in 1962 to the Stop and Shop Companies of Braintree, MA. After a brief retirement he partnered with Jacob Bernstein of Longmeadow, MA, in the formation of a consumer packaging company which was sold in 1988. He was a major supporter and contributor to all Jewish philanthropies and the greater community at large. He never forgot the opportunities that were afforded to him as a result of his American citizenship, and worked for the eventual freedom for all of his family that remained behind in the Soviet Union. He always believed that ''if you take care of the inside, the inside will take care of the outside.'' The funeral and burial were in Springfield, MA on Sunday, October 8, 2000.

title: Nazi Code Machine Poses a New Enigma for the British

title: Media Talk; Have Soft Money, Will Print Books

title: Philip Glass Takes on a History of the Cosmos
description: One of the most interesting points in Philip Glass's Symphony No. 5 -- or, to be fair, the single interesting point -- came right at the end. The work was receiving its North American premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday evening, with Dennis Russell Davies conducting the Brooklyn Philharmonic, the Dessoff Choirs and the Brooklyn Youth Chorus, and for more than an hour and a half it had been supplying the composer's usual earnest musical rudiments to clothe sacred writings from around the world in a 12-part history of the cosmos.

title: Belem Journal; In Acts of Faith on Amazon, Middle Ages Live On

Those lucky enough to grasp the thick cord held on tightly, their sweaty faces contorted by fatigue and fervor, as the procession meandered for eight hours to a basilica just three miles away.

title: O.K., Not Quite as Bratty, But They're Still Rowdy

The doctrine is that anyone can play it. That's why Green Day, midway through a concert at Roseland on Wednesday night, called for volunteer musicians from the audience to climb onstage and bash through one of the cornerstones of punk, the Ramones' ''Blitzkrieg Bop.''

title: SmithKline Beecham to Buy Block Drug Company for $1.24 Billion
description: LONDON -- SmithKline Beecham PLC is to buy U.S.-based Block Drug Co. for $1.24 billion, the pharmaceutical giant announced Monday. SmithKline Beecham has made a cash tender offer for all outstanding Block common stock at $53 per share, the drug group said in a statement. Block Drug, based in Jersey City, New Jersey, manufactures Sensodyne toothpaste, Poli-Grip denture adhesive and other consumer health care products. The firm reported sales of $864.3 million in the year to March 31, 2000. SmithKline said it had received commitments from a majority of Block shareholders to tender into the offer. "This acquisition will significantly enhance SB's Consumer Health Care business, which is a key part of out strategy for corporate growth," said SmithKline Beecham CEO J.P. Garnier. SmithKline Beecham sold $4.1 billion worth of consumer health care products in 1999, a third of its total sales. The deal places SmithKline, which already produces the Aquafresh brand, among the world's top three toothpaste manufacturers. The company said it was too early to say what effect the takeover would have on jobs at Block Drug, which employs 3,000 people "In any merger or takeover, jobs are lost," said SmithKline Beecham spokeswoman Lynne Smith. "We will have a process that ensures we keep the best people ... There will be an effect in both companies." The deal, which must gain regulatory approval in the United States and Europe, is not expected to affect SmithKline Beecham's proposed merger with Glaxo Wellcome PLC, the statement said. That merger, which also is awaiting U.S. and British regulatory approval, is scheduled to be completed by the end of the year.

The Yankees have performed like the Sybil of baseball teams lately, one personality expecting something good to happen and the other expecting something bad to happen.

Two glamorous opera stars, the soprano Renee Fleming and the baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky, with the Orchestra of St. Luke's conducted by Mark Elder, sang some chestnut arias and favorite duets.

title: One Germany
description: Germans last week celebrated the 10th anniversary of their nation's reunification, an event once as inconceivable as it is now uncontroversial. Contrary to the initial concerns of wary neighbors, Germany did not turn inward or resuscitate threatening ambitions in the aftermath of reunification. The nation remains a responsible advocate for continued European integration and a strong champion of the Atlantic alliance. Germany still faces formidable challenges in bringing together east and west, but from the perspective of the international community, a united Germany of 83 million people has proved a rousing success.

description: America is a young country with stories to tell. So rapid is our history that we like our stories simple, our characters unequivocal and our conflicts vivid, and this is why we turn so many of them into operas. This kind of narrative balladry has taken on an American style of its own: a lyrical storytelling in which music is an amiable, often meek appendage, happy to echo pastoral themes and bend to the dynamism of words and action.

title: Both Sides Brace for Worst as Israel Shuts for Holy Day
description: Diplomatic and military dialogue steered Israelis and Palestinians away from a broader confrontation today, but leaders on both sides remained braced for the possibility that the fighting that has already claimed at least 85 lives could still worsen.

title: Deadly Infection Re-emerges As People Get Adventurous
description: After falling out of her raft on a whitewater expedition this spring in the Costa Rican rain forest, Dr. Nicole MacLaren was so grateful she was alive that it did not occur to her that her near-drowning might lead to something else -- a potentially fatal bacterial infection called leptospirosis.

title: The Boss: The Dean Is In. Now Pay Up.
description: When I was an economics student at the University of Chicago, my wife and I used to house-sit for my doctoral adviser, Merton H. Miller, who ended up winning a Nobel Prize. We would tramp over twice a day and change his cats' litter and feed them. One day, there was a water-main break, and we spent the afternoon in the basement, sopping wet, cleaning it out with the plumber.

title: Zimbabwe Authorities Crack Down on Political Opposition
description: Two months after President Robert Mugabe bowed to election results and welcomed an opposition into the Parliament for the first time with promises of cooperation, relations have soured. The opposition leader 10 days ago warned Mr. Mugabe that if he didn't step aside, he would be ousted ''violently.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGINNIS, ARTHUR J. SR.
description: McGINNIS-Arthur J. Sr., The Trustees of Monmouth Medical Center and Monmouth Health Care Foundation wish to express their condolences at the passing of Arthur J. McGinnis, Sr., a very loyal Trustee & generous benefactor.

title: A Doctor Like This? You Should Be So Lucky
description: Near the end of the powerful opening episode of ''Gideon's Crossing,'' the camera closes in on Andre Braugher as Ben Gideon, the head of experimental medicine at a Boston hospital. Jogging on a foggy road at night, he is explaining to a friend how he argued with his wife as she was dying of ovarian cancer. ''Bitter fights,'' Mr. Braugher says with restraint, shaking his head and allowing pain to flicker across his face as if it had risen from the depths of his soul. He had wanted her to resist death longer; she was ready to let go. ''Things I said to this poor dying woman,'' he says slowly, his subtle performance capturing all the shades of Gideon's emotions.

title: 3 Israelis Are Now Pawns in a Growing Deal
description: Hezbollah's capture of three Israeli soldiers along the Lebanese border on Saturday was a well-planned operation intended to coincide with the outburst of Palestinian protests over control of a Jerusalem site sacred to both Muslims and Jews, according to leaders of the guerrilla group and military experts.

title: HIGHER FUEL PRICES DO LITTLE TO ALTER MOTORISTS' HABITS
description: When the price of oil tripled in the mid-1970's, Americans' consumption of gasoline fell sharply. Congress approved sweeping new rules calling for a doubling of the fuel efficiency of cars. Gasoline-sipping Honda Civics and Toyota Corollas became some of the most popular cars on the road, shaking the confidence of the American automobile industry.

title: A Prodigious Molecule and Its Growing Pains
description: In the world of chemistry, the soccer-ball-shaped molecule called the buckyball is like a child prodigy yet to live up to early acclaim. But after a quiet adolescence, scientists say the buckyball is on the verge of fulfilling some of its early promises.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVERANT, ISRAEL E. ''ZEKE''
description: LIVERANT-Israel E. ''Zeke''. Antiques dealer of Colchester, husband of Joanna Liverant, passed away peacefully Sunday, (October 8, 2000) at his home. He was born November 26, 1916 in Colchester, where he resided his entire life. Zeke served in the Army during World War II. He was the son of the late Nathan & Esther Liverant. He is survived by two daughters and sons-in-law, Linda and Donald Barger of New Albany, OH, and Abby and Richard Gerrity of Sarasota, FL. He is also survived by a son and daughter-in-law, Arthur and Gigi Liverant of Colchester. Zeke enjoyed seven grandchildren, Neill, Charity & Austin Barger, Hannah and Samara Liverant, and Ryan and Sloane Gerrity. He is survived by a sister, Pearl Vogel; and two brothers, Abraham and Philip. He was predeceased by a sister, Ruth Feir Peck; and two brothers, Benjamin and Samuel. He was also predeceased by his wife, Sylvia. He was the second of a three-generation, nationally known, antiques business in Colchester. He was respected in the field of American Antiques. He was a retired board member of the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society and the Lyman Allyn Museum. Zeke was also a member of the Antiques Dealer Association and the Appraisers Association of America. He was an active member of the Colchester community, serving as the founder of the Colchester Historical Society, a retired member of the Bacon Academy Board of Trustees, and long-term board member and officer of Congregation Ahavath Achim. Funeral services will be held at 11 A.M., on Tuesday, October 10, at the Congregation Ahavath Achim Synagogue on Lebanon Avenue in Colchester. Rabbi Kenneth Alter officiating. Shiva will be observed by the family on Tuesday, at the home of the deceased, at 12 Buckley Hill Road; and Wednesday and Thursday at the home of Arthur and Gigi Liverant at 43 School Road. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Bacon Academy Board of Trustees, the Colchester Historical Society, Congregation Ahavath Achim, the Cragin Memorial Library, or a charity of the donor's choice.

title: Stock Picking's Newest Wave: Democracy
description: When Djordje Radulovic took a job as a research associate at an Internet start-up in May, he never thought he would fulfill his daydream of becoming a professional money manager, and certainly not by the beginning of the fall. But earlier this month, Mr. Radulovic, a 25-year-old employing a bargain-hunting investing style made famous by Warren E. Buffett, started his own investment fund.

title: Postseason Is Agreeing With Edmonds
description: Great players do not always enjoy great postseasons. Ask Barry Bonds or Frank Thomas.

title: Sirimavo Bandaranaike, 84, Matriarch of Sri Lanka, Dies
description: BANGALORE, India, Oct. 10  Sirimavo Bandaranaike of Sri Lanka, the first woman in the world to serve as a prime minister, died today shortly after voting in Sri Lanka's elections. She was 84.

title: Williams-Sonoma Warns on Profits as Catalog Sales Slacken
description: Williams-Sonoma Inc., the kitchen goods and home furnishings chain, said today that its third-quarter profit would fall on lower-than-expected catalog sales and higher costs. The statement sent its shares down as much as 30 percent.

title: Tap the Oil Reserve, and Entrepreneurship Flows
description: Four stories above the streets of central Harlem, Lance Stroud has created a one-man oil company that, after going head to head with the multinationals, may now play a role in the nation's energy agenda.

description: Shares of Netgem S.A. tumbled 26 percent, their steepest drop ever, amid concern that the company's earnings will be hurt if its main client is found guilty of falsifying financial information.

title: The Week in Science: The Ethics of Life-Saving Therapies
description: Is it right for a baby to be conceived to provide tissues to heal an elder sibling? Before saying no, consider the case of the Nash family of Englewood, Colorado, whose 6-year old daughter Molly has Fanconi's anemia. A blood cell transplant from a relative had at best a 50:50 chance of success, but from an unaffected sibling the odds in favor were 85 percent.

title: The Right Trial for Milosevic
description: What is to be done with Slobodan Milosevic? And who is to do it? The lines from Macbeth come to mind: ''We have scotch'd the snake, not kill'd it.'' This particular snake faces us all with the dilemma of balancing the demands of justice against the imperative of an orderly transition of power in Belgrade.

He forced himself to consider another Giants road victory, a 4-2 record and a tie with Washington atop the National Football Conference East. Then he popped in a videotape of the 13-6 victory over the Falcons, and all of his fears came rushing back.

title: YAHOO TO OFFER PHONE-BASED SERVICES
description: Yahoo plans to announce today that it will offer new services directed through a telephone rather than a computer. To that end, Yahoo intends to use a network built by Net2Phone, which transmits telephone calls using Internet technology. Under the brand Yahoo by Phone, Yahoo intends to give consumers access to personalized information and e-mail by calling a toll-free number. Using Net2Phone's network, Yahoo will also offer free voice mail and free phone calls from computers to standard telephones in the continental United States. Seth Schiesel

title: EMACHINES AND MICROSOFT TEAM UP
description: EMachines and Microsoft have agreed to produce an Internet device specifically for Microsoft's MSN online service. The device will cost $400 and be called the MSN Companion. It will be based on a 200-MHz National Semiconductor Geode microprocessor and will join specialized appliances from companies like Compaq, America Online that are intended to make surfing the Web and using e-mail simpler and less expensive. The eMachines appliance will be sold through Circuit City, Office Depot, some Wal-Mart stores and other retailers. It will be promoted with a $400 rebate for customers who commit themselves to a three-year, $21.95-a-month subscription to the MSN service. Microsoft's move toward devices like the MSN Companion and other nonpersonal computers is a reversal. Its executives once ridiculed the idea of such specialized computers. John Markoff

title: A Populist Likes His Country Elegant

Was the Clyde Barrow of country music, the smoothest outlaw ever to sing honeyed words into a microphone, going to pull off this latest caper, promoting a new album on a punk label to an audience of relatively youthful downtowners?

description: MOSCOW, Oct. 10  In a sign of escalating tension, a Russian border guard was killed and five other soldiers were wounded in a fire fight on Tajikistan's border with Afghanistan during the weekend, the Russian armed forces confirmed today.

title: CALGON CARBON SHARES DECLINE ON SLOWING IN SALES
description: Shares of the Calgon Carbon Corporation, the Pittsburgh-based producers of air and water purification systems, fell about 23 percent yesterday after the company warned that slow sales would give it disappointing third-quarter profits. The company said late Friday that earnings per share would be less than the 5 cents it reported in the quarter a year earlier. First Call/Thomson Financial had estimated earnings per share of 9 cents. Third-quarter sales will fall 13 percent from the $73.8 million a year earlier, Calgon Carbon said. The stock fell $1.81, to $5.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: JOINT VENTURE FOR WEB PAYMENTS
description: The First Data payment services company and the iFormation Group, an investment and consulting firm, have started eOne Global, a company geared to improving existing electronic payment technologies that process financial transactions on the World Wide Web. First Data, which owns Western Union, will invest about $360 million in the new company and iFormation about $135 million. Ric Duques, chief executive of First Data and chairman of eOne Global, said the new company would work on ''additional fraud and security products and services that will help'' make credit card transactions more secure. Catherine Greenman

What they did not think was that the history would be from the 1980's, and it would involve players named Ozzie Smith and Willie McGee -- not John Rocker and Chipper Jones.

title: Dousing the Mideast Fire
description: President Clinton has spent the better part of the past week trying to quell the violence in the Middle East, and has offered to travel to the region to meet with Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. Mr. Clinton's instincts are right. If the bloodshed continues, years of peace diplomacy will very likely collapse, with potentially severe consequences for the entire region and for American security interests.

title: Editorial Observer; Why the St. Louis Cardinals Could Be Trouble for the Yankees and Mets
description: Ever since 1989, the year of its founding (with me as a charter member), I have been looking for a way to mention the Stan Musial Society in the pages of The New York Times. The society was named after the best all-around player in the history of the St. Louis Cardinals, and now numbers 300 members, all upright citizens who also happen to be terminally weird on the subject of the Cardinals. There has been no reason to mention the society because, with the exception of 1996, the Cardinals have not appeared in the post-season playoffs. Now here they are, having conquered the Atlanta Braves in three straight, with only the New York Mets standing between them and their sixth World Series encounter with the New York Yankees. The Yankees themselves must first overcome the Seattle Mariners, but that they will do, for reasons of historical necessity to be explained in a moment.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Bob Evans may be down on the farm, but some shareholders think it is also out to lunch.
description: THERE'S the bull market, and the bear market. And then there's Bob Evans Farms.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA RISES ON NAVY NEWS
description: Shares of Electronic Data Systems rose 10 percent yesterday after the information systems consulting company won a contract worth $6.9 billion over eight years from the Navy. In an announcement late Friday, Electronic Data said it had agreed to build a computer network connecting all of the Navy's 300 or so bases worldwide. The system will be designed to be less vulnerable to cyber- attacks. Navy Secretary Richard Danzig called it the largest such contract awarded by the government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLANE, EDWIN J.
description: MULLANE-Edwin J. It is with deepest sorrow that we announce that Edwin J. Mullane, President of Mullane Ford of Bergenfield, N.J. and President and Founder of the Ford Dealers Alliance died at his home on Saturday, October 7, 2000 of pulmonary complications, the residual effects of polio, a disease he contracted as a youth. Ed was a man of strong character and strong convictions. He lived his life by those convictions, always trying to make a difference in the world in which he lived. Upon graduating from Fordham University in 1935, Ed and his brother Bill ran Mullane Brothers Appliance business in New Jersey from 1935 to 1955, except for the time spent in the Army during WWII. He became a Ford dealer in 1956. In 1969, upon successfully challenging Ford on a warranty issue, he and the Newark and New York dealers realizing what could be accomplished as a group, founded and incorporated the Ford Dealers Alliance. Over the past 30 years, Ed became best known as an outspoken protagonist for dealers' rights. He had strongly and consistently espoused the rights of dealers and the consumer and unstintingly criticized the factory encroachment of those rights. His message has been carried in The New York Times, NBC National News and many other major news media, and has been mentioned in such books as Emma Rothschild's ''Paradise Lost'' and ''Iacocca's Autobiography'' in which he was the only dealer mentioned by name. In 1993, he was named one of the one-hundred most influential people in the history of the automobile industry by Automotive News, a trade publication. He believed in the words of Edmund Burke, who he often quoted, ''The only thing for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing.'' This is the motto by which he lived his life. He was a good man who never tired of working towards ending factory injustices. With Ed's passing, we lose the staunchest supporter of dealer rights, a devoted leader, but most importantly, we lose a very good friend. We will all miss him terribly. Ed's wife Ruth passed away in 1996. He is survived by his brother Bill, his daughter Mary Alice Hill, and his son Michael, and by seven grandchildren and one great grandchild.

title: In Caribbean, Endangered Iguanas Get Their Day

Sinopec is seeking to sell a 20 percent stake to overseas investors to raise cash to finance a corporate overhaul and to repay debt, in the third major sale of state-owned assets from China this year.

Concord and Star provide electronic transaction authorization to supermarkets, convenience stores and gas stations. Star operates the Star Network, the largest electronic-payments network.

title: Celebrities Take Back Web Site Addresses From Squatters
description: GENEVA, Oct. 10 -- French actress Isabelle Adjani and Grammy Award winner Sade have won the right to their domain names after independent arbitrators ruled in their favour in cybersquatting cases, a United Nations agency said on Tuesday. The arbitrators, named by the World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO), issued decisions ordering contested domain names transferred to the two female stars who argued they had established common law trademark rights to their names. A decision is expected later this month from the Geneva-based agency on a complaint filed by the American singer Madonna over the disputed domain name madonna.com. It was first registered by Dan Parisi, a New Jersey-based businessman known for having the on-line porn site whitehouse.com. Adjani, a Geneva resident whose films include La Reine Margot, Camille Claudel and L'Histoire D'Adele H, won the domain name isabelle-adjani.net from Second Orbit Communications Inc and Shi Young, of Mountain View California, the ruling said. The firm registered the name in April, but failed to respond to the arbitrator, who found it had no right or legitimate interest in the domain name being used it in bad faith. The Nigerian-born Helen Folsade Adu, who uses the stage name Sade, won the domain name sade.com from Quantum Computer Services Inc, based in Louisiana, in the United States. Sade, a singer, songwriter and recording arist since 1983, has recorded albums which have netted combined sales worldwide in excess of $37 million, according to her claim. Hits include "Smooth Operator, "No Ordinary Love" and "Cherish the Day." Quantum offers Internet users "personalised" e-mail addresses via its sites where they can select and assign to themselves a "novelty" address. It had registered the domain name sade.com. using the alias "The Sade Internet Fan Club." The London-based singer claimed ownerhip of the unregistered trademark in which she claimed to have established significant common law rights in jurisdictions throughout the world through sales of records, tours, and appearances as a performing artist. The panel found that Quantum had intentionally attempted to attract, for commercial gain, Internet users to its website or other on-line locations by creating a likelihood of confusion. It had used a false name purely for the purpose of trading on Sade's goodwill, of which it is neither owner nor licensee, for its own financial gain, according to the decision. WIPO, the U.N. agency that protects trademarks and copyrights, has received more than 1,300 cases of disputed domain names since starting its fast-track arbitration system last December. Decisions have been made in more than half of the alleged cybersquatting cases, with 80 percent of complainants winning transfer of the contested site. Trasnfers must be made within 45 days. A decision may be challenged within 10 days.

Under the terms of the transaction, Verizon Wireless will pay $236 million to acquire 24.2 percent of Sacramento Valley from Roseville Communications of Roseville, Calif., effectively increasing its interest in the company to more than 76 percent. Sacramento Valley serves an area with 3.8 million potential customers, including the cities of Sacramento and Modesto in California and Reno, Nev. Simon Romero

Chiyoda's failure, with nearly $27 billion in liabilities, made it Japan's biggest postwar bankruptcy.

title: CARADON TO SELL PLUMBING UNIT
description: Caradon, a British maker of building and home improvement products, said it would sell its plumbing businesses to HSBC Private Equity for $:442 million, or about $639 million, in cash as it focuses on more profitable businesses. The division, which includes brands like Ideal Boilers and Twyford Bathrooms, accounted for nearly one-third of the company's sales last year, but only a quarter of profits. Caradon, which is changing its name to Novar, said it would use the proceeds to pay down debt. Suzanne Kapner

title: FORTIS ACQUIRING DUTCH INSURER
description: To gird against hostile takeover attempts, Fortis, the Belgian financial products company, agreed to pay 3.3 billion euros, or about $2.9 billion, to acquire the 80 percent of the Dutch insurer ASR Verzekeringsgroep that it does not own. Europe's insurance industry is consolidating, as insurers profit from increased investment by Europeans supplementing government pensions, and insurers in smaller European markets have been frequent takeover targets. Shares in ASR rose 51.9 percent, to 98.80 euros, while Fortis shares declined 7.4 percent, to 32.36 euros, on concerns the price paid was excessive. John Tagliabue

title: BANCO SANTANDER ACQUISITION
description: In its latest move into the Latin American market, Banco Santander Central Hispano of Spain is to buy a majority stake in Banco Caracas of Venezuela and combine the institution with its Banco de Venezuela to create the country's largest bank, with assets of $4 billion. Banco Santander Central Hispano owns 97 percent of Banco de Venezuela. The new entity will have a market share of more than 20 percent and the deal still requires the approval of Venezuelan regulators. Banco Santander Central Hispano is Spain's largest bank and the leading foreign bank in Latin America, which accounts for a third of its assets, loans and profits from operations in a dozen countries. Benjamin Jones

title: CONNETICS SHARES DECLINE SHARPLY AS DRUG FAILS TEST
description: Shares of the Connetics Corporation fell as much as 81 percent after a study found no benefit for relaxin, a drug the company is developing to treat a disfiguring and potentially fatal skin disease called scleroderma. Connetics said it would not seek marketing approval of relaxin after a 239-patient study found that it did not substantially ease hardening of the skin, a primary symptom of scleroderma. The shares fell $20.19, to $5.31, making it the biggest percentage loser in the markets. Hopes for relaxin had helped fuel a 60 percent gain in the stock over the last two weeks, pushing it to a 52-week high of $26.88 on Thursday.

title: EXECUTIVES LEAVE STAMPS.COM
description: Stamps.com, which runs a Web site where users can buy and print United States postage, says Loren Smith will leave his posts of president and chief operating officer but remain on the company's board. Mr. Smith was named to the new positions last October. No replacements have been announced. Stamps.com also says its chief financial officer, John LaValle, and comptroller, Candelario Andalon, are leaving to pursue other positions. A company statement said there were no financial or accounting problems related to the departures.

description: WEXLER-Betty. Of New York City and Bal Harbour, FL. Beloved wife of the late Harry Wexler. Adored and loving mother of Lois, Robert, Ginger and the late Paulette. Cherished Grandma to Heidi and Jeni. Loving sister to Shirley Nitkin and Nate Musicant, both of California. Rest in peace beautiful lady. We will all miss you. You will remain with us forever. Service Wednesday, October 11th, 12:45PM at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Tired Yankees Hope Neagle's Fresh Arm Is on Target
description: Exhaustion set in about a half-hour after the Yankees eliminated Oakland late Sunday night, after they hosed down each other with Champagne. Tired and thrilled and relieved all at once, about a dozen players leaned back in chairs quietly, a few perching a beer on a knee, looking like a crew of trench diggers satisfied at the end of a hard day.

title: Vodafone Said to Be in Talks To Buy Irish Wireless Stake
description: The Vodafone Group is in talks with Eircom, Ireland's telecommunications conglomerate, about taking a majority stake in or buying all of Eircell, its mobile subsidiary, people close to the discussions said today.

title: Fusaichi Pegasas Is Withdrawn From Gold Cup
description: Fusaichi Pegasus, winner of the Kentucky Derby and a leading candidate for Horse of the Year, sustained a minor cut on his left front hoof and was withdrawn yesterday from the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup on Saturday at Belmont Park.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles this week about four New York socialites in their 90's who continue to lead active public lives misspelled the middle name of a writer and politician whose conversation one of the women is said to remember from 70 years ago. The writer is Clare Boothe Luce, not Booth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULLATY, LOMEO, SONJA
description: BULLATY - LOMEO - Sonja. Be loved partner of Angelo Lomeo, for 49 years, died on October 5, 2000. She was 76 years old. A renowned photographer with a passion for life, she inspired many through her beautiful images. Bereft of family by the Holocaust, Sonja opened her heart to the world. She will be deeply missed by all of us who knew and loved her. A Memorial Service is being planned but not yet scheduled. Friends who wish to know the date can write to: AG Editions, 41 Union Square West, Suite 523, New York, New York 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, HARRY
description: DAVIS-Harry. Our congregation mourns the loss of our partiarch, a past President and devoted worker. Loved by all, he will be missed. Burial took place on October 8. Temple Beth El of Long Beach Abraham Kupchik, Rabbi Harry Brown, President

title: Article 2000101093338815855 -- No Title

title: Plane Skids to Halt After Hitting Bird in Nepal
description: KATMANDU, Nepal -- A bird struck the left engine of a Chinese airliner with 212 people aboard as it took off Tuesday but the pilot managed to stop a few feet from the end of the runway at Katmandu airport, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, JENNY
description: GREENWALD-Jenny. On October 8, 2000. Mother of Michael and Mark; Grandmother of Jayne, Matthew, Melanie and Chloe. Mother-in-law of Stephanie and Sheryl. We will miss you.

title: I.B.M. Will Invest $5 Billion to Produce Newer Microchips
description: I.B.M. said today that it will invest $5 billion to expand its semiconductor production, including $2.5 billion, its largest single capital investment ever, on a new manufacturing operation in East Fishkill, N.Y., that will make microchips incorporating a number of recent research breakthroughs.

title: Hirschbeck Brothers Lead Umpiring Crew
description: Two brothers, John and Mark Hirschbeck, will work on the same umpiring crew for the American League Championship Series, while the 30-year veteran Bruce Froemming will be behind the plate for the National League Championship Series opener.

description: ROSENTHAL-Frances Ressner Bender. Died October 10, 1998. Dear Mom, it doesn't get easier. Love always, Richard, Susan, Robert, Ronal

description: KOMINSKI-Ronald L. Of Pelham Manor, N.Y. Died on Friday, Oct. 6 in New York City, of brain cancer. Donations may be made in his memory to support brain tumor research in the Neurological Department, C/O Dr. Jeffrey Raizer, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021. Services at the Church of Christ The Redeemer, Pelham Manor on Wed, October 11, 11 AM.

title: Rug Maker to Miss Forecast
description: The Dixie Group , a rug maker, said yesterday that it would post losses for the third quarter and the year because of costs from higher inventories and from integrating some operations. The losses, it said, would result in the violation of a covenant in its senior credit agreement, and that it expected to amend the loan agreement to reflect these results. Dixie said it would report a loss of 27 to 32 cents a share for the third quarter and expected a loss of 30 to 35 cents for the year. Analysts on average had forecast 6 cents profit a share for the quarter and 19 cents for the year.

title: Public Interests; Inside George's Web
description: Attention, fans of ''Charlotte's Web'' and ''Stuart Little.'' Gov. George Pataki is sorry he made fun of E. B. White.

title: Why PlayStation 2 Isn't Child's Play; Early Shipment to U.S. Halved, and Some Fault Intricate Chips
description: The Sony Corporation raised the blood pressure of millions of American parents recently when it announced that its initial shipment of PlayStation 2, the cutting-edge entertainment device that is expected to be the hottest gift of this holiday season, would be half what it had promised. Only 500,000 machines will arrive in stores on Oct. 26, not a million, Sony said.

title: Israel Awaits Drop in Violence After Postponing Its Deadline
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 10  Israelis and Palestinians backed haltingly away from further direct confrontation today as armed clashes subsided and a parade of prominent diplomatic visitors urged both sides to rein in the violence and resume peace talks.

title: Shelling, Political Death Overshadows Sri Lanka Elections
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka -- Shelling by Tamil Tiger rebels, election-eve murders and the untimely death of the matriarch of national politics cast a pall over Sri Lanka's parliamentary elections Tuesday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Former Catalyst Returns as an Irritant
description: The one and only Rickey Henderson returned to New York yesterday to prepare for another playoff game. It was hard to miss him. He wore a hooded sweatshirt under his blue jacket, stood next to the batting cage and razzed his teammates loudly.

title: Flirting With Exoticism And a Loss of Control
description: Ian Fountain, pianist

title: Frustrated Parents Hope Their Votes Will Change Schools' Ways
description: Voters will consider a record number of education questions on state ballots next month, including whether to offer private school vouchers to parents, shut down bilingual classrooms, pay teachers based on student performance and virtually eliminate any mention in the classroom of homosexuality.

title: Setback for Antibiotics as Heart Treatment
description: Taking an antibiotic for three months failed to reduce the risk of new heart attacks and death among people with coronary artery heart disease, a Utah study has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, AARON W.
description: WARNER-Aaron W. Husband of Miriam. Father of Abby Myerson and Rachel Warner Cook. A Memorial will be held in Saint Paul's Chapel, at Columbia University, on October 12, 2000 at 2 P.M.

title: Even in Frigid North, Hints of Warmer Temperatures
description: As the men and women stationed at this Canadian military base prepare to kick off four months of polar night with a ''sunset party'' on Oct. 14, the threat of global warming seems far from the northernmost human settlement in the world.

title: MOTOROLA IS EXPECTED TO REPORT HIGHER EARNINGS
description: Motorola, the second-largest maker of cellular phones, will report higher third-quarter earnings today as it sold more cell phones, chips and digital TV set-top boxes, analysts and investors said. Analysts expect a profit of 26 cents a share, the average estimate in a poll by First Call/Thomson Financial. That is compared with a split-adjusted 16 cents in the year-earlier period. Sales are forecast to rise to $9.77 billion from $7.69 billion, based on estimates gathered by IBES International. Investors said they were still watching Motorola's operating margin, or pretax profit as a percentage of sales, in the cellular phone business for signs of improvement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEUER, GLORIA F.
description: SCHEUER-Gloria F. Died October 8, 2000. at her home in Greenwich, CT. after a long illness with which she dealt with dignity and through which she was supported by her husband and the untiring attention and love of Maria Lima. She is survived by her husband Robert, her son Alan Scheuer of Greenwich, her daughter Kay James of Boulder, CO., four granddaughters and her mother Ida Foxman. Gloria lived a life of involvement with her family and community and was a founding member and moving spirit for Adopt-A-Dog of Greenwich. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Foreign Affairs; Name-Dropping
description: Let's not mince words here: George W. Bush did not come in second last week in the debates. He came in fourth, because anyone watching could see that Al Gore, Dick Cheney and Joe Lieberman all had a better command of the issues than Mr. Bush and seemed more like presidential timber than he did.

title: Knicks Start With New Look
description: The first game of the post-Patrick Ewing era will take place Tuesday night at 7:30 when the Knicks play host to the Chicago Bulls in an exhibition game at Madison Square Garden.

title: Lahore Journal; A Jihad Leader Finds the U.S. Perplexingly Fickle
description: The professor uses henna to redden his long beard, and that, along with a natural smile, makes him appear somewhat jovial, an unexpected cheerfulness from someone who commands what many believe to be a group of terrorists.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO DIPS. -- The euro fell against the dollar amid expectations that the United States economy would continue to outpace Europe's. In New York, the euro settled at 86.83 cents, down from 86.84 cents on Friday.

title: Prevention: A Gold Star for Silver, on a Catheter
description: Silver-coated urinary catheters may sound extravagant, but they can more than pay for themselves, according to a University of Michigan study that has led to a change in practice at the university's medical center.

title: MUPPETS OWNER'S EARNINGS OVERSTATED
description: Shares of EM.TV and Merchandising, the German media company that bought the Jim Henson Company as well as a 50 percent stake in the Formula One racing organization earlier this year, plunged 32 percent after the company said it had overstated earnings. The sell-off reduced the company's market value by more than $1 billion, and was aggravated by the rout of many European technology and media companies. EM.TV, based outside Munich, had been one of Germany's most spectacular stock market performers, climbing 31,000 percent between the time it went public in 1997 and its peak last February. The company said first-half profits at Henson, which produces the Muppets television shows and movies, had been overstated by about $16 million. Edmund L. Andrews

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A credit on Thursday for a front-page picture of Diana Brooks, the former chief executive of Sotheby's, misspelled the photographer's given name in some copies. She is Frances Roberts, not France.

title: Two Americans and Russian Share Nobel Physics Prize
description: STOCKHOLM, Sweden -- A Russian and two U.S.-based researchers won the Nobel Prize in physics Tuesday for work that helped create modern information technology, leading to everyday devices like pocket calculators, CD players and cell phones.

title: Timorese Refugees Tell of Terror By Militias After Foreigners Left
description: Across the river from this small border town, beyond the banana palms that glow in the early morning sunlight, lies Indonesia's latest scene of terror, where armed gangs have run wild, holding tens of thousands of refugees hostage in defiance of international condemnation.

title: Lazio Steps Up Criticism of Mrs. Clinton Over Mideast
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio today stepped up his criticism of Hillary Rodham Clinton's response to the violence in the Middle East, suggesting Mrs. Clinton should have used her stated influence with the president to persuade him to veto the United Nations resolution censuring Israel.

description: Pluramon

title: Valentine Makes a Gutsy Choice
description: The Mets are in the League Championship Series, and the Atlanta Braves are not. To think that the Yankees came close to being home, too, for the winter. That scenario would have been a trifecta more delicious for the Mets than anything they could have concocted.

title: Corrections
description: A picture grouping in Arts & Ideas on Saturday with an article about a theory of threatened masculinity carried a misspelled credit. The picture agency is Corbis-Bettmann, not Bettman.

title: 3 Share Nobel Prize in Medicine for Studies of the Brain
description: Three scientists who have made important contributions to understanding the long-term changes in the brain that underlie memory and mood were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine yesterday.

title: For Belgrade, a Fateful Moment
description: To the Editor:

title: Englewood Residents Pin Hopes On Election to Fix Ailing Schools
description: Four years ago, Idelma Diaz O'Rourke moved to this suburb overlooking the George Washington Bridge for the same reason as many others. She and her husband liked the small city's proximity to Manhattan, its ethnic diversity, its graceful mix of wealthy neighborhoods and tidy, affordable homes.

title: In His Arrest, Chinese Editor Sees Success Of His Journal
description: As he was being questioned by the political security department of the Beijing police in August, Huang Beiling suddenly realized that he had achieved literary success.

title: Testaverde Is a Question Mark Against Patriots
description: Vinny Testaverde received a cortisone shot in his neck today to help relieve the inflammation around the pinched nerve that knocked him out of Sunday's 20-3 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers after one play. Then he was sent home early -- before the offensive meetings were over -- after he experienced discomfort at the point of the injection.

title: SMITHKLINE TO BUY BLOCK DRUG FOR $1.2 BILLION
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., which plans to merge with another drug maker, Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., said it would buy the Block Drug Company for $1.2 billion in cash to gain the company's Polident denture cleaner and Sensodyne toothpaste. SmithKline, which reaps a third of its sales from consumer products like Aquafresh toothpaste, will pay $53 a share, said a spokeswoman, Lynne Smith. That is about 5 percent more than Block's closing price Friday of $50.63. The purchase shows SmithKline's commitment to the consumer business at a time when other companies, like Bristol-Myers Squibb, are selling theirs to focus on drugs. SmithKline aims to keep profiting from pharmaceuticals that have lost patent protection by converting them to nonprescription products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARATH, EDWARD NOAH
description: SARATH-Edward Noah, 78, of Ridgefield, CT, passed away October 7, 2000 in the loving company of his family. Survived by his cherished wife, Florence, seven children-Carol, Edward, Maria, David, James, Patrice and Steven and 8 grandchildren. He was a social and spiritual visionary and author of two books-An Awakening Soul and The Mark of the Galilean. His radiant smile and concern for others, which characterized his life through his very last days, will be remembered by all who knew him.

description: An unexpected delay was granted in the Lockerbie bombing trial today when prosecutors surprised the court by announcing that they had new evidence ''of some complexity and considerable sensitivity'' that they needed time to consider.

In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Fried Award Fund, Brooklyn College.

title: European Union Greets Yugoslav Government
description: The European Union embraced Yugoslavia's new government today, lifting major sanctions and pledging to contribute about $2 billion in aid for rebuilding the shattered country.

description: BY CARL S. KAPLAN

title: U.S. CONCRETE PURCHASES HANSON CONCRETE PRODUCTS
description: U.S. Concrete, a maker of ready-mixed concrete used in road and building construction, said yesterday that it bought closely held Hanson Concrete Products and that second-half sales would be below analysts' expectations. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed. Hanson, based in Milpitas, Calif., makes precast-concrete products. U.S. Concrete's sales were below forecasts because of slower residential construction around Memphis and lower volume at the company's material hauling operations in Texas and Oklahoma. Third-quarter sales were 3 percent to 4 percent below expectations. U.S. Concrete had sales of $69.5 million in the year-earlier quarter. Shares of U.S. Concrete, based in Houston, fell 38 cents to $6.38.

title: MCSI SAYS ANNOUNCES ACQUISITION OF INTELLISYS GROUP
description: MCSi, which sells computer and office-automation supplies, said it would buy Intellisys Group to gain access to audio and visual products. Terms of the transaction, which is subject to regulatory approval, weren't disclosed. The purchase is part of a Chapter 11 reorganization agreement for Intellisys. Intellisys Group, based in Westlake Village, Calif., sells and installs equipment for videoconferencing and displays. The acquisition will be the seventh in the last year for MCSi, which is based in Dayton, Ohio. The shares of MCSi, formerly Miami Computer, rose 38 cents to $31.75.

title: Drama of the Debates
description: In the current New Yorker, the magazine's Washington correspondent, Joe Klein, recounts an exchange from a 1992 campaign debate in which President Bush gave a fumbling answer to a question from the audience about how the national debt affected the ''economic problems of common people.'' Because the woman who asked the question was black, Mr. Bush noted that he had been to an A.M.E. church recently. Then he veered awkwardly to the subject of teenage pregnancies. When Bill Clinton's turn came, he stepped toward the woman and said, ''Tell me how it's affected you again.'' In Mr. Klein's view, this demonstration of Mr. Clinton's superior empathic ability was a pivotal moment in their competition. The observation touches on the perennial questions of what voters look for in the candidate debates and how they process what they see and hear.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; Enduring Memories, in the Womb
description: If you talk to a fetus, will it remember what you said? Probably not. But it may recall the sound at least for a little while, a brief report in The Lancet suggests.

description: Charles B. Yates, a banker, businessman and former New Jersey legislator who was a proponent of campaign finance reform and a supporter of stricter ethical rules for elected officials, died on Friday in an airplane crash in Massachusetts. He was 61.

They are calling her death a homicide, but say they have no suspects.

title: EIDOS SHARES FALL 13%
description: Shares of Eidos, the British video game maker that created the animated hero Lara Croft, fell 39.5 pence, or 13.4 percent, to 255 pence, after the company said it had terminated merger discussions with an unnamed party, because the price was too low. In June, Eidos said it was in early negotiations that might lead to an offer for the company. Eidos said that ''despite a low level of activity in the retail market, sales were in line'' with directors' expectations. Suzanne Kapner

title: Syndrome X and Its Dubious Distinction
description: A condition known as insulin resistance is emerging as yet another risk factor threatening the good health of your heart. And, doctors who focus too narrowly on serum cholesterol may be overlooking this potentially dangerous syndrome, as often happens with high homocysteine levels.

title: Record Ozone Hole Refuels Debate on Climate
description: The hole that opens in the ozone layer over Antarctica each southern spring formed earlier and grew bigger this year than at any time since satellites have been monitoring the polar atmosphere, scientists have reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLAS, CARL
description: NICHOLAS-Carl, 88, long-timeNew York City resident and fixture of the Broadway Stage, died peacefully at Encore Senior Village in Tucson, AZ October 7, 2000. Mr. Nicholas born in Appleton, WI in 1912, graduated from Lawrence University in 1935, then came to New York to further his vocal studies at The Juilliard School. His first appearance on Broadway was in Knickerbocker Holiday (1939), followed by roles in DuBarry Was A Lady (1939) and Lady in The Dark (1940). With the advent of World War II, Mr. Nicholas joined the cast of Irving Berlin's This Is The Army, touring the world and entertaining U.S. troops overseas for the duration. With his reentry to civilian life, he returned to the theater, and began an unprecedented string of Broadway performances in, among other shows, Guys And Dolls (1950), Music Man (1957), Mr. President (1962), Walking Happy (1966), Jimmy (1969) and, ultimately, My One and Only (1983) with Tommy Tune and Twiggy. Mr. Nicholas is survived by his brother Robert, of Tucson, nephews David (Paula), of Fairview, NC, and Richard (Gale), of Suisun City, CA, and dear and caring friends.

title: Crowds of Jews Rampage in Nazareth
description: Several hundred Jews, apparently tired of feeling trapped for 12 days in this predominantly Arab city, rampaged on Sunday night, attacking Arab homes and touching off a melee in which the Israeli police killed two Arabs, more than a dozen Arab witnesses said.

title: G.M. TO ASSESS DAEWOO ASSETS
description: The General Motors Corporation and Fiat said they would evaluate the assets and businesses of the Daewoo Motor Company before making any decision about buying all or part of the ailing South Korean automaker. ''G.M. and Fiat will conduct a preliminary due diligence,'' which is ''expected to proceed rapidly and upon further agreement will be followed by formal negotiations,'' General Motors said in a statement. G.M., the world's largest automaker, and Fiat, the sixth largest, became the most likely candidates to purchase Daewoo Motor after the Ford Motor Company withdrew a $7 billion bid last month. Samuel Len

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 27 about Lawrence G. Hauck, a former news editor of The New York Times, referred incorrectly to his military service and omitted a survivor. Mr. Hauck served in air combat intelligence with the Navy in World War II; he was not a pilot. His sole immediate survivor is a daughter, Linda Lamb of Manhattan.

title: Sudan, at U.N., Fails to Win Council Seat
description: A Sudanese bid to win a two-year term on the Security Council was defeated today after four rounds of voting. The contested African seat finally went to the Indian Ocean island nation of Mauritius.

title: Introduction
description: Good cooking requires an open mind; you have to see how a savory ingredient can also be sweetened for dessert (think of crepes), for instance, or how a sauce can also be a soup. Often, exciting cooking is about building from the bottom up. Pasta or rice or potatoes aren't much to start with, but they can become just about anything once imagination takes hold. That's why slavish devotion to recipes can be so damaging to creativity; just cooking by the numbers.

title: BRAZIL COMPANY ENDS FREE WEB ACCESS
description: Latin America's largest Internet service provider, Universo Online, is shutting down its free Internet unit in November. The company said the free service, Brasil Online, was not financially feasible. UOL, which is planning an initial public offering on Nasdaq later this year, is the second company in the last month to end its free Internet operations in Brazil. Jennifer L. Rich

title: A Spanish Region Blossoms
description: TEN years ago, the wines of the Priorato region of Spain were considered primitive and rustic. This area, high in the country's northeastern hills, clung to its old-fashioned methods for making highly alcoholic oxidized wines even as nearby regions like Penedes were gaining worldwide attention for exciting, innovative blends.
