description: Basic Recipe: Tomato Coulis

title: Kenneth Kimes Takes Reporter As a Hostage
description: When Sante and Kenneth Kimes -- the hand-holding, mother-and-son grifter team -- were sentenced to 125 years in June, it seemed like the end of a surreal string of crimes that culminated in the murder of an elderly Upper East Side socialite. But yesterday, during a prison interview, Mr. Kimes took a Court TV reporter hostage for four hours, holding a pen to her neck.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the trial of two Libyans charged in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, which exploded in 1988 over Lockerbie, Scotland, misstated the relationship of a witness to the case. A man depicted in cables by the Central Intelligence Agency as a chronic liar was a central witness for the prosecution, not for the defense. Defense witnesses will not testify until the prosecution concludes its case.

title: Valentine-La Russa: So Close, So Far Away
description: Two very smart managers presided over two mundane workouts at Busch Stadium on the eve of the National League Championship Series yesterday. One is a baseball genius. So is the other. One talks confidently like the lawyer he was. One speaks like the champion debater that he was. One manages the Mets and one manages the Cardinals and both do not like each other.

title: Defining a New Yorker
description: One of the better moments in Sunday's debate between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick Lazio has somehow been lost in a small furor over whether Gov. George Pataki had ever heard of E. B. White. Mr. Pataki's clumsy effort to mock Mrs. Clinton, who mentioned the essayist and children's book writer in the debate, has landed him in a great deal of well-deserved trouble with lovers of Mr. White's work, ranging from ''Charlotte's Web'' to ''The Elements of Style'' to ''Here Is New York,'' his 1949 ode to New York City.

title: Oh, Dahling, Tallulah's Back in Town
description: There may a good story to be told onstage in the life of Tallulah Bankhead, the Alabama beauty who became one of the more notoriously dissolute divas of stage and screen. Let's hope so; this season will give us three different shows that purport to tell it, but the first of them, ''Tallulah Hallelujah!'', which opened at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater on West 42nd Street yesterday, is little more than an extended cabaret skit.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS METROMEDIA IN DEAL FOR SITESMITH

title: HILTON HAS OPTION TO BUY STAKE IN LODGENET
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation has obtained an option to buy as much as $42.9 million in stock of the LodgeNet Entertainment Corporation, which will provide pay television and Internet service in its rooms. Hilton can buy as many as 2.1 million LodgeNet common shares over the next seven years for $20.44 each, giving it a 13 percent stake. Hilton will initially buy about 1.5 million shares, Scott Petersen, LodgeNet's chief executive, said. Lodgenet will start offering movies, Internet service and Nintendo games in Hilton rooms by the end of the year. LodgeNet shares fell $2.75, to $20.88. Hilton fell 19 cents, to $10.25.

title: Messier Returns as Garden's Featured Performer
description: Perhaps more than any other professional athlete in New York City, Mark Messier has been at the center of some of the most unforgettable performances at Madison Square Garden.

title: Choosing a Child's Seat That Fits
description: CAR crashes are the primary cause of death among children ages 6 to 14 in the United States, killing more than 1,800 of them a year. And though the numbers of deaths of children 5 and under has been falling with the widespread use of safety seats, experts say the use of proper restraints among older children is the best way to reduce fatalities further.

title: Good With Children
description: The Nickelodeon cable network has been the top-rated cable channel on a daily basis for the last five years.

title: Motorola Reports Increase Of 66% in Quarterly Profit
description: Motorola Inc., the big telecommunications and semiconductor company, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 66 percent, in line with Wall Street estimates, on strong sales of broadband equipment and computer chips.

title: First Came the Car. Then the Wrong Turn. Voila: The Map.
description: SOMETIME in 1905, a New York draftsman whose name is lost in the mists of history took up a crow-quill pen and scratched on a sheet of linen the boulevards and byways of a nearby bucolic area for the use of devotees of the upstart touring device known as the automobile.

title: From Top Chefs, Dinner in a Kit
description: HOW many home cooks have the time or inclination on a busy weeknight to create a velvety leek puree, prepare a glossy lamb jus and coat perfectly trimmed lamb loins with a crust of fine black trumpet mushroom crumbs? Not many, even if they are sophisticated cooks.

title: Metro Business; Bloomberg in Deal With Time Warner
description: Bloomberg Television officials announced an agreement with Time Warner Cable yesterday that will open the door for the cable company's regional systems to carry Bloomberg programming.

title: Desktop Driver Training: It's Fun, but Does It Help?
description: THE shelves of software stores are crowded with programs that put you in command of an F-15 fighter, a submarine or a tank. But how about a Taurus or a Camry?

title: Cars
description: For some people, life is a search for the car that says ''This is who I am.'' Or many cars that say it. Charles Strum looks at the boom in collecting and the reasons for it. Plus: Articles on Web sites for collectors, on the world's most expensive (and desirable) car, on some of the least expensive (but most lovable) cars, and on those that presidents proudly drove.

title: COLLECTING: Driven: 3 People With a Passion for the Classic; The Professor Of Parking
description: MR. POOLE pulled the red 1956 MG down a tight slot between the rows of cars, inches from a 1973 Jaguar V-12 convertible, a red 1957 Porsche 356-A coupe and a 1981 silver Rolls-Royce Corniche -- about $100,000 worth of vintage chrome and steel, whose value would be instantly and sharply depreciated by the smallest scratch.

title: Sotheby's And Amazon To Share Site
description: Eighteen months after Sotheby's announced that it was joining forces with Amazon.com to run two separate online ventures, Sothebys.com and Sothebys.amazon.com, the beleaguered auction house said it would combine the two sites into one -- Sothebys.com.

title: The Sleeping Beauties Of Couture Are Waking
description: PARIS  The success stories of Gucci and LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton and the high risks involved in Internet start-ups are prompting venture capitalists to turn to fashion as a long-term investment.

title: News Analysis; State Find Child Health Aid a Puzzle
description: When Vice President Al Gore talks about what he would like to do for Americans who have no medical insurance if he is elected president, he more or less suggests that the nation become just like New York State.

title: CHINA LAYS OUT INVESTMENT RULES
description: China clarified what value-added telecommunications services would be opened to foreign investors after the country joins the World Trade Organization. An article in the government's Peoples Daily said the value-added sector includes Internet services and content, e-mail and voice-mail services, databases, fax services and videoconferencing. The sector also includes the reselling of basic services like mobile and fixed-line telecommunications and wireless paging and online handling of data and transactions. Upon its entry to the W.T.O., China has promised to allow 30 percent foreign ownership of ventures providing such value-added services, rising to 49 percent after one year and 50 percent after two years. It had not previously said what those services included. Craig S. Smith

title: PROCTER SETS AMBITIOUS GOALS
description: The giant consumer products company Procter & Gamble expects to take half of its orders from major retailers like Wal-Mart over the Internet within 12 months, A. G. Lafley, P.& G.'s chief executive, said. Mr. Lafley said the company would also begin buying its raw materials through online auctions. The move is part of P.& G.'s plan to cut costs and cast off ancillary brands after 17 disappointing quarters. Analysts characterized the company's targets for Internet sales as aggressive, but necessary. ''You usually don't break out of a slump by setting timid goals,'' said Edward Keon of Prudential Securities. Greg Winter

title: In Mexico, They Still Have a Thing for the Old Bug
description: IN the two decades since the original Beetle was last sold in the United States, the car that was a paisley-powered rite of passage for millions of driving Americans has faded from memory. Whatever lingering and unrequited affection there was for the old dumpling, it might be fair to assume, was satisfied by the introduction two years ago of the New Beetle, a glossy, postmodern rendition of the adorable Bug that beyond appearances has almost nothing in common with the original.

title: Advertising: Addenda
description: L. L. BEAN CHOOSES MARTIN/WILLIAMS

title: A Knowledge Gap
description: Re: "Highfalutin but Hardly Proud of It," by Clyde Haberman (NYC column, Oct. 9):

title: COLLECTING: Driven: 3 People With a Passion for the Classic; The Mini Collector
description: NANCY C. GOULD has an obsession that has become a family affair.

title: Divining Miss M, So Supremely Anxiety-Ridden
description: As Bette Midler prepares to go onstage, her sitcom husband asks her how she feels: ''Supremely overconfident or riddled with anxiety?''

title: INFLATION SURGE IN BRITAIN
description: The rising price of crude oil and a blockade that prevented gasoline deliveries for part of September inflated British consumer prices by 0.7 percent last month. That pushed the annual inflation rate up to 3.3 percent from 3 percent in August. Excluding mortgage interest, the rate rose to 2.2 percent from 1.9 percent the prior month, the National Statistics Office said. The increase was more than had been expected and reinforced speculation that the Bank of England might increase interest rates. Suzanne Kapner

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW JERSEY

title: Attacking Bush on Pollution
description: The Democratic Party this week released a television advertisement that attacks Gov. George W. Bush's record on the environment.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Olerud Has No Regrets About Signing With Seattle
description: When the Seattle Mariners emerged from the clubhouse and settled in the dugout before last night's game at Yankee Stadium, some of them seemed surprised by the swarm of reporters and photographers that greeted them.

title: XEROX SHARES RISE AFTER NEWS OF DIVIDEND CUT
description: Shares of the Xerox Corporation rose yesterday, one day after the company said it would reduce its quarterly dividend to 5 cents from 20 cents a share per quarter. The $400 million the company expects to save each year from the cut has restored some confidence among the lending community, Peter Enderlin, an analyst at Ryan, Beck Southeast Research, said. The stock fell 26 percent last week after a warning that the company would post a third-quarter loss of 15 cents to 20 cents a share, reversing estimates of a modest profit. Yesterday, shares closed up 56 cents, at $11.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Throw in the Local Cuisine, and It Adds Up

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about two fatal crashes on the Wittpenn Bridge in Jersey City misidentified the Hudson River tunnel east of the bridge. It is the Holland Tunnel, not the Lincoln.

title: The Enduring Battle Over Choice
description: The subject of reproductive rights has long been difficult terrain for politicians. Abortion is an intensely private question and a moral issue for many Americans, but the debate over reproductive rights is also about the broader cultural struggle over women's social and economic autonomy and the role of government in policing the most private sphere of American life.

title: Lazio Runs National Ad Campaign to Raise Money for His Senate Race
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio has mounted a nationwide television advertising campaign, running commercials on cable stations that ask people to call a toll-free number or go to his Web site to make donations.

title: Forget the Minivan: Women Like Hot Cars, Too
description: I DRIVE a minivan, and until just the other day I was quite happy with that. Then I had an opportunity to borrow a red Toyota Solara convertible for an afternoon. I had seen an advertisement for it in a women's magazine, promising a certain glamour missing from my humdrum suburban mom existence. ''The wind in your hair. The sun on your face. The bugs in your teeth,'' the copy read. (No kidding.) ''With its 200-horsepower, V-6 engine and power top, it will blow your skirt up. And then some.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHLIN, BENJAMIN
description: ROCHLIN-Benjamin. On October 8, 2000, in his 92nd year. Husband of the late Ruth Kaltman Rochlin and Esther Zimmerman Rochlin. Father of Alfreda Finkelstein (Martin) and Gail Rochlin-Meyer. Grandfather of Ruth Sheinfield (Michael) and William Stein. Brother of Mordecai Rochlin. Funeral services Wednesday, October 11, 1 PM, at C.J.L. Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale. Interment Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOD, G. CONGDON, PHD.
description: WOOD-G. Congdon, PhD., 84, of Ridgefield, CT. on October 9, 2000. Beloved husband of Bari (Prosterman). Father of Christopher, Jonathan, David and Andrew. Grandfather of 9. Graduate of Haverford College and Cornell University. Former Assistant Vice President of Professional Education of the American Cancer Society. Graveside service Friday at 1pm at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Contributions to the American Cancer Society, 372 Danbury Rd., Wilton, CT 06897

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the trial of two Libyans charged in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, which exploded in 1988 over Lockerbie, Scotland, misstated the relationship of a witness to the case. A man depicted in cables by the Central Intelligence Agency as a chronic liar was a central witness for the prosecution, not for the defense. Defense witnesses will not testify until the prosecution concludes its case.

title: CALENDAR
description: Pumpkin Primer

title: In a Better World, Five 'Halo' Cars That Would Have Been
description: IN 1956, a Newsweek cover depicted a car of the 21st century. It had a fighter plane's plastic bubble-roofed cockpit with a little spire antenna, three tail fins and wheels that were tucked well out of sight, perhaps because the designers were embarrassed that it did not fly. Half a century ago, cars dreamed of being airplanes.

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, EDMUND
description: LEVINSON-Edmund. On October 9th, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Eva (nee Baehr). Loving father of Lawrence and Lynn. Cherished grandfather of Steven and Richard. Adored great grandfather of Jacob. Dear brother of Morton, Helen and Elanor. Eddie was a retired employee of The New York Times after over 40 years of service. Service to be held Wednesday, October 11th, 10 AM, at Garlick Funeral Home at 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx, NY. Burial at Cedar Park Cemetery, New Jersey. Sitting shiva at 2877 Harding Avenue, Bronx, New York, October 11-October 13.

title: McGwire Is Dangerous, but Mets Are Armed
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 10  If there is a most important factor in winning a postseason series, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine said he has not seen it. Just after he said that, though, Valentine offered insight into what could be a crucial matchup in the National League Championship Series, which begins Wednesday night between the Mets and the Cardinals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, MORRIS (MARTY)
description: FREEMAN-Morris (Marty). A printer and teletype operator at the New York Times for more than twenty years died in his sleep on Saturday, October 7 at the Village Nursing Home in Greenwich Village, his home for the past year. A W.W. II veteran stationed in Africa, he began his life-long love affair with photography, people of the street and his family being his favorite subject matter. Marty began his career as a printer at The Journal of Commerce and The New York Daily Mirror. When the Mirror folded, he joined The New York Times, first as a printer and then as a teletype operator. He retired from the Times in 1980 to spend time taking pictures and developing them in his own makeshift darkroom. Marty was also an avid reader and sports enthusiast. Known as Marty to his friends and family, he leaves behind his ex-wife of 35 years, Sue Stein Freeman, his daughter, folk artist Dena Stewart (Miami Beach, FL.), and his two loving sons, Larry Freeman, L.C.S.W., and avant-garde jewelry designer Stuart Freeman (both residing in NYC) and sisters, Henrietta Freeman and Faye Colon. Services were held last Sunday at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue and he is interned at Mt. Zion Cemetery in Queens, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations in his honor can be sent to his favorite charity, Center for Folk and Community Art (CFCA), 1800 Michigan Avenue, Miami Beach, Florida 33139.

title: Bush Makes His Attack From Turf Of Opponent
description: Gov. George W. Bush landed on his opponent's doorstep today, at least politically speaking, to portray Vice President Al Gore as someone who had spent so much time in Washington that he had lost touch with voters even in his home state.

title: Bruce Vento, 60, Congressman Who Sought Protection for the Environment
description: Representative Bruce F. Vento of Minnesota, a Democrat who championed environmental causes and bank reform during 12 terms in Congress, died today at his home in St. Paul, three days after his 60th birthday.

title: E.U. Approves Time Warner, AOL Merger
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 11 -- The European Commission gave a green light today to Time Warner Inc.'s $129 billion merger with America Online Inc., but the companies face bigger objections from antitrust regulators in Washington.

title: L. L. Bean Chooses Martin/Williams
description: L. L. Bean, the apparel retailer in Freeport, Me., has named Martin/ Williams in Minneapolis, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle its account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million. The decision came after a three-month review that had been narrowed to Martin/ Williams; Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies; and FCB Worldwide in New York, part of True North Communications.

title: COMPAQ WINS ERICSSON ORDER
description: Compaq Computer said that Ericsson agreed to spend at least $500 million on Compaq server computers that help manage cellular telephone service. The four-year agreement could be worth as much as $1 billion, an official said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, WILLIAM.
description: GOLDSTEIN - William. Beloved husband of Irene. Devoted father of Arthur and Susan Goldstein, Ronald and Sharon Goldstein, Sharon and Mark Weinreb and the late Eugene Goldstein. Adored grandfather of Adam, Allison, Jeffrey, Brett, Kevin, Jake and Zachary. Services today 1:45pm at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Reckonings; A Retirement Fable
description: There once was a land where people lived only two years. In the first year they worked; in the second year they lived off their personal savings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLBERT, REV. JOSEPH D.
description: COLBERT-Rev. Joseph D. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor of St. Pancras Church, 72-22 68th Street, Glendale on October 10. Reposing at George Werst Funeral Home, 71-41 Cooper Ave, Glendale, Wednesday, October 11, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM and Thursday, October 12, from 2 to 5 PM. Mass of Transferral at St. Pancras Church at 7:30 P.M. Funeral Mass on Friday, October 13, at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: G.O.P. Says Gore Will Force The Elderly Into H.M.O.'s
description: In the battle for vote-rich Florida, the state's Republican Party has mailed pamphlets to older Floridians that accuse Vice President Al Gore of planning to force elderly people into a ''government-run drug H.M.O.''

title: Addressing the Confusion Over Dietary Supplements
description: AFTER years of double-digit growth, sales of herbal supplements have slowed down. Maybe it's because there has been so much negative publicity about their safety and effectiveness. Maybe it's because, despite all the promises from the manufacturers, the supplements don't provide a quick fix. Or maybe it's because there are so many of them that most people are completely bewildered.

title: Janitors' Strike Grows in Connecticut's Commercial Buildings
description: Lorenza Oliva gave a simple reason for being on strike along with 250 other Fairfield County janitors: she cannot make ends meet earning $6.15 an hour and working 20 hours a week.

title: On a TV Show, Jerusalem Is All Anger and Yelling (but Nobody Gets Hurt)
description: Moments before the taping tonight of a special ABC News ''Nightline'' town meeting in the Holy Land, the audience was in an uproar befitting the Israeli-Palestinian crisis: the moderator, Ted Koppel, and his producers were forced to broker a kind of arms agreement before the show could go on, and it took hours.

title: New Film Role for Joan Allen: Star; A Filmmaker's Devotion Puts a Familiar Supporting Actress At the Center of 'The Contender,' a Political Thriller
description: What took so long? Astounding as it seems, Joan Allen, one of the country's most respected actresses for the better part of two decades, is only now seeing the release of an American film in which she plays the lead character.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think I'll sigh a little bit less in this debate.''

title: Halama Isn't Much of a Fan
description: Many New Yorkers are swept up in baseball excitement. John Halama is not among them.

title: Judge Orders Ford Recall Regarding Ignition Defect
description: Astate judge in California today ordered the Ford Motor Company to recall up to 1.7 million cars and trucks, following up on his finding that Ford knowingly installed defective ignition mechanisms blamed for a stalling problem.

title: New Shows And Oldies Are Off And Running
description: It may have been an aversion to baseball or to politics or both, but American television viewers displayed a rare hunger for their nightly ration of prime-time network entertainment in the first week of the new television season, which resulted in impressive to outstanding performances by a number of new network offerings as well as by several returning favorites.

title: An Industry on the Brink of Good Cheer?
description: AMERICANS are drinking more good wine than ever before, and regardless of what happens to the economy, they could, by 2015, be drinking a whole lot more.

title: MELLON FINANCIAL BUYING TRUST COMPANY OF WASHINGTON
description: The Mellon Financial Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the Trust Company of Washington, which specializes in handling the assets of affluent individuals, families and nonprofit organizations. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. After the acquisition, Trust Company of Washington, based in Seattle, will operate as part of Mellon Financial's Private Asset Management unit. (Dow Jones)

title: NTT TO OFFER BIGGER DISCOUNT ON SHARES
description: The Japanese government and Nippon Telegraph and Telephone plan to sell $14.1 billion of the company's shares at a steeper discount -- 3 percent to 5 percent -- than last year because demand for the stock is not as strong. About 1.3 million shares of the company, Japan's dominant telephone operator, will be sold at a discount to the close on the day it is priced, said Mitsutaka Inagaki, the Ministry of Finance official in charge of the sale. A price for the shares being sold this year will be decided between Oct. 20 and Oct. 24. Investors' willingness to buy NTT shares this year has been muted by the 30.6 percent drop in the company's shares since the $14.3 billion sale of stock last year.

title: Article 2000101194282312581 -- No Title
description: BY CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREINSKY, RUTH
description: GREINSKY-Ruth. On October 9th. Devoted wife of Ira; beloved mother of Charles and daughterin-law Ilene; loving grandmother to Jason and Sara. Services to be held Wednesday, 1PM at Menorah Chapels, Inc., 2145 Richmond Ave., Staten Island. Interment United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island. Contributions can be made to the National Jewish Hospital, Denver, CO. or Congregation B'Nai Israel, Staten Island.

title: They're Just a Lot of Displaced Air
description: VINNIE RODRIGUEZ has no doubt that the spoiler on his 1970 Plymouth Road Runner Super Bird -- a yardwide upside-down wing set on pillars more than two feet high -- does what it is supposed to do.

title: Irish Poetry, Composed in the Kitchen
description: THE gentle rains still fall and the torrents of words still flow. Ireland is still Ireland. But the harshest winds of poverty and isolation blow no more; a new prosperity has utterly transformed the place in the last decade.

title: Price of Crude Oil Rises 4% After a Cold Spell Spurs Demand
description: Crude oil rose 4 percent yesterday after a cold spell in the United States raised demand, and tensions in the Middle East raised concern about possible supply disruptions.

title: Test Plane Crashes at Kansas Airport
description: WICHITA, Kan. -- A business jet taking off on a routine test flight crashed into a field then burst into flames, killing two crew members. The Challenger 604 made by Bombardier Inc. skidded across the runway Tuesday to the west edge of Wichita's Mid-Continent Airport, said Felix Lococo of the Federal Aviation Administration. The badly burned fuselage was mostly intact, but the plane lost its left engine and tail. Debris was scattered across a nearby road. The plane's third occupant was hospitalized in critical condition. "There was the explosion. And then a couple of lights shook and it definitely felt like a sonic boom," said meteorologist Chance Hayes, who heard the crash from the National Weather Service office nearby. "It made the building shake and we definitely knew something had happened." The crash stalled rush-hour traffic in the western part of the city. Commercial flights were not interrupted, but part of the airport was closed. The plane's flight data and cockpit voice recorders were still in the aircraft for the National Transportation Safety Board to recover Wednesday. The plane, manufactured by Montreal-based Canadair, a unit of Bombardier Aerospace, had been in service since 1994 and logged 1,227 hours, company executives said. Bombardier Aerospace, one of the world's biggest airplane makers, manufactures its Learjet line in Wichita and uses its Wichita facilities as a flight test center. Tests scheduled Wednesday at the facility were suspended. The identities of the three crew members -- two pilots and a flight test engineer -- were not immediately released.

title: Clinton, After Courting Arafat, Feels Frustrated by Latest Turn
description: After nearly eight years of dealing with Yasir Arafat, of lavishing more attention on him than on any other world leader, the White House feels exasperated, bewildered, even betrayed, as the Palestinian leader eludes their entreaties for the restoration of calm, officials said today.

title: Light, Fluffy: Believe It, It's Not Butter
description: ONE of the best desserts we've ever tasted was chocolate cupcakes served by a friend on her porch in South Carolina. They looked like any old homemade cupcakes, but they had a silken tenderness that was somehow intensely rich and at the same time extremely light.

title: Mireille Johnston, Authority on Food, Dies
description: PARIS  Mireille Johnston, 65, an author and television personality whose work was well known in France, the United States and Britain, died Thursday in Paris, where she lived.

title: A Start-Up's Hiring Attracts Unwanted Attention
description: Like a lot of start-ups, Cardima Inc., a maker of medical devices in Fremont, Calif., found it hard to predict how big a permanent staff it would need. So, in 1993, the company hired mostly independent contractors to fill the gap.

title: Sports of The Times; It Is Up To El Duque Once Again
description: IN only three seasons with the Yankees, Orlando Hernandez, the Cuban right-hander known as El Duque, has emerged as the pride of their postseason. And now that the Seattle Mariners have knocked the Subway Series slightly off the track, at least for the moment, that pride will be on display again in today's second game of the American League Championship Series.

title: Vouchers That Win
description: On the face of it, school vouchers are a polarizing issue this election year, with George W. Bush and free-market conservatives backing them and Al Gore and supporters of public education vehemently opposed. But voucher proposals don't have to lead to partisan deadlock. Limited, moderate voucher plans have shown they can build powerful and unusual alliances.

title: South Korea Points Fingers On Two Recent Failed Deals
description: The South Korean government began trying to assign blame today for the recent failures of two large business deals that have raised questions about the country's commitment to economic reform.

title: The Fine Art of Selling
description: Playful to the point of decadent, charming in their detail, sleek and bold -- the posters, brochures and magazine advertisements shown here represent some of the best of automotive art. Financed by big corporate budgets, these designs, spanning the years 1912 to 1958, were selling not just cars but also glamour, romance, modernity, success, happiness and the good life.

title: Mariners Shut Out Yankees in Opener
description: The Seattle Mariners defeated the punchless Yankees, 2-0, last night in the opening game of the American League Championship Series.

title: Frown, You're on Red-Light Camera!
description: RED-LIGHT cameras have your number.

title: Pre-1975 Pill Tied to Breast Cancer in High-Risk Families
description: Women who took birth control pills before 1975 and whose mothers or sisters had breast cancer have a substantially increased risk of developing the disease and should take special care to have regular mammograms and breast exams, researchers are reporting.

title: Canseco To Sit In This Series
description: Jose Canseco, whose 446 career homers would have been the most for any player in the American League Championship Series, was dropped from the Yankees' active roster yesterday and replaced by Jason Grimsley.

title: North Korean at White House, Continuing a Warming Trend
description: President Clinton today became the first president to meet with a North Korean official, who carried with him a letter from the North's leader, Kim Jong Il, that White House officials said contained a series of proposals for a further easing of half-century-old tensions on the divided peninsula.

title: Two Synagogues Outside of Paris Set on Fire
description: VERSAILLES, France, Oct. 11 -- Two Paris synagogues were set on fire overnight Tuesday and one of them partially destroyed in attacks police fear could be linked to the violence in the Middle East.

title: A Fix for the Broadcast Giveaway
description: Chairman William Kennard of the Federal Communications Commission called on Congress yesterday to force broadcasters to speed up their promised conversion to digital television. That is a polite way of asking Congress to reverse its craven decision four years ago to give the politically powerful broadcasters spectrum rights worth perhaps $70 billion without demanding anything meaningful in return. The broadcasters were supposed to use the new spectrum to provide high-resolution pictures or new interactive data and information services. But they have little financial incentive to roll out these expensive new services anytime soon. Yesterday Mr. Kennard blew the whistle.

title: A Failure With Many Fathers
description: Given the recent and ongoing demonstration of the Israeli and Palestinian penchant for mutually assured destruction, it is worth asking whether the ''peace process'' is dead or only breathing hard. Whatever the answer, it is clear that we have come to this sorry state thanks to a dearth of effective leadership on both sides.

title: Demolition Begins On Old Buildings Of Hotel in Catskills
description: Two years ago the legendary Concord Hotel closed its doors in what local residents and summer visitors regarded as the last gasp for the once-thriving Catskill resorts.

title: THE CHEF; Caramel Abandons the Dessert Menu for a Steak
description: IN most restaurants, caramel is sticky and sweet and part of dessert. But Asian influences dominate my cooking, so sugar plays a more complex role. Following a tradition popular in Southeast Asia, I use caramel as the base for a savory glaze for steaks.

title: Uncertainty Casts a Shadow on Support for a Measure That Allows Imports of Drugs
description: Doubts are growing about legislation to allow imports of low-priced prescription drugs, and no one in the government or the drug industry can say how it will work, or even whether it will work.

title: In the Mideast, Time for a Recess
description: To the Editor:

title: European Union Approves Time Warner, AOL Merger
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 11  The European Commission gave a green light today to Time Warner Inc.'s $129 billion merger with America Online Inc., but the companies face bigger objections from antitrust regulators in Washington.

title: Parents Want High Schoolers Closer to Home

title: NEW SIGN OF STRENGTH IN JAPAN
description: Japan's machinery orders posted their biggest rise in almost four years in August, paced by phone makers, who bought more machinery to produce the latest cellular phones. Orders, excluding those by shipbuilders and electric utilities, rose 26.6 percent last month from July, seasonally adjusted, the Economic Planning Agency said. From a year ago, orders rose a record 45.8 percent. The increase in orders, which point to spending in about six months time, signals capital investment will continue to underpin economic growth.

In San Diego, the Padres randomly test minor leaguers for steroids at spring training and find that about one in five test positive. In Miami, a veteran outfielder says he believes as many as 40 percent of major leaguers have used the muscle-building drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORGE, SANNA SARABEL.
description: BORGE-Sanna Sarabel. Beloved wife of entertainer, Victor Borge, died at their home in Greenwich, CT, on September 19th. Born in Otwell, Indiana, the former Sarabel Scraper started her own business representing commercial artists in Chicago, Illinois. There she met Victor Borge, at which point she gave up her clients to devote her energies to his burgeoning worldwide career. In 1953 they married. Mrs. Borge, an avid reader and gardening enthusiast, traveled extensively with her husband and, with him, created homes for their family in Denmark, Southbury, CT, St. Croix (U.S. Virgin Islands), Greenwich, CT and Portugal. She is survived by her husband, a sister (Bettye Downey of Dayton, Ohio), five children (three daughters: Sanna Feirstein of New York City, Janet Crowle of St. Michaels, MD, Frederikke Borge of North Egremont, MA; and two sons: Ronald Borge of Rowayton, CT, and Victor Bernhard (Vebe) Borge of New York City) and nine grandchildren. A private service was held on September 22nd. Donations may be made in her name to The Greenwich Hospital.

title: PACIFICARE HEALTH MAY HAVE 3RD-QUARTER LOSS
description: PacifiCare Health Systems Inc. expects third-quarter results of break-even to a loss of 10 cents a share based on higher-than-anticipated commercial and Medicare health-care expenses. The company's anticipated earnings are lower than analysts' expectations. PacifiCare's shares were halted for news and last traded at $32.63, down 88 cents. A First Call/Thomson Financial survey of 19 analysts had produced a mean earnings estimate of $1.90 a share for PacifiCare's third quarter. For the third quarter ended Sept. 30, 1999, and excluding 4 cents a share in charges, PacifiCare earned $1.58 a diluted share on revenue of $2.52 billion. PacifiCare said yesterday that it expected third-quarter pretax earnings to decrease $120 million to $130 million.

I'm not talking about Car and Driver or Road and Track; those are generalist books, uniting car enthusiasts across boundaries of time, category and brand. Nor am I concerned with hot-rod or classic-car magazines (too mainstream) or, for that matter, the many periodicals devoted to well-known single marques (Vette Vues, Hot VW's).

title: America Online, Time Warner Merger Approved by European Union
description: BRUSSELS, Belgium -- The European Union's executive body on Wednesday conditionally approved America Online Inc.'s $129 billion acquisition of Time Warner Inc., removing another obstacle in the proposed combination between the world's largest Internet and media companies. Under the terms of the approval, AOL and Time Warner agreed that they will not unfairly muscle out rivals from the emerging media and entertainment markets in Europe, the European Commission said. In a statement, the commission of the 15-nation European Union said that AOL is to sever its structural links with German media giant Bertelsmann AG. That condition is meant to allow Bertelsmann to remain an independent competitor in Europe. "The commission has a duty to prevent creation of dominant positions in all sectors, be they in the old or new economy," said EU antitrust commissioner Mario Monti. Antitrust officials were concerned about a resulting integrated company that "could have dominated the online music distribution market and music players," Monti said. The AOL-Time Warner merger still has to be cleared by U.S. antitrust authorities, but the EU decision was seen as key for the chances of the merger going through. Sources said the EU antitrust authorities only formally endorsed the merger after the companies agreed to several concessions, including ending ties with Bertelsmann, Europe's biggest media company. That move will prevent AOL "from having access to Europe's leading source of music publishing rights, thereby eliminating the risk of dominance in the emerging markets for online delivery of music over the Internet and software-based music players," the commission statement said. The companies also have provided guarantees that they will not unfairly discriminate against other companies that provide Internet content or within the music industry. The vote of the 20-member commission on Wednesday came at its weekly meeting -- two weeks ahead of its deadline. EU authorities made quick progress on the issue after Time Warner last week dropped a separate joint venture plan with EMI Group of Britain, which would have created a major music company. European regulators had strongly opposed that deal. With Bertelsmann, Europe's largest media company, competing on its own, the commission said it concluded that AOL-Time Warner "wouldn't have the critical mass in terms of music publishing to dominate the market." Bertelsmann's BMG subsidiary is one of the world's five major music companies and EU antitrust officials feared the merger would have left the new company with the ability to keep the industry in a stranglehold. Bertelsmann is investing heavily to become the largest supplier of media content via the Internet. The antitrust division of the commission opened a probe into the proposed AOL-Time Warner merger in June, stressing the need for an open, competitive environment in the emerging cybermusic and entertainment markets.

title: Blue Jays Fire Fregosi but Retain Their G.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLE, RALPH L., JR.,
description: ENGLE-Ralph L., Jr., M.D. The Boards, Faculty, and Staff of Weill Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences of Cornell University and New YorkPresbyterian Hospital are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear colleague and friend, Dr. Ralph Engle, on October 7. Dr. Engle, who was associated with New York Weill Cornell Medical Center for almost half a century, was Professor Emeritus of Medicine and Public Health at the time of his death. His warmth, his charm, his love for medical education will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Dr. Mary Allen Engle, and family.

Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary mourn with profound sorrow the tragic death of a devoted Yeshiva College alumnus murdered by an enraged and incited Palestinian mob near Joseph's Tomb-thus becoming the latest martyr for Eretz Israel. His sacrifice will not be forgotten, and the memory of his courage and conviction will always inspire us. Our hearts go out to his wife, Yael; his seven children; parents, Rabbi Zevulun (and Joyce Bracha) Lieberman, rosh yeshiva and holder of the Maxwell R. Maybaum Memorial Chair in Talmud and Sephardic Codes (Halakhah), RIETS; sisters, Tehilla and Elyora Chaya; and the entire family. May the Almighty comfort them among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees

It may be painful for Mets fans to recall, but it may have pertinence to tonight's opening game against the Cardinals in the National League Championship Series. Hampton, after all, is the starting pitcher, the left-hander the Mets are hoping can put them on the freeway to victory. The scene in question occurred in the third inning of Game 1 of the National League division series last Wednesday in Pacific Bell Park in San Francisco.

But now, rear-wheel drive is coming back, especially in luxury cars.

title: Giants Hope the Defense Can Maintain Its Ferocity

He jogged back onto the field, and his reward on the next play was seven Giants charging through the Falcons' offensive line. Chandler was slammed to the ground and sidelined for the rest of the game.

title: G.M. RECALLING BRAZILIAN CAR
description: In an operation that would involve vehicles sold in Brazil and abroad, General Motors said it planned to recall all Corsa model cars made in Brazil. The company declined to give further details, saying that an official announcement would be made on Monday. The recall is expected to begin next week. The company declined to comment on a report in the Brazilian daily O Valor Economico that the recall covered close to a million cars and would replace a seat belt that could come loose. Jennifer L. Rich

title: GLAXO SUES OVER PLAN TO SELL GENERIC VERSIONS OF DRUG
description: Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., which plans to merge with a British rival, SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., this year, has sued Impax Laboratories Inc. after Impax filed to sell generic versions of Glaxo's Wellbutrin antidepressant drug and its Zyban treatment for quitting smoking. Glaxo filed the lawsuit in California, asserting that Impax's plans to introduce the drugs interfered with Glaxo's patents, Impax said in a written statement. Wellbutrin and Zyban are the same chemical compound, but they are sold as different treatments. Glaxo is trying to extend patents for the drugs, which had combined sales of about $400 million in the first half of the year. Impax, which says its filings do not infringe on Glaxo's patents, has applied for United States approval to make generic versions of eight drugs.

title: SINGAPORE GROWTH QUICKENS
description: Singapore's economy grew 10.2 percent in the third quarter compared with the period a year earlier, its fastest pace in three years, according to preliminary estimates released by the Minister of Trade and Industry. Fueling growth were orders for computer chips and other computer-related goods, which drove exports to a record. The numbers appeared to defy predictions that slowing growth in United States demand would hobble Asia's export-dependent economies, especially Singapore's. The numbers prompted the government to raise its prediction for full-year economic growth to 9 percent from a range of 7.5 percent to 8.5 percent. Wayne Arnold

But Yankees Manager Joe Torre had no intention of inserting a pinch-hitter for Sojo, a career utilityman, because two weeks into October, Sojo is the Yankees' most productive hitter.

Some crave power, some chase status, all seek to be one with their car of yesteryear.

title: BERTELSMANN OPENS SECOND ONLINE FRONT
description: Bertelsmann, already fighting the free distribution of music in court, is now fighting it over the Internet -- with its own online music distribution strategy. The company's record label, BMG Entertainment, said it would make singles and albums available over the Internet for digital download. BMG started the service on Lycos.com, offering 100 singles and albums from artists including Christina Aguilera, Toni Braxton and Santana. Unlike Napster, the free music exchange service that the record labels are challenging in court, BMG's digital downloads come at a price: $1.98 to $3.49 for singles and $9.98 to $14.98 for albums. The company said it planned to make 2,500 albums and singles available by the holiday season on a variety of Web sites. Matt Richtel

description: In a Silicon Valley rendering of ''The Empire Strikes Back,'' Intel Corporation executives took the stage at an industry gathering today to deflect the first inroads of a tiny but highly visible competitor in the lucrative chip market for portable computers.

title: Latest National Surveys Reflect an Even Race and a Limited Supply of Enthusiasm
description: Neither Gov. George W. Bush nor Vice President Al Gore has yet been able to pull ahead in the presidential campaign, with each man's weaknesses becoming magnified in the minds of voters, according to five national polls out this week. Mr. Bush has the edge in three of the surveys, Mr. Gore in two, but they are well within each poll's sampling error.

description: Dr. Laura Schlessinger, the conservative radio and television talk show host who has provoked the ire of gay groups for calling homosexuality deviant and derivative of ''biological error,'' will issue a public apology today to those she might have offended.

title: 10 That Can Still Turn Heads
description: The following is an arbitrary selection of 10 cars -- one from each decade of the 20th century -- that may appeal to potential car collectors. Current prices are for cars that are well restored or in good condition. Optional equipment, as well as the region where it is being sold, can affect prices, too. In each case, a current or previous owner has been asked to describe what's so special about the car. The owners' organizations listed with each car can provide more information.

title: America Online, Time Warner Merger Approved by European Union
description: BRUSSELS, Belgium -- The European Union's executive body on Wednesday conditionally approved America Online Inc.'s $129 billion acquisition of Time Warner Inc., removing another obstacle in the proposed combination between the world's largest Internet and media companies. Under the terms of the approval, AOL and Time Warner agreed that they will not unfairly muscle out rivals from the emerging media and entertainment markets in Europe, the European Commission said. In a statement, the commission of the 15-nation European Union said that AOL is to sever its structural links with German media giant Bertelsmann AG. That condition is meant to allow Bertelsmann to remain an independent competitor in Europe. "The commission has a duty to prevent creation of dominant positions in all sectors, be they in the old or new economy," said EU antitrust commissioner Mario Monti. Antitrust officials were concerned about a resulting integrated company that "could have dominated the online music distribution market and music players," Monti said. The AOL-Time Warner merger still has to be cleared by U.S. antitrust authorities, but the EU decision was seen as key for the chances of the merger going through. Sources said the EU antitrust authorities only formally endorsed the merger after the companies agreed to several concessions, including ending ties with Bertelsmann, Europe's biggest media company. That move will prevent AOL "from having access to Europe's leading source of music publishing rights, thereby eliminating the risk of dominance in the emerging markets for online delivery of music over the Internet and software-based music players," the commission statement said. The companies also have provided guarantees that they will not unfairly discriminate against other companies that provide Internet content or within the music industry. The vote of the 20-member commission on Wednesday came at its weekly meeting -- two weeks ahead of its deadline. EU authorities made quick progress on the issue after Time Warner last week dropped a separate joint venture plan with EMI Group of Britain, which would have created a major music company. European regulators had strongly opposed that deal. With Bertelsmann, Europe's largest media company, competing on its own, the commission said it concluded that AOL-Time Warner "wouldn't have the critical mass in terms of music publishing to dominate the market." Bertelsmann's BMG subsidiary is one of the world's five major music companies and EU antitrust officials feared the merger would have left the new company with the ability to keep the industry in a stranglehold. Bertelsmann is investing heavily to become the largest supplier of media content via the Internet. The antitrust division of the commission opened a probe into the proposed AOL-Time Warner merger in June, stressing the need for an open, competitive environment in the emerging cybermusic and entertainment markets.

title: Two Americans Share Nobel Economics Prize
description: Two American professors won the Nobel Prize in economics today for research that helps statistically analyze the basic choices we make in life, like what jobs we take, where we live and how many children we have.

title: A REORGANIZED LOEHMANN'S EMERGES FROM CHAPTER 11
description: Loehmann's Inc., a discount clothing retailer, said yesterday that it had emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and had completed a deal to get $75 million in debt financing. Loehmann's, based in the Bronx, filed for protection from its creditors in July. Loehmann's has formed a holding company, Loehmann's Holding Inc. The company's new stock and notes will be distributed to creditors who were allowed claims in the Chapter 11 case. The company's old common stock has been canceled, Loehmann's said. Loehmann's, which had $432 million in sales last year, has 44 stores in 17 states.

title: OIL DEAL IN NEW ZEALAND
description: Moving to strengthen its share of Asia's market for natural gas, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group said it would join with Apache of Houston to take over Fletcher Challenge Energy of New Zealand for $1.6 billion. Shell will pay $1.03 billion for control of Fletcher's gas fields in New Zealand and Brunei. Apache will get Fletcher's oil and gas assets in Canada and Argentina for $600 million. The deal is part of a broader effort to dismantle Fletcher Challenge, one of New Zealand's largest companies. Wayne Arnold

title: Tomato Concasse and Tomato Parsley Salad
description: The plum tomato is finer, denser and juicier than the beefsteak. That makes it preferable in an uncooked tomato sauce although a concasse like the one we are preparing here can be cooked, too. The tomatoes really don't have to be peeled but we've chosen to because removing the peel, which is a waxy natural protection for the tomatoes flesh, makes more of the flesh available to absorb flavoring and also makes the dish more delicate. The reason you plunge the tomatoes into cold water immediately after removing them from the boiling water is to prevent any cooking -- this is a raw concasse, after all.

title: G.O.P. Has Big Advantage In Its Campaign Treasury
description: During three months this summer, the Republican National Committee raised $100 million, or more than $1 million every day, Republican officials said today. The $100 million total represents the largest sum raised in a single quarter by a national party in American history and leaves the party with a significant cash advantage over the Democrats in the final weeks of the campaign.

title: Safeway Recalls Taco Shells After Test Questions Corn Origin
description: The unapproved genetically engineered corn connected with a nationwide recall of taco shells has been found in a second brand of shells as well, a coalition of biotechnology food critics said Wednesday night.

title: THE BOSS; The Dean Is In. Now Pay Up.
description: When I was an economics student at the University of Chicago, my wife and I used to house-sit for my doctoral adviser, Merton H. Miller, who ended up winning a Nobel Prize. We would tramp over twice a day and change his cats' litter and feed them. One day, there was a water-main break, and we spent the afternoon in the basement, sopping wet, cleaning it out with the plumber.

title: Proof From MetroCard Ends Fare-Beating Case
description: City officials have decided to settle a federal civil rights case filed by a 19-year-old Brooklyn student who was arrested two years ago for jumping a turnstile when he had, in fact, paid his fare using a MetroCard.

title: S & P LOWERS OUTLOOK ON DAIMLERCHRYSLER
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation revised its outlook on DaimlerChrysler A.G. to negative from stable yesterday. The negative outlook reflects the risk that the poor profitability of DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler division will not prove temporary, S.& P. said. Management has said Chrysler, which had accounted for about half of the group's earnings since the merger in late 1998, is expected to record an operating loss of $520 million in the third quarter, largely reflecting temporary problems with its new minivan, S.& P. said. But competition in minivans, sport utility vehicles and pickups is also a problem, despite record demand in North America, S.& P. said. If earnings do not improve, the ratings could be cut, S.& P. said.

title: Changsha Journal; Hunan Style Television: Spicy and Crowd Pleasing
description: As Chinese provinces go, Hunan has few natural advantages. A landlocked square, it lacks the cosmopolitan muscle of the coast, the prosperity of its southern neighbors, the exotic minority cultures of China's west.

title: Jim, I Have a Feeling We're Not in Indiana Anymore
description: Like most sitcoms, ''Welcome to New York'' has a sledgehammer concept: a Midwestern weatherman moves to New York City. Unlike most sitcoms, this sharply written and acted series has genuine wit. It works slyly, not with punch lines but by transforming the obvious premise into winning satire, taking a droll view of how we lock other people into stereotypes. Though the show's humor creeps up instead of bashing you over the head, it has the strongest premiere episode and is the most promising comedy of the season.

title: Federal Appeals Court Repeals Fairness Rules in Broadcasting
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  A Federal appeals court today repealed two long-established rules that had required radio and television stations to provide free reply time for opponents of political candidates endorsed by the stations and for candidates and others whose integrity is attacked.

title: U.S. Indicts 4 In Inquiry In Connecticut

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, ORA GRILL,
description: YOUNG-Ora Grill, 84, of White Plains, NY on October 3, 2000. A resident of Westchester County for 55 years, she served on the Greenburgh Board of Education for 9 years and was a founder of the Union Child Day Care Center. A graduate of Radcliffe College, she married Dennison Young, M.D. in 1940. Mrs. Young had a zest for life and family and an abiding concern for others. She is survived by her children, Dennison Young, Jr. of NYC, Amy Geiger (Larry) and Andrew Young (Mary O'Keefe) of White Plains, and her 7 grandchildren to whom she was devoted. There will be a private memorial service for the family. Contributions may be made in her memory to the Dennison Young, M.D. Fund for Education in Pediatric Cardiology at Montefiore Medical Center, 111 E. 210th St., Bronx, NY 10467.

title: PRIMEDIA IS ACQUIRING KAGAN WORLD MEDIA
description: Primedia Inc., the publisher of magazines like Seventeen and New York, has agreed to buy the media research company Kagan World Media Inc. for an undisclosed amount of stock. The transaction includes the closely held company's Kagan Euromedia and Asia Cable and Satellite World magazines, 38 industry newsletters, 95 forecasting reports, 20 executive conferences, and Kagan Consulting, Primedia said in a written statement. Paul Kagan, chairman and chief executive of Kagan, has been named vice chairman of Primedia's venture capital unit. Primedia, based in New York, said there were no plans to lay off any of Kagan's 140 employees.

title: Hampton Files Last Week in Past
description: ST. LOUIS -- Last impressions can be lasting. And the image of Mike Hampton flummoxed on the mound, his Mets cap pulled tightly around his ears and steam rising from them, is memorable. It may be painful for Mets fans to recall, but it may have pertinence to tonight's opening game against the Cardinals in the National League Championship Series. Hampton, after all, is the starting pitcher, the left-hander the Mets are hoping can put them on the freeway to victory. The scene in question occurred in the third inning of Game 1 of the National League division series last Wednesday in Pacific Bell Park in San Francisco.

title: Middle East Tense, With Fears of Terrorism, Hints of Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 11 - Despite an intensive international effort to defuse the tensions here, the violence continued on a low broil as Prime Minister Ehud Barak warned Israelis that renewed terrorism could follow the rioting and gun battles of the last 13 days.

title: House Passes Bill on Tire and Car Defects
description: The chairman and chief executive of Bridgestone/Firestone Inc., Masatoshi Ono, resigned from those jobs today, and was promptly succeeded by John Lampe, the executive vice president of the American subsidiary of the Japanese company. The House of Representatives, meanwhile, prepared to take up a bill that would require auto companies that replace motor vehicle parts in a foreign country for safety reasons to notify American regulators and would require tire manufacturers to give regulators data on warranty claims. Ford replaced Firestone tires for owners of its Explorer sport utility vehicles in Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, but did not tell American regulators.

title: All Aboard the Foreign Language Express

So he hired a Japanese dental assistant and, with her help, began learning basic phrases. He also installed a phone line with an answering message in Japanese, had his dental forms translated into Japanese and posted notices in convenience stores frequented by the growing Japanese community in Westchester County.
