title: Study on Polar Flights
description: A joint Canadian-Russian study has found that opening air traffic routes over the North Pole to thousands of commercial flights a year is ''feasible and desirable.'' Aviation experts said the study, to be released today, lays the groundwork for an increase in the number of polar flights and may make practical nonstop flights between far-flung cities.

title: An Old Pro Learns Some New Tricks
description: THE Cuisinart's profile, so familiar for more than 25 years, has had a curvaceous makeover. The latest model, the PowerPrep Plus, has a sleek white rounded base instead of an angular one. Also new are touch-pad buttons, which replace levers, and a work bowl made of clear, not smoky, plastic. The feed tube, originally in the front, is there again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLTARSH, ELAINE
description: OLTARSH-Elaine. The Sisterhood of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue mourns the loss of our devoted Board member and extends condolences to her bereaved family. Irma Lopes Cardozo, Carla S. Schein, Co-Presidents

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURD, JEANNE O'NEAL.
description: HURD-Jeanne O'Neal. On Oct. 9, 2000 as the result of a stroke on Sept. 29. Former wife of the late Charles P. Hurd, beloved mother of Jeanne and Patricia of N.Y.C & River Vale, N.J. Aunt to six loving nieces & nephews and mother-byproxy to many other daughters & sons. Born in Washington, D.C. & raised in Manhattan, Jeanne was a resident of River Vale for 45 years. She will be remembered as the heart of her family and the fire around which we all gathered for warmth. No services will be held. Contributions may be made in her name to Fund for Animals, 500 West 57th St, New York City 10019.

title: 'Metamorphosen,' Literally
description: Strauss's somberly beautiful late work for 23 strings, ''Metamorphosen,'' is usually performed at orchestra concerts. So James Levine could have included it on one of the programs that the Met Orchestra will perform at Carnegie Hall this season. Instead, and much more interestingly, Mr. Levine conducted this thick-textured, ruminative 35-minute work at Sunday afternoon's concert by the Met Chamber Ensemble upstairs in Weill Recital Hall. The chance to hear ''Metamorphosen'' as a chamber work in a chamber hall was just one of the pleasures of this engrossing concert.

title: When One Model Lifts a Line
description: THE first Thunderbird was inspired by a visit to the 1951 Paris auto show by Lewis Crusoe, a Ford Motor Company executive, and the designer George Walker.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Deutsche Bank offers to buy National Discount Brokers.
description: IF Deutsche Bank's $1-billion-plus offer yesterday to acquire National Discount Brokers Group is any indication, there is a hot market for market makers.

title: All Moving! Chanting! Harmonizing!
description: Dyed-to-match toe shoes, folding chairs and cigarette-puffing performers were once among the signs in dance that the audience was in for a disappointing evening. The surest sign today is an onstage videographer prowling solemnly through a piece.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Hear Cases of Deportable Inmates With Nowhere to Be Deported To
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the government can keep a deportable alien behind bars indefinitely for lack of a country willing to accept him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMAN, JACK H. JR.,
description: LEHMAN-Jack H. Jr., 82. Of Boynton Beach, Florida and Oakhurst, New Jersey. Died peacefully at home on October 10, 2000. Most loving and caring husband of Barbara. Adored father, teacher and friend of Bill L. Feist and Jack H. Lehman III. Wonderful and generous Poppop of Jeffrey and John Feist, Michael, Katherine, Skye and Lexi Lehman. Beloved brother of Babette Newman and most and supportive stepfather of Karen Kates. His unique personality affected wll who knew him. His guidance, wisdom and courage to the end filled us with pride. We have all been blessed with his love, humor and devotion. Funeral Private. Family will be receiving friends at 222 Park Avenue, Oakhurst, NJ on Thursday, October 12th from 2-4 P.M. and from 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: Hospice (VNA of Central New Jersey), 1100 Wayside Road, Tinton Falls, NJ 07712 or Monmouth Medical Center, Attn: Bridget Murphy, 300 Second Avenue, Long Branch, NJ 07740. LEHMAN-Jack H., Jr. The Officers, Trustees and Members of the Hollywood Golf Club note with sorrow the passing of their longtime friend and member, Jack H. Lehman, Jr. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his family. Bernard D. Karasic, President Charles Weissman, Secretary LEHMAN-Jack Jr. The members of the Ocean Beach Club regret the passing of their good friend and member and send heartfelt condolences to his family. Sandy Paskin, President Nancy Lobell, Secretary LEHMAN-Jack H. Jr., The Boards of Trustees of Monmouth Medical Center and Monmouth Health Care Foundation express sadness at the passing of a very special benefactor and extend their heartfelt sympathy to his family & friends.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Governors Are People, Too

title: Protecting Trademarks
description: To the Editor:

title: PANAMSAT EARNINGS DROP 73%
description: The largest commercial satellite operator, PanAmSat, said its third-quarter profit fell 73 percent on increased costs for its Internet service. The company, 81 percent owned by the Hughes Electronics unit of General Motors, said net income fell to $9.25 million, or 6 cents a share, from $33.9 million, or 23 cents, a year earlier. Revenue fell 5.4 percent, to $199.3 million. PanAmSat's expenses rose 53 percent, to $63.8 million from a year earlier. The company is spending more on its new Internet service, called Net/36. PanAmSat's third-quarter 1999 sales also included a one-time payment of about $15 million to end a contract to provide satellite video services in India. Its shares fell 38 cents, to $28.75.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: 3 Men Vital to the Internet Share Nobel Prize in Physics
description: Citing the worldwide impact of the Internet enabled by their work, the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences has awarded the 2000 Nobel Prize in Physics to three scientists who developed electrical components that allow for fast communication using fiber optics and satellites and that serve as the soul of the personal computer.

title: Candidates Meet in Restrained Debate
description: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Oct. 11  Seated side by side in their second debate, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush cautiously discussed foreign affairs tonight, largely agreeing on the nation's policies in the Mideast and the Balkans while arguing over military readiness and the intervention in Haiti.

title: Kramnik Defeats Kasparov To Take Lead in Title Match
description: Garry Kasparov cracked under pressure and lost Game 2 of the Brain Games Network World Chess Championship to Vladimir Kramnik in London yesterday. That gives Kramnik the lead by 1 1/2- 1/2.

title: New Hampshire Supreme Court Justice Is Acquitted in His Impeachment Trial
description: The country's first impeachment trial of a state supreme court's chief justice ended today in a full acquittal. The New Hampshire Senate found Chief Justice David Brock not guilty on four charges -- including two of improperly allowing disqualified justices to comment on cases -- and sent him, chastened but unbowed, back to his bench.
CARS and presidents. Two national obsessions. Both stem from that most American phenomenon, which is a form of self-invention: we can be whoever we want to be, including president.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the trial of two Libyans charged in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, which exploded in 1988 over Lockerbie, Scotland, misstated the relationship of a witness to the case. A man depicted in cables by the Central Intelligence Agency as a chronic liar was a central witness for the prosecution, not for the defense. Defense witnesses will not testify until the prosecution concludes its case.

title: In Grand Central, a Savory Vietnamese Connection
description: SALADS can be divided into two main types. The first, and more improvisational, makes imaginative use of whatever ingredients happen to be in the refrigerator, cobbled together more by experience and instinct than by design. At best, these salads can be joyous cornucopias, bright and delightful.

title: Article 2000101190221123632 -- No Title
description: Ithink I'll sigh a little bit less in this debate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKIERNAN, FRANK
description: McKIERNAN-Frank. On October 8, 2000. Native of Swanlinbar, Co. Cavan, Ireland. Beloved husband of Margaret (nee Flatley). Loving father of Joan, Frank & Kathleen McKiernan Blackman. Dear brother of Peter, Sean, and Thomas Gabriel; all of NY and Bridget Lenihan of Dublin, Ireland. Adoring grandfather of four and great grandfather of one. Cherished father-in-law of Georgia, Ed Maloney and Ian Blackman. Reposing Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10AM, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: U.S. WARNING CHINA ON TRADE PLEDGES
description: President Clinton sent his top trade negotiator to Beijing today to warn China that its efforts to back away from crucial trade concessions threatened the trading rights that it won after a prolonged fight in Congress.

title: Nets Are Looking Forward To the Easy Part: Playing
description: As practice wore down into the fourth hour, the Nets had to run extra sprints today, making the players even more eager for Wednesday's first preseason game.

title: Metro Business; Utility and Union Settle
description: The New York Power Authority, the state-owned utility, and the union representing 418 power plant workers have reached a tentative contract, it was announced yesterday.

title: RWE TO CUT POWER OUTPUT
description: Germany's largest electric utility, RWE, said it would cut power production by 16 percent in the next three years to counter falling prices. The company will instead focus on making more acquisitions abroad. The company plans to shut down 5,200 megawatts, or enough to light 5.2 million homes, and close a nuclear power station.

title: Pact Ends Apartment Workers' Strike
description: After an eight-day strike, maintenance workers at 532 apartment buildings in Westchester County reached an agreement yesterday with building owners, the lawyer for the owners said.

title: How a Planetary Transmission Changed Her Mind Forever
description: I HAVE heard people speak of America's love affair with the automobile, and I have never understood. Over the years, I have suffered house envy and income envy, but never car envy.

title: European Union Moves to Embrace Yugoslav Leadership
description: The world began to embrace the new Yugoslavia and its new president, Vojislav Kostunica, in earnest today, with the visit here of the French foreign minister, Hubert Vedrine, representing the European Union.

title: Tomato Coulis and Tomato Mint Soup
description: Big beefsteak tomatoes are perfect for a coulis (as they are when you want a big slice of tomato for a salad). You don't have to peel or seed them (the straining will take care of that), they are mealier and less juicy than plum tomatoes but they are going to be stewed and then pureed and the mealiness will actually end up helping the texture of the final dish. Once cooked and strained, the coulis can be seasoned with herbs to become a sauce for pasta or fish. It can be used as a cooking medium for chicken fricassee. But, with almost no work at all, it can be used for a tomato soup (as we do below). By the way, tightly sealed in a plastic bag, the coulis freezes well for later use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLBERT, JOSEPH D.
description: COLBERT-Joseph D., Rev. Of Glendale, NY, died on October 10, 2000 at age 67. A Pastor of Saint Pancras R.C. Church, he was ordained May 30, 1959. He is survived by dear sister, Maureen McMahon. Visitation Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M., Thursday 2-5 at George Werst Funeral Home, 7141 Cooper Avenue in Glendale, NY. Mass of Transferral at 7:30. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10:30 at Saint Pancras R.C. Church. Interment to follow at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Buies Creek, N.C.

title: A Surprise Partner Helps Create a Juicy Duck
description: MANY people are afraid to cook duck, and not entirely without reason. Roasting the whole bird long enough to release most or all of the fat dries out the meat, but undercooking leaves the leg meat tough.

title: COLLECTING: Driven: 3 People With a Passion for the Classic; The Hudson Fixer
description: JOHN SONEFF'S first Hudson was a 1940 convertible in sea-foam green. He bought it almost new, for $1,055, from a Hudson dealer near his boyhood home whose address he can still rattle off as if it were right down the street.

title: Technology Stocks Are Down Sharply on Earnings Fears
description: Technology stock prices fell sharply again yesterday as fears spread that a slowing economy would drag down corporate earnings through the end of the year.

title: Kathie Lee Who?
description: When NBC's ''Today'' announced that it was expanding to three hours from two, it looked like potential trouble for Regis Philbin, whose morning talk show already seemed to be in jeopardy because it would have to meet the fall without its perky co-host, Kathie Lee Gifford (who left the program in July).

title: DELIVERY COMPANIES' DEAL COLLAPSES
description: Negotiations for Kozmo.com to buy Urbanfetch.com have officially ended after more than three months of discussions, officials said yesterday. A tentative deal had been reached last week. But on Monday, officials said that Gerry Burdo, Kozmo's president and acting chief executive, had raised concerns as early as last Thursday, after reviewing Urbanfetch's books in London. One senior Urbanfetch executive disputed that account, saying that Kozmo officials had had access to most of those records for three months. The two companies, both based in New York, deliver goods ordered online. Jayson Blair

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILLMAN, SUSAN
description: TILLMAN-Susan. Beloved wife of the late Morty. Loving mother of Pamela and the late Jonathan. Cherished daughter of Sylvia and the late David Sverd. Dear sister of Jeffrey Sverd and sister-in-law of Barbara. Adored aunt of Peter and Farryl. Loved by all who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, RITA
description: BARNETT-Rita. Of Bronxville, NY on October 10, 2000. Wife of Harold. Mother of Paula Kennedy and Christopher Barnett. Sister of Olga Serricchio & Clare Servedio. Calling hours are at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home Bronxville between the hours of 24 and 7-9 PM Wednesday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Thursday October 12th. at 10 A.M. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to St. Joseph's Church Bronxville, New York.

title: Clinton Has Warm, 'Very Positive' Talk With North Korea's No. 2 Official
description: WASHINGTON  President Bill Clinton met Tuesday in the White House with Jo Myong Rok, the highest-ranking North Korean official ever to visit Washington, in a meeting that was praised by U.S. officials as "very positive."

title: Study Finds Air Route Over North Pole Feasible for Flights to Asia
description: A joint Canadian-Russian study has found that opening air traffic routes over the North Pole, currently used by two or three flights a day, to thousands of commercial flights a year is ''feasible and desirable.''

title: Tomato Garnish
description: Cherry tomatoes are sweeter than all the others, so sweet that they can even be used in fruit salad. They also have the handy characteristic of being bite-size, so most of the time they can be served whole. Another quality they bring to the table is color variation: These days red and yellow are pretty common, but if you live near a farmers' market, you may also find orange and even green (yes, ripe, but green). Here we take advantage of the whole, colorful tomatoes to bring to life just about any simply grilled meat or fish. In the video demonstration, we chose tuna.

title: Article 2000101193818292842 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL MILLS, GLADYS
description: SIEGEL MILLS-Gladys. At 94. On Saturday, October 7, 2000. A lifelong New Yorker. Wife of the late Samuel W. Siegel. She is survived by her daughters Judith Lippman, of Baltimore and Vivian Meyers of Westport, CT, a sister Florence Manning of Boca Raton, her grandchildren Kenneth, Mandy, Sarah, Fred and Andy, and her seven great grandchildren. A pioneer woman real estate broker and founder of Gotham Realty. She dedicated her life to giving love. Private burial at Westchester Hills, October 11th. The family will sit shiva in New York (240 Central Park South) Thursday evening, and in Connecticut, Saturday evening and Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOMBOROW, ABRAHAM SAMUEL.
description: GOMBOROW-Abraham Samuel. On Monday, October 9, of Brookline, MA. Beloved son of the late Joel & Jessie (Green) Gomborow. Dear brother of the late Emma Ehrlich and her husband Louis Ehrlich and three siblings who died at birth. Mr. Gomborow was one of the original Jewish settlers in Jerusalem. Services were held at the Levine Chapel, Brookline, Massachusetts on Tuesday, October 10. Interment followed at the Beth El Cemetery, Baker Street, West Roxbury, MA. Remembrances may be made to the Abraham S. Gomborow Trust Fund, C/O Kolbe Associates, P.O. Box 610409, Newton Highlands, MA. 02461.

title: SECOND SOGO SUICIDE
description: A former vice president of the failed Sogo department store chain was found dead in his home after hanging himself, the police said. Yukio Nakazawa, 74, the second executive at the company to commit suicide, was one of the managers at Sogo sued by the current management for mismanaging the company, leading it into bankruptcy in July with $17 billion in debts, one of Japan's biggest corporate failures. Sogo sought protection from creditors when public pressure forced the government to cancel a debt relief plan for Sogo that would have used taxpayer money. Miki Tanikawa

title: Elevating the Kinks to a Losers Pantheon
description: A question hung in the air on Thursday at Westbeth Theater: Could Joe McGinty take the Losers out of the Lounge? On the second of four sold-out nights in new digs, the Losers Lounge concert series was in the midst of a transformation.

title: METROMEDIA IN DEAL FOR SITESMITH
description: Signaling the growing sophistication of services provided by fiber optic companies, Metromedia Fiber Network agreed to acquire SiteSmith, a supplier of hardware and software for Web sites, for about $1.36 billion in stock. With the acquisition, Metromedia, a provider of fiber optic services based in White Plains, will supply customers with a range of services including unmetered fixed-cost broadband capacity and corporate Internet operations management. SiteSmith shareholders will receive 55 million to 62.5 million Metromedia shares as a result of the transaction. Metromedia's shares fell $2.19, or 10 percent, to $19.63. Simon Romero

title: Turning Tables, Gore Camp Raises Truth Issue
description: Faced with a Republican assault on Vice President Al Gore's truthfulness and credibility, the Gore campaign has mounted a counterattack, accusing Gov. George W. Bush and his running mate, Dick Cheney, of being the ones with credibility problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, WALTER F.
description: DAVIDSON-Walter F. Died September 22nd. A native of Hinsdale, Illinois, he is survived by two sisters Margery Rucker and Gail Bazzarre who both live in Virginia. A private family memorial will be held at a future date.

title: Japan Makes First Arrests for Nuke Accident
description: TOKYO, Oct. 11 -- Police on Wednesday arrested six former executives and employees of JCO Co, the company at the center of Japan's worst nuclear accident.

title: Voters All Tepid and Bothered About Candidates
description: Joan Rovy, 75, a retired secretary here, usually votes for Democrats. But she said she just could not commit herself to Vice President Al Gore.

title: The Magic Touch
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Market Place: Decline and Fall of Tech Stocks
description: The Nasdaq stock market, enduring its most persistent selling pressure in more than six years, has now returned to the lows of six months ago, when panic briefly gripped investors. This time the fall has been a bit less abrupt, but it has been even more relentless as one technology company after another has warned investors that growth is slowing.

title: Political Memo; Time Is on Clinton's Side on Budget
description: President Clinton did not seem to be conducting budget negotiations today as he traipsed through Pennsylvania raising campaign money for House Democrats.

title: Lonely People Aren't Nice; Just Ask One
description: Playing a less than merry widow in ''The Beginning of August,'' the somber screwball comedy by Tom Donaghy now at the Atlantic Theater Company, Mary Steenburgen has that grown-up waif look that makes sane people run for cover. She's Little Orphan Annie with cleavage, a manicure and an aggressive air of neediness. The words ''dangerously vulnerable'' come to mind, as long as it's understood that the danger in this instance is to others.

title: Antarctic Test Raises Hope On a Global-Warming Gas
description: Bolstering the theory that iron is a vital -- and often missing -- link binding the atmosphere, oceans and climate, scientists have found that dispersing small amounts of the metal in biologically barren seas near Antarctica produces large blooms of tiny plants that pull an important greenhouse gas, carbon dioxide, out of the air.

title: Article 2000101290116723612 -- No Title
description: Technology stocks are now guilty until proven innocent.

title: Packing Material Takes a Back Seat
description: Pressed polypropylene foam, the humble packing material used to protect products in shipping, has been innovatively adapted to furniture by the London designer Ross Lovegrove. The lightweight and stackable Air One lounge chair ($530), below, and Air Two stool ($115 each), left, were manufactured in Italy by Edra, a company known for its innovative use of transparent plastic and coated metallic paper for upholstery.

title: Hands That Hold Memory and Knowledge
description: From the 15th century through the 17th century, scholars often used the human hand as a symbol and a tool for explaining the mind, anatomy, religion and science. ''Writing on Hands: Memory and Knowledge in Early Modern Europe,'' an exhibition at the Trout Gallery at Dickinson College in Carlisle, Pa., through Nov. 25, offers several illustrations at www.writingonhands.org. The Web site images, some with animation or sound, depict hands used to show astrological signs, to teach a sign language for counting large numbers and to teach music theory. The exhibition will be at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington from Dec. 13 to March 4. SHELLY FREIERMAN

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; Israel Needs an Ally
description: ''Jerusalem is mentioned over 500 times in the Bible,'' said Ariel Sharon, at breakfast in New York a couple of weeks ago. ''It belongs to the world's Jews, and we in Israel are its custodians. Now, for the first time in thousands of years, a leader of Israel is willing to give up sovereignty in Jerusalem.''

title: Article 2000101292149289593 -- No Title
description: Cutting The Web Down to Size

title: On Strike, Actor Shows Her Activist Side
description: SOME actresses can cry prettily, at least on camera, cry so that their noses do not run or their eyes turn red, but Marge Royce, an organizer for the long-running actors' strike against the advertising industry, cannot do this. The nose is not too bad but the eyes turn bright red within moments of hitting an emotional hot spot.

title: CLINTON TO SCRAP BELGRADE EMBARGO ON OIL AND TRAVEL
description: President Clinton is to announce on Thursday that he is lifting many of the trade and economic sanctions against Yugoslavia that were intended to speed the fall of Slobodan Milosevic, immediately ending the ban on American flights and an embargo on oil to the country, senior administration officials said.

title: Dog Attacks Two Children
description: Two toddlers were attacked by a dog outside the Loving Arms Day Care Center at 156-04 113th Avenue in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday.

title: Rivals Massage Their Images In Conversational Exchange
description: For Vice President Al Gore, the second presidential debate was basically an act of contrition, a sustained and sometimes lightly self-mocking acknowledgment of where he had gone wrong the first time around.

title: Urbanfetch Says It Will Close Down Online Delivery Service
description: Urbanfetch, the online delivery service that came to New York less than a year ago to compete with Kozmo.com, announced plans today to shut down its Web site and operate as a business courier company.

title: Moving Beyond Online Billboards
description: IN the last couple of years, moviegoers have become accustomed to seeing Web site addresses tacked to anything advertising a film, from the movie trailer itself to posters on the sides of city buses. As Hollywood and the Web begin to overlap, each increasingly cranking out technology-driven entertainment, perhaps it is not surprising that Web sites first created to promote new films are now being designed to reinterpret them.

title: Strike Shuts Many Los Angeles Agencies
description: Couples needing marriage licenses, parents needing birth certificates and homeowners needing a deed recorded were all out of luck today in Los Angeles County as more than 42,000 county employees -- mostly clerical and service workers -- began a general strike at dawn in jails, libraries, beaches, health clinics and other departments in a dispute about wages and a new contract.

title: The Pop-Up Book Picks Up Magical Dimensions
description: IMAGINE a book coming to life as you read it: a samurai warrior from a children's tale suddenly leaping up from the page, or satellite data on air moisture in a manual suddenly assembling itself into clouds that float above the text, or an architect's drawing of a cathedral springing from the paper as a foot-high image, shimmering and resplendent from any angle.

title: Suspect Admits Attacking Immigrants, the Police Say
description: A teenager covered with 18 tattoos, including swastikas and white supremacist symbols, has confessed that he left his Queens home before 5 on a Sunday morning and traveled 50 miles to a Long Island town to attack two day laborers because they were Mexican, the police said today.

title: The Mideast Violence Strikes a Raw Nerve
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Abortion Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: FRANCE TELECOM CONFIRMS TALKS
description: France Telecom confirmed that it was talking with Equant, which operates one of the largest data communication networks, about ''a possible transaction.'' But the French company said it did not expect a deal under the current market conditions. Over the last year, Equant has discussed mergers with many partners, including Global Crossing and Infonet. This is the second time it has held talks with France Telecom. Disagreements over the value of the 34 percent of Equant owned by SITA, a consortium of major airlines, as well as SITA's demand for cash, have proved obstacles to any deal, people close to the discussions said. Suzanne Kapner

title: Write 100 Times: Give Homework
description: To the Editor:

title: Professors Find Bush Outscores Gore in Round 2
description: Historically, first debates between presidential contenders have been more important than those that followed. In other words, first impressions have been difficult to modify.

title: Murray Hill Story: What's Worth Keeping?
description: BACK in the late 1960's, when Kenneth Jay Lane, the jewelry designer, saw the narrow green town house in Murray Hill, he bought it for the same reason many of his neighbors had bought theirs: it was in an area close to Midtown where doctors, lawyers and advertising executives were not only living, but working.

title: The Watch That Roars: Pilots Can Strap On Some Life Insurance
description: Here's the latest accessory for the licensed pilot: a watch that doubles as a rescue beacon. The watch, the Breitling Emergency, looks like an ordinary wristwatch (that is, it looks like an ordinary wristwatch that costs several thousand dollars). But in addition to telling time, it includes a tiny transmit-ter and two antennas that can broadcast a signal to search-and-rescue crews trying to locate a downed pilot.

title: The Mideast Violence Strikes a Raw Nerve
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the death of Daniel Newman, whose car collided with an unmarked police car on Broadway in Staten Island, gave an incorrect cause from the police for the accident. The cause is still under investigation, but the police now say their car did not run a stop sign.

title: Gemstar Plans Major Push of Its Format for Electronic Books
description: Henry Yuen, chairman of Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc., will outline today the details of his bid to make his company's technology the dominant format for electronic publishing. The goal is to become the central distributor, bookstore and bookshelf for anyone who reads electronic books, but the scale of his ambitions has already stirred some anxieties about his potential power in the fledgling market.

title: Gunmen Hold Two in Bank Robbery Attempt
description: Three gunmen wearing ski masks waited in a dark parking garage underneath a building here this morning, ambushed two workers and tried to force their way into a bank office on the first floor, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARSONS, MARSELIS C., JR.
description: PARSONS-Marselis C., Jr. Of Lyme, NH. Died Friday, September 22, 2000. A memorial service will be held 1 PM, Monday, October 16, at Christ Church, Rye, NY. A longer notice will appear Sunday, October 15.

title: Hate-Crime Charges Filed In Vandalism of Synagogue
description: Bronx prosecutors filed hate-crime charges against three young men yesterday in connection with the vandalism of a Riverdale synagogue on Sunday. The suspects are believed to be the first charged under the state's new bias-crimes act, which took effect Sunday and provides for stronger penalties.

title: Transcript of Tyler Kepners Visit to the Mets Forum
description: Tyler Kepner, who covers the Mets for The Times, visited the forum on Thursday, Oct. 12, to discuss the team and answer questions. Here is a transcript of the event:

title: In America, New Names Face an Uphill Struggle
description: NEW YORK  You're a young creative American fashion designer and you want to make your name. Should your first move be to catch a plane to Europe?

title: Nobel Winner Laments Poverty of Russian Science
description: One day after becoming the first Russian since 1978 to win a Nobel Prize for science, Zhores Ivanovich Alferov bitterly charged the Kremlin today in a speech before Parliament with failing to spend enough money on basic scientific research.

title: On Park Avenue, Another Trophy Changes Hands
description: A pair of German developers has won the bidding war for the Seagram Building, the latest in a series of trophy properties changing hands in a frenzied Manhattan real estate marketplace.

title: Americans Keep It Interesting
description: The United States played to a scoreless tie against Costa Rica in a frantic World Cup qualifying game here tonight and now might need a victory in Barbados next month in the last game of the group to advance to the regional final.

title: The Pop-Up Book Picks Up Magical Dimensions
description: IMAGINE a book coming to life as you read it: a samurai warrior from a children's tale suddenly leaping up from the page, or satellite data on air moisture in a manual suddenly assembling itself into clouds that float above the text, or an architect's drawing of a cathedral springing from the paper as a foot-high image, shimmering and resplendent from any angle.

title: A Tough Cow to Follow
description: Last year, 324 decorated fiberglass cows brought $250 million in tourism to Chicago, said Michael Lash, a director in the city's Cultural Affairs Department. Next summer comes Suite Home Chicago, with artists' conceptions of fiberglass sofas, chairs with ottomans, and television consoles, right -- all boxy, so water will run off, and reinforced with steel, because people will sit on them. ''The furniture is 1950's Moderne that recalled people's memories,'' said Nathan Mason, a curator of special projects. Sponsors pay $4,000 (a television) to $10,000 (a suite). Information, (312) 742-5595. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Discovery Thunders Into Orbit on 100th Shuttle Mission
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- Space shuttle Discovery thundered into orbit Wednesday evening on NASA's 100th shuttle flight, carrying seven astronauts on a crucial construction trip to the international space station.

title: Cilcain Journal; Farmer Who Sowed Wind That Rattled Britain
description: The rolling Clwydian Hills present a serene landscape of sheep pastures, signposts in the consonant-thick Welsh language and hamlets of stone cottages with smoke curling idly from chimney tops. It's hardly the place you would expect to find the leader of a popular uprising that brought an entire country to a halt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNOFSKY, MORRIS
description: CHERNOFSKY-Morris, age 78. Died yesterday. Loved husband of Helen. Adored father of Irving and Molly, and Scott and Diana. Cherished grandfather of Melissa, Sheryl, Lianne, Corey and Elliot. Beloved brother of Hyman and William. Loving brother-in-law of Rita and Herb Stavisky. Services are today at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows.

title: Back in Town With a Voice Both Polished And Profound
description: Every interpretive singer must decide how to balance the desire to sound beautiful with the quest for dramatic truthfulness, and in this age of mass cosmetic surgery a glossy vocal finish increasingly cancels out the divulging of an inner life. Yet a few singers still know how to balance that equation. And in her first New York nightclub appearance in 35 years, Polly Bergen is a triumphant example of a singer having her cake and eating it, too. Ms. Bergen's opening night show on Tuesday at Feinstein's at the Regency, where she is appearing through Oct. 21, was, in a word, great.

title: The 'Makeup' Debate
description: Like two students dutifully taking a makeup exam, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush tried earnestly and politely last night in their second debate to make a better impression on Americans than they did the first time. Their goals were obvious. Mr. Bush wanted to look smarter, and Mr. Gore, chastened by criticism over the last week, wanted to be less off-putting. Both succeeded, but at first blush the Texan may have gained more from the kinder, gentler atmosphere. Mr. Bush thrived in the low-intensity environment, appearing markedly more confident and sure-footed than he had in the past. But Mr. Gore could get a payoff in the days ahead. He had clearly made a bet that by abandoning his bullying tactics of the first debate, he might gain in the long run with voters inclined toward him on issues but troubled by his officious manner.

title: 2nd Presidential Debate Between Gov. Bush and Vice President Gore
description: Following is a transcript of the presidential debate last night in Winston-Salem, N.C., between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, as recorded by The New York Times. The moderator was Jim Lehrer of PBS.

title: Palestinians Kill 2 Israeli Soldiers in Police Custody
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Oct. 12 -- Youths stormed a Palestinian police station in the West Bank on Thursday and killed two Israeli soldiers who were in custody, police sources and witnesses said.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Turf Marks Gone, Battle Erupts on Brooklyn Bridge
description: For three months, Susan Boyle said, people have been calling her bicycling and walking group about the chaos on the Brooklyn Bridge. Cyclists complain that pedestrians are freely wandering into their half of the wood-slatted walkway and yelling or even slugging them.

title: Mrs. Clinton, in Ad, Faults Lazio for Missed Votes
description: If it was good enough for Alfonse M. D'Amato when he ran for re-election to the Senate in 1998, then it is good enough for Hillary Rodham Clinton as she runs for the Senate in 2000.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the acquittal of Chief Justice David Brock of the New Hampshire Supreme Court on impeachment charges misstated the length of a court term. Justices must retire at 70; they do not serve for life.

title: Salesgirls Set Tokyo's Trends
description: TOKYO  There was a time when the Tokyo girl took her fashion cues from Naomi Campbell and Elle MacPherson, when she was willing to dole out 800,000 yen for an Hermes bag because Jane Birkin had one just like it.

title: Jil Sander Chief Contests Article
description: Editors' Note: The letter below from Patrizio Bertelli, chairman of the managing board of Jil Sander AG, refers to an article that appeared in the International Herald Tribune on Oct. 5, 2000. His reply is published in accordance with the French law of July 29, 1881.

title: Stottlemyre News Good, According to His Wife
description: Jean Stottlemyre, the wife of the Yankees pitching coach Mel Stottlemyre, threw out the ceremonial first pitch before yesterday's game.

title: Clinton Expected to Allow Cuba Food Sales
description: Despite his previous reservations, President Clinton is now expected to sign a bill that would permit the sale of food to Cuba, the most significant rollback of United States sanctions to the island in four decades, White House officials said today.

title: U.S. Agents Raid Tax People Offices
description: Federal agents armed with search warrants yesterday raided the Topeka, Kan., headquarters of the Tax People, a company that has been selling tax-avoidance techniques to middle-class Americans.

title: Testaverde Contends He Feels No Pain
description: Jets quarterback Vinny Testaverde said today that he no longer had pain in his neck, that the numbness in his left arm and hand caused by a pinched nerve had improved and that he hoped to start Sunday against the New England Patriots.

title: WRINKLE IN BANESPA SALE
description: A new Brazilian court injunction threatens to delay the Nov. 20 sale of the Sao Paulo state bank Banespa, one of the biggest privatizations in Brazil's financial industry. The federal attorney general's office has appealed the decision, handed down by the Sao Paulo Regional Federal Tribunal, to reinstate an old injunction brought by a bank employees union blocking the sale of the bank. If the appeal fails, the government must take the case to the Supreme Federal Tribunal, which recently overturned two previous injunctions brought by the bank employees union. The latest injunction comes just a week after the Brazilian government set a minimum price of $1 billion for the bank. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Bordick Not Sure In Game 2
description: The Mets had just clubbed two homers off Mike James in an ugly ninth inning tonight when Mike Bordick sauntered to the plate. The setting was too blatant for a reliever to throw at a batter. It would look too obvious. It would look as if it were retaliation for the homers. James hit Bordick anyway.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro dropped as confidence in the American economy eased concern that stock losses could lead foreign investors to pull money out. In New York, the euro settled at 86.88 cents, down from 87.16 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NOLAN, FRANK A.
description: NOLAN-Frank A. In loving memory of our beloved father, grandfather, and great-grandfather on 0ctober 12th., his 100th birthday

title: Daughter of Drabware
description: Now there is no reason to cry over broken Drabware. The stark khaki Wedgwood pattern was inexplicably discontinued a few years ago, and was nearly impossible to replace. But Martha Stewart, who uses Drabware in her own home, has introduced tableware, above, that is a dead ringer for the original, in a color she calls ''scone'' and at a fraction of the price. A set of four dinner plates is $12.99, four salad plates are $9.99. A mug, coffee cup or cereal bowl is $2.49, the water pitcher is $12.99 and the salt and pepper set is $4.99. Also in eight other colors. At Kmart, (800) 866-0086, or through www.bluelight.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Death in the Internet Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, UDITH
description: ROSENTHAL - Udith. 1919 - 1992. Your warmth, gentleness, and love of life is always with us. Your family and friends

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEEDLEMAN, MAX, MD.
description: NEEDLEMAN-Max, MD. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the physicians and staff in the Department of Psychiatry in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our dear friend and beloved colleague, Max Needleman, M.D. Beginning with his residency in 1935, Dr. Needleman served with great distinction as a member of our medical staff for more than 55 years, including tenure as Director of Psychiatry. He established the hospital's first psychiatric inpatient unit and will forever be remembered as an outstanding clinician and teacher. He also was a longtime member of the Beth Israel Medical Board and the Doctors Alumni Association, and was a recipient of the Alumnus of the Year Award. In recognition of his outstanding career, the Psychiatry Department established in 1984 the Max Needleman, M.D. Award for teaching excellence. To his son, Dr. Jack Needleman, his family and friends, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew E. Fink, MD, President and CEO Henry S. Singman, MD, President, Medical Board Arnold Winston, MD Chairman, Dept. of Psychiatry Robert L. Salant, MD, President, Doctors Alumni Assoc.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Public Lives page on Tuesday about a party held in a West Village loft for Vice President Al Gore and his family referred incorrectly in some copies to Fran Lebowitz, a guest. She is a writer, not a photographer.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Vice President Al Gore's debate preparation misstated the day on which his aides showed him a tape of a ''Saturday Night Live'' parody of his first debate with Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. It was Monday, not Tuesday.

title: After Worst of Times, Building for the Best
description: THE old warehouse on Auburn Avenue was long an eyesore, and Alton Evans, 40, can remember when it was worse. Just a few years ago, he said, the building sat gutted, a haven for transients and drug dealers. That was the mid-1990's in the central city neighborhood known as the Old Fourth Ward, and anything could happen. In those days, residents say, the area resembled the Wild Wild West.

title: Tensions Ease in a Blur of Runs
description: The tension in the dugout was at high tide again, and Yankees Manager Joe Torre tried a small joke. ''Are you guys trying?'' he asked Derek Jeter after the Yankees' streak of scoreless innings reached 20 yesterday.

title: Henderson Out of Lineup
description: Seattle left fielder Rickey Henderson was out of the lineup yesterday after bruising his ankle running the bases in Game 1. But Lou Piniella, the Seattle manager, said Henderson was available to play in yesterday's game, and he would be available in the games to come. Buster Olney

title: DEFAULT BY CHINESE TRUST
description: China's Hainan International Trust and Investment Company has defaulted on a bond issue for 14 billion Japanese yen, or about $130 million, after a 14-day grace period lapsed on a missed payment. The default is the latest of a string of financial scandals to rock Hainan Island, China's southernmost province and the country's fifth special economic zone. Japanese government officials are expected to raise the issue of China's investment environment with Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji when he visits Tokyo. It is unclear whether Japanese holders of the bonds will take legal action against the Hainan trust. Craig S. Smith

title: AUSTRIAN UTILITY WANTS TO EXPAND
description: An eastern Austrian utility, EVN A.G., and its partners said they were making a bid of more than 6 billion schillings ($381 million) for a 25 percent stake in Energie A.G. Oberoesterreich to expand in northern Austria. EVN; WienStrom, the electricity unit of Wiener Stadtwerke A.G.; and ESG Linz said they also wanted Energie A.G. to join their Energie Allianz cooperative. EVN fell 0.05 euro, to close at 31.9 euros. The power distributor is the worst performer on Austria's ATX Index so far this year, having fallen 37 percent.

title: CALENDAR
description: Textiles by Women

title: Speed Plus Suppleness and Intricacy
description: Dayton Contemporary Dance Company from Ohio has returned to the Joyce Theater, its first season here since Jeraldyne Blunden, the troupe's founder and artistic director, died nearly a year ago.

title: China's No. 2 Oil Company Prepares to Go Public
description: Compared with the firestorm that engulfed the stock offering of PetroChina last April, the impending sale of shares in China's second-largest oil company, Sinopec, has generated barely any smoke.

title: Exchanging Obesity's Risks for Surgery's
description: At a support-group meeting in June at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, Lori Silverman proudly announced that in the last seven months she had lost 106 pounds. Ms. Silverman, 42, who used to weigh 306 and hopes to reach 120, won a round of applause.

title: Democratic New Spending vs. Republican Tax Reductions
description: The Republican National Committee released two new commercials this week attacking Vice President Al Gore for proposing a budget that it asserted would turn projected surpluses into deficits and endanger the nation's prosperity.

title: New York Times Puts Digital Unit Offering on Hold
description: By NYTIMES.COM STAFF By NYTIMES.COM STAFF

title: News Analysis: A Delicate Dance of the Interventionist and the Reluctant Internationalist
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  For the better part of a year now, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush have gingerly stepped around much detailed discussion of how America should exercise its unchallenged economic, diplomatic and military strength and harness its power around the world.

title: Miami Is Heaven for Vintage Fashion
description: MIAMI  Like the ritzy resort towns Las Vegas and Monte Carlo, Miami is in a fashion timewarp. Autumn-winter may decree a return to the '80s but in Miami they never went away. Cruise the strip on Ocean Drive, where Miami's patron saint Gianni Versace lived and died, to see leopard print teeny bikinis, diamonds for daytime and major maquillage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, HILLEL
description: LIEBERMAN-Hillel. We mourn the tragic death of Hillel Lieberman, modest in all ways, but in his love of Eretz Yisrael and his faith in Hashem. We extend our love to his wife Yael and seven children, Rabbi Zvulun and Bracha Lieberman and sisters Tehila and Elyorah. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judge Paul and Lea Lieberman David, Meira & Arielle Lieberman Dr. Jeffrey, Alyse, Jason and Samantha Lieberman Rochelle, Mark, Daniel and Julia Brandsdorfer

title: Senate Passes Bill on Terror Victims' Lawsuits
description: The Senate enacted legislation today that would allow victims of terrorism to collect court-awarded damages from countries that sponsor terrorist activity. The bill, passed overwhelmingly by the House last week, goes to the president who is expected to sign it into law.

title: Agency Plans to Study Drug Makers' Records to See Whether Deals Delay Generics
description: The Federal Trade Commission announced plans today to subpoena records from 90 pharmaceutical companies to see whether drug industry strategies were keeping lower-cost generic drugs from patients or harming consumers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURLING, BARBARA CROLL
description: BURLING-Barbara Croll. 79, of Rumson, NJ, and East Orleans, MA, survived by five children, four grandchildren, a brother, and six nephews. Service Thursday October 12, 2000 at 2 P.M. at First Presbyterian Church of Rumson.

title: Restaurants Expansion
description: By Bloomberg News

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EATON VANCE CORP., Boston, which creates, markets and manages mutual funds, said it would split its stock two for one on Nov. 13 to shareholders of record on Oct. 31 and raise its dividend 26 percent this quarter.

title: Melting-Pot Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: AOL-Time Warner Merger Is Cleared by Europeans
description: The European Commission officially gave a green light today to Time Warner's $165 billion merger with America Online, but the companies face bigger objections from antitrust regulators in Washington.

title: Article 2000101294015367812 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: CHINA FORGIVES SOME AFRICAN DEBT
description: China promised that it would cancel as much as $1.2 billion in debt to African countries, though it did not say which countries would benefit. China's trade minister, Shi Guangsheng, told a forum in Beijing on China-Africa cooperation that the offer would be made to heavily indebted poor countries and the least-developed countries. The offer represents a fraction of the money African states owe China. Craig S. Smith

title: Article 2000101294127024898 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Talented and Enterprising Young Stylists Do Their Own Thing : Greek Designers Rewrite the Classics
description: ATHENS  Young designers are proving that Greece is bursting with the right ingredients to make high-quality fashion.

title: 4th-Grade Test Scores Improve In New York Private Schools
description: Students in New York City's private schools improved their scores sharply this year on the state's more rigorous fourth-grade reading and writing test, with 52 percent passing, compared with 43 percent last year, education officials said yesterday.

title: Donald Dewar, Scottish Leader, Dies at 63
description: Donald Dewar, a lifelong Labor politician whose devotion to greater power for Scotland was rewarded in 1999 when he became first minister of the first Scottish Parliament in almost 300 years, died of a brain hemorrhage today at a hospital in Edinburgh, aides said. He was 63.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWE, JEANETTE MARMOTT
description: LOWE-Jeanette Marmott. With heavy hearts and profound sadness we mourn the loss of Jeanette Marmott Lowe (Beauty), October 8, 2000. Precious mother of Gail Lowe Maidman (Richard), devoted grandmother of Starr Elizabeth Haymes and Evan Adam Haymes, sister of Edith Bloch, Perry Zitter, and the late Ernest Marmott, daughter of the late Louis George and Esther (Blumenthal) Marmott. We will miss our Beauty and the tender, loving, kindness she showed us. Shiva at Gail's home today, October 12, 11AM to 1PM and 4PM to 7PM. Concluding Friday 11AM to 4 PM. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Oil Workers in Venezuela Walk Off Jobs
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 11  As tensions mounted between President Hugo Chavez and opposition labor groups, tens of thousands of oil workers went on strike today to demand higher wages.

title: INGERSOLL-RAND UNIT TO SELL SMALL POWER GENERATORS
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company said yesterday that it had formed a unit to sell small power-generation equipment. The company, based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., expects to begin selling the refrigerator-sized power plants next year. The new unit will be based in Portsmouth, N.H., a spokesman said.

title: Dublin: Now Fair And Worldly
description: ALEX WILLIAMS put down his mop and apologized for the mess. ''I had a raging party in here last night,'' he said. Even so, the apartment looked good. A sleek blue sofa and expensive stereo accented the living room. Oak shutters framed wide windows.

title: He's Spelling It His Way
description: Knowing how to spell ''wild boar'' in Italian (cin ghiale) won't help you look up Mark Strausman's new restaurant in an old meat-packing plant. People couldn't pronounce it (''chin-gee-AH-lay''), so he spelled it his own way: Chin ghalle. The menu and the design are eclectic (call it New York brasserie). The massive chandeliers are by Johnson Schwinghammer Lighting Consultants in New York City, top; the logo, above right, was by Jake, an Englishman; and acid-etched steel on the bar is from Belgium, as is the glassware, above. Mr. Strausman finds thick glasses comfortable and sexy. ''Thin glass is elegant and fine and modern,'' he said. ''These glasses are like holding on to the past.'' The glassware is in Mr. Strausman's store, Campagna Home, 29 East 21st Street, from $7.50, to $42.50 for a pitcher. Chinghalle opens Oct. 23 at 50 Gansevoort Street (Washington). It is beside another new restaurant, Macelleria (''butcher shop'' in Italian), which is spelled right. LINDA LEE

title: Market Place: Decline and Fall of Tech Stocks
description: The Nasdaq stock market, enduring its most persistent selling pressure in more than six years, has now returned to the lows of six months ago, when panic briefly gripped investors. This time the fall has been a bit less abrupt, but it has been even more relentless as one technology company after another has warned investors that growth is slowing.

title: Metro Business; E.P.A. Opposes Meadowlands Mall
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency yesterday recommended that a permit be denied to the Mills Corporation of Arlington, Va., to build a retail mall on environmentally sensitive property in the New Jersey Meadowlands.

title: Yugoslav Chief Upset at Some of His Allies
description: President Vojislav Kostunica of Yugoslavia said today that he was having ''almost as much trouble from my friends as from my enemies'' in the transition from the rule of Slobodan Milosevic and that he was concerned that his own authority was being compromised.

title: 2 Americans Win the Nobel For Economics
description: Two Americans won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday for work that has helped to explain complex behavior, like why some working mothers make more than those with fewer children and why one route is favored for a new highway over another.

title: I.B.M.'s Revival in Hudson Valley Gets a Ho-Hum
description: When I.B.M. announced on Tuesday that it would spend $2.5 billion and hire 1,000 new employees to create ''the world's most technologically advanced'' chip factory here, the conventional wisdom, perhaps, was that the news would elate the residents of this Hudson Valley town.

title: Economic Scene; The model doesn't quite fit Medicare drug insurance.
description: ONE of the few things that Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush agree on is that elderly citizens should have government-subsidized prescription drug insurance. The Gore plan is much more generous and gives more details than the Bush plan, but both proposals deviate from the ideal model of economic insurance. The reasons reveal as much about politics as they do about economics.

title: Rebuilding Yugoslavia
description: Forcing Slobodan Milosevic to acknowledge defeat and resign Yugoslavia's presidency was only the first step in what will be a long and difficult process of undoing the damage of 13 years of war and dictatorship. The new President, Vojislav Kostunica, will have to dismantle still dangerous elements of the Milosevic political machine and security apparatus even as he vies with more radical elements of his own coalition impatient with his commitment to constitutional change.

title: Lazio Tax Cut Is Better for State, Conservative Group Says
description: A new study asserts that Hillary Rodham Clinton's tax cut plan would be less beneficial for New Yorkers than the one proposed by Representative Rick A. Lazio, because hers relies more on giving reductions to people who make certain expenditures and have incomes below specific ceilings.

title: Digital Meets Chemical
description: NO matter how cool you might think your digital camera is, or how impressed you are by its capacity to draw upon millions of pixels to render stunning images, there always seems to be one in every crowd of potential admirers of the technology who wants nothing less than magic from your camera.

title: Philippines V.P. Quits Cabinet as Scandal Against President Grows
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 12  The vice president of the Philippines resigned today from her cabinet post as pressure mounted for President Joseph Estrada to step down in a growing bribery scandal.

title: Promising Start for Hampton and the Mets
description: Mike Hampton made these the first words of his postgame news conference tonight: ''It wasn't pretty.'' His manager, Bobby Valentine, opened with these: ''His performance was fabulous.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Einstein the Ladies' Man And His Scientific Wife
description: EINSTEIN IN LOVEA Scientific RomanceBy Dennis Overbye416 pages. Viking. $27.95.

title: Candidates Meet in Restrained Debate
description: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Oct. 11  Seated side by side in their second debate, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush cautiously discussed foreign affairs tonight, largely agreeing on the nation's policies in the Mideast and the Balkans while arguing over military readiness and the intervention in Haiti.

title: The Passions And Fears Of a Fugitive On the Run
description: Saturday evening's concert at Weill Hall, an installment in Carnegie Hall's excellent ''Making Music'' series of encounters with composers, brought to the stage a vast array of percussion instruments and, confined by them to a corner, Hans Werner Henze to talk a little with Ara Guzelimian, the hall's artistic adviser, about his ''Cimarron.'' This is the story in music of a Cuban who escaped from slavery to live in the forest, emerged in 1895 to join the war of independence, and was still alive in 1969 to tell the composer his exploits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIDLER, HAROLD
description: EIDLER-Harold. The employees of Spiegel Associates express their deepest sympathies to Alan Eidler our Chief Executive Officer, his mother Harriet & his sister Bonnie over the loss of his father, Harold Eidler on October 10, 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRELLICH, MARVIN G. M.D.
description: DRELLICH-Marvin G. M.D. The faculty of the Psychoanalytic Institute and The Department of Psychiatry at New York Medical College mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague and share our sadness with his wife Helen and their family. Dr. Drellich was an outstanding teacher, clinician, mentor and friend. Joseph T. English, M.D. Professor and Chairman Myron L. Glucksman, M.D. Director The Psychoanalytic Institute

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRUCH, HARRY
description: SPRUCH-Harry. Our treasured friend and longtime associate passed away on October 9. Everybody in our industry knew and loved ''Big H''. His passing leaves a big void in our midst. Our hearts go out to his beloved Bashie, daughters Susan, Cory, son-in-law Richard & adored granddaughter Felice. The Treitels

title: Boutiques in London Recall Swinging '60s
description: LONDON  Pulsating music, throbbing crowds and endless racks of wear-it-once fashion. Sound familiar? Shoppers take note. If quick-fix high street stores make you dizzy, then allow yourself the pleasure of the boutique experience.

title: Appeals Court in Compromise On Microsoft Case Timetable
description: The United States Court of Appeals announced a schedule today that would bring the two sides in the Microsoft Corporation's antitrust appeal back into the courtroom at the end of February.

title: House Backs Year's Delay In Extra Care For Lab Rats
description: An agreement by the Agriculture Department to bring mice, rats and birds under federal rules for animal care in research would be delayed for at least a year under a bill approved yesterday by the House.

title: Debating Foreign Interventions
description: Governor George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore were given a list of United States military interventions - in the case of Rwanda, a nonintervention - over the last 20 years and asked to say whether or not they approved. Their specific answers did not differ a great deal, but the tone of the discussion did.

title: UBS SELECTS SUCCESSOR
description: The Swiss bank UBS said its chairman, Alex Krauer, would step down next year and be replaced by Marcel Ospel, the chief executive. Mr. Ospel, 50, left, is expected to be approved as chairman at the April board meeting. Mr. Krauer, 69, put his retirement plans on hold to take over the UBS post in a hurry in 1998. He replaced Mathis Cabiallavetta, who, with three other executives, was forced to resign after the bank lost nearly $750 million on global equity derivatives and hedge fund investments. The board will be asked to elect new American, British and Dutch members to reflect UBS's global reach, the bank said. The American candidate is Lawrence A. Weinbach, 60, chairman and chief operating officer of the Unisys Corporation. Elizabeth Olson

title: S.E.C. LOOKS AT PRICEWATERHOUSE AUDIT OF PINNACLE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into whether PricewaterhouseCoopers had a conflict of interest when it audited Pinnacle Holdings Inc., according to an S.E.C. document. The document, an investigative order that is normally kept confidential, said officials at Pricewaterhouse, the world's largest accounting firm, might not have been ''independent in fact or appearance'' in their audit work for Pinnacle. The S.E.C. order, dated Sept. 25, was included in public records at the agency headquarters in Washington. The order said Pinnacle, based in Sarasota, Fla., may have committed fraud, filed untrue annual and other periodic reports and failed to keep its books and maintain a system of internal accounting controls properly. Pinnacle officials could not be reached.

title: Palestinians Kill 2 Israeli Soldiers in Police Custody
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Oct. 12 -- Youths stormed a Palestinian police station in the West Bank on Thursday and stabbed to death two captured Israeli soldiers, Israeli military sources said.

title: Write 100 Times: Give Homework
description: To the Editor:

title: To Many Israelis, a Sad, Familiar Story
description: In the hours after Hezbollah's capture of Sgt. Adi Avitan, 20, and two other Israeli soldiers at the Lebanese border, his mother dialed and redialed his cell phone. She listened, her eyes glistening with tears, to her son's voice on the message tape. Always she left the same response: ''Adi, come home.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEB, POLLY PORTER
description: LIEB-Polly Porter. On October 11, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Harry A. Lieb. Cherished aunt. Services Sunday, October 15, at 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The subject of divorce is becoming more common as another backdrop in campaigns.
description: DIVORCE is the kind of unhappy topic advertisers typically like to avoid.

title: T. J. Maxx Invites 7 Into Review
description: T. J. Maxx in Framingham, Mass., the discount retailer owned by the TJX Companies, has invited seven agencies to participate in a review for its broadcast account. Spending was estimated at $20 million.

title: Continuing Mideast Violence Includes Long Gun Battles at West Bank Settler's Funeral
description: Despite an intensive international effort to defuse the tension here, the violence continued today, and Prime Minister Ehud Barak warned Israelis that renewed terrorism by Islamic militants could follow the rioting and gun battles of the last 13 days.

title: Safeway Recalls Taco Shells After Test Questions Corn Origin
description: The unapproved genetically engineered corn connected with a nationwide recall of taco shells has been found in a second brand of shells as well, a coalition of biotechnology food critics said last night.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Digital Meets Chemical
description: NO matter how cool you might think your digital camera is, or how impressed you are by its capacity to draw upon millions of pixels to render stunning images, there always seems to be one in every crowd of potential admirers of the technology who wants nothing less than magic from your camera.

title: Israeli Military Shells Ramallah After Mob Kills Two Soldiers
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Oct. 12  As the Middle East crisis escalated to the brink of open war, Israeli helicopter gun-ships rocketed Ramallah and Gaza City after a Palestinian mob stabbed and stomped to death two Israeli reserve soldiers at a Palestinian police station and then paraded a mutilated corpse through town.

title: Swedish Computer Team Crack 10 of the Worlds Toughest Codes
description: LONDON, Oct. 12 -- A team of Swedish computer buffs have fought off thousands of rivals from around the world to crack what was billed as the toughest code challenge ever set. It took the Swedes the equivalent of 70 years of computer time to decipher 10 increasingly difficult codes set by author Simon Singh in his international bestseller "The Code Book." They ranged from ciphers dating back to ancient Greece through Victorian codes and the famed Nazi Enigma code machine from World War Two. "It is the toughest code that has ever been cracked," Singh said on Thursday before handing over the first prize cheque for 10,000 pounds ($15,000) to the team headed by Fredrik Almgren. Almgren works on Internet security. He solved the puzzle with software developer Torbjorn Granlund and a trio of computer buffs from the Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm. The challenge had obsessed thousands of codebreakers around the world. They even set up their own website which attracted 2,500 fans from a 14-year-old schoolboy to maths professors. Singh, believing that the ultimate prize was out of their reach, had already given a 1,000-pound prize to two computer buffs who had cracked the first nine codes. But then the Swedes came through with the solution to the final "512 bit" code. Singh, who has a doctorate in physics at Cambridge University, took two years to create the brain teasers with Dr Paul Leyland, who works for Microsoft in Cambridge. They worked in total secrecy. "I regularly went into my little garden, dipped the relevant papers in molten wax and set them alight," Singh told Thursday's Daily Telegraph. Almgren admitted that it was a long, hard grind and the Swedish team were tempted to abandon ship at times. "The first stages were very simple but at one point we thought we wouldn't get any further than stage eight," he told BBC radio. "When you do come to the 10th stage it is a question of heavy mathematics and rather difficult algorithms that I don't even claim to understand myself." The cipher the team finally cracked is similar to the on-line security used by Internet banking and shopping outlets. But Singh argued that this did not mean Internet security had been compromised. "It is the sort of thing that some people do use on the Internet for Internet security," Singh said. "That doesn't necessarily mean that Internet security is invalid because it took a year for a team of Swedes to crack this with some very sophisticated computers."

title: U.S. CHECKS POSSIBLE ILLEGAL TRADING OF BRISTOL-MYERS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether shares of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company were traded illegally on the basis of advance knowledge of unfavorable test results on the Vanlev blood pressure drug. On Nov. 8, 1999, Bristol-Myers presented research to the American Heart Association showing that Vanlev lowered blood pressure better than some top-selling medicines. Since then, according to an S.E.C. order dated Sept. 22, people under investigation may have traded Bristol-Myers shares while making misleading statements about Vanlev. On April 19, the company said it was delaying its application for approval of the drug, citing safety concerns raised by the studies; the shares fell 22 percent. In the previous 12 months, they had risen 13 percent. Bristol-Myers said it was cooperating with the inquiry. The disclosure of the inquiry was inadvertent, the S.E.C. said.

title: DAEWOO REFORM PLAN
description: Creditors of South Korea's ailing Daewoo Motor Company will consider making additional loans to the carmaker after receiving the company's self-rescue plans, Korea Development Bank said. The automaker has said it needs an additional 450 billion won ($402.1 million) by the end of this year to stay in business. The state-run bank and four other creditor banks provided Daewoo Motor with 100 billion won ($89.4 million) earlier this week as part of a previously agreed financing package. While Daewoo Motor said it would submit a rescue plan soon, 135 executives at the carmaker resigned in a gesture to aid the company's restructuring. Daewoo was placed under a debt workout program in August 1999. Samuel Len

title: The Return of a Modern Master
description: AS is true for only a handful of 20th-century designers, the hallmark style of Jean-Michel Frank -- his elegance of form, spare geometries and exquisite proportions combined with luxurious materials -- renders his work timeless. Perhaps it was Christie's sale of Frank furniture in May -- or last month's Paris Biennale, with its display of a 1935 room, complete with quilted leather walls, which Frank designed for the Guerlain family -- but Frankmania is in the air again. Robert Couturier, a New York decorator, is one of many who feel an aesthetic debt to the designs of this master, who died in 1941. ''In these days of excessive affluence, it's nice to see luxurious simplicity,'' said Mr. Couturier, who grew up in a Paris apartment decorated with Frank furniture. The designer ''undressed fancy rooms,'' he said, adding, ''He respected the space of a room and never overcrowded it.''

title: MOTOROLA FALLS 19% AFTER EARNINGS WARNING
description: Motorola Inc. shares fell 19 percent yesterday after the company, the No. 2 maker of cell phones, said fourth-quarter and 2001 earnings would lag forecasts as growth in semiconductor sales and cell-phone profit declined. The stock fell $5, or 19 percent, to $21.63, on trading of 72 million shares. The decline cut about $10 billion from the company's market value, which had already fallen $33 billion this year. During the day, the stock fell as low as $20.50, down 22 percent, its largest one-day percentage drop in at least 20 years. The company expects fourth-quarter earnings of 27 cents a share, unchanged from the quarter a year earlier, on sales of $10.5 billion. It had been expected to earn 37 cents a share, First Call/Thomson Financial said.

title: GENENTECH EARNINGS RISE 27%

Genentech said profit from operations rose to $85 million, or 31 cents a share, from $66.9 million, or 26 cents, a year earlier. The results met the average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Sales rose 29 percent, to $445.2 million from $345.3 million. Herceptin, a treatment for breast cancer, had sales of $72.6 million, up 52 percent from $47.9 million a year earlier and 8.8 percent higher than sales in the second quarter. The results were not enough for investors, however; Genentech shares slid $4.31, or 2.8 percent, to $149.

title: Chinese Novelist Wins Nobel Prize for Literature
description: STOCKHOLM, Sweden -- Chinese novelist Gao Xingjian won the Nobel Prize in literature Thursday for his "bitter insights and linguistic ingenuity, which has opened new paths for the Chinese novel and drama." Gao, 60, is a political refugee and playwright whose works have not been performed in China since his work "The Other Shore" was banned in 1986, the Swedish Academy said. He left China a year after and lives in Paris, the citation said. It described him as a novelist, translator, dramatist, director and critic. Gao is the first Chinese writer to receive the prestigious literature prize. The Swedish Academy cited Gao for his writing about the struggle of the individual. "He is a perspicacious skeptic who makes no claim to be able to explain the world. He asserts that he has found freedom only in writing," according to the citation. The prize this year is worth $915,000. Guenter Grass won last year's prize as one of the most prominent authors to emerge from a group of young intellectuals who set out to revive German literature after the Nazi era. The literature award -- usually the first -- was the fifth and last Nobel prize unveiled in Stockholm this week. The Nobel Peace Prize winner will be named Friday in Oslo, Norway. Two Americans won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics on Wednesday for developing theories on how people work and live, contributing greatly to employment training programs and transportation and communication systems. James J. Heckman, 56, of the University of Chicago, and Daniel L. McFadden, 63, of the University of California at Berkeley, were cited for methods of analyzing statistics that have had wide-ranging practical applications, according to the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. The physics prize was shared by American Jack Kilby, 76, who invented the integrated circuit at Texas Instruments in 1958, Herbert Kroemer, 72, of the University of California-Santa Barbara, and Zhores Alferov, 70, of the A.F. Ioffe Physico-Technico Institute in St. Petersburg, Russia. This year's chemistry prize went to Alan Heeger, 64, of the University of California-Santa Barbara, Alan MacDiarmid, 73, of the University of Pennsylvania and Hideki Shirakawa, 64, of the University of Tsukuba in Japan, for their discovery that plastic could be modified to conduct electricity. The medicine prize recognized Arvid Carlsson, 77, a professor emiritus of the University of Goteborg in Sweden, Paul Greengard, 74, of Rockefeller University in New York, and Eric Kandel, 70, an Austrian-born U.S. citizen with Columbia University in New York, for discoveries about how messages are transmitted between brain cells, leading to treatments of Parkinson's disease and depression. The Nobel Prizes are funded by a trust set up in the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, the inventor of dynamite. Nobel said the literature prize should recognize an author whose work moves in an "ideal direction" without specifying exactly what he meant. Swedish King Carl XVI Gustaf will present the prizes as always on Dec. 10, the anniversary of Nobel's death in 1896.

title: CHAIRMAN NAMED AT LASTMINUTE.COM
description: Allan Leighton, a well-respected British retailing executive, is to become nonexecutive chairman of Lastminute.com on Oct. 20. He will replace Pieter Bouw, who will remain a nonexecutive director. As chief executive of Asda Group P.L.C., a British supermarket chain, Mr. Leighton secured its sale to Wal-Mart last year. He then joined Wal-Mart as chief executive of Wal-Mart Europe, a post he resigned last month. Shares of Lastminute.com, which has struggled along with other consumer-oriented Internet sites, closed at 131 pence, down 6.6 pence. Suzanne Kapner

title: Cutting The Web Down to Size; New Tools Let You Get the Information You Want (as Long as Your Computer Doesn't Crash)
description: THE average Web surfer opens the Netscape or Internet Explorer browser, punches in a Web address, comes to a Web page, then clicks from page to page. When lost, the person tries to maneuver through an array of bookmarks or, more often than not, resorts to the Back button.

title: Biala, 97, Whose Paintings Were Cryptic and Luscious
description: Janice Brustlein, whose painting career, pursued under the name Biala, spanned two art capitals and several generations, died on Sept. 24 at her home in Paris. She was 97 and had lived in Paris since 1958.

title: In Relentless Steps, Nasdaq Slides Back Near Low of Year
description: The Nasdaq stock market continued its plunge and has now returned to the lows of six months ago, when panic briefly gripped investors. This time the fall has been a bit less abrupt, but it has been even more relentless as one technology company after another has warned investors that growth is slowing.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about an Agriculture Department agreement to bring laboratory mice, rats and birds under the care of the Federal Animal Welfare Act misstated the nature of a decision by Judge Ellen S. Huvelle of Federal District Court for the District of Columbia. The judge decided that Johns Hopkins University could not intervene to stop the agreement, thereby allowing it to go forward; she did not rule on the substance of the agreement itself. Later developments are reported today on Page A16.

description: HONG KONG  Hong Kong shoppers have traditionally favored small shops and boutiques, keeping both Main Street retailers and mall tenants busy.

description: WENDY EWALD, 49, a photographer and video artist with the graying, dirty-blond bob and milk-plastic sunglasses of a 1940's movie star, was sitting at a weathered table in a shady corner of the garden behind her cottage in Red Hook, N.Y. She lives there with her husband, Tom McDonough, a writer and cinematographer, and their son, Michael, 4, whom they adopted in Colombia.

title: No Detail About Debate Is Too Minor for Negotiation
description: When it comes to the clash of candidates on national television, no detail, it seems, is too minor for negotiation, no risk too small to eliminate. Not even the seemingly innocuous issue of the precise moment at which the debaters' microphones were to be switched on.
