description: The first public election to select five members to the international board that administers the Internet domain-name system demonstrated distinct similarities to the issues that plague many national political elections: disputes over the campaign process and low voter turnout.

title: Swedish Computer Team Crack 10 of the Worlds Toughest Codes
description: LONDON, Oct. 12 -- A team of Swedish computer buffs have fought off thousands of rivals from around the world to crack what was billed as the toughest code challenge ever set. It took the Swedes the equivalent of 70 years of computer time to decipher 10 increasingly difficult codes set by author Simon Singh in his international bestseller "The Code Book." They ranged from ciphers dating back to ancient Greece through Victorian codes and the famed Nazi Enigma code machine from World War Two. "It is the toughest code that has ever been cracked," Singh said on Thursday before handing over the first prize cheque for 10,000 pounds ($15,000) to the team headed by Fredrik Almgren. Almgren works on Internet security. He solved the puzzle with software developer Torbjorn Granlund and a trio of computer buffs from the Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm. The challenge had obsessed thousands of codebreakers around the world. They even set up their own website which attracted 2,500 fans from a 14-year-old schoolboy to maths professors. Singh, believing that the ultimate prize was out of their reach, had already given a 1,000-pound prize to two computer buffs who had cracked the first nine codes. But then the Swedes came through with the solution to the final "512 bit" code. Singh, who has a doctorate in physics at Cambridge University, took two years to create the brain teasers with Dr Paul Leyland, who works for Microsoft in Cambridge. They worked in total secrecy. "I regularly went into my little garden, dipped the relevant papers in molten wax and set them alight," Singh told Thursday's Daily Telegraph. Almgren admitted that it was a long, hard grind and the Swedish team were tempted to abandon ship at times. "The first stages were very simple but at one point we thought we wouldn't get any further than stage eight," he told BBC radio. "When you do come to the 10th stage it is a question of heavy mathematics and rather difficult algorithms that I don't even claim to understand myself." The cipher the team finally cracked is similar to the on-line security used by Internet banking and shopping outlets. But Singh argued that this did not mean Internet security had been compromised. "It is the sort of thing that some people do use on the Internet for Internet security," Singh said. "That doesn't necessarily mean that Internet security is invalid because it took a year for a team of Swedes to crack this with some very sophisticated computers."

I wish I could say that the quarrels the neighbors overhear are confined to such trivial issues as what color Jell-O to use in the human-brain mold or whose turn it is to wear the light-up werewolf fangs.

description: David Dukes, a veteran television, film and stage actor who won critical acclaim for his performance as a homosexual persecuted by the Nazis in the Broadway production of ''Bent,'' died on Monday in Spanaway, Wash., near Tacoma. He was 55 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Pure, Simple Fun. Cynics, Beware.
description: ANY adult who has ever been transfixed by the comic whirl of Sesame Street knows that some of the world's best entertainment is made for children. In the world of games, you can find that same sort of bright, cynicism-free joy in Humongous Entertainment's Pajama Sam 3: You Are What You Eat From Your Head to Your Feet, an adventure game aimed at children ages 3 to 8 that can entertain just about anybody.

title: Technology Briefing
description: E-COMMERCE BET.COM TO BUY 360HIPHOP.COM The Internet media company BET.com completed an agreement to buy 360HipHop.com from the rap impresario Russell Simmons in an equity deal, increasing consolidation in Internet media. Terms were not disclosed. Black Entertainment Television 's BET Holdings II controls BET.com. Microsoft, USA Networks and the News Corporation also own stakes. 360HipHop.com will get access to traditional media channels like Black Entertainment Television's cable network, which reaches 60 million households. BET.com will get more urban and black content and the star power of Mr. Simmons, above, founder of the Def Jam record label.

description: Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore agreed more than they disagreed last night in an event that was often closer to a cordial conversation than a debate as they exchanged views on tense foreign conflicts and domestic matters like racial profiling, gun control and same-sex marriage.

title: 5 U.S. Sailors Killed in Yemen After Explosion Near Warship
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  An American Navy destroyer refueling in Yemen was rocked by an enormous explosion today in what President Clinton said appeared to be a deliberate act of terrorism. At least five American sailors died and 36 more were injured, some of them severely. Twelve others sailors were reported missing, and officials said the death toll would rise.

title: U.S. Ship in Yemen Damaged By Raft Filled With Bombs
description: DUBAI, Oct. 12 -- An explosive-laden rubber raft slammed into a U.S. Navy destroyer in the Yemeni port of Aden on Thursday and four U.S. sailors were killed and one went missing, a U.S. Navy spokesman said.

title: Mideast Riots Continue
description: Despite an international effort to defuse the tension, violence continued yesterday between Palestinians and Israeli soldiers.

title: Even for Those With All Thumbs, Help With Cell Phone Messaging
description: IF cell phones are to become the mobile communication device of the future, as many experts predict, there is one major hurdle to overcome: the phone keypad was made for entering numbers, not letters. Trying to type a message on a phone is akin to typing on a shrunken keyboard that is missing two-thirds of its characters.

description: George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, said yesterday that he would propose expanding the first round of the baseball playoffs to seven games from five games and scheduling doubleheaders during the regular season to allow time for the longer series.

title: Junk Bond Losses at Morgan Stanley
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company said yesterday that losses from holdings of high-yield bonds in the third and fourth quarters will total about $89.7 million as the company moved to dispel the speculation about bigger write-offs that has recently hammered its shares.

title: Women Who've Been There
description: Some see it as the fastest growing fancy in the trade. Publishers are busy signing up first-person nonfiction books that are not exactly adventure yarns, like tales of mountain climbing, but journalistic accounts of someone unusual doing something unusual. Many of the authors are young women, at a moment when more and more novels of love and emotion are being written by men. Could it be that it's the women who are from Mars, and the men who are from Venus?

description: The Paine Webber Group, which is being bought by the Swiss bank UBS, said yesterday that its earnings fell 1.7 percent in its final quarter as an independent company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMAN, JACK H. JR.
description: LEHMAN-Jack H. Jr., 82. Of Boynton Beach, Florida and Oakhurst, New Jersey. Died peacefully at home on October 10, 2000. Most loving and caring husband of Barbara. Adored father, teacher and friend of Jill L. Feist and Jack H. Lehman III. Wonderful and generous Poppop of Jeffrey and John Feist, Michael, Katherine, Skye and Lexi Lehman. Beloved brother of Babette Newman and most kind & supportive stepfather of Karen Kates. His unique personality affected all who knew him. His guidance, wisdom and courage to the end filled us with pride. We have all been blessed with his love, humor and devotion. Funeral Private. Family will be receiving friends at 222 Park Avenue, Oakhurst, NJ on Thursday, October 12th from 2-4 P.M. and from 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: Hospice (VNA of Central New Jersey), 1100 Wayside Road, Tinton Falls, NJ 07712 or Monmouth Medical Center, Attn: Bridget Murphy, 300 Second Avenue, Long Branch, NJ 07740.

title: Sports of The Times; The Revival of a Red-Tinged Rivalry Stirs Passions in the Midwest
description: ENCOUNTERED by a New Yorker in the lobby of a local hotel, a Cardinals fan was asked if it was true or just hype that people around here don't like New York, and the Mets. ''It's genuine,'' the man said. ''New Yorkers can be very antagonistic. When you meet New Yorkers, you get the impression that they don't think there's any place but New York.''

title: BEST BUY TO SELL AT&T SERVICES
description: Best Buy, the operator of the nation's largest chain of electronics stores, will begin offering AT&T's high-speed Internet and digital cable television services next month. The deal, considered a boost for AT&T's ambitions to offer a variety of broadband communications and entertainment services, is part of a wider trend. RadioShack has similar agreements with Verizon Communications, Sprint and Microsoft, while Best Buy stores already offer Microsoft's MSN Internet service. ''Retail will be important,'' said Doug Seserman of AT&T's broadband division, ''as a source of information that will help us work with consumer electronics manufacturers on innovative products for the future.'' Simon Romero

description: He is in the beat-up county car again, this time driving to dinner. The Nassau County executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, steers to Bryant & Cooper Steakhouse in Roslyn on a recent night. He does not exactly know the way, and some at the restaurant do not exactly seem to know who he is, though he has been county executive for almost 14 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNE, MARC BRUCE
description: HORNE-Marc Bruce, 42 yrs., of Jericho on October 8, 2000. Beloved husband and soulmate of Fran Kiperman-Horne for 7 years. Loving father of Jason, Jennifer, and Christopher. Survived by his adoring mother Zelda; his father Harvey and stepmother Minerva; and by Beth, Sol, Neil, Troy and Amanda Kiperman. His untimely passing has left an incredible void in the lives of all he touched in his personal life and in his career as a detective for the New York State Attorney General's Office, Special Task Force. Services will be held at Gutterman's Thursday, October 12, 10 AM, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. In lieu of flowers/ baskets donations may be made to, American Heart Association.

title: Gao Xingjian Wins the Nobel Prize for Literature
description: LONDON, Oct. 12  The Nobel prize for literature was awarded today to Gao Xingjian, the exiled Chinese writer who is best known for daring plays that combine a modernist sensibility with traditional elements from Chinese drama, and whose work was banned after he wrote a play set against the backdrop of the Tiananmen Square massacre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEELE, KEN
description: STEELE-Ken. The faculty and staff of the New York State Psychiatric Institute mourn the loss of Ken Steele, a devoted friend and advocate of the mentally ill. As a member of our Institutional Review Board and as a guest lecturer, he vigorously represented the patient's perspective to us. Students from all disciplines benefited greatly from his fund of knowledge. We will miss him. John Oldham, M.D. NY State Psychiatric Institute

description: The day felt strangely empty to the Miami Heat players, the game, in the end, a little more meaningless than a typical preseason game.

title: DELPHI AND PALM BACK AUTO PRODUCT
description: Delphi Automotive Systems and Palm Inc. have announced plans to develop MobileAria, a system that will bring voice-activated Internet and phone access to automobiles. The Mayfield Fund, a venture capital company, has also invested in the system. Terms of the three companies' investments in the new system were not disclosed. The hardware for MobileAria, which is expected to be available early next year, includes a docking station that will accommodate Palm hand-held computers and Ericsson cell phones. Voice activation software will let users operate both kinds of devices. The software will also read back Internet and Palm information. John Shea, a spokesman for Delphi, said the company planned to make the system compatible with a range of wireless phones. Catherine Greenman

description: Denny Neagle did not win Game 1 for the Yankees, but he did pitch well enough to give the Yankees a chance to win, and that means he will probably start Game 5.

title: AIR CANADA BUYING AIRBUS JETS
description: Canada's dominant airline, Air Canada, has agreed to buy 14 passenger jets worth an estimated $575 million from the European consortium Airbus Industrie. Robert Milton, president and chief executive of Air Canada, said the dozen 160-seat A321's and two 112-seat A319's are the the first purchase in a renewal program to replace older-generation aircraft like the DC-9 and Boeing 737. Most of the planes will be delivered in 2002. With its takeover of Canadian Airlines earlier this year, Air Canada has 372 aircraft, 98 of them made by Airbus. The airline is expected to spend $3 billion over the next decade to replace about 100 aging jets. Timothy Pritchard

title: Aspen Journal; Ski Resorts Struggle to Lure Workers
description: Here in the crown jewel of Colorado's ski resorts, no one really asks who wants to be a millionaire. Many residents and visitors already are. Far more important questions around town include: Who wants to be a housekeeper? Who wants to be a waiter? And who wants to be a retail clerk?

title: Emigre Composer Confronts Outsider's Pain
description: When P. Q. Phan agreed to write a new work for the American Composers Orchestra, he had every intention of creating a work to celebrate the turn of the millennium, exactly as Dennis Russell Davies, the orchestra's music director, had requested. The piece, ''When the Worlds Mixed and Time Merged,'' was a contribution to Mr. Davies's three-year ''Millennium Snapshots'' series, an exploration of musical responses to some of the historical events and social trends of the 20th century.

title: Arafat Must End Violence In Mideast, Lieberman Says
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman praised Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel today as the Palestinians' best hope for peace and placed the onus for halting Mideast violence squarely on the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat.

title: Former Indian Prime Minister Sentenced to Jail
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 12 -- A special Indian court sentenced former Indian Prime Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao and a cabinet colleague to three years in jail on Thursday after they were convicted last month in a vote-buying case. "I hereby sentence the accused P.V. Narasimha Rao and Buta Singh to rigorous imprisonment up to three years and a fine of 100,000 rupees ($2,150)," special court judge Ajit Barihoke said in his order at the high security courtroom.

title: Outburst of Hits Answers Fans' Pleas
description: With the scoreboard message urging it on, the Yankee Stadium throng chanted: ''We want a hit. We want a hit. We want a hit.'' Except it was not simply a chant. The fans were begging -- begging their heroes to get a hit. The players shared their feeling. The Yankees had not done much hitting against Seattle's sizzling pitching staff in the first two games of the American League Championship Series and were jeopardizing their extended presence in the postseason.

title: Einstein the Ladies Man And His Scientific Wife
description: In the late 1980's, Albert Einstein's personal correspondence, along with much other related material, became available to the public for the first time, at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem. Those accustomed to the iconic figure on innumerable T- shirts were taken aback by what was revealed. For one thing, remarks in Einstein's letters to his first wife, Mileva Maric, seemed to suggest that the theory of relativity was their joint project, although she was not acknowledged in any of his papers. Another surprise was the number of women with whom Einstein was involved. These goings-on were rather widely known at the time but do not fit well with the modern myth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATZKIN, JACK L.

title: Former Prime Minister of India Sentenced in Corruption Case
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 12 - Former prime minister P.V. Narasimha Rao was sentenced today to three years of "rigorous" imprisonment for his role in bribing members of Parliament to vote for his government in a 1993 no-confidence measure.

title: Surf the Palace at Versailles. Donations Accepted.

It housed queens and mistresses, played a large part in the revolution and was the place where two wars officially ended.

On Tuesday, Scandinavia House, a sleek new cultural center and exhibition space by James Stewart Polshek, opens at 58 Park Avenue. And last week, pieces by two young Swedish designers were introduced at ICF, a design showroom. Millibar bar stools, above, made of chrome and transparent polyester fabric in a range of colors, are $950 each. Multiplicity, a lounge chair ($960 in wool) can be linked with others, below, to form a sofa. Both are by Anya Sebton. A chrome serving cart with shelves of leather, glass or laminate by Gunilla Allard (not shown) was inspired by Eileen Gray. ICF is at 920 Broadway (22nd Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Furniture on the Run
description: Young American furniture designers are earning notice for their playful pieces. ''American Contemporary Furniture'' (Universe, $50) offers the first survey of those designers, including Constantin and Laurene Leon Boym (the Strap Chair, above center) and Rodney Allen Trice (the Luggage End Table, above). What they share is a desire to make affordable, fun objects. ''Nobody wants to lug heirloom bureaus around anymore,'' said Cathy Lang Ho, co-author of the book with Marisa Bartolucci.

title: Philippines V.P. Quits Cabinet as Scandal Against President Grows
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 12  The vice president of the Philippines resigned today from her cabinet post as pressure mounted for President Joseph Estrada to step down in a growing bribery scandal.

title: El Duque Still Doing What He Does Best
description: Orlando Hernandez was asked last night through a translator how he planned to celebrate his birthday, and a smile tickled the corner of his mouth like a leftover dab of frosting. He said there would be a party late last night on the Yankees' long flight to Seattle, and it sounded as if that would be plenty for him.

title: Patriots Turn the Tables on Excuses
description: The New England Patriots began the season one play away from victory -- the final play of the game against Tampa Bay -- but a pass by Drew Bledsoe landed out of the end zone and the Patriots lost, 21-16. The next week the Patriots jumped to a 19-7 lead against the Jets but allowed 13 consecutive points in the final 10 minutes of the game and lost, 20-19.

title: Weaving Memories of Mother, Talismanic and Tender
description: Donna Sharrett knows that generations of Americans, generalists and specialists alike, have drawn a distinction between fine art and crafts. From baskets to handblown glass, craft objects have traditionally been regarded as more functional than artistic, even if part of that function is decorative.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTIN, MAURICE
description: AUSTIN-Maurice. The Baruch community records with sorrow the passing of Maurice Austin, Class of '25, distinguished tax lawyer, scholar and dedicated alumnus. For much of his busy life he taught Baruch students the fine points of accountancy while also serving with distinction as an early member and Honorary Trustee of the Baruch College Fund. Mr. Austin's generous support to Baruch, bestowed through the J.M. Kaplan Fund, helped advance the reputation of the College and the education of many deserving students. We offer our deepest sympathy to his children, his grandchildren and Jennie Austin, his wife of seventyone years. He will be sorely missed. Edward V. Regan, President, Baruch College Lawrence Zicklin, President, The Baruch College Fund

title: The Mideast Violence Strikes a Raw Nerve
description: To the Editor:

title: From Whose Perspective?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Full-Bodied Voice Rings Inconsistent
description: Mary Phillips, an American mezzo-soprano who has been active on the recital circuit and as a soloist with orchestras, including the New York Philharmonic under Kurt Masur last season, added a debut recital at Weill Recital Hall to her resume on Oct. 6. It must have been gratifying for Ms. Phillips to have so many friends and enthusiastic supporters in the hall on this important occasion.

title: Senate Clears 4 Money Bills; 5 Tough Measures Remain
description: The Senate today approved four of the nine remaining spending bills needed to keep the government running, setting the stage for lawmakers and the White House to focus on the most contentious measures next week as Congress prepares to adjourn for the year.

description: There's an opportunity to do serious one-stop shopping today at Sotheby's. In fact, Americana fans could fill an entire house with these pedigreed treasures of American furniture.

description: Salander-O'Reilly Galleries

title: INSIDE
description: Back on the Campaign Trail

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Midtown Throng Gathers, Rallying Support for Israel
description: An estimated 15,000 people and much of New York State's political establishment gathered on the streets near the Israeli Consulate in Midtown Manhattan yesterday to angrily condemn recent outbursts of Palestinian violence and rally behind Israel during what several speakers and politicians called one of the most critical moments in Israel's history.

title: Golden Mysteries From the Cowboys of the Steppes
description: CERTAIN kinds of art are box office gold. Art made of gold is one. People are nuts about it. It's just one of those things.

title: Yankees Gain Lead Over Mariners in A.L.C.S.
description: SEATTLE -- The Yankees finally are playing like the Yankees.

title: Five Bodies of U.S. Sailors Killed in Blast Flown to Germany
description: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany, Oct. 13  The remains of five American sailors, killed on Thursday during a terrorist attack on the U.S.S. Cole near Yemen, arrived here today aboard the first of several Air Force cargo planes that are evacuating the dead as well as the injured.

title: Craze for Customization Tears Up the Rules
description: PARIS  Fashion is having a do-it-yourself moment. It seems everywhere you look, there's a brand or designer encouraging the customer to get involved in the design process: to tear your T-shirt apart, create your own running shoes, customize your cocktail dress, all in the name of individuality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNET, LILLIAN
description: BENNET-Lillian. On October 12, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Philip Bennet and Carol Schoenberg. Also survived by five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Service Friday, 10:30 AM, at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th Street at Madison Avenue, New York.

title: Soros Group Said Ready to Take Over Bluefly
description: The George Soros hedge fund group plans to announce today that it is taking over the struggling Internet retailer Bluefly Inc., a person close to the situation said yesterday.

title: Gill Proves to Be a Surer Shot From His Natural Position
description: Kendall Gill is enjoying the comforts of home this season. The 6-foot-5 Nets veteran has embraced his return to his natural position, shooting guard, after a four-year exile at small forward. He looks like a man who appreciates what he missed.

title: Why the Serbs Rebelled
description: To the Editor:

title: Potpourri of Treats Defines Collector's Eye
description: Any museum would rejoice in having a donor like Cyril I. Nelson in the wings, and the Museum of American Folk Art is rejoicing. Interested in art and antiques since his New England childhood, Mr. Nelson, a book editor in the decorative arts field, has given the museum no fewer than 113 objects dating from the late 18th to the mid-20th century and promised many additional works in anticipation of the museum's new building on West 53rd Street.

title: When Judges Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Second Debate, a New Scorecard
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS WEEK 7
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: Bush Stance on Bias Crimes Emerges as Campaign Issue
description: Halfway through the presidential debate on Wednesday, after Vice President Al Gore expressed support for hate crimes legislation and cited the 1998 slaying of a black Texas man, James Byrd Jr., the moderator Jim Lehrer turned to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and asked his views on hate crimes laws.

title: Martinez Is Going in the Right Direction
description: The Yankees' losses at the end of the season were one-sided, embarrassing. But from behind the batting cage, the Yankees' hitting coach, Chris Chambliss, could see at least one redeeming quality in those dark days: Tino Martinez had found the timing in his swing.

title: Clinton Trip to North Korea Is Possible This Year
description: The White House said today that President Clinton may travel to North Korea later this year, in what would be the first visit by an American president to the Communist country.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about an American-born Jewish settler killed in the Mideast last weekend misidentified him as a cousin of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman. The man, Hillel Lieberman, was found slain near Nablus, on the West Bank. Senator Lieberman said yesterday, after speaking to the man's father in New York, that the father's information about a relationship with the senator was apparently incorrect. Further developments are reported today on Page A10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINACH, JACQUELYN
description: REINACH - Jacquelyn (nee Krasne) died peacefully on September 30 in Los Angeles, after a brief illness. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, daughter and sister. Talented composer, writer of more than 50 books, co-creator of Sweet Pickles, music and video producer and long-time feminist. In her 70 years, she touched multitudes through her love and humanitarianism. Her work promoted health, literacy and self-esteem in young people. Her life supported love, understanding, self-knowledge and communication. Grieving family and friends will miss her deeply. Memorial service October 24 at 6PM at Church of the Advent Hope, 111 East 87 Street.

title: After the Second Debate, a New Scorecard
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pigeon Project Adds Romance to Reality
description: Jennifer Monson called her new piece "The Pigeon Project," but the three creatures who flew through the dance seemed more romantic night birds than the avian pedestrians the title suggests.

title: Imbroglio Over the Elf-Kohl Payoff:Was It a Hoax to Hide Kickbacks?
description: PARIS  For three years, Europe has been buzzing about a massive secret payment allegedly made in 1992 by Elf Aquitaine, the French oil company, to the political slush fund of Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany. Elf officials have said that the payment was ordered by the late French president, Francois Mitterrand.

title: On the Web, in the Heart
description: Google search results:

title: Volatile World Events Cause Investor Flight From Stocks
description: Investors stormed the stock market's exits yesterday on news that oil prices were surging, turmoil in the Middle East was escalating and earnings at a major Untied States retailer would be worse than expected.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Congressional consideration of H.M.O. payments misidentified the House member seated between Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and Representative Michael Bilirakis. It was Bill Thomas, not Bill Archer.

title: Homework That Works
description: To the Editor:

title: In Effect, Two First Ladies; Both Women in Giuliani's Life Are Playing Public Roles
description: New York City, a place of abundance, has long been home to two baseball teams, two opera companies and two major airports. Lately, it has also seemed the home of two first ladies.

title: A Haze As Ever Purple
description: BY now everyone should be good and tired of thinking about Jimi Hendrix. He may have been the ultimate icon of countercultural rock, but decades have passed since his death. In the hip-hop era, whole new sound worlds have emerged. The three genres Hendrix helped found -- heavy metal, jazz fusion and funk -- have evolved beyond his contributions. After the millionth time around on classic rock radio, it seems impossible that songs like ''Purple Haze'' could offer anything new.

title: Batsman, Guard Your Wicket!
description: With the score 118 to 36, it was officially garbage time in the night's match between Putnam and Simply Paradise, two teams in the Calypso Night Cricket League. The mostly West Indian crowd of about 300 had lost all interest in the game, turning its attention to Red Stripe beer, fried codfish cakes and the reggae music blaring on the sound system. Even the participants had grown weary of the game. ''We can come back against them, right?'' I asked Putnam's manager, Nigel Seale. He stared into the distance, forlornly shaking his head.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Times Co. Withdraws Plan for Online Unit's Stock Offering
description: Investors' disenchantment with Internet investments prompted The New York Times Company to back away yesterday from its plans for an initial public offering of a stock that would track the performance of its online subsidiary, New York Times Digital.

title: People
description: Bobbi Merkel Scott was named to the new position of managing partner at Einson Freeman, Chicago, part of the WPP Group. She had been vice president for brand development at the Boston Beer Co., Boston.

title: After the Second Debate, a New Scorecard
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Co. Quarterly Earnings Meet Analysts' Expectations
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its third-quarter per-share earnings edged up, matching analysts' estimates, as the company faced higher newsprint costs and made a bigger investment in its Internet operations.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first and second days of Sukkot, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side street cleaning regulations will be suspended tomorrow and Sunday.

title: New Questions For First Lady On Donations
description: The Senate campaign of Hillary Rodham Clinton obtained 1,400 names from an official government list of visitors to the White House and sent them solicitations for political contributions last month. Mrs. Clinton's campaign acknowledged yesterday that she had played a role in the transfer of the names, though the campaign insisted that what happened was accidental.

title: Sort of Like 'Seinfeld,' Sprinkled With Acid
description: A man goes to the movies with a friend. Before the show starts, he buys popcorn. On the way to his seat, he struggles to get past the woman sitting by the aisle. They both get huffy, and then she accuses him of looking at her breasts, which aren't entirely tucked inside her low-cut dress.

title: Yashin Faces the Cold Shoulder
description: Aleksei Yashin is the most talented player on a good Ottawa hockey team. Two years ago, he was captain of the Senators and the runner-up for the Hart trophy as the most valuable player in the National Hockey League.

title: Little by Little, Designers Take To Web Sales
description: NEW YORK  One in the morning: I am working late in the office, but fancy a spot of shopping. Bergdorf Goodman is closed, but Luxlook.com is open 24 hours a day, and I quickly find a flamboyant Versace tie with the designer's signature medallions for dollars 115. A few clicks, and the tie is ordered.

title: Michigan Unions Push Hard for Gore
description: From a purple trailer emblazoned with the Service Employees International Union name, 18 corrections officers at a computerized telephone bank were calling 1,500 union members an hour this week to tell them that Al Gore is a friend of working families.

title: Bombing of British Embassy Recalls Troubled Past With Yemen
description: LONDON, Oct. 13  When an explosion rocked Britain's embassy in Sana early today, the blast sent off echoes of a murky terrorist underworld in Yemen whose activities have been linked to suspected Islamic extremists in Britain.

title: No Corpse, but Plenty of Precedent
description: A smart murderer leaves no body behind, Robert Bierenbaum told his wife years ago, according to a witness who testified recently in the murder trial of Dr. Bierenbaum, a plastic surgeon.

title: Urbanfetch Closing Web Site and Becoming Office Courier
description: Urbanfetch, the online delivery service that was started in New York less than a year ago to compete with Kozmo.com, announced that it was shutting down its Web site and would lay off more than 160 employees. Urbanfetch officials said they would continue operating its business courier company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, HILLEL
description: LIEBERMAN-Hillel. Tha National Jewish Outreach Program mourns the brutal murder of Rabbi Hillel Lieberman, H.Y.D., killed while on his way to save sacred Jewish books from desecration by rioting Palestinians. Condolences to his wife and children, his parents, Rabbi and Mrs. Zevulun Lieberman, his sister Elyorah (and Ian) Ellison, devoted friends of NJOP and his entire family. Yehi Zichro Baruch. Rabbi Ephraim Buchwald, Dir.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: ADDENDUM APPENDED

title: 'One'
description: Directed by Tony Barbieri

title: Lack of Offense
description: Although happy with splitting the first two games in New York, the Mariners are still concerned about their lack of offense. In their last 31 postseason innings, they have managed only 5 runs and 22 hits. Against the Yankees, they have put together more than one hit in only two of the 18 innings.

title: The Story the Interviewer Never Wanted
description: JUST after Kenneth Kimes, convicted murderer and confirmed mama's boy, put Court TV's Maria J. Zone in a stranglehold and jammed a black Paper Mate pen against her carotid artery during a Tuesday afternoon prison interview, he told the sobbing ''Crime Stories'' producer that she should realize he was doing her career an enormous favor by taking her hostage. They'd be infamous together.

title: Nelson Favored in Nebraska
description: In heavily Republican Nebraska, a moderate Democrat and former two-term governor, Ben Nelson, is favored to defeat a longtime rival, Don Stenberg, for the Senate seat being vacated by Senator Bob Kerrey.

title: For a Glasgow Boy, Rats Are Just the Beginning
description: ''Ratcatcher'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Elvis Mitchell's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 7. The film -- in strong Glasgow dialect, with English subtitles -- opens today in Manhattan.

title: Martinez and Yanks Going in Right Direction
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 12  The Yankees' losses at the end of the season were one-sided, embarrassing. But from behind the batting cage, the Yankees' hitting coach, Chris Chambliss, could see at least one redeeming quality in those dark days: Tino Martinez had found the timing in his swing.

title: Israel in Shock as It Buries Mobs Victim
description: OR AKIVA, Israel, Oct. 13  Israel buried Vadim Norzich today, and with him much of its hope for real peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADOMSKY, HYMAN
description: RADOMSKY-Hyman, 80. On October 11, 2000. Holocaust survivor, born in Poland. Beloved husband of Gloria and devoted father of Rosalie and Pauline.

title: As Shuttle Nears Station, NASA Plans to Reward Engineer
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- A NASA engineer who spied a 4-inch pin wedged against space shuttle Discovery's fuel tank will get a medal for quite possibly saving the lives of seven astronauts who are now en route to the International Space Station.

title: Hendrik Casimir, 90, Theorist In Study of Quantum Mechanics
description: Dr. Hendrik B. G. Casimir, a leading theorist of quantum mechanics, has died at age 90.

title: ENGLE HOMES IS BEING ACQUIRED BY TECHNICAL OLYMPIC
description: Engle Homes, a builder of single-family homes and condominiums, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell itself for $465 million in cash and assumed debt to Technical Olympic USA. Technical Olympic USA will pay $19.10 for each share of Engle, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla. The buyer is a unit of Technical Olympic S.A., a construction company based in Athens that also operates in Britain and Romania. The price represents a 21 percent premium to Engle's closing price Wednesday of $15.75. The offer includes the assumption of about $250 million in debt. Engle's stock gained $3.06, to $18.81.

title: Ninth-Inning Magic, and Countdown Hits 6
description: Bobby Valentine led a contingent of drained and delirious Mets up the dugout runway and through the gray metal doors to the visiting clubhouse last night, a pack of men pushing, shoving and shouting with every step.

title: Such Fascinating Creatures . . . So Beguiling, So Special and, Um, He Oughta Know
description: The first scene in Robert Altman's ''Dr. T and the Women'' shows a proper Dallas lady of a certain age, in an elegantly plumed and veiled pillbox hat, making nervous small talk with her gynecologist as he performs an internal exam. The man with the speculum is Sully Travis, the most popular ob-gyn in Dallas and the only man in the city, by his own estimation, who truly understands women. His examination rooms are named after local heroines -- Belle Starr, Phyllis George and Gov. Ann Richards.

title: Jules Olitski
description: Ameringer Howard

title: Aventis Gives Up License To Sell Bioengineered Corn
description: The Environmental Protection Agency effectively revoked the license yesterday for the genetically engineered corn that has now been linked to the nationwide recalls of two brands of taco shells.

title: NISOURCE TO CUT 800 JOBS AFTER COLUMBIA ACQUISITION
description: NiSource Inc., owner of Indiana's largest utility, said yesterday that it would eliminate about 800 jobs to cut costs after it completed its $8.5 billion purchase of the natural gas supplier Columbia Energy Group. The job cuts are part of a plan expected to result in savings ranging from $100 million next year to $175 million in 2004, NiSource said. The cuts, which will be made beginning Dec. 1, represent about 5 percent of the combined work force. Some workers will be offered early retirement while the rest will be laid off or will leave through ''voluntary separations,'' NiSource said.

title: Anti-American Acts in Recent Years
description: Some of the most serious terrorist attacks against Americans:

title: McCain and Bush Seldom Connect on the Trail
description: In the last few weeks, Senator John McCain has been one busy surrogate. He has made more than 90 radio and television commercials for Republicans running for Congress. He has stumped for dozens of those candidates in their districts. He is scheduled to appear in spots for people running for state legislature seats. He has even performed in a public service announcement produced by Comedy Central.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGFRIED, GLADYS DICK
description: SIEGFRIED-Gladys Dick. On October 12, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Loving mother of Robert and Jonathan. Dear grandmother of Amanda, David, Matthew, Jeremy and Rachel. Devoted sister of Marilyn Goldstein. Services are at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue and 65 Street, Sunday, October 15, 12:30 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions her memory may be made to a cancer association of your choice.

title: Internet Law Heats Up
description: Professor Paul M. Schwartz grasped the sides of a wooden lectern and stared down at the sixty or so students in his Internet Law course at Brooklyn Law School last week.

title: Seesaw Battle Ends in Draw In the Championship Match
description: Vladimir Kramnik chose the same defense yesterday in Game 3 of the Brain Games Network World Chess Championship as he had in the first game Saturday in London, and once again it was good for a draw, but that's where the parallel ends.

title: The Big City; Role Reversal Over Tax Cuts And Spending
description: LONG ago, back when a husband might refer to his wife as the little woman, there was a joke about who wore the pants (another quaint phrase from that era) in the typical American household. A couple sitting on the front porch is asked who makes the family's decisions.

title: I.M.F. and Ex-Russian Premier Deny Bush Charge of Aid Theft
description: Gov. George W. Bush's accusation that aid money from the International Monetary Fund lined the pockets of a former Russian prime minister was denied today by the monetary fund and the former Russian official, raising questions about Mr. Bush's pointed charge in Wednesday's otherwise cordial discussion of foreign policy issues.

title: Review/Fashion; Lagerfeld in Neon, Seeking to Amuse
description: Karl Lagerfeld's show today for Chanel was literally switched on. ''I call it 'Walking on Light,' '' he said, referring to the latest cure for boredom, a platform sandal with a clear plastic sole that beams with neon light at each step. ''But it's not a red-light district.''

title: PHONE BIDDER ELIMINATED
description: Italy eliminated Tu Mobile S.p.A., a group controlled by Tu Tlc Utilities S.p.A., from the bidding for licenses to run new mobile telephone networks. The action reduced the number of bidders for the five licenses to six. Tu Mobile was ruled out for failing to provide proper bank guarantees, the government said. The government's decision was ''legitimate,'' the company chairman, Emanuele Castrignano, said in a statement. He said though that Tu Mobile reserved the right to sue the government and try to block the auction before it starts if the company's lawyers decide Tu Mobile was discriminated against. Prime Minister Giuliano Amato, leaving the cabinet meeting, said the auction would begin on Oct. 19.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the finalists for the National Book Awards referred incorrectly to the career of one finalist. David Levering Lewis, who was named for his biography ''W. E. B. Du Bois: The Fight for Equality and the American Century, 1919-1963,'' has written nine other books, including the first volume of the Du Bois work, for which he won the Pulitzer Prize for biography in 1994; he is not a first-time author.

title: Residential Real Estate; As Prices Climb, Terminology Is Also Stretched
description: In what might be called terminology inflation, penthouses are descending and town houses are levitating as architects, developers and marketers of new luxury buildings stretch definitions in seeking to sell their seven-figure wares.

title: In Texas Stop, Lieberman Faults Bush on Environmental Record
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman visited this industrial city today to drive home the Democrats' accusation that Gov. George W. Bush, as president, would pose a national environmental threat.

title: The Bias the Candidates Deplore
description: In Wednesday night's debate at Wake Forest University, both presidential candidates spoke out firmly against racial profiling, the police practice of stopping cars because of the race of their drivers. ''I can't imagine what it's like to be singled out because of race and stopped and harassed,'' George W. Bush said. ''That's flat wrong.'' Asked by the moderator, Jim Lehrer, if he would support a federal law to stop racial profiling, Mr. Bush said yes.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Wednesday about ''Tallulah Hallelujah!,'' a play about Tallulah Bankhead at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, misidentified the Lillian Hellman play in which she made her Broadway acting breakthrough in 1939. It was ''The Little Foxes,'' not ''The Children's Hour.''

title: After the Second Debate, a New Scorecard
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Official Reassures U.S. Envoy on Firm Plans to Open Trade
description: Prime Minister Zhu Rongji has given ''absolutely emphatic'' assurances that China will not back away from the market-opening commitments that it made to gain entry into the World Trade Organization, the American trade negotiator said here today.

title: Business Briefing
description: Smithsonian Names Magazine Publisher

title: U.S. Markets Climb Higher
description: By SAM AMES, CNET NEWS.COM By SAM AMES, CNET NEWS.COM

title: 2 Top Executives To Leave Agencies
description: Two top executives are leaving agencies, one with another job and the other without.

title: Albums of the Week
description: TOM TOM CLUB: ''The Good, the Bad and the Funky'' (Rykodisc). The female bass player is a fixture in countless punk and indie bands. But the stereotypical role owes its existence to real pioneers, especially Tina Weymouth of the Talking Heads and the Tom Tom Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, CHARLES
description: SUSSMAN-Charles ''Chuck''. The Officers and the Board of Directors of the Merrick Jewish Centre, Congregation OHR Torah, mourn the passing of our dear member Charles ''Chuck'' Sussman on October 6 and extend our sincere condolences to his wife Elaine and the entire family. May they know no more sorrow. Barry M. Lasky, President Rabbi Charles A. Klein

title: Knicks Win, Despite a Few Knocks
description: Five minutes before halftime of last night's exhibition game against the Philadelphia 76ers, Coach Jeff Van Gundy inserted a lineup that many expect to become the Knicks' staple. Latrell Sprewell took over at point guard, Allan Houston joined him in the backcourt and Glen Rice played small forward.

title: A Soprano Takes a Dramatic Turn
description: After a recent midday rehearsal for the new Metropolitan Opera production of Beethoven's ''Fidelio,'' which opens tonight, the glamorous soprano Karita Mattila, dressed in casual slacks and sneakers, came bounding into the company's press room for an interview, beaming with the hearty, dimpled bloom of the Finnish farm girl she once was. In her shoulder bag she carried the opera's score along with apples, raw carrots and a bottle of spring water to keep her going on a busy day. Even in her soprano-at-work mode Ms. Mattila, who recently turned 40, looked stunning.

title: In a Casino of One-Acts, 7 Chances for Fulfillment
description: Evenings of one-acts are like evenings at the blackjack table: you hope that the winners outnumber the losers, or at the very least that the overall entertainment value is worth dropping a little cash. ''Snapshots 2000,'' the Worth Street Theater Company's third annual presentation of minimally budgeted one-acts, won't bankrupt the low-rolling gambler, but there isn't a big payoff to be had, either.

title: Franks and Corzine Debate Race, Education and Disclosure
description: Following are excerpts from yesterday's debate between the New Jersey senatorial candidates Jon S. Corzine and Representative Bob Franks, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Rangers' Malakhov to Miss A Month With Injured Knee
description: The Rangers signed defenseman Vladimir Malakhov last summer so he could take pressure off Brian Leetch on the point during power plays. But it will be a month before Malakhov can rejoin Leetch.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the debate on Wednesday between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas misattributed a quotation in some copies. It was Mr. Bush, not Mr. Gore, who said, ''If we're an arrogant nation, they'll resent us. If we're a humble nation, but strong, they'll welcome us.''

title: College Football Matchups for October 14
description: SATURDAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STORPER, SIDNEY
description: STORPER-Sidney. Beloved husband of Charlotte; loving father of Marsha and Larry Brooks, Henry and Fran Storper; devoted grandfather of Scott, David and Andrew Storper, Beth and Seth Joseph, and Scott's fiancee Claudia Arzate; and bedazzled great-grandfather of Samantha Joseph, passed away Tuesday, October 10, 2000. Sidney Storper grew up in New York City where he was an accomplished swimmer and lifeguard. Subsequently, he was a brilliant chemical engineer who developed a fuselage coating that saved many U.S. planes during World War II and for years thereafter. Known as a ''problem solver par excellence'', he was also a successful real estate owner and manager, work he continued to do after moving to Florida in 1991. Adored by family and friends, he always had a firm hand shake, a winning smile, and a great one-liner. Services will be held Friday, October 13, 2000 at 11 AM at Beth Israel Memorial in Delray Beach. The family will receive friends on Saturday and Sunday at Henry and Fran Storper's home in Miami.

title: Franks Accuses Corzine of Trying To Buy His Way Into Senate Seat
description: Representative Bob Franks, the Republican candidate for Senate from New Jersey, kept Jon S. Corzine on the defensive today throughout their second debate as he continued to accuse Mr. Corzine of trying to buy the election and of advocating big-government spending programs that the nation can ill afford.

title: A Plan B That Gets Straight A's
description: K. C. Keeler, the successful football coach at Rowan University, says he has no resume. A resume is as vital to a young, aspiring college football coach as a good whistle. Keeler says he has better things to do with his time.

title: World Business Briefing
description: WORLD TRADE

title: Metro Business; Work Starting for Plant
description: Work is to start soon on an $8 million project to improve truck and rail access to a major industrial plant in Buffalo. The work is the final step in a two-year, state-aided effort to help the operation remain viable and increase its 860-employee work force, New York State officials say.

title: E.S.A. Eyes Mission to Mercury
description: PARIS, Oct 13 - Mercury, one of the most intriguing planets of the Solar System, will be targeted for scrutiny by the European Space Agency at the end of this decade, ESA officials said Friday.

title: Mets Say Reliever Threw at Bordick
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12  The general manager says the opposing reliever intentionally threw at his shortstop. The reliever and the opposing manager say the G.M. is stupid. The shortstop is out of the lineup.

title: Behrens to Test Lemon Drop Kid in Gold Cup
description: ''He's developed into a man,'' Scotty Schulhofer was saying yesterday at Belmont Park, saluting his horse, Lemon Drop Kid. ''He belongs in the big leagues.''

title: Style Magazine Covers Reveal The Demise of Celebrity Chic
description: LONDON  Celebrity, however meager, sells fashion magazines. The October crop of British glossies boasts covers featuring the ubiquitous Victoria Adams (Elle), Sporty Spice (Marie Claire) and Robbie Williams (Vogue) and the notorious Eminem (The Face). But two new London-based magazines fire warning shots this season in fashion's fight against celebrity saturation.

title: Testaverde on the Mend And Is Likely to Start
description: Jets quarterback Vinny Testaverde appears to have recovered enough from the pinched nerve that knocked him out of last week's game to start Sunday against New England.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CRISSEY, GARY E.
description: CRISSEY-Gary E. We hope you're in a wonderful place now. Your family and friends remember you on this day and always.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YELLIS, HELEN
description: YELLIS-Helen. Died on October 12, 2000. Beloved mother of Robert and Elissa. Services Friday, 12 noon at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels.'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Navy's Visits to Risky Port Sought Better Ties to Yemen
description: Despite the known risks of terrorism in Yemen, American ships like the destroyer Cole have made refueling stops there 12 times in recent months as part of an American strategy to improve ties with the Arab country.

title: Cone Awaiting Chance That May Never Come
description: David Cone warmed up in the bullpen on Tuesday night, late in Game 1 of the American League Championship Series. The rookie Randy Choate was pitching, and as Jason Grimsley threw from one mound in the home bullpen, Cone got up and started throwing from the other one.

title: The Truth About Racial Profiling
description: The racial profiling scandal in New Jersey seemed to subside in 1999. The Whitman administration admitted that some state police officers were stopping and searching motorists based on race and accepted a police monitoring procedure devised by the United States Justice Department. But newly disclosed documents have revived the scandal. They show that the police uncovered evidence of racial profiling by highway officers as early as 1996 and deliberately hid the data from federal investigators.

title: 'Just Looking'
description: Directed by Jason Alexander

title: Getting to Know Outcast Cultures
description: Worlds apart in all other respects, two first-rate documentaries released on Tuesday are equally savvy in working their territories.

title: Import Prices Other Than Oil Fell Sharply in September
description: Prices of imports other than oil showed the largest decline in one and a half years last month, government figures showed today, suggesting the nation's appetite for foreign-made goods is helping contain inflation.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE STATES

title: Article 2000101392877700758 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: The Goal Changes, From Peace to an End to Violence
description: Egypt offered today to hold an emergency regional summit meeting, but President Clinton said that he would not attend until Palestinian and Israeli leaders had committed publicly to end the violence, a senior administration official said.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KHAZANEH, DR. ABBAS
description: KHAZANEH-Dr. Abbas. We were deeply saddened to hear of the passing of Dr. K. He was a wonderful, friendly, caring man who will be missed by all who knew him. Our heartfelt sympathy to the Khazaneh family. Jeffrey Haber Michael Fischman

title: Credibility Is Job No. 1 at MG
description: IT takes perhaps 10 minutes to walk from the National Exhibition Center here to the headquarters of what is now known as the MG Rover Group. And yet, when a biennial motor show opens to the public at the center next Thursday, there will be no display of MG Rover's cars.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: First the meatpacking district, now the Lower East Side. In days gone by, it was artists who colonized the city's iffier neighborhoods, but they seem to have been supplanted by young chefs in search of nothing more than a little place to call their own.

title: Surfing the Music Scene With Web Masters of Rock
description: Sweeping comparisons can be useful in assessing pop obscured by media hoopla. When the noise surrounding a band is big, think big. To wit: Radiohead is the rock equivalent of the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, FAY
description: HOLLAND-Fay (Brodkin). On October 11th, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Bernice Schargel (Sol) and Gerald Holland (Phyllis), loving grandmother of Gail Powell, Pam Montgomery and Allison Holland, dear great-grandmother of Sam, Grace, Kate, Emma and Jake. Loving sister of Berta Gapin and the late Anna Guberman and Ben Brodkin. Graveside service Friday, October 13, at 11 A.M. at Union Field Cemetery, Cypress Avenue, Ridgewood, New York.

title: Oil Prices Rise On New Fears About Mideast
description: The price of crude oil surged yesterday, as news of escalating violence on the West Bank and an apparent terrorist attack on a United States naval ship in Yemen stoked fears of a wider Middle East conflict that could disrupt the flow of oil from the region.

title: For a New Lucinda Childs, Less Minimalism Is More
description: Lucinda Childs, always an experimental choreographer and increasingly luminous in her geometric eye-riveting patterns, has chosen ''Parcours'' as the title of her company's 25th anniversary program in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival.

title: A Goddess of Self-Love Who Did Not Sit Quietly
description: We are all narcissists now. These days it is not considered pathological for people to acquire hundreds of photographs of themselves in a lifetime. But in the middle of the 19th century you really, really had to try.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWE, JEANETTE MARMOTT
description: LOWE-Jeanette Marmott. With heavy hearts and profound sadness we mourn the loss of Jeanette Marmott Lowe (Beauty), October 8, 2000. Precious mother of Gail Lowe Maidman (Richard), devoted grandmother of Starr Elizabeth Haymes and Evan Adam Haymes, sister of Edith Bloch, Perry Zitter, and the late Ernest Marmott, daughter of the late Louis George and Esther (Blumenthal) Marmott. We will miss our Beauty and the tender, loving, kindness she showed us. Shiva concluding at Gail's home, today 11AM to 4 PM. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Couple Give $2 Million For Gay Student Center
description: In what is apparently the largest gift from a gay benefactor to a campus project for gays and lesbians, two men who began living together as undergraduates at the University of Pennsylvania in the 1980's have donated $2 million for a new gay and lesbian student center at the university.

title: Response By Barak To Attack
description: Following are excerpts from a statement today by Prime Minister Ehud Barak about the killing of Israeli soldiers and the military response, as recorded and translated by The New York Times:

title: President Orders Review of Wireless Spectrum
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  With growing congestion of the airwaves threatening the development of a new generation of handheld wireless devices, President Clinton today ordered the Federal government to review and then reassign wide swaths of the spectrum now controlled by such agencies as the Defense Department, as well as by private companies.

title: MITSUBISHI FORMS ALLIANCE WITH SOFTBANK
description: Mitsubishi, perhaps the bluest of Japan's blue-chip companies, said it would team up with Softbank, the country's leading Internet investment company, to form a company called Eupholink Inc. to offer advisory services and capital to fledgling and established companies alike that are seeking to do more business online. Mitsubishi will hold a 49 percent stake in the company, which will have initial capitalization of 490 million yen, or about $4.5 million, and two Softbank subsidiaries will own the rest. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: Edmonds Shoulders Blame for Loss
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12  Tony La Russa played manager tonight. He began with making a 50 percent turnover of his roster to combat the Cardinals' offensive woes. He continued by pulling pitcher Rick Ankiel after the rookie allowed two runs in a disastrous first inning.

title: Mets, Majoring in Drama, Win in 9th
description: The Mets were built to win this season. That was the mandate from ownership, and that is why the roster is loaded with veterans. In the grand plan, no rookies figured to play any significant roles.

title: European Commission Approves Vivendi Acquisition of Seagram
description: PARIS, Oct. 13  The European Commission officially approved today the $34 billion acquisition of the Seagram Company by the French conglomerate Vivendi, as executives of both companies began a barnstorming effort to sell the concept of a world of entertainment and telecommunications where the combination hopes to reap a windfall.

title: Most Eighth Graders Fail State Math Test
description: More than three-quarters of New York City's eighth graders failed to reach acceptable levels on a statewide mathematics test last spring, raising serious questions about whether they will be able to pass a newly required Regents math exam before they graduate from high school in 2004.

title: Accounts
description: StraightAway, Naples, Fla., formerly Auto2Auto, a service for buying and selling used vehicles, to Frankfurt Balkind Partners, New York, to handle its first account. Spending was estimated at $20 million.

title: REGULATORS RAID MATSUSHITA
description: Inspectors from Japan's Fair Trade Commission conducted a surprise raid on offices of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the world's largest maker of consumer electronics. The commission swooped into the company's consumer product sales offices in Tokyo, Osaka and 10 other locations, the company said. Inspectors are looking into allegations that the company pushed retailers to charge higher prices than it suggested, threatening that it would cut off product supplies if they did not comply.

title: Israeli Guards Keep Young Men From Old City Mosque Services
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 13  A huge Israeli security cordon prevented thousands of Palestinians from attending Friday prayer services at the ancient mosques inside the Old City today, a move that further angered Muslims here but kept the embattled holy site from exploding anew into violent confrontation.

title: Gliding in a Floating World, Life Is but a Dream
description: To see New York City from the water is to see it anew, spread out serenely along the horizon in the shifting light, distorted by distance, blurred by haze, magically rearranging itself as you move in the muffled quiet toward someplace, anyplace or, better yet, no place at all.

title: Philippine Vice President Quits Cabinet, Citing Scandal
description: The vice president of the Philippines resigned from her cabinet post today as pressure mounted for President Joseph Estrada to step down in a growing bribery scandal.

title: BLAST KILLS SAILORS ON U.S. SHIP IN YEMEN
description: An American Navy destroyer refueling in Yemen was rocked by an enormous explosion on Thursday, and President Clinton said it appeared to be a terrorist attack. At least 6 American sailors died and 11 others were missing and presumed dead, officials said. Nearly three dozen others were injured, some of them severely.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: South Korean President Awarded the Nobel Peace Prize
description: OSLO, Oct. 13 -- South Korean President Kim Dae-jung won the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday for his drive to improve ties with Stalinist North Korea and so defuse a final flashpoint of the Cold War.

title: FORD SAYS IT WILL INCREASE FOURTH-QUARTER DIVIDEND 5%
description: The Ford Motor Company, the world's second-largest automaker, said yesterday that it would increase the dividend on common and Class B shares 5 percent, to 30 cents, in the fourth quarter. Ford also declared a dividend of 51.5625 cents a share on depository shares representing Series B cumulative preferred stock. The dividend declaration comes about a month after the automaker said it would buy back as much as $5 billion of common and Class B stock, increasing the amount of cash it plans to distribute to shareholders by $700 million, to $10.7 billion. All of Ford's Class B stock is held by members of the Ford family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAPOLI, FANNIE
description: NAPOLI-Fannie (Eugenio). May 22, 1911-October 10, 2000. She dreamed a life. She lived the dream. She will be forever loved & missed. Viewing at the Fairchild Funeral Home, Manhasset, New York. Funeral Mass at St. Mary's Church, Roslyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Miami Heart Research Institute, Miami Beach, Florida, will be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTMANN, CHARLES T.
description: MATTMANN-Charles T. Of Locust Valley, LI suddenly on October 10, 2000, age 81. Beloved husband of the late Barbara Moore, father of Sandra M. Gros, Barbara M. Walkley (Philip F.), Wendy M. McHale (Kevin) and Debbie M. Williams (Dewayne), brother of Jane Hamilton, John and Ted. Vovo of ten. Greatgrandfather of 3. Friends may visit at the funeral home of DodgeThomas, Glen Cove Saturday, 4-7, Sunday 2-5 PM. Service St. Johns of Lattingtown, Monday at 11 AM.

title: In Utility Power Play, East Meets West; Buyers Circle Debt-Ridden German Pawn
description: Until recently, the sparkling new power plant in eastern Germany looked like a Taj Mahal of good intentions gone wrong.

description: To the Editor:

title: Weak Bench Could Hurt U.S. Bid
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 12  A scoreless deadlock with Costa Rica on Wednesday proved that the Americans' depth chart is rather thin for World Cup matches, and the gap between the regular starters and the players on the bench is much wider than many observers had thought.

title: Softbank Sets Up Credit Lines To Help Raise Money Quickly
description: TOKYO, Oct. 13  The Softbank Corporation, one of the biggest Internet investment companies, said today that it would establish revolving credit lines with 10 banks for roughly $1.3 billion to provide more flexibility in raising money quickly.

description: 'The Hiroshima Project'

title: Pacers' Rose Out With Broken Wrist
description: Jalen Rose of the Indiana Pacers will probably miss the next four to six weeks with a broken left wrist sustained in Wednesday's 91-83 preseason victory over Minnesota, the team said yesterday.

title: 2 Israeli Soldiers Slain by a Mob; Helicopters Hit Back
description: Israeli helicopter gunships rocketed Ramallah and Gaza City today after a Palestinian mob here stabbed and stomped to death two Israeli reserve soldiers and then paraded a mutilated body through town.

title: South Korean President Awarded the Nobel Peace Prize
description: OSLO, Norway -- South Korean President Kim Dae-jung won the Nobel Peace Prize Friday for his work toward reconciliation with North Korea.

title: Portugal Shows Off the Treasures It Gathered in Africa
description: It's no surprise that Portugal has strong connections with African art, as for centuries the country -- an active explorer and colonizer in sub-Saharan Africa -- held vast tracts of land in wildly diverse cultural areas of the continent.

title: Lagerfeld Raises the Bar for YSL : Chanel Leaps High
description: PARIS  Using his intellectual brilliance, his witty imagination and his years of experience, Karl Lagerfeld sent out a superb collection for Chanel  sporty, pretty and modern, yet chock-full of references to the legendary Coco, not least in her name on face veils.

title: Days of Rage in the Mideast
description: The Middle East shuddered with new violence yesterday that spilled the blood of Americans, Israelis and Palestinians and brought the region to a level of instability it has not seen since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait a decade ago. The deadly attack on an American naval vessel in Yemen, the sickening lynch-mob murder of two Israeli soldiers in Ramallah and retaliatory Israeli air strikes against targets in Palestinian-ruled areas of the West Bank and Gaza unsettled Washington and Wall Street, introduced an unpredictable element into the presidential campaign and left little hope for a speedy revival of the Middle East peace effort.

title: Article 2000101394016744680 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: General Motors' Earnings Decline 5.5% in Quarter
description: Facing falling sales in Europe and stiff competition in the United States, General Motors said yesterday that its third-quarter profit dropped 5.5 percent, but its per-share earnings topped analysts' expectations by a penny.

title: 'Wearable Art' Show Takes on the World
description: WELLINGTON  An off-beat fashion show that began 12 years ago in a small New Zealand town has grown to become a popular showcase of creativity featuring weird and wonderful entries from all over the world.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Salisbury, Md.

description: To the Editor:

title: Neighbors Fear Turmoil Could Threaten Them
description: While Arabs have been involved in the growing violence between Israel and the Palestinians with furious street protests and growing outrage against Israel, moderate Arab leaders increasingly fear that the deadly cycle threatens not only the Arab-Israeli peace effort, but also their own stability.

title: Promised Veto Appears to Doom Congressional Agreement on Overhauling Bankruptcy Law
description: Congressional efforts to overhaul the nation's bankruptcy system appeared all but doomed today when the White House said that President Clinton would veto a last-ditch measure that sailed through the House.

title: As Dreams of Peace Take Flight, Many Angry Fingers Point Toward Arafat
description: At a grocery store tonight, watching televised scenes of the killing of two Israeli soldiers and the helicopter strikes in Ramallah, Chaim Bachar's old misgivings about peace with the Palestinians came flooding back.

title: Founders Stepping Aside As WebMD Troubles Grow
description: Jim Clark, the billionaire Silicon Valley visionary who dreamed of a software company that would forge connections among just about everybody in health care, resigned yesterday from the board of the firm he helped create, WebMD. Martin J. Wygod, whose dreams are more concerned with profits, took full control as the surviving chief executive of the troubled company.

title: 'Whispers'
description: 'An Elephant's Tale' Directed by Dereck Joubert

title: Lieberman Finds No Relation to Settler Killed in West Bank
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Democratic candidate for vice president, said yesterday that he was apparently not related to Hillel Lieberman, an American-born settler killed last weekend in the violence between Israelis and Palestinians on the West Bank.

title: At Rubble of Arafat's Office, Pledges of Revenge
description: At dusk, after the Israeli air attacks on targets in Gaza, a four-car convoy began making its way through the dusty side streets to inspect the damage.
