description: For Serenity

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYNOLDS, PEGGY BRADY
description: REYNOLDS-Peggy Brady. Of NYC, and Westhampton, L.I., on October 11, of heart failure after an extended illness. Survived by her husband Jack, son Thomas, grandchildren Tommy Jr., Scott and Katlyn. Predeceased by daughter Meg. Loving sister of Anne, Marion, Eileen and Joan. Classical designer of sports wear for Evan Picone and colorful swimwear for Peter Pan. She built a beautiful home in Westhampton, decorated with a loving touch to welcome family and friends. She was a smart, stylish, gutsy and generous woman-as beautiful on the inside as the outside. Reposing at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Ave., near 70 St., NYC, Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10 AM, Church of the Holy Family, 315 East 47 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, HORACE BROOKES
description: ROBINSON - Horace Brookes Blackwell. The Board of Trustees of NYU Downtown Hospital note with sadness the passing of Horace B.B. Robinson, a distinguished officer and life trustee of the Board for more than five decades. Mr. Robinson was a great nephew of Elizabeth Blackwell, M.D., a founder of the New York Infirmary and the forerunner to NYU Downtown Hospital. In his passing we lost a dedicated trustee and a link to our past. We offer our deepest sympathy to his family. Nelson Schaenen, Jr., Chairman Ronald H. Menaker, Past Chm Susan B. Roschen, Past Chm Leonard Aubrey, President & CEO

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on Wednesday misstated Procter & Gamble's financial performance under Durk I. Jager, its former chief executive. The company had 17 consecutive disappointing months, not consecutive quarters.

title: Instant Media Analysis Often Proves at Odds With Public Opinion
description: Anyone unsure of who ''won'' the second presidential debate had only to consult a newspaper, Web site or television network yesterday for an unequivocal answer.

title: Fewer Watched Last Debate Than Most Previous Ones
description: Wednesday night's debate between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas was watched by fewer people than any previous presidential debate except one, the second debate between President Clinton and Bob Dole four years ago, according to figures released yesterday by Nielsen Media Research.

title: Israeli Guards Keep Young Men From Old City Mosque Services
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 13  A huge Israeli security cordon prevented thousands of Palestinians from attending Friday prayer services at the ancient mosques inside the Old City today, a move that further angered Muslims here but kept the embattled holy site from exploding anew into violent confrontation.

title: One Busy Visitor
description: Mikhail B. Piotrovsky is a man with multiple missions. On a five-day visit to New York, Dr. Piotrovsky, the director of the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia, was on hand yesterday for the opening of ''The Golden Deer of Eurasia: Scythian and Sarmatian Treasures From the Russian Steppes'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He also gave a lecture at the Met on its show and was honored at the annual dinner of the American Friends of the Hermitage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, ROBERT
description: WINTER-Robert. On October 10, 2000. Beloved husband of Claire. Loving father of Karen and Joel Lamm, Ann and Richard Winter. Devoted grandfather of Jordan and Ben Laser, Samantha and Justin Winter, Adam and Jenna Lamm. Services Friday October 13th. I. J. Morris, Dix Hills, L.I. 12:15PM. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEARNS, MAUD
description: KEARNS-Maud, 89. Of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, died Tuesday, October 10, 2000. at her residence. Formerly of Long Island, NY, she had been a resident of Ft. Lauderdale since 1980. She was the widow of Joseph P. Kearns and was a retired restaurateur. Survived by loving sisters, Lauraine G. Smith and Sheila G. Fox, both of Ft. Lauderdale; her brother James F. Murphy of East Williston, NY, and many nieces and nephews. A mass of Christian Burial was concelebrated Thursday, October 12, in Ft. Lauderdale with interment following. For information Fairchild Funeral Home, Ft. Lauderdale, Florida, (954) 763-4488.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about an American-born Jewish settler killed in the Mideast last weekend misidentified him as a cousin of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman. The man, Hillel Lieberman, was found slain near Nablus, on the West Bank. Senator Lieberman said yesterday, after speaking to the man's father in New York, that the father's information about a relationship with the senator was apparently incorrect. Further developments are reported today on Page A10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARINO, GASPARE
description: MARINO-Gaspare. Son of Domenico and Caterina. Prominent restauranteur and amateur opera singer in the New York City scene since the early 1950's. Well respected in the community and leader of his extensive family, died October 11 in his retirement retreat in Bagheria, Sicily, just outside the city of Palermo. He leaves behind his faithful wife Rosa, his daughter Cathy Marino Speciale and son, Dominick Marino, four loving grandchildren, Maurizio, Valentina, Michael and Laura and his sister Frances Marino Saladino and brother Matteo Marino. His wit, courage and generosity will be greatly missed.

title: Islanders Still Seek a Victory
description: Fast start? What fast start?

title: Two Marriages Go Happily Bad
description: Two new adaptations of Ibsen and Strindberg classics -- both awash in marital woe and both adapted by bright American talents -- are wheeling into sight for possible spring productions.

title: Watchmakers Say It's Time to Get Two-Faced
description: HONG KONG  Fickle fashion and hard-nosed economics are conspiring to promote a growing trend toward watches that mix classic analog style with discreet digital functionality.

title: Sinopec Raises $3.5 Billion
description: Brushing aside last-minute questions about its parent company's dealings, China's No. 2 oil company, Sinopec, raised $3.5 billion in an initial public offering today. Sinopec priced the offering at 1.61 Hong Kong dollars, or 21 cents, a share, and $20.65 for each American depository receipt. It is the year's second-largest Chinese stock sale after China Unicom, a cellular company, which raised $5.6 billion in June. Just before the offer, Sinopec confirmed that its parent owned a joint venture in Sudan.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sonja Bullaty, 76, a Photographer of Lyricism
description: Sonja Bullaty, a photographer noted for lyrical composition and startling use of color and light in a vast body of work created during a five-decade collaboration with her husband, Angelo Lomeo, died on Oct. 5 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 76, and had homes in Manhattan and Bellmont, Vt.

title: Two Mets Rookies Provide Spark in Win
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12  The Mets were built to win this season. That was the mandate from ownership, and that is why the roster is loaded with veterans. In the grand plan, no rookies figured to play any significant roles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMICOLA, ALBERT A.
description: FORMICOLA-Albert A. of Rye Brook, NY. On October 11, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Yolanda. Loving father of Carl and the late Janet. Dear grandfather of Jennifer, Katie, Leah, Michael and Jamie Cobelli. Also survived by his son-in-law Dr. Neil Cobelli and his wife Marcie, his brother Frank and sisters Ann, Margaret and Ida. Pre-deceased by his brother Jerry. Visiting hours Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY. Mass of Christian burial Saturday 9:45AM at The Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Charles Hartshorne, Theologian, Is Dead; Proponent of an Activist God Was 103
description: Charles Hartshorne, a philosopher, theologian and educator who wrote more than 20 books and 100 articles in a lifelong mission to prove that God was a participant in cosmic evolution rather than the supreme composer, died on Tuesday at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 103.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Not Quite Live With Regis

title: Seattle Journal; In a Turbulent Year, a City Is Cheered by Baseball
description: It's being called what else to call it? -- ''the Battle in Seattle.''

title: At Destroyer's Home Base, All Are 'Just Waiting'
description: In worry and uncertainty, more than 100 spouses and children waited together through the day at the Norfolk Naval Base for some official word on precisely who perished and who survived the explosion on the destroyer Cole.

title: Architect's Works Maintain Ties to Builder's Art
description: Renzo Piano, who attained the highest formal honor an architect can achieve when he won the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 1998, once wondered if he should have been a contractor. After all, his grandfather, father and brother were all builders.

title: Gay Officer Gets $20,000 In Bias Case
description: New York City will pay a $20,000 settlement to a former police officer who claimed in a lawsuit that she was discriminated against for being gay, according to records released yesterday.

title: For Democracy in Peru
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, ANNE MISHLER
description: WARREN-Anne Mishler, 85. Of Red Bank died Wednesday 10/11. She was the Administrative Assistant of the Training Department of Merril Lynch for many years. She was predeceased by her husband, Edward, her daughter Bette Jane Soltano. She was survived by two daughters, Wendy Tooker of Red Bank, NJ, Heide Goldstein of Marathon, NY, seven grandchildren, Lisa Paige Soltano, Andrew Soltano, Dr. Emily Soltano, Josh Tooker, Jessica Voglesong, Amy Hughston and Joey Steinhagen, two great-grandchildren, Dale Hughston and Casey Voglesong. Graveside services 11:00 Monday at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn. Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels, Ocean Township.

title: Giuliani Says He Would Consider Abolishing Term Limits for City Council
description: Quiet attempts by the New York City Council to overturn part of a 1993 law on term limits appeared to gain momentum yesterday when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he might support such a measure. Under the law, 36 of the Council's 51 members would have to leave office on Dec. 31, 2001.

title: LOSS OF CONFIDENCE IN PHILIPPINES
description: Alarmed by a severe slide in the value of the peso, the central bank of the Philippines raised interest rates by 4 percentage points, to 15 percent. It was the second time in a month that the central bank raised rates and was the biggest increase in Philippine rates since the Asian financial crisis three years ago. The central bank's move, aimed at halting a stampede of money into assets denominated in dollars, reflected the growing sense of crisis in the Philippines, where President Joseph Estrada is immersed in financial scandal and has refused widespread calls for him to resign. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: EXTENSION IN CORPORATE TAX RULING
description: The World Trade Organization approved extending until Nov. 1 the deadline for the United States to comply with an earlier ruling to overhaul its system of tax breaks for American exporting companies. United States trade officials, who had asked for an extension, had already agreed with the European Union, which had brought the complaint that the United States Foreign Sales Corporation program was an export subsidy that violated global free trade rules. Legislation to change the program is working its way through Congress, but has yet to clear the Senate.

title: SYCAMORE WINS BELLSOUTH CONTRACT
description: Shares of Sycamore Networks surged yesterday after the company won a contract to provide BellSouth with new-generation optical switches and transport equipment for its planned Internet gateway service center in Florida. BellSouth and Sycamore did not disclose the terms of the deal, but analysts said its symbolic value was far greater than its dollar value. Sycamore expects to begin recording revenue from the BellSouth contract in 2001, but officials declined to specify in which quarter. Sycamore shares rose $3.45, to close at $76.14. (TheStreet.com)

title: Bomb Hits British Embassy in Yemen
description: YEMEN -- An explosion at the British Embassy in Yemen's capital Friday shattered windows but injured no one, embassy officials said. The blast came a day after 17 Americans were killed in an apparent terrorist attack at a Yemeni port. The cause of the blast was not immediately known, but British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook said it appeared a bomb had been thrown over a wall into the embassy area. "It was not a particularly professional attack, rather an opportunistic one, and it seems to have landed on a diesel generator and has caused quite a substantial explosion," he said in an interview with Britain's Sky News. At the time of the blast, shortly after dawn, only a Yemeni night guard was on duty, a British Embassy spokeswoman said on condition of anonymity. "We sustained considerable damage to the building itself," she said. The explosions in Yemen, an impoverished country on the tip of the Arabian Peninsula, come amid anti-U.S. fervor in the region sparked by two weeks of Israeli-Palestinian clashes. The embassy explosion shook the entire neighborhood, said Hisham al-Qubati, a secretary at the nearby Yemen Times building. "I heard a loud explosion at 6:05 a.m. (11:05 p.m. EDT, Thursday) and rushed over to the embassy. They wouldn't let us in, but I could see shattered windows and the damage to a school next to the embassy," al-Qubati said. Beyond damage to the three-story embassy and neighboring school, both of which normally are closed on Fridays, the explosion just after dawn blew out windows of the nearby Dutch Embassy. Several embassies are located in the neighborhood. A forensics team was trying to determine the cause of the blast, the embassy spokeswoman said.

title: PHILLIPS SELLS ITS COAL OPERATIONS FOR $191 MILLION
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that it had sold its coal business in three separate transactions for $191 million. Phillips, based in Bartlesville, Okla., sold its 50 percent stake in the Walnut Creek Mining Company, which operates in Texas, to the Kiewit Construction Company of Omaha, and its 50 percent stake in the Dry Fork coal assets in Wyoming to Western Fuels-Wyoming Inc. of Denver. The company sold other coal interests in Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi to the North American Coal Corporation of Dallas. Phillips said it would record gains of $48 million from the sales. (Bloomberg News)

title: SHELL ACQUISITION BLOCKED
description: Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Apache Corporation's $1.6 billion bid for Fletcher Challenge Energy was blocked by New Zealand regulators on concern the new business would dominate the nation's natural gas market. Fletcher Energy shares fell 19 percent in Australian trading. The New Zealand dollar dropped to a record because Fletcher Energy shareholders would not need to exchange the United States dollars Shell is offering for their shares. The planned purchase would give Shell ownership of more than 80 percent of New Zealand's oil and gas reserves.

title: HEWLETT INTERNET INITIATIVE
description: An initiative announced yesterday by HewlettPackard will seek to bring Internet access to poor people in developing markets across the globe. As part of the project, Hewlett-Packard and partners from the public and private sectors will sell, lease or donate $1 billion in products and services in markets in Africa, Latin America, China and Eastern Europe next year. Hewlett-Packard officials acknowledged that developing markets for their products was an important motivation for the initiative. But Carleton S. Fiorina, the company's chief executive, said bringing computers to these markets will help people reap the economic benefits of the Internet.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckold's Nest
description: For what it is, a 90-minute spinoff of a ''Saturday Night Live'' sketch, Reginald Hudlin's film ''The Ladies Man'' is not bad. If you have some familiarity with recent examples of this benighted genre -- like ''Stuart Saves His Family,'' ''It's Pat,'' ''A Night at the Roxbury'' or ''Superstar'' -- you will take this evaluation as a giddy rave. ''The Ladies Man'' has some funny, dirty-minded jokes, a few amusing cameos (including Julianne Moore in clown makeup) and a soundtrack loaded with juicy cuts of mid-70's vintage soul and funk: a lot of Gamble and Huff, a soupcon of Isley Brothers and a plateful of Parliament's ''Up for the Down Stroke.''

title: Four Plead Not Guilty To Charges Of Bribery
description: A former Republican candidate for secretary of the state, his sister-in-law and two Boston businessmen pleaded not guilty today to federal corruption charges linking them to Connecticut's former treasurer, who admitted last year that he had accepted bribes while in office.

title: Bomb Hits British Embassy in Yemen

The attack followed a suicide bomb attack on a U.S. Navy destroyer a day earlier in the Yemeni port of Aden and prompted immediate fears of a resurgence of what Cook called "terrorist" activity.

title: Escaping a Miner's Life For a Career in Ballet
description: ''Billy Elliot'' tells the story of an 11-year-old boy living in a coal mining town in northern England who dreams of becoming a ballet dancer. Billy's father (Gary Lewis), a miner locked in inarticulate grief after the death of his wife, is horrified and embarrassed at his son's terpsichorean bent, and so the boy must secretly train with a tough, kindly local dance teacher named Mrs. Wilkinson (Julie Walters), who pushes him to audition for a place in the Royal Ballet School.

title: Foreign Affairs; Arafat's War
description: Maybe the most revealing feature of this latest explosion in Israeli-Palestinian violence is the fact that this war has no name. The ''intifada,'' the Palestinian uprising of the late 1980's, got its name almost immediately. Intifada loosely means ''shaking off,'' and Palestinians were said to be trying to shake off the Israeli occupation. The name made so much sense that even Israelis used it. But the violence of the last two weeks still has no name. And that is not an accident. It's because even the participants can't explain what it's about, or, deep down, they're embarrassed to do so.

What makes this twisty, cautionary yarn, written and directed by Rod Lurie, delicious is a cast that chews the scenery with such obvious enjoyment that you're happy to put up with its tin-eared oratory and preposterous plot turns for the sake of a good ride.

title: JUNIPER PROFIT TOPS EXPECTATIONS
description: Juniper Networks announced quarterly earnings that blew past Wall Street's expectations yesterday, as analysts said the company continued to whittle away at Cisco Systems' dominance of the Internet-switching technology market. Juniper reported net income of $58.1 million, or 17 cents a share, nearly double the 9 cents analysts had predicted. The company lost $1.59 million, or 1 cent a share, a year earlier. Sales were $201.2 million, up 78 percent from the prior quarter. Analysts had predicted revenue of about $147 million. Sales were $29.6 million for the period a year earlier. Christin Armacost, an analyst with SG Cowen, said the results exceeded even Wall Street's highest ''whisper'' numbers. Juniper said it now expected annual revenue of $625 million to $640 million, up from an earlier prediction of $520 million. Its shares had dropped $6.41, to $199.59, before the earnings release, which came after markets closed. After hours, the shares rose $3.26, to $202.87. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Vivendi Offer on Its BSkyB Stake Is Reported

Ashton shares fell as much as 1.3 percent, extending Wednesday's decline of 4.7 percent.

title: GAZPROM POSTS PROFIT

title: LVMH POSTS HIGHER SALES
description: LVMH-Moet-Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A. said third-quarter sales rose 35 percent as it opened new stores in San Francisco; Seoul, South Korea; and elsewhere to sell its fashions and leather goods. Sales rose to 2.86 billion euros ($2.48 billion) in the quarter from 2.13 billion euros in the 1999 period, the company said. September sales climbed to their highest ever. The biggest gain came from LVMH's distribution unit, which opened its first Galleria store in the United States and added Sephora perfume shops in Europe.

title: Review/Fashion; Repressed Anguish As a Virtue
description: There aren't many designers not many human beings, actually -- who could, without a hint of irony, make people listen to Bette Midler sing the theme from ''The Rose'' and still retain citizenship in the republic of the unimpeachably groovy. But Veronique Branquinho, who opened her spring 2001 show here on Tuesday night to that recording, is so firmly entrenched in the world of those who are never left out of the loft party that she could have gotten away with playing the theme song from ''Beaches.''

The Columbia Law School faculty, staff and nearly three decades of students deeply mourn the untimely passing of Professor Kellis Parker, a member of the faculty since 1972. Professor Parker's classes in contract law and seminars on the music industry, remedies, and the roots of African-American law educated and edified many generations of students. We will deeply miss the optimism, enthusiasm and generosity he brought to every endeavor. The Law School Community extends its heartfelt sympathy to his family. A memorial service will be held this Sunday, October 15, 1:30 PM at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University Campus. title: Real Differences in the Debate
description: Gov. George W. Bush's confident performance at the presidential debate on Wednesday night rested in part on the skillful way he portrayed the differences between himself and Vice President Al Gore. On issues ranging from hate crimes to prescription drugs, the environment and education, he spoke as if he and Mr. Gore were pursuing the same goals by somewhat different means. The new, subdued Al Gore let pass several opportunities to rebut Mr. Bush's characterizations. That may be a smart tactic, but it does little to clarify the policy record of the campaign. There is nothing ''fuzzy,'' to use the governor's words, about many differences between the two candidates.

description: The New York Times plans to stake a gossamer claim to the mid-Manhattan skyline with a faceted, shimmering, semitransparent headquarters by Renzo Piano, an Italian architect who has enjoyed the international spotlight since the construction of the Centre Pompidou in Paris 23 years ago.

title: Sports in Black and White At a Virginia High School
description: Remember the Titans

title: Bosnian War Crimes Suspect Injures 4 NATO Peacekeepers, Commits Suicide
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 13 -- NATO said on Friday a Bosnian Serb war crimes suspect indicted for gang-rape detonated a hand grenade and killed himself as peacekeepers tried to arrest him.

title: Bomb Kills a Dozen People in Chechnya's Capital
description: A powerful car bomb exploded in the center of Grozny, the Chechen capital, today, killing a dozen or more people and wounding more than 20, hospital and police authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINKLER, LOIS
description: WINKLER-Lois. On October 11, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Loving mother of Ellen and Richard (Rita). Adoring grandmother of Kyle, Kerry and Kara. Dear sister of Howard Fields and the late Gerald Finkelstein. Cherished aunt, sister-in-law & friend. Service Friday, 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Colombian Rebels Said to Seize 10 Foreign Oil Workers
description: Members of the largest guerrilla group in Colombia kidnapped five American and five other foreign oil workers today in the Amazon region of Ecuador and hijacked a helicopter to take them across the Colombian border into territory they control, the Ecuadorean government said.

title: Yankees' Express Starts Pulling Away
description: The deeper the Yankees move into October, the more they look the way they usually do this time of year, confident and relaxed, on track, like the D train moving steadily through the Bronx, closing in on the city.

title: Playoff Games in Both Leagues Really Are (Yawn) Getting Longer
description: The question, as Casey Stengel never asked it, isn't "can't anyone here play this game?" but rather, can't anyone here play this game faster?

title: Franks, Facing a Rich Rival, to Receive Republican Aid
description: It isn't much, compared with the $50 million Jon S. Corzine has poured into his campaign for the United States Senate so far. But after struggling for months to raise money, the Republican candidate, Representative Bob Franks, is finally going to get a little help from his friends in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGOMERY, MARSHALL HUGH
description: MONTGOMERY-Marshall Hugh 91, retired Senior Vice-President of A.J. Lanston, New York, died Wednesday, October 11 in Delray Beach, Fla. Mr. Montgomery was a graduate of Middlebury College Class of 1931. He is survived by his wife Prudence Ingham.

title: Day-Laborer Issues Prompt Opposing Rallies
description: As the Suffolk County police continued to search yesterday for a second suspect in the beating of two Mexican day laborers last month, groups on both sides of the debate over illegal immigrants planned weekend events to rally public support.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Gore's Brother-in-Law Plays Crucial Role in the Campaign
description: As soon as the first presidential debate ended last week, Vice President Al Gore's wife, three daughters and son-in-law joined him on stage, creating a handsome family portrait for the cameras. But Mr. Gore thought the picture was incomplete. He motioned to the audience, summoning an older man with a weathered face and a shock of white hair, who bounded up, giving Mr. Gore a hearty hug and a slap on the back.

title: Corrections
description: A letter to the editor in Circuits on Thursday about computers in schools misspelled the writer's surname. She is Sara Adler, not Alder.

title: Kosovar Prisoners
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Overturns Lead-Paint Control Law, Citing 'Perfunctory' Review by City Council
description: The lead-paint control law that New York City enacted last year has been overturned by a judge who faulted the City Council for not making a required review of the law's environmental impact.

title: Power of the Press
description: Yesterday's workout was optional, and many of the Mets who showed up at Shea did not participate. The players had to show up to be available for interviews, a league rule, but Manager Bobby Valentine was not thrilled with that idea.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE RUNNING MATES

title: Palestinians May Seek General Assembly Vote to Condemn Israel
description: The Palestinian mission at the United Nations, faced with an American vow to veto any Security Council resolution on the fighting between Israel and the Palestinians, may seek a special General Assembly session to condemn the Israelis, diplomats said today.

title: Officers' Corruption Trial Under Way in Los Angeles
description: The first of what could be dozens of trials of police officers stemming from the worst police corruption scandal in this city's history began today, with a blistering attack by defense lawyers of the state's case and its potential star witness, Rafael Perez.

title: Article 2000101494126132885 -- No Title
description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

title: 'Ghetto Fabulous' Glitter Fades
description: NEW YORK  Not so long ago in New York, the Gucci flagship reopened on Fifth Avenue with a grand celebration. The store had been renovated with great expense and folks were eager to see the revitalized building which also happened to be the Gucci empire's first home in the United States.

title: Palaces Tell a Tale Of Two Empresses
description: THE one sits in life-size bronze majesty, surrounded by her generals and other illustrious men, overlooking the Ring opposite the Burgtor entrance to the Hofburg; the other displays her tiny waist  it looks to be about 17 inches  and flowing tresses on chocolate boxes in many a pastry-shop window. Although different in almost every respect, the two empresses, the 18th-century monarch Maria Theresa and her 19th-century successor Elizabeth, the wife of Francis Joseph, are alike in serving as Vienna's tutelary spirits. They are especially present in the city's two great Hapsburg palaces, the Hofburg and Schonbrunn.

title: Thousands March to U.N. To Support Palestinians
description: Thousands of Muslims closed shops, left homes and skipped classes yesterday to rail against Israeli violence and to pledge support for Palestinians during a protest march that brought the tensions of the Middle East to the East Side of Manhattan. Chants of outrage cut the autumn afternoon air until the rally ended in prayers to Allah, just yards from the United Nations complex.

title: Sports of The Times; It's a Very Long Way From Japan to Shea
description: LEGEND has it that Omar Minaya signed Timo Perez. ''He deserves the bulk of the credit because he took the ball and ran with it,'' Bobby Valentine said of the Mets' senior assistant general manager. First, however, came a handoff from the man sitting in Valentine's office yesterday, the manager's guest, invited over for the playoffs from Chiba, Japan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, JOSEPH
description: STEIN-Joseph. Beloved husband of Blanche. Loving father of Mariana, Mark, Lisa and Cheryl. Loving granddad to Yarusha, Roshina, Adam, Leah, Maddy and Emily. Loving father-in-law of Jeffrey and Douglas. Friend to all who he touched. We will miss your strength and beauty.

title: Riding the Cosmic Line, The Last Stop Is Death
description: Think of ''Straight as a Line,'' Luis Alfaro's 70-minute one-act, as a poem; it will save sorting out a lot of confusion that can come of expecting a play-as-we-know-it. Even though a man dies of AIDS onstage, it is not necessarily a work about AIDS; almost any irreversibly degenerative disease would have served. In Mr. Alfaro's poems, stories and performance pieces, wasting is a deep theme; if there were a literary laureate of the second law of thermodynamics, he would have a good claim on the title.

title: Emile Kuri, 93, Set Decorator For Movies and Disney World
description: Emile Kuri, an Oscar-winning set decorator who also contributed designs to Disneyland and Walt Disney World, died on Tuesday at the Motion Picture Country Home in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 93.

title: Israel in Shock as It Buries Mob's Victim
description: Israel buried Vadim Norzich today, and with him much of its hope for real peace.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Saturday about a proposed measure in the House of Representatives condemning the mass killings of Armenians between 1915 and 1923, as part of an Ottoman campaign to force them out of eastern Turkey, misstated the death toll accepted by Armenians. It is more than a million, not thousands.

title: Piniella Applauds Yankees Player Moves at Right Time
description: Lou Piniella spent enough time with the Yankees as player, coach, manager and general manager that he was intimately familiar with the number of players who filed through the roster's revolving door. But he never saw anything like the influx of players who filed through the door this season.

title: U. of Maryland Branch Is Beacon for Minorities in Math and Science
description: As Elton Holmes sprinted through public school by the wheat fields of Maryland's Eastern Shore, collecting top honors in science and math, smart money would have bet that the most selective universities would come courting, eager to sign up a star minority student like Mr. Holmes.

title: Zap! Rat-a-Tat-Tat! Ping! Ah, 'Tis Art Aborning
description: Are computer games our era's new art form? And what is an art form, anyway? Henry Jenkins, the director of the comparative media studies program at M.I.T., raised these and other questions in his article ''Art Form for the Digital Age,'' which appeared in the September/October 2000 issue of Technology Review. Here are excerpts.

title: Article 2000101491784886674 -- No Title
description: Cutting The Web Down to Size

title: Softbank of Japan, an Internet Investor, to Get Bank Credit Lines
description: The Softbank Corporation, one of the biggest Internet investment companies, said today that it would establish revolving credit lines with 10 banks for roughly $1.3 billion to provide more flexibility in raising money quickly.

title: Shock Waves From the Mideast, on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Own Words
description: GEORGE W. BUSH

title: Cash to Fight First Lady Used For Overhead
description: In the first half of this year, the Conservative Leadership Political Action Committee collected $5,000 -- a single contribution from a Florida retiree. Then the group hitched its fate to New York's Senate race, billing itself as the Emergency Committee to Stop Hillary Rodham Clinton, and it says that from July through September, it raised $1.9 million.

title: Whats Doing in Paris
description: In Paris's gently declining temperatures, the low-hung fall sun will still warm you outdoors, if you choose a cafe on the north side of the street, and gas heaters start going on for those who choose the southern, sunless side of the boulevards.

title: Bomb Jars Embassy, A Reminder Of Tense Tie
description: The explosion that rocked Britain's Embassy in Yemen today jarred memories of Britain's uncomfortable relationship with its former colony, and of the terrorist underworld that seems to be at work there, British experts said.

title: 2 Men, Fresh From Prison, May Hold Key to Trove of Stolen Art
description: William P. Youngworth III, the antiques dealer who claimed three years ago that he could broker the return of the immensely valuable paintings stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here, is back.

title: In France, a New Class Reinvents the Good Life : 'Bobo' Style Has It Both Ways
description: PARIS  The French have embraced a new expression to describe those who have it all: Bobo. The term is short for bourgeois and bohemian, two social castes no one ever expected to find mixed up together.

title: Shock Waves From the Mideast, on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:

title: If you go
description: Schonbrunn Palace is open daily 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. November through March, and 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. April through October; the grounds are open daily from 6 a.m. to sunset. Of the two self-guided tours, the longer, which includes 45 rooms and costs about $8 (at 15.6 Austrian schillings to $1), is recommended. The carriage museum is open 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Tuesday to Sunday, November through March, and daily from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. April through October; admission is about $4.

title: Club Owner Pleads Guilty in Mob Murder Case
description: Facing the start of his trial in four days, a Miami nightclub owner pleaded guilty yesterday to committing murder and armed robbery in the service of a violent Brooklyn Mafia crew.

title: Rested Bordick Should Start
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine said he expected shortstop Mike Bordick to start Game 3 of the National League Championship Series today. Bordick was hit on the knuckle of his right thumb by a pitch from the Cardinals' Mike James in Game 1 and did not start Game 2.

title: Chevron Nears Deal To Acquire Texaco
description: Chevron, the nation's third-largest oil company, is close to an agreement to acquire Texaco for about $36 billion in stock plus the assumption of debt, executives close to the negotiations said. Both boards are planning to meet, and the deal could be announced as early as Monday.

title: Sports of The Times; For Justice, A Gentler Place to Play
description: NOTHING David Justice heard over his shoulder last night could ever match the crude and malicious taunts he used to hear in Yankee Stadium.

title: Different Views, Similar Feelings
description: The noon prayers at Omar's Mosque on Getty Avenue ended about 2 o'clock. Afterward, hundreds of worshipers filed out, somber and grim-faced, and walked two blocks to the buses waiting to take them to the anti-Israel demonstration on Manhattan's East Side.

title: LONDON STOCK EXCHANGE BID
description: OM Gruppen, the parent of the Stockholm stock exchange, increased its bid for the London Stock Exchange by as much as 53 percent, to $:1.06 billion, or $1.54 billion, in an effort to woo shareholders who had dismissed its original offer as too low. Under the new terms, OM Gruppen is offering the holders a choice between an all-stock deal valued at $:35.83 a share and a mixture of stock and cash valued at $:32.79 a share. The London exchange, which has been resisting the takeover effort since it was announced Aug. 29, called the sweetened offer inadequate. Suzanne Kapner

title: Al Hirschfeld Drops Suit and Resumes Ties With Gallery
description: Al Hirschfeld, the caricaturist famous for his witty portraits of stage and screen stars, has dropped a lawsuit against Margo Feiden, the gallery owner who for 30 years had exclusive rights to the sale of his work.

title: Palaces Tell a Tale Of Two Empresses
description: THE one sits in life-size bronze majesty, surrounded by her generals and other illustrious men, overlooking the Ring opposite the Burgtor entrance to the Hofburg; the other displays her tiny waist  it looks to be about 17 inches  and flowing tresses on chocolate boxes in many a pastry-shop window. Although different in almost every respect, the two empresses, the 18th-century monarch Maria Theresa and her 19th-century successor Elizabeth, the wife of Francis Joseph, are alike in serving as Vienna's tutelary spirits. They are especially present in the city's two great Hapsburg palaces, the Hofburg and Schonbrunn.

title: INSIDE
description: South Korean Leader Wins Nobel Peace Prize

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, KELLIS
description: PARKER-Kellis. The Columbia Law School faculty, staff and nearly three decades of students deeply mourn the untimely passing of Professor Kellis Parker, a member of the faculty since 1972. Professor Parker's classes in contract law and seminars on the music industry, remedies, and the roots of African-American law educated and edified many generations of students. We will deeply miss the optimism, enthusiasm and generosity he brought to every endeavor. The Law School Community extends its heartfelt sympathy to his family. A memorial service will be held this Sunday, October 15, at 1:30 P.M., at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University Campus. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that gifts be made to Columbia Law School for the Kellis E. Parker Memorial Scholarship Fund. Dean David W. Leebron and The Columbia Law School Community

title: Clemens Pitches One-Hitter in Yankees Win
description: SEATTLE -- Nothing is working for the Seattle Mariners anymore -- especially their hitting.

title: Lieberman on Attack Over Texas Shantytowns
description: Hammering again at Gov. George W. Bush's record in Texas, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman today visited one of the desperately poor shantytowns strung along the Rio Grande, accusing the governor of failing to improve conditions there.

title: Shock Waves From the Mideast, on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZLIZH, HARRY
description: HERZLIZH-Harry. Temple BethEl of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: All the Basics Of a Mexico Trip
description: AS temperatures drop in much of the United States, travelers' daydreams may turn to Mexico. Its warm climate, relaxed pace, miles of beaches and value continue to attract visitors from the north; the Mexico-United States border is one of the busiest in the world.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits last Saturday with a television review of the new romantic comedy series ''Ed,'' on NBC, included an erroneous identification from the network. The production designer is Chris Shriver, not Patricia Goldstein.

title: Cell Phones on the Road
description: To the Editor:

title: From a Slab of Brute Force To Lyrical Sophistication
description: Miller Theater continues to be a source of excellent things in terms of new music. On Tuesday evening Speculum Musicae, an ensemble happily on an upturn, offered much strong playing in some stark choices: primitivism raw (in Iannis Xenakis's ''Eonta'') or measured (in Varese's ''Ecuatorial''), sophistication of tone color (in Tristan Murail's ''Desintegrations'') or of line and harmony and subject matter (in Elliott Carter's ''Tempo e tempi'').

title: The Occasion for Arab Diplomacy
description: This is a critical moment for moderate Arab leaders to try to restore calm between Palestinians and Israelis. Since Anwar el-Sadat negotiated with Israel at Camp David 22 years ago, the evolution of peace diplomacy in the Middle East has drawn strength from moderate Arab leaders like Mr. Sadat's successor as Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, and King Hussein of Jordan and King Hassan of Morocco.

title: Los Angeles Designers Celebrate City's Diversity
description: LOS ANGELES  As a booming economy feeds the city's growing apparel industry, Los Angeles is emerging from the Big Apple's shadow. While New York saw a 16 percent decline in apparel manufacturing jobs between 1993 and 1998, Los Angeles experienced a 19 percent increase over the same period. The time may be right for Los Angeles designers to find their place on the international fashion scene.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first and second days of Sukkot, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side street cleaning regulations will be suspended today and tomorrow.

title: Essay: Making the Connection In a Faraway World
description: PERHAPS it is because I left my country, Cuba, at 16, but when I travel I search for home. I don't mean I actually look at real estate listings, although I've been known to do that. My quest is more spiritual than physical.

title: Superpower Suddenly Finds Itself Threatened by Sophisticated Terrorists
description: The explosion that ripped apart the destroyer Cole was more than just another terrorist attack. It achieved a new degree of sophistication.

title: Correspondents Report
description: Crew Members Fault Air Quality on 777's THE Boeing 777, the jewel in the fleet of many of the world's largest airlines, may be more likely to make passengers feel dizzy or nauseated than other, older airplanes, according to anecdotal reports from crew members and passengers.

title: European Regulators Clear Vivendi Deal With Seagram
description: The European Commission officially approved the $34 billion acquisition of the Seagram Company by the French conglomerate Vivendi today after the companies promised concessions to dilute the power of their combined business, which will be a major force in entertainment and telecommunications.

title: U.S. Officials Tell of Getting Warning Last Month, but Say It Was Too Vague
description: The United States received a general warning of a possible attack on an American warship last month, senior defense officials said here today, but the warning lacked detail and did not specify the country in which to expect the attack.

title: Korea Stakes a Claim to Place on World Stage
description: SEOUL  In a society noted for styles ranging from derivative to imitative, South Korean fashion houses are stepping out this month to show they can make it on their own  at least for export.

title: Toll Rises to 17 in Ship Blast, as U.S. Hunts Suspects
description: Seventeen sailors were killed in the blast on the destroyer Cole on Thursday, the United States Navy announced tonight, after divers spent the day searching the harbor bed for bodies and for clues to the explosion's cause.

title: Beirut Army Reins In Angry Protesters
description: Lebanon's border with Israel was quiet today as the Lebanese Army and local Palestinian officials confined angry Palestinian protests to their refugee camps.

title: Highflying Asian Start-Up Returns Abruptly to Earth
description: For more than a year, Richard Li floated in the gossamer winds of cyberspace. A few weeks ago, gravity began exerting its pull. Today, Mr. Li landed with a hard thud.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC., Woodland Hills, Calif., the third-largest shipbuilder for the United States Navy, said it would build an oil tanker for the Phillips Petroleum Co., Bartlesville, Okla., the sixth-largest oil company, valued at $197 million.

title: Op-Art
Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, SIDNEY
description: GROSSMAN-Sidney, M.D. On October 13, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Service Monday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Masonic Service 11:00 am.

title: Tanker Fire On L.I. Linked To Old Defect
description: Investigators for the National Transportation Safety Board say that a fiery gasoline tanker accident that killed a Suffolk County woman last month may have been caused by a common safety problem with tankers that was pinpointed more than a decade ago but has not been corrected.

title: Riches the Hapsburgs Sent to the Attic
description: SOON after the Hapsburg monarchy collapsed in 1918, the Austrian president set up offices in the former Imperial Palace in Vienna and began receiving official visitors in what was once Empress Maria Theresa's bedroom. Its royal family having gone into exile, Austria placed the glittering crowns and silver on public display.

title: Making Playoffs Hinges on Beating the Beatable
description: Football players and coaches never admit to looking past a coming opponent. The reality is that every team is aware that a 16-game schedule has its perilous stages and its periods of opportunity. The focus may be week to week; the understanding is that success is measured in groups of games.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Zeile Learned Quickly to Handle the Scrutiny
description: Todd Zeile figured he would hear about it. He has been reminded of his error in Game 3 of the 1996 American League Championship Series for four years and has come to view it in a healthy way. "It's an interesting anecdote to my career," said Zeile, the Mets first baseman.

title: Shock Waves From the Mideast, on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Music Critics Get New Roles
description: Bernard Holland, who has been the chief music critic of The New York Times for five years, has been named to the new position of national music critic.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: BANNED IN BOSTON

title: Shock Waves From the Mideast, on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:

title: Arafat and Barak to Meet in Emergency Summit
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 14 - After more than two weeks of spiraling violence that cost nearly 100 lives, Israeli and Palestinian leaders agreed today to meet with President Clinton in Egypt to seek a truce and perhaps even a way back to the peace table.

title: Redefining Their Rap Without Raunch or Guns
description: The most influential critics of gangsta rap aren't writing articles or holding Senate hearings. They're rapping themselves, determined to redefine real hip-hop as something more expansive, intelligent and uplifting than the current best-selling cliches of gunplay and raunch.

title: If you go
description: Tours in English and German are offered by Dr. Brigitte Timmermann, (43-1) 774 8901, fax (43-1) 774 8933; e-mail to brigitte@viennawalks.tix.at; Web: www.viennawalks.tix.at. They take place at 4 p.m. Mondays and Fridays; private tours given by special arrangement. Group two-hour tours are $12 a person, at 15.6 Austrian schillings to the dollar; $11 with a Vienna card. (The card costs $11.50 and is good for 72 hours of unlimited travel on public transportation, with discounts for museums, restaurants and many guided tours.)

title: Article 2000101491741668440 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINT, EDNA
description: QUINT-Edna. Temple Israel, Lawrence, New York, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends deepest sympathy to the bereaved family. Allen Kaplan, Rabbi Alan Hartstein, President

title: OIL PRIVATIZATION IN ANGOLA
description: Angola plans to sell off as much as 49 percent of the domestic distribution and marketing arm of the state oil company, Sonagol, the official news agency reported. Despite Angola's protracted civil war, the country has become sub-Saharan Africa's second-biggest oil producer, after Nigeria, even as Angola's population remains one of the poorest in the world. By next year, Angola, which is emerging as an important United States supplier, hopes to be pumping a million barrels a day. Henri E. Cauvin

title: New Coach Helps Van Horn Change Direction
description: Keith Van Horn had his left knee wrapped in ice but he was still smiling, if not glowing, under the lights of the Nets' practice facility. They seem to be casting a sunny tint in the swamplands this year.

title: Article 2000101492956630406 -- No Title
description: October 13, 2000

title: Viennas Haunting Third Man Theme
description: IN 1948, when Carol Reed and Graham Greene started work on "The Third Man," they had in mind a thriller infused with Greene's famous moral ambiguity and haunting sense of place. They wound up producing not just a cinematic landmark but also what many regard as a valuable documentary, a kind of time capsule, of post-World War II Vienna.

title: Colombia Rebels Deny They Kidnapped Foreign Oil Workers
description: The largest guerrilla group in Colombia has denied reports that it kidnapped 10 foreign oil workers on Thursday in the Amazon region of Ecuador, further clouding the fate of the captives, who were apparently flown by a hijacked helicopter into Colombia.

title: Both Parties Break Records For Donations At This Stage
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has raised $125 million in six months for the Republican National Committee, more than twice the $60 million that Vice President Al Gore has raised for the Democratic National Committee, according to officials from both parties.

title: ORANGE SALE NEXT YEAR
description: France's dominant phone company, France Telecom, said it would sell shares in Orange, the mobile phone business it bought from Vodafone AirTouch, early next year. The statement comes as a steep decline in the share prices of many telecommunications stocks has caused analysts to question whether certain large equity deals scheduled to come to market in the next few months will proceed as planned. France Telecom declined to comment on whether the size of the Orange offering would be scaled back from original expectations.

title: Quibbling Over Taxes as Nassau Refinances Debt
description: As the state panel overseeing Nassau County's fiscal crisis voted today to refinance a chunk of the county's mammoth debt, Republican and Democratic legislators seemed more inclined to quibble over property taxes: how high to raise them when they pass a budget next week.

title: Serene and Restless, Freely Juxtaposed
description: Two-tenor bands -- small jazz groups with two tenor saxophones out front -- are a bit rare and special; with the overabundance of deep, rich sound onstage, there has to be a considerable difference in style between the saxophonists to make it work. The quartet led by the young bassist Chris Lightcap, which opened on Thursday night at the Knitting Factory's Old Office (74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa), has that distinction.

title: Viennas Haunting Third Man Theme
description: IN 1948, when Carol Reed and Graham Greene started work on "The Third Man," they had in mind a thriller infused with Greene's famous moral ambiguity and haunting sense of place. They wound up producing not just a cinematic landmark but also what many regard as a valuable documentary, a kind of time capsule, of post-World War II Vienna.

title: South Korean President Wins Nobel Peace Prize For Efforts to Heal Rift
description: President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea, a longtime champion of democracy whose tireless push for national reconciliation led to a groundbreaking summit meeting between the divided Koreas in June, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize today.

title: The Price of America's Naivete
description: History is long and merciless in the Middle East. The suicide boat-bombing of the U.S.S. Cole in the port of Aden, Yemen, and the turmoil in Israel, Gaza and the West Bank are, above all else, violent expressions of the age-old confrontation between Islam and the West. America, no less than Israel, is inextricably tied to the Muslim-Christian tug-of-war that began in the seventh century when Arab armies first conquered Palestine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISELS, MARGARET
description: MEISELS-Margaret. Of Teaneck, NJ, and formerly of Los Angeles, CA, was laid to rest on Friday, October 13. Loving mother of Allen (Peggy), Steve (Jill) and Ida. Adored grandmother of Jessica, Lauren, Blair and Alexis Meisels, and Jesse Shapiro. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her, especially her Linda. She is now reunited with husband, Leo.

title: Cradle of a Political Dynasty
description: LET me have my Farm, Family, and Goose Quil, and all the Honours and Offices this World can bestow, may go to those who deserve them better, and desire them more. I covet them not," John Adams wrote to his wife, Abigail, in 1776.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Poem Inspires Echoes of Jazz and Ice
description: Wolfgang Sawallisch's concerts with the Philadelphia Orchestra have typically had a sense of Germanic propriety: everything is in place, yet the music-making can seem safe or even stolid. But at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, Mr. Sawallisch and his players sounded unusually youthful and vigorous, perhaps because they played a program that demanded as much.

title: A Dirty Job, But It Seems More People Want to Do It; Planting the Seeds for a Resurgence of the Small Farm
description: After a full day of plucking and pulling at beans, peppers and potatoes, Amy Sprague is thinking about tomorrow morning, and all the kale, collards and cilantro she has to gather before heading to the farmers' market. The late-rising sun means that she and her co-workers are hitting the fields later these days. ''We're doing 6:30 now,'' she says, concealing whether she considers it an unwelcome delay, or a half-hour of extra sleep.

title: Shock Waves From the Mideast, on Two Fronts

title: Religion Journal; Honoring Christian Science Founder
description: In trying to describe New England in spiritual terms one is likely to evoke a place identified with a religious establishment, whether that be the Puritans of 350 years ago, their Congregationalist heirs or, most recently, such important Roman Catholic jurisdictions as the Archdiocese of Boston.

title: Shock Waves From the Mideast, on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:
