description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNET, LILLIAN
description: BENNET-Lillian. Sisterhood of Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the death of a longtime member and former president. She was a lovely and gracious lady and will be sorely missed. Matilda G. Goldberg, President

title: Corrections
description: A table in the World Business section on Wednesday showing the previous day's closing prices for United States stock indexes misstated the figure for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. It closed at 1,387.02, not 1,387.94 -- down 15.01 points for the day, not 16.09. That was a decline of 1.07 percent, not 1.15.

title: Shock Waves From the Mideast, on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:

title: Vienna, Where Ethereal Strudels Meet Savory Schnitzels
description: ON a recent trip to Vienna there was a fall bite in the air. Although it was still warm enough to have cake and coffee at a sidewalk cafe, the leaves were turning, and signs of autumn were evident on every menu. In addition to the year-round dumplings, strudels, schnitzels and sacher tortes, there was an abundance of wild mushrooms, pumpkins, venison and boar.

title: The World, As Filtered By the City
description: AS the self-proclaimed capital of the world, New York City has long reserved the right to its own foreign policy.

title: Heating Oil Falls
description: Profit taking contributed to a decline in home heating oil, which fell after a run-up on Thursday. In New York, heating oil for November delivery fell 6.12 cents, to $1.02 a gallon.

title: Col. Pat Porteous Dies at 82; World War II Hero for Britain
description: Col. Pat Porteous, who as a captain in the British commandos received the Victoria Cross, the British Commonwealth's highest award for valor, for leading a bayonet charge on a major German gun battery during the Dieppe raid in World War II, died Monday. He was 82.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about Democratic efforts to regain control of the House of Representatives incorrectly summarized statements from Adam Putnam, a Republican candidate in the 12th District of Florida, about the use of commercials in the race. While Mr. Putnam said television commercials had never been used in elections in the 12th District, he did not say he saw no need for them in his race against Mike Stedem.

title: Connecticut College Leader Plans to Resign in Spring
description: The president of Connecticut College, who has been a primary architect in remaking its hometown, New London, as well as the college, said yesterday that she would step down in June after taking a sabbatical during the spring semester.

title: Jury Finds for Police Officer Who Claimed Harassment
description: A federal jury in Manhattan yesterday awarded $1.25 million in damages to a former officer who had accused the Police Department of retaliating because she complained that she had been sexually harassed on the job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERANI, NORMAN
description: ERANI-Norman ''Nissim''. Beloved husband of Dorine, devoted father to Vivian, Olivia and Jane, and sweet inspiration to his grandchildren, Seth, Lisa, Darya and Juliette, a tzadik and leader of his Community. Funeral services at 10 AM on Monday, October 16 at Riverside-Nassau North, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Civil Rights Versus States' Rights
description: The heated debate in the Supreme Court on the scope of federal authority over the states reached a pivotal moment this week. The justices heard arguments in an Alabama case that bears not only on the civil rights of disabled Americans but, more broadly, on Congress's power to enforce constitutional guarantees of equal protection.

title: Torre's Plan: Get Yanks to the Station
description: The Yankees and the Mets have work to do before the Subway Series becomes a reality, and Manager Joe Torre said that first he was focusing on ''our part of it.''

title: Seeing the Tango Through the Filters of the Classical
description: All looked right with the world when two ebullient young women in pink tutus bounced out at the start of the program by Julio Bocca and his Ballet Argentino on Wednesday night at City Center. True, Mr. Bocca has no more luck than the next company director finding choreography as good as the dancers, to judge from some of the dances on the program. But the freshness and spirit of this 10-year-old company are irresistible. And with the leavening of sensuous charisma offered by Mr. Bocca, a seasoned international ballet star, the evening was a happy one.

title: Islanders Searching For Success At Home
description: What the Islanders need tonight, Coach Butch Goring said, is some good home cooking.

title: It's a Senator's Seniority vs. Youth
description: In this tiny state of 750,000 people, which takes pride in its moderate traditions and civil campaigns, voters seem truly torn over having to choose between two of their favorite politicians, now rivals in one of the nation's most hotly contested Senate races.

title: RANGERS DEMOTE PURINTON
description: The Rangers insist that Dale Purinton is part of their future. However, Purinton, a 24-year-old defenseman, is obviously not in the team's current plans.

title: Leaders Also Approve 200 Million for Serbia : EU Seeks Stable Oil Prices
description: BIARRITZ, France  Leaders of the European Union said Friday they would seek a "reasonable and stable" price for oil in talks with the petroleum-producing countries and appealed for an emergency summit meeting on Middle East peace.

title: National News Briefs
description: Astronauts Rendezvous With Space Station

title: Shock Waves From the Mideast, on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:

title: For casual dining, with coffee or wine
description: There are at least three typically Viennese modes of casual eating: the cafe, the heuriger (wine tavern) and the stand-up sandwicherie.

title: NEW CONCERNS RISE ON KEEPING TRACK OF MODIFIED CORN
description: Efforts to trace shipments of a bioengineered corn unapproved for human consumption have raised concern among food and grain industry officials that the corn -- which has already been discovered in two brands of grocery products -- may have made its way more widely into production channels for the nation's food supply.

title: Cradle of a Political Dynasty
description: LET me have my Farm, Family, and Goose Quil, and all the Honours and Offices this World can bestow, may go to those who deserve them better, and desire them more. I covet them not," John Adams wrote to his wife, Abigail, in 1776.

title: Hot Dogs Recalled Over Contamination
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  A Tennessee company has recalled 900,000 pounds of hot dogs and suspended production of frankfurters after tests found that the meat may be contaminated with dangerous bacteria.

title: After Health Setback, Running Hard in North Dakota
description: THERE is a certain pep to the step of the candidate wearing the warm-pink blazer and black leather heels at this midmorning gubernatorial debate inside a half-filled, sleepy college auditorium. But the race is not given to the swift.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'STEEN, SAM
description: O'STEEN - Sam. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the sudden death of our devoted member, Sam O'Steen. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his beloved wife, Barbara, daughters Molly and Daniele, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Senior Rabbi Mark Biderman, President

title: Conflict, as a Ghost Lurks Sadly at the Podium
description: In ways that could not have been anticipated when the repertory was chosen months ago, Leonard Bernstein nearly showed up for the New York Philharmonic subscription series commemorating the 10th anniversary of his death today: Bernstein the blustering, bullying humanist taking all suffering personally, as well as composer. Although the carefully regulated dose of his music, the ''Jeremiah'' Symphony, is dispensed quickly at the start of the program, it proved singularly appropriate at the first performance, on Thursday, after the loss of Israeli, Palestinian and American lives in the Middle East.

title: Travel Advisory
description: AMANDATORY STOP, EVEN IF IT'S NOT NECESSARY Along with bungee jumping, spectacular scenery and friendly people, New Zealand now boasts a public bathroom on its list of tourist attractions.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The dollar rose to a three-week high against the euro as U.S. stocks surged, bringing the euro below its supported level last month. In New York, the euro settled at 85.44 cents, down from 86.22 on Thursday.

title: Producer Prices Jumped 0.9% in September, Mostly Because of Oil
description: American manufacturers were able to charge surprisingly high prices for their goods in September, the government reported yesterday, but most analysts said the increases were probably not a harbinger of broader inflation. Investors seemed to agree, as major stock indexes rose.

title: U.S. Base in Germany Receives Remains of First 5 Sailors
description: The remains of five United States Navy seamen, killed on Thursday during an explosion on the destroyer Cole in Yemen, arrived here aboard the first of several Air Force cargo planes that are evacuating the dead and wounded.

title: No Angst This October For the Pettitte Family
description: A passive, relaxed observer of baseball, Tom Pettitte is not. He studies games like an extra coach. He wants to know if his son, Andy, has his fingers with or against the seams of the baseball. He wants to know what Don Zimmer just whispered to Joe Torre in the dugout.

title: Shock Waves From the Mideast, on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:

title: William M. Farrell, 89; Reported for Times
description: William Melville Farrell, a former reporter for The New York Times, died at a nursing home in Huntington, N.Y., on Sunday. He was 89.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Tuesday about Democratic efforts to regain control of the House of Representatives incorrectly summarized statements from Adam Putnam, a Republican candidate in the 12th District of Florida, about the use of commercials in the race. While Mr. Putnam said television commercials had never been used in elections in the 12th District, he did not say he saw no need for them in his race against Mike Stedem.

title: If you go
description: Schonbrunn Palace is open daily 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. November through March, and 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. April through October; the grounds are open daily from 6 a.m. to sunset. Of the two self-guided tours, the longer, which includes 45 rooms and costs about $8 (at 15.6 Austrian schillings to $1), is recommended. The carriage museum is open 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Tuesday to Sunday, November through March, and daily from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. April through October; admission is about $4.

title: Buenos Aires Journal; Errant Soccer Star Tells Not Quite All
description: Move over Jorge Luis Borges. Here comes Diego Maradona.

title: To the Party, Victor's Exile Invalidates China Nobel
description: For decades, Chinese intellectuals have brooded over the lack of a Chinese Nobel laureate in literature, half blaming the outside world for its ignorance, half wondering if their artists are up to standards and always bemoaning the severe language barrier. Only this week, a popular newspaper here ran articles on what it called the ''Nobel blues.''

title: Article 2000101490088144883 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: First Lady Admits Error; Lazio Calls It Crime
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that she took ''full responsibility'' for her campaign's improper solicitation of political contributions last month, but insisted that it was unintentional and isolated and would not be repeated.

title: Marshall McLuhan Is Back From the Dustbin of History; With the Internet, His Ideas Again Seem Ahead of Their Time
description: Until relatively recently, the media guru Marshall McLuhan, with his gnomic pronouncements about ''acoustic space'' and ''cool'' media and ''square'' people, appeared to be a dated artifact of 1960's culture destined to go the way of tie-dyed shirts, Peter Max posters and Timothy Leary. ''Once exalted as oracular, Marshall McLuhan's theories now seem laughably inadequate as an intellectual guide to our times,'' one critic wrote in 1987, seven years after his death.

title: Manuel Martin, 66, Playwright On the Cuban Life in the U.S.
description: Manuel Martin, a director and playwright who used theater to explore the Cuban experience in the United States, died on Sept. 28 in Manhattan. He was 66 and lived in Manhattan.

title: At Safeco, Mariners' Offense Fizzles
description: They collected enough hits to hold a garage sale, but the scoring funk continued for the Seattle Mariners tonight as fizzled rallies and the frustrated superstars Alex Rodriguez and Edgar Martinez highlighted an 8-2 loss to the Yankees.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- No events.

title: Devils Can't Shake The Rust, Falling Short in Ottowa
description: There comes a point when rest turns to rust. The Devils, idle since their season-opening victory last Friday, demonstrated their sluggishness from the long layoff tonight with a flat-footed first period as they fell behind the Ottawa Senators by a goal at the Corel Center.

title: Bush Leads G.O.P. Criticism of Gore Over Russian Arms
description: Gov. George W. Bush said today that he was troubled by a report that Russia was continuing to deliver conventional arms to Iran in violation of a deal signed by Vice President Al Gore in 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKE, CAROL
description: PARKE-Carol (nee Phillips), 88, of Denville, NJ, October 13, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Stephen Parke. Best friend and mother of Jill (Ronald) Levitt and Barbara (Robert Reff) Parke, loving grandmother of Justin, Brendon, Tracy and Jeremy. Donations to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, PO Box 650309, Dallas TX 75265.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDLICH, DR. THEODORE
description: EDLICH-Dr. Theodore, Jr. On October 13, 2000. Retired Internist at Saint Clares and Cabrini Hospitals. Devoted husband of DeDe and the late Virginia. Beloved father of Theodore III, Dr. Richard and the late Stephen. Dear grandfather and great-grandfather. Dear brother of Marguerite Volmer and uncle of Robert Volmer. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to: The Multiple Sclerosis Foundation or Diabetes Foundation. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20 Street), New York City, Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services will be held at the funeral home Monday at 11:30 AM. Interment at Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Essay: Making the Connection In a Faraway World
description: PERHAPS it is because I left my country, Cuba, at 16, but when I travel I search for home. I don't mean I actually look at real estate listings, although I've been known to do that. My quest is more spiritual than physical.

title: JAPANESE LEASE COMPANY NEAR COLLAPSE
description: Nippon Shinpan, Japan's biggest credit card company, said it might liquidate its debt-ridden affiliate the Inter-Lease Corporation. The move would be one of the country's biggest corporate failures since World War II. The leasing unit is on the verge of collapse because of its liabilities of 774 billion yen ($7.2 billion) and 277 billion yen in bad debts as of August, said Hidetaka Yotsuji, a Nippon Shinpan managing director. Creditors will agree to liquidate, said two of the banks that are owed money.

title: ROLLS GETS SINGAPORE JUMBO ORDER
description: Securing an order that could be worth as much as $1.5 billion, Rolls-Royce of Britain beat GE/Pratt & Whitney in a deal to supply Singapore Airlines with the engines for its superjumbo Airbus A3XX aircraft. Last month, Singapore Airlines said it would spend $8.6 billion to buy 25 of the Airbus planes, giving the European consortium a crucial endorsement for the new aircraft, which can carry more passengers than Boeing's 747 models. The first of the new airplanes is scheduled to arrive in 2006. Wayne Arnold

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the arrest of a Maspeth, Queens, man on charges that he attacked two Mexican day laborers on Long Island included an erroneous report from neighbors about the suspect's school history and misstated a school's address. Christ the King, a Roman Catholic high school, is in Middle Village, not Flushing. It said it had no record of the suspect, Ryan Wagner, 19.

title: DIGITAL CREATIVE WILL SPIN OFF RESTAURANT BUSINESS
description: The Digital Creative Development Corporation, the restaurant operator that is remaking itself into an entertainment company, said yesterday that it would spin off its Arthur Treacher's Fish and Chips and Pudgie's Famous Chicken restaurant chains to focus on its new business. Digital changed its name from Arthur Treacher's in August. Its shareholders will receive shares in two separate companies when the restaurant operations are spun off, expected later this year after Digital completes its purchase of closely held Pudgie's Famous Chicken, said a company spokesman.

title: On Shabby Chic Side of Tokyo
description: TOKYO  One of the problems with Tokyo is that the districts are too clearly defined by demographics. Over-40 businessmen go to Shimbashi, where tiny bars are crammed into alleys. Teenagers have practically sealed off a place called Shibuya as their personal fort. Young and wealthy housewives have transformed Jiyugaoka, a former quiet, residential area, into a giant three-dimensional Williams-Sonoma shopping catalogue.

title: Cone and Gooden Reside in Uncertain New World
description: SEATTLE -- There is a gnawing sensation in the pit of the stomach that both Doc Gooden and David Cone associate with their new residence in the bullpen.

title: A Reprise of Mrs. Clinton's Top Themes
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign for Senate began broadcasting last night.

title: Arafat and Barak to Meet in Emergency Summit
description: JERUSALEM -- Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat agreed Saturday to attend a summit aimed at ending the worst Israeli-Palestinian violence in decades, dropping his demand for what had been a deal-breaker -- an international commission of inquiry into the fighting.

title: Travel Q & A: Como Without a Car...Around Antalya...Chesapeake Cruises
description: Como Without a Car

title: Vienna, Where Ethereal Strudels Meet Savory Schnitzels
description: ON a recent trip to Vienna there was a fall bite in the air. Although it was still warm enough to have cake and coffee at a sidewalk cafe, the leaves were turning, and signs of autumn were evident on every menu. In addition to the year-round dumplings, strudels, schnitzels and sacher tortes, there was an abundance of wild mushrooms, pumpkins, venison and boar.

title: Article 2000101490694905267 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Arafat and Barak to Meet in Emergency Summit
description: President Clinton said Saturday he will attend a Middle East summit Monday in Egypt with Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak andPalestinian leader Yasser Arafat.

title: Article 2000101490194857561 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Clinton Orders an Auction Of Underused Airwaves

title: AGILENT TO SELL EQUIPMENT DIVISION TO CIT GROUP
description: Agilent Technologies Inc., the Hewlett-Packard Company spinoff that makes test and measurement equipment, said the commercial finance company CIT Group would buy Agilent's equipment-financing and leasing business. Terms were not disclosed. CIT, based in Livingston, N.J., will form a unit called Agilent Financial Services Inc. The CIT unit will lease and finance equipment to Agilent customers, as well as others. Agilent will continue to sell equipment to the unit. Agilent makes communications and analysis equipment used in the electronics, health care and semiconductor industries.

title: High Hopes for Seton Hall, but First Up, a Little Fun
description: When Tommy Amaker was hired to rebuild Seton Hall three years ago, he refused to play host to Midnight Madness, instead choosing to begin the preseason in a low-key manner.

title: Cardinals Regain Face With Win Over Mets
description: NEW YORK -- The St. Louis Cardinals sent a clear message from the start: Don't stock up on those subway tokens just yet.

title: Blaming Immigrants
description: Next time you are stuck in traffic, blame an immigrant. That seems to be the message of a deplorable advertising campaign by the Federation for American Immigration Reform (FAIR), an advocacy group that seeks to restrict immigration. FAIR's broadcast and print ads highlight the ills associated with suburban sprawl, then point to immigration as the underlying culprit. FAIR ran anti-sprawl commercials earlier this year in Iowa and South Carolina during the primary season, and is now concentrating on the Washington D.C. area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, JOHN FRANCIS
description: RYAN-John Francis, 88, on October 11, 2000, of Brightwaters, LI. Devoted husband of the late Catherine Muller Ryan. Cherished father of John F. Ryan, Jr., Patricia Armstrong, Elizabeth Torphy, Frances McKeon, Jean Casey, Robert K. Ryan and Mary Pat Ryan. Fun-loving grandfather of 14 and one step great grandson. Beloved father-in-law of Katherine Bell Ryan, Frederic Torphy, Kevin McKeon and William Casey. Beloved brother of William J. Ryan. Senior Vice President, Group Insurance and Actuary for New York Life Insurance Company, where he was employed for over 40 years. Former member of the Board of Directors of Good Samaritan Hospital and St. John's University. Reposing at The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Highway (1/4 mile west of Robert Moses Cswy). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bay Shore, LI on Saturday 8:45 AM. Interment St. Patrick's Cemetery, Bay Shore, LI. Visiting Friday 2-4PM and 7-9PM.

title: Hard Way, Easy Way, It's All The Same to the Computer
description: The closest finish in any of the world championships decided last month in Maastricht, the Netherlands, attracted no attention at all, perhaps because there were no emotional humans loudly proclaiming victory. It was the World Computer Bridge Championship, organized by Al Levy of Stony Brook, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLMAN, MICHAEL
description: WOLLMAN-Michael. New York Metropolitan Region of The United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism mourns the untimely loss of the brother of our Vice President Carole Korowitz. Our condolences to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Eugene D. Zinbarg, President Bruce F. Greenfield, Exec Dir

title: Dior Parody Reveals Dilemma for Designers Balancing Two Labels : Balenciaga's Angels Soar, Galliano Crashes
description: PARIS  An angelic collection from Balenciaga  all cascading white dresses that were pretty yet edgy  contrasted with a vile show from John Galliano that was a parody of the worst of his Dior designs.

title: DOUBLECLICK SHARES FALL AFTER COMPANY ISSUES WARNING
description: DoubleClick Inc. shares fell more than 31 percent after the Internet advertising company said that sales will slow during the next six months, and that its third-quarter loss widened. The shares dropped $5.69, to $12.44. Internet ad spending will slow down from the year-earlier pace in the fourth quarter of this year and the first quarter of next year, the company said. Money flowing into Internet companies from initial public share sales and investments has slowed, so online advertising will not grow as fast in the next few quarters as it did in the last year, said Kevin Ryan, DoubleClick's chief executive.

title: Fast-Track Certification Program For Teachers to Expand Tenfold
description: Facing a state-imposed deadline to get thousands of uncertified teachers out of New York City classrooms, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy will expand, almost tenfold, a fledgling program that offers novices a crash course in teaching and grants them an alternative form of certification.

title: Bill of fare
description: Many Viennese restaurants add cover charges of $1.25 to $4 a person to the bill. But it is also customary to tip up to 10 percent, which is considered generous. Prices are based on a meal for two with a bottle of wine but no tip. Smoking is allowed in all these restaurants, and unless specified, they accept all major credit cards.

title: Review/Fashion; At Saint Laurent, Tom Ford Speaks With His Own Voice
description: In the end, all the anticipation that had been mounting in the days before Tom Ford's first show tonight for Yves Saint Laurent ran out like the wind in a balloon. The collection was good, not great, but more important, Mr. Ford found a way through the dense vocabulary of Saint Laurent to say his own thing.

title: Bid to Call Summit Talks Fails as Palestinians Balk Unless Israel Lifts 'Siege'
description: Intensive efforts to convene an emergency summit meeting of Israeli, Palestinian, American and Egyptian leaders ended without success early today, with the Palestinians continuing to insist that Israel must first lift its ''siege.''

title: IMAX SALE CANCELED
description: The Imax Corporation, the Canadian designer of giant movie screens and high-technology sound systems, canceled plans to sell itself after the price of its shares dropped 70 percent on Thursday on a warning that third-quarter results would be lower than expected. The shares fell $10.22, to $4.28, on Thursday; yesterday they gained $1, closing at $5.28. In a statement, the co-chief executives, Richard L. Gelfond and Bradley J. Wechsler, said that the stock price did not reflect Imax's long-term value and that the search for a ''strategic alternative,'' begun in July, would be scrapped. The stock was trading at $25 to $30 in August and early September on speculation that Imax might be bought by a big movie maker like Walt Disney. The company has built 220 large-screen theaters in 26 countries. Timothy Pritchard

title: Shock Waves From the Mideast, on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:

title: Cairo Prayer Leader Tries To Stem Cries for Holy War
description: Sheik Muhammad Seyyed Tantawi, resplendent in his formal gray robe and tightly wrapped white turban, pleaded in vain with the worshipers at Cairo's central mosque today.

title: Mireille Johnston, 65; Gave U.S. a Taste of France
description: Mireille Johnston, an author and television figure widely known for her cookbooks on French regional cuisines, died Oct. 5 at her home in Paris. She was 65.

title: Europes Off-Season Is on Top
description: FOR the first time since World War II, when overseas trips were controlled by an entirely different agenda, off-peak travel to Europe from the United States has exceeded peak- season levels. Figures released last month by the Office of Tourism Industries, part of the United States Commerce Department, show that the departures of United States citizens for the off-peak months of October 1999 through April 2000 totaled 5,918,726, slightly more than the May-through-September 1999 peak-season total, 5,918,631.

title: A Former Republican Stronghold Has Divided Loyalties These Days
description: Like his neighbors in the Floral Park section of this old Orange County city, Pete Suica, a wholesale burglar-alarm salesman, worries about the little things: how to keep his well-tended street of 1920's and 30's bungalows safe and tidy for himself and his wife, Jennifer Proctor, a nurse. But he worries about the big things, too, like the economy.

title: Abroad at Home; But There Is No Peace
description: In April 1993, as South Africans were negotiating an end to the apartheid system, white extremists assassinated a popular black leader, Chris Hani. Black anger brought riots that threatened to derail the negotiations. Nelson Mandela, asked by the white government to speak on state television, called for calm. The negotiations went on, and succeeded.

title: BRUNSWICK TO SELL SOME OF ITS BRANDS TO A SKI MAKER
description: The Brunswick Corporation, a maker of sporting goods and fitness equipment, said it planned to sell several outdoor-equipment brands to the ski maker K2 Inc. and to take third-quarter charges of about $150 million. K2 will pay $200 million in cash, stock and assumed debt for Brunswick's brands, including Zebco fishing gear and Igloo coolers. Brunswick said the sale was subject to K2's obtaining bank financing. Brunswick said its remaining business would be marine engines, boating, exercise equipment, bowling and billiards.

title: Do Horror Films Filter The Horrors of History?
description: The idea that horror films reflect, or even caricature, society's collective anxieties is nothing new. ''Invasion of the Body Snatchers'' is frequently read as a critique of McCarthy-era pod people. King Kong? A metaphor for the Great Depression or the threat of the black man to white social norms. Godzilla? A Japanese reaction to the devastation of the bomb. And the vampires haunting us of late? A coded response to the trauma of AIDS.

title: Clinton Orders A New Auction Of the Airwaves
description: With growing congestion of the airwaves threatening the development of a new generation of hand-held wireless devices, President Clinton ordered the federal government today to review and then auction wide swaths of the spectrum now controlled by government agencies, as well as by private companies.

title: F.A.A. Is Ignoring Questions Of Defective Bolts, Audit Finds
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has avoided evidence that nuts and bolts used in airplanes are frequently substandard, according to a government audit released today.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: BANNED IN BOSTON

title: Four generations and where they lived
description: GETTING THERE By car: From Boston, take I-93 south to Exit 7 onto Route 3 south (direction Braintree-Cape Cod). Take Exit 18 (Washington Street/Quincy Center). Bear left to Burgin Parkway and follow signs to Quincy Center and the National Park Service Visitor Center.

title: Travel Advisory
description: AMANDATORY STOP, EVEN IF IT'S NOT NECESSARY Along with bungee jumping, spectacular scenery and friendly people, New Zealand now boasts a public bathroom on its list of tourist attractions.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCER, CHURCHILL
description: SPENCER-CHURCHILL-Lady Sarah. Of Old Lyme, Connecticut. Died suddenly on October 13, 2000. Mother of Serena Balfour, Consuelo Russell, Alexandra Birch and Jacqueline Williams. Sister of the Duke of Marlborough, Lady Rosemary Muir, Lord Charles SpencerChurchill & the late Lady Caroline Waterhouse. Grandmother of Morgan McConnell, Lucinda McConnell, Consuelo Lily Balfour, Alastair Balfour, Alexander Judson, Nicholas Judson, Ian Judson, Eugene Williams, Harry Williams, and Philip Williams. She will be remembered and missed by all. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday 5-7PM. Services to be held at St. James Epispocal Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street, Tuesday at 12 noon.

title: Article 2000101490756558753 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: A Senseless Health Deduction
description: The House speaker, Dennis Hastert, called this week for President Clinton and the Democrats to help Republicans pass a tax deduction for uninsured families that buy health policies with little or no help from their employers. The Democrats should not take the invitation seriously. The proposed tax deduction would be ineffective, expensive and stacked in favor of high-income families.

title: Explosion Claimed 17 Mostly Young Lives, Cutting Short Careers and Aspirations
description: She was only 19, fresh out of basic training, just beginning to grasp what the United States Navy might be all about. It was Lakeina Monique Francis' first sail as a proud member of her country's armed services. She was assigned to the destroyer Cole. As the ship plowed through the ocean, she had no doubt that she was at sea.

title: A Baseball Tradition Thrives in St. Louis
description: In October, baseball is more than just games between teams that represent a city. It's often one area of America against another.

title: Now, Now, Be Nice
description: Derek Jeter was on first base when David Justice rapped a grounder to first baseman John Olerud in the first inning. Olerud fired the ball to Alex Rodriguez at second base and Jeter slid in hard on the Seattle shortstop and his close friend.

title: From a Summons to a Slap: How the Fight in Yugoslavia Was Won
description: The Yugoslav foreign minister, a loyalist to the ousted Slobodan Milosevic, quit today as the new president, Vojislav Kostunica, pursued a steady but scarcely sweeping campaign to assert his authority.

title: Bush Camp Sees Unrest as Validation of Its Views
description: Even as he continued to voice support for the Clinton administration's approach to the Middle East, Gov. George W. Bush, along with his running mate, Dick Cheney, found ways today to frame the crisis there as an argument for their ticket and a validation for Mr. Bush's proposals on energy and the military.

title: In Gardens, Groundhogs Show Whos the Boss
description: I Tried hard to know the enemy, the better to defeat him.

title: Leslie Kish, 90; Improved Science of Surveys
description: Leslie Kish, an authority on scientific population sampling who predicted President Harry S. Truman's upset victory over Thomas E. Dewey in 1948, died on Oct. 7 in a hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 90 and lived in Ann Arbor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGFRIED, GLADYS DICK
description: SIEGFRIED-Gladys Dick. On October 12, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Loving mother of Robert and Jonathan. Dear grandmother of Amanda, David, Matthew, Jeremy and Rachel. Devoted sister of Marilyn Goldstein. Services are at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue and 65 Street, Sunday, October 15, 12:30 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions her memory may be made to a cancer association of your choice.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you see a group of black students walking together on a college campus, your first thought might be, 'Oh, there goes the basketball team.' Here you think, 'There goes the chemistry honors club or the chess team.' It's just a different attitude on campus.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAD, GARY
description: GRAD-Gary, M.D. The Horace Mann community records with deep sorrow the passing of Dr. Gary Grad, adored father of Jennifer and Jason, and loving husband of Dr. Linda Grad. We have lost a courageous, loyal and devoted friend. He was a compassionate, wise and committed individual. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Grad family. Dr. Eileen Mullady, Head of School Marilyn Tabak, Parents Association President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEITZER, IRVING

title: When It Matters Most, Alfonzo Is the Mightiest Met
description: Benny Agbayani and Robin Ventura have hit important home runs. Jay Payton has two game-winning runs batted in. Mike Piazza and Todd Zeile have knocked in a combined five runs in St. Louis. Timo Perez has sparked rally after rally, and the bench players have made valuable contributions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIAMOND, SIGMUND
description: DIAMOND-Sigmund. A rare man of principle, whose analytic gifts, wit, & zest for intellectual jousting, endure in memories of students, colleagues, and friends. Don and Le

title: Cardinals Are Hoping The Dream Is Possible
description: They lined up outside Busch Stadium, by the indoor parking lot and facing -- of all things -- an avenue named Broadway. They huddled in sleeping bags or tents and kept the faith. Cardinal fans must be among the most devoted because these may have been wasting their time.

title: School Aide Is Arrested in Assault on 12-Year-Old Student
description: The police arrested an aide at a special-education school in Brooklyn yesterday on charges that he punched a 12-year-old student several times in the chest, causing the boy, who the authorities said suffers from a heart murmur, to pass out.

title: 'Execution Duty'
description: To the Editor:

title: Turning Liability Into an Asset
description: This 30-second commercial, titled ''In Debt,'' was released by Jon S. Corzine, a Democrat, in his campaign against Representative Bob Franks for United States senator from New Jersey. It began running yesterday on television stations in New York and Philadelphia.

title: A Baseball Town, Again
description: As New York anticipates the possibility of a Subway Series this year, I remember the autumns of a half century ago, when the city was never finer. Back then, as the days crispened and the sky turned marble blue, we had our own World Series right here in town. Let the rest of the country turn to football or fox hunting. The Brooklyn Dodgers, the New York Giants and the New York Yankees ruled baseball and, in our minds, ruled the world.

title: Toshiba Settles With U.S.
description: Toshiba has agreed to pay the federal government $23 million to settle part of a class-action lawsuit over faulty floppy disk controllers, the Justice Department said today. Toshiba also agreed to pay the government $10.5 million in coupons for the purchase of its products. The settlement releases Toshiba from liability for the sale of defective laptop computers to the government.

title: Four generations and where they lived
description: GETTING THERE By car: From Boston, take I-93 south to Exit 7 onto Route 3 south (direction Braintree-Cape Cod). Take Exit 18 (Washington Street/Quincy Center). Bear left to Burgin Parkway and follow signs to Quincy Center and the National Park Service Visitor Center.

title: Correspondents Report
description: Crew Members Fault Air Quality on 777's THE Boeing 777, the jewel in the fleet of many of the world's largest airlines, may be more likely to make passengers feel dizzy or nauseated than other, older airplanes, according to anecdotal reports from crew members and passengers.

title: Bill of fare
description: Many Viennese restaurants add cover charges of $1.25 to $4 a person to the bill. But it is also customary to tip up to 10 percent, which is considered generous. Prices are based on a meal for two with a bottle of wine but no tip. Smoking is allowed in all these restaurants, and unless specified, they accept all major credit cards.

title: Shock Waves From the Mideast, on Two Fronts
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CODY, LOUISE F.
description: CODY-Louise F. February 18, 1952 to October 12, 2000. Loved by many. Best friend always of Susan Vellone. I will miss you forever.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of Representative Bruce F. Vento of Minnesota on Wednesday misstated the date of one of his last major votes, opposing normal trade relations with China. It was May 24, not May 2.

title: Europes Off-Season Is on Top
description: FOR the first time since World War II, when overseas trips were controlled by an entirely different agenda, off-peak travel to Europe from the United States has exceeded peak- season levels. Figures released last month by the Office of Tourism Industries, part of the United States Commerce Department, show that the departures of United States citizens for the off-peak months of October 1999 through April 2000 totaled 5,918,726, slightly more than the May-through-September 1999 peak-season total, 5,918,631.

title: If you go
description: Tours in English and German are offered by Dr. Brigitte Timmermann, (43-1) 774 8901, fax (43-1) 774 8933; e-mail to brigitte@viennawalks.tix.at; Web: www.viennawalks.tix.at. They take place at 4 p.m. Mondays and Fridays; private tours given by special arrangement. Group two-hour tours are $12 a person, at 15.6 Austrian schillings to the dollar; $11 with a Vienna card. (The card costs $11.50 and is good for 72 hours of unlimited travel on public transportation, with discounts for museums, restaurants and many guided tours.)

title: Case Illustrates Risks of Altered Food
description: The genetically engineered corn that is linked to a widening web of food recalls has not been approved for human consumption because it contains a protein that is not normally part of the human food supply and that shares some characteristics of known food allergens. But there is no evidence that the corn actually does cause allergies, and some experts say that consumers need not worry about eating products that might contain the corn.

title: Riches the Hapsburgs Sent to the Attic
description: SOON after the Hapsburg monarchy collapsed in 1918, the Austrian president set up offices in the former Imperial Palace in Vienna and began receiving official visitors in what was once Empress Maria Theresa's bedroom. Its royal family having gone into exile, Austria placed the glittering crowns and silver on public display.

title: For Corzine, the Confidential Has Become Political
description: In the world of politics, where secrecy is often equated with trying to hide something that people have a right to know, Jon S. Corzine's decision not to release his income tax returns has become a major issue.

title: Frazzled Cardinals Trying to Regroup
description: The previous two nights in St. Louis had been rough for the Cardinals, and arriving in New York did little to soothe their feelings. After flying through the night and landing at 5 o'clock yesterday morning, the team gathered in the afternoon for the bus to take them from the team hotel in Manhattan out to Shea Stadium for an off-day workout. But the Cardinals waited as the bus got caught in traffic caused by a rally near the United Nations, arriving 45 minutes late to pick them up at 1:30 p.m., the time they were scheduled to be on the field at Shea for their workout.

title: Suddenly, a Chatty Bartok And an Inexorable Liszt
description: Some concert hall or performing institution somewhere should try to persuade Maurizio Pollini to become its artistic director, for this great Italian pianist has demonstrated a knack for inspired programming through Carnegie Hall's Perspectives series. Last season, working with other soloists, ensembles and orchestras, Mr. Pollini began his examination of connections between music from the 14th century to the present. When the series is completed next year, he will have performed in and planned nearly 30 programs.

title: All the Basics Of a Mexico Trip
description: AS temperatures drop in much of the United States, travelers' daydreams may turn to Mexico. Its warm climate, relaxed pace, miles of beaches and value continue to attract visitors from the north; the Mexico-United States border is one of the busiest in the world.

title: Western Styles Rival Traditional Dress : Fitting India to Measure
description: NEW DELHI  India's leading fashion gurus recently commissioned a study of the typical Indian body in an attempt to come up with homegrown, standard clothing sizes.

title: Police Block Thousands of Muslims From Attending Prayer Services in Old City's Mosques
description: A huge Israeli security cordon prevented thousands of Palestinians from attending Friday Prayer services at the ancient mosques inside the Old City today, a move that further angered Muslims here but kept the embattled holy site from exploding anew into violent confrontation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUNDY, WILLIAM P.
description: BUNDY-William P. of Princeton, NJ on October 6, 2000. Memorial Service will be held at Miller Chapel, Princeton Theological Seminary, Mercer St, Princeton, November 10th, at 12PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Rocky Mountain Institute, Snow Mass, Colorado.

title: Music and Movies Web Site In Bankruptcy-Law Filing
description: Scour Inc., the Los Angeles company that abets the trading of music and movies over the Internet, has filed for bankruptcy-law protection, a move the company said could shelter it from copyright infringement lawsuits it faces from record companies and movie studios.

title: Taking Aid and a Message to a Swing State
description: Appropriately attired for the day in bolo ties, two cabinet secretaries came here today to announce a new program that is intended to make it easier for American Indians to secure mortgages.

title: Napster and Buggies
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Nasdaq in Comeback, Surging Almost 8%
description: Stocks rallied yesterday after falling on Tuesday and Wednesday and plunging on Thursday. With investors jumping in to snap up bargains, as they have in the past, the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 1.6 percent and the Nasdaq composite index, which had fallen the most, surged 7.9 percent, its second-biggest one-day gain ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSANO, MICHAEL
description: ROSANO-Michael. Gay and Lesbian Independent Democrats mourn the passing of longtime member, Michael Rosano. His dedication, friendship and humor enriched us all.

title: Pennington Part of Quarterback Mix
description: Vinny Testaverde and Ray Lucas are getting ready for the Jets' game Sunday at New England, but today the rookie quarterback Chad Pennington completed a week of practice in which he took snaps with the first team for the first time.

title: Whats Doing in Paris
description: In Paris's gently declining temperatures, the low-hung fall sun will still warm you outdoors, if you choose a cafe on the north side of the street, and gas heaters start going on for those who choose the southern, sunless side of the boulevards.

title: Hard Times Cripple A Football Legacy; Broke Erasmus Team Sits Out Season
description: Mitchell Austin should have been on the football field this afternoon. He should have been tearing open the defensive line from his spot at right guard. It's something that Mitchell, a 6-foot-1, 300-pound senior at Erasmus Hall High School, does particularly well.

description: Today's KEY GAMES

title: For casual dining, with coffee or wine
description: There are at least three typically Viennese modes of casual eating: the cafe, the heuriger (wine tavern) and the stand-up sandwicherie.

description: Como Without a Car

title: Gore Again Alters Day to Meet on Middle East
description: For the second consecutive day, Vice President Al Gore altered his campaign schedule today to return to Washington for a White House meeting concerning the instability in the Middle East.

title: WHERE THE MONEY GOES
description: What makes Americans part with their dollars, and why? The Times Magazine examines the spending habits of today's society, in a variety of ''shopping centers'' -- from Fifth Avenue to the inside of a jail, from a pawnshop to a research lab. The biggest spenders include a generation of rich anti materialists, and splurgers who know that money may not buy happiness but take their chances anyway. A special issue.

title: Chevron Seen Close to Terms To Buy Texaco
description: The Chevron Corporation, the nation's third-largest oil company, is close to an agreement to acquire Texaco Inc. for about $36 billion in stock plus the assumption of debt, according to executives close to the negotiations.

title: Ex-Pentagon Planner Defends Sending U.S. Ships to Yemen
description: The architect of the plan to send United States Navy ships into the port of Aden as part of the larger goal of improving relations with Yemen defended his decision today, saying he was trying to prevent Yemen from becoming a ''rats' nest'' of terrorist groups.

title: Falling Short of Peace
description: During a June lunch at the whitewashed headquarters of the Palestinian Authority on the West Bank, Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, told Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright that he was not ready for a summit meeting that would define a permanent peace with Israel.

title: Jersey City Still Competes for Development
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with a capsule analysis of a new television commercial released by Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate from New Jersey, was published in error. It showed a scene from a new commercial by Mr. Corzine's opponent, Representative Bob Franks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTMANN, CHARLES T.
description: MATTMANN-Charles T. Of Locust Valley, LI suddenly on October 10, 2000, age 81. Beloved husband of the late Barbara Moore, father of Sandra M. Gros, Barbara M. Walkley (Philip F.), Wendy M. McHale (Kevin) and Debbie M. Williams (Dewayne), brother of Jane Hamilton, John and Ted. Vovo of ten. Greatgrandfather of 3. Friends may visit at the funeral home of DodgeThomas, Glen Cove Saturday, 4-7, Sunday 2-5 PM. Service St. Johns of Lattingtown, Monday at 11 AM.

title: Japanese Newcomer Offers Some Exotica
description: AFTER a slow start, Japanese restaurants have become almost as ubiquitous as their Chinese counterparts on Long Island. Separating the contenders from the pretenders is a difficult task because most of these spots look alike. The two-month-old Nisen, in a small strip shopping center at 1969 Jericho Turnpike in East Northport (631-462-1000), is just such a place. Its light wood, Asian lanterns, pagoda-roofed sushi bar, rice-paper partitions, Japanese dolls and sumo wrestler hanging room divider give it a cookie-cutter stamp as a kimono and carry-out storefront. At first glance, its menu too looks like a carbon copy of many others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBERT, ARTHUR W.
description: LAMBERT-Arthur W. North Andover, MA, 91 died October 11, 2000. From 1955-75 he was an elementary and junior high school teacher in various schools in NYC. Widower of Babette (McLaine). He is survived by three sons, James of North Andover, Peter and Thomas, both of Denver, a sister Claire Foley, four grandchildren, one great-grandson. Friends are invited to memorial services on Saturday, November 18 at 11AM, at the North Parish Church in North Andover. Info call Dewhirst & Conte Funeral Home of North Andover, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STORPER, SIDNEY
description: STORPER-Sidney. Beloved husband of Charlotte; loving father of Marsha and Larry Brooks, Henry and Fran Storper; devoted grandfather of Scott, David and Andrew Storper, Beth and Seth Joseph, and Scott's fiancee Claudia Arzate; bedazzled great-grandfather of Samantha Joseph and devoted brother of Stanley Storper, passed away Tuesday, October 10, 2000. Sidney Storper grew up in New York City where he was an accomplished swimmer and lifeguard. Subsequently, he was a brilliant chemical engineer who developed a fuselage coating that saved many U.S. planes during World War II and for years thereafter. Known as a ''problem solver par excellence'', he was also a successful real estate owner and manager, work he continued to do after moving to Florida in 1991. Adored by family and friends, he always had a firm hand shake, a winning smile, and a great one-liner. Services were held Friday, October 13 in Delray Beach. The family will receive friends on Sunday at Henry and Fran Storper's home in Miami.

title: Energy Salvation? Not in the Arctic
description: To the Editor:

title: Pudlin Pulls Ahead To Beat Donohue
description: Julia Pudlin of Bryn Mawr, Pa., won a homestretch duel over New Jersey's Erin Donohue yesterday in the girls' Eastern States High School Cross-Country Championship at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: At Saint Laurent, Tom Ford Speaks With His Own Voice
description: PARIS, Oct. 13  In the end, all the anticipation that had been mounting in the days before Tom Ford's first show tonight for Yves Saint Laurent ran out like the wind in a balloon. The collection was good, not great, but more important, Mr. Ford found a way through the dense vocabulary of Saint Laurent to say his own thing.

title: Putting Something on the Shelf That Didn't Come From a Store
description: PRESERVING, once a necessary activity for stocking the larder as the growing season wound down, has now become recreation. There is unquestionable delight in dipping into a jar of homemade jam at breakfast or opening a container of well-spiced chutney that did not come from a store to serve with roast duck or pork. And when good-looking seasonal apples or pears beckon from a farm stand, why not preserve them to use in myriad recipes?

title: Italian Ingredients
description: BEFORE writing down my impressions of Panevino Ristorante, I asked the chef, Anthony Guglielmelli, how he might describe the place if he were talking about it to a friend. I was sure he'd boast about the pair of boccie courts out back or the vibrant drawings of food that add a personal touch to the cheery dining room. I thought he would at least touch on the herb garden or the wood-burning pizza oven.

title: October 8-14; Not on Their Time
description: After more than 30 years of litigation, broadcasters prevailed in winning the repeal of the last major vestiges of the fairness doctrine. An appeals court ordered the Federal Communications Commission to repeal two regulations that required radio and television stations to provide free reply time to candidates and others attacked on the airwaves. The judges also accused it of years of dawdling and failing to respond to concerns that the rules had chilled the First Amendment rights of the broadcasters. Stephen Labaton

title: Answering a Calling To Make You Believe
description: LAST Sunday in these pages, two Americans, the actress Mary-Louise Parker and the director and former actor Joe Mantello, who went to theater school together, talked about the proper education of actors and audiences.

title: High Oil Prices Start to Exact a Toll on the Market
description: For much of this year, the surging price of oil did not seem to worry stock or bond investors. Even as the price of a barrel of crude jumped from $27 a barrel to $33 in August, the stock market rallied and the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note fell, dropping well below 6 percent.

title: Profiles in Splurging
description: What village elders have said for all time was confirmed nearly 30 years ago by the economist Richard Easterlin. Examining the results of polls taken in America since World War II, Easterlin found that as our prosperity increased, our levels of contentment did not. We reach our material goals, replace them with new, ever more expensive goals and get no closer to satisfaction. Easterlin called it our ''hedonic treadmill.'' Money, he concluded, cannot buy happiness.

title: Arizona Tops Washington State in Triple OT
description: TUCSON, Ariz. -- Leo Mills scored on a 2-yard run in the third overtime, and Antonio Pierce ended the game with an interception as No. 22 Arizona beat Washington State 53-47 on Saturday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREMS, HANS J.
description: BREMS-Hans J. On Sept. 16, 2000 in Urbana, Illinois, at age 84. Beloved husband of Ulla for 56 years. Devoted father of Lisa Brayton, Marianne Brems and Karen Kurreck. Brother of Niels Brems. He was retired as a Professor of Economics at the University of Illinois at UrbanaChampaign. Born in Denmark, he studied at the University of Copenhagen and Harvard University. He taught at the University of Copenhagen and the University of California at Berkeley before taking a position at University of Illinois. He wrote eight books and many scholarly articles on economics & European history. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM on October 22 at Clark-Lindsey Village, West Windsor Road, Urbana, IL. Contributions in his memory may be made to The University of Illinois Foundation, Harker Hall, 1305 W. Green Street, Urbana, IL. 61801.

title: In the Region/Rockland; On a Pier in the Hudson, a White-Glove Building
description: THIS former mill town, known for attracting day-trippers who like to stroll its quaint main street, filled with antique stores and sidewalk cafes, is not normally associated with million-dollar condominiums with concierge service and fitness clubs.

description: To the Editor:
