description: October 15, 2000

title: Jets Get It Together and Rout Patriots
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Oct. 15  Vinny Testaverde came back today and the Jets were back to themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTINEAU, CYRIL FRANCIS
description: MARTINEAU-Cyril Francis, 92. Died in Atlanta, GA, October 4, 2000, at his son's home. Retired Advertising Manager of Shell Oil Co., USA. Longtime resident of Tuxedo Park, New York. Born in London, March 13, 1908, the son of Cyril Edgar Martineau and Muriel Delano Robbins. Cousin of Franklin Delano Roosevelt. Educated at Harrow School and University College, Oxford, where he was a Rowing ''Blue'' and stroke of the Oxford crew, 1930. Served in WWII as Major, Royal Canadian Artillery and Chief Instructor in Gunnery, Canadian Army. Member Tuxedo Club and Leander Club (Oxford). An avid oarsman, lawn and real tennis player, golfer and skier. Predeceased by his wife, the former Margery Nan Sample, his brother, Warren Delano and his sister, Ann Jean M. de Cazenove Aschan. Survived by sons Neal Delano and Warren Douglas, six grandchildren, seven great grandchildren. Memorial service at 2PM, October 20 at St. Mary's-inTuxedo, Tuxedo Park, N.Y. 10987.

title: Anne Moles and Edward Mulick
description: THE owner and operator of High Mountain Bobcat Trucking in Bellevue, Idaho, Edward Mulick, describes himself as ''a real Idaho boy.'' He works outside, plowing snow in the winter, dirt in the summer. He idolizes potato farmers the way some people worship movie stars. No matter what, he's loyal to his friends, who have nicknames like Fathead and Squirrel and beards so bushy they store pencils in them.

title: Article 2000101592379915923 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: MURDER SUSPECTS INDICTED:
description: Rasheeda Farmer, 17, the Mount Vernon high school student charged in the robbery and murder of Devon Clarke, a college student, on Aug. 20, has been indicted on a charge of second-degree murder. The other suspect in the case, Raul South, 20, of Poughkeepsie, was indicted on a more serious charge of first-degree murder, which could result in a death-penalty prosecution. Second-degree murder carries a maximum sentence of 25 years to life. Robert Worth

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, JOSEPH
description: STEIN-Joseph. Beloved husband of Blanche. Loving father of Mariana, Mark, Lisa and Cheryl. Loving granddad to Yarusha, Roshina, Adam, Leah, Maddy and Emily. Loving father-in-law of Jeffrey and Douglas. Friend to all who he touched. We will miss your strength and beauty.

title: Metromedia to Acquire A California Company
description: Metromedia, a White Plains-based company that provides fiber-optic infrastructure to businesses, announced plans to acquire the California-based SiteSmith Inc., in an all-stock deal that could be valued as high as $1.5 billion.

title: Average White Guy
description: THE GREEN SUIT

title: LOW-COST INSURANCE FOR CHILDREN
description: After a campaign in the summer to promote free and low-cost health insurance for children and teenagers, the Westchester Health Department received 343 applications for coverage of 528 children and 13 pregnant women. As of the end of last month, 186 children were signed up for coverage, including 59 percent through Medicaid and 41 percent through Child Health Plus. As many as one in seven children in the United States do not have health insurance, which translates into about 23,000 uninsured children in Westchester, according to the county executive's office. The county also has a 24-hour line at (914) 637-2454 to provide families with information about how to sign up their children for comprehensive health coverage. Elsa Brenner

title: Handling McGwire With Care
description: Major League Baseball, in conjunction with the St. Louis Cardinals, could have staged an intriguing fan participation contest this postseason. When fans entered the park where the Cardinals were playing that particular day, they could have been handed punch-out computer cards with three questions to answer:

title: Lisa Lewandowski, Ronald Schneider Jr.
description: Lisa Ann Lewandowski, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Lewandowski of Carlstadt, N.J., was married yesterday to Ronald Milton Schneider Jr., a son of Anita L. Schneider of Ridgewood, N.J., and Dr. Schneider of Port Jefferson, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Kelly performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Assumption Church in Wood-Ridge, N.J.

title: Raising Crops, and Self-Esteem, on a Special Farm
description: High Point Farm is a working farm in the extreme northwestern corner of the state next to High Point State Park. But unlike other farms, this 477-acre tract is a retreat that is staffed by members of Fountain House in New York City, a treatment center for adults with persistent mental illnesses. The farm will be open to the public to tour the grounds and view the fall foliage from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Oct. 21 and 22 and Oct. 28 and 29. Charlie Saggese, a social worker and program coordinator for High Point Farm, recently talked about Fountain House.

title: A Band Suspended in Time
description: THE word clock -- indeed the whole notion of time passing -- crops up in the lyrics of several songs on ''The Friends of Rachel Worth,'' the new album by the Australian rock band the Go-Betweens. Somehow, that's not surprising. After all, it is the group's first release in 12 years.

title: INVESTING WITH -- Andrew C. Stephens; Artisan Mid-Cap Fund
description: HE may not exactly be a farm boy, but he did grow up in the Wisconsin countryside. And he is not a carpenter, either, although he and his wife are restoring the old, lakefront house they bought recently.

title: 'Harry Potter' Is Not Just for Kids
description: ABOARD an early morning train to Manhattan, commuters from Westchester sipped their coffee and buried their heads in their newspapers. But one passenger, Lawrence Mandelker, noticed a fellow commuter with a book tucked discreetly between the pages of the paper.

title: NOTICED; Equal Rites: Men's Engagement Rings
description: IT'S every young man's fantasy: After a moonlit walk, his girlfriend fidgets before dropping to one knee. She presents him with a gleaming ring, and says, ''Will you marry me?''

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; An Unstoppable Woman
description: In the French novelist Alexandra Lapierre's enthralling new novel, ARTEMISIA (Grove, $27), 17th-century Italy is a place where ''Art always prevailed over Justice'' and is collected with criminal voracity, and where a sycophantic connection to powerful popes and noble families was a prerequisite to any aspiration to success. Lapierre's book is an account of two renowned real-life painters, Orazio Gentileschi and his daughter and erstwhile model, Artemisia, who would become one of the Western world's first significant female artists. It's a tale of twisting fortunes at a time when painters were used as spies and methods of art collection foreshadowed those of the Nazis. Artemisia, raped at an early age by one of her father's partners, Agostino Tassi, has the temerity to take him to trial. The ordeal destroys the family and spins her into an ill-made marriage; she never loses her devotion to painting, however, taking as her subjects an array of heroines who are depicted vanquishing falsehood and securing freedom. The rift with her father exacts a heavy toll, separating them for years. But as her father says, ''Love knows no bounds. . . . Its excesses are its measure''; little does Artemisia know that her costliest sacrifice is yet to come. Though published here, in this graceful translation by Liz Heron, as a novel, the book features extensive notes and a text threaded with documentation, suggesting why it was published as a narrative biography in England. Whatever its genre, ''Artemisia'' employs admirable artistry in depicting the turbulent life and times of two great painters. Peter Bricklebank

title: Jenifer Steig, William Strugger
description: Jenifer Anne Steig and William Randolph Strugger are to be married today by Cantor Theodore Aronson at the Manhattan Penthouse.

title: A Tower and a Shadow
description: A FEW blocks off this city's booming waterfront stands a 10-story brown stucco reminder of the real estate bust of the late 1980's, a former industrial building where a residential conversion was left unfinished after its developers went bankrupt and their lender became one of the era's failed savings and loans.

title: Lisa Dallenbach, Donald Burkitt
description: Lisa Marie Dallenbach, a daughter of Mary Dallenbach-Kaffke of Bernardsville, N.J., and the late Robert H. Dallenbach, was married yesterday to Donald John Burkitt, the son of Lena Castro of Neptune Beach, Fla., and John Burkitt of Merrick, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Rolfs performed the ceremony at St. Francis Solano Roman Catholic Church in Sonoma, Calif.

title: Joan Baez Fights Myth of Being Joan Baez
description: THE Joan Baez who will be performing this Tuesday at the Community Theater in Morristown, is very different than the 1960's model. This millennial version is a more mellowed rendition of the former firebrand.

title: Reviving Main Street, Or Living in the Past?
description: IN its marketing brochure, this picturesque county seat 18 miles from the center of Philadelphia likes to portray itself as ''everybody's hometown.'' But to property owners like Al Anderson, this mostly white, middle-class burg of 6,000 seems anything but.

title: With Bats Ablaze, the Cardinals Roar to Life
description: The St. Louis Cardinals came out swinging, the Mets went down looking, and the National League Championship Series suddenly has a very different feel to it.

title: Cure It With Drugs
description: To curb her hunger to shop, Barbara G. dropped her 13 credit cards in a jar, filled it with water and put the plastic cocktail in her freezer. On other occasions, she sealed her credit cards in an envelope and locked them in a box. And once, she cut them into pieces. But all for naught: she'd drive to Nordstrom, ask a saleswoman to look up her account number and charge more clothes.

title: Where There's A Will There's a Win
description: WHEN the Haddonfield Memorial High School track team arrives at another school, you hear the whispers. Which one is Erin Donohue? There she is; it's Erin Donohue.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-15-00: Economics Of An Underdog Campaign; The Price of Admission
description: The First Half-Million Is the Hardest

title: STOCK CAR PLAN FALLS THROUGH
description: Plans to build a 100,000-seat stock car racetrack at the Meadowlands Sports Complex have all but died following the state's refusal to subsidize the $400 million project with taxpayer money and low-interest loans. The Whitman administration, which has been negotiating with professional racing over the past year to bring a Nascar speedway to New Jersey, bowed out of the project recently, saying that Nascar's request for a $200 million subsidy was too high. Although the Meadowlands racetrack project appears highly unlikely, the industry has not given up its plans to secure a presence in the area. Stock car racing is hugely popular in other parts of the country, and Nascar has had its eye on the New York metropolitan region for some time. The Meadowlands currently houses the Jets, Giants, Nets, Devils and MetroStars, and all except for the Giants have talked of relocating. Anne Ruderman

title: In Search of Starry, Starry Nights
description: EVEN on a clear night in New York, the sky is a hazy, purple blanket and the heavens are difficult to find. A constellation here, a moon there, but the city cannot compete with the country, where stars are sprinkled like diamonds on black velvet.

title: Oil Companies' Deal Awaits Vote
description: Officials from the Chevron Corporation and Texaco Inc. spent yesterday working on details of a combination valued at about $36 billion that would create the fourth largest oil company in the world, according to executives close to the talks.

title: Honors for Companies That Employ the Disabled
description: Companies ranging in size from Fleet Bank to the Mount Kisco Frame Shop will be among 50 employers to be honored on Monday for hiring disabled workers at the 15th annual Achievement Awards Breakfast at Doral Arrowwood in Rye Brook. Sixty-three disabled workers will also be honored.

title: SOAPBOX; A Twilight Ride Down the Taconic
description: I RODE my little Integra like a silver bullet down the Taconic, the Wild West highway of the East that goes up to Albany. Like a cowgirl on her pinto, I rode that scenic highway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILGRAM, SYLVIA
description: MILGRAM-Sylvia. On October 9, 2000, in Rockville, MD, longtime resident of Manhattan. Beloved sister of Norma Spector and sisterin-law of Paul Spector. Dear aunt of Sarah Spector and Gordon Spector. Former inspiring teacher of Art at Washington Irving High School and Music and Art High School, and fascinating lecturer at the Museum of Modern Art. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Katherine Bodkin, Scott Robinson
description: Dr. Katherine Donovan Bodkin and Scott Arthur Robinson were married on Friday in Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Luke Travers, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Church of SS. John and Paul.

title: Nassau $820,000 in Hole With Seized Cars
description: IT was with great fanfare 20 months ago that the Nassau County executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, announced a new county policy to confiscate the vehicles of people charged with driving while under the influence of alcohol. Mr. Gulotta touted the crackdown as a boon for public safety and spun visions of a windfall from the resale of seized cars.

title: Saramago to Visit Newark
description: What would happen if the Iberian Penisula floated out to sea? If a proofreader inserted the word ''not'' into books? Or if God and the Devil negotiated about evil? These are some of the things that happen in the books of Portuguese novelist Jose Saramago, winner of the 1998 Nobel Prize for Literature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARSONS, MARSELIS C., JR.
description: PARSONS-Marselis C., Jr. Of Lyme, NH. Died Friday, September 22, 2000 in Hanover, NH. He was born in Rye, NY, August 30, 1904, son of Marselis and Jessie Parsons of Furzen Hill-now the Rye Nature Center. He worked on Wall Street, then for U.S. Senator Royal Copeland of New York, before entering the U.S. Foreign Service in 1935. He served in Washington and several foreign posts, retiring from Copenhagen in 1962. He had lived in the Upper Valley of New Hampshire since then. He is survived by two sons, Marselis C. Parsons III of Shelburne, VT, his wife Julie and their daughter Susan, and Stephen Parsons of Lake Forest, IL, and his son William. He was predeceased by his wife of 45 years, Elinor Crow Parsons, in 1987. A memorial service will be held 1 PM, Monday, October 16, at Christ Church, Rye, NY.

title: EVENING HOURS
description: Oct. 4: Lincoln Center inaugurated this season's Great Performers series with an opening night gala at Avery Fisher Hall. Dinner for 320 guests on the Grand Promenade was followed by a concert that included the soprano Renee Fleming and the baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky singing arias and duets. The evening raised $633,000.

title: 'Best Kept Secret' in Croton Falls
description: THE trouble with autobiographical drama is that it is not always as interesting to a wide audience as it is to its author.

title: Adding Life to Paintbrushes and Rollers
description: A GOOD quality paintbrush or roller can last a lifetime if it is carefully cleaned and stored after each job. Unfortunately, most do-it-yourselfers look on brush and roller cleaning as a tedious chore and they do it in a rather haphazard manner. This is unfortunate because improper cleaning leaves paint that will eventually clog the fibers so the brushes and rolls eventually become useless.

title: Cost Of Being Alive; The Provider
description: Jose is a 47-year-old farmer from Choluteca Province in Honduras.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; A Serenade To Souped-Up Cars
description: It's hard to imagine a more perfect package of freedom, rebellion and American can-do than a teenager and a souped-up car. The Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston pays tribute to this country's renegade romance with the car in an exhibition of 75 prints, paintings, photographs, drawings, sculptures, installations -- even an actual customized car. ''Customized: Art Inspired by Hot Rods, Low Riders, and American Car Culture'' runs from Oct. 25 to Dec. 31.

title: Rutgers's Coach May Be Finished
description: The probability of Rutgers Coach Terry Shea's being dismissed neared certainty tonight. The players' quitting on Shea appeared to be a done deal.

title: The War on Stink
description: Dr. George Preti first offers me armpit. Later, we'll get to ''swine slurry'' and halitosis, but we start with the odor that he claims is his favorite. Preti holds a small strip of clear material under my nose, saturated with 3-methyl-2-hexenoic acid, the principal ingredient in underarm odor. Smelling this strip is like savoring distilled gym locker, and not something you want to do often. Preti, who grins as I take it in, whiffs this stuff for a living.

title: Nassau May Be Losing Best To Employee Buyout Offer
description: ''WE may wind up with the budget fixed, but the county won't work,'' the Nassau County parks and recreation commissioner, John B. Kiernan, quipped as he looked at a list of 56 people in his office -- including himself -- who took an early retirement incentive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITESIDE, THOMAS
description: WHITESIDE-Thomas. Of Needham, MA. Died Oct. 12. Survived by his former wife Christiana B. Whiteside and predeceased by his wife Ruth F. Whiteside. Father of Judith Whiteside and Janet W. Cooke both of Wareham and Thomas Whiteside, Jr. of No. Attleboro. Also survived by six grandchildren. Brother of the late Howard S. Whiteside. Memorial service Wednesday, October 18 at 11AM in the Dover Church, Dover, MA. Please omit flowers. Donations in his name may be made to the Pine Street Inn, 444 Harrison Avenue, Boston, MA. 02118, or a charity of your choice.

title: October 8-14; A Brother's Review
description: ''This book is an explication to the Mexican people.'' Thus begins a nearly 1,400 page apologia by former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. Its release created a media spectacle and raised widespread public skepticism. But the greatest doubt cast on his version of Mexico's economic and political troubles has come from an unexpected source -- Mr. Salinas's own brother, Raul. Mexican television released a mysterious audiotape of Raul, imprisoned on murder charges, claiming that contrary to the book's assertions, Carlos knew all about more than $90 million discovered in Swiss bank accounts traced to Raul. Anthony DePalma

title: Teacher, Tour Guide and Author
description: ROBERT GLOBERMAN'S days of leading group tours are over, but he has his memories. Like the plane in Turkey that almost departed leaving half his group behind. And the tour bus that sank in the mud. There was the aging widow on a tour of India who became so enamored of a young man from Jaipur that she decided to stay behind to pursue a second chance at love.

title: Energy Salvation? Not in the Arctic
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-15-00: Itinerary; Money Travels
description: More than 400,000 people have registered the serial numbers of five million bills, worth a total of more than $33 million, at the Web site www.wheresgeorge.com. Each bill is marked with the site's address -- O.K. so long as the bill is not rendered useless -- and then spent with the hope that subsequent possessors will visit the site and register the bill again, providing a fossil-like record (gaps included) of its movements.

title: Edith Josephson, David Owen
description: Edith Louise Josephson, a daughter of Ruth Goddard Josephson and Ronald P. Josephson of Simsbury, Conn., was married yesterday to David Robert Owen, a son of Lynn Rasmussen Owen and Judge Richard Owen of Manhattan. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton performed the ceremony at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Manhattan.

title: Virtuoso, a Russian Expatriate, Escapes the Label of Tormented Artist
description: ABOUT making the piano sing: it seems impossible -- after all, the piano is a percussion instrument with a Rube Goldberg construction. Its strings are not stroked by a bow, but hit with little hammers attached through a mechanism to each key. On the other hand, when Evgeny Kissin plays Liszt piano transcriptions of Schumann's or Schubert songs, (on Red Seal and Deutsche Grammophon labels) the fluid tone sounds as if some mystical singer is smoothing notes into a blended line.

title: Energy Salvation? Not in the Arctic
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICAL BRIEFING
description: A Sign of Progress In a Georgia Contest

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: BANNED IN BOSTON

title: Alexandra Hannan, Eldon Scott Jr.
description: Alexandra Jean Hannan and Eldon Sullivan Scott Jr. were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Susannah Smith performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church.

title: Wild on the Mound, Cardinals' Ankiel Keeps His Control Off It
description: Early Friday morning, Rick Ankiel pushed in the videotape and began the harsh assignment of watching his brief and painful performance from the night before. Pitches sailed wildly over and around Mets hitters, five of them flying all the way to the backstop, before Cardinals Manager Tony La Russa mercifully lifted Ankiel after just two- thirds of an inning. Ankiel watched the tape and laughed.

title: Help Plants Adjust
description: If you rushed houseplants indoors when temperatures plunged, help them adjust to their drastically different conditions. During the day, move them outside to progressively shadier spots, and then back indoors at night. Inspect plants closely: check the undersides of leaves and stems for aphids, scale and mealybugs, and drainage holes for slugs, sowbugs and earwigs. Spray with a hard stream of water to dislodge pests, or wash with a solution of a few drops of mild soap diluted in a gallon of water.

title: New Arrest Is Made in the Theft of Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14  The brother of the man rewarded for finding 52 of 55 Oscar statuettes stolen just before this year's Academy Awards has been arrested in connection with the theft.

title: Helping Businesswomen Network
description: WHAT drives Cecile Singer after all these years?

title: 'Half Lenin, Half Gandhi'
description: HO CHI MINH

title: Behind the Ivy at Yale's Open House
description: FOR the first time in its history, Yale University is opening up its campus to the public, holding an all-day open house next Saturday to kick off the celebration of its 300th birthday next year.

title: Just the Right Size
description: To the Editor: After ''Sometimes, Smaller is Better'' (Aug. 20) by John Rosenthal, and ''larger is better when it's raining'' (the letter from Seymour Goldberg, Sept. 3), I feel a little like Goldilocks. As far as cruise ships go, small may suit some and large others, but for me our midsize ship was just right for Alaska.

title: Tie Decision
description: Plaid isn't just for trench coat linings anymore. After last year's craze for Burberry plaid, the fashion world is finding ways to tweak the tartan. This season, using whimsical materials like leather and fur, and processes like tie-dyeing and silk-screening, designers are exploding the pattern of decorum. Even Burberry breaks out of the traditional grid -- as witnessed by its new monochrome jacquard plaid ties and bold plaid high-heel boots. To be sure, too much of a good thing can cause ganglion overload: Don't try these combos outside your home.

title: Nothing New
description: To the Editor:

title: Jacqueline Lowey, David Kuperschmid
description: Jacqueline May Lowey, a daughter of Representative Nita M. Lowey and Stephen Lowey of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday evening in East Hampton, N.Y., to David Kuperschmid, a son of Eleanor and Norman Kuperschmid of Sarasota, Fla. Rabbi David Gelfand officiated at East Hampton Point, a restaurant.

title: Seeing Earnings Reality, Belatedly
description: LAST fall, the stocks of small companies were taking off. By the end of the year, the Russell 2000 index was up 19.6 percent, outdueling the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for the first time since 1993.

title: Paris
description: In Paris's gently declining temperatures, the low-hung fall sun will still warm you outdoors, if you choose a cafe on the north side of the street, and gas heaters start going on for those who choose the southern, sunless side of the boulevards.

title: Muslim Leader in Bosnia Retires
description: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Oct. 14  The Bosnian Muslim leader, Alija Izetbegovic, who led the resistance to the Serbs in the 1992-95 Bosnian war, stepped down today from the country's tripartite presidency, two years before his mandate was to expire.

title: Jagr's Four Goals Overwhelm the Rangers
description: The Rangers have often said how much they want to play up-tempo hockey this season. Tonight, Jaromir Jagr and the high-flying Pittsburgh Penguins were only too happy to oblige.

title: INSIDE
description: A Town Searches Its Soul

title: A Postmodern Hamlet By a Driven Provocateur
description: ON Wednesday, an Argentinian theater company, famous for its grisly confrontational scenes, will begin performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music of a 23-year-old German play that has had only one prominent American production, 14 years ago, even though critics and scholars generally consider it the signal text of the post modern theater. ''Hamletmachine'' is the work that catapulted the East German author Heiner Muller to international fame, promoting him from Berlin notoriety to avant-garde stardom.

title: The Do-Gooder
description: LOVING GRAHAM GREENE

title: TRANSACTION
description: FOOTBALL

title: FOR YOUNG VIEWERS
description: Ash, center, and his friends (from left, Pikachu, Cyndaquil, Chikorita and Totodile) travel to a mysterious land where more than 100 unfamiliar faces await them in ''Pokemon: The Johto Journeys,'' which has its weekday premiere on Friday at 4 p.m. on Kids' WB. (Nintendo)

title: Justice in Yugoslavia
description: To the Editor:

title: Tribute to Helen Hayes
description: THE Helen Hayes Performing Arts Center in Nyack will celebrate the 100th birthday of its namesake with wine, women, men and song next Sunday. James MacArthur, the son of the actress and of the playwright Charles MacArthur, will be master of ceremonies for the evening.

title: Together Again in Old Bridge
description: Despite the fact that this band was born out of the Seattle rock scene of the 1990's and two of its members went on to become Foo Fighters, Sunny Day Real Estate is not a grunge outfit. After several breakups and makeups, the band is a bit of everything -- from arena-rock to progressive Yes-like flourishes. They touch many bases, giving up much of the dark, punk emotions of its past, especially on their most recent recording, ''Rising Tide.''

title: POSTINGS: Aided by Anonymous Gift of $200,000; Riverdale Church Restored
description: Congregants of Christ Church Riverdale are to gather today to rededicate their 134-year-old church after a decade-long restoration, whose completion was aided by a munificent, and surprise, intervention.

title: Benes Makes His Playoff Return Worth the Wait
description: The game is rerun occasionally on cable television late at night, and when Andy Benes sees himself giving up the home run to Don Mattingly, he smiles. Sure, his Mariners came back to win that division series in 1995, but Benes grew up a Mattingly fan in southern Indiana and appreciated the standing ovation his hero received that night.

title: Specialists Scour U.S.S. Cole for Clues to Deadly Blast
description: ADEN, Yemen -- The crew of the crippled USS Cole gathered on its listing deck Sunday to pay tribute to 17 shipmates killed in an apparent suicide bombing that also ripped into the U.S. Navy's strategic plans in the Middle East.

title: A Music Collection Gets a Home
description: IT was lunchtime on a Tuesday in the kitchen of Samuel and Ann Charters in Storrs, and over a turkey sandwich, Mr. Charters was discussing rap music, particularly the work of early gangsta rappers like the Geto Boys and the late Tupac Shakur.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: A VAST CONSPIRACY: The Real Story of the Sex Scandal That Nearly Brought Down a President, by Jeffrey Toobin. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14.) In this account of how some unanswered questions about an Arkansas land deal led to the Starr report and the impeachment trial of President Clinton, the author argues that the legal system is increasingly supplanting the political system. The result is an ''admirably clear, vigorously written, plain-spoken and common-sensical book,'' Thomas Powers wrote here earlier this year. In Shrub: The Short but Happy Political Life of George W. Bush, by Molly Ivins and Lou Dubose (Vintage, $8.99), two Texas journalists launch a relentless, if good-natured, broadside against the Republican presidential nominee, primarily taking aim at his record as governor and deal maker. ''It serves as a useful, opinionated brief for the prosecution,'' Peter Applebome said here earlier this year.

title: Sailors' Town Is a Mecca for the Boat Industry
description: A thin, sporadic drizzle mixed with the chilled northerly breeze did nothing to raise the comfort level of the gathering throng. But this is a sailor's town, and last Monday the blast of unseasonable weather did nothing to dissuade the locals from assembling on the waterfront for what has become an annual boating spectacle.

title: Why We Split
description: Four years ago, when my girlfriend and I moved in together, we considered it a step toward marriage. She was working as a waitress then. The money I made as a magazine editor would have been considered good most any place else except New York City, which is where we were living. Having grown up here, though, I had a bit of a boost, like the storefront apartment in Brooklyn I rented from my stepfather for slightly below market. My share of that rent was cut in half the day we moved her stuff from TriBeCa in three vanloads. The spending that was left to do we shared with a graceful eagerness to be the first to reach into our pockets to cover the grocery bill, the tab at a restaurant or the bar, even the dry cleaner. We didn't have much, but we spent what we had and didn't worry about it.

title: WATER LEVELS THREATENED
description: The State Department of Environmental Protection is holding up issuing water permits for five Salem and Gloucester County building projects after a United States Geological Survey report said ground water levels in the area could drop by as much as four feet if the permits were issued. The projects include a sod farm in Pilesgrove Township, an industrial park in Pedricktown and housing developments in Harrison, Woolwich and Logan Townships. Robert Strauss

title: Joining the Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSANO, MICHAEL
description: ROSANO-Michael. Political activist, respected publicist, and devoted friend. He began his career in public television at Channel 13. He worked for Manhattan Borough President and City Council President Andrew Stein as deputy press secretary and for City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman as a community liaison. He served the gay and lesbian community as political director of the Empire State Pride Agenda and of the Anti-Violence Project, and served all New Yorkers until his passing as Deputy Communications Director to State Senator Martin Connor, Minority Leader of the New York State Senate. A faithful supporter of Congresswoman Bella Abzug throughout her career, a democrat in all senses, Michael was warm, generous, witty, and loving: loyal to his friends, to the causes he believed in, to the public interest he served with selflessness, dignity, humor, and honor. In our sorrow, we remember the strength, courage, and grace with which Michael endured until the end, and we join the Rosano family in grief. Eve Abzug, Liz Abzug, Barbara Baer, William Bryk, Ronnie Eldridge, C. Virginia Fields, Harold Holzer, Elizabeth Holtzman, Brenda Levin, Jesse Masyr, Walter McCaffrey, Martin McLaughlin, John Mullins, Maggi Peyton, Andrew Stein

title: Juliet Litterer, Ketan Majmudar
description: Juliet Maria Litterer, the daughter of Janet Dinius Litterer and Joseph W. Litterer of Fairfield, Conn., was married Friday to Ketan Dinesh Majmudar, a son of Kala and Dinesh Majmudar of Germantown, Md. Pandit Chaitanya B. Agnihotri, a Hindu priest, performed the ceremony at the Greentree Country Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Yesterday, the Rev. Dr. David J. Rowe performed a Congregational ceremony at Greenfield Hill Church in Fairfield.

title: Kids, Don't Try This With the Taurus at Home
description: AGATHA CHRISTIE he is not, but Ron Hazelton unravels the mysteries hidden deep inside your car in ''The Body Shop,'' a two-hour program that kicks off the History Channel's ''Modern Marvels: Men at Work Week,'' at 9 p.m. Eastern time Monday.

title: Mugabe's Foes in Zimbabwe, Stymied, Talk of Violence
description: The opposition legislators now speak the language of ayes and nays, motions and resolutions and their names appear in neat black type on white government doors. But the jubilation over their sweep in June elections of more than a third of parliamentary seats has quickly dissolved into discontent.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS; Celebration for Helen Hayes
description: The Helen Hayes Performing Arts Center in Nyack will celebrate the 100th birthday of its namesake with wine, women, men and song next Sunday. James MacArthur, the son of Miss Hayes and the playwright Charles MacArthur, will serve as the master of ceremonies for the evening.

title: Fairfield Wrestles Over School Expansion
description: CONNECTICUT'S baby boomlet, which has resulted in 100,000 more school-aged children since 1990, has produced an obvious side effect that municipalities are struggling to reconcile: A soaring student population demanding increased classrooms and teachers at a price taxpayers are willing to pay.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Nobels: Dazzled By the Digital Light
description: THE Nobel prize in physics is usually bestowed for an abstract theoretical insight or esoteric experimental technique that deepens science's comprehension of the world. And physics being physics, it is often a challenge to explain to anyone but specialists just what the laureates are being honored for. Last year two Dutch physicists were recognized, in the Nobel committee's words, ''for elucidating the quantum structure of electroweak interactions.'' The year before two Americans and a German bagged the prize ''for their discovery of a new form of quantum fluid with fractionally charged excitations.''

title: Navy Mother Mourns, As Does a Navy Town
description: Two levels of grief were at work today in this quintessential Navy town. In one, elected officials and Navy families gathered at a waterfront park for the long-planned dedication of a new statue, ''The Homecoming,'' which by a somber coincidence with the tragedy of the destroyer Cole, depicts a joyous sailor safely reuniting with his family after a tour of foreign duty.

title: MIDEAST PARTIES AGREE TO MEETING TO DISCUSS TRUCE
description: After more than two weeks of spiraling violence that cost nearly 100 lives, Israeli and Palestinian leaders agreed today to meet with President Clinton in Egypt to seek a truce and perhaps even a way back to the peace table.

title: The Rail Line North of Wassaic
description: To the Editor:

title: Wannstedt Eases Up to Keep Team Fresh
description: DAVIE, Fla., Oct. 14  Midweek lethargy and midafternoon heat were taking a toll as the Miami Dolphins struggled through practice, so Coach Dave Wannstedt decided to ease up.

title: Discovering in 'Bungler' A Different Moliere
description: IT'S no news that Doug Hughes is a classy, attention-getting artistic director. And there is no rest for the classy and the attention getting. Not when such adjectives as bold and innovative, so often tossed off about the Doug Hughes style, dare you to keep on daring.

title: Pomp Was Also Popular Among Some Populists
description: THE chairs that American presidents chose to use in the Executive Mansion have revealed a lot about their politics, their personalities or both. Throughout the nation's history, most presidents, not their wives, have dominated in making decisions about the decor of the White House, and many have preferred imperial-looking chairs in the public rooms even during the presidencies of Andrew Jackson, Theodore Roosevelt, Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy, champions of the common man.

title: Two Museums Sponsor Tours to Cuba
description: Traveling to Cuba has become politically acceptable enough that two cultural institutions, the School of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston and the American Museum of Natural History in New York, are sponsoring trips there in January.

title: 2 Men Fired Upon by Needlelike Objects
description: Two men were struck early yesterday by what the police described as needlelike objects fired by a group of men in a car in two incidents on the West Side.

title: 2 Fatally Shot In Restaurant In the Bronx
description: Two men were killed and a 73-year-old woman was wounded early yesterday after a misstep in the entrance to a Bronx restaurant led to an argument and gunfire, the police said.

title: A Living Fence and All That Goes With It
description: PRIVACY is one of the main reasons people build stone walls or erect fences.

title: Step Into History
description: Even if you can't afford a 200-year-old lead cherub, there's no reason why you can't fill your garden with antiques. Try heirloom bulbs such as the little Guinea Hen Flower or Checkered Lily (Fritillaria meleagris). The Checkered Lily is a small plant with pendant, tulip-like blossoms that seem to be marked with a checkerboard pattern. It has been documented since at least 1572. Plant them amid clumps of the white daffodil Avalanche, which is also sometimes known as Seventeen Sisters (from 1700 or before). Find old cultivars at Brent and Becky's Bulbs, 4763 Heath Trail, Gloucester, Va. 23061, (804) 693-3966 or online at brentandbeckysbulbs.com; or at Old House Gardens (send $2.00 for catalog), 536 W. Third Street, Ann Arbor, Mich. 48103, (734) 995-1486 or online at old housegardens.com. ELISABETH GINSBURG

title: Children's Books
description: THE AUSTERE ACADEMY

title: Injured U.S. Sailors Head Home from Germany
description: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany -- Thirty-three U.S. sailors injured in an attack on their ship in Yemen headed home Sunday after treatment by military doctors in Germany, but six shipmates who were more seriously hurt stayed behind.

title: An Underdog on the East End
description: LOWELL H. JUDSON had never laid eyes on Regina Seltzer, the candidate who beat Representative Michael P. Forbes by just 35 votes in last month's Democratic primary election, but he did not hesitate when asked to host a fund-raiser for her.

title: Boonton-Based Band Plays Eclectic Sound
description: IF there is nothing new under the sun, as philosophers say, don't tell the eight members of the Boonton-based roots rock band Swampadelica. It might make them feel like switching occupations, and, judging by their debut self-produced album, also called ''Swampadelica,'' that would be a loss.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Shot Seen 'Round the World
description: LOU GERARD didn't smell a rat. Instead, he was staring one straight in the eye. Little did either one know how that rodent would change sports television forever.

title: Article 2000101590175741145 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Betsey Kittenplan, Edward Pick
description: Betsey Anne Kittenplan, a daughter of Gail and Stephen Kittenplan of New York, was married yesterday to Edward Noel Pick, the son of Karol and Pablo Pick, also of New York. Dr. Arthur Caliandro, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, officiated at the Plaza.

title: Baby Steps
description: THE night before starting her new job, Maria nervously spread potential outfits for the big day across her narrow single bed. Choosing between pants and dresses and between a sassy lavender and a sedate beige, she sought a look that reflected the hope she invested in every detail of starting over.

title: Micki Chen, Steven Gross
description: Micki Mai-hsi Chen and Prof. Steven Allan Gross are to be married today at the Sequoia, a restaurant in Washington. Judge Emily Hewitt of the United States Court of Federal Claims in Washington is to officiate.

title: Six Californians Killed in Plane Crash
description: ENSENADA, Mexico -- A small airplane crashed Saturday near a Mexican military base in Baja California state, killing six Americans working with a volunteer doctors group, police and the doctors organization said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IAVARONE, JERRY
description: IAVARONE-Jerry. On October 12, 2000, of Garden City, LI. Beloved husband of Grace. Jerry was very special and will be remembered forever. Services at St. Anne R.C. Church, Garden City, on October 16, at 10 AM.

title: Peter Turgeon, 80, Stage and Screen Actor
description: Peter Turgeon, an actor, writer and director, died on Oct. 6 at the Long Island State Veterans Home at Stony Brook. He was 80 and lived in Amagansett, N.Y.

title: October 8-14; Caution Over the Pill
description: A study linked birth control pills made before 1975 to an increased risk of breast cancer in women whose mothers or sisters had the disease. Researchers do not know whether women with a family history of breast cancer face an increased risk from today's pills, which contain far lower hormone doses than the ones made before 1975. Denise Grady

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, NORMA
description: KAUFMAN-Norma. Beloved sister of Claire Greenberg, Mamaroneck, NY; Benjamin Kaufman, Andover, CT; and the late Samuel Kaufman. Devoted Aunt and Great Aunt. Family graveside service. Donations may be made to the United Hebrew Geriatric Center, 60 Willow Drive, New Rochelle, New York 10805.

title: New-Look Islanders Disappoint in Home Opener
description: New players. New attitude. New direction.

title: In Nader Supporters' Math, Gore Equals Bush
description: From the standing-room-only logjam near the stage to the nosebleed seats near the championship banners of the Knicks and Rangers, about 15,000 people of all ages, hair colors and political backgrounds filled Madison Square Garden on Friday night for the biggest rally yet supporting Ralph Nader's presidential bid.

title: Gore Aides Say Bush Camp Is Exploiting Mideast Crisis
description: The presidential campaign turned again toward the Middle East today, as Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush talked of hope and prayers for peace and their aides battled over charges that the Bush camp was exploiting the turmoil for political gain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HODGES, KATHLEEN
description: HODGES - Kathleen. October 4. Died while brushing her teeth in her home in New York City of heart arrhythmia. She was 59 years old. Fiercely beloved mother of Jennifer Hodges of New York City and Bettina Hempel of Lausanne, Switzerland; sister to Edward DeMar and proud aunt to Julie, Beth and John; cherished daughter of the late Kathleen McHale and Edward DeMar. Kathleen grew up in Lordship, CT and attended Our Lady of Mercy-Lauralton Hall High School after which she moved to New York to receive a degree from Columbia Teachers College. She worked as a medical transcriptionist in many of New York's hospitals, most recently at Columbia-Presbyterian. Quirky, quiet, with a great oddball sense of humor, Kathy is deeply, inconsolably missed. She was buried on October 7 at the Oak Lawn Cemetery in Fairfield, CT. She is Happy. Contributions can be made to an endowed scholarship in her name that will benefit daughters of single mothers. Please contact Georgia in the development office of Lauralton Hall, (203) 877-2786, Ext. 29. God Bless Us All.

title: Avian Housing
description: Youngsters will be able to learn about birds and build their own bird houses today in Mount Vernon at the Arts-on-Third Festival 2000 on Third Street between First and Fifth Avenues from 1 to 6 p.m.

title: Marsalis in Morristown
description: Since Branford Marsalis made his recording debut in 1984 with ''Scenes in the City,'' he has built a reputation as one of the best and most versatile jazz saxophonists playing today. He has ventured into the rock 'n' roll and pop arena playing with the Grateful Dead, Bruce Hornsby and Sting. Ten years after his debut, he broke new ground combining jazz and hip-hop in ''Buckshot LeFonque.''

title: A Deal Master Evolves, Gracefully
description: JOSEPH R. PERELLA is half of the most famous pair to hit Wall Street in the modern deal-making era. But the announcement of his promotion last month at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, from chief of investment banking to chairman of the institutional securities group, was overshadowed by rumors of huge losses -- later revealed to be smaller than feared -- in the firm's bond department.

title: Diverse Italian Fare, Highlighted by Calamari
description: AROUND the corner from the Shubert theater and within a few blocks of the Yale University campus, art museums and Yale Repertory Theater, is the Amalfi Grille, one of New Haven's newest Italian restaurants.

title: IN MY...BRIEFCASE: JOHN DOERR
description: AS one of the most sought-after venture capitalists in Silicon Valley, John Doerr of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has a lot on his shoulders. About 50 pounds, to be exact, in a large black leather briefcase.

title: New Haven Symphony Heads Down Route 66
description: THIS Thursday night, Route 66 will intersect Interstate 95 in New Haven.

title: Parity Begins at Home
description: Women and human Development

title: A Vowel, Please
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: To Help the Homeless, New York Must Build
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE GALLERY WITH/Sigmund Balka; A Lawyer Who Turns Office Spaces Into Exhibition Halls
description: SIGMUND BALKA knows his law. That's why he is general counsel of Krasdale Foods, a major grocery distributor with headquarters in White Plains and a distribution center in the Bronx.

title: It's Hard to Kill a Good Oriental Carpet
description: TAKE a look down there, below your feet. There's your Oriental carpet, finely woven, perhaps 100 years old. It may be a treasured heirloom, or a valuable purchase worth tens, or even hundreds of thousands of dollars. Yet you lay it on the floor and walk on it day in and day out. The children spill juice on it, the dog has accidents on it and the cats claw it when nobody is around.

title: Latin America Loses Its Technology Gleam
description: SCANNING the wreckage of Latin American technology stocks, it is hard to believe that just six months ago investors in both North and South America were giddy about prospects that the Internet would grow faster in the region than anywhere else in the world.

title: Rent Laws Affecting Conversions
description: CHANGES in New York laws governing rent regulation in the last decade have strengthened the hand of owners seeking to convert buildings to co-ops or condominiums, real estate lawyers say.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 24 about the performance work ''Lifegame'' referred incorrectly to Keith Johnstone, who developed the improvisational exercise on which the show is based. He was not the founder of the Royal Court Theater in London; George Devine was.

title: Bookshelf
description: WHERE'S WALLACE? Written and illustrated by Hilary Knight. Simon & Schuster. $17. (Ages 4 to 8) Wallace is a cute little ape who escapes from the zoo. His keeper, Mr. Frumbee, chases him all over town; the game of this book, first published in 1964, is to find the rascal in the double-page panoramic illustrations. There are all sorts of witty vignettes in each busy scene.Young children are best at the game. The ''Waldo'' books, which came decades later, are based on the same joke. Wallace is as charming as ever.

title: Jerusalem's Meaning For People Besides Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: McKay Provides the Power in Devils' Power Play
description: Most of his teammates lean back to catch their breath between shifts, but Randy McKay always props an elbow on the boards and leans forward, as if he is ready to propel himself back on the ice at a moment's notice.

title: Sports of The Times; Laying Down the Law, High and Very Tight
description: As a Texan, Roger Clemens is straight from the western movies, the hired gun brought in to restore law and order.

title: Daniel H. Lavezzo Jr., 83, Owner of Famed Saloon, Dies
description: Daniel H. Lavezzo Jr., who for more than half a century as an owner of P. J. Clarke's saloon offered patrons from ironworkers to movie stars the comforts of cold beer, a dark refuge and juicy hamburgers, died of heart failure Tuesday at his Manhattan home. He was 83.

title: Behind the Artists' Curtain
description: In a nice bit of interconnectedness, Princeton-area artists are offering an unusual event today to benefit a historic house, which is in turn hoping to create create something that will benefit the dramatic arts.

title: Jacqueline Golaine, Robert Florio
description: Jacqueline Brooke Golaine, a daughter of Rosalyn Golaine of Demarest, N.J., and Joseph Golaine of Bellaire, Tex., was married last evening to Dr. Robert Armand Florio, a son of Dolores Florio of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Armando Florio. Rabbi Roger Ross officiated at the Castle at Tarrytown, N.Y., with the Rev. Neil O'Connell, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Energy Salvation? Not in the Arctic
description: To the Editor:

title: Drivers Are Concerned About Steering Clear of Trouble
description: The biggest complaint by drivers using carburetor restrictor plates at Nascar's biggest tracks has been the lack of throttle response when trouble arises.

title: T.C.U. Fears It May Miss a Top Bowl
description: FORT WORTH, Oct. 14  Texas Christian University, one of only seven undefeated Division I-A teams in the country before this weekend's games, has its highest ranking in The Associated Press since 1984 at No. 12, and only Nebraska has a longer winning streak than the Horned Frogs' 10 in a row.

title: October 8-14; L.A. on Strike
description: More than 40,000 Los Angeles County employees -- mostly clerical and service workers -- walked off the job at welfare clinics, beaches, libraries and the marriage license bureau to protest stalled negotiations on a new contract. Leaders of Local 660 of the Service Employees International Union agreed to return to work the next day, after a plea from Cardinal Roger Roger M. Mahony, who said the strike was hurting the poor. But a separate strike by bus and subway operators dragged into a fourth week. Todd S. Purdum

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the second day of Sukkot, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side street cleaning regulations will be suspended today.

title: Ex-Premier Of Singapore Sees Pitfalls In Debt Relief
description: Lee Kuan Yew, who turned a pestilential port called Singapore into a country with living standards to rival those of Europe, is warning leaders of developing nations against viewing debt relief as a panacea for faltering economies and also urging them to avoid the trap of development theories that are more ideological than practical.

title: Habitats/Jersey City; A View of the Skyline, From Across the Hudson
description: GOING to the waterfront in Jersey City is a bit like going to Disneyland. On the shores of the Hudson River, the tall buildings are all new, their lawns perfectly trimmed. Glistening and clean, the towers sit across from the old land of Manhattan in the new land of -- well, the new land that is five minutes away from Wall Street on the ferry. Call it, maybe, Ferryland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDLICH, DR. THEODORE, JR.
description: EDLICH-Dr. Theodore, Jr. On October 13, 2000. Retired Internist at Saint Clares and Cabrini Hospitals. Devoted husband of DeDe and the late Virginia. Beloved father of Theodore III, Dr. Richard and the late Stephen. Dear grandfather and great-grandfather. Dear brother of Marguerite Volmer and uncle of Robert Volmer. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to: The Multiple Sclerosis Foundation or Diabetes Foundation. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20 Street), New York City, Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services will be held at the funeral home Monday at 11:30 AM. Interment at Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: An Adventurer's Map to a World of Information
description: IT'S all made up,'' Matthew Ritchie says with a characteristically inscrutable grin as he settles into a chair in his Chelsea studio. ''Except for all the parts that are true.''

title: Article 2000101590325647389 -- No Title
description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-15-00; Investing Is the New Spending
description: In May, as he bickered with Gov. George W. Bush over the wisdom of allowing individuals to invest portions of their Social Security withholding taxes, Vice President Al Gore made a startling admission: he hadn't made a single dollar from the bull market. In fact, Gore explained, to avoid any conflicts of interest or the appearance thereof, he didn't even own stock, and hadn't since 1976, when he first joined Congress. The man fighting for ultimate stewardship of American fiscal policy had taken a pass on the greatest investment opportunity of our time in favor of an interest-bearing checking account.

title: Vienna, Where Ethereal Strudels Meet Savory Schnitzels
description: ON a recent trip to Vienna there was a fall bite in the air. Although it was still warm enough to have cake and coffee at a sidewalk cafe, the leaves were turning, and signs of autumn were evident on every menu. In addition to the year-round dumplings, strudels, schnitzels and sacher tortes, there was an abundance of wild mushrooms, pumpkins, venison and boar.

title: A New Fight for a Rich Slice of the Insurance Pie
description: LONG ago, the Chubb Corporation figured out that wealthy people would pay a little more to insure their mansions and yachts if, when it came time to collect on a claim, they were treated royally.

title: Not-Quite Landmark Languishes in Limbo
description: Last year, a ceiling in the Angelo Petromelis College Point Senior Center nearly caved in under the weight of pigeon droppings. The birds had nested in the roof, and their droppings were eating through the ceiling.

title: In an Enclave, The Spectrum Is From Gore To Nader
description: THE SETTING -- Ralph Nader may not be included in the presidential debates, but on Tuesday night, inside the cozy auditorium of Public School 321, Park Slope's purple-turtleneck and grizzled-beard set made a place for him. Below walls hung with hand-painted quilts, 200 residents filed in for a local version of the Nader-Gore debate that never was.

title: October 8-14; Company for Rudolph
description: The airspace over the North Pole, once avidly scanned for incoming missiles, could soon see thousands of flights by commercial jets. The demand for the polar shortcut between places like Chicago and Hong Kong is more than adequate to pay for the air traffic control investments that would be needed, according to a joint Canadian-Russian study. As many as 8,000 flights a year might use the shortcut by 2004, according to proponents. Matthew L. Wald

title: In Search of New Music, Both Ancient and Modern
description: IT'S been said that the physicist and radio pioneer Guglielmo Marconi harbored hopes of inventing a device to capture and amplify the faint but theoretically still resonant residue of historic sounds, and that his own wish was to hear Jesus delivering the Sermon on the Mount. That's the kind of dream John Schaefer can appreciate.

title: A Disappearing Novel
description: THE COLOR OF SUMMER

title: Banned in Boston
description: To the Editor: Martha Weinman Lear and I grew up in Boston at about the same time. Her Boston in the 1950's was a ''consummately dull town.'' My Boston was enjoyable, stimulating; hers, it seems, insulated and insular.

title: Quaking at the Thought of a Subway Series; The Secret Shame of Some Fans: Losing Would Be Too Much to Bear
description: Lou Palumbo was in no mood to confess, but confession -- like a tiny chicken bone -- was caught in his throat. To spit it out required a secluded corner of a busy bar, the company of his two best friends and the assistance of at least three rounds of bottled beer.

title: Guerrilla Sect Emerges as Force in Palestinian Uprising
description: Hezbollah, the Lebanese Shiite Muslim guerrilla movement, appears to be playing a growing role in encouraging the Palestinian uprising against Israel in recent days.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Benefits column last Sunday about a fund-raiser that offers a preview of the Giorgio Armani show at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum misstated the date. It is this Wednesday; it was not last Wednesday. Information and tickets: (212) 935-1033, ext. 202.

title: When Bribery Is Lost in Translation
description: BRIBES are tricky. Well, not the bribes themselves. Deciding what constitutes a bribe and then whether you should pay one to do business in a foreign country -- knowing full well that if you don't, a less ethical competitor might -- can be the real quandary.

title: Campaigns and Global Crises
description: Once again the United States has been jolted by foreign crises in the midst of a presidential campaign. Indeed, the turmoil in Israel, the deaths of American sailors in Yemen and the overthrow of Slobodan Milosevic in Serbia all serve as reminders that we are not just choosing a chief architect of domestic policy on Nov. 7. We are also choosing a commander in chief and the nation's principal diplomat. Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush expressed substantial agreement in their debate last week on the centrality of America's role in an unstable world. But recent events underscore that variations in approach can be very important in dealing with real-world events.

title: Airlines Raise Fares For Fifth Time in 2000
description: Major airlines have raised full coach fares for the fifth time this year by imposing fuel surcharges of $20 to $60 on round-trip tickets. Heavily discounted leisure fares are not affected by the latest fuel surcharge, initiated by Delta on the Sept. 30 weekend and quickly followed by all the other major carriers except Southwest. The surcharge is $10 each way for up to 500 miles, $20 for 500 to 999 miles and $30 for longer trips.

title: Children's Books
description: HENRY HIKES TO FITCHBURG

title: Lebanons Hezbollah Captures Israeli Colonel
description: BEIRUT, Oct. 15 -- Lebanon's Hezbollah said on Sunday it had seized an Israeli colonel in a "complex security operation" eight days after it captured three Israeli soldiers in south Lebanon. "With God's help, I am honored to inform you gladly that the Islamic Resistance performed a qualitative and complex security operation, capturing an Israeli colonel, who works for an Israeli security apparatus," Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah announced at a conference in Beirut amid applause.

title: If It Glitters, Wear It
description: Sparkling gold for day or evening, a whole range of sandy beiges and dark brooding bronzes make up the first color palette to emerge for fall, raising the question: Could they be the new black? These sunset colors signal autumn in New York. Shown here are women who captured the look in all its variations, in clothes that echo popular sporty and classic looks. For many, it's in the mix of fabrics and textures: far left, a suede skirt, a finely knitted sweater and a fur bag in the same tones; far right, top and bottom, gold leather coats, jackets and skirts. For others, gold is an accent accessory in shoes, bags and belts. All this shine seems to put a positive spin on dressing.

title: 'Rats in the Grain'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Spend Now
description: Everyone knows the conventional story about American spending habits. It begins with the Great Depression, which instilled a permanent thrift mentality. Scarred by deprivation, sobered by the scarcity of the war years, Americans in the middle of the 20th century were transformed en masse into tightfisted, financial neurotics, perpetually saving for the next rainy day.

title: Keep the Boundaries
description: To the Editor:

title: Havens for Babies, Choices for Mothers
description: THE phone call came into the Nassau hot line run by the AMT Children of Hope Foundation on the morning of Oct. 6. Timothy Jaccard, the foundation's founder and president, answered. But on the other end of the line, there was silence. ''Are you looking for help? Are you are in trouble and pregnant?'' Mr. Jaccard asked. The caller, a woman, exhaled a sob. He reassured her that she had options and pleaded with her to go to a hospital, where she would remain anonymous and could relinquish her child if she wished. Then, there was a dial tone.

title: Soaring and Plunging, But Without the Private Jet
description: For Michael H. Jordan, the former chief executive of Westinghouse, the biggest change in moving from the old economy to the new as chairman of Luminant Worldwide, a provider of e-commerce services based in Dallas, was in transportation. ''Life in the private sector -- i.e., without your Gulfstream -- really lacks,'' he joked last week.

title: They Have All the Answers
description: HOW many cows does it take to produce the nation's supply of milk and dairy products? What about in 1928?

title: Spiritual Traditions as a Perpetual Well of Inspiration for Art
description: 'The Perpetual Well'

title: New Ghosts in the Machine
description: HALLOWEEN may be two weeks off, but ghosts will soon be flying in Madison Square Park. ''The Influence Machine,'' an installation by Tony Oursler that opens on Thursday evening, uses projections onto smoke and trees to create ghostly images.

title: N.J. VINES/Bridgeton; California Conditions, New Jersey Soil
description: Marimac Vineyards occupies ''an amazing California site'' in one of New Jersey's most favorable fruit-growing areas, in Gary C. Pavlis's judgment.

title: Oh, Brother...
description: He's a streetwise 14-year-old with a penchant for trouble. She's a sophisticated 15-year-old whose life's ambition is to set him straight.

title: You Friars Eat With Those Dirty Mouths?
description: The comedian Richard Belzer was sitting in the kitchen of the Hilton Hotel in Midtown working out some jokes for the Friars Club roast of Rob Reiner. The material was about as sharp as a bowling ball. But still, he was laughing at it.

title: A Colder, Fuel-Burning Winter Is Expected to Chill the Northeast
description: Winter in the Northeast this year is expected to be colder and snowier than in recent years, the National Weather Service says, raising the prospect of significantly higher heating bills for consumers even as oil prices have already been rising.

title: Endpaper; The Going Rate
description: The widow wanted the cherry coffin. All she could think of was her husband, dead. Dead at 40 in the dead of winter; dead in the front yard of a Sunday morning with the ice spud beside him and his ice-fishing gear -- tip-ups and jig poles, thermos and brandy -- spilled from the white plastic bucket he kept them in, all littered in the snow and on the ice around him.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: A HOUSE IN EARNEST

title: Of the Courts And Home Contractors
description: To the Editor:

title: Unwanted by Many, Rice Now Aims to Prove His Critics Wrong
description: A summer that began with a National Basketball Association championship, and the expectations of heavy courtship and a big payday, quickly turned grim for Glen Rice. The respect that usually comes with winning a title never came and the long line of teams battling to sign one of the league's best shooters to a near maximum-level contract never materialized.

title: WILDWOOD'S VISION
description: Wildwood officials last week announced a $40 million redevelopment plan that plays on the beach resort's 50's style architecture. The plan, for which officials are seeking state and federal grants, includes a big neon arch on Rio Grande Avenue and replacing a pedestrian mall on Pacific Avenue with two-way traffic, ideally cruising with the top down. Steve Strunsky

title: With Echoes From a Dark Past
description: THE REV. JAMES FLAVIN still remembers what it was like to visit 17-year-old Mark Wahlberg in the Deer Island prison near Boston where the future rapper, underwear model and movie star was serving time for attacking a man with a hooked stick that took out his eye during a robbery.

title: Out of the Hospital After 13 Months
description: THIRTEEN months after she was admitted to New York United Hospital in Port Chester with West Nile virus, Danuta Trojanowska has finally been released.

title: Kathleen Seiler, Sean Neary
description: Kathleen Marie Seiler, a daughter of Patricia and William Seiler Jr. of Fairfax, Va., was married yesterday to Sean Matthew Neary, the son of Marjorie and James Neary of Merrick, N.Y. The Rev. Donald Greenhalgh, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Historic Church in Fairfax Station, Va.

title: What's Next? Rights For Mites?
description: SHOULD rats have rights? Should mice have standing? Does the canary's desire to sing deserve the law's protection?

title: Reckonings; The Un-COLA Economy
description: According to the script, we were supposed to spend this first year of the new millennium celebrating the glories of the new economy. If things did go wrong, they were supposed to go wrong in some appropriately futuristic fashion -- the Y2K bug would shut down the world, or we would have an exotic financial crisis involving e-commerce. (Business Week's economics editor has just published a book titled ''The Coming Internet Depression.'')

title: The Wildest World Series
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14  Forbes Field, its ivy-covered walls then as much a tradition as those at Wrigley Field, was rocking and rolling and shaking to its foundation, exhaling a burst of joyful sound that  and many talked about it the next day  could easily be heard several miles away in downtown Pittsburgh.

title: Who Keeps Track Of the Tree-Cutters?
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Books From The Times
description: Why was there enough science in the 20th century to make this newspaper engage a whole staff of science writers and editors and produce a science section (Science Times) every week? Maybe because, as Stephen Jay Gould points out in his foreword to SCIENTISTS AT WORK: Profiles of Today's Groundbreaking Scientists From Science Times, edited by Laura Chang (McGraw-Hill, paper, $19.95), the sciences drew, for the first time, on a democratic pool of talent. In this country and others, bright and curious kids from poor homes or unfashionable backgrounds could rise through public university systems to the great laboratories and the glittering prizes. The 50-odd scientists profiled in this volume are an amazingly various lot, and so are their scientific enterprises, from proving Fermat's last theorem (it took 356 years) to trying to develop new experimental animals. One woman here, Anne Simon of the University of Massachusetts, is the science adviser to ''The X-Files.'' A couple, Kathy Schick and Nicholas Toth of Indiana University, make prehistoric-style stone tools and study whether a chimp can do likewise (so far, no). Theorists of everything and theorists of practically nothing abound, but in a way the most radical is Lene Vestergaard Hau of the Rowland Institute for Science, who has slowed the speed of light down to 38 miles per hour and is working on reducing even that.

title: The Nation: Drug Wars; What Is the Matter With Mary Jane?
description: THE medicinal use of marijuana has scored some smashing victories at the polls in recent years, winning approval by voters in seven states, and it's on the ballot in two this fall. But in Alaska, an important test is at hand for those who use images like ''Trojan horse'' and ''camel's nose under the tent'' to argue that medical marijuana's advocates are really out to clear the way for the legal recreational use of the drug.

title: Cradle of a Political Dynasty
description: LET me have my Farm, Family, and Goose Quil, and all the Honours and Offices this World can bestow, may go to those who deserve them better, and desire them more. I covet them not,'' John Adams wrote to his wife, Abigail, in 1776.

title: For casual dining, with coffee or wine
description: There are at least three typically Viennese modes of casual eating: the cafe, the heuriger (wine tavern) and the stand-up sandwicherie.

title: How They Make a Fake
description: Drawing an envelope from an inside pocket of his leather jacket, Fabio slides out a fresh $100 note and, clasping it gingerly between thumb and forefinger, holds it up to the bare bulb. ''It's a good one,'' he says. ''High quality.'' He hands it to his friend, a cocaine-and-arms dealer, who turns it over in his fingers and nods. We are in a house in north Bogota, the capital of Colombia, which is the principal source of counterfeit bills in the United States. After a series of negotiations that led me downward through Bogota's underworld, I was introduced to Fabio, who agreed to explain to me the process of counterfeiting and the business choices counterfeiters make.

title: Promoting the Flea Market System
description: Several years ago, Jerry Stokes took on the task of organizing what he estimates to be a multibillion-dollar industry representing more than one million vendors and 100 million regular shoppers. He succeeded. Three years ago, he became the founding executive director of the National Flea Market Association, based in Charlotte, N.C. ''The largest flea markets dwarf the average-size mall,'' Mr. Stokes said.

title: MOUNT PLEASANT: FUTURE OF COMMUTER LOT
description: The fate of a 120-space commuter lot built by Mount Pleasant two years ago will be decided in State Supreme Court in White Plains this month. The Federated Conservationists of Westchester County, a 30-year-old environmental group, sued the town in 1998, claiming that the property is part of a county park and the town should not have cut down trees on the two acres of it used for the lot, which serves the Valhalla train station. The group wants the parking lot turned back to woods or, if that is not possible, it wants Mount Pleasant to give the county comparable land for its parks system. Mount Pleasant contends that the state owns the land and it received permission to use the property from the State Department of Transportation. Elsa Brenner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROWLEY, RICHARD LEA
description: CROWLEY-Richard Lea. 54. On October 13, 2000 of Franklin Square, NY. Formerly of Susquehanna, PA, after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Mary Ann (nee) Korba. Loving father of Jennifer Lea Crowley and Mary Beth and Ryan Osborne. Devoted son of Jane Crowley. Dear brother of Fr. Thomas Crowley and Kay and Tom Culnane. Fond uncle of many loving nephews and nieces. Also survived by a loving and caring extended family and numerous friends and co-workers. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th Street, Garden City, Sunday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Visiting at the Hennessey Funeral Home, Susquehanna, PA, Tuesday 2-4 PM and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday 12 noon, St. Johns Evangelist Church, Susquehanna. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Family and Children's Association, 100 E. Old Country Road, Mineola NY 11501 appreciated.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A Happy, Scary New Day for Design
description: IT is scary to be living at a time when a particular creative field grips the public imagination as powerfully as design has in recent years. I can't recall anything like it since the late 60's and early 70's, when movies and pop music exercised a magnetic hold on the minds of baby boomers. Today, the vigor pulses through fashion, furniture, art direction, graphics and product and image design with a similarly captivating verve. Design has taken on its own life, and this raises a problem often encountered in consumer culture. The energy is pure delight. But can we turn it off?

title: The Privileged: Inmates Who Earn Honor Rooms
description: WHEN Jean Coaxum first moved into Fiske Cottage in 1994, she had trouble sleeping. After 10 years in prison, she missed the sound of doors slamming, keys rattling, toilets flushing and people screaming. It was too peaceful.

title: Banned in Boston
description: To the Editor: Reading Martha Weinman Lear's essay ''Born and Bred (and Banned) in Boston,'' (Sept. 24) felt as if I were reading my own words, better written.

title: Unbelievers Struggle in a House of Faith
description: LIKE Abraham and his tribe, the New Schul and its rabbi wandered the lunar month from Rosh Hashana (the New Year) and Yom Kippur (the Day of Atonement), through the harvest festival of Sukkot and then Simhat Torah, which falls next Saturday and completes the year's reading of the Torah.

title: The Sweet Water of Montville
description: THREE judges held up their goblets, sniffed the bouquet, and sipped. And the winner was: the well water from Independence Village, an elderly housing complex in Montville.

title: Vienna's Haunting 'Third Man' Theme
description: IN 1948, when Carol Reed and Graham Greene started work on ''The Third Man,'' they had in mind a thriller infused with Greene's famous moral ambiguity and haunting sense of place. They wound up producing not just a cinematic landmark but also what many regard as a valuable documentary, a kind of time capsule, of post-World War II Vienna.

title: Cost Of Being Alive; The Week-to-Weeker
description: Jeff Rogers, 18, dropped out of high school last winter and worked to get his G.E.D. Theoretically, he's saving to go to college, but saving doesn't come easy. He recently got a job at Crystal's, a shoe store in Boston, where his first check netted him $201. The money went fast.

title: The First Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: We're No. 1, and Paying for It
description: It was an eerie coincidence. On Wednesday night, Al Gore and George W. Bush debated foreign policy for some 40 minutes. The next day, the tense confrontation between Israelis and Palestinians erupted into virtual open warfare, and in Yemen, the American Navy destroyer Cole was bombed in a terrorist attack that took the lives of 17 sailors.

title: Hollywoods Aging Divas Make a Film About . . . Aging Divas
description: HOLLYWOOD -- Elizabeth Taylor sits in bed and tells Debbie Reynolds how much she regrets stealing her husband 40 years ago. Ms. Reynolds owns a pathetic hotel where she displays her old costumes and sings in the casino. Shirley MacLaine is in a perennial road company of "Mame" and immersed in reincarnation. And Joan Collins not only undergoes liposuction and facial surgery every few years, she also speaks with a phony British accent, even though she's from Kansas.

title: Letters
