title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Chinese Leader, in Japan, Focuses on Economic and Security Issues
description: TOKYO, Oct. 15  The last time a top Chinese leader came to Japan, he lectured at every stop over the nation's past war crimes, demanding an apology, and the visit quickly degenerated into a fuming, finger-pointing session that damaged relations between Asia's two most powerful countries.

title: Cost Of Being Alive; The Self-Doubter
description: Paul knew he'd be rich someday, not because he had driving ambition, but because his dad owned a large company that would one day be passed on to him and his siblings. Now 43, Paul works as a graphic designer for the company. He receives a salary of $90,000 a year and maintains a lifestyle that costs him $30,000 a month.

title: A Star Volleyball Player Who Happens to Be Deaf
description: IT happened a year ago. It was an honor, but a daunting one for a pre-freshman.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We should be under no illusions. The good news is the parties have agreed to meet but the path ahead is difficult.''

title: Corrections
description: The Commercial Property column last Sunday, about brokers who specialize in small spaces, misstated the title of Bruce Mosler of Cushman & Wakefield, who said such transactions often began relationships with new customers. He is president for United States operations, not only for the New York metropolitan area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEITZER, IRVING
description: SCHWEITZER - Irving. Beloved husband of the late Betty. Devoted father of Mel. A beautiful, sweet, gentle soul. He will be sorely missed by everyone he touched; Maxine and all his loved ones, and his extended family of friends and admirers. Service Monday, 12:30 PM, at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87 St. and Madison Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to Simon Senior Center, Riverdale YM-YWHA, 5625 Arlington Ave., Bronx, NY 10471.

title: Carlyn Henry, Michael Mandelbaum
description: Carlyn LaRue Henry and Michael David Mandelbaum were married last evening at the Rough Creek Lodge in Glen Rose, Tex. The Rev. Michael G. Wallens, an Episcopal priest, performed a ceremony that combined Episcopal and Jewish traditions.

title: A SHORTAGE OF WORKERS
description: RECORD low unemployment and the booming high-tech industry are causing a labor shortage in Westchester, posing problems for employers and spurring growth in reverse-commuting from New York City.

title: Islamic Radicals in Indonesia Vow to Expel Israelis or Kill Them
description: For the last three days, gangs of grim-faced young men dressed in white uniforms with green scarves have stalked through Sukarno-Hatta International Airport, wooden rods in hand and one goal in mind: to kill any Israeli who sets foot in this, the world's largest Muslim country.

title: Suzanne Fowle, Narain Schroeder
description: Suzanne Charlesworth Fowle, a daughter of Marcia and Bruce Fowle of New York, was married yesterday to Narain Schroeder, a son of Suzannah and Mark Schroeder of Belvidere, Vt. Richard Grossman, a nondenominational minister performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in Sheffield, Mass.

title: Boston College Uses 4 Interceptions to Topple Syracuse
description: This afternoon's Boston College-Syracuse matchup was hardly a game for the Big East highlight reel. The starting quarterbacks were a combined 18 of 45 for an often wobbly 250 yards passing. The winning team gave up 306 yards on the ground. When the game was finally over, about all that was positive to say was this: It was a lovely, sunny day in New England for the 44,500 here at Alumni Stadium.

title: Nighttime Logic
description: Plaid isn't just for trench coat linings anymore. After last year's craze for Burberry plaid, the fashion world is finding ways to tweak the tartan. This season, using whimsical materials like leather and fur, and processes like tie-dyeing and silk-screening, designers are exploding the pattern of decorum. Even Burberry breaks out of the traditional grid -- as witnessed by its new monochrome jacquard plaid ties and bold plaid high-heel boots. To be sure, too much of a good thing can cause ganglion overload: Don't try these combos outside your home.

title: Three Bags Full
description: Plaid isn't just for trench coat linings anymore. After last year's craze for Burberry plaid, the fashion world is finding ways to tweak the tartan. This season, using whimsical materials like leather and fur, and processes like tie-dyeing and silk-screening, designers are exploding the pattern of decorum. Even Burberry breaks out of the traditional grid -- as witnessed by its new monochrome jacquard plaid ties and bold plaid high-heel boots. title: The Scorecard: One Double, Some Anger and a Slew of Baffled Batters
description: One by one, the Seattle Mariners acknowledged Roger Clemens's greatness tonight in the Yankees' 5-0 victory, offering awestruck testimonials that matched the pitches they tried to hit.

title: Cappelli Enterprises to Build Tower on New Rochelle Site
description: New Rochelle officials announced plans to sell a 1.9-acre downtown lot to Cappelli Enterprises, Inc., the developer of New Roc City, for $2.5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEICHMAN, LORRAINE AGNES
description: LEICHMAN - Lorraine Agnes. Peacefully at home in the arms of her beloved husband of 53 wonderful years, Carl Maclin Leichman, on October 5, 2000. Loving mother of Laurence and Andrew. Adored niece of Gertrude Salomon. Devoted friend to many. Lorraine, an effervescent woman of great charm, intelligence, courage, spirit, understanding, compassion, wit, and humor, had the marvelous gift to make people laugh and feel alive. A medical social worker and consultant for the aged and disabled, teacher, community activist, past vice-president of B'Nai B'rith and Hadassah, alumna of Adelphi University, and member of Temple Beth Shalom in Flushing, NY. Lorraine will be deeply missed by all.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Jane Reilly, Gerald Mount Jr.
description: Jane Wasey Reilly, the daughter of Lukie Chapman Reilly of Chatham, Mass., and William F. Reilly of New York, was married yesterday to Gerald Kenneth Mount Jr., the son of Myrl Kluge of Charleston, S.C., and Mr. Mount Sr. of Orangeburg, S.C. The Rev. Philippa A. Turner performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Shira Kaplan, Eric Kahan
description: Shira Beth Kaplan and Eric Howard Kahan were married yesterday evening by Rabbi Joel Sisenwine at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Boston.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINBURN, RICHARD GARDNER
description: WINBURN-Richard Gardner. 82, died on October 12, 2000 in Oklahoma City, OK. Born on July 31, 1918, he moved from NYC to Oklahoma City in September of 1998. Dick was the fourth generation of a family of photographers. He worked for Neiman Marcus, The New York Times, and Manufacturers Hanover Trust. A veteran of World War II, he served in the U.S. Army Air Force. Preceded in death by his mother Gertrude Gardner and his father Jay Te. Survived by his sons Richard Winburn Jr., of Bedford, TX, Charles D. Winburn and family of Oklahoma City; his former wife Mary Melton Winburn of Chickasha, OK; brothers Jay Te Winburn and family of Brandon, Manitoba, Canada, Walter Winburn and family of Sharon, CT; George Winburn and family of Corpus Christi, TX. He will be fondly remembered for his keen wit and ability to make people laugh from presidents to children.

title: Cost Of Being Alive; The Tightwad
description: Representative Mark Sanford of South Carolina adamantly opposes a pay increase for members of Congress. The 40-year-old Republican does not buy the argument that representatives need pay hikes because they are forced to maintain households in both Washington and their districts. ''I'm proof positive you don't have to pay two rents,'' Sanford says. When Congress is in session, Sanford sleeps in his office.

title: Food; A Chef of One's Own
description: 'Our idea of luxury is getting more basic the richer we get,'' says my friend who recently became more than a millionaire. She is calling to ask if I know anyone who would like to earn ''high five, low six'' figures a year cooking dinner five days a week for her and her husband. ''All I want is a decent meal on the table when I get home,'' she says. ''And maybe something fancier for dinner parties once in a while.''

title: Students Weigh In On Banned Book
description: The Port Washington school district has a national reputation for diversity and open-mindedness; we should keep it that way. So we were surprised and distressed when we first heard about the school board's decision to ban Julia Alvarez's novel ''In the Time of the Butterflies'' because it included a drawing showing how to build a bomb [''School Board Questions Fitness of Book Because of Bomb Diagram,'' Oct. 1].

description: Dr. Jennifer Allison Granite and Dr. David Dominic Matunis, veterinarians in New Jersey, were married last evening by Rabbi Peter Hyman at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Tackling a 'Culture of Secrecy' Over a Lack of Textbooks
description: Ever since school started in September, some students at Life Sciences Secondary School on 96th Street and First Avenue have been without textbooks.

title: The Great Hand-Me-Down Heap
description: Johnson's Ropa Usada, a concrete-and-cinder-block warehouse in the Texas border town McAllen, is the final resting place for some of the detritus of American consumer culture. The massive building is cooled by a giant, cacophonous fan. White light pours down from skylights. And strewn across the floor in huge, heaping mounds, like a brilliantly striated mountain range, are piles upon piles of used clothes. On Saturdays, the clothes go on sale for 30 cents a pound.

title: First Lady Proposes Aid for Care of Elders
description: Building on a campaign theme that has played well with many voters, Hillary Rodham Clinton today announced a new health care proposal aimed at providing financial assistance to families who care for elderly relatives and those with disabilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCER, CHURCHILL, LADY SARAH
description: SPENCER-CHURCHILL-Lady Sarah. Of Old Lyme, Connecticut. Died suddenly on October 13, 2000. Mother of Serena Balfour, Consuelo Russell, Alexandra Birch and Jacqueline Williams. Sister of the Duke of Marlborough, Lady Rosemary Muir, Lord Charles SpencerChurchill & the late Lady Caroline Waterhouse. Grandmother of Morgan McConnell, Lucinda McConnell, Consuelo Lily Balfour, Alastair Balfour, Alexander Judson, Nicholas Judson, Ian Judson, Eugene Williams, Harry Williams, and Philip Williams. She will be remembered and missed by all. Services to be held at St. James Epispocal Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street, Tuesday at 12 noon.

Higgins performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Joseph's Cathedral in Buffalo.

description: HARRY BALK died a young man in 1925. He was just 21, and like many impoverished Jews living here at the time, he was probably taken away by tuberculosis, influenza or a simple infection. His grief-stricken family spent a lot on a handsome granite marker, affixed to it his photograph, and etched in stone the following words:

description: LEHRER-Sidney. On October 13, 2000. Beloved husband of Martha. Devoted father of Stuart and Gary. Services Monday, 10 AM, at ''Guttermans Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI. Interment at the New Montefiore Cemetery.

description: Frank J. Prial II, publisher of The Chief, a newspaper for government workers in New York City, died Sunday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 80 and lived in Greenwich.

description: Nobody wins a Subway Series. Or maybe everybody does.

title: A Take-a-Kid-Fishing Trip: Not Just Children Get a Lift
description: My friend Chris von Strasser looked ready to go fishing. Dressed on this oppressive August day in safari shorts, sturdy brown shoes and a faded ochre shirt, he had slung over his shoulder the familiar, ratty old-world rucksack that appeared to have endured the Crimean campaign. However, as he was standing in the middle of Lexington Avenue, frantically flagging a cab, a cell phone pressed to his right ear, I knew this would be a fishing trip of a different kind.

title: Making the Connection In a Faraway World
description: PERHAPS it is because I left my country, Cuba, at 16, but when I travel I search for home. I don't mean I actually look at real estate listings, although I've been known to do that. My quest is more spiritual than physical.

title: Riches the Hapsburgs Sent to the Attic
description: SOON after the Hapsburg monarchy collapsed in 1918, the Austrian president set up offices in the former Imperial Palace in Vienna and began receiving official visitors in what was once Empress Maria Theresa's bedroom. Its royal family having gone into exile, Austria placed the glittering crowns and silver on public display.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKFURT, DORA WILKES
description: FRANKFURT-Dora Wilkes. On October 13, 2000 at the age of 105. Beloved wife of the late Jacob Frankfurt and Harry Wilkes. Loving mother of Daniel and Ruth Frankfurt, and Dina and Daniel Katz. Proud grandmother of Judith and Jim, Jackie and Mark, Aaron and Joanne and Lila and Stuart. Great-grandmother of Jordan, Joseph, Gabriel and Benjamin. She had a lifelong devotion to the support of Yiddish culture. Graveside service Sunday, 1 PM at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Mix Sex and Politics; Add a Feminist Twist
description: FEMALE sexuality is the great fearsome force at the center of the culture war: the social history of the past two decades is written on the bodies of women. There are the legions of unmarried mothers, abortion seekers, raped and battered women, anti-pornography demonstrators. And there are the stars of our national psychodramas: Madonna and Karen Finley; Candice ''Murphy Brown'' Bergen and Ellen DeGeneres; Amy Fisher and Lorena Bobbitt; Anita Hill and Monica Lewinsky. Even the locker room of government, with its pervasive scent of masculinism and Victorian hypocrisy, has been invaded not only by women seeking to join the team, but by sex uncensored and unsublimated. A subject once largely excluded from the public conversation on the grounds that it was private, obscene or trivial -- for each of these one might read ''feminine''-- is now an issue that no branch of government and no political leader can ignore.

title: Hezbollah Says It Seized an Israeli Colonel
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 15 -- Hezbollah guerrillas said today that they had captured an Israeli army colonel "in a complicated security operation."

That performance made it an easy decision for the Mets to start him against St. Louis.

description: As the White House announced today that President Clinton would head to the Mideast to mediate peace talks, Representative Rick A. Lazio continued his criticism of the administration, saying: ''What Israel needs right now is not a broker. It needs an ally.''

description: Most people can only dream of such problems, but according to some therapists and counselors, new money can weigh heavily on the wealthy. At the forefront are three women: Jessie O'Neill, a millionaire and therapist who founded the Affluenza Project in Milwaukee; Joan Indursky DiFuria, a co-founder of the Money, Meaning and Choices Institute in San Francisco, where the phrase ''sudden-wealth syndrome'' was coined; and Pamela York Klainer, an executive coach in New York who specializes

title: Grumman Site Getting High-Tech Incubator
description: SINCE 1994, when the Northrop-Grumman plant assembled its last F-14 and E-2 aircraft here, the 2,900-acre naval weapons facility has been in a holding pattern. Amid a host of development proposals, ranging from a golf course to a cargo airport, Riverhead's political and business leaders have been unable to decide on a course that would best replace the jobs and tax revenue that took flight when Northrop-Grumman abandoned its aircraft facility.

description: After earnings reports, rising oil prices and violence in the Middle East scared them away for most of the week, buyers came out in droves on Friday the 13th and pulled the major stock market averages out of the depths of just a day earlier. Trading volume was huge.

title: Ideas & Trends: A Nobel in the Family; My Brother, the Genius: Now I Know What He Does
description: AT 5:30 Monday morning my phone rang. Oh, swell, I thought, somebody died. But it was good news. My brother, Paul Greengard, was calling. ''I just won the Nobel Prize,'' he said. He sounded as though he didn't want to talk too loudly for fear his head would fall off.

title: Nature Painting That Looks Unnatural
description: WERE it not for several nearly life-size, Technicolor oil paintings propped against the walls, Alexis Rockman's TriBeCa studio might be mistaken for a taxidermy shop. The shelves are jammed with scientific books about everything from piranhas to praying mantises. A display case is cluttered with scorpion specimens and raccoon and beaver skulls, as well as a stuffed armadillo. ''Did you know the armadillo is the only mammal besides humans that gets leprosy?'' Mr. Rockman asked in all seriousness, if somewhat irrelevantly.

description: ERANI-Norman ''Nissim''. title: DRUG COMPANY SOLD
description: Block Drug Company, based in Jersey City since 1938, will be sold to the drug company SmithKline Beecham for $1.24 billion. Block Drug, founded in Brooklyn in 1907, produces Sensodyne and Poli-Grip denture adhesive, among other pharmacy items. Block Drug's net income in the previous fiscal year was $56.8 million. London-based SmithKline Beecham, which had $4.1 billion in consumer sales last year, and makes Nicorette gum and Tums antacids, among many other products, has more 47,000 employees in 160 countries. It is also preparing to merge with Glaxo Wellcome, a pharmaceutical research company. The Block family, which owns about 16 million shares of the Block Drug Company, will receive roughly $848 million for the sale. Block Drug employs about 3,000 people worldwide, 900 of them in New Jersey. Hugh Burns, spokesman for Block Drug, said the company expected the sale to lead to layoffs. The sale is expected to pass regulatory clearance in the United States and Europe by the end of the year. John Holl

title: Making Calligraphy Jump Off the Scroll
description: THE lobby of the Quick Center at Fairfield University, where theatrical and musical entertainment is presented, is fittingly festooned with large banners and scrolls. These works, with buoyant floral motifs and other images festive and profound, by Wang Ming, also serve as a lead-in to an exhibition by Mr. Ming in the adjacent Thomas J. Walsh Art Gallery.

description: LEBOWITZ - Professor Milton. (Mickey). Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Devoted father of Michael and Beth. Loving grandfather of Jacob, Ariel, Ben and Max. Devoted friend of Berthe Small. Services Monday, 10 AM, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave. (corner of E. 10 St.)

title: October 8-14; The End of the Discount Wars
description: Get ready to pay more for books. This year, the country's biggest bookstore chains and online stores all quietly raised their prices.

title: October 8-14; On Sale Now
description: With the New York market sizzling, landlords and investors have been putting some of the world's best-known real estate trophies on the block, from Rockefeller Center to the World Trade Center, in the hopes of scoring big before the boom peters out. The first to go was the Seagram Building, the bronze and glass skyscraper designed by Mies van der Rohe, which was snapped up by a pair of German developers for a cool $379 million. The bidding on Rockefeller Center has already topped $2 billion. And the paddles are just beginning to go up for CBS's Black Rock tower and the 42-story PaineWebber Building. Charles V. Bagli

title: Angered by Trucks, Residents Try To Reclaim a Street, Sign by Sign
description: A fight over oversized trucks on Broome Street has turned into a game of cat and mouse over traffic signs.

title: Cost Of Being Alive; The True Believer
description: Jo L. has never worked for money a single day of her life. She is 68 and lives alone in a lovely apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side. ''I never think about money, ever,'' she swears. ''I have no idea what things cost.''

title: Market Turbulence Does Little to Curb Investors' Optimism

Lucent Technologies, the club's biggest investment, had announced a profit shortfall that morning, and its stock had plunged 32 percent.

title: Technology's Standouts, Overtaken By Change
description: IN the last six weeks, more than $1.3 trillion has been stripped from the market capitalization of the Nasdaq composite index. That is just a bit less than a whole year's worth of economic output in Britain. Perfidious Albion indeed.

title: Banned in Boston
description: To the Editor: Having encountered hundreds of ex-military who served in Boston in World War II, I have yet to have one ask about the swan boats or Fenway Park. Practically all, however, can recall escapades in Scollay Square. The ''sin squad'' was a facade behind which the real Boston offered as much as any other major city in night life.

title: BRIEFING: EDUCATION; COLLEGE SQUEEZE
description: The number of students applying to colleges in New Jersey is increasing so rapidly that state-supported colleges will face a crisis in the next decade, according to a report issued last week by the New Jersey Association of State Colleges and Universities. The group said more than 38,000 applications were received for fall 2000 by the nine state schools it represents, compared with 35,000 a year earlier, and that more high school graduates apply to college. Deborah Nussbaum

title: Calling Corzine a Big Spender
description: This 30-second commercial, titled ''Money,'' was released on Thursday by the Republican Leadership Council, a national organization of moderate Republicans that supports Representative Bob Franks, the party's candidate for United States Senate from New Jersey. Mr. Franks is a member of the council's advisory board, but he says he did not ask for or authorize the ad. Because the commercial does not explicitly tell viewers to vote for Mr. Franks or against his Democratic opponent, Jon S. Corzine, it is not subject to federal campaign contribution limits. The ad will run on broadcast and cable stations in New York, New Jersey and Philadelphia over the next two weeks, at a cost of $520,000, a very modest media buy.

title: The Nation; Preventing Terrorism After the Cole Bombing
description: YEMEN is a failed state on the mend just around the corner from Somalia, in a truly wild neighborhood. It has been a haven for international terrorists and radical Islamic groups and there is little evidence that the government has any control over them.

title: Where to Go When You're Broke
description: The shelves at Spino's Pawn Shop in Waterbury, Conn., brim with mismatched goods: stereos, vacuums, saxophones, crossbows, video games, yellowing packages of Krazy Glue. The brothers who run the place pay hard cash for what people drag in, though they draw the line at anything that's alive; a fisherman once tried to pawn a string of wriggling carp. The money that the Spinos shell out is technically called a loan -- the interest is about 15 percent, the item itself is the collateral. If the loan is not repaid within a month, the Spinos sell the merchandise for two or three times what they spent.

title: When Josie Comes Home to Long Beach
description: ANDREW PISELLI is living every chef's dream. After working in the kitchens of others (Fishermen's Catch in Point Lookout and Newport Grill in Garden City) he now has a place of his own. Along with his partner, Darlene Barone, he opened Josie's last summer.

title: A Father's Triumph Over Cancer
description: BILL DRYSDALE and his wife, Laura, are putting up their Halloween decorations this week -- ghoulish purple lights strung from the trees, glowing pumpkins on the doorstep of their raised ranch house here. That doesn't sound like a big deal, but a year ago, Mr. Drysdale didn't know if he would see another Halloween.

title: Where the Elite Meet and Really Mean Business
description: ONE evening last month, Jim McCann, chairman of 1-800-Flowers, stood near the cold seafood appetizers in a private room in Hofstra University's library, reachable only by private elevator. He greeted about 100 invited guests who nibbled on shrimp and two types of caviar before heading into the adjacent dining room.

description: BEIRUT, Oct 15 - Lebanon's Hezbollah said on Sunday it had seized an Israeli colonel in a "complex security operation" and Israel confirmed that a businessman who is also an army reservist had been taken captive from Europe.

title: Leather On the Hill
description: Plaid isn't just for trench coat linings anymore. After last year's craze for Burberry plaid, the fashion world is finding ways to tweak the tartan. This season, using whimsical materials like leather and fur, and processes like tie-dyeing and silk-screening, designers are exploding the pattern of decorum. Even Burberry breaks out of the traditional grid -- as witnessed by its new monochrome jacquard plaid ties and bold plaid high-heel boots. To be sure, too much of a good thing can cause ganglion overload: Don't try these combos outside your home.

title: POSTINGS: Public and Private Construction Activity; Spending Soars 38% in the City
description: Spending on construction in New York City is expected to total $16.4 billion this year, an increase of 38 percent over 1999, when $11.9 billion was spent, according to a study of public and private construction activity commissioned by the New York Building Congress. Employment in the industry is expected to exceed 120,000 jobs, up from a total of 113,600 last year.

title: Bush Gains Ground In Democratic Bastion
description: Arkansas Democrats loved Al Gore back in 1988, when the state was one of only five where he won the party primary on his first presidential campaign. But now, even the Democratic Party headquarters of this rapidly growing city north of Little Rock is steeped in doubt and political ambivalence, much like the rest of the state and several of its Southern neighbors.

title: It's Off the Map, but It's His Country, Right or Wrong
description: ROBBIE FULKS doesn't sound entirely convincing when he allows, with Clintonesque caveats, that ''country is my first love, probably, at this point.''

title: Editorial Notebook; Memory, Musical Desire and the Beatles
description: When I was 11 and 12, my bedroom lay in a slanting, second-story afterthought grafted onto the back of a cavernous old house in Osage, Iowa. The only way into the room was through the one full bathroom in the house, and my window looked out past the garage and a back gate and onto the alley that ran behind Main Street.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Greg Reynolds, 48, Liturgical Choreographer
description: Gregory Christopher Reynolds, a dancer and choreographer, died on Sept. 21 at New York University Downtown Hospital in Manhattan. He was 48 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Word for Word/Mark David Chapman; Vanity and a Small Voice Made Him Do It
description: ON Dec. 6, 1980, Mark David Chapman boarded a plane in Hawaii for New York City, where he planned to win infamy by murdering a Beatle. He had a .38 caliber revolver tucked in his luggage and, by his own account, ''a small voice'' in his head telling him to kill. Two days later, John Lennon was shot dead.

title: Tommy Hilfiger Expands Store at The Westchester
description: The Tommy Hilfiger store at The Westchester has reopened after nearly doubling in size.

title: Amanda Vineyard, Kevin Kavanagh
description: Amanda Rahn Vineyard, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon C. Vineyard of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married yesterday to Kevin Patrick Kavanagh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Kavanagh of Grasmere, Staten Island. The Rev. Joseph A. Bassett, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Church in Chestnut Hill.

title: Places to Bring Out Night of the Living Fun
description: IT'S the season for spooks and haunts and Connecticut has it all. You can find everything from Colonial graveyards to Halloween theme parks, from simple hayrides through the woods to elaborate haunted houses. The only limitations are your stamina, your ''fright factor'' and the ages of other members of your party.

title: Bookend; The Gentle Realist
description: In his novel ''So Long, See You Tomorrow,'' based on a true story about passion and murder on a farm in the Midwest, William Maxwell invented -- for the purpose of witnessing some crucial events -- a thinking dog. As in: ''The dog took note of the fact that he didn't do any of these things.'' And: ''The dog couldn't imagine what had gotten into them.'' This thinking dog caused a stir in the fiction department at The New Yorker when the novel was about to be serialized there in 1979. Maxwell's editor, Roger Angell, and others of us in the department thought that the dog was a mistake. On several occasions Roger urged Maxwell to put the thinking dog to sleep. Maxwell is reported to have responded, in Bartlebyesque fashion, ''I'd like to keep it.'' Roger Angell is not and never has been an easy editor to face down, but this was no contest. If you look back at The New Yorker issues of Oct. 1 and Oct. 8, 1979, you will find the thinking dog there thinking away, to say nothing of taking note and imagining. He probably suspects that some time ago someone wanted to rub him out, and he may even pause to wonder why you're there checking on him.

title: The Art of Sisterhood
description: Karen Carrino was a 19-year-old coming into her own as an artist before she was killed in 1972 in a hit-and-run accident on the Garden State Parkway in Bloomfield. Her sister, Deborah, her brother, then 8, and a 3-year-old for whom Deborah was baby-sitting, survived. But Karen's legacy seemingly did not. Her grieving father sold most of her artwork, about 400 drawings and paintings of children, and gave the proceeds to two art students. About 10 years ago, Deborah, herself an artist specializing in tile murals, began a search for Karen's works. Her quest garnered television reports and newspaper articles (including one in this section in 1991), and drew out owners of the work from all over the country. She has managed to find 278 pieces, and has published photographs of 124 of them (including some clay sculptures) in ''The Spirit of Children: The Art and Life of Karen Carrino'' (Prometheus Books, $29). As her sister writes in the introduction: ''It feels in some way I'm doing right by Karen.''

title: Children's Books; A High-Anxiety Mouse
description: Kevin Henkes has a way with mice. He makes them human. And therein lies the charm of characters like Lilly, whose headstrong ways get her into trouble in ''Lilly's Purple Plastic Purse'' and ''Julius, the Baby of the World,'' and like Chrysanthemum, whose name causes her angst in ''Chrysanthemum.'' And now Henkes brings us Wemberly, whose worries never seem to end.

title: A Coach Relishes Miamis Rebirth
description: More than anyone else, Art Kehoe knows what it has been like at the University of Miami. And right now, it is like old times for the Hurricanes.

title: Why Living in a Rich Society Makes Us Feel Poor
description: Most of us are taught from an early age not to worry about how others' possessions compare with our own, and we seem to recognize the soundness of this advice. There will always be people with more, and becoming preoccupied with that is a recipe for misery. So if asked whether we fret about the size of our neighbors' house or about the cars they drive, most of us would insist we do not.

description: KEW GARDENS, Queens, is the kind of place where many pedestrians will not cross the street until the sign says ''Walk'' and will not feel sheepish about waiting to cross, even when there is no traffic.

title: Rookie Comes to the Giants as 300 Pounds of Talent
description: At 300 pounds, he can dunk a basketball with his back to the basket and his hands behind his head. He can dunk it with a reverse double pump. He can dunk it from the baseline, the foul line, the end line.

title: Corrections

title: Seles Inability to Place His Curveball Led to Game 3 Disaster for Mariners
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 14  Aaron Sele might have been the perfect pitcher for the Yankees to face at a time like this, when their offense is in need of a refresher course on the value of discretion. They mastered Sele on their way to a title in 1998, again in 1999, and on Friday they aced Sele again, taking one more step toward a possible Subway Series.

title: Playoff Games in Both Leagues Really Are (Yawn) Getting Longer
description: The question, as Casey Stengel never asked it, isn't "can't anyone here play this game?" but rather, can't anyone here play this game faster?

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 15 -- Hezbollah guerrillas said today that they had captured an Israeli army colonel "in a complicated security operation."

title: October 8-14; Security Council Elections
description: It's election time at the United Nations, too. An unusually intense fight for five rotating seats on the Security Council went into four rounds of secret ballots in the General Assembly before Mauritius, a small island nation in the Indian Ocean, was able to beat back a bid by Sudan -- with a little help from friends in Washington. Among the Europeans, Ireland won handily but Norway, the eventual winner, and Italy had to battle it out for the second vacant seat. Colombia and Singapore won the Latin American and Asian seats uncontested. The new members' two-year terms will begin Jan. 1, 2001. Barbara Crossette

title: October 8-14; The Speed to Know
description: The two services that distribute nearly all corporate press releases in the United States ended the decades-old practice of offering media organizations 15-minute advance copies. The reason: With thousands of Internet sites offering investors a chance to read the releases for themselves, financial newswires like the Dow Jones News Service are no longer the best way to ensure that all investors receive information at the same time. Alex Berenson

title: Leslie Anatol, Anthony Deckoff
description: Leslie Frances Anatol, the daughter of Theodora Affong of New York and Selwyn Anatol of Leesburg, Va., was married yesterday to Anthony Adlai Deckoff, a son of Jane and Marvin Deckoff of New York. The Rev. Brent Hart, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony at the Footprints Eco Resort in Culloden, on the island of Tobago.

title: Susanne Ricard-Konig, Daniel Power
description: Susanne Ricard-Konig and Daniel Louis Power were married yesterday on the beach in Southampton, N.Y. Mayor Joseph P. Romanosky Jr. of Southampton officiated.

title: Hastings-on-Hudson Again Moves to Revive Its Waterfront
description: FOR the better part of the 20th century, this village's residents could not make their way to the water's edge without running the risk of a trespassing charge. The land along the river was industrialized, owned by companies exploiting the convenient transportation afforded by the river.

title: October 8-14; Oil Workers Kidnapped
description: Ten foreign oil workers, including five Americans, were kidnapped in Ecuador by gunmen thought to be Colombian guerrillas. But the fates of the captives, who were whisked into Colombia by hijacked helicopter, grew more uncertain after the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, denied responsibility. American officials said privately that they believed a FARC unit had kidnapped the workers but that it might not have had permission from the group's high command. Clifford Krauss

Though long an Armani follower, when last we saw her she was wearing a black low-cut cocktail dress by Herve Leger in ads for her start-up, CrossWorlds Software. ''That was kind of shocking,'' said an Armani executive in California.

title: 'Forever Plaid' Returns To Place of Its Youth
description: ELEVEN years ago, a show jump-started and then slipped out of Teaneck, by all accounts a loser, never for all the world to see. Now it has come home a legend, or as close to one as any popular entertainment calling itself theater appears to be.

title: An Educator With a Vision Of Racial Harmony
description: WHEN Ronald O. Ross became Mount Vernon's Superintendent of Schools in September 1998, the city's school board was bitterly divided along racial lines.

title: Neighbors Are Happy to See a New St. George Going Up
description: Now that work is under way on renovations to the fire-damaged St. George Hotel, cranes and scaffolding have surrounded the site, creating noise and cutting off access to the sidewalk. Some neighbors said they were worried about how the new hotel would be run. But many expressed relief that a building was finally going up on the blighted lot. A lawyer for Moshe Drizin, the owner, said the new boutique hotel, an 11-story structure with 220 rooms, was scheduled to be finished in early 2002.

description: THE Boeing 777, the jewel in the fleet of many of the world's largest airlines, may be more likely to make passengers feel dizzy or nauseated than other, older airplanes, according to anecdotal reports from crew members and passengers.

title: Iraq Says It Resolves Saudi Jet's Hijacking
description: At least two men, apparently armed with explosives, hijacked a Saudi Arabian passenger jet enroute to London today and forced it to land in Baghdad, where after three hours Iraqi officials announced that they had succeeded in negotiating the freedom of all those on board.

description: He is a stranger in a strange land. An American soccer player in Europe. Germany for 10 years. He is no longer a young man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, FRANCES BARRETT
description: WHITE-Frances Barrett, educator and life partner of renowned artist, Charles White, passed away September 25, 2000. Frances' commitment to social and economic equality was marked by grace and tenacity. Born September 30, 1926, she spent her early years in Harlem with her parents, Marguerite Cassidy Barrett and Francis Barrett, Episcopal Pastor of The Advent Mission. Her loving children, Jessica Francis and Charles Ian as well as many dear friends will miss her wisdom and loving spirit. Cabot & Sons 626-793-7159.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, HILLEL ELIYAHU
description: LIEBERMAN-Hillel Eliyahu. Congregation Beth Torah mourns with deep sorrow the tragic murder of Hillel Lieberman, OBM, son of our beloved Rabbi Zevulun Lieberman. He was a kind and gentle person who dedicated and gave his life for the integrity of the land of Israel. Hillel was murdered by a Palestinian mob near Joseph's tomb while rescuing religious articles. Our hearts and prayers go out to his parents, Rabbi Zevulun and Bracha Lieberman, wife, Yael Lieberman, seven children, sisters, Tehila Lieberman, and Elyorah Ellison, and family. May The Almighty comfort them amoung all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Elie Abadie, Rabbi Executive Committee Congregation Beth Torah

title: The Nation: Tall Tales; Is What We've Got Here a Compulsion to Exaggerate?
description: ONE of Vice President Al Gore's favorite stories is about the time he fell for a trick played on him as a cub reporter at the Nashville Tennessean. He was writing obituaries one night when a funeral director called to report that a Swedish gynecologist, a certain Trebla Erog, had passed away. Subsequent calls -- secretly placed by one of Mr. Gore's colleagues, Jerry Thompson -- kept adding dramatic details. Finally, he learned that the doctor's distraught wife had died, too, on her way to the hospital.

title: Indictments in Silvester Scandal May Not Be the Last of Them

title: How Yugoslavia Won Fight for Change
description: Ljubisav Djokic, a construction worker, was asked to bring his bulldozer along to a mass demonstration in central Belgrade. When he found himself eye to eye with the police, he said, he decided to finish the job he came to do and advanced on the Parliament building. After 13 years under Slobodan Milosevic, Serbia had risen. It looked chaotic. But more planning lay behind the march on Belgrade than the final tumult suggests.

title: Israelis, Palestinians Gloomy on Summit Prospects
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 15 -- Israelis and Palestinians played down chances that a summit with President Clinton in Egypt could do more than break a wave of violence that claimed its 100th fatality on Sunday.

title: The Exchange Rate Behind Bars
description: The buildings that make up the Suffolk County Jail resemble a Moscow government complex. They are gray with staggered green windows and slab walls of cement, all ringed in high hurricane fencing and razor wire. Visitors are prohibited from bringing gum, candy or food. No medications. No hats or belts. No sweaters, jackets or coats. No jewelry. No hair curlers. No paper of any kind. No cigarettes or cigars. No alcohol.

description: MORAN-John D. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John D. Moran associated with The Times from 1967 until 1984.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Acura MDX; Through the Woods in Comfort
description: IF you come late to the party, you can make a grand entrance and be the center of attention, or you can find yourself so tardy that most of the guests have already gone home. There is no doubt that Acura has come very late to the luxury sport utility festivities.

title: Gazing Up Third Avenue and Seeing the Future
description: Commissioned to create the look of the major new business district planned around the Hub, the corner of 149th Street and Third Avenue, architects from City College roamed the area with cameras last week, craning their necks over a steady stream of traffic heading north to Yonkers and trying to see the future.

title: Skintight Clothes in a Skintight Shop
description: IT could have been a scene right out of a Candace Bushnell story. Three 30-something blondes were trying on leather pants, crowding in front of a mirror. Although they didn't know each other, the women had arrived simultaneously at Three Star Leather, an Upper East Side tailor, and were now bonding over the buttery hides.

title: Streetscapes/The Frick Art Reference Library; A Memorial Built by a Daughter for Her Father
description: IT looks like a colossal town house, but the limestone building at 10 East 71st Street -- 13 floors masquerading as 4 -- is really the Frick Art Reference Library, built in 1935 by Helen Clay Frick as a memorial to her father, Henry. Readers now dodge netting and dripping water from restoration crews to enter one of the world's great art libraries, created by a woman who found in her father's art collection both triumph and torment.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IT'S easy to forget what a skillful work Robert Zemeckis's FORREST GUMP (1994) is. Six years later, the special effects (from the hero, chatting with presidents to Gary Sinise's amputated legs) don't seem so amazing, but Tom Hanks's gut-level sincerity in the title role does. This is the story of a simple man's life, his love for one woman (Robin Wright, who is lovely as the emotionally bruised Jenny) and his encounters with Elivs, J.F.K., Bear Bryant, Dick Cavett, the Black Panthers, Vietnam, shrimp boats, Apple Computer stock and long-distance running. ''Forrest Gump'' won six Oscars, including best picture, best actor and best director, and it proved that an I.Q. of 75 and a good heart can get big cosmic free-for-all. You decide -- Saturday at 8 p.m. on Channel 7.

title: Coles Wounded in Germany, With Most in Fair Shape
description: LANDSTUHL, Germany, Oct. 14  Some were lining up for dinner on Thursday when a small boat loaded with explosives blew an 80-foot hole in the side of their warship. Others were asleep and were jolted out of their bunks.

title: Jeter Pays Price in Off-Season; Seattle Pays Price in Postseason
description: The alarm clock buzzes at 8 a.m. in January, and Derek Jeter crawls out of bed to start another day of workouts. He stumbles across the hardwood floors and into his kitchen for some orange juice, and leaves his house by 8:30. Spring training is six weeks away, but Jeter is already working because he wants to be able to do exactly what he did last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEDINE, WILLIAM S.
description: MEDINE-William S. 95 years old, on Tuesday, October 10 in Arlington, VA. Bill, whose former residence was West Palm Beach, FL, died quietly in his sleep at home. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife Edith. He is deeply mourned by his daughters Amy Medine Stein & Laurie Alexander. He was much loved by his son-in-law Arthur Alexander and his son-in-law Marvin Horovitz. He was honored in life by his late sonin-law Morry Stein. Bill's five grandsons, who adored him, are Eric, Tony and George Stein and Paul and Peter Saperstone. Grand daughters by marriage who benefited from his warmth are Mary Stein, Stacia Saperstone & Nancy Saperstone. He was thrilled to have four great grandchildren Amanda, Zachary, Emily and Jack and dearly loved his niece & nephew Bobbie and Phil Rubin and sister Anna Pero. Bill, with his wife Edith, was the founder of Camp Echo Lake, Warrensburg, NY. They served as directors from 1946 through 1963 wisely and lovingly guiding the many boys and girls who passed through their hands. From 1963 forward Bill and Edith mentored the second and third generation of family leadership, Amy and Morry Stein, then Tony, George and Mary Stein at the camp he loved so much. This past August he eloquently and proudly addressed the alumni who attended the festivities marking the 55th anniversary of the founding of Echo Lake. His vast family of friends feel privileged to have been touched by his elegance, wisdom and humor. His family is inspired by a patriarch whose devotion to his wife and family was without peer. His spirit, intellect and mind were vibrant until the very end. Shiva will be observed on Monday and Tuesday evenings at 49 Clubway, Hartsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Morry's Camp, a summer camp and year-round program he so generously endowed. The address is 3 West Main Street, Elmsford, New York 10523.

title: Foot Prints
description: Plaid isn't just for trench coat linings anymore. After last year's craze for Burberry plaid, the fashion world is finding ways to tweak the tartan. This season, using whimsical materials like leather and fur, and processes like tie-dyeing and silk-screening, designers are exploding the pattern of decorum. Even Burberry breaks out of the traditional grid -- as witnessed by its new monochrome jacquard plaid ties and bold plaid high-heel boots. To be sure, too much of a good thing can cause ganglion overload: Don't try these combos outside your home.

title: Mariners Win and Series Goes Back to New York
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 15  Roger Clemens pushed the Mariners to the edge of elimination on Saturday and it was left to the rest of the Yankees to push them off for good this afternoon. But after the Yankees flubbed several scoring chances early, the Mariners jumped back into the series.

title: October 8-14; Cosmic Clues
description: After pieces of a huge meteorite fell on the frozen surface of Tagish Lake in British Columbia last January, Jim Brook, who lived in a nearby cabin, collected the black fragments and kept them in a freezer. Scientists who analyzed the material now say it is the most important meteorite discovery in the last 30 years. The meteorite, a rare or new type of carbonaceous chondrites, appears to be the oldest and most pristine extraterrestrial material yet found. It may well bear clues about the early solar system and the origin of life. John Noble Wilford

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Patricia Field; Fits and Starts
description: DUSK was settling over Chelsea Piers, but at the rear of the huge Manhattan complex where ''The Street'' was recently being videotaped, the light blazed bright as noon.

title: How to Break New Jersey To the Kids
description: THE experts say that you shouldn't listen to the news in front of small children, because you never know when a truly disturbing story will come on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTER, STEPHEN G.
description: KANTER-Stephen G. Cherished son of Wendy and Richard. Beloved brother of Jordan and Bradley. Dearest grandson of Norman and Naomi Trigg, and the late Evelyn and Hy Kanter. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at ''BoulevardRiverside Chapels,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. Visitation Monday evening, 7-9 PM, at funeral home.

title: Different Styles Stirred Into a South Bronx Stew
description: THE space is huge and airy, with a wall of handsome old small-paned windows at the back. Men, women and children of all races sit expectantly in their seats as the lights go out. A dog barks behind a curtained dressing space as a small, solidly built man slips out and positions himself in the dark. Welcome to the world of Arthur Aviles and his Typical Theater.

title: A Red for All Seasons
description: Pinot noir is sometimes called a bridge wine because of its synergy with light through heavy dishes, from grilled salmon, roast chicken and grilled sausage to pork, lamb, duck (Long Island, of course) and beef.

title: Huddled Masses of City Statuary Face Eviction
description: THE doughboy gazes stoically through the mesh steel cage, unfazed by the clownish dent in his helmet or the bronze plaque leaning against his chest. He is surrounded by heads without pedestals, lampposts without lamps, eagles without perches.

title: Letters: Return to Sender, but Only if You Can
description: To the Editor:

title: GAS RATE INCREASE
description: Natural gas costs will increase for more than two million New Jersey residents under new rates approved by the Board of Public Utilities last week. The increases are a response to the 50 percent rise in wholesale natural gas prices since last summer. Public Service Electric & Gas, which serves more than 1.6 million customers, and New Jersey Natural Gas, with 400,000 customers, will increase gas costs this winter by 16 percent. Elizabethtown Gas Company's 250,000 customers will see a 17.3 percent increase. If wholesale prices continue to rise, the three companies will be permitted to increase rates by 2 percent each month from December to April. Angela Starita

title: Clemens Takes Defiant Streak To a New Level
description: Roger Clemens was trying to block out everything around him and focus on the Seattle Mariners tonight, but the information age is a tough place to hide when everybody in the ballpark and the baseball world is talking about you.

title: Wendy Wall, Andrew Robertson
description: Dr. Wendy Lynn Wall and Dr. Andrew Whitmore Robertson, history professors, were married yesterday in Malibu, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Gary Hall, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: World's Health Officials Seek Global Treaty to Curb Smoking
description: Tackling one of the top health scourges in the world, officials from 191 governments are gathering next week to begin negotiating a new global treaty aimed at controlling the use of tobacco and curbing smoking, especially among adolescents.

title: Dayne Carries the Giants to a Win
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 15  Giants Coach Jim Fassel had lost his star cornerback to injury and benched his top wide receiver. His special teams were in such disarray that a dropped snap, which did not result in a blocked kick, was a highlight. Twice he had turned to game officials to reverse a play via instant replay and twice the referee withdrew his head from the isolation of a sideline monitor and offered a head-shaking rebuke.

title: Cone and Gooden Reside in Uncertain New World
description: SEATTLE THERE is a gnawing sensation in the pit of the stomach that both Doc Gooden and David Cone associate with their new residence in the bullpen.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Veeco Announces Resignation of President

title: They Don't Have More Fun
description: FOUR Blondes By Candace Bushnell. 245 pp. New York: Atlantic Monthly Press. $24.

title: Observers Who Just Talk Weather
description: THEY record their backyards' temperature every day for decades and count inches of snow while others are counting sheep. They swap stories about the storms of '38 and '47 and '50 as if those cyclonic bad dreams were old friendly enemies. They are an integral part of the government's collective finger in the wind, and what the late Tip O'Neill said about politics, they fervently believe about the heavens: all weather is local.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GLADSTONE, KENNETH
description: GLADSTONE-Kenneth. Dear Kenny, It's been a year since you have left us and your family misses you and loves you very much. I feel great loneliness for you, but I have beautiful memories to sustain me. We hope you have found peace. With love always, Lucy, the children and the grandchildren.

title: The World; The Serbs Ask a Chance to Judge Their Own Guilt
description: OVER the warm remains of the regime of Slobodan Milosevic, the cries from abroad for extradition and repentance are growing stronger. The Serbs are getting credit for finally having dumped the man who ran the country for 13 years, through the wars of secession and the crimes that filled those wars, but the praise is leavened with doubts and questions.

title: So Nearly Everything Goes Wrong? Right!
description: Larry David and his wife didn't want to go to the pornography star's dinner party. They called the man by accident (a telephone number mix-up) and accepted only out of courtesy.

title: Ambitious Antidrug Plan For Colombia Is Faltering
description: Three months since the United States approved a huge aid package for Colombia, the overarching $7.5 billion plan to stabilize that nation and thwart its guerrilla movements and drug traffickers is already showing signs of disarray, officials and experts say.

title: Torre Looks to a Met for Strategic Inspiration, and Is Glad He Did
description: Todd Zeile of the Mets helped Manager Joe Torre of the Yankees learn a lesson that paid off, in a roundabout way, in Game 3 of the American League Championship Series on Friday night.

title: INVESTING; Seven Road Maps for the Treacherous Market
description: THE battered stock market has transformed from Santa to Scrooge in the course of six months.

title: Gore and Bush Health Proposals Fall Short of Counterparts' Plans 8 Years Ago
description: Vice President Al Gore has accused Gov. George W. Bush of ignoring the plight of the uninsured in Texas, which ranks near the bottom in health coverage.

title: Children's Books
description: SWITCH ON THE NIGHT

title: Accorsi Pact Is Extended Through 2003 Season
description: Giants General Manager Ernie Accorsi has signed a two-year contract extension, assuring not only that one of the best team executives in the National Football League will remain with the franchise through at least the 2003 season, but also that Accorsi will decide the coaching future of Jim Fassel.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVEE, FRANCES
description: LEVEE-Frances. Happy 7th birthday in Heaven, Grandma. Always in my thoughts. Love, Michae

title: Ellen Trachtenberg, James Copaken
description: Ellen Stacy Trachtenberg, the daughter of Joanne and Alan Trachtenberg of Berlin, N.J., is to be married today to James Matthew Copaken, a son of Bunni and Paul Copaken of Mission Hills, Kan. Rabbi Michael Zedek is to perform the ceremony at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: As Retail Space Grows and Spending Wanes, Some Stores Feel Pinch
description: Warner Brothers seemed to have a hit on its hands in 1993, when an astounding 20,000 people a day began streaming through its newly opened studio store at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 57th Street, plucking Bugs Bunny T-shirts, Batman dolls and action figures from the shelves.

title: Korea Could Get Too Peaceful
description: If North and South Korea reconcile, peace on their peninsula may come at the price of open hostility between China and Japan. The American troops who have patrolled the border for 50 years have also frozen in place old rivalries. By Howard W. French.

title: Mets' Reed Fails to Prolong The Festive Mood at Shea
description: The crowd arrived early yesterday at Shea Stadium and so did the hubris. The fans were lured by sunny autumn weather and a chance for a tailgate party on a weekend afternoon. Their overconfidence came from the Mets' two-games-to-none lead over the St. Louis Cardinals in the National League Championship Series.

title: In a Gray Area
description: A WHALE HUNT

title: A Chat-Room Merlin Drops His Wand
description: IN the Arthurian legend, Merlin was an enigmatic figure, an enchanter and seer who advised King Arthur -- but a wizard with a demonic side as well.

title: Clerk Challenges System, and Finds That It Works
description: ''If not for Howie Zibel ''

title: Piniella Applauds the Player Moves That the Yankees Made at Midseason
description: Lou Piniella spent enough time with the Yankees as player, coach, manager and general manager that he was intimately familiar with the number of players who filed through the roster's revolving door. But he never saw anything like the influx of players who filed through the door this season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUCKMAN, HAROLD
description: SCHUCKMAN-Harold. Respected retired profesor and former Chairman of Department of Psychology of Queens College. Son of Sam and Evelyn Schuckman. Beloved husband of Sally Schuckman. Loving father of Alisa, Larry and Harvey. Loving father-in-law of Rick, Kathleen and Jenny, and loving grandfather of Jackson. He will be rememberd and missed by all.

title: Liberties; As the World Churns
description: We were sleepwalking toward the election, not loving our choices, but not really too worried, with the country on palmy automatic pilot. Suddenly, three weeks out from a new president, the Middle East blows up and the markets tank.

title: Detainees Begin Hunger Strike, Advocates for Immigrants Say
description: Dozens of detainees at a federal immigrant detention center in Elizabeth, N.J., have started a hunger strike to protest conditions and what they call an unfair parole process, friends and a lawyer who have spoken with detainees in the last two days said yesterday.

title: Suzanne Elkin, Peter Borowsky
description: Suzanne Denise Elkin, a daughter of Sandra Elkin of San Francisco and the late Ernest Elkin, was married last evening to Peter Neil Borowsky, a son of Faye and Allen Borowsky of Boca Raton, Fla. Cantor Bernard Fitch officiated at Windows on the World in New York.

title: October 8-14; Bust and Boom
description: With companies from Home Depot to Motorola warning of profit disappointments, and oil prices surging as high as $37 a barrel as the Middle Eastern situation deteriorated, it was a rough week on Wall Street. By Thursday, the Nasdaq was at its lowest level in nearly a year. But Friday produced an explosive rally, with the index leaping 7.87 percent in its second-best day ever, as the oil price slipped a bit. Still, the price of crude oil ended the week at $34.99 a barrel, a gain of more than $4. Floyd Norris

title: Ithaca Journal; Sweet Fishing and a Gorgeous Gorge, if You Don't Mind All That Old Lead
description: Longfellow pictured an arrow shot into the air as the perfect metaphor for life's mysteries and the unknowable implications of our actions. But here, he might have pictured lead -- millions upon millions of tiny lead shotgun pellets, each about one-sixteenth of an inch in diameter, all fired into the air over the course of 100 years of manufacturing and testing firearms at a place called the Ithaca Gun Company.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THIS CRAFT OF VERSE By Jorge Luis Borges. Edited by Calin-Andrei Mihailescu. Harvard University, $22.95.

title: Scotty, Beam Me Up
description: Plaid isn't just for trench coat linings anymore. After last year's craze for Burberry plaid, the fashion world is finding ways to tweak the tartan. This season, using whimsical materials like leather and fur, and processes like tie-dyeing and silk-screening, designers are exploding the pattern of decorum. Even Burberry breaks out of the traditional grid -- as witnessed by its new monochrome jacquard plaid ties and bold plaid high-heel boots. To be sure, too much of a good thing can cause ganglion overload: Don't try these combos outside your home.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AXLER, MELVIN
description: AXLER-Melvin. Dearest Father. Our tears will never dry. Words cannot express how very much we miss you. Marsha and Toni

title: Conveying Sponsor's Rights
description: Q: Some members of our condominium's board are arguing with some unit owners over whether a member of the board who is also the holder of unsold units in the condominium has the same rights as the original sponsor. This board member bought his apartments from the sponsor 16 years ago shortly after the plan was declared effective. He says that since the original sponsor has the right to sell or rent apartments without regard to the building's rules, he has that same right. May his tenants and the new owners of the apartments he sells disregard the rules of the condominium that the rest of us follow? . . . Naomi Katcher, Manhattan.

title: Crime Rates Fall Again, but Decline May Slow
description: Crime in the United States fell again in 1999, the eighth consecutive decline, with the murder rate dropping to 5.7 per 100,000, its lowest level since 1966, according to an annual report by the Federal Bureau of Investigation being released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, HAROLD
description: HERMAN-Harold. 91, of Tamarac, FL, formerly of Rockville Centre, NY. Beloved husband of the late Ida (nee Jaffe). Father of Stephen (Elizabeth) and the late Henry Richard. Brother of the late Irma Meyer. Grandfather of Hunter and Sasha. His was a life of love. Funeral services Monday, 11 AM, at Riverside Gordon Chapel, 6701 West Commercial, Tamarac, FL, and Tuesday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Gifts may be made to the Ida Herman Memorial Fund at Winthrop University Hospital, Mineola, NY, or the Ricky Herman Memorial Symposia at L.I. Jewish Medical Center (Schneider Children's Hospital) in New Hyde Park.

title: Cost Of Being Alive; The Persister
description: Though she lives in Manhattan's Little Italy, surrounded by trendy restaurants and fabulous boutiques, Angela M., a 43-year-old actress and comedian, leads the life of an ascetic. She dreams of spending no money at all. ''I am thrilled when I get through a day without spending a cent,'' she says. Because her livelihood depends on it, Angela funnels absolutely everything she can into self-presentation, and that requires a lot of scrimping.

title: Dulling the Senses
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM; Sort of Pals in a Kind of Pas de Deux
description: I'M being eaten alive,'' a shy, freckled 15-year-old whispered to his director at the party following the premiere here last month of ''Billy Elliot,'' the film in which they both make their debuts. The young actor, Jamie Bell, was an unknown a month ago but is now being talked about as an Oscar contender. The director, Stephen Daldry, was called ''The Hit Man'' by London's Guardian newspaper. And their film, an affecting story of a miner's son who his family to learn ballet, took in the equivalent of $4.2 million in its first week, outdoing the breakthrough film ''Four Weddings and a Funeral.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-15-00: On Language; Blip
description: ''We don't react to day-to-day blips,'' said James Gorman, a Merrill Lynch sales chief. On ''Wall Street Week,'' Louis Rukeyser dismissed ''some renewed jitters in the wake of a blip in retail sales.''

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball Tradition Thriving in St. Louis
description: IN October, baseball is more than just games between teams that represent a city. It's often one area of America against another.

title: Jennifer Sliney, Aslan Cattaui
description: Jennifer Gray Sliney, the daughter of Robert and Diane Sliney of Skillman, N.J., was married yesterday to Aslan Basil Cattaui, a son of Maria Livanos Cattaui of Paris and the late Stephane Cattaui. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: Seeing Patrick Ewing From the Cheap Seats
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: In a Charter School Debate, Race Becomes an Issue
description: WE NEED a Marshall Plan for our schools,'' Ronald O. Ross said as he bounded up a staircase, two steps at a time, at Lincoln Elementary School here.

title: Article 2000101590602397506 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Trouble Filling the Ranks
description: THE Hartford Police department has had its problems. The last year was marked by a state criminal investigation that cleared a white officer who fatally shot an unarmed 14-year-old black robbery suspect, the arrest of seven officers accused of sexually assaulting prostitutes, and the removal of Acting Police Chief Deborah Barrows, the second African-American woman in the nation to be police chief in a major city. The department's critics, including many minority leaders, have said officers are often out of touch with those they serve, especially the minority community.

title: South Korea's Peacemaker
description: Two global flash points, the Middle East and the Balkans, have been in the spotlight in recent weeks for different reasons. Now comes a reminder from Oslo -- in the form of a Nobel Peace Prize -- of encouraging signs in another of the world's most enduring trouble spots. President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea has been awarded the prize for his efforts to secure peace and reconciliation on the Korean peninsula.

title: Quintet: No Instruments Needed
description: PICTURE one of those Saturday morning cartoons where an illustration in a book suddenly comes to life, leaping from two dimensions into three. That, roughly, is the sensation an uninitiated listener gets upon hearing Rockapella for the first time: the world of a cappella music, which had seemed like a calm, predictable place inhabited by barbershop and madrigal singers, suddenly is full of all sorts of new possibilities.

title: Mets Win and Edge Closer to World Series
description: The little guy started most of the trouble, and the big guy cashed in on it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-22

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILFORD, SOPHIE
description: WILFORD-Sophie, 86 years old of Port Washington and Glen Cove, New York. A former employee of The New York Times, she died on October 8, 2000. Wife of the late Olaf, designer for Tiffany & Company. Mother of Marion S. Quinn (John E.), Margaret Wilford-Tyson (Richard B.). Sister of the late Harry Shibuk (Velia) of Florida, and half sister of Charles Shibuk. Grandmother of Arthur G. (Colleen) and Andrea M. A Prayer service and burial was held at Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington, New York.

title: The Cajun Bug Bites And Feet Start Tapping
description: FOR an idea of what the zydeco dance concerts held once a month at the South Presbyterian Church here are like, imagine ''Saturday Night Fever'' with an uptempo rhythm and a blues soundtrack made even spicier by a dousing of Louisiana hot sauce.

title: What's Wrong?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cost Of Being Alive; The Compensator
description: Stuart Lishan is 36 years old. He studied art history at Lewis & Clark College, but left school early and lived hand-to-mouth as a restaurant manager in northwest Portland, Ore., until May 18, 1989, when an explosion in his apartment set him on fire.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Mixed-Use Development Plan for a Bleak Waterfront
description: IT is not much to look at:a 50-acre slice of Perth Amboy's waterfront dotted with empty factories and polluted, rubble-strewn lots. They are the remnants of industry's exodus in the 1970's from this once-bustling port city across the Raritan Bay and Arthur Kill from Staten Island.

title: The World; If Koreas Unite, Will Asia Divide?
description: FOR nearly 50 years, American troops billeted along the most heavily fortified border in the world have helped stave off a surprise attack by North Korea and have kept the line separating it from the south frozen in place.

title: SOAPBOX; Greg's Excellent Party
description: THE black stretch limo showed up in front of our house punctually at 10:45 on a recent morning. The assembled children, ages 9 through 12, were waiting on the front lawn. It was Greg's ninth birthday party.

title: Driven by Love
description: To the Editor:

title: In Camden, A Street Paved With Promises
description: Joe Brown looks over the dumbbells laid out on a table in front of a small, weathered truck. He chooses a pair of five-pounders, plunks down $10 bill and gathers his change. Then he walks away, careful to miss the muddy lake that covers about half the vacant lot at the center of the Admiral Wilson Boulevard where the truck sits.

title: In Gardens, Groundhogs Show Who's the Boss
description: I TRIED hard to know the enemy, the better to defeat him.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a word is omitted from an article on Page 29 of Arts & Leisure today about televised political advertising. The affected sentence should read, ''The power of televised political advertising has been proved repeatedly over the last half century, to the point that two out of every three campaign dollars at all levels, or about $1 billion this year, is spent on TV ads.''

title: Europe's Off-Season Is on Top
description: FOR the first time since World War II, when overseas trips were controlled by an entirely different agenda, off-peak travel to Europe from the United States has exceeded peak-season levels. Figures released last month by the Office of Tourism Industries, part of the United States Commerce Department, show that the departures of United States citizens for the off-peak months of October 1999 through April 2000 totaled 5,918,726, slightly more than the May-through-September 1999 peak-season total, 5,918,631.

title: Coal Sludge Blankets Kentucky Countryside
description: INEZ, Ky., Oct. 14  A gooey mixture of coal particles and water that leaked from a plant near here has been swallowing driveways, bridges and lawns in the countryside for the last four days.

title: October 8-14; Campaign Laugh Track
description: A running tally ranking the most joked-about politicians in late-night network TV monologues: Friday night,Oct. 6, through Thursday night, Oct. 12.

title: So Right In the Store, So Tacky At Home
description: IT happened last June, on a day early in the month when the air was still sweet and full of possibilities. I'd had lunch on Carnegie Hill with my mother and an old friend of hers, a former war correspondent who'd just written a novel.

title: All the Basics Of a Mexico Trip
description: AS temperatures drop in much of the United States, travelers' daydreams may turn to Mexico. Its warm climate, relaxed pace, miles of beaches and value continue to attract visitors from the north; the Mexico-United States border is one of the busiest in the world.

title: The Power of the Images Paid for by Politicians
description: IN 1948 Rosser Reeves the advertising executive who would later create the ''melts in your mouth, not in your hands'' commercials for M&M's -- approached the Republican presidential candidate, Thomas E. Dewey, with the idea of advertising on the new medium of television. Dewey flatly turned him down. Television, Dewey said, was undignified.

title: WESTCHESTER'S OWN EMS REGION
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has signed into law a bill permitting Westchester to form its own Emergency Medical Services Region. Until now, Westchester's EMS money was tied to six other counties, including Rockland, Putnam, Dutchess, Orange, Ulster and Sullivan, none of which are as urban as Westchester. State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, Republican of Yonkers, and Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, Democrat of Greenburgh, are authors of the bill. They contend that even though Westchester has 14 hospitals and the other counties only two or three each, it did not get its fair share of financing. Under the new law, the remaining counties will not lose any money. Elsa Brenner

title: Blue Jays Aide Wont Manage
description: TORONTO, Oct. 14  While the Toronto Blue Jays continue their search for a new manager, one name they can eliminate from any list of candidates is that of Dave Stewart.

title: Hyphenated Life
description: The Night My Mother Met Bruce Lee Observations on Not Fitting In. By Paisley Rekdal. 209 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.

title: Rent Increase May Expel a Longtime Day Care Center
description: The Henry Street II Day Care Center has served families in the Loisaida section of the East Village for three decades. But the city-run center, at 710 East Ninth Street, may have to close because of a rent increase.

title: Saving Your Way Into Debt
description: Savings, like chastity, is one of those hallowed American virtues that has, well, never really caught on. When it comes to the religion of thrift, Americans have sinned and sinned and sinned again. In the year 1999, for the first time since the Depression, the personal savings rate in the United States dropped below zero. Meanwhile, national credit-card debt has zoomed past the half-trillion-dollar level; the average American family carries about $6,000 on its plastic.

title: Opposites Meeting For Title In M.L.S.
description: It will be the best offense against the best defense in Sunday's Major League Soccer championship game.

title: Salvaging the Reputation of Sanctions
description: WITH euphoria sweeping the newly liberated Serbia, President Clinton might have expected a hearty greeting when he phoned Vojislav Kostunica last week to congratulate him on the democratic revolution he led. The conversation was cordial enough, the Serbian leader's aides said, but Mr. Kostunica had a few sharp words for Mr. Clinton: Lift the sanctions now.

title: Cost Of Being Alive; The Worrier
description: Last spring, Hanya Yanagihara, 26, was told that her lease was expiring. She had less than a year to find something new, and she decided to buy. ''First I saw the $80,000 studios, of which there were a lot, disappear. Then I saw the $100,000 studios disappear. By January, I knew that if I didn't do something, I would get priced out.''

title: OPINION; The Re-Emergence of Excess
description: ONE hundred years later, the Victorian age has recaptured the American landscape. The material power of the robber-baron era has reappeared, as have many of its values and tastes. The quest for instant gratification and its glaring facade is being achieved, especially in the domestic realm. In this age of ''political correctness,'' where freedom of expression is gradually eroding, a frenetic creative spree is taking over the home front. On both shores, and in between, this architectural and stylistic phenomenon has firmly gripped Long Island.

title: The Big Federal Freeze

Bush, you'd think this election represents a clash between radically different visions of what the federal government will spend money on in the years ahead. Gore seems to want to throw new cash everywhere -- preschools, teacher salaries, personal savings accounts. Bush, by contrast, pledges a government that trusts ''real people,'' not Washington bureaucrats, to do what's best with their money.

But one of Mr. Clinton's top foreign policy goals -- integrating China into the world economy -- will be tested later this month in Geneva, when the stalled negotiations on China's entry to the W.T.O. resume. Joseph Kahn

title: Inciting Intellect as Well as Passion
description: IN the final scene of ''Not Garden,'' his 1998 treatment of Dante's ''Inferno,'' the dancer and choreographer Stephen Petronio leaned so far forward that with the help of a harness, he appeared to hover just above the stage in a radiant column of light. In the context of the dance, the image served as a metaphor for redemption and enlightenment, as if he were falling into something deeper. To viewers familiar with Mr. Petronio's blistering brand of expressionism, it also signaled a more profound level of creative prowess.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-15-00: Salient Facts: Insurance Settlements; After the Crash
description: On Sept. 2, 1998, Swissair Flight 111 plunged into the Atlantic Ocean off the Nova Scotia coast. All 229 people on board were killed. To the next of kin, Swissair immediately offered $20,000, plus another $3,000 for emergency expenses. Three months later, as mandated by the Intercarrier Agreement and the Department of Transportation, Swissair made more money available -- $137,000 per victim, to be deducted from any additional future settlement. (There are 167 claims pending against the airline and its manufacturer.) Some families declined the payment; among those who accepted it -- Swissair will say only that it was the majority -- their reasons for doing so, and the manner in which they have spent the money, vary widely.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Revitalizing a Blighted Area Through New Housing

title: The World: Battle Cry; Forsaking Trust, the Middle East Hurtles Backward
description: THE Israelis and Palestinians are now being pulled violently toward the black hole of their conflict. They have been there before -- a place so dense in passion that it emits no light by which they can truly see the other's legitimacy as a people. If they get there again, despite the summit convened for Monday, they will be back at the core of the battle. For this has always been a clash of two nationalisms, not two states, trying to defy the law of physics by occupying the same space at the same time.

title: On His Own, A Rolling Stone This Dylan Isn't
description: IT'S hard to imagine a location more conducive to chilly reflections on the aging of rock 'n' roll than this corner office high above the Sunset Strip. There are the lightly misted views of Century City law offices and Beverly Hills verdure; the desk, barren of all implements except a long-barreled pair of binoculars; the brass and crystal reliquaries commemorating Jimmy Buffet tours. But intimations of mortality are easily stirred in members of my graying generation by the fact that it is now necessary when mentioning a Dylan song to specify whether one means the work of Bob, Woodstock Nation's apocalyptic auteur, or of his youngest son, Jakob, the lead singer and Grammy-winning songwriter for the contemporary rock group the Wallflowers.

title: BUSINESS; A Soft Stock and Absorbent Debt. What's a Towel Maker to Do?

title: WHITE PLAINS: JUDICIAL INSTITUTE FOR PACE
