The three-story, 28,000-square-foot institute, which will take two years to complete on the Pace campus, will include conference and training rooms and will offer training in areas like cross-examination procedures. The only other judiciary school in the United States is the National Judicial College of Reno, which is neither run by the courts nor connected to a law school. Elsa Brenner

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Flashing Their Psyches
description: Pop stars make great studies for caricature because of the mix of public image and self-disclosure in their performances. ROLLING STONE: The Illustrated Portraits (Chronicle, $40) is a compilation of more than 200 illustrations by almost 100 artists from 30 years of the magazine's history. The key to longevity, apparently, is, never appear the same way twice, and don't look back: Bob Dylan morphs from an angelically smooth-faced kid to thoughtful bearded bard in a line sketch by Milton Glaser to mirror-shaded rock star in a 1974 painting by Paul Davis. The illustrators show insight into the stars' psyches: Gary Kelley's picture of Madonna in the style of the art deco painter Tamara de Lempicka captures her narcissism, and a lacquered sculpture of Lou Reed, with leather jacket and still-smoking cigarette, expresses his deadpan cool. The text of interviews is unsatisfying, especially the throw-away reactions by the stars to their portraits. Printed on heavy paper, the images have an extra density and snap, but the succession of borderless, full-bleed pictures gives the feel of a workbook catalog. A major oversight is that the artists' media are nowhere discussed. Nevertheless, the book shows that when the match of illustrator and subject is just right, in the words of the caricaturist Robert Risko, the artist can ''get into their skin and try to find out what goes on in the inside by imitating the person's outside.'' Eric P. Nash

title: Bill of fare

title: Pile It On

This season, using whimsical materials like leather and fur, and processes like tie-dyeing and silk-screening, designers are exploding the pattern of decorum. Even Burberry breaks out of the traditional grid -- as witnessed by its new monochrome jacquard plaid ties and bold plaid high-heel boots. To be sure, too much of a good thing can cause ganglion overload: Don't try these combos outside your home.

title: Palaces Tell a Tale Of Two Empresses
description: THE one sits in life-size bronze majesty, surrounded by her generals and other illustrious men, overlooking the Ring opposite the Burgtor entrance to the Hofburg; the other displays her tiny waist -- it looks to be about 17 inches -- and flowing tresses on chocolate boxes in many a pastry-shop window. Although different in almost every respect, the two empresses, the 18th-century monarch Maria Theresa and her 19th-century successor Elizabeth, the wife of Francis Joseph, are alike in serving as Vienna's tutelary spirits. They are especially present in the city's two great Hapsburg palaces, the Hofburg and Schonbrunn.

Amid the cosmic disarray, he discovered hundreds of stories and sketches, some finished, some unfinished, left behind by this grand master of the macabre.

title: Anti-Israeli Anger Swells Flow of Aid
description: The doctor at the central blood bank advised Nagwa Omar not to donate because she is breast-feeding her fourth child. But the 37-year-old university professor was adamant.

title: How Lucent Stumbled: Research Surpasses Marketing
description: It was on Sept. 30, 1996 that Lucent Technologies left the nest and began its new life as a maker of communications equipment independent from its parent, AT&T. That day, Lucent's shares closed at a split-adjusted value a bit below $11.

title: U.S. Suspends All Refueling in Yemen for Security Inquiry
description: The Pentagon today suspended all naval refueling operations in Yemen until officials determine whether lax security in the port at Aden left the American destroyer Cole vulnerable to a presumed bombing attack that killed 17 sailors and wounded more than three dozen others.

title: Vatican's Role at U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: China's Premier, on Japan Visit, Wears a Friendly Face
description: The last time a top Chinese leader came to Japan, he lectured at every stop over the nation's past war crimes, demanding an apology. The visit quickly degenerated into a fuming, finger-pointing session that damaged relations between the two countries, Asia's most powerful.

title: F.C.C.'s Rift With Industry Is Widening
description: What would be the plot line if television tried to capture the rocky relationship between William E. Kennard, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, and the nation's largest broadcasting companies?

title: Outbursts and Surprises From Composers Separated in Time but Not Spirit
description: George Rothman, the music director of the Riverside Symphony, works closely with the composer Anthony Korf, who serves as artistic director, in putting together the orchestra's concerts. Giving a composer and conductor equal input into the process may be one reason that the Riverside Symphony's programs are so stimulating, as was Wednesday night's at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Inaugurating A Season With a Dose Of the Odd
description: Symphony Space, the enterprising Upper West Side performing-arts center that has been an occasional setting for dance, inaugurated what Isaiah Sheffer, its artistic director, called ''our first full dance season'' on Thursday night.

title: Article 2000101692467802222 -- No Title
description: October 15, 2000

title: PRESIDENT HEADS TO MIDEAST TALKS HOPING FOR TRUCE
description: Setting an urgent goal of a truce between Israelis and Palestinians, President Clinton headed today for a Middle East summit meeting in Egypt that aides described as potentially the most difficult of his presidency.

title: I.B.M. Invests to Profit From Latest Chips
description: Last week, I.B.M. announced a plan to pour $2.5 billion into constructing a new microchip factory in East Fishkill, N.Y., the biggest investment in I.B.M.'s history. It then underscored its intent to be a superpower in semiconductors well into the 21st century by committing an additional $2.5 billion to modernize chip plants in Burlington, Vt., and overseas.

title: Milosevic's Ex-Communists Are Reborn Yet Again
description: Zoran Radovanovic, 30, wears his hair slicked back close to his head and a black shirt under a colored jacket. The new local leader in Nis of Slobodan Milosevic's Socialist Party of Serbia, he is already speaking of the need to transform the party and ''change a large number of the leaders.''

title: Handspring Stresses Color and Fast Chip In New Products
description: Handspring Inc., which makes electronic organizers that run on Palm Inc.'s operating system, said it has introduced two products with added features to appeal to higher-income users.

title: Palestinian Militias: Motley but Armed
description: Yasid Abu Abed, a veteran fighter in Yasir Arafat's wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization, stepped over the chunks of concrete, broken beams, twisted iron reinforcing rods and mangled furniture strewn about his headquarters in Gaza City.

title: The top speakers at a national conference talk freely, at last.
description: THE annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers, which began here on Friday, is as notable this year for who the speakers are as for what they are saying.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

title: Helping Homeless Families
description: Over the summer, some 500 homeless families found themselves sleeping on the floors of New York City's emergency assistance office for lack of room in the homeless shelters. This desperate situation made it impossible to maintain any normal routine, such as getting children to school or holding down a job. It also violated a court order that requires compliance with a city ordinance banning the practice of having the homeless sleep on office floors.

title: Fox Pursuing a Gentler Reality
description: Good pets won't be going bad and faux millionaires with dicey pasts won't be marrying unsuspecting gold diggers, but the Fox network soon will have game show contestants trying to survive military-style boot camp, unmarried couples testing their fidelity on an island filled with male and female models and longtime girlfriends trying to compel their boyfriends to propose on a show called ''Surprise Wedding.''

title: Tension High Before Talks Despite Lull In Fighting
description: Although there were few actual clashes today, Israelis braced for Palestinian terror attacks, Palestinians were alarmed by Israeli warnings of fierce reprisals against any more mob violence, and neither side could muster much hope that the summit meeting in Egypt on Monday could yield more than a shaky truce.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Within the G.O.P., Concern and Criticism That Lazio's Campaign Is Adrift
description: Rick A. Lazio showed up at the Rotary Club in Rochester last week, about as friendly a setting as a Republican candidate in New York State could ask for, to explain why he was running for the United States Senate against Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Amid the Isolation, Finally, a Friend; A Movement to Confront Hidden Abuse in Immigrant Families
description: She arrived in New York less than four years ago, a bride from India hoping for a good life with a man who bragged of being a millionaire. The reality broke her heart and nearly cost her life.

title: King Cugat Wins as Stroll Turns to Sprint
description: On the day after Lemon Drop Kid and other favorites faltered at Belmont Park, the 3-year-old grass star King Cugat overcame several problems of time and pace, caught Mandarin Marsh after a duel down the homestretch and won the Jamaica Handicap by a nose yesterday.

title: Equity Schedule for Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Lawyers Call For Changes In Death Penalty in Texas
description: In a broad critique of capital punishment in Texas, a new report concludes that the state's death penalty system is in dire need of change because of problems like prosecutorial misconduct, racial bias, phony experts and inadequate lawyers for poor defendants.

title: Chevron Agrees to Buy Texaco For Stock Valued at $36 Billion
description: The Chevron Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Texaco Inc. for about $36 billion in stock, creating the world's fourth-largest oil concern.

title: Ladies Singing the Blues (and More), but Their Way
description: We all have a certain repetition obsession about patterns that helped determine our lives. Barbra Streisand is probably compelled to give farewell concert tours because she has been conducting farewell tours of musical forms since her career began.

title: Bishkek Journal; Heroin and Needles: Battling AIDS in Central Asia
description: Sveta stretched across the couch in the cramped apartment with lace curtains, tilted her head back and slowly massaged her bare neck. With the tenderness of a lover and the expertise of a long-time practitioner, Aleksandr located the vein, slipped the needle into her neck and sent the heroin on its way.

title: Vincent Canby, Prolific Film and Theater Critic for The Times, Is Dead at 76
description: Vincent Canby, whose lively wit and sophisticated tastes illuminated film and theater reviews in The New York Times for more than 35 years, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Center in Manhattan. He was 76 and lived in New York.

title: In Widespread Anti-Semitic Episodes in France, a Synagogue Is Destroyed by Arson
description: As the sabbath approached last week, Michel Mimouni was busy turning a conference room into a makeshift synagogue, collecting prayer shawls and other items from concerned Jews in nearby neighborhoods.

title: Leaders Open Discussions at Mideast Summit in Egypt
description: SHARM EL-SHEIK, Egypt -- Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat met face to face Monday at an emergency summit brokered by President Clinton and other world leaders struggling to end the bloodshed in the West Bank and Gaza. In Israel, a gunbattle erupted near Nablus, and scores of Palestinian rock-throwers clashed with Israeli soldiers in two other West Bank towns. About 1,500 Palestinians marched toward an Israeli army checkpoint on the outskirts of the town. About 500 broke away from the march and began throwing stones at three Israeli army jeeps. Several gunmen, shooting from olive groves, fired on Israeli soldiers, drawing return fire. Two Palestinians were injured, witnesses said.

title: Exuding Confidence, Avoiding Complacency
description: Only an hour or so after Gov. George W. Bush's well-reviewed performance in Wednesday night's presidential debate, one of his top aides called to tell him that he ''just became the president of the United States.''

title: Wandering In Uncertainty With Beckett
description: The head decomposes and recomposes, a flesh-shedding skull one instant and a smooth rubber mask the next. The abruptness of the transitions is scary, matching the tones and rhythms -- sometimes primal, sometimes mechanical -- that emanate from that long, nearly lipless mouth. Forget about the little girl in the newly rereleased ''Exorcist.'' There's not a special effects man in Hollywood who can rival what Bill Irwin is doing with his own unadorned face and voice at the Classic Stage Company.

title: Accounts
description: Horizon Organic, Boulder, Colo., which produces and markets certified organic dairy products, to Hoffman/Lewis, San Francisco, to handle its account, which had most recently been at Citron Haligman Bedecarre, San Francisco. Spending was estimated at $5 million.

title: Article 2000101692600661690 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Hezbollah Says It Seized an Israeli Colonel
description: Hezbollah guerrillas said today that they had captured an Israeli army colonel ''in a complicated security operation.''

title: When All Else Fails, Giants Give the Ball to Dayne
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel had lost his star cornerback to injury and benched his top wide receiver. His special teams were in such disarray that a dropped snap that did not result in a blocked kick was a highlight. Twice he had turned to game officials to reverse a play via instant replay and twice the referee withdrew his head from the isolation of a sideline monitor and offered a head-shaking rebuke.

title: Gus Hall, American Communist Leader, Dies at 90
description: Gus Hall, the zealous, lifelong Communist who led the American branch of the party from the turblence of the Cold War through political oblivion in the post-Soviet era, died on Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 90 and lived in Yonkers, N.Y.

title: New Economy; As Apple prepares its next-generation operating system, it is again in a complex dance with its old nemesis, Microsoft.
description: TO sit down in front of the stunning computing control screen that defines the new Apple Macintosh OS X operating system is to be struck not just by the shock of the new, but also by the startling return of the old.

title: Did Verizon Have the Wrong Number!
description: Verizon Communications sent letters to 250,000 customers in the state of New York earlier this month, telling them how the company was ''shaking things up.'' Little did the recipients suspect how truly hot the offer was.

title: Lawyers Call for Changes in Death Penalty in Texas
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 15  In a broad critique of capital punishment in Texas, a new report concludes that the state's death penalty system is in dire need of change because of problems like prosecutorial misconduct, racial bias, phony experts and inadequate lawyers for poor defendants.

title: School Vouchers: The Right Path?
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATS HAVE OUTSIDE  CHANCE TO WREST SENATE
description: Democrats are likely to pick up at least a seat or two in the Senate in next month's elections and have an outside chance of winning a narrow majority.

title: Article 2000101690251666520 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: La Russa, in Starting Kile, Thinking Much Too Hard
description: Tony La Russa, the thinking man's manager, thought the St. Louis Cardinals would be best served by having Darryl Kile, their 20-game winner, pitch last night's Game 4 against the Mets, working on only three days of rest instead of the usual four. That way, La Russa explained, Kile could pitch Game 7, if there was a Game 7.

title: I.P.O. Company to Expand Into New Securities
description: When demand for new stocks wanes, investment bankers look for ways to repackage and sell stocks that are already on the market. In that regard, Epoch Partners, while billing itself as a new breed of investment bank, is taking a page from the Wall Street playbook.

title: Thousands March for Family Unity
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  Blending his old militance with a new tone of conciliation, Louis Farrakhan urged thousands of people gathered for his Million Family March today to build a new America based on self-respect and respect for one another.

title: Why Polls Are Fickle
description: CHICAGO  One week Al Gore leads in the polls, the next week George W. Bush does, and the week after that they switch again. Or in the same week, one major pollster picks Mr. Gore and another picks Mr. Bush. It may be a close race, but it is doubtful that the voters are really as capricious as they have seemed this fall. What may be skewing our picture of their preferences are the questions the polls are asking.

title: Title Teams Turn to Defense
description: Coach Tommy Bowden was bummed. His Clemson team had just defeated Maryland by 35-14 for a 7-0 record and its best start since the 1981 Tigers were undefeated and won the national championship. Why was the coach singing the blues? His offense gained only 464 yards and all five of its touchdowns were on the ground.

title: Q & A / Jane Healy : A 'Shortsighted' Fad
description: Criticizing many long-cherished notions of how computers can best be used to teach children, Jane Healy's recently published book, "Failure to Connect," has sparked serious debate in the United States about whether billions of dollars paid out by schools for new computers and software was well spent. Mrs. Healy, an educational psychologist based in Vail, Colorado, recently spoke with Thomas Crampton of the International Herald Tribune.

title: An Oil Merger That Assumes That Bigger Is Not Just Better, It's Necessary
description: With violence raging in the Middle East and lofty oil prices drawing harsh criticism of petroleum companies, it might seem an inopportune time for Chevron and Texaco to announce a merger that opens them to the scrutiny of the federal government and the jittery stock market.

title: No Handouts Without a Handover
description: As global leaders move toward welcoming Serbia into the community of Western nations, the White House is considering the issue of aid to Belgrade's fledgling democratic government. The urgent question, as Congress heads toward adjournment, is whether to tie such aid to the prosecution of Serbia's war criminals.

title: Piazza Seems to Have Eye for St. Louis Pitching
description: Mike Piazza led the National League in grand slams this year, with three in the regular season. So it seemed his kind of moment when he came to the plate with the bases loaded in the sixth inning last night against the St. Louis Cardinals in Game 4 of the National League Championship Series at Shea Stadium.

title: States Prod Tiremaker on Replacement Offer
description: Concerned that Bridgestone/Firestone was not getting the word out to customers that it would replace 700,000 suspect tires outside the 6.5 million it has recalled, several states on Monday issued public reminders of the offer.

title: One Less Tax-Time Headache: Software to Download Data
description: One of the most tedious aspects of doing one's own income taxes is having to enter all the data from every W-2 wage statement and 1099 income report from banks and mutual funds.

title: Sailors Praised for Saving Ship After Collapse of a Bulkhead
description: With 12 dead crewmates still lying trapped in buckled, flooded compartments below decks, sailors of the destroyer Cole struggled again today to keep their stricken ship afloat, winning praise for their heroism from commanders who were forced to cancel a memorial service for the dead.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Saturday with a capsule analysis of a new television commercial released by Jon S. Corzine, the New Jersey Democratic candidate for United States Senate, was published in error. It showed a scene from a new commercial in support of Mr. Corzine's opponent, Representative Bob Franks. A correction in this space yesterday misidentified the sponsor of the new commercial. It was paid for by the Republican Leadership Council, not by Mr. Franks.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Corrections
description: A pop review on Tuesday about the country singer Merle Haggard misstated the day of his appearance at Irving Plaza. It was Oct. 8, not last Monday. The review also misstated the title of his new album and its lead song. It is ''If I Could Only Fly,'' by Blaze Foley, not ''I Wish I Could Fly.''

title: Changing of Guard at Washington Monthly
description: The question has long been served on the canape trays circulating in Washington cocktail parties and journalistic confabulations: when will Charles Peters, founder of The Washington Monthly and neoliberal godfather to legions of journalists, retire from his position as editor in chief -- and grandfatherly but cranky mentor?

title: Schools Chief Says State Rule Hinders Hiring
description: More than 1,200 newly certified teachers have turned down jobs in New York City this fall because of a court order that would have forced them to work in the city's lowest-performing schools, according to the schools chancellor, Harold O. Levy.

title: Cardinals Talk a Good Game After Playing a Sloppy One
description: Eric Davis barely raised his voice. He stood in the rear of the St. Louis Cardinals' clubhouse at Shea Stadium last night surrounded by television cameras and everyone could hear him. Outside of Davis, the room was dead quiet. The few players at the food table had finished picking through their chicken, showered, dressed and left.

title: Mariners Stand Up to Yankees And Send the Series Back East
description: Roger Clemens knocked the Mariners off their feet in October's tug of war in Game 4 on Saturday, and when Luis Sojo ripped a two-run double early in Game 5 this afternoon, he could feel Seattle tumbling and collapsing once and for all. One big hit; that's all that was needed to finish the job.

title: Gill Out With Eye Injury
description: Nets shooting guard Kendall Gill, playing a position already thinned by injury, suffered a corneal abrasion in his left eye during Saturday's preseason loss to the Miami Heat. He is listed as day to day but will likely miss tonight's preseason game in Orlando. Center Jim McIlvaine is questionable with a strained groin in that same game. But forward keith Van Horn returned to practice after missing six days and two preseason games because of strained ligaments in his left knee. He is expected to play tonight.

title: Hampton Won't Say If He Will Stay or Go
description: It is one of the great mysteries around the Mets, and the person in the middle of it never drops a clue. Does Mike Hampton want to re-sign with the Mets, or is he a mercenary about to leave town?

title: A Game They Let Slip Away
description: Scott Brosius dived to his left for Alex Rodriguez's liner, a desperate third baseman in flight. Brosius missed the ball by a few inches because he had to dive up and not straight across. After Rodriguez's single narrowly eluded him and drove in two go-ahead runs, Brosius remained squatting on his knees for about 30 seconds.

title: I Do in 8 Languages as the Pope Presides
description: ROME, Oct. 15 (AP)  Pope John Paul II presided today at a group wedding of eight couples from five continents, lauding the joys of marriage and parenthood in a rain- soaked ceremony on the steps of St. Peter's.

title: Two Agencies Gain Additional Business
description: Two advertisers are expanding relationships with agencies.

title: Patents; Inventions to cull more music from the Internet and indulge in better karaoke, too.
description: NOT long ago, if someone threw a party and wanted her own dance music, she could cobble together a party tape by painstakingly recording selected songs onto a cassette, an especially tortured process if you were trying to tape Top 40 music from the radio.

title: 2 Plays Decide for Redskins As Immovable Objects Meet
description: The Battle of the Beltway offered 112 plays, but the game was determined by the battles on two critical ones. The Washington Redskins won today on both counts and beat the Baltimore Ravens, 10-3, here at FedEx Field before 83,252 fans dressed in a smattering of Redskins burgundy and Ravens purple, fun-loving fans who throughout the game taunted one another and enjoyed the rivalry of teams that are feuding neighbors.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Saturday with a capsule analysis of a new television commercial released by Jon S. Corzine, the New Jersey Democratic candidate for United States Senate, was published in error. It showed a scene from a new commercial in support of Mr. Corzine's opponent, Representative Bob Franks. A correction in this space yesterday misidentified the sponsor of the new commercial. It was paid for by the Republican Leadership Council, not by Mr. Franks.

title: Sports of The Times; Don't Count Jones Out Just Yet
description: GLENDON RUSCH essentially became Bobby J. Jones's stand-in last night, emerging stage left, about where he left off in June. This time in relief, and saving what might have been a shuddering experience for Mets fandom.

title: Chevron Agrees to Buy Texaco for Stock Valued at $36 Billion
description: The Chevron Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Texaco Inc. for about $36 billion in stock, creating the world's fourth-largest oil concern.

title: In a Democratic Europe, Belarus Stays Authoritarian
description: If Europe's only remaining strongman of any note was shaken by the specter of Slobodan Milosevic's sudden fall from power in Yugoslavia, he showed no signs of it at the polls in his own country today.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Reluctant Stars Turn Bull Run into a Texas Trot
description: Somewhere up in he-man heaven, Ernest Hemingway must be spinning like a lathe.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Oct. 7 about William P. Bundy, a presidential adviser on Vietnam policy, misstated the given name of a junior partner in his former law firm who was the brother of Alger Hiss, to whose defense Mr. Bundy contributed $400. The partner was Donald Hiss, not David.

title: THE TWO JOSEPHS/A special report.; Uncommon Albany Access Stirs Questions of Improper Influence
description: They lingered in the restricted halls of state government with a familiar air, their cell phones ringing. They huddled with state officials and spent time between appointments lounging outside Governor Pataki's office. They were ubiquitous enough to earn a nickname: the Two Josephs.

title: Adding Manners to Muscle To Make a Football Team
description: On Thursday nights in the fall, it is Eddie Estes' job to help with the heavy hitting and pushing, to whack the other guy so hard he will see stars and finally plunge helplessly to the ground, after a bone-crushing tackle.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Small Defenders Jump Off Depth Chart
description: As soon as Jason Sehorn went out, Emmanuel McDaniel knew he was in at right cornerback and Reggie Stephens knew he would be the nickel back.

title: Article 2000101693713001421 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Mrs. Clinton Visits Harlem as Lazio Courts Upstate Vote
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton urged Bronx and Harlem churchgoers yesterday to pray for peace in the Middle East, while her opponent, Rick A. Lazio, stumped for votes in western New York, visiting tailgaters assembled for a Buffalo Bills game and Italian-Americans gathered in Geneva for a lasagna dinner in his honor.

title: Payoff Scandal Over Gambling Not Easing Up in Philippines
description: MANILA, Oct. 15  Opposition politicians in the Philippines said today that they would move forward in seeking the impeachment of President Joseph Estrada despite his apology for a scandal over alleged gambling payoffs.

title: INSIDE
description: Ulster Pact Threatened

title: In the Best Game of His Career, Clemens Was Unusually Calm
description: His mother remarked to Roger Clemens how calm he looked in Game 4, when he struck out 15 and allowed just one hit, and his wife and his manager said the same thing about Clemens. He usually stalks around the mound like a ravenous bear, but he admitted feeling strangely sedate.

title: The Winds of Change
description: Alex Rodriguez and Lou Piniella have offered few clues this postseason as to what they will do after this year, but the Seattle Mariners could soon be looking for a new shortstop and a new manager.

title: Article 2000101693276335949 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Reflecting the Palestinian Viewpoint in a World of Images
description: HASAN ABDEL RAHMAN, the de facto Palestinian ambassador to the United States, understands the power that a single photograph can wield. When he thinks of the Vietnam War, he says, ''I am always reminded of that image of the young Vietnamese girl running down the street after being burned by the napalm.''

title: A Camp Meeting Celebrates the Vision of a Hindu India
description: Dust rose in dervishes across the dun-colored parade ground here, swirling around the legs of almost 60,000 uniformed men and boys from more than 7,000 villages. Those foot soldiers in the quest for a Hindu nation stood in ruler-straight lines that stretched as far as the eye could see.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Revived Mets Just One Victory Away From the Series
description: It was his turn in the batting cage, so Edgardo Alfonzo politely removed himself from a conversation with reporters before the fourth game of the National League Championship Series last night.

title: Times Square Tower For Accounting Firm
description: Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm, has signed a lease with Boston Properties that would enable the developer to build a 47-story, $600 million skyscraper at the south end of Times Square. The building would be the last of four office towers at the core of a plan to transform Times Square from a dowdy and foreboding crossroads into a vibrant entertainment and commercial district.

title: Actor Sees Politics in Editing of Film
description: In ''The Contender,'' the DreamWorks SKG film released last Friday, Gary Oldman plays a balding, nasty Republican congressman bent on destroying the reputation of an elegant, righteous Democratic vice presidential nominee, played by Joan Allen. And Mr. Oldman, who in real life is politically conservative, is furious.

title: Saving a Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico's Governing Party Battling in Crucial Southern State
description: After a race marred by charges of vote-buying and unethical control of the news media, the long-governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as PRI, faced the possibility of another stunning upset in elections today in the southern state of Tabasco.

title: Bush Recruits Governors and Women for Final Stretch
description: Beginning the final phase of the presidential campaign, Gov. George W. Bush plans to send the nation's Republican governors in a three-day fly-around to battleground states as well as deploy a phalanx of women and his onetime bitter primary rival, Senator John McCain of Arizona, to woo swing voters.

title: Peruvian Talks To Set Election Are Suspended
description: Talks between the government and the opposition to reset Peru on a democratic course have broken off over accusations that allies of President Alberto K. Fujimori have backed away from promises to conclude a Congressional session and set a new date for presidential elections.

title: One Professor and Two Grateful Pupils
description: The Ph.D. of Pitching came through again this year. His classroom work is one of the major reasons the St. Louis Cardinals are playing the Mets this week. One of his prized pupils submitted to his latest test last night; another takes one of his final exams tonight.

title: A Master of Bipartisanship With No Taste for Details
description: Gov. George W. Bush has written that ''by far the most profound'' decision he or any governor can make is whether to proceed with an execution.

title: Police Hiring Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Bush's Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Polls Are Fickle
description: One week Al Gore leads in the polls, the next week George W. Bush does, and the week after that they switch again. Or in the same week, one major pollster picks Mr. Gore and another picks Mr. Bush. It may be a close race, but it is doubtful that the voters are really as capricious as they have seemed this fall. What may be skewing our picture of their preferences are the questions the polls are asking.

title: A Writer Wildly Tearing Up His Life to Feed His Art
description: BELLOW

title: Credit Offerings Planned During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Why the Mind Shrivels for the Body Politic
description: Does the dialogue of the presidential debates seem more juvenile than eloquent?

title: A Shield for H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; The Death Capital
description: There's a new report out today on the death penalty in Texas.

title: School Vouchers: The Right Path?; Public and Private
description: To the Editor:

title: A Polemic Ripped From Today's Headlines
description: Current events play into the hands of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Fidelio.'' Gone is the tatty eyesore that limped regularly on and off the Met's stage. In its place, Jurgen Flimm's grim update of prison walls, cellblocks and civil unrest: stage pictures that would fit credibly on the screens of television news.

title: Lease Deal Helps Pave Way for Fourth New Tower in Times Sq.
description: Arthur Andersen, the world's largest accounting firm, has signed a lease with Boston Properties that would enable the developer to build the last of four office towers at the core of an 18-year-old plan to transform Times Square from a dowdy and foreboding crossroads into a vibrant, neon-drenched entertainment and commercial district.

title: Sports of The Times; In Seattle, A-Rod Seizes New Day
description: FOR the first time in his young life, Alex Rodriguez had trouble sleeping Saturday night. He thought about picking up his cell phone and calling somebody, but there was nobody awake in any time zone familiar to him.

title: Agencies Announce Partnership Deals
description: Agencies have announced partnership agreements.

title: The Bulls, the Bears and Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Kellis E. Parker, Law Professor and Activist, Dies at 58
description: Kellis E. Parker, one of five black students who integrated the University of North Carolina four decades ago and went on to become the first black law professor at Columbia University, died Tuesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 58.

title: Health Coverage for the Elderly
description: Medicare, the 35-year-old program that provides elderly Americans basic health coverage, is one of the 20th century's great legislative successes. But the program is not ready for the 21st century.

title: For Meola, It Was a Career Year
description: Tony Meola once tried out as a place-kicker for the Jets, but the gods of American football probably could not abide the ponytail he audaciously wore at the time. So Meola, a native of Kearny, N.J., tucked the oval pigskin back into the closet and again grabbed the round football. The Kansas City Wizards, the new Major League Soccer champions, are glad he did.

title: Giving Today's Rockefellers A Dime for Their Thoughts
description: A promo for ''The Rockefellers'' lays out the family's many traumas, from public scorn to crises of conscience, then asks the derisive question ''Who wants to be a millionaire?'' The obvious answer is ''Everybody.'' Yet this two-part family portrait (the season opener of ''American Experience'' on PBS) views the Rockefellers in the sympathetic way in which the so-called ''cousins'' would like to be seen.

title: Community Debates Its Role in the Debate
description: It all started over a shortage of desks in a crowded high school biology class, and became, for many people here, a lesson in political science.

title: Families Arrive in Washington For March Called by Farrakhan
description: Family caravans streamed into the capital's downtown today on the eve of a day of ''atonement, reconciliation and responsibility'' proclaimed by Louis Farrakhan, the Nation of Islam leader who organized the Million Man March here five years ago.

title: Finally, Good News for Rutgers Squad
description: Mike Sherrod, a promising freshman guard for the Rutgers basketball team, was declared eligible just minutes before Coach Kevin Bannon took the dais yesterday at the Scarlet Knights' media day in Piscataway, N.J.

title: New Violence Erupts on West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 16  As an emergency Middle East summit meeting began in Egypt today, fighting continued between Israeli soldiers and Palestinians armed with rocks in several West Bank and Gaza towns.

title: Texas, the Death Capital
description: There's a new report out today on the death penalty in Texas.

title: Offensive Puzzle Frustrates Giants
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel approached his offensive coordinator, Sean Payton, who was on the sideline in the second half holding the industrial-sized cue sheet of offensive plays that resembled a Christmas card with all the colors on it. Fassel wasn't angry, but was animated, communicating with Payton, his hands moving excitedly in a blur.

title: Tale of Recovery From a Bad Boy Of Letters; Will Self Explores the Dangers Of Self-Obsession and Drugs In a Dark, Impudent Satire
description: There was no moment of crisis, no particular cataclysm that forced the novelist Will Self finally to renounce the destructive habits that were overrunning his life. Unless you count the time he was caught taking heroin on Prime Minister John Major's campaign plane.

title: Using a Bit of 007 to Keep Spies in Check
description: For those who have ever had the sneaking suspicion that someone is spying on them, Mick W. Stwertnik is selling a device to help them figure out whether they have valid concerns or need to consider counseling.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: The Mideast Summit Meeting
description: Today's emergency summit meeting in Sharm el Sheik, Egypt, will have to overcome long odds even to achieve agreement on restoring calm in Israel, the West Bank and Gaza. More than two weeks of bloodshed have hardened attitudes and pulverized trust between Israelis and Palestinians. It is hard at this point to imagine going further and resuming progress toward a negotiated peace. But the fact that Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, will be meeting, along with President Clinton and other international figures, is cause for muted optimism.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They've stopped the flooding and saved the ship.''

title: Stunts and Thrills at Daybreak; Competitive Hysteria Drives the Morning News Programs
description: Dakota, a dog, was mad as hell and wasn't going to take it anymore.

title: Weight Training
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Struggling with new ideas, marketers try to guess how the Web will alter the way they do their jobs.
description: THE 2000 annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers, the trade organization representing the country's largest marketers, ended last night with a wide-ranging assessment of what one speaker, Douglas M. Sweeny of International Business Machines, described as ''a business revolution that strikes terror.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONSON, ZOLA A.
description: ARONSON-Zola A. On October 15, 2000. Husband of Jeanne (nee Rubenstone). Father of Emily A. Ross, Theodore Aronson and Miriam (Merry) Aronson. Also survived by three grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to a memorial service Wednesday, 12 Noon at the late residence. Inquiries Joseph Levine & Son, www.levinefuneral.com

title: A Deserved Peace Prize
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, HAROLD
description: HERMAN-Harold. 91, of Tamarac, FL, formerly of Rockville Centre, NY. Beloved husband of the late Ida (nee Jaffe). Father of Stephen (Elizabeth) and the late Henry Richard. Brother of the late Irma Meyer. Grandfather of Hunter and Sasha. His was a life of love. Funeral services Monday, 11 AM, at Riverside Gordon Chapel, 6701 West Commercial, Tamarac, FL, and Tuesday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Gifts may be made to the Ida Herman Memorial Fund at Winthrop University Hospital, Mineola, NY, or the Ricky Herman Memorial Symposia at L.I. Jewish Medical Center (Schneider Children's Hospital) in New Hyde Park.

title: Campaigns Set a Brisk, Focused TV Pace
description: On television in Tampa, the Democrats are starting to aim poison-tipped arrows at Gov. George W. Bush. ''Two million more pounds of toxic chemicals dumped into Texas waterways,'' the commercial's voice-over intones, adding, ''Now imagine Bush's Texas record in Florida's Everglades.''

title: Clashes Continue as Palestinians Protest Summit Meeting
description: Stone-throwing clashes punctuated by exchanges of gunfire erupted across the West Bank and Gaza Strip today as thousands of Palestinians took to the streets in a message of defiance over the summit meeting in Sharm el Sheik.

title: Court Might Review a Unocal Patent
description: The Supreme Court indicated that it might review a Unocal Corporation patent for cleaner-burning gasoline, asking the Justice Department for input on an appeal by five rival oil companies. Hundreds of millions of dollars are at stake.

title: RESCUE OF ARGENTINE AIRLINE
description: Shareholders cleared a $650 million rescue package for the ailing Aerolineas Argentinas after an agreement on the cash infusion between the governments of Spain and Argentina. SEPI, the Spanish state holding company that owns 85 percent of the airline, will provide most of the package. Privatized in 1991, the carrier is burdened with about $900 million in debt and had $240 million in losses last year. Benjamin Jones

title: AMGEN TO BUY KINETIX
description: Amgen said that it would acquire the privately held Kinetix Pharmaceuticals for $170 million in stock. Kinetix, based in Medford, Mass., has expertise in developing drugs that interfere with protein kinases, enzymes that regulate communication within cells and between cells and their environment. Amgen, the nation's largest biotechnology company, said the deal would help it develop drugs for cancer and inflammation. Moreover, Kinetix's expertise is in so-called small-molecule drugs, which usually can be taken as pills, whereas Amgen up to now has specialized in protein pharmaceuticals that must be injected. Amgen, based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., said the acquisition would result in a one-time charge of $30 million, or 3 cents a share. Separately, Amgen said data were presented at meetings in Canada and Europe showing the effectiveness of Aranesp, also known as NESP, which is a new version of the anemia drug erythropoietin that requires less frequent dosing. Andrew Pollack

title: Article 2000101791702407361 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Reminders Issued on Firestone Tire Replacements
description: Concerned that consumers are not getting the word that Bridgestone/ Firestone would replace some 700,000 suspect tires outside of the 6.5 million it has recalled, several states issued public reminders of the offer today.

title: MOODY'S UPGRADES BRAZIL
description: In a move that could help reassure skeptical investors, Moody's Investors Service upgraded Brazil's credit rating less than two years after an international financial crisis led to a 40 percent currency devaluation. Moody's said it had raised the foreign currency rating on bonds and notes to B1 from B2. The upgrade, which had been expected, could help lower the country's international borrowing costs. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Payton's Blood Spills, Then Champagne Flows
description: Noticeably more placid than most of his Champagne-spraying teammates, the Mets rookie Jay Payton stood stationary in the clubhouse at Shea Stadium following the team's pennant-clinching 7-0 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals last night. A teammate with a bottle in his hand ran up to him and shouted, ''You should have kicked his butt.''

title: Liberian President Urges U.N. to Move Into Rebel-Held Areas in Sierra Leone
description: President Charles Taylor of Liberia has suggested that United Nations peacekeeping troops be allowed to move into rebel-held diamond-producing areas of Sierra Leone while the rebels return to the negotiations that were shattered in May by their breach of a peace accord.

title: Technology Briefing
description: RESEARCH

title: Brooklyn Native Is Loyal To Seattle
description: John Halama caught a red-eye flight from Seattle to New York Friday night and made it to his sister's wedding Saturday in Brooklyn. Like so many other New York natives, he had been swept up in all this talk about a Subway Series.

title: Finally, Good News For Rutgers Squad
description: Mike Sherrod, a promising freshman guard for the Rutgers basketball team, was declared eligible just minutes before Coach Kevin Bannon took the dais yesterday at the Scarlet Knights' media day in Piscataway, N.J.

title: A candidate weighs in on an accounting rule change.
description: SIX years ago, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman was instrumental in derailing stricter accounting rules on stock options. And with businesses facing new accounting rules on acquisitions that could hurt their bottom line, Senator Lieberman, now the Democratic vice presidential candidate, joined 12 other senators earlier this year in pushing for a delay of the new rules.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Could Big Oil Mean Less Opera?

title: Case Goes to New York F.B.I. Office
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has assigned its New York office to lead the investigation of the Yemen bombing, a law enforcement official said yesterday.

title: Missouri Governor Dies in Plane Crash
description: Missouri's lieutenant governor was sworn in as acting governor today hours after Gov. Mel Carnahan, who was running in a closely contested Senate race, was killed in a plane crash on Monday night.

title: Revelations About Greed, as Seen Through 160 Years of Dust
description: Edward Bulwer-Lytton, a prolific Victorian playwright and novelist as well as a politician, was the author, most notably of ''The Last Days of Pompeii,'' but he lives on more formidably in anonymity by virtue of lines that have become familiar aphorisms. In his play ''Richelieu'' he coined ''The pen is mightier than the sword,'' and he began his novel ''Paul Clifford'' with a line so embedded in the popular mind that it was frequently appropriated by Snoopy: ''It was a dark and stormy night.''

title: Market Gauges Are Mixed On Concerns Over Earnings
description: The main stock market gauges were narrowly mixed yesterday as worries about third-quarter earnings continued to trouble investors.

title: Leader of the Free World (Free TV, That Is); In Its Second Season, 'The West Wing' Is Turning Into a Certified Hit
description: Maybe it was the record nine Emmy awards ''The West Wing'' won last month. Perhaps it was NBC's heavy promotion of that drama series during the recent Olympics. Was it the nation's focus on the presidential election? Or does the idealistic country-lawyer persona of the fictional President Josiah Bartlet represent wish fulfillment on the part of the audience? (Bumper stickers spotted in Los Angeles read ''Bartlet for President.'')

title: Archbishop Joseph T. Ryan, 86; Served Military
description: Archbishop Joseph T. Ryan, who was the spiritual leader for more than two million Roman Catholics as the first archbishop of the Archdiocese for the Military Services, died Oct. 9 in Albany. He was 86 and lived in Albany.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Friday, about Maria J. Zone, a television producer for Court TV's ''Crime Stories'' who was taken hostage at a New York prison last week by the convicted murderer Kenneth Kimes, misstated the outcome of a case covered in a previous episode of the program. The defendant, Terri Gilbert, was acquitted in 1998, not convicted, in the killing of her husband in New Mexico.

title: Currency Nears Its Low As ECB Leader Seems Hesitant on Intervention : New Doubts On Support Push Euro Downward
description: FRANKFURT  Europe's common currency slid back toward its record low Monday after Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, appeared to cast doubt on the commitment of central banks to intervene anew in support of the euro.

title: Leaders in the Middle East Agree to Seek a Cease Fire
description: SHARM EL-SHEIK, Egypt (AP) -- Israel and the Palestinians agreed Tuesday to end the street violence that has torn their region apart for more than two weeks and to get back on the path toward a permanent solution to their conflict.

title: Nassau Plan To Raise Taxes By 10 to 20%
description: Trying to prevent a state takeover of Nassau County's finances, the Democrats who control the County Legislature said today that they would seek a double-digit percentage increase in the county portion of the property tax rate next year and reject costly raises for county police officers and detectives.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ELEC COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Norwalk, Conn., a local and long-distance provider, said it would acquire the closely held Line One Inc., New York, a telemarketing company, to gain access to the company's marketing and call-center capabilities. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Transcript of the Presidential Debate
description: Following is an excerpt of the presidential debate last night at Washington University in St. Louis between Vice President Al Gore and Governor George Bush of Texas, as recorded by The New York Times. The moderator was Jim Lehrer of PBS.

title: In Trial Without a Body, Prosecutors Put a Theory on Video
description: It is possible, even easy, to push a 110-pound body from an airplane while flying the plane at the same time, Manhattan prosecutors want a jury to know.

title: Leaders in the Mideast Agree to Seek Cease-Fire
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, Oct. 17 - After 28 hours of intensive diplomatic intervention, the Israelis and the Palestinians agreed today to take immediate steps to stanch the bloodshed and prevent the violence raging in the West Bank and Gaza from a potentially cataclysmic escalation.

title: A River Town Makes Amends; After 175 Years, Schenectady Honors All Erie Canal Wrought
description: When the Erie Canal opened in 1825, it was a triumph of human invention heralded from Buffalo to New York City. Cannons saluted passing boats. Fireworks and bonfires lighted the sky. And drinking, dancing and merrymaking overflowed its banks.

description: To the Editor:

title: One-Two Punch for Losing Pounds: Exercise and Careful Diet
description: When Bill Evans moved to Little Rock, the heat got to him and he stopped running. But prompted by a ballooning paunch as he approached his 50th birthday, he bought a bicycle. In early August he started cycling to and from work, about 50 minutes each way, and in just two months he had worked off the 10 extra pounds.

description: The Jets were playful, tossing back at Al Groh his own motivational tactic: ''They teased me with it, 'Why can't we win a game, 34-17?' ''

title: Dioxin in Arctic Circle Is Traced to Sources Far to the South
description: The Inuit people of Canada live on the far northern tundra and ice, 500 miles from any significant source of pollution, yet studies have shown that somehow they carry in their bodies twice the amount of the pollutant dioxin as Canadians living near areas where it is produced.

title: Lazio and Mrs. Clinton Trade Charges Upstate
description: Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton battled for votes in upstate New York today, with Mr. Lazio charging that Mrs. Clinton would bring a return of Mario M. Cuomo's economic policies, and Mrs. Clinton asserting that her opponent had ''turned his back completely on upstate New York'' by failing to offer a plan to stimulate its economy.

title: China Blames Taiwan and U.S. For Military Tension in Region
description: China described its current relationship with Taiwan as ''complicated and grim'' in a policy paper on national defense issued today. It blamed the scheming of ''separatist forces'' in Taiwan and American arms sales to the island for continued tensions in the region.

title: Thompson Wins Award; Williamses Are Top Team
description: The swimmer Jenny Thompson, smiling assuredly in a crimson leather skirt and suede sneakers to match, shrugged off the paradox that most of her Olympic medals came as a member of relay teams when she accepted the Women's Sports Foundation Sportswoman of the Year award yesterday.

title: 7 Brokerage Firms Are Fined
description: Prudential Securities, Lehman Brothers and five other brokerage firms were fined $213,000 by the National Association of Securities Dealers for improper handling of customer orders, the association said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Colombian rebels' denial that they kidnapped 10 foreign oil workers in the Amazon region of Ecuador last week misidentified the Ecuadorean presidential spokesman who commented on the investigation. He is Alfredo Negrete; Gustavo Naboa Bejarano is the president.

title: Hernandez's Postseason Proof Is in the Preparation
description: It would be months before anyone knew whether his complicated delivery needed to be junked, or if he threw hard enough to win in the majors. But Orlando Hernandez had been with the Yankees for only a few hours before he radiated something unique, in the way he walked, the way he moved and in his mannerisms.

title: Baby Dies After 15 Floor Fall
description: NEW YORK -- A 3-month-old boy died Tuesday morning after being thrown from a 15th-floor window of a Bronx apartment building, police said. His parents were being questioned. Police were dispatched to the Co-op City building about 1:40 a.m. after receiving a call about a domestic dispute. One officer, drawn to an open window, spotted the baby dead in the courtyard below. The parents' names were withheld because no charges were immediately filed in the case. The boy's 30-year-old father was arrested for allegedly violating his wife's order of protection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, BERNICE

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE -- BELARUS: VOTER TURNOUT IN DOUBT -- Belarus officials said turnout in parliamentary elections on Sunday had approached 61 percent, well over the 50 percent needed to certify the balloting as valid, but democratic opponents countered that 28 of the 110 seats at stake still had not drawn the legal minimum number of voters. At 49 percent, turnout in Minsk, the capital, was especially low. Districts that did not elect legislators must try again in three months. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: VENEZUELAN OIL SHAKE-UP
description: President Hugo Chavez said on Sunday that the state-owned oil monopoly would be reorganized. He started by firing the company's president. Mr. Chavez named Guaicaipuro Lameda Montero, a general and engineer who was heading the government budget office, the new chief of Petroleos de Venezuela. Mr. Lameda replaced Hector Ciavaldini, above.

description: Li Chiao-Ping Dance

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, LOUIS J.
description: BENJAMIN-Louis J. The officers, members & staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound sorrow at the loss of Louis J. Benjamin of Sarasota, FL., an illustrious leader of our organization. As Technion Guardians, he and his wife Miriam demonstrated the highest level of commitment to the Technion, the ATS and Israel. They have been dedicated friends of the Technion since their first visit there in 1959. Among the few couples in Technion to be jointly honored with an Honorary Fellowship, in 1986, and individually with Honorary Doctorates in 1991 and 1993, they were affectionately referred to as ''Mr. and Mrs. Technion''. They organized the Society's Sarasota Chapter and have been leaders there for many years. Louis Benjamin was also a member of the National Board of Directors, Board of Regents, and the Technion International Board of Governors. Together they have supported many projects over the years including the Louis & Miriam Benjamin Chair in Computer and Communication Networks, the Louis & Miriam Benjamin/Sarasota Chapter Auditorium, two Sarasota Chapter Computer Laboratories and the Undergraduate Chemistry Laboratory. We extend heartfelt condolences to Miriam Benjamin and the entire Benjamin family. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Lawrence S. Jackier, President Irving A. Shepard, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom, Exec. V.P. Milton Richter, Sarasota Chapter President Bruce Wertheimer, Sarasota Chapter Chairman Albert G. Effrat, Southern Region Director

title: Shares of Polaroid Tumble 20% As Profit Falls Short of Forecast
description: Polaroid said today that its third-quarter profit fell 16 percent on lower-than-forecast film sales, sending its shares down 20 percent.

title: Article 2000101793548035499 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: 10 Years Older but Still a Young Firebrand
description: It's hard to believe that the Russian pianist Evgeny Kissin is 29. The young man who walked out to greet the audience at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night seemed hardly changed from the awkward, unsmiling and bushy-haired adolescent who made his sensational American recital debut on the same stage 10 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERENDEEN, THOMAS G.
description: HERENDEEN-Thomas G. Jr. of Manhattan died on October 13 following an extended illness. During World War II he served in the US Navy taking part in seven invasions including D-Day. He retired from Stern Brothers after 27 years as an advertising executive. He is survived by Noemi Carrera, his wife of 42 years, four children, two sisters, and twelve grandchildren. Services will be held October 17 at 3:00PM at The Riverside Church, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Diabetes Association, 149 Madison Ave., New York, New York 10016.

title: Court TV Makes Selection of New Shop
description: Court TV, which is owned by the Time Warner Entertainment unit of Time Warner and the Liberty Media Corporation, said yesterday that it had named Hampel/Stefanides in New York, part of the Envoy Communications Group, as its advertising agency of record, responsible for all strategic, creative and media work.

title: Scientists Envision A New Electronics, Based on Plastic
description: In present-day electronic devices, different materials play different roles, just as a football team would have separate specialists playing offensive and defensive positions. Copper, stretched into wires, conveys electrical power. Silicon, the semiconductor, is responsible for the calculating prowess of computer chips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLACHET, DR. PETER J.
description: SCHLACHET-Dr. Peter J. On October 15, 2000. Mourned by his sons David, Daniel and Joshua, daughter-in-law Lisa, grandson Gabriel, and his life partner Anna Aragno, and her daughters Natasha and Katya. He will also be missed by his cousins, dear friends, and colleagues in the psychoanalytic community. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Tuesday, October 17, at 2 PM.

title: On Baseball; From Wild Card to World Series
description: The only team that knows it will play the opening game of the 2000 World Series on Saturday night is -- blast the trumpets, beat the drums, clang the cymbals -- the New York Metropolitans.

title: Texas Inmate's Confession Slips Through the Cracks
description: The letter began ''Re: Murder Confession.'' It was written by a Texas prison inmate who said ''my conscience sickens me'' because two men were serving life sentences in prison for a rape and murder that the inmate claimed he had committed.

title: Editorial Observer; A Reassuring Scorecard for Affirmative Action
description: Affirmative action -- preferential treatment toward women and minority applicants as practiced by employers, university admissions officers and government contractors -- remains under attack 32 years after President Johnson ordered federal contractors to seek female and minority employees. Two states have voted to wipe out the use of race- and gender-based preferences by state agencies. Parents have challenged the race-based admissions policies of public schools. Even Joseph Lieberman, the Democratic candidate for vice president, once opposed policies ''based on group preference instead of individual merit.''

title: German Report on Milosevic's Money Trail
description: Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, placed more than $100 million in foreign accounts and was involved in drug trafficking, Germany's foreign intelligence agency has charged in a secret report.

title: Cingular Wireless Hires 2 Offices of BBDO
description: Cingular Wireless, a new business 40 percent owned by BellSouth and 60 percent owned by SBC Communications, said yesterday that it had named the Atlanta and New York offices of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle its creative and media account. Billings were estimated at $200 million.

title: Hubble Unveils an Ancient Cataclysm
description: Astronomers reported last week that they had measured the age of a cosmic smoke ring and determined that the stupendous blast in which it originated would have lit up the skies of ancient civilizations on Earth.

title: South African Retreats From AIDS Debate
description: South Africa's President, Thabo Mbeki, who has confounded much of the world by challenging prevailing scientific thinking on AIDS, is stepping out of the messy debate he touched off earlier this year, the government's chief spokesman said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the World Business Briefing column on Saturday with a report about the reorganization of Aerolineas Argentinas was published in error. It showed Stanley Fischer, deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund, not Jose Luis Machinea, the economy minister of Argentina.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about Senate campaigns around the country carried erroneous shading to denote the party affiliation of the Senate seat being contested in Delaware. It is Republican, not Democratic.

title: Immersion Promoted as Alternative to Bilingual Instruction
description: A draft report by a mayoral task force recommends that public school students who do not speak English be given the option of a speedier immersion in it, a proposal that would most likely curtail many of the city's long-running bilingual programs.

title: Religious Groups Slow to Accept Government Money to Help the Poor
description: With the government stepping out of the welfare business, Congress turned to churches and other religious organizations to step in and apply for government money to start programs to help poor people make the transition from welfare to work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESTER, STELLA CHARLOTTE
description: LESTER-Stella Charlotte. On October 13, 2000. Sister of the late Albert and Gertrude Sawyer. Beloved aunt of Richard, Penny and Jill. Past Vice President of Grey Advertising. Memorial contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE POLLS

title: Sports of The Times; The Man Who Made The Mets
description: AFTER the rain came the revelry. Shea Stadium literally shook on a raw October night, rattling the Cardinals and the Champagne on ice. On their way to drinking it, the Mets danced to a tune they began humming on May 22, 1998.

title: Public Interests; An Ode to Pork
description: It is a truth universally acknowledged that a town in possession of a congressman running for re-election must be in want of a new parking lot.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Joan Roughgarden; A Theorist With Personal Experience Of the Divide Between the Sexes
description: Speaking to a standing room only crowd at the annual meeting of the Ecological Society of America in Snowbird, Utah, Dr. Joan Roughgarden, one of the world's most influential theoretical ecologists, is methodically taking apart the way that biologists think about sex.

title: Op-Art; Magnetic Debate
An Arrow Out of the Head and Into a Shy Heroine's Heart
description: No one would accuse Steve Martin of not being self-aware.

title: China Plans to Divert Rivers to Thirsty North
description: Faced with a growing scarcity of water in its northern cities and farms, China has decided to push ahead with a costly, long-debated plan to divert river waters hundreds of miles across the country, from the rainy south to the thirsty north.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDLICH, THEODORE
description: EDLICH-Theodore, Jr., M.D. The Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart and the medical staff of Cabrini Medical Center mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, who served our institution for may years. Dr. Edlich was a decicated physician who always showed sincere concern for his patients and for Cabrini Medical Center. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to his family. Maurizio Daliana, M.D., President, Medical Staff Morton Davidson, M.D., Medical Director Paul Candino, Pres. & CEO, Cabrini Medical Center

title: The Debate on TV
description: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush will debate tonight at 9:00 in the final encounter of the campaign. The event at Washington University in St. Louis will be shown live, in its entirety, on ABC, CBS, C-Span, CNN, the Fox News Channel, MSNBC and PBS.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in the Company News column of Business Day on Saturday referred imprecisely to an agreement between Agilent Technologies and the CIT Group. Agilent is selling CIT some assets of its equipment-financing and leasing business, not the entire business.

title: Mourning Is Out for Season With a Kidney Disease
description: Miami Heat center Alonzo Mourning, the best defensive player in the National Basketball Association the last two years, is suffering from a serious kidney disease and will miss the entire season receiving treatment, he and his doctors announced at a news conference in Miami yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANLEY, IRA
description: STANLEY-Ira. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member, Ira Stanley. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest condolences to his wife Jane and family. Bernard Steinweg, President David Herschberg, Secretary

title: Melancholy, Wit and Glitter in a Civilized Way? But of Course
description: France's uneasy and occasionally loud confrontations with the world tend to obscure a national personality deeply private and peculiarly ardent in its veiled and melancholic way. The music of Henri Dutilleux reminds us that global pressures have not quite erased the elusive, retreating quality of French musical art, but to experience it with clarity we do best to retreat a century. There we find Debussy's ''Pelleas et Melisande'' and around it the art songs so strikingly set forth by Jose van Dam in two recitals at Alice Tully Hall last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EKLUND, GEORGE J.
description: EKLUND-George J. Age 57, of Mendham on Sunday, October 15. Husband of Audrey (nee Tallo) Eklund. Father of Drew and Gray Eklund. Brother of Ann Sawicki, Barbara Auris and Evelyn Motte. A Mass of the Resurrection will be offered on Thursday, October 19 at 10 A.M., at St. Mary's Abbey, Delbarton School, Morristown, N.J. Visitation Wednesday 2 to 4 and 7-9PM at the Bailey Funeral Home, Inc., 8 Hilltop Road, Mendham, N.J. Memorial gifts may be made to Delbarton School, Mendham Road, Morristown, N.J. 07960 or the Brain Tumor Society, 124 Watertown Street, Suite 3H, Watertown, MA. 02472-2500.

title: BANKRUPTCIES IN JAPAN
description: Corporate failures in Japan in the first half of its fiscal year left behind liabilities that reached 10.9 trillion yen ($100.9 billion), a postwar record, Teikoku Databank reported. In the six months ended Sept. 30, there were 9,473 bankruptcies reported, a 19.6 percent rise from the period a year earlier. Teikoku predicted bankruptcies would also increase in the second half. Miki Tanikawa

title: Mideast Turmoil Is Like No Other
description: To the Editor:

title: The Crisis That Maybe Cried Wolf; Heating Oil Supplies Might Exceed Official Estimates
description: Despite the recent turmoil in the Mideast that has raised the specter of higher oil prices and supply disruptions that could make for a precarious winter, there is growing evidence that the shortfall of home heating fuel in the Northeast may not be as dire as earlier feared.

title: 2 Candidates Claim Victory In Mexico Vote
description: The gulf state of Tabasco, ravaged in recent weeks by torrential rains, seemed poised for another type of storm today as results from state gubernatorial elections on Sunday indicated that the long-governing Institutional Revolutionary Party won a razor-thin victory over a left-leaning opposition party.

title: KELLOGG REORGANIZES DIVISIONS TO TRY TO INCREASE SALES
description: The Kellogg Company, the world's largest cereal maker, said yesterday that it would cut its operating divisions to two from four as it tries to bolster sluggish cereal sales. Kellogg's United States, Europe, Asia-Pacific and Latin America business groups will be consolidated into Kellogg USA and Kellogg International, the company said. Kellogg USA will continue to be headed by David Mackay. Kellogg International will be run by Alan Harris, president of Kellogg Europe.

title: E-Commerce Accounts Are Awarded by Two
description: Two advertisers have named agencies to handle new e-commerce assignments without a review.

title: Bre-X Gold Scandal Survivor Goes on Trial in Toronto Court
description: Nearly three years after Bre-X Minerals collapsed in one of the biggest gold-discovery frauds of all time, its chief geologist went on trial here today, in the only criminal prosecution arising from a scandal that wiped out holdings of many investors in Canada and the United States.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Court to Review Benefits Tax on U.S. Judges
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Congress violated the Constitution in the early 1980's by imposing Social Security taxes for the first time on the salaries of federal judges.

title: Greeting Ives as an Old, Familiar Friend
description: You could tolerate not hearing Ives's ''Concord'' Sonata too often -- oddly few pianists offer it -- if every performance were as fresh, as inviting, as cogent and as delectable in sound and gesture as Marilyn Nonken's at Miller Theater on Thursday evening.

title: Boo.com, Online Fashion Flop, Is Ready to Rise From Ashes
description: Like the pointy-toed cowboy boots last seen in the 1980's and now making a comeback with a vengeance, fashion thrives on an endless cycle of reinvention.

title: 1 New Oil Company, 2 Corporate Cultures
description: In 1993, a little over a year after the Soviet Union crumbled, the Chevron Corporation planted its flag in a remote corner of a country that had just appeared on the map, Kazakhstan. While most other oil concerns hesitated, Chevron bet big on the Tengiz field, buying a 50 percent stake in a huge find of six billion to nine billion barrels of oil hard against the Caspian Sea and far from any pipeline.

title: On Stage, Bush and Gore Spar in Lively Town Meeting Debate
description: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas met in their third debate tonight, dropping the agreeable demeanor of their last meeting, and instead emphasizing their differences on health, taxes and education.

title: Surabaya Journal; Yielding to the Dreamy Tug of Ancient Shadows
description: It was 3:15 a.m. on a balmy Saturday, and 7-year-old Rudi Hayono could barely focus his drowsy brown eyes on the lively shadow puppets dancing across the screen in front of him. It had been more than seven hours since the traditional Javanese puppet show began, and Rudi, cradled in his father's arms, perhaps echoed what was on the minds of many in the audience when he asked, ''Papa, when will it end?''

title: A Flair for Politics And Fund-Raising
description: He might have grown up to become a common laborer in his native Dominican Republic or perhaps a livery driver in New York. But opportunity always had a way of finding Bienvenido Perez.

title: Brazilian Magic Levitates the Audience
description: Bale Folclorico da Bahia, a professional folk troupe from Salvador in northeastern Brazil, made its New York debut in 1996 and has since carried its exuberant message of multicultural cheer throughout the United States.

title: 2000 Postseason Archive
description: Here is a complete archive of The Times coverage of the 2000 baseball playoffs, including coverage of both the Mets and the Yankees.

title: SCHLUMBERGER AGREES TO BUY CONVERGENT
description: The oil services company Schlumberger said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Convergent Group for $276 million to expand its presence in the utilities business. The $8-a-share offer for Convergent, which provides consulting and other services to utilities and local government clients, represents a 69 percent premium to its closing price on Friday of $4.72. Schlumberger, based in New York, provides technical services to the oil and gas, utility, semiconductor testing and network software industries. Convergent, based in Englewood, Colo., had 1999 revenue of $66.61 million. Under the deal, Schlumberger will acquire a 72 percent interest in Convergent Group, and Convergent's current management and an affiliate of Convergent's largest client, the Cinergy Corporation, will own the remaining 28 percent of the new entity.

title: O'Neill in the Shadows, And Cannot See Light
description: The intense self-analysis might begin with a shrug of the shoulders or a wave of the hand and graduates to a high-pitched voice filled with frustration. Paul O'Neill is doing it again, telling a teammate or even a reporter why he is so bad or asking them how bad he looks. The door to his psyche is always open.

title: Race Profiling By Troopers Under Review By Legislature
description: New Jersey legislative leaders have asked a former United States attorney to review 50,000 pages of newly surfaced state police documents showing that law enforcement officials were slow to respond to evidence of racial profiling during traffic stops, and may have misled lawmakers and the public about the extent of the problem.

title: Titans Make It Five Straight, Over Jaguars and Over All
description: Is there a Jacksonville Jaguars voodoo doll with pins stuck in it under the Tennessee Titans' bench? Do all of the Titans play against the Jaguars with rabbits' feet in their pockets?

title: CHINESE BOND ASSURANCE
description: Prime Minister Zhu Rongji of China said in Tokyo that he would urge the Hainan International Trust and Investment Corporation to repay Japanese bondholders. The Chinese company defaulted on a $130 million yen-denominated bond last week shortly before Mr. Zhu traveled to Japan. The default has rattled Japanese confidence in the creditworthiness of Chinese state-owned companies. Craig S. Smith

title: Foreign Affairs; The Wrong Answer
description: If there has been a low point for the press following the Bush-Gore campaign, surely it has been the mass rush to judgment that because George W. Bush was able to tick off world hot spots in the last debate, he understands foreign policy enough to be president. In fact, Mr. Bush uttered a stunning howler during that debate. When asked by Jim Lehrer which of the recent U.S. interventions abroad he would approve of, Mr. Bush said he did not approve of Haiti, but he did approve of Lebanon in 1982. Oh, really? Too bad Mr. Lehrer did not have time to ask him: ''Governor Bush, what was it about Lebanon that you liked?''

title: Can Arafat Turn It Off?
description: What is implicit in the demands by Israel and the United States to the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, to shut down the street action in the West Bank and Gaza, is the presumption that he can turn the violence on and off.

description: Heeding the call of Minister Louis Farrakhan, tens of thousands of people converged on the national Mall today in a daylong commitment to renewing family solidarity as a force in American life.

Guggenheim Museum, one thinks of what the writer Janet Flanner said 40 years ago of another immortal, Thomas Mann. Like Mr. Armani, a scion of the purely sensual, Mann, she wrote, has endured ''the singular experience of being regularly described, while still alive, in terms usually reserved for the exceptional dead.''
