description: POWERS-James C. On October 15, 2000. Beloved son of Margaret and the late Liam. Loving brother of William and the late Beatrice Dennehy, Thomas, Michael and James' twin brother Stephen. Also survived by fifteen nieces and nephews, and many great nieces and nephews, and also left behind his fiancee, Phyllis Cerrato. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 9:45 A.M. at St. Andrew's Church.

title: State Chides City Over Teacher-Hiring Process
description: Stepping up his battle with Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy, the state education commissioner yesterday sharply criticized the system New York City uses to recruit teachers, calling it ''disorganized'' and suggesting that the city was not working hard enough to match applicants with jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLACHET, PETER
description: SCHLACHET-Peter. The Staff, Faculty and Trustees of Postgraduate Center for Mental Health mourn the passing of Peter Schlachet, Ph.D., distinguished faculty member, senior supervisor, psychoanalyst and author. His contributions to our individual and group training programs and to the development of clinical theory will always be remembered. We express our heartfelt sympathy to family and friends. Dr. Jacob Barak President and CEO Dr. Mary Beth Cresci Dean of Training

title: Confusion on Child Health Coverage
description: New York State's Child Health Plus program is a model for the nation in providing health insurance for low-income children. About 550,000 children are receiving subsidized coverage under the state program, which was expanded after Congress provided more money through the federal Children's Health Insurance Program that passed in 1997.

title: Gus Hall, Unreconstructed American Communist of 7 Decades, Dies at 90
description: Gus Hall, the zealous lifelong Communist who led the American branch of the party from the cold war through political oblivion in the post-Soviet era, died on Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 90 and lived in Yonkers.

title: Yankees Win American League Championship Series
description: The hopes and fears of New York baseball fans are a reality. The Yankees will play the Mets in the city's first Subway Series since 1956, and the first ever between these two franchises, following the Yankees wild pennant-clinching victory at Yankee Stadium early this morning.

title: Seamen Recall a Day When Quiet Turned to Chaos
description: Everything in the harbor at Aden looked normal to Andrew A. Nemeth as he stood on the deck of the destroyer Cole last Thursday, chatting in the morning sun with a buddy who was helping refuel the ship.

title: Mideast Turmoil Is Like No Other
description: To the Editor:

title: Continental Airlines Profit Is Up Despite Higher Oil Costs
description: Cashing in on a seemingly insatiable demand for business travel, Continental Airlines said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 32 percent, surpassing Wall Street expectations.

title: FAST NEW I.B.M. SERVER
description: International Business Machines will sell a new server computer that may give the company at least a temporary advantage over rivals. The server, the pSeries 680, part of I.B.M.'s new eServer line of business computers, is the most powerful server using the popular Unix operating system, the company said. It is the first such server able to process more than 200,000 transactions a minute, a key industry benchmark, said Brad Day, a senior analyst at Giga Information Group.

title: RISE IN ONLINE MARKETING SPENDING EXPECTED
description: Businesses say they plan to increase their online marketing budgets as part of their holiday marketing plans this year, according to a survey conducted by Millward Brown IntelliQuest in Austin, Tex., part of the Millward Brown International unit of the WPP Group, and Responsys.com in Palo Alto, Calif. The respondents -- marketing decision makers at businesses that have an online presence -- reported, on average, that 32 percent of their holiday budget would be designated for online marketing, compared with 25 percent of last year's holiday budgets being set aside for online marketing. Allison Fass

title: Surgery for Obesity
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If somebody wants to be entertained, they ought to go to the circus. They ought to go to the movies. Or they ought to go to the ballgame. I didn't sign on to entertain people for 90 minutes three times.''

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Earthquake Threat

title: The Pulse, Dreams And Reserve Of the East
description: By presenting in succession three works by Asian-American composers, ''Pacifica,'' a concert by the American Composers Orchestra conducted by Dennis Russell Davies at Carnegie Hall on Sunday, invited its enthusiastic audience to listen for traces of ethnic origin. And the evidence came in plenty: in modal flavors, most of all, but also in rushing rhythms on percussion and a precise realization of form.

title: The Big City; The Secret To Becoming Bilingual
description: PUBLIC school officials and politicians today will debate bilingual education in a hearing at City Hall, but their arguments will not carry much weight at St. Rose of Lima School in Washington Heights. The students and teachers there already have a program that works.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ARTHUR Y.
description: SCHWARTZ-Arthur Y. The Officers and Board of Directors of the Merrick Jewish Centre, Congregation Ohr Torah, mourn the passing of our dear member and extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Ann, and family. May they know no more sorrow. Barry M. Lasky, President Rabbi Charles A. Klein

title: Oregon and Washington in Anyone's Guess Column
description: Having awarded their electoral votes to Michael S. Dukakis in 1988 and to Bill Clinton in the next two presidential elections, Washington and Oregon would seem to be immensely hospitable terrain for a Democratic aspirant to the White House -- perhaps so much so that neither major party candidate would worry much about bothering with campaigning here.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Fargo, N.D.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRINTZILAS, MARGARET
description: FRINTZILAS-Margaret. On October 14, 2000. In her 73rd year. Retired research chemist. Beloved daughter of the late Helen and John. Loving sister of George, Gus and the late Peter. Dear aunt of John, Julie, Virginia and Matthew. Reposing at Thomas M. Quinn and Sons, Inc., 35-20 Broadway (corner of 36 Street), Long Island City, New York. Tuesday from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Funeral Liturgy is on Wednesday, at 10 A.M., St. Demetrios G.O. Cathedral, (Astoria). Interment Mount Olivet Cemetery.

title: Social Services Official Admits He Broke Conflict-of-Interest Law and Is Fined
description: Jason A. Turner, New York City's top social services official, has acknowledged that he broke city conflict-of-interest laws by using his executive assistant and city telephones, computers and a fax machine to complete work on an Arizona consulting contract he had won before arriving in the city in 1998.

title: Cheney Presses Case for Shoring Up Military
description: Dick Cheney continued to press his case today for maintaining a strong military even in times of peace, invoking not only last week's attack on the destroyer Cole but also the hostage crisis in Iran and President Jimmy Carter's ill-fated effort to rescue the 52 American captives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARK, DANIEL
description: STARK-Daniel. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the untimely passing of Daniel Stark, beloved son of ADL National Commissioner George Stark and his wife Lois, of Houston. We extend our deepest condolences to George and Lois and the entire family. Howard P. Berkowitz National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: Yemeni Security Officials Say Two Attackers Traced
description: ADEN, Yemen -- Yemeni investigators have found bomb-making equipment in a house near the port of Aden and believe two men who spent several days there are linked to the bombing of the USS Cole, security officials said Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLACHET, PETER J.
description: SCHLACHET-Peter J. The Eastern Group Psychotherapy Society (EGPS) mourns the death of their esteemed colleague and friend. Dr. Schlachet served as a leader of our professional community. He was a Past President (1989-1991), Book Review Editor and Editor of the EGPS professional journal, GROUP (1986-1997). Dr. Schlachet presented numerous workshops, institutes and papers at EGPS conferences. His gentleness, charm, integrity and wisdom will be missed by all. Felicia Einhorn, DCSW, CGP President Jeffrey Kleinberg, PhD. President-Elect Board of Directors, EGPS

title: Tools Offer Glimpse of Long-Ago Science
description: Nowadays, researchers take for granted a huge array of precision instruments and machines that would have dazzled their predecessors in science and engineering.

title: Hezbollah on the Kidnapping: It's a Cloak-and-Dagger Tale
description: Hezbollah's leader asserted today that an Israeli taken captive by the group was a spy who had been lured to Beirut and captured in an elaborate cloak-and-dagger operation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, STANLEY A.
description: LEWIS-Stanley A. He died the way he lived-stubbornly refusing to take no for an answer. His last battle was fought with courage, strength, perseverance and dignity. His tenaciousness was also reflected in his business and charitable endeavors. His fierce love for his family will never be forgotten. His absence will leave a profound void. Survived by his wife Judy; his children Jordan, Jonathan and Elizabeth; mother Mae; brother Robert and Phoebe Lewis; and sister Margery and Stuart Frost. Service Monday, 1:15 PM, ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. For those who wish to make a donation in his memory the family would appreciate that it be made to The City of Hope, 1500 East Duarte Road, Duarte, CA 91010, Attention: Stephen J. Forman, M.D., Director of Hematology-BMT.

title: CHINA AIR TALKS
description: China's largest airline, the China Southern Airlines Group, is in merger talks with the China Northern Airlines Group, Chinese news reports said. China's airline regulator has been pressing the 10 airlines under its control to merge into the three largest airline groups: Air China, China Eastern Airlines and China Southern Airlines. Craig S. Smith

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERST, EVELYN
description: GERST-Evelyn. On October 14, 2000 at the age of 88. Beloved wife of the late Dr. George. Devoted mother of Judith Gerst Silverstein and Stephanie Douglas Furman. Cherished grandmother of George, Alfred and Jane Silverstein, and William Douglas and Lyn Douglas Vera and greatgrandmother of Leah, Sarah, Julia and Steven Douglas. Dear sister of Tillie Rosen Greenwald. Service Tuesday, 10:00 AM at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: Dance in Review
description: Mysterious Journeys Within and Without

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYERS, JACK
description: MAYERS-Jack A, 91, of Springfield, NJ (formerly of Maplewood and Newark, NJ). On October 14, 2000. Beloved husband of Freda (nee Samberg), devoted father of Claire Nierenberg, of South Orange, NJ, and Sandy Mayers, of Riverdale, NY, devoted father-inlaw of Aaron Nierenberg, & loving grandfather to Marla, Hanan, Rachel Nierenberg, and Jodi Chen, and Perry Chen. Spanning over sixty years in business and service to his community, Mr. Mayers was respected as a man who could ''get things done,'' but above all, came family and his bride of sixty-one years, Freda. Shiva will be observed beginning sundown Sunday evening through Tuesday evening at the residences of his daughters. Donations can be made to Temple B'nai Abraham of Livingston, New Jersey.

title: VISTEON PLANS VENTURE WITH LUCENT
description: The Visteon Corporation, an automotive systems supplier, announced an accord with Lucent Technologies yesterday to develop a wireless communications systems for vehicles called Bluetooth. With the deal, whose financial terms were not disclosed, Visteon seeks to offer interaction between cars and devices like mobile phones and personal digital assistants. Bluetooth is a wireless networking system, primarily used to connect electronic devices that transmit small amounts of data. Martin Reynolds, a research fellow at Gartner Dataquest in San Jose, Calif., said such technology would not appear in most cars for at least two years. Chris Gaither

title: After 22 Years, N.Y.U. Allows an Army Recruiter to Visit
description: A Defense Department recruiter visited New York University Law School yesterday -- the first permitted there in 22 years -- and in a scene reminiscent of the Vietnam protests of 30 years ago, the event was marked by scores of protesters who chanted, hooted and called for her to leave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRITAN, DR. RONNIE GAIL
description: BRITAN-Dr. Ronnie Gail. Sutton Place Synagogue extends heartfelt condolences to our dedicated trustee and benefactor, Gertrude Goldstein on the loss of her cherished daughter and to longtime active members Susan (Martin) Goldstein and their son, Gregory on the loss of their beloved sister and aunt. We pray that the family will be comforted by their cherished memories. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Lieberman Stakes Claim to Basic Values
description: Laying claim to the most basic of shared values, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman said today that his and Vice President Al Gore's policies stemmed from fundamental American and religious principles.

title: Ozone Hole
description: To the Editor:

title: Corporate Case in Ohio Raises Questions on Internet Anonymity
description: John Hritz wants to get to know Jane Doe.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: CASINO RIVALS MEET

title: Planning for Strategic Home Reserves
description: The cold weather may have already crept in, but homeowners still have time to take steps that could prevent heating oil bills from rising drastically this winter.

title: Meola, Almost a Jet, Now an M.L.S. Star
description: Tony Meola once tried out as a place-kicker for the Jets, but the gods of American football probably could not abide the ponytail he audaciously wore at the time. So Meola, a native of Kearny, N.J., tucked the oval pigskin back into the closet and again grabbed the round football. The Kansas City Wizards, the new Major League Soccer champions, are glad he did.

title: Russian Court Rules Against McDonalds
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 16  A Russian court ruled today that McDonald's improperly disciplined an employee, a decision that could benefit workers trying to unionize a company plant outside Moscow.

title: Even This Sunny Setting Can't Lift the Bleak Mood
description: The natural beauty of this sprawling resort town on the Red Sea, framed by the mauve silhouettes of the mountains of the Sinai, inspires awe, and a sense of relaxation.

title: Twins, 13, Are Held in Rape and Robbery in Bronx
description: Two brothers, 13-year-old identical twins, were arrested early yesterday in the rape and robbery of a 40-year-old woman in the Bronx on Sunday, the police said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: The Mixed Prospects of Indonesia
description: The Indonesian government, which presides over the weakest of Southeast Asia's economies, is rebuffing criticism from international donors even as it approaches them for $4.8 billion in assistance.

title: Bush in Clinton's Backyard To Attack Gore on Spending
description: Gov. George W. Bush flew into President Clinton's home state today on his way to the final presidential debate and tweaked the Democrats by declaring, ''Arkansas is going to be George W. country.''

title: More ETA victims in Spain
description: SEVILLE, Spain (Reuters) - Spain Tuesday mourned the 15th fatal victim attributed to the Basque separatist group ETA this year but celebrated the arrest of two suspected gunmen in a rare counterattack against the guerrillas.

title: Article 2000101794283700036 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Article 2000101790993525222 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Green Giant Account Moves to New Agency
description: The Bcom3 Group in Chicago is shifting the account for the Green Giant brand line of vegetables and frozen dishes from Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit, to a sibling agency, N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York.

title: Sehorn Is Out, but Giants Expect a Short Absence
description: For the third consecutive year, the Giants will try to find a way to replace Jason Sehorn, their star cornerback, who bruised his collarbone and cracked a rib in the victory over the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday.

title: Korean Air Strike Vote
description: Demanding higher wages and reduced work hours, a recently formed pilots' union at South Korea's flagship airline began voting today on whether to strike. If a majority of the pilots at Korean Air support a strike at the end of voting on Friday, the 1,330-member union plans to walk off their jobs beginning Sunday, the union said in a statement. The strike threat is the first for the labor union since its formation in August of last year after a protracted confrontation with the airline's management. The union said major complaints are the higher salaries given to foreign pilots and the long work hours. Currently, Korean Air pilots work 80 hours a month, compared with the international standard of 75 hours. Foreign pilots receive double the salary.

title: Gauging the Rain
description: Q.: I recently bought a rain gauge, a cylinder with a flared upper rim and a scale in inches on the side. The diameter at the bottom is about two inches and at the top about four inches. Why is it shaped and marked that way?

title: MORE LOSSES AT EGG
description: The European online bank Egg said its pretax loss for the nine months ended Sept. 30 rose to $:115 million ($168 million). Operations costs increased 36 percent as the company, which is 80 percent owned by Prudential P.L.C., spent more to develop and market its products. Although Egg added 120,260 customers in the third quarter, it lost older customers with larger balances to younger customers with lower balances. Egg's shares were higher in London. Suzanne Kapner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULLATY, SONJA
description: BULLATY-Sonja. With great sorrow, all of us at the International Center of Photography note the passing of Sonja Bullaty. Her warmhearted cheerfulness and love of photography were a constant in the field for many years. She will be sorely missed and we extend our deep condolences to Angelo Lomeo, her companion in life and photography. Cornell Capa, Director Emeritus Willis Hartshorn, Director ICP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYNTER, MAUREEN TAITT
description: WYNTER-Maureen Taitt. Passed away on October 13, 2000. She was the daughter of the late Arthur and Marjorie Taitt of Bridgetown, Barbados. Maureen resided in Long Island, N.Y. for the past 31 years, where she was a nurse at Mercy Hospital. Survivors include daughter Lisa, sister Marion, brothers Anthony, Gordon, Lionel and George, aunt Lilliam Temberfeld, uncle Wilbert McLean and many cousins and wonderful friends. Special thanks to all her co-workers and friends at Mercy Hospital. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 28 at St. George's Church, 319 Front Street, Hempstead, N.Y. 11550

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPINCOTT, ELEANOR HALLOWELL
description: LIPPINCOTT-Eleanor Hallowell. Died October, 15, 2000, Princeton, New Jersey. Mother of John Willard Lapsley, Marian Lapsley Schwarz, Nina Lapsley Alexander, Katherine Boucher Beug, and sister of Phillips Hallowell. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Channel Thirteen. Memorial Service at Princeton Unitarian Church, Cherry Hill Road, 11 A.M. Saturday, October 20, 2000.

title: QUALCOMM GAINS ON CHINA DEAL
description: China Unicom, the country's second-largest telecommunications carrier, and the Shenzhen Zhongxing Telecom Company, a large Chinese telecommunications equipment maker, will sell and produce wireless handsets using technology patented by Qualcomm. Under the agreement, China Unicom will sell a dual-mode wireless phone produced by Shenzhen that will function using Qualcomm's code division multiple access, or CDMA, technology, in addition to a rival wireless technological standard, global system for mobile communications, or GSM. The agreement advances Qualcomm's ambitions in Asia by apparently easing tension in a techno-political drama in which the American company was relentlessly lobbying high-level Chinese officials as it tried to gain a foothold in that nation's wireless industry. Investors yesterday bid up Qualcomm shares by nearly 8 percent, to $77. Simon Romero

title: Colleges Post Average Rise In Tuition Of 5 Percent
description: The nation's colleges and universities raised tuition and fees for students by roughly 5 percent this year, capping a decade of price increases that are steadily outpacing family income.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Biotechnology Companies In a $900 Million Merger

title: Cease-Fire Accord Reached by Israeli and Palestinian Leaders
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, Oct. 17  After 28 hours of intensive diplomatic intervention, the Israelis and the Palestinians agreed today to take immediate steps to apply a tourniquet to the bloodshed and prevent the raging violence in the West Bank and Gaza from turning into a cataclysmic escalation.

title: Team Encourages Gore to Be Himself in the Final Debate
description: After being criticized as too pushy in the first debate and too subdued in the next, Vice President Al Gore turned to average citizens again today to help him prepare for his third and final encounter with Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Private Copter Use Is Down but Not Quite Out
description: A multimillionaire financier who commutes 40 miles by helicopter to Manhattan from his Westchester County estate here may have to find a more earthbound -- and quieter -- mode of transportation.

title: Mysterious Journeys Within and Without
description: Mary Seidman

title: Steelers' Witman Undergoes Surgery
description: Pittsburgh Steelers fullback Jon Witman underwent surgery after injuring his right leg in Sunday's 15-0 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals, the team said yesterday.

title: Guinea-Bissau's Music Drives Its Industry: the Clubs
description: The surrounding jungle is slowly engulfing the tiny capital of this former Portuguese colony. More than a year after a devastating war, little has been rebuilt. The new president, elected in January, doesn't even have his own office, and his presidential palace, like many government buildings, is a burned-out shell. The broken streets are mostly empty by day.

title: STRONGER RESULTS AT ALCAN
description: Alcan Aluminium of Canada reported a 25 percent increase in third-quarter operating profit, to $147 million, or 69 cents a share, meeting the consensus estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Including nonoperating gains of $34 million, or 16 cents a share, final profit was $181 million, or 85 cents a share. The president and chief executive, Jacques Bougie, said that despite weaker demand for some products, prices remained firm. Timothy Pritchard

title: Kostunica Agrees to Transitional Government for Serbia
description: Slobodan Milosevic's party ceded its last bastion of power today, by agreeing to share duties in a transitional government of Serbia leading to new elections.

title: HORIZON PHARMACIES REPORTS ELIMINATING 260 JOBS
description: Horizon Pharmacies Inc. said yesterday that it had reduced its work force by 26 percent, or 260 employees, as part of its plan to cut costs. Horizon, which is based in Denison, Tex., now employs 740. Horizon said it expected to report a third-quarter loss because most of the cuts were not effective until the middle of the quarter. The company operates an online pharmacy, and 48 retail, 2 mail-order and 5 institutional pharmacies.

title: Farmers Cite Scarce Data In Corn Mixing
description: Some farmers who planted a variety of bioengineered corn unapproved for human consumption say they were not adequately warned about restrictions on how it was to be planted, stored and sold, despite suppliers' claims to have done so.

title: Networks Watch the Ratings Drop
description: They are seen live, with no delay, except in the length of time required to complete them. Their natural flow is not interrupted by profiles or features. Yet the baseball playoffs are suffering the same fate as the Summer Olympics: stumbling ratings.

title: As Greenland's Seal Population Surges Its Fishermen Look to Revive the Hunt
description: Over a bowl of caribou stew in his wooden house overlooking a fjord here, Kaaleeraq Ringsted, an Inuit hunter and fisherman, remarked on a new arrival in his timeless world of glaciers and icebergs: seals, seals and more seals.

title: For Zeile, A Dream Takes On Reality
description: Even before the Mets became the eighth team of his baseball career, Todd Zeile enjoyed a New York state of mind. As a visiting athlete playing on teams in both major leagues, he rode the subway to the ballpark and enjoyed the ambience of Manhattan. He knew the feeling of playing against the Yankees in October.

title: Man Gets the Maximum, 25 to Life, for Killing Ex-Girlfriend
description: A state judge yesterday imposed the maximum sentence of 25 years to life on a young man convicted of murdering his former girlfriend, a Columbia University law student.

title: The Mariners Believe
description: Perhaps all they proved was that they could beat Denny Neagle. Yet after a 6-2 victory in Game 5, the Mariners swiftly embraced views much larger than the one suggesting they only delayed the inevitable elimination by the Yankees and Orlando Hernandez in Game 6.

title: The Terrorist Threat at Sea
description: The terrorist bombing of the U.S.S. Cole in Yemen last week left a charred, twisted opening in the vessel's hull and an equally gaping hole in the sense of complacency many Americans felt about the impregnability of the nation's naval forces. Scenes over the weekend of flag-draped coffins arriving at Dover Air Force Base and of wounded sailors returning home to Norfolk to be met by anxious relatives were poignant reminders that even in this age of smart missiles and American might, military service is a dangerous endeavor.

title: China Says Its Economy Grew At 8.2% Rate in 3rd Quarter
description: Strong exports and a mild rebound in domestic spending drove China's economic growth rate to 8.2 percent in the third quarter, the government reported today. The rate was faster than expected and virtually ensured that a seven-year slide in the country's growth rate has ended.

title: Mideast Turmoil Is Like No Other
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry on Moneymaking at Dominican Consulate
description: At the Dominican Republic's consulate in New York, there seemed to be fees for everything. And for Dominicans, the city's largest and poorest immigrant group, almost all of the fees seemed excessive.

title: Knicks in a Somber Mood After Hearing About Mourning
description: The Knicks were in no mood today to discuss their enhanced position in the Eastern Conference after learning that Alonzo Mourning, the Miami Heat's All-Star center, would miss the season with a kidney disorder.

title: Islanders Eager To Change Luck
description: Performing well when there is no pressure is one thing. Performing well when a lot is at stake is something else, as the Islanders are quickly learning.

title: Shuttle Astronauts Install Docking Station
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- Two spacewalking astronauts working with a crewmate inside shuttle Discovery attached a new docking port to the international space station on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAGGER, DONALD H.
description: BAGGER-Donald H. Of Mountainside, NJ. Devoted husband of Elizabeth (Broback) Bagger. Beloved father of Paula M. Bagger of Hingham, Mass., Jonathan A. Bagger of Baltimore, MD, Richard H. Bagger of Westfield, NJ and Matthew C. Bagger of New York City. Also survived by eight granddaughters. Loving brother of Doris B. Marsh of Marblehead, Mass. and the late N. Bruce Bagger. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a memorial service at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 414 E Broad St, Westfield, NJ at noon on Saturday, October 21st. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Donald H. Bagger Memorial Fund of the Westfield Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Shea Start for Clemens Looms
description: The Yankees will be in a far superior position to line up their World Series pitching rotation if they can beat the Seattle Mariners tonight in Game 6 of the American League Championship Series. But if they don't, then it is possible that Roger Clemens will pitch in Shea Stadium in the World Series in what would most likely be a highly confrontational atmosphere.

title: Mideast Turmoil Is Like No Other
description: To the Editor:

title: Where U.S. Power Is Beside the Point
description: The recent history of United States engagements in the Arab-Muslim lands is best told through the names of American battleships and destroyers. That history of sorrow and heartbreak telescopes easily. A generation ago, in 1984, it was the battleship New Jersey, off the coast of Lebanon, with its 16-inch guns shelling the hills, covering up a policy of bluster and failure. America had wandered unaware into another people's wars, and was drawn into feuds it never understood. Today it is the destroyer Cole in the waters of Aden, Yemen, attacked and crippled by two men in a small motorized boat.

title: LODGIAN IS TARGET OF TAKEOVER BID BY SHAREHOLDER
description: Lodgian, which owns and operates Marriott, Holiday Inn and Crowne Plaza hotels, received a $140.6 million hostile takeover bid from its largest shareholder, Edgecliff Holdings L.L.C. William Yung, president of Edgecliff, offered to buy all shares outstanding of the Atlanta-based company for $5 each, financed through a combination of cash and debt from Edgecliff, DLJ Real Estate Capital Partners and Lehman Brothers.

title: Shea Full of What-Ifs for Dunston
description: His parents were in the crowd last night, torn between loyalties and playing outcasts in a sea of Mets fans at Shea Stadium. Shawon Dunston returned to New York this week, slept at his home in Brooklyn  he never stays at the Cardinals' hotel in Manhattan  and tried not to think about what might have been had he remained with the Mets last winter.

title: Reforms Ordered to Protect Hispanic Vote
description: Seeking to end what he called a pattern of discrimination against Hispanic voters in Passaic County, a court-appointed election monitor said yesterday that he had ordered the printing of bilingual voter education pamphlets and the recruitment of Spanish-speaking poll workers.

title: Theodore Berry, 94, Civil Rights Pioneer, Dies
description: Theodore M. Berry, a civil rights leader who became Cincinnati's first black mayor after serving as a high official in President Lyndon B. Johnson's war on poverty, died Sunday at a nursing home in Loveland, a Cincinnati suburb. He was 94.

title: Man's Fate, Through Dry but Sorrowful Irish Eyes
description: THE HILL BACHELORS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLFIN, SYLVIA
description: COLFIN-Sylvia (Sally). February 13, 1919 to October 15, 2000. Civilian Employee for US Army during WWII with Artist Corps. Was first secretary to Willard Cummings' Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture. During a 52 year marriage to Abe Colfin she was a devoted wife and mother. She was an avid volunteer, Den Mother and employee at the East New York YM-YWHA. At the age of 50 she began a second career as a civil servant retiring at age 75 from the payroll office at Brooklyn Development Center in East New York. She leaves two sons Larry and Bruce, their wives and three grandchildren, a foster daughter, a sister and nieces and nephews whom she raised. Services to be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY at 10AM, Wednesday, October 18th.

title: Mideast Turmoil Is Like No Other
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW JERSEY

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Colombian rebels' denial that they kidnapped 10 foreign oil workers in the Amazon region of Ecuador last week misidentified the Ecuadorean presidential spokesman, who commented on the investigation. He is Alfredo Negrete; Gustavo Naboa Bejarano is the president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRINGTON, HARCOURT AINSLIE
description: CARRINGTON-Harcourt Ainslie, Ph.D. Professor Emeritus, CUNY, and Psychologist. Adored husband & best friend of Bette Kerr; father of Harcourt M. (Robin); grandfather of Renee and of Anthony (Kirkland); brother of Madaline (Slater), Jackye (Cooper), and Lawrence Carrington. Dignity, courage and integrity pervaded your life. Your wisdom and love continue to guide a legion of family and friends. Memorial service Saturday, November 4th, 12:00 noon, St Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

title: Mideast Turmoil Is Like No Other
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 Train Awaits: Mets Reach World Series
description: All year long, they promised to be Amazin' Again. That was the Mets' vow, and it was everywhere, from the billboards to the pocket schedules, and there was reason to believe the pledge. The Mets fell just short of the World Series last year, thrilling and intriguing their fans with comebacks and controversy. This year brought more of the same.

title: Wilpon Looks Beyond Series
description: Before the Mets won by 7-0 over St. Louis, Fred Wilpon, the team's co-owner, looked up to the threatening skies and tapped his foot on the damp grass at Shea Stadium yesterday. His team was playing host to a playoff game at its 37-year-old park, and Wilpon was dreaming of a grander stage, of a retractable roof and a field that stays dry.

title: Mideast Still Plagued by Violence
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 17  Israeli soldiers continued to battle Palestinians throughout the West Bank and the Gaza Strip today, and critics on both sides denounced an agreement to halt the violence.

title: Wrestler Fails Drug Test and May Lose Gold
description: The International Olympic Committee's medical commission recommended yesterday that the gold medal be taken from a German freestyle wrestler because he tested positive for the steroid nandrolone at the Summer Games in Sydney, Australia.

title: Valentine's Future Unsettled
description: As the Mets' games have become more intense, so has speculation about the future of their manager, Bobby Valentine. And Valentine, whose contract expires in two weeks, is troubled by the talk.

title: Legends in Their Own Times
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paths of Transit: Once Forgotten, Bound for Duty; Sealed Tunnels Unearthed For Rail System in Newark
description: Kresge's must have been having a heck of a sale that Christmas in 1938. Misses' blouses started at $1.50, children's shoes were $2 a pair and an ''apronette,'' a dress with a ''darling matching apron,'' was selling for $3.25.

title: The Price of Stopping Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: WARNING SIGNS IN SINGAPORE EXPORTS
description: Falling demand for computer disk drives and chemicals offset rising demand for semiconductors to crimp Singapore's export growth last month, the government said. Nonoil exports rose 11.7 percent in September compared with the level for September 1999, below expectations, with slower shipments to the United States and Europe. Although economic growth in Singapore has been quickening this year, the data heightened concerns in financial markets that slumping global demand for electronics could mean trouble for Singapore and Southeast Asia's other export-dependent economies. Wayne Arnold

title: Emerging From Its Crisis, East Timor Rebuilds
description: Terezinha Orleans is building a new home. Charred tin roofing for the door and shutters. Fire-blackened nails to hold their frames in place. No roof yet, only a blue plastic tarpaulin donated by the United Nations and held in place by dangling stones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLADING, JOHN
description: GLADING-John. The Officers and Directors of the PSAL Wingate Memorial Fund mourn the passing Monday, Oct. 16, 2000 of John Glading, the former Assistant Director of Health & Physical Education, and Director of the Public Schools Athletic League of New York City. John was a long-time President of the PSAL Wingate Memorial Fund and an innovative, caring and dynamic force for the development of the student athletes of New York City. Donations in his memory may be made to the John Glading Scholarship Fund, C/O Ticonderoga High School Bus. Office, 351 Amherst Avenue, Ticonderoga, N.Y. 12883.

title: Devils and Thrashers Tie On a Late Goal by Brylin
description: The Devils feasted on the expansion Atlanta Thrashers last season, winning all four games between the teams and outscoring Atlanta by 24 goals to 2 in perhaps the easiest cakewalk all season for the defending Stanley Cup champions.

title: CIBA REPORTS STRONG RESULTS
description: Greater demand in Asia and increased sales of detergent ingredients contributed to a 46 percent surge in the third-quarter earnings at Ciba Specialty Chemicals, a leading chemical maker based in Basel, Switzerland. Ciba, a dominant manufacturer of detergent whiteners, said earnings rose to 114 million Swiss francs ($64 million) in the quarter on a 9 percent increase in sales to 1.98 billion francs ($1.12 billion). The results were stronger than expected and pushed up Ciba's share price 1.2 percent, to 95.5 francs ($53.85). Elizabeth Olson

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Intel has a passing report card, but it doesn't come without an asterisk.
description: AFTER warning investors last month that its revenue would not meet earlier expectations, the Intel Corporation reported third-quarter numbers yesterday that beat analysts' lowered forecasts. But the company gave wary investors other reasons for concern, reporting stagnant chip sales and projecting a relatively soft holiday season.

title: Survey Finds Support for School Filters
description: The overwhelming majority of Americans say schools should install filters to block students from accessing pornography and hate speech, according to a new national survey commissioned by the Digital Media Forum.

title: Food Stuff: Where to Find Your Bag: Just Look Under Your Martini
description: The handbag on the floor. The handbag hanging from the back of a stool. The handbag gone, disappearing amid the happy hour mayhem at a bar. It happens all too often.

title: A Playful Souvenir on the Petit Four Plate: The Lollipop
description: THE petit four plate is a chef's last chance to dazzle, and most take it very seriously, serving the tiniest, most precise tartlets and truffles. But a few chefs, all within a block or two of each other in Midtown, are getting whimsical as well, sending out the most childish of treats just before the very grown-up check.

title: ROCHE SALES INCREASE
description: Roche Holding said sales in the first nine months of the year rose 7.5 percent, to $11.4 billion, helped by increased demand for diagnostic tests. Roche, based in Basel, Switzerland, also announced it would establish a new biotechnology company called Basilea Pharmaceutica to focus on dermatology and anti-infection drugs. Franz B. Humer, chief executive of Roche, said it was looking for investors for the new company and would keep a significant minority stake. Elizabeth Olson

title: Social Security Increase Is Biggest in Years
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  More than 45 million American on Social Security will get the biggest cost-of-living increase in nearly a decade next year. But the Medicare premium deducted each month for coverage of visits to doctors' offices will also go up, and several experts said today that health-care costs over all may offset much of the Social Security adjustment.

title: Technology Briefing
description: DEALS MARVELL BUYING ISRAELI CHIP MAKER A communications chip maker, the Marvell Technology Group , said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Galileo Technology Ltd., an Israel-based maker of network routing and switching equipment, for about $2.7 billion in stock. Investors apparently thought Marvell had overpaid, and they knocked its stock down 30 percent from $57.06, to $24.69, and thereby cut the value of the deal to about $1.85 billion. Marvell is betting that its acquisition of Galileo will make it more competitive by allowing it to offer a full suite of products. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Philip Morris Posts Best Earnings Since '97
description: Despite hundreds of millions of dollars in antismoking advertising and record-high prices, a resurgence in domestic cigarette sales is providing some of the nation's largest tobacco companies with their biggest gains in years.

title: A High-Technology Festival Takes a High-Anxiety Turn
description: This year's theme for Agenda, a computer industry conference that annually draws some of high technology's best and brightest, is supposed to be ''Who's got the juice?''

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Eau Claire and La Crosse, Wis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, FRANCYS
description: HIRSCH-Francys. With profound sorrow, we announce the passing of our dear mother, grandmother and great-grandmother-Oma-who passed on peacefully in Netanya, Israel on October 17, 2000 at the age of 101. A Holocaust refugee, orphaned by the Nazis, Francys came to the United States in 1939 with her husband Julius and son Henry. She took great pleasure in Henry and daughter-in-law Renie, with her three grandchildren Mark, Jonathan and Daniel and with her eleven great-grandchildren. Oma always had a kind and an appropriate word for everyone, keeping her family together-while stressing a need for a belief in God and always maintaining deep religious commitment and observance. Oma kept her high spirits right through her very last breath. We will always cherish her memory and keep her love within us. The Hirsch family

title: No New Penalties for Father in Newborn's Death
description: The Delaware judge who imprisoned Brian C. Peterson in 1998 for his role in the death of his newborn son declined yesterday to impose new probation penalties relating to his arrest at a Mets game at Shea Stadium on Sept. 26.

title: 2 SIDES IN MIDEAST PROMISE TO WORK TO STOP VIOLENCE
description: After 28 hours of intensive diplomatic intervention, the Israelis and the Palestinians agreed today to take immediate steps to apply a tourniquet to the bloodshed and prevent the raging violence in the West Bank and Gaza from turning into a cataclysmic escalation.

title: Konrad E. Bloch, 88, Nobelist Who Studied Cholesterol, Dies
description: Dr. Konrad E. Bloch, who won a Nobel Prize for explaining how cholesterol is formed in the body, died Sunday at the Lahey Clinic in Burlington, Mass. He was 88 and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, JACK
description: MORRISON-Jack. Beloved husband of Mary. Loving father of Roy, Carol, Elaine and Diana and father-in-law of Sonia. Devoted grandfather of Victoria. Caring brother of Sarah and Edythe. Former partner of Advanced Demolition. Services today 7:30 PM to 9:30 PM at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, (Avenue J). In lieu of flowers donations may be made to either The Simon Wiesenthal Foundation or The Lighthouse.

title: Firestone Announces Production Cutbacks in 3 Plants and Layoffs
description: Acknowledging that sales had fallen after reports of more than 100 deaths linked to the failure of Firestone tires now being recalled, Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. announced today that it would lay off indefinitely 450 workers at its factory in Decatur, Ill., and would close the Decatur factory and two other plants for two to four weeks.

title: STRONG GAINS AT PHILIPS
description: Royal Philips Electronics, the Dutch semiconductor and consumer electronics company, said third-quarter profit more than doubled as it sold more chips that power mobile phones and other digital products. Philips earned 771 million euros ($655 million), more than expected and up from 331 million euros ($282 million) in the quarter a year earlier. Sales grew 21 percent, to 9.4 billion euros ($8 billion). Suzanne Kapner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHS, HILDA
description: SACHS-Hilda. Age 89. Died quietly at her home, on Sunday, October 15. Beloved wife of Edgar Sachs. Loving mother of Stephen. She was a prolific writer and lyricist, a former member of the editorial staff of House & Garden Magazine and a prominent and highly respected publicist in the Home Fashion Industry. Well beloved by all who knew her. Funeral services are private.

title: No Days Off Are Allowed, Experts Argue
description: No one looking at her would ever guess that Eileen Barton has a food obsession. She seems so utterly normal: a part-time administrative assistant at her church, Crosspointe Church at Cary, N.C., part-time freelance writer and a conservatively dressed mother of a 12-year-old boy. She is a woman whose calm demeanor indicates a life that is balanced and in control.

title: To Be State Senator, He Must Beat the Incumbent, Again
description: When he entered a barber shop on this city's northeast side recently, Byron W. Brown, a city councilman and the victor in a highly competitive State Senate primary in September, was treated as though he were a celebrity.

title: Manila Journal; This Whistle-Blower Could Topple a President
description: Luis Singson, the man who may bring down the president of the Philippines, was holding court in a sun-drenched room at the Manila Yacht Club. His black-and-white motor yacht, which he says he bought with winnings from gambling, was tethered to a pier outside.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the investigation into the explosion that killed 17 American sailors on the destroyer Cole last week misstated the size of the hole in the ship. The Navy says it is roughly 40 feet by 40 feet; it is not 80 feet wide and nearly as deep.

title: Archbishop Quietly Makes His Mark
description: In the month after his installation as head of New York's Roman Catholic archdiocese in 1984, Archbishop John J. O'Connor cut an ebullient, outspoken and photogenic figure, making rounds of parishes and schools.

title: INSIDE
description: Congress Backs Debt Relief

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday and a related article yesterday about a lawsuit against eBay referred imprecisely to a preliminary ruling in the case. In that ruling, which was made last Wednesday, the judge granted eBay's request to dismiss the complaints in their current form. But she let the plaintiffs refile the case with more specific arguments, accusing eBay of neglecting to protect consumers from sales of forged sports memorabilia in its online auctions. The judge did not support eBay's motion to dismiss the case itself. On Monday, the plaintiffs responded by refiling.

title: Torch Singer's Estate May Become a Connecticut Park
description: Claiming a victory against suburban sprawl, government officials and the Trust for Public Land announced today that they had agreed to buy 95 wooded acres surrounding the storied estate here called Treetops, once owned by the torch singer and actress Libby Holman. They said it would be preserved as open woodlands next to Mianus State Park.

title: MARVELL BUYING ISRAELI CHIP MAKER
description: A communications chip maker, the Marvell Technology Group, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Galileo Technology Ltd., an Israel-based maker of network routing and switching equipment, for about $2.7 billion in stock. Investors apparently thought Marvell had overpaid, and they knocked its stock down 30 percent from $57.06, to $24.69, and thereby cut the value of the deal to about $1.85 billion. Marvell is betting that its acquisition of Galileo will make it more competitive by allowing it to offer a full suite of products. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: BILLION-DOLLAR CONTRACT FOR NORTEL
description: The fiber optics equipment maker, Nortel Networks, said it won a contract to supply $1 billion of optical products and professional services to the closely held Aerie Networks Inc. Nortel, based in Canada, will finance as much as half of the purchases. The four-year contract is subject to financing agreements that Aerie must fulfill. Terms of those agreements were not disclosed. Aerie, a start-up based in Denver, has plans to build the biggest United States fiber network at 20,000 miles, using rights of way from pipeline companies.

title: I.B.M. Met 3rd-Quarter Profit Estimates
description: Unable to get enough microchips to make everything it could have sold, the International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday that it had squeezed out the profits Wall Street had expected for the third quarter but had fallen short of revenue projections.

title: Executives Line Up For Couch Treatment
description: Handing off a family business to the younger generation is always fraught with risk, but the Manhattan psychiatrist and business consultant Kerry J. Sulkowicz did not appreciate how much so until the day a client -- an executive who wanted to pass on his stake to his son -- said he was thinking of building a cinder-block wall in the executive suite to seal off his younger brother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITAN, ARTHUR
description: LEVITAN-Arthur on October 17, of Tallahassee, Florida, formerly of Mendham, NJ. Beloved husband of Miriam, devoted father and father-in-law of Mark and Gabrielle, Steven and Anna, and Don and Chelsie. Grandfather of Daniel, Jeremy and Keeha. Loving brother and uncle. Graveside service 1:30pm Thursday at Hebrew Congregation Cemetery, South Road, Mount Freedom, NJ. Memorial donations to Deborah Hospital, Browns Mills, NJ.

title: I Show How Things Work
description: I started with AT&T over 20 years ago, before the breakup, and have since worked for several of the spinoffs. Working for communications companies means that I have drawn mostly phones or phone switches, or diagrams showing how to use them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGOMERY, MARION
description: MONTGOMERY-Marion, 74. Of Fair Haven, N.J. died at home October 15, 2000. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y., she lived in Rumson, N.J. and the surrounding area for 60 years and had a residence in Vero Beach, FL. She was an artist, writer, homemaker and, for fifteen years, the owner of the Screen Door. Surviving are her husband of 52 years, John L. Montgomery, Jr., three daughters, Leslie, Jill & Margo Montgomery, two sons-inlaw, Gene Kelly and Jonathan Ward & four grandchildren, Devon and Ryan Kelly, and Matthew and Mackenzie Ward.

title: Medicare Bill That Favors H.M.O.'s Faces a Veto
description: The White House said today that President Clinton would veto the latest version of a bill restoring money to Medicare because it gave too much money to health maintenance organizations.

title: Blithely Taking Comfort From Life's Tastier Crumbs
description: Nobody turns a stage into a cozy front porch better than Victoria Williams. So it seemed perfectly natural when Ms. Williams's dog, Rupy, ambled onstage at Joe's Pub (425 Lafayette Street, East Village). The big golden-red mutt curled up under the pedal-steel guitar during Ms. Williams's set and an opening set by her husband, Mark Olson. It was just another touch of the casualness Ms. Williams carries with her like a charmed circle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOWITZ, SAMUEL W.
description: LEIBOWITZ-Samuel W. The Yeshivah of Flatbush deeply mourns the passing of Samuel W. Leibowitz, beloved father of Honorary President and Honorary Trustee Reuben Leibowitz and Harold and Elihu Leibowitz. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Leibowitz family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Paul Kopyt, President Dennis M. Eisenberg, Exec. V.P.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Kramnik Holds 1-Point Lead After Another Tense Draw
description: Garry Kasparov and Vladimir Kramnik fought a grim battle to a 66-move draw in Game 6 of their world championship chess match in London yesterday. The early tide of the game saw Kramnik press hard to produce a mating attack, but Kasparov forced exchanges of material that pulled him through what looked like the worst. But it wasn't.

title: Asian Pears, Grown in Bags, Are Plump With Sweet Nectar
description: Good fruit deserves a little pampering. Once the blossoms fall off the Asian pear trees at Umpqua Organic Farm in Roseburg, Ore., each tiny budding fruit is enclosed in a two-ply paper bag imported from China. The bags keep the skin tender and uniform in color and prevent insect damage as the fruit matures on the tree. The pears are picked at their peak, then nestled in boxes with form-fitting foam liners for shipping.

title: Gwen Verdon, Actress and Dancer, Dies at 75
description: Gwen Verdon, whose high-kicking artistry, flaming red hair and head-turning figure made her an unforgettable presence in musicals like "Can-Can," "Damn Yankees" and "Chicago," died today in Woodstock, Vt. She was 75 and had homes in Bronxville, N.Y., and Quogue, N.Y.

title: It's a Very Lucky Worm That Finds These Apples
description: They look like tiny candy apples, but these apple-shaped truffles on a stick are not at all for the little ones at Halloween. They are adult treats, made by Christopher Norman Chocolates, with a chocolate and caramel filling infused with apple and coated with marbleized chocolate and chopped hazelnuts. The truffles, about the size of lady apples, are $6 each at Balducci's, $8 in the food hall at ABC Carpet & Home, and $35 for four, plus shipping, from www.eluxury.com.

title: Mayor's Wife Begins Her Run in 'Monologues'
description: Donna Hanover, the estranged wife of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, delivered monologues last night about orgasm, lesbian sex and the rape of Bosnian women in her debut performance in the Off Broadway hit ''The Vagina Monologues.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONER, SAMUEL NEWTON.
description: FONER-Samuel Newton. Of Temple Terrace, FL. (Tampa area) on Saturday, October 14, 2000. Born March 21, 1920 in New York City, died of cancer. Dr. Foner, an atomic and molecular physicist was a specialist in mass spectrometry and molecular beams. He worked on the Manhattan project during WWII and spent a long and distinguished career at the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory from 1945 until his retirement in 1990 in Florida. He received numerous distinguished service awards for his studies of constituents of flame reactions. During his research at APL he served in several management positions including Vice Chair of the Milton S. Eisenhower Research Center 1975-1983 and Senior Scientist of Strategic Systems 1984-1990. His degrees, all at the Carnegie Institute of Technology, in Pittsburgh, a BS in Physics and in Mathematics in 1940, MS in 1941 and D.SC in 1945 in Physics. He was a Fellow of American Physical Society, Life Fellow of the American Association for Advancement of Science, Fellow of the Washington Academy of Sciences, member of the Philosophical Society of Washington, member of Cosmos Club, The Combustion Insititute, The American Vacuum Society, Phi Kappa Phi and Sigma Xi. He leaves siblings, Dr. Max Foner of Memphis, TN, Mary Foner Rosenthal of Pittsfield, MA, Rachel Foner Powell of Thorneville, OH, Dr. Simon Foner of Belmont, MA, and David N. Foner of N. Andover, MA. Friends will gather at the Burton L. Hirsch Chapel, 2704 Murray Avenue, Sq. Hill (Pittsburgh, PA) (opposite Morrowfield Apartments) on Thursday at 12 noon, then leave to attend a Graveside Service at Beth Shalom Cemetery at 1 P.M.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: WORLD BUSINESS: When Greenland Exports, It's Ice; Bottled Water and Cube Sales to Seekers of Boutique Purity
description: For Greenland's 55,000 people, the defining fact of life has always been the ice sheet, a mammoth expanse nearly three times the size of Texas that blankets 85 percent of their island. Now, entrepreneurs on this Arctic frontier think they have figured out how to capitalize on the icecap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, TIM
description: ROSENTHAL-Tim. We of the National Cartoonists Society profoundly mourn the untimely loss of our beloved friend, Tim Rosenthal, whose spirit, decency, professionalism, good will and boundless generosity graced our ranks for many years. Beyond all that, we will long remember Tim's incredible courage and grace while knowing the end was so near. Our condolences and love go out to his dear Robyn, Jennifer and Timmy, who ask that you memorialize Tim by helping the Scleroderma Foundation, Western NY Chapter, 5083 Morgan Parkway, Hamburg, NY 14075 (Attn: M.G. Henry, Sr.). We will miss our buddy Tim very much. May the skies where he is always be #

title: 2 Senate Candidates Eagerly Woo Moderates
description: The nominees for United States Senate here in Florida are grappling for votes from the ideological center by trying to shove each other away from it, the Democrat pushing the Republican farther to the right, the Republican nudging the Democrat toward the left.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HODGSON, WILLIAM JOHN
description: HODGSON-William John. The friends of William J. Hodgson will hold a Memorial Service to celebrate his life at The House of the Redeemer, 7 East 95th Street, NYC, at 4:30 P.M. on Wednesday 25th of October, 2000.

title: The Nets' Van Horn To Miss 4-6 Weeks
description: The Nets' injury curse struck down one of their pillars last night when forward Keith Van Horn broke his left leg in the second quarter of a 99-94 exhibition loss to the Magic in Orlando. Nets officials said he would be out for four to six weeks, which means Van Horn will miss at least the first two weeks of the regular season, which begins Oct. 31 against Cleveland.

title: A Change in the Equation
description: The death of Missouri's governor has probably diminished the Democrats' chances of recapturing the Senate this year, Democrats and political analysts said. Page A21.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORIS, MARTIN
description: BORIS-Martin. An unusual man of dignity and distinction. You have left indelible impressions on the lives of our family and so many others. Best friend and most special husband for 48 years to Gloria. Cherished father to Elizabeth, Ron, Adam, Shirley, Haryn and Noel. Grandfather/Poppa extraordinaire to Amanda, Perri, Joey, Olivia, Julie, Katie, and Jonas. Beloved son-in-law of Esther Sharf. Friend and brother of Bob and Carolyn, Linda and Michael. Private services to be held. Donations in the name of Martin Boris to the Hewlett/Woodmere Public Library: 1125 Broadway, Hewlett New York 11557. BORIS-Martin. Our dearest friend has left us. His uniqueness and love will remain with us forever. Renee and Jack Arenstein

title: Transportation Bond Act Gets Mixed Reviews From Fiscal Watchdog Groups
description: New York City's two most influential fiscal watchdog groups gave contrasting reviews yesterday on the $3.8 billion transportation bond act on the state's Nov. 7 ballot.

title: Article 2000101891534221453 -- No Title
description: MORE 7 DAY INDEX NEWS

title: Offering Poor An Alternative To Vouchers
description: SUPPORTERS of private school tuition vouchers for low-income families say they only want the poor to have the same options as the middle class.

title: When the Children Vote
description: Nail biting over the outcome of the presidential campaign can possibly end on Sunday night, at 8:30 p.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSLAND, ELIZABETH CORBIN.
description: KINGSLAND-Elizabeth Corbin. Passed away peacefully October 15, 2000, in New York City. She leaves behind a son, Nicholas Corbin Kingsland, of Washington, D.C., & a daughter, Lucia Gesinus Visser, of Versoix, Switzerland. She was devoted to both, and they will both miss her very much. She will also be much missed by her two brothers, R. Beverley Corbin, Jr., of Newport, R.I., and Robert E. Corbin, of Palm Beach, FL. She grew up in Newport, R.I., and New York City, where she spent her final years. Service on Monday, October 23, 2000, 1:30 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC.

title: PREDICTIVE SYSTEMS PLANS ACQUISITION
description: A leading networking consulting firm, Predictive Systems Inc., plans to announce today that it has agreed to acquire a subsidiary of Science Applications International for about $92 million in cash and stock, a person close to the deal said. Predictive Systems, which provides technical consulting services to telecommunications carriers, has agreed to acquire Global Integrity, the Science Applications unit that provides electronic security services, the person said. Global Integrity brings about 130 employees and a Japanese office to Predictive, which is based in New York. Seth Schiesel

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The debt relief issue is now a speeding train. We've got the pope and every missionary in the world involved in this thing, and they persuaded just about everyone here that this is the noble thing to do.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a protest against a military recruiter at New York University Law School over the military's ban on openly gay service members misstated the amount of research money the university receives from the Defense Department, which has threatened to withhold funds from universities that bar recruiters. It is about $8 million, not more than $200 million.

title: Teams Cannot Avoid The Subject Any Longer
description: The question has followed the Yankees and the Mets all season and both teams have mostly deflected it. The Yankees never really wanted to talk about the Mets and the Mets felt the same way about the Yankees. Wait and see if the Subway Series happens and we will talk about it then, they said.

title: Skills for the Real World
description: To the Editor:

title: Toil and Trouble at the Public; A Debate Over Whether George Wolfe's Institution Needs New Direction
description: By all appearances, the double whammy of two Broadway flops in a row -- ''On the Town'' and ''The Wild Party'' -- spelled danger for the Joseph Papp Public Theater and its artistic director, George C. Wolfe. The Public had to foot most of the bill for the shows' collective losses: $14 million, a punishing amount for a nonprofit theater.

title: OWNER OF TAXOL PATENT SUES F.D.A. AGAIN OVER GENERIC
description: American BioScience Inc., owner of a patent on the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company's cancer treatment drug Taxol, has sued the Food and Drug Administration for the second time over its approval of the Ivax Corporation's generic version of the drug. American BioScience, which is based in Santa Monica, Calif., is asking a judge to make the F.D.A. accept Bristol-Myers' latest application to list an American BioScience patent on Taxol. Listing the patent with the regulatory agency would effectively delay Ivax's introduction of a generic version of Taxol, which won F.D.A. approval earlier this month. Taxol generates more than $1 billion in annual sales for Bristol-Myers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNITOW, VIRGINIA LEVITT.
description: SNITOW-Virginia Levitt. On October 16, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Mother of Ann and Alan. Grandmother of Tania. Services Wednesday, 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. SNITOW-Virginia. The Officers and membership of the American Jewish Congress express their sorrow over the passing of Virginia Snitow, Honorary President of the Women's Division. In her many years of service to our organization, Virginia served in a variety of high level positions, including President of the Women's Division, National Vice President of AJCongress, and Co-Chair of the Governing Council. In her service to the Women's Division, Virginia provided the inspirational leadership that made the Division one of the most powerful voices on behalf of Jewish women in the United States and Israel. Virginia's elegance and gentleness did not diminish her passion for social justice nor her fierce resolve and determination to pursue remedies for inequity and discrimination wherever she encountered them. We extend our condolences to Virginia's daughter Ann, her son Alan, and her entire family. Jack Rosen, President Phil Baum, Executive Director Belle B. Faber, Assoc. Exec. Dir. Lois Waldman, Dir., Comm. for Women's Equality SNITOW-Virginia. Inspiring leader in America's progressive movements for peace, civil rights, labor, education and women's equality. She leaves a legacy as the creative founder of US/Israel Women To Women, which has helped improve the status in quality of life for Israeli women, both Jew and Arab. Board of Directors US/Israel Women to Women

title: 45 Bowls Of Risotto On the Wall . . .
description: So many risottos, so little time. The new Risotteria at 270 Bleecker Street (Morton Street) has 45 combinations ($6.50 to $10.50), in flavors like salami and parsley, asparagus and saffron, calamari with olives and peppers, roasted Italian sausage and spinach, and pesto and mozzarella. And of course, the classic, with Parmesan.

title: Judge Rules That Tax Shelter Worth $6 Billion Is a Sham
description: A federal judge in Delaware, in a decision made public yesterday, held that one company's corporate tax shelter was a sham and noted that 85 other large corporations used the same deduction to avoid paying $6 billion in corporate income taxes.

title: Accord by Auction Houses Is Still Unsigned
description: Nearly a month after agreeing to pay $512 million to settle claims that they cheated buyers and sellers by fixing commission fees, Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses still have not signed the final settlement papers, and the judge in the case has ordered them to appear in court Monday to explain why.

title: Senate Candidate's Death Hurts Democrats' Chances
description: The death of Gov. Mel Carnahan of Missouri in a plane crash on Monday night has thrown the already tumultuous politics of this important swing state into disarray and probably diminished the Democrats' chances of recapturing the Senate this year, Democrats and political analysts said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSUCK, RUTH
description: ROSSUCK-Ruth. On October 16, 2000 at age 100. Longtime resident of Sag Harbor, NY. Beloved wife of the late Alvin. Dear aunt and great-aunt.

title: Uzbekistan Dreams Made of Music
description: Uzbekistan is a new country, an arid network of old Persian, Mongol and Uzbek capitals that did not find independence until the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991.

title: Mideast Crisis Management
description: The emergency summit meeting that ended yesterday in Egypt proved as tense and difficult as advertised. But Israel and the Palestinians emerged from it with a fragile new opportunity to end nearly three weeks of traumatic clashes that have killed more than 100 people. Doing so can be a first step toward rebuilding the trust that will be needed to negotiate a more permanent peace.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: For Clinton, the Suspense Is Not Over
description: Seven years after President Clinton presided over a historic handshake between Israeli and Palestinian leaders in the Rose Garden, he tried one more time today to move the Middle East toward some kind of lasting peace.

title: SCC COMMUNICATIONS AGREES TO PURCHASE A LUCENT UNIT
description: The SCC Communications Corporation, a provider of 911 services to telephone carriers, agreed to buy the public safety systems unit of Lucent Technologies Inc. for about $41 million. SCC will issue 6.1 million shares for the unit, which is based in Lisle, Ill., and provides emergency services software and equipment. Lucent, the largest phone-equipment maker, will own about 35 percent of SCC, which is based in Boulder, Colo. SCC said the acquisition would help it develop new systems that can be used on all kinds of technologies, including wireless communications devices.

title: ACCOR GRANADA TALKS END
description: Accor of France said it had abandoned talks to buy Granada Compass's hotel business because it was unable to agree on a price. Granada Compass, meanwhile, has decided to hold an auction for its Forte hotel division, which includes the Posthouse, Heritage and Signature chains. Accor said it would not participate in an auction, but potential bidders for the division, which could fetch around $5.8 billion, include Marriott International and the Hilton Group, analysts said. Suzanne Kapner

title: More Maneuvers On Audit Rules
description: Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has asked Congress to refrain from trying to delay an S.E.C. proposal that would limit the consulting work that accounting firms do for audit clients, but a senior lawmaker said that the agency needed more time to work on the proposal.

title: Poll Finds Corzine Spending Is Not a Problem for Voters
description: Although Jon S. Corzine is shattering spending records in his New Jersey race for the United States Senate, most voters either do not know or do not care, a New York Times poll has found.

title: After 44 Years, Another Subway Series
description: New York City is back at the center of the baseball universe, where most of its citizens undoubtedly believe it should be. By virtue of the Yankees' thrilling, come-from-behind triumph over the Seattle Mariners last night, following by one day the Mets' victory over the St. Louis Cardinals, New Yorkers can begin obsessing about their first subway Series since 1956, when the Yankees beat the Brooklyn Dodgers in a seven-game World Series that included Don Larsen's perfect game.

title: Step, Wince, Step, Wince
description: I have long viewed feet as a feminist issue. After years of tottering on painfully decorative footwear, I am convinced that the women's shoe industry is the last acceptable haven for misogynists. But this year, my consciousness has been raised to a new level.

title: Mrs. Clinton Suggests That U.S. Engage Aggressively in World Affairs
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, in her most detailed views on foreign policy in the New York Senate race to date, yesterday called for the United States to reject isolationism and aggressively engage itself in world affairs in the tradition of President Harry S. Truman at the end of World War II.

title: U.S. Aid to Colombia Worries Hemisphere's Defense Leaders
description: Defense ministers from throughout the Western Hemisphere assembled here in the heart of the Amazon today to begin four days of meetings aimed at strengthening military and security cooperation in the region.

title: Islanders Upended in a Matter of Seconds
description: With the Anaheim Mighty Ducks deep in the Islanders' territory on a power play, John Vanbiesbrouck allowed himself the luxury of a quick glance at the scoreboard. The clock showed 15 seconds remaining in the second period.

title: 3COM ROLLS OUT AN INTERNET APPLIANCE
description: Amid predictions by its developers that it would transform the use and storage of digital information by American households, the 3Com Corporation introduced an Internet appliance it called the Audrey yesterday. Unlike most Net appliances, which are basically stripped-down personal computers for Internet use only, Audrey is not aimed at the millions of American households that do not have computers. Eric Benhamou, the chairman and chief executive of 3Com, said the stylish $499 device, with its slim monitor and small wireless keyboard, was intended for the ''connected home, people who already have one or two PC's.'' The first of the company's new Ergo product line, the Audrey is meant easily to send and receive e-mail messages and provide access to the Internet. It can also create a household calendar and synchronize it with Palm hand-held devices. Michel Marriott

title: Put Milosevic on Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, RUTH HURLEY.
description: HUGHES-Ruth Hurley. October 15, 2000. Wife of David H. Hughes. Daughter of Patrick J. and Ruth Wilson Hurley. She is survived by her husband, eight children, David, Wilson, Ian, Peter, Graeme, Cecily and Ruth Hughes, and Anne Kieve. Also eleven grandchildren, and a sister, Patricia Hurley, and brother, Wilson P. Hurley. A memorial service will be held at 12 noon, Wednesday, October 18, at St. Philip's in the Hills, Tucson, AZ.

title: Will Senate Race Take Them Out to the Ballgame?
description: The setting was a cabbage farm here in a remote stretch of Suffolk County, but Representative Rick A. Lazio and his tiny audience of local farmers had strayed beyond the topic of crops to an issue of more immediate concern.

title: A Brisk Diet, And Magically, Vigor Returns
description: Brahms is about as standard as the standard repertory gets, yet programs devoted solely to his works come along infrequently enough that the all-Brahms concert by the Orchestra of St. Luke's at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening seemed unusual, if perhaps a bit quaint. The program notes revisited the feud between Brahms and Wagner -- a musical battle that now seems distant and almost incomprehensible compared with the more understandably passionate disputes between supporters of Minimalism and Serialism.

title: Consortium Opens Study Of Cancer
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani helped open what is expected to be the largest cancer study in the nation at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine yesterday, then stayed for an examination by his own cancer doctor.

title: Watch the Closing Doors''
description: When the Yankees nailed down their 37th American League pennant last night, they set up the 14th Subway Series, the first one against the Mets and the first in 44 years. After losing the first two such intracity showdowns to the New York Giants in 1921-22, when both teams shared the Polo Grounds as their home field, the Yankees won the next nine Subway Series, until the Brooklyn Dodgers broke the spell in 1955. The team from the Bronx is 10-3 in Subway Series: 4-2 against teams from Manhattan; 6-1 against teams from Brooklyn, and 0-0 against the team from Queens. By RAY CORIO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HRBEK, ANNE B.
description: HRBEK-Anne B. We all extend our deepest sympathy to Barbara Hrbek Zucker and family on the passing of her mother Anne. David & Laurie Zucker Lederman Barbara & Wayne Albinder David & Dana Zucker

title: Bush and Gore, in Last Debate, Stage Vigorous Give-and-Take
description: In their final confrontation before the nation's voters last night, Vice President Al Gore cited accomplishments throughout his public career as evidence that he is a champion of working Americans, while Gov. George W. Bush cast himself as a leader from outside Washington with a record of uniting Republicans and Democrats.

title: Fassel Cringes But Stays Upbeat
description: A week ago, Coach Jim Fassel viewed the films from the Giants' victory over the Atlanta Falcons and admitted that what he saw scared him. This week, the films showed the Dallas Cowboys doing everything they could to self-destruct, yet the Giants could not nudge past them until the final minutes. Still, Fassel was smiling as he took a breath, counting his blessings as the Giants headed into their bye week with a 5-2 record.

title: In Search Of Perfection In the Round
description: DOUGHNUT makers are a furtive bunch.

title: To Help Children, Computer Lessons for Parents
description: Andrene Francis, 38, had never turned on a computer, let alone used a mouse before. She fumbled. She shook. She was embarrassed in front of other parents who appeared to know the difference between left and right clicking.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARBASH, ROSLYN M.D.
description: BARBASH-Roslyn M.D. 1/5/11-10/ 18/85. Wise physician, loving wife and mother, loyal friend. 15 years gone, your memory still shines

title: Mets Are Mentally and Physically Ready for Series
description: They had spent almost a quarter of their season on the edge, consistently winning the close, low-scoring games that were supposed to be the stuff of nostalgia. When the Mets hit September, they had the best record in the National League. Who cared if they could pitch and field but only get just enough hits?

title: HERCULES WARNS ON PROFIT AS CHIEF EXECUTIVE RESIGNS
description: Hercules Inc., a specialty-chemicals maker, said its third-quarter profit would be lower than expected, and its chief executive resigned. The chief executive, Vincent Corbo, was replaced by Thomas Gossage, who had retired as chairman and chief executive in 1996. Hercules expects a profit of 13 cents a share, which would be short of the 21 cents expected by First Call/Thomson Financial. The company will evaluate the revamping program begun under Mr. Corbo, and weigh its alternatives, including a sale.
