title: Sam O'Steen, 76, Film Editor Nominated 3 Times for Oscars
description: Sam O'Steen, a film editor whose work brought him three Academy Award nominations, died on Wednesday in Atlantic City. He was 76 and lived in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, NATHANIEL H.
description: SOLOMON-Nathaniel H. October 16th. at Beth Israel Hospital, NYC. Devoted husband of 59-1/2 yrs of Miriam. Beloved father of Shelah and Charles. Loving grandfather of Samuel, Alexa and Molly. His great passion was the practice of pediatrics which he devoted 53 years. He served in General Patton's Third Army in WWII when they marched into Germany. He was a Captain in the Medical Corp, decorated for bravery with a Bronze Star. Member of Queens Pediatric Society. He was a pediatric staff member at Long Island Jewish Hospital, Beth Israel Hospital NY and the New York Hospital of Queens. His optimism was extraordinary and he will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Services 2PM Wednesday at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd at 76 Road, Forest Hills, New York. SOLOMON-Nathaniel H., M.D. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the physicians and staff of the Milton and Bernice Stern Department of Pediatrics in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our dear friend and former colleague, Nathaniel H. Solomon, M.D. Beginning with his residency in 1937, Dr. Solomon served the patients of Beth Israel with great distinction for more than 50 years, retiring in 1992. To his beloved wife, Miriam, his daughter Shelah, the entire Solomon family and all who loved him, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Henry S. Singman, M.D. President, Medical Board Andrew P. Mezey, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Pediatrics Robert L. Salant, M.D. President, Doctors Alumni Assoc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVITT, SANFORD
description: LAVITT-Sanford. The American Camping Association-NY Section is deeply saddened by the loss of Sandy Lavitt, a leader & dedicated supporter of S.C.O.P.E. (Summer Camp Opportunities Provide an Edge), a program that sends inner-city children to summer camp. Sandy was a unique individual whose tireless efforts touched the lives of many children. We will miss his friendship, support and love of life. We extend our deepest sympathy to Arlene, Keith, Jason, Lisa and Michelle. Barry Royce, President ACA-NY Marc Honigfeld, Chairperson of S.C.O.P.E.

Along with the United States, Russia, China, Britain, France, Ukraine, the Netherlands, Bangladesh, Mali and Jamaica, the 11 included Canada.

description: Al Leiter and Dennis Cook are poised for their second World Series wild-card experience, but their former Florida teammate Edgar Renteria can be more objective about what the Mets face.

description: WHEN chefs get their hands on classic comfort foods, they often wind up with macaroni and cheese enriched with half a dozen European cheeses, or meatloaf with foie gras. The high style obliterates the simple pleasure.

title: Pietro Palazzini, 88, Cardinal Honored for Holocaust Rescue
description: Cardinal Pietro Palazzini, a retired Vatican official who was honored by Israel for rescuing an Italian Jew in the Holocaust, died in Rome last Wednesday. He was 88.

title: Show Tunes, From Personality To Propulsion
description: The difference between traditional Broadway singing and its contemporary theatrical incarnation has rarely been delineated more sharply than it was on Monday evening at City Center, where a multigenerational gathering of stars performed ''My Favorite Broadway: The Love Songs.'' The glittering, swiftly paced variety show, taped for ''Great Performances'' on PBS, featured songs by everyone from George Gershwin to Jonathan Larson. Its top-of-the-line production values included an orchestra conducted by Paul Gemignani playing arrangements by the likes of Don Sebesky and Peter Matz.

title: A City Happily Pitted Against Itself
description: As Tino Martinez's glove snapped shut on the final out, the stars clicked into alignment in the sporting firmament above New York and a constellation that had not been seen in 44 years lighted up the skies of a city deliciously and deliriously divided against itself.

title: IRISH INFLATION ABATES SOMEWHAT
description: Fears about soaring Irish inflation eased as the government reported that the inflation rate remained steady at 6.2 percent for the year to September. Analysts had widely predicted that the rate would break 7 percent. Brian Lavery

title: Markets Are Down Broadly; Financial Issues Join Losers
description: Talk of weak earnings continued to plague stocks yesterday, and major market averages moved sharply lower.

title: THE BOSS; Calculus and Tomatoes
description: My inspiration is my grandmother, who's still alive at 96. She raised me from the time I was 8 on a dairy farm in Wisconsin. In another era she could have done what I do, although I didn't know what a C.E.O. was then. I'm a real go-getter and don't know any other way. I tell my 12-year-old daughter, if you have a test, why not try for an A? I don't believe in half doing something.

title: Business Travel; Corporate fliers complain a lot about airlines, but airports are also an important part of their lives.
description: ''LARGE coffee please.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMPSEY, LOUIS F.
description: DEMPSEY-Louis F. Of New York City died at home on October 16, 2000. Dearest and beloved husband of Patricia. Devoted father of Maryann Sedlack (Jeffrey) of Carlisle, Pennsylvania, Patricia Hammond (William) of Summit, New Jersey, Kathleen Malhame (George) of Manhasset, New York, Louis F. Dempsey (Maria) of Riverside, Connecticut, and Thomas F. Dempsey (Melinda) of New York, New York. Cherished grandfather of William, Anne, Meg, Charlie, Mary, Katie, Jack, Luke, and Mark. Beloved son of the late Louis F. Dempsey and the late Clara Lade Dempsey of Morristown, New Jersey. He is survived by his brothers Charles L. Dempsey of Landsdowne, Virginia, Joseph H. Dempsey of Morristown, New Jersey and his sister Maryclare Myers of Morris Plains, New Jersey. Mr. Dempsey's career in international banking spanned 50 years. He was employed by Chase Manhattan Bank in Hong Kong and San Juan, Puerto Rico, The Northern Trust Company in Chicago, Illinois where he was an Executive Vice President responsible for the International Banking Division, and Chemical Bank where he was an Executive Vice President responsible for international private banking. He retired in 1998 from Brown Brothers Harriman where he was a Senior Advisor. He served on a number of financial boards and advisory committees throughout his career including Chinese American Bank, Bluestone Capital, China Trust and LendingTree. Mr. Dempsey served on the boards of The Transfiguration Church of New York City, The Woodstock Theological Center of Washington D.C., The Financial Advisory Committee of the Passionist Missionaries, The Cardinal's Committee for the Laity of the Archdiocese of New York, and the Development Fund of the Catholic Archdiocese of New York. Following Mr. Dempsey's freshman year at Georgetown University, he enlisted in the U.S. Marine Corps and served with the First Marine Division during World War II. In June of 1945, Mr. Dempsey was a scout sniper in the battle for Okinawa at Kunishi Ridge. Mr. Dempsey later served as part of the China Occupation Forces. He returned home and graduated from the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University in 1948 where he later served on the Board of Regents. The family will receive friends at the Fairchild Sons funeral home at 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York on October 17 from 7:00 to 9:00 P.M. and on October 18 from 3:00 to 5:00 P.M. and from 7:00 to 9:00 P.M. A mass of Christian Burial will be said on October 19 at 11:15 A.M. at the Church of St. Mary s, 1300 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York. Burial will be held at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Inner City Scholarships Fund of the Catholic Archdiocese of New York at 1011 First Avenue, New York, New York 10022.

title: THE CHEF; New Source of Comfort
description: WHEN chefs get their hands on classic comfort foods, they often wind up with macaroni and cheese enriched with half a dozen European cheeses, or meatloaf with foie gras. The high style obliterates the simple pleasure.

title: NEW YORK, NEW YORK
description: The roller coaster ride that captured the Yankees this year and sent them careering hither and yon gave them a final stomach-turning dip last night before David Justice grabbed hold of the controls and directed the Yankees to the customary final stop on their postseason ride.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, HARVEY ALLAN.
description: WIENER-Harvey Allan. Beloved husband of Phoebe, devoted and loving father of Shellie Wiener Geist (Alan) and Mardi McDougall (Peter), cherished grandfather of Lewis and William Geist. Services to be held on Thursday, October 19, 12 noon at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York.

title: The Sounds of Silence: Hearken or Perish
description: Few theater actors working today find the sounds in silence that David Strathairn does. Give him a stage and a character with a reason to be quiet and he'll highjack your attention, no matter what kind of noise is going on around him.

title: The Boss: Calculus and Tomatoes
description: My inspiration is my grandmother, who's still alive at 96. She raised me from the time I was 8 on a dairy farm in Wisconsin. In another era she could have done what I do, although I didn't know what a C.E.O. was then. I'm a real go-getter and don't know any other way. I tell my 12-year-old daughter, if you have a test, why not try for an A? I don't believe in half doing something.

title: Tyson and Golota: Protect Yourself at All Times
description: Most major heavyweight fights are promoted with a catchy nickname or slogan that is splashed across every billboard for the bout. No one has bothered to do that for Friday's Mike Tyson-Andrew Golota fight.

title: Miss America Falters
description: There used to be a time when a network television executive could count on a few things year in and year out. One was that a sweeps month, ripped-from-the-headlines, made-for-TV movie would draw a very large audience. (Who could resist Alyssa Milano as Amy Fisher?) Another was that the annual ''Miss America'' pageant would have solid ratings as well.

title: ADVERTISING SPENDING RISES
description: Internet ad spending rebounded in September, according to AdZone Interactive, an advertising research firm that tracks advertising on 1,300 Web sites accounting for more than 95 percent of all United States Internet advertising revenue. Despite an overall increase among all online spenders, the 10 heaviest-spending brands collectively cut ad outlays by 8.6 percent. Sears

title: Classic Sauce Takes On A New Partner
description: IN and around Rome, a simple but powerful tomato sauce spiked with garlic, chilies and mint is traditional with tripe. But tripe is a hard sell to most Americans, and it has to cook a long time to become tender. Substitute shrimp and the dish is not only irresistible but practically done as soon as you add them to the hot sauce.

title: The Other Whiskey, Standing Up on Its Own
description: AMERICANS drink their Scotch, bourbon and Canadian whiskey any number of ways -- on the rocks and neat, in highballs and in cocktails. But we drink most of our Irish whiskey, if we drink it at all, mixed with hot, sweetened, creamy coffee.

title: Wrestlers Await I.O.C. Ruling
description: Brandon Slay is growing accustomed to the prospect of replacing the silver medal he won in freestyle wrestling at the Sydney Olympics with a gold one. But he is not yet ready to celebrate.

description: A United States trade agency ruled today that computer chip manufacturers in Japan, Taiwan and the United States had violated the Atmel Corporation's patents on digital memory circuits and ordered the companies to stop shipping products containing the devices to this country.

title: Aged Steak and Rare Old Strippers
description: IT was only a matter of time before someone put quote marks around the old-fashioned American steakhouse. Strip House is not so much a steakhouse as a catalog of hip references to the idea of a steakhouse, a kind of restaurant that really has no natural place in the heart of Greenwich Village. Without the quotes, Strip House would be naked.

title: The Final Presidential Debate
description: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush dropped the pleasantries of their previous debate last night and held their most spirited confrontation to date while outlining their disagreements over tax cuts, health care, schools, campaign finance and other subjects. Taking questions this time before a ''town meeting'' audience, both the candidates put in vigorous performances, but it was Mr. Gore who dominated their exchanges. He offered a tighter, more cogent presentation of his policies and for the first time in weeks recaptured some of the passion of his Democratic convention speech. The Texas governor responded by promising to bring a new tone of bipartisan cooperation to Washington, but he seemed less at ease than in last week's debate in engaging the budgetary and legislative details laid out by Mr. Gore.

title: Mets Fans in the Bronx? Not in Yankee Territory
description: There was a misty rain pelting Yankee Stadium as dozens of hopeful fans gathered outside the players entrance yesterday afternoon. The first pitch was still four hours away, but the fans turned giddy when David Justice nodded to them; they were even excited that Luis Polonia walked within 50 feet of them.

title: The Agony in Bosnia, Frame by Comic Book Frame
description: After devoting almost four years to "Safe Area Gorazde," a book about his experiences in Bosnia, a thought haunts Joe Sacco: history can intervene, and suddenly there is more than marriage, work, children. You are forced to reorganize your life and your priorities, and nothing will ever be the same.

title: Getting Involved Up to His Neck
description: Another television season is under way, and David E. Kelley is back at the salt mine, otherwise known as the desk where he writes scripts in longhand for all his television series.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: West 10th's New Mood

title: SNAG IN RUSSIAN OIL DEAL
description: A Russian oil company said it would proceed with a plan to regain an important production unit, despite opposition from a rival company that threatens to unravel the deal. Sidanco, which is 10 percent owned by BP Amoco, lost its subsidiary last year when Tyumen Oil pushed it into bankruptcy. The companies agreed to salvage BP Amoco's investment in Sidanco last December by giving Tyumen a stake in the company in exchange for returning assets. But Tyumen now says it will not participate if Sidanco gives Tyumen new shares instead of existing shares. Sabrina Tavernise

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRINITY INDUSTRIES, Dallas, a major manufacturer of products used in transportation, construction and other industries, said that it would close three railcar and parts manufacturing plants in Pennsylvania, Ohio and North Carolina and fewer than 200 workers would be laid off.

title: BRAZIL BANK MERGER
description: One of Brazil's largest banks, Banco Itau, paid $872 million in an auction for Banco do Estado do Parana, a bank in Brazil's Parana state, increasing Itau's base of seven million customers by more than a half million. Itau paid a 303 percent premium over the minimum price set at an auction, beating bids from two local rivals. Itau, which previously acquired the state banks of Minas Gerais and Rio de Janeiro, is also considered one of the main contenders in the coming auction of the Sao Paulo state bank, Banespa. Jennifer L. Rich

title: ADVANCED MICRO SHIPS FASTER CHIPS
description: The main rival of Intel in the market for computer processors, Advanced Micro Devices, said yesterday that it had begun shipping faster versions of its products, extending its lead in the race for the speediest chip. The company is selling 1.2 gigahertz Athlon processors for high-end computers and 800 megahertz Durons for cheaper machines. It said Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer would use the new chips. Intel's top Pentium runs at a speed of 1 gigahertz.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO CLIMBS. The euro rose, snapping a four-day slide, as sinking United States stocks dimmed the dollar's appeal. In New York, the euro settled at 85.58 cents, up from 85.05 cents on Monday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the big-band trombonist Britt Woodman yesterday misstated the surname of John Philip Sousa's first trombonist, whose solos Mr. Woodman admired as a young man. He was Arthur Pryor, not Price.

title: 7 Companies Agree to Cut Gas Emissions
description: DuPont, Shell, Alcan Aluminium and four other large companies yesterday joined a growing list of businesses committing themselves to substantial voluntary reductions in releases of heat-trapping greenhouse gases.

title: British Train Derails, Killing 4 And Raising New Safety Alarms
description: At least four people were killed and 33 injured today when a high-speed train traveling north from London derailed, raising new concerns about the safety of Britain's privatized railroads.

title: Agencies Selected For 2 Accounts
description: Ask Jeeves, an online question-and-answer service, has named the San Francisco office of Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group, its agency of record. The San Francisco office of a Grey sibling, MediaCom, will handle media duties. Spending was estimated at $50 million. Euro RSCG DSW Partners in Salt Lake City, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising, previously handled it.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: City's Bilingual Education Debated at Spirited Hearing
description: Armed with a sheaf of rising test scores, Ron Unz, the Silicon Valley entrepreneur who led the drive to end bilingual education in California two years ago, told a raucous hearing at City Hall yesterday that New York would be wise to follow his state's lead.

title: And Miles to Go Before I Eat, and Miles to Go . . .
description: HOW far would you drive for a great doughnut?

title: Not Just for Beer, Ball and Jelly Fans
description: ARRIVING in Singapore for the first time a number of years ago, we dropped our bags at our hotel and immediately headed outside, eager to sample the mix of Asian cuisines that make up the vibrant street food scene.

title: Senate Opponents Disagree On Israel Resolution in U.N.
description: The two candidates for the Senate from New Jersey, Jon S. Corzine and Representative Bob Franks, disagreed again tonight on American policy on a recent United Nations resolution criticizing Israel's role in the violence in the Middle East.

title: 'Blood Is Boiling' in West Bank and Gaza
description: Israeli soldiers continued to battle Palestinians throughout the West Bank and the Gaza Strip today, and critics on both sides derided a provisional truce.

title: At Boston's Gala, Morsels for All
description: Symphony Hall, home of the Boston Pops as well as the Boston Symphony Orchestra, has, over its 100 years, been many things to many people. In that respect, the concerts celebrating the hall's centenary on Saturday and Sunday surely covered the ground.

title: U.S. Says Yemen Has Found 'Leads' in Bombing
description: Yemeni security officials have searched an apartment in Aden that they suspect was used for several days by men who may have played a role in the bombing last week that killed 17 American sailors, American officials in Washington said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPINCOTT, ELEANOR HALLOWELL.
description: LIPPINCOTT-Eleanor Hallowell. Died October, 15, 2000, Princeton, New Jersey. Mother of John Willard Lapsley, Marian Lapsley Schwarz, Nina Lapsley Alexander, Katherine Boucher Beug, and sister of Phillips Hallowell. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Channel Thirteen. Memorial Service at Princeton Unitarian Church, Cherry Hill Road, 11 A.M. Saturday, October 21, 2000.

title: A Chosen Few Questioners, but Few With Made-Up Minds
description: Leo Anderson was surprised to be called on. He rose, waited for a microphone to be handed to him and slowly unfolded his crumpled index card. Then he put it to George W. Bush.

title: Scientist Has First Session to Explain Downloading
description: Four and a half weeks after he pleaded guilty to one felony count, the former Los Alamos scientist Wen Ho Lee had his first session today with government officials and began explaining why he had illegally downloaded a library of nuclear secrets, an activity that the government said imperiled national security.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the effect of resurgent Arab nationalism on the Middle East peace effort misstated the name and mission of a policy group whose director commented on the situation. It is the Washington Institute for Near Eastern Policy, not Near Eastern Affairs. It describes itself as a public educational foundation that supports scholarly research and debate on the Middle East, not a pro-Israeli group.

title: A Festival of Today's French Dance
description: Nine choreographers and their companies will be featured in ''France Moves,'' a festival of contemporary French dance at six New York theaters from April 23 to May 6.

title: Cartoonist Makes a Big Mark on Broadway
description: IN the last month or so, Roz Chast has had half a dozen cartoons published in The New Yorker. No news there -- happens all the time. She has also ushered her son and daughter into another school year. No news there, either -- happens every year. And been a featured entertainer on a trans-Atlantic cruise. Now that's news, if not the stuff of a Roz Chast cartoon. But that is not the big news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLIN, MAURICE
description: BERLIN-Maurice, 79. Master jeweler of Southbury, CT, on October 15, 2000, born in Antwerp, Belgium, August 6, 1921. Beloved companion of Thelma Hahn. Loving father of Joelle Erazo and Mireille LaRussa. Grandfather of five, greatgrandfather of one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANDIS, JOAN E.
description: GRANDIS-Joan E. March 18, 1932-October 16, 2000. Assistant Director of Speech Improvement for New York City Board of Education, will be missed by her devoted husband Paul, 45 years of marriage, and all who knew her as a kind, scholarly and compassionate person. Taught at Hunter College and NYU Downtown. I will miss you forever as a friend and husband, traveling all over the world together. Have a good trip to another world, this time alone. Services will be held on Friday, October 20, 2000 at 1:15 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel at Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, 212-362-6600.

title: Taking Credit for Patients' Rights Where It's Not Necessarily Due
description: In tonight's presidential debate, Gov. George W. Bush presented himself as a champion of a patients' bill of rights in Texas, saying he ''brought Republicans and Democrats together to do just that in the state of Texas.'' He made the same assertion in television commercials during the Republican primaries.

title: BOOTS, A BRITISH COMPANY, BUYS P.& G.'S CLEARASIL BRAND
description: Boots P.L.C., a British retailer of health, beauty and food products, said yesterday that it had bought the Clearasil acne treatment brand from Procter & Gamble for $340 million. Global sales of Clearasil, the leading brand of acne treatment products, totaled $137 million in 1999, with 39 percent of its users in the United States. Boots said the purchase would enhance its earnings within a year. Procter & Gamble, which also makes Crest toothpaste and Tide detergent, is shedding what it sees as minor brands in an effort to restore sagging profits. Alan Cowell

title: Production In September Rose, but Pace Was Slower
description: Industrial production slowed in September from a month earlier, closing out the weakest quarterly performance for manufacturers since early last year, Federal Reserve statistics showed today.

title: Bruce Palmer Jr., 87; Led Forces in Vietnam
description: Bruce Palmer Jr., deputy commanding general of American troops in South Vietnam, later Army vice chief of staff and then the author of a book analyzing the military failure of the United States in Southeast Asia, died on Oct. 10 at a hospital in Alexandria, Va. He was 87.

title: New Advice for Parents: Saying 'That's Great!' May Not Be
description: Five-year-old Cristina bounced up to her preschool teacher in this quiet Iowa farm town, waved her crayon drawing dotted with brightly colored stickers and asked, ''What do you think of my picture?''

title: BROADCOM PICKS UP TEXAS CHIP MAKER
description: The manufacturer of semiconductors for cable modems, Broadcom, said it had agreed to acquire Allayer Communications, a chip maker for computer networks, for $273.5 million in stock. The deal is part of Broadband's strategy to bolster its broadband product offering for networking services for local, metropolitan and wide area networks. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Thomas Labrecque, 62, Dies; Ex-Chief of Chase Manhattan
description: Thomas G. Labrecque, the former chairman and chief executive of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, died Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York.

title: Doomed Plane Apparently Had Instrument Trouble
description: As rescue workers and federal officials searched a remote wooded area today for wreckage of a twin-engine plane that carried Gov. Mel Carnahan, his son and a campaign adviser, an investigator said the pilot had reported an instrument problem moments before the plane crashed on Monday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARIGNANI, CAROLINE
description: MARIGNANI-Caroline (nee Curtayne). Of Southbury, CT. on October 17, 2000. Beloved daughter of Grace Smith Curtayne and the late E. Vincent Curtayne. Loving mother of Matteo Marignani and Marta Leo. Sister of Mary Wellman and Sr. Mary Alphonsus. Mass of Christian Burial to be held Thursday, October 19, 10AM at Sacred Heart Church, Southbury, CT. Calling hours today, 4-8PM at Munson-Lovetere Funeral Home, 235 Main Street No., Southbury, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to The Sisters of the Poor Convent, 1365 Enfield Street, Enfield, CT. 06082.

title: LOEWS MOVIE CHAIN SAYS QUARTERLY REVENUE FELL 12.6%
description: The troubled movie theater chain Loews Cineplex Entertainment Corporation said yesterday that it expected to report that second-quarter revenue fell 12.6 percent compared with the same 1999 period. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company, which is based in New York, also said it expected revenue for the six months ended Aug. 31 to be 6.9 percent lower than the 1999 figure. In the second quarter a year ago, Loews posted net income of $15.8 million and revenue of $303.2 million. Loews said on Monday that it had had to revise its loan terms with syndicate banks because of ''continued disappointing results at the box office.'' Loews operates 2,960 screens in 376 locations worldwide.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES. Coffee rose more than 3 percent on speculation that dry weather could damage next year's crop in Brazil. In New York, coffee for December delivery rose 3.05 cents, or 3.6 percent, to 88.7 cents a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKOWITZ, HARRY
description: MARKOWITZ - Harry. Passed away Tuesday, October 17, 2000. Of West Palm Beach, FL. Loving husband of Celia. Adored father of Dr. Jeffrey and Sheree Markowitz and Elaine and Jerome Eckers. Cherished grandfather of four. Beloved brother of Ralph. Services today, October 18, 2000, 12:15PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, Long Island.

title: How the Senate Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times poll of New Jersey is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 12 through 15 with 1,158 adults throughout the state. Of those, 908 said they were registered to vote.

title: Mel Carnahan, 66, Missouri Governor and Democratic Senate Candidate
description: In recent years, supporters of Gov. Mel Carnahan of Missouri had taken to wearing gold lapel pins shaped like straight arrows. The symbolism was clear: Mr. Carnahan's dominant characteristic as a politician was his reputation for being clean and on the level.

title: TRENDS; Calling the Shots: Not Just Athletes Are Free Agents
description: An increasing number of Americans are answering to aboss who really does care: themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWERS, JAMES C.
description: POWERS-James C. Jimmy, dear friend, family member, valued confidant. We will surely miss you at our table and in our hearts. We raise a glass to many fond memories. Andi, Jay, Brad, Harry, Jeremy

title: The Price of Stopping Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Transit Strike in Los Angeles Is Resolved With New Contract
description: Buses were scheduled to begin running here on Wednesday morning after both sides in a monthlong transit strike approved an agreement that negotiators had reached early today.

title: Grown-Up Chenin Blancs From a Tiny Appellation
description: IN the middle of the Loire Valley, from the Anjou region east past Tours, the greatness and versatility of chenin blanc is revealed. This grape, which has a reputation for making dull, indifferent wines elsewhere in the world, produces wines in this region that are light and crisp, and others that are nearly dry but for their slightly honeyed finish. They can be sparkling and refreshing or they can be thick and luscious enough to have for dessert.

title: Getting To Know Eschenbach
description: A willing one or not, Christoph Eschenbach has been identified as a candidate for the music directorship of the New York Philharmonic. He was at Carnegie Hall on Monday night as conductor of the NDR Symphony Orchestra from the north of Germany, one of his many executive jobs around the world. Given Mr. Eschenbach's itinerary, which sends him ricocheting from Hamburg to Paris to Chicago to Houston and back, one wonders how he might squeeze in the Philharmonic. Maybe there would be time on alternate Mondays.

title: Sprint Profits Increased 7%
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 17 (AP)  Sprint said today that its third- quarter profit had risen 7 percent, helped by increased earnings from its long-distance and local telephone operations.

title: Bell Puts Down the Phone And Props Up His Ankle
description: Derek Bell knew better than to call the Mets clubhouse on Monday, after his teammates won the National League championship without him. Bell, who reached the World Series with Toronto in 1992, knows how celebrations can be.

title: CALENDAR
description: Terminal Tastings

title: Big Spender, Bush Cries; Big Miser, Gore Counters
description: Gov. George W. Bush tried to paint Vice President Al Gore tonight as a traditional big-spending Democrat whose proposals would lead to a bigger, more intrusive federal government.

title: Gestures Said Much More Than Words
description: Thousands of words tumbled out of the candidates mouths' tonight -- small ones and big ones, fancy references and colloquial terms -- but there was something else that spoke much more loudly and eloquently.

title: A U.S. Role Is Crucial For Peace
description: No American politician ever lost an election by speaking too fondly of Israel or too poorly of the Palestinians. But this is a time for sober calculation about events in the Holy Land and their implications for American interests, not for emotionally or electorally satisfying rhetoric.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAVEZZO, DANIEL H., JR.
description: LAVEZZO-Daniel H., Jr. A Memorial Gathering will be celebrated at the Belasco Room at Sardi's Sunday, Oct 22nd from 6pm-9pm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARENGA, WILLIAM T.
description: FARENGA-William T. On October 16, 2000. Dear friend of Henry O. Golightly, brother of Charles Farenga, long term member of NSID. He was a noted interior designer in the metropolitan area for many years. Memorial Service Friday October 20, 2000, at 11 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Animal Rescue Fund, Easthampton, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, JOSEPH
description: MARKS-Joseph. Beloved husband of Lillian Shapiro. Devoted father of Daniel, Sheila Blake, Jonathan. Adored grandfather of Hill, Jane, Benjamin, Amy and Gabrielle and adored great-grandfather. Services Thursday 1PM at Schwartz Jeffer Funeral Home, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: The Water Goes Up, The Coffee Comes Down, Piping Hot
description: Can a futuristic, slightly lopsided-looking, two-part plastic contraption be the key to good coffee? A vacuum coffee maker, called the Utopia, has just been introduced by Starbucks. It uses a method of brewing coffee that produces a truer, cleaner coffee flavor than a French press, a percolator or a filter drip pot.

title: Fund Manager, 23 Years Old, Is Arrested on Fraud Charges
description: A 23-year-old hedge fund manager was arrested yesterday and charged with trying to defraud investors in his fund, Ashbury Capital Partners, officials said yesterday.

title: But the Authorities Are Not Amused and Talk of Legal Action : Web Site Offers an Auction for Votes
description: WASHINGTON  The Internet has been used to sell, or try to sell, many improbable things: from tickets to witness an execution to a piece of French toast.

title: MANAGEMENT: Getting Religion On Corporate Ethics; A Scourge of Scandals Leaves Its Mark
description: Archer Daniels Midland pleaded guilty to a price-fixing conspiracy that cost consumers millions of dollars a year in higher prices for soft drinks and detergents. It agreed to pay a $100 million fine.

title: From Honey-Dipped to Chocolate-Coated
description: DOUGHNUTS show up in all sorts of places in New York: restaurants, diners and bakeries. Here are some of the places where they are made with care. The best, like those made at Gramercy Tavern, Il Forno and Eli's Manhattan, are worth a detour.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: EMERSON ELECTRIC CO., St. Louis, named David N. Farr, chief operating officer, to the additional post of chief executive. He succeeds Charles F. Knight, who remains chairman.

title: Resolved: That High School Debate Is Back
description: Standing at a school desk, wearing shiny high-heel boots, Stacey Martin, 17 years old, rapped her fist on the table, looked straight into the judge's eyes and spoke with the aplomb of a seasoned lawyer and the dizzying speed of an auctioneer.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: BLAME FOR HIGH BILLS -- A consultant to the Independent System Operator, a group that administers the wholesale energy markets in New York State, yesterday attributed much of the summer increase in electricity prices in the metropolitan area to the shutdown of a Con Edison generating plant. The consultant, David B. Patton of Capital Economics, challenged Con Edison's position that much of the increase resulted from the group's rules, which discourage economical imports of electricity. Mr. Patton said the shutdown of the Indian Point 2 power plant after an accident in February forced Con Ed to buy more expensive replacement power. A Con Ed spokesman, Joseph Petta, said the utility stood by its position. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: New Yugoslav Leader Tries To Calm Wary Montenegro
description: With a deal for a new Serbian government sealed, President Vojislav Kostunica of Yugoslavia turned his attention today to the challenge of forming a federal government and to forging a new relationship with the independent-minded republic of Montenegro.

title: Article 2000101892684384887 -- No Title
description: TECHNOLOGY

title: Titans Still Have Jaguars' Number
description: The question was simple: for as long as you have played football, have you ever been on the futile side of a rivalry like Tennessee versus Jacksonville, the side where Jacksonville now resides?

title: Prosecutor Calls First Ladys Testimony on Travel Office Inaccurate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  In his final report about the firing of seven longtime employees of the White House travel office, released today, Robert W. Ray, the independent counsel, asserted that Hillary Rodham Clinton gave "factually false" sworn testimony when she minimized her role in the incident.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Change the Woolworth? No Way, a Board Says
description: Is a lily like the Woolworth Building in need of gilding?

title: Hernandez Overcomes His Failings
description: Shortly after the ball left the right hand of Orlando Hernandez, it also left the field of play, launched into the right-field stands by the bat of Carlos Guillen. The two-run homer gave the Seattle Mariners a four-run lead in the fourth inning, and it seemed as if it might give the Yankees pitcher known as El Duque the first postseason defeat of his career.

title: Reckonings; We're Not Responsible
description: However this election turns out, future historians are likely to see this as the year that America failed a big political test.

description: The latest New York Times poll of New Jersey is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 12 through 15 with 1,158 adults throughout the state. Of those, 908 said they were registered to vote.

title: Astronauts Complete Third Spacewalk
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- Two spacewalking astronauts clamped power equipment onto the international space station on Tuesday and inadvertently added to the collection of junk whizzing around Earth.

title: Yanks Win 37th Pennant With a Comeback Effort
description: The hopes and fears of New York baseball fans are a reality.

title: Ganache With Panache: A Master Shows How
description: AT the heart of every chocolate truffle is ganache, a velvety amalgam of chocolate and cream that is often enhanced with flavorings as luxurious as Champagne and as exotic as black tea. But ganache is not just for candy makers. Spooned into a pastry shell it makes a glossy chocolate tartlet. It can be sandwiched between cake layers or spooned warm over ice cream for hot fudge gone to heaven. Add egg yolks, then whipped egg whites and perhaps whipped cream folded in, and you have chocolate mousse.

title: For a 6-Year-Old Boy, the Series Is but a Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: Where to Find Your Bag: Just Look Under Your Martini
description: The handbag on the floor. The handbag hanging from the back of a stool. The handbag gone, disappearing amid the happy hour mayhem at a bar. It happens all too often.

title: SUNRISE MEDICAL WILL BE BOUGHT BY ITS SENIOR MANAGERS
description: Sunrise Medical Inc., a maker of medical products, agreed to be acquired by an investor group that includes its chief executive, Michael Hammes, and other senior managers in a transaction that values Sunrise at about $224.4 million. The investor group will pay $10 a share in cash for each Sunrise share, 55 percent more than its closing price of $6.44 yesterday. The company, which is based in Carlsbad, Calif., makes products used in rehabilitation and treatment of respiratory conditions in nursing homes and by home health-care providers. The investor group also includes Park Avenue Equity Partners and Vestar Capital Partners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARABUENA, JOY LETICIA
description: CARABUENA-Joy Leticia (Woodcock). Of Mount Vernon, N.Y. Died on October 15, 2000 at the age of 32. She is survived by her husband, Adam Woodcock, mother, Leticia, father, Cesar, two brothers, John and Glen, and one sister, Jean Marie Carabuena. Friends may call at the Yannantuono Funeral Home, 584 Gramatan Ave., Mount Vernon, on Wednesday, 5-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, St. Peter and Paul Church, 10 AM. Donations to the Memorial SloanKettering Pediatric Cancer Center would be appreciated.

title: Spanish Utility to Acquire Rival in $12.7 Billion Deal
description: In a friendly deal that will create one of the world's biggest power companies, Grupo Endesa of Spain agreed today to acquire a domestic rival, Iberdrola, for stock and cash worth about $12.7 billion.

title: Doig Dropped By the Rangers
description: Jason Doig is only 23 years old. But the Rangers have already decided that they have seen enough.

title: A Case of Neglect: White Bordeaux
description: WHITE Bordeaux at two meals in one day? Even in Bordeaux the odds are against it. But I did it last week, both times in the company of dedicated red wine producers.

description: BASEBALL

title: Knicks' Big Backcourt Sputtering
description: There were moments when they shined, such as when Allan Houston powered through the lane and a cluster of defenders for a resounding dunk, or when Latrell Sprewell fed Glen Rice for an open 3-pointer.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE GREEN PARTY

title: ARTS IN AMERICA; The Agony in Bosnia, Frame by Comic Book Frame
description: After devoting almost four years to ''Safe Area Gorazde,'' a book about his experiences in Bosnia, a thought haunts Joe Sacco: history can intervene, and suddenly there is more than marriage, work, children. You are forced to reorganize your life and your priorities, and nothing will ever be the same.

title: If Home's Too Far to Get to, a Place in Harlem Beckons
description: IN a world that reveres the richest and the greatest, it's reassuring to know that a corner in heaven is reserved for the homiest, too. Miss Maude's Spoonbread Too, a bright new restaurant in Harlem, celebrates the virtues of family meals without the childish nostalgia implicit in expressions like ''comfort food.''

title: New York Following Senate Race More Closely Than New Jersey
description: Both New York and New Jersey are holding elections for open Senate seats this year, but one seems to be getting all the attention.

title: A Bridge to Cuba?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Says a Tax Increase Is No Way to Help Nassau
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, who in May offered a state bailout to help Nassau County out of its fiscal crisis, yesterday criticized Nassau Democrats' plans to raise the county portion of municipal property tax bills by 16.3 percent next year.

title: Mayor Backing a New Mets Park
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani expressed hope yesterday that the city could complete negotiations for construction of a new Ebbets Field-style ballpark next to Shea Stadium.

title: Eyes Are Now on the Arab Leaders
description: Arab leaders, uneasy riders atop a wave of militant anti-Israel sentiment across the Middle East, began to regroup after the Sharm el Sheik summit meeting today in preparation for a weekend meeting of their own that will test regional support for a negotiated peace with Israel.

title: Slowly, a Swift Coles Breaks Out of the Pack
description: Slowly, but inexorably, Laveranues Coles, the fastest player in the history of Florida State football, is making an impact on the Jets' offense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABRECQUE, THOMAS.
description: LABRECQUE - Thomas. The Board of Trustees, Medical Staff and Administration of the Hospital for Special Surgery mourn with profound sorrow the death of Thomas Labrecque, a dedicated Board member and friend. He served on the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees, chaired the HSS International Council, and established the Thomas and Sheila Labrecque Trauma Research Endowment. He gave unstintingly of his time and knowledge to support the Hospital in its pursuit of the highest degree of excellence. He was a great humanitarian and an extraordinary contributor to the civic life of New York. He will be greatly missed and always remembered. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Sheila, his children Thomas, Douglas, Karen and Barbara, and to all members of his bereaved family. Richard L. Menschel, Chairman Aldo Papone, Co-Chairman Board of Trustees Russell F. Warren, MD, Surgeon-in-Chief Stephen A. Paget, MD, Physician-in-Chief Philip D. Wilson, Jr., MD, Surgeon-in-Chief Emeritus John R. Reynolds, President & CEO LABRECQUE-Thomas G. The Women's Committee of The Central Park Conservancy extend their sincere condolences to Sheila Labrecque and her family on the loss of their beloved husband and father. We mourn Tom's passing as too soon and too quick, a man taken in the prime of life. His warmth, generosity and love for his family and friends, will be long remembered and missed. We offer our support and love, our thoughts and prayers. We pray that the family's faith in God will sustain them. The Board of Directors of The Women's Committee LABRECQUE-Thomas G. The Board of Directors of the International Rescue Committee notes with great sorrow the passing of our dear colleague, Thomas G. Labrecque. As a member of our Board Tom made extraordinary contributions to the IRC and the cause of refugees. We will miss his selfless leadership and passion for helping others in need. On behalf of the Board, we extend our condolences to his wife, Sheila and their family. Winston Lord, James C. Strickler, M.D. Co-Chairmen of the Board LABRECQUE - Thomas. We mourn the passing of our friend and fellow Board member, Thomas Labrecque. We have benefited greatly from his wisdom, counsel and dedication for nearly two decades and are deeply saddened by his loss. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Sheila, his children and his family. The Board of Trustees The Central Park Conservancy A.J.C. Smith, Chairman

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Wednesday about Genetic ID, the laboratory that found genetically modified corn in a batch of taco shells, misidentified the agency that is considering starting a program to certify food as being free of modified ingredients. It is the Department of Agriculture, not the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Idol of Millions Yet a Bit of a Phantom
description: JOE DIMAGGIO

title: Earnings Jump at Citigroup and Merrill
description: Markets may be rocky, but there was not much sign of trouble in the strong third-quarter earnings reported by Citigroup and Merrill Lynch yesterday.

title: A Way to Defeat Xena
description: When it made its debut five years ago, ''Xena: Warrior Princess,'' a syndicated program about a leather-clad, towering, fantasy-age female warrior, provoked plenty of guffaws inside and outside the television industry. In large part the laughter was directed at the underlying sexual tension that seems to run through the series, which is geared for teenagers and young adults. (Its action sequences are often good for a laugh, too.)

title: HANDSPRING LOSS WIDENS
description: The fiscal first-quarter loss of Handspring Inc. widened as the company accelerated sales of its electronic organizers. Handspring lost $16.4 million, or 17 cents a share, in the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with a loss of $9.2 million in the year-earlier period, according to regulatory filings. Analysts had forecast a loss of 12 cents a share. Handspring, which shipped its first products about a year ago, posted sales of $70.5 million, a 36 percent rise from the prior quarter. Its shares rose 31.25 cents, to $77.875.

title: From Ingmar to Ikea, New Center Gives City a Nordic Touch
description: There is a new six-story building on Park Avenue four blocks south of Grand Central Terminal. It is called Scandinavia House: The Nordic Center in America. It has tinted windows and a smooth gray facade. Above all, it is well-branded.

title: Transcript of Post-Debate Discussion
description: On Tuesday, October 17 at 10:30 p.m., columnist Gail Collins and Southern Bureau Chief Kevin Sack joined a live online audience to discuss the final presidential debate between Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore, held at Washington University in St. Louis, Mo. A transcript of this event follows.

title: Step, Wince, Step, Wince
description: STANFORD, Calif.  I have long viewed feet as a feminist issue. After years of tottering on painfully decorative footwear, I am convinced that the women's shoe industry is the last acceptable haven for misogynists. But this year, my consciousness has been raised to a new level.

title: Op-Art; Out of Business.com
Leaders in Congress Agree to Debt Relief for Poor Nations
description: Congressional leaders said today that they planned to grant President Clinton all the money he had sought to forgive debts of the world's poorest nations this year, a victory for a coalition of rock stars, religious figures and charity groups that have made debt forgiveness a moral touchstone for wealthy nations.
