description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

title: Police Say Enraged Father Dropped Infant 15 Floors
description: A father, apparently enraged by a fight with his estranged wife over when he could visit his 3-month-old son, threw the infant from the window of her 15th-floor apartment in Co-op City yesterday, killing the boy instantly, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATEL, MAHENDRA, MD.
description: PATEL-Mahendra, MD. With a profound sense of loss, we mourn the passing of our good friend and colleague, Mahendra Patel, MD. As an outstanding physician, he treated so many patients with compassion and humility; as an exceptional educator, he taught countless residents and medical students, and us all, with kindness and insight; as a beloved friend, he inspired us with his unending courage and optimism. To his beloved wife, Suli, and children Lipi and Anshul, we want you to know that your pain is our pain. We will miss terribly Mahendra's gentleness and sensitivity, his smile and good humor, his sense of professionalism and mentorship, his wit and wisdom, his nobility and character. His memory will live on for eternity in the endeavors of his students. Mitchell A. Goldman, MD, Chairman, Dept. Radiology Jay Cinnamon, MD, Vice-Chairman, Dept. Radiology Long Island Jewish Medical Ctr North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Hi-Tech Volunteerism
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Greenspan Says Oil Prices Having Modest Effect on Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19  The low-inflation new economy is up against an old economy challenge  a surge in oil prices  and so far the new economy is holding its own, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today.

title: A Close Race Both Parties Think Is Theirs
description: There are moments when the bitter rematch between Representative James H. Maloney, a two-term incumbent Democrat, and his Republican challenger, Mark Nielsen, actually seems to live up to its billing as one of the most important Congressional races in the country.

title: Torre May Give Cone the Start in Game 4
description: David Cone has been saying for a month that he was looking for one chance in the postseason, one opportunity to recoup his frustrating season, and he may well get it, if Manager Joe Torre picks the right-hander to start Game 4 of the World Series.

title: Balkans After Milosevic: Still Perilous Waters
description: The removal of Slobodan Milosevic in Serbia has opened new opportunities for peace in the Balkan region, but also created a fluid situation where treacherous problems abound.

title: Taking On the Oceans, Alone in a Rowboat
description: MICK BIRD, a burly Hawaiian-born adventurer, says he is determined to challenge the world's major oceans one on one. This fall he began the fourth and longest leg -- 8,000 miles across the Indian Ocean -- in his attempt to be the first person to circle the globe alone in a rowboat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLUB, DAVID
description: GOLUB-David. The Herbert Barrett Management, Herbert Barrett, President; John A. Anderson, Executive Vice President; Mary Lynn Fixler, Vice President; Rob Robbins, Vice President; Nancy Wellman, Senior Advisor and Personal Manager to Mr. Golub, mourn the sudden passing of the extraordinary pianist/conductor David Golub in Milano, Italy on October 16, 2000. David was internationally renowned for his brilliant and majestic musical interpretations as pianist, conductor, chamber musician and recording artist. He was a man of so many gifts, especially for deep and abiding friendships around the world. We are filled with appreciation for his accomplishments and sorrow for this great loss. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Maria in Milano, his parents Benjamin and Sima Golub, in San Diego, his cousin David Ben Golub of New York and Seattle, and all of his family and friends worldwide. Private services are held Thursday, October 19th in Milano. A memorial concert will be held in New York City in Spring 2001.

title: Modern Unveils Design for New Outpost in Queens
description: The Museum of Modern Art, which is to close in the summer of 2002 for a full architectural overhaul, unveiled the design for its temporary home in Long Island City, Queens, yesterday.

title: Last Debate Clearly Left Some Voters Dissatisfied
description: For at least one heterogeneous audience, here in one of the most closely contested battleground states of the campaign, the final presidential debate of 2000 was more about reinforcing political views previously reached than about arriving at new conclusions.

title: Bodies of 6 Remind Italy of Migrants' Plight
description: The bodies of six illegal immigrants, believed to have suffocated in a truck, were found dumped on the side of a highway in southern Italy today, a grim reminder of the perils of trying to immigrate to Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, FRANCYS
description: HIRSCH-Francys. Forever in our hearts! Oma, you were one of a kind and will be dearly missed. Mark, Jill, Julia, Emily and Katie

title: The Ears Behind a Philharmonic Venture
description: SEDGWICK CLARK can tell you who coughed during the Wagner at the New York Philharmonic. Not last night, not the night before, but on Jan. 26, 1970.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS MEETS ESTIMATES
description: Citing growing demand across its full range of semiconductor products, Texas Instruments said its third-quarter per-share earnings increased 27 percent, meeting expectations. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, pro forma net income was $591 million, or 33 cents a diluted share, compared with $453 million, or 26 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 25 percent, to $3.15 billion, while operating profit rose 43 percent, to $745 million.

title: Boxes Full of the Past, But Loved by So Few
description: ASHLEA EBELING and Craig Bloom bought a low-slung 60's house here last year for the same reason any newlyweds would buy a house in the suburbs: they wanted space, light, a lawn and room to raise a family.

title: Apple Posts Results That Narrowly Miss Analysts' Estimates
description: Three weeks after warning investors that revenue would fall short of estimates, Apple Computer today announced quarterly earnings that narrowly missed even Wall Street's lowered estimates.

title: STATION CASINOS TO SELL MISSOURI OPERATIONS
description: Station Casinos Inc., whose casinos in Missouri have been the subject of an investigation by the state, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell those properties to Ameristar Casinos Inc. for $475 million. The deal ended an agreement made in July to sell the casinos to a group led by the company's management. Ameristar will acquire properties in St. Charles and Kansas City. Ameristar will sell its Reserve casino in Henderson, Nev., to Station for $70 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARENGA, WILLIAM T.
description: FARENGA-William T. On October 16, 2000. Dear friend of Henry O. Golightly, brother of Charles Farenga, long term member of NSID. He was a noted interior designer in the metropolitan area for many years. Memorial Service Friday October 20, 2000, at 11 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Animal Rescue Fund, Easthampton, New York.

title: Effem Consolidates Canadian Account
description: Effem, a division of Mars Inc., consolidated its media planning and buying account in Canada at MediaVest Canada, part of the Starcom MediaVest Group unit of the Bcom3 Group. Billings for the account, which includes media planning and buying in Canada for products like Uncle Ben's and Snickers, were not disclosed.

title: Sculptural And Sensual, It's Odissi
description: Classical dance in India has a select number of master teachers. Guru Kelucharan Mohapatra, who performed with his small group at Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College on Saturday night, is revered for an even greater contribution: the prominent role he played in the revival of Odissi dance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADY, REVEREND THOMAS
description: BRADY-Reverend Thomas Edward, S.J. Loving brother of Annabelle Black, Mary White, William, Edward, Joseph, John and Robert. Reposing at Jesuit Chapel, Murray Weigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Road, Bronx, NY. Visiting Friday, 3-5PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday, 7:30PM at Murray Weigel Hall Chapel. For information contact Farenga Bros, Inc., Directors.

title: LOSS WIDENS AT COVAD
description: Burdened by overdue payments for its high-speed Internet services, Covad Communications reported a third-quarter loss of $190 million, or $1.22 a share, more than three times its loss in the period a year earlier. The company attributed the results to late payments from nine large clients. Several brokerage firms downgraded their recommendations on Covad stock to hold from buy, and the shares dropped 59 percent, to $3.56. Covad's difficulties underscore how numerous providers of broadband services are coming under financial strain even as they aggressively expand their customer bases and increase their revenue. Simon Romero

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Colleges Rushing to Compile Crime Statistics for the Web
description: Under pressure from Congress to disclose campus crimes more fully, American colleges are rushing to release new crime statistics by a federal deadline of Tuesday.

title: Cheating Shoppers
description: To the Editor:

title: If Unmatched Spoons Won't Do
description: Tom Penn has made Kuroshiwo sterling-silver flatware for babies, above, and for adults, left. Because the tail of the flatware reminds him of the crest of a wave, he named the pattern after a current that runs along the Japanese coast. Among the children's pieces are two Victorian items, a food pusher (left, $205) and a closed spoon (third from left, $225); also available are teaspoons ($165 each) and a cup ($245). For the family that likes to dine with matching flatware, a full-size five-piece place setting is $1,550. Information: Old Newbury Crafters, (800) 343-1388. Incidentally, although his father is Irving Penn, the younger Mr. Penn decided not to become a photographer. ''I'd be doomed,'' he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLPORT, ALEXANDER W.
description: ALLPORT-Alexander W. Thanks, Sandy, for nearly 50 years of fun and friendship. Sleep well. Jim Prideaux

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: The Debates Are Over. Now It's the Voters' Turn.
description: To the Editor:

title: Less Popular Creatures
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Study Finds For-Profit Schools No Better
description: A teachers union analysis of standardized test scores at schools managed by Edison Schools, the country's largest for-profit manager of public schools, finds that Edison students perform no better than students in comparable, traditional public schools.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: A Vine of Plenty

title: Sprint PCS Customers Get Instant Messages
description: Sprint PCS users will find today that the phone fairies have been hard at work overnight, installing three new messaging services on all of their Web-enabled phones.

title: Piazza Ready To Move Past Head Games
description: It is the unavoidable subtext of the World Series, a memory bubbling just under the surface. The Hall of Fame-bound pitcher fires a fastball. The Hall of Fame-bound catcher, struck on the emblem of his helmet, crumbles to the ground. The Yankees' Roger Clemens will face the Mets' Mike Piazza again very soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MECHANIC, CAROLYN
description: MECHANIC-Carolyn. October 18, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Sonny. Sister of Audrey. Dearest aunt and friend of Dena, Peter, Susie, Viggo, Charles and Pat. Great aunt of Peter, Rita and James. Services Sunday 1 PM at Hirsch & Sons, Bronx, New York.

title: Lieberman Cites Religion as Foundation of Environmentalism
description: Once again citing religion as a foundation for policy, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman said today that he and Vice President Al Gore would be good stewards of nature, while Gov. George W. Bush would spoil it.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about chronic dieters misspelled the surname of the director of the weight management and nutrition center at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in New York, who urged patients to have realistic goals. She is Cathy Nonas, not Monas.

title: Economic Scene: Tax Cuts May Be Fashionable, but Nows a Good Time to Raise Gas Taxes
description: WITH all the talk of tax cuts, this may be an inopportune time to propose a tax increase. But it is easier to put tax reforms in place when times are good than when they are bad, and United States policy on gasoline taxation could be much improved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, CAROLYN SEIDEN
description: MILLER-Carolyn Seiden. On October 18, 2000. An independent women of courage and great strength. Her life was her family; to her grandchildren-Stephen, Jenny, Katie and Jonathan-she promised the stars, and they gave her the universe. She leaves behind her loving daughters Barbara Behar and Jane Bursky, devoted sons-in-law Joel Behar and Andrew Bursky, and the Hirsch Family, brother-in-law Barry, newphews, Terry and Neil and niece Nancy. She will always be remembered by family and dear friends for her fight and spirit, her courage and grace. We will always cherish her memory. Services Friday, October 20. 10:00 AM, Temple Emanuel, Great Neck, New York.

title: Medicare Premiums and Social Security Will Rise
description: Medicare premiums will rise nearly 10 percent next year, to $50 a month, and Social Security checks will grow by 3.5 percent, to cover increases in the cost of living, the government said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNT, WILLIAM E.
description: HUNT-William E., 77. October 14, 2000. Producer and Director. Bill founded the Red Barn & Tinker's Pond theaters on Long Island and co-designed Theater East in Manhattan. He directed well over 100 plays and reviews, many of which he adapted, off Broadway and in Stock from 1953-1999 including ''Green Julia'' with James Woods and ''Get Happy'', The Music of Harold Arlen. Bill was also a tireless volunteer especially in the battle against AIDS. He brought his own particular brand of comfort to clients of God's Love We Deliver, Goldwater Memorial Hospital, St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital Center, and to many others. He was a hero of the epidemic. Humanitarian and man of the theater, he will be missed. Kathleen Chalfant Beverly Chase

title: Mayor Seeks Stiffer Rules Against Asset Seizures
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would seek changes in state and federal medical assistance programs to offer city residents more protection against having their assets seized when the government is paying for a spouse's nursing home care.

title: Public Theater's Uptown 'Party' Leaves a Hangover
description: On Jan. 26, just three weeks into rehearsals for the Broadway musical ''The Wild Party,'' the Hollywood producer Scott Rudin wrote a letter to George C. Wolfe, the producer of the Joseph Papp Public Theater, to tell him that he was pulling his money out of the show.

title: World's Dying Languages, Alive on the Web
description: ACHUMAWI: there are 10 elderly speakers of this language left in northern California. Kiowa Apache: 18 speakers in western Oklahoma. Comanche: 854 speakers, most of them middle-age or older in western Oklahoma. Alawa: 17 to 20 fluent speakers in northern Australia. Manx: became extinct during the 1900's as a native language on the Isle of Man.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: EASTMAN KODAK CO., Rochester, named Ted Lewis senior vice president for digital business development. He had been president at DaimlerChrysler Research and Technology, a unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G.

title: Living Under Siege in Israeli Bunker
description: The Israeli soldiers bottled up at this outpost in flak jackets and helmets spend most of their days listening. They listen to the periodic shots that ring out with disconcerting thuds as they slam into the three-foot-thick cement walls around the compound. They listen to the crash of gasoline bombs that send jets of flame skyward. And they listen to their tormentors, who crawl to within a few feet of them, yell ''Death to the Jews!'' in Hebrew, and open fire.

title: Trial to Start For Continental And Northwest
description: Do partners need to get along for a business relationship to succeed? Shareholders and customers of both Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines may want to consider the question as the two head to court next week in the government's first attempt to stop an airline merger since the industry was deregulated in 1978.

title: Dow Comes Back From Plunge but Ends Below 10,000
description: Stock prices fell further yesterday as a recovery from a steep early plunge was not enough to keep the Dow Jones industrial average, weighed down by I.B.M., from finishing below the 10,000 mark for the first time since March.

title: Ancient Bacterium Is Reported Found
description: A bacterium that last flourished before dinosaurs tore flesh or the Appalachian Mountains emerged has been revived from a drop of fluid trapped in a crystal of rock salt for 250 million years, say biologists at West Chester University in Pennsylvania. But their result was immediately challenged by another biologist.

title: Yankees Hoping Swoon Is Just a Memory
description: The Yankees are champions of the American League three weeks after they couldn't beat Tampa Bay and Baltimore, much less come within 10 runs of the Devil Rays and the Orioles, two of baseball's worst teams this year.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: News Analysis -- THE CONTEXT; Debates Put in Focus Images and Reality
description: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush entered the three presidential debates with strikingly different objectives. For Mr. Bush, it was to persuade Americans that he was no slacker but a leader of presidential stature, a Washington outsider and a fresh alternative to the Democrats' tax-and-spend tradition.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: LUXURY BUILDING

title: Geeks, Proud of the Name, Start a Volunteer Corps
description: SARAH WUSTNER, a Seattle software engineer, thought about joining the Peace Corps when she graduated from the University of California at San Diego in 1998. But, she said, ''they didn't have anything that really fit my skills.''

title: KODAK ISSUES WARNING ON 4TH-QUARTER PROFITS
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit would fall below analysts' forecasts because sales were slowing. The company also said third-quarter profit from operations fell 7.7 percent, to $430 million, or $1.40 a share, compared with $466 million, or $1.45 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts, who had cut their forecasts because of a warning in late September, had expected $1.37 a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. Kodak said it took a charge of $12 million in the third quarter for the closing of factories, making net income $418 million, or $1.36 a share. In the period a year earlier, the company took a charge of $231 million, or 72 cents a share, to cover job cuts and to shut a plant, making net income $235 million, or 73 cents a share. For the fourth quarter, the company expects to earn $1 to $1.15 a share, below the $1.14 to $1.32 estimated by First Call. Shares of Kodak rose $1.81 yesterday, to $38.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, ANNE
description: KAYE-Anne. On Oct. 12, 2000, of congestive heart failure. She was President of Kay Preparations, a cosmetics firm, & a formulator of products. Survived by her cousins and friends. Memorial Service, Lincoln Guild House, 303 West 66 Street, Sunday, Oct. 22 at 11 AM.

title: Ship Bomb Inquiry Focuses on Safe Houses and Deserted Car
description: Yemeni and American teams investigating the bombing of the destroyer Cole centered their inquiry today on two safe houses and a car found abandoned across the harbor from where the ship was attacked last Thursday, killing 17 sailors.

title: Naked Came the Really Strange Interiors
description: JUSTIN JORGENSEN was visiting the office of a friend who works in the online pornography business last year, and he was appalled by what he saw. Mr. Jorgensen, 25, is not easily shocked, but there was something profoundly unsettling in the amateur photographs.

title: MP3 IN PACT WITH PUBLISHERS
description: The National Music Publishers Association has reached a licensing agreement with the embattled digital music site MP3.com. If it is approved by the association's 25,000 members, the three-year agreement will permit distribution of more than a million digital music files on MP3.com's download service, which stores music files that subscribers have already paid for. ''This will enable the public to reach out and get their music, and the publishers to get their payment,'' said Ed Murphy, chief executive of the association. MP3.com has settled copyright violation cases with four major record labels. It is facing $100 million in damage payments after being found liable for infringing copyright owned by Seagram's Universal Music Group. Catherine Greenman

title: Mets vs. Yankees: Then and Now
description: If the Mets, who will play the Yankees in the World Series beginning Saturday night, were placed against the Mets, who played the Yankees in their first interleague series in 1997, the image would be startling.

title: Gwen Verdon, Redhead Who High-Kicked Her Way to Stardom, Dies at 75
description: Gwen Verdon, whose high-kicking artistry, flaming red hair and head-turning figure made her an unforgettable presence in musicals like ''Can-Can,'' ''Damn Yankees'' and ''Chicago,'' died yesterday in Woodstock, Vt. She was 75 and had homes in Bronxville, N.Y., and Quogue, N.Y.

title: Both Clinton And Lazio Seek Support Among Jews
description: Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton campaigned for support among Jewish voters yesterday, with Mr. Lazio meeting rabbis and Orthodox Jewish leaders in Flatbush and Borough Park, and Mrs. Clinton visiting a synagogue damaged in a suspicious fire in Syracuse.

title: Math by E-Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Euro Falls to Another Low; Intervention Seen as Unlikely
description: The euro sank to a new low against the dollar today, two days after the president of the European Central Bank provoked a furor by publicly suggesting that central banks would not intervene soon to strengthen the struggling currency.

title: Essay; King Pyrrhus's Victory
description: If the town hall meeting between Bush and Gore were a prizefight being scored on points, the judges would declare Al Gore the winner. He earned more debating points and gets credit for aggressiveness in carrying the fight to his opponent.

title: Both Sides Take Steps to Achieve Calm in Mideast
description: A day after meeting in Egypt, Israeli and Palestinian leaders took their first promised steps to avert further violence, with Israel pulling back some troops and reopening border posts and the Palestinian Authority pledging to ''work on calming the situation.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENBAUM, FRED S.
description: SCHOENBAUM-Fred S. Of White Plains, NY, on October 17, 2000. Fred was predeceased by his wife, Vera. Dear father of Lucy Schmolka and Marjorie Trachtenberg; father-in-law of Lenny Schmolka; grandfather of Andrew and Gregory Schmolka and Beth Trachtenberg; great-grandfather of Jordan and Corinne. Funeral services are private.

title: Salvadoran Admits Abuses In Trial Tied to Nuns' Deaths
description: Almost 20 years after Salvadoran soldiers beat, raped and shot four American churchwomen to death, the country's former defense minister testified in court for the first time today, saying that while men in his forces ''could have'' committed abuses, such crimes were in no way emblematic of the military as a whole.

title: Slump Vexes Creators of 'Almost Famous'
description: ''Almost Famous,'' a critically praised film that was widely expected to match the box office success of previous hits from the writer and director Cameron Crowe, goes into its sixth weekend with a cumulative box office of just $27 million, less than half of the film's $60 million budget, and with bleak prospects of reaching even $40 million in United States ticket sales.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY COMPANY HURT
description: Shares in the British biotechnology company Cantab Pharmaceuticals plummeted 67 percent, to 76.5 pence ($1.11), after it said a genital-wart vaccine called TH-GW had failed in tests. The company said the pharmaceuticals giant SmithKline Beecham had stopped work on the drug after tests showed no improvement over standard therapies. Alan Cowell

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE SENATE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, JOSEPH
description: MARKS-Joseph. Beloved husband of Lillian Shapiro. Devoted father of Daniel, Sheila Blake, Jonathan. Adored grandfather of Hill, Jane, Benjamin, Amy, Gabrielle and Thomas, and adored great-grandfather. Services Thursday 1PM at Schwartz Jeffer Funeral Home, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: The Debates Are Over. Now It's the Voters' Turn.
description: To the Editor:

title: In Modern E-Mail Romances 'Trash' Is Just a Click Away
description: ONE night this summer, Jason Kellogg, a 24-year-old publishing assistant, left a bar in Brooklyn after spending a good deal of time talking with a woman he had met that evening. When he left the bar, his friends demanded the requisite information: How old is she? Is she from the area? Does she have any good-looking friends? And most important, did you get a phone number?

title: Cut, Paste and Clarify
description: To the Editor:

title: SONY IN DEAL WITH SOLECTRON
description: The world's top maker of consumer electronics, Sony, has agreed to sell manufacturing operations in northern Japan and Taiwan to Solectron of Milpitas, Calif., a leading maker of electronics for other companies. Terms were not disclosed. Sony will outsource manufacturing of consumer products like auto satellite navigation systems, car audio equipment and lithium-ion batteries to Solectron. Sony's president, Kunitake Ando, told a news conference that the deal represented the beginning of a new relationship between the companies, suggesting that further sales of some Sony operations to Solectron were possible. Miki Tanikawa

title: First Daughter Proving to Be Quiet Political Force
description: She rarely says a word, at least not near a microphone. She stands behind her mother, careful not to upstage her. She is kept far away from reporters, just as she has been throughout the past eight years.

title: Access Ordered In Auction Case
description: A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's and a target of the government's investigation into auction-house collusion, won a judge's approval yesterday for access to information described as crucial to his case.

title: WorldCom Might Issue New Stock
description: Frustrated by the price wars and slow growth that have come to characterize much of the long-distance telephone business, WorldCom Inc. intends to issue a new stock to track its consumer and wholesale long-distance units, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: Benched Against Dallas, Giants' Toomer Is Puzzled
description: When things were going badly for the Giants at the end of last season, Amani Toomer was doing well. And now, strangely enough during a 5-2 season, Toomer wonders why the good times stopped for him -- the Giants' No. 1 receiver.

title: Van Horn Expects To Return In a Month
description: Keith Van Horn heard the sickening, telltale pop. As he lay on the court and pain coursed through his lower left leg, he was sure.

title: A Dialogue From Auschwitz
description: Books are still man's greatest invention, despite the nonsense so often published between their covers. But their singular marvelousness, I guess, is that there will never be a Harry Potter movie that can reveal the wonder of the story the way the books do. Nor will there ever be a movie, no matter how skillful, that can capture the horror of the concentration camp the way a book can.

title: Discovery Astronauts Complete Work on Space Station
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- Two spacewalking astronauts wrapped up construction work outside the international space station on Wednesday, then fired up their jetpacks and cruised around.

title: Rethinking Transportation Modes
description: The Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum has long offered Design Directions, free workshops for New York City public high school students. In the most recent session, which started last week, students are rethinking ''people movers,'' what most of us would call scooters and cars. Gary Natsume, a senior designer at Frogdesign, an industrial design company in SoHo, is teaching the course, which is called ''Make Stuff, Break Rules, Change the World.'' One student has already sketched a scooter like the one above, but with wheels all along it, like in-line skates. This session, which continues tonight and next Thursday, 3 to 6 p.m. at Frogdesign, 96 Spring Street, has four openings. The next workshop, ''Tag Your Threads,'' starts Nov. 14 and has 10 openings. Carlos Uribe, an artist, will teach students to design and print graphic images on T-shirts at the Harlem Textile Works. Information: (212) 849-8381.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASEY, ELIZABETH F.
description: CASEY-Elizabeth F. October 19, 1960 to January 30, 1998. Our Lizzie, treasured by your family and missed each day, we are thankful for your strong and beautiful life. We'll love you always. The Casey Family

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DIAL CORP., Scottsdale, Ariz., said it cut its quarterly dividend 50 percent as part of its strategy to repay debt associated with acquisitions.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: TODAY'S SCHEDULES

title: Lopsided Budgets and Polls in Health Care Fight
description: About 40 doctors and nurses picketed outside the downtown offices of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Massachusetts today in favor of a ballot initiative that would guarantee health care coverage to everyone in the state.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROCHLIN, PAUL
description: ROCHLIN-Paul. You live forever in my dreams-bathed by the lambent Bermuda Sea, warmed by her golden sands. Marjorie.

title: Wilson Understands What Players Are Feeling
description: Amid the craziness of clinching a pennant, Mookie Wilson seemed an oasis of calm. While many of the Mets have waited years for a shot at the World Series, and New York has waited 44 years for a Subway Series, Wilson has seen the postseason at its most bizarre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEYSHON, MARION
description: LEYSHON-Marion. On October 14, 2000, beloved wife of the late Hal I. Leyshon, and devoted mother of Hal R. Leyshon. Private service to be announced. (802223-4172). In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Grace Church School Scholarship Fund, 86 4th Avenue, New York City, New York 10003.

title: State to Adopt Privacy Rules On Information From Insurers
description: New York State plans to adopt, within a month, new insurance regulations that will restrict the health and financial information that insurers may share with banks and securities houses about their customers.

title: U.S. Intends to Focus And Play as a Team
description: Players who have competed in both the Presidents Cup and the Ryder Cup have noticed at least one similarity. Winning makes the experience more enjoyable.

title: Freud at the Ballpark
description: A highly inconvenient law of physics states that two objects cannot occupy the same space at the same time. Consequently, as New York rejoices in the first Subway Series since my high school days of 1956, we also lament that two of the three sacred places of past contests -- Brooklyn's Ebbets Field and the Giants' Polo Grounds in upper Manhattan -- now exist only as memories beneath housing projects, and not as material realities.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the former film and theater critic Vincent Canby on Monday misstated the location of the Christchurch School, where he attended high school. It is in Christchurch, Va., about 55 miles east of Richmond, not in Alexandria.

title: INSIDE
description: Inflation Pace Picks Up

title: AOL and Time Warner Slightly Beat Profit Estimates
description: With just a month or two before their proposed merger is expected to be consummated, America Online and Time Warner each posted quarterly earnings yesterday that were largely as expected. But the top management of both companies spent much of the day trying to counter the pessimism on Wall Street.

title: If Yankees And Mets Are Up, Dow Isn't
description: Investors, watch out. There's a Subway Series coming. And that has meant, in the past anyway, that the stock market will most likely have a subpar year. Even worse, the Mets are going to be in it. When the Mets make it to the World Series, it is usually a good time to get out of the stock market.

title: Investigators Rule Out Arson As Cause of Fire in Edgewater
description: A team investigating the cause of a fierce fire that destroyed an unfinished apartment complex, nine houses and 12 cars in Edgewater, N.J., in August found that there was no evidence of arson, the Bergen County Prosecutor's Office announced yesterday.

title: Liberties; The Popular Pariah
description: Al Gore has said he would consider putting a 24-hour-a-day Webcam, or Alcam, in the Oval Office.

title: Microsoft Handily Beats Estimates, Aided by Windows
description: Pointing to the strongest quarter ever for its Windows operating system, Microsoft yesterday surpassed analysts' earnings estimates for the latest quarter.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Discovering Lyricism In Noisy Bestiality
description: In a red apron and dripping sweat, David Thomas looked like a post-punk Sweeney Todd at Pere Ubu's 25th-anniversary show Saturday at the Knitting Factory. Instead of barbering and butchering human customers, though, he led that storied Cleveland punk band in making a fine meat pie of rock as a way of taking the knife to his own big heart.

title: Utopia, and the Rest of All Possible Worlds
description: Why do we keep dreaming about utopia?

title: Op-art; Sub-liminal
Giants Retire Gifford's No. 16
description: Frank Gifford, who still holds Giants records for career touchdowns, rushing average and receiving yards -- as well as remaining a symbol of great Giants years -- finally saw his number retired.

title: BRAZIL BANK RESULTS MASK STRENGTH
description: Brazil's biggest bank, Banco do Brasil, reported a 49 percent decline in third-quarter earnings, to 373 million reais ($200 million), but the results reflected an extraordinary gain the year earlier, when loss provisions from foreign investments worth $270 million were reported. Without the extraordinary effect, third-quarter profit would be 64 percent higher than the year before. Jennifer L. Rich

title: It's Root, Root, Root, But for Which Team?
description: Giving it just a moment's thought, Allen Sherman minced no words yesterday in relating what to him was irrefutable common knowledge.

title: Sweethearts for Some Lucky Table
description: THE materials are the message here: leather, rich woods, rattan and wicker make these sleek dining chairs too appealing to hide under the table. Many are comfortable enough for reading or lounging between meals. And none of the basketwork chairs felt prickly, so hold the cushions.

title: What Does a Start-Up Need? Poetry
description: FOUR years ago, buried in the conference notes for a gathering of engineers, was an unlikely description of one of the participants, a software designer named Moses Ma:

title: Two if by Air, 12 if by Sea
description: ORDERING furnishings from London, or anywhere in Europe, takes work, time, and, of course, money. Companies that make furniture to order like Twentytwentyone may require a 50 percent deposit, a final payment before shipping, and may not allow returns. Make sure that the final price includes shipping (from two weeks by air to 12 weeks by sea). For example, Inflate's Snoozy bed sells for $850, plus a $73 air freight charge; the Robin Day Avian armchair from Twentytwentyone will cost $1,703 plus $412 for air freight and Manhattan delivery, or $225 sea freight and Manhattan delivery. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNITOW, VIRGINIA
description: SNITOW-Virginia. The Trustees of the Hunter College Foundation and the entire college community mourn the loss of Virginia Snitow (nee Levitt), who was a tireless supporter of the college and its mission of research, education and service. An alumna and founding member of the Hunter College Foundation, Mrs. Snitow was also an active member of the Scholarship and Welfare Fund. In addition, she served on the Committee for the Restoration of Roosevelt House, was a member of the Hunter College Hall of Fame and was a loyal supporter of the Hunter College Women's Studies Program. We will miss her commitment and dedication to the college, and we extend our condolences to her daughter, Ann, and her son, Alan. Evangelos J. Gizis, Interim President Hunter College Allan H. Kurtzman, Chair Hunter College Foundation

title: Anything for a Laugh At a Carnival of Oranges
description: ''The Love for Three Oranges'' is a period piece within a period piece that relies on our enduring sense of the ridiculous for its survival. Prokofiev's 80-year-old opera, revived on Tuesday night at the New York City Opera, rehabilitates Carlo Gozzi's mid-18th-century stage work for use against a new set of enemies.

title: D.S.P. Is the Leaner, Nimbler Chip
description: ALTHOUGH Digital Signal Processor chips may not be as sexy as their more muscular cousins that drive personal computers, they are more common and likely to inhabit devices people regularly use, and use a lot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOWITZ, SAMUEL W.
description: LEIBOWITZ-Samuel W. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Samuel Leibowitz, a friend and supporter of this organization, whose life and good deeds are continued by his sons and family. To his sons, Reuben, Harold, and Elihu, and to the entire family we extend our sincere condolences. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: The Quackatorium and Other Web Troves
description: Whether your tastes run to medieval illuminated manuscripts or to wax figures of George Burns, Museumspot.com can help you track down museums full of treasures (www.museum

title: STMICROELECTRONICS PROFITS
description: The big Dutch chip maker STMicroelectronics said third-quarter profit tripled as sales surged. Net income rose to $415 million, or 45 cents a share, from $135 million, or 15 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 60 percent, to $2.04 billion.

title: A Mideast Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about William M. Farrell, a former reporter for The New York Times, misstated the year of his marriage to Anne Byrne. It was 1939, not 1969.

title: Death Inquiry Resumes After New Accusations in Auto Lawsuit
description: Prosecutors have reopened the case of a New Jersey woman whose 1997 death behind the wheel of a Ford Explorer was ruled accidental. The decision to reopen the case came after lawyers for the Ford Motor Company argued in a civil suit that she was strangled and that her husband was having an affair at the time.

title: Yankee TV, Court TV
description: The battle over Yankee television rights is back in court.

title: Baking Them Proud
description: Ryder Ripps, 14, may have a propensity for design. His mother, Helene Verin, designs interiors, furniture and shoes. His father, Rodney Ripps, is an artist. So, it wasn't a huge leap for Ryder, left, to feel inspired to transform Silpat baking sheets, a Martha Stewart favorite made of pliable heat-resistant plastic, into lampshades.

title: Confused Account Is Meant To Aid Doctor in Murder Case
description: The sole defense witness in the trial of a doctor charged with killing his wife struggled yesterday to recall the size and shape of the woman he had gazed at in a Manhattan bagel store 15 years ago, on the day the wife disappeared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABRECQUE, THOMAS
description: LABRECQUE-Thomas. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York regret the passing of Thomas Labrecque, former chairman and chief executive of Chase Manhattan Corporation. We join the leadership in our Banking & Finance Division in extending sincerest condolences to Mr. Labrecque's friends and colleagues at Chase, a corporation that has expressed concern for Jewish and humanitarian causes through its exceptional generosity. Our heartfelt sympathies go to Mr. Labrecque's beloved wife, Sheila; his 4 children, Thomas Jr., Douglas, Karen Shea, and Barbara Corbin; his 5 grandchildren; and the entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Hate-Crime Law Cited in Synagogue Attack
description: Two young men accused of vandalizing a synagogue in the Bronx were indicted yesterday for hate crimes and will be the first suspects prosecuted under the state's new hate-crime law, the authorities said.

title: Pace of Inflation Picks Up Even as Economy Seems to Slow
description: Inflation is now on pace for its largest annual jump in a decade, the government reported yesterday, although the price increases remain largely confined to energy costs.

title: Last-Minute Congressional Mischief
description: It is now nearly three weeks into the new fiscal year, and Congress still has not finished work on several key appropriation bills, including measures to finance foreign operations and the departments of Commerce, Justice, State, Labor, Health and Human Services and Education. At this point it seems likely that most of these measures will be rolled into a giant omnibus bill loaded with riders and other surprises that neither the public nor even most members of Congress will have understood or digested before they become law. End-of-session chaos has become the norm in recent years, and the picture this year seems no better.

title: A Day After Sharm el Sheik Accord, Palestinians Mount U.N. Offensive
description: Disregarding a plea by the United Nations secretary general, the Palestinians carried their bitter confrontation with Israel into a special session of the General Assembly today. They accused the Israelis of unleashing ''savagery and brutality'' in the last few weeks in a ''deadly campaign of repression'' against the Palestinians.

title: Cane Chairs for Small Sitters
description: At spring break, some college students go to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., drink beer and call it fun. Not the product design students at Parsons School of Design in Manhattan. Last spring, Tony Whitfield, the chairman of the school's product design department, took 15 students to Guyana, where they collaborated with Liana Cane Lab, a local furniture company, to transform designs into reality. The students spent three days in the rain forest, where they saw how cane, a renewable aerial root, grows.

title: Emmerling Post Changes Its Name
description: Emmerling Post Advertising in New York is changing its name to Post & Partners to reflect that Peter Post has bought John Emmerling's stake in the company. Mr. Post, 53, president at Emmerling Post, was named to the new post of chief executive at Post & Partners. Mr. Emmerling, 62, chief creative officer at Emmerling Post, relinquishes his creative duties to Steve Crane, 43, acting creative director at Emmerling Post, who was named creative director at Post & Partners. Mr. Emmerling continues with the agency as chairman until year's end, and will consult for two years.

title: Russia Nears A Decision On Keeping Mir in Orbit
description: Russia's aging Mir space station, unoccupied and starved for the money necessary to operate it, may be near the end of its 15-year life, experts said today.

title: Columbia Debates a Professor's 'Gesture'
description: When Edward W. Said, a celebrated literary scholar, Columbia University professor and outspoken Palestinian advocate, hurled a rock toward an Israeli guardhouse from the Lebanese border in July, a photographer caught the action. The photo, which captured Mr. Said with his arm reached far behind him, ready to throw, appeared in newspapers and magazines in the Middle East and the United States.

title: In Streets and Parliament, Calls for Philippine President's Ouster
description: Cries for the ouster of President Joseph Estrada resounded in the halls of power and on the streets here today as opposition legislators filed a resolution to impeach him on charges of taking bribes from gambling rackets.

Norden, loving mother of Peter & Ruth, cherished grandmother of Linda and Will and the late Debbie, great-grandmother of Luke and Alec. Services Friday, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to Congregation Habonim, 44 West 66th Street, New York City 10023.

title: So, How's the Coffee?
description: CONSIDERING that cafes in Italian train stations routinely achieve espresso perfection hundreds of times a day, producing a satisfying cup in the United States seems far more difficult than it ought to be. Fine restaurants routinely botch the operation, while efforts at home, particularly with those inexpensive stove-top pots, range from murky water to mud.

description: Honeywell has its own take on the wireless Web, which, if not as big as all outdoors, is at least as big as your backyard.

description: Q. Is there another way I can move a large number of WordPerfect files from my old PC laptop to my new iMac (which does not have a floppy-disk drive) besides sending them via e-mail one at a time?

description: A traffic officer who also serves as the treasurer of a public employees union was charged in court yesterday with cheating two recent immigrants of more than $1,600 while running a tax and immigration aid business.

title: Europeans Buy 2 U.S. Money Managers
description: The European appetite for American money management firms continued apace yesterday as two European financial firms struck deals to buy two domestic asset management firms. The deals are part of a trend that has Europeans shopping for American investment firms to help them capitalize on a shifting pension landscape at home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, DOROTHY
description: CANTOR-Dorothy. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member, Dorothy Cantor. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest condolences to her family. Bernard Steinweg, President David Hershberg, Secretary

title: While Children Grow Fatter, Experts Search for Solutions
description: Maria Sanchez's own children told her they needed help with their weight. But until the family began attending an experimental weight-loss program for Mexican-American families, run by a Stanford University pediatrician, they had no idea where or how to cut back.

title: Ratings on NBC and Fox Are in Free Fall
description: Baseball's postseason ratings slide continued Tuesday when Game 6 of the American League Championship Series on NBC generated an 8.8 Nielsen rating.

title: 4 Companies Emerge in Bid To Privatize Worst Schools
description: Board of Education staff members have narrowed the list of candidates to privately manage some of New York City's worst-performing schools to four companies, education officials said yesterday.

title: New Media Meets An Old Medium In the Phone Book
description: ''WHAT'S your e-mail address?'' may soon have a new answer: ''It's in the book.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Pace of Inflation Picks Up As Economy Seems to Slow

title: Mexico Revisits the Past
description: When Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary Party ceases to be the world's longest-ruling political party on Dec. 1, it will not only surrender control over the presidency. It will also surrender its control over the past. The PRI for decades has zealously kept government archives from public view and pushed its self-serving version of history. So it is appropriate for President-elect Vicente Fox to promise Mexicans a new look at their own past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASRI, ALBERT
description: BASRI-Albert. Died October 18, 2000. Loving husband, father and grandfather. He leaves his wife, Annette Iny Basri, of Lakewood, NJ; children, Dr. Raymond Basri of Middletown, NY, Dr. William Basri of Marlboro, NJ, and Carole Basri of NYC and Deal, NJ. A physician for over 35 years at Paul Kimball Hospital, Lakewood, NJ, he was born on January 18, 1919 in Baghdad, Iraq and studied medicine in Baghdad and at the Royal College of Surgeons in London, England. Service Friday at Belkoff Funeral Home Lakewood, N.J.

title: AMR Posts 51% Profit Rise; US Airways Reports a Loss
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, said today that its third-quarter profit rose as it benefited from higher fares and problems at the rival United Airlines. But rising fuel costs played a role as the US Airways Group posted a loss.

title: Testimony About Travel-Office Dismissals
description: In declaring in a report today that Hillary Rodham Clinton gave ''factually false'' sworn testimony minimizing her role in the firing of employees of the White House travel office, the independent counsel, Robert W. Ray, released segments of grand jury testimony and other sworn statements by Mrs. Clinton and others.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEEL, COURTNEY
description: STEEL-Courtney. The soul takes flight to the world that is invisible but there arriving she is sure of bliss and forever dwells in paradise.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Oct. 10 about a campaign stop in Florida by Vice President Al Gore, before he shopped on a break from debate practice, misidentified the location of the appearance. It was in Lido Key, not Longboat Key.

title: Julie London, 74, Sultry Singer and Actress of 50's
description: Julie London, whose understated voice and striking honey-blond appearance made her one of the top female vocalists of the 1950's and 60's, died yesterday at a hospital in Los Angeles. She was 74.

title: The Debates Are Over. Now It's the Voters' Turn.
description: To the Editor:

title: Controlled Chaos Theory, Via Superheroes
description: Stephen Petronio has long been one of the brainiest and hippest of New York's modern-dance choreographers. The combination can be fatal, and Mr. Petronio has sometimes succumbed to mere cheekiness over the 15 years he has worked with his own company. But his new ''Strange Attractors,'' performed on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, glows with maturity and a surprising grandeur.

title: SENATE APPROVES EASING SANCTIONS ON FOOD TO CUBA
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a bill easing nearly four decades of sanctions on the sale of food to Cuba, all but assuring the measure will become law.

title: Whitman Hobbs, 81, Ad Executive and Columnist
description: Whitman Hobbs, an advertising agency executive and columnist whose voice was heard interviewing advertisers in television and radio commercials that he created for The New Yorker in the 1970's, died on Oct. 8 in Bradenton, Fla. He was 81.

title: DNA Tests Link Sexual Attacks On Girls in Queens to One Man
description: Using DNA evidence, the police have linked six sexual assaults against women and girls as young as 9 in Queens and the Bronx to one man, officials said yesterday.

title: Joy in Gotham: New York Takes Series!; The Glory of Today
description: To the Editor:

title: HYUNDAI RAISING CASH
description: Hyundai Engineering and Construction said it would raise 20 percent more than it first planned by selling parts of its businesses, hoping to win more time to meet its 5.1 trillion won ($4.5 billion) of debt in return for a bigger repayment. Hyundai Engineering said it would raise 1.8 trillion won ($1.58 billion) by selling more property near Seoul and possibly about half its 19.86 percent stake in Asan, which oversees tourism resorts, industrial parks and other investments.

title: Lapses Cited In Disciplining Of the Police
description: Federal prosecutors investigating how the Police Department handles brutality cases have briefed police union officials on findings that they contend show how serious lapses in department procedures allowed brutal officers to go unpunished, according to several union officials.

title: BRITISH UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS
description: For the 19th consecutive month, British unemployment fell, reaching a 25-year low of 3.6 percent, in another reflection of the strength in the economy. But there have been recent signs that growth could ease. The Bank of England said its monetary policy committee voted unanimously this month to hold the benchmark interest rate at 6 percent because reduced growth in the United States and the Continent's euro zone and falling stock prices and rising oil costs raised risks of a slowdown. Alan Cowell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, HERBIE EDWARD
description: KLEINMAN-Herbie Edward. Untimely passing October 17, 2000, just shy of his 30th birthday on November 1. Wonderful light of all our lives. Adored son of Nedra and Louis; best friend of brother Eric; beloved friend to so many people from childhood through his adult years. Everyone who met you, loved you Herbie. You enjoyed sports, rock music, and life itself. All of us enjoyed every minute of the time you spent with us. Your laughter and your love has always been our most joyful and treasured inspiration. Your leaving is unbearable for us but your life and love will stay within us in memory and with enduring love. Memorial service to be held at 12:45 PM on Friday, October 20 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street (at Amsterdam Avenue) in New York City.

title: Homey, to a Panda
description: Can giant pandas, who dislike hot and humid weather, find happiness in a muggy Washington summer? What if designers could find a way to air-condition their outdoor pens? Those questions may be answered next year, if negotiations succeed in bringing two giant pandas, Mei Xiang, a 2-year-old female, and Tian Tian, a 3-year-old male, from China to the Panda House at the National Zoo. The house was once home to Hsing-Hsing and Ling-Ling, above, until their deaths, Ling-Ling's in 1992 and Hsing-Hsing's last year. To lure the new pandas outdoors on even the hottest days, the zoo hired Chatelain Architects of Washington and Nelson-Byrd Landscape Architects of Charlottesville, Va., to renovate their home and create outdoor microclimates. Imagine the wilds of China in a 17,500-square-foot outdoor exhibition area divided into two grassy yards. Although both yards are planted with Chinese firs, hemlocks and red cedars, each has a different microclimate. ''One side has a grove of trees with a mister in it,'' said Robert Hoage, a zoo spokesman. ''The other has the same grove of trees, but with a fogger in it, where smaller drops of water roll out like fog.'' In one den, the air is cooled by traveling over cold-water pipes; the other (above) has an ordinary air-conditioner. Scientists want to see which environment makes a panda happy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, JOAN EDWARDS
description: FISHER-Joan Edwards. October 16, 2000. Aunt of Julia Fisher White. She is also survived by her cousins, Edward C. Johnson III, Elsie P. Mitchell and Peter Johnson. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Ford Says 3rd-Quarter Results Fell Because of Tire Troubles
description: This autumn's recall of Firestone light truck tires led to the Ford Motor Company's first quarterly drop in operating income in four years and has prompted Bridgestone/Firestone to undertake a broad reorganization, with Japanese executives taking control of key operations, the companies announced today.

title: Tonight's N.F.L. Matchup
description: Detroit (4-2) at Tampa Bay (3-3)8:30 p.m. Eastern TV: ESPN

title: Jacoby & Springer In Expanded Role
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G., has again expanded its relationship with Jacoby & Springer in Hamburg, Germany, by naming the agency to handle creative duties for two Mercedes-Benz car models, the C-Class Sportcoupe and the C-Class T-Model, which are to be introduced next year in several crucial markets worldwide. Billings were estimated at more than $30 million.

title: Buoyant Gore Camp Wants to Rerun Debate on Cable
description: Sensing that Vice President Al Gore's debate performance on Tuesday night has revived his candidacy, Mr. Gore's advisers said today that they wanted to buy 90 minutes of time on cable television channels in various swing states to rebroadcast the entire debate.

title: Fighting in Colombia Stops Commerce and Creates Refugees
description: Fierce fighting in southern Colombia has halted commerce and made hundreds of people seek refuge in Ecuador and elsewhere in Colombia, officials said today.

title: Pilot Sought Better Weather Before Crash
description: Federal officials said today that Roger Carnahan, who was flying the plane in which he died along with his father, Gov. Mel Carnahan, and a political adviser, requested permission to change course to seek better weather moments before the plane crashed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, JERRY
description: GREENSTEIN - Jerry. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Loving father of Marcy, Alan and Penny and their spouses Peter, Ruby & Perry. Cherished grandfather of Emily, Lisa, Madye, Nathan and Georgia. Services ''Boulvard - Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 12:30 P.M. on Thursday.

title: Respect for Serbs
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Old Dodger Dread Resurfaces
description: DREAD and foreboding fill the air. They really are going to play this Subway Series, aren't they?

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Yankee fans are much more highly educated. We have to be. It's harder to spell Yankees than Mets.''

title: Her Home Page Takes Care of the Home
description: AS the owner of five large Victorian houses divided into more than a dozen apartments here, Jackie Craven finds herself telling a painter how to do the trim on an 1880's stick-style Victorian. Then again, Ms. Craven, a guide to architecture and home repair on the Web site www.about.com, gives a lot of instructions all the time, in addition to answering questions both easy (''How do I fix a dripping faucet?'') and hard (''What color should I paint my house?'').

title: MEDIA ARTS CO-FOUNDER OFFERS TO BUY REST OF COMPANY
description: Media Arts Group Inc. said yesterday that Thomas Kinkade, a board member and co-founder, had offered to buy all the shares of the company, an art and home-decor concern, that he did not already own for about $62.9 million. Mr. Kinkade's $6.25-a-share offer was 85 percent more than Media Arts' closing price Tuesday of $3.38. Media Arts, based in San Jose, Calif., had 13.2 million shares outstanding as of June 30. Mr. Kinkade owns 24 percent of Media Arts' shares outstanding, the company said. Media Arts shares closed yesterday at $5, up $1.63.

title: The Fading Copier King; Xerox Has Failed to Capitalize on Its Own Innovations
description: The Xerox Corporation, which only days ago was fending off rumors of its impending bankruptcy, is talking to venture capitalists about selling its Palo Alto Research Center, which in the 1970's pioneered much of the technology for the personal computer industry.

title: Number of Debate Viewers Rises From the First but Remains Low
description: The third and final scheduled debate between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas on Tuesday night was watched by slightly more people than watched their debate last week, figures released yesterday by Nielsen Media Research showed.

title: Doing the Math Behind Candidates' Debate Claims
description: In their three debates, Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore have waded deep into the thickets of tax policy, Social Security and the budget surplus. The numbers they have thrown around have often been confusing and conflicting -- and sometimes wrong.

title: Bumper Crop of Babies
description: Demographers say that the echo baby boom (bigger than the postwar baby boom) ended with the 90's. Really? Then why do there seem to be so many babies around? Anecdotal evidence points to more Asian-American babies born in the Year of the Dragon, a propitious lunar period that began Feb. 5. Other parents wanted babies born with the century. And then there was the Y2K factor, babies born nine months after their parents celebrated New Year. The first week of October, there were 2,534 babies born in New York City, versus 2,281 last year. Erich Giebelhaus, a spokesman for the Department of Health, said the increase is too small to make a baby boomlet. Tell that to retailers.

title: To Some Complaints, Focus Groups Emerge as Stars of the Fall Season
description: Seventeen of those prized catches of the political season -- undecided voters from a swing state -- munched on a buffet dinner of chicken and meatballs before the presidential debate on Tuesday as a CNN anchor and then a CNN news executive gave them their marching orders for the night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERDON, GWEN
description: VERDON-Gwen. Nicole and Jim, our prayers are with you. Gwen was to us, a very special, caring lady who we loved and admired for many years. Her memory will always be with us. Aaron and Elaine Shapiro

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, STANLEY
description: LEWIS-Stanley. We dearly send you all our love forever and always. Marilyn and Ron Caplan

title: IDEALAB WITHDRAWS OFFERING
description: In the latest sign of the downturn that has befallen Internet content and commerce companies, the high-profile technology incubator Idealab said it would withdraw its registration for a public offering. It had filed for an initial public offering last April, after raising $1 billion from investors.

title: 4 Big Magazine Wholesalers Face Federal Inquiry
description: The Justice Department is examining the business practices of the major wholesalers who deliver 90 percent of the magazines to newsstands in the United States, according to magazine industry executives and Justice Department officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AHEARN, EDWIN JAMES
description: AHEARN-Edwin James. Of Commack, NY on Oct. 16, 2000. Beloved husband of Carol. Loving father of Brian, Kevin, Patrick, and Michael. Adored grandfather of Lauren. Devoted son of Jane. Visiting Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Brueggemann Funeral Home, 522 Larkfield Road, East Northport. Funeral Mass Saturday 10:00 a.m. at Christ the King R.C.C., Commack. Cremation private.
