description: The Miami Dolphins' surprising success has been achieved with a defense that has historians dusting off the National Football League's record book.

title: General Who Exposed Graft in Key Combat Unit Being Investigated : Indonesian Reformer Under Fire
description: JAKARTA  A leading reformer in the Indonesian military, who recently exposed evidence of high-level corruption in a key combat unit, is being investigated for possible violations of discipline and may be dismissed from the army.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERER, DOROTHY
description: SCHERER-Dorothy. Loving wife, mother, sister, grandmother and godmother, Your family will miss you always. You were the best mother a son could ever have. Hope you are finally at rest and at peace. From your children, Robert K. Scherer, Jerold M. Scherer, and Barrymore L. Scherer

title: CREDITORS RENEW INDONESIA AID
description: Indonesia's biggest foreign donors agreed to extend it $4.8 billion in credit to help it offset next year's government deficit and added $530 million for what they called technical assistance. The World Bank, which leads the Consultative Group on Indonesia, said the donors were convinced that Jakarta would satisfy demands for greater progress on economic restructuring and on pacifying renegade militias in Timor. Economists had predicted that donors, led by Japan, had too much invested in Indonesia's economic recovery to make aid contingent on the military situation in Timor, over which many believe the government has little effective control. Wayne Arnold

title: Bush, Gore Jostle Over the Economy
description: NEW YORK -- Al Gore boasted that "America has put its house in order" and urged voters to stay the economic course, while George W. Bush challengedany attempt by Gore to take credit for the nation's prosperity. Gore focused on the economy in a speech Thursday to business leaders in New York, offering no new proposals but outlining differences with his GOP rival onthe issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, DONALD BAHNSEN
description: MCGUIRE-Donald Bahnsen. Retired Stuyvesant High School NYC teacher, died October 15. Funeral service Saturday, October 21 at 11 AM at The Cathedral of All Saints in Albany. Contributions to the ALS Regional Center at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany, NY. Call Bryce Funeral Home for information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, MAX
description: GOLD-Max (Larry). Of Fairlawn, New Jersey. Beloved husband of Ray. Cherished father of Ava (Roger) Brown, Marion and Stanley. Loving grandfather of Taylor and Scott. His smile, humor and great strength will live on in the hearts of his loved ones. I join his family in mourning his loss. Jerry Marcus

title: Here, There and Everywhere: Jets' Lewis Simply Does It All
description: Linebacker Mo Lewis had been patient, not complaining about his reduced role on the Jets' defense. But last Sunday, he showed the Jets what they had been missing.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Tuesday about ''Money,'' at the Studio Theater in Manhattan, misidentified the actress who plays Lady Franklin, the sister of Sir John Vesey, a conniving estate owner. As shown in the cast listing, the role is played by Suzanna Geraghty; Colleen Crawford plays Georgina Vesey, Sir John's daughter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLTARSH, ELAINE
description: OLTARSH-Elaine. Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends its deepest sympathy to her family. Alvin Deutsch, Parnas

title: Most Fans Don't Take the Subway to the Subway Series Anymore
description: It has such a sonorous ring: Subway Series. It's certainly a lot easier to say than All-New York World Series. And it nicely conjures up baseball's working-class past, images of Pee Wee Reese taking the BMT to Ebbets Field, just like any other Brooklynite on his way to work.

title: Slow Down, Britain Tells Trains After One Derailed, Killing 4
description: Britain ordered its high-speed trains to slow down on some sections of the nation's railroads today, a day after part of a train traveling 115 miles an hour derailed and killed four people and injured 35.

title: Official Sees Attempt to Halt His Overhaul Of State Police
description: In a testy rebuttal to recent news reports that New Jersey law enforcement officials concealed evidence of racial profiling for years, Attorney General John J. Farmer Jr. suggested today that some unnamed adversaries of the state police were trying to tarnish the reputation of the agency and derail his attempts to overhaul the force.

title: In America; Mr. Gore in Top Form
description: This time Al Gore got it right, and not a moment too soon.

title: New Criticism of First Lady In Final Travel Office Report
description: In his final report about the firing of seven longtime employees of the White House travel office released today, Robert W. Ray, the independent counsel, asserted that Hillary Rodham Clinton had given ''factually false'' sworn testimony when she minimized her role in the incident.

title: BOEING PROFITS BEAT ESTIMATES IN 3RD QUARTER
description: The Boeing Company, bolstered by more commercial jet orders and faster assembly lines, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 20 percent, despite a drop in revenue. Profit from operations climbed to $622 million, or 72 cents a share, compared with $518 million, or 56 cents a share, in the 1999 quarter. Sales fell 11 percent, to $11.88 billion from $13.28 billion. Analysts had expected profit of 67 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. The company took a charge of $13 million, or 2 cents a share, to pay for a trial launching of the Delta 3 rocket, making net income $609 million, or 70 cents a share. In the 1999 quarter, Boeing took a charge of $141 million, or 15 cents a share, because of declining F-15 jet production, and it had gains of $100 million, or 11 cents a share, from selling businesses, making net income $477 million, or 52 cents a share.

title: Varian Fry Fought U.S. State Dept. to Rescue Jews in World War II : Marseille Honors an American Hero
description: MARSEILLE  An American ambassador came back to Marseille on Wednesday to join the city in honoring a countryman who fought the prejudices and bureaucracy of the U.S. State Department to save refugees' lives during World War II.

title: Little Attention to Spending Bills in Capitol
description: Earlier this week, Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California, sat in his Capitol Hill office, devouring the new biography of Joe DiMaggio. Representative Fred Upton, a Republican, remained home in Michigan, campaigning, tending his tomatoes and attending a debate party in Kalamazoo. Having adjourned last Thursday, most members of the House took the weekend off, as well as Monday, Tuesday and much of the day Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAHVER, MOSHE
description: BRAHVER-Moshe. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of the beloved father of our Benefactor, Barry Brahver. Heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier Michael B. Weisbrod, President Seymour G. Siegel, Treasurer

title: World of Experience: Advantage, Yankees
description: Chuck Knoblauch opened his mouth wide enough to fit an apple, and Jason Grimsley obliged his request by spraying a funnel of Champagne into it, as if Grimsley were shooting water into a clown's mouth at a carnival. The two soggy, happy Yankees were about 15 feet from the entrance to the clubhouse on Wednesday morning, stopping a steady flow of reporters with their innovative celebration. Grimsley's aim was sloppy, on purpose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKLESTEIN, MARILYN
description: FINKLESTEIN-Marilyn. The East End Chapter/Jeanne Kaye League of City of Hope would like to extend its deepest condolences to Dr. Howard Finklestein and family on the loss of Marilyn Finklestein, devoted East End Chapter/Jeanne Kaye League member. Please know our thoughts, love and prayers are with you at this time of sadness.

title: Delta Announces $1.6 Billion Expansion Plan for Kennedy Airport
description: Delta Air Lines plans to demolish the former Pan Am Worldport, built as New York's gateway to the jet age, to greatly expand its presence at Kennedy International Airport, more than tripling the number of its daily flights there by 2005.

title: Children's Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ultimate Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Debates Leave Instant Analysts Hedging Their Bets
description: Doing the post-mortems after Tuesday night's debate, Peter Jennings on ABC referred to ''the sink-in factor'' that would develop over the next days and George Stephanopoulos said people in the Gore camp ''believe they will win the second-day spin.''

title: Office Renovated For Mac
description: MICROSOFT WORD 2001 for the Macintosh just came out this month, and as someone whose first choice for word processing is Word on a Mac, I am apprehensive.

title: FRONTLINE TO MAKE OPERATIONAL CHANGES
description: The FrontLine Capital Group, which invests in real estate and technology-related companies, said it would stop making investments and would separate its temporary-office-leasing business, HQ Global Workplaces, from its other businesses. The move comes after an 83 percent drop this year in the shares of the company, based in New York. Yesterday, the shares rose $1.25, to $11.63. ''This structure will make the value of our investment in HQ Global more evident and will allow investors to better understand the true worth of FrontLine,'' Scott Rechler, chief executive, said in a statement.

title: Shanghai Journal; In This Job, the Suspense Might Really Be Killing
description: China's spidermen, its legion of low-tech window washers, may not be super heroes, but they are nearly superhuman in what they are willing to risk for $4 a day. Suspended from single, thumb-thick ropes, they hang like spiders hundreds of feet in the air, cleaning this country's high-rise windows.

title: Autumn's Promise to Spring
description: IT'S best to forget the Dr. Zhivago stuff when planting bulbs. Remember those drifts of daffodils and Julie Christie's tragic expression as ''Lara's Theme'' rose in crescendo? So where's Omar Sharif when you need help planting all those thousands of bulbs?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROUSE, MICHELLE SCOTT
description: CROUSE-Michelle Scott. Of Darien, Connecticut on October 17, 2000. Mother of William M. III, John B., David S. and Michael S. Crouse. Sister of Henry C. Scott, Jr. Grandmother of seven. Friends may call at the Lawrence Funeral Home, Darien, CT on Friday, October 20, 2000 from 2-4 and 6-8 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. John's Roman Catholic Church, Darien, CT on Saturday, October 21, 2000 at 9:00 A.M. Burial will take place at Most Holy Trinity Church Cemetery, East Hampton, LI. Memorials may be sent to Miss Porter School, 60 Main Street, Farmington, CT 06032 or Post 53 Ambulance, PO Box 2066, Darien, CT 06820.

title: Sports of The Times; Valentine Is Poised To Cash In
description: POOR Bobby Valentine, the emperor with no contract, who now must manage against a man even George Steinbrenner would dare not fire.

title: Catalogs for the In Box, Not the Mailbox
description: IN the past week, I have received 33 catalogs in the mail, a stack that weighed more than the cat. Even taking into consideration the fact that my bathroom scale routinely overestimates its load by one pants size, 13 pounds of glossy photos translates into a lot of leather luggage stands, dog breath spray and elk antler twig baskets that I will never buy.

title: With the Help of the Series, Giuliani Giddily Finds His Inner 7-Year-Old
description: How much time will Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani devote to the Subway Series during the next week? ''As much as possible,'' the lame-duck mayor and lifelong Yankee fan swiftly replied.

title: Clinton Leads Tribute to the Cole's Crew
description: Beneath skies as gray as the warships looming behind him, President Clinton paid tribute today to the crew of the destroyer Cole, the living and the dead. He vowed that those who bombed the ship in the Yemeni port at Aden six days ago would not escape American justice.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Party Prescriptions Elude Patients

title: They Love New York
description: Darryl Hamilton grew up in Louisiana, Turk Wendell in Massachusetts. They had one thing in common: an abiding distaste for and confusion about New York sports fans.

title: Rupert Murdoch lends his voice to those worried about a cooling of television ad spending.
description: AFTER years of white-hot intensity, most recently driven by a media buying frenzy by start-up dot-com companies, the television advertising marketplace is cooling by almost all accounts.

title: TV SOCCER TALKS END
description: The cable TV provider NTL Inc. failed to strike a deal with the Premiership soccer league of England to broadcast pay-per-view games the next three years. NTL, which has 3.4 million customers in Britain and Ireland and is financially backed by France Telecom and Microsoft, said it had offered $447 million for the rights to broadcast 40 pay-per-view games a year. The 20-team Premiership League, which includes Manchester United and other top teams, is Britain's richest league. Alan Cowell

title: Postell Acting and Playing Like a Keeper
description: Lavor Postell didn't act like a second-round pick when he was drafted by the Knicks. He nearly held out of training camp while his agent, Dan Fegan, demanded a trade over the summer. Then, when he finally signed with the Knicks, Postell spoke as if he intended to challenge the All-Stars Allan Houston and Latrell Sprewell for playing time.

title: One Reason to Be Wary Of Dark-Horse Romanians
description: The final of the OKbridge Internet World Championship will be played in Birmingham, Ala., on Nov. 16 as a curtain raiser for the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals. One team, the winner of the Western Hemisphere zone, consists of Jay McKee, Joao Campos, Benito Garozzo, Lea Dupont, Raija and Richard Reisig. This is a cosmopolitan group: Garozzo, who lives in Florida, won many world titles for Italy; Campos has represented Brazil successfully; and Raija Reisig is from Finland. In the semifinal they upset the defending champions headed by Doug Simson, winning by 30 imps.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Gyrations in a Confused and Divided Market
description: Some investors gave up and got out yesterday morning, creating one of the worst openings ever for the American stock market. Prices soon rallied, but the Dow Jones industrial average still closed under 10,000 for the first time since March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, DOROTHY VAN BRINK
description: CANTOR-Dorothy Van Brink, 77. Of Greenwich, Ct and Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, passed away Saturday, Oct. 14. Mrs. Cantor, a native of New York City, she was active in volunteer work in Greenwich, CT. She was an avid reader who also traveled the world extensively. She is survived by her husband of nearly 60 years, Samuel C. Cantor, retired Executive Vice President of Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, two daughters Judy C. Stone of Rockaway, NJ and Barbara C. Palm of Ponte Vedra, FL, & three grandchildren, Jeremy Stone, and Alicia and Michael Palm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to The Greenwich Library, Putnam Ave., Greenwich, Ct 06830.

title: ONLINE INVESTING SITES TO MERGE
description: Two privately held Internet companies, IExchange.com and InteractiveFunds.com, will announce a deal today to merge, an IExchange spokesman said. They plan to create a family of mutual funds that take their stock picks from a community of Web-based investors. IExchange is already host to a community of investors on its Web site. InteractiveFunds, a start-up, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to run community-based mutual funds. The combined company will be based in Dallas. Danny Hakim

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, HORACE BROOKES
description: ROBINSON - Horace Brookes Blackwell. On October 3rd, peacefully at home. Beloved husband of Henrietta T. Father of Edward T., Thomas D. and J. Howland. Grandfather of Lloyd and Elizabeth, William & Emily, Samuel and Evelyn. Memorial service on Friday, October 20, 11AM, at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and 91st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Brick Church, 62 East 92nd Street, NY, NY 10128, or to the Youth Foundation, 36 West 44th Street, New York, NY 10036.

title: BROADWING RESULTS TOP EXPECTATIONS
description: Broadwing Inc., the fast-growing communications carrier that evolved from the old Cincinnati Bell, intends to announce quarterly financial results today that will modestly exceed analysts' expectations. Officials said Broadwing, which focuses on digital services, would report a loss of 19 cents a share, excluding special items, while Wall Street was expecting a loss of 20 cents a share. Other results will also exceed expectations. For example, Merrill Lynch has forecast that the company will post Internet and data services revenue of $250 million, but the data revenue will be $264 million. Seth Schiesel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, ANNETTE
description: STEINBERG-Annette (nee Gruder) ''Connie''. Passed away on Monday, October 16, 2000 after a very long illness. Sister of the late Beatrice Steiner and Leon Gruder. Survived by Herman Gruder, Vivian Gruder, Ruth and Moe Rimler, nieces and nephews. Services at Gramercy Park Funeral Chapel, 2nd Ave. and 10th St. today at 11 AM. May she rest in peace.

title: AIDS in Central Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, IRVING
description: SMITH-Irving. Devoted husband of Celia. Loving father of Ira and Sydell, and Barry and Rona. Cherished grandfather of Matthew, Allison, Jennifer, David and Letty. Beloved great-grandfather of Alex, Loren and William.

title: Swedes Said to Join Group To Bid for Seagram's Liquors
description: In a move that promises to redefine what had largely been considered a two-horse race, Vin and Sprit, the Swedish state-owned company that owns the rights to the Absolut vodka brand, has joined forces with Bacardi International Ltd. and the Brown-Forman Corporation to bid for the drinks business of the Seagram Company, people close to the companies said today.

title: Five Years Later, A Female Kicker's Memorable Victory
description: On a cold afternoon in the fall of 1992, Heather Sue Mercer persuaded her father to accompany her to a field near their Westchester County home and hold a toy football on the ground while she practiced place-kicking. She had seen her high school team's kicker in action and, characteristically, thought it looked like fun and something she could do. A 16-year-old junior, she was a swimmer, diver, fencer, and played softball, basketball and varsity soccer, in which she was known for her strong legs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, HARVEY ALLAN
description: WIENER-Harvey Allan. Beloved husband of Phoebe, devoted and loving father of Shellie Wiener Geist (Alan) and Mardi McDougall (Peter), cherished grandfather of Lewis and William Geist. Services to be held on Thursday, October 19, 12 noon at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Is Bigger Oil Better?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tonic for East Timor's Poverty
description: One of the newest, poorest and least developed nations in the world, East Timor is the ultimate welfare state -- a ward of the international community subsisting almost entirely on handouts from abroad.

title: A Modern, Connected Twist On the Early 1990's Organizer
description: In the wake of the success of the Palm, the shape of personal digital assistants has morphed to imitate the large, open face of Palm devices. But Diamond Multimedia, the company that introduced the first commercial MP3 music player a couple of years ago, has decided to go retro with its new P.D.A., the Mako.

title: Brooklyn School Breaks From the Pack; A Case Study in How State Testing Was Used to Improve Education
description: Just a year ago, John Q. Adams was holding his aching head and wondering what had gone wrong. The results of a new state math test had just come out, and only 39 percent of the eighth graders at his school in Brooklyn had met state standards.

title: Sun Microsystems Reports Record Quarterly Earnings
description: Sun Microsystems announced record quarterly earnings and revenue today, including strong sales in Europe, where other computer makers say they have faltered. But the company's stock ended down for the day, and analysts said a slip in gross profit margins was to blame.

title: Lady Sarah Consuelo Spencer-Churchill, 78, Dies
description: Lady Sarah Consuelo Spencer-Churchill, a volunteer worker who was a cousin of Winston Churchill, died on Friday in Middletown, Conn. She was 78 and lived in Old Lyme, Conn. Her family said she died during surgery.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LABRECQUE, THOMAS G.
description: LABRECQUE-Thomas G. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York, N.Y., on November 8 at 10:00 A.M. A private funeral service for the family and friends will be held at Holy Cross Church, Rumson, NJ on October 19 at 10:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorials be sent to: the Thomas G. Labrecque Leadership Institute of Red Bank Catholic High School, 112 Broad St, Red Bank, NJ 07701 or Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center - Lung Cancer Research Fund, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TULLOCH, MARSHALL ELLIOT
description: TULLOCH-Marshall Elliot. Died Oct. 16 in Wilmington, Del., at the age of 62. Husband of Marilyn Holmes Tulloch, father of Margaret, of Washington, and Hilary; brother of Eleanor Tulloch Schultz of White Plains, N.Y. Funeral Friday at Christ Church, Wilmington.

title: Quietly, Rangers Gain a Victory
description: The United Center had all the vibrancy of a wax museum after-hours tonight, and the play on the ice was not much better. But that did not keep the Rangers from snapping a two-game losing streak with a 4-2 victory over the Chicago Blackhawks.

title: Candidates Accept Fox's Offer of Free Time
description: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush have accepted an invitation to share an hour of free time on the Fox television network during which each candidate will tell viewers why he thinks he should be president.

title: FEDERAL INVESTIGATORS ARE LOOKING AT ITT EDUCATIONAL
description: ITT Educational Services Inc. said its compensation of student recruiters is being investigated by the federal Department of Education. The company's shares fell $5.25, or 24 percent, to $16.69, on release of the news. The company, which operates ITT Technical Institutes, is preparing a response to the Office of Inspector General. The company offers associate's, bachelor's and master's degrees, and nondegree programs, at 69 trade schools in 28 states.

title: The Topkapi Treasures Find Friends in South Florida
description: For years the Greater Fort Lauderdale Convention and Visitors Bureau has wanted something else to lure the tourists, something other than the golden sun and its sparkling, deep-blue portion of the Atlantic.

title: Drive-Time Radio On 100 Channels; Digital Transmissions Could Transform Radio In the Car and at Home
description: WHILE television's purveyors tout the value of reality shows, pristine digital transmissions and interactive programming, television's ancestor, radio, remains mired in program formats and static-prone transmission standards that have improved little in the past 50 years.

title: Shrugging Off a Party Label in Georgia
description: In the debate on Sunday night among the candidates for United States senator from Georgia, former Senator Mack Mattingly scored what he considered a personal triumph: he got Senator Zell Miller to publicly state his choice for president, live and on camera.

title: On the London Scene, Practicality Is Radical
description: HERE'S an idea. Design innovative furniture. Make it useful. Sell it.

title: How Does It Do on Strained Peas?
description: Vaska Herbal Fresh Laundry Powder, in a humble recycled brown-paper carton, is a mixture of pure soap (not detergent) and lavender. So it's perfect for the baby being raised All Natural.

title: The Debates Are Over. Now It's the Voters' Turn.
description: To the Editor:

title: Digital Legerdemain: Irish Mists Into Music
description: AN artist and a computer scientist in Ireland have come up with a new use for rain: making music.

title: Calendar
description: Armani Retrospective

title: From Milan, Steam Power
description: FOR Richard Sapper, there is no such thing as a simple cup of coffee. Twenty-one years ago, he won the gratitude of caffeine connoisseurs everywhere with a stove-top espresso maker that has sold 1.2 million copies. And now Mr. Sapper, a Munich-born honorary Italian -- he lives in Milan -- is back in the kitchen again.

title: Nassau Republicans Say County Must Raise Taxes
description: Reversing themselves, Nassau County's Republican lawmakers said today that a property tax increase was necessary to help bring the county's troubled finances into balance next year. But their proposal for a 5 percent rise in the county portion of local property tax bills fell well short of the 16.3 percent being sought by Democratic legislators.

title: Earnings Roundup
description: Investors were keeping a close eye on the profit reports of some of the top names in technology:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JOHN FRANCIS
description: SMITH-John Francis (Jay). Age 87, former analyst of corporate securities at Wood Struthers & Winthrop in New York City, died on October 14, 2000. Memorial Service, Friday, November 24, 2000 at 11:30 AM at the Quadrangle, 3300 Darby Road, Haverford, PA.

title: ECONOMIC SCENE; Tax cutting may be in fashion, but it's a good time to raise gasoline taxes.
description: WITH all the talk of tax cuts, this may be an inopportune time to propose a tax increase. But it is easier to put tax reforms in place when times are good than when they are bad, and United States policy on gasoline taxation could be much improved.

title: The Debates Are Over. Now It's the Voters' Turn.
description: To the Editor:

title: Harry Cooper, Unlucky Golfer, Is Dead at 96
description: Harry Cooper, the hard-luck Hall of Fame golfer who had 31 victories on the PGA Tour in the 1920's and 1930's but never won any of what are now considered the four major tournaments, died yesterday at White Plains Hospital. He was 96.

title: Senate Candidates Attack Each Other With New TV Ads
description: Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, courted the labor vote in the center of the state today, while he and his Republican opponent, Representative Bob Franks, attacked each other with new television commercials.

title: SINGAPORE STOCK INVESTIGATION
description: The Singapore Exchange, the island's stock and derivatives marketplace, said it was continuing investigations into the 30 percent last-minute surge in Singapore Telecommunications share price on Friday after establishing that it was not a result of an error trade. Singapore Telecommunications, the largest stock on the index by market value, jumped 80 Singapore cents (46 cents), to 3.50 Singapore dollars ($1.99) on Friday, its biggest one-day gain ever. Before the price increase, the shares traded between 2.61 Singapore dollars ($1.49) and 2.72 Singapore dollars ($1.55).

title: Climate Change Led to Mass Extinction 34 Million Years Ago
description: LONDON, Oct 18 - Severe climate changes 34 million years ago wiped out 90 percent of all tiny sea creatures living along the Gulf Coast in the United States, scientists said on Wednesday.

title: Printing Envelopes Presents a Problem for Desktop Computers
description: THE relationship between a computer and a printer can have the precariousness and unpredictability of a blind date. After all, the two devices may have little in common and have never met. If they are introduced patiently, under ideal circumstances, they may get along.

title: The Teacher Recruitment Battle
description: New York City and the State Department of Education have been snarling at each other for months over a new state regulation requiring the city to hire only certified teachers in low-performing schools beginning this fall. But a difference of opinion about how to proceed has erupted into administrative warfare. The city's schools chancellor asserts that the new rules have caused hundreds of certified teachers to turn down jobs in the city, a tragic loss to a system that desperately needs qualified teachers.

title: Company Challenges Law Banning Net Tobacco Sales
description: In the latest of a flurry of lawsuits seeking to use the federal Constitution to trump state efforts to regulate controversial online services and products, a major tobacco company has challenged a recently-enacted New York law that effectively bans the sale of cigarettes to New York consumers via the Internet, mail-order or telephone.

title: Bush Says Gore's Election Would Endanger Prosperity
description: Gov. George W. Bush plunged into the final three-week stretch of the presidential race today, arguing that Vice President Al Gore would endanger the nation's prosperity and using his own pledge of tax cutting to rally his party's base.

title: The Debates Are Over. Now It's the Voters' Turn.
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000101990208130121 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Flipping Through Photos Instead of Watching Football
description: By stuffing a Power PC microprocessor chip into a Zip drive, the Iomega Corporation has created a gadget that allows digital camera owners to use their television, rather than a computer, to view their snapshots. ''The television is really a natural place to view photos,'' said Robert Puzey, product manager for the Iomega FotoShow Digital Image Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILTON, SYBIL
description: MILTON-Sybil. The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourns the untimely passing of its Archives Consultant, Sybil Milton. A most distinguished archivist and historian, she brought a range of expertise unmatched in her fields, and was of invaluable help to us in framing our future direction. She will be greatly missed. Marshall Weinberg, Chair of the JDC Archives Committee Sherry Hyman, Director of JDC Archives and Records

title: Joy in Gotham: New York Takes Series!; The Glory of Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Family's In-House Hacker Gets an Eyeful
description: DISOBEDIENCE

title: Terror Suspect Asked Officer To Kill Him, Interrogator Says
description: A man charged with participating in a global terrorism conspiracy pleaded to be shot during a lengthy interrogation in Germany before he was brought to the United States for trial, a German police official testified yesterday.

title: Enchanted Tyson Is Still Enticing
description: Mike Tyson's tour of Detroit continued today with an entertaining workout at the gym where Joe Louis once trained, a modest brick facility at the doorstep of the city housing project where Diana Ross and the Supremes were raised.

title: Mars and Venus
description: To the Editor:

title: VLASIC SAYS COMPANY WILL PROBABLY BE SOLD
description: Vlasic Foods International Inc., the maker of Vlasic Pickles and Swanson frozen entrees, said a review by Lazard Freres & Company would probably result in the sale of all or part of the company. Vlasic told employees of the development yesterday, a spokesman, Kevin Lowery, said. The company, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., has 3,455 employees.

title: Dueling Commercials in Senate Race
description: Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for Senate from New Jersey, yesterday released a new 30-second commercial, titled ''Crucial,'' in his campaign against Representative Bob Franks. Meanwhile, Mr. Franks, a Republican, yesterday began running his first commercial in the New York City media market, a 15-second ad titled ''Impossibly Expensive.'' Following are summaries of each and an analysis of both.

title: Chase, Nearing J. P. Morgan Merger, Reports Profit Shortfall
description: Chase Manhattan, whose stock had already fallen 34 percent since it announced its $31 billion merger with J. P. Morgan last month, gave investors more bad news yesterday. Chase announced third-quarter operating earnings of $905 million, or 68 cents a share. That was down 26 percent from the prior year, and far below the 93 cents analysts had expected.

title: Childhood Dreams Become A Reality
description: As children, they would roam their Bensonhurst neighborhood in Brooklyn looking for Borden's milk cartons. Twenty cartons meant a free ticket in the upper deck at Shea Stadium, so John Franco and his brother, Jim, would go through garbage cans and pester their relatives.

title: Barbara Bush Joins G.O.P. Women on Stump to Try to Bridge Gender Gap
description: It is a sure sign that Election Day is around the corner when the big guns come out, and today the Bush campaign unleashed its silver-haired, pearl-draped howitzer. The former first lady, Barbara Bush, hit the trail, pressing her outsized and enduring popularity into the service of Gov. George W. Bush's aspirations.

title: Joy in Gotham: New York Takes Series!
description: To the Editor:

title: Conflicts of Interest
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Illegal Migrants Bound for U.S. Found in Box at Hong Kong Port
description: Hong Kong customs agents discovered 26 illegal Chinese migrants today, hidden in a shipping container bound for Long Beach, Calif., after they detected carbon dioxide gas emanating from the container.

title: Gore Intensifies Attack on Bush Tax Plan
description: Vice President Al Gore said yesterday that Gov. George W. Bush's tax cut proposal would drain Social Security, jack up interest rates and undermine economic growth by giving ''too much to too few at the expense of too many.''

title: Charmion von Wiegand Blanche Lazzell
description: Michael Rosenfeld Gallery

title: A Not-So-Old Professor's Take on Baseball
description: AS some people wear their hearts on their sleeves, Prof. Joseph Dorinson wears on each of his lapels the photo of a baseball great.

title: The Empty Center of Campaign 2000
description: If you are expecting to soon find out what the election will turn on now that the debates are over, you're going to be disappointed. In fact, you may be puzzled about the whys of the outcome even after we know the winner of campaign 2000.

title: Commuter Survey Finds Improvement in Service on L.I.R.R.
description: They've been working on the railroad, and the passengers have noticed. The oft-maligned Long Island Rail Road got good grades today from a riders' group that found improvement in 38 of 46 areas that commuters were asked to grade.

title: The Great Debaters (Starting in School)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank Chief Admits Euro Gaffe As Currency Hovers Near Low : Duisenberg Acts To Limit Damage
description: PARIS  Wim Duisenberg, the president of the European Central Bank, acknowledged Thursday that a loose-lipped blunder had undermined the euro, but he answered questions about whether he would resign with a terse "no."

title: Set 'Em Up, Joe, for Roaring Kung Fu
description: You can almost tell Jackie Chan's age by looking at his nose: the older he is, the wider his nose because it has probably been broken a few more times since you last saw him. As any fan of the Hong Kong action genre knows, the acrobatic Mr. Chan does all his own stunts and suggests much of the high-flying choreography for his films. There is probably no better platform for his inventive movement than the 1994 ''Legend of Drunken Master,'' a pluperfect vehicle for his tricky martial slapstick.

title: Gore's Surrogates Bluntly Question Bush's Competence
description: After watching the three presidential debates, several prominent Democrats on Capitol Hill bluntly questioned Gov. George W. Bush's capacity to lead yesterday, reinforcing a theme that surrogates for Vice President Al Gore plan to voice repeatedly in the final days of the campaign.

title: All Joking Aside, Bush Faces Letterman
description: It started like a normal night on the ''Late Show with David Letterman.'' Expecting Gov. George W. Bush as his guest, Mr. Letterman quizzed an audience member about Texas. He showed footage of the governor emerging from a black car. He brought up Mr. Bush's open-mike faux pas about a reporter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROVEGNO, GEORGE F.,
description: ROVEGNO-George F., of Huntington, on October 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of George Jr., Richard, Kathryn Larkin, Betsy Bozian and Edward. Cherished grandfather of 12. Friends may call at M.A. Connell, 934 New York Ave., Huntington Station, on Friday from 2-5 and 7-9. Mass on Saturday, 9:30 AM, Church of St. Patrick, 400 Main St., Huntington. Interment, St. Patrick's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his name to The Chaminade High School Scholarship Fund, Attn: Father James, 340 Jackson Ave., Mineola, NY 11501 or the pro-life organization of your selection.

title: To Keep the Mideast Talks Alive
description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywood Glamour but No Shopping on the Steppes
description: This Sunday's presentation of PBS's ''Nature'' series opens with the image of Julia Roberts sitting in a bureaucrat's office in Ulan Bator, the capital of Mongolia, while arrangements are made for her trip into the country's heartland. She has arrived in this remote nation north of China because she loves horses, she says. Montana, apparently, just wouldn't do.

title: A Fine Meal: Please Pass The Vitriol
description: THE panic sets in when the doors are locked. Five of the six characters in ''The Dinner Party,'' the exceedingly odd new melocomedy that opened last night at the Music Box Theater, have been wondering who has brought them together in a private room in an expensive Parisian restaurant.

title: What Goes Around Comes Around? Doing Good Deeds in a Bad World
description: The title of ''Pay It Forward'' refers to an idea dreamed up by a seventh grader named Trevor McKinney who lives with his mother, a waitress struggling to stay on the wagon, in a modest ranch-style house on the edge of Las Vegas. Trevor's social studies teacher, Mr. Simonet, a sarcastic fellow with a badly scarred face and an impressive vocabulary, has given his class a yearlong extra-credit assignment: to think of something that will change the world and to put it into action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUCKO, NATHALIE I.
description: HUCKO-Nathalie I., 92, died October 17, in New York City. Survived by daughters Lois (Roland) Worthington and Grace Hucko; two granddaughters, Marjorie (Christopher Wixson) and Valerie Worthington. Viewing at CookeKennedy, 117 W. 72nd St., Saturday, October 21, 2-8PM. Services, St. John's Lutheran Church, Bloomfield, NJ, Sunday, 2:00PM. Transportation to services provided by family by pre-arrangement.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: All over New York multiple sins have been committed in the name of baba gannouj. Hummus has been subjected to unspeakable acts. Right off the bat, Mamlouk deserves praise for restoring luster to these Middle Eastern staples. The hummus has no tricks up its sleeve other than fresh ingredients mixed in the proper proportions and a texture that's pure satin. The same goes for the wonderfully smoky baba gannouj, sprinkled with a few jewel-like pomegranate seeds. These two classics made up only two-fifths of the first course in Mamlouk's set menu the night I ate there. They were joined by a puree of red bell peppers thickened with ground walnuts, a salsalike avocado salad and a sweet, syrupy mound of grilled marinated bell peppers.

title: Nasdaq in a Big Rally
description: Stocks rose sharply on a rebound in technology shares, with the Nasdaq posting its third-biggest one-day gain ever, at 7.79 percent. The S.& P. 500 increased 3.5 percent, and the Dow was up 1.7 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKLESTEIN, MARILYN
description: FINKLESTEIN-Marilyn. We are saddened beyond measure at the passing of our beloved friend, ''Malk''. So many years, so many memories, and such pleasure in knowing and loving ''Malk'' and her husband Howard. We send our deepest condolences to their children, Beverly and Jane, and their grandchildren, Matthew, Farin, Michael, Jeffrey and Steven. She will remain in our hearts and minds forever. Bunny and Bert Podell FINKLESTEIN-Marilyn. Time can never erase a lifetime of memories. We will always love and remember you. Janice and Sam

title: Possible Lapses in Security At Yemen Port Investigated
description: American warships visited the Yemeni port of Aden two dozen times even though there had been no security reviews of local harbor workers and Yemen's coast was known to be susceptible to entry by terrorists, defense and administration officials said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Mideast Truce Tested

title: F.D.A. BAN SOUGHT ON CHEMICAL USED FOR COLD REMEDIES
description: A panel of scientific experts recommended today that a common ingredient in decongestants and appetite suppressants be removed from over-the-counter products, citing new evidence that the chemical may increase the risk of stroke in young women.

title: Stottlemyre Smiles From Afar
description: The loneliness of following his pitchers from afar has surprised Mel Stottlemyre. But the Yankees pitching coach, recovering from treatment for bone-marrow cancer, expressed deep appreciation for the regular phone calls from Yankees Manager Joe Torre.

title: Ailment Might Sideline Cook
description: Even though he announced his starting pitching rotation yesterday, Bobby Valentine has promised not to disclose the Mets' final roster for the World Series until the last possible moment, and now he has good reason to wait. That is because Dennis Cook has a kidney stone, and Valentine is not sure if the reliever will be available when the series begins tomorrow night.

title: The Ex-Con Is Determined to Go Straight, but . . .
description: As ''The Yards'' grimly wends its way toward a sudden surprise ending that's corny enough to cap a 1940's Warner Brothers crime story, it is impossible not to admire the film's epic ambitions, thwarted though they may be by the final spasm of nobility. But until that moment, ''The Yards,'' directed by James Gray (''Little Odessa''), impresses as one of the few films in recent years to dare to tread in the sacred shadow of Francis Ford Coppola's ''Godfather'' movies. For that kind of nerve, it deserves points.

title: WHITBREAD SELLING PUBS
description: Shares in Whitbread P.L.C. rose 8.7 percent to 469 pence, or about $6.80, after the company said it would sell its 3,000 pubs, moving further away from its traditional markets. The 258-year-old company sold its brewing business last May, reflecting the assessment that Britons spend less time in pubs and drink less beer. Whitbread said it would focus on its brands including Marriott and Travel Inn hotels, Brewers Fayre and Beefeater restaurants and David Lloyd leisure health clubs. Alan Cowell

title: Foreign Affairs; The Arabs' Road Map
description: The first Arab summit meeting in a decade convenes in Egypt tomorrow, and it will signal what road the Arab world intends to go down in the 21st century. There are three possibilities: (1) This summit will end with Egypt still leading the Arab world on a road of cold peace with Israel and integration with the West; (2) it will end with Iraq and Syria leading the Arab world on a path against Israel and America; (3) or the summit could end in a way that will totally shock the 22 Arab leaders. That would be with the world looking at this Arab summit and wondering why the Arab East is the only region in the world, including sub-Saharan Africa, that is still ruled entirely by dictators, autocrats and kings, without one real democracy.

title: Bush Is Hit on Social Security
description: The Democratic National Committee released a new commercial this week attacking Gov. George W. Bush's proposal to create private investment accounts in the Social Security system. Building on criticism that Vice President Al Gore directed at the Bush plan in the final presidential debate on Tuesday night, the commercial says Mr. Bush cannot meet his promise to create investment accounts for younger workers without shortchanging retirees.

title: An Even Worse Week for Euro Stirs Central Banker's Regrets
description: Wim Duisenberg, the gruff and blunt-speaking president of the European Central Bank, admitted today that he had blundered in his recent comments and vowed to hold his tongue more in the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILDER, BEA
description: GILDER-Bea. We greatly mourn the passing of our longtime Board member. She contributed much to the organization's growth, serving faithfully and loyally as President of our Essie Bierman League, of which she was a co-founder, for over 30 years. She will be missed by all. She is survived by her daughter Jacqueline Blass, her son David Gilder, six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Our deepest condolences and sympathy go out to them. Services to be held at Campbell's (81st and Madison), Oct. 20 at 11AM. Joan Siegel, President Board of Directors Children's Day Treatment Center & School, 255 West 71 St., NY 10023 GILDER - Bea. Congregation Rodeph Sholom notes with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Bea Gilder, mother of Jaclyn Blass. Bea's grandfather David Cahn was our congregation's first Cantor. Her great-grandchildren are 6th generation members. We send condolences to Jackie, Norman, David and Saundra and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Senior Rabbi Mark Biderman, President GILDER-Beatrice. Passed away October 18th at 94 years of age. Beloved wife of the late William Gilder. Devoted mother of Jackie and Norman Blass and David and Sandie Gilder. A wonderfully loving grandmother of six, Michael, Jon, Mark, Steven, Peter and Elisabeth and great-grandmother of nine. Funeral at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday 11AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Children's Day Treatment Center, Congregation Rodeph Sholom or a charity of your choice. Mama Bea-you will be missed by all.

title: RANGERS' DOIG CLEARS WAIVERS
description: When the Rangers put the 23-year-old defenseman Jason Doig on waivers this week, they were gambling that they could sneak him through so they could send him to the minor leagues without losing his rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENTINI, FRANK J.
description: LENTINI-Frank J. 1937-2000. Frank was an innovative contributor to the fashion industry. Besides creating his own clothing line, he was Sr. Vice President for the 500 Fashion Group and President of the International Association of Clothing Designers and Executives. He leaves behind a wife, four sons and many friends.

title: Bush and Gore Clash Over Social Security
description: Gov. George W. Bush struck back hard at Democratic commercials attacking his Social Security plan, accusing Vice President Al Gore of being irresponsible and divisive on the sensitive subject.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, ALIX HEGELER.
description: SEGAL-Alix Hegeler. Beloved wife of Joel Segal. Loving mother of Hilary Good and Brian Good. Stepmother of Mark Segal and Gregg Segal. Grandmother of Nina Segal. Alix passed away peacefully in her home in New York City on October 18, 2000. Alix will be in all of our hearts forever. Alix graduated Summa Cum Laude from Fordham University in 1994 with a degree in History. She was a member of the Honor Society of Phi Kappa Phi and served on the Fordham University Board of Advisors. She was more than proud of her association with Fordham. A burial service will take place on Monday, October 23, at 3:00 PM, at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue at 71st St., where Alix was a longtime parishioner. A reception will follow immediately at the Mark Hotel, 25 East 77 St. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be made to the New York Hospital Pulmonary Education Fund, Attn: Divisional Administrator, Weill Medical College of Cornell University, 1300 York Ave., Box 96, New York, NY 10021.

title: Guggenheim and Hermitage to Marry in Las Vegas
description: Looking for a place to marry high art and popular culture, where a tourist in Bermuda shorts can wander into an art gallery fit for kings?

title: Article 2000102093432989412 -- No Title
description: New Media Meets An Old Medium In the Phone Book

title: Support Is Growing in Congress for Internet Filters in Schools
description: Congressional support is growing for efforts to require schools and libraries with Internet access to install software to block access to pornography, obscenity and materials considered harmful to minors.

title: Little Shop Of Learning
description: During the 1970's the Los Angeles independent studio New World Pictures was famous for turning out exploitation films with a little something extra, movies with titles like ''Night Call Nurses'' and ''Humanoids from the Deep.'' Founded by the legendary drive-in auteur Roger Corman (''Little Shop of Horrors'') and his wife, Julie, the company became known for its willingness to give creative freedom to promising young directors, provided that they stayed within tight budgets and respected certain rules (like having the leading lady remove her shirt at least once every couple of reels).

title: When Jews and Muslims Uneasily Shared Morocco
description: The drive west from the interior of Morocco to the Atlantic port city of Essaouira in summer is a desert trip. The heat is blistering; the terrain stays the same for hours, brown earth and platinum light. Suddenly there's a change. As if someone had thrown a switch, the temperature drops, a moist breeze stirs, green appears. The sea is miles away and invisible, but you feel its presence like a balm.

title: Erasmus, Class of '35
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parenthese. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.

title: Sports of The Times; Unlikely Hero Of '55 Series. Well, Sort Of.
description: MAYBE you heard about how Popeye -- he was simply called Don Zimmer in those days -- was single-handedly responsible for the one and only time the Brooklyn Dodgers won the World Series, in 1955, in the first of back-to-back Subway Series with the Yankees. And he wasn't even playing. A lot of people aren't aware of how it happened, even fans in all the boroughs who have followed baseball right up to this weekend, when a Subway Series in these populous woods resumes after a parched 44-year interruption.

title: U.S. Says It Was Warned On Egyptian Islamic Group
description: American intelligence officials said yesterday that they received reports in late May that a militant Egyptian Islamic group was in the final stages of preparing a terror attack against American targets and that they passed on the warning to all American posts and foreign governments in the Middle East.

title: Company Challenges Law Banning Net Tobacco Sales
description: In the latest of a flurry of lawsuits seeking to use the federal Constitution to trump state efforts to regulate controversial online services and products, a major tobacco company has challenged a recently-enacted New York law that effectively bans the sale of cigarettes to New York consumers via the Internet, mail-order or telephone.

title: Executive Shifts At Two Agencies
description: Executives are changing posts at two agencies.

title: Showdown at Chess Corral Just Leads to a Quick Draw
description: Garry Kasparov offered and Vladimir Kramnik took a draw after only 11 moves of the seventh game of their Brain Games Network World Chess Championship in London yesterday. Kasparov spent 38 minutes and Kramnik 9 minutes on this remnant game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEGER, GEORGE H.
description: NEGER-George H. Age 98 of Riverdale, NY. Beloved husband of Sadie (Landsman). Devoted father of Lois Laitman and Shirley Benjamin. Loving grandfather of five granchildren and 12 great grandchildren. Services Friday 10:00 AM ''Wien & Wien'' 129 Engle St, Englewood, NJ. Contributions to Cabrini Hospice or your favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERDON, GWEN
description: VERDON-Gwen. The family of Peter Gennaro expresses its deepest sympathy to Nicole and her family. Our dear Peter respected, admired and loved Gwen throughout his lifetime. We join you in mourning her loss. VERDON-Gwen. Nicole and Jim, our prayers are with you. Gwen was to us, a very special, caring lady who we loved and admired for many years. Her memory will always be with us. Aaron and Elaine Shapiro VERDON-Gwen. Our deepest sympathy to Jim and Nicole. Gwen, for over 40 years, was not only our client but a dear, dear friend. Aaron Shapiro, Michael Lobel and all at Shapiro and Lobel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRASER, ANN BREWER,
description: FRASER-Ann Brewer, 98, surrounded by family, died peacefully on Sunday, October 15th in her beloved cabin in Newcomb, NY. She was married to George E. Brewer, Jr. for 45 years and is survived by her daughters, Effie Kimball, Ann Knox, her daughter-in-law Charlotte Brewer, 13 grandchildren and 20 great-granchildren. Her sons, Michael and George Fraser, predeceased her. Born in NYC, she attended the Brearley School and graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1923. During World War II, while her husband was overseas, she served with the Red Cross and took in a war-displaced English family of five. She was Chairman of the Board of the New York School of Social Work at Columbia University and served on the boards of St. Faith's Home, Tarrytown, NY and Camphill Village, Copake, NY. A long-time resident of NYC, she was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. In 1990 she moved to Collington, a retirement community near Washington, DC. There will be a service in Newcomb on October 21 and a later memorial service at Collington, MD. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Ann Brewer Memorial at the Student Conservation Association, PO Box 550, Charlestown, NH 03603.

title: A Plan to Offer High Schoolers Better Choices
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has proposed a far-reaching plan to change the way most students are assigned to New York City high schools, with an emphasis on creating more appealing choices for students in their own neighborhoods.

title: Balancing Acts, With Contrast And Some Risk
description: Some concert programs strike a lovely balance without seeming to try, and the double bill of duets presented last Friday night at the Stanley Kaplan Penthouse by Jazz at Lincoln Center did it right. The tenor saxophonist Joe Lovano and the pianist Gonzalo Rubalcaba gave bravura performances together, in an almost actorly display of strength and craft; the guitarist Jim Hall and the bassist Scott Colley, by contrast, put on an understated and humorous set.

title: Weaving Tassels On Rock's Fringe
description: HOPE springs eternal at the CMJ Music Marathon, the annual rock convention and showcase that opened last night in dozens of clubs around New York City.

title: Kucks Remembers Old Glory in Game 7
description: Given the two prevalent baseball themes on people's minds, it was not surprising that Johnny Kucks was asked by a friend the other day if he recalled how long it took for him to pitch the last Subway Series game 44 years ago.

title: Some Prosecutors Willing To Review DNA Evidence
description: For nearly 16 years, Carlos Lavernia, a Cuban refugee, has languished in a Texas prison since being found guilty of a 1983 rape that he swore he did not commit.

title: Yanks Don't Need to Go Right When Mets Go Left
description: The traditional method of beating the Yankees has been to throw left-handers against them, to combat lineups stacked with left-handed hitters. The Mets are well equipped to do this and will start the left-handers Al Leiter and Mike Hampton in Games 1 and 2.

title: Connecticut Approves Plan For Takeover By Con Ed
description: Over the objections of Connecticut's attorney general, the state's regulatory authority gave its final approval yesterday to Consolidated Edison's proposed $3.8 billion acquisition of Northeast Utilities.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Calendar column of the Dining section on Wednesday about a tasting of foods today at the stalls and cafes of Grand Central Terminal misstated the starting time. It is 3 p.m., not 10 a.m.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LABRECQUE, THOMAS G.
description: LABRECQUE-Thomas G. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York, N.Y., on November 8 at 10:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorials be sent to: the Thomas G. Labrecque Leadership Institute of Red Bank Catholic High School, 112 Broad St, Red Bank, NJ 07701 or Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center - Lung Cancer Research Fund, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCVEIGH, CHARLES S., JR.
description: McVEIGH-Charles S., Jr. Memorial Service on Monday October 23, 2000, at 2 P.M. at The Church Of The Advent, 555 Advent Street, Westbury, Long Island.

title: New Kind of Vaccine, Made of DNA, Controls AIDS Virus in Early Tests on Monkeys
description: Using a new kind of vaccine, researchers report that they have been able to control a particularly lethal strain of AIDS virus in monkeys. The vaccine, made of DNA, did not prevent the animals from becoming infected, but it did prevent them from becoming ill, keeping the level of the virus so low that it was virtually undetectable in the animals' blood.

title: NASA Tests System to Warn Of Runway Collision Dangers
description: Everything the captain could see through the clear night air indicated a perfect landing: gear down, engines rumbling at idle, and the autopilot receiving signals from the ground that would bring his lumbering Boeing 757 right over the middle of three parallel runways, touching down amid the thousand skid marks of the landing zone. It looked like another one of the 20,000 unremarkable jet landings a day.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: BID FOR COAL PRODUCER
description: QCT Resources Ltd. said it recommended that shareholders accept a $465 million takeover bid by the Broken Hill Proprietary Company and Mitsubishi Development after they secured almost half of QCT's shares. QCT, a coal producer, said the latest offer of $1.20 a share and a 10-cent dividend still undervalues the company, but with major shareholders, like Santos Ltd., accepting the offer, the bidders are likely to gain control. Broken Hill and Mitsubishi, a unit of the Mitsubishi Corporation, want more control over two coal mining joint ventures they own with QCT in Queensland at a time when the price of coking coal used by steel makers is expected to rise. Australia is the world's biggest coal exporter.

title: Americans, on a Roll, Leave the International Team in a Big Hole
description: After the first day of the Presidents Cup, the United States had all the momentum and the International Team had none of the points.

title: Belgrade Journal; From the Wings, a Prince Takes the Stage in Serbia
description: Among the diplomats and foreign leaders flocking here to congratulate Serbia and greet the newly elected Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, this week, the heir to the Yugoslav throne, Crown Prince Alexander, has stood out in his enthusiasm.

title: An American Calculus: Immigration and Sprawl
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Candid Return

title: 'Just One Time'
description: Directed by Lane Janger

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DIGITAL BIOMETRICS, Minnetonka, Minn., the maker of fingerprinting and identification devices, agreed to buy the closely held Visionics, Jersey City, for $36.8 million in stock to develop new security products.

title: Crime Family Dealt a Blow, Police Say
description: With arrests in three states early yesterday, federal authorities and the police announced a racketeering indictment that they said would devastate the DeCavalcante crime family and break its grip on businesses and labor unions in New York and New Jersey.

title: Export Surge Helps Reduce Trade Deficit
description: The nation's trade deficit narrowed in August to a six-month low as a surge in exports of aircraft engines, computer chips and other capital goods reduced the effect of record imports, government figures showed today.

title: People
description: Jerry Lee, managing director at Health Medical Consumer Advertising and Marketing, New York, part of the Omnicom Group, was named president at TBWA/Health, New York, a new division of the TBWA/ Chiat/Day unit of TBWA Worldwide, also part of Omnicom, that is absorbing the employees and clients of Health Medical Consumer.

title: A Republican Plan For Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Buffett Shows Gillette's Chief the Door
description: Warren E. Buffett, the world's most famous long-term investor, finally lost patience with Gillette yesterday.

title: You Talkin' to My Daughter? That Better Be All, Buddy
description: Meet the Parents

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS GAINS. Natural gas fell as warm weather was seen keeping heating demand low. In New York, natural gas for November delivery fell 27.7 cents, or 5.3 percent, to $4.951 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: AVENTIS DROPS STARLINK DEADLINE
description: The creator of StarLink corn, Aventis CropScience, said it had dropped a deadline of today for farmers to sign up to sell the bioengineered corn back to the company. Aventis has also extended the buyback program to cover other corn crops grown within 660 feet of StarLink fields, some of which may have been fertilized by drifting StarLink pollen. In addition, according to Tom Miller, the Iowa attorney general, Aventis agreed this week that farmers can participate in the buyback without giving up their right to sue the company. Mr. Miller said Aventis had also agreed to pay for storage and transportation to approved distribution sites for corn that has become intermingled with the StarLink varieties. Aventis has been struggling to contain the StarLink corn, which is approved only for animal feed and industrial use, since reports last month that it had shown up in taco shells. Barnaby J. Feder

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, ALFRED
description: SCHREIBER-Alfred. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Alfred Schreiber beloved husband of our devoted member Evelyn Schreiber. Deepest sympathy to her, her daughter Linda Bejoian, grandchildren Tyler and Kasper, and the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Jane and Louise Wilson
description: 303 Gallery

title: Lazio Goes to Kissinger for Cachet in Foreign Policy
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio staked a claim on foreign policy and women's issues yesterday, meeting with Henry A. Kissinger and then, an hour later, plopping down on a couch with his wife for an interview with Barbara Walters and the other hosts of the ABC program ''The View.''

title: After Attacks, Bush Strikes Back Hard in Defense of His Social Security Proposal
description: With the Democrats running new commercials attacking his Social Security plan, Gov. George W. Bush struck back hard yesterday, contending that Vice President Al Gore was pitting ''grandparents against grandchildren'' for political gain.

title: Public Interests; One for Mo, Mo for All
description: ''Ah am talkin' 'bout YOU!'' cried 5Al Gore at a big rally in Flint, Mich. Populist Al is back, sounding as if he had just emerged from the overnight shift at the steel mill. Like George W. Bush, Mr. Gore is more Southern on some days than others. The one thing we know about the next administration is that it will be headed by a guy with hot and cold running accents.

title: Mets and Yanks Warming Up to the Task
description: Mike Hampton hits and acts like an everyday player, right down to his attitude about watching games from the bench. He hates it -- ''I pull my hair out,'' the Mets left-hander said -- but one of the few things he enjoys is watching Al Leiter bat. Hampton hit .274 this year, Leiter .053.

title: Where Ego Sashays In Style
description: THE Guggenheim Museum has served up another plateau of urban history: a retrospective of the Milanese fashion designer Giorgio Armani. This show may lack the depth of the Guggenheim's other urban excavations, like ''The Great Utopia,'' ''The Italian Metamorphosis: 1943-1968'' and the recent ''1900: Art at the Crossroads.'' But what it lacks in depth it makes up for with sparkle. Organized by Germano Celant and Harold Koda, ''Giorgio Armani'' polishes up a familiar facet of urban life: the grand promenade through flattering reflections of ourselves (superimposed on fantasies of how much better we would look if we could afford nice clothes) that we take through the great shopping streets of Paris, Milan and New York. The show's pretext may be Mr. Armani, but its real subject is autoerotica, and the perverse generosity of which extreme narcissists are capable. And the show does it without mirrors.

title: Official Who Embarrassed Bush Is Removed
description: The Texas commissioner of health, whose public comments had become a embarrassment for Gov. George W. Bush, was placed on an indefinite leave of absence today.

title: Man Charged in Terrorism Asks to Take the Stand
description: A man charged in a global terrorism conspiracy told a federal judge yesterday that he wanted to take the witness stand and give his own account of a lengthy interrogation he underwent in 1998 in Germany before he was brought to the United States for trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTENBAUM, ANN
description: KESTENBAUM - Ann. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Sherri Keiler-Lane and Marilyn Zinovoy. Dear sister of Max Butan. Adored grandmother of Stacey, David, Sandy and Scott. Services today 12:45PM at ''Gutterman's'' Funeral Home (Parkside Building), 98-60 Queens Blvd., corner 66th Ave., Forest Hills, NY.

title: Opponents of India Dam Project Bemoan Green Light From Court
description: Anti-dam crusaders, including the novelist Arundhati Roy, expressed sorrow today that a Supreme Court decision will allow the long-stalled construction of a huge dam on the Narmada River to resume. They say the dam project will destroy the homes and livelihoods of hundreds of thousands whose needs have been neglected.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Defending Attendance Record
description: The Lazio campaign released a new 30-second advertisement yesterday in response to a Clinton ad that attacked Rick A. Lazio for missing votes this year in the House of Representatives in order to campaign. It is also the first ad to directly criticize Hillary Rodham Clinton's failed 1993 attempt to overhaul health care.

title: To the Sea They Went, Roving and Raiding
description: At the center of everything in the gallery there is the ship, where it should be. The exhibition, after all, is about the Vikings, people of the sea, traders and raiders of the coasts of the known world, explorers and settlers out in the unknown.

title: Greenspan Says Oil Prices Haven't Done Much Harm
description: The low-inflation new economy is up against an old-economy challenge -- a surge in oil prices -- and so far the new economy is holding its own, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today.

title: Arthur Goldberg, Builder of Casino Empire, Dies at 58
description: Arthur M. Goldberg, who parlayed a small stake in a struggling gambling company into control of the nation's largest casino operator, died yesterday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 58.

title: INJURY SIDELINES ISLES' MUCKALT
description: The Islanders departed for tonight's game in Atlanta in search of a victory and without wing Bill Muckalt, who will be out four to six weeks with a dislocated right shoulder sustained in the loss to Anaheim on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDEN, FREDERICK E.
description: WALDEN-Frederick E. On Oct. 18th, 2000. Beloved brother of Eleanor. Dear cousin of Reverend Kenneth Nilsen and Robert A. Nilsen. Devoted friend of Bernice Bengtsson and Dorothy Weatherington. Visiting Friday, 7-9 PM, at the Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Ave., Brooklyn. Religious Service Friday evening, 8 P.M. Funeral Saturday, at 10 A.M.

title: MEDTRONIC AGREES TO PAY $225 MILLION FOR PERCUSURGE
description: Medtronic Inc., the No. 1 manufacturer of pacemakers, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held PercuSurge Inc. for about $225 million in stock. The addition of PercuSurge, based in Santa Rosa, Calif., gives Medtronic, based in Minneapolis, the leading product to capture material dislodged during artery-clearing procedures and prevent it from traveling to other blood vessels or the brain, analysts said. PercuSurge's product, already used in Europe, is in clinical trials in the United States. Arthur D. Collins Jr., Medtronic's chief operating officer, said the market for the product could be about $420 million in three years. Shares of Medtronic fell 50 cents, to $53.44.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN AGREES TO BUY UNIT OF FIRST TENNESSEE
description: Chase Manhattan, based in New York, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the corporate and municipal trust unit of the First Tennessee National Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Chase will gain 1,400 accounts representing $20 billion in outstanding debt. First Tennessee, based in Memphis, said it would take a pretax gain of about $33 million in the fourth quarter. Last month, Chase's institutional trust unit bought the corporate trust business of Fuji Bank and Trust. Chase shares rose $2.06, to $38.94. First Tennessee rose $2.06, to $21.38.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Checking Tire Pressure From the Driver's Seat
description: WHATEVER the flaw that causes some Firestone tires to shed their treads, with sometimes lethal results, the company says that failure is highly unlikely if the tires are inflated properly.

description: FARENGA-William T. We all extend our deepest sympathy to Henry O. Golightly, dear friend of William. Just One Break, Inc.

title: Hurley's Retirement Becomes Official
description: Bobby Hurley has retired from professional basketball, a spokeswoman for his agent, David Falk, said, officially ending Hurley's once-promising career. Hurley, 29, was a high school standout at St. Anthony of Jersey City and an all-American guard at Duke University.

title: COOPER TIRE SAYS IT WILL CUT 1,100 JOBS AND CLOSE PLANTS
description: The Cooper Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,100 jobs, or 4.8 percent of its work force, and close, sell or consolidate 18 plants and offices to cut costs. Cooper will take a charge of $35 million to $40 million in the fourth quarter to cover the closings and job cuts. The announcement came as Cooper said third-quarter net income fell 32 percent, to $23.4 million, or 32 cents a share, from $34.6 million, or 45 cents, in the period last year. Sales rose 59 percent, to $843.6 million, from $531.9 million, primarily from its acquisition of the auto-parts maker Standard Products. The company will close plants immediately in Luzerne and Mio, Mich., and in Rocky Mount, N.C. It will also close the Oliver Rubber plant in Dallas.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: McCall Criticizes Pataki For Opposing Tax Rise
description: Two days after Gov. George E. Pataki declared that he opposed any significant increase in property taxes as part of Nassau County's fiscal solution, the state comptroller sternly criticized his stance yesterday.

title: Article 2000102090787422678 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Surviving The Lockup One Way Or Another
description: As a director Steve Buscemi inspires actors to do some of their most finely shaded work, and in his thoughtful new film, the prison drama ''Animal Factory,'' his performers expose aspects of themselves that are off-putting and compelling. Willem Dafoe steals the picture with his comic timing, something that hasn't happened since his turn as a military school honcho on an episode of ''The Simpsons.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about reaction in Beijing to the awarding of the Nobel Prize in Literature to an exiled Chinese writer misspelled his given name. He is Gao Xingjian, not Xingjiang.

title: Nasdaq Climbs As Technology Stocks Surge
description: Technology stocks soared yesterday, lifting the Nasdaq composite index to its third-biggest gain ever as upbeat profit reports and a sunny forecast by Nokia dispelled many of the clouds hanging over Wall Street.

title: UNOCAL STEPS UP INVESTMENT
description: The California-based oil company Unocal said it would invest $500 million in Thailand next year, up from $400 million this year. The company recently struck oil in waters off Thailand and hopes to begin pumping up to 15,000 barrels of crude oil a day from the offshore field next year. Unocal's natural gas fields in the Gulf of Thailand already supply 30 percent of the country's power needs, according to the company, and generated 34.6 billion baht ($800 million) in revenue last year. Unocal also supplies Thailand with natural gas from a joint venture in neighboring Myanmar. Wayne Arnold

description: PENGUINS 3, SENATORS 3: Martin Straka scored with 22 seconds left in regulation to lift the Pittsburgh Penguins to a tie with Ottawa.

Contributions may be made to Brain Injury Association of Colorado, 6825 E. Tennessee Ave, Denver, CO 80224 or charity of your choice.

description: And there you have it: Game One of the World Series. I'm Bob Costas, and with me is our analyst Joe Morgan. Joe, who won?''

title: Afghan Opium Crop Declines, but Central Asians Still Worry
description: Opium production in Afghanistan dropped 28 percent this year because of widespread drought and a United Nations crop-substitution program, the senior United Nations drug-control official said today.

description: Minutes before the House was to vote on a measure condemning the mass killings of Armenians in Turkey 85 years ago as genocide, J. Dennis Hastert, the speaker, withdrew the resolution tonight, citing President Clinton's warnings that a vote could harm national security and hurt relations with Turkey, a NATO ally.

title: CHIEF QUITS AT ALTAVISTA
description: Rod Schrock, left, has resigned as chief executive of AltaVista, the company said. AltaVista, an Internet portal that is majority-owned by CMGI Inc., said its president, Greg Memo, and chief financial officer, Ken Barber, would share Mr. Schrock's duties until a replacement was found. Last month, the company said that it would lay off 25 percent of its staff as part of cost-cutting measures aimed at saving as much as $120 million. Such steps are becoming increasingly common as Internet companies, concerned by the volatile stock market, focus less on rapid, expensive growth and more on profitability. Laura M. Holson

title: TEXTRON TO CLOSE PLANTS AND CUT JOBS OVER NEXT YEAR
description: Textron Inc., a maker of helicopters, jets and industrial products, said yesterday that it would close plants, eliminate jobs and take $200 million in pretax charges over the next four or five quarters to cut costs. The company, based in Providence, R.I., has not determined which plants will be closed or how many jobs may be cut, a spokeswoman said. Third-quarter profit rose 8.2 percent and sales increased 16 percent, but the company said that sales dropped at its OmniQuip business, a maker of light construction equipment. OmniQuip was also unprofitable in the quarter. Shares of Textron rose 50 cents, to $43.38. They have dropped 44 percent this year.

title: Dreams Chained in Place Restrain a Pair of Lives
description: OFF KECK ROAD

description: The Travel Slide Show Archive

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, RUTH M.
description: BERGER-Ruth M. Of South Salem, NY, died peacefully at home on October 18, surrounded by her loved ones. She was, and always will be, the beloved and adored wife of Alan and adored and cherished mother of Danielle. Our hearts ache with the suddenness and shock of losing you. You brought from your beloved Switzerland a zest for life and you filled our days with love and joy. We will always hear your song, see your face, and cherish the love we shared. And in all that we do we will always be guided by your loving and generous spirit.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about television ratings for the three debates between Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore misstated viewership for the last one, on Tuesday. It drew more viewers than the Oct. 11 debate, but not more than the one on Oct. 3.

title: Financing Films on a Personal Basis
description: BOMBAY  Bharat Shah, India's biggest financier, says there are no lawyers present when he agrees to finance a movie, contracts are a perfunctory four pages long and he almost never reads the script.

title: Article 2000102091395171310 -- No Title
description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

title: A Revival Of 'Capeman'?
description: It was one of the most expensive and contentious flops in Broadway history, an $11 million disaster that seemed to inspire record levels of nastily expressed joy in a business famed for super-strength schadenfreude. The show, Paul Simon's ''Capeman,'' closed in March 1998 after 68 performances and countless swipes at its pop-icon composer.

description: THE OTHER CONTEST
