title: Cleaning Graffiti-Scarred Areas, a Wall at a Time
description: The homeboys hit the street at 5 the other morning before the sun and the shooters had a chance to get up and out.

title: Stalling Bedtime While the Batter Is Up
description: Parents beware: Your kids have strategies, part stealth and part seduction, to defy regular bedtimes for the duration of the Subway Series.

title: A Verdict on Travelgate
description: The independent counsel Robert Ray has concluded that Hillary Rodham Clinton was ''factually false'' in sworn testimony about her role in the firing of seven members of the White House travel staff in 1993. At the same time he has concluded that he cannot prove beyond a reasonable doubt in court that her statements were ''knowingly false,'' and therefore will not pursue criminal charges against her. Judging from the voluminous public record, Mr. Ray's decision to drop the case is legally sound. Judging from the same record, his characterization of Mrs. Clinton's account of her role in the matter also seems on the mark.

title: SINGAPORE AIRLINES ORDERS SIX PLANES FROM BOEING
description: Boeing said yesterday that it had won a $1.3 billion order for six 747-400F freighter planes from Singapore Airlines, the world's No. 5 cargo carrier, in what is Boeing's largest order for the aircraft this year. The airline also renewed options for nine more planes. For the six firm 747-400F orders, the $1.3 billion price tag includes a $218 million order for 24 engines made by United Technologies' Pratt & Whitney unit. Also yesterday, GKN P.L.C., a British aerospace and automotive parts maker, said that it would buy Boeing's St. Louis-based military plane structures unit for $61 million.

title: From Roman Rarities to Mickey Mouse, a Global Bazaar
description: Emerging triumphant from acres of shipping containers and oceans of bubble wrap, the International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show has ensconced itself in the Seventh Regiment Armory for its 12th annual appearance in New York.

title: TRIAD HOSPITALS IN $1.4 BILLION DEAL FOR QUORUM
description: Triad Hospitals said yesterday that it would buy the Quorum Health Group for $1.4 billion in cash and stock, and $1 billion in assumed debt. The deal would make Triad the third-largest hospital company. Triad is paying $3.50 in cash and 0.4107 share for each share of Quorum. That values Quorum at $16.13 a share, 18 percent above its closing price on Wednesday. The acquisition unites two former HCA units. Quorum was HCA's hospital-management division. Triad shares started trading in May 1999 after Columbia/HCA spun off its hospitals in smaller cities. After the purchase, Triad will have 53 hospitals and 14 surgery centers with revenue of about $3 billion. Triad shares fell $1, to $29.75, and Quorum shares fell 75 cents, to $12.88.

title: Summer Delays Take Toll on UAL; Northwest Beats Expectations
description: Paying the price for the record delays and flight cancellations of the summer, the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, reported a greater-than-expected loss yesterday for the third quarter, while Northwest Airlines exceeded Wall Street expectations.

title: The Excitement Spreads
description: Buses, subway cars and even some of the landmark buildings in Manhattan soon will be caught up in the Subway Series frenzy. The efforts come, not surprisingly, courtesy of Major League Baseball, which yesterday unveiled at City Hall what it is calling its ''Pledge Your Allegiance'' campaign.

title: Tyson or Golota Would Benefit From Real Fight
description: As carnivalesque as the atmosphere has been in anticipation of Friday night's heavyweight fight between Mike Tyson and Andrew Golota, if something truly odd should happen -- like a clean fight -- the bout has a chance to be entertaining and even revealing.

title: Yankees Add Canseco
description: Jose Canseco is back on the Yankees' roster. Even though he probably will be used only as a pinch-hitter, Canseco said yesterday that he is ready to help his team with his legs and glove, too.

title: Study Finds That Many Large Companies Pay No Taxes
description: Goodyear, Texaco, Colgate-Palmolive, MCI WorldCom and eight other large corporations earned more than $12.2 billion in profits in 1996 through 1998, but none of them ended up owing corporate income taxes over that period, according to a study released yesterday. Indeed, as a group, the companies received $535 million in credits or refunds, the report found.

title: Black & Decker Buyback
description: The Black & Decker Corporation, the world's biggest maker of power tools, said today that it would increase its stock buyback program to five million shares from two million shares. The five million shares are worth $162 million at current market prices. The buyback, which will take place over an unspecified time, represents about 6 percent of Black & Decker's stock outstanding. Black & Decker, based in Towson, says it regards its stock as undervalued. The shares are 38 percent below their 52-week high of $52.38, which was set in January.

title: Reported Plea Bargaining in Turnpike Shooting Causes Concern in New Jersey
description: Several New Jersey civil rights leaders and black lawmakers said today they are concerned that state officials are preparing to offer a plea bargain to the two state troopers who shot three unarmed minority men during a traffic stop in 1998, in order to avoid a prolonged criminal trial focusing on racial profiling.

title: Buyer Is Leaving Initiative Media
description: Bill Croasdale, one of the best-known national broadcast television media buyers, is leaving his position as a consultant to Lou Schultz, chairman and chief executive at Initiative Media North America in Los Angeles, part of the Initiative Media Worldwide unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

Former Chairman of the Foreign Language Dept. at Lafayette High School in Brooklyn. Services Friday, October 20, 10:30AM at Dimiceli & Sons, 182 Lexington Ave, NY, NY.

title: Iraq Poverty Said to Undermine Food Program
description: The administrator of the United Nations ''oil for food'' program in Iraq said today that although that distribution system ranked among the world's best, the lot of ordinary Iraqis has failed to improve because their living conditions remain mired in chronic deprivation.

title: U.N.-NATO Court Setup in Kosovo Faulted
description: The joint United Nations-NATO administration of Kosovo has been harshly criticized for running a justice system below international standards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, PONY BOUCHE,
description: SIMON-Pony Bouche, 93, a Millbrook resident, died Saturday, October 14, 2000 at Sharon Hospital, Sharon, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Pony Simon Scholarship Fund at the Kildonan School, 425 Morse Hill Road, Amenia, New York 12501. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Peter's Church in Lithgow, New York at 4:00 P.M., on Sunday, October 22nd. Allen Funeral Home, Franklin Avenue, Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Plan to Seal Some Criminal Records Debated
description: A proposal to seal lower-level convictions of some nonviolent criminals drew the appearances at City Hall yesterday of former mayor Edward I. Koch, who argued the merits of the measure, and Police Commissioner Bernard Kerik, who staunchly opposed it.

title: Sports of The Times; Speaking Up For 2 Owners Who Don't
description: THE last time the Yankees lost a World Series, George Steinbrenner said he was sorry. ''I want to sincerely apologize to the people of New York and to the fans of the New York Yankees everywhere for the performance of the Yankee team in the World Series,'' the owner declared.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

description: ORGEL-Jerome J. DDS. On October 16, 2000. Beloved husband of Marion. Devoted father of David, Carole, Josh and Andy. Loving grandfather of twelve. Services private.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Oct. 11 about a campaign by New York parents for a return to traditional neighborhood high schools misstated the address of the Lab School for Collaborative Studies, a magnet school that draws students from all over the city. It is at 333 West 17th Street. Another Lab School, at 1700 Third Avenue, is an elementary school.

title: Northern Ireland's Perilous Prospects
description: Peace in Northern Ireland is once again precarious. Support for the Good Friday peace agreement signed in 1998 has dropped dangerously among Protestants, mainly over the issues of a new name for Northern Ireland's police and the Irish Republican Army's reluctance to give up its weapons. Later this month the council of the Ulster Unionist Party, the major Protestant party in the peace agreement, will meet. While it is likely that the party's leader, David Trimble, who has become a courageous champion of the peace agreement, will keep his job for the present, the party's council will probably pass resolutions that would sabotage the peace agreement by pulling the party out of the process soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, HARRY
description: COOPER-Harry. Legendary golf professional, inspired and touched so many, passed away October 17. Services Friday, October 20, from 7 PM to 9 PM & Saturday, October 21, 9 AM-10 AM at the Graham Funeral Home, Rye, New York. COOPER-Harry E. The Board of Governors and Members of Metropolis Country Club note with saddness the loss of Harry Cooper an Honorary Member and Our Club Professional for 26 years. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Emma. Jay M. Rosen, President Corey B. Rabin, Secretary

title: EMPLOYMENT RISES
description: Unemployment in New York City continued to drop last month, and has declined sharply over the last year, according to figures released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor. After adjustment for seasonal factors, the jobless rate in the city fell to 5.6 percent, from 5.8 percent in August and 6.7 percent a year ago. The rest of the state did not fare as well in September; the unemployment rate rose slightly, to 3.9 percent, which was also the national rate. A year ago, both upstate New York and the nation had jobless rates of 4.2 percent. The end of the communication workers' strike against Verizon caused an unusually big increase in the number of people working in September. But job growth has been strong over the last year, rising by 2.1 percent in the state and 2.5 percent in New York City. Rockland County experienced the fastest pace of job growth in the state, at 2.9 percent; in Buffalo and Niagara Falls, the number of jobs edged up only 0.3 percent.

title: War Crimes Court Rejects Rwandan's Appeal of Life Sentence
description: Six years after 500,000 civilians were killed in a mass frenzy in Rwanda, the country's former prime minister learned today that he would spend life in prison for the crime of genocide after a United Nations tribunal rejected his appeal.

title: It's Bollywood!/'They Can't Compete With Us in Emotions' : Indian Movies Speak to a Global Audience
description: KUALA LUMPUR  By the time India's No. 1 film star, Shah Rukh Khan, had finished answering questions in a hotel conference room here, he had deflected one marriage proposal, signed dozens of autographs requested by starry-eyed women and posed with several groups of camera-toting fans.

A graduate-school dropout, stand-up comedian and aspiring writer, Ms. Query -- shown in an early home-movie clip reading ''Free to Be . . . You and Me'' with her mother -- has also worked as a stripper at a San Francisco peep-show house called the Lusty Lady.

description: To the Editor:

title: ANOTHER SEAT BELT RECALL IN BRAZIL
description: The Brazilian unit of the Italian carmaker Fiat plans to recall about 400,000 of its Palio 1.0 cars to reinforce the seat belts. A weakness in the seat belts was detected after a local consumer safety magazine put the car through a series of crash tests. According to Fiat, no accidents have been reported where the seat belts have failed. The recall announcement came less than a week after the Brazilian unit of General Motors recalled 1.32 million Corsa cars for a similar problem. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Caps' First Victory Comes Over Devils
description: Uncharacteristic failures by the defending Stanley Cup champion Devils resulted in a 5-2 loss last night in Washington to a Capitals team that had gone without a victory in its first six games.

title: EATING OUT
description: Mixing Cuisines

title: Salvadoran General Admits He Knew of Abuses
description: The retired head of the Salvadoran National Guard admitted in court today that he knew that his troops, five of whom were convicted in the killings of four American churchwomen in 1980, had been involved in the torture and killings of civilians when he was appointed to lead the guard in 1979.

title: Alfonzo Grows on the Field and in the Dugout
description: The scene was hidden by the dugout roof, but may have been the most surprising development for the Mets in the National League Championship Series. On Monday night, with a chance to clinch a World Series berth, the Mets had loaded the bases in the fourth inning -- and the normally low-key Edgardo Alfonzo was standing in the dugout, yelling.

title: A Family's Only Hope Lost at the Altar of Pride
description: Things are grievously stressed in the tenement home of the Boyle family when the curtain goes up on ''Juno and the Paycock,'' Sean O'Casey's bitter drama set in 1922 Dublin during the Irish civil war.

title: Yemenis Link Bomb Inquiry to Border Region and a Somali
description: The inquiry into the attack on the destroyer Cole has led investigators to a mountainous region on the eastern border with Saudi Arabia that has been a stronghold of Islamic groups returning from the war against Soviet forces in Afghanistan, American and Yemeni officials said today.

title: 'The Tavern'
description: Directed by Walter Foote

title: Japanese Government Raises Forecast of Growth to 1.5%
description: The Japanese government raised its economic growth forecast today, saying its previous estimate was too cautious in light of robust corporate spending and an expected increase in consumer spending.

title: PROFIT DOUBLES AT SOFTWARE MAKER
description: SAP A.G. said third-quarter profit doubled as sales of Internet business-management software rose. Net income at the world's largest maker of business management software rose to 88 million euros ($74 million), or 0.28 euro a preferred share, from 45 million euros, or 0.14 euro, in the same quarter a year ago. Sales increased 27 percent to 1.42 billion euros. The rebound was smaller than expected, because of disappointing sales in the United States, which is SAP's largest market, analysts said. SAP shares fell as much as 20.40 euros to 223 euros. Earnings were driven by sales of SAP's Internet software, mySAP.com, which rose to 294 million euros and amounted to 61 percent of all software sales, up from 47 percent in the second quarter.

title: 2 MANUFACTURERS ARE SET TO MERGE IN $40 BILLION DEAL
description: The United Technologies Corporation, one of the last old-style conglomerates that makes everything from jet engines to elevators, is expected to buy Honeywell International Inc. for about $40.3 billion in stock, according to executives close to the talks.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Sunday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Campaign Facts and Fantasies
description: Both presidential candidates used their final debate this week to set up their stretch drives to the election. Gov. George W. Bush proclaimed himself the cure for partisan bickering in Washington and painted Vice President Al Gore as a big-spending, big-government liberal. But Mr. Gore came away with two overriding issues to exploit in the closing weeks. He hammered away at Mr. Bush's tax giveaway to the rich, and he forced Mr. Bush to acknowledge that his partial privatization of Social Security would divert $1 trillion from the surplus into private accounts, siphoning off funds that will be needed in the future to pay benefits to retirees.

title: Everglades Restoration Plan Passes House, With Final Approval Seen
description: The House approved one of the largest environmental-restoration projects in the nation's history today, voting decisively for a $7.8 billion plan intended to revive the Florida Everglades over the next four decades.

title: Village Harassed Landlord Who Rented to Blacks, Jury Finds
description: A federal jury has found the village of East Rockaway discriminated against one of its local businessmen because he rented apartments to minorities. The jury awarded the businessman, Robert Gunning of East Rockaway, $750,000 in compensation for violations of his constitutional right to equal protection and due process.

title: For Clemens, No Start at Shea Is No Secret
description: Joe Torre's team meetings are secret, held with the thick blue clubhouse doors closed, a jacketed sentry posted outside. But deciphering his private message can sometimes be simple: just listen to his players afterward. They often echo his words, like a campaign mantra.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSING, LOUIS
description: MESSING-Louis. On October 18, 2000 at age 89. Devoted husband of Ruth. Loving father of Arnold, Norma and Shelley. Cherished grandfather of Cheryl, Ilene and Noah. May his memory be a blessing.

title: The Way It Was, in the Booth, and the Way It Will Be
description: Forty-four years ago, Bob Wolff was the voice of the Washington Senators when he landed his biggest national break: the Gillette Safety Razor Company chose him to call the World Series alongside Bob Neal, a Cleveland Indians announcer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREIBERG, SYLVIA
description: FREIBERG-Sylvia 7/15/11-10/20/98 Having grown up poor in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, she never lost her social conscience. We miss her humor and her insights during this election and throughout the year. Life isn't the same without her. The Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASRI, DR. ALBERT S.
description: BASRI-Dr. Albert S. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a longtime friend, esteemed pathologist and valued member of the Lakewood, NJ, Jewish community and Iraqi Jewish community. He and his wife, Annette Iny Basri, highly respected member of YU's Sephardic Council of Overseers, provided scholarship aid for Sephardic students at Yeshiva College, Stern College for Women, and YU High Schools, and supported projects of the YU Women's Organization and YU Museum. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Annette; children, Dr. Raymond (and Ava) Basri, Dr. William Ezra (and Nancy) Basri, and Carole Basri; grandchildren; and the entire family. Min hashamayim tenuhamu. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Dual Purpose of a U.S.-Jordan Trade Pact
description: The United States plans to sign a wide-ranging free trade agreement with Jordan next week, bolstering a partner in the troubled Middle East peace effort while helping Vice President Al Gore show that he could reinvent the way trade deals are done.

description: To the Editor:

title: Group Presses Whitman for Decision on Aid for Newark Arena
description: Backers of a proposed sports arena here for the New Jersey Nets and the New Jersey Devils gathered today to prod Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to quickly commit state aid to the project, arguing that it had economic and social benefits for both the state and the city.

description: Laurence Miller Gallery

title: WORLD BUSINESS: German Giants to Clash in Britain; Volkswagen and BMW to Vie for Sales to the Very Wealthy
description: The red-brick car assembly plant in the unassuming suburbs of this town in northwest England seems an unlikely front line in a looming clash of titans in the German auto industry.

title: It's Monsters Against Cretins In a Den of Curdled Affluence
description: The charismatic, predatory stranger who through sexual manipulation and bullying takes over a household in which he's either a guest or a servant is a ready-made metaphor for class struggle that the movies have plied for decades. Raw working-class ambition trumps aristocratic ''decadence'' every time. Jon Reiss's film, ''Cleopatra's Second Husband,'' might be described as an American yuppie variation on the theme, even though the class distinctions are blurred.

title: Bush and Gore Mix Jokes And Barbs at Smith Dinner
description: The campaign for president made a rare stop in New York last night, as Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore gave dueling pointed speeches before a white-tie audience that included two people who had, until yesterday, kept a distance from those two presidential candidates: Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick A. Lazio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLUB, DAVID
description: GOLUB-David. Benita Valente, William Stone and Janice Mayer, of Janice Mayer & Associates LLC., mourn the passing of our gifted and cherished collaborator and friend, pianist, Daivd Golub. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Maria, his family, our colleagues at Herbert Barrett Management, and to his many friends worldwide. GOLUB-David. The Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival mourns the sudden loss of our colleague David Golub, a great talent and a great friend over the years. His seasons with us were an honor and a pleasure. We will miss him. Kenneth S. Davidson, Chairman Marya Martin, Artistic Director Elizabeth Ellis Hurwitt, Executive Director

title: It's Fudge But Not Sweet
description: My daughter could write a book about what it's like to have a pesky little brother. Of course, it would have some stiff competition: Judy Blume's classic ''Superfudge,'' which has been adapted into an hourlong musical by Theaterworks/USA.

title: The Devil Made Him Do It, Didn't She?
description: ''Bedazzled'' is about a troubled young man, unhappy with his life and desperate for wealth, love and power, who signs away his immortal soul in exchange for everything he thinks he desires. Does this sound familiar?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARLOWE, RICHARD
description: MARLOWE-Richard. The Board of Governors and we of North Shore Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Richard Marlowe. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Muriel and family. Jerome H. Grossman, President Enid Rosenthal, Secretary

title: As Lilly Ends Prozac Pact, Sepracor Stock Falls Nearly 30%
description: Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that it had terminated its agreement with Sepracor, a small drug company, to make a new version of the antidepressant drug Prozac after some patients taking the new formulation in clinical trials developed abnormal heart rhythms.

description: To the Editor:

title: Subway Series Reflections: A Ride on the Carousel of Time
description: The yearning by New Yorkers for a Subway Series goes back to their grandparents' tales of the glory years when New York had three major league teams and the World Series was as much a part of its calendar as October itself.

title: Boy Is Stabbed in Brooklyn After School-Cafeteria Fight
description: A fight that began in a high school cafeteria ended in the fatal stabbing of a 12-year-old immigrant from Guyana yesterday, the authorities said.

title: Images of Still Water That Always Run Deep
description: ''The minimum you can say about life is that it's wet.''

title: Fewer Catches Not a Concern For Chrebet
description: Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet is not upset that he is averaging fewer than four catches a game, that the running backs Richie Anderson and Curtis Martin are the team's leading receivers. He is not upset that at this rate, he would catch only 56 passes this season, fewer than he has caught in any of his professional seasons, except last year, when he missed five games and caught 48 passes.

title: DOCTORS WIN LABOR RULING
description: The Doctors Council, a union representing salaried physicians, announced yesterday that the National Labor Relations Board had upheld the council's right to represent almost 200 doctors at Metropolitan Hospital in Manhattan. The labor board rejected an appeal by the New York Medical College, which employs the doctors at Metropolitan Hospital. The medical college had asked the labor board to overturn a unionization election held on April 18 in which Metropolitan's doctors voted, 89 to 22, for the Doctors Council.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, HERBIE EDWARD.
description: KLEINMAN-Herbie Edward. Untimely passing October 17, 2000, just shy of his 30th birthday on November 1. Wonderful light of all our lives. Adored son of Nedra and Louis; best friend of brother Eric; beloved friend to so many people from childhood through his adult years. Everyone who met you, loved you Herbie. You enjoyed sports, rock music, and life itself. All of us enjoyed every minute of the time you spent with us. Your laughter and your love has always been our most joyful and treasured inspiration. Your leaving is unbearable for us but your life and love will stay within us in memory and with enduring love. Memorial service to be held at 12:45 PM on Friday, October 20 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street (at Amsterdam Avenue) in New York City. KLEINMAN-Herbie. We are deeply saddened by the tragic death of our friend. We send our deepest sympathies to his parents, Lou and Nedra and his brother and best friend Eric. Herbie, you were a true friend. You brought laughter and joy to our lives. Our group would not have been complete without you. You'll always be remebered in our hearts and memories. Your spirit will live on. We will miss you, Herbie. Love, Annie, Jake, Jeremy, Jay, Andrew, Aaron, Alex and Nessim KLEINMAN-Herbie. The Calhoun School deeply mourns the loss of Herbie Kleinman, Class of 1989. Our heartfelt condolences to his parents, Nedra and Lou and his brother Eric. KLEINMAN-Herbie. Our memories are sweet, our hearts are sad. We will miss you. Evelyn, John, Joe and Jake

title: First Presenting Clothes, Now Himself
description: There was rejoicing in the fashion flocks when the documentary film ''Unzipped'' appeared in 1995. For in that movie, it seemed, was born an heir to the great and terrible Diana Vreeland, the fashion editrix whose biblical pronouncements on style were indeed gospel to men and women of the cloth -- the cloth being, in this case, silk organza or double-faced cashmere.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORN, JACQUELINE L.
description: HORN-Jacqueline L. Jacqueline L. (Jackie) Horn, 69, of Lee's Summit, MO died October 17, 2000 at home. Services will be 1 P.M. Saturday, October 21 at the Lee's Summit Community Church, Lee's Summitt, MO. Cremation, with interment at Longview Memorial Gardens. Visitation will be 7-8:30 P.M., Friday, October 20 at the Church. The family suggests contributions to the Lee's Summit Community Church or Wayside Waifs Animal Shelter. Jackie was born January 2, 1931 in New York, NY. She earned a B.S. degree from Skidmore College, and also attended Case Western Reserve. She was an art teacher, a realtor, a broker, former editor of The Bratenahl (Ohio) Lamplighter, a Sunday School teacher, vacation Bible School teacher, past president of the PTA, past president of the Bratenahl School Board, and a member of the American Contract Bridge League. She is survived by sons; Douglas G. Brown, Keith H. Brown, Chaz D. Horn, all of Lee's Summit, MO. A sister; Marion E. Kelsey of Miami, FL and grandchildren; Naomi R. Brown, Michael K. Brown, Stephanie R. Brown, Rachel J. Brown, Daniel W. Brown, Matthew D. Brown, Tyler R. Horn, Jayme N. Horn all of Lee's Summit, MO. D.W. Newcomer's Longview Funeral Home.

title: QUALCOMM GETS SECOND CHANCE IN CHINA
description: The code division multiple access technology of Qualcomm Inc. has been given a second chance in China, months after the country's second-largest mobile phone company, China Unicom Ltd., said it had decided not to back the system. Qualcomm's technology is a rival to the global system for mobile communications, which is more widely used in China. China Unicom's president, Wang Jianzhou, said Wednesday that his company would take over and expand a trial system using Qualcomm's technology that now serves one million customers, but that Unicom would let ''market demand'' determine which system would survive. The decision came after heavy lobbying by the United States government and Qualcomm's chairman, Irwin Jacobs, who met with China's prime minister, Zhu Rongji, this month. Craig S. Smith

title: Ebay's Net Income in Quarter Topped Wall St. Expectations
description: The Internet auction giant eBay reported quarterly earnings yesterday that beat Wall Street's expectations and offered a sharp contrast to the recent high-technology gloom.

title: A Republican Poverty Victim; Years of Political Work Get Little for Senate Candidate
description: As a high school student during the psychedelic Sixties, he earnestly asked classmates to focus long enough to become Young Republicans. As a seven-term assemblyman and state party chairman, he played a role in so many Republican campaigns that ''trusted lieutenant'' became his honorific. As a congressman, he signed the Contract with America and voted for the impeachment of President Clinton.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUINTA, JACQUELINE
description: GUINTA-Jacqueline. The Board, Staff and neighbors of HamiltonMadison Settlement House mourn the passing of Jackie, an employee of this Settlement House for almost 30 years. She was one of the most loved workers at this Settlement and will be missed by all. Our sincerest sympathy and prayers are extended to her husband, Dominick, her children, Jackie, Ann, Joseph, and her six grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting that donations in memory of Jackie be sent to Hamilton-Madison House, 50 Madison Street, NY, NY 10038. Joseph P. Ritorto, Board President Frank T. Modica, Exec. Director

title: WIRELESS ALLIANCE PLANNED
description: An alliance with Aether Systems has been announced by MicroStrategy. The two would develop a technology combining their wireless technologies and communications software to permit both to offer a broader range of services. The alliance includes a $25 million investment in Strategy.com, a subsidiary of MicroStrategy, by Aether Systems, a worldwide wireless and mobile technology provider. The companies have also assigned a team of engineers to develop MicroStrategy 7M, a wireless communications platform that will be used on a variety of devices. MicroStrategy said it was getting $28 million from other investors, whom it did not identify.

title: JUDGE TELLS HEINZ TO PUT OFF BEECH-NUT ACQUISITION
description: A judge ordered the H. J. Heinz Company yesterday to hold off completing its $185 million buyout of a rival baby-food maker, Beech-Nut, while antitrust enforcers appeal the court's refusal to block the transaction. Under the order issued by Judge James Robertson of United States District Court in Washington, Heinz cannot complete its acquisition of the closely held Milnot Holdings Company, owner of Beech-Nut, while the Federal Trade Commission seeks an emergency injunction from an appeals court to block the merger. The judge gave the F.T.C. until Monday to seek an injunction.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page E1 of Weekend today about the CMJ Music Marathon in New York includes an outdated reference in some copies to a planned appearance by the band Confrontation Camp. The appearance has been canceled.

title: Nearing the End of the Tunnel, Buchanan Glimpses a Sunset
description: He has fought the good fight, surviving nasty party factionalism to get his name onto the ballot in almost every state and obtain $12.6 million in federal campaign money. He has even ridden out three recent hospital visits for gallstone problems.

title: Taxes, the Market and Luck Underlie the Budget Surplus
description: In all the political debate about how to spend the rapidly emerging budget surplus, almost nothing is said about where it came from. It is a patchwork creation, hard to keep sewn together.

title: Taking Aim at Tax Havens, I.R.S. Seeks Credit Card Slips
description: The Internal Revenue Service, struggling against Caribbean havens it suspects of draining away at least $70 billion a year in personal income tax revenue, has set its sights on a new target -- the credit card slips of suspected tax evaders.

title: Residential Real Estate; Harlem Block Transformed After 10-Year Pause
description: After an 18-month renovation, the rundown rows of empty buildings that, like battered bookends, long filled the corners of Morningside Avenue at West 117th and West 118th Streets in central Harlem, have been turned into 49 condominium apartments.

title: Coke Issuing Widespread Pay Increases
description: Struggling to retain employees after a turbulent year, the Coca-Cola Company has instituted sweeping salary increases for the first time in at least two decades, according to company officials.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 8
description: SUNDAY 1 p.m.

title: CHIP MAKER'S EARNINGS RISE
description: Shares of Parthus Technologies increased $3.88, or 9 percent, to $47, a day after the company, an Irish maker of processors for wireless Internet devices, reported a 204 percent increase in third-quarter license revenue and introduced its latest product for mobile computing. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, Parthus had a net loss of $2.3 million on sales of $8.6 million, up 76 percent from a year earlier. Licensing and royalty revenue rose to $4.5 million from $1.5 million in the prior year. The Parthus Info-Stream chip, designed in collaboration with the British mobile device maker Psion, uses Psion's Symbian operating system, but also runs the Linux, Palm OS and Microsoft Pocket PC operating systems. Psion and Motorola have signed licensing agreements to use the chip in future releases of personal digital assistants and cell phones. Previous Parthus chips incorporate global positioning technology into car navigation systems, and wireless audio streaming into MP3 players. Brian Lavery

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: 7-Hour Gun Battle in West Bank Strains the Cease-Fire
description: An army-escorted hike by three dozen Jewish settlers in the hills above Nablus, in the West Bank, touched off a long firefight today that weakened expectations that the two-day-old cease-fire agreement would take hold.

title: Clinton Raises the Stakes on Stopgap Spending Measures
description: President Clinton said today that he would no longer sign multiday, stopgap spending measures, and sought to inject a sense of urgency into slow-moving Congressional deliberations over bills needed to keep the federal government running.

description: ANDORS-Myrtle S. Of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved wife of Nathan. Devoted mother of Jay Andors and Beth Lesser. Cherished mother-inlaw of Steven Lesser. For information call Gutterman-Musicant, 800-522-0588.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUMINER, SHARON
description: HOUMINER - Sharon. Beloved daughter of Ehud and Naomi. Loving sister of Talia, and Orly and Yaacov. Service Monday, 10 AM, Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Rd, White Plains. For information call Plaza Memorial, 212-769-4400.

title: David Golub, 50, Pianist and Conductor Known for Chamber Music
description: David Golub, a pianist and conductor, who was seen as Isaac Stern's accompanist in the 1979 film ''From Mao to Mozart'' and who performed regularly with several chamber ensembles, most notably the Golub-Kaplan-Carr Trio, died on Monday at his home in Milan. He was 50 and lived in Milan and New York.

title: Camby Sending Out Encouraging Signs for Knicks
description: His opponents have not been of the household-name variety, but it is worth noting that Marcus Camby has played exceptionally well in the Knicks' last three games. He has rebounded tenaciously, attacked the rim with aggressiveness and even banged his slender 6-foot-11-inch, 225-pound frame against the competition.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Arts & Leisure on Sunday about the dance company Typical Theater misstated its performance dates at the Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance. They are Oct. 27 and 28, not today and tomorrow.

title: Franks Takes Direct Route To the Voters
description: Representative Bob Franks, the underfinanced underdog vying for the United States Senate, told a group of elderly voters here that his well-heeled opponent was distorting his record on Medicare.

title: U.P.S. Reports Rise In Quarterly Profit
description: United Parcel Service Inc. said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 22 percent as the company, the nation's largest package-delivery concern, handled more international and overnight shipments.

title: A FAT MAGAZINE THINS RANKS
description: Red Herring, the ad-heavy magazine of the Internet industry, laid off 7 percent of its staff yesterday. Christopher J. Alden, interim chief executive of the privately held Red Herring Communications, said online advertising had failed to increase as much as expected. Alex Kuczynski

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABRECQUE, THOMAS G.
description: LABRECQUE-Thomas G. We mourn the untimely death of our partner and friend, Tom Labrecque. His strength of character and commitment to values was an example for us all. Tom's friendship and counsel will be missed. We are thankful that he was part of our lives and we will remember him always for his commitment to excellence. Walter V. Shipley, Retired Chairman and CEO of the Chase Manhattan Corporation William B. Harrison, Jr. Chairman & CEO of the Chase Manhattan Corporation

title: UCAR to Shed 70 Workers
description: UCAR International Inc., the country's largest producer of graphite electrodes, said today that it would lay off 70 workers at its North American plants because of reduced demand for its products. The company, based in Nashville, said it would reduce its inventory and added that the weak euro had also hurt its results. Graphite electrodes are used to generate heat in the production of steel. Last year, UCAR had more than 4,400 employees.

title: When Companies Talk, Who Gets to Listen?; Corporate News Will Soon Flow Simultaneously To Everyone
description: Ever wondered what you were missing from corporate America? No longer will you have to wait for disclosures that could affect your stock portfolio to be filtered through Wall Street. The days of being shut out of conference calls between executives and analysts are coming to an end.

title: A Harbinger Of Strangeness
description: If independent film has a tough time these days, it was no easier in 1983.

title: Once Close to Clinton, Gore Keeps a Distance
description: After eight years together, here is the state of the relationship between President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore: Mr. Gore won't pick up the phone. He doesn't call, and Mr. Clinton doesn't know why.

title: A Republican Plan For Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Arab League Meeting May Seek Balancing Act
description: As their foreign ministers gathered here today in advance of a weekend summit meeting, Arab leaders sought to formulate a unified position that could appease popular demands to punish Israel but also keep the door open to future Arab-Israeli peacemaking.

title: A Master Who Can Perceive Unorthodoxy in the Ordinary
description: Among photography's masters, few have shunned the limelight as resolutely as Robert Frank or been as disinclined as he to revisit the past by making prints of earlier work, which includes, in his case, the iconic images from his 1959 book ''The Americans.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ARTHUR M.
description: GOLDBERG-Arthur M. Untimely passing on October 19, 2000. Arthur was a loving father, husband and brother and beloved grandfather who will live in our hearts forever. Arthur was an extraordinary man who provided warmth, leadership and inspiration to all those whose lives he touched. He will be remembered for his dedication to his family, loyalty to his friends, his business acumen and his numerous philanthropic endeavors. Arthur was internationally renowned for his corporate leadership and vision, most recently as the chief executive of Park Place Entertainment, the world's largest gaming company. At the time of his passing, he was a board member of Villanova Law School, his alma mater, Cardozo Law School, Presbyaterian Hospital and The New York and Presbyterian Hospitals. Arthur was a hero to the many who will cherish his memory long after his passing. He died much too soon of complications arising from bone marrow failure. Arthur is survived by his wife Veronica, his four children, six grandchildren and brother Gary. Interment will be private. The family will be receiving friends at the Arthur Goldberg family residence from 4-8PM on Friday and 2-8PM on Saturday. Gifts in his memory can be made to The Fund for Johns Hopkins Medicine, Attention: Arthur M. Goldberg Memorial Fund, 1620 Mc Elderry Street, Baltimore, MD. 21205. GOLDBERG-Arthur. Was a man of extraordinary energy, commitment and vision. His zest for life and the sense of excitement he brought to running and growing his business was unmatched. I was blessed to have known him for almost a decade. He was a friend and inspiration to me and the people of the MWW Group. We will miss him. Michael W. Kempner and the entire staff of The MWW Group. GOLDBERG-Arthur, Dear Arthur, You were such an important part of our lives. Our memories of you will never be forgotten. ''Relay'', we will miss you. Our thoughts and prayers are with Ronnie, Kerry and Tarek, Wendy and Derek, Jody and Ed, and Michael. Much love, Lisa and Manny Pearlman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMAN, RABBI CHARLES DAVID.
description: LIPPMAN-Rabbi Charles David. The leadership and staff of the Beth Israel Medical Center family join with its Department of Pain Medicine and Palliative Care and the Jacob Perlow Hospice in acknowledging with great sadness the untimely death of our beloved friend and devoted colleague, Charles D. Lippman, Rabbi and Senior Chaplain for Jacob Perlow Hospice. Rabbi Lippman's generosity of heart and spirit that extended to his patients and our staff will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his longterm partner, Alan Frank, his parents, Hy and Elly Lippman, his brother Robert and loved ones. Chuck's death is a tremendous loss to the medical community and we will miss his presence among us. Alan R. Batkin, Chairman, Board of Trustees, Jacob Perlow Hospice Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO, Beth Israel Russell Portenoy, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Pain Medicine and Palliative Care Paul Brenner, Director, Jacob Perlow Hospice LIPPMAN-Rabbi Charles David. The staff of the Jacob Perlow Hospice mourns the unexpected death of our Senior Chaplain, Rabbi Charles David Lippman. We will miss the gentleness of his humor, the wisdom and understanding that he brought to difficult situations, and his unerring ability to work with patients and their families at the time of death. Chuck was a man of great gifts and warmth and he taught us a great deal about life and living. We express our sympathy to his partner, Alan Frank, to his parents, Hy and Elly Lippman, to his brother Robert and to their families. We have lost a wonderful colleague and friend. The staff and volunteers of Jacob Perlow Hospice LIPPMAN-Charles D. The congregation of the Park Avenue Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) shares in the mourning of the death of Rabbi Charles D. Lippman, D.D. We will keep our friends of the Temple of Universal Judaism in our prayers and our hearts extend to Chuck's beloved partner Alan Frank. Rev. Dr. Suzanne Webb, Interim Minister Rev. Dr. Richard Sturm, Moderator LIPPMAN-Rabbi, Dr. Charles D. Suddenly on October 18, 2000 in his 55th year. Cherished life partner of Alan G. Frank. Beloved son of Hy and Elly. Adoring brother of Robert and his wife Rita and the late Florence L. Petrus. Loving uncle of Jeffrey, Jeremy, Matthew and David. Services Sunday, October 22, 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Please make contributions to the charity of your choice in Chuck's name. LIPPMAN-Rabbi Charles D. The entire family of The HealthCare Chaplaincy mourns the sudden death of its esteemed and beloved colleague. Chuck embodied in his life and ministry an astute and sensitive care for the whole person. We extend our prayerful sympathy to all who loved him. William G. Spears, Chairman The Rev. Dr. Walter J. Smith, S.J., President & CEO

title: Does an International Bear Market Mean World Recession?
description: REMEMBER 1998? As Asian currencies crumbled and stock markets crashed, panic spread around the world. Amid fears of global recession, the Federal Reserve aggressively eased credit. Markets recovered as it became clear that disaster would be averted.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Atlanta

title: LODGIAN SAYS IT WILL CONSIDER EDGECLIFF'S HOSTILE BID
description: Lodgian Inc., which owns and operates Marriott, Holiday Inn and Crowne Plaza hotels, said yesterday that it would consider a hostile takeover bid received Monday from its largest shareholder, Edgecliff Holdings. Edgecliff's bid of about $140.6 million tops an offer by two real estate funds managed by the Goldman Sachs Group. Edgecliff, based in Fort Mitchell, Ky., owns 14.9 percent of Lodgian, based in Atlanta. Edgecliff offered to buy all the stock outstanding of Lodgian for $5 a share. Lodgian said it had received a bid of about $127 million, or $4.50 a share, from the Goldman Sachs funds.

title: Nokia's Earnings Surge a Stronger-Than-Expected 40%
description: Bucking a marked downward trend among rivals, Nokia of Finland, the world's leading mobile phone manufacturer, reported a 40 percent gain in third-quarter earnings today. The results were far stronger than expected and contributed to a broad rebound in depressed technology stocks in Europe and the United States.

title: Signed, Al Hirschfeld
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Odyssey Of Twins, 13, In Rape Case
description: When her twin sons were born, Janice Lynch remembers holding them close and thinking, ''I have some cute little twins who are going to be movie stars when they grow up.'' Yesterday, the twins, 13-year-old seventh-graders still barely five feet tall, were arraigned on charges of raping and robbing a 40-year-old neighbor on Sunday in front of her terrified toddler.

title: G.O.P. Chiefs Agree on a Disputed Medicare Bill
description: Brushing aside objections from President Clinton, Republican leaders of Congress announced today that they had agreed on a plan to pump $28 billion into Medicare over the next five years, mainly by increasing payments to health maintenance organizations, hospitals and other providers that care for the elderly.

title: Art Coulter, 91, Defenseman And Captain of 1940 Rangers
description: Art Coulter, one of the National Hockey League's top defensemen of the 1930's, the captain of the Rangers' 1940 Stanley Cup championship team and a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame, died Saturday in Mobile, Ala. He was 91.

title: Accounts
description: IntelliSpace, New York, which offers Internet services, to Burkhardt & Hillman, New York, to handle its worldwide account, which had been at CMG Communications, New York. Spending was estimated at more than $5 million.

title: Album of the Week
description: ''BAIAO DE VIRAMUNDO: TRIBUTE TO LUIZ GONZAGA'' (Stern's Brasil). The singer, accordionist and songwriter Luiz Gonzaga, who died in 1989, remains a powerful symbol of regional Brazilian culture -- its glory and its backwardness. He came from the backlands of the northeastern state of Pernambuco, and even though his route to success came via the Rio record and radio business in the 1940's, his music was unmistakably country. His songs lurched forward in 2/4 rhythm, and the heart of his music was accordion, bass drum and triangle; it was dance music based in what rural bands played for harvest parties.

title: Long in Love With Artifacts Of the Indians
description: Donald Ellis is a clever man: he turned a childhood hobby into a profession. Mr. Ellis, a Canadian dealer in 18th- and 19th-century Canadian and American Indian artifacts, is exhibiting for the first time at the International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show, which opens today at the Seventh Regiment Armory (review, Page 47). In a fair known for its sumptuous Louis XV furniture, old-master paintings and Tang horses, Mr. Ellis's booth is bound to stand out.

title: A Tribute to Latin Jazz And the Artists Behind It
description: Sometimes, a critic wonders if a movie seen at a festival, where audiences are so eager to be moved by anything, will maintain its magic outside such a forgiving setting. ''Calle 54,'' Fernando Trueba's wonderful documentary tribute to Latin jazz, is even better on a second viewing because the film is such a pure expression of the director's love for the music, a love so infectious it should leave you elated.

title: To Be, Or Not To Be, or Something
description: It is a curtain call revelation that there are four cast members in ''Maquina Hamlet.'' You might think there are more of them. But until they take their somber bows, the actors have been hard to keep track of, performing as they do without speaking and often wearing rat-head masks among mannequins who are often in similar masks.

title: For Giants' McDaniel, Pain Isn't in Game Plan
description: Two Giants trainers hovered over the defensive back after he was accidentally poked in the eye, no big deal for a little guy who had already played with a painful hip pointer and a torn shoulder muscle. After all, Emmanuel McDaniel vowed after a kidney injury in high school that pain alone would never stop him again.

title: The Big City; Old Grudges Are Missing In This Series
description: WHERE is the hate?

title: Selling a Rug With a Past
description: Sotheby's has omitted a few details from its catalog for today's sale of the contents of Mercer House, the 19th-century Italianate mansion in the heart of Savannah, Ga., that is perhaps best known as the home of Jim Williams. He was the antiques dealer who was the protagonist in ''Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil,'' the best-selling book, and in the movie based on it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, DR. HERMAN I.
description: FRANK-Dr. Herman I. Of Bayonne, NJ. Beloved husband of Claire (nee Belinkoff). Devoted father of Judith Frank, Margot Faivush, Barbara Frank and Sally Frank. Loving grandfather of Michael & Rachel Faivush. Services Friday, 10 AM Temple Beth AM, Bayonne. For information ''Wien & Wien'', 800-322-0533.

title: From Agbayani to Zimmer: A Primer
description: You know who you are. Your knowledge of baseball is so limited you think that a sacrifice bunt is a kind of religious ritual, that ''Yogi'' is a term of deference for some rubber-faced guru in New Jersey. In fact, you secretly believe that Bobby Valentine is the stage name of a lounge singer in Atlantic City.

title: John Constable
description: Salmagundi Club

title: TRADE CENTER BIDDING ADVANCES
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has narrowed the number of bidders for the World Trade Center to Brookfield Financial Properties, Silverstein Properties, Vornado Realty Trust and Boston Properties, according to state officials and real estate executives. Last month, the Port Authority accepted eight bids, ranging up to $3 billion, for a 99-year lease of the 11 million- square-foot complex. Analysts said the actual value of the offers would probably be $500 million less, because the city insisted after the bids were submitted that the new owners would have to pay full property taxes, rather than the reduced $25 million annual payment the Port Authority makes. Among the losing bidders was Tishman Speyer Properties.

title: $8 Million Gift by AOL's Case Draws Protest
description: Gay rights advocates expressed concern today over an $8.35 million donation by Stephen M. Case, the chairman of America Online, and his wife, Jean, to a Florida school that is affiliated with a church that seeks to ''cure'' homosexuals.

title: Batter Up! The Battle of New York Is at Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: CADBURY EXPANSION IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: In another move to consolidate control over its holdings in South Africa, Cadbury Schweppes, the British beverage and candy company, said it planned to acquire the outstanding 45 percent stake in its South African subsidiary for about $207 million. Cadbury said that Tempora Investments Ltd., which holds nearly half of the minority stake in the South African company, had agreed to the deal, which follows Cadbury's sale of its South African soft drink business last year to Coca-Cola. Henri Cauvin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, AMY GLADYS
description: FARRELL-Amy Gladys. On Oct. 20, 2000. Born February 23, 1911. Wife of Herman D. Farrell Sr. of Jamaica, West Indies. Mother of State Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., grandmother of Monique Guidry and Herman D. Farrell III, and great-grandmother of Simone Guidry. Reposing at Benta Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Ave, at 141st St. Visiting Sunday, 48PM. Funeral services Monday, 11 AM, Church of Intercession, 550 W. 155th St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Alzheimers Association, 360 Lexington Avenue, 5th Floor, NY, NY 10017.

title: U.N. Assembly Adopts Resolution Condemning Israel for an 'Excessive Use of Force'
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan, who returned two days ago from his own shuttle diplomacy in the Middle East, today asked the General Assembly to make ''a real difference'' by helping to bring an end to the fighting between the Palestinians and Israel.

title: SOFTBANK-ARIBA ALLIANCE
description: Japan's leading Internet investment company, Softbank, formed an alliance with Ariba, an electronic- commerce company based in Palo Alto, Calif., to create online business-to-business marketplaces in Japan. Under the terms announced by Softbank's president, Masayoshi Son, the company will take a 40 percent stake in Ariba's Japanese subsidiary for 4.3 billion yen, or about $40 million. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: CANADIAN INFLATION RATE RISES
description: Canada's annual inflation rate rose to 2.7 percent in September from 2.5 percent in August, with most of the increase resulting from rising gasoline and fuel oil prices. The increase was less than most economists had expected. The price of gasoline rose by 6 percent last month, making it 18 percent more expensive than a year earlier. Fuel oil and natural gas prices were 24 and 44 percent higher on the year. Excluding energy, the consumer price index rose at a 1.5 percent annual pace in September, which compared with 1.7 percent in August. An increase of 3.2 percent in university and private school fees was the smallest in 22 years and helped restrain core inflation. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Satire in the Ivory Tower Gets Rough; You Can't Make an Academic Spoof Without Breaking a Few Eggheads
description: Once upon a time, the world of academic satire seemed to be a British protectorate. Kingsley Amis's ''Lucky Jim'' set the rules of the game and David Lodge's trio of academic farces, ''Changing Places,'' ''Small World'' and ''Nice Work,'' earned him an adjective: Lodgean.

title: America's Bolshevik
description: Don Quixote himself might have despaired at the prospect of leading America's Communist Party during the cold war, but not the indefatigable Gus Hall. Mr. Hall died last week at the age of 90. His life story, improbably enough, is a genuine American tale.

title: Roll 'Em: Yanks and Mets Ready for a Wild Ride
description: The Subway Series begins tonight and the participants will be greatly relieved, because when the Yankees' Andy Pettitte throws the first pitch to the Mets' Timo Perez in Game 1, they will all be temporarily bunkered from the bombardment of ticket requests.

title: Batter Up! The Battle of New York Is at Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: Ukrainian Troupe Brings a Legend From the Caucasus
description: ''The Legend of Tamar'' came out of the Caucasus Mountains to the stage of the City Center on Thursday night. The legend was wispy, but the dancers and musicians who brought it to life were sturdy.

title: Lazio Denies He Is Distancing Himself From Bush
description: A day after barely crossing paths with Gov. George W. Bush on his New York visit, Representative Rick A. Lazio said today that he had not tried to distance himself from the Republican presidential candidate. But he also insisted that the Senate race was about his candidacy, not about other Republicans.

title: Airlines Ordered to Tell Callers Internet May Offer Cheaper Fares
description: The Transportation Department warned airlines yesterday that they faced sanctions if they did not tell consumers who made reservations over the telephone that cheaper fares might be available on the Internet, but it stopped short of requiring the airlines to say exactly what those fares would be.

title: Its Prices, and Its Reach, Push Wal-Mart to Top
description: Sometime before the end of the year, a milestone in American capitalism will pass. Wal-Mart Stores' annual sales are on track to exceed those of General Motors, the largest American company for much of the last half-century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOONE, ELAINE ALTIERI
description: BOONE-Elaine Altieri. Born April 22, 1944 in Corona, New York, died October 15, 2000 in Hilton Head, South Carolina. She lives with joy and inspiration in the hearts of her children Jennifer and Colin, husband Geoffrey, sisters Carol Ann and Vinita, father Vincent, wonderful family and friends. Elaine was graduated Valedictorian of her class with a Bachelor's Degree in Theatre and Communications from Marymount Manhattan College and earned her Master's Degree in Speech Pathology and Audiology from Pennsylvania State University. With her knowledge of American Sign Language, unique creativity and outstanding professional ability Elaine built bridges of communication between children, their families and their world. Throughout her life she remained current in her chosen field of expertise, publishing numerous papers on the latest trends and discoveries in speech and hearing innovations, and was an active member of the American Speech and Hearing Association. She was Executive Director of the Toronto Board of Education's Speech and Hearing Department and worked as a Speech Pathologist at both Beaufort and Hilton Head Elementary Schools. Elaine was a staunch supporter of all auxiliary activities, including Hilton Head Preparatory School's Parent Teacher Association, and wrote articles for Hilton Head Monthly Magazine. Elaine shone on the island stage in productions at both the Hilton Head Playhouse and Self Family Art Center. With equal grace and gusto Elaine brought to all she knew her infectious love of life, and a laughter that rings in our ears to this moment. She is a flame that has brightened every room she has ever entered, and every heart she has ever blessed. To use past tense in reference to her is not accurate, because she is not gone. It is only that her soul outgrew the body we could touch. A memorial service in Toronto, Canada will be held the week of November 20th.

title: A Filipino Linked to 'Love Bug' Talks About His License to Hack
description: Did Onel de Guzman create the ''Love Bug,'' the most destructive computer virus in history?

title: REUTERS TO PROCEED WITH INSTINET SALE
description: The British media company Reuters said it had decided to proceed with an initial sale of shares in Instinet, its electronic trading subsidiary, although it did not specify the size or a date of the proposed offering. Reuters also said third-quarter sales rose 16 percent, to $:888 million, or about $1.29 billion. Instinet sales rose 46 percent, to $:189 million, or about $276 million. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: For Yankees, It's a Workout In Progress
description: Andy Pettitte would reach the seventh or eighth inning this year, and he would sense his fastball starting to lose its zip, fatigue gnawing at his body. At least that is what he thought.

title: Making Room for Canseco
description: The Yankees have to make a roster move today to create a spot for the slugger Jose Canseco, who is being added to the 25-man roster. The Yankees' staff is trying to choose between dropping the right-hander Jason Grimsley -- who is pitching with a bad elbow that will require surgery in the off-season -- and the left-hander Randy Choate, whose potential value is diminished by the fact that the Mets have only one prominent left-handed hitter, third baseman Robin Ventura. Buster Olney

title: LUND, AUTO PARTS MAKER, PLANS TO CUT ABOUT 70 JOBS
description: Lund International Holdings Inc., a maker of automotive parts like visors and shock absorbers, said yesterday that it was cutting about 70 jobs as it stops making fiberglass at a plant in Minnesota. Lund will contract out fiberglass manufacturing to another company, it said. As part of a plan to scale back manufacturing to five plants from eight, Lund said it was moving a distribution center to Lawrenceville, Ga., from Anoka, Minn. Lund will also move its corporate headquarters to Duluth, Ga., from Anoka. The Anoka distribution center employs 137 people.

title: The Missing Chapter in the Bush Bio: A Modest Summer in Alaska
description: Despite the scrutiny applied to George W. Bush's life this election season, one small chapter has largely escaped attention. In an episode he has discussed with a few friends but not biographers, Mr. Bush spent the summer of 1974 working for a young airline-and-construction business in Alaska, during the oil-boom days when construction on the 800-mile trans-Alaska pipeline was just beginning.

title: The Gates to College Should Be Open to All
description: To the Editor:

title: Phil Lesh, Still Lighting Out and Looking All Around
description: When somebody begins a solo in Phil Lesh's band, the chances are high that within four bars a few other musicians will begin to pile on with their own improvisations. And the tangle of all those single notes isn't a momentary diversion but the goal. The emphasis isn't on the primacy of the individual soloist, but on the weave. It can confound somebody who is used to the principles of jazz, much less the principles of rock, where so much activity at once is usually understood as clutter.

title: Piazza Goes to Bat for Valentine's Lineup Decision
description: Mike Piazza has waited through eight seasons in the major leagues for this chance, an opportunity to perform on baseball's biggest stage, and he finally gets his shot at the World Series tonight. But on the eve of Game 1 at Yankee Stadium, Piazza learned he would not be behind the plate. Instead, he will be the Mets' designated hitter while Todd Pratt catches.

title: Challenger Tries for a Comeback in a Maverick State Senate District
description: Vincent J. Gentile, a two-term state senator who represents parts of Brooklyn and Staten Island, has yet to have an easy campaign season. A Democrat in a Senate district that often gives Republicans big majorities, Mr. Gentile has faced well-financed, well-known opponents.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Bin Laden looked at the picture of the American embassy and pointed to where a truck could go as a suicide bomber.''

title: I.M.F.'s Hand Often Heavy, A Study Says
description: The photo captured what Kipling might have called the financial man's burden: Michel Camdessus, head of the International Monetary Fund, towered over President Suharto of Indonesia as Mr. Suharto agreed to terms for rescuing his nation from economic oblivion.

title: Offer From G.E. Breaks Up $40 Billion Deal for Honeywell
description: A counteroffer from General Electric's chairman, John F. Welch Jr., broke up United Technologies' deal to buy Honeywell International yesterday, setting off a rush of activity as other suitors considered bidding for all or part of Honeywell.

title: Caring for the Elderly: A Precarious State
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ARTHUR M.
description: GOLDBERG-Arthur M. The Boards, Faculty and Staff of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons, and the Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College of Cornell University are deeply saddened by the passing of our great friend and esteemed Hospital Trustee, Arthur M. Goldberg. Mr. Goldberg became a Trustee of The Presbyterian Hospital in 1996. When it merged with The New York Hospital in 1998, he became a Trustee of the merged institution, serving as Co-Chair of the Human Resources Committee. He was a man of great warmth, vision and courage, who was unfailingly devoted to the support of medical education, research and patient care. Mr. Goldberg's wise counsel and guidance were invaluable. He was much loved and will be truly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, children, and grandchildren.

title: The Odysseys of Two Fans; Learning to Like the Yankees
description: I never thought I'd see the day when I actually rooted for the Yankees. As a boy growing up in New Jersey in the 1940's, I learned to loathe them. They were so lordly, so insufferably efficient, so smugly confident, so appropriately pinstriped. Others might thrill to the sight of DiMaggio effortlessly shagging a fly ball in center field, or King Kong Keller lofting one into the stands, or Fireman Joe Page shutting down a rally. But I couldn't stand a team that was so unbelievably excellent, so clearly dominant that it seemed inhuman.

title: Headquarters Of The Times Is Considered As Landmark
description: While The New York Times plans a new headquarters on Eighth Avenue, New York City preservation officials are planning to designate as a landmark the building at 229 West 43rd Street that has been the newspaper's home since 1913.

title: More Bang for the B.T.U.; New York Ranks Near the Top For Efficient Use of Energy
description: The term ''energy efficient'' sounds jarringly incorrect in describing New York. Big, sprawling, arrogant, corrupt -- those are things people expect. ''Efficient'' seems a little too Jonathan Livingston Seagull and not enough Damon Runyon.

title: Masterpieces From an Unparalleled Collection : A Treasure Trove From Japan
description: NEW YORK  It is every museum director's dream.

title: Newscasters Leave Black Rock, the House Edward R. Murrow Built
description: As usual, traffic and weather came together ''on the eights'' on WCBS Newsradio 880 yesterday afternoon. But after the 1:58 briefing came something extra: ''That's it for us from Black Rock. Goodbye, Black Rock.''

title: In Mets Outpost, No Tears in the Beer
description: The geography of New York baseball is an inexact science, a course of study as enigmatic as determining how many stadium beers will get you drunk.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a Yale University study linking risk of stroke to an ingredient in some decongestants and appetite suppressants referred incorrectly at one point to the position of staff scientists at the Food and Drug Administration. While scientists speaking for the nonprescription drug industry disputed the study, F.D.A. scientists indeed found the study convincing, in part because of their own estimates that the ingredient was responsible for 200 to 500 strokes a year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Makes Up Ground, But Is Down for the Year

title: Knoblauch's Reply Is Loud and Clear
description: The angry, haunting lyrics will spill out of the public address system at Yankee Stadium as soon as Chuck Knoblauch ambles from the on-deck circle to the plate in the first inning tonight. Knoblauch, the Yankees second baseman, feels misunderstood and mistreated, which is why his every step is accompanied by Eminem's vocals about being irritated with people who hound him and who think that they know him.

title: John Worsley, 81, Artist Whose Wartime Creation Outfoxed the Nazis
description: John Worsley, a British artist who as a prisoner of the Germans in World War II hoodwinked guards with a dummy P.O.W. named Albert, later a part of British wartime lore, died Oct. 3 in London. He was 81.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NRG ENERGY INC., Minneapolis, a power-plant operator that first sold shares to the public in May, agreed to buy three electrical-generating assets from Sierra Pacific Resources, Reno, Nev., a utility holding company, for $273.3 million.

title: Maybe I Remember DiMaggio's Kick
description: Let me begin with a memory. It was Oct. 5, 1947, and I was in the Yankee Stadium bleachers, with the Yankees trailing 8-5 in the sixth. With two men on and two men out, Joe DiMaggio hit a tremendous drive to the deepest part of center field. A huge roar went up from the Yankee partisans in the bleachers, and then, as Al Gionfriddo made his celebrated catch, it seemed to ebb and turn into a gasp, while from the same section a second roar of approval exploded from the Dodger fans seated right there with us. Did I actually see the catch? I think I did. Did I see DiMaggio famously kick the dirt as he reached second, a moment replayed on countless television biographies of him because it was the rarest display of public emotion on his part? Again, I think I did. Who knows? Memory is often less about truth than about what we want it to be.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: G.E. Bid Breaks Up Deal for Honeywell
description: General Electric made an offer yesterday to buy Honeywell International, ending United Technologies' $40.3 billion deal to acquire the Morristown, N.J., company.

title: Bicycles, Roman Toilets and Other Microscholarship
description: At times scholarly work seems so specialized that nonacademics wonder about its relevance. Here are a few unusual academic niches with explanations from professors of how they became interested in their subjects and why they are important.

title: NESTLE REPORTS STRONGER RESULTS
description: One of the world's leading food companies, Nestle, said nine-month group sales rose 9.4 percent, to 59.5 billion Swiss francs, or about $33.3 billion, helped by growing demand for products like Nescafe and Perrier mineral water in new markets. Food sales for the first nine months were strongest in Asia and Africa, followed by Latin America. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Tale of an Irish Martyr to Drug Lords
description: Veronica Guerin, a courageous Dublin newspaper reporter whose articles had enraged the underworld, was shot and killed in 1996 as she sat in her car at a suburban intersection. Her investigative reports on her country's drug traffic had been alarming; her death further underscored the power of organized crime in Ireland and prompted the government to dedicate greater resources to addressing that power.

title: In Lean Times for Chinese Art, Dealers Triumph Over Auctioneers
description: NEW YORK  Last September, a marked shift in the balance of commercial power between auction houses and the art trade could be observed in the international scene within a specific area that has never had it so good  Chinese art.

title: Appeals Court Reinstates Ruling to Allow Some School Prayers
description: A federal appeals court has reinstated a ruling that permits student-led prayer in public-school assemblies and classrooms, after the United States Supreme Court ordered in June that the ruling be reconsidered.

title: Mideast States Urged to Use An Arms Pact To Build Trust
description: The director of the international organization charged with ridding the world of chemical weapons made a plea yesterday to Israelis, Egyptians, Palestinians and others in the Middle East to adhere to the treaty banning such weapons as a way to reduce tensions in the region.

title: Batter Up! The Battle of New York Is at Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: Leading Off and Playing...
description: As the final batted ball of the National League Championship Series descended from the dark Shea Stadium sky toward his big, blue glove, Timo Perez began jumping in jubilation. He paused briefly to catch the ball, then he started another ragged dance toward his celebrating teammates after they eliminated the St. Louis Cardinals on Monday night. Few players would have made a play quite this way, but Perez, a rookie sensation, is full of surprises.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELNER, MARJORIE S.
description: ZELNER-Marjorie S. Age 49. Loved and loving wife, mother and daughter. Survived by her husband Lawrence, son Jonathan and mother Judith Swirsky. Daughter of the late Dr. Leo Swirsky. Born in Brooklyn, NY and resident of Closter, NJ since 1985. Former Executive Director of The Institute for General Semantics. President of the Closter Board of Education. A dedicated business administrator and volunteer devoted to the mission of excellence in public education. Donations may be sent to Closter Board of Education, The Marjorie Zelner Fund, 340 Homans Ave., Closter, New Jersey 07624. Visiting at family home in Closter from 12:00 to 6:00 PM, Sunday, October 22. Please contact the family about interment arrangements.

title: Jets Will Try to Keep Testaverde on His Feet Against Miami
description: Al Groh learned a few things at the University of Virginia, where he majored in commerce. But now the Jets' coach is trying to reinvent a law of football -- opposites repelling -- on Monday night, when the Jets and their retooled offense face the sack-happy Miami Dolphins.

title: Merck Net Rises 19%, Beating Forecast
description: Merck & Company, the big drug maker, said today that its third-quarter profit rose 19 percent on sales of its drugs, including a painkiller, Vioxx; a cholesterol drug, Zocor; and a blood-pressure pill, Cozaar.

title: Vick Finds Pressure On and Off the Field
description: There are some things that 4.2 speed in the 40-yard dash and a left arm that can launch a football the length of a football field cannot help you with. Like fingers poking through your face mask at the bottom of the pile and punches banging against your kidneys when you are caught near the sideline.

title: LACROSSE FOOTWEAR TO CUT WORK FORCE BY 200, OR 21%
description: LaCrosse Footwear Inc. will lay off about 200 employees at its plant in LaCrosse, Wis., about 21 percent of its work force, to reduce escalating costs. The employees' last day will be Dec. 18, said Robert Sullivan, the chief financial officer. LaCrosse Footwear, which makes footwear under the brands LaCrosse and Danner, has about 950 employees. Expenses for the third quarter rose 23 percent, to $9.61 million from $7.83 million a year earlier, in part because of higher distribution costs at its plants.

title: Cost of Manhattan Apartments Drops as Stock Market Slumps, Report Says
description: The average cost of an apartment in much of Manhattan fell 7.7 percent in the third quarter of 2000, a sign that a slump in stock prices may finally be affecting New York's housing market, according to a study.

title: In the Dugouts, Opposites Distract
description: The 28-year-old utility player had been assured by the manager that he would make the Mets to start the 1979 season, so naturally he was incensed when the team released him in the final week of spring training. He was so incensed about feeling misled that he held a news conference the next day to discuss how he had been mistreated.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUMINER, SHARON
description: HOUMINER - Sharon. Beloved daughter of Ehud and Naomi. Loving sister of Talia, and Orly and Yaacov. Service Monday, 10 AM, Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Rd, White Plains. For information call Plaza Memorial, 212-769-4400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGIBBONS, JOAN
description: FITZGIBBONS-Joan. October 19, 2000. Beloved wife of the late John A. Fitzgibbons. Devoted & loving mother of Ann Fitzgibbons and Jack Fitzsgibbons. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Saturday 7-9PM and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial Monday October 23, 11 AM, St. Joan of Arc Church, 82nd Street at 35th Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Batter Up! The Battle of New York Is at Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Security's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE POLLS

title: Batter Up! The Battle of New York Is at Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz Hands Knicks First Preseason Loss
description: Despite playing without Karl Malone, their All-Star forward, the Utah Jazz handed the Knicks their first loss of the preseason last night, 96-90, at the Pepsi Arena in Albany.

title: Carter Sadly Turns Back On National Baptist Body
description: Jimmy Carter, a third-generation Southern Baptist and the first United States president to call himself a born-again Christian, has reached what he calls ''a painful decision'' to sever ties to the Southern Baptist Convention, saying that parts of its ''increasingly rigid'' doctrines violate the ''basic premises of my Christian faith.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCVEIGH, CHARLES S., JR.
description: McVEIGH-Charles S., Jr. Memorial Service on Monday October 23, 2000, at 2 P.M. at The Church Of The Advent, 555 Advent Street, Westbury, Long Island.

title: The Battle Inside the Lines
description: YANKEES: Untrusting of his middle relief, Joe Torre essentially relied on six pitchers in the first two rounds of the playoffs. The formula won't change in the World Series: Torre will look to pitch starters Andy Pettitte, Roger Clemens and Orlando Hernandez deep into games, before turning over leads to relievers Mike Stanton, Jeff Nelson and Mariano Rivera. Those six accounted for 7813 innings of the first 97 in the postseason. The two built-in off-days will help Torre rest his top three relievers, which is why rainouts would hurt the Yankees.
