Torre seems to be leaning toward starting David Cone in Game 4, and given that Cone has not pitched into the middle innings of any game in more than a month, Torre will probably have Denny Neagle and Dwight Gooden prepared to step in quickly.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- No events.

title: The Odysseys of Two Fans; Learning to Love the Mets
description: Here's how fandom creeps up on you: You start out in the other room while your husband listens to the Mets, sticking your head in on big plays just to see why he's pounding the table like Khrushchev. The next year, you grudgingly go along on a couple of trips to Shea. Then you start yelling at the radio when Rey Ordonez, once again, swings at the first pitch. Soon, when your husband calls from a trip overseas, you find yourself discussing the well-being of the baby and the Mets, not in that order.

title: Willie Cook, 76, Lead Trumpeter With Gillespie and Ellington
description: Willie Cook, a lyrical lead trumpeter with a soft tone who played in big bands led by Jay McShann, Earl Hines, Dizzy Gillespie and Duke Ellington, died on Sept. 22 in Stockholm. He was 76.

title: Subway Series Experience Absent From Both Teams
description: For all their dominance during the playoffs in getting here, only four Mets have World Series experience.

title: U.S. Raises Estimate of Plutonium Spilled Making Arms
description: The Energy Department has concluded that the amount of plutonium and other man-made radioactive elements released into soil or buried in flimsy containers in the first four decades of nuclear weapons manufacture was 10 times larger than it had estimated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDLICH, THEODORE, JR. M.D.
description: EDLICH-Theodore, Jr. M.D. The Daughters of Mary and the medical staff of Saint Clare's Hospital and Health Center mourn the loss of our esteemed collegue and friend who served our institution for many years. Dr. Edlich was a dedicated physician who always showed sincere concern for his patients and for St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to his family. Theodore Flogaites M.D, President, Medical Staff Paul Marino, Medical Director James A. Rutherford, Pres/CEO St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center

title: Lieberman Declares His Party Built the Boom
description: Calling the Democrats ''the party of fiscal responsibility and economic growth,'' Senator Joseph I. Lieberman today claimed for them the credit for the nation's extraordinary economic boom, and said only they would sustain it.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday listing statistics about subway lines serving Shea and Yankee stadiums misstated the figures for the average miles between mechanical failures for trains on the No. 7 and No. 4 lines for the last six months of 1999, as calculated by the Straphangers Campaign, a rider advocacy group. No. 7 trains traveled 125,682 miles (not 125,612), and No. 4 trains traveled 163,227 miles (not 63,227).

title: Islanders Earn Their First Victory
description: Tired of talking about his team's slow start, the grim-faced Islanders Coach Butch Goring had these words for his players before last night's game against the Thrashers in Atlanta: There's been enough said. It's time to go out and play and get it done.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Nebraskans to Vote on Most Sweeping Ban on Gay Unions
description: Nebraskans will vote this Election Day on the country's most sweeping effort to bar gay unions, a proposed amendment to the state Constitution that not only bans gay marriages but also declares same-sex civil unions and domestic partnerships invalid.

title: Journal; Who'll Serve Clinton's Third Term?
description: And so on Tuesday night, we finally got what the talking heads had promised -- ''the knockout punch'' settling this interminable battle once and for all. The definitive blow was administered by David Justice, whose three-run homer insured a Subway Series possibly even more riveting than the other high New York drama of the night, Donna Hanover's much-awaited debut in ''The Vagina Monologues.''

title: Defense Lawyer Fights to Keep Skakel Charged As a Juvenile
description: A lawyer for Michael C. Skakel, the Kennedy relative charged with the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley, made one last effort today to keep the case in juvenile court, trying to counter a court-ordered background report that seems to suggest Mr. Skakel should be tried as an adult.

title: THE $10 MILLION RACE
description: Running out of money was not a problem for James Rogan (Republican) and Adam Schiff (Democrat), Californians who are competing in the most expensive Congressional campaign in history. Running out of ideas on how to spend it sometimes was. A report by James Bennet in The Times Magazine.

title: Barak May Halt Peace Moves To Revamp His Government
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak, elected on a platform of peacemaking, announced tonight that he was prepared to take an indefinite ''timeout'' from the Israeli-Palestinian peace effort. That would pave the way for him to forge a national emergency government with the right-wing opposition next week.

title: Russian Media Tycoon and Biggest Creditor Near an Agreement
description: A dispute between the media mogul Vladimir V. Gusinsky and his biggest creditor has moved closer to a resolution, which could ultimately prevent his company from being controlled by the Russian government.

title: One or the Other, Choose!
description: The Subway Series has yet to be decided, but the reveling and the rooting officially kicked off yesterday in Bryant Park, where thousands of Yankees and Mets fans ducked out of work and trudged through the mud to pledge their allegiance to their teams.

title: Olympic Bridge May Separate Sexes Again
description: Should men and women ever be segregated at the bridge table?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, NATHANIEL H., MD.
description: SOLOMON-Nathaniel H., MD. The Officers and membership of the Queens Pediatric Society express their sorrow at the passing of our colleague and an active member of the Society for many years. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Miriam, and the entire Solomon family. Gaddam Reddy, MD, President Mozafar Salemi, MD, Secretary

title: Berlin Operas Are Feuding, With Anti-Semitic Overtones
description: Berlin's opera world is often turbulent, riven by East-West rivalries of cold-war intensity. But apparently anti-Semitic comments about Daniel Barenboim, the artistic director of the Staatsoper, have created a storm unusual even by the standards of this city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, STANLEY
description: SCHIFF-Stanley. On October 19, 2000 at age 90. Survived by Anne, his much beloved wife of 64 years. Devoted father of Posey & Helen (Richard). Former member of the New York Stock Exchange. He will always be remembered for his generosity and love of life. The Family

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Batter Up! The Battle of New York Is at Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: SLOWDOWN IN BRITISH ECONOMY
description: Britain said economic growth slipped in the third quarter, reinforcing assessments that there is little current pressure on the Bank of England to increase interest rates in Britain, Europe's second-largest economy. The National Statistics Office said economic output expanded by 0.7 percent in the quarter, compared with 0.9 percent in the second quarter. Economists had expected a rise of 0.8 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: To Recruit More Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Ignoring the Details
description: To the Editor:

title: A Presidential Imprint on the Fed; Gore or Bush Will Stand To Influence Central Bank
description: When it comes to the Federal Reserve, the two presidential candidates profess to share a basic approach: hands off.

title: A Texas Prosecutor Who Seeks Evidence of Innocence
description: IN a state that has executed more criminals than any other and earned an international reputation for being relentlessly tough on crime, Ronnie Earle is an anomaly, a soft-spoken prosecutor, more prone to discuss values than vengeance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVEY, ALAN
description: DAVEY-Alan. Passed away Oct. 18, 2000, at 64 years of age. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Davey. Loving stepfather of Nina Endler & Thomas Manno. Loving step-grandfather of Anna Endler. Alan worked for 30 years for The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary as an Accountant. He loved traveling, church and classical music. He was a happy man and rarely complained. Service is Wednesday, Oct 25, 2 pm at All Saints Chapel, Trinity Church, Wall & Broadway.

title: Drug Companies Defend Use Of Ingredient in Cold Products
description: Facing potential restrictions on a major ingredient in some of their best-known brands, pharmaceutical companies staunchly defended the safety of their products yesterday and accused the Food and Drug Administration of placing an unwarranted amount of faith in what they called a questionable study.

title: Gore Reunites With President For Just a Day
description: Air Force Two cozied up to Air Force One at an airport near here today, setting up a very public runway reunion of President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore and their wives -- a flurry of hearty handshakes and air kisses that aides said was meant to discredit reports that the relations between the men were strained.

title: Colombia Says Rebels Have Killed 56 Troops
description: Fifty-four soldiers and two police officers have died in three days of fighting with leftist rebels in a small northwestern town, military officials said today. Among them, 22 died when their Black Hawk helicopter crashed as a ground battle raged.

title: Nomadic Net Feels at Home
description: Of all the distant places stamped in his memory and in his passport, Venezuela was the loneliest for Stephen Jackson. He was 18, and basketball was his translator and his currency.

title: NEWS CORPORATION CUTS JOBS AT INTERNET OPERATION
description: News Digital Media, the online media unit of the News Corporation, has dismissed about 20 percent of its New York news staff and has told all New York sports staff members to move to Los Angeles or lose their jobs. The employees were informed late Thursday and Friday, a day or two after Rupert Murdoch, the company's chairman, told investors at the Australia-based company's annual meeting that he was not confident in the business models of Internet companies that rely on advertising revenue. Separately, 12 of the 82 New York-based news editorial staff members were laid off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, HARRY BURTON
description: JONES-Harry Burton. On October 20, 2000. He leaves behind his wife Laure & two sons, Peter & Kevin. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 11:00 AM St. Anastasia Church in Douglaston. Donations may be made to North Shore Hospital-Extended Care Facility Attn: Mr. Dennis Conners, 330 Community Drive, Manhasset, New York 11030.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Gov. George W. Bush's criticism of Vice President Al Gore's economic plans misstated a question Mr. Bush was asked at the presidential debate on Tuesday. The moderator, Jim Lehrer, asked him to respond to Mr. Gore's criticism that the governor's proposed tax cut ''benefits the top 1 percent of the wealthiest Americans.'' Mr. Bush responded: ''Of course it does. If you pay taxes, you're going to get a benefit.'' Mr. Lehrer did not ask whether the proposal would benefit ''mainly'' that group.

title: Get Ready for a Show About Something
description: You'd think we'd be happy. Here we are in a World Series we can't lose. It's us against ourselves. Hey, how about if the winner of this plays the Knicks? Every sports town is always so desperate to get its team into a championship final. We've got two, why are we all so anxious? I guess for the same reason things got a little testy between the states around 1861. The fact is, you have to consider the Civil War to be the original Subway Series. Same basic idea, just take a bunch of guys we all like, put them in different uniforms, then stand back and watch the fireworks. And I bet major league pitchers today probably throw about as hard as the little balls that came out of those muskets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDMAN, MAXINE
description: RUDMAN-Maxine. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck George N. Abrahams, President

title: Maili Suu Journal; Living at Ground Zero of Possible Atomic Disaster
description: Isolated between two of the world's tallest mountain ranges, the Fergana Valley is the breadbasket of Central Asia. Its tens of thousands of acres of fields, pastures and orchards feed millions of people in the region, and its cotton production is crucial to the economy.

title: Scholarly Editions in Jeopardy
description: Congress recently authorized the first funding increase for the National Endowment for the Humanities in four years. But the increase, a miserly $5 million, will not be enough to make up for years of Congressional stinginess. Nor will it console the directors of major scholarly projects financed by the endowment, who have been warned that they may have to find private money in order to survive.

title: Abroad at Home; Bob And Weave
description: By the ordinary logic of politics, the vice president of an administration that has given us the greatest prosperity in history should be way ahead in this election. That he is not is a tribute to the campaigning skill of George W. Bush. No one can doubt any longer that Mr. Bush is a formidable candidate.

title: For Mrs. Clinton, Health Plan Left Lessons and Questions
description: To this day, puzzling questions hover over Hillary Rodham Clinton's effort to remake the nation's health care system in 1993 and 1994, the most ambitious project of her public life.

title: Skiff That Bombed U.S. Destroyer Now Said to Have Moved In Alone
description: In the moments before it exploded, tearing a ragged hole in the destroyer Cole moored in Yemen, a white motorized skiff circled around the ship's bow and slowly skirted along its portside. Two men aboard the skiff nonchalantly waved to armed sailors standing watch on the Cole's deck, and the sailors waved back, officials said today in a new account of the attack.

title: Another Japanese Insurer Sets Record for Bankruptcy
description: The Kyoei Life Insurance Company sought court protection today from creditors in Japan's biggest bankruptcy since World War II, nearly two-thirds larger than the previous record corporate failure, by another insurer, just 11 days ago.

title: CHINESE REGULATORS SUED
description: A Chinese development company has sued the nation's market regulator for refusing to approve its application to list on a mainland stock exchange. The company, Hainan Kaili Development and Construction, contends that it was treated unfairly by the China Securities Regulatory Commission, which routinely favors large state-owned concerns over private companies in deciding who can raise capital on the country's two stock markets. A decision in Hainan Kaili's favor would set an important precedent for thousands of private companies clamoring for access to the country's capital markets. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Courting the Hispanic Voter
description: The Republican National Committee released a new 30-second Spanish-language television commercial this week that promotes Gov. George W. Bush's promise to improve public schools and salutes his record on the issue in Texas. It is running in five states, most of them where the presidential candidates are in close races and all of them with many Hispanic voters: California, Florida, New Mexico, Nevada and Pennsylvania.

title: The St. Louis Takes Its Turn At a Rite for Stravinsky
description: At Carnegie Hall this season comes what it calls a ''Focus on Stravinsky'': a good way to mark the end of the century he so dominated and an opportunity to get to know pieces that are still seldom performed. The St. Louis Symphony's concerts on Wednesday and Thursday included a few of these, among them the ''Ode'' and the ''Circus Polka,'' both from the early 1940's, when the composer had recently arrived in the United States and did not know quite what to do with himself here, and also, from an earlier period, the Four Studies and ''The Song of the Nightingale.''

title: Subway Cars of the 1950's Evoke Nostalgia, Too
description: There were gently churning ceiling fans. There were comfortable cane seats. In the summer, a cool breeze might rustle the pages of your carefully folded newspaper.

title: Police Say Detective, After Drug Buy, Killed Man Trying to Rob Him
description: An undercover narcotics detective who minutes before had bought $30 worth of heroin in a buy-and-bust operation in Brooklyn yesterday shot and killed a man who tried to rob him, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMAN, CHARLES D., RABBI
description: LIPPMAN-Charles D., Rabbi. The Board and congregation of the Temple of Universal Judaism mourns the death of our spiritual guide, teacher, mentor and friend, our beloved Rabbi Charles D. Lippman, D.D. Chuck was our light and inspiration. He was a magnet who drew us together. We will miss his strength of character, integrity, compassion and wit. As much as his death is unfathomable to us, he will be forever in our hearts. We extend our deepest condolences to his partner and morning star Alan, and the rest of his family, Hy, Elly, Robert, Rita, Jeffrey, Jeremy, Matthew and David. A funeral service will be held Sunday, October 22 at 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Please make contributions to the charity of your choice in Rabbi Lippman's name. A memorial service is planned for later this year.

title: Kansas Files Suit Against Tax People
description: The Kansas attorney general filed a civil lawsuit yesterday to stop a company in Topeka from marketing a system to reduce income taxes.

title: Excerpts From Guilty Plea in Terrorism Case
description: Following are excerpts from a preliminary court transcript of a hearing in Federal District Court in Manhattan in which Ali A. Mohamed pleaded guilty to five charges in connection with a broad terrorism conspiracy:

title: Corrections
description: The global stocks table in the World Business section on Oct. 4 misstated the closing number for the Johannesburg Top 25 industrial index and its performance this year to date. It closed on Oct. 3, at 9,307.86, not 9,173.43. Through Oct. 3, the index was up 2.32 percent in South African rand (not 0.85 percent), and down 12.81 percent in dollars (not 14 percent).

title: Modern and Postmodern, the Bickering Twins
description: Where are the manifestoes of yesteryear? There was a time when declarations of aesthetic commitment were commonplace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPORN, SHIRLEY A.
description: SPORN-Shirley A. The Light of My Life. The Joy of My Life. For 55 Glorious Years and Forever. ''Sugar'' Sporn, wife of Woodrow Sporn, died yesterday after a long illness in White Plains hospital. Courageous & brave, she endured many years of silent suffering. Shirley is survived by daughters Andrea and Susan; grandchildren, Alexandra, Daniel, Abbey and Douglas; extraordinary son-in-law, Dr. Jerome Haber; sister, Roslyn Reiffel; nephews and nieces, Dr. Max and Joan Sporn, Drs. Susanne and Robert Reiffel, Dr. James and Bonnie Reiffel, Linda and Jeffrey Halbreich; brother-inlaw Morty Halbreich. Shirley was a Scarsdale resident 38 years; active in the Parent School Association, a Girl Scout leader and involved in many other community activities; in the past twelve years, she was a resident of Purchase and a Board member of the Purchase Free Library. She was the first woman to serve on the Board of Westchester Cerebral Palsy. She was an avid bridge player and at one time was captain of the Fairview Country Club Women's Bridge Team. She will be missedmissed-missed. All my love, Sugar, forever and forever. ''Semper Fidelis'' Woody. Graveside services, Monday, October 23, at 1 PM, Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOURAUD SHEILA MARGUERITE
description: GOURAUD Sheila Marguerite, 21 Oct. '94 Irma Schlesinger, 21 Oct. '55 In loving memory. Jackson, Meg, George, Charles, Steven, Tracey

title: The Closing Statements From the Senate Debate
description: Following are the closing statements from the fifth and final debate between Jon S. Corzine and Representative Bob Franks, the candidates for United States Senate, as recorded by The New York Times. The hourlong debate, which was taped yesterday at the College of New Jersey in Ewing, will be broadcast on Sunday on WPVI-TV in Philadelphia at 10 a.m., and on WABC-TV in New York at 10:30 a.m.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SILVERSTEIN, FLORENCE CAHN
description: SILVERSTEIN-Florence Cahn February 21, 1907-October 21, 1999. Dear Mom, miss you so. Love you bunches, Joa

title: A Slow Start Solved, Hampton Looks Inside for the Keys to Success
description: The question was about what Mike Hampton has learned this year, about how he has changed. Hampton, a left-handed pitcher for the Mets, was about to let a visitor into his world, which does not happen too often.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Sports of The Times; Hispanics Put World In Series
description: ''THERE you go again,'' Jose Vizcaino complained, in a courteous, almost tender way, to a couple of city-bred reporters yesterday in front of his dressing stall at Yankee Stadium. ''Why do you all call it the Subway Series?''

title: This Election Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: More Bang for the B.T.U.; Against High Costs, A Better Light Bulb
description: High-strung, high-maintenance New York may never surpass laid-back Hawaii as the nation's most energy-efficient state, but a thunderclap of events in recent months in the Northeast have created what energy experts say is a glittering opportunity to try.

title: Upset Neagle Wants To Chat With Torre
description: Although Yankees Manager Joe Torre continued to assert yesterday that Denny Neagle did not pitch aggressively enough in his last start, he said that Neagle had not been dropped from the team's World Series starting rotation as a result. Torre has not named a starting pitcher for Game 4 of the World Series, which is to be played Wednesday at Shea Stadium, leading to speculation that the Yankees would start David Cone over Neagle. But Torre has not made that official.

title: Tyson Wins by TKO When Golota Gives Up
description: Like a child refusing his medicine, Andrew Golota stubbornly kept his lips pressed together as his trainer Lou Duva tried to force Golota's mouthpiece back into his mouth.

title: Sports of The Times; After Attack on Cole, Norfolk Puts Games in Proper Perspective
description: FROM his distant view in downtown Norfolk, Va., Dave Rosenfield, the general manager of the Norfolk Tides, said the Subway Series seemed like a page out of some subterranean nightmare. He has been following the drama, reading the dueling headlines laden with talk of Civil War and battles. He has watched with the mixed feelings of someone with one foot in the baseball world of metaphors and similes and the other foot in the world of the United States Navy, where real people sometimes die defending the right of a country to enjoy the national pastime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINS, CLARENCE B. JR
description: HIGGINS-Clarence B. Jr, decorated naval aviator, attorney and jazz pianist, passed away Thursday, October 12 in Albany. He was 80 years old and lived in Gilboa, New York, having retired there from Bronxville, NY. In WWII, Mr. Higgins flew carrier missions off the USS Hoggatt Bay as a torpedo bomber pilot Lieutenant (JG) in the battles at Iwo Jima, Okinawa and Lingayen Gulf. He received the Distinguished Flying Cross and six air medals: navy unit citationtwo stars, American Theater, Asiatic-Pacific-three stars and Philippine Liberation-one star. An attorney in tax and corporate reorganization, Mr. Higgins was also a pianist of note, playing in New York nightclubs throughout the fifties and sixties and at various events in recent years as an accompanist and entertainer. Mr. Higgins was born on March 24, 1920 in Milton, Massachusetts. He was graduated from Deerfield Academy, Duke University and Boston University School of Law. He received a Master's of Law from Columbia University. He is survived by his wife Margaret (Greta) Higgins and his former wife Carol Bluhme Higgins and their three children, Heather, Ariel and Scott. Also a son, Kim Higgins Townsend, by his earlier marriage to Theresa DeMarco Townsend. Services will be held privately at the convenience of his family.

title: Jean Peters, Actress of the 50's, Dies at 73
description: Jean Peters, a 20th Century Fox contract player whose unpretentious beauty earned her leading roles in some of the top films of the late 1940's and early 50's before she abandoned her career and practically disappeared from view after a secretive marriage to the billionaire Howard Hughes, died on Oct. 13 at her home in Carlsbad, Calif. She was 73.

title: INSIDE
description: Nuclear Waste Figures Rise

title: Bush Campaign Makes Public Candidate's 1999 Tax Return
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and his wife, Laura, reported income of $1,610,400 last year and paid $449,827, or 27.9 percent of that amount, in federal income taxes, their 1999 tax return, which his campaign made public last night, showed.

title: McCain Joins Bush, Calling Him 'Fully Prepared'
description: Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain stumped side by side today, with the senator declaring at a rollicking airport rally that the governor was ''fully prepared'' to lead. But once again things did not go quite as planned between the two former primary rivals.

title: Helicopters in Combat
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERDON, GWEN
description: VERDON-Gwen. Nicole and Jim, your mother meant a great deal to the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers' family. We mourn with you. Ted Pappas, President

title: Yemen, an Edgy Place, Faces Flood of Americans
description: As Navy pallbearers in dress whites loaded the flag-draped aluminum coffins of the last four sailors recovered from the destroyer Cole into an American military plane here tonight, two crumpled-looking Yemeni colonels in khaki uniforms and red berets stood at attention. Beside them, in a stiff salute and immaculately tailored and crisply pressed, stood an American admiral and the United States ambassador.

title: A Special Section, Pages D1-D13
description: The World Series between the Mets and the Yankees, the first Subway Series since 1956, gets under way tonight at Yankee Stadium after days of anticipation and desperate searches for tickets. Inside is a detailed look at how the two teams got this far.

title: Special-Interests' Ads Saturate a District
description: In Scranton, Pa., the Business Roundtable's newborn babies are fighting the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s kindly pharmacist. The National Republican Congressional Committee is represented by a Sherlock Holmes impersonator. The United States Chamber of Commerce features an elderly consumer picking up medicine (but not from the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s druggist). And the Sierra Club is providing a soothing interlude for voters with pristine streams and forests.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro fell against the dollar as doubts mounted that the European Central Bank would buy the currency for a second time to stem its decline. In New York, the euro dropped to 84.12 cents, from 84.37.

title: This Season, A Tense Knot In the Belly
description: I am going to need some mantras to get through this Subway Series. The sort murmured by people who are afraid to fly, like, ''I have a better chance of being kicked to death by a mule than dying on this aircraft.'' I will twist that soothing phrase to apply to the odds of losing to the Mets.

title: Three Utterly Unlike Sisters Trapped in Their Worlds
description: In the strangely hilarious ''Pandora's Box of Sweets,'' Susan Tierney's deity assumes the stage with a blithe acceptance of fantastical female entitlement. She wears a princess gown and exaggerated makeup; her bright eyes flash with delight as she chooses among her culinary tokens of affection, sweets that she often spears on the points of her tiara. Imagine an eclair atop a model's blond mane.

title: Scouts Anticipating Hard-Hitting Games
description: Timo Perez made a major impact on the National League playoff series between the Mets and the St. Louis Cardinals. Among the people who watched him the closest and with the most interest were opposing scouts who followed the Mets before and during the playoffs.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS AGREES TO SPLIT INTO 3 COMPANIES
description: The chairman of ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., Milan Panic, bowing to investor pressure, agreed to split the drug maker into three companies and give up control of the unit that owns the rights to its only blockbuster drug. Mr. Panic, who founded ICN four decades ago, had resisted demands by shareholders to relinquish control of Ribapharm, the unit that makes the hepatitis C drug ribavirin. A revamping plan he announced in June only added to the discord. Facing a potential proxy fight at ICN's annual meeting in December, Mr. Panic said today that he would separate Ribapharm, ICN's international operation, and its North and South American businesses to create three independent public companies. Mr. Panic, a former prime minister of Yugoslavia, will also cut all management ties with Ribapharm and remain head of the overseas business, which is mainly in Eastern Europe.

title: As Art Prices Soar, Aesthetics Take a Back Seat : When Buyers Overlook Beauty
description: LONDON  Like a forest fire jumping from one dried-up tree to the next, inflation is running through the entire art market. The well known cause is the inexorable shrinking of art supplies. The less familiar consequence is the gradual elimination of aesthetics as a criterion in the price-making process.

title: The First 13 Stops
description: From 1921 through 1956, more than a third of the World Series played never left New York City. The Yankees won 10 of them, the Giants won 2 and the Dodgers won the other one as well as the hearts of underdogs everywhere. RAY CORIO

title: Americans Overcome Slow Start To Keep Lead
description: After a day of shifting momentum at the Presidents Cup, the United States team remained in control as the International team remained in deep trouble.

title: The Dramatic Galleries of Carlo Scarpa, Architect : A Choreographer of Light
description: VERONA, Italy  When the Venetian architect Carlo Scarpa said in 1972 that he would rather design museums than skyscrapers, he was ahead of his times, anticipating the situation today, when galleries have become absolutely prime prestige projects, and the design of a museum can attract more attention than its contents.

title: Trial of Salvadoran Generals in Nuns' Deaths Hears Echoes of 1980
description: ''I hope you come to find that which gives life a deep meaning for you,'' Sister Ita Ford once wrote to a teenage niece. ''Something worth living for, maybe even dying for.''

title: BUSH WOULD STOP U.S. PEACEKEEPING IN BALKAN FIGHTS
description: If elected president, George W. Bush plans to tell NATO that the United States should no longer participate in peacekeeping in the Balkans, signaling a major new division of labor in the Western alliance, according to Mr. Bush's senior national security aide.

title: ERICSSON WARNS OF WEAKNESS
description: Shares of Ericsson plunged almost 16 percent after the company warned that sales and margins would be lower than expected for the fourth quarter because of losses in mobile-phone manufacturing. The warning overshadowed news that Ericsson's third quarter results were better than expected. Ericsson's president, Kurt Hellstroem, said the company planned to restore earnings by narrowing the product line and moving manufacturing to emerging markets. Ericsson said earnings nearly doubled to 4.3 billion kronor, or about $430 million, and sales grew 37 percent. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNELIS, REV. PATRICK J.
description: McNELIS-Rev. Patrick J. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor of Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, 2805 Ft. Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, on October 19. Reposing in Pitta Funeral Home, 300 McDonald Ave., Brooklyn, on Sunday October 22, from 25 PM. Mass of Transferral on Sunday, October 22 at 7:30 PM. Funeral Mass on Monday, October 23 at 10:30 AM. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Batter Up! The Battle of New York Is at Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: My Hunt For Moscow Gold
description: I met Gus Hall, America's most durable official Communist, in 1983, when I paid him a visit in his baronial eighth-floor office at the West 23rd Street headquarters of the American Communist Party. Then, as at his death last week, he seemed stubbornly unapologetic about being general secretary of a party whose time had passed.

title: Whipping Boys Of Baseball Smell a Victory
description: It was before a regular season game against the St. Louis Cardinals this summer and the Mets were saluting the 10 greatest moments in club history. Among them: Tom Seaver's almost perfect game and the trade for a washed-up Willie Mays.

title: Delgado Becomes Top-Paid Player
description: With one signature, Carlos Delgado settled two issues yesterday: he agreed to a new four-year, $68 million contract with the Toronto Blue Jays, ensuring his continued employment as the team's first baseman and eradicating a question about who had been baseball's highest-paid player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLUB, DAVID
description: GOLUB-David. The Board and staff of Chamber Music Northwest deeply mourn the untimely loss of our esteemed pianist, David Golub. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his family and his many musical colleagues. Portland was immeasurably blessed by David's artistry and friendship over the years, and we will cherish the memories forever. Linda Magee, Executive Director David Shifrin, Artistic Director

title: Money a Focus In Last Debate In New Jersey
description: Judging from today's fifth and final debate, the New Jersey contest for the United States Senate has come down to which candidate the voters will trust more to spend billions in new federal money for education, health care, land conservation and other programs, without burning up the entire government surplus.

title: Fastballs in Polonia's Future?
description: Luis Polonia has just two at-bats in the postseason, and there is a chance he will not bat during the World Series. But Polonia knows that if he does bat, after weeks of languishing on the bench, he will probably be called upon to face the Mets closer, Armando Benitez.

title: Batter Up! The Battle of New York Is at Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the earnings of eBay, the Internet auctioneer, referred imprecisely to its revenues for the period ended Sept. 30. The figure of $102.8 million was for online operations; consolidated net revenues were $113.4 million.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil shot up 2.6 percent as violence in the Middle East escalated yesterday. Crude oil for November delivery rose 84 cents, to $33.75 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: 1956 vs. 2000? It's Deja Vu All Over Again, Except for When It's Not
description: During a desperately contested presidential election, in the media and cultural capital of the world, in a boom town where Broadway theaters were flourishing and entrepreneurs were pioneering a fledgling new video industry, New Yorkers took to the subways to cheer on pennant winners from rival boroughs as they waged World Series war.

title: Share Prices Up for the Week on Profit and Sales Growth
description: Stocks rose yesterday, finishing their first winning week in seven, as computer-related and telecommunications companies reported faster-than-expected profit or sales growth.

title: Fire Kills 20 in Mexico City; Site Was Long Seen as Danger
description: At least 20 people died today when a fire destroyed a huge nightclub in the heart of Mexico City that had been repeatedly cited for safety violations, officials said. The deaths set off an outcry against Mexico's ingrained public corruption. which may have contributed to the deaths.

title: Corrections
description: An article and an illustration in Business Day on Thursday tracing troubles at the Xerox Corporation misstated the role of the company's Palo Alto Research Center in developing the computer mouse. The mouse was invented in the 1960's by Douglas C. Engelbart and William K. English at the Stanford Research Institute; the Xerox center built on that work.

title: A Shrine and a Bowl, But Both Are Home
description: Baseball, the most nostalgic of games, is inherently reverent about the concept of home. The home team gives visitors first ups, but keeps the privilege of last licks and turning out the lights. The game's most majestic event is a journey of departure and return, the home run. Indeed, all batters seek to leave home plate, but the finest teams are those who bring them back to it most often. It's even shaped like a house.

title: Article 2000102192133637469 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Beliefs; Bright religious thinkers and scholars seldom appear on America's common cultural stage.
description: Nothing like a train ride for catching up on unread magazines. But this week, an old question about religious thinkers and American culture cropped up again -- halfway, as a matter of fact, between Washington and New York and halfway through a charming article on predestination.

title: BIN LADEN LINKED TO EMBASSY BLAST BY AN EX-SOLDIER
description: A former sergeant in the United States Army has directly linked Osama bin Laden for the first time to the bombing of the American Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, in 1998. The link came as the former sergeant, Ali A. Mohamed, pleaded guilty yesterday to participating in a terrorist conspiracy against Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCK, STANLEY
description: LOCK-Stanley. Sarah Lawrence College notes with sorrow the death on October 8 of Stanley Lock, faculty member emeritus, pianist, teacher, beloved colleague. His love of music and his superb talent enriched the lives of the entire College community where he taught from 1949-1991. Michele Tolela Myers, President Barbara Kaplan Dean of the College

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Off the Menu column of the Dining section on Wednesday about Jimmy's Uptown, at 2207 Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard (130th Street), was published in error. The restaurant is not scheduled to open until Nov. 13.

title: KOREAN AIR STRIKE THREAT
description: Despite $200 million spent over the last three years by Korean Air to upgrade safety, pilots are threatening to strike, saying the airline is unsafe because they are forced to fly too many hours. The strike vote will continue into this weekend, and if the results favor a strike, the 1,330 unionized pilots plan to walk off their jobs at 6 a.m. Sunday. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: A New Respect for Age in Florida
description: Pauline Bracken got home last Sunday to find a long message on her answering machine that began: ''Hello, this is Barbara Bush. I'm calling to tell you about my son George W.'s plan to protect Social Security.''

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com

title: Liberties; Dare Speak His Name
description: Set him free!

title: A French Bistro Beckons in Larchmont
description: FROM its place on the broadness of Chatsworth Avenue here, Encore glows its welcome. With sunny yellow walls and chandeliers and sconces of flowers in amber glass, this bright bistro francais delights the eye. As its name cleverly suggests, return visits are in order, and we would eat here again despite a few flaws.

title: One Good Turn Is Likely to Lead to Another
description: WHAT had been 13 acres of corn to feed a small herd of cattle has became a labyrinthine affair for those seeking a navigational challenge and willing to pay a $5 entry fee for it.

title: Lover of Bright Colors Always Finds Her Coat
description: To the Editor:

title: Legislator Makes the News By Reading It on Television
description: When Diane Allen was a news anchorwoman in Philadelphia, she was known for wheedling information out of sources, disarming them with charm and then zeroing in for the kill, making her popular among viewers and admired among her peers.

title: The Widow Peaks
description: Would anyone care about Yoko Ono's work if she weren't related to John Lennon? To find out, perhaps she could do a performance piece in which she gives all her money away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELNER, MARJORIE
description: ZELNER-Marjorie. We mourn the passing of Marjorie Zelner, wife of our friend and business partner Larry Zelner. Marjorie's friendship, integrity, competence and family devotion set an example for all who knew her. May Larry and her son Jonathan draw consolation from the close and loving relationship which they shared. Laurie and Barry Badner

title: It's Generational
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Roadside Recollections
description: Before Las Vegas hotels began belching flame and impersonating Venice and Paris, there were motor courts, tiny roadside collections of cabins where tired motorists would pull in at the end of a long drive. They often had no air-conditioning, and the closest thing to a data port was a newspaper box.

title: Wendy Benson, Michael Landes
description: Wendy Cunningham Benson, a daughter of Gigi and Harry Benson of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Christopher Landes, a son of Patricia and Bernard Landes of Laguna Niguel, Calif. Canon Harry E. Krauss performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Paul Tabor, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Bookend; Return to Gitche Gumee
description: When Henry Wadsworth Longfellow was in England in 1868 to receive an honorary degree from Cambridge University, Queen Victoria invited him to tea. She was a great admirer of his work and found his company delightful. When she accompanied the poet to the door and watched him walk down the long palace corridor, she saw something slightly disconcerting. ''I noticed,'' she confided to her diary that night, ''an unusual interest among the attendants and servants. I could scarcely credit that they so generally understood who he was. When he took leave, they concealed themselves in places from which they could get a good look at him as he passed. I have since inquired among them, and am surprised and pleased to find that many of his poems are familiar to them. No other distinguished person has come here that has excited so peculiar an interest.''

title: Experts With Feet of Clay? Test Them.
description: FEELING left out? Don't worry; there's a group or club or society you can join for any interest you might have.

title: New Leader Of Yugoslavia Due in Bosnia
description: Vojislav Kostunica, the new Yugoslav leader, will visit Sarajevo on Sunday for the first such visit by a Yugoslav president since Bosnia declared independence in April 1992 and a three-and-a-half-year war followed.

title: Making People on the Margin Real
description: LAURENCE FISHBURNE had come to know well the universe depicted in his new movie ''Once in the Life,'' an urban landscape where the streets are bleak and menacing, where the habitats are drug lords' garish lairs and junkies' decrepit shooting galleries. But it was professional rather than personal experience that had given him the education. Growing up in the acting business, Mr. Fishburne, who is 39, played a passel of standard-issue street types, the thugs and hustlers who often reside at the shabby edges of movies, television shows and plays about crime and depravity in the city.

title: With Ads and Rallies, Bush and Gore Hope to Mobilize Their Core Supporters
description: Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush each sought to energize their core supporters today, with Mr. Gore reaching out to union members and black ministers and Mr. Bush telling Republican get-out-the vote meetings in Washington State that his opponent favors ''meddling, overbearing government.''

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: INWOOD; Beloved Library Is Shuttered Even Longer Than Expected
description: The Inwood Regional Library, which closed nearly two years ago for a $3.8 million expansion and renovation, is not expected to reopen until next April, library officials have said. The reopening is now a year behind schedule, and residents say they want their library back.

title: Cemeteries as Storytellers
description: Tucked into almost every old community in New Jersey is a cemetery that became the final resting place of the famous, the infamous and the ordinary folks who helped create the state.

title: Chechnya Caught In Unending Limbo Of War and Peace
description: Zura Uzuyeva was just cleaning up the dishes in the courtyard of her small brick home in the Oktyabrsky district of the Chechen capital last week when the staccato drone of a Russian attack helicopter bathed the neighborhood, the volume rising as it approached.

title: Can't Find a Parking Spot? Aww.
description: To the Editor:

title: Open-Space Fund Goes to Historic Buildings, Too
description: Forty-nine historic sites received approval for funding last week under a state program that to date has provided money primarily to preserve farmland and open spaces.

title: Timeouts for a Son's Football Games
description: One of the most husbanded resources in any campaign is time. In a campaign as close and important as this year's presidential race, the candidates' daily schedules are negotiated only after countless arguments and untold hours of polling analysis.

title: For the Passionate Collector
description: WITH collecting vying with gardening as America's leading hobby, the annual antique show at Lockwood-Mathews Mansion has chosen ''Collecting in the 21st Century'' as its theme.

title: Idees Fixes
description: Thousands of fashion fans, in Paris recently for the spring 2001 collections, wore their newest clothes, and three ideas stood out.

title: Taking the 'Hippie-Dippie' Out of Health Food Stores
description: THINK organic food stores and what comes to mind?

title: Experience Counts
description: The Yankees dropped the rookie left-hander Randy Choate from their 25-man roster to make room for Jose Canseco for the Series. The Yankees debated whether to keep Choate or Jason Grimsley, a right-hander who is pitching with a sore elbow that will require surgery. ''Basically, it came down to experience,'' Joe Torre said.

title: Farewell, Travelgate
description: The final report on Hillary Rodham Clinton's behavior in the 1993 dismissal of White House travel office employees was released and it showed that Robert W. Ray, the independent counsel, believed her claim to have had little involvement was ''factually false.'' But he said there was insufficient evidence to bring criminal charges for perjury or obstruction of justice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGIBBONS, JOAN
description: FITZGIBBONS-Joan. October 19, 2000. Beloved wife of the late John A. Fitzgibbons. Devoted & loving mother of Ann Fitzgibbons and Jack Fitzsgibbons. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Saturday 7-9PM and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial Monday October 23, 11 AM, St. Joan of Arc Church, 82nd Street at 35th Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Selig Says Series Is the Hottest Ticket
description: Commissioner Bud Selig has heard the talk that a Subway Series will hold little allure outside New York, but from the way the phones have been ringing at Major League Baseball's offices this week, he is certain that there is little truth to it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORGEL, JEROME J., D.D.S.
description: ORGEL-Jerome J., D.D.S. On October 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Marion. Devoted father of David, Carole, Josh and Andy. Loving grandfather of twelve. Services private.

title: Murder in Laramie
description: Losing

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Back on the Stage With a Mission

title: Nassau Begins Process of Tax Reassessment
description: A LEVELING of an uneven, outdated and flawed property assessment system that is widely conceded to favor the rich and penalize minorities began in Nassau County last week, with property assessors snapping pictures of homes in the Village of Hempstead.

title: Can Riddick Bowe Answer the Bell?
description: Riddick (Big Daddy) Bowe is pacing, as if he's warming up before a title fight. A few purposeful steps to the left, then an abrupt turn as if he has reached the ropes. He is not, however, in a 20-foot ring at Caesars Palace. Nor is his left hand sheathed in a 10-ounce glove, ready to inflict damage. No, the left hand of the former heavyweight champion of the world is wrapped in a red sweat rag. It's sweltering inside his 12-car garage, and Bowe, now weighing nearly 300 pounds, daubs perspiration from his brow and stares thoughtfully at his machines: two Mercedeses, a Rolls-Royce Seraph, a BMW 750, a Harley, a Bentley, a vintage 1970 Caddy, a customized Ford Suburban and, Bowe's first car, a 1990 Jeep Cherokee. After a minute, Bowe's small brown eyes widen. He turns to me and flashes the clownish grin -- now made even more impish by the addition of braces -- that delighted and confounded boxing fans just a few years ago.

title: A Start-Up at Paumanok
description: Paumanok's '98 cabernet franc rates a B-plus for effort and a C-plus for accomplishment. That's pretty good, considering that it is the winery's first stand-alone cabernet franc (with 10 percent cabernet sauvignon providing support in the blend).

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK LAUGHTER; How Do You Celebrate a 2,039th Birthday? Steak, Potatoes, and Pass the Wisecracks
description: It was a once-in-a-millennium celebration.

title: A True Subway Series
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A credit on Oct. 8 for an illustration with an essay called ''An Armchair Husband'' misspelled the artist's surname. She is Emily Lisker, not Lister.

title: Kellogg Shuts Memphis Plant Over Genetically Altered Corn
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  The Kellogg Company has shut down a cereal plant because it could not guarantee that corn used in production would be free of a genetically modified grain approved only for animal consumption.

title: It Certainly Glitters, but What Is It Worth?
description: PETER L. BERNSTEIN would be a wonderful dinner partner. He has an immense base of knowledge, from which he combs one good story after another. His tales are all rich with interesting characters and charmingly told. Though he has clearly done the scholarly reading, he would never bore you with minutiae. At the end of such an evening, you would understand that his stories all served his theme.

title: After 20-Year Effort, Shadmoor's a State Park
description: THE Shadmoor property, nearly 100 acres of Montauk moorland with spectacular views from shoreline bluffs overlooking the Atlantic Ocean, will become the 162nd state park and the third state park created on Long Island in two years.

title: IN BRIEF: Development; NEW CASTLE: GOLF COURSE APPROVED
description: The Board of Legislators has approved $1.75 million to design and build an 18-hole golf course in New Castle on 174 acres formerly owned by International Business Machines. The course, to be known as Hudson Hills, will be the county's sixth public course. The property had been used as a golf course from 1926 to 1984, when I.B.M. bought it as an office site. But I.B.M. did not build on the land and sold it in 1997 to the county for $3.6 million. The county is still studying whether its Parks Department or a private contractor should operate the course. Elsa Brenner

title: Prying Secrets When Men Meet
description: WITH baseball, football, hockey and preseason basketball all clamoring for attention at the moment, the notion that five men might spend two hours in a room together and not talk about sports seems beyond improbable. Yet that is just what happens in ''Elephant Sighs,'' the flawed but likable comedy now having its East Coast premiere at the Forum Theater in Metuchen.

title: Chasing Fame Until It Bites
description: WHAT would Cameron Crowe write about Jennifer Lopez if he were a 15-year-old music journalist today? In ''Almost Famous,'' Mr. Crowe presents a giddy, lightly fictionalized account of his own adventures in the mid-1970's on the road for Rolling Stone magazine with bands like Led Zeppelin and the Allman Brothers. Rock was at its most potent, and Rolling Stone covers were monumental publicity.

title: When That Corner Office Is Also a Dorm Room
description: COLLEGE as a networking opportunity. The Internet as a protective screen, through which performance trumps age and inexperience. Trading the leisure of youth for the chance to make an impact -- and wondering whether it is worth it.

title: Hindu Hard-Liners Pressing To Keep Excluding Muslims
description: Bangaru Laxman, the new president of the Bharatiya Janata Party, which leads India's coalition government, has been trying lately to distance the party from its Hindu nationalist roots and the Hindu chauvinist thinking that has long alienated Muslims and many others in this predominantly Hindu nation.

title: A Principal Is Fired at P.S. 3, And Angry Parents Ask Why
description: The principal of P.S. 3, a highly regarded, progressive school in Greenwich Village, was fired late Friday afternoon, angering many parents and teachers, who vowed to challenge the decision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORELICK, SHIRLEY
description: GORELICK-Shirley. On Thursday, October 19, 2000, of Chevy Chase, MD. Beloved wife of Leonard Gorelick. Mother of Jamie Gorelick and Steven Gorelick. Motherin-law of Richard Waldhorn. Grandmother of Alyssa Gorelick, Daniel and Dana Waldhorn. Memorial contributions may be made to the Shirley Gorelick Fund for the Arts at Georgetown Day School, Washington, DC, or the National Museum of Women in the Arts.

title: The Art of the Glimpse
description: The Hill Bachelors

title: Guess What Sells Cars. Guess Again.
description: IN a borough of $4,000-a-month studios and private-school girls flinging Fendi baguettes around like, well, loaves of French bread, you can hardly blame Mercedes-Benz Manhattan for imagining that its cheeky new print advertisement would arouse little more than sophisticated smiles.

title: Immigrant Women, And Their Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Getting Better
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR YOUNG VIEWERS
description: This week's episodes of ''Dragon Tales'' (Monday through Friday at 9 a.m. on Channel 13) focus on Cassie, shown here with her friend Emmy.

title: G.O.P. Fight With Clinton On Immigrants Splits Party
description: Congressional Republicans are locked in a battle with the White House over easing immigration law that threatens to undercut Gov. George W. Bush's efforts to court Hispanic voters and shed the party's lingering image as insensitive to new immigrants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUMINER, SHARON
description: HOUMINER - Sharon. Beloved daughter of Ehud and Naomi. Loving sister of Talia, and Orly and Yaacov. Service Monday, 10 AM, Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Rd, White Plains. For information call Plaza Memorial, 212-769-4400.

title: Economic Windfall Is Not Guaranteed
description: No one doubts that the Subway Series has bathed New York in spiritual riches. It has lifted the morale of baseball fans all over the region and drawn national attention to the Big Apple; it is also a great spectacle, an epic contest between a long-reigning champion and a wild-card challenger.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-22-00; What They Were Thinking
description: Helen Dixon, Winters, Calif., August 1955

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE CASE OF DR. SACHS

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on Sept. 24 about building a labyrinth as a site for meditation on East 136th Street in the Bronx referred incorrectly to Friends Inc., the social service agency that commissioned it. The group is independent and nonprofit, not a project of the Visiting Nurse Service, which provides Friends with a crisis intervention team. The article also referred misstated the involvement of Katherine G. Levine. She is the director of that team, not a director of Friends.

title: The Subtle Drama Found in Silence and Rue
description: WHEN Edward Zwick and Marshall Herskovitz began developing the drama series ''thirtysomething'' almost 15 years ago, they gathered a group of writers to propose story ideas. ''What if Hope got raped?'' one asked, referring to a central character. The two producers were appalled, not by the prospect of reckoning with a sexual assault on network television but by the notion that it could be handled plausibly in a single episode. In real life, they said, the effects of such a crime would rumble for years.

title: Robinson Mixes It Up, and Devils Respond
description: Dissatisfied with the way his club had been playing, Devils Coach Larry Robinson made several moves tonight that lighted a fire under the defending Stanley Cup champions. With Chris Terreri making his first start in goal and with three centermen joining new line combinations, the Devils trounced the Tampa Bay Lightning,7-2, at Continental Arena.

title: Of Love Lost And Found (Also Music)
description: IT's a warm September afternoon, a fine day for listening to the Cole Porter melodies that trickle out of one of the spacious studios at American Ballet Theater's headquarters in downtown Manhattan. Inside, the choreographer Christian Holder is rehearsing ''Weren't We Fools?,'' his new ballet for the company's two-week season, which begins on Tuesday at City Center.

title: Single-Issue Groups Double Efforts
description: Every weekend, Gary Davis folds his 6-foot-5-inch frame into a black pickup truck -- the one with the license plates that say, ''THE NRA'' -- and rides like some latter-day Paul Revere to local gun shows, gun shops and shooting ranges bearing this alarm: Vice President Al Gore and his Democratic allies are coming, and they want to take away your guns.

title: Rio's Polluted Beaches Pose a Challenge
description: FOR the past decade, irate residents of this city have been complaining of a mounting pollution problem that has on occasion led health officials to declare such world-famous beaches as Copacabana and Ipanema unfit for swimming. But now, with the Southern Hemisphere summer tourist season fast approaching, authorities are investing heavily in public works projects intended to improve the water quality of those and other beaches.

title: The Stiff Guy vs. The Dumb Guy
description: The endorsement of the vice president by Fabio, ''the musclebound patron saint of non-butter-disbelievers,'' should have been satirized by the ''Daily Show'' writers as: ''Al Gore -- I can't believe he's not Bubba!''

title: SOAPBOX; Tales of 10-Cent Banana Splits
description: MY grandson is waiting for a bedtime story. Harry Potter is put aside. Dr. Seuss is rejected.

title: One Bad Cop
description: Lou Cannon (Oct. 1) contrasts ''the sheer lack of public outcry'' in the Los Angeles Police Department's Rampart corruption scandal to the response to the 1992 riots. But the riots frightened the city's upscale communities, creating a specter of Molotov-cocktail-wielding mobs rampaging through Beverly Hills.

title: NEW FRONT OPENS IN EFFORT TO FIGHT RACE BIAS IN LOANS
description: Two class-action lawsuits filed in Nashville against two of the nation's most prominent automobile finance companies have opened a critical new battlefront in government efforts to combat racial discrimination in the consumer credit markets.

title: MUSIC; A Megastar Long Buried Under a Layer Of Blackface
description: ON a Sunday night in September 1918, the great operatic tenor Enrico Caruso stepped onstage at the Century Theater in New York to perform as part of a special program put on by the Army Tank Corps Welfare League. Caruso dazzled the audience with his rendition of Italian war songs, before launching into a surprising finale, the patriotic tune ''Over There,'' which left the audience in a state of frenzy.

title: The Magical and the Mythical
description: AN expressive figurative style and vivid colors are two characteristics that come to mind when one envisions Latin art. What escapes this preconceived notion is a mythical or magical quality, which becomes the central theme of a new show at the Rye Art Center here, titled ''Introducing Friends and Neighbors: Contemporary Mexican and Cuban Art.''

title: Stars Do the Talking
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSLAND, ELIZABETH CORBIN
description: KINGSLAND-Elizabeth Corbin. Passed away peacefully October 15, 2000, in New York City. She leaves behind a son, Nicholas Corbin Kingsland, of Washington, D.C., & a daughter, Lucia Gesinus Visser, of Versoix, Switzerland. She was devoted to both, and they will both miss her very much. She will also be much missed by her two brothers, R. Beverley Corbin, Jr., of Newport, R.I., and Robert E. Corbin, of Palm Beach, FL. She grew up in Newport, R.I., and New York City, where she spent her final years. Service on Monday, October 23, 2000, 1:30 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC.

title: There Is No Choice but to Love the Yankees
description: Don't take this as a confession, an apology or a boast. It is barely a disclosure. It is a fact so simple, so obvious, so in character, that it bears declaration only because of this feverish moment in the life of the city.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Page 12 of the Travel section today about luxury resorts in the Caribbean includes an outdated reference to the reopening of the Four Seasons Resort Nevis. It is scheduled for Nov. 19, not Nov. 24.

title: Anjali Kapoor, William Bissell
description: Anjali Kapoor, a daughter of Manju and Vijai Kapoor of New Delhi, is to be married there today to William N. Bissell, the son of Bimla Bissell of New Delhi and the late John L. Bissell. Acharya Shastri, the chief priest at the Chattarpur Temple in Old Delhi, is to perform the Hindu ceremony at the bride's home.

title: 'Rosie the Riveter' Honored in California Memorial
description: It has been more than half a century since the photographer Dorothea Lange came to the bustling wartime shipyards of this long-beleaguered city across the Bay from San Francisco to chronicle the lives of real-life ''Rosie the Riveters.''

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for MICHELE BURNS; How an Airline Burns Less Money
description: AMONG the nation's airlines, the top performers in the third quarter were those that did the best at protecting themselves against soaring energy prices.

title: Along With a Lender, Is Citigroup Buying Trouble?
description: WALL STREET rejoiced last month when Sanford I. Weill, the legendary deal-making chairman of Citigroup, announced that it was buying Associates First Capital, one of the nation's largest consumer finance concerns, for $31 billion. Investors bet that the deal would repeat the success of Mr. Weill's other mergers, notably Salomon Brothers and Citicorp, while bolstering Citigroup's presence in Asia, where Mr. Weill is staking a big part of his company's future.

title: Can't Find a Parking Spot? Aww.
description: To the Editor:

title: Behind the Veil
description: Persian Mirrors

title: Correspondence/Chinese Street Justice; A Fender-Bender Becomes a Journey Down the Path of Least Resistance
description: IN China, foreign journalists tend to take a dim view of the police, who keep track of where we live, hassle us over visas and occasionally shoo us away from demonstrations or people that seem newsworthy.

title: Travel Advisory
description: ASYNAGOGUE REOPENS NEAR AUSCHWITZ Every year more than 500,000 people visit Auschwitz-Birkenau, where over one million Jews were killed between 1940 and 1945. Few, however, cross the Sola River to the nearby town of Oswiecim (pronounced ohsh-vee-EN-tseem), which in 1939 was a bustling Polish community of roughly 12,000 people, most of them Jewish. Only one Oswiecim synagogue, the Chevra Lomdei Mishnayot, survived the war, having first been used as a Nazi munitions depot and then as a carpet warehouse under the Communist regime.

title: Ukrainian Says He Arrested Wallenberg
description: An elderly Ukrainian has claimed in an interview broadcast here that he was the World War II fighter who arrested Raoul Wallenberg, the legendary Swedish diplomat who helped thousands of Jews escape Nazi capture before vanishing forever into Soviet hands in 1945.

title: A Home Is Damaged After a Mercury Spill
description: WHEN mercury spilled in the basement of Frank and Susan Giampiccolo's home in Tarrytown, N.Y., in August during a routine pressure test of the gas lines, it became a homeowner's nightmare.

title: Whitney Lucas, John Rosenberg
description: Whitney Gay Lucas and John William Rosenberg were married on Friday by the Rev. Orlanda Brugnola, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: SEPTEMBER UNEMPLOYMENT
description: The state's unemployment rate dropped to 3.8 percent last month, down from 4.0 percent in August, the state Labor Department reported last week. The September unemployment rate marks the seventh consecutive month that New Jersey has held unemployment at or below 4 percent. The jobless rate has also been at or below the national rate since the beginning of the year and is 0.8 percentage points below a year ago. The state added 14,600 jobs in September. Of the new jobs, the Labor Department reported that 6,0000 were in the public sector and 8,000 were in the private sector. Local government also gained 8,100 jobs, offsetting a decrease in the number of people employed at the state and federal level. Anne Ruderman

title: A Caribbean Campus Where Relaxation Is a Major
description: I'D never before been to Jamaica, and didn't know quite what to expect. Before my husband, Stuart, and I left, my mother-in-law, an inveterate reader of travel magazines, had warned us that every criminal in the country was lying in wait for American tourists. But what we found upon landing at Montego Bay and rounding the corner into customs, was a group of musicians, in native garb, greeting us with a hokey welcome song.

title: Style; A New Balance
description: In the spiritual realm, one is told, there is no loss, just change.

title: An Artist Who Captured A Song in a Drawing
description: Reflecting on his career, Sidney Leff, 99, said, ''I knew when to hang out the moon and the stars.''

title: Paris Burns to a Tropic Beat
description: PARIS is getting so much better!'' Bernadette Hirsch said last Saturday. Actually, she was hollering. It was the only way to be heard above the din at the hot new Paris restaurant where Ms. Hirsch was, at the moment in question, standing on a dining table writhing to an Arabic cover of the theme from ''Shaft.''

title: Cheney, an Alpha Candidate, Casts His Line in a Sea of Men
description: Dick Cheney has not kissed Oprah, chatted up Regis or schmoozed with Rosie O'Donnell. In the great tradition of vice-presidential candidates, who have long been used to rally their party's political bases, Mr. Cheney seems to be shoring up the support of one of Gov. George W. Bush's most vital voting blocs: men.

title: An Incorrect Artifact With Aging Fans
description: IN a ballroom at the Holiday Inn in Rockville Centre, on Long Island, Clive Baldwin was channeling the performance of the legendary vaudevillian Al Jolson in the 1927 movie ''The Jazz Singer'': his lips curled into a sorrowful grimace, his white-gloved hands opened wide in supplication, the whites of his eyes flashed with maudlin emotion. He crouched on one knee, hands over heart and pleaded to the rafters: ''Mammy! Mammy! I'm comin' home, Mammy!''

title: A Means to an End
description: To the Editor:

title: Outside the Stadium: Scalpers, Hope and Disappointment
description: The scene outside Yankee Stadium yesterday, as night fell and the noise rose, was a bazaar, filled with the wide-eyed and the mercilessly shrewd, the out-of-towners and the out-of-luck.

title: Dark Chocolate: 70's Movie Is an Unlikely Cult Hit
description: Oompa loompa doopity doo, I've got another riddle for you: Why is the 29-year-old movie ''Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory'' suddenly so popular all over town?

title: Not the Real Thing
description: The police said yesterday that they had seized hundreds of counterfeit World Series tickets and arrested 14 men in three schemes. And the police warned fans that if they bought from scalpers, they could end up with bogus tickets.

title: An Organ Legend In Vivid Memory
description: HOW many musicians -- performers, not composers -- ever achieve reputations strong enough that even 20 years after they've gone, people will still pay up to $100 a ticket to hear a concert in their honor?

title: Tracking the Customer To Her Office Lair
description: Three clothing stores for professional women opened last month on the site of the former Woolworth's on Third Avenue between East 41st and 42nd Streets. The stores offer many similar styles and are owned by the Casual Corner Group of Enfield, Conn. At the corner of 42nd Street is Petite Sophisticate, which offers outfits designed for the working woman in sizes 0 to 14. At the middle of the block is Casual Corner, for sizes 2 to 14, and August Max Woman, for sizes 14 to 26.

title: CITY LORE; The Day Tomorrow Died
description: THE Future died 60 years ago this Friday.

title: A Redemption Run? Conner Seeks Cup
description: With the Subway Series at last under way, it promises to be an eventful autumn week for some of the giant names in New York sports: Derek Jeter, Mike Piazza, Joe Torre, Dennis Conner.

title: Sarah Newbery, Garrett Finney
description: Sarah Wells Newbery, a daughter of Jane Newbery and the Rev. Charles Newbery of Scarborough, Me., was married in Philadelphia yesterday to Garrett Stevens Finney, a son of Katharine and Graham Finney of Philadelphia. The bride's father, who retired as the rector at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, N.Y., officiated at the home of Martha Finney, a sister of the bridegroom.

title: Trailing at Halftime, Virginia Tech Sidesteps Syracuse Upset
description: For 58 minutes 26 seconds tonight, Michael Vick was merely human. He had been sacked 8 times, had lost 46 yards the 15 times he had tried to run the ball and had completed 6 passes for 75 yards. Virginia Tech was clinging to a 15-14 lead with the clock winding down and the Hokies had third-and-5 at their 45-yard line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APFELBAUM, DORIS JANE
description: APFELBAUM-Doris Jane. On October 20, 2000. Beloved wife of Adek. Loving mother of Randy, Teri Lubin, and Scott. Adored grandmother of nine. Dear sister of Mae Folb. Service Monday, 1:30PM at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: NEWARK TUNNELS
description: Sealed and forgotten for decades, a segment of subway tunnel beneath downtown Newark will be resurrected for a new light rail line between the Broad Street train station and Elizabeth, officials announced last week. By recycling about 1,000 feet of tunnel beneath Raymond Boulevard, New Jersey Transit said it would save at least $80 million and a year of construction time on the line, which will also serve the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the Riverfront Baseball Stadium, Pennsylvania Station and Newark International Airport when it opens in 2005. The tunnels, built in the 1930's, once funneled 2,000 streetcars a day from Newark's suburbs to a downtown trolley terminal. Andrew Jacobs

title: Bowlmor Looks
description: What looks like a bowling shoe, has influenced Prada and is walking out of a new SoHo store on some of the hippest feet downtown? It's the Camper shoe, a Spanish brand whose retro athletic look has been spotted on the dogs of Hilary Swank, Kim Hastreiter of Paper magazine and DJ Spooky. The drawstring closures with little toggles that started appearing on Prada shoes a few seasons ago were first used by Camper in the 1970's. Another Camper signature -- a rubber athletic sole combined with a stylish leather upper -- seems to have inspired Louis Vuitton and Hermes.

title: Where Obsessed Hunters of Music Still Prowl
description: CUSTOMERS come from as far as Scotland and Japan or as close as around the corner. Over the last 20 years, the Record Exchange here has flourished while many neighborhood shops -- seemingly not much different -- have failed.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: I Love You, Ronnie

title: IN THE STUDIO WITH/Jim Fuess; Despite a Disorder, a Creator With Many Hats
description: AS a full-time artist, Jim Fuess fills canvases with vivid acrylics that he coaxes to flow, bubble, blend and feather into intriguing forms.

title: Golota's Early Departure Leaves Tyson Exasperated
description: For four hours on the undercard of Friday night's Mike Tyson-Andrew Golota heavyweight fight, a series of little-known boxers, several bloodied and bruised, raised themselves from a wooden stool in the corner of the ring and continued bouts they were sure to lose.

title: ATLANTIC CITY CENTER
description: Fairleigh Dickinson University's School of Hotel, Restaurant and Tourism has inaugurated a center in Atlantic City. Twenty-five students, most of whom are employed in the casino industry, enrolled in the program this month. The program is a partnership between the university and the Greater Atlantic City Hotel-Motel Association. Students choose from nine courses, taught at the Ocean One Mall, in such topics as leadership, casino accounting, food safety and the history of American casino gaming, which can be applied to a bachelors or masters degree. Bill Kent

title: Freud KO's Plato
description: HAPPINESS, DEATH, AND THE REMAINDER OF LIFE

title: Hands Off; Proposal for a State Law on Driving While Phoning
description: THERE has been considerable debate lately about the use of wireless phones by drivers in motor vehicles. Some local ordinances restricting motorists' wireless phone use have been hotly contested and widely reported.

title: Reinventing John Jay Or Merely Redistricting?
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Cheers For Sweatshops
description: Two cheers for sweatshops? With a third cheer for what? Naked corporate greed (Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn, Sept. 24)? Surely, huge corporations like Nike can devote a tiny part of their earnings to ensure that their workers are paid a living wage, work under humane conditions and aren't forced into 100-hour workweeks.

title: Fees for Dominican Passports Reduced
description: Accusing a predecessor of raising fees for passports and other consular services without permission, the head of the Dominican Consulate in New York announced a series of reductions yesterday in service costs paid by Dominicans, the city's poorest immigrant group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JAY J.
description: COHEN-Jay J. On October 19, 2000. Beloved husband of Clair. Devoted father of Brian and Michael.

title: Traffic Reports By Phone in 3 Digits
description: Last month Cincinnati became the first city to use the three-digit 511 telephone number to provide travelers with reports on traffic and road conditions, public transportation and other information. The number will gradually be introduced all across the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SOL
description: KAPLAN-Sol. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Sol Kaplan, associated with The Times since 1960.

title: Walking Under Water, With a Helmet
description: AS a science writer with an aversion to snakes, spiders and scorpions and a closet taste for creature comforts, I jumped at the chance to write the biography of the naturalist and explorer William Beebe when a friend offered me the project. A biographer, I imagined, would just write about scary scientific exploits. Besides, I knew that Beebe -- who began his career in 1899 as curator of ornithology at the newborn Bronx Zoo, went on to found the field of tropical ecology, then became famous in the 1930's by descending more than half a mile below the surface of the ocean in the tiny, fragile bathysphere -- had lived a civilized three-martini life wherever he had worked.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Ambitious Waterfront Plan for Stamford's South End
description: THE most ambitious real estate venture undertaken since the redevelopment of this city's downtown 30 years ago, a $200 million mixed-use waterfront complex to be built on 40 acres along the west branch of Stamford Harbor, is being hailed in many quarters of Stamford as a long-sought catalyst for the rebirth of the city's troubled South End peninsula. But the project is so large that some are already questioning certain details.

title: Again, Leiter Watches His Work Go to Waste
description: This has happened to Al Leiter before. Two previous times in the past two seasons, Leiter has pitched well enough to earn playoff victories only to see the Mets' usually dependable bullpen waste them.

title: Package Deal
description: Having attended college in Hartford a number of years ago, I remember that every weekend was kicked off by a trip to the ''packy.'' Perhaps George W., a Yale graduate, could confirm this.

title: Amy Healy, Adam Bahna
description: Amy Katharine Healy, a daughter of Katharine and Thomas Healy of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Ralph Adam Bahna, a son of Dorothy Bahna and Ralph M. Bahna of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. William J. Kennedy performed the ceremony at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Forgotten Sequel
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Simpson, Nick Hayes
