description: Lisa Courtney Simpson and James Nicholas Hayes were married on Friday in Hamilton, Bermuda. The Rev. James W. Francis, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony at Waterloo House, a hotel.

title: Getting Gases Down
description: Seven large manufacturing and energy companies joined a growing list of businesses pursuing sharp -- and voluntary -- cuts in their emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases. As a group, the companies, which included DuPont, Shell, and Alcan Aluminium, agreed to reduce emissions by about 90 million tons a year by 2010, which would put them 15 percent below their combined annual output a decade ago.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Critic's Choice movie page of the Television section last Sunday misidentified the actor standing beside Erich von Stroheim in the film ''Grand Illusion.'' He was Pierre Fresnay, not Jean Gabin.

title: Dangerous Debt Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: Game Turns on a Pressure-Packed At-Bat
description: It had been exactly four years since the Yankees, the powerful Yankees, had lost a World Series game. Enough time to serve a full term as president of the United States, enough time to earn a college degree and enough time for George Steinbrenner to once dismiss five managers. That is a long, long time.

title: Can't Find a Parking Spot? Aww.
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-22-00: ShopTalk; To Tell the Truth
description: Before stepping down on Oct. 1, Joe Lockhart won praise for his straightforward performance as White House press secretary. Over the same period, Allison Janney won praise -- and an Emmy -- for her artful performance as C.J. Cregg, White House press secretary on NBC's ''West Wing.'' Here, the two talk about watching each other work and the differences between their jobs.

title: A Legacy of Hints for Stain-Free Living

title: The Fuel for More Benefits
description: The surge in energy prices this year will help at least one group of Americans in 2001.

title: Return of the Native
description: THE RETURN OF FELIX NOGARA By Pablo Medina. 278 pp. New York: Persea Books. $25.95.

title: Resisting Temptation With Your Savings
description: Roll over, roll over, roll over. Retirement planners can repeat that financial advice to mobile young workers until they are blue in the face, but the message does not always get across, especially when cold hard cash is involved.

title: RACIAL PROFILING INQUIRY
description: Faced with news reports that New Jersey law enforcement officials may have concealed evidence of racial profiling for nearly three years, state legislators have called for investigations of who knew what and when. One focus will be former Attorney General Peter Verniero, now a state Supreme Court justice. During his confirmation hearings in May 1999, Mr. Verniero said he had no solid evidence that troopers discriminated against minority drivers until his office conducted its own investigation in early 1999. But state police memos from the fall of 1996 show that police commanders had detailed data showing that minorities were disproportionately stopped and searched by the State Police. Another memo indicates that Mr. Verniero was at a January 1997 meeting in which State Police commanders decided to limit what data they would turn over to investigators from the federal Justice Department. David Kocieniewski

title: Blue Chip to Blue Plate
description: Given Xerox's recent troubles -- market share eroding, cash evaporating, management scrambling, rumors swirling -- it can be hard to find anyone on Wall Street willing to bet on its stock.

title: London Theater Guide For the Disabled
description: The Society of London Theatre has begun an online guide to access for the disabled at London theaters, www.theatre-access.co.uk. It contains information about wheelchair access, sound amplification systems and admission policy for guide dogs. The guide also lists which performances feature sign-language interpretation and audio descriptions. There is a print version, as well, Access Guide for Disabled Theatergoers, available free in large type, Braille or on tape. Call (44-20) 7557 6751.

title: Here's Your Host
description: PARASITE REX

title: Two Ways to Get Ahead of a Global Index Curve
description: WOULD you like to have some fun at the expense of some index funds? A couple of opportunities are ahead.

title: Uncommonly Lucky
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENNELL, THOMAS FRANCIS III.
description: FENNELL-Thomas Francis III. Of New York, died October 20, 2000 after a courageous battle with cancer. He was the son of the late Thomas F. Fennell II, and Teresa Winters of New York. He is survived by his beloved wife Jenny McDonagh and brothers Daniel of Wyncote, PA, John of Wilmington, NC, Rupert of Spencertown, NY and Philip of Pawling, NY. He is also survived by four step-daughters, many nephews, nieces and cousins. According to his wishes, his remains are being donated for scientific research. A memorial service will be held soon. Donations in Tommy's memory may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice of Beth Israel Hospital, 1st and 16th St., New York, NY 10003.

title: A Seller's Tasting of Gems
description: A sundown chill swept off the glimmering Hudson and through the back door of Rockwood & Perry, which under different names has sold liquor and wine since 1934, starting right after Repeal. It was a slow Wednesday evening, a good time for a tasting.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: MR. WROE'S VIRGINS, by Jane Rogers. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $13.) This fact-based novel tells of the self-proclaimed prophet John Wroe (1782-1863), who persuaded his congregation to give him seven virgins for ''comfort and succor'' as servants in his Lancashire mansion. ''Rogers has conjured an engaging, serious and gleefully ironic novel, one that leaps headlong into the most ambitious and risky territories: faith, love and existential meaning,'' Kathryn Harrison wrote here last year.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with the continuation of a front-page article about the role of design in contemporary culture misstated the location of a Calvin Klein store designed by John Pawson. It is in Seoul, South Korea, not Manhattan.

title: WEEHAWKEN ZIP CODE
description: Weehawken may get its own ZIP code. The town now shares 07087 with Union City, but Representative Bob Menendez and Mayor Richard Turner of Weehawken last week announced that next month, the city will send residents a survey asking whether a new code is needed. If a majority respond affirmatively, a new code will be assigned by July; the new number has not been decided. The mayor said Weehawken mail was frequently delivered to Union City addresses and that Weehawken was overlooked in Web searches made by ZIP code. Angela Starita

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; Rivals Combine to Develop Exxon Mobil Campus
description: CORPORATE mergers breed real estate opportunities. Such an opportunity recently attracted two development companies that over the years have been both rivals and neighbors to become partners as well.

title: Food; Meat Loaf: The Musical
description: Oliver Clark, the actor, cook, magician, mechanical-bank collector, folk-art enthusiast and one of the all-time 10-best brilliant dinner guests, pours olive oil into a pan and tosses in half a head of garlic with the theatrical flourish that is one of his many trademarks. He stands in a friend's kitchen, whipping up meat loaf and rigatoni, and it reminds me of the time we worked on a musical together.

title: IN BRIEF: Environment; RESTORING A SALT MARSH
description: A $140,000 federal grant will allow Westchester to restore a 55-acre salt marsh in Rye city. The restoration project, to be undertaken by the county's Department of Planning, will be paid for in part by a $47,500 county contribution of in-kind services (staff time for overseeing the design and construction.) A salt marsh is a tidal wetland, or a wetland found in or next to salt waters. Elsa Brenner

title: Streetscapes/The 1905 Gorham Building, at Fifth Avenue and 36th Street; Recreating a Stanford White Design -- Using Paint
description: IN 1960, the owner of the 1905 Gorham Building at Fifth Avenue and 36th Street, which was designed by Stanford White, ordered his architect to rip out delicate arches and carved relief figures as part of a redesign. Now a new owner of the building, which was declared a landmark in 1998, would like to restore the lost architecture -- but with paint, not with stone.

title: A Store of Their Very Own
description: LIKE hunters circling their prey, Nicole Pucci and Adrienne Hayes assessed the racks of clothes at Boo Girls. Would their quarry be the sequined skirt? That velvet top? Or perhaps the paisley dress?

title: Gun Control, Ignored
description: To the Editor:

title: Louis Vuitton to Open Store at The Westchester
description: Louis Vuitton will open a store next month in The Westchester in White Plains, selling the kind of luxury goods that are usually found on Madison Avenue. At the 1,700-square-foot store, fans of the brand's prints and patterns will find handbags, small leather goods and accessories like scarves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMASINO, ANGELO ANDREW
description: TOMASINO-Angelo Andrew. Beloved husband of Nancy. Devoted father of Joanne Scognamiglio and Christine Tomasino. Fond father-in-law of Gennaro Scognamiglio. Loving grandfather of Neil, Andrew and Nora. Longtime employee of the New York Times. Reposing at Hillebrand Funeral Home, 63-17 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 9:30 AM, St. Mary's Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Viewing hours Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to Jacob Perlow Hospice, 1st Ave. at 16th St., NYC 10003, and Families With Children From China Greater New York, PO Box 865, Ansonia Station, NY 10023.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILHELM, GLENN D.
description: WILHELM-Glenn D. With great sorrow, Mobile Wall One, Inc., greatly mourns the passing of our beloved friend and Chief Executive Officer, Glenn D. Wilhelm at the young age of 50. On behalf of all of the employees at Mobile Wall One, we extend our deepest condolences to his family. You will be in our hearts forever. Funeral services will be held at 2:30 PM at Goldsteins' Rosenberg's Raphael Sacks Suburban North, 310 2nd St. Pike, Southampton, PA, between County Line and Street Roads. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association, 800-242-8721.

title: PARENTAL NOTICE
description: In a new approach to requiring parental notification before minors get an abotion, the State Assembly held a public hearing last week on a constitutional amendment that would require parents to receive notice before their children undergo any medical or surgical procedure or treatment. The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled in August that a bill requiring parental notification before minors could obtain an abortion was unconstitutional. The amendment must receive either a three-fifths majority in both houses of the Legislature in one year or a simple majority in both houses in two consecutive years and then be ratified in a public ballot. Abhi Raghunathan

title: A Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: Next Hurdle: The 'Credit Divide'
description: FACING the television cameras, Jack Kemp, the former vice presidential candidate, sat proudly beside Jimmy Carter and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, ready to hail the 100,000th home built by Habitat for Humanity. It was a serene and dignified occasion, until Mr. Kemp's cell phone suddenly rang.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, KONRAD E.
description: BLOCH-Konrad E. The Board of Directors of the Camille and Henry Dreyfus Foundation records with deep sorrow the death of our distinguished friend and colleague on October 15, 2000. As an advisor to the Foundation for over 13 years from 1974 to 1987, he provided critical guidance in developing the Foundation's approach to its mission of supporting chemistry research and education.

title: Police and Union Chiefs Meet To Address Racial Profiling
description: The Rich Forum, Stamford's downtown arts center, usually features opera, ballet and concert performers like Peter, Paul and Mary and the Village People. But for two days this week, the quiet theater was a gathering place for two dozen police chiefs and police union presidents. They discussed racial profiling and other issues that strain relations between the police and racial minority groups, and strove to find solutions.

title: Crime
description: A promiscuous teenager is murdered in Lisbon. A grim police inspector opens the investigation. Suddenly, time slips its moorings in Robert Wilson's intelligent, unsettling thriller A SMALL DEATH IN LISBON (Harcourt, $25), winner of the 1999 Golden Dagger Award in England, wrenching the story from modern-day Portugal into a world at war in 1941. In this hellish place, the Germans are installed at the Hotel Parque, the British legation is next door at the Hotel Palcio, and the streets are swarming with war profiteers and refugees desperate to book passage on one of the packed ocean liners moored at the docks.

title: 'Gesture of Joy'
description: To the Editor:

description: WITH help from a tape of ''This Old Man,'' the class was counting to 10. Brittney Wei held up her fingers, one by one, and sang: ''Yat, yi, saamsei, ng, luk.''

The owner, Hiro Hirano, said he sells ''the kinds of things you won't find at Toys ''R'' Us and Kmart.'' But now you can find Mr. Hirano's toys on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, SANFORD N.
description: SHERMAN-Sanford N., 88, on October 10, 2000, in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. ''Shep'', a native of Cleveland, a New Yorker for over 50 years and a social worker beginning in the 1930's, was a pioneer in the field of family therapy. He was long employed by Jewish Family Services of New York, retiring as Executive Director in 1978. Husband of the late Anne (Goldman) Sherman, father of Ralph Sherman of Sudbury, MA., and Richard Sherman of Newton, MA, grandfather of Ben, David, Anya and Michael Sherman, father-in-law to Anita (Stern) Sherman and Leah (Frisher) Sherman. Also survived by his sister Gwen Balin of Canton, OH, and his companion, Yvette Davison. By his request, no service is being conducted.

title: 'Getting It'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-22-00: The Ethicist; Third-Party Time
description: In the coming presidential election, a third-party candidate best represents our beliefs, but we fear that a vote for him will help elect the worse of the two major-party candidates. However, to vote out of fear for the less bad major-party candidate works against desired long-term change. So, which is better: to vote for good or against evil? -- K. Cohen and M. Hoffmann, Portland, Ore.

title: Finding a Woman's Place On the Web and in the Market
description: The way she tells it, Muriel F. Siebert, founder of the Siebert Financial Corporation, the discount brokerage firm, has had every women's Web site in need of financial backing knocking on her door over the last couple of years.

title: The Widow Peaks
description: Yoko Ono might have been politely tolerated at the concert Amei Wallach attended (Sept. 24). But I've seen her mesmerize much larger (and more mainstream) crowds. The news media needs to get more in step with the public, since Ono is usually covered either as a rock star who dabbles in arcane art or, in this case, as an artist who makes ''caterwauling she calls music'' on the side. The point of Ono's career is to think outside of such boxes, and to show everyone how much better it feels out there.

title: Macbeth: Pageantry, but No Power
description: IT is the year of the men who mean to be president and it is the year of multiple Macbeths. It doesn't take a Shakespearean maven to figure out the connections.

title: Billowing Jewelry To Take the Edge Off
description: A small sterling silver jewelry shop, Chimaera, opened on Oct. 12 at 117 East Seventh Street (between First Avenue and Avenue A). The store's free-form jewelry is designed by the store's owner, Robin Morris. It is inspired by Ms. Morris's life experiences, she said, even though she lives in the hard-edged landscape of New York City. ''My jewelry is very organic, it's very asymmetrical,'' she said. One design used in both a ring ($65) and a bracelet ($220) is called Gate, and Ms. Morris said it was inspired by wrought iron gates she noticed in front of brownstones in the Village and the Upper West Side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KETIVE, SHIRLEY ''SHIRL
description: KETIVE-Shirley ''Shirl.'' Of Fort Lauderdale, FL, on October 20. Adoring, devoted wife of the late Nathan. Beloved mother of Alice (Fred) Rudin, Harriet Lerner and Sam (Randy) Ketive. Revered grandmother of Mitchell and Robert Rudin, and Rebecca Rudin Schoenberg, Valerie Ann and Jacques Lerner, and Kimberly Ketive. Great-grandmother of Scott and Benjamin Rudin, Elisabeth and Katherine Lerner, Greg, Jacob and Lilly Rudin, Miles and Paul Schoenberg. We pray she gets a chance to be with her beloved ''Nicky'' again. Interment private. Visits may be paid to the home of Randy and Samuel Ketive, Monday evening through Wednesday, October 25. Donations in her memory to the Alzheimers Foundation. For information, Gutterman-Musicant, 800522-0588.

description: When Columbia running back Johnathan Reese began to show flashes of greatness last season, Coach Ray Tellier switched to a one-back offense. Yesterday, Reese validated the decision with a career-defining game in the Lions' 49-21 victory over Dartmouth.

title: A Rare Opportunity For Real Architecture Where It's Needed
description: WE were getting a lot of mail from readers complaining that I never write about New York buildings, so my employers decided to build one. Not just any building, but a work of architecture, a project with the potential to raise the quality of building in New York. Last week, when I learned that Renzo Piano had been chosen to design the new headquarters for The New York Times, I knew that we had such a project.

Graduate of Fordham University. Former Customer Relations Manager for Pan American Airlines. Served in the U.S. Marine Corps in W.W. II. Reposing Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (NYC), Sunday 1-4PM. Funeral Mass Epiphany RCC, on Monday at 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELNER, MARJORIE S.
description: ZELNER-Marjorie S. Age 49. Loved and loving wife, mother and daughter. Survived by her husband Lawrence, son Jonathan and mother Judith Swirsky. Daughter of the late Dr. Leo Swirsky. Born in Brooklyn, NY and resident of Closter, NJ since 1985. Former Executive Director of The Institute for General Semantics. President of the Closter Board of Education. A dedicated business administrator and volunteer devoted to the mission of excellence in public education. Donations may be sent to Closter Board of Education, The Marjorie Zelner Fund, 340 Homans Ave., Closter, New Jersey 07624. Visiting at family home in Closter from 12:00 to 6:00 PM, Sunday, October 22. Please contact the family about interment arrangements.

title: The Nation: Voter Tune Out; Focusing on the Few, Blind to the Many
description: IN the cliffhanger that is the 2000 race for president, the drama should be palpable. Suspense should be building because, with just 16 days left, either Vice President Al Gore or Gov. George W. Bush could take the White House.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 22, 2000
description: Weeks

title: The Stiff Guy vs. The Dumb Guy
description: It is not surprising that late-night television comics are able to influence the outcomes of presidential elections (Marshall Sella, Sept. 24). Shallow, gaffe-a-day press coverage of politicians is more entertainment than news; members of Congress spend more time fund-raising than legislating; and candidates are willing to say just about anything to get elected. Our political system has been a joke for years.

title: Johnson Fights on Boards And at Table
description: Larry Johnson knows that his test will soon come. He will arrive at a hotel late one night, wide-awake and hungry after a plane ride or a game. The menu will be full of temptation, everything from chicken fingers and french fries to filet mignon. And Johnson, a long-time heavy eater, will somehow have to find a way to resist.

title: Braised, Deep-Fried or Sauteed Artichokes
description: JUST as the summer harvest fades, artichokes are back on the scene. When I was growing up, we only had them two ways: hot, with hollandaise, or cold, with mayonnaise. Each leaf was savored until you got down to the best part: the heart, or bottom.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Loud Edge of Brooklyn
description: Such is Amram Ducovny's skill as a writer that in his new novel, CONEY (Overlook, $26.95), he is able to transport readers swiftly into the garish and seamy heart of Coney Island on the eve of World War II; it's as if the lights of Dreamland and Luna Park were still brightly lit. This richly drawn portrait of 15-year-old Harry Catzker, the son of a writer whose stories are serialized in a Yiddish daily newspaper and a beautiful but alienated mother, offers a welcome twist on the coming-of-age novel. ''Coney'' is also a noirish thriller and a darkly comic and moving glimpse into the lives of Jewish immigrants in the 1930's. The story begins as Harry is offered an after-school job picking up betting slips from Coney Island's carnival freaks for the local bookie. The rude, oversexed, often hilarious fat ladies and dwarfs, not to mention his new gangster friends, offer Harry a welcome respite from the combative and pessimistic mood of his family. Take his grandmother, whom he calls Bama, for instance. After arriving in the United States in 1919, she immediately ''sniffed a mean, godless country. . . . She learned no English, guarding her illiteracy like a jewel. When Harry asked her why she did not speak English, she summoned a tone of irrefutable logic. 'For what do I need English? Did they speak English in Warsaw?' ''But Ducovny -- who, as it happens, is the father of the actor David Duchovny -- never resorts to Jewish stereotypes. Harry and his complicated, unpredictable family, as well as the Yiddish poet who boards with them, are struggling with more than just being strangers in a strange land. The grim shadow of the impending Holocaust abroad presages, it turns out, a smaller-scale disaster closer to home. The story of how Harry and his friends and relatives survive, thrive and flame out is as satisfying and exhilarating as a ride on the Cyclone. Dana Kennedy

title: 'Best Wishes, George Allen's Daughter'
description: Coincidentally, I purchased Jennifer Allen's book the day her article appeared in your magazine (Sept. 24). The article tells us a lot about the facts surrounding George Allen's career and his professional relationship with the owners. It tells even more about the character of Ms. Allen. At a time when speaking ill of the dead is in vogue, she hasn't written a ''Daddy Dearest,'' but rather a fair portrayal of a man who ''only wanted to coach.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: They'll Swim, Not Sink
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Fall Failure For the Mets' Benitez
description: Armando Benitez and Mariano Rivera become different pitchers every October. Rivera, the Yankees' closer, elevates his performance. Benitez, the Mets' closer, often crumbles. That disparity could be the most glaring in this World Series.

title: Spare the Praise, Help the Child
description: To the Editor:

title: One Bad Cop
description: Your writer insightfully draws the conclusion that the problem of police perjury lies not only with the police officer. Blame must be shared by the judge who accepts the police officer's perjured testimony and the prosecutor who presents the police witness and argues his credibility without challenge. But there is another player in the criminal justice system who must share some of the blame. That player is the underpaid public defender or court-appointed lawyer who tells himself and his client that it's no use challenging the police and the prosecutor.

title: Honey Taylor, Jed Nachman
description: Marjorie Armstrong Taylor, the daughter of Mary Scott Kendall of Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, and the late Carter Taylor, was married last evening to Joseph Robert Nachman Jr., a son of Penelope Stout Strakhov of Bedminister, N.J., and Mr. Nachman Sr. of New York. Belinda Jimenez, the chief judge of the department of civil registry in Puerto Vallarta, officiated at Hacienda Cora, a hotel there.

title: YOUTH DRUG USE
description: Fewer seventh and eighth graders are smoking marijuana and drinking, a report by the Partnership for a Drug Free New Jersey found last week. In its survey, 9 percent of students reported smoking marijuana within the past year, down from 13 percent in 1995, and drinking fell from 49 to 41 percent over the same period. The survey also found that students who talk to parents daily are less likely to drink or take drugs. Steve Strunsky

title: In Defense of Patrons
description: To the Editor:

title: Redskins' Owner Criticized Over Etiquette
description: Daniel Snyder, the Washington Redskins' owner, has quickly made enemies among a significant number of owners in the National Football League. But suddenly Snyder is beginning to irritate the league office as well, and now comes the possibility Washington could be fined a draft pick if Snyder continues what the N.F.L. views as an arrogant disregard for one of its rules.

title: Newcomers Savings and Loan
description: WHEN Jemma Legall Romain moved to New York from Trinidad in 1984, she flew on a ticket her mother had bought for her through a saving system known as a susu. Years later, when Ms. Romain had to raise money toward the down payment on her three-family house in Bedford-Stuyvesant, she too saved money in a susu. After she bought the house, she made it pay for itself by renting out two floors.

title: Artist Takes the Ordinary For an Extraordinary Spin
description: IN this season of political spinmeisters, what could be more appropriate than artwork that celebrates spin?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMAN, CHARLES
description: LIPPMAN-Charles. We shall miss the love, generosity, guidance, friendship and understanding Chuck shared with us for 30 years. He can never be replaced in our hearts and our lives. Sincere condolences to Alan and his family. The Gilston Family The Goorfin Family

title: An Unfinished Choreographer's Unfinished Work
description: FIVE years ago, in midcareer, Ralph Lemon disbanded his dance company. After a decade of successful choreographing and touring, he and his dancers decided that the strain of keeping the troupe together was no longer offset by the aesthetic rewards. So the dancers went their ways, and Mr. Lemon went enthusiastically into freefall.

title: One Bad Cop
description: It's frightening to consider the absolute power that these corrupt officers held, and their utter lack of respect for justice and even human life. As a veteran New York City cop (since 1973) and a prosecutor of police officers (since 1988), I see similarities between the Rampart scandal and the rogue cop Michael Dowd's career of corruption in the 75th Precinct, which led to the Mollen Commission in New York in the 1990's.

title: Making the Hudson Live Inside a Museum
description: THE Hudson River Museum sits amid green fields and river views, in a setting as gracious as the Victorian mansion from which it sprung. Until now, however, the river was merely a timeless backdrop, or the subject of paintings that hung on the museum's walls.

title: A Synagogue Reopens Near Auschwitz
description: Every year more than 500,000 people visit Auschwitz-Birkenau, where over one million Jews were killed between 1940 and 1945. Few, however, cross the Sola River to the nearby town of Oswiecim (pronounced ohsh-vee-EN-tseem), which in 1939 was a bustling Polish community of roughly 12,000 people, most of them Jewish. Only one Oswiecim synagogue, the Chevra Lomdei Mishnayot, survived the war, having first been used as a Nazi munitions depot and then as a carpet warehouse under the Communist regime.

title: In Affluent Rye, Man Named 'Pete' Lives Out of a Shopping Cart
description: THOMAS EDWALD ALDON cuts an unusual figure in this town of conservative, fashionably dressed residents.

title: A Lifetime of Kinship With Borges's Ambitions
description: IT is no surprise to discover links between the Argentina-born artist Osvaldo Romberg and the literary magician Jorge Luis Borges.

title: What Will Happen To Texaco's Headquarters?
description: If Chevron follows through with its acquisition of Texaco, what will happen to Texaco's 770,000-square-foot headquarters in Harrison?

title: Another Kind of E-Book
description: No, the Internet isn't everywhere, but it will be by next year. That's when when Verizon Communications, the corporate successor to Bell Atlantic, sends out its new phone books, in which people will be able to list e-mail and personal Web page addresses, along with their phone numbers. The annual cost is $36 for each listing.

title: Living With Wildlife Without Killing It
description: To the Editor:

title: Spices and More Around Murray Hill
description: ALI BABA

title: Melvin A. Cook, 89, Creator Of Explosives Used by Allies
description: Melvin A. Cook, an explosives expert whose innovations helped change the face of warfare and mining, died on Oct. 12 in Salt Lake City. He was 89.

title: Cruise Lines Sail Ocean Green
description: EAGER to improve its environmental image after several incidents of illegal dumping at sea, the cruise industry is taking steps ranging from monitoring ocean pollution to using surplus hydroelectric power at one port.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-22-00; The Gray American Novel
description: Poor Rabbit Angstrom -- he's missing out. In 1990, his creator, John Updike, killed him off at the premature age of 56 (two years younger than Updike at the time), curtailing an eager, questing life that had spanned four novels and as many decades. The message seemed to be that vitality belonged to the next generation -- to characters like Rabbit's daughter-in-law, Pru, with whom he guiltily enjoyed a quickie not long before he died. But now Rabbit is back -- at least, as a spectral presence -- in the novella ''Rabbit Remembered'' (due out next month), and a lot has happened in his absence. On the one hand, his children -- Nelson, the former cokehead, and Annabelle, his illegitimate daughter -- have turned out better than expected. On the other, Rabbit's widow, Janice, has married, of all people, the crude and angry Ronnie Harrison, Rabbit's old teammate and nemesis. Though now in their 60's, they have, we are clearly given to understand, a more than satisfactory sex life: Ronnie is easily Rabbit's match in the lovemaking department, and Janice boasts to herself about her frequent orgasms. At one point the 42-year-old Nelson, now separated and living at home and reduced to fantasizing about television actresses, comes upon Ronnie copping a feel in the kitchen.

title: Fly the Angry Skies
description: I suggest that flight attendants commit Jeff MacGregor's name and his characterization of us as ''flying waitresses'' to memory. That way, should an emergency occur on one of his flights, the cabin crew would know to concentrate their efforts on saving the lives of those passengers who respect our jobs as safety professionals.

title: POSTINGS: New Westchester County Golf Course; 18 Holes, $7 Million
description: After years of discussion over whether Westchester should build another public golf course, the Board of Legislators voted last week to appropriate $7 million for construction of an 18-hole course in New Castle in the northern part of the county, on 170 acres of land formerly owned by I.B.M.

title: Picture Is Worth 1,000 Hours
description: NEW YORKERS pride themselves on the quickness and acuity of their eyeball calculus: they find empty taxis in the rain and dodge weirdos weaving their way from afar. But Robert U. Akeret, a psychoanalyst and keen observer, thinks even New Yorkers fall short when it comes to analyzing what the camera captures.

title: Jumping In, As Exposed As the Cast
description: IT'S easy to overlook David Yazbek, the composer and lyricist responsible for the music that has made ''The Full Monty'' a new musical. Not only is he a Broadway novice, Mr. Yazbek is also laboring in the shadow of his own show's widely advertised male strippers. Behind all that onstage exposure, though, a composer is waiting to be discovered. And now, with ''The Full Monty,'' opening on Thursday at the Eugene O'Neill Theater, perhaps he will be.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: BATTLE OF WITS

title: Big Oil Gets Bigger
description: The Chevron Corporation announced that it would acquire Texaco Inc. for about $36.5 billion, thereby creating the world's fifth-largest oil company.

title: Sonia Lassiter, James Shelton III
description: Sonia Patrice Lassiter, the daughter of Evelyn and Herbert Lassiter of Ahoskie, N.C., was married yesterday to James Hugo Shelton III, a son of Joan McKinley Shelton and James Shelton, both of Washington. The Rev. H. Beecher Hicks performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Baptist Church in Washington.

title: Back to Nature
description: FOR many years the Naugatuck River had a reputation as one of the dirtiest, most dangerous rivers in the state. Now that dubious distinction could be its salvation.

title: POSTINGS: A Manufacturing Site Is Rezoned; New Apartments in Shadow of Manhattan Bridge
description: When construction was first proposed in the early 1990's, a manufacturing building was to go up in the shadow of the Manhattan Bridge at 148 Madison Street, east of Chinatown, a site zoned for commercial and manufacturing use. Now the site has been rezoned, and the plans call for an 11-story building with 80 apartments on its top nine floors and offices and retail space on the bottom two.

title: Belle Donne
description: To the Editor: Of Bologna's many nicknames that Elisabetta Povoledo mentions ''In Bologna, a Grand Plaza Defines the City'' (Sept. 24), she omits what I consider the most engaging moniker: la citta delle belle donne -- the city of beautiful women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEMINWAY, VIRGINIA CARBERY BOYD SEMENENKO
description: HEMINWAY - Virginia Carbery Boyd Semenenko. On September 21, 2000. Loving wife of the late John Hylan Heminway and the late Serge Semenenko. Cherished mother of Christine Semenenko. Adored grandmother of Dylan Semenenko Clark and adored mother-in-law of Anthony Eastburn Clark. Beloved sister of Bey Hartford, Kathleen Poole and Honor Smith. Friend of devoted caregivers. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Debaters, Done Answering? Now If I Could Follow Up . . .
description: It was almost imperceptible. But I suppose from having appeared on television hundreds of times, he knew the camera was not on him.

title: Rock 'n' Roll on the Block
description: Many rock 'n' roll stars pass through Atlantic City and some leave a little something of themselves behind.

title: Surging American Team Drains All the Suspense From This Cup
description: The Presidents Cup will conclude on Sunday, but much of the suspense ended today.

title: Because of the Pitcher's Eyes
description: If he's around, I would like Mike Scott, formerly of the Houston Astros, to know about this. I would like him to know that because of his eyes I am somewhat interested in baseball, that I even watched a whole game on television when the Yankees finally clinched the game that sent them to the Subway Series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDMAN, MAXINE A.
description: RUDMAN-Maxine A. Of Great Neck, NY. Died peacefully in her sleep the morning of the 20th of October in her 70th year. She was, and always will be, the beloved wife of Burton for almost 50 years; devoted daughter of Sophie Field, treasured sister of Douglas Field; cherished mother of Ellis, Rick, Seth and Lori; adored grandmother of Sarah, Jessica, Gabrielle, Amanda, Rachael, Adam, Ezra, David and Lauren. She was a dedicated teacher of Great Neck's young children for over 18 years. You were such an important part of our lives. Our memories of you will never be forgotten. Services Monday, 11:30 AM, at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Expressions of sympathy may be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, NYC, NY.

title: A High School Where Grieving Is Part of the Curriculum
description: The state's core curriculum suggests that loss and grief be considered in a section on health and fitness. Hunterdon Central Regional High School in Flemington takes the suggestion to heart and requires that every senior attend a 90-minute workshop on death, loss and grief. Joe Rampulla, a school counselor, recently spoke of the workshop he runs.

title: A Manager Who Sings of a Manger
description: When Carla A. Harris, an investment banker with the rank of managing director in equity transactions at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, talks about a new issue, she is not necessarily talking about stocks. She has just released her first CD, a compilation of carols, called ''Carla's First Christmas.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKOK, RICHARD SANFORD
description: HICKOK-Richard Sanford. Of Brewster, MA. Died October 20, 2000. He is survived by his wife Janet Allsopp Hickok; three sons, Sanford, Steven and Jonathan; a daughter Wendy Peters; eight grandchildren; a brother James K. of Scottsdale, AZ and a sister Sally Bockus of Mountainside, NJ. Mr Hickok lived in Cranford, Summit and Morristown, NJ. He graduated from Summit High and the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania. He served as a Lt. J.G. in the U.S. Navy. A certified public accountant in New York and several other states, Mr. Hickok was a partner in the firm Hurdman and Cranstoun in New York City. At his retirement in 1983, he was Chairman of the U.S. Affiliate of the International firm K.M.G. Main Hurdman. After his retirement, he founded Hickok Associates, a financial consulting firm in NYC, as well as authoring technical books and articles. He was a member of professional committees and lectured extensively on corporate governance. Mr. Hickok served as a director of numerous public companies including Marsh and McLennan, Comstock Resources and Marcam. A Memorial Service will be held Tuesday, October 24 at 11:30 AM at the Brewster Baptist Church, 1832 Main St. Gifts in his memory may be made to the Brewster Ladies Library, 1842 Main St., Brewster, MA 02631 or a charity of your choice.

title: Silences Are Eloquent as African Junta Runs an Election
description: At the campaign headquarters of a contender in this West African country's presidential election on Sunday, an official admitted that his party had fallen ''very, very, very far from its goal of raising'' about $2.7 million.

title: A County Consumed by Supermarket Envy
description: WITH all the variables confronting home buyers in Westchester -- cost, commute, schools, mortgage rates, taxes, termites -- it's no wonder that the local supermarket rarely enters the equation.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the decor of the White House omitted the surname of the designer of a chair ordered by James Monroe in 1817. He was Pierre-Antoine Bellange.

title: IN BRIEF: Environment; DAVIDS ISLAND REVISITED
description: The Board of Legislators has authorized the county to conduct a review with New Rochelle of Davids Island, the site of an abandoned Army post. The study will focus on how to use the 78-acre property as a park. The county and New Rochelle have agreed to spend up to $75,000 in consulting fees for the study. Elsa Brenner

title: Keys to Savings In a Home Swap
description: WHEN we walked through the door of the house just outside Paris, all we could do was grin and congratulate ourselves on how smart we were. It was our first vacation home exchange, and the house in which my family would be spending the next two weeks was opulent, with high ceilings, elaborate moldings and stately rooms where we couldn't help but feel royal.

title: Pamela Fleming, Peter Horan
description: Pamela Marie Fleming and Peter Claver Horan were married yesterday by Tristram King, a nondenominational minister, at Mirassou Champagne Cellars in Los Gatos, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, SAM
description: SCHNEIDER-Sam. Beloved husband of Sara, loving father of Judy, Ed and Liliane, and Amy and Keith Amchin. Devoted grandfather of Jeremy and Evan Schneider and Livy and Jana Amchin. A gentleman, an artist and a scholar, he was a caring friend to many. Memorial service Sun, October 22, 2000, 2:30PM at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, NOEL
description: HYMAN-Noel. Services Sunday, 11 AM, Riverside Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon. Beloved companion of Nancy Lerner; father of Jeff and Mitch; brother of Henry and Sy.

title: Los Cabos
description: Los Cabos was a wild, free place a generation ago. South of the Tropic of Cancer, where the Pacific meets the Gulf of California, were two untamed coasts graced by a few good hotels, a noble native fishing fleet and a growing clan of grizzled refugees from western civilization who had run out of road at the end of the planet's fourth longest peninsula.

title: Artist's Reflections of a Past Teacher
description: PERIODICALLY, and especially when he reaches a landmark like a retrospective exhibition, an artist will reflect on how he got where he is. Some artists are able to recognize their earliest influences and inspiration even if they were experienced before picking up a brush or camera.

description: Grace Glueck and Milt Freudenheim were married on Friday evening at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur A. Levin in Manhattan. Mr. Levin, the county clerk of Kings County, N.Y., officiated.

title: Nassau Retirees Needed To Help Disabled
description: Nassau County's budget woes have prompted an early retirement exodus by county employees [''Nassau May Be Losing Best to Employee Retirement Offer,'' Oct. 15]. Among the 566 employees who are opting for early retirement or severance packages are experienced workers of all levels up to and including commissioners.

title: Not Best vs. Best
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'Red Menace' to Warhol's Factory: The City as Bohemia
description: Early in the 20th century, a tide of modernism swept from Europe to the shores of America, carrying new forms of art and literature. It was also a time of political radicalism and changing sexual mores. ''Nowhere did the instinct for the new flourish more extravagantly than in New York City,'' Christine Stansell writes in ''American Moderns: Bohemian New York and the Creation of a New Century.'' Ms. Stansell describes the city's ''willful, ambitious arrivistes'' who came to be known as bohemians. Their spiritual heirs have continued to find a home in the city, among them the beats of the 50's like Jack Kerouac and the latter-day bohemians described by Ann Powers.

title: Hillary Clinton for the Senate
description: When Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived in their state 16 months ago, New Yorkers deserved to be deeply skeptical. She had not lived, worked or voted in New York State. She had never been elected to any public office, yet she radiated an aura of ambition and entitlement that suggested she viewed a run for the United States Senate as a kind of celebrity stroll. She seemed more at home at East Side soirees and within the first lady's question-free cocoon than in unscripted conversations with voters or the political press. She encountered civic doubt and open hostility from predictable sources, as well as a surprising resistance from feminists offended by her passive response to the marital humiliations inflicted by her husband.

title: Vizcaino Is Pinching Himself
description: The day before, when he learned he would be a surprise starter in the first game of the World Series, Jose Vizcaino said: ''It's like a dream come true. When you sign as a professional, it is your dream to go to the World Series. After 10 years, I have a chance to go to the World Series.''

title: Hilary Guberman, Jeffrey Pohlman
description: Hilary Jane Guberman, the daughter of Dr. Sandra Guberman and Irving Guberman of New York, is to be married today to Jeffrey Pohlman, a son of Margaret Conwell of Bozeman, Mont., and Dolphy O. Pohlman of Butte, Mont. Rabbi Roger Ross is to officiate at the Yale Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSON, MARY
description: LIPSON-Mary. Formerly of Little Neck, died October 20, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Isadore. Mother of Diane Sanders of Parkersburg, WV, and Joanne Levine of Hingham, MA. Grandmother of Nathan, Rachel and Benjamin.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Although Lee Radziwill has been photographed many times, and by many masters, including Horst, Irving Penn and Richard Avedon, one of her favorite photographs of herself is a newspaper photo taken by The New York Times in December 1969 (a). Cecil Beaton escorted her to the opening of ''Coco'' on Broadway, and Radziwill wore a silk velvet dress by Yves Saint Laurent, her favorite designer at the time. Saint Laurent also did six of the costumes she wore when she appeared in a Chicago stage production of ''The Philadelphia Story'' in 1967 (b).

description: Last week George W. Bush accused Al Gore of ''analog thinking in a digital age.'' It's a terrific line; my compliments to whoever wrote it. It's also a bit unfair.

description: TWO presidents, Bill Clinton and Nelson Mandela, and two prime ministers, Tony Blair and Ehud Barak, have turned to the pollster Stanley B. Greenberg for advice.

description: The Westchester office market continued in the third quarter with strong leasing activity and a declining vacancy rate, according to a survey by Insignia/ESG.

title: Options With Home Heating Systems
description: THE heating system is an important factor to consider when buying or building a new home. The system is in two parts: the heat-producing unit, and the machinery that distributes the heat throughout the house. While it is important to consider both components when evaluating a heating system, the distribution system is a little more important and it should be considered first.

title: Rededicating a 1797 Landmark
description: It was to have been a joyful occasion - the dedication of the first Methodist Church in White Plains in 1975. But across the street, a farmer was burning brush. A spark from the fire ignited the new roof, and on the very day of its dedication the church burned to the ground.

description: To the Editor:

title: Baltimore Displays Presidential Fashions
description: While the United States focuses its attention on the next presidential election, the Baltimore Museum of Art is presenting a collection of furnishings and fashion, art and china associated with 15 residents, ranging from George Washington to Bill Clinton.

title: The View From/Litchfield; Site for Beecher Museum Remains a Debated Topic
description: IN August, at the big bash that was meant to mark the homecoming of Harriet Beecher Stowe's birthplace in Litchfield, guests clanked cups of a potent rum punch and hooted at the celebratory cannon fire honoring the planned resurrection of the childhood home of the town's most famous native.

title: Repairing A Leaky Roof
description: Q. We have a 71-year-old Tudor house in Great Neck, N.Y., with an original tile roof that rarely gave us any trouble. However, after a recent storm caused a major leak into the living room, we were told that the problem was the valley alongside the chimney and that the bill for repairing it would be $5,400. The finished job has left an uncovered sheet of copper about 3 1/2 by 12 feet behind the chimney. The roofer says that he cannot cover this with tiles because putting nails into the copper sheeting could cause leaks. We fail to see anything that looks like this on similar homes in our area. Is this the proper way to repair these roofs? . . . Gerald P. Mirrer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PERRY, EDWARD C.
description: PERRY-EDWARD C. Remembered and missed always. Love, Elizabet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVITT, SANFORD (SANDY) MARK
description: LAVITT-Sanford (Sandy) Mark. Of Woodbury L.I. on October 15, 2000. Beloved husband of Arlene. Devoted father of Jason and Keith. Loving brother of Carole Adler, Thelma Rosenberg and Arthur Lavitt. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to charity. The two organizations Sandy was most involved with are SCOPE-Summer Camp Opportunities Provide An Edge, 1375 Broadway, New York, NY 10018 and United Jewish Appeal, 6900 Jericho Tpk., Syosset, NY 11791. Sandy was a very special person who will be deeply missed for his strength, courage, humor and consideration of others.

title: A Man Who Eats, Sleeps and Sells Music
description: THE recording industry earned $14.6 billion last year, making listening to music one of America's favorite pastimes. But for some people music is more than entertainment -- it is an obsession.

title: Finding Peace And a Platform
description: Kevin Mawae bowed his head at a conference for Christian athletes in San Diego two years ago and prayed. Mawae asked for guidance, for God to put him, the best young center in football, wherever he wanted him.

title: 5 Are Slain Across City In a Period Of 3 Hours
description: In less than three hours beginning late Friday night, five people were killed in unrelated incidents in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens, the police said yesterday.

title: Unlikely School for Purple Hair and Tattoos
description: SINCE the dress code was relaxed a few months ago at the Katharine Gibbs School in Melville, stockings are no longer mandatory. Shoulders don't have to be covered. Sandals, but not sneakers, can be worn instead of pumps. Guys can sport T-shirts; ties are no longer necessary. Along with the new informality, purple hair and piercings, even tattoos, have begun showing up on students in the hallways.

title: Petworking
description: JUST below the Eleanor Roosevelt statue at the West 72d Street entrance to Riverside Park is a 16,000-square-foot space that might be the city's best-kept networking secret. In the dog-meet-dog world of ''petworking,'' people can look for work as they walk their pets.

title: Colds and Heart Attacks
description: Citing evidence that the active ingredient in dozens of decongestants and appetite suppressants poses a small risk of stroke in young women, a panel of scientific experts recommended the chemical be removed from over-the-counter products. Drug makers insist the ingredient, phenylpropanolamine, or PPA, is safe. A decision by the Food and Drug Administration is pending; meanwhile, officials advise consumers to read labels carefully. Sheryl Gay Stolberg

title: Immortality
description: Biologists at West Chester University in Pennsylvania said they had revived a bacterium, 250 million years old, that had been trapped inside a crystal of salt mined from the salt beds that house the government's plutonium waste repository in New Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAGLIETTA, FRANK R.
description: MAGLIETTA-Frank R. 12/12/1610/22/99. In memory of the most wonderful and gracious father ever, who was also a best friend and buddy that was always there for us and made a difference in our lives. Dad, we miss you a lot.

title: Package Deal
description: It may just be true that, as William Safire suggests, ''some politically sensitive soul'' changed ''liquor store'' to ''package store'' in Senator Lieberman's acceptance speech (On Language, Oct. 1). But package store is not just (as Safire suggests) a dated or odd term, or even a ''business euphemism.'' It is normal regional English for a liquor store in much of Connecticut, and has been for decades. A search for ''package store'' in Southern New England Telephone's online yellow pages yields 250 hits in Connecticut.

title: Just Give Us The Damn Ball
description: Men are seldom kind about women playing team sports. If you've ever overheard a group of them sitting in front of a big-screen TV when an ad for the W.N.B.A. comes on, it isn't pretty. But mention that a group of women in the Deep South (where every man, woman and child follows the game with Pentecostal intensity) has started a league to play professional tackle football, and you get a different reaction entirely, one of mute astonishment -- followed by slow, serious nods and mutterings of ''Now, I'd like to see that.'' Truth is, a fully suited female defensive tackle gets as much silent male respect as the 5-foot-2 housewife alighting from the driver's seat of a Dodge Ram 3500 Cummins Turbo Diesel in a supermarket parking lot. Some things are such powerful evidence of guts that they negate even gender. Tackle football is one of them.

title: Portland Journal; Lingering Harvest, Lingering Doubts
description: Bales of hay lie scattered across charcoal-black soil. There is a hint of winter in the wind blowing through rows of golden cornstalks and green grass, an air of peace over this prairie now that the harvest is nearly done.

title: Feeling O.K.? Just Wait
description: Betrayal of Trust

title: A Peek Over the Precipice, Then a Shrug
description: One brutal October morning on Wall Street -- why does that phrase seem so familiar? -- demonstrated in quick succession investors' hair-trigger nervousness about the market break that everyone seems to expect, and their extraordinary willingness to jump back in with both feet at every buying opportunity that their collective jitters create.

title: The Oys Of Yiddish (Ignore at Your Peril)
description: What a noodge! She made me shlep to the theater for tickets to a schmaltzy play. While I waited, this nudnik kept kibitzing. I don't mean to kvetch, but his schmoozing was annoying. His shtick made me so meshuga, I walked away. But I tripped. Sometimes, I can be a klutz.

title: Letters on Travel
description: BELLE DONNE

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Upper Yorkville; Old World Vestiges in a Changing Area
description: TO those who have witnessed its gentrification, Upper Yorkville can feel like a place where much of the onetime low-rise, Old World ambience has yielded to the advance of sharp-edged modern high-rises. But to those who have arrived more recently, the neighborhood's flourishing vibrancy marks it as a safe, attractive destination where construction cranes in recent years have been punctuating a northward march of tall apartment buildings.

title: A Jump on the Competition
description: You don't attend a football game in helmet and pads or a swim meet in a bathing suit. But some of the 40,000 or so spectators at the Far Hills Race Meeting, the eight steeplechase races at Moorland Farms in Far Hills next Saturday, don their jodphurs and hacking jackets for the event. The highlight of the day is the Breeders' Cup Steeplechase, two and five-eights of a mile and 14 fences long; the purse is $250,000, the richest in America. People-watching is as much of a sport. Aside from the haute tweed set at their elaborate tailgate parties or the high rollers in the corporate tents, there is a younger, singles crowd who watch the horses and one another from the middle of the track. Post time for the first race is 1 p.m. Tickets are available at the gate on race day for $80, or, for $40 in advance from sites listed at www.farhillsrace. org. The beneficiary of the day is Somerset Medical Center, which since 1954 over 46 years, has garned more then $12 million from the race meeting.

title: The Stiff Guy vs. The Dumb Guy
description: What is sad is the smugness of the comedy writers. In the midst of congratulating themselves on their political acuity, they fail to recognize that the left has become the establishment and that the bold role they have assumed is less that of irreverent jester than toady.

title: Giving a Theater Force His Due
description: LEAVE it to A. R. Gurney, a celebrated playwright of today, to sum up the significance of Hofstra University's tribute to Robert Anderson, a celebrated playwright of yesterday.

title: Long Shot Comes to Front On Day for New York Breds
description: On a day that featured seven stakes races for horses bred in New York State, the grandest horse yesterday turned out to be a 12-1 long shot named Turnofthecentury, who won the $250,000 Empire Classic by a length and a half.

title: How the Crisis Queen Controls the Damage
description: A DOZEN years ago, Katherine Heaviside awoke to a 7 a.m. phone call from a Manhattan lawyer who sometimes steered damage-control work her way. ''Get the paper,'' he commanded. ''My client's on the front page.''

title: Keeping Homeowners in Their Homes
description: TWO weeks after Vehronna Smith bought her five-story, five-apartment brownstone on Dean Street in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, last March, she slumped onto the old, crooked hallway stairs, wept and said to herself, ''Oh God, what have I done?''

title: Spare the Praise, Help the Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Plant Spring Bulbs
description: October and November are peak times for planting spring bulbs. Start with ones that squirrels dislike, like daffodils and fritillarias. Plant fritillarias on their sides to prevent water from collecting and rotting the bulb.

title: Just a Drive Can Inspire Songwriter
description: FOR good reason, a song called ''Westchester Dreamin' '' is included on the latest album by Bob Baldwin, a contemporary jazz keyboardist and composer.

title: STATE WOODPILE
description: New Jersey residents, faced with increases in the cost of home heating oil this winter, can supplement their fuel supply by cutting wood in four state forests and one state park for $15 a cord while the supply lasts. A total of 490 cords of wood are available from selected sites in Wharton State Forest, Hammonton; Lebanon State Forest, New Lisbon, Belleplain State Forest, Woodbine; Stokes State Forest, Branchville, and High Point State Park, Sussex. Reservations for a cutting permit, issued by the Department of Environmental Protection and good for two days, must be made at the individual forests or park. Karen DeMasters

title: 'Gesture of Joy'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bargains Under Tropical Skies
description: ON the small, beautiful island of Nevis, where charming plantation inns grace misty slopes, little Oualie Beach Hotel down at the seaside is a bit less exalted. Its neat white cottages are dotted along the shore, facing a pretty bay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, LEE MACHLES
description: MOSS-Lee Machles. Widow of Judge Allen Moss. Mother of Susan M. Daum, MD and Ellen M. Poler, JD. On October 13, at age 90. Memorial service, Sunday, November 19, at 3 PM at the 92nd St. YMHA Art Gallery, 92nd St. and Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the 92nd St. YMHA 60+ Program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, WILLIAM M.
description: FARRELL-William M. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William M. Farrell, associated with The Times from 1929 until 1977.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLUB, DAVID
description: GOLUB-David. With tremendous sorrow, the Board of Directors, Artist Members and Staff of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, mourn the sudden loss of our dear friend & colleague David Golub. An Artist Member since 1993 and an extraordinary pianist, conductor and musical interpreter, David brought his probing intellect and superb musicianship to countless brilliant and engaging performances as a solo pianist, chamber musician and conductor. He embraced the music of 4 centuries, while ardently championing the work of today's composers. Beyond the concert stage, he was a true Renaissance man, profoundly interested in the connectedness between art and life. David's depth of musical insight and great humanity inspired all who knew and loved him. He will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Maria, and his parents, Benjamin and Sima. Donaldson C. Pillsbury, Chairman Peter Frelinghuysen, President David Shifrin, Artistic Director Norma Hurlburt, Exec. Director

title: In Bronx Bleachers, Mets Fans Survive
description: In past years, they have been known to hurl batteries at opposing outfielders. Pummel the occasional Boston Red Sox fan. Pour beer on the poor soul foolish enough to root for that team from Queens.

title: Newark Journal; A Slice of the Old City, On Rye, With Schmaltz
description: Sam Brummer wants you to have lunch.

title: Keeping Up With the Croesuses
description: I FIRST became concerned two years ago, when my daughter, who was 11 at the time, came home from a house party where the children had a choice of swimming in the pool or at the family's private beach.

title: For Grumman and Those Who Toiled There
description: NO matter how much white shrink-wrap you swaddle it in, there's just no way to hide an F-14 Tomcat fighter plane. So heads swiveled and eyes widened in August when a big tow truck and flatbed trailer rumbled up Route 105 carrying an object that, despite its covering, showed enough of the Tomcat's distinctively raked wings to erase any possibility that the trailer was hauling another mobile home.

title: How Just Is Justice in the Lone Star State?
description: Texas Defender Service, a nonprofit group of defense lawyers, released a broad and scathing assessment of Texas's administration of the death penalty. The group found that the system was corroded with prosecutorial misconduct, racial bias and a failure to provide adequate counsel to indigent capital defendants. The report also said too many defendants are convicted based on unreliable testimony from jailhouse informants or from dubious experts. State officials and prosecutors rejected the claims. Jim Yardley

title: Malyn Vallarta, Michael Sheridan
description: Malyn A. Vallarta, a daughter of Ludita and Carlos Vallarta Jr. of Washington and New York, was married yesterday to Michael Charles Sheridan, a son of Doris Sheridan of Nyack, N.Y., and the late Charles Sheridan. The Rev. Steven Fogel, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Yale Club of New York City.

title: Chopin Through a Friend's Eyes
description: HARRY CLARK, the founder of Chamber Music Plus, is often asked where he learned so much about music history.

title: All the Buzz
description: Even before they arrived at Yankee Stadium, there was no doubt that yesterday was a little different for Mets Manager Bobby Valentine and General Manager Steve Phillips. The area was buzzing with baseball.

title: GORE ASSAILS BUSH ON PLAN TO RECALL U.S. BALKAN FORCE
description: Vice President Al Gore and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright today denounced a proposal by Governor George W. Bush to withdraw United States ground forces from their peacekeeping mission in the Balkans.

title: Tag Sale Archaeology
description: THE detritus of suburban life is on display on front lawns these fine fall weekends, the height of tag sale season here, when we spread our used and useless goods, outgrown or outmoded, on blankets and card tables, priced at a dime or a dollar.

title: Business; The Office Tower as Its Own Wired World
description: AS president of Liberty Cable, Peter O. Price spent five years in the 1990's waging a David-and-Goliath battle against Time Warner for cable television customers in Manhattan.

title: Female Troubles
description: Peter D. Kramer's acute analysis of Prozac and Sarafem (The Way We Live Now, Oct. 1) omitted a key point. Prozac's release was not only a pharmacological advance but an important step toward destigmatizing depression. The success of Prozac (and of Kramer's book ''Listening to Prozac'') gave depression more public acceptability. Eli Lilly's cynical repackaging of Prozac as Sarafem for PMS threatens to have the opposite effect: it's Prozac for people who fear taking a psychotropic medication for their mood problems.

title: One Bad Cop
description: The isolation of the Rampart Crash unit is critical. The officers concluded at some point, not illogically, that their duty was not to uphold the law but to suppress crime, and that the bad guys do not follow the rules. Stopping them, therefore, meant they didn't need to follow the rules, either. This is the stuff of popular fiction.

title: The Widow Peaks
description: Yoko Ono is an exemplar for those of us in the visual arts whose lives, too, have been touched by violence and death.

title: Army Halts the Slide At Tulane's Expense
description: Army avoided a record 11th straight defeat today when quarterback Joe Gerena fired an 18-yard touchdown pass to tight end Clint Dodson with 40 seconds left to lift the Black Knights to a 21-17 victory over Tulane.

title: With More Games, Islanders' Productivity Rises
description: With the Islanders playing only four games in the first 13 days of the regular season, right wing Brad Isbister said that a better indication of the team's ability would come when the games began to occur more frequently, such as this weekend's consecutive encounters with Atlanta and Washington.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-22-00: Questions for Milan Protic; Mittel Hizzoner
description: Q: There was a revolution here in Belgrade on Oct. 5. Protesters stormed the federal Parliament, stormed the main television station, stormed the main police station, and then the next day you started as mayor of the city. What was your first day on the job like?

title: Graying of the Arts: Who Will Take Over?
description: ABOUT 30 years ago, when the second wave of city dwellers migrated to Long Island, many of them discovered a cultural wasteland in suburbia. To fill the void, they founded groups like the New Community Cinema, the Long Island Baroque Ensemble, Friends of the Arts, the Islip Arts Council and the American Chamber Ensemble.

title: Two Tests of Fairness for Congress
description: Earlier this month, in a shameful bow to anti-gay voices within their party, Republican Congressional leaders killed hate-crimes legislation that had strong bipartisan support in the House and Senate. It remains to be seen whether hard bargaining by President Clinton over pending budget bills can help persuade the Republicans to revive the measure.

title: Not a Chat Room
description: To the Editor:

title: Christine Parlamis, Scott McAllister
description: Christine Phyllis Parlamis, the daughter of Marguerite and Michael Parlamis of Tenafly, N.J., was married there yesterday to Scott Christopher McAllister, a son of Lynne and Sidney McAllister of Upper St. Clair, Pa. The Rev. John Alexandrou performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. John the Theologian.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IANNONE, ANTHONY M., M.D.
description: IANNONE-Anthony M., M.D., 75, died peacefully in the home, of cancer on Thursday, October 12. As the founding Chairman of the Neurology Department at the Medical College of Ohio, he established the Neurology residency program and spearheaded research in a variety of specialized fields including gait disorders, Parkinson's, Clonus and stroke. He was a guest researcher at the National Insitute of Health, Bethesda, MD. Dr. Ianonne's thirty years at the Medical College of Ohio also included service as Chief-of-Staff, teaching Professor, and Professor Emeritus. He was board certified in Neurology and a member of the American Academy of Neurology, Society for Neurosciences, American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology, the American and Ohio State Medical Associations and the San Francisco Neurological Society, along with extensive publications. He attended Stuyvesant High School, Columbia University, and at the age of 23, graduated from the Columbia School of Medicine. He is survived by his children Antoinette (Roger) Smith, Mary Ann (Roger) Bell, Michael (Maggie), James (Terese) of Toledo, OH and Susan (William) Frakes and Anthony (Amy) of Ann Arbor, MI, and thirteen grandchildren. Along with two children Christine (John) Abrams, and Martha Hudson of Martha's Vineyard, MA; four grandchildren, and one great-grandchild from a previous marriage, brother James (Lillian) Iannone of W. Hartford, CT and sister, Lola (Pasquael) Sylvestri of Rosyln Heights, Long Island. He was preceded in death by loving wife, Mary (Flanagan) Iannone, and children Peter and Joseph. Services were held at the Coyle Funeral Home, Toledo, OH.

title: Finally, Mets and Yankees Are Good Enough to Be the Best
description: CHASS -- Over the years, there have been very few seasons, if any, where the Mets and the Yankees have both been good enough to reach the playoffs. For a while, it was the Yankees and then the Mets, and back to the Yankees, and then the Mets again. So they never had this opportunity.

title: Airlines Increase Flights to Hawaii
description: Domestic airlines are increasing the number of seats from the mainland to Hawaii by nearly 10 percent this year as they add new departure cities, increase the frequency of some flights and switch to larger planes.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-22-00: Point Of Purchase; Camera Obscura
description: It's no surprise that the export of weapons and encryption devices is closely regulated. But according to the constellation of federal agencies (Departments of Commerce, Defense, State and Energy) that regulate such matters, a number of entirely mundane items would be only too convenient for a foreign terrorist or political foe. Keep it in mind as you stroll down the aisle at Kmart.

title: Middle Eastern Fare at Pleasing Prices
description: MONDAY is doomsday for restaurants, a Death Valley of empty seats, the biggest homebody day of the week. No wonder more eating places close on that day than any other. Then why, on a Monday night, are people scurrying across the parking lot at the Plainview Center and streaming into Ayhan's Shish Kebab Restaurant? The parade of patrons starts as early as 5 p.m. and rarely lets up until closing.

title: Business; WHAT THEY'RE READING
description: Jim Barton, 42

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPORN, SHIRLEY A.
description: SPORN-Shirley A. The Light of My Life. The Joy of My Life. For 55 Glorious Years and Forever. ''Sugar'' Sporn, wife of Woodrow Sporn, died yesterday after a long illness in White Plains hospital. Courageous & brave, she endured many years of silent suffering. Shirley is survived by daughters Andrea and Susan; grandchildren, Alexandra, Daniel, Abbey and Douglas; extraordinary son-in-law, Dr. Jerome Haber; sister, Roslyn Reiffel; nephews and nieces, Dr. Max and Joan Sporn, Drs. Susanne and Robert Reiffel, Dr. James and Bonnie Reiffel, Linda and Jeffrey Halbreich; brother-inlaw Morty Halbreich. Shirley was a Scarsdale resident 38 years; active in the Parent School Association, a Girl Scout leader and involved in many other community activities; in the past twelve years, she was a resident of Purchase and a Board member of the Purchase Free Library. She was the first woman to serve on the Board of Westchester Cerebral Palsy. She was an avid bridge player and at one time was captain of the Fairview Country Club Women's Bridge Team. She will be missedmissed-missed. All my love, Sugar, forever and forever. ''Semper Fidelis'' Woody. Graveside services, Monday, October 23, at 1 PM, Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York. Family and friends welcome. Visiting at family home in Purchase, NY after the service.

title: Boatyard Locale, but More Than Seafood
description: AUTUMN on the North Fork is what summer is on the South Fork: the season when the area glows. This time of year many Long Islanders drive east to visit fall festivals, tour vineyards, pick pumpkins and apples and savor an ear of roasted corn at a farmstand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILFORD, SOPHIE
description: WILFORD-Sophie. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Sophie Wilford, associated with The Times from 1957 until 1968.

title: The Stiff Guy vs. The Dumb Guy
description: It will be interesting to see if these new political forces pull more voters into the voting booths this November; perhaps someone will survey the election to discover if those who laugh their way through this autumn are among those who do not vote.

title: Introduction
description: Some readers scrutinized our article on political comedy -- and counted campaign buttons on the cover -- for signs of liberal bias; others invented their own one-liners. Many found the officers' isolation at the root of the L.A.P.D. scandal. And ''flying waitresses'' plotted revenge.

title: 'Best Wishes, George Allen's Daughter'
description: As an impressionable 12-year-old in 1972, I still remember how George Allen turned around a flailing Redskins team. I hope he receives that Hall of Fame nomination he deserves.

title: Doing Nothing Is a Fine Art
description: OUR arrival on Palm Island felt dreamlike. After a five-hour flight from J.F.K. to Barbados and a 45-minute flight on a six-seater plane through a rainstorm from Barbados to Union Island, my friend Deborah Kampmeier and I stepped into a private launch. We were ferried to a small palm-fringed island where a waiter glided across the dock to welcome us with two tall drinks the color of a sunset. A chef knelt behind him stuffing a vivid blue fish into a sack. Alongside the dock rocked a small boat with four fierce, almost mythical-looking, fishermen, one of whom rose to his feet and held aloft a glistening red-gilled barracuda that looked at least five feet long. We clutched our drinks and stared at the barracuda. And at the fisherman. ''You caught that?'' we gasped. ''Speared it!'' he exclaimed, before the boat sped away across the ocean.

title: Disabled Say Island Is Even More So With Old Elevators
description: Roosevelt Island has thousands of disabled residents, but on some days, they say, they feel isolated. The reason is that two of the island's few links with the outside world, the tram and the island's one subway station, are not always accessible to them.

description: Newsday Ends One Edition And Begins New Web Site

title: Corzine and the Tax Factor
description: This 30-second commercial, titled ''Numbers,'' was released Friday by Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate from New Jersey, in his campaign against Representative Bob Franks.

title: Voices of an Amateur Choral Group Reach Beyond Dobbs Ferry
description: ON a recent Monday night, two dozen voices filled an otherwise empty church here with glorious song. To the untrained ear, it sounded flawless; then Susanne Peck jumped up from her chair.

title: Study in Contrasts: Clinton and Lazio on Taxes
description: Plowing through the tax plans of the Senate candidates in New York, it is easy to get bogged down in the arcane details, to be distracted by the mind-boggling billions of dollars involved, or to be lulled by the mind-numbing slogans employed on both sides. (Protect Social Security! Pay down the national debt!)

title: The Guts Of Times Square
description: Stephen Wilkes photographs of Times Square document some seldom-seen corners of what Guy Debord once called the spectacular system -- the conversion of the public into consumers of banal visual experience. In the late 20th century, the spectacular system became increasingly decentralized. Television, superhighways, suburban malls and multiplexes displaced city streets as channels for communication. Eventually, however, the systems specialists came to realize that there should be the occasional urban center, in the traditional manner of 19th-century industrial cities. These have now been deployed around the globe. Planners call them social condensers. They are designed to give consumers the impression that there still exist places where they can sample the fragrant atmosphere of cosmopolitan freedom, even though that atmosphere now comes canned.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing on Page 45 of Arts & Leisure today for a piano concert by Melvyn Tan at the Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, in Manhattan, misstates the day. The concert is next Sunday, not Friday.

title: In Hollywood's Las Vegas, Happiness Is Luck
description: IN the good old days, the 20's and 30's, when the powers in Hollywood liked to issue edicts about pictures being better than ever and a reliable route to prosperity, happiness and a flawless complexion for the optimum number of Americans, those powers were counting cards and shooting craps. They might have been the highest-paid people in the land, as well as the providers of wholesome stories for the nation's young citizens, but they were late-night gamblers.

description: ULIUS-Jeanne (Eugenie Eliscu). 98 years of age. Beloved wife of the late Frank. Devoted sister to Sally Piken. Adored aunt, great aunt and great great aunt. She will be sorely missed. Sunday Meet 12:30 Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave before graveside service.

title: Yemeni and U.S. Teams Focus On Boat Used to Attack Cole
description: American and Yemeni investigators were encamped today at a remote boat ramp seeking clues to the identity of the two suicide bombers who launched a small boat and headed into Aden's harbor for the attack on the destroyer Cole, which killed 17 American sailors.

title: Rock Opera in Atlantic City
description: The Trump Marina Casino-Hotel, in its attempt to attract youthful visitors, will present Atlantic City's first rock opera, ''Grendel's Lair,'' written by Suze DiPietro and Frank Gorgo, starting Friday at 7 p.m. The story line has a bad-boy rocker, Vlad, losing his girlfriend, Jenny Jenny, to a new-rocker-on-the-block, Johnny Dollar. Grendel's Lair is the club where they and their acolytes hang out and it is inspired by a club of the same name that was the anchor of the South Street neighborhood of Philadelphia in the 1970's and 1980's. Robert Strauss

title: Kara Berklich, Ben Weber
description: Kara Lynn Berklich, a marketing executive, and Ben Weber, an actor, were married yesterday on the Outer Banks of North Carolina. The Rev. Thomas LeGrand, a Baptist minister who is a cousin of the bride, officiated.

title: Answers to an English Question; Instead of Ending Program, New York May Offer a Choice
description: Now that California has repudiated bilingual education in a statewide referendum, and Arizona is expected to do the same in November, New York, with its large immigrant population, would seem to be another domino likely to tumble.

title: IN BRIEF: Honors; LIFETIME ACHIEVEMENT AWARD
description: Environmental Advocates, a lobbying group in Albany, has given a lifetime achievement award to Assemblywoman Audrey G. Hochberg, who is retiring, for her efforts on behalf of the state's solid waste policy. Appointed to the state's Legislative Commission on Solid Waste in 1999, Ms. Hochberg, who represents the 88th Assembly District, organized a hearing to examine recycling programs. ''Audrey Hochberg's commitments to public service and environmental issues earn her our deepest gratitude,'' Environmental Advocates said. Elsa Brenner
