description: COOPER SQUARE

title: Health Concerns
description: To the Editor: A letter in your Q & A column on Sept. 10 asked about medical insurance abroad for travelers. Those concerned about health care options overseas may be interested in an organization called the International Association for Medical Assistance to Travelers, which provides a free directory that lists 500 medical centers in more than 100 countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORBIN, LENORE
description: CORBIN-Lenore. Beloved mother of David, cherished grandmother of three. Services today, 10 AM, at Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels, Manalapan, NJ. Interment to follow at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Donations to American Cancer Society.

title: Making Alterations In a Co-op
description: ONE of the more important documents used by a co-op is the agreement shareholders sign before beginning major repairs or alterations.

title: A Hybrid Flourishes in Oregon
description: Muller-Thurgau, a hybrid that the eminent British critic Hugh Johnson wants banned from top vineyards in Germany because of its wimpy wines there, has found a new identity, respect and pizazz in Oregon.

title: In the Region/Long Island; At SUNY in Farmingdale, a New Bioscience Park
description: THE State University of New York at Farmingdale on Route 110 here has been given both a new grand entrance and a new mission with the recent opening of the first building at its Broad Hollow Bioscience Park.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-22-00: On Language; Enjoy!
description: Alissome Japanese waitress at the Yosaku restaurant in Bethesda, Md., presented me with a bowl of Nabayaki Udon -- thick noodles in broth with bits of chicken and shrimp -- smiled and said, ''Enjoy.''

title: Keri Ann Law, Joseph Sack
description: Keri Ann Law, the daughter of Florence and Richard Law of Manhasset, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Joseph A. Sack, the son of Randi Sack and Joseph W. Sack of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Parkes performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Sports of The Times; An Instant Museum Exhibit in the Bronx
description: IT'S a World Series museum. It's Yankee Stadium, where, after nearly half a century, another Subway Series opened last night. Too bad nobody thought to put a chunk of an old subway car (no graffiti, please) or maybe an E-ZPass sign out there in the empty area beyond center field. Not for laughs. For atmosphere.

title: Sports of The Times; Unforgettable: This One Was Worth Waiting For
description: AROUND here, we are nothing if not grandiose. The first Subway Series game since 1956 became -- what else? -- the longest game in World Series history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREWER, ANN FRASER
description: BREWER-Ann Fraser, 98, surrounded by family, died peacefully on Sunday, October 15th in her beloved cabin in Newcomb, NY. She was married to George E. Brewer, Jr. for 45 years and is survived by her daughters, Effie Kimball, Ann Knox, her daughter-in-law Charlotte Brewer, 13 grandchildren and 20 great-granchildren. Her sons, Michael and George Fraser, predeceased her. Born in NYC, she attended the Brearley School and graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1923. During World War II, while her husband was overseas, she served with the Red Cross and took in a war-displaced English family of five. She was Chairman of the Board of the New York School of Social Work at Columbia University and served on the boards of St. Faith's Home, Tarrytown, NY and Camphill Village, Copake, NY. A long-time resident of NYC, she was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. In 1990 she moved to Collington, a retirement community near Washington, DC. There will be a service in Newcomb on October 21 and a later memorial service at Collington, MD. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Ann Brewer Memorial at the Student Conservation Association, PO Box 550, Charlestown, NH 03603.

title: Stottlemyre Reappears
description: The Yankees' pitching coach, Mel Stottlemyre, who is recovering from treatment for bone-marrow cancer, strolled into Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon, sheepishly waving to fans who screamed his name. Stottlemyre had said last week that he would not go to the park when there were lots of fans around, but his arrival before Game 1 was a little later than he had originally planned.

title: INVESTING WITH: Paul A. Blaustein; Whitehall Growth Fund
description: AS Paul A. Blaustein sees it, investing is an evolutionary process, and flexibility is a key to success. He has used that philosophy throughout his 27-year investing career, most recently at the $173.7 million Whitehall Growth fund, which has become a standout among its peers.

title: Milosevic's Rainy Day Fund
description: Germany's version of the C.I.A., the Foreign Intelligence Service, has prepared a secret report charging that Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, put more than $100 million in foreign bank accounts, some of it from drug trafficking.

title: Lives; The Nature of the Beast
description: Alexis Rockman's chosen subject is the natural world, so every so often he and a few of his like-minded artist friends abandon the comforts of modern life for a spell in the wilderness. Last year, they spent two weeks in equatorial South America. There Rockman photographed his friends in various poses and found the inspiration for the paintings in his current show, ''Expedition,'' at the Gorney Bravin & Lee gallery in New York. The painting above, ''Big Game,'' is part of that exhibition, which runs through Nov. 11.

title: QUICK BYTE/The Internet; Where the Menu Is on the Screen
description: Saying that Rosie Saferstein started her online dining forum before the Internet age is like saying Washington crossed the Delaware before the auto age. It was 10 years ago, a time when most people still communicated using a quaint hand-held instrument called the telephone, and Ms. Saferstein, a public school speech pathologist who lives in West Orange, was noodling around on her husband's new Macintosh. Before long, she discovered that Prodigy -- one of the nation's first online services -- had a bulletin board for dining in New Jersey.

title: Big Shoes to Fill With Wine and Whiskey
description: Big Foot needs a coat.

description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey's No Joke, Especially Its Art
description: To the Editor:

title: The Beginning of the End For the Cuba Boycott
description: The Senate decisively approved legislation relaxing nearly 40 years of sanctions on the sale of food to Cuba. The measure, endorsed 86 to 8, now seems assured of becoming law, but anti-Communist opponents of Fidel Castro's regime were successful in winning prohibitions on United States government credit and private financing for any sales, which will make it difficult, if not impossible, for food shipments to be made to Cuba in the near future. Eric Schmitt

title: A Fall Line In Full Color
description: Renato Nucci, the Paris fashion company, opened its first retail store in the United States last month at 131 Spring Street (between Greene and Wooster Streets) in SoHo. The store is showing the fall line, which emphasizes pastels, includes a multicolored tweed wool suit for $740 (the jacket costs $520 and the 24-inch skirt $220). One of the store's best-selling suits is made mostly of purple and yellow silk with velvet fringes, and costs $555. The store also offers accessories that complement the clothing line.

title: At the Stanhope House, Echoes of Past and Beat of Present

''They feel the spirits here are very friendly, similar to when they started out in Chicago.''

title: Air Security

On a Korean Air domestic flight from Seoul to Cheju Island, one person was able to obtain boarding passes for our group of four adults. At no time were any of us asked for identification.

Dr. Drellich was a PastPresident of the Academy, which he served with vigor, talent, and generosity during its entire 45 year history. Marvin Drellich embodied the finest qualities of a psychoanalyst and a physician. He was known for the respect and regard with which he listened to all, and for the excellence of the standards he set. He exemplified the life well-lived. The Academy wishes to express its profound sympathy to Dr. Drellich's wife, Helen, to his children, and to his grandchildren. Sheila Hafter Gray, M.D. President Joan G. Tolchin, M.D. Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ARTHUR M.
description: GOLDBERG-Arthur M. The Boards, Faculty and Staff of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons, and the Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College of Cornell University are deeply saddened by the passing of our great friend and esteemed Hospital Trustee, Arthur M. Goldberg. Mr. Goldberg became a Trustee of The Presbyterian Hospital in 1996. When it merged with The New York Hospital in 1998, he became a Trustee of the merged institution, serving as Co-Chair of the Human Resources Committee. He was a man of great warmth, vision and courage, who was unfailingly devoted to the support of medical education, research and patient care. Mr. Goldberg's wise counsel and guidance were invaluable. He was much loved and will be truly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, children, and grandchildren.

title: Shopping the Mall Called Seoul
description: I'M proud of my shopping chops, honed in New Jersey bargain-basement sales, further sharpened on Orchard Street on the Lower East Side and buffed to a fine polish in the open-air markets of Southeast Asia. But there was a moment, during my visit to Seoul in September, when I realized that as a shopper I was still a lightweight. For Seoul is the World Series, the Indy 500, the Olympics of commerce. Even the main downtown business streets teem with sidewalk vendors hawking things I never realized I needed until that instant: Hello Kitty inflatable chairs, matchbox-size cell phones on neck chains, bags of French-fried yams, stuffed toy rabbits, live rabbits.

Producer, creator, host of TV series ''Inside The Arts'' 1967-76. Producer, narrator of TV documentaries. Taught voice at Yale Drama School. Ink and watercolor artist. Tremendous presence, incredible wit and true compassion were his hallmark, as artist, professor, actor, writer and friend. Survived by Renny, Derek, Robin, and Toby. Memorial November 12th Grace Church, Brooklyn. Call before.

title: Wheeling and Dealing

He's smart, gutsy and can always find the perfect pointed barb with which to slay his adversaries. In other words, he is your typical 13-year-old boy- except for the fact that he is confined to a wheelchair and has limited use of his arms.

title: The Next Court
description: 'The next president is going to appoint three, maybe even four, justices of the Supreme Court,'' Al Gore declared in a moment of enthusiasm during the first presidential debate. But Gore and George W. Bush said little about their visions of the court, except to dance around the one question that has obsessed presidential candidates since 1980. ''The main issue is whether or not the Roe v. Wade decision's going to be overturned,'' the vice president announced. ''This is a very important issue, because a lot of young women in this country take this right for granted, and it could be lost.'' Bush countered with echoes of Richard Nixon's campaign rhetoric from 1968. He promised to appoint judges ''who will strictly interpret the Constitution,'' as opposed to ''liberal, activist judges who will use their bench to subvert the legislature.''

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: AL PACINO'S character in THE INSIDER (1999) is a little too nobly heroic at times, but the film in enthralling. Mr. Pacino stars as the ''60 Minutes'' producer who puts some appalling truths about the tobacco industry on national television. Russell Crowe plays the whistle-blower, a former Brown & Williamson scientist who agrees to spill secrets and soon finds himself the target of death threats. Christopher Plummer is uncannily on the mark as the newsman Mike Wallace. And the beauty of the story is that it's all about integrity, its values and dangers, but never treats it as an absolute. The film received Oscar nominations in seven categories, including best director (Michael Mann) and best picture. CBS plays the villain - Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:45 a.m. on Starz!

title: An Exile-to-Be Hymns Farewell to His Fatherland
description: AS a song topic, travel may place second in popularity only to love. So when the New York Festival of Song, bastion of imaginative thematic programming, gave a mixed bill of ''Songs of Travel'' last February, the singers had an embarrassment of riches to choose from. Among the surprises the Austrian baritone Wolfgang Holzmair came up with was Ernst Krenek's cycle ''Reisebuch aus den Osterreichischen Alpen'' (''Travel Album From the Austrian Alps'') of 1929.

title: Life After 'Rugrats': It's Not Easy Being Cool
description: Twelve-year-old Ginger Goutley (bottom right) traverses the rickety bridge between childhood and adolescence in the new weekly animated series ''As Told by Ginger,'' which has its premiere on Wednesday at 8 p.m. on Nickelodeon. Created by Emily Kapnek, a 28-year-old playwright, and produced by Klasky-Csupo, the masterminds behind ''Rugrats,'' ''The Wild Thornberrys'' and ''Rocket Power,'' the show dissects junior high anxiety as Ginger is welcomed into the cool crowd - and struggles to remain true to herself and her old friends.

title: IN BRIEF: Education; BONDS FOR CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS APPROVED
description: Eastchester and Harrison voters have approved bonds for construction projects. In Eastchester, a $12.4 million bond was passed, 1,260 to 592, for renovations and expansions in the district's elementary schools. The bonds will cost the average taxpayer $90 a year starting in 2003-2004. In Harrison, the vote was 1,563 to 697 for a $1.044 million bond to provide an eight-classroom modular unit at the Louis M. Klein Middle School. During the three-year life of the bond, the average homeowner will see a tax increase of about $26 annually. Merri Rosenberg

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Artist Behind the Figure
description: Because Duncan Grant was a member of the Bloomsbury group, his personal life has largely overshadowed his artistic achievement. Grant (1885-1978) indeed lived a colorful life, featuring affairs with John Maynard Keynes and Lytton Strachey, and a lifelong relationship with Vanessa Bell, with whom he fathered a child. But as the art historian Simon Watney argues in THE ART OF DUNCAN GRANT (John Murray/Trafalgar Square, paper, $29.95), his art merits serious consideration in its own right. Surveying Grant's career, he shows his painting to be intimately linked with that of artists like Piero della Francesca, Titian, Chardin, Rembrandt, Cezanne and Picasso. This facility with Western art history lies at the core of his work, and according to Watney, ''paintings about painting constitute one of Grant's most significant contributions to the modernist movement.'' Grant's style was marked by lyricism and an exuberant use of color. His protean output also included prints, book illustrations, fabric designs, costumes, ceramics, murals and interior decoration. These various art forms became intricately merged in Charleston, the country house Grant shared and transformed with his fellow artist Vanessa Bell. Watney deems this decorated domicile the finest monument to Grant's art, exemplary of the brand of domestic modernism that defined the Bloomsbury aesthetic. While doing justice to Grant's work, the book also acknowledges his unevenness, conveying the complexity of an artist who proved as polymorphous in his work as he was in his private life. Suzanne Ramljak

title: Kramnik Holds a Slim Lead After a Draw at the Midpoint
description: For the first time in the world championship match, Garry Kasparov did not suffer with the black pieces, but let Vladimir Kramnik do the heavy lifting to get a draw. An innovation at Move 16, in a line he had played before against Kramnik, but with the White army, gave him a dynamic play that drove Kramnik into a careful cessation of hostilities.

Summoning his fortitude, Mr. Irons, clad in black-on-black Armani and looking like a reedy impersonation of himself, said, ''Armani is always understated.'' Mr. Irons has worn the designer's clothes on and off for more than 20 years, and he added with a grin, ''He knows how to make me look less stuffy than I normally do.''

This is the setting for an adaptation of Langston Hughes's short story ''Cora Unashamed,'' the first in ''American Collection,'' a series of stories by or about writers from the United States.

title: A Child's World In No Man's Land
description: THE first thing you ought to know about ''George Washington'' -- the first clue that this is a film that isn't much interested in being about the obvious -- is that it is not at all about the Father of Our Country. In fact, it is a film that is mostly about 11- and 12-year-old children, poor and undersupervised, who spend large portions of their days in the dilapidated ruins of a factory in their rural Southern town, mulling their horizons. It is true that a central character is named George, and though his last name is not Washington, another character says she thinks of him as George Washington. Perhaps you are getting a feel for the patient way this film meditates on the subjects that cross its mind.

title: Investing; Funds That Vanguard Hates to Love
