But that doesn't mean that Vanguard executives have much nice to say about E.T.F.'s, the fledgling products that act like index mutual funds but can be traded like stocks.

title: From Baltimore Warehouse to Giant Office Building
description: AN old Montgomery Ward warehouse is being transformed into what will be Baltimore's largest office building. In the largest adaptive use project under one roof in the city, the 1.3 million square foot building on 28 acres is to become office space that will eventually house up to 5,000 workers. The rehab will be based on a ''green'' design approach that reduces energy consumption costs and uses sustainable materials that are environmentally sensitive.

title: Let Vines Hide Sound Barriers
description: To the Editor:

title: Is The Choice Between These Two Guys Worth 10 Million?
description: In the hills over Los Angeles on the Fourth of July, it was possible for a moment to believe that Republican Congressman James Rogan and Democratic State Senator Adam Schiff did not loathe each other. They were opponents in what was shaping up as the most expensive Congressional race in the history of the republic -- and one of the fiercest -- and yet there they were chatting amiably in the morning sunshine near the convertibles that would carry them in the day's first parade, two suburban white guys trading updates on their kids.

title: Taming Wagner And His Ilk, All in Good Time
description: PLACIDO DOMINGO'S venture into the German dramatic tenor repertory, a move that took many of his admirers by surprise, began much earlier in his career than is generally remembered. In January 1968, a few weeks before his 27th birthday, Mr. Domingo sang the title role of Wagner's ''Lohengrin'' with the Hamburg Opera. This was nine months before his Metropolitan Opera debut in Cilea's verismo melodrama ''Adriana Lecouvreur'' and seven years before his first performance as Otello, the role generally considered the pinnacle of the Italian dramatic tenor repertory.

title: Moby at Hunka Bunka Ballroom
description: One of music's most commercially successful mavericks, Moby -- a disk jockey, composer, producer and engineer -- uses his eclectic background to create provocative techno music. He integrates jazz, punk, soundtrack music and clever breakbeats into a highly stylized mix. His 1999 release ''Play,'' a blend of funky hip-hop and traditional folk and blues, was hailed by many critics as the year's best album. He recently released a greatest hits album, ''Mobysongs: 1993-1998.'' Don't expect him to be standing behind a turntable -- this guy is all over the stage, as he is all over the musical spectrum. Rare in the world of Backstreet Boys and ex-Mousketeers, Moby is an iconoclastic innovator. He will perform on Thursday at the Hunka Bunka Ballroom in Sayreville. Robbie Woliver

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, DR. KENNETH I.
description: HOWARD-Dr. Kenneth I. Noted Psychologist and Professor of Psychology at Northwestern University, Evanston, Illinois, at age 68. Husband of Sue Taylor Howard. Father of Matthew, Rebecca, David, Lisa, Peter and Deborah. Step-father of Kevin and Paul Merritt. Son of Simon and the late Florence. Brother of Robert Howard and Sharon Skolnik. Grandfather of eight. For additional information Weinstein Family Services 847-256-5700.

title: Christine Grahl, Andrew Gottesman
description: Christine Helen Grahl, a daughter of Kathleen and Larry Grahl of Mattaponi, Va., was married last evening to Andrew Kober Gottesman, the son of Barbara Gottesman of West Orange, N.J., and Harold Gottesman of Old Lyme, Conn. Rabbi Michael Joseph officiated at Old St. John's, a chapel in King William, Va.

title: Films for Surviving Girlhood
description: BOTH sexes can catch the second half of a four-day film festival by, for and about girls today and tomorrow at the Anthology Film Archives. The festival is titled ''Here's Looking at You, Kid!'' and is presented by the Lower East Side Girls Club. Short movies, features, documentaries and animated films deal with issues that girls face growing up, involving parents, school, boys, sports and society's views on beauty and ambition.

title: Meg McAllister, John Toner
description: Marjorie McAllister and John F. Toner were married on Friday by Msgr. John Torney at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Critic's Choice movie page of the Television section last Sunday misidentified the actor standing beside Erich von Stroheim in the film ''Grand Illusion.'' He was Pierre Fresnay, not Jean Gabin.

title: Parents Clear a Path to School With a Parking Ticket Blitz
description: On a typical morning at P.S. 33, cars, buses and pedestrians jockey for space as parents hurriedly drop their children off for the day.

title: BENEFITS
description: Family Revelry, With Reptiles

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLENBERG, ROSE
description: POLENBERG-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Ben. Devoted mother of Claire Spack, Arthur and Ellen. Dear sister of Molly Small. Adored grandmother of Shari, Steven, Larry, Lorraine, Jennifer and Adam. Loving and cherished great-grandmother. Forever in our hearts. Graveside service, Monday, 10:00 AM at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A clue in the crossword puzzle in The Times Magazine on July 30 misstated the name of a film. The answer for 6 across was ''Cate,'' and the clue should have read, ''Actress Blanchett of 'Elizabeth,' '' not ''Titanic.'' This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Four Dogs and a Wedding
description: CUPID has long been known to unleash his arrows among dog owners, and New York parks provide particularly good hunting.

title: Grow Your Own Craft Project With Gourds
description: GARDENERS who are fond of peering into the past already know that human history is littered with gourds. Ancient people used the hard shell Lagenaria (Calabash) varieties as utensils and containers. Early Egyptians sealed them in tombs along with other earthly necessities they thought that the deceased would need in the afterlife. Native Americans grew and used hard shell gourds and passed the habit along to the colonists.

title: Warning: Annoying Merger Ahead
description: Mergers, like marriages, do not always result in happiness. No matter how ardent the courtship and how sunny the visions of the future, reality may prove a jolting journey into the unforeseen -- sometimes for better and sometimes for worse.

title: The Foreign Assignment: An Incubator, or Exile?
description: FOUR years ago, Steven Kydd wondered whether an overseas stint for his company was a good career move. It wasn't until earlier this year, after he came back from Hong Kong, that he realized it was.

title: Greyhound Skirted Proper Procedure, Local Leaders Charge
description: Four months ago, at the height of the summer tourist season, Greyhound Lines resumed direct bus service to and from Downtown Brooklyn for the first time in 10 years.

title: At Last, War Tales Are Told
description: LIKE many war veterans, Tracy Sugarman couldn't talk about his combat experience in World War II when he got home. But Mr. Sugarman, who had participated in the invasion of Omaha Beach as a naval ensign, had recorded his impressions of battle in letters and drawings that he sent home to his wife, June. Now those words and images have been put together in a book called ''My War,'' published by Random House.

title: A Steady Gaze at Stage and Screen
description: ESSAYS and reviews by Vincent Canby, who died on Oct. 15, appeared in The New York Times for more than 35 years. His style of commentary on film and theater was unadorned, direct and witty. Following are excerpts from his work that appeared in Arts and Leisure:

title: Alexandra Ward, John McCarthy
description: Alexandra Lee Ward, the daughter of Virginia Costigan Ward of Columbia, Md., and John Vines Ward of Tokyo, was married yesterday to John Anselm McCarthy, a son of Mavourneen and Colman McCarthy of Washington. The Rev. Winthrop Brainerd, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Epiphany in Washington.

title: Berra Sees Merits of the D.H.
description: Mike Piazza was the Mets' designated hitter last night, not the starting catcher, and he was 1 for 5 and left three runners on base.

title: Investing; For Funds, Ripples From the Middle East
description: IN just two weeks this month, as investors worried whether the violence in the Middle East would escalate into war, the stock market in Israel fell 16 percent. In Egypt, the market dropped 20 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the impact of television coverage on sporting events misidentified the winner of the 1927 ''Long Count'' boxing bout. It was Gene Tunney, not Jack Dempsey.

title: Erin Graves, Roger Gould
description: Erin Michelle Graves, a daughter of Bonnie and Michael Graves of Bloomington, Minn., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Roger van Blerkom Gould, a son of Lois Gould of Manhattan and the late Philip Benjamin. Judge Saralee Evans of Manhattan Civil Court officiated at the Friends Meeting House.

title: Norwich Hopes to Remove Dams on Yantic
description: DAMS have held back the waters of the Yantic River of Norwich for more than 300 years. But they may soon disappear as part of a nationwide effort to restore rivers' natural flow and ecology, to solve chronic flooding problems, and to alleviate the risk of failure of old dams that no longer serve a purpose.

title: Infrequent Visitors To a Bird Sanctuary
description: Just south of Bear Mountain, Iona Island is closed except for a few times a year. Last week, a group from the Beczak Environmental Education Center in Yonkers was taken there by Erin Copeland, an Americorps volunteer who is developing interpretive plans for the 556-acre island, parts of which have been a wildlife refuge since the 1930's.

title: Corporate-Sponsored Brides
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Positions in the Series
description: Even as stock prices fluctuate, thoughts on Wall Street have turned from the Big Board to the Big Diamond.

title: Longtime G.O.P. Incumbent Faces Tough Race on East Side
description: Even Roy M. Goodman acknowledges that this is the most difficult race he has faced in his 32 years in the State Senate.

title: Give at the Office, or Else
description: A survey making the rounds last week found that three out of four business executives reported feeling pressure to make political contributions, and half thought there would be ''adverse consequences'' for refusing. Just 22 percent of the 300 executive respondents said contributions by business were meant to advance an ideological agenda; most chalked it up to a desire for access and influence.

title: Death and the Senate
description: The death of Gov. Mel Carnahan of Missouri in the crash of a small plane last Monday night has diminished the Democrats' hopes of reclaiming the Senate this year.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Porsche 911 Turbo; Exploring the Need for Speed: 175 m.p.h. and a Cloud of Dust
description: THE world looks different at 175 miles per hour. This vast alkaline lake bed turns to a creamy blur as the Porsche 911 Turbo skims across its surface at 257 feet per second. Traffic cones, a quarter-mile apart, appear as orange pinpoints on the heated horizon, then streak past every 5 seconds or so.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Jewish holiday of Simhat Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Ideas & Trends: God and Nature; Saving Souls and Salmon
description: ARCHBISHOP ALEX BRUNETT entered the towering St. James cathedral in downtown Seattle and walked over to a baptismal font. ''The water isn't just sitting there,'' Archbishop Brunett said, gesturing to the small, clover- leaf-shaped pool where the holy water was circulated by a pump. ''We don't baptize people in stagnant water, but flowing water, water that is alive.''

title: Saving a 'Sparkling' Gem, and Fish
description: RICHARD FOOT, executive director of the Westport/Weston Y.M.C.A., unlatched the gate on Richmondville Avenue that leads to the Y.M.C.A.'s hidden treasure. There it was -- Lees Pond Dam, a 17-foot-high stone dam spanning the Saugatuck River a mile north of the Post Road.

title: Marni Miller, Bennett Spencer
description: Marni Elizabeth Miller, a daughter of Jill and Alan Miller of Gladwyne, Pa., was married last evening to Bennett Colin Spencer, the son of Penny and Alan Spencer of Northbrook, Ill. Rabbi Max Weiss officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Firm Ground
description: Oct. 19: The American Museum of Natural History previewed ''Vikings: The North American Saga.'' A tour and dinner for 150 guests was followed by a reception for 1,000 more. The museum's rotunda and Hall of African Mammals had been turned into a Viking village.

title: OPINION; Dead Letters at Great Neck Library
description: A LIBRARY is a passive institution, a house of books, and an unlikely place for speech to wear a gag. Yet the Great Neck Library board of trustees disrespects the written word. The tip-off was a series of ordinary letters, hum-drum even, that fell victim to an intriguing fate.

title: Gore on the Bible and Ecology
description: Following is an excerpt from ''Earth in the Balance,'' Vice President Al Gore's environmental manifesto, which bolsters its arguments with frequent references to spirituality.

title: Arab Summit Is Dominated By Moderates
description: Moderate leaders advocating perseverance in Arab-Israeli peace talks held the floor today at the opening session of the first summit meeting of Arab nations since 1996. But the tone of their speeches, largely aimed at domestic audiences, was harshly critical of Israel and the perceived pro-Israeli tilt of American diplomacy.

title: Debt Debate Ignores The Country's Other Options
description: PAYING off the national debt has been elevated to an obsession. Politics does that. Vice President Al Gore, in the presidential debate last Tuesday, solemnly promised millions of Americans that he would ''eliminate the debt in the next decade.'' So would Gov. George W. Bush. And in their unanimity, they deprive the country of a necessary debate on a crucial question: Is zero national debt healthy for the economy?

title: The Nation: Who Needs Oil?; Energy Independence
description: IF there was one thing America's scientists seemed sure of during the energy crisis of the 1970's, it was that new methods of generating energy from the wind, the sun, the ocean waves and other sources would soon free the country from its dependence on foreign oil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENSTER, ARTHUR (W2EXH)
description: FENSTER-Arthur (W2EXH). Of Baldwin (formerly of Roosevelt). Beloved husband of Jean. Loving brother to Charles. Devoted father and father-in-law of Fred and Sandy Fenster, Susan and Roy Sparber. Loving grandfather of Jessica, Joshua, Jordan and Sarah, and great - granddaughter, Miriam. Graveside services Monday, October 23, 10:15 AM at Beth Moses Cemetery. His love and kindness enriched the lives of his family and all who knew him.

title: Lauren Blick, Thomas Rotko
description: Lauren Eden Blick, the daughter of Elaine and Michael I. Blick of Jericho, N.Y., was married last evening to Thomas Charny Rotko, a son of Ruth Charny of New York and Michael J. Rotko of Unionville, Pa. Rabbi Marvin Antosofsky officiated at the Woodcrest Club in Syosset, N.Y.

title: Special Train Ride Comes to Fans Who Wait
description: It might seem like poor sportsmanship to say it, but it probably should be noted: the Subway Series Special train did not run on time last night.

title: Newark's Train to The Plane
description: It might look like a stranded parking garage, but the concrete wedding cake rising from the industrial plain in west Newark is expected to be the first link between the railroad lines that snake through the state and the New York area airports.

title: SLOWING E-ZPASS USERS
description: E-ZPass was designed to speed traffic flow but if drivers use it too speedily, they risk losing their passes. Starting in January, drivers who move through the E-ZPass lanes at more than the posted 5 miles per hour will have their E-Z Pass privileges temporarily suspended. If more infractions follow, drivers could lose the pass permanently. State troopers will be stationed at some toll plazas. Karen DeMasters

title: City Awards $1 Million to Aid Synagogue
description: Venturing gingerly into the church-state divide, the City Council and the Manhattan borough president have awarded $1 million toward the rehabilitation of the landmark Eldridge Street Synagogue on the Lower East Side.

title: Janet Browner, Jason Noyes
description: Janet Elaine Browner, a daughter of Kate and Michael A. Browner of West Bloomfield, Mich., was married last evening in Ringwood, N.J., to Jason Christopher Noyes, the son of Sonia and Donald Noyes of Hasbrouck Heights, N.J. Rabbi Jerry Heller officiated at Skylands Manor in Ringwood State Park. The Rev. Albert Berner, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Generous Servings and Views of Fall Foliage
description: WE found ourselves recently in the Garden Room of the White Hart Inn in Salisbury. It is a great time of year to visit this northwest corner of the state , when the fall foliage is at its most spectacular.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, ELAINE BEVERLY WOLF
description: ZIMMERMAN - Elaine Beverly Wolf. Passed away October 20, 2000. Beloved and cherished wife of Dr. Theodore Zimmerman. Loving mother of Rick, Jacqui, Ron and Deborah Zimmerman. Devoted sister to Renee Wolf Steinberg. Adoring grandmother to David, Aaron, Ezra and Joseph Zimmerman. Services will be on Monday, October 23, 12 Noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY. Interment at Westchester Hills Cemetery. She touched our lives with beauty and love.

title: Roberta Forbes and Michael Warren
description: MALCOLM S. FORBES, who was known for collecting Faberge eggs and throwing tented parties in Morocco, was not an understated man. One might expect the wedding of his granddaughter Roberta Aimee Forbes to take place on a family-owned Fiji island with private jets ferrying guests in.

title: Clubhouse Confidential
description: To the Editor:

title: Can't Find a Parking Spot? Aww.
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Todd Krieger; Punditry to Go
description: TODD KRIEGER was sitting in the Gaslight bar on far West 14th Street, explaining the Tao of cocktail parties. ''The longest time I talk to one person is 15 minutes,'' he said, slurping club soda through a straw. ''Engaging with someone is so great that if you do it, run with it. You know what they say about Michael Jordan: Always come out on top.''

title: THE GUIDE
description: The Guise of the Grotesque

title: Getting Over It
description: Glory Goes and Gets Some

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAINE, STUART
description: BLAINE-Stuart. Died in NYC of cancer on Friday, October 20. Mr. Blaine was born on July 6, 1923. He was was co-founder of the design firm of Blaine and Booth and enjoyed a distinguished career as a designer and actor. He will be sorely missed by his family and many friends fortunate to have known him. A private memorial service will be held in Millbrook.

title: Zeke Manners, 'Hillbilly' Who Ruled Radio, Dies at 89
description: Zeke Manners, once a popular hillbilly singer and disc jockey and the composer of ''The Pennsylvania Polka,'' among hundreds of other songs, died on Oct. 14 in Los Angeles. He was 89 and lived in West Hollywood.

title: Fashion Forward Armed Forces
description: At the dawning of a new century and millennium, the United States Army is undertaking what its chief of staff, Gen. Eric K. Shinseki, calls a ''transformation.''

title: Tracy Straus, Steven Postel
description: Tracy Straus, the daughter of Joan Straus Cullman and Barnard S. Straus Sr., both of New York, is to be married today to Steven Postel, the son of Diana Postel of Katonah, N.Y., and the late Dr. Allen H. Postel. Rabbi Ruth Gais will officiate at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Joseph F. Cullman 3rd, in New York.

title: Running Away From a Daunting Television Legacy
description: THE two big moments in the first episode of the new ''Fugitive'' are physically spectacular. The first comes near the beginning when Dr. Richard Kimble, once again running from a justice system that has convicted him of killing his wife, escapes from his nemesis, Lieutenant Gerard, by jumping from an overpass onto a moving truck; he avoids being decapitated by executing a leap-and-grab maneuver that would have earned him gymnastic gold at the Sydney Olympics.

title: Hedi Katz, Michael Rorro
description: Hedi Tamara Katz, a daughter of Betsy Katz Oden of Hurley, N.Y., and Sherman Katz of Williston Park, N.Y., was married on Thursday to Michael Louis Rorro, the son of Dr. Gilda Rorro-Baldassari of Mercerville, N.J., and the late Dr. Louis M. Rorro. Mayor Ann McNamara of Tinton Falls, N.J., officiated outside the Twin Lights Historical Site, a 19th-century lighthouse in Highlands, N.J.

title: The Pacific Rim, a Continent Away; Asians, the State's Fastest-Growing Minority, Are Changing the Face of New Jersey
description: ON the western bank of the Hudson, right on the river's edge, stands a pagoda-roofed restaurant with postcard view of Manhattan and a serene rock garden in the rear. A few feet away, there is a warren of small, interconnected stores that sell everything from origami paper to kimonos to the latest Godzilla comic books.

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''The Ralph Nader Reader'' in the Book Review last Sunday referred incorrectly to Mr. Nader's Feb. 21 speech announcing his candidacy for president. It is indeed available, on the Nader campaign Web site, www.votenader.com.

title: Connecticut's Reluctant Candidate Awaits Turn
description: Richard Blumenthal, Connecticut's attorney general, sank into a plush red wing chair in his office antechamber today and said, ''I could easily do this job for many more years and be very satisfied.''

title: Gore Has Explored a Range of Beliefs From Old Time to New Age
description: At New Salem Missionary Baptist, the little country church in Tennessee where Senator Albert Gore's private funeral was held, folks were not at all sure that a woman should be allowed to speak from the pulpit, even if she was an Episcopal bishop, in from Washington, D.C.

title: The Value of the M.B.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeing New Risk In Corporate Bonds
description: THE stock market is looking for help from the Federal Reserve Board in the form of lower interest rates. But for now, the Fed is looking out the window.

title: Albright Heading to North Korea to Pave Way for Clinton
description: Embarking on a landmark visit that signals an accelerating thaw in relations, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright was to leave today for North Korea for a meeting with the Communist country's leader, Kim Jong Il, that could pave the way for a visit by President Clinton.

title: Relief for the Poorest
description: Bono, Pat Robertson, George W. Bush and the Pope make a formidable lobbying quartet. The rock star, religious leaders and Republican presidential candidate joined forces to pressure Congress to finance the United States' share of debt relief for 41 poor nations.

title: Billboard Foes Yearn to Breathe Free Without Its Presence
description: Looming over northbound traffic on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, visible from the Brooklyn Heights promenade, two children stare out from a red-tinted billboard depicting a clogged freeway and bearing this statement: ''Immigration is doubling U.S. population in our lifetimes.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASSAF, MENDEL
description: ASSAF-Mendel. Beloved husband of the late Ziporah. Devoted father of Esther and Ruth. Loving brother of Zwi. Adored grandfather of Michelle, Elyse, Robin, Evan, Lea and Jonathan. Services 10 AM, Monday, at ''BoulevardRiverside Chapel,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: The Candidates' Faith
description: Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore have both relied on their religious beliefs in helping to shape their presidential campaigns, making their spiritual life an intricate part of their political one.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 22, 2000
description: Weeks

title: IN BRIEF: Government; AWARD FOR TECHNOLOGY
description: Westchester's Community Help Desk, which provides assistance to residents on the Internet, has won a ''Best Practices Award'' from the New York State Forum for Information Resource Management. The award is one of four the county has received for improved government services through the use of technology. The Community Help Desk also recently received a Certificate of Recognition for ''innovative government solutions'' from the Eastern Regional Government Technology Conference Advisory Board in Albany. Earlier in the year, the county received an achievement award for its Geographic Information Systems from the Environmental Systems Research Institute in Redlands, Calif. The help desk stores knowledge from professionals who deal with at-risk youths and the elderly. Elsa Brenner

title: Clinton Accuses Lazio of Breaking a Pact on the Use of Soft Money in Campaign Ads
description: Calling a state-financed radio advertisement that promoted the economy of upstate New York an obvious plug for Representative Rick A. Lazio, her opponent in the Senate race, Hillary Rodham Clinton contended today that Mr. Lazio had violated an agreement to restrict spending on commercials.

title: Putting Wings on Fast Food
description: For those who ventured here a couple of weeks ago, there was a choice: cheesecake or pizza.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WRESTLING WITH THE ANGEL

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Oct. 8 with an article about the restoration of an 1890's film clip known as the ''Dickson Experimental Sound Film'' was received from a public relations agency in mirror image and printed that way. The two dancing men should have been at the right.

title: Girls' School In Drive for Arts Center
description: THE Urusline School, a Catholic girls' school here, has begun a campaign to raise $6 million for an arts center.

title: One Bad Cop
description: Cannon notes the lack of public outcry over the corruption scandal at the Rampart unit of the Los Angeles Police Department. Yet you glorify the corrupt cop by putting his picture on your cover -- in a macho pose, no less. Where is your outrage?

title: The World: Arab Leaders' Choice; Unleashed, Anger Can Bite Its Master
description: THE Palestinian ''problem'' has driven politics and policy in the Arab world for nearly as long as there have been independent Arab states. More than a preoccupation, it has had the force to undermine rulers, incite revolutions, circumscribe development and define patriotism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONS, ALEXANDER
description: SIMONS-Alexander. Of Palm Harbor, FL. Died October 19 in Safety Harbor, FL. Born in New York City, Mr. Simons moved to Florida in 1964. An entrepreneur, he was in retail furniture sales in NY, an importer and was a builder and developer in Pinellas County, FL. Surviving family includes his son Steven Simons, Beldon, MS; daughter Rosalind Steinmetz, Palo Alto, CA; companion Gwen Huising, Palm Harbor; seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Funeral services and entombment in Palm Harbor, FL. Call Curlew Hills Funeral Home for more information.

title: Parents Say Stable's New Site Means Dust and Distraction for Children
description: A carriage horse company is setting up a stable next door to Public School 51, and parents are worried about schoolchildren breathing in the stable's dust and odors as well as being distracted by the clip-clopping of carriages. The city has promised to keep the arrangement temporary, however, and says the stable will be a good neighbor.

title: Game Recognition Figures In Seltzer-Grucci Race
description: Regina Seltzer has another uphill battle to fight in her First District congressional campaign against Felix J. Grucci [''An Underdog on the East End,'' Oct. 15]: His free name recognition.

title: Katherine W. Fanning, Pioneering Editor, Is Dead at 73
description: Katherine W. Fanning, a former owner of The Anchorage Daily News who later served as editor of The Christian Science Monitor, died on Thursday. She was 73.

title: Elizabeth Bagot, Arthur Huh
description: Elizabeth K. Bagot, a daughter of Kenneth G. Bagot of St. Petersburg, Fla., and the late Roseann M. Bagot, was married yesterday to Arthur C. Huh, a son of Heung-Sook Huh and Dr. Soung-Yoon Huh of Lima, Ohio. The Rev. Boniface Ramsey performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: Porsche Pulls a Really Fast One
description: GENUINE surprises are rare in the auto industry, where secrets are routinely spilled by spy photos, orchestrated news leaks and calculated rumors. Yet Porsche managed to keep its Carrera GT a secret until it was unveiled at the Louvre last month at the opening of Mondial de l'Automobile, the Paris auto show.

title: Some Gateway Numbers Stay Inside the Box
description: AS the dark and stormy night descended upon technology companies in the third quarter of 2000, the results of Gateway shone like a beacon. On Oct. 12, the company said its revenues had grown 16 percent in the quarter from the comparable period of 1999, while earnings per share rose 31 percent. ''The sky is not falling,'' said John Todd, Gateway's chief financial officer.

title: Shirts Hit a Homer
description: In a town eating and breathing Subway Series, what could be a more appropriate fashion statement than the licensed T-shirt of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority? In Grand Central Terminal, where the No. 7 train to Shea Stadium meets the No. 4 to Yankee Stadium, more than 300 shirts bearing the authority's logos for the lines were sold in nine hours on Thursday at the New York Transit Museum store. Earlier this year, No. 7 shirts were hot properties, following the ill remarks about the line in Sports Illustrated by John Rocker of the Atlanta Braves. New Yorkers snapped up a diversity-celebrating version of the No. 7 shirt with ''International Express'' on the back in 17 languages.

title: A Palestinian Protest Leader Vows to Keep Up the Volume
description: A leader of Yasir Arafat's Fatah movement who has organized the biggest West Bank street protests vowed today to continue confrontations with Israeli forces until they withdraw from the entire West Bank and Gaza Strip, as they did from Lebanon earlier this year.

title: And They Are Off and Running
description: The Mets lost this morning, and they may want to take some time before tonight's second game of the World Series and review the baseball rule book. A refresher course on the definition of a fair ball is in order. Todd Zeile and Jay Payton, in particular, could benefit from turning to Page 16. Come to think of it, the Mets could use a refresher course on base running in general before Game 2.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: MORGAN'S RUN By Colleen McCullough. Simon & Schuster, $28.

title: Jeans Feel Mighty Low
description: Move over, Earl. There's a new trendy denim line in town, and it also has a man's name on the label: Frankie B. The collection, inspired by ''Charlie's Angels,'' was created by Daniella Clarke of Los Angeles, who has been recutting and resewing her own jeans to make them extra tight and low-slung since she was 12.

title: New President Seeks Higher Visibility for Pace
description: DAVID ARMAND CAPUTO, a Fulbright scholar and the past president of Hunter College, was installed on Wednesday as the sixth president of Pace University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANBY, VINCENT
description: CANBY-Vincent. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Vincent Canby, associated with The Times since 1965.

title: University's Neighbors Don't Rally Around New School's New Flag
description: The color is somewhere between hunter green and emerald. And although it lacks a catchy name like, say, Dartmouth Green, it is the official color of the New School University.

title: Husband's Death by Gunfire Is a Campaigner's Issue
description: It happened Tuesday on a campaign stop like thousands of others being held around the city in this hectic election year. In the basement of Calvary Presbyterian Church on the North Shore, two candidates for the State Assembly had just unspooled their spiels for the West Brighton chapter of the American Association of Retired Persons.

title: Israel Weighs Plan to Create Borders if Talks Fail
description: The Israeli government is making contingency plans for a total breakdown of the peace effort. Anticipating a Palestinian unilateral declaration of statehood, the Israelis are laying the groundwork for a ''unilateral separation,'' as they call it: us here and them there.

title: Auctioning Relics Of Big-Top Days
description: As a mecca for big-top circuses and a center for carving carousel horses, New York played a major role in the history of public amusements. So it is fitting that on Friday and Saturday Guernsey's will auction off thousands of items recalling those shows. Among the items on the block at Pier 92 are, left, an example of craftsmanship from the Brooklyn studio of Charles Carmel, restored with glass gems and horse-hair tail, and, above, a horse by Stein & Goldstein of Coney Island. Posters for old circuses will also be sold, including, at right, an image of Chinese acrobats enjoying rice and tea while spinning from their braids. DAVID KIRBY

title: Fly the Angry Skies
description: Jeff MacGregor's amusing analysis of the state of American air travel misses one important point (The Way We Live Now, Sept. 24). Air travel has lost its appeal because it's now available to everyone. Modern planes are nothing more than flying buses. Your fellow passengers are now the same ones who, years ago, made you swear you'd never ride a Greyhound again.

title: Business; How Gold Has Burdened Economies
description: IN 1940, directly out of Harvard, Peter L. Bernstein joined the Federal Reserve Bank of New York as a researcher. He was given a tour of the gold vaults five stories underground. The sight of 100,000 gold bars, stacked floor to ceiling, gleaming in the light, was unforgettable and chilling, Mr. Bernstein recalled.

title: Conspicuous by Its Absence Is a Sidewalk of New York
description: Salvatore Cucuzza is generally proud of the appearance of his Glendale neighborhood. But one piece of land near his house has embarrassed him for years.

title: Moving From Public to Personal Expression
description: THE American Avant Garde: A Decade of Change, 1936-1946'' at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich is a show about how we got from here to there.

title: Habitats/401 East 74th Street; 2 Apartments Combined And Filled With Interest
description: TIM AND BLANCHE BRANTON live in a typical boxy postwar apartment, but one would never know it. Their place is a lesson in how vacuous spaces (unlike vacuous politicians) can be injected with character.

title: The Nation; 'The Bat Shall Be a Smooth, Round Stick'
description: EVEN among those Americans for whom no known thermometer can detect a trace of baseball fever, and for whom the World Series is simply a reason to rediscover public broadcasting, the basic rules of the game tend to occupy some remote corner of the brain. A home run goes over the fence. A strikeout is shaming for the batter and brings good cheer to the pitcher and his supporters. Runs are scored (not points, mind you) by making trips around the bases.

title: The Nation; The Legal Profession Smells a Rat
description: FOR at least a few centuries, lawyers have been portrayed in jokes, cartoons and other expressions of popular culture as maggots, vipers, sharks, locusts and other creatures you wouldn't necessarily ask for a dance. But these days one of the most persistent images -- the treacherous rat -- seems to be emerging as the dominant symbolic stand-in for members of the legal profession.

title: Disabled on Board
description: To the Editor: In contrast to the unfortunate experiences of a traveler using a wheelchair described by Betsy Wade (''Cruise Ships and the Disabled,'' Aug. 6), we had a wonderful time recently on the Pacific Princess, the original ''Love Boat.''

title: The Writings on the Wall
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHFELD, FREDA
description: ROTHFELD-Freda. On October 21, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. Loving and devoted mother of Susan Rothfeld and Dr. Ira Rothfeld. Dear mother-in-law of Angela Silva Rothfeld. Services private.

title: Barak Seeks To Heal Rift With Inquiry And New Aid
description: Trying to heal a rift with Israel's Arab citizens, Prime Minister Ehud Barak announced an inquiry today into the deaths of 13 Israeli Arabs in the current unrest and unveiled a four-year development plan for Arab communities.

title: Consolidation Skews Field In Magazine Distribution
description: Far from the gleaming steel canyons of Manhattan, where tirelessly urbane editors craft the magazines that entertain and inform the American public, the real heartbeat of the magazine industry beats in a squat office building, in a town on the banks of the Tennessee River, two hours' drive from Memphis.

title: The Web as Home for Racism and Hate
description: Twelve years ago Costa-Gavras made a movie called ''Betrayed,'' which raised the specter of white supremacist groups using computer networks to promote racist ideology. As a film it wasn't good and was quickly forgotten, but it has turned out to be a remarkably acute prognosticator of vile things to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKICIOLI, SILK, CATHERINE M. (NEE TROCCOLI)
description: ROCKICIOLI-SILK-Catherine M. (nee Troccoli). On October 21, 2000. She had a distinguished career as one of the first women to have her own fashion business on 57th Street. Inaugural gowns she made for Eleanor Roosevelt are part of the First Ladies Collection at the Smithsonian Institute. She also made costumes for the Ziegfeld Follies, Lou Walters Latin Quarter Shows, Sonya Heinie, Theda Bara, and the Gish sisters. She served as President of the American Legion Auxiliary and was a charter member of the local chapter of the AARP. Her most cherished role was as a devoted mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother to her family. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Loving mother of Assunta and Manuel Carballeira, and Ralph and Alfonsa Rockicioli. Cherished grandmother of Catherine, Joseph and Katie, Andrew and Margaret, Lita and Daniel, Frances and Albert. Dear great-grandmother of Andrew, James, Brooke, Christopher, Matthew, Rose, William, Joseph, and Caroline. Loving sister of Thomas, Joseph, Dominick, and Esther. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd at 193rd St. Visiting hours 2-5 and 7-10 PM, today. Funeral Mass Tuesday, St. Andrew Avellino RC Church at 10:15 AM. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Astor Home, Children's Fund, POB 5005, Rhinebeck, NY 12572.

title: No Time for Napping in Today's Kindergarten
description: It's only October, but already Nicky Beldoch is exhibiting symptoms of student ennui. The other day, when his mother asked him the best thing about school, he said lunch. Most boring? Art history.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC BUYING HONEYWELL IN $45 BILLION DEAL
description: The General Electric Company has agreed to acquire Honeywell International, the diversified manufacturer, for $45 billion in stock, capping several intense rounds of deal making that broke up an impending merger between United Technologies and Honeywell.

title: Eve.com Ceases Doing Business
description: Eve.com, a seller of cosmetics and beauty products over the Internet, said it had fired most of its 164 employees, closed its New York office and ceased operations.

title: America's Endless War on Fat
description: To the Editor:

title: Balancing Classic Jazz and Bubbly Melodies
description: Attending a Bobby Short performance these days is a little like going to the beach on a misty morning. As the sun peeks in and out of the fog, patches of brilliant blue sky appear, and by the end the weather has mostly cleared, with only a few wisps hovering on the horizon. That was the impression Mr. Short made on Wednesday evening, the second night of his 33rd fall season at the Cafe Carlyle, as his voice changed from a raspy saxophone into a bright ringing trumpet.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWAN, ALFRED J.
description: SWAN-Alfred J. Of Plandome, Long Island, NY, who died at home October 21, 2000, lived a life of supporting and caring for his family, friends and community. His wife Ruth (Dattner), his daughters, Peggy and Fran, their husbands, Norman Feldman and Kenneth Peres, their children, Jonathan Hammer and Benyumin and Anushka Peres celebrate his life of 88 years. Alfred J. Swan graduated from Dartmouth College ('33) and Cornell Law School ('36). He served as a lieutenant in the US Navy in WWII, serving on the Destroyer Escort USS Atherton. From 1952 until December 1999, he was a partner in the law practice of Maggin and Swan, NY. Active and loving life until just one year ago, Alfred was a leader in both North Shore communities where he resided, in Great Neck, and since 1969, in Plandome. In the village of Kings Point, Great Neck, he was Trustee and Chairman of The Planning Board, co-founder and thereafter President of the United Community Fund, and member of the United Parent Teachers Council. He was chairman of the NonPartisans Citizens Nominating Committee which was then the leading group for nominating members to serve on the Great Neck School Board. In the Village of Plandome he served a term as Mayor, was Trustee of the Village from 1980-1987, was a member of Plandome Field and Marine Club and Plandome Civic Association and was also instrumental in the reconstruction of the Plandome Train Station in the style of the original building. Two positions of which he was very proud were fire policemen in the Plandome Volunteer Fire Department since 1970, and past Commodore of Knickerbocker Yacht Club. Alfred was an avid sailor and racer on Manhasset Bay. Memorial services for Alfred J. Swan will be held at Temple Beth-El, Old Mill Rd, Great Neck, on Tuesday, October 24, 2000, at 2 PM. The body will be cremated and according to the wishes of this man who loved the sea, the ashes will be scattered on Manhasset Bay. The family requests no flowers please, but if desired, contributions can be made to Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, NY 11590, or to the charity of your choice in the loving memory of Alfred J. Swan.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The notion that kindergarten is a place where kids come and play is an anachronism.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUMINER, SHARON
description: HOUMINER - Sharon. Beloved daughter of Ehud and Naomi. Loving sister of Talia, and Orly and Yaacov. Service Monday, 10 AM, Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Rd, White Plains. For information call Plaza Memorial, 212-769-4400.

title: New Economy; There's just one thing wrong with name-your-own-price businesses: You're not naming your own price.
description: NAME your own price . . . and save!''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ELAHI, CYRUS
description: ELAHI-Cyrus. One with love in his heart never dies.

title: Khannouchi Sets Record in Chicago
description: For the third time in four years, Khalid Khannouchi took first place in the Chicago Marathon. Yesterday, he finished in 2 hours 7 minutes 1 second, the first American citizen to win the race since Greg Meyer in 1982 and setting an American marathon record. The old record of 2:09:32 was set by David Morris of New Mexico at last year's Chicago Marathon.

title: A Hat Trick Spoils Richter's Return
description: Mike Richter made his return last night. A happy homecoming it was not.

title: Hughes Electronics recasts itself as a media company.
description: THE Hughes Electronics Corporation has an identity crisis.

title: Home-Field Advantage
description: In his pregame news conference yesterday, Manager Bobby Valentine of the Mets implied that the dirt in front of home plate in Saturday's game was deliberately softened and resulted in a slowing of Timo Perez's ninth-inning grounder. Catcher Todd Pratt, the runner on third base, did not break for home and never scored.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAINE, STUART
description: BLAINE-Stuart. Died in NYC of cancer on Friday, October 20. Mr. Blaine was born on July 6, 1923. He was was co-founder of the design firm of Blaine and Booth and enjoyed a distinguished career as a designer and actor. He will be sorely missed by his family and many friends fortunate to have known him. A private memorial service will be held in Millbrook.

title: My Data, Mine to Keep Private
description: I was one of those paranoid Americans who chose not to answer all questions on the long form of the 2000 census. My husband and I decided that the government did not need to know, or had other ways of finding out, what time we left for work, how much our mortgage payment was or the amount of our income that came from wages. We were willing to risk the $100 fine to take a stand for individual privacy in an increasingly nosy and automated age.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: A Private Signing for a Cancer Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  Advocacy groups have won overwhelming bipartisan support in Congress and passage of a bill to provide health care to thousands of women with breast cancer. Now they are pleading with President Clinton to sign the bill he supports in a public ceremony at the White House, to publicize the benefits that will become available to low-income women.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the physicist Hendrik B. G. Casimir on Oct. 13 misstated the year of his birth. Dr. Casimir, who died at 90, was born in 1909, not 1901.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPHAEL, ROBERT A.
description: RAPHAEL-Robert A. He is deeply grieved by his son Ronald, his daughter-in-law Carol, his grandaughter Lisa, his great-grandson Anthony, his sister Evelyn, and his longtime, dear friend Shirley Sweetman. Services will be private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Article 2000102390465485426 -- No Title
description: New Media Meets An Old Medium In the Phone Book

title: Behind Art Show, an Onassis Intrigue
description: Until this weekend, dozens of modern Greek paintings were propped against the walls, waiting to be hung at the new Onassis Cultural Center in the basement of Olympic Tower on Fifth Avenue.

title: Better Bilingual Classes
description: To the Editor:

title: Belmont Closes As Velazquez Sweeps Stakes
description: Belmont Park ran its last races of the year yesterday when it ended its fall season and began to move horses, starting gates and office furniture to nearby Aqueduct in Queens, where New York racing will be conducted until next May.

title: Once Banned, Now a Hero of Greek Music
description: It was once music to get arrested by. But tonight it will ring through Avery Fisher Hall, where Charles Dutoit is to lead the Montreal Symphony Orchestra in a 75th birthday tribute to Mikis Theodorakis, Greece's foremost composer and scourge of the colonels of the Greek dictatorship from 1967 to 1974.

title: Investigators Discouraging Speculation In Cole Attack
description: Despite new clues suggesting that the bombing of the destroyer Cole may have involved more than the two men who died in the blast, American officials cautioned today against concluding that they were close to identifying the group responsible or to retaliating militarily.

title: After Charter School, Charter College?
description: With charter schools -- public schools managed by private entities -- firmly established and multiplying, some of their advocates are floating a new idea: charter colleges.

title: Chinese Official Beats Albright to North Korea
description: China's defense minister flew to North Korea today for ''friendly talks,'' just hours before Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright was due to arrive in the North Korean capital.

title: Asia and Latin America Lead PC Sales Surge
description: The personal computer industry continued its torrid pace of worldwide growth in the third quarter, according to two reports scheduled to be released today.

title: Nothing Sub About Us, Suburban Fans Say
description: The numbers do not lie, even if they might damage an old lovable truth about the city and baseball: Most of the people who go to the games at Shea and Yankee Stadiums do not come from the city. They are suburbanites, arriving by S.U.V. instead of IND.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBY, FRANK H. JR, PH.D.
description: EBY-Frank H. Jr, Ph.D. Of Broomall, PA, age 73, on October 19, 2000. Dr. Eby was a retired Villanova University professor. Beloved husband of 25 years to the late Kathleen (nee Toohey). He is survived by his son Frank H. Eby III (''Butch'') and his daughter, Patricia L. Seltzer and her husband Jeffrey, of Paoli, PA. Family and friends are invited to attend his funeral service on Tuesday, at 11 AM, at Spencer T. Videon, Garrett Rd, at Shadeland Ave, Drexel Hill, PA. Interment will be in Arlington Cemetery. Friends may call Monday, from 7-9 PM, and Tuesday from 10-11 AM, at the funeral home.

title: Warner Is Injured as Rams Fall From the Unbeaten Ranks
description: The Kansas City Chiefs believed they could beat the glitzy, fleet and purely offensive-minded St. Louis Rams in only one of two ways -- either stop the Rams from scoring or score more. Simple, right? But so many teams had tried both tactics against the Super Bowl champions and had failed.

title: The Last Lap
description: At the beginning of the final phase of the presidential race, Gov. George W. Bush is clinging to the narrow lead in the polls that he has held the last two weeks. Vice President Al Gore is even sounding like an underdog, with his combative promises to ''fight for you,'' while Mr. Bush has returned to the safety of his early theme of wanting to unite Americans. The governor's standing is a tribute to his effectiveness at the debates, where he held his own against a more experienced, knowledgeable and aggressive opponent. If Mr. Gore is to win, he will have to build on his own assets, talk more about the Democrats' economic record and somehow sharpen his attack on Mr. Bush without alienating voters.

title: President Draws Crowds and Money for First Lady's Race
description: President Clinton flew into New York today to lend his assistance to the Senate campaign of Hillary Rodham Clinton -- and the presidential campaign of Al Gore -- traveling from one end of the state to the other as he denounced Republicans and declared that his wife and the vice president would assure the continuance of his policies once he leaves office in January.

title: Buffalo, Often Butt of Jokes, Is Serious Senate Battleground
description: The Queen City is finally being treated like one, at least until Nov. 7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTNOY, SUSAN E.
description: PORTNOY-Susan E. Age 57, on October 21, 2000. Devoted daughter of Sara and the late Louis David Portnoy. Loving sister of Robert Portnoy of Plantation, FL, and Sharon Siegel of Forest Hills, NY, and aunt of Jessica Siegel, Leah Beth Portnoy and Michael Portnoy. Cherished companion of Jeffrey Haveson of West Orange, NJ. Susan taught in the kindergarten and pre-kindergarten program at P.S. 380 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, for 37 years, following in her mother's footsteps, often touching the lives of succeeding generations of the same families. She was the paradigm of educational excellence, both for her students and for her colleagues. Susan's imprint on the community was such that the parent's resource room at the Nuestros Ninos Child Development Center is being named for her. Services today, 12 noon, at the Kehila Chapel, 16 Brighton 11th St, Brooklyn. Contributions may be made to the Alliance For Lung Cancer, P.O. Box 849, Vancouver, WA 98666.

title: Market Place; A pesky accounting rule won't stop Sprint from replacing options to help its employees.
description: FOR many corporate executives, the ability to profit from stock options is viewed as something close to a right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARDEN, MAUD BELLING
description: VARDEN-Maud Belling. On October 16, 2000. Daughter of Clem and Dora Belling. Vaudevillian with Clem Belling and Company.

title: E-Commerce Report; PBS and NPR find unexpected success selling on the Web.
description: LIKE many industries, public broadcasting was not exactly thrilled to add the Web to its to-do list in the mid-90's. At the time, conservative members of Congress were calling for the end to federal subsidies, cable networks like the Learning Channel were threatening to lure away public television viewers, and the competition for private donations stretched the fund-raising abilities of public radio and television stations alike.

title: Talent-Laden Baltimore Can't Get Offense Going
description: The Baltimore Ravens are among the best-run, most talent-laden teams in the National Football League, with a hungry defense and young draft picks who are paying dividends. But this is what the Ravens' season has come to: The team is looking to Trent Dilfer as a possible savior.

title: Qualcomm's Shrinking Act Could Pay Off Big; Company Prospers by Shedding Divisions and Focusing Fiercely on Patents
description: Irwin Jacobs, the chairman of Qualcomm, had already left China after meeting with Premier Zhu Rongji when word caught up with him at a hotel room in Budapest last week: China's second-largest telecommunications company, China Unicom, had finally confirmed plans to construct a wireless communications network using technology patented by Qualcomm.

title: PeoplePC Finds Niche in Corporate Sales
description: It has been two years since a handful of ambitious start-ups began offering personal computers at no additional charge to customers willing to pay for several years of Internet service and, in most cases, to view a constant stream of online advertising. Only a few still exist.

title: Beijing Journal; Chinese Scholar Learns the Danger of Criticizing
description: When Yu Jie published his first book of essays in 1998, as a 25-year-old graduate student, he was immediately hailed here as an important new voice.

title: Time, AOL and Early Illusions
description: As the wedding day moves closer for America Online and Time Warner, it is worth asking whether this couple seems as right for each other as they did when the engagement was announced in January.

title: ZymoGenetics Will Become Independent of Novo Nordisk
description: One of the nation's oldest biotechnology companies is getting a new life. ZymoGenetics Inc. said it had arranged for $150 million in private financing that would allow it to become independent of its parent company, Novo Nordisk A.S. of Denmark.

title: With Economy Booming, Canadian Leader Calls for Elections
description: Prime Minister Jean Chretien called today for new elections, apparently counting on a booming economy and a popular new tax-cutting package to make him the first Canadian leader since World War II to win a third consecutive mandate.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball Has Long-Running Problem: Making the Game Shorter
description: FORTUNATELY for the Yankees, Jose Vizcaino was still awake at 1:04 in the morning Eastern time yesterday. For, as everyone at least east of the Hudson knows, he interrupted the sleep of many New Yorkers by striking a single in the 12th inning of an amusement in the Bronx. Game 1 of the Subway Series had lasted 4 hours 51 minutes, the longest game in World Series history.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COLLINS, BROTHER JAMES X.
description: COLLINS-Brother James X. From all your friends and colleagues at Manhattan Coll. and around the world. You're missed and remembered on this 7th anniversary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ARTHUR M.
description: GOLDBERG-Arthur M. Yeshiva University and its Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law are saddened by the untimely passing of a dear friend, an eminent corporate executive and philanthropist who served with distinction as a member of the CSL Board of Directors for over a decade. He and his wife, Veronica, are CSL Fellows. We extend our heartfelt condolences also to children, grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Earle I. Mack, Chairman CSL Board of Directors

title: To Our Readers
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, as well as information about errors that call for correction. Starting this week, an editor will respond to messages e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left at this toll-free number: 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397).

title: Essay; Habitual Prevaricator
description: Remember all the claims by Hillary Clinton's see-no-evil supporters that the decision by independent counsel Robert Ray not to prosecute her in the travel office affair ''exonerated' her?

title: The Prizes Are Ready, But the E-Books Aren't
description: Conceived about a year ago by Dick Brass, a vice president of Microsoft, the Frankfurt eBook Awards were intended to publicize the idea of reading from a screen and to encourage the publication of new electronic books.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, IDA
description: NEWMAN - Ida. The Ramaz School family mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our generous benefactor William Newman and of our esteemed Honorary Chairman of the Board and generous benefactor Melvin D. Newman. The Morris and Ida Newman Education Center, which houses our Upper School and which bears her name and that of her late husband will stand as a living monument to her and to her entire family. We extend heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Principal David N. Kahn, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Maryland Case Puts Focus On Abuses by Lobbyists
description: The last time a high-rolling Maryland lobbyist was convicted of corrupt behavior, the newly incarcerated felon boldly continued to enlist clients and lobby the Statehouse from a jailhouse pay phone.

title: A Bipartisan Effort to Remove Politics From Judicial Races
description: In an effort to limit aggressive campaigning for state judgeships across the country, a bipartisan national group is asking judicial candidates to promise to follow newly drafted standards of conduct.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

title: Nippon Life Plans Alliance With 3 Companies
description: The Nippon Life Insurance Company, one of Japan's largest insurers, said today that it was working toward a loose alliance with three nonlife insurance companies that would create one of the largest insurance groups in Japan.

title: G.O.P. Governors Carry Bush's Message
description: In an orchestrated display of party muscle and unity, all but one of the nation's Republican governors descended on the Texas capital today, vowing to wage a relentless fight to propel one of their own into the White House.

title: Zagat Survey Reflects Restaurant Boom
description: With New York's restaurant boom showing no signs of abating, a record-setting 311 restaurants opened in the city in the last year, according to the latest edition of the Zagat Survey, which is available today. The average number of openings since 1996 has been 273 a year.

title: Katherine W. Fanning, 73; Pioneering Newspaper Editor
description: Katherine W. Fanning, a former owner of The Anchorage Daily News who later was editor of The Christian Science Monitor, died on Thursday. She was 73.

title: Yankees Counter Mets On Holding Runners
description: The Mets have an unorthodox method of holding runners at first base. They station first baseman Todd Zeile about eight feet from the bag and in front of the base runner, sometimes obstructing the runner's view of the pitcher. Zeile may also feint toward the base, which often confuses the runner, so that even if the pitcher throws home, the runner sometimes reacts to Zeile's movement and retreats toward first.

title: Metro Matters; City Is More Than Where A Subway Is
description: TURN for just a moment from Series to Subway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANFILIPPO, KATE (NEE CALOGERO)
description: SANFILIPPO-Kate (nee Calogero). On Octber 21, 2000, age 95. Devoted wife of the late Joseph SanFilippo. Beloved mother of J. Anthony SanFilippo, M.D. Cherished grandmother of Joseph and Mary Kate SanFilippo and John and Maryann SanFilippo. Great-grandmother of Joseph Anthony SanFilippo and Emma Rose SanFilippo. Dear mother-in-law of Catherine SanFilippo. Loving sister of the late Thomas Calogero, Frances Micalizio, Josephine Giamboi, Anthony Calogero, Noel Calogero and William Calogero. Reposing at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY, Monday, 7-9, and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10 AM, Church of St. John and Mary, Chappaqua, NY. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: ARAB STATES TAKE DIPLOMATIC STEPS TO PUNISH ISRAEL
description: Eager to demonstrate a get-tough attitude toward Israel while keeping the door ajar to a resumption of peace talks, Arab leaders said today that they would freeze all but formal diplomatic contact with Israel until it made tangible progress toward a final settlement with the Palestinians.

title: In Final Days, Voters Still Wrestle With Doubts on Bush and Gore
description: Even after absorbing three debates and months of campaigning, American voters are thoroughly ambivalent about their choices for president, still vexed by doubts about Vice President Al Gore's sincerity and Gov. George W. Bush's preparedness for the White House, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: America's Endless War on Fat
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidates Name Heroes And Define A House Race
description: For all the disputes over abortion or whose Oklahoma roots run deeper, the race in the Second Congressional District was summed up today when the two candidates named their political heroes. Brad Carson, the Democrat, picked Robert S. Kerr. Andy Ewing, the Republican, named Tom Coburn.

title: In a Texas Church, Gore Campaigns for Morality, Values and 'Prosperity of the Spirit'
description: Taking a Sabbath rest from his relentless focus on fiscal policy, Vice President Al Gore preached today that America must match its economic successes with a ''prosperity of the spirit'' that can only be nurtured through a renewed commitment to families and values.

title: Bolivia Wiping Out Coca, at a Price
description: Leonardo Marca is down to his last acre of coca, and he has no intention of giving it up without a fight.

title: Clinton, Sounding Like a Candidate, Rebuts Bush's Attacks
description: President Clinton plunged into the presidential race today, forcefully rebutting Gov. George W. Bush's attacks on his administration and giving an extensive listing of his accomplishments in a fund-raising swing through upstate New York.

title: Barak Formally Declares Timeout in the Peace Effort
description: Despite intense criticism from key figures in his government, Prime Minister Ehud Barak today formally declared a ''timeout'' from the peace effort.

title: Everybody's a Homebody in Turk Tally
description: It wasn't exactly the day the earth stood still, but one of the world's largest and most cosmopolitan cities was a virtual ghost town today as Turks were confined to their homes for a national census.

title: Greek Lovers in a Hip, Rock Setting
description: Myths are tailored to the way we live (geography, history, mortality) and to the way we dream of living (religion, philosophy and immortality). Where Greeks mythologized pastoral musicians who moved rocks and rivers with their songs, ethereal nymphs and bloodthirsty bacchantes, Americans mythologize big-time rock stars who make millions with their songs, earthbound nymphets and thrill-hungry fans. Both cultures dream of the kind of love that alters lives, tests faith and outlasts death.

title: Sports of The Times; Mets Fans Gasping for Air As Yankees Amaze Them
description: IF you care about the Mets and liked their chances in this Subway Series, you watched Sunday's bizarre Game 2 with a sinking feeling in your heart -- that this series might be over. Even though the Mets came from 6-0 to 6-5 in the ninth inning, the deep-seated doubts you thought had vanished once and for all rushed back and left you gasping for air and wondering: Can we compete with this team?

title: Champion Shares a Lifetime's Experience
description: There is no way to identify the world's best bridge teacher, but there are some necessary requirements. Obviously he or she must be able to project effectively to a large group and explain the concepts involved.

title: A Wounded Giant, AT&T Is Weighing A Split Into 4 Parts
description: AT&T's board intends to consider a plan today to divide the company into four parts and focus more closely on specific segments of the fast-changing telecommunications market, people close to AT&T said yesterday.

title: Even in Church, the Great Rivalry's Pervasive
description: The Lord had not yet announced his pick, but the ushers of St. Barbara's Roman Catholic Church were already laying bets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, DR. LESTER E. JR.
description: COLEMAN-Dr. Lester E. Jr., age 69. Beloved husband of Kathleen A. (nee Deak). Dear father of Robert Scott (wife Paula) and Kenneth John (wife Janice). Loving grandfather of Heather A. Pettit (husband Andrew), Gregory S., Andrew G., Elaine W. and the late Christopher Ryan. Dear son of the late Lester E., Sr. and Ethel A. (nee Miller). Dear brother of the late Dr. John F. (wife Cynthia). Dearest uncle of Regina Milan (husband Fred), Victoria Ellinger (husband David), J. Anthony and great-uncle of Alexandria, Daniela, and Lauren. Retired Chairman and CEO of The Lubrizol Corporation. Captain U.S. Air Force Veteran. Family suggests contributions may be made in Lester's memory to Boy Scouts of America Western Reserve Council or to the University Ireland Cancer Center, University Hospitals of Cleveland, c/o Lung Cancer Research, 2074 Abington Rd, Cleveland, OH 44106. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, October 25, 2000, at 11 AM, at St. Joan of Arc Church, 496 East Washington St, Chagrin Falls. Interment Crown Hill Cemetery. Family will receive friends to pay tribute and celebrate the life of Les at DeJohn-Flynn-Mylott Funeral Home of South Euclid, 4600 Mayfield Rd. (just east of Green Rd.), Tuesday, 2-5 and 6-9 PM. For directions please visit www.DeJohnFuneral.com

title: Trying to Push State Off the Fence
description: The moment has come in Michigan for the big boys to push all their chips to the middle of the table. But they are not yet doing it. Not quite.

title: Protectionism on the Sly
description: Senator Robert Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, has single-handedly pushed a protectionist trade provision into an agriculture spending bill that now goes to President Clinton. Mr. Clinton opposes the provision. But, just weeks before an election, he is unlikely to veto the bill for fear of alienating the steel industry and other potential supporters of Vice President Al Gore. So a measure that is likely to harm consumers and antagonize trading partners will become law without benefit of debate on the floor of either chamber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, AGNES C.
description: KELLY-Agnes C. On October 20, 2000. Devoted wife of the late Francis E. (Sgt.-NYPD). Beloved mother of Eileen Potash, Connie Leisenfelder, Patricia Smyth, Frank, Robert and Kathleen Malone. Cherished grandmother of 20. Dear great-grandmother of 17. Funeral Tuesday, 8:30 AM, from The Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd, Brooklyn, NY 11234. Mass Good Shepherd R.C. Church, 9:30 AM. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Visiting hours 2-5 and 7-10 PM, Monday.

title: Council of Churches Proposes Meeting With Christian Groups
description: The National Council of Churches, a venerable but financially straitened organization that represents 35 Protestant and Eastern Orthodox churches, plans to seek an unusual meeting next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KETIVE, SHIRLEY ''SHIRL.''
description: KETIVE-Shirley ''Shirl.'' Of Fort Lauderdale, FL, on October 20. Adoring, devoted wife of the late Nathan. Beloved mother of Alice (Fred) Rudin, Harriet Lerner and Sam (Randy) Ketive. Revered grandmother of Mitchell (Bonnie) and Robert (Alissa) Rudin, and Rebecca (Robert) Schoenberg, Valerie Ann and Jacques Lerner, and Kimberly Ketive. Great-grandmother of Scott and Benjamin Rudin, Elisabeth and Katherine Lerner, Greg, Jacob and Lilly Rudin, Miles and Paul Schoenberg. We pray she gets a chance to be with her beloved ''Nicky'' again. Interment private. Visits may be paid to the home of Randy and Samuel Ketive, Monday evening through Wednesday, October 25. Donations in her memory to the Alzheimers Foundation. For information, Gutterman-Musicant, 800522-0588.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOWITZ, SAMUEL
description: LEIBOWITZ-Samuel. The Jewish Community House of Bensonhurst is saddened by the passing of our long term member and father of our former President Harold Leibowitz. Our condolences to the entire family. David P. Berkowitz, President Cheryl Fishbein, Chair Howard Wasserman, Exec VP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDER, BETTY
description: BENDER-Betty. Died October 21, 2000. She was 95 years old and lived in New York City until moving to Scottsdale, AZ, in 1997. Her family and friends mourn the loss of a woman of great love and spirit. Her love of learning, music and art, and of New York, enriched and inspired all who knew her. She is survived by her sons Richard (Professor of Architecture and Dean Emeritus at the University of California at Berkeley) and Paul (Professor of Law and Dean Emeritus at Arizona State University), her daughters-in-law, Sue and Margaret, and four grandsons Michael, David, John and Matthew.

title: A Writer for the Stage and the Blackboard; An English Teacher in Queens Tells Tales Out of the Lounge, in Two Acts
description: It was lunchtime in the teachers' lounge at Amsterdam High, and Wallace Johnson was complaining that he had not received the first paycheck of the school year, even though October was half gone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILHELM, GLENN D.
description: WILHELM-Glenn D. With great sorrow, Mobile Wall One, Inc., greatly mourns the passing of our beloved friend and Chief Executive Officer, Glenn D. Wilhelm at the young age of 50. On behalf of all of the employees at Mobile Wall One, we extend our deepest condolences to his family. You will be in our hearts forever. Funeral services will be held at 2:30 PM at Goldsteins' Rosenberg's Raphael Sacks Suburban North, 310 2nd St. Pike, Southampton, PA, between County Line and Street Roads. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association, 800-242-8721.

title: Between Cheek-Pinching and Pasta, Lazio Makes Appeals to Immigrants
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio hopscotched across central New York today, making distinctly different appeals to different groups of ethnic voters who may be pivotal to the outcome of the Senate race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STETZER, SEYMOUR
description: STETZER-Seymour. Beloved husband of Gloria. Devoted father of Edward and Pamela, Steven and Diane. Adored grandfather of Jamie, Justin, Alexandra, Lindsay and Emily. Dear brother of Mimi Blond. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, today, at 2:15 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASCH, ROBERT B.
description: MASCH-Robert B. 76 of Cortlandt Manor, NY, formerly of Freeport, on October 20, 2000. Devoted husband of Dolly. Loving father of Jan, Debra, Stuart, Roger, and daughter-in-law Carol. Grandfather of Jody Lynn and Rebecca. Services will be today, October 23, at 10 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St, Mount Vernon, NY. Interment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Donations to UJ Federation and Memorial Sloan-Kettering.

title: On Baseball; Clemens at His Best, and Most Bizarre
description: Roger Clemens didn't throw at Mike Piazza last night. That is, he didn't throw a baseball at Piazza. He did throw part of a splintered bat, and that act was more bizarre than the pitch he threw on July 8, the one that hit Piazza in the head.

title: INSIDE
description: Albright in North Korea

title: Future of Cup Half Full After U.S. Completes Rout
description: The issue on the golf course was settled early today, but long-range issues concerning the Presidents Cup will take longer to sort out.

description: AL GORE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, LESTER J.
description: MORRIS-Lester J. Of Bloomfield Hills, MI, and Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Jewell Prentis Morris. Dear father of Patrice (Dr. Eric) Phillips, Robert Prentis Morris and good friend JoAnn Ross and the late Jimmy Prentis Morris. Loving grandpa of Jennifer and Rachel Phillips. Brother of Beatrice Smith of New York. Services are being held today in Detroit. For information call the Ira Kaufman Chapel, 1-800-325-7105.

title: Fear of Cutbacks Rattles Papers In Philadelphia
description: By almost any business measure, the Knight Ridder newspapers in Philadelphia would be deemed a success. Since 1995, profit margins at The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Philadelphia Daily News have more than doubled, reaching close to 19 percent after years of single-digit doldrums.

title: Mitchell Sviridoff, 81, Dies; Renewal Chief
description: Mitchell Sviridoff, a national leader in urban social policy and philanthropy who played an important role over three decades in developing strategies for lifting people out of poverty and reviving decaying neighborhoods, died early Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81.

title: Excuse Me, Class, While I Go Slit My Wrists
description: In a raucous high school classroom a teacher has left a message on the board: ''Gone to kill myself. Hope you're happy!'' The teacher sent to replace her complains: ''I can't even get them to turn off their boom boxes. They're animals.'' He has no room to talk; he is being blackmailed by a pretty blond student with whom he has been in a compromising situation.

title: Site Lifts Presence Through Charity
description: Better to throw money at charities than at advertisers.

title: EROTICA INC. -- A special report.; Technology Sent Wall Street Into Market for Pornography
description: The video-store chain that Larry W. Peterman owned in this valley of wide streets and ubiquitous churches carried the kind of rentals found anywhere in the country -- from Disney classics to films about the sexual adventures of nurses. Mr. Peterman built a thriving business until he was charged last year with selling obscene material and faced the prospect of bankruptcy and jail.

title: WRITERS ON WRITING; After 20 Years, Meditation Still Conquers Inner Space
description: At a recent weeklong silent retreat I had the insight that if I had not divorced my very admirable husband and suffered horribly the irrevocable loss of his friendship, I might never have discovered meditation. Although the ancient Chinese alerted us to the fact that one house move is equal to three fires, no one had told me how difficult it would be to separate from someone I loved deeply but did not wish to live with anymore.

title: Difficult Days for Mideast Peace
description: The cease-fire President Clinton tried to broker between Israelis and Palestinians last week never took hold and any early return to peace negotiations seems unrealistic. As a result, Israel has begun thinking about unilateral moves to disentangle its territory and economy from the Palestinians and Arab leaders have called for a temporary freeze on new ties with Israel. But no irrevocable steps have yet been taken, and such drastic actions still can be avoided if the coming days see a significant reduction in the violence that has killed more then 120 people and wounded thousands.

title: America's Endless War on Fat
description: To the Editor:

title: Oldsmobile Invites 3 To Vie for Account
description: The Oldsmobile division of General Motors is inviting three agencies to compete for creative responsibility on a new divisional campaign that will also be used for all individual vehicle advertising. The decision could change Oldsmobile's relationship with its lead agency, Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, which has worked for Oldsmobile since 1967. Billings have not been determined.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the singer and actress Julie London on Thursday misspelled the surname of her second husband, who died last year. He was Bobby Troup, not Troupe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, MIRIAM
description: WEINER-Miriam. October 19, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Eleanor Revson. Cherished grandmother of Alexandra Borowik, Paul Revson and great grandmother of Olivia, Louisa, Sarah and Sebastian. Funeral private.
