description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Albright Arrives in North Korea to Test the Waters for Clinton
description: The most senior American official to visit North Korea since the end of the Korean War nearly 50 years ago, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright landed here today to a bare-bones arrival ceremony on a gray, balmy fall morning.

title: New York Was Watching
description: The rating for Game 1 of the Subway Series, which the Yankees won by 4-3 in 12 innings, produced a 14.0 preliminary overnight Nielsen rating with a 25 share Saturday night, down 7 percent from a 15.0 (26 share) for the same game last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALDER, ALEXANDER WILLIAM
description: CALDER-Alexander William. Age 76, of Oil City, PA, formerly of Pittsburgh. Died October 20, 2000, in Franklin, PA.

title: Beyond Tans and Tinsel; A New Los Angeles Museum Show Seeks to Smash California Cliches
description: A surfboard from the forgettable 1964 movie ''Ride the Wild Surf'' rests in a corner of one gallery at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Another gallery displays plaintive visions of Mexicans in California by 1930's muralists like Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo and David Alfaro Siqueiros. A third shows harrowing photographs documenting the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II.

title: No Jeffrey Maier
description: Todd Zeile could not believe his sixth-inning drive in Game 1 on Saturday bounced off the top of the left-field wall and stayed in play. Zeile pumped his fist as if he had homered before realizing that the ball did not go out. He got a double, but Timo Perez was thrown out trying to score from first base after slowing down near second base. Zeile could not help but recall another infamous moment in Stadium history.

title: Heisman Math Adds Victories
description: It's not an age-old question. It's certainly not as urgent to the five boroughs as which team is going to win the Subway Series. But it matters to anyone who follows college football: what constitutes a Heisman Trophy winner?

title: A Feisty Torre Defends Pitcher
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre raised his voice, challenged his questioners and seemed about to walk out on a news conference. The Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, was a little less emotional, but perhaps made the stronger insinuation about the Mets, their opponents in the World Series. Their comments came in defense of Roger Clemens, the hard-throwing pitcher, after the Yankees defeated the Mets by 6-5 last night at Yankees Stadium to take a 2-0 lead in the World Series.

title: No Excuses for Perez
description: While saying Tim McClelland, the left-field umpire in Game 1, made the right call on Todd Zeile's near-homer on Saturday, Bobby Valentine said McClelland's inactivity may have caused a base-running mistake by Timo Perez.

title: Arab Statement: 'Criminals of War Who Committed Massacres'
description: Following are excerpts from the statement issued today by Arab leaders at the end of their summit meeting as translated by The New York Times:

Besides Barry Scheck and Jim Dwyer, the authors included Peter Neufeld.

title: After an Inexplicable Situation, the Mets Are Searching for an Explanation
description: Mike Piazza was confused, desperate for an answer that he never got. His teammates were alternately puzzled or enraged. The Mets had added incentive to beat the Yankees' Roger Clemens in Game 2 of the World Series last night at Yankee Stadium, and their emotions worked against them after Clemens picked up a piece of Piazza's broken bat and flung it toward him in the first inning.

description: SILVERSTEIN-Sylvia M. Beloved mother of Sanford and the late Arnold. Adored grandmother. Past President of the Judith Group of Hadassah, Bklyn N.Y. Services Old Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Blvd, Queens, Tuesday at 11 A.M.

title: RICE'S KNEE PASSES EXAM
description: After soreness in his left knee had kept him out of two practices and two preseason games, Glen Rice participated in shooting drills with the Knicks yesterday. An M.R.I. exam was performed on Rice's knee on Saturday. The results were negative, and the diagnosis was a bone bruise. He did not run in practice yesterday, and he is listed as day to day.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Gus Hall, longtime chairman of the American Communist Party, misstated the title held by Nikita S. Khrushchev when he was the Soviet leader. Khrushchev became premier in 1958; he was not premier in 1956 and he never held the title head of state.

title: Robinson's Line-Shuffling Makes a Difference for Devils
description: The absence of the unsigned center Jason Arnott forced Devils Coach Larry Robinson to look in all directions for the right player combinations on Saturday night. After several experiments, Robinson looked toward Russia and the Czech Republic, and he might have solved the puzzle.

title: A Little Democracy on Wall Street
description: American investors have been riding a roller coaster. Last Wednesday, the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted a sickening 438 points, or 4 percent, in the first hour of trading -- only to recover before the closing bell. The next day, the Nasdaq, after having dropped nearly 30 percent in the previous month, shot up 247 points, or 7.8 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONENCLAR, JOSEPH
description: SONENCLAR-Joseph. Beloved husband of the late Bernice. Loving father of Judy and Stanley Adelsheimer and Leslie and Larry Chalson. Dear grandpa of Michael and Ivy Levy, Alan Levy, Maggie and Andrew Chalson, and Erica and Toni Adelsheimer. We'll miss his determination.

title: Some Have to Be There, Even if They Can't Get In
description: Before Yankee Stadium underwent an extensive renovation in the mid-1970's, any big baseball fan with small resources could take the No. 4 train to 161st Street, walk out to one end of the elevated platform and, with no ticket other than a token, gaze down onto a slice of the emerald green field where legends were playing.

title: Schumacher's Team Wins the Title
description: A close season ended with a close race yesterday as Michael Schumacher drove his Ferrari to victory in the Malaysian Grand Prix in Sepang, crossing the finish line less than a second ahead of David Coulthard in a McLaren-Mercedes.

title: 10 Hours on the Aegean, Masked and Mythic
description: By the end of Part 6 of ''Tantalus,'' the mammoth 10-part theatrical treatment of the Trojan War and its prelude and aftermath that is being given its world premiere by the Denver Center Theater Company here, the siege of Ilion is over, the city is sacked, Priam and Hector are dead, and the Trojan women have been enslaved and driven onto the ships of the conquering Greeks. About to begin their trip home, Menelaus and Odysseus have a war-weary exchange on the circular, sand-strewn stage that is here the bloodstained shores of Troy but serves the show as the Aegean of both antiquity and modernity.

title: Early Lessons in Tyranny, Repeated in Modern Times
description: THE PERFECT HERESY

title: Jacquelyn Reinach, 70, Writer Known for an A-to-Z Menagerie
description: Jacquelyn Reinach, a writer, composer, television producer and co-creator of the ''Sweet Pickles'' series of children's books, which featured characters like Accusing Alligator and Smarty Stork, died on Sept. 30 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 70.

title: A House Firebrand Says Goodbye to All That, for Now
description: JOHN R. KASICH has this to say about his impending retirement from the House of Representatives: ''I would actually like to be president one day.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, RUTH
description: THOMPSON-Ruth. Age 91, of Greenwich, CT, died Friday, October 20. Sister of Jean T. Makepece of Greenwich, aunt of Marilyn Makepece and William Lloyd Makepece. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, at 3 pm, in Second Congregational Church, 139 E. Putnam Ave, Greenwich. Memorial contributions may be made to the Nature Conservancy or the Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perryridge Rd, Greenwich, CT 06830.

description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about an Italian constitutional amendment that allows citizens living abroad to elect their own legislators referred incorrectly in some copies to the voting method. Absentee balloting is not allowed.

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Old A.F.C. East Rivalry With New Twist: Defense
description: When Jimmy Johnson stopped by to visit Dave Wannstedt, his good friend and successor as Miami's coach, last week during Dolphins practice, he delivered a message filled with pride and a bit of envy: you are doing what I wanted to do last year -- playing defense, running the ball and not turning the ball over.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 11 about Genetic ID, a testing lab for genetically modified crops and foods, referred incorrectly to a press briefing that followed the company's discovery of unapproved corn in a brand of taco shells. Genetic ID announced the briefing in August, the month before the taco-shell findings were disclosed by opponents of bioengineered foods; the company says the gathering was not called to publicize the discovery.

title: Oversize Appetite for Life and Letters
description: Overweight and occasionally overwrought, Gerard Depardieu brings marvelous, blustery emotion to ''Balzac: A Life of Passion,'' Bravo's pleasurable vision of the great French author. With its elegant score and lavish sets, this handsome French-language production (with subtitles) has a lusciousness that suits its subject, a man who was outsized in almost every respect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'INZILLO, STEVE
description: D'INZILLO-Steve. The officers, members and staff of IATSE Projectionists Union Local 306 mourn the passing of our president and longtime chief officer. He was Representative/former vice president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, and an activist in progressive civic, charitable and entertainment industry organizations. Deepest condolences to the family. May his good works live long.

title: Hampton Wants Another Chance
description: Mike Hampton has maintained through the year that he will not address his future until after the Mets' season is over. After his mediocre outing last night, Hampton did not want to contemplate that his season and perhaps his Mets career could have ended so miserably.

description: BRODY-Lowell. A longtime resident of Englewood, NJ, and recently of Southbury, CT, on October 20, 2000, at the age of 77. He was an architect and emeritus member of the AIA. He is survived by his wife Shirley, two sons David Brody of New York and Brooke Brody of West Virginia, a daughter Lesley Nelson of Maine, and three grandchildren. Services will be private.

title: Media Titan Surveys His Empire at Frankfurt Book Fair
description: At around 1 o'clock on Friday afternoon, word swept through the cavernous halls housing the 52nd annual Frankfurt Book Fair that Thomas Middelhoff, chairman and chief executive of Bertelsmann A.G., had arrived to tour the fair. Executives of Bertelsmann businesses, from its German printing operations to its mammoth Random House publishing group, hurried to their stations to prepare for a visit from the chief.

description: ALLENTUCK-Max A. 1911-1995. Here's to the good times, Maxie. All Our Love

description: Charles Savage, a Miami Herald reporter on the front lines of the newspaper's Everglades-to-ocean circulation war with the newly renamed South Florida Sun-Sentinel, found himself the not-exactly-proud possessor of a decidedly awkward exclusive this month.

title: Peru's Ex-Intelligence Chief Reported to Leave Panama
description: The former Peruvian intelligence chief, Vladimiro Montesinos, who had fled Peru last month for Panama to seek political asylum following accusations of corruption, left Panama tonight on a private plane heading for Ecuador, Panamanian officials said.

title: Kramnik's Berlin Wall Holds And Game 9 Ends in a Draw
description: Vladimir Kramnik doesn't mind if his pawns look disreputable. If his pieces are battling mightily, he's happy and safe.

description: HALPERN-Margarete. My dearest friend Maggie, you loved life, you were a good person. Andie Schwalbe Milstein Properties My love, E.H.-Dance in heaven

title: Clemens Throws a Bat, Then Dominates the Mets
description: Roger Clemens threw fastballs that reached 99 miles an hour, but drew even more attention for firing a broken bat in the direction of the Mets' Mike Piazza last night, pitching eight shutout innings and heightening the emotions of the Subway Series that is being controlled by the Yankees.

title: Many Stay Away From Polls In Boycotted Ivory Coast Vote
description: Ten months after the military seized power in an initially popular coup, Ivoirians voted today in a presidential election that included the putsch leader and four civilian candidates, but excluded those of the two biggest parties.

title: Yugoslav Leader Treads Softly at Poet's Rite in Bosnia
description: Vojislav Kostunica today made the first visit to Sarajevo by a Yugoslav head of state since war broke out here eight years ago, hastily starting a dialogue of peace to soften what many see as his support for Serbian nationalism.

title: Patents; A Web site invites bounty hunters to disprove ownership of ideas, even those of its founders.
description: TO opponents of business-methods patents, Jeff Bezos, founder and chief executive of Amazon.com, has become a poster boy for his patent covering a ''one click'' electronic ordering system. One critic has been Tim O'Reilly, a publisher of software books and online information, who posted an open letter to Mr. Bezos on his Web site last winter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINREB, MARVIN S.
description: WEINREB-Marvin S. Age 74, of Oakland, CA, a dedicated dermatologist, loving family man, and humanitarian, died on October 14, while volunteering in Mexico with The Flying Doctors. He is survived by his wife Ilene, former mayor of Hayward, CA, daughters Rachel, Deborah and Judith, all of northern California, sister Anita Weinreb Katz of Manhattan, brother Joseph Weinreb of Florida, and four granddaughters.

title: No Excuse for Pitcher Being a Bully
description: The replay of Roger Clemens planting a fastball on Mike Piazza's helmet three and a half months ago and Piazza subsequently crumpling to the dirt was a popular slice of videotape. Flip on any sports highlight show and there was an excellent chance of seeing a replay of a future Hall of Fame pitcher decking a future Hall of Fame catcher. Over and over until you reached for the remote.

title: A Classic That Already Endures
description: For one of those rarest of times, the people of this city spent the night together. Beneath a blanket woven by electronic transmissions and draped over skyscrapers and bodegas, they followed an athletic drama unfolding dreamily in the bluish Bronx haze of one Saturday night in autumn.

description: In a re-row of the finals of the Sydney Olympics men's single sculls, and a reversal of the finish order in the women's Olympic singles, the New Zealanders Rob Waddell and his wife, Sonia, won the inaugural 580-meter Schwab Sprint yesterday in the Head of the Charles Regatta in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Alice Walker: After 20 Years, Meditation Still Conquers Inner Space
description: At a recent weeklong silent retreat I had the insight that if I had not divorced my very admirable husband and suffered horribly the irrevocable loss of his friendship, I might never have discovered meditation. Although the ancient Chinese alerted us to the fact that one house move is equal to three fires, no one had told me how difficult it would be to separate from someone I loved deeply but did not wish to live with anymore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, BLANCHE
description: FRIEDMAN-Blanche. 90, died peacefully in her home October 20, 2000. She is survived by Israel, her beloved husband of 63 years, her daughter Lois Friedman of New York City, her son Dr. Matthew Friedman of Longmeadow, MA, and her cherished grandchildren Jessica Hutchins of Manhattan Beach, CA, Carly Friedman of Washington, DC, and Daniel Friedman of Ann Arbor, MI. She earned a BA degree at New York University and a masters degree in Psychology at The University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. She worked 20 years for the New York City Board of Education as a teacher of hospitalized children at Tisch Goldwater Hospitals.

title: No Time for a Balkan Exit
description: Sharp contrasts emerged over the weekend in the way the Bush and Gore campaigns view America's proper military role in Europe. The debate began when Condoleezza Rice, one of Gov. George W. Bush's leading foreign policy advisers, told The Times's Michael Gordon that a Bush administration would ask European members of NATO to gradually take over full responsibility for providing peacekeeping forces for Bosnia and Kosovo. Vice President Gore countered that carrying out such a policy could destabilize the Balkans and jeopardize the future of NATO, America's most important military alliance.

title: In Homestretch, Gore Maps Route Through Fickle Ground

title: Foreign Affairs; Cultural Revolutions
description: In the wake of the latest Middle East violence it's easy to fall into the trap of believing that this tribal war is the world. It is useful to remember that the very same week that 10.3 million Palestinians and Israelis fell back into conflict, America agreed to terms for 1.3 billion Chinese to enter the World Trade Organization, Slobodan Milosevic was ousted from power in Belgrade, President Clinton completed plans to visit Vietnam, the No. 2 leader in North Korea came to the Oval Office and asked the president for ''normal relations,'' and Jordan became the fourth country to reach a free-trade agreement with America.

title: Timing's Perfect As Hernandez Rides Into Shea
description: The replays of Roger Clemens hurling a bat past Mike Piazza in Game 2 of the Subway Series exacerbated the anger and frustration of the Mets yesterday, as some of them spoke of the Yankees' pitcher with a derision barely contained.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the Congressional record of Representative Rick A. Lazio misstated the endorsements of the National League of Conservation Voters in the race for the United States Senate from New York. The organization has endorsed both him and Hillary Rodham Clinton, not just Mrs. Clinton. The New York League of Conservation Voters, a separate group, has endorsed only Mrs. Clinton.

title: The Jets Are the Last Team Standing
description: The first cheers the Jets heard Monday night did not come until just 6 minutes 33 seconds remained in the first half, long after the color had drained out of Coach Al Groh's face, after the humiliation seemed to be well under way.

title: For Bach and Soulmate, Song Is Hardly the Whole Story
description: Murray Perahia began his Great Performers recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon with a group of Bach chorale preludes as transcribed by Busoni. ''Nun Komm, der Heiden Heiland'' was a gem of counterpoint in which the voices were equally clear, equally melodious and equally distinct in color. There was a beautifully soft bass line -- a special characteristic of Mr. Perahia's, freely and wonderfully used throughout the recital -- and a firm sounding of the chorale tune. In ''Nun Freut Euch, Lieben Christen,'' the rushing right hand was all joy. In ''Ich Ruf' zu Dir, Herr Jesu Christ,'' what mattered was the slow melody, and the want that it created for a much larger musical span.

title: HYUNDAI ENGINEERING LAYOFFS
description: An affiliate of the Hyundai Group, South Korea's largest conglomerate, says it plans to lay off about 25 percent of its top executives in response to mounting pressure to reduce its debts. The affiliate, Hyundai Engineering and Construction, the nation's largest contractor, said it would lay off 63 executives, close two local and four overseas offices, sell parts of its business and spin off 10 other units. The company has about 20,000 workers. It has been having difficulty meeting an end-of-the-year deadline for selling off its assets to take its debts below 4 trillion won ($3.5 billion) from the 5.1 trillion won goal its creditors are demanding. Samuel Len

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTNOY, SUSAN ELAINE
description: PORTNOY-Susan Elaine. On October 21st, 2000. Beloved daughter of Sara Portnoy. Dear sister of Sharon Siegel and brother Robert Portnoy. Loving nieces Jessica Siegel, Leah Beth Portnoy and nephew Michael Portnoy. She will be greatly missed.

title: Scientists Watch Giant Storms Colliding on Jupiter
description: PASADENA, Calif., - Astronomers have, for the first time, witnessed two giant storms on the planet Jupiter collide and merge, scientists at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) said Monday.

title: Lebanese Businessman Once Again is Premier
description: Rafik Hariri, the owner of a billion-dollar construction and engineering company, was named prime minister tonight, as Lebanese hoped to see the battered country on the difficult road to recovery.

title: 'Thou Aeronautical Boll Weevil, Illuminate Yon Woods Primeval'
description: Cabaret Convention Tribute

title: Consortium Quits Bidding as Italy Ends Wireless License Sale
description: After only three days of bidding, an auction for licenses to operate a new generation of wireless devices in Italy ended in confusion today after a consortium backed by British Telecommunications backed out, leaving only five bidders for the five licenses.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Robert Chapman, 81, Playwright And Retired Harvard Professor
description: Robert Harris Chapman, a retired teacher of English and drama at Harvard University and a co-author of the stage version of Herman Melville's ''Billy Budd,'' died on Sept. 27 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHRMAN, VERA
description: LEHRMAN-Vera. Age 95. On October 22, 2000. Teacher and Artist. Devoted wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Laura, Robert (Jane). Proud grandmother of Lynne Gregory (David), Lisa Gugenheim, Karen Resheff (Doron), great-grandmother to Jonathan, and Adam, Danielle & Rachel. Private graveside services. Donations appreciated to Art Students League, New York City.

title: Barak and Sharon Open Talks on Forming a Coalition
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel formally opened talks today with Ariel Sharon, the rightist opposition leader, on forming a coalition government as gun battles with Palestinians erupted again on the edge of Jerusalem and with no end in sight to the violence.

title: Plague Can Wax When Rats Wane
description: Bubonic plague, the Black Death that killed a third of the population in 14th-century Europe and millions more worldwide at the turn of the 20th century, is one of the most feared diseases. But when it comes to understanding how plague spreads, researchers in Britain say, it's not about humans, it's about rats.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Anchorage and Seattle

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Penguins and Climate

title: Answer to Vouchers?
description: To the Editor:

title: DRUGSTORE.COM REPORTS EARNINGS
description: The medicine continues to be bitter at Drugstore.com. On Friday, the company said it was laying off 60 employees, some 10 percent of its work force. Yesterday, the company said it had scaled back its marketing and other spending plans for next year to preserve its cash. The company also released its third-quarter results yesterday, reporting a loss of $33.3 million, or 58 cents a share. That was better than the 64 cents a share that analysts had expected. Sales for the quarter rose to $26.5 million, from $12.2 million last year. Saul Hansell

title: INSIDE
description: Israeli Coalition Talks

title: Knoblauch Accepts Benching In Game 3
description: Joe Torre said more than a week ago that Chuck Knoblauch would play second base in the World Series, when the games shifted to Shea Stadium. The Yankees manager spoke resolutely, in the same way he might declare Derek Jeter to be his shortstop.

title: Bush and Gore Get 2 1/2-Minute PBS Forums
description: PBS is offering the major presidential candidates two and a half minutes to address the public on topics of their choosing after ''The Newshour With Jim Lehrer.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: NEW LOW FOR EURO. The euro hit a new low on speculation that central banks will allow the currency to slide further before they intervene again. In New York, the euro settled at 83.58 cents, down from 84.12 cents on Friday.

title: Piazza Is Calm As Teammates Scorn Clemens
description: The Mets waited 14 years to get back to the World Series, and several veterans had waited nearly as long or longer to experience baseball's showcase. But the Series could be over by tomorrow night, and all the talk is about a nasty incident that is not going away.

title: For Back Pain Sufferers, a Technique Under Study May Offer Hope
description: A 21-year-old dancer pushed her face into a pillow last spring as a needle probed one disk and then another in her lower back in a chilly radiology suite. Less than a teaspoon of dye oozed from the needle into the first disk, showing up on an X-ray as a dark puddle within the lighter disk. The needle slipped into the next spot, and again the dye pooled dark inside the disk.

title: Attacked From Right, but That's Nothing New
description: Republicans here say the liberalism of Lane Evans, the Democratic congressman who has represented the district for 18 years, scarcely fits this farm-and-factory region of northwestern Illinois.

title: Giants Get 2 Breaks: A Bye Week and Key Injuries to Coming Opponents
description: A bye week has kept the Giants idle for several days, and while they have rested, by coincidence, the star quarterbacks for two coming opponents have sustained serious injuries. The Giants are focusing this week on the Philadelphia Eagles -- improving division rivals who come to Giants Stadium on Sunday -- but the landscape and preparation for the two pivotal games that follow have taken a quirky turn because of two freakish injuries.

title: Take Me Out to the Fashion Show
description: Did the Yankees really adopt pinstripes because they made Babe Ruth look slimmer? Not really. But just because the oft-told story is a canard doesn't mean ballplayers are outside fashion's ineluctable pull. Just check out El Duque's dark knee socks. Miuccia Prada showed that look for Spring 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KETIVE, SHIRLEY
description: KETIVE-Shirley. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Alice and Fred Rudin, Harriet Lerner, Randy and Sam Ketive, all of her treasured grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. May you take comfort in the fact that she is at peace. Carol and Richard Kalikow

title: Quiet Signing for Cancer Bill That Was Backed by Lazio
description: Advocacy groups have won overwhelming bipartisan support in Congress and passage of a bill to provide health care to thousands of women with breast cancer. Now they are pleading with President Clinton to sign the bill he supports in a public ceremony at the White House, to publicize the benefits that will become available to low-income women.

title: Political Consultants Thrive in Cash-Rich Politics
description: When Peter Fenn became a media political consultant 20 years ago, he said he was motivated more by a love of politics than a love of money.

title: WABASH NATIONAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE BREADNER GROUP
description: The Wabash National Corporation, the maker of truck trailers, agreed to buy the Breadner Group, a Canadian trailer and parts dealer, to expand its retail network into Canada. Financial terms of the letter of intent were not disclosed. Wabash, the maker of Wabash and Fruehauf truck trailers, said the purchase would bolster sales through its retail network as much as 25 percent. Breadner, a closely held company based in Kitchener, Ontario, had sales last year of $100 million, according to Wabash, which is based in Lafayette, Ind. Wabash shares fell 13 cents to $7.88.

title: A Game Complicated By Rooting for Home
description: The Yankees lead the Subway Series 2-0. Any fan would know that this is because of a winning run in the bottom of the 12th in Game 1 and 95 mile per hour pitching in Game 2. The Mets have had their own highlights despite the defeats -- the five-run rally in Game 2's ninth inning, for instance.

title: Sybil Milton, 59, Scholar of Nazis and Holocaust
description: Sybil H. Milton, a leading scholar of Nazi Germany and the Holocaust and a senior historian at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, died on Oct. 16 in the clinical center of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. She was 59.

title: Robert Lax, 84, Minimalist Poet Known for Experimental Forms
description: Robert Lax, an American minimalist poet who was praised for his originality and spirituality, died on Sept. 26 at his family's home in Olean, N.Y. He was 84.

title: Rangers Timid, but Coach Isn't: Graves Out as Messier Linemate
description: Ron Low, stationed at the blue line with his whistle in his hand, suddenly began to chomp his chewing gum with a fury, and he elevated his voice so that it rattled off the rafters of the old Playland rink.

title: SETTLEMENT REPORTED ALMOST READY IN AUCTION CASE
description: After more than four weeks of arguing over details, lawyers for Sotheby's and Christie's and customers suing the auction giants for price-fixing are close to signing a $512 million civil settlement, a lawyer told an impatient federal judge yesterday. With no sign of the final papers since the parties reported reaching agreement Sept. 22, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan called both sides into his Manhattan courtroom yesterday to say that without a formal settlement they faced a February trial date. Richard Drubel of Boies, Schiller & Flexner, lead counsel for the class of more than 100,000 customers who say they were cheated by collusive practices, told the judge he expected a final agreement ''within 48 hours.'' Ralph Blumenthal

title: Keeping Weight Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Photography, the New Cavity-Fighter
description: ''Open wide. A little wider, please. Very good. Now say 'cheese.' ''

description: Following is a transcript of a speech by Vice President Al Gore on Saturday night at Martin Luther King High School in Philadelphia, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Gore Sharpens His Message in Campaign's Frenetic Closing Days
description: With the clock ticking to Election Day, Vice President Al Gore's stump speech has taken on a new urgency.

title: Spanish Music Out of France With Some Help From Canadians
description: Though it's not polite to say so out loud, some of the best Spanish music was written by French composers, especially Debussy and Ravel, who were completely enamored of everything Spanish.

title: Bats Were Tougher
description: In the 1940's and 50's, bats didn't shatter the way Mike Piazza's did Sunday night in Game 2 of the World Series against Roger Clemens.

title: Sports of The Times; Without 13, It Can't Be The Dolphins, But It Is
description: THE uniform colors were the same: aqua and coral. But at Giants Stadium last night, the visiting team could not possibly be the Miami Dolphins because Dan Marino was not out there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, IDA
description: NEWMAN-Ida. Beloved wife of the late Morris B. Newman and mother of William (Anita), the late Joseph (Rosalyn) and Melvin (Carol). A devotee of Hebrew language and culture, she lived a long and fruitful life. She was a patron of Jewish education and pursued knowledge until her final days. She will be greatly missed by her children and her many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Funeral services Tuesday, 1:15 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILTON, SYBIL
description: MILTON-Sybil. Dear colleague, unique historian. Friends privileged to work with you at the Holocaust Museum will sorely miss you, and mourn this great loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAHY, RICHARD J.
description: LEAHY-Richard J. Attorney, 79, a founding partner of the law firm of Leahy, Nyberg, Curto and D'Apice, died on October 21 at Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, NY. He lived in Yonkers, NY. Dick Leahy was a Vermont native who moved to Yonkers in 1949 with his wife of 52 years, Mildred King Leahy. A graduate of Manhattan College in 1942, he then served as a PT Boat Squadron Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy during World War II and later received a law degree from Fordham University in 1949. Dick's legal career began in Westchester County in 1949. He started as a solo practitioner, serving clients in the Yonkers and Westchester County communities in a number of general practice areas. He then went on to help found the law firm of Leahy, Nyberg, Curto and D'Apice in Yonkers in 1973, where he continued to practice until his death. Dick was a member of the New York State Bar Association, the New York State Trail Lawyers Association, and the Westchester County Bar Association, which recently awarded him their ''50 Years in Practice'' distinction. Dick Leahy was a devoted member of Our Lady of Fatima Catholic Parish in Scarsdale, where he was a member of the Catholic Order of the Knights of Malta and a Eucharistic Minister. He was also a longtime member of Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, an active member of the international Kiwanis Club, where he served as New York District Governor from 1973-1974, and also a founding member of the PT Boat Veterans Association of the United States. His wife Mildred died in 1999. Survivors include a brother, Alfred Leahy of Largo, Florida; a brother-in-law, Bill King, and a niece, Patricia Munhall, both of Las Vegas, Nevada; and a nephew, Christopher Leahy of Falls Church, Virginia. A public wake will be held on Monday, October 23 between 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM at Flynn Memorial Home at 1652 Central Park Ave Yonkers, NY. A memorial Mass with interment following will be offered on Tuesday, October 24th at 10 AM, at Our Lady of Fatima Catholic Church, 5 Strathmore Rd., Scarsdale. Memorial contibutions may be made to Catholic Relief Services, P.O. Box 17090, Baltimore, MD 21298.

title: After 'a Traumatic Second'
description: Following are excerpts from ''Always On Call'':

title: Moms and Dads Flunk a Parenting Test
description: Many new parents wonder if they know what they're doing. A new study suggests there may be grounds for these worries.

title: Thus Far, It's Painful To Watch
description: Bad baseball is more painful than bad teeth. And after watching these last two games, we Mets fans are feeling as if we got a double root canal.

title: Please, Let Mets Win One
description: Here is a statement that may be used against me in divorce proceedings: I need the Mets to win.

title: The Tax Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Lieberman Appeals for Help From Florida Ethnic Groups
description: Hopping among ethnic groups, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman set out to whip up supporters today in the crucial state of Florida, urging them to get out the vote and, paraphrasing a Frank Sinatra song, telling them, ''If we win it here, we'll win it everywhere.''

title: Lotus Notes Developer to Introduce a New Internet Tool
description: Today, three years after leaving I.B.M., the designer of the Lotus Notes program will introduce his latest effort: a software tool intended to provide a wide range of new ways for workers to collaborate over the Internet. It is, in essence, a sort of Napster for the workplace.

title: Camden Mayor Goes on Trial As State Works On a Takeover
description: As New Jersey officials move to consolidate their takeover of Camden, federal prosecutors yesterday opened the trial of the city's beleaguered mayor. A conviction would force Mayor Milton Milan to leave office, simplifying the state's task of persuading the rest of city government to cooperate.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE PLUMMETS. Coffee plunged on prospects for an end to a dry spell in Brazil that threatened to reduce next year's production. In New York, coffee for December delivery fell 5.7 cents, or 6.8 percent, to 78.45 cents a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWLING, JOHN P.
description: DOWLING-John P., 67. Surrounded by family, died at home on October 22, 2000. He is survived by his much beloved wife of forty years, Eileen Frances (nee Toomey), and his cherished children, Timothy Dowling (wife Elizabeth) of Charlotte, NC, Eileen Dowling and Madeleine Dowling, both of Manhattan, Elizabeth Glazer (husband Neil) of Philadelphia, and his adored grandchildren, Emily and Grace Dowling, of Charlotte. He is also survived by his dear devoted sister, Joan McCormick, of Osterville, MA. John was an extraordinarily generous man who loved and valued his family and friends. His loving and warm presence will be missed sorely by all that knew him. A resident of Ridgewood, NJ, John was a graduate of Fordham Preparatory School, Fordham University, the Fordham University School of Law, and the Harvard Business School Advanced Management Program. Having served in the United States Army in Germany as a Lieutenant from 1954 through 1956, John retired as a Senior Vice President of Manufacturers Hanover. John was firmly committed to community service and served on the Board of Trustees of Calvary Hospital for nineteen years and was also a member of the Finance Committee of the Parish Council of Our Lady of Mount Carmel. John was a member of Ridgewood Country Club. Family and friends are invited to visit Feeney Funeral Home in Ridgewood, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM, on Tuesday, October 24. The celebratory mass will be held at Our Lady of Mount Carmel in Ridgewood on Wednesday, October 25, at 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: Calvary Hospital, attn: John Dowling Memorial Fund, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, CHARLES HENRY
description: JONES-Charles Henry. Died October 20, 2000 after an illness of several months. He was born July 25, 1935 in Atlanta, GA. the youngest of six. Survived by his sister Janet Jones of Atlanta and a nephew, Bradley Keith Jones of Washington, D.C. Predeceased by his parents and brothers Oliver, Clarence and Earl. Mr. Jones attended Morehouse College in Atlanta before joining the U.S. Air Force where he trained in telecommunications at the Overseas Division of the University of Maryland in England 1956-1959. He served at Mitchell Air Force Base and later worked for Olin as a telecommunications engineer. Gentle giant and outstanding community activist, Charles was a past President of the West Side Community Garden, where he will be sorely missed by many friends. A memorial tribute is in the planning.

title: BUS COMPANY TO SEEK NEW FINANCING
description: The bus company, Laidlaw, whose stock has dropped 95 percent this year, said it had won approval from debt holders to seek as much as $350 million in new financing as it tries to avoid filing for bankruptcy protection. The company, based in Burlington, Ontario, needed permission from the holders of its $3.4 billion in debt because it was in default after deferring $22.95 million in interest on May 16 and calling an interest-payment moratorium shortly after.

title: Intelligence Chief Returns, Sending Peru Into Disarray
description: A month after fleeing, the former intelligence chief returned here today, plunging the government of President Alberto K. Fujimori into disarray.

title: Scientists' Hopes Raised for a Front-Row Seat to Evolution
description: For more than a century, scientists have assumed that it was all but impossible to witness the evolution of a new species in nature, a process thought to be too long and drawn out to be captured in the lifetime of any human researcher.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR FORECAST
description: National Semiconductor, one of the top makers of chips for cellular phones, said fiscal second- and third-quarter revenue and earnings might fall as mobile-phone sales have slowed. The shares dropped as much as 35 percent on the news. Second-quarter sales will fall 6 percent to 8 percent from $641 million in the first quarter, said a company spokesman, Bill Callahan. National Semiconductor is the latest company in the wireless-phone industry to lower forecasts for revenue or profit.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: 1,000 Performers Happy With Life On the Margins; Festival Shows That Many Bands No Longer Need Mainstream's Pull
description: There has never been a better time for rumors. Deployed right, they can hop around the world in minutes on the Internet; they can shake up giant companies or summon international attention.

title: Technology-Rich Morris County Shrugging Off Mergers
description: In the last year or so, three companies based in Morris County have announced they were merging with bigger companies and closing at least part of their operations here. Now it is happening again.

title: Bush Says Gore Social Security Plan Creates Huge Debt
description: Gov. George W. Bush said today that Vice President Al Gore's proposal for Social Security would create about $40 trillion in debt by the middle of the century, saddling future generations with an onerous burden and leaving the system of financing the program unfixed.

title: All the World's a Stage? One Storefront Sure Is
description: ''As You Like It'' is taken by the Liars' Club as an invitation from Shakespeare rather than as a mere title, and the company interprets the invitation pretty broadly. That's not a bad idea: this is a hardy play, and turning it into a circus not only produces unexpected laughter but also reminds us of how infinitely subversive the playwright's imagination was.

title: Choice Hotels Beginning Review for Its Account
description: Choice Hotels International, a hotel franchiser for brands like Comfort, Quality and Econo Lodge, is beginning a review for its consumer advertising account. Billings were estimated at $35 million to $40 million. The account has been at Gray, Kirk/VanSant in Baltimore for about 20 years.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Nassau Democrats Back Off Plan To Cut Aid to Local Government
description: As budget negotiations continued today between Nassau County officials and members of a state board monitoring the county's fiscal crisis, Democratic lawmakers withdrew their support for a plan to eliminate millions of dollars in aid to the county's three towns and two cities.

title: F.D.A. CLEARS NEW DOSAGE FOR MERCK OSTEOPOROSIS DRUG
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that Merck & Company had been given approval to market a a once-a-week dose of its bone-building drug Fosamax. The drug has been on the market in a once-a-day dose for five years for women with osteoporosis, which causes brittle bones. Fosamax last month became the first drug approved by the agency to treat osteoporosis in men. Fosamax is one of the keys to Merck's growth as it loses patent protection on older drugs. Fosamax had third quarter sales of $360 million.

title: REALNETWORKS UPGRADE RELEASED
description: RealNetworks, an Internet music software publisher, yesterday released RealAudio 8, an upgrade to its underlying audio technology that the company says will reduce the amount of space users need to store sound files. The new technology was developed in conjunction with Sony, which provided a format called Atrac3 that is being included in RealAudio 8. RealAudio converts music into audio files that can be downloaded, sent by e-mail or played on the Web. RealNetworks contends the new technology will allow users to store a CD-quality song using 2.5 megabytes of space on a hard drive, about half what it takes using some other technologies. Matt Richtel

title: Clemens and the Bat: The Wrong Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: LINCOLN ELECTRIC SAYS OFFER FOR CHARTER HAS LAPSED
description: Lincoln Electric Holdings, a maker of welding machines and equipment, said yesterday that its $565 million offer for Charter P.L.C. of Britain had lapsed and would not be extended, a spokesman, Roy Morrow, said. Lincoln Electric will take an after-tax charge of about $17 million in the fourth quarter to account for costs related to the elapsed bid. Shares of Lincoln Electric, based in Cleveland, rose 19 cents, to $15.44.

title: China's Failing Memory
description: To the Editor:

title: SBC Reports Unchanged Quarterly Profit
description: SBC Communications said today that its third-quarter profit was nearly unchanged, as it added a record number of wireless customers and data sales soared while expenses rose more than $1 billion.

title: With General Trailing, Ivory Coast Vote Tally Suddenly Dries Up
description: The results in Sunday's presidential election were delayed without explanation today, and Ivoirians expressed fears that the military government was trying to manipulate the outcome.

title: Embracing the Music, Twisting in Its Charms
description: Jonathan Hollander's Battery Dance Company has found a place in New York with an unusual range of activities: performing (often outdoors), teaching in public schools and introducing choreographers from Asia and Europe by inviting their companies to share programs during Battery's regular seasons.

description: ATTIAS-Rafi. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of the brother of our esteemed member, Eli Nachmani and extends to the bereaved family its heartfelt condolences.

description: When a top deputy to Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile suspected by the authorities of masterminding the bombings of two United States embassies in East Africa in 1998, pleaded guilty on Friday to terrorism conspiracy charges, the news caught many people by surprise.

title: Minnesota Mining Quarterly Profit Up 8%
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that its third-quarter profit rose 8 percent on increased sales of telecommunications and computer equipment in Asia.

description: Twenty-one years after Latanisha Carmichael, a 3-year-old, was beaten to death, her tiny remains entombed in a bedroom closet, a State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn convicted the child's mother of second-degree murder and the little girl's brother of criminally negligent homicide yesterday.

description: Cricket Thermometers

title: In Spring's Tough Chic, It's Boy Meets Girl
description: To look at Steven Meisel's fall advertisements for Versace and Max Mara, in which the women are displayed as prettily as Canton porcelain, is to imagine a world in which the men have permanently adjourned to the library for brandy and cigars. In that way the ads are curiously old-fashioned. They may contrive to leave a hip impression of female superiority, but as with an old movie, when the couples divide after dinner, don't you share the heroine's gloom to be stuck out with the ladies?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENSCH, CONSTANCE (NEE GIOBBE)
description: MENSCH - Constance (nee Giobbe). On Oct. 22, 2000. Beloved wife of Homer. Loving sister of Susan Dull. Dear cousin of Gloria Ficalora. President of the Board of Trustees, The Dalcroze School of Music, President of The Bohemians, Chairman of the Young Artists' Committee of the Musicians' Club of New York. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9 PM with service Thursday, 1:30 PM. Interment to follow at Mount Saint Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Dalcroze School of Music, or the Musicians' Foundation of the Musicians' Club of New York.

title: French Conductor Named Music Director for Spoleto Festival U.S.A.
description: Emmanuel Villaume, a 36-year-old French conductor, has been named music director for opera and orchestra at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., in Charleston, S.C. Next year, in Spoleto's 25th season, he will conduct the Festival Orchestra in an opera and in a symphonic concert, neither of which has been chosen.

title: Shangri-La In a Bottle?; A Wall Street Lion's Campaign to Promote A 'Miracle Drug'
description: ''Are you a man who has trouble controlling your temper? Do your friends and family refer to you as quick-tempered or a hot-head?''

description: Mets fans can keep their chins up and Yankees fans can keep their brooms in the closet: there has never been a four-game sweep in a Subway Series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, MURRAY
description: ROTHSTEIN-Murray. Of Delray Beach, FL., formerly of Hillside, N.J. On October 21, 2000. Devoted father of Judi and Irving Kamsler, and Michael and Una Rothstein. Dear brother of Leonard and Sylvia Rothstein. Loving grandfather of Victor and Sophia. Graveside services will be held at the United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island, Tuesday, October 24th, at 1 PM. For information call ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Broadway dancer Gwen Verdon on Thursday misstated the title of a song in the 1966 musical ''Sweet Charity'' and misattributed the performance. The title was ''Big Spender,'' not ''Hey, Big Spender,'' and the performance was by a group of dancers, not by Ms. Verdon.

title: Yemeni Supply Firm Emerges as a Focus of Inquiry Into Ship Attack
description: As the destroyer Cole rounded the Cape of Aden 12 days ago and followed a pilot boat to its berth in Aden harbor, its arrival set off a flurry of activity at a ramshackle suite of offices near the port.

title: SHORTER WORKWEEK CRITICIZED
description: The Bank of France made its strongest criticism to date of legislation that would cut the workweek to 35 hours, saying it could accentuate a ''very dangerous'' inflationary spiral unless wage moderation prevailed. The Bank of France said in its monthly bulletin that it would have to be ''even more attentive'' to general inflationary risks if wages increased more than consumer prices did ''because of the impact on unit labor costs and corporate competitiveness of the reduction in work times.''

title: Hold the Arts & Crafts: After-School Programs Go Digital
description: As computers crowd out traditional arts and crafts in after-school programs, two national groups are taking starkly different approaches in linking extracurricular technology programs to students' daily school activities.

title: TWO SPECIALIZED I.S.P.'S MERGING
description: Two Internet service providers focused on the engineering and building industry, Bidcom and Cephren, said yesterday that their two privately held companies had agreed to merge. The new company, to be called Citadon, will combine Bidcom's strength in business process management with Cephren's emphasis on project management and electronic commerce. After the merger, Citadon's products will include software for managing electronic commerce, like bid requests and purchase orders, and a printing program for managing large-scale printing projects through a network of service centers. The new company's headquarters will be in San Francisco. Laurie J. Flynn

title: The Big City; Infringing On the Right To Be Scalped
description: YOU might think Subway Series tickets are hopelessly unaffordable, but let's put the price in perspective. Would you rather attend tonight's baseball game or spend a weekend in Atlantic City? Would you rather take your child to the Subway Series or to Disney World?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAINE, STUART
description: BLAINE-Stuart. Died in NYC of cancer on Friday, October 20. Mr. Blaine was born on July 6, 1923. He was was co-founder of the design firm of Blaine and Booth and enjoyed a distinguished career as a designer and actor. He will be sorely missed by his family and many friends fortunate to have known him. A private memorial service will be held in Millbrook.

title: Corzine Woos the Elderly; Rival Woos Donors
description: As Jon S. Corzine continues to court elderly voters in minimalls and laborers in union halls across New Jersey, his Republican rival for the United States Senate, Representative Bob Franks, has been receiving glowing testimonials from his own most ardent supporters: Republicans from out of state.

title: PRI Claims Mexico State Vote But Opposition Cries Fraud
description: The political party that has governed Mexico for seven decades claimed victory in an important governor's race in the state of Tabasco today after a hotly disputed weeklong recount that ended in the middle of the night.

title: A Choice for Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: Clemens's Act Marring Yanks' Quest for Greatness
description: The 2000 World Series will forever be remembered as the one in which Roger Clemens threw the barrel of a broken bat (choose one) at, near, in the vicinity of, in a space unexpectedly intruded upon by Mike Piazza. It will not be remembered as the World Series in which Clemens threw a baseball (his version) at the first-base line at least 45 feet off from first base.

title: The VH1 Love Affair With the Camera
description: Sweeping down the red carpet at the VH1/ Vogue fashion awards on Friday night, Andre Leon Talley, Vogue's editor at large, eclipsed even high-wattage stars like Uma Thurman, Christian Slater, Lenny Kravitz and fashion's premier bird of paradise, Donatella Versace, who was poured into a shockingly slashed gown.

title: DAIMLERCHRYSLER IS SAID TO CUT BACK MODELS
description: Faced with rising gasoline prices, a slowing market for large sport utilities and intense pressure from its corporate parent in Germany to cut costs, the American operations of DaimlerChrysler have changed plans for future models, said a person familiar with the plans. The former Chrysler operations have canceled plans to build a full-sized Dodge sport utility vehicle and will make fewer costly design changes than previously planned in the next Jeep Grand Cherokee, the person said. The big Dodge vehicle, which would have competed with the Chevrolet Suburban and Ford Excursion, has been repeatedly canceled and then revived over the last seven years. Ward's Automotive Reports reported the Dodge plans over the weekend, while Reuters reported yesterday that the next Grand Cherokee would not be heavily redesigned. Keith Bradsher

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Now a Majority: Families With 2 Parents Who Work
description: For the first time since the Census Bureau began tracking the numbers, families in which both parents are working have become the majority even among the most traditional families: married couples with children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREED, GEORGE
description: BREED-George. On October 20, 2000 of Annapolis, MD. Beloved husband of Martha Breed and the late Jane Walby Clark Breed. Loving father of Richard Edwards Breed III of Annapolis, Lynn Breed Snyder of Santa Fe, NM, Deena Moore Breed Larlee of Orlando, FL., and the late Dudley Clark. Cherished grandfather of Rachael and Ishmael Snyder and Madeleine Jane Breed. A Requiem Eucharist will be held Thursday, October 26 at 2:00 PM at St. Anne's Episcopal Church, Annapolis. Interment Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Tarrytown, NY. For information John M. Taylor Funeral Home, Annapolis, Maryland.

title: A Mild-Mannered Nerd Turned Cool Rock Star
description: In one of the mini-essays he regularly composes, Moby, dance music's philosopher king, wrote that ''context is determined by collective subjective assessment, and not so much by geography or history.'' He was discussing his ingenious reworkings of field recordings of African-American singers, collected by Alan Lomax in midcentury, into millennial disco affirmations on his hit album ''Play'' (V2). Moby might have lugged out the same academic jargon to define his whole project, which reached its latest apotheosis on Wednesday night at Hammerstein Ballroom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ETHEL
description: GOLDSTEIN-Ethel. Died October 20, 2000 at 93 years old. Beloved mother, grandmother, greatgrandmother, friend and colleague. She was a loving support to all who knew her, a pioneer who began her second career at age 60 at N.S. Bienstock where she remained until age 93. Her memory and spirit will always be with us.

title: Fat but Fit: A Myth About Obesity Is Slowly Being Debunked
description: A year ago, Sandy, age 56, could not do any of the floor exercises in her movement class because she was so overweight and out of shape that she had great difficulty getting down to the floor and up again. Even the class's 15-minute walk in the park tired her out before it was over, she recalls.

title: GAZPROM REPORTS PROFIT
description: In Russia, OAO Gazprom, the country's natural gas monopoly, reported a first-half profit, after a loss for the similar period last year, as rising world gas prices increased revenue. First-half net income totaled 20 billion rubles ($720 million), or 0.84 ruble a share, compared with a loss of 48.4 billion rubles, or 2.27 rubles a share, in the comparable period last year. Analysts said the earnings, reported under international accounting standards, were better than expected. Gazprom supplies 25.7 percent of the gas used in Europe.

title: The Coach in Chief
description: The campaign is ticking by and the alarm meter among the Democratic faithful is ticking up. What happened to the Vice President Al Gore who made the smashing convention speech in Los Angeles and seemed ready to snatch Florida away from Gov. George W. Bush? How did the Democrats' Great Debater manage to let Mr. Bush slip-slide away with generalities about leadership and Beltway bickering? Finally, is it time to send out an S O S to the most restless lame duck in modern presidential campaign history?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, PAUL
description: BROWN-Paul. Beloved husband of Ethel. Devoted father of Gail and Dennis Carr and Diane. Dear brother of Elaine Weisbrot and Ann Kader. Loving grandfather of Justin. Service Tuesday 11AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, corner of 91st St. & Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers contributions to Park Ave Synagogue will be appreciated.

title: Report Faults Laws for Slowing Growth of Unions
description: Marie Sylvain, a longtime nursing home worker, was so upset about her low wages and workload -- feeding, washing, dressing and changing linens for 14 patients each shift -- that she decided to lead a unionization drive.

title: DEMAND SLOWER IN TELEPHONE SHARE SALE
description: The Japanese government's sale of one million shares of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the former telephone monopoly, which coincided with the company's decision to sell 300,000 new shares on its own, attracted fewer investors than government officials and underwriters had anticipated. Investors signed up to buy 150 percent to 200 percent more shares than the 1.3 million made available, but a sale last year was five to six times oversubscribed. The company's shares have lost more than 40 percent of their value this year and continued to fall yesterday, losing 31,000 yen ($285) to close at 979,000 yen ($9,000). The weaker-than-anticipated demand for the offering means less money for the Japanese government, which is struggling to manage a deficit that is expected to reach 130 percent of gross domestic product next year. Stephanie Strom

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE GREEN PARTY

title: On to Shea, With an Issue
description: The World Series moves from the Bronx to Queens tonight, with the Mets playing host to Game 3 at Shea Stadium and looking for their first victory.

title: Azamgarh Journal; Back to Life in India, Without Reincarnation
description: Lal Bihari, founder of the Association of Dead People, first learned he was deceased when he applied for a bank loan in 1975.

title: GENCORP AGREES TO ACQUIRE DIVISION OF LAIRD GROUP
description: GenCorp Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Draftex International Car Body Seals division of Laird Group P.L.C., a British engineering company, to double the size of its vehicle sealant business. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. With the transaction, GenCorp will become the world's second-largest vehicle sealant supplier. GenCorp's sealant business has $460 million in annual sales. Draftex has $425 million in annual sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SVIRIDOFF, MITCHELL
description: SVIRIDOFF-Mitchell. It is with deepest sorrow that the Local Initiatives Support Corporation mourns the passing of its founder Mitchell Sviridoff. Like thousands of community development corporations from coast to coast, LISC owes much of its growth and success, and in our case our very existence, to Mike Sviridoff's vision, energy, and wisdom. Mike has been a source of inspiration and confidence to people and organizations across America who often had no other champions, no material wealth, and little political influence. With his encouragement and example, they have transformed poor neighborhoods and rural communities against overwhelming odds. Mike has been the visionary, conscience, mentor, and teacher to three generations of grassroots entrepreneurs. His leadership is irreplaceable, but his example will remain a national treasure. Michael Rubinger, Pres. & CEO Robert E. Rubin, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARKENTIN, HELENE ENRIGHT
description: WARKENTIN-Helene Enright. Of Haymarket, VA., passed away peacefully on Friday, October 20th, 2000 at the Halquist Memorial Hospice Center in Arlington, VA. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, New Milford, CT and Mt. Kisco, NY, she was 91. She was the beloved wife for 27 years of the late William Jennings Warkentin, a loving mother & a devoted grandmother. She is survived by her children, William Enright (wife, Jeanne), Donald Loreaux (wife, Mary Ellen), Bruce Nelson, Theodore Jennings (wife, Peggy), and Ann Elizabeth (husband, Mike) Warkentin; grandchildren, William E., Scott (wife, Sandy), Donald, Katherine (husband, Andrew), William J., Melissa, Laura and Emily; great-grandchildren, Ryan, Kelsey and Nicholas. She is also survived by her brother, George Enright. Preceding her in death was her sister, Mabel Castellucci. Funeral services were held on Monday, October 23rd, at the First Presbyterian Church in Mt. Kisco. A graveside service followed at the Oakwood Cemetery in Mt. Kisco. For further information the Oelker & Cox Funeral Home in Mt. Kisco. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Hospice of Northern Virginia, PO Box 1576, Merrifield, VA. 22116-1576.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Saturday for a dance review of ''The Legend of Tamar,'' performed at the City Center by the Georgian National Singing and Dancing Ensemble, misstated the troupe's nationality. As the review noted, it is Georgian, not Ukrainian.

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Ratings Improve
description: Fox Sports generated a 15.2 overnight Nielsen rating for Game 2 of the World Series on Sunday, down 4 percent from the comparable Yankees-Braves game a year ago, but 9 percent above Saturday's Game 1 rating.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; This is the story of Wall Street's most influential Internet analyst and how she got that way.
description: IN the land of the blind, the one-eyed analyst is queen.

title: Suspect in Racial Attack Tells of Life of Rage
description: To prosecutors, Ryan Wagner is a would-be murderer. To two Mexican day laborers, he is the knife-wielding white man who took a turn beating them last month in an abandoned factory on Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKOK, RICHARD S.
description: HICKOK-Richard S. The Board of Directors of Marsh & McLennan Companies mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague & friend Richard Hickok, who was a valued member of our Board for more than 15 years. We have benefited greatly from Dick's wisdom and counsel and are saddened by his loss. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Janet (''Boots'') and his family. J.W. Greenberg, Chairman

title: Extinction Turns Out to Be a Slow, Slow Process; Some Severely Depleted Species Adapt to Altered Habitats and Hang On for Years, Puzzling Biologists
description: Scientists studying the planet's stressed-out rain forests, rivers, reefs, deserts and islands are increasingly confronting a new kind of species -- the living dead. They are extant, but, in almost every way, are already extinct.

title: PaineWebber Merger Vote
description: The PaineWebber Group, one of the nation's biggest brokerage firms and investment banks, said yesterday that its shareholders had approved the company's pending merger with the Swiss financial services giant UBS. PaineWebber shareholders representing 123.1 million shares, or 99.3 percent of those ballots cast, voted in favor of its merger with UBS. In July, New York-based PaineWebber announced it was being acquired by UBS for $12 billion. Under the deal, PaineWebber shareholders will receive $73.50 a share in cash or 0.4954 of UBS share for each PaineWebber share. PaineWebber traded at $66.75 yesterday, down 56 cents, or 0.8 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEETIN, THOMAS
description: SWEETIN-Thomas. The Alumni Association of Townsend Harris High School is saddened by Tom's passing. He was a caring, committed, and brilliant teacher of English and foreign languages. He was the omnipresent moderator of the Crimson and Gold, and in his retirement, he served throughout his painful illness as a dedicated director of the Alumni Association. His spirit will live in the lives of those he touched.

title: U.S. Military Placed on Highest Alert in Several Hot Spots
description: American troops and diplomats in parts of Turkey, Saudi Arabia and the small Persian Gulf states of Bahrain and Qatar were placed on the highest state of alert today because of credible threats of a terrorist attack, a senior Clinton administration official said.

title: Candidates Play Leapfrog, in Very Small Hops, Surveys Show
description: Two daily tracking polls show that Vice President Al Gore has regained some of the ground he lost to Gov. George W. Bush in recent weeks. While Mr. Bush maintains a marginal lead, it has narrowed each day since the final debate last Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOX, JEANNE M.
description: KNOX-Jeanne M. (formerly Loeb). Of Longboat Key, FL, on October 22. She is survived by her daughters Bonnie Strauss of NYC, Nancy Rackoff of Pittsburgh, PA, and her son Thomas Loeb of Weston, CT. She is also survived by six grandchildren. Graveside services for family and friends will be held at Mt. Neboh Cemetery, Queens, NY, on October 26, at 11:00 AM. Family will be receiving at the home of Bonnie and Tom Strauss on Wednesday evening, October 25, between 7 and 9 PM. Expressions of sympathy may be sent to the Bachmann Strauss Dystonia and Parkinson Foundation, The Mount Sinai Medical Center, 1 Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1490, New York, New York 10029, or Mote Marine Laboratory, Inc., 1600 Thompson Parkway, Sarasota, Florida 34236.

title: Warding Off Parkinson's With Caffeine
description: Caffeine, and not some other unsuspected component of coffee, appears to be responsible for what some researchers have identified as coffee drinkers' decreased risk of developing Parkinson's disease, a new study reports.

title: Metro Business Briefing; COMMUNITY NEWS ON THE WEB
description: Two Manhattan community newspapers, Our Town and West Side Spirit, both owned by News Communications Inc., began providing neighborhood news and cultural listings yesterday to EdificeRex.com, a Web site that offers news and building services guides to the residents of about 250 luxury apartment buildings in Manhattan. The advertising staffs of the newspapers and EdificeRex plan to package print and online advertising jointly. The publisher and editor in chief of the newspapers, Tom Allon, said, ''This will give them a sampling of what we have.'' Peter Price, the chief executive of EdificeRex.com, said that RexOffice.com, a similar site owned by the EdificeRex for commercial buildings, planned to join with Crain's New York Business for business-oriented local news within a month.

title: CONSTELLATION ENERGY PLANS TO FORM 2 COMPANIES
description: The Constellation Energy Group said yesterday that it planned to split itself into a wholesale power-generating business and a retail-services company that would include its Baltimore Gas and Electric Company utility. The Goldman Sachs Group will invest $250 million in the generation business and receive a stake of as much as 17.5 percent, Constellation said. That business will keep the Constellation name while the retail business will be called the BGE Corporation. Constellation is following other energy companies in splitting its regulated utilities from faster-growing units, like power generation, that can fetch the higher prices investors are willing to pay for less-regulated generators. Shares of Constellation rose $5.19, to $44.81.

title: BKN Will Close Down Its Media Services Unit
description: BKN Media in Chicago, the media services division of BKN, is being closed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSON, SIDNEY L.
description: OLSON-Sidney L. We mourn the passing of our dear friend, Benefactor and esteemed member of our Board of Overseers, whose commitment to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University and compassion for others is both a legacy and an inspiration. With his beloved wife, the late Miriam K. Olson, he established a professorial chair in cardiology at our institution and was a Fellow of the University's Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law. In recognition of his outstanding service to his community, the University awarded him an honorary degree and the College presented him with its Distinguished Achievement Award. To his children, Norman Olson and Arlene Muravchick, to his grandchildren and to the entire family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Yeshiva University Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dr. Dominick P. Purpura The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: Lazio Focuses on Upstate
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the Lazio campaign plans to begin broadcasting.

title: To Our Readers
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, as well as information about errors that call for correction. Starting this week, an editor will respond to messages e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left at this toll-free number: 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKMAN, SARA
description: GLICKMAN-Sara. The Board of Directors and Staff of Family Focus Adoption Services mourn the loss of our Board member and friend, and one of the founding Board members of our agency, Sara Glickman, who died yesterday. Sara was a tireless adoption advocate and activist who worked as an Adoption Specialist and Adoption Supervisor at this agency for thirteen years before her recent retirement and return to our Board. She will be remembered as an outspoken and creative woman with more than fortytwo years of linkage to the local and national adoption communities. All of us will miss her unflagging commitment to ''waiting'' children and adoptive family life. Our deepest sympathies go to her husband Arthur, and children Alan and Mindy. Joel Fridovich, Board President Maris Blechner, Exec Director

title: Lazio and Clinton Find Foreign Policy Differences Only on the Prickly Margins
description: For all their sniping about misplaced kisses and handshakes abroad, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio largely share a foreign policy agenda based on expanding trade, paying America's bills at the United Nations and forgiving some of the debt of many developing nations.

title: Baseball Justice
description: Even the most ardent Yankee fans were unsettled by the behavior of Roger Clemens in the opening moments of Sunday's World Series game, when the pitcher threw a large, jagged piece of broken bat across the path of the Mets' Mike Piazza. It skittered by without hitting Piazza, but even so the umpires would have been justified in ejecting Clemens from the game. They made a judgment call not to do so, probably because they did not want to disrupt a championship game. That was an understandable decision, but Major League Baseball should make clear to Clemens that it will not tolerate any further misconduct during the Series.

title: AIRLINE TICKET SITE GOING LIVE
description: Hotwire.com, an online ticket-selling service backed by six major airlines, plans to open its Web site today. The San Francisco start-up secured initial financing of $75 million in January from the Texas Pacific Group, a private investment firm that has owned stakes in two of the airlines: Continental and America West. The other Hotwire-affliated airlines are American Airlines, Northwest Airlines, United Airlines and US Airways, to sell excess inventory -- seats that would otherwise be unfilled and that are not published on industrywide sites like Travelocity.com and Expedia.com. Hotwire's chief executive, Karl Peterson, says the company wants to make it easier to set travel plans with a home computer. Priceline, another online travel site, for example, requires users to bid for seats and accept the lowest fare offered. Hotwire, however, negotiates with airlines to determine the lowest possible fare for a desired route; the consumer then has the option to accept the offered rate. The process lasts minutes rather than hours, he said. Hotwire has been operating a beta site about six weeks.

title: Testaverde Perseveres And Jets Follow
description: The first time Vinny Testaverde dropped back to pass Monday night, he rolled to his right with ample time to survey the field. He continued floating toward the sideline in search of a receiver until he ran out of room and options, stepping out of bounds for a 2-yard loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWAN, LOUIS
description: SWAN-Louis. Of Freeland, WA, and formerly of Old Bethpage, Long Island on October 15, 2000 at the age of 46. Devoted and adored wife of Todd, cherished daughter of Mildred and the late Abraham Goldstein of New York City. Beloved sister of Fredricka Stillman, Karen Ferber and David Goldstein. Gifted Landscape Architect and lover of nature who brought passion to all of her interests and loves. A brave and courageous soul who had a strong sense of right, a loving compassion for those in need, and who left a positive mark on all she met.

description: RoseAnne Spradlin

title: FORKLIFT MAKERS IN ALLIANCE
description: The Nissan Motor Company and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries have agreed to an alliance aimed at improving the profitability and sales of their forklift businesses. In a move to bring down costs, the two Japanese companies will jointly develop forklifts and obtain parts for production and service needs. They will also manufacture forklifts for each other in hopes of expanding their customer base. Stephanie Strom

title: ALBRIGHT GREETED WITH A FANFARE BY NORTH KOREA
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright plunged into Communist North Korea today, meeting with the nation's mysterious leader, Kim Jong Il, and attending a gargantuan spectacle of about 100,000 performers that celebrated the cult of her host.

title: Democrats Hammer at Bush's Texas Record
description: Intensifying their assault on Gov. George W. Bush's job performance, national and local Democratic officials fanned out to nearly 100 cities in 20 hotly contested states yesterday to introduce a new video that savages Mr. Bush's record in Texas on matters like air quality, schools, medical care and improving living conditions for the poor.

title: Hillary Clinton, For and Against
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Showdown in the Bowl Stakes
description: The Nebraska Cornhuskers (7-0) are No. 1 and the Oklahoma Sooners (6-0) are No. 2 in this season's first Bowl Championship Series ranking, which was released yesterday. But their rankings are certain to change after the two teams meet on Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENOWITZ, YETTA
description: BENOWITZ-Yetta. The Greenberg family mourns the passing of Aunt Billie. We will miss you. Harold and Barbara, Sharon, Jonathan and Michael Greenberg.

title: She's Happy. Hirschfeld's Happy. The Secret?
description: LADY art dealers are typecast as a brass-knuckled bunch, but what kind of woman would slug it out in court with the sole artist she has represented -- forsaking all others and getting rich along the way -- for nearly three decades? Who would take a swing at Al Hirschfeld, the 97-year-old caricaturist designated as a living landmark by the New York Landmarks Conservancy?

title: Coke Calls On Former Officer To Guide It in a New Culture
description: When Douglas Daft, chairman and chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company, first introduced his ''think local, act local'' strategy earlier this year, it sounded to many like a radical departure from the centralized, monolithic culture that had prevailed at Coke in recent years.

title: J. Walter Thompson will acquire Tonic 360 of San Francisco to help with interactive marketing.
description: IN another shift in the fast-changing realm of interactive advertising, the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York is poised to acquire Tonic 360 of San Francisco, which specializes in digital branding campaigns.

title: A Parallel Mideast Battle: Is It News or Incitement?
description: When Israel unleashed a retaliatory rocket barrage nearly two weeks ago against the police station here, where two of its soldiers were killed by an angry mob, the helicopters took out a second target as well: the transmitters of the Voice of Palestine, the Palestinian Authority's official radio network, which Israel contends has deliberately incited mass violence and ethnic hatred.

title: Officials in 3 States Are Pushing To Strengthen Laws on D.W.I.
description: Hours after President Clinton signed a bill requiring states to adopt a lower blood alcohol level as the legal threshold for drunken driving, law enforcement and elected officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut said today that they planned to urge lawmakers to pass such laws in the months ahead.

description: To the Editor:

description: ''At appropriations time, lobbyists work like ninjas, doing their work under cover of darkness.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, BERNARD A.
description: WEBER-Bernard A. Suddenly on October 23, 2000. Beloved husband of Ronnye Shamam. Devoted father of David and Valerie, Madeline Weber and Bill Shamam. Loving grandfather of Samantha and Jonathan. Dear brother of Carol Kirshenbaum and the late Rose Kleinman. Services Wednesday, October 25, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Tentative Pact Is Reached In Actor Strike
description: A nearly six-month strike by thousands of actors who appear in television commercials was tentatively resolved today, ending a bitter labor dispute that involved issues ranging from pay in commercials on cable programs to advertisements on the Internet.
