title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, LESTER J.
description: MORRIS-Lester J. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Lester J. Morris, and extends sincere sympathy to his family and friends. David Mack, President Marshall Hess, Secretary

title: The Race Begins to Build a Small Car for China
description: General Motors said today that it would begin producing a small car in China in December, the first of several such offerings planned by some of the world's largest automakers, each hoping to dominate this country's potentially huge market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDRICKSON, RITA G.
description: HENDRICKSON-Rita G. Goodbye, Rita. A good family friend for over ninety years. We will always remember your stories about your early years on East 88th Street ....your big sister, enjoying a little beer and some Limburger cheese with black radish on black pumpernickel with your father. Sorry you couldn't wait for the end of the World Series. Pour yourself a Dewar's tonight, there's plenty of ice. Eisenkramer & Brown Families

description: To the Editor:

title: C.I.A. Chief Agrees to Release Documents on Chile
description: George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, has agreed to release several hundred documents related to United States covert operations in Chile in the years around the 1973 military coup that ousted President Salvador Allende, officials said today.

title: Torre Discusses Clemens; The Volcano Calms Down
description: His eyes were sleepy, his words were deliberate and his mannerisms were listless. Joe Torre did not really look like a manager whose team had grabbed the first two games of the World Series as he shifted behind a lectern at Shea Stadium. Torre looked like someone who was delivering the dreary news about how a business that supports most of the residents in a town was closing.

title: Bush's Barnstormers Get Tours Under Way
description: Hundreds of Americans were tending to their business today at senior centers, in restaurants and on factory floors around the country when teams of Republican governors suddenly swept into their midst, stumping for a colleague, George W. Bush.

title: Lazio and Clinton Take Each Other to Task on Health Care
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio today intensified his criticism of Hillary Rodham Clinton's failed health care reform effort six years ago, unleashing a new series of advertisements and deriding her effort as ''bad medicine for New York.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILEY, JUDITH S.
description: BAILEY-Judith S., 67, of Washington Township., Morris County, N.J. on October 17, 2000. Beloved wife of Holmes Bailey of Washington Township NJ. Surviving are: daughters Dr. Alison Bailey of Bloomington, IL, and Katherine Bailey, of Oregon City, OR. For information Cochran Funeral Home, 905 High Street, Hackettstown, NJ. 07840. Service on Sunday, November 19, at 4 PM at Christ Church in Short Hills, NJ.

title: After the Bat, A City Looks At the Belfry
description: In the combustible aftermath of the second game of the World Series, the insistent matter on the minds of opinionated New Yorkers yesterday was the deeper meaning -- or, in fact, any meaning -- of a thrown piece of splintered wood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, RICHARD C.
description: HAYES-Richard C. On October 22, 2000 at age 62. Beloved husband of Barbara. Loving father of Neil, Christopher, Todd and his wife Kerry, Anna, Cathy, and Sarah. Grandfather of Matthew, Sarah, and Evie. Dear brother of Christine Walsh. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. on Tuesday, 7-9:00 PM and Wednesday, 2-5:00 and 79:00 PM. A celebration of his life will be held on Thursday at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Ave. at 54 St. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Richard C. Hayes Memorial Fund in support of the study of pancreatic cancer, and sent to The Mount Sinai School of Medicine, 1 Gustave Levy Place, Box 1049, NY, NY 10029.

title: Jury Seen as Divided in Doctor's Murder Trial
description: An alternate juror in the trial of a plastic surgeon charged with killing his wife 15 years ago said yesterday that he and other jurors thought the prosecutors' case was weak, since there was no body or direct evidence.

title: Hammer Lands With Dull Thud In European Phone Auctions
description: LONDON  The last major European sale of licenses to provide high-speed Internet access from mobile phones ended with a whimper Monday when Italy's auction of five licenses raised only 12.2 billion, half of what the government and most analysts had expected.

title: AT&T Is Planning To Split Up Again
description: The board of AT&T, the nation's largest communications company, approved a plan late yesterday to split up the company in what would be AT&T's most significant overhaul since the court-supervised breakup of the company's Bell System in 1984.

title: Churches and the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Did G.E. Just Purchase Boeing Without Boeing Knowing It?
description: The General Electric Company's proposed $45 billion purchase of Honeywell International has been widely promoted as the last hurrah of G.E.'s chairman, John F. Welch Jr. But it may ultimately be remembered for cementing a dominant position for G.E. in the global aviation business.

title: Now That the G.O.P. Wants Education Spending, the Fight Changes
description: Like a hardy perennial that makes its annual appearance during the intense end-of-session negotiations between Congress and the White House over spending bills, education has once again emerged as a key and highly contentious issue.

title: Undecided and Fickle. Why Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: STAMPS.COM LAYS OFF 240
description: An Internet postage company, Stamps.com, of Santa Monica, Calif., said yesterday that it would cut 40 percent of its work force, or 240 full and part-time employees, to reduce its costs to try to become profitable. The company, which first sold shares to the public at $11 each in June 1999, closed at $2.78 a share yesterday. Stamps.com, which is issuing third quarter earnings on Wednesday, saw its second-quarter loss widen to $52.3 million, from $5.71 million a year earlier. The announcement of layoffs comes just two weeks after the resignations of the company's chief executive. A former United States postmaster general, Marvin Runyon, is serving as interim chairman. Laurie J. Flynn

title: St. Paul Gets A Conductor
description: Andreas Delfs has been appointed music director of the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, where he is to succeed Hugh Wolff in September. Mr. Delfs, 41, is also the music director of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra and will retain that post.

title: Bush Economics
description: To the Editor:

title: The Two-Wheeled Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Moody Tracks for a Post-Punk Antihero
description: Although he joked about it during his Twilight Singers' show last Tuesday at the Bowery Ballroom, there will never be a VH-1 ''Behind the Music'' episode about Greg Dulli.

title: Bush Criticizes Gore Plan
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas said Vice President Al Gore's proposal for Social Security would create about $40 trillion in debt by the middle of the century. Page A25.

title: Subway Doesn't Go to Nat Rizzuto's World Anymore
description: The Yankees had the Mets on the ropes. They were fighting for a Subway Series sweep. It was easy to imagine that every baseball fan within 100 miles of New York City was looking forward to this evening's game, but there were some who were looking instead into the shadows of the past.

title: Serbia Is Not Freed Of Its Ugly Illusions
description: Several days ago a Serbian law student told me, in excellent English, that he wanted to become a judge so that he could help clean up the corrupt legal system that is one of the poisonous legacies of Slobodan Milosevic. When our conversation turned to international politics, the student recounted a popular conspiracy theory: that Mr. Milosevic, who worked in New York as a banker before rising to power in his homeland, was a C.I.A. agent of some sort, carrying out a plan hatched in Washington to bring Serbia to its knees.

title: Martinez Is Hot, Williams Is Not
description: It was late September when a more patient Tino Martinez finally tossed an unsettling hitting slump aside. It appears to have it traveled like a virus to the bat of Bernie Williams.

title: REGIONAL AIRPORTS IN GROWTH PHASE
description: At Stewart International Airport near Newburgh, N.Y., they are promoting a new corporate hangar, dreaming about helicopter shuttles to Manhattan and dubbing themselves the ''Gateway to the Hudson.'' At MacArthur Airport in Islip, N.Y., they are hoping to add four gates to a refurbished terminal, buoyed by the recent arrival of Southwest Airlines. At Lehigh Valley International Airport near Allentown, Pa., 10 miles from the New Jersey state line, they are buying 1,500 acres of adjacent land and hoping to extend a runway to the lengths found at Kennedy or Newark International Airports.

title: The Personal Is Political
Watching Volunteers, Experts Seek Clues to Eating Disorders
description: In a small room on the ninth floor of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan, volunteers come to eat in the name of science.

title: INVESTMENT IN INDONESIAN BANK
description: The International Finance Corporation, the World Bank's private investment arm, said it would invest $10 million for much as 15 percent of PT Bank, one of Indonesia's strongest banks. International Finance, which plans to acquire the stake next year through the bank's sale of new shares and by converting an earlier loan into equity, said the purchase was consistent with its goal of investing more in Indonesia.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: The Two-Wheeled Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Camby Misses Practice, But Says Don't Worry
description: Just when Marcus Camby's play around the basket was beginning to outshine the condition of his ailing right knee, the Knicks were hit with a reminder of how frighteningly fragile the health of their gangly center is. Camby sat out of practice today with pain in his lower back.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about ''Tantalus,'' a 10-play cycle about the Trojan War, being given its world premiere by the Denver Center Theater Company, misidentified the actress playing Cassandra. As noted in the credit listing, she is Alyssa Bresnahan; Annalee Jefferies played four other parts.

title: Clemens Threw a Bat, Fox Dropped the Ball
description: Roger Clemens pitched brilliantly in Game 2 of the World Series, putting the Yankees up, two games to none, against the Mets. But was that the story? Hardly. What people will remember in a week, and in 10 years, is that Clemens hurled the sawed-off barrel of Mike Piazza's bat toward the Mets' catcher in the first inning.

title: From Bumblers to Stars in One Game
description: Center Kevin Mawae had seen enough. All around him during the Jets' game against Miami last night was ugliness. The offense had gained 9 total yards after the opening quarter. The defense missed a good half-dozen tackles in the first half. There were false starts, two illegal-formation penalties and personal-foul miscues. The Jets were being outhit, outplayed and outcoached.

title: Communications Lobby Puts Full-Court Press on Congress
description: As Congress nears adjournment, some of the nation's most powerful corporations have enlisted important lawmakers to tuck provisions into spending bills that could reshape the balance of power among telephone companies, Internet companies, broadcasters and cable operators.

title: Stern Can Void Smith's Pact
description: Commissioner David Stern can void the one-year contract between Joe Smith and the Minnesota Timberwolves after an arbitrator found that the player, the team and a former agent, Eric Fleisher, violated the league's salary cap with a secret agreement, the N.B.A. announced yesterday.

title: The Caviar Begrudged, And Other Mortal Slights
description: SHADOWS OF A PRINCESS

title: Chairman of Lucent Is Ousted by Board After Profit Erosion
description: The board of Lucent Technologies has ousted its chairman and chief executive, Richard A. McGinn, in a move to curb the earnings erosion that threatens to undermine Lucent, the world's largest manufacturer of telecommunications equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, MARY, ELLEN (NEE FERTEL)
description: FEINBERG-Mary-Ellen (nee Fertel), beloved wife, sister, mother & grandmother, died the morning of October 23. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Harvey Feinberg, her sisters, Myra Kaplan and Judith Davilman, her children, Monica and Jeffrey Cohen and Jessica and Kenneth Lesnik, and grandchildren, Danielle and Frances Cohen and Sam and Amanda Lesnik. She touched the lives of all who knew her. A great woman. She will be sorely missed. Services on Wednesday, at 11:15 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours Tuesday, 4-6 PM.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: When Friends and Family Fill Most of a Patient's Medical Needs
description: ''Always On Call: When Illness Turns Families into Caregivers,'' edited by Carol Levine (United Hospital Fund of New York, $20).

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WESCO INTERNATIONAL INC., -- Pittsburgh, a distributor of electrical supplies to businesses, said it had bought the closely held KVA Supply Co., a supplier of parts for underground high-voltage power transmission, for an undisclosed price to expand its division that sells to utility companies.

title: Chase Manhattan Gets Lift From G.E.-Honeywell Deal
description: For a passing moment during his presentation of General Electric's $45 billion acquisition of Honeywell International yesterday, John F. Welch Jr. interrupted himself to tip his hat to one of the men behind his biggest deal ever: his banker, Geoff Boisi, the head of investment banking at Chase Manhattan and the soon-to-be co-chief executive of J. P. Morgan investment banking.

title: Russia Shifts Its Focus Away From Mir
description: The once-mighty Russian space program, out of money and buried in debt, is fighting to survive through imagination, guile and the forging of worldwide partnerships.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAY, JOSEPH
description: JAY-Joseph. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member Leon Jay, upon the loss of his beloved brother. May he and the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: What's in a Name? A Series Ticket

title: Kramer Re-emerges, Disguised as an Inept Detective
description: Vic Nardozza seems like a character out of a confusing dream: he's Kramer but at the same time he's not Kramer; he is a detective at an agency where the photographer is a recovering voyeur; he is controlled by people who have trouble figuring out what week it is. This is not some surreal trick but the misbegotten premiere of ''The Michael Richards Show.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBSTEL, JOHN
description: EBSTEL-John. Dedicated husband of his late wife Jean. As a member of the Photo League, John's clarity of vision and technical expertise shaped the work of many young photographers. The highlight of his career was his role as the exclusive photographer for Louis Kahn's architectural works. Born on Bastille Day, John strove to integrate his esthetic vision with his commitment to social equality. John and Jean were founding member of the Hillman Cooperatives on the Lower East Side. John's vitality and tenacious spirit will be missed by all who knew him.

title: A Sacred Ceremony Travels Across Space and Time
description: 'Sound of Ecstasy and Nectar of Enlightenment'

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about financial problems of farmers in North Dakota referred incorrectly in some copies to the age of Kipp Knudson, who wants to run his family's farm there. He is 25, not 23. In some copies the article misstated the year his great-grandfather Knut S. Knudson homesteaded an earlier family farm. It was 1879, not 1829.

title: Unlocking Secrets of Magnetic Fields' Power
description: On Earth, magnetic fields generally make for a dull show. Yes, compass needles point along the magnetic field lines sprouting from Earth's poles, and iron filings on a piece of paper trace the same kind of field lines when they are produced by a bar magnet. Those magnetic fields, however, just exist without doing much, and they have little influence on the surrounding atmosphere.

title: Frankie Crocker, a Champion Of Black-Format Radio, Dies
description: Frankie Crocker, a veteran radio broadcaster and program director who helped catapult WBLS-FM, the black-music format radio station, to the No. 1 spot among listeners ages 18 to 34 in New York City twice in the last three decades, died Saturday of pancreatic cancer. His age was uncertain.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JULIA, RAUL
description: JULIA-Raul. A Mass will be held in honor of the late Raul Julia at Holy Trinity Church, 213 West 82 St, on Friday, October 27 at 6:30PM. October 24 marks the sixth anniversary of Mr. Julia's death

title: INTEL TO BUILD PLANT IN CHINA
description: The Intel Corporation said it would spend about $400 million to build a new semiconductor assembly plant in Shanghai, tripling its investment there. The new plant, which will produce computer chips for personal computers and servers, is expected to be finished by the end of next year. Craig Smith

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARSONS, JOEL
description: PARSONS-Joel. On October 15, 2000. A loving part of so many people's lives. He is survived by his sister Carolyn and brother Frank. Actor, friend, godfather, great-godfather; filled with grace, humor, dignity and love. From Jackson: ''Death is the awakening of a dream. Life is the dream''.

title: 7th District Congressional Race Is a Tossup
description: Michael A. Ferguson was in Vicki's Diner on South Broad Street the other day, shaking hands and handing out campaign literature for his Republican Congressional race.

title: Plentiful Sandbill Cranes Blaze Trail for Rare Relatives
description: Twelve young sandhill cranes and an equal number of biologists and wildlife specialists are on their way to completing the longest human-led bird migration yet, over 1,250 miles from Wisconsin to Florida.

title: UTILITY STAKE SALE
description: Portuguese Finance Minister Joaquim Pina Moura announced that the government had earned $1.35 billion in the sale last week of an 18.2 percent stake in the national utility company Electricidade de Portugal. The power company said that investors had bid for 5 billion shares, or 23 times the 240 million shares on sale. The government still controls 32 percent of Electricidade de Portugal. Over the coming months, the state plans to shed its remaining 15 percent stake in Portugal Telecom and sell 10 percent of the cement producer Cimpor. Benjamin Jones

title: Hillary Clinton, For and Against
description: To the Editor:

title: A Police Dept.'s Growing Allure; Crime Fighters From Around World Visit for Tips
description: Compact video cameras emerged from tote bags, and silver cameras were whisked from the folds of dark suits as the visitors from Hubei Province in China took turns sidling up to an oversized statue and posing with shy half-smiles.

title: Ikea Announces Search To Find New Agency
description: Ikea, the home furnishings retailer, said yesterday that it was beginning a review for its account, with billings estimated at $40 million. Deutsch in New York, which has handled creative, media, direct marketing, interactive and other tasks for Ikea for 11 years, has decided not to take part.

title: Florida State Women Upsetting the Top 20
description: The investment in women's soccer is starting to pay off handsomely at universities like Notre Dame, Nebraska, Penn State and Clemson. The latest program in the news is Florida State, a school without a men's program.

title: Malaysia Says U.S. Failed To Obey Ruling on Shrimp
description: A dispute that has brought environmentalists into conflict with the World Trade Organization was revived today when Malaysia accused the United States of failing to revamp its laws to allow unrestricted shrimp imports.

title: President Crisscrosses New York for His Wife's Race and for Gore's
description: In a second day of sprinting around his newly adopted home state, President Clinton stumped for his wife's United States Senate bid yesterday, while also broadening his efforts to bolster Vice President Al Gore's standing in an election that the president suggested would in part determine how lasting his legacy would be.

title: A Snappy Love Story on the Open Frontier
description: For even more proof of the renaissance of the Joffrey Ballet of Chicago, one had only to drop in on its new landmark stagings of Martha Graham's ''Appalachian Spring'' and Eugene Loring's ''Billy the Kid.'' Both 20th-century classics, odes to the American frontier, were part of a company tribute to Aaron Copland this weekend.

title: No Chance to Boo
description: Roger Clemens will not pitch in the games at Shea Stadium, and his name will not be announced before Game 3 tonight.

title: HENRY SCHEIN TO SELL STAKE IN NOVOCOL PHARMACEUTICAL
description: Henry Schein, a dental equipment supplier, said yesterday that it would sell its 50 percent stake in dental aesthetic maker Novocol Pharmaceutical of Canada Inc. to Deproco Inc., a unit of France's Specialties Septodont S. A. Terms were not disclosed. The move will enable Henry Schein, based in Melville, N.Y., to concentrate on its supply business. Henry Schein said it would still purchase anesthetic products from Novocol. Costs associated with the sale will lower fourth-quarter earnings by 5 cents a share, Henry Schein said. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had expected a profit of 48 cents a share. Shares of the company fell 6 cents, to $20.63.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, DAVID
description: SINGER-David. Died peacefully in his home due to complications from Parkinson's Disease on Oct. 23, 2000 at age 85. Beloved husband of Constance. Loving father of Raymond Benn & Susan Siegel. Adoring grandfather of Aaron, Daniel, Jessica & Ana. Dear brother of the late Lou and Al Singer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9PM with service Wednesday 11:30AM. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Parkinson Disease Foundation.

title: GORE PUTS FOCUS ON SMALLER STATES ONCE SEEN AS SAFE
description: At a time when Vice President Al Gore should be scrapping for votes in large swing states like Ohio and Michigan, he is devoting virtually his entire week to campaigning in smaller states that he should be able to ignore -- even his home state, Tennessee.

title: Easy Answer May Not Be the Right One
description: Steve is a 17-year-old with a scraggly goatee, a propensity to wear Grateful Dead T-shirts and a strange medical complaint. A few months earlier, in response to symptoms of clinical depression, I had placed him on Prozac, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, known as S.S.R.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, PHYLLIS B.
description: LANE-Phyllis B. Of Fort Lee, New Jersey (formerly of Fairlawn). Beloved wife of the late Jerome M. Devoted mother of Jeffrey, Tracey and David. Dear sister of Harriet Copeland, loving grandmother of Jeremy. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday 2 PM (1-800-522-0588).

title: Hartford Hires a New Chief for Its Troubled Police Department
description: City officials announced today that they had chosen a former F.B.I. special agent who is now a police chief in Texas to lead Hartford's demoralized, understaffed police department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVISON, MAE F.
description: DAVISON-Mae F. On October 23, 2000. Formerly of St. George, Staten Island. Beloved wife of the late Thomas H. Davison. Sister of the late Joseph A. Ferrante. Dear aunt of Arthur Ferrante of Sea Girt, NJ. Mrs. Davison was active in historic and cultural organizations on Staten Island. For further information Meehan Funeral Home, Spring Lake Heights, New Jersey.

title: Beating Yankees Would Be Payback for Reed
description: Rick Reed suggested one way that the Mets could retaliate appropriately for Roger Clemens having thrown a broken bat at Mike Piazza.

title: BANK STAKE TALKS END
description: The Spanish banking company Banco Santander Central Hispano announced that it had abandoned talks with Commerzbank of Germany on raising its stake in Commerzbank from 5.1 percent, to 10 percent. A spokesman for Commerzbank told Spanish reporters that the negotiations had foundered over differences on fixing the value of CC-Bank, which is owned by Banco Santander and specializes in automobile financing in Germany. Banco Santander would have traded CC-Bank and cash for the additional 4.9 percent stake in Commerzbank. Analysts said Commerzbank had hoped a larger stake for Banco Santander would help fend off a hostile bid from Cobra, a German investment group, which is the bank's major shareholder with 17 percent. Benjamin Jones

title: Public Interests; This Just In From Elmira . . .
description: The presidential race has gotten so interesting that people are losing track of that Other Election here in New York. Fear not, I'm prepared to take questions.

title: Plan to Divide AT&T Is Approved by Board
description: The board of AT&T approved a plan to split up the company in what would be AT&T's most significant overhaul since the court-supervised breakup of the company's Bell System in 1984.

title: USA NETWORKS WEIGHS REUNITING TICKETMASTER
description: USA Networks said yesterday that it might seek to merge its Ticketmaster unit, the No. 1 ticket seller, and Ticketmaster Online-CitySearch, the affiliated Internet business USA Networks brought public in 1998. USA Networks wholly owns Ticketmaster and still holds a majority stake in Ticketmaster Online, based in Pasadena, Calif. Shares of the latter have fallen 67 percent this year. The parent company, based in New York, now may seek to bring the online and traditional businesses back together, it said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Ticketmaster Online shares rose $2, to $14.63. USA Networks shares rose 63 cents, to $18.63.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, PHILIP
description: TUCKER-Philip. The Board of Directors and Staff of WSFSSH mourn the loss of Phil Tucker, our dear friend, volunteer fiscal consultant for more than 20 years and husband of Leonor, our Personnel Director. We are so grateful for his guidance, support and mentoring of our accounting staff and for his enthusiastic embrace of our mission. He was a source of strength and encouragement for us all. Our heartfelt condolences to Leonor and to Jeffrey, Lacey, Juan Carlos, Halbert and their families.

title: Hidden Hazards of Tutus and Toe Shoes
description: Ballet is not usually considered a contact sport -- at least not when all goes well on stage -- but that doesn't necessarily make it safer than football.

title: Sports of The Times; Clemens's Fire Doesn't Burn Piazza
description: IF Roger Clemens were a 38-year-old Olympian, with a competitive fever running so much higher than the breathtaking double digits his fastball still registers on the radar gun, there might be a different standard of suspicion regarding the cause of his shocking behavior on the pitcher's mound Sunday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, ALFRED
description: SCHREIBER-Alfred. Of NYC, on October 16, 2000. Beloved husband of Evelyn, devoted father to Charles and daughter-in-law Margaret, and Evelyn's children, Linda and Chris, Pamela and David, adored ''Pappa'' to Tyler, Kasper and Lucinda Rose, loving brother to Rosie Pearlstein and Friedl Borisewitz. His love of life was second only to the love for his family.

title: ROBINSON HONORED
description: Three assistant coaches put the Devils through practice yesterday in West Orange, N.J., because Coach Larry Robinson was in Canada, where he was inducted into Ottawa's Hall of Fame.

title: A Dry Cocktail Of Wit and Sadness
description: Wesla Whitfield

title: This Land is Your Land, This Land is My Land
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Totalitarian Chic Reigns in Spotless Pyongyang
description: A young man with disheveled hair squatted on the ground, paintbrush in hand, adding golden touches of fall to his watercolor. His paint box rested on the ground too, and beside him a black umbrella was propped open to protect his work in case of rain.

title: QWEST PROFIT UP 5%
description: Qwest Communications International said third-quarter earnings rose 18.5 percent, easily surpassing Wall Street's estimates, on strong demand for its Internet and data services. The results, as expected, pleased Wall Street. Shares of Qwest rose $2.31, or 5 percent, to $47.69, after the earnings announcement. Qwest said that excluding merger-related costs and other nonrecurring items, it earned $231 million, or 14 cents a diluted share, in the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with $195 million, or 12 cents a share, a year earlier. The Denver-based Qwest said sales rose 12.4 percent, to $4.8 billion, as the company opened five new Web host centers across the country and recorded more than $450 million in revenue from new contracts.

title: Loneliness of a Long-Distance Campaigner
description: WHEN Gov. George W. Bush of Texas made a rare visit to Manhattan last week, he did not make time for Leticia Remauro.

title: The Net Is Turning Into a Total Zoo
description: ON March 6, the first artificially inseminated African elephant was born in the Indianapolis Zoo. The birth was broadcast live on the Web, as has been its babyhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYLE, MARGARET MARY
description: BOYLE-Margaret Mary. October 21, 2000. Beloved daughter of the late Austin and Margaret Boyle. Loving sister of the late James A. Boyle. Devoted aunt of Margaret Birckhead of Richmond, VA. and Sean Morkan of Jupiter, FL., Adam Morkan of Indialantic, FL. Friends may call at the Abbey Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 & 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, October 26, 10:30AM, Epiphany Church, 239 East 21 Street, NYC. Contributions in her memory may be made to Catholic Relief Services, 209 West Fayette Street, Baltimore, MD. 21201.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONSNORTEL SAYS ACQUISITIONS LED TO LOSS Nortel Networks , the Canadian maker of telecommunications equipment, reported a third-quarter loss of $586 million, or 20 cents a diluted share, far wider than a loss of $79 million, or 3 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Excluding the costs of acquisitions in the quarter, Nortel said it would have had earnings of $574 million, or 18 cents a share. Fueled by sales of fiber optic and wireless equipment, Nortel's revenue climbed 42 percent in the quarter to $7.31 billion. Among large telecommunications equipment companies, Nortel is considered to have been the most prescient in deploying fiber optic technology, which allows huge amounts of data to be transmitted on wavelengths of light. But the market was disappointed in the sales figures. Nortel's shares dropped 20 percent in after-hours trading, to $50, after closing regular trading at $63.31, off $3.13, or 5.4 percent.

title: Political Memo; Clinton Fills His Stage, But the Seats Are Empty
description: President Clinton convened Democratic lawmakers on the South Lawn today for another in a series of events promoting his budget proposals. Today, the topic was school construction. Last week, he played up the minimum wage and hate-crimes legislation. Before that, he spoke of the need to hire more teachers for the public schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, DAVID
description: SINGER-David. Died peacefully in his home due to complications from Parkinson's Disease on Oct. 23, 2000 at age 85. Beloved husband of Constance. Loving father of Raymond Benn & Susan Siegel. Adoring grandfather of Aaron, Daniel, Jessica & Ana. Dear brother of the late Lou and Al Singer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9PM with service Wednesday 11:30AM. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Parkinson Disease Foundation.

title: Judge Rejects Guilty Plea In Bomb Plot
description: In a surprising twist in the embassy bombings case, a second defendant appeared yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan and said he wanted to plead guilty to the conspiracy charges against him. Just Friday, another defendant in the terrorism prosecution pleaded guilty after making a deal with the government.

title: This Time, Benitez Holds Up
description: The suggestion to stay aggressive wasn't as important as the quick therapy Edgardo Alfonzo provided. The Yankees' Chuck Knoblauch had just led off the ninth inning with a single up the middle and all of Shea Stadium seemed to groan. The flashbacks to Game 1 were unavoidable. Could the Mets' Armando Benitez possibly lose a two-run lead in Game 3 of the World Series?

title: Their Roots Give Former East Germans an Edge
description: LAST year, when Oliver Schwarz and his partner, Bertram Hesse, founded their Internet software start-up in Berlin, they needed a name for the company. Mr. Schwarz and Mr. Hesse, both from the East German town of Jena, brainstormed with their core team -- most of whom were also originally from the former East Germany -- and found themselves rejecting cyber-sounding names like ''SiteSprint,'' one of their earlier choices, in favor of terms from the Communist era.

title: New York Swaggers, But America Shrugs
description: Karen Warner, a die-hard Chicago baseball fan, confesses that she has been touched by the mystique and glory of the vaunted Subway Series in New York.

title: Don't Cast About; Look Here
description: NOT nearly as common as Norwegian, Scottish or other varieties, Irish smoked salmon can be found in many New York restaurants and food shops.

title: Merchants Eagerly Vie to Add Services to Their Services
description: INSTEAD of coming home to find a note from the deliveryman, downtown workers in this bustling city can pick up their parcels at a ''depot'' near subways and commuter concourses, courtesy of Empori.com, a start-up that merges the role of concierge with the convenience of the Web.

title: When Using Concierges, Don't Give Too Much Away
description: HERE are some tips on using a Web concierge service:

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE POLLS

title: Spinners' Web Weapons: T-Chips and Dark Sites
description: WHEN Taco Bell introduced a new tortilla chip last March, the company's public relations firm, Edelman Public Relations Worldwide, knew it would not be easy to generate coverage.

title: A Fourth for Bridge or a Cozy Chat in an All-Night Bingo Hall
description: I HAVE some new friends. Well, not friends exactly. I wouldn't recognize them if we bumped into each other, and I don't even know their real names. But they are always there when I need them -- to play games.

title: Changes at PBS
description: When she took over as president and chief executive of PBS last year, Pat Mitchell, formerly an executive at CNN, promised big changes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNSTENAAR, ADRIANA SALINAS
description: KUNSTENAAR-Adriana Salinas. On October 23, 2000. Beloved wife of Maurice. Devoted mother of Jean-Pierre, Claude and Yvonne. Adoring grandmother of Marc, Adriana, Alexandra, Richard and Analisa. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday, 1 PM, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th St.

title: HEWLETT IN STOCK DEAL FOR BLUESTONE
description: In a move aimed at bolstering its electronic business capabilities, Hewlett-Packard said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Bluestone Software for about $467 million in stock. Bluestone, based in Philadelphia, makes Internet technologies for business-to-business, business-to-consumer and mobile transactions. Hewlett-Packard said it would pay 0.2433 share for each share of Bluestone. Shares of Hewlett-Packard dropped $6.38, to $92, while Bluestone jumped $1.25 to $23.19. Earlier, Bluestone reported a net loss of $7 million, or 33 cents a share, on sales of $11.6 million for the third quarter. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Perry W. Gilbert, 87, Dies; Shark Expert and Defender
description: Perry W. Gilbert, a noted biologist and a leading defender of one of nature's most reviled creatures, the shark, died on Oct. 15 at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 87.

title: SECURE MUSIC MAY NOT BE, YET
description: Researchers this week said they had hacked into several of the Secure Digital Music Initiative's proposed technologies, which are designed to encode music so it cannot be pirated over the Internet. Researchers at Princeton and Rice universities and Xerox Parc claimed to have defeated four of the six technologies. But initiative officials said they had yet to verify the researchers' claims. The hackers' efforts came as part of a contest sponsored by the Secure Digital Music Initiative, which is made up of 200 record, consumer electronics and technology companies, to test the security of the proposed technologies. The contest, which offers an award of $10,000, has drawn 447 entries. Matt Richtel

title: Many Voters Shrugging Off Senate Race In New Jersey
description: In New Jersey, the Senate candidates plead and the voters yawn.

title: Martin Gets Closer but Has Far to Go
description: Coach Byron Scott of the Nets wanted to see the real Kenyon Martin -- the top overall pick in the 2000 draft, the consensus college player of the year -- and not, as Scott warned his rookie on Monday, ''his twin brother who plays real bad.''

title: 3rd Party Lament: Anyone Listening?; It's Not Easy Being Green. Or Libertarian or Socialist.
description: It is a pretty safe bet that Mark J. Dunau is the only New York candidate in the Senate race who has an organic salad at a Manhattan restaurant named in his honor. He is without a doubt the only candidate who lives in a barn where the bathroom has curtains for walls and the guest quarters are known as the Love Shack. And he alone sees political capital in boasting that Click and Clack of public radio's ''Car Talk'' once broadcast a question about his old Suburban.

title: A Hip-Hop Innovator Adds The Internet Into His Mix
description: IN the beginning, that is, a few years ago, celebrity sites were usually little more than fans' altars to the famous. In recent years, more and more celebrities have set up their own sites, realizing the power of the Internet to make them even more famous.

title: TENNECO AUTOMOTIVE TO DISMISS 700, 16% OF WORK FORCE
description: Tenneco Automotive Inc., the largest maker of shock absorbers, said it would eliminate as many as 700 jobs, or 16 percent of its work force, as third-quarter earnings fell 67 percent. The company expects to take a charge of as much as $60 million in the fourth quarter for job cuts, which so far total 285 in North America. The moves are expected to save $45 million annually along with other cost cuts. Profit from operations slid to $9 million, or 23 cents a share, from $27 million, or 86 cents pro forma, a year ago.

title: Another Jets Comeback Is Just Like Another Day at the Office
description: Jets Coach Al Groh went ballistic at halftime, throwing things in the locker room. A furious center Kevin Mawae blistered his offense on the sideline during the second quarter.

title: Early-Web Era Law Is Pushing Providers Onto the Same Page
description: WHEN Congress last passed an important insurance law, back in 1996, e-commerce was barely taking its baby steps and had not yet toddled anywhere near a hospital, doctor's office, pharmacy or claims center.

title: Factory Workers Fight the Squeeze On Health Benefits
description: No one goes to work in a clothes-hanger factory to have fun or make a lot of money. The 275-odd employees of the plant that Tyco International acquired here in 1996 earn $5.75 to $9.55 an hour to churn out plastic hangers. In each 8-hour shift, just two 15-minute rest periods, plus a 5-minute ''water break'' are allowed. No lunch. Every other week, they are required to work an extra Saturday.

title: MICROSTRATEGY SETTLES LAWSUITS
description: MicroStrategy Inc. announced two settlements yesterday, totaling nearly $97 million, in lawsuits filed against the company after it came under investigation for misstating its earnings since 1997. In the first, which settles a class action suit filed in Federal District Court in Virginia, members of a class-action group will be awarded $80.5 million plus 550,000 MicroStrategy shares that the company says are worth $16.5 million. The second agreement settles a shareholder's lawsuit, and requires the company to name a new independent director to its board's audit committee. Also as part of the second agreement, three of the company's officers, including Michael J. Saylor, founder and chief executive, will be required to contribute a portion of the 550,000 shares with a total value of $10 million. MicroStrategy said it would receive $13 million from its insurance carriers to help pay the settlements.

title: HOME-EQUITY LENDER ADVANTA TO SELL MORTGAGE BUSINESS
description: Advanta, a mortgage and home-equity lender, said it would sell its mortgage business to an unidentified financial institution. Terms were not disclosed. A transaction would result in the sale of virtually all of Advanta's mortgage assets at a price above book value. Those assets represented 33 percent of Advanta's owned assets as of Sept. 30. Advanta, based in Spring House, Pennsylvania, said it would use some of the proceeds to pay off outstanding debt. The shares of Advanta rose $3.13, or 46 percent, to $10. The stock had fallen 62 percent this year.

title: The Furtive 3 P.M. Phone Ritual
description: IT three o'clock this afternoon, give or take an hour, countless employees will pick up the telephone and make a most unbusinesslike call. If their employers were to listen in (which, as we all know, they can do, but that's a subject for another column) they would hear some variation of the following: ''Did you do your homework?'' ''Are you sure you locked the door?'' ''Don't talk back to the baby sitter.'' ''Don't let anyone in, and don't answer the phone.''

title: In the Land of Kim Jong Il
description: Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's visit to North Korea this week illustrated the opportunities and risks of defrosting relations with the world's last Stalinist state. Dr. Albright was given a gracious reception and spent six hours in constructive talks with Kim Jong Il, the North Korean leader. But she and the reporters accompanying her saw a highly regimented society organized around a slavish personality cult even as it struggles with severe shortages of food, electricity and most of the basic conveniences of modern life.

title: CARLTON TO BUY HTV
description: Carlton Communications said it had agreed to buy HTV, which broadcasts channel ITV to Wales and western England, from Granada Media for $:181 million, or $263 million, cash and Carlton's 20 percent stake in Meridian, the ITV broadcaster for southeastern England, of which Granada already owns 80 percent. HTV has 4.5 million viewers and had operating profit of $:14 million last year, on $:110 million in advertising sales. After the acquisition, Carlton Communication's stations will account for 40 percent of ITV's advertising revenue, and just more than 10 percent of total television viewing. Suzanne Kapner

title: Bear Market Encourages Alternative Investments
description: KUALA LUMPUR  The challenge for any investor in a bear market is to escape the galloping herd: thousands of people reacting to the same bad news by hitting sell buttons within seconds of one another.

title: A Multicultural Project Takes a High Road, the Silk Road
description: The Silk Road Project, a multicultural brainchild of the cellist Yo-Yo Ma that has long been a subject of vague rumor and speculation in the music business, takes on shape today with a public announcement of its various activities.

title: Mets Top Hernandez, 4-2, And Get Back Into Series
description: The Subway Series threatened to become an express, a Yankee sweep. But last night, the Mets beat a pitcher who had been unbeatable in the postseason and won a game they had to win.

title: Article 2000102592135728665 -- No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  With no fanfare and no ceremony, President Clinton signed the bill to provide medical care to thousands of low- income women with breast cancer.

title: Hail to the pre-election marketing campaigns of 2000.
description: THE politician is sitting before a microphone at an official-looking hearing where he confesses: ''I'm not denying I used cellular -- it was an experimental time and someone passed it to me. I put it to my ear, but I didn't talk. I only listened.''

title: Much Too Good for a Bagel
description: IT'S a beautiful, beautiful animal,'' Frank Hederman said, holding up a silvery 12-pound salmon, bright of eye and red of gill, less than 10 hours out of the sea. ''These guys swim 4,000 or 5,000 miles to get here. By comparison, the farmed salmon, the ones who live in those cages off the coast, are essentially goldfish.''

title: THE CHEF
description: AS I child I often visited my grandmother in Malaysia during the holidays, when the house was full of people who needed to be fed. In the morning, she would soften rice noodles in hot chicken broth, drain and oil them and put them in a large bowl on the counter. Throughout the day, everyone would duck into the kitchen, put noodles in a soup bowl, add chopped cilantro and then ladle in some spicy coconut broth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENSCH, CONSTANCE (NEE GIOBBE)
description: MENSCH - Constance (nee Giobbe). On Oct. 22, 2000. Beloved wife of Homer. Loving sister of Susan Dull. Dear cousin of Gloria Ficalora. President of the Board of Trustees, The Dalcroze School of Music, President of The Bohemians, Chairman of the Young Artists' Committee of the Musicians' Club of New York. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9 PM with service Thursday, 1:30 PM. Interment to follow at Mount Saint Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Dalcroze School of Music, or the Musicians' Foundation of the Musicians' Club of New York.

title: Ivory Coast Ruler Declares Himself Winner
description: The military ruler, Gen. Robert Guei, declared himself winner of Sunday's presidential election today, dissolving the electoral commission that had shown him trailing his main opponent and dashing hopes that the vote would reverse this West African country's yearlong slide into political instability.

title: Rejecting Favoritism Claim, Court Upholds a City Welfare Contract
description: An appeals court handed the Giuliani administration a major victory yesterday, ruling that Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi overstepped his authority in March when he rejected $104 million in welfare-to-work contracts while raising what the court called unfounded allegations of corruption.

title: A Series That's Back on Track
description: Had Bobby Valentine wanted to use a cliche, he could have said he stayed with the people who brought him to the dance. But he chose other words to explain why he didn't make some moves he could have made in the sixth inning and thus risked losing the third of three World Series games the Mets have played with the Yankees.

title: For Chemical Industry Old-Timers, There's a New Formula
description: ONE executive went to a start-up called Elemica. One founded the Internet company CheMatch. Another heads Fob.com, a purchasing hub.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARINE, SALLY S.
description: MARINE-Sally S. On October 22, 2000. Beloved wife of Roy, devoted sister of Irving, loving aunt of Tamar and Eitan. Services private.

title: South African Firms Are Going High-Tech At Their Own Speed
description: WHEN Sasol Ltd., a world leader in energy resources and a powerhouse of South African industry, decided earlier this year to start buying its paper and pens online, it went to its longtime supplier and fellow Johannesburg company, Waltons Stationery, and outlined its plans.

title: BRITISH TRADE BALANCE
description: Britain reported its first trade surplus with European Union countries since November 1995, or before the euro was introduced as a common currency. For August, the surplus was less than $:100 million, or $145 million, compared with a deficit of $:300 million in July, according to the Office of National Statistics. The reversal comes as the euro continues its slide against sterling, and belies commonly held beliefs among British manufacturers that they are at a disadvantage against European companies given the euro's relative weakness. Worldwide, Britain recorded a trade deficit for goods and services of $:1.4 billion, compared with a $:2.1 billion deficit in July. Suzanne Kapner

title: Article 2000102593270979843 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JULIA, RAUL
description: JULIA-Raul. A Mass will be held in honor of the late Raul Julia at Holy Trinity Church, 213 West 82 St, on Friday, October 27 at 6:30PM. October 24 marks the sixth anniversary of Mr. Julia's death.

title: Article 2000102593394489344 -- No Title
description: October 25, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MORDETSKY, HARVEY
description: MORDETSKY-Harvey. Birthday remembrances of a good, kind and decent man, my best friend. Russell

title: Job Seekers Are Looking Out for No. 2
description: The transfer to London from Montreal was Sophie Bouchard's for the asking. And Ms. Bouchard, 31, the top sales representative in Canada for TMP Worldwide Inc., an executive recruiter based in New York, wanted it badly.

title: Metro Business Briefing; FIRED MANAGER WINS JUDGMENT
description: A jury has awarded $750,000 to the Metropolitan Museum of Art's former assistant banquet manager after finding that the museum's food contractor, Restaurant Associates, had fired him illegally. The jury made the award Thursday after finding that the company's dismissal of the manager, Luke Davis, was illegal on the ground that it had constituted discrimination because of his disability. Mr. Davis has Tourette's syndrome, a neurological disorder that causes involuntary motor and vocal tics. During the trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Mr. Davis testified that Restaurant Associates managers had referred to him as a ''cripple'' and a ''disturbing element.'' Mr. Davis testified that he was fired after he was forced to leave work ill on a day that a manager had insulted him because of his symptoms. Larry Jones, the general counsel for Restaurant Associates, said that the company planned to appeal the verdict and that Mr. Davis had not been discriminated against. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: No Special Alert for Cole Before Bombing
description: American naval officials said today that the destroyer Cole, at the moment of the bombing that killed 17 sailors, was at a medium-level alert, no different from that routinely in force in the Persian Gulf, despite the violence in Israel and a general warning of a possible terrorist attack on an American warship.

title: No Fun for Sisyphus: the Woes of WebMd and Medscape
description: BACK when the idea of e-health seemed fresh and inevitably lucrative, three companies were often described as the sector's sure winners: Medscape, Healtheon and WebMD. In a new and already crowded field, the three promised to go beyond the popular patient information sites and change the nature of medical communication, restructure the nation's health care systems and, oh yes, save lives.

title: TBWA Unit to Give Up Part of Kmart Account
description: The New York office of TBWA/ Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, said yesterday that it would relinquish part of the Kmart Corporation account, which the office was awarded last month.

title: With Chance to Swing, Zeile Punishes Yankees
description: Todd Zeile looked into the Mets' dugout, pleading with Manager Bobby Valentine. There were two runners on and nobody out in the sixth inning, with the Mets trailing Game 3 of the World Series, 2-1. Zeile had failed in his first bunt attempt, and he wanted no more of that exercise.

title: Clinton Urges Arafat to Calm Rioting in the West Bank
description: President Clinton called Yasir Arafat today to urge him to bring rioting in the West Bank and Gaza under control quickly. But Mr. Clinton received no assurances and no response to an invitation for Mr. Arafat to travel to Washington soon to map a way back to peace talks, administration officials said tonight.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- San Francisco and Fresno, Calif.

title: Sports of The Times; The Yankees Will Continue To Evolve
description: THERE is a growing perception that the Yankees are a dynasty in decline.

title: Austin's 'Dellionaires' Aren't Ready for the Ranch Just Yet
description: EVERY wheel has a hub. In Seattle, Microsoft laid the groundwork for the broader software scene that has grown up there, luring talented young people to the Northwest, then turning them into millionaires able to comfortably jump ship and start their own companies.

title: A Rose by Another Name: White Merlot
description: WINEMAKERS struck gold in the 1980's by turning red zinfandel grapes into pink wine and calling it white. Now, 20 years later, they are going for the gold again with the latest bit of wine alchemy, white merlot.

title: NBC Shelves 2 Sitcoms
description: NBC has won this season's dubious achievement of being the first network to cancel a new series, announcing yesterday that the comedy ''Tucker'' had been dropped from its schedule after just four weeks on the air.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Zagat Adds Cozy Spots

title: Feel Under the Weather in Canada? Log On for an Electronic House Call
description: WHEN Damian Ivers, a tour-boat owner here, injured his back in August, he didn't go to a doctor's office; he logged on to eSalveo.com, an e-health Web site. He sent a description of his symptoms to his family doctor, who replied through eSalveo, a privately owned site that allows patients to communicate electronically with their doctors for a fee, opting out of the free government health care.

title: HEALTH: Hospital, Clinic, Practice: 3 Views of Doctors and the Web; Privacy, Costs and Wariness Slow One Medical Group's Web Use
description: THE 20 doctors in the Katonah Medical Group in northern Westchester County are not anti-technology. Some even describe themselves as techies, eager to try new gadgets and regularly surfing the Internet.

description: NEWS

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Under Circumstances, No Pomp as Clinton Signs a Bill
description: With no fanfare and no ceremony, President Clinton signed the bill to provide medical care to thousands of low-income women with breast cancer.

title: Amazon.com Surpasses Wall St. Forecast
description: Amazon.com beat Wall Street's expectations yesterday, posting higher sales and a lower loss than expected in the third quarter.

title: Bush's Road Out of the Balkans
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000102590131181843 -- No Title
description: E-COMMERCE SPECIAL SECTION

title: Master Chef, Patricia Yeo: Shellfish in Spicy Coconut Sauce
description: This is the third of eight columns by Patricia Yeo, the executive chef at AZ in Manhattan. They are being written with Jack Bishop.

title: Profit Is Strong at Pfizer and Schering-Plough, but Shares Fall
description: Pfizer Inc. and the Schering-Plough Corporation said yesterday that their earnings for the third quarter were very strong as the companies continued to benefit from rising sales of prescription drugs, especially in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, KLEIN, BINA
description: BERG-KLEIN-Bina. On October 23rd, 2000. Wife of Marvin Klein and the late Ben Berg. Mother of Aviva Golan, Tamar Berg and the late David Berg. Grandmother of Gillian, Ben, Adam and Jacob. Sister of Miriam Brownstein. Services private.

title: After Managed Care, Insurers Look to the Web for Plan B
description: THE nation's health insurance companies are rushing, belatedly in most cases, to transfer their exasperating, clunky dealings with doctors and patients to the Internet. After 10 years of trying to save money by spending less on care, they hope to squeeze savings from their bloated administrative costs.

title: E-Commerce
description: Combining the Internet and health care could save money and lives. But the experience of a hospital in Worcester, Mass., that is neither a leader nor a laggard shows why change is coming slowly. Also: Articles on business-to-business exchanges, shopping and entertainment, and reports from overseas.

title: Study Casts Doubt on Texas Test Scores, and Gives the Democrats Ammunition
description: A new study questioning the validity of rising student test scores in Texas roiled the presidential race today as aides to Gov. George W. Bush sought to discredit the findings while the campaign of Vice President Al Gore and other Democrats used them to attack Mr. Bush on his signature issue, education.

title: AT&T Board Said to Meet On Overhaul
description: After approving a plan to overhaul AT&T on Monday, the company's board met yesterday to nail down the details and complete the necessary legal documents, people close to the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, SOL
description: BERNSTEIN-Sol. In memory of the sweetest, kindest, most generous father ever, whose death one year ago today left an emptiness in my life that can never be filled. Often unappreciated, Daddy, you were forever needed and loved. And though the earth now covers you, my heart will always see you and miss you. Barbara

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASRI, DR. ALBERT
description: BASRI-Dr. Albert. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Dr. Albert Basri beloved father of our devoted member Carole Basri, and grandfather of our Day School Alumni Joshua and Zachary. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SALOSHIN, EDITH
description: SALOSHIN-Edith. Your love was the highlight of my life. We miss you more each day and will cherish your memory forever. Rest in Heavenly peace. Fred & Cliffor

title: To Preserve Our Culture, Byte by Byte
description: To the Editor:

title: Europeans Say Bush's Pledge to Pull Out of Balkans Could Split NATO
description: A promise by George W. Bush that, if elected president, he would negotiate the removal of American troops from peacekeeping duties in the Balkans and leave such work to the Europeans has provoked a collective sigh of anxiety and even weariness among European diplomats, officials and analysts.

title: The Bill for Terror
description: President Clinton is ready to sign a bill that would authorize huge payments to American victims of international terrorism. Under the new law, more than $213 million in compensatory damages would be paid to eight families that have won judgments against Iran over terrorist acts.

title: What to Look For in a Senator From New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARBURG, INGRID SPINELLI
description: WARBURG-Ingrid Spinelli. The family announces with deep sorrow the passing of Ingrid on October 23, 2000 in Rome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONENCLAR, JOSEPH
description: SONENCLAR-Joseph. Temple Israel, Lawrence, New York, mourns his loss & extends deepest sympathy to the family. Alan Hartstein, President Allen Kaplan, Rabbi

title: Rev. T.R. Peterson, 71, Seton Hall Ex-Chancellor
description: The Very Rev. Thomas R. Peterson, a former chancellor and president of Seton Hall University who played a major role in its fund-raising, died on Sunday at a nursing home in North Kingstown, R.I. He was 71.

title: Luigi Marinelli, 73, Critic of the Vatican
description: The Rev. Luigi Marinelli, a retired monsignor who ran afoul of the Vatican when he published a best-selling expose on church intrigue, died of liver and bone cancer on Monday, his nephew said. He was 73.

title: Cupid Goes Online for Romances That Click
description: IT was inevitable, practically preordained. A marriage made in cyberheaven: matchmaking and the Internet.

title: As Competition Heats Up, So Does the Threat of Collusion
description: IT is a paradox of the new Internet economy. Thousands of companies have begun to participate in hundreds of new business-to-business exchanges, buying and selling supplies and products and achieving new economic efficiencies, creating a more transparent marketplace that holds great promise for better prices, lower costs, faster production and greater competition.

title: Charles Perkins, 64, Advocate For Aborigines in Australia
description: Charles Perkins, a campaigner for the rights of Aborigines who was sometimes described as the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. of Australia, died last Wednesday in Sydney. He was 64.

title: When Competitors Are Partners, How Bare Do They Dare?
description: CONVERSATIONS in the boardroom are using the language of the bedroom -- openness, commitment, vulnerability and trust -- as e-nabled companies give one another come-hither looks. It isn't mergers they want, but partners. With the Internet cutting the cost of information exchanges and transactions, e-commerce executives say networked partnering is the best way to create goods and services.

title: Judge Backs Cash Award in Race-Based Transfers
description: A federal judge has upheld a jury's monetary awards to black police officers who were transferred to a Brooklyn precinct after Abner Louima was tortured there in 1997.

title: Clemens, Piazza And a Bad Call
description: To the Editor:

title: Off-Duty Police Officer Fatally Shoots Brooklyn Woman in Building Where Families Feuded
description: An off-duty police officer fatally shot a 21-year-old Brooklyn woman after she and her mother attacked him with a baseball bat and a pool cue, the police said.

title: Last Year's Winners Back in New York
description: The winners of the New York City Marathon last year will be back this year.

title: Anti-U.S. Fury in Jordan's Streets Overshadows a Trade Pact
description: On the day that Bill Clinton held a White House ceremony with Jordan's king to sign a trade pact, Muhammad Nubeni and his friends paraded through the streets here today denouncing the American president.

title: Full Strength but Feeble, the Rangers Go Meekly to Philadelphia's B Team
description: The most excitement at Madison Square Garden last night came during the first intermission. It was created by two peewee teams from Staten Island.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Gene Modified Corn Is Found in Japan
description: The Consumers Union of Japan said today that it has found traces of a controversial genetically modified corn from the United States in snack foods and animal feed sold here.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: The Cadillac Of Chronographs

title: Ford Shows Off Devices for Improved Safety and Mileage
description: Seeking to restore its reputation for safety and respond to high gasoline prices, the Ford Motor Company announced today a half-dozen high-technology approaches to improving traffic safety and gas mileage.

title: STEEL TALKS IN JAPAN
description: Two of Japan's top steel producers, the NKK Corporation and the Kawasaki Steel Corporation, said that they were in talks about sharing research and development facilities but denied a report in Yomiuri Shumbun, a Japanese newspaper, that they are in merger talks. The speculation of the merger comes amid global consolidation of the steel industry. Facing competitive pressures at home and abroad, NKK and Kawasaki have been struggling under the weight of over 1 trillion yen of interest-bearing debt and looking for ways to cut costs and capacity, analysts said. A merger of the two companies, the No. 2 and No. 3 steel makers in Japan, would create the largest steel producer in the world. Miki Tanikawa

title: Singer's Charity Moves Online
description: ELTON JOHN AIDS FOUNDATION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILTON, DR. SYBIL
description: MILTON-Dr. Sybil. Agudath Israel of America notes with sorrow the passing of this uniquely gifted historian. Her creative encouragement of the study and preservation of Jewish heritage, including the establishment of the Orthodox Jewish Archives of Agudath Israel of America, is her noble legacy for future generations. Rabbi Shmuel Bloom, Exec. V.P. Rabbi Moshe Kolodny, Director, Orthodox Jewish Archives

title: Yankees' Clemens Is Fined $50,000
description: Roger Clemens survived an inquiry into his bat-throwing incident, avoiding suspension for the rest of the World Series. But the Yankees' controversial pitcher was fined $50,000 yesterday, matching the stiffest non-drug-related fine ever levied against a player.

title: Culinary Exploits of Homer's Sons
description: IT'S well known that all self-respecting Greek diners serve the same rice pudding. The question is why.

title: Bush's Road Out of the Balkans
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000102594283447269 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: The Fears May Be Needless, but Here Come the Secure Cards
description: ROBERT McKINLEY, the chief executive of Cardweb.com, which tracks the payment card industry for consumers and issuers, long ago shed his fear of using a credit card to buy goods online. But he remains puzzled as to why so many people are still Web-wary.

title: A Glass of Wine Helps Show What Buyers Want
description: WHEN the Internet began evolving into a mass medium in 1995, it struck fear into the hearts of retailers, who worried that enabling consumers to quickly and easily compare prices would force ever thinner profit margins. Then their businesses, like the cursed fat lawyer in Stephen King's 1994 novel ''Thinner,'' would be reduced to skin and bones.

title: Liberties; Boys Going Batty
description: Baseball isn't only about testosterone, of course.

title: Photography Center Presents Renovated Midtown Space
description: Renovating the Midtown quarters of the International Center of Photography, Gwathmey Siegel & Associates Architects have fashioned an airy, cascading series of permanent galleries that will serve as the center's new home.

title: Campaign Against Employee Supplier Intensifies
description: John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., plans to meet several thousand union members early today in a parking lot in Tacoma, Wash., and lead a march on a relatively obscure and financially troubled company in the business of supplying temporary blue-collar workers.

title: Take Star Power, Add Issues
description: ROSIE O'DONNELL

title: Metro Business Briefing; ENERGY PROFITS UP
description: KeySpan Corporation, the owner of Brooklyn Union Gas, said yesterday that third-quarter profits rose 62 percent because its power plants sold more electricity and its exploration business benefited from higher oil and gas prices. Net income increased to $14.6 million, or 10 cents a share after payment of preferred dividends, from $9.02 million, or break even, during the same period a year ago. Sales rose 76 percent to $947.1 million from $538.5 million, Robert Mahony, a company spokesman, said. KeySpan said its gas distribution businesses in New York City and on Long Island lost $28 million, or 21 cents a share, in the third quarter, about the same as a year earlier.

title: Baseball in Broad Daylight
description: If you believe in fairy tales, and most baseball fans do, you know that it is always possible to make one wish too many. Who could ask for anything more than a Subway Series? Well, there is just one more thing -- a Subway Series played, at least in part, during these still-lingering autumn afternoons. Call it a nostalgic impulse, or simply the way the game was meant to be played, but you can almost imagine what it might be like. Someone would dream up a special promotion -- fedora day -- so that when the cameras glanced over the crowd, you might almost imagine you were looking back in time to the 1930's or 40's, when a baseball stadium was invariably a sea of hats.

title: Watch These Mice Nibble Through Red Tape
description: ON the Web pages of the Occupational Health and Safety Administration, a worker worried about safety on the job can file a complaint with little more than a click of the mouse.

title: Marriage Law Roils Vermont Elections
description: Never before have Vermont's autumn colors blazed so hot, some here are saying proudly these brilliant gilded days. Unfortunately, the same goes for Vermont's politics, others are saying with concern.

title: NORTEL SAYS ACQUISITIONS LED TO LOSS
description: Nortel Networks, the Canadian maker of telecommunications equipment, reported a third-quarter loss of $586 million, or 20 cents a diluted share, far wider than a loss of $79 million, or 3 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Excluding the costs of acquisitions in the quarter, Nortel said it would have had earnings of $574 million, or 18 cents a share. Fueled by sales of fiber optic and wireless equipment, Nortel's revenue climbed 42 percent in the quarter to $7.31 billion. Among large telecommunications equipment companies, Nortel is considered to have been the most prescient in deploying fiber optic technology, which allows huge amounts of data to be transmitted on wavelengths of light. But the market was disappointed in the sales figures. Nortel's shares dropped 20 percent in after-hours trading, to $50, after closing regular trading at $63.31, off $3.13, or 5.4 percent. Simon Romero

title: Bush's Road Out of the Balkans
description: To the Editor:

title: A Case Study That Starts in a Botanical Garden
description: SARAH-LOU REEKIE does not work on Internet time. She does not rush when she checks in with the warehouse that stocks her product -- an herbal insect repellent called Alfresco -- or when she chats with the factory that makes it.

title: If a Site Is All About Your Health, Who Else Might Be Peeking?
description: WHEN Kaiser Permanente tries to persuade members to join its online service, the health care giant likes to talk about its advice-nurse feature, which guarantees a response to questions within 24 hours.

title: Filling the Peruvian Niche on Avenue A
description: PERUVIAN cuisine is a melting pot of Asian, European, African and ancient American influences, so it's not so improbable that a Malaysian is behind Cocina Cuzco, a new Peruvian restaurant in the East Village. Hann Low, the owner, has no connection with Peru, though. He enjoyed the food at Chicama, Douglas Rodriguez's nuevo Latino restaurant specializing in Peruvian ceviches, and believed there would be a niche for this sort of food on Avenue A.

title: A Double Expatriate Struggling Within One Body
description: A WOMAN UNKNOWN

title: THE BOSS; My Mistakes Make ESPN
description: I found out at a young age that it's easy to throw a person out of the game. You can do that every night. It's hard to keep someone in the game. Look at Roger Clemens the other night. Charlie Reliford, the umpire, got in between Mike Piazza and Clemens and defused the situation. Reliford could have thrown him out. But the players have more respect for you if you go in and try to use some psychology.

title: O'Neill's Hits in the Present Could Earn Him a Future
description: Some fans may overlook Paul O'Neill's performance last night because his Yankees lost by 4-2 to the Mets in Game 3 of the World Series at Shea Stadium. But it is a sure thing that the Mets pitchers paid attention.

title: Metro Business Briefing; MORE WATERFRONT OFFICES
description: Two office towers totaling 1.5 million square feet will be added to the Harborside Financial Center office complex on the Jersey City waterfront, with Charles Schwab & Company to occupy a fifth of the new space, the developer announced yesterday. The developer, Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, based in Cranford, N.J., held a groundbreaking ceremony for the larger building, a 915,000-square-foot tower that will rise 33 stories when completed in fall 2002. Schwab has signed a 15-year lease on 300,000 square feet in the smaller building, which will be 19 stories, with 575,000 square feet of space, said Virginia Sobol, a Mack-Cali spokeswoman. The space would house Schwab's newly expanded East Coast headquarters. Construction costs for the two buildings are estimated at $400 million. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Democrats Hear Thunder on Left, and Try to Steal Some of Naders
