title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHRMAN, VERA
description: LEHRMAN-Vera. Age 95. On October 22, 2000. Teacher and Artist. Devoted wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Laura, Robert (Jane). Proud grandmother of Lynne Gregory (David), Lisa Gugenheim, Karen Resheff (Doron), and Ted, great-grandmother to Jonathan, and Adam, Danielle & Rachel. Private graveside services. Donations appreciated to Art Students League, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, BERNARD A.
description: WEBER-Bernard A. Suddenly on October 23, 2000. Beloved husband of Ronnye Shamam. Devoted father of David and Valerie, Madeline Weber and Bill Shamam. Loving grandfather of Samantha and Jonathan. Dear brother of Carol Kirshenbaum and the late Rose Kleinman. Services Wednesday, October 25, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Earnings Triple For Spiegel
description: Spiegel Inc., the clothing and home-furnishings retailer, said today that its third-quarter profit more than tripled as sales rose at catalog, Internet and credit-card units.

title: Labor Praises New Trade Pact With Jordan
description: President Clinton and King Abdullah of Jordan signed a free trade agreement today that commits them to safeguard worker rights and the environment, an unprecedented step that won praise from labor unions and environmental groups that have opposed every major trade initiative of Mr. Clinton's presidency.

title: Q & A /Andrew Fisher, head of Coutts Group : Preserving Confidentiality in an Era of Openness
description: Andrew Fisher, recently appointed chief executive of the Coutts Group, the international private banking group owned by the Royal Bank of Scotland Group, talked to Stephanie Apap Bologna about how one of the world's oldest private banks is reacting to international pressure on offshore centers. He explains why a decision was made to pull out of the U.S. domestic market and discusses the launch of NatWest Private Banking.

title: A Second Act For the No. 7 And Its Riders
description: Over the last week, the No. 4 train has had more than its share of baseball-related attention. Even the unsung D train to Yankee Stadium has garnered a little. But perhaps no New York subway line associated with the game of baseball has been placed under quite so intense a worldwide gaze as the No. 7 train.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Despite strong sales, Computer Associates still lacks credibility with investors and analysts.
description: IN announcing its second-quarter earnings yesterday, Computer Associates posted some big numbers.

title: Mayor of Union City Resigns Under Fire; Rival Replaces Him
description: The embattled mayor of Union City, N.J., resigned yesterday, allowing a county official who had been pushing for a mayoral recall election to take office.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: In the World of the Deaf, Hearing Poses Dangers
description: ''Sound and Fury'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films Series. Following are excerpts from Anita Gates's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 8. The film opens today at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: ROCKWELL WILL ACQUIRE PARENT OF AEROSPACE COMPANY
description: Rockwell International's aviation unit agreed to buy the parent of Kaiser Aerospace and Electronics for $300 million, only a day after General Electric said it would buy Rockwell's rival, Honeywell International. Rockwell Collins, part of Milwaukee-based Rockwell International, signed ''a definitive agreement'' to buy K Systems, the parent of Kaiser Aerospace and Electronics, a maker of display products for fighter aircraft and related products for the military industry, Rockwell said.

title: For Limited Government? That's Me, Gore Says
description: Vice President Al Gore laid claim to being the candidate of limited government today, rebutting Gov. George W. Bush's labeling of him as a big spender by promising that he would not increase the number of federal employees while he was in office.

title: Gore Appears in Excellent Health
description: Vice President Al Gore is in excellent health and has not taken a sick day in eight years in the White House, Mr. Gore and his doctor said in their first full interviews about Mr. Gore's health. Mr. Gore is ''fit for duty,'' Dr. Richard J. Tubb, a White House physician and Mr. Gore's personal doctor since mid-1995, said of his patient on a flight on Air Force Two from Milwaukee to Washington on Oct. 11.

title: For a Winter Adventure, Finding the Right Site
description: NORM WESTON makes his living taking fishermen through South Florida mangrove swamps to pursue big fish in shallow waters, fish that only the most experienced anglers can catch.

title: Judges and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: What's So Funny About A Purple Skirt?
description: TRACEY ULLMAN,

title: Commercial Real Estate; Redeveloping Space to Keep Manufacturing Jobs
description: When the Greenpoint Manufacturing and Design Center opened in 1994, supporters of manufacturing in New York City cheered: what had once been a decrepit rope factory on the Brooklyn waterfront had been turned into a low-cost home for light manufacturing companies and artisans.

title: Business Travel; CNN has a plan to conquer airport departure lounges around the world.
description: THERE are two issues I want to discuss about the CNN Airport Network, the service that has been pumping television news and feature programming into airport departure lounges since 1992, when airports began clamoring for it in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Bush's Road Out of the Balkans
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOX, JEANNE M.
description: KNOX-Jeanne M. (formerly Loeb). Of Longboat Key, FL, on October 22. She is survived by her daughters Bonnie Strauss of NYC, Nancy Rackoff of Pittsburgh, PA, and her son Thomas Loeb of Weston, CT. She is also survived by six grandchildren. Graveside services for family and friends will be held at Mt. Neboh Cemetery, Queens, NY, on October 26, at 11:00 AM. Family will be receiving at the home of Bonnie and Tom Strauss on Wednesday evening, October 25, between 7 and 9 PM. Expressions of sympathy may be sent to the Bachmann Strauss Dystonia and Parkinson Foundation, The Mount Sinai Medical Center, 1 Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1490, New York, New York 10029, or Mote Marine Laboratory, Inc., 1600 Thompson Parkway, Sarasota, Florida 34236.

title: Praise, Without Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Obscure Diversions Well Worth the Detour
description: IN this information-saturated world, it often feels as if nothing is left to discover, but it's amazing what can be found on the back roads of the world's wine regions.

title: Bob Franks for the Senate
description: The contest for United States Senate in New Jersey poses a difficult problem for voters inclined toward candidates who want the government to take an active role in addressing social needs. The choice is between Jon Corzine, a Democrat who calls for expanded health and education programs, and Representative Bob Franks, a cautiously moderate Republican. But the issues have unfortunately been overshadowed by Mr. Corzine's extravagant personal spending on television ads and his blatant use of money to secure political endorsements. We prefer Mr. Franks, a solid lawmaker with whom we disagree on some issues, over Mr. Corzine, whose approach to campaign finance and financial disclosure is contrary to the values of this page.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about investments by large companies in sexually explicit entertainment referred incompletely to the relationship between the News Corporation and the EchoStar Communications Corporation, which provides explicit films by satellite to subscribers. The article quoted a lawyer for a video store owner in Provo, Utah, as saying that his client's prosecution was unfair because many companies that provided ''adult'' entertainment were heavily backed by large corporations, including the News Corporation.

title: Compaq Beats Profit and Sales Forecasts
description: Compaq Computer reported earnings and sales that beat Wall Street's expectations yesterday, bolstering arguments that the company is rebounding from problems that had hurt its performance the last two years.

title: A Health Revolution, in Baby Steps
description: IN many ways, Dr. Anne Seger could not be happier. From her home or office, she can key any of her patients into her computer and instantly spy almost every piece of information she needs -- results from a blood test and X-rays, the operating room's report from recent surgery and the patient's next appointment.

title: Cheney Earned 80% on Stakes in Nine Initial Public Offerings
description: In the summer of 1999, Dick Cheney, who is now the Republican vice-presidential nominee, repeatedly received the closest thing to a guaranteed profit that the stock market has known: the opportunity to buy shares of technology companies at the initial price that they were offered to the public.

title: $1,000 Wines You Never Heard Of
description: THE vines, bereft now of their grapes, are turning red, gold and russet, and the brisk autumn air is spiced with the bouquet of new wine. ''A Medieval City,'' say the placards on the town hall, and indeed in this sleepy wine center 30 miles east of Bordeaux, little seems to have changed in five centuries.

title: Subway Series Ratings Need Lift
description: Barring a miraculous surge of viewing nationwide, the Subway Series will most likely become the lowest-rated World Series in history, falling behind the Yankees-Padres matchup of 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, RICHARD C.
description: HAYES-Richard C. On October 22, 2000 at age 62. Beloved husband of Barbara. Loving father of Neil, Christopher, Todd and his wife Kerry, Anna, Cathy, and Sarah. Grandfather of Matthew, Sarah, and Evie. Dear brother of Christine Walsh. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. on Tuesday, 7-9:00 PM and Wednesday, 2-5:00 and 79:00 PM. A celebration of his life will be held on Thursday at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Ave. at 54 St. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Richard C. Hayes Memorial Fund in support of the study of pancreatic cancer, and sent to The Mount Sinai School of Medicine, 1 Gustave Levy Place, Box 1049, NY, NY 10029.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULTMANN, JOHN E.
description: ULTMANN-John E., 75, died peacefully at home in Chicago, IL on October 23 from complications of lymphoma. Until the time of his death, he was continuing a rewarding 32 year career at the University of Chicago Pritzker School of Medicine. He is survived by his cherished wife of 48 years, Ruth E. Ultmann, three children Monica H. Ultmann (David A. Harris) of St. Louis, Michelle C. Ultmann (Robert F. Fierstein) of Pittsburgh and Barry F. Ultmann (Audrey) of Chicago, five grandchildren-Josh and Rachel Harris, Lisa and Sara Fierstein and Matthew Ultmann. He touched the lives of so many family, friends and colleagues all over the world and each of us will hold him closely in our memories. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to: The John E. Ultmann Fund, University of Chicago Cancer Research Center, MC1140, 5841 So. Maryland Ave, Chicago, IL 60637-1470

title: Clemens, Piazza And a Bad Call
description: To the Editor:

title: Redefining Coverage to Cut Out the Middleman
description: JUST about everybody agrees that managed health care is ailing and needs to be fixed. Employers dislike the rising expenses and responsibility, and consumers and doctors hate the restrictions. Seeing an opportunity, several Web companies are offering new ways to pay for medical services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKMAN, SARA G.
description: GLICKMAN-Sara G. Age 77. Beloved wife of Arthur, devoted mother of Alan R. Glickman, Mindy Gelok, the late Marcia Ann and Norman. Sara revolutionized the entire foster care industry in the United States. Since 1967, her untiring lobbying has led to over 150, 000 children being adopted out of foster care. She was one of the founders of ''Family Focus Adoption Services'' in Queens, NY. Services Thursday, October 26th, 12 noon at Robert Schoem Chapel, 150 E, Route 4, Paramus, NJ.

title: Five Views On Web's Role For Consumers
description: DR. JOHN BARTLETT

title: Gun Lessons Are Suddenly All the Rage in Israel
description: At the Battle Shooting Range, Kady Harari, 36, stood with her feet planted wide, raised a semiautomatic weapon, set her sights on the target's heart and trembled. Then, feeling sick, she later said, she squeezed the trigger of a pistol for the first time in her life and sent a bullet ricocheting off the padded ceiling.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions on the Fashion page yesterday with a report about women's clothes with a masculine touch misspelled a designer's given name and the name of an apparel company. The designer is Nicolas Ghesquiere, not Nicholas; the company is Max Mara, not Marra.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AGCO CORP., Duluth, Ga., named Donald R. Millard senior vice president and chief financial officer. He had been president and chief executive at Matria Healthcare.

title: Group Critical of Nassau Executive's Contract Awards Backs Ballot Measure
description: A local political group criticized the Nassau County executive today for awarding more than $23 million in no-bid contracts to 33 companies that donated money either to him or to the county Republican Party.

title: Con Ed's Plan To Buy Utility Looks Shakier
description: Casting further doubt on its proposed $3.8 billion acquisition of Northeast Utilities, Consolidated Edison said today that it would ask Connecticut's utilities regulatory agency to reconsider its decision last week to impose dozens of conditions that company officials said could kill the deal.

title: TV Toolhead Turning Into Web Toy Maker
description: TIM ALLEN,

title: Kramnik Routs Kasparov To Take 2-Point Match Lead
description: In the midst of hurly-burly tactics, Garry Kasparov blundered against a mating attack by Vladimir Kramnik in Game 10 of their Brain Games Network World Chess Championship in London yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Amazon Reports a Loss

title: Sports of The Times; Door Swings Open To Wild and the Great
description: IT is now officially safe for Mets fans to invoke names like Rocky and Mookie, Cleon and Nails, Tug and Bobby O.

title: Neagle Can Erase Sour Series Memory
description: In the background of the Yankees' euphoria unleashed with the folklore swing of Jim Leyritz in Game 4 of the 1996 World Series, there was the frazzled Atlanta pitcher who set up the spectacular comeback by the Yankees.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Rick A. Lazio's criticism of the health care overhaul proposed by Hillary Rodham Clinton in 1994 misstated her explanation of its legislative failure. She has said that she made a mistake in trying to push so ambitious a proposal through Congress. She did not blame Republican control of Congress; Democrats controlled the House and the Senate in 1994.

title: That Carmen, She's Still The Ultimate Cigarette Girl
description: There are times when the rest of ''Carmen'' seems like just a way of getting to the great scene in the fourth act when everything else has been cleared away -- the minor characters, the chorus and, in Franco Zeffirelli's staging at the Met, the flamenco dancers, the donkeys, the priest and servers, the horses and the dogs -- to leave just Carmen and Don Jose onstage, alone and together. So it was on Monday night, when the Met revived Mr. Zeffirelli's production for the first of only five performances with Olga Borodina in the title role and Roberto Alagna as her lover, her victim and her nemesis.

title: HEALTH; Safety Tips For Buying E-Medicines
description: WHEN buying drugs or other health products online:

title: Blacklist Raises a Storm In the Channel Islands
description: LONDON  When Jersey and Guernsey appeared on the blacklist of 35 offshore centers deemed by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to engage in unfair tax competition, it came as a surprise, not least to authorities and businesses in the two Channel Islands. Offshore centers are seldom thought of as whiter than white, but Jersey and Guernsey have always been regarded as comfortably on the white side of gray.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Oct. 14 and 16 and a front-page chart on Oct. 16 about the acquisition of Texaco Inc. by the Chevron Corporation misstated the total 1999 revenue for the companies. Including their Caltex joint venture, which sells petroleum products in Asia, the combined revenue for the companies was $85 billion, not $66.5 billion.

title: Surgeon Convicted of Murdering Wife
description: A Manhattan jury yesterday found a plastic surgeon guilty of killing his wife in 1985 and disposing of her body by dropping it from an airplane into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, CHARLES R.
description: KING-Charles R. October 22, 2000 at the age of 86. Devoted husband of the late Betty S. King. Father of Michael (wife Claire) of Carlisle, MA, and Jonathan (wife Kathleen) of Englewood, NJ. Grandfather of Adam, Brian, Gabrielle and Benjamin. Also survived by his brother Roger (wife Louise) of Port Chester, NY, and his former wife Maxine of Topsham, ME. Stepfather to Carla Vozios and Paula Lonborg and step grandfather to John Vozios, Anna and David Lonborg. Throughout his life, Charles' natural curiosity and intellectual energy drove him to pursue many interests. In recent years Charles devoted time and passion as a volunteer at the American Museum of Natural History. As a tour guide he thrived on the discovery and sharing of new knowledge. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the American Museum of Natural History, Volunteer Services, 79 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5192, or to a charity of your choice. Interment private.

description: In percent

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: After 7-Year Fight, Homeless Get $816,000 in Back Wages
description: They slept on plastic chairs or in makeshift beds in a church, rising to put in long shifts in menial jobs, like security patrols at banks across Manhattan's East Side, or cleaning toilets at a shelter. Instead of being paid minimum wage, they got $1 an hour and promises of a path out of homelessness that never seemed to lead anywhere.

title: Rice Not Fighting 6th-Man Role
description: The regular-season opener is one week away, and Jeff Van Gundy acknowledged today that he was sitting on a potentially explosive situation. The Knicks' coach realizes that his decision to play Glen Rice off the bench for the first time in his 12-year career could upset the three-time All-Star. But he is thankful that Rice has thus far accepted the situation with a smile.

title: Lazio Criticizes President on Cancer Bill
description: President Clinton is missing an opportunity to promote breast and cervical cancer awareness, Representative Rick A. Lazio said today, by deciding to privately sign a bill that Mr. Lazio had backed.

title: Attempted Murder Charge Dropped Against Trooper
description: Prosecutors dropped the attempted murder charge today against one of the two state troopers involved in the 1998 New Jersey Turnpike shooting that wounded three unarmed minority men and made racial profiling on the state's highways a national issue.

title: Executives Forming Their Own Agencies
description: Executives are leaving agencies to open shops of their own.

title: Spike Lee's Show
description: Spike Lee hates television. So he has signed on to change it.

title: Giants Hoping Kickoff Unit Will Slow Down the Eagles
description: On a team that symbolizes perfectly how professional football is played these days -- with winning or losing often dependent on lucky bounces or gusts of wind -- the Giants are working feverishly on their kicking game this week to get that bounce and offset that wind.

title: Bush's Road Out of the Balkans
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Principles
description: To the Editor:

title: Boiling Down the Old Broadway Melodies
description: When Lincoln Center announced its American Songbook series three years ago, its plan to have an informal repertory company of America's finest pre-rock singers perform popular standards with a full orchestra sounded irresistible, if a bit vague. The laudable goal was to devote the same attention and expertise to popular music that Lincoln Center had brought to jazz. If successful, the series's main concerts at Alice Tully Hall would be glorious musical convocations that illuminated pop history in new ways and built bridges between the past and present.

title: When the Mind and Heart Share an Elusive Equation
description: ''Proof,'' a Manhattan Theater Club production that was presented off Broadway last spring, reopened on Broadway yesterday at the Walter Kerr Theater, 219 West 48th Street. Following are excerpts of a review by Bruce Weber that appeared on May 24.

title: Honor for Leiter
description: Mets pitcher Al Leiter was presented before the game as the recipient of the 2000 Roberto Clemente Award, given to the major league player who combines skills on the field with a sense of civic responsibility.

title: U.S. Tax Decision Hurts Secrecy
description: PARIS  In a country like Switzerland where freezing the bank account of the deposed Philippine dictator Ferdinand Marcos caused a national furor over coveted bank secrecy laws and where tax evasion is not a criminal charge, new rules forcing Swiss banks to police clients with U.S. tax obligations have stirred up a hornet's nest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JOHN L.
description: SMITH-John L., 52. In Rowayton CT, banker for Bank of Montreal. Father of Emily T. Smith of Rowayton and brother of James Smith of Darien Ct. Memorial services Saturday, October 28, 11 AM, Rowayton United Methodist Church, 5 Pennoyer Street, Rowayton, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLAIMAN, DON
description: SLAIMAN-Don. The Officers, Members and Staff of The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union mourn the loss of Don Slaiman, a great friend of working people, a leader in the battle for civil rights in this country and a fighter for justice throughout the world. Don Slaiman believed in the rights of all workers to be treated with dignity, justice and respect, and devoted his life to advancing their cause. People throughout the world have been touched by his integrity and commitment. We will miss him greatly. Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union UFCW, AFL-CIO, CLC Stuart Appelbaum, President Charlie N. Hall, Senior Secretary Treasurer Lenore Miller, President Emeritus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, ALFRED
description: SCHREIBER-Alfred. 1919-2000, on October 16. Beloved father of Charles Ertag Schreiber.

title: Click On, and Send Those Unwanted Pounds Off Into Cyberspace
description: THE only way to lose weight is to eat fewer calories and exercise more.'' This was my father's diet mantra during our teenage years. Back then, my sister and I were inevitably seduced by the latest diet du jour -- Atkins, Beverly Hills, Scarsdale or our own Tab Soda Diet. Dad's slow and steady approach wasn't as much fun.

title: Glossy Visits to Flea Markets and Cooking Schools
description: THERE'S a shiny new face in the parade of glossy food magazines: Taste, a well-mannered publication just introduced by Williams-Sonoma. It is pretty enough, and it covers a broad territory: cooking, entertaining, wine, travel and chefs. But it lacks the depth or distinctive voice of Saveur or Cook's Illustrated.

title: Corzine's Spending Leaps Off the Page
description: A common theme is emerging on newspaper opinion pages as they begin issuing their endorsements for the Senate race in New Jersey. Those that favor the Democratic candidate, Jon S. Corzine, do so in spite of what they call his campaign spending excesses. Those who favor the Republican, Representative Bob Franks, do so largely because of Mr. Corzine's spending.

title: New Choice for F.D.A. on Engineered Corn
description: Even as it struggles to remove an unauthorized variety of genetically engineered corn from the nation's food chain, the developer of that corn is preparing to ask the government for temporary authorization for the corn to be used in food, according to food industry and government officials.

title: DDB Regroups Its Top Management
description: The DDB Worldwide Communications Group in New York is reorganizing top management as part of a planned succession.

title: Genetically Modified Corn From U.S. Reported in Japan
description: TOKYO, 25 October  A Japanese consumer group today offered what they said was the first evidence that a genetically modified corn from the United States has made its way across the sea and into cornmeal manufactured here for human consumption.

title: A Woman Long Dutiful, At Last Able to Speak Out
description: In ''Cora Unashamed'' the image of dried, brown leaves appears repeatedly to remind viewers that death is in the air, literally and spiritually. The music by Patrice Rushen often controls the emotional calibration.

title: Europe's Aid Plan for Colombia Falls Short of Drug War's Goals
description: Signaling reservations about Colombia's deep reliance on American military support, the European Union announced a package of nonmilitary aid today that fell short of expectations. The decision could undercut Colombia's $7.5 billion program to curtail coca production and curb the influence of leftist guerrillas.

title: INSIDE
description: Ivory Coast Power Play

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILTON, SYBIL H.
description: MILTON-Sybil H. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the passing of former colleague, Sybil Milton and extends its deepest condolences to her husband, Henry Friedlander. Rabbi Irving Greenberg, Chair Ruth B. Mandel, Vice Chair Sara J. Bloomfield, Director United States Holocaust Memorial Museum 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place S.W. Washington D.C. 20024

title: Fans Shed Pessimism As a Victory Develops
description: The pregame atmosphere outside Shea Stadium was more like a morgue than a madhouse. The home team was down two games to none and the fans still had visions of Roger Clemens dancing in their heads. That was, of course, before the Mets beat the Yankees, 4-2, in Game 3 to make this a series again.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about companies that have moved corporate headquarters out of Morris County, N.J., misstated the reason Schering-Plough pharmaceuticals moved to Kenilworth, in Union County. The company, which still has an office in Morris County, moved to a new, larger building in Kenilworth to improve corporate communications, a spokeswoman said. Schering-Plough did not merge with another company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNUR, ROBERT
description: SCHNUR-Robert. On October 24 at age 55. Loving son of Bernard. Cherished brother of Myrna (Michael), Wendy (Howard). Services will be held today 1:15 PM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARPE, DR. LAWRENCE
description: SHARPE-Dr. Lawrence. Died from cancer Thursday, October 19, 2000 at the McKeene Pavillion, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. Dr. Sharpe was born in London on December 25, 1930. He completed his medical training at University College Hospital, London, 1961. His first academic position in the United States was as an Instructor in Psychiatry at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, Maryland. He was an Assistant Professor of Psychiatry at State University New York & became an Associate Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at the University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1967. Dr. Sharpe joined the Biometrics Research Department of the New York State Institute in 1967. As a Research Psychiatrist he worked on the NIMH US/UK Diagnosis of Mental Disorders Project for many years. He joined the Department of Research Assessment and Training in 1980 and was involved in all of their projects until the last week of his life. He is survived by Robert Roy Nicholson, friend; his brother Robert Arden and wife Joy; his niece Suzy; his nephew Matthew and his wife Alex and their daughter, his great niece, Talullah. A memorial service will be held to celebrate his life on November 4 at 2:00 PM at the Church of Incarnation, 209 Madison Avenue, New York, New York 10016 (at 35th Street). In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy may be sent to the American Cancer Society.

title: Magic Touch Finally Abandons Hernandez
description: Orlando Hernandez decided earlier this season that it made more sense to say absolutely nothing to the reporters who cover the team. Rather than reveal his true feelings, Hernandez offers brief and colorless comments about himself, his pitching and his team. That is too bad, because he is a fabulous story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINBERG, SUE
description: KLEINBERG-Sue. The partners and staff of Kleinberg, Kaplan, Wolff & Cohen, PC, offer their heartfelt condolences to Fred Kleinberg and his family on the passing of his mother, Sue Kleinberg.

title: Take Steaming Seriously? Chefs Do
description: TODAY'S buzzwords for menu writers are roasted, grilled and braised. No steaming on that list. It has fallen victim to its own virtuous image: these days, steaming sounds like deprivation cuisine; too healthy, too boring.

title: CYBERWORKS STOCK FALLS
description: Shares of Pacific Century CyberWorks plunged in Hong Kong, as a stock and bond offering announced by its founder, Richard Li, seemed to stoke, rather than soothe, fears about the company. Mr. Li said Pacific Century CyberWorks would seek to raise $1.8 billion through a $500 million rights issue and up to $1.3 billion in convertible bonds. Investors were not comforted, even though Mr. Li himself will underwrite the share sale and buy $500 million worth of the bonds. Analysts said the financial maneuvers indicated that CyberWorks was under mounting pressure to pay down $9 billion in debt. The stock fell 11.5 percent, to 74 cents a share, 80 percent off its high. Mark Landler

title: How Do You Invest in Online Health? Very, Very Carefully
description: THEIR euphoria has waned, but some venture capitalists remain hopeful about e-health companies, which use the Internet to disrupt antiquated ways of doing business in the specialized and fragmented health care industry.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Their policy for six months has been to ignore me. So obviously we welcome this enhanced attention.''

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO RISES. The euro rose on speculation that finance ministers and central bankers who are meeting in Montreal may indicate support for the currency. In New York, the euro settled at 83.72 cents, up from 83.58 cents on Monday.

title: Making Face-to-Face Time Possible on the PC
description: THE Internet has revolutionized business people's ability to talk with one another, not just through e-mail messages but also through Web conferences, which allow participants at many sites to share verbal commentary, documents and slides at the same time.

title: Article 2000102593493980886 -- No Title
description: New Media Meets An Old Medium In the Phone Book

title: HEALTH; A Web Bazaar Turns Into a Pharmaceutical Free-for-All
description: DEBI SAPOLIN, a 38-year-old manufacturing representative from Yonkers, had always dreamed of motherhood but almost gave up when her insurance company refused to cover the cost of infertility treatments. ''But I had heard of a pharmacy in Europe which sold drugs cheaper than here,'' Ms. Sapolin said, ''so I combed the Internet until I found a pharmacy in France where I could buy my medication for a price I could afford.''

title: BANQUE WORMS ACQUISITION TALKS
description: Europe's biggest bank, Deutsche Bank, is in talks to acquire Banque Worms, a Paris commercial bank, from the AXA insurance group. AXA acquired Worms in 1997 but Worms fared poorly in recent years as a result of heavy investment in the foundering French real estate market of the mid 1990's. John Tagliabue

title: Twisting the Classics: Italian Goes Nuova
description: FERNICOLA OSTERIA clings to the upper edge of Williamsburg like a climber to a sheer sheet of granite. Two steps to the north, a long, lonely industrial strip extends deep into Greenpoint. Out the front window, across Kent Avenue, a stark wooden fence runs along a scrubby stretch of riverfront park that attracts the braver kind of jogger. The restaurant, a 100-year-old tavern, sheds a warm, hospitable light onto a cold-looking street. It seems a million miles away from the big city across the river, whose pinpoint lights glitter like an artificial galaxy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUHN, LENORE ''SUNNIE.''
description: KUHN-Lenore ''Sunnie.'' October 24th, 2000. Beloved wife of Leo. Loving mother of Bobby and his wife Rona and Jimmy and his wife Marjorie. description: Fogdog, a high-profile online sporting goods retailer, agreed yesterday to be acquired by Global Sports, which provides e-commerce services to retailers, for $38.4 million in Global Sports stock, the companies said.

description: FELICIA GRIFFIN intends to hoard a little holiday cheer for herself this year when she buys gifts. Her strategy is to shop with a select group of online merchants -- those who share a percentage of the purchase price in a rebate that will be invested in a choice of mutual funds.

title: N.T.T. INVESTIGATION
description: The Japanese Fair Trade Commission has begun an investigation into allegations that a unit of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, Japan's former telephone monopoly, has tried to prevent competitors from setting up lines for faster access to the Internet. The commission said it was looking into whether NTT East, which provides local telephone services, had worked to slow the rollout of digital subscriber lines that offer connections to the Internet that are more than 10 times faster than the service provided by N.T.T. Junichiro Miyazu, N.T.T.'s president, confirmed that the commission was conducting an investigation but said he did not know what it was looking into. The commission said the inquiry might take as long as a year to complete and could result in penalties against N.T.T. Tokyo Metallic, a small DSL provider that is partly owned by J. P. Morgan, and other providers of new ways to connect to the Internet, as well as consumers, who have complained that N.T.T. takes an inordinate amount of time to get their services hooked up. Stephanie Strom

title: ESTEE LAUDER SAYS QUARTERLY SALES EXCEEDED FORECASTS
description: Estee Lauder, the maker of Clinique makeup and Aveda shampoo, said fiscal first-quarter sales rose more than expected and forecast strong holiday sales, sending its shares up as much as 11 percent. Profit from operations rose 15 percent, to $94.6 million, or 37 cents a diluted share, from $82.6 million, or 32 cents, in the year-ago period. Sales in the quarter ended Sept. 30 rose 7.7 percent, to $1.18 billion, from $1.09 billion. Higher-than-expected demand in North America helped Estee Lauder top forecasts of a sales increase of 6 to 7 percent. The company said sales in the second quarter would rise 9 percent to 10 percent.

title: Christmas Is Coming! Time for Another Fight to the Death!
description: TRY to buy a toy on the Internet, and it is shocking what you find: violent battles, shotgun marriages, painful excess, sudden death.

title: Dutch Figure Seen as Choice For U.N. Post With Refugees
description: A former prime minister of the Netherlands, Ruud Lubbers, will be nominated to be United Nations high commissioner for refugees by Secretary General Kofi Annan, Dutch government officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANAU, KENNETH JOHN JR.
description: HANAU-Kenneth John Jr., of Sanibel Island, FL and Madison, CT, died Monday, October 23, 2000 at The Madison House in Madison. Beloved husband of Carol Rossner Hanau for 51 years. He was born February 27, 1927 in Montclair, NJ and was the son of the late Kenneth John and Elizabeth Oliver Hanau. After graduating from Montclair and Blair Academies, Mr. Hanau served in the U.S. Navy during W.W. II. He graduated from Wesleyan University in Middletown, CT in 1951. Mr. Hanau then went on to have a distinguished business career. He was Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of K&H Corrugated Case Corporation, headquartered in Walden, NY, with additional plants in Bennington, VT (Vermont Container), and in Wallingford, CT (K&H Containers). He founded the company in 1956 and owned it for over 40 years. He was Chairman of the Executive Committee on the Board of Directors of US Home Corporation. He also served on the board of Tingue Brown Corporation and numerous other boards. He was a past President of the Madison Beach Club and an officer of the Chief Executive Organization. Besides his wife, Mr. Hanau is survived by, three daughters, Holly Hanau Koncz of Guilford, CT, Jill Minicucci of South Norwalk, CT, Lori Carol Hanau of Keene, NH, one son, Kenneth J. Hanau III, of Bronxville, NY, nine grandchildren, and a sister Helen Hanau Breen of Montclair, NJ. Mr. Hanau will be missed by friends and family for his strength, courage, spirit, and love of others. A Funeral Liturgy will be held Friday, 12:00 P.M. at St. Margaret's Church in Madison. Burial will be private. Calling Hours will be held Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 P.M. at the Swan Funeral Home, 825 Boston Post Rd., Madison, CT. Memorial donations may be made to Women and Family Life Center of Guilford, 96 Fair Street, Guilford, CT. 06437.

title: Oregon Ballot Full of Voter Initiatives Becomes Issue Itself
description: Forgive Carolyn Knowles for feeling a bit ''overwhelmed,'' as she put it, when Volume I of the Oregon voters' guide -- all 376 pages of it, encompassing 26 ballot measures and 607 arguments for or against them -- showed up in her mailbox a few days ago.

title: SERONO'S PROFIT JUMPS
description: Serono S.A., Europe's biggest biotechnology company, reported a 62.3 percent rise in net profit, to $209.9 million, for the first nine months. Strong sales of Rebif, a drug for multiple sclerosis, helped the company exceed analysts' expectations of a 50 percent profit increase. Serono said sales of Rebif reached $68.1 million, a record level, in the third quarter, and nine-month sales of the drug doubled to $179.7 million. Elizabeth Olson

description: Concerned that Ralph Nader has become a major threat to Vice President Al Gore's ability to win the presidency, the Democratic Party and its allies in the labor, environmental and women's movements are mounting aggressive campaigns in swing states across the country to dissuade liberal voters from supporting Mr. Nader, the Green Party candidate.

title: Cute, Ghoulish and Sweet, and Just in Time for Halloween
description: LET the timid eat candy corn. Kitchen Market in Chelsea is importing chocolate and jellied sweets this month that are just as sugary and even more symbolic than the harvest kernels, but it takes nerve to pop them into your mouth.

title: Corrections

description: Teachers in this shore township went on strike this morning after state-mediated talks broke down just two hours before school was to open.

description: Carnegie Hall has been swept by a wave of resignations and dismissals as its new executive director prepares to present a strategy that will bring significant change to this 109-year-old landmark institution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENDRICKSON, RITA G.
description: HENDRICKSON-Rita G. Goodbye, Rita. A good family friend for over ninety years. We will always remember your stories about your early years on East 88th Street ....your big sister, enjoying a little beer and some Limburger cheese with black radish on black pumpernickel with your father. Sorry you couldn't wait for the end of the World Series. Pour yourself a Dewar's tonight, there's plenty of ice. Eisenkramer & Brown Families

title: COVAD SUED OVER STATEMENTS ABOUT FINANCES
description: Angelo, Gordon & Company, a New York hedge fund management company, has filed suit against Covad Communications, saying that the provider of high-speed Internet services misled investors about its financial situation. In a lawsuit filed in California Superior Court in Santa Clara, where Covad is based, Angelo, Gordon is seeking the rescission of more than $46 million of convertible notes it bought from Covad only days before the company revealed problems with overdue payments this month. The hedge fund manager claims the subsequent decline in Covad's stock price, to about $6.66 yesterday, deflated the potential value of holders' investment, which would have allowed investors to convert the securities at a price of $17.775. Simon Romero

title: Call It What You Want, It's Gossip and I Love It
description: WHERE there are stars, there is gossip. And the Web, which was originally made to spread data among military researchers, has turned out to be even better at spreading the dish, especially on those fast connections at work. These days, news about your favorites' flings travels the world faster than you can say ''Rocco Ritchie'' (the name of Madonna's second child -- if you didn't know that, you need to check out a few of these sites). And with interactive forums and chat rooms, news is analyzed and digested more quickly and by more people than ever before, leading to . . . more gossip.

title: ALBRIGHT REPORTS PROGRESS IN TALKS WITH NORTH KOREA
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said tonight that ''important progress'' had been made in her talks here with North Korea's leader toward persuading North Korea to ''restrain missile development and testing, as well as missile exports,'' though any final agreement will have to await further talks.

title: Minnesota Penalized by N.C.A.A.
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association placed the University of Minnesota men's basketball program on probation for four years yesterday, took away five scholarships and put limits on recruiting contacts for what the organization called the most serious violations to come before it in 20 years.

title: Seeking Core-Business Survival, Xerox to Sell Many Operations
description: The Xerox Corporation, which lost money in most of its businesses this quarter, said yesterday that it would sell pieces of most of its operations -- from inkjet printers to its finance businesses to its share of Fuji Xerox. It is even looking to sell a majority stake in its most prestigious asset, its ground-breaking Palo Alto Research Center.

title: Warmer, Fuzzier Internet Is Seen in New Survey
description: The Internet might not be such a sad and lonely place after all.

description: A daylong suspense drama played itself outside the ticket window at Shea Stadium. By 9 a.m., a handful of the faithful had gathered in hope of grabbing tickets, some of them good ones, made available by last-minute cancellations. By 9:30, the handful had grown to a couple of dozen.

title: Investors Pay $48 Million For 15% of Nasdaq Japan
description: Nasdaq Japan, the fledgling stock market that is a joint venture of the National Association of Securities Dealers and the Softbank Corporation, has sold a 15 percent stake to a group of foreign and domestic brokers.

title: REPUBLICANS AGREE ON ABORTION DEAL TO ADVANCE BUDGET
description: Seeking to avoid a pre-election confrontation with President Clinton, Congressional Republicans agreed today to remove legal restrictions inhibiting private family planning groups that receive federal funds from spending their own money to provide abortions or promote abortion rights in foreign countries.

description: THERE'S a formula to chowder. Its flavor often comes from bacon or salt pork and onions, its texture from potatoes and its personality from the seafood that is used. On that last ingredient, Jasper White is well versed.

title: Corrections
description: An Oct. 22 Op-Ed misspelled the name of a Daily News sportswriter; his name is Vic Ziegel, not Siegel.

description: Kindergartners are discussing the shapes they see at the ballpark: the square bases, the round ball, the oblong bullpen.

title: Born to Be Wild But Growing Up
description: In its early years the Steppenwolf theater troupe was known, if it was known at all, as a gang of wild men and women whose stage work consisted largely of shrieking, smashing furniture and beating one another up. They set out to revolutionize American theater, but it seemed far more likely that they would soon be consumed by the fire of their emotions and disappear.

title: Test Scores May Reflect Social Shifts
description: EDUCATORS are under pressure to jump-start performance, and every politician has a favored panacea. But solutions are elusive because the roles of spending, curriculum, leadership and home environment are so intertwined.

title: Dr. Spock Lives On in Books; Coming Soon, the Web Site
description: DR. BENJAMIN SPOCK'S most widely quoted advice is contained in the very first words of ''The Common Sense Book of Baby and Child Care,'' the 1946 volume that redefined child-rearing in America. ''Trust yourself,'' he told parents. ''You know more than you think you do.''

title: A New Push To Combat Dirty Money
description: A group of major international banks, stung by the growing reputation of the banking industry as a haven for ill-gotten gains, is pledging to form a global front against money laundering.

title: Internet Radio Offers a Wide Choice to a Slim Audience
description: AT first glance, the Midtown Manhattan studio of Eyada.com seems like a typical radio station. A hallway cluttered with posters and photocopied notices leads to a cramped room where an engineer prepares for the next station break. But on this particular evening, Eyada's computer game server has been hopping. Players have gathered from around the Internet for ''The Totally Intense In-Your-Face Thumb-Twitching Joystick-Vibrating Hard-Drive-Crashing Videogame Show.''

title: HEALTH: Hospital, Clinic, Practice: 3 Views of Doctors and the Web; Reams of Information, Some of It Even Useful
description: After a year, the jury is still out. We are probably not practicing any better medicine than we were a year ago, wisdom and judgment not being commodities that are easy to download. For lesser things, though, instant Internet access has proved to be a handy, although not entirely risk-free, tool.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, IDA
description: NEWMAN-Ida. The President of Baruch College and the Trustees of the Baruch College Fund extend their heartfelt sympathy to our friend and colleague William Newman and his family on the death of his mother, Ida. Matriarch of a remarkable family, Ida Newman was a strong supporter of education and culture and of the Hebrew language. Hers was a long and productive life and she passed her generosity and vision on to her sons. Edward V. Regan, President, Baruch College Lawrence Zicklin, President, The Baruch College Fund

title: 3 Oil Concerns Post Records In Earnings For Quarter

title: Florida Voters to Decide Judicial Selection
description: In a year when aggressive judicial politicking has drawn calls for reform in many states, Florida voters will decide whether to end political campaigns for trial courts in favor of an appointive system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, GENEVIEVE L.
description: MURRAY-Genevieve L., 91. Of Glastonbury and Windsor, CT, formerly of New York City, died October 21, 2000. Daughter of James and Elizabeth Clemens Murray, she grew up in Hartford and was later employed by the City of New York as a secretary at Bellevue Hospital. She leaves a niece Susan Potter, nephews T. James Murray, Ronald Murray and Jeffrey Potter. Predeceased by her siblings Madeleine Murray, T. James Murray, Marguerite Collins, Catherine Peterson and Evelyn Potter and her nephew Robert Murray. Genevieve was a person of exemplary courage, faith, and dignity. She will be missed by all who had the privilege of knowing her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, MARTIN
description: RICH-Martin, 95. Conductor. Died October 23, 2000 peacefully after massive stroke at Roosevelt Hospital. Cherished husband of Maria. A Memorial Service will be announced at a later date.

title: For $300 an Hour, Advice on Courting Elite Schools
description: It is no secret that for many Manhattan parents, getting a child into the Ivy League starts in nursery school. And as competition to get into the city's most elite private schools has stiffened, a growing number of parents are doing something that would have seemed bizarre or just plain silly a decade ago: spending as much as $300 an hour for private counselors to guide them through the nursery and elementary school application process.

title: Ex-Peru Spy Chief Says He'll Avoid Politics
description: President Alberto K. Fujimori's shadowy intelligence chief, whose surprise return from exile in Panama plunged the country into a crisis, said today that he had no intention of playing a role in politics.

title: Series Thrills Lost on Fans Of Also-Rans
description: PAUL CAMPBELL was born in 1956, a year of almost mythic proportions for sports-minded New Yorkers. By now, even those in a trance for the last week must be aware that 1956 was the last time this city wallowed in the splendors and excesses of a Subway Series.

title: Hold the Arts & Crafts: After-School Programs Go Digital
description: As computers crowd out traditional arts and crafts in after-school programs, two national groups are taking starkly different approaches in linking extracurricular technology programs to students' daily school activities.

title: Bush's Better Inclination
description: For George W. Bush, compassionate conservatism has been a fair-weather campaign theme. When he was dominating the Republican field in 1999, or maintaining a sizable lead over Al Gore most of this summer, Mr. Bush could afford to spend all his time talking about his innovative programs for the poor and what they said about his heart.

title: Shelf Companies Weather Crackdown
description: HONG KONG  To hear law enforcement officials tell it, the global paper trail behind which money launderers hide is created in an office just like Ted Powell's.

title: Porter, an Icebreaker, Please, and Step on It
description: Shall we start with Eileen Atkins's right leg? It is, like her left leg, slender and shapely, and it has no doubt served this fine actress well over the years as something to stand on. But in ''The Unexpected Man,'' the cigarette-slim play by Yasmina Reza that opened last night at the Promenade Theater, Ms. Atkins turns her right leg into something far more resonant: an index of the vanity, anxiety and authority of the woman she is playing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOLNICK, LILLIAN
description: SCOLNICK-Lillian. On October 19, 2000. Lifetime resident of The Bronx. Devoted wife of the late Meyer Scolnick. Wonderful mother to Judy Beckwith and Barbara Pressberg and beloved Nanny to Alex, Eric, Emily, Caroline and Abby. Beloved sister, sister-in-law, aunt, great aunt and friend. Memorial contributions may be made to N.Y. Botanical Gardens, Bronx.

title: A Rarefied Roast of Beef
description: FEW meats are as tender, juicy and flavorful as good roast beef, yet none are easier to prepare. It needs nothing beyond salt and pepper and proper cooking. And while it is most commonly sliced thin, it can also be carved thick and served like steak, especially if you start with sirloin.

title: Filling a Shortage of Standards
description: SOME worry that fraud on the Internet will spread like kudzu, choking the growth of e-commerce. Others worry that the Internet's spectacular growth will become its greatest barrier as infrastructure strains and incompatible systems proliferate globally.

title: Lieberman Revisits Faith's Role in U.S.
description: Returning to one of his most cherished and provocative themes, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman called today for a greater role for religion in public discourse, as a source of shared moral principles and an antidote to ''the vacuum of values'' in American culture.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS. Natural gas dropped on forecasts for continued mild weather in the United States into early November. In New York, natural gas for November delivery fell 25.2 cents, to $4.82 for a million B.T.U.'s.

title: EARNINGS AT INSURER LINCOLN NATIONAL BEAT FORECASTS
description: Lincoln National, the sixth-largest American life insurer, said third-quarter earnings rose 48 percent, lifted by strong sales of annuities and life insurance and a number of one-time items. The insurer, based in Philadelphia, said operating income, which excludes investment gains and losses, rose to $190.7 million, or 98 cents a share, from $131.4 million, or 66 cents a share. The results beat the average estimate of 89 cents by First Call/Thomson Financial. Under its chairman, Jon A. Boscia, Lincoln has been shedding unprofitable business lines in an effort to improve profitability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRUSSLIN, HILDA (DANZIGER)
description: PRUSSLIN-Hilda (Danziger). Of Brooklyn, NY. Suddenly and peacefully passed away in her sleep on Oct. 23. Survived by her beloved husband Herbert, loving children Norman, Marc and Gail Prusslin, daughter-in-law Susan Risoli, son-in-law Michael Yellin, grandchildren Hannah, Rebecca, Allison, Amanda and Alexandra, & sister Shirley Binin. Her generosity, dedication and love of family will be forever remembered. Memorial services are at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn at 2:30 P.M., October 26.

title: He Loves to Swap. She Loves to Swap. Where's the Profit?
description: WITH a sports card collection that fills his basement and a desire to refine it, Jeff Tidwell, a steelworker in Granite City, Ill., sees potential in swap sites on the Internet.

title: Math on the Mound
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: STRONG SUMMER SEASON HELPS BOLSTER HILTON PROFITS
description: Hilton Hotels said third-quarter earnings rose 9.1 percent on a strong summer travel season and higher room rates at its hotels. Hilton, which is based in Beverly Hills, Calif., said profit from operations rose to $60 million, or 16 cents a share, from $55 million, or 15 cents, in the period a year earlier. Revenue rose 11 percent, to $867 million from $784 million, the company said. Results matched the average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: AT&T Outlines Its Plan To Split Into Four Parts

title: New Method Expected for Seeking Donations to Aid Parks
description: City officials conceded yesterday that the informal system of soliciting donations from corporations and other private groups that hold events in public parks was flawed and vulnerable to abuse, and said they would revamp it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MELISSA GRANT
description: DAVIS-Melissa Grant. Died Oct. 21, 2000. Beloved by her friends and family: husband, father, stepmother, sisters, brother, in-laws, niece, nephew & extended others. She was a wonderful woman who will be deeply missed. Love, Adele and Bill Grant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLMAN, EMILY
description: ULLMAN-Emily, 87, o f Port Washington, NY, died peacefully in her sleep at home on October 25. Emily was a wonderful wife, mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother who led an extraordinary life. Her strength, intellect and compassion touched many. She devoted much of her life to charitable activities. She was a volunteer at the Human Resources School in Albertson, NY for 25 years and also served as a trustee of the Unitarian-Universalist Congregation at Shelter Rock, NY, of which she and her husband were members for 50 years. An accomplished pianist, she loved music. She also acted in many local theatre productions. Emily and her husband, Frank, to whom she was married for 64 years, survived the Holocaust in hiding in Amsterdam. They immigrated to the U.S. and settled in Port Washington, NY in 1947. Her family and friends will miss her very much. Her life and love will always be remembered. She is survived by her husband, Frank, her sons Henry and Leo, her daughters-in-law, Kathleen and Katharine, six grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. A service to celebrate her life will be held at The Unitarian-Universalist Congregation at Shelter Rock Rd., Manhasset , NY on Sunday, November 5 at 4 PM.

title: Williams Frustrated By Lack of Production
description: Bernie Williams emerged from the Yankees' clubhouse last night, took a sharp left turn to address a group of reporters and acted as if he had been pinned against the gray cinder-block wall when they surrounded him. For a second or two, Williams feigned as if he were helpless. It was a fitting metaphor.

title: In New Jersey, Corzine or Franks?
description: To the Editor:

title: Carl Reiner Ad-Libs And Gets Humor Prize
description: At the beginning of the performance at the Kennedy Center's concert hall Tuesday night, the sound system failed and a man in the balcony shouted, ''Does anyone have four double-A batteries?''

title: A 5-Year-Old's Life: Work and Play
description: To the Editor:

title: Elderly Help Gore Compete in Florida, Poll Says
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 25  Vice President Al Gore is showing considerable strength in Florida among elderly and independent voters and is seen as more likely than his opponent to reduce the cost of health care and prescription drugs and protect the environment, a New York Times/CBS News poll shows.

title: Envelopes? No Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Fujimori Orders Military To Arrest His Former Spy Chief
description: President Alberto K. Fujimori ordered military units to hunt down his former intelligence chief tonight, but after security forces searched five locations, they could not find him.

title: Metro Matters; Positioning For Credit On Cancer
description: THE politicization of diseases is an old story by now. Public officials so routinely enlist in a fight against the most high-profile malady of the day that even those offended by such transparent tactics have come to accept them. After all, political attention raises awareness and money -- good things, whatever the motivation.

title: In Last Days, Lazio Forced To Focus On Upstate
description: When Rick A. Lazio arrived here for a Monroe County Republican reception this evening, he could be forgiven for feeling that he had been in these parts before. He had. Many times.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report on the Public Lives page yesterday about a party for the International Fine Arts and Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory referred incorrectly to two guests. The soprano Jessye Norman declined the red, blue and green drinks that were being served in martini glasses. It was Barbara de Portago, vice president of the Versailles/ Giverny Foundation, who joked about her blue drink's matching her Givenchy suit.

title: Judge Orders Tax Concern To Cease New Solicitations
description: Renaissance/The Tax People, which has been marketing a system to reduce income taxes that the authorities say is really a pyramid scheme, was ordered by a Kansas judge yesterday to stop soliciting new clients.

title: Metro Business Briefing; HARLEM RESTAURANT REOPENS
description: Manna Soul Food & Salad Bar, on Frederick Douglass Boulevard and 125th Street, reopened this month after undergoing a $500,000 expansion. Located opposite the new Harlem U.S.A. shopping center, the restaurant opened in 1983 as the tiny B & R Barbecue, named for its owners, Betty and Rick Park, immigrants from Korea. Now expanded to two floors, the cafeteria-style restaurant -- one of the few alternatives to fast food on 125th Street -- can seat 90 people. Several new restaurants have opened in Harlem recently, including Amy Ruth's, at 116th Street between Lenox and Seventh Avenues; Bayou, on Lenox Avenue between 125th and 126th Streets; Londel's Supper Club, on Frederick Douglass between 139th and 140th Streets; and Miss Maude's, on Lenox Avenue between 137th and 138th Streets. Terry Pristin

title: Under Fire From Democrats, Nader Assails Gore's Record
description: In the face of growing efforts by the Democratic Party and its allies to deflate his support, Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate for president, criticized Vice President Al Gore today more sharply than ever before, accusing him of repeatedly breaking promises to clean up the environment, help the poor and reform the federal government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLETTE, FRANCES
description: GILLETTE-Frances, 88, New York resident for over 60 years. Custom-clothing seamstress for theater, television and show business personalities. Travelled extensively in Europe and patron of the arts. Sister of the late Myra Harper Boland. Survived by her niece Mrs. Duane T. Kinsman of Fairfax, Virginia.

title: Brash Cellular Legacy Leaves Home
description: AT&T's plan to break itself up offers challenges and opportunities for all four of the corporate fiefs that will be spawned from the mother company, but AT&T Wireless may be the operation that has the most to gain.

title: Pilots Approve New Contract at United
description: Pilots for United Airlines, part of the UAL Corporation, have voted 95 percent in favor of a four-year contract that gives them the best pay in the industry, their union said today.

title: Sensor Fish Brave the Bumps to Tame Dams for Young Salmon
description: FOR a young salmon, spawned on the upper reaches of the Columbia or Snake Rivers in the Pacific Northwest and determined to make it to the Pacific Ocean, a trip through one of the rivers many hydroelectric dams is like a ride on a bad roller coaster with a giant blender thrown in for good measure. Severe pressure changes as the fish travels through the dam can leave it stunned and disoriented, easy prey for other fish and birds once it gets through. And the spinning turbine blades that power the electric generators can kill the fish.

title: Proceedings Are Consolidated In Federal Tire Recall Cases
description: A panel of federal judges decided today to consolidate in Indianapolis the pretrial proceedings in all but one of the 64 federal lawsuits against Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. and the Ford Motor Company involving the failure of Firestone tires on Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles.

title: E-Mail Bridges
description: To the Editor:

title: Strawberry Facing Charges That He Violated Probation
description: Darryl Strawberry was arrested yesterday on charges of violating his probation after he slipped out of a Tampa drug clinic and smoked crack cocaine and popped Xanax pills, Florida prison officials said.

title: Manhattan Realty Groups Are Close to Deal on Single Web Site for Listings, Executives Say
description: A heated rivalry among Manhattan real estate companies appears to have cooled down, with the city's smaller real estate concerns close to an agreement to merge their Web site with one planned for four of the city's largest brokerage companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECCO, SALVATORE
description: RECCO-Salvatore. Of Lansdale, formerly of New Britain Township, PA, died Tuesday, October 24, 2000 at his home; he was 74 years old. He was the devoted husband of Joan Kotchie Recco. Born in Queens, NY he was the son of the late Salvatore and Mary Picano Recco. Mr. Recco lived in New Britain Township for over 20 years. He was the owner and mechanic of a floor covering business for many years in Queens, NY. He also worked for the Byrne Stain Glass Co., in Doylestown. Sal was a very active member and volunteer for Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church. He was a member of the Sons of Italy Lodge, #

title: It's Up To Leiter To Keep Mets Alive
description: All of his nervous twitches and cartoonlike expressions aside, Al Leiter has repeatedly stood on the mound under the pressure of a postseason game, calmly reached back and thrown pitches that bent like question marks in front of one befuddled batter after another.

title: Talks Advance on Bill With Tax Relief and Increase in Minimum Wage
description: President Clinton and Congressional Republicans narrowed their differences today over a tax-cut package that includes relief for small businesses and an increase in the federal minimum wage, but significant hurdles still blocked final agreement.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Strangers in a Strange Land: Yankee Fans at Shea
description: The difference is obvious, although the sample is unscientific. Just listen. With the Mets and the Yankees playing in the all-New York World Series, there is more cheering for the visiting team when the games are at Shea Stadium than there is when the games are at Yankee Stadium.

title: SAN JOSE CLEARS CISCO COMPLEX
description: The networking giant Cisco Systems, Silicon Valley's biggest employer, received final government approval for a planned $1.3 billion corporate office complex to be built in a rural area south of San Jose, Calif. The expansion project, which calls for a 688-acre office park for 20,000 Cisco employees, was unanimously approved by the City Council, with one member abstaining because of a conflict of interest. The project was approved several weeks ago by the city planning commission. Cisco's proposal has been at the center of controversy in recent months because it will encroach on one of Silicon Valley's last rural tracts, known as Coyote Valley. To appease opponents of the plan, Cisco announced recently that it would donate $3 million and help raise $97 million more for land preservation efforts. But it remains unclear whether those steps will be enough to placate environmental opponents.

title: For Mets, Lots of Faith, Few Runs
description: There are two pieces of white paper taped above Edgardo Alfonzo's locker at Shea Stadium. Written on one are a few of the standard inspirational sports words: faith, passion, consistency, victory. On another is a passage from the Bible: ''Now faith is assurance of things hoped for, a conviction of things not seen.''

title: A 5-Year-Old's Life: Work and Play
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC INDUSTRY ARREST
description: The former president of Liquid Audio Japan, which licenses software technology from Liquid Audio of Redwood City, Calif., was arrested on suspicion that he abducted a colleague and held him captive, according to the police. The former executive, Masafumi Okanda, 32, who quit the Japanese company last month, is suspected of kidnapping a former director of the company and holding him captive for three days in June 1999. The police declined to identify the victim or to say what Mr. Okanda's motive might have been. Both Liquid Audio Japan and Liquid Audio provide secure music delivery systems for online music retail stores.

title: Martin Rich, 95, Who Conducted at the Met
description: Martin Rich, a conductor who enjoyed a 26-year association with the Metropolitan Opera and who worked alongside such eminent conductors as Herbert von Karajan, Bruno Walter and William Steinberg in music festivals around the world, died on Monday in New York. He was 95 and just the previous week had attended concerts at Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center.

title: Battling for Tennessee, Gore Attacks Bush on Education
description: Forced to campaign in his home state today, Vice President Al Gore framed his differences with Gov. George W. Bush of Texas on education by emphasizing his commitment to the public schools while criticizing Mr. Bush's proposals as ''half-measures'' and his Texas record as ''hollow.''

title: Filming in Iran's Rugged Corner, Hoping Prayer Works
description: When Bahman Ghobadi decided to make his first feature film and set it in his native Kurdistan in the northwest corner of Iran, he turned to his family for help. One brother became the production manager. Another became an assistant director. An older sister found suitable locations and mediated disputes on the set. Most important was Mr. Ghobadi's mother, who cooked hot meals for the cast and crew every day and visited her local mosque in times of crisis.

title: A Standpipe Bursts In Yankee Clubhouse
description: A standpipe in the visiting clubhouse at Shea Stadium burst during the game last night, so the Yankees' clubhouse was closed to the news media after the Yankees beat the Mets, 3-2, in Game 4 of the World Series.

title: $100 Million Voted for Serbia, but With War-Crimes Strings
description: Congress approved a $100 million aid package to Serbia today, but made it contingent on the new Yugoslav government's cooperation in apprehending those indicted on charges of war crimes, including the country's former president, Slobodan Milosevic.

title: A Museum Wing To Bear Witness To Jewish Life
description: In an expansion designed to more than triple its exhibition and teaching space, the Museum of Jewish Heritage: A Living Memorial to the Holocaust breaks ground today for a new wing at Battery Park City, across New York Harbor from the Statue of Liberty.

title: Clinton Almost Blames Arafat for Not Controlling Violence
description: President Clinton walked to the edge of blaming Yasir Arafat today for failing to rein in violence and offered some of his warmest praise of Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel, who he said was ''getting the worst of both worlds'' as he struggled to remain in power.

title: 'Face Time,' With a Twist
description: WITHIN days of the debut of his new Web site three weeks ago, James C. Hong managed to attract thousands of visitors. The response might have been more gratifying if only they had found him to be better-looking.

title: DAEWOO MOTOR TO LAY OFF MANAGERS
description: Daewoo Motor of South Korea said it would lay off 30 percent of its upper management as part of its reorganization plan. The move comes as Daewoo has been afflicted by liquidity problems after the Ford Motor Company withdrew from a takeover deal in September. About 40 members of the management staff will be affected by the layoffs, including 22 top-ranking officials, Daewoo said. It also said that it had failed to pay its employees this month. Daewoo will outline a restructuring plan by the end of the month and will adopt stronger reorganization measures starting in November in a bid to enhance profitability, it said. Creditor banks are currently negotiating with General Motors and Fiat of Italy to complete the sale of Daewoo Motor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, JOSEPHINE
description: WEINER-Josephine. The National Board of the National Council of Jewish Women is deeply saddened by the loss of a distinguished leader and dear friend, Josephine Stern Weiner. As NCJW President from 1967-1971 she set an extraordinary example by her dedication to improving the lives of women, children and families here and in Israel. During her presidency, NCJW published ''Windows on Daycare'' a groundbreaking study of the severe lack of quality, affordable childcare in the nation, and launched RIFIE, NCJW's Research Institute for Innovation in Education at Hebrew University. Under her leadership NCJW became a founding member of Women in Community Service (WICS), an interfaith coalition that finds meaningful employment for women living in poverty in urban centers. A respected civic leader in her hometown of Detroit, a series of lectures on volunteerism at Wayne State University bears her name. Jo's dynamic leadership and her loving kindness will remain an inspiration to NCJW and everyone she touched.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE INTEREST GROUPS

title: Kodak Camera Lets User Point, Shoot and Pick
description: With its smart, ergonomic styling and color L.C.D. screen in a button-studded back panel, the new Kodak Advantix Preview camera looks like another point-and-shoot that has gone thoroughly digital.

title: Quantum Leap May Transform Chips
description: FOR most microchip designers, quantum theory, which is usually applied to the behavior of atoms and subatomic particles, is something they would rather not think about for a while.

title: Embassy Bombing Suspects Try to Put American Courts on Trial
description: Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan told a defendant in the embassy bombings case this week, ''I really don't want to get into a debate with you about the American system of justice.''

title: Dirk J. Struik; Historian Was 106
description: Dr. Dirk Jan Struik, a prolific historian of mathematics who taught at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology from 1926 to 1960, died on Saturday at his home in Belmont, Mass. He was 106.

title: Shea Is Fine With Doubleday
description: When Nelson Doubleday, a Mets co-owner, looks around Shea Stadium, he sees two decades of warm memories that he would like to preserve. To do this, Doubleday said last night, he would raise the field, change the seats, reconfigure the third tier and create a ring of bleachers beyond the outfield fence.

title: DuPont Earnings Fall 14%; Pessimism This Quarter, Too
description: The DuPont Company said today that its third-quarter profit fell 14 percent and that profit in the fourth quarter would be hurt by a slowing economy and lower sales in its drug business.

title: An Agent's Role In the New Age
description: The noise from Hollywood, swaddled as it is in exuberant mumbo jumbo, is about agents for the stars also becoming their clients' managers, like a one-stop shopping mart. Isn't publishing about ready to enter the e-book, Internet era, in which new thoughts must be thought? Will the trend move east, and change the role of the literary agent? The author's agent as career planner? ''Hello, I'm Daniel Webster, Stephen Vincent Benet's career planner.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SESSA, FRANCIS X.
description: SESSA-Francis X. 0n Oct. 24, 2000. Funeral Director 55 yrs. Beloved husband of Catherine P., loving father of Peter and Jay. Dear brother of Robert J. (Fresno, CA), Papa-Cheech to Courtney, Dana, Peter, Reid & Samantha. Visiting Thursday, 7-9, Friday, 2-5, and 7-9, Jospeh V. Sessa Funeral Home, 6924 Ft. Hamilton Pkway, Mass of Christian burial, Saturday 10:15am at St. Ephrem Church. In lieu of flowers, donations to Poly Prep in Frank's memory appreciated.

title: Timberwolves Pay Dearly for Secret Contract
description: Imposing the harshest penalty ever levied by a major American professional sports league, the National Basketball Association fined the Minnesota Timberwolves $3.5 million yesterday and stripped the team of its first-round draft picks for the next five years for violating salary-cap rules.

title: Yugoslavia, Turning a Page, Is Expected to Rejoin United Nations
description: Yugoslavia will soon apply to join the United Nations, indicating a clear change in policy under its new president, Vojislav Kostunica, the American ambassador to the United Nations, Richard Holbrooke, said today after meeting with Balkan leaders.
