title: Recall Day Games? Well, Forget About It
description: As the No. 7 train from Shea Stadium pulled out after Game 3 of the World Series, a chorus of fans groused about returning home at 1 a.m. yesterday after a 3-hour-39-minute Mets victory.

title: Replacing Shoppers With Students
description: Mini-malls are in vast supply in Los Angeles, and there is a shortage of schools. Philip Lance, an Episcopal priest and director of Pueblo Nuevo Development, a community redevelopment organization, had a creative solution: turning a mall into a school. He enlisted a nonprofit school developer, EXED, as well as Paul Cummins, an expert in founding new schools, and hired the architects Daly Genik to create the newly opened Camino Nuevo Charter Academy, above. The architects transformed an 11,000-square-foot mini-mall, which had never opened, into a vibrant school building in the Rampart district with classrooms for 250 children, from kindergarten to fifth grade. They added new windows and doors and gave the building a bright splash of paint. An existing external balcony and stairs were transformed into a striking structure made of steel and a beige synthetic ''lumber'' made of recycled plastic and paper pulp. An entrance to underground parking was relocated, making way for more classrooms and a play area, and giving teachers their own parking area under the school, an important security issue in this low-income area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELLENBERGER JAMES ADAMSON
description: SHELLENBERGER James Adamson, recently of Reed's Landing, Springfield, MA, died Monday, October 23rd. Born on December 24, 1913, in Philadelphia, PA, Mr. Shellenberger was an editor of the Ladies Home Journal and The American Home Magazine during the 1950's. He later was a Senior Partner at Anna Rosenberg Associates in New York. Mr. Shellenberger worked as a consultant to Jujamcyn Theatres in his later life, and served as head of the National Corporate Theatre Fund for two years. Mr. Shellenberger was an avid orchid hobbyist, and served for several years on the Board of the American Horticultural Society. His wife, Ann Howard Shellenberger of Greenwich, CT, died in 1996. He is survived by five daughters: Mary S. Graves of Rowayton, CT; Frances Goode, of Pollock Pines, CA; Jane Shellenberger, of Boulder, CO; Susan Shellenberger of Belchertown, MA; and Ann S. Insalaco, of Scotland, CT, and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Saturday, October 28 at 10 AM at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168th Street, New York, New York 10032-9982.

title: MICROSOFT SETTLES WEBTV COMPLAINT
description: Microsoft's WebTV unit settled Federal Trade Commission charges that it misled consumers by saying its TV-based Internet browser gave viewers the same ability to surf the World Wide Web as computer users. In a settlement with the F.T.C., WebTV Networks Inc. agreed to distribute consumer-education brochures and advertising to correct any impression that the television-based Web browsing service provided the same access to the Internet that consumers could get with a personal computer. The Microsoft unit also agreed to reimburse some consumers for long-distance charges they did not expect to incur for connecting to the Internet by way of WebTV.

title: Essay; The Great Mentioning
description: Based on a few tips and heavy thumbsucking, here is a way to compare possible Bush and Gore administrations.

title: A Metaphor for B-Ball and V-Ball
description: The new Pacific Palisades Gymnasium for basketball and volleyball was designed by Stephen Kanner of Kanner Architects for the Los Angeles City Department of Recreation and Parks. Gym walls, above, are clad in gray and silver corrugated steel. Bathrooms and offices are contained in a corridor that wraps around the gym inside a wavy wall of glass blocks, right. The oval windows with criss-cross lines are metaphors for ''balls compressing against hard surfaces,'' Mr. Kanner said. Half of the $2 million budget was raised by the community, which has access to the building. The gym is in Palisades Park, off Alma Real Drive.

title: Craving Series Tickets? Gulping Hot Sauce Might Do the Trick
description: One man rented a wheelchair and coasted into the handicapped section at Yankee Stadium -- with nothing more serious than a broken foot. A roofing contractor guzzled a bottle of hot sauce and nearly threw up to score a ticket to Game 3 at Shea Stadium. A 13-year-old, open-mouthed and in the dental chair, made a bet with his orthodontist and won a pair of tickets to a Subway Series matchup.

title: Rivera & Co. Shut Door In 3-2 Nail-Biter at Shea
description: The Mets needed to build on the momentum of their Game 3 victory, but it didn't even last a single pitch in Game 4 of the Subway Series last night. Derek Jeter clubbed Bobby J. Jones's first offering of the game for a home run, giving the Yankees a lead they never relinquished, and now the Yankees are on the verge of another championship.

title: Poll Watch: Looking Beneath the Surface: Who Prefers Whom for President
description: Presidential candidates George W. Bush and Al Gore may currently be locked in a statistical tie in polls across the country, but beneath the surface, many groups of voters have taken clear sides, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: The Condo Board That Stole Halloween
description: THERE'S a noticeable lack of black widow spiders in a certain apartment building in Kips Bay. Skeletons, too.

title: Metro Business Briefing; ADVOCACY GROUPS WIN
description: Three workers' advocacy groups announced yesterday that Street Beat Sportswear, a women's clothing manufacturer, agreed this week to pay them $85,000 in legal fees and damages. That settlement came after a judge ruled that the company had filed an improper, retaliatory lawsuit against the three organizations.

title: Strahan-Runyan Battle Will Have Major Impact
description: Amani Toomer today called Philadelphia Eagles tackle Jon Runyan, with whom Toomer played at the University of Michigan, ''one mean guy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITKIN, JOYCE
description: WITKIN-Joyce. Beloved wife of Richard. Devoted and loving mother of Debra (Eliot) Zimbalist, Ken (Susan) Witkin. Cherished grandmother of Stephanie, Katie and Melissa, Cara and David. Devoted sister of Barbara Davis. Services will be held today, 11:30 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

title: The Minimalist's Table
description: Call it Melrose Heights. A section of town at the intersection of Melrose and Crescent Heights is emerging as a design destination. Among six stores in this area to open this month is Fitzsu Society, below, owned by Fitz and Su Sazama. Fitzsu sells contemporary housewares by Droog, Pure and Alessi, among others. Shown, Hackman cutlery by Antonio Citterio (from $24 to $79). Fitzsu Society is at 7970 Melrose Avenue, (323) 655-1908. Arp, above, is a few blocks away on West Third near Crescent Heights. It's a minimalist store selling delicate, hand-crafted pieces by four artisans: Alison Berger (whose glassware is shown, with prices ranging from $165 to $1,100), Ted Muehling, Gabriella Kiss and Vibe Harslof. Arp is owned by William Hermsen and Joany Lee, who were both formerly on staff at Dosa, a fashion and design company. Arp is at 8311 1/2 West Third Street; (323) 653-7764.

title: Gore Uses Scare Tactics, Bush Tells Florida Elderly
description: Gov. George W. Bush made an aggressive appeal to elderly voters in Florida today, pitching his plans for Social Security and Medicare as superior to Vice President Al Gore's and casting Mr. Gore's assertions to the contrary as blatant scare tactics.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Poverty, Paradox and a 'Dear Leader'
description: When Kim Il Sung, the father of the current leader of North Korea, founded the Communist Party here in the 1940's, educated North Koreans say that he had an uncommon piece of wisdom. Unlike the Russians and the Chinese, they say, Mr. Kim respected intellectuals and embraced them as true members of the North Korean party.

title: Gore, Devoted Father of a Football Player, Scoffs at Money, but Not Gimmicks
description: If Vice President Al Gore has failed to close the sale with some voters on policy grounds, like promising to put the Medicare surplus in a lockbox, he has now come up with a few new arguments.

title: The Great Unraveling: End of Oslo Era, With a Bang
description: To hear Ahmed Qurei declare the Oslo peace track all but dead is to realize how much has unraveled in the last few weeks.

title: Utah's Crime Mysteries Go Online
description: THE police in Utah have a new tool for solving cases of murder, missing persons and unidentified bodies: a Web site that provides statewide crime information for investigators and the public.

title: A 5-Year-Olds Life: Work and Play
description: To the Editor:

title: Piazza Is Down, In Games And Spirit
description: Mike Piazza remained seated in the dugout as Matt Franco looked at strike three from Mariano Rivera to end Game 4 last night. Piazza stayed there as Bobby Valentine walked by and patted his right knee, trying to comprehend how his first World Series could be one loss from ending.

title: Corporate Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Join Pack Trying to Recruit An Available Star
description: The Knicks have set their sights on the 6-foot-10-inch forward Joe Smith, whose contract with the Minnesota Timberwolves was voided today by the National Basketball Association, making him a free agent.

title: What's in a Game? A Use for a Gadget; Geocaching' Fills a Need: What to Do With All Those G.P.S. Units
description: EARLIER this month, Robert A. Casinghino took a walk in the woods. A student at Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., he had driven into the Dutchess County countryside in an old Chevrolet that he had borrowed from his parents. He was seeking the perfect place to leave a two-gallon paint bucket with a modest treasure trove: a waterproof brass match case, a few packages of field rations, a set of camping utensils, a log book and a pencil.

title: Home Resales Dropped 2.7% In September
description: Sales of previously owned homes fell last month to a pace that still shows the economy has not lost much of its vigor, industry figures showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ALEXANDER N.
description: WOLF-Alexander N. Belove d husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Stephen (Anne) and James. Loving brother of Mae Levin. Adored grandfather of Erica, Hillary and Scott. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANAU, KENNETH J. JR.
description: HANAU-Kenneth J. Jr. The world was a better place for having you as a part of it. We are better people for having had the privilege of being your friends. We will remember you and miss you. Helaine and Fred

title: Trying to Touch the Top Untouchable on the Web
description: UNDER ''hubris,'' the dictionary ought to say, ''See Eliot Ness,'' Al Capone's archenemy, immortalized on television and on film in ''The Untouchables.'' But to appreciate the full weight of his pride-punished-by-the-gods tragedy, the place to look is not Chicago, but Cleveland. That is where Ness, the highly (some said over- and self-) glorified gangbuster, moved after the Capone years and where his career began a long slide.

title: SWISS WIRELESS AUCTION CANCELED
description: Switzerland's communications regulator said it had canceled a planned auction of GSM mobile telephone licenses and, instead, will sell the frequencies to three existing operators. The auction had been postponed initially because two of the operators, One.Tel Global Wireless Holdings and Telenor Communications, dropped out of the bidding. That left only Swisscom, Orange Communications and Diax, the three companies that provide mobile service in Switzerland, to bid on the three licenses. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Bioengineered Corn Reportedly Detected in Japan
description: A Japanese consumer group said today that bioengineered corn not approved for human consumption had made its way from the United States into cornmeal manufactured here.

title: Jets Play Catch-Up With Style And Frenzy
description: Do not look for a Jets player among the league leaders for quarterback, receiver, running back, sacks or interceptions. The Jets are not ranked among the top offensive or defensive teams, either. There is only one place in a sea of statistics where one can easily find the Jets: atop the American Conference East.

title: PlayStation 2: Game Console as Trojan Horse
description: EVAN LEVINE and Oliver Barrett, both 14, buzzed around a video game store in their Upper West Side neighborhood earlier this week with the unmistakable ease bred by countless visits. On this afternoon stop, the boys, self-proclaimed gamers, kept finding themselves drawn to a wall display of shrink-wrapped video games and accessories designed for the PlayStation 2, Sony's new version of its popular game console that goes on sale today.

title: Prosecutors Say Two Detectives Were Couriers For Drug Ring
description: Two decorated New York City police detectives and a retired officer were charged yesterday with ferrying cocaine, heroin and drug money across the country for a Washington Heights drug lord, the authorities said.

title: A Real Bid for Immortality From a Hall of Fame Player
description: If asked to identify the most remarkable bid in the history of the game, it is likely that a panel of knowledgeable experts would select the final action in the diagramed deal. It was played almost half a century ago, and the hero was Sidney Lazard of New Orleans, long one of the country's brightest stars. In Anaheim, Calif., in August, he was inducted into the American Bridge League's Hall of Fame, and the episode was recalled by his regular partner, Bart Bramley.

title: Brown Brothers Makes Offer on Site in Battery Park City
description: Brown Brothers Harriman & Company and a developer have made an offer to buy control of a site in Battery Park City where the bank plans to build a new waterfront headquarters.

title: Trying to Make Package Delivery As Easy as Shopping Online
description: Shopping online is usually the easy part: point, click, credit-card number. It's the arrival of the purchases that can be less than convenient, especially if one doesn't happen to be home when the packages arrive.

description: For Nets point guard Stephon Marbury, these are the dog days of fall. Marbury has not gone full speed this preseason, assuming that nothing counts until opening night, Oct. 31.

description: Congressional negotiators said today that they had reached a tentative agreement that would avert threatened cuts in Medicaid payments to hospitals and other health care providers in New York, Illinois and a few other states.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SVIRIDOFF, MITCHELL
description: SVIRIDOFF-Mitchell. Arg us Community mourns the passing of Mitchell Sviridoff, a longtime member of the Argus Board of Directors, a wise counselor and a true friend. Our board and staff extend condolences to his wife Doris, his daughters Karen and Michelle, and his extended family. He will be grievously missed.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Friday with an obituary of Art Coulter, a former National Hockey League player, was misidentified by The Associated Press and published in error. It showed Murray (Muzz) Patrick, Mr. Coulter's New York Ranger teammate. The obituary also omitted four survivors. In addition to Mr. Coulter's brother, Tom, of Chicago, he is survived by a son, Art, of Miami; a daughter, Patricia Mundy, of Metuchen, N.J.; and two grandchildren.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Pittsburgh and Erie, Pa., and Toledo, Ohio

title: Morgan Stanley Fires Bond Trader Who Filed Bias Complaint
description: A bond trader at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter who has accused the firm of sexual discrimination filed additional complaints with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission yesterday, accusing Morgan Stanley of firing her on Tuesday in retaliation for her complaints.

title: CBS Agrees to Settle Discrimination Suit
description: CBS has agreed to pay $8 million to about 200 of its female technicians who said in a class-action lawsuit that they had been sexually harassed and discriminated against at six CBS stations.

title: IVAX PROFIT ROSE 82% IN QUARTER ON GENERIC DRUG SALES
description: The Ivax Corporation said its third-quarter profit rose a better-than-expected 82 percent, as demand increased for generic drugs and the company's own higher-profit brand-name medicines. Ivax, which is based in Miami, said net income rose to $30.7 million, or 19 cents a share, from profit from operations of $16.9 million, or 11 cents, a year earlier. The company was expected to earn 15 cents a share, the average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Sales rose 12 percent, to $182.4 million from $163.3 million. Increased demand for Ivax's chronic-ailment and respiratory medicines and proprietary products like its Easi-Breathe asthma inhalers in Europe, as well as a ''favorable'' tax structure, drove earnings higher, said Dr. Phillip Frost, its chairman and chief executive.

title: In Cosmic Baseball, the Subway Can Swing a Bat
description: THE baseball playoffs are over. Behind the veteran pitcher Charles Manson, the Psychedelphia Woodstockings defeated the Speed City Velocitors and their star second baseman, the Apollo 11 command module, in the decisive fifth game. The Woodsox are now likely to face Cyd Charisse, the Paradise Pisces' high-kicking hurler, when the Universal Series opens on Nov. 23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSON, DR. SIDNEY L.
description: OLSON-Dr. Sidney L. We mourn the loss of a true Ba'al Chesed in the world of Jewish and general philanthropy. As a Benefactor of the Medical Center, together with his wife, Miriam, his outstretched hand of kindness made an invaluable contribution to the people of Jerusalem and Israel. His exceptional efforts at chairing the fund-raising activities of the Shaare Zedek Southeast Region will always be cherished, as well as the personal friendship that he developed with each and every one on the Board. An Honorary Life Member of the International Board of Governors, he demonstrated a deep commitment to the Hospital. His presence added a great measure of prestige to the Board and his wise counsel was respected. Sidney personified the highest values of Jewish tradition and ethics which were the hallmarks of his life. Our sincerest condolences to his daughter, Dr. Arlene Olson-Muravchick, his son, Norman Olson and the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Medical Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLAS, FRED J.
description: NICHOLAS-Fred J., 5 5, passed away October 24, 2000. He is survived by his wife, Jill Nicholas; daughters, Debra Suied and husband Albert, Sabrina Ewart, Ashley Ewart; and his mother, Dulcie Nicholas. A Memorial Service will be held at 2 P.M., Friday, October 27, 2000 at J.B. Earthman-Tanglewood Chapel, 5740 San Felipe at Bering; Rev. Dan Danford, officiating. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to the National Colo Rectal Research Alliance, 11132 Ventura Blvd., Ste. 401, Studio City, CA. 91604

title: Playful and Painful Contrasts As China Meets Mississippi
description: ''Tree,'' the second work in a dance trilogy by the experimental choreographer Ralph Lemon, ends with a magical moment at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Harvey Theater. Robert Johnson, a blues singer, is heard on an old recording as Li Wen Yi, a farmer and folk musician from China, sits on a bench and vocalizes the tune in his own way.

title: A Tough No-Decision for Neagle
description: When Denny Neagle walked off the mound in Shea Stadium last night, he may have been making his last appearance as a starting pitcher for the Yankees. If so, it must have been a bittersweet moment for Neagle, who becomes a free agent after this World Series. Certainly his removal was a bold and cold decision by Joe Torre, his manager, and it was a maneuver that worked out well.

title: Peace Corps, Geeks Corps
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; Looking at Poverty, Seeing Untapped Riches
description: The outskirts of third-world cities today are vast jumbles of tin, concrete and misery. Practically every large city in Latin America, Asia and Africa is ringed with settlements of migrants from the countryside. These migrants claim their plots in nighttime land invasions, living under blankets and poles while stockpiling materials for better housing. They establish threadbare small businesses selling fruit or cobbling shoes for their equally impoverished neighbors. And all this takes place outside the margin of the law.

title: A Threat to Irish Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: A TV Space Opera Becomes a Video Game
description: THE television series ''Star Trek Voyager'' seems an odd choice as the basis for an action game because there is little action on the show itself. Characters endlessly discuss what they should do and make speeches about what they will do but not much is ever actually done.

title: 2 Motormen Are Injured In Collision Of No. 4 Trains
description: Two subway trains with no passengers aboard collided on the elevated No. 4 tracks in the Bronx last night, injuring both motormen, one of them seriously, the authorities said.

title: 83 Dead in Russian Military Plane Crash
description: BATUMI, Georgia -- At least 83 people were killed when a Russian military plane crashed into a mountain in western Georgia, Russian military officials said Thursday. The Defense Ministry plane was en route from the Chkalovsky military airfield near Moscow and was attempting to land in harsh weather at a Russian military base near Georgia's Black Sea port of Batumi when it crashed on Wednesday night. Rescuers reaching the crash site about 15 miles east of Batumi found pieces of the plane and scorched earth. Rescuers on Thursday recovered the plane's black box, or flight recorder, the Interfax news agency reported, but had not yet determined the cause of the crash. "Rain was falling, the plane was in pieces, and everything was on fire," said officer Kakha Beridze of the Georgian Ministry of Emergency Situations, whose team arrived about three hours after the crash. "There was no one to save, they were all dead." Alexander Drobyshevsky, an air force spokesman in Moscow, said that at least 72 passengers and 11 crew members were aboard, and that all were presumed dead. However, he said that there were discrepancies between the passenger manifest and the list of people who had cleared customs in Moscow, so there could have been more people on board. The flight was carrying Russian servicemen and their families. Georgian President Eduard Shevardnadze's spokesman, Kakha Imnadze, said that seven children were on board, including a 9-month-old infant. Russian media reported eight children aboard. The cause of the crash was not immediately known. Drobyshevsky said the plane had "violated the flight altitude." And the head of the Georgian civil aviation agency, Alexander Silagadze, said that the plane had veered off course on approach in "difficult weather conditions." Another official from the Georgian agency, Zurab Chankotadze, told The Associated Press that the radar tracking the plane had shown that the pilot did not make the final turn necessary for approaching the landing strip. "It is so far hard to say whether it was a mistake by the pilot or navigator, or whether the cause was difficult weather conditions," Chankotadze said. A witness told Russia's ORT television that the plane had been in flames before hitting the mountain. After the crash, three explosions could be heard, witnesses told AP. Russian military officials said the plane, an Il-18 transport, was at an altitude of 5,300 feet when communications with it were lost, the Interfax news agency reported. It crashed 4,265 feet up the mountain, Georgian Emergency Situations Ministry officials said. Rescue workers said Thursday morning that they had found fragments of just three bodies, but that many more could be scattered over a wide area. Shevardnadze arrived in Batumi about midday Thursday. He had spoken by telephone with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin, and the two agreed to launch a joint investigation, Imnadze. Although Georgia became an independent country after the 1991 Soviet collapse, Russia still maintains military bases there. Russia is in the process of removing its troops and equipment from two bases in Georgia, and is negotiating withdrawal from two more. Equipment from the bases is being shipped through Batumi. Il-18 planes, which can seat up to 100, first flew in 1957. Production ceased in 1970. The planes were used by the Russian military as a submarine hunter and airborne command post, and as a passenger plane by the Soviet national airline Aeroflot.

title: Using Baseball Talk As an Opening Verse
description: A good day for a Mormon missionary is when only a third of the doors you knock on get slammed in your face. There are not many good days during a Subway Series.

description: SHMELKA-Jean. Last eight years have been very lonely years. Wow! Do we miss you. Rob & Dee

title: FRANKLIN IS IN $825 MILLION DEAL FOR MONEY MANAGER
description: Franklin Resources, the operator of the Franklin, Templeton and Mutual Series mutual fund groups, announced a deal yesterday to acquire Fiduciary Trust for $825 million in an all-stock transaction. The new company will manage assets of more than $280 billion. Charles B. Johnson, chairman and chief executive of Franklin, said the deal would combine ''complementary'' businesses. ''Franklin has been primarily a retail operation and Fiduciary has been primarily an institutional operation,'' he said. Franklin, based in San Mateo, Calif., is the No. 8 manager of mutual funds. Fiduciary Trust of New York manages about $50 billion for wealthy and institutional clients. Danny Hakim (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, GEORGE J.
description: COLLINS-George J. A s chool designer and education planner who surveyed, analyzed and designed over 500 schools world wide, died on October 22 in Hollywood, FL. He was 79. He remained active in his profession up to the time of his death. Dr. Collins was born in New Haven, CT, on April 20, 1921. He was raised by his mother, Alice Mursko, and his grandparents, Ameilia and Louis Mursko. He attended local New Haven schools, graduating from Hillhouse High School in 1939 where he captained the basketball team and was active in school sports. Prior to World War II, he served as a foreman at Chance Vought building navy fighters. He reported to Fort Benning, GA where he entered his OCS and became a ''90-day-wonder'', later serving in Europe as a 2nd Lieutenant in the Infantry with the Third Army under Patton. He captained the Third Army basketball and baseball teams to championships after the war ended. He was a career Army Reservist who switched to medical corps before the outbreak of the Korean War and later held the rank of Colonel. He loved the U.S. Army and the opportunities it provided. After a short career in professional basketball where he owned the local New Haven team, he took advantage of the G.I. Bill and, at 28, entered New Haven State Teachers College. He earned a B.S. degree with high honors, majoring in math, while holding down two part-time jobs. He continued to pursue a career as an educator, obtaining a M.A. from Yale University in psychology and an Ed.D. from Teachers College Columbia University where he won a twoyear fellowship. His dissertation included a comprehensive study of the Summit, New Jersey School System. Dr. Collins' early education positions included ''Master Teaching'' with Southern Connecticut University, Assistant Superintendant for Business at Hartsdale, NY, Professor and Director of Planning at the University of New Mexico. In 1962, Dr. Collins came to the U.S. Office of Education in Washington, D.C. where in 1965, he authored The Higher Ed ucation Facilities Act for President Johnson. While in Washington, he earned a Juris Doctor from George Washington University School of Law. His law degree was instrumental in helping him win over numerous city councils and legislators as he championed education facilities, first as Associate Commissioner of Education for Massachusetts, and later as President of his own companyGeorge Collins Educational Associates, Inc. His school building studies and surveys include more than 500 projects throughout the Commonwealth, as well as U.S. State Department Schools in more than 68 overseas schools including: Warsaw, Prague, Budapest, Panama, Costa Rica, Honduras, San Salvador, Athens, Barcelona, Madrid, Milan, Lesetho, Lusoka, Eritrea, Moscow. ''His strategic plans in Rome helped save the Marymount School. In Milan, Dr. Collins was credited with saving the former Chase Bank Library for use as the American School. He introduced high-tech innovations and insisted on CNN channels of communication in U.S. schools throughout the world as a tool to keep students current on world affairs and to spread democracy,'' according to his close friend, Dr. Sal J. Rinaldi, Diplomat in Residence at Florida Atlantic University. Dr. Collins returned to Washington as Special Assistant to the Commanding General at U.S. Army Corp of Engineers for a short stint in 1980. Locally, Dr. Collins played on several teams in the West Haven Twilight League where he is a ''Gold Bat'' recipient. In Branford, West Haven, and Hollywood, FL, Dr. Collins was knows in later years for his deft touch on the tennis court and ''shooting the eyes out of the basket'' with his radar-like one and two-handed set shots. Dr. Collins authored to high school textbooks-''An Introduction to Nuclear Physics'' and ''The Challenge of Understanding Your Laws''. Dr. Collins is survived by his wife of 61 years, Orien; two sons, George, Jr. of Gibson Island, MD, and Robert D. of Madison, CT; six grandchildren, George B. of Stamford, CT, David of Greenwich, CT, Jonathan of Miami, FL, Derek of Baltimore, MD, Justin of Boston, MA, and Courtney of Madison, CT; and seven great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory should be directed to: George J. Collins Scholarship at Southern Connecticut State University, Teachers College Columbia University or National YMCA. Viewing will be at the West Haven Funeral Home on Thursday, October 26 from 4-8PM. A mass will be celebrated on Friday, October 27 at 11AM, at St. John Vianney in West Haven, CT.

title: MATSUSHITA TO CUT WORK FORCE IN WALES
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan, the world's largest maker of consumer electronics, said it planned to cut about 40 percent of the work force at its Panasonic plant in Cardiff, Wales, where the pound's strength against the euro has eroded profitability. Matsushita, based in Osaka, said it would eliminate 700 of the 1,800 permanent jobs early next year through voluntary resignations. The plant exports televisions and other appliances throughout Europe. Matsushita Electric is the second large Japanese manufacturer to announce job cuts in Wales this month to cope with the weaker euro. The Sony Corporation the world's No. 2 maker of home electronic appliances, said last week that it would eliminate 400 manufacturing jobs in the region.

title: Looking Forward, Now and Then
description: Futuristic buildings with names like Backslash and Stealth (above) have emerged in Culver City in the last decade. Designed by the architect Eric Owen Moss and occupied by high-tech and film production companies, the complex is open for a walking tour ($65) on Sunday as a fund-raiser for the MAK Center for Art and Architecture. Information: (323) 651-1510.

title: Jeter Takes Out Shea Fans Right Off
description: Shea Stadium was buzzing in the afterglow of the Mets' first victory of the World Series on Tuesday night when Derek Jeter was introduced as the leadoff hitter for the Yankees last night. Jeter was oblivious to the rowdy energy around him. His attention was on his good buddy sitting behind home plate, Seattle shortstop Alex Rodriguez.

title: So Bewitched, Why, He Feels Almost Human
description: MERRICK

title: Every Game System Needs At Least One Great Game
description: BEHIND every great new game system is at least one great game. On the Sega Saturn, it was Panzer Dragoon. On the Sony PlayStation, it was Ridge Racer. The Nintendo 64 had Super Mario World, and the Sega Dreamcast had NFL 2000.

title: Princesses of Prints
description: THE Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology was overflowing with happy faces last week at the opening of ''A Woman's Hand: Designing Textiles in America, 1945-1969.'' Forty designers are represented in the show. Many of them are being honored for the first time, although their designs are well known.

title: Good Book Bargains Harder to Come By
description: THE main difference between Pavlov's dog and me is that the dog did not have a customer password at Amazon.com. I, on the other hand, have been conditioned by dozens of comforting visits to Amazon, where I am reliably greeted with a familiar salutation: ''Hello, M. Slatalla. We have recommendations for you.''

title: An all-out effort is under way to market an artificial sweetener.
description: WORLD of home-baked coconut pie, made without sugar? That is among the promises that the marketers of Splenda, an artificial sweetener generically known as sucralose, are making through a large-scale campaign that began last month and will peak in January with a series of television commercials intended to create consumer interest in the product.

title: Threat of Unconventional Terrorism Is Overstated, Study Says
description: The threat of terrorism involving chemical and germ weapons has been highly exaggerated, and much of the federal government's response to this small, but growing challenge is wasteful and ill-conceived, according to a new study of the administration's domestic emergency preparedness programs by a Washington-based research center.

title: A Top Deputy Admits Using Office for Gain
description: The top deputy at the city's Human Resources Administration, following the lead of his boss, has admitted that he violated the city conflict of interest laws and has agreed to pay a $8,500 fine.

title: ASTRAZENECA LOWERS SALES ESTIMATE
description: Shares of AstraZeneca of Britain fell after the company lowered estimates for full-year sales and said its Losec ulcer medicine was facing growing competition in the United States. AstraZeneca reported operating profit for the third quarter of $976 million, including exceptional items, compared with $949 million last year. Sales grew 3 percent, to $4.3 billion. Tom McKillop, chief financial officer, said in a statement that sales for the year would grow about 8 percent, below the 10 percent analysts had been expecting. AstraZeneca's results are in contrast to those of Sanofi-Synthelabo of France, which said third-quarter sales jumped 14 percent; and Akzo Nobel of the Netherlands, which reported a 36 percent rise in sales for the period. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS TO NEW LOW. The euro sank to a record as traders speculated that chances are fading that central banks will prop up the currency. In New York, the euro settled at 82.81 cents, down from 83.72 cents on Tuesday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Charles Rembar, 85, Dies; Lawyer Fought Censorship
description: Charles Rembar, who fought and won some of the most important censorship cases in American law, died Tuesday in the Bronx. He was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLAIMAN, DON
description: SLAIMAN-Don. The Officers, Members and Staff of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union mourn the loss of Don Slaiman, a great friend of working people, a leader in the battle for civil rights in this country and a fighter for justice throughout the world. Don Slaiman believed in the rights of all workers to be treated with dignity, justice and respect, and devoted his life to advancing their cause. People throughout the world have been touched by his integrity and commitment. We will miss him greatly. Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union UFCW, AFL-CIO, CLC Stuart Appelbaum, President Charlie N. Hall, Sr. Secretary-Treasurer Lenore Miller, President Emeritus

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Xerox's reorganization plans misstated the relationship between the company and Tektronix, which makes testing and measurement devices. Xerox bought Tektronix's color printer business this year, not the entire company.

title: Yanks Push Mets Towards the Edge
description: Not much time has elapsed since Timo Perez and Edgardo Alfonzo auditioned for their roles as the Mets' Dynamic Duo. In Game 4 of the National League Championship Series against St. Louis, Perez and Alfonzo, the first two batters in the lineup, drilled two of the five doubles the Mets hit in the first inning. In Game 5, they stroked successive singles in the first inning, propelling the Mets to a quick 3-0 lead.

title: In New Jersey, Corzine or Franks?
description: To the Editor:

title: Viacom Net Falls but Not as Much as Feared
description: Viacom said yesterday that it had net income of $33.4 million, or 2 cents a share, for the third quarter of 2000. Though the figure was down sharply from the third quarter of 1999, when the company reported profits of $96.7 million, or 16 cents a share, the latest results came as a positive surprise to analysts, who had expected a small loss for the quarter.

title: Pentagon Aide Quits; Warnings Ignored, He Says
description: A Pentagon intelligence analyst resigned one day after terrorists bombed the destroyer Cole in Yemen, protesting that his superiors had ignored his warnings of an imminent threat to American forces in the region, senators and defense officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about presidential election polls misstated the dates covered by Newsweek's latest one. It was taken last Wednesday through Friday, not through Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUHN, LENORE ''SUNNIE.''
description: KUHN-Lenore ''Sunnie.'' October 24th, 2000. Beloved wife of Leo. Loving mother of Bobby and his wife Rona and Jimmy and his wife Marjorie. Cherished Nana of Joseph, Carly, Justin, Jake and Remy. Devoted sister of Phyllis Alpert and the late Buddy Brode, and aunt of Barbara Alpert. Funeral Service Thursday October 26, 2000, 9:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St.

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: An Appeal From a Spouse
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the Lazio campaign began broadcasting statewide yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Mets Seem Outsiders In This Showdown
description: THIS was in late March, when Benny Agbayani heard rumors he might be sent down. He was with the Mets in Japan, a long way from home for most of the players but close to the Pacific center of Agbayani's soul.

title: Major Chaos In the World Of the Oddly Named
description: Animated by a spirit of whimsy, characters with names like Finola Cornflakes, Granny Gee and Dr. Disposio enliven Neena Beeber's new comedy ''Hard Feelings.'' The props include a pair of pale green bunny slippers and a revolver. Recognizable problems abound -- self-realization, self-image, unhappy love affairs, senile dementia, child custody and career choices among them.

title: AT&T Realigns Its Planets
description: If only AT&T worked as hard at telecommunications engineering as it does at financial engineering, maybe investors would treat it with more respect. The newest breakup of AT&T is a desperate effort to make Wall Street happy, something the company seems to think it can accomplish by dishing out lots of investment banking fees while reducing dividends paid to its shareholders.

title: Fugitive Arrested in Austria After a Year on the Run
description: A year after he jumped bail, a Brooklyn-born businessman who was sentenced in absentia to 845 years in prison for his role in an immense insurance fraud scheme was arrested Tuesday afternoon in Austria.

title: In America; At Last, the Issues
description: Lesson number one: Be careful what you wish for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NYE, JOSEPH PAINTER JR.
description: NYE-Joseph Painter Jr. On October 24, 2000 at his residence in Alexandria, VA. Beloved husband of Cheryl Dunigan Nye of Alexandria, VA. Father of Sarah, Jessica and Molly Nye of Alexandria, VA. and Summer Hinshaw and son-inlaw Todd Hinshaw of Alexandria, VA. Brother of Patricia Allee and brother-in-law of Charles P. Allee of Los Angeles, CA. Uncle of Susan, Chip and John Allee. Son-inlaw of Henry Ford Dunigan of Petersburg, W.VA.Memorial services will be held on Friday, October 27, 2000 at the St. Mary's Catholic Church, 310 So. Royal St., Alexandria, VA at 10AM. Interment private. Memorial contributions may be made in his name to the Inova Mt. Vernon Hospital Bridge Rehabilitation Program in c/o Dr. Ali Ganjei, 2501 Parkers Lane, Alexandria, VA. 22306. For more information contact Demaine Funeral Home, 703-549-0074.

title: Economic Scene; Are Bush and Gore flip-flopping over how to manage the economy?
description: JUST after the political conventions this summer, it looked as if America had a clear-cut choice about how the economy should be managed. About $2.7 trillion of the projected $4.6 trillion in surpluses over the next 10 years are estimated to be generated by Social Security and Medicare. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas favored giving most of the rest -- some $1.3 trillion -- back to Americans in the form of a tax cut.

title: Rough Play Is Out
description: The Big East, long known for its bruising style, used yesterday's media day as a forum to discuss the impact of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's new emphasis on eliminating rough play. It's very necessary because the game has not been called the way the rules are written, St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis said. Rafael Hermoso

title: Rodriguez Takes Good Look
description: Among the fans in Shea Stadium last night was one Alex Rodriguez, a resident of Miami, who may indeed be shopping for a new place of employment before the next baseball season.

title: Third Party, Mainstream Hopes
description: As Election Day approaches with the major candidates in a dead heat, Democratic denunciations of Ralph Nader supporters grow louder and more bitter. We are accused of disloyalty and irresponsibility, of ignoring the differences between the candidates and of being willing to throw the election to George W. Bush so that we can indulge in a meaningless gesture. Or, on the assumption that Nader supporters are all of the upper middle class, we are mocked for having the ''luxury'' of contributing to a Republican victory for which the vulnerable poor will suffer.

title: Nassau Legislators Ready To Vote on Fiscal Bailout
description: At last, after weeks of political sparring, backroom maneuvering and last-minute policy reversals by both Democrats and Republicans, the Nassau County Legislature expects to vote Thursday on a four-year fiscal rescue plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, MORTIMER A.
description: SHAPIRO-Mortimer A. At 84, died peacefully at his home. A life well led. Beloved husband of Mimi. Father of Sylvia and David. Grandfather of Luke, Nathan, Lily and Hazel. Dearest friend, colleague and drinking partner of many. Code-breaker and veteran of the Aleutian Campaign in his youth. Practiced the art of law in New York for over 60 years. Mentor and partner of Sylvia for over 20 years. His memory will be cherished by all who knew him. Morty, order yourself a martini with a side of ice. There's plenty tonight. If you wish to pay condolences you may stop by 40 East 84 St., Apt. 17B, 3:00 to 7:00 PM today.

title: If City Worker Has Conflict, She's Watching
description: CHEATS have always driven Joan R. Salzman crazy. She's 43 now, yet there's no missing the flush of adolescent pique undermining her veneer of grown-up makeup as she thinks back to grade school and the earth science classmate who cheated her way to good test marks whenever the teacher's back was turned.

title: IRISH ECONOMY GROWS
description: Ireland's gross domestic product in the first quarter of the year increased 11.7 percent compared with the first quarter of 1999, according to a government report. Gross national product, which includes the many multinational investments in Ireland, increased 8.8 percent versus the same period. Consumer spending increased 9.6 percent, and investments in new buildings and capital equipment rose 16.6 percent. The results coincided with a warning from a Harvard economics professor Michael Porter, who was speaking in Cork, that the Irish economy faced stagnation because of a lack of innovation in indigenous industry. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Arms Deal Tied to Gore Is Called Within Law
description: State Department officials told Congress today that a 1995 deal approved by Vice President Al Gore allowing Russia to sell a large cache of conventional weapons to Iran was legal and did not threaten American security.

title: Whose Jolly Old Elf Is That, Anyway?; Literary Sleuth Casts Doubt on the Authorship of an Iconic Christmas Poem
description: Every Christmas for more than 150 years, children have hung their stockings by the chimney with care and learned to thank Clement Clarke Moore for the tradition.

title: Tiny Changes, Big Ideas In AOL's Version 6.0
description: If this is October, there must be a new America Online. AOL 6.0 for Windows became available yesterday for downloading by the service's 23 million members. (A Macintosh version is scheduled for next year.) The new software offers a long list of tiny improvements, a reworked toolbar and progress toward the company's goal of offering its members all AOL, all the time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPCHIK, ABRAHAM RABBI
description: KUPCHIK-Abraham Rabbi. The Officers and Members of Temple Beth El of Long Beach mourn the untimely passing of our beloved Rabbi Abraham Kupchik. We extend our sincerest condolences to his dear wife Evelyn, children and grandchildren. Harry Brown, President Sidney Smith, Chair of Board

title: Candy-Coated Airtime For Teenagers
description: Now, a new enticement to extract cash from teenagers. The Kode cell phone, above, allows up to six people to talk simultaneously. Teens can also access their e-mail and a personalized Web site through voice commands or a display screen. The phone system was created by Talking Drum, an Oakland-based business, which describes itself as a ''lifestyle communication company.'' The Kode phone, which needs to be programmed by a computer, will be available in Sacramento on Friday and elsewhere next year. From $29.95 to $69.50 a month, depending on airtime. Information (510) 250-5633.

title: Metro Business Briefing; OXFORD'S PROFITS ROBUST
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc., one of the biggest New York-area health insurers, said third-quarter profit almost tripled as it cut expenses, worked with doctors to control medical costs and raised premiums.

title: INSIDE
description: Bombing Inquiry in Yemen

title: CORNING'S PIRELLI DEAL CLEARS F.T.C.
description: Corning, the world's biggest maker of fiber optic cables, said United States antitrust authorities had cleared its $3.6 billion acquisition of Pirelli S.p.A.'s optical components unit. Corning said the Federal Trade Commission had declined to conduct a more extensive review of the company's purchase of Pirelli's 90 percent stake in Optical Technologies USA of Delaware. Corning, seeking to meet spiraling demand for fiber optic systems to handle Internet traffic, has spent billions of dollars this year in acquisitions to expand its capacity to produce components that speed light signals through telecommunications networks. Shares of Corning fell $13, to $77.

title: Conoco Norwegian Deal
description: Conoco, one of the largest oil companies in the United States, agreed to buy a 6.4 percent interest in a North Sea oil field from Norway's Statoil for about $60 million to bolster its output in the region. The acquisition by the Conoco's Norwegian affiliate, Norske Conoco, in the sea's Grane Field reserve will add more than 13,000 barrels of oil to its daily production. Conoco said it expected to close the Grane Field acquisition in the first quarter of 2001.

title: TELEFONICA WILL SELL PART OF MOBIL UNIT
description: Telefonica said it planned to sell as much as 12 percent of its mobile-phone unit in an initial offering expected to raise $5 billion, pushing ahead even after European phone shares have fallen by a third since March. Telefonica, the largest phone company in Spain, is selling shares in Telefonica Moviles to finance the 6 billion euros ($5 billion) of wireless permits it bought in Spain, Germany and Italy. Its Ipse 2000 venture won the Italian license this week for 2.44 billion euros, about half the expected price. European phone shares have been hurt by concerns about the $300 billion that is being spent for permits and networks to offer fast wireless services.

title: Yemen Reports Arrests of Foreign-Born Arabs in Cole Attack
description: President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen said today that ''preliminary investigations'' indicated that at least one of the two men who reportedly carried out a suicide bombing attack on the destroyer Cole was an Egyptian and that an unspecified number of ''Yemenis, Egyptians, Algerians'' and other foreign-born Arabs had been detained on suspicion of assisting in the attack.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAMUELS, HOWARD J.
description: SAMUELS-Howard J. 10/26/84. To my heart you carried the key. My man-for all seasons. See you, partner-BBF

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENSCH, CONSTANC E (NEE GIOBBE)
description: MENSCH - Constanc e (nee Giobbe). On Oct. 22, 2000. Beloved wife of Homer. Loving sister of Susan Dull. Dear cousin of Gloria Ficalora. President of the Board of Trustees, The Dalcroze School of Music, President of The Bohemians, Chairman of the Young Artists' Committee of the Musicians' Club of New York. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9 PM with service Thursday, 1:30 PM. Interment to follow at Mount Saint Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Dalcroze School of Music, or the Musicians' Foundation of the Musicians' Club of New York.

title: Independents and the Elderly Lift Gore in Florida, Poll Says
description: Vice President Al Gore is showing considerable strength in Florida among elderly and independent voters and is seen as more likely than his opponent to reduce the cost of health care and prescription drugs and protect the environment, a New York Times/CBS News poll shows.

title: Comparing Social Security Proposals
description: With the population about to get decidedly older and the nation enjoying a moment of prosperity, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush agree that now is the time to put Social Security on sound footing for generations to come.

title: HALLIBURTON SHARES FALL 12% ON PROFIT REPORT
description: Shares of Halliburton fell 12 percent a day after it said that third-quarter revenue at its engineering and construction businesses declined 21 percent. Shares fell $5.13, to $37.06, in trading of 25.3 million, more than eight times the three-month daily average. The drop trimmed $2 billion from Halliburton's market value and put the stock down 7.9 percent for the year. The oil-services company said that third-quarter earnings more than doubled, to $109 million.

title: China Says Huge Dam Project Is Going Smoothly
description: Stung by torrents of criticism of the giant Three Gorges Dam being built on the Yangtze River, Chinese officials announced today that construction and population resettlement were proceeding smoothly, and that costs were well within budget.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'REILLY, BERNARD (BERNI E)
description: O'REILLY-Bernard (Berni e). Suddenly, on October 24, 2000. 62 years. Businessman and consultant to the computer industry. Beloved son of Catherine and the late Bernard. Loving brother of Patrick and Thomas. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends Friday, 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 St., Bronx. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at St. Margaret's of Cortona Church, Saturday, 11:00 AM.

title: Article 2000102693517039982 -- No Title
description: Remarks yesterday in an appearance with Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, at Seminole Community College in Sanford, Fla.:

title: Bottoms Up, the Murphy's Back
description: IVY FAHRER recently built a seven-bedroom Gothic-style home with her husband in Harrison, N.Y. A wing of their house includes a large suite for her sister, who visits occasionally from Texas. What's unusual about the suite is where sister will slumber: A Murphy bed, king-size and custom-designed, complete with a pillow-top mattress. ''Only the best for the princess and the pea,'' Ms. Fahrer, the president of Cebon Cosmetics, said, laughing. ''My sister is very particular about where she sleeps.''

title: Print Only the Pages That Fit Your Needs
description: Q. Is there a way to get Internet Explorer not to print pages that are blank or have one line of fine print at the end?

title: RANGERS RECALL MOTTAU
description: They tried to be patient, but yesterday, one day after losing for the fourthtime in five games, the Rangers decided they could afford to wait no longer. So they recalled the 22-year-old defenseman Mike Mottau from Hartford.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Struggle to Keep Domain Namesake

title: Endorsements And a Poll Buoy Franks Campaign
description: As Representative Bob Franks savored a wave of newspaper endorsements and a new poll showing the New Jersey contest for the United States Senate might be turning into more of a race after all, his Democratic opponent, Jon S. Corzine, campaigned in one of the state's most heavily Republican counties today, scouring for the independent-minded voters his advisers say could decide the outcome of the campaign.

title: Battling to Keep Majority, the G.O.P. Spreads Cash Around
description: ''If we win this seat, we're going to control Congress,'' Representative Thomas M. Davis III of Virginia, head of the National Republican Congressional Committee, told a group of party loyalists gathered to support Shelley Moore Capito for Congress.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA DROPS. Cocoa plunged after the military leader of the Ivory Coast fled, easing concern that political strife would disrupt exports. In New York, cocoa for December delivery fell $34, or 4.2 percent, to $775 a metric ton.

title: Not Just a Roof, but Roots for a Season
description: DOMINGO RODRIGUEZ, in after-shower boxers and a T-shirt, appeared fresh even after nine hours of apple picking. While a stereo played Spanish music, the lacy window curtains fluttered and the bistec sizzled under the broiler, Mr. Rodriguez, a migrant worker, gave a tour of the modest 810-square-foot house he shares with Alain Leon Burgos. He reveled in its comforts as if it were a fine hotel. Mr. Rodriguez and Mr. Burgos are part of a six-man crew that came up from Puerto Rico in June to help harvest 400 acres of apples and 200 acres of peaches at Bream Orchards, in the fruit-picking heartland of Pennsylvania near Gettysburg.

title: Article 2000102692107491356 -- No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  With the population about to get decidedly older and the nation enjoying a moment of prosperity, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush agree that now is the time to put Social Security on sound footing for generations to come.

title: Beijing Journal; Celebrating Korea's War Even as Peace Seems Near
description: Here it is always called the ''War to Resist America and Aid Korea.'' Today China is celebrating the 50th anniversary of its entry into that conflict -- the day its ''volunteers'' poured across the Yalu River to surprise the American-led United Nations forces in North Korea and went on to battle them for three miserable years toward an uneasy truce.

title: Accounts
description: * E*Trade Securities, Menlo Park, Calif., to Admerasia, New York, to handle marketing aimed at Chinese-American consumers, including a new Chinese-language Web site at www.chinese.etrade.com. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Magazine Group Names an Officer
description: The Magazine Publishers of America in New York has named Ellen W. Oppenheim executive vice president and chief marketing officer. Ms. Oppenheim, 47, who joins the association in January, had been senior vice president and media director at the New York office of FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications.

title: Saudi to Direct U.N. Program Aimed at Controlling Population
description: Thoraya Ahmed Obaid, an American-educated Saudi woman, was chosen today to be executive director of the United Nations Population Fund, which has made the expansion of women's rights central to its mission of cutting population growth worldwide.

title: Divers Recover the First Bodies From Sunken Russian Submarine
description: Divers entered the wreck of the Russian submarine Kursk for the first time today and removed the bodies of three of the 118 crewmen entombed there in one of Russia's worst naval disasters.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The mistake Guei made was to let us watch scenes from Belgrade.''

title: Visit Revises Image of North Korean
description: When Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright landed here this week, the Clinton administration had closely watched what it viewed as the erratic and threatening behavior of the leader, Kim Jong Il, for more than six years.

title: Hold That Listing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYLE, MARGARET MARY
description: BOYLE-Margaret Mary. October 21, 2000. Beloved daughter of the late Austin and Margaret Boyle. Loving sister of the late James A. Boyle. Devoted aunt of Margaret Birckhead of Richmond, VA. and Sean Morkan of Jupiter, FL., Adam Morkan of Indialantic, FL. Friends may call at the Abbey Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 & 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, October 26, 10:30AM, Epiphany Church, 239 East 21 Street, NYC. Contributions in her memory may be made to Catholic Relief Services, 209 West Fayette Street, Baltimore, MD. 21201.

title: In His Own Words: Ralph Nader
