title: All Warm And Cozy, Angeleno Style
description: It does get cold here -- cold enough to light fires. For stoking fires stylishly, Larry Schaffer, who has a housewares store called OK, sells a range of fire irons designed by Conmoto, a German manufacturer. A stainless steel set with wood handles, below, costs $675 and comes with a stand. Other Conmoto sets, designed by Peter Maly, run from $250 to $975. Mr. Schaffer calls OK a ''warm and fuzzy'' cross between the New York shops Moss and Troy. OK, at 8303 West Third Street, is near Arp (see top left); (323) 653-3501.

title: Corrections
description: The signature on Tuesday for a report in the World Briefing column about the espionage trial of an American businessman in Moscow misspelled the writer's surname. She is Sabrina Tavernise, not Tabernise.

title: Mrs. Clinton Says She Will Return Money Raised by a Muslim Group
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that she would return $50,000 in political contributions received at a fund-raising event sponsored by a Muslim organization based in California.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about plans by a developer of bioengineered corn to ask the government to modify a ban on its use in food misidentified the agency that could act. It is the Environmental Protection Agency, not the Food and Drug Administration.

title: A Team in the Series and a Business in the Doldrums
description: If you squinted over Paul O'Neill's shoulder, past Todd Pratt and around the home plate umpire, you might have seen John W. Henry Saturday night in Yankee Stadium. Mr. Henry, a genial and soft-spoken man of 51, is a farmer's son living in a field of dreams.

title: PROFITS TRIPLE AT OXFORD; TEXAS PACIFIC BUYBACK SET
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said third-quarter profit almost tripled as it cut administrative expenses and worked with doctors to control medical costs. Net income rose to $80.6 million, or 81 cents a share, after payment of preferred stock dividends, from $28.3 million, or 34 cents, a year earlier. Premium revenue fell 1.3 percent, to $1.01 billion, as Oxford had fewer customers. Oxford had been expected to earn 57 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. Oxford also said it would buy back $220 million in preferred stock and warrants from the Texas Pacific Group and exchange all other preferred stock and warrants for common stock worth $195 million. Texas Pacific, which invested $350 million in Oxford in May 1998, will own 11 million shares of Oxford common stock, or about 10 percent of the shares outstanding, when the transaction is complete.

title: Garth Fagan's First Images Reverberate In New Work
description: Garth Fagan Dance opened its two-week season at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night with a retrospective of sorts. The four dances suggested that Mr. Fagan has followed a surprisingly consistent artistic trajectory over the 30 years of his company's life, years that have included his ascension to Broadway as the choreographer of ''The Lion King.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BORGWARNER INC., -- Chicago, the No. 2 maker of four-wheel-drive systems in the world, said it would supply those parts for the light trucks of General Motors, Detroit adding about $200 million in annual sales.

title: Candidates Plans for Surplus Face Threat in Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  Congress and the Clinton administration are still wrangling over the final pieces of this year's federal budget, but by the time they are finished they could spend more than 40 percent of the surplus that the two presidential candidates are counting on to pay for their own proposals, analysts from both parties said today.

title: Lautenberg to Raise Funds as Term's End Nears
description: Frank R. Lautenberg is not leaving quietly or easily.

title: Born in Iran, Trained in France, Sought in America
description: WHAT magic ingredients turn a designer like India Mahdavi into a success in three years' time? The answer is talent, certainly, but also luck and an eclectic background that marks her work as exotic, global and sophisticated.

title: Sports of The Times; Groh Gets High Marks On Tests
description: WHEN Al Groh described his halftime tirade during the Jets' 40-37 Monday night classic victory over the Miami Dolphins in overtime, he smiled.

title: Players On No. 7? Triple Play Is Likelier
description: There were a couple of riders on the No. 7 train yesterday who looked very much like professional baseball players. There was the very tall man who got on at the 61st Street-Woodside Station decked out in what appeared to be a complete Mets uniform. But he did not in the least resemble Mike Piazza, whose name was stitched on the back of his jersey.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Bond Market Signals Worry Over Economy
description: The bond markets appear to be signaling that America should be more worried about an economic slowdown than about the prospects of higher inflation. Are bond investors -- who have been pretty good at spying clouds on the horizon well before the rest of the world -- right this time?

title: The Heat of the Game
description: The intense national seminar about Roger Clemens and the broken bat he threw toward Mike Piazza during Game 2 of the World Series may seem an overblown fascination with what is in the end only a game. But there is good reason to pay attention to such a primordial conflict between two athletes. It seems we have acknowledged in this episode that males can be physically dangerous and that tight regulations are necessary to limit their behavior.

title: AFFYMETRIX SOARS ON NEWS OF PROFIT
description: Shares of Affymetrix Inc., a manufacturer of chips used in genetic research, jumped 31 percent after the company reported its first quarterly profit and predicted it will post another in the fourth quarter. The shares rose $16.05, to close at $68.36 after touching $70.38 earlier in the day. Affymetrix earned $295,000 in the third quarter, compared with a loss of $5.8 million a year earlier. On a per-share basis, it broke even, after losing 11 cents a share a year earlier. Analysts had expected the company to lose 12 cents a share in the current quarter. Revenue rose 89 percent to $55.8 million.

title: Kellogg to Acquire Keebler for $4.4 Billion
description: Kellogg Company, the maker of Eggo Waffles and Rice Krispies, announced today that it would acquire Keebler Foods Company for $4.4 billion in cash and assumed debt.

title: Corn Developer Appeals to E.P.A.
description: Aventis CropScience, the developer of StarLink corn, asked government regulators today to allow its use in food for four years, saying new studies demonstrated ''reasonable certainty'' that consumers would not be harmed.

title: In His Own Words: George W. Bush
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } The 2000 Election function displayDate(month) { if (month == "Jan") smon = "January"; else if (month == "Feb") smon = "February"; else if (month == "Mar") smon = "March"; else if (month == "Apr") smon = "April"; else if (month == "May") smon = "May"; else if (month == "Jun") smon = "June"; else if (month == "Jul") smon = "July"; else if (month == "Aug") smon = "August"; else if (month == "Sep") smon = "September"; else if (month == "Oct") smon = "October"; else if (month == "Nov") smon = "November"; else if (month == "Dec") smon = "December"; return (smon ); }

title: Late Goal by Elias Gives Devils Victory Far Away From Home
description: The Devils visited the Florida Panthers tonight hoping to more closely resemble the offensive juggernaut they have been at home.

title: A Better Approach to Drug Offenders
description: Come November, California voters will face Proposition 36, a measure that would dramatically change public policy on how drug offenders are handled in the criminal justice system. According to recent polls, Californians favor this measure, as well they should. The measure may also cause other states, including New York, to reform punitive drug laws that have failed to curb addiction or reduce drug-related crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULER, HAROLD (HAL)
description: SCHULER-Harold (Hal). Of New York City, Gramercy Park. Passed away October 22. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Leave No File Behind
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Says Surfers Are Antisocial?
description: THE Internet might not be such a sad and lonely place after all.

title: 18-Year-Old Is Fatally Shot While Helping Change Tire
description: A young man shot by a robber Tuesday as he changed a tire outside a Brooklyn high school died of his injuries early yesterday, the police said.

title: An Architect Of Finance, Creativity And Intrigue
description: It seemed yesterday as if the last person C. Michael Armstrong wanted to credit for AT&T's breakup plan was John C. Malone, the cable television entrepreneur who has been the most vocal proponent for change among AT&T's board members.

title: Psychiatric Defense Planned By Doctor in Needle Attack
description: A Westchester County doctor who has been accused of trying to abort a pregnant nurse's baby by injecting her with a labor-inducing drug plans to argue that he was mentally unbalanced at the time, a lawyer for the doctor said yesterday.

title: To the Well-Connected Go the World Series Spoils
description: To the multitudes of everyday fans who argue that getting good seats at World Series games is all about who you know, Ron Rosenberg could be Exhibit A.

title: Departure of Chief at ABB Pushes Shares Sharply Lower
description: Describing himself as ''a punch-card type of guy'' in the Internet era, Goran Lindahl, chief executive of Swiss-Swedish technology group ABB Ltd., said today he would step down at the end of the year after four years in which he steered the company into technology-based businesses and away from its 110-year traditions in power generation and heavy engineering.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Birthday Gift: $2 Million for Her Campaign
description: President Clinton helped his Senate candidate wife celebrate her 53rd birthday last night, giving her the best possible gift so soon before the election. Rather than presenting her with roses or jewelry, he was the host of a star-studded Manhattan fund-raiser and dinner that funneled $2 million into Hillary Rodham Clinton's New York Senate bid.

title: Envelopes? No Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Need a Cushion for Life's Blows? This Show House Delivers
description: LIKE many show houses, the Traditional Home Built for Women Showhouse, opening today, has good ideas for the do-it-yourselfer. It also has a celebrity factor, with 11 suites of rooms designed with the personal lives of 11 contemporary divas in mind: Elizabeth Taylor, Tina Turner, Bette Midler, Diane Sawyer, Candice Bergen, Donna Karan, Liz Smith, Jane Seymour, Evelyn Lauder, Barbara Walters and Karol DeWulf Nickell, the editor in chief of Traditional Home magazine, which is the event's sponsor.

title: New Strategies In the Deer Wars; Homeowners Are Manning Backyard Battle Stations
description: In this guarded enclave of money and privilege, intruders ravaged Cindy Aloi's lake-front property this summer after hurdling a seven-foot mesh fence or wriggling underneath it. They used to swim across the lake, too, until she put a stop to that with an electric fence along the shoreline.

title: Article 2000102691499057918 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Some Are Ready to Embrace More Corporate Change, Some to Resist It
description: Flocks of noisy Canada geese descended on the lake in front of the sprawling AT&T corporate headquarters here today, roiling the water much the way C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman, was stirring the corporate waters.

title: OFFENSIVE BY BUSH PRODUCING RESULTS ACROSS CALIFORNIA
description: For more than a year, the smartest money in both major political parties on both coasts held that Gov. George W. Bush could not win California, that his positions on gun control, abortion and the environment were out of step with voters in a state where the Republican Party was reeling. Most of the smart money still thinks that Mr. Bush will not win here, but it is harder these days to find experts in either party who say flatly that he cannot.

title: Injured Cole Sailors Honored
description: The national anthem is a ritual that has been part of the sports landscape for decades. The color guard comes out, and someone usually sings as a prelude to the game.

title: As Tensions Ease, Calm Settles on West Bank and Gaza
description: A relative calm prevailed on the streets of the West Bank and Gaza Strip for the third day today, as both sides seemed to be taking a deep breath and considering their options.

title: D. S. Slaiman, 81, Union Official Active in Civil Rights Movement
description: Donald S. Slaiman, a labor union official who worked to get unions more involved in the civil rights movement and rose high in the A.F.L.-C.I.O., died on Tuesday at a hospital in Alexandria, Va. He was 81 and lived in Washington.

title: Abandoned Farmhouses Evoke Iceland's Past
description: Nokkvi Eliasson, a photographer from Reykjavik, Iceland, has dozens of black-and-white images of abandoned farmhouses on his Web site, most of them with Iceland's big sky looming in the background (www.islandia

title: Exuberant And Focused On Every Bach Phrase
description: The Bach anniversary (he died 250 years ago) grinds on in high profile and low. Murray Perahia's concert on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall was well promoted and, by all reports, of high quality. Less visible, certainly less well attended, but of considerable substance was Anne-Marie McDermott at Alice Tully Hall on Monday playing the C minor and B flat Partitas and the G minor English Suite before intermission and music by Brahms after it.

title: A Strike Could Reduce Turnout In Philadelphia, Democrats Fear
description: Democratic officials are voicing fears that a threatened teachers' strike in Philadelphia could hurt Vice President Al Gore's chances in Pennsylvania by suppressing voter turnout in heavily Democratic Philadelphia.

title: Gore Attacks Bush on Education While Battling for Votes in Familiar Territory
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } The 2000 Election function displayDate(month) { if (month == "Jan") smon = "January"; else if (month == "Feb") smon = "February"; else if (month == "Mar") smon = "March"; else if (month == "Apr") smon = "April"; else if (month == "May") smon = "May"; else if (month == "Jun") smon = "June"; else if (month == "Jul") smon = "July"; else if (month == "Aug") smon = "August"; else if (month == "Sep") smon = "September"; else if (month == "Oct") smon = "October"; else if (month == "Nov") smon = "November"; else if (month == "Dec") smon = "December"; return (smon ); }

title: Pilot Project to Use Web Site In Cases of Domestic Violence
description: Promising ''a 21st-century solution to a very old social problem,'' the Brooklyn district attorney's office yesterday announced a pilot project to put photographs and videotape evidence of domestic violence crimes online in hopes of garnering more accurate evidence and resolving cases faster.

title: AT&T, IN PULLBACK, WILL BREAK ITSELF INTO 4 BUSINESSES
description: Running out of time with impatient investors, AT&T yesterday pulled back from an expensive three-year effort to become the first one-stop shop selling long-distance, wireless, cable television and Internet services across the nation as a single package with a single bill. It announced that instead it would break itself into four parts.

title: Pairing Off To Show Off The Ballet Theater
description: Happy dancegoers kept seeing double on Tuesday night. American Ballet Theater opened its autumn engagement at City Center with a gala performance that showed off many of its principal dancers.

title: Judge Delays Court Date for Northwest and Continental
description: A federal judge yesterday agreed to postpone a court battle in which the Justice Department is trying to force Northwest Airlines to sell its controlling stake in Continental Airlines.

title: Article 2000102694042589359 -- No Title
description: Remarks yesterday at the National Press Club, Washington:

title: Homes to Go
description: Architectural students of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts used to travel to Rome and Greece to draw great antiquities. Jean-Maurice Moulene, a Beaux-Arts trained French architect, gives the classical treatment to homes of gilded Angelenos, including movie producers. Many of Mr. Moulene's clients own multiple trophy homes. ''When they go stay in Colorado they like to have a picture of their house in L.A.,'' he said. Watercolors like the one below start at $1,200, depending on the complexity and size of the rendering, usually 11 by 17 inches. Information: (888) 320-9814.

title: The Web Gets a New Dashboard
description: FANS and foes of the Microsoft Corporation can certainly agree on one thing: Microsoft hates to lose. Whether competing for market share in Web browsers, handheld computers or corporate servers, Microsoft spends whatever years and dollars are necessary to produce the dominant product -- or at least the one with the most features.

title: Bruised by Joltin' Joe
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Returns to Education
description: The Bush-Cheney campaign has begun showing more television commercials about education. Mindy Tucker, a campaign spokeswoman, said the advertisements were being shown in ''battleground'' states, which she would not identify. One is titled ''Expect More.''

title: Farm Union Takes Aim At a Big Pickle Maker
description: Working the fields here the last 26 years, stooping over rows of cucumbers or sweet potatoes or tobacco, Jose Pablo Carreon has occasionally had some of his five children along.

title: GERMAN IMPORT PRICES RISE
description: German import prices soared 13.4 percent in September, compared with a year earlier, the biggest jump since 1981, the government reported. The increase was higher than most economists had expected and reflected the combined impact of high oil prices and the sinking euro. Coming just a day after the German government reported a sharp rise in producer prices, the news raised new fears about inflation throughout the 11-nation region that has adopted the euro as a common currency. The weak euro is pushing up the price of all imports from outside the euro zone. Though oil prices were the biggest reason for higher import prices, economists noted that prices for other imports rose at a steep monthly rate of 0.9 percent. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FABRICANT, BENJAMIN, MD.
description: FABRICANT-Benjamin, MD. Devoted husband of the late Ida and Dorothy. Devoted father of Susan and Sam Hess, Carole and Allan Kasmin, Stephen and Barbara Benjamin, Laura Benjamin and Barbara Schwartz. Dear brother of Betty Lieberman and the late Lou and Charlie. Adored grandfather and great-grandfather. Services Thursday, 11 A.M., at Schwartz Bros, Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Time to Stow Those Gags
description: NOT all wall beds answer to the name Murphy. Today, there are many manufacturers who make fold-up or mobile beds, with platforms or European-style wood-slat bases. Most are custom-made to fit into idiosyncratic spaces and satisfy diverse lifestyle (and style) needs.

title: PEUGEOT UNIT TO BUY DIVISION OF SOMMER
description: PSA Peugeot Citroen of France, one of Europe's biggest carmakers, and its parts division, Faurecia, said they planned to acquire Sommer-Allibert's automotive business for 1.48 billion euros ($1.24 billion), creating the world's third-biggest maker of car interiors. Peugeot will buy SIT, the family holding company that controls Sommer, then hand it to Faurecia. In exchange, its stake in Faurecia will rise to 70 percent from its current 53 percent. The new company will be better able to compete with its rivals in the United States, executives from the two companies said. European parts makers are under pressure from the Lear Corporation and Johnson Controls, which are pushing for more business outside the United States.

title: Parade Plans
description: One thing not in dispute about the Subway Series is that it will culminate in a ticker-tape parade up Broadway in Lower Manhattan. But questions remained yesterday over when it will be held, and whether City Hall will honor both teams.

title: Workers Get Backslaps, Back Wages Plus Hugs
description: There was a homecoming party of sorts at the offices of the Coalition for the Homeless on Chambers Street last night.

title: Once a Monopoly and Still a Threat
description: The telecommunications dispute between the United States and Mexico that has simmered for most of this year involves pennies. But since those pennies add up to hundreds of millions of dollars a year in interconnection fees, this has become one of the thorniest trade squabbles to test relations between the two nations.

title: POPULAR UPRISING ENDS JUNTA'S RULE OVER IVORY COAST
description: As columns of black smoke rose all across this city, tens of thousands of people poured into chaotic streets today and converged on the center of Abidjan, overthrowing the military ruler, Gen. Robert Guei, one day after he declared himself the winner of a disputed presidential election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASRI, ALBERT
description: BASRI-Albert. Young Israel of 5th Avenue mourns the death of the father of our esteemed member Carole Basri and extends to her its condolences. Israel Wohlgelernter, Rabbi

title: Mr. Nader's Electoral Mischief
description: Back in June, we criticized Ralph Nader's presidential bid as a self-indulgent crusade that could gull some voters into thinking that there were no clear policy choices between Al Gore and George Bush. As the election nears, what once seemed a speculative threat has become a very real danger to the Gore campaign, with polls suggesting that Mr. Nader's meager share of the vote could nevertheless make the difference in eight states with 70 electoral votes. That is one reason Mr. Gore returned this week to places like Washington and Oregon. In these and other states that once seemed safe for the vice president, Mr. Nader is wooing liberals by arguing that both parties are captives of the same financial interests. He also appears to be hurting Mr. Gore with charges that he has betrayed his principles and promises on the environment.

title: A 5-Year-Old's Life: Work and Play
description: To the Editor:

title: AOL Seeks Permission to File Brief in Microsoft Appeal
description: America Online today asked a federal appeals court for permission to file a supporting brief in the appeal of the Microsoft antitrust case, noting that the plaintiffs in the case -- the federal government and 19 states -- support the idea while Microsoft opposes it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, DR. GILBERT N.
description: SANDLER-Dr. Gilbert N. on October 24, 2000, of Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of Jacqueline, loving son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel H. Sandler. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th St., Garden City, Thursday 6-9PM. Service 10AM Friday at the Fairchild Chapel. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery, Locust Valley, NY. Donations to Memorial SloanKettering, Mercy Hospice or Estherville Animal Shelter, Greenfield Center, NY 12833 appreciated

title: I.B.M. IN BRAZIL WEB-HOSTING VENTURE
description: I.B.M. and Diveo Broadband Networks, an Internet infrastructure provider, agreed on a five-year pact to offer Web hosting services in Latin America. As part of the deal, which the companies said was worth $120 million, I.B.M. contracted for Web-hosting space and bandwidth in Diveo's Internet data centers in Buenos Aires, Sao Paulo and Mexico City. In turn, Diveo hired I.B.M. Global Services to manage the operations of the data centers. The companies plan to offer comprehensive Web-hosting services in Argentina, Brazil and Mexico, Latin America's three largest Internet markets. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: CALENDAR
description: On Paper and More

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about administrative changes and dissension at Carnegie Hall under its new executive director, Franz Xaver Ohnesorg, misspelled the surname of his predecessor, who died in 1998. She was Judith Arron, not Aaron.

title: Sports of The Times; Maneuvering by Torre Reflects a Sense of Urgency
description: IT turned out that Joe Torre had even less faith in Denny Neagle with a lead last night than Bobby Cox did four years ago. Mike Piazza had hit one tape-measure foul ball against Neagle in the first inning. He had belted a two-run homer into the Shea Stadium picnic area in the third. By the fifth inning, with Neagle one out from being the pitcher of record on the winning side, Torre would not allow Piazza to feast his eyes on Neagle again.

title: Defibrillators Let Lay People Save Lives
description: Many people who suffer cardiac arrest and would otherwise die can be saved if ordinary people are trained to use defibrillators to shock them back to life, researchers are reporting today.

title: NISSAN SAID TO HAVE CHOSEN SITE OF SECOND PLANT
description: Nissan is moving closer to choosing a site for a second assembly plant in the United States, with The Birmingham News in Alabama reporting yesterday that the automaker had chosen Mississippi over Alabama. Nissan declined to comment. Nissan, which already builds midsized cars, pickups and sport utility vehicles in Smyrna, Tenn., has been looking for a place to assemble full-sized pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and minivans. Like other foreign automakers, Nissan prefers to manufacture in the South, where the United Automobile Workers union has had limited success in organizing workers. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Stocks Tumble On Sales News From Nortel
description: Technology stocks plunged yesterday, pulling the broader stock market with them. The Nasdaq composite index fell 5.6 percent, its biggest daily decline since May, while the Dow Jones industrial average ended down just 0.6 percent.

title: A Shift in Stance on Global Warming Theory
description: Greenhouse gases produced mainly by the burning of fossil fuels are altering the atmosphere in ways that affect earth's climate, and it is likely that they have ''contributed substantially to the observed warming over the last 50 years,'' an international panel of climate scientists has concluded. The panel said temperatures could go higher than previously predicted if emissions are not curtailed.

title: U.S.O.C. Chief Quits, Citing Lack of Support
description: Eight months after he was hired to bring a streamlined, corporate approach to the volunteer-based United States Olympic Committee, Norm Blake, its chief executive officer, resigned yesterday, saying that he lacked internal support to remake the organization.

title: In His Own Words: Al Gore

title: Waxing Poetic
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEIL, ELSE
description: WEIL-Else. Always in our hearts. Bob and Fred

title: Aqueduct Favorite Wins in Short Field
description: Without missing a day, New York racing moved yesterday from Belmont Park to Aqueduct, where the meet will be conducted for the next six and a half months. Opening day belonged to a short favorite, Left Bank, who led all the way against only three rivals to capture the $100,000 Discovery Handicap for the fifth victory in his last six starts.

title: Astronomers Find Large Asteroid Near Pluto
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn. - Astronomers have discovered a new minor planet between Neptune and Pluto in the outer fringes of the solar system, Yale University said Wednesday.

title: WIRELESS ACCESS FOR SCHOLASTIC SITE
description: Scholastic Inc., the children's educational publishing company, said it would make content from its scholastic .com Web site available to students and teachers who use Palm wireless hand-held organizers. Scholastic.com features a daily news service, lesson planners and educational events. Mike Lorion, vice president for education at Palm, said the company could not say how many teachers or students currently used Palm hand-held devices, but he said students made up a large percentage of buyers of Palm's lower-priced m100 unit.

title: BMW Seeks Agency To Introduce Brand
description: BMW of North America is beginning to search for an agency to introduce its Mini brand in the United States, which has long been popular in Europe. Spending was not disclosed.

title: Twasnt the Night Before Christmas
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Spinning Mirages Like Cotton Candy
description: I'm looking out the window of my hotel room, and the first thing I see is the Eiffel Tower, which seems to have lost its bearings. For some reason, it's straddling the Louvre and the Palais Garnier. I can also see the Great Pyramid, the Statue of Liberty, the Bridge of Sighs and the Imperial Palace.

title: Big East Top Picks? Ralph And, of Course, the Huskies
description: Last year, the Big East women's basketball coaches chose Svetlana Abrosimova of Connecticut as the conference's preseason player of the year.

title: Dr. Ramzi S. Cotran, 67, of Harvard, Long a Leading Pathologist
description: Dr. Ramzi S. Cotran, an internationally recognized pathologist who helped transform a small clinical program in Boston into one of his profession's premier training grounds, died on Monday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 67.

title: Suicide Attack in Gaza Strip Increases Tension in Mideast
description: A Palestinian suicide bomber, heading on his bicycle toward an Israeli Army outpost in the Gaza Strip, succeeded only in killing himself this morning. But he raised considerable anxiety in Israel that the violence was shifting into a new phase of terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVIDON, ALLAN
description: AVIDON-Allan. October 21, 2000, age 88. Devoted husband of the late Miriam Avidon. Survived by his son & daughter-in-law, Nelson and Rachel of NYC, and his son, Michael, of New London, CT. Allan said this to everyone he met: ''Stay well and enjoy life.''

title: Dearth of Ads Makes Race in Kansas a Snooze

title: Payton Throws Away Mets' Chance on Play at the Plate in the Ninth
description: The instant Mets center fielder Jay Payton saw the Yankees' Luis Sojo gently slap Al Leiter's 142nd pitch of the night up the middle with two out in the ninth, he sprinted forward as he watched the ball bounce past the pitcher's mound and between the lunging shortstop and second baseman.

title: Playing Cat and Mouse, With Copters, in Peru
description: During his decade in power, President Alberto K. Fujimori has been the master of feint, surprise and sleight of hand. But his secret weapon whenever he was in deep trouble was his spy chief, who built up an intimate knowledge of every Peruvian who could cause his boss trouble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROTTER, SYLVIA. MRS.
description: PROTTER-Sylvia. Mrs. Sylvia Alter Protter, died October 23, 2000 after a short illness. Survived by her children Iska and Bernard Alter, and her grandsons Ethan and Jesse. Funeral October 27, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave. at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, a contribution in her name to one's favorite charity. She will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Leaving Las Vegas
description: For four years the casino owner Stephen A. Wynn has been the most closely watched buyer of fine art at auction. His $285 million investment in masterpieces by artists including Degas, van Gogh, Picasso and Matisse filled the Bellagio Gallery of Fine Art, Mr. Wynn's mini-museum in Las Vegas. Some of the works were purchased by the Bellagio hotel and casino; Mr. Wynn bought others back from the casino and rented them to the gallery.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Tuesday showing the demographics and past election results of the Seventh Congressional District in New Jersey, in which candidates are vying for an open seat, misstated the percentage of residents aged 65 and older. It is 14.4 percent, not 83.6.

title: McCarver's Foresight Nearly 20-20
description: Tim McCarver's analysis is usually touched with an uncanny prescience, an ability to first-guess a play, even if he did not predict with precision that the Yankees would win the World Series with a 4-2 victory in Game 5 last night. Once or twice a game, McCarver, the Fox sportscaster, will foretell or suggest a play, followed quickly by that very thing happening.

title: Holy Cow! Profits Are Outta Here!
description: With its concrete floor and exposed sheetrock, the small store near Grand Central Terminal looks like a bar with an under-construction motif or a place with no interest in a long-term lease.

title: Beyond the Casinos
description: Las Vegas is 2,530 miles southwest of New York City. A sampling of attractions, along with travel information:

title: Teary Steinbrenner Soaks Up the Excitement
description: Already soaked with Champagne and overcome with emotion, George Steinbrenner stood in a corner of the jammed Yankees clubhouse last night and cried as he struggled to finish his first few sentences.

title: HIDDEN CHARGES: A special report.; Extra Costs on Car Loans Draw Lawsuits
description: Shawn Core and Retina Massey-Core, newlyweds from Athens, Tex., were shopping for their first car -- a Valentine's Day gift for each other -- when they found a used Lincoln Town Car at a local Ford Lincoln Mercury dealer in 1995. With no established credit history, they were grateful when the dealer declared that they had been approved for a car loan by the Ford Motor Credit Company.

title: GAMBRO LOWERS EARNINGS FORECAST
description: Gambro A.B., the world's second-largest provider of dialysis products and services, lowered its fourth-quarter profit target and said the head of its health care unit would quit after eight months on the job. Brad Nutter, 48, will leave Denver-based Gambro Healthcare, which generates more than half of the Swedish company's total revenue. The departure comes less than five months after Mikael Lilius quit as chief executive to head Finland's Fortum. The Stockholm-based company is reorganizing to focus on dialysis, a process that cleanses the blood of patients whose kidneys have failed.

title: 'Collectors'
description: Directed by Julian P. Hobbs

title: SKYSCRAPER PLAN DROPPED IN BRAZIL
description: The Brazilian real estate developer Mario Garnero, left, has canceled plans to build the world's tallest building in the center of Sao Paulo after the project's financial backers pulled out of the $1.65 billion deal. The Maharishi Global Development Fund, which is linked to Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, abandoned the project after the Sao Paulo city government appeared unlikely to approve the 108-floor, pyramid-shaped complex. The Sao Paulo mayor's office said that the project had stalled because of a lack of financial guarantees. The fund is in talks to relocate the complex to Dallas. It would hold 50,000 people with offices, apartments, a university, shopping malls, hotels and a convention center. Jennifer Rich (NYT)

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Risks of Foster Care
description: To the Editor:

title: There Goes the Surplus
description: In its waning days, Congress is squandering the burgeoning budget surplus on ill-considered spending projects and tax cuts that will go primarily to those who least need help. The wastage will strip Congress of the money it needs to do anything important for years to come and will deprive the two presidential candidates of the money they need to pay for their proposals. President Clinton promised yesterday to veto the tax bill, but his veto can force fixes of only the bill's worst features.

title: Clinton Threatens Spending Plan Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27  A $39.9 billion spending bill gained final Congressional approval with a 49-to-42 Senate vote today, but President Clinton said he would veto it if it reaches the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, LILLIAN T.
description: SCHREIBER-Lillian T. Widow of Morris Schreiber. Retired New York City teacher. Died October 24 in Los Angeles. Survived by her son Harvey Keith (Los Angeles); her sister, Gertrude T. Greenberg (Reston, VA) and her brother Matthew Turetsky (Hollywood, FL). Her family and friends will always remember her with love and admiration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEITCH, LEE MURPHY
description: VEITCH-Lee Murphy died on 18th October, after a courageous fight with the ''big C''. Dearly loved and ever loving wife of Robin, beloved daughter of Jean & Albert Murphy and sister of David Murphy. Funeral service to be held at Mortlake Crematorium, Kew Meadow Path, Richmond, London on Wednesday, November 1st at 2:00PM. Family flowers only but donations, if desired, to The Mayhew Animal Home or The Royal Marsden Hospital Charity C/O Holmes & Daughters, 461 Upper Richmond Road West, London SW14 7PU, UK. Phone: 01144.208.392.1012

title: White House Reassures Steel Makers Over Imports
description: Reacting quickly to pre-election pressure brought by steel companies, unions and 235 members of Congress, the Clinton administration has promised to take the first steps toward new limits on steel imports.

title: AIR CANADA'S PROFIT UP
description: Profit for Canada's largest airline, Air Canada, dipped 7 percent to 107 million Canadian dollars ($70.5 million) in the third quarter, the first period to include its former rival Canadian Airlines, acquired earlier this year. While share profit of 73 Canadian cents (48 cents), beat the latest 62-cent consensus estimate by First Call/Thomson Financial, it was well short of the 1.10 Canadian dollars (73 cents) several analysts expected before airline officials phoned them 10 days ago with a profit warning. Third-quarter revenue rose 11 percent, to 3.08 billion Canadian dollars ($2.03 billion), but higher fuel prices and the threat of a strike by Air Canada pilots cut expected operating income by a third. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Las Vegas

title: Lazio Criticizes President For Weak Foreign Policy
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio offered a broad indictment of the Clinton administration's foreign policy today, asserting that weakness and indecision by the White House over the last eight years had undermined the nation's credibility and contributed to increased turmoil in China, Russia and, most of all, the Middle East.

title: The Real Improvement in Texas Schools
description: Earlier this week the Rand Corporation, a research group, released a study that questions rising student test scores in Texas. According to the study, Texas students demonstrated greater improvement in recent years on the state's own exam than on the leading national test, the National Assessment of Educational Progress.

title: Dictator Gone, Violence Erupts In Ivory Coast
description: A day after toppling the military dictator in a popular uprising, residents of Ivory Coast furiously turned against one another today, and the deadly clashes quickly took on religious and ethnic overtones and spread to smaller cities.

title: Earnings Increase 2.5% at Dow Chemical
description: The Dow Chemical Company said today that its third-quarter profit rose 2.5 percent as increased sales more than covered a $600 million jump in energy and raw materials costs.

title: Coleman Comes Up Big On and Off the Field
description: When Marcus Coleman signed his five-year, $20 million contract with the Jets after last season, his fellow cornerback Aaron Glenn had a talk with him.

title: Murrow's House at CBS
description: To the Editor:

title: Nader's Damage to Gore Most Evident in Oregon
description: In the downtown streets of the biggest city in Oregon, it is remarkably easy to find people who say they are truly struggling with how to cast their vote this year. But it is remarkably difficult to find people in that group who see the decision as a choice between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AMERICAN GENERAL, Houston, named John V. LaGrasse, most recently executive vice president for information technology at its life insurance division, to the post of executive vice president and chief technology officer.

title: King Coal Casts Shadow on Governor's Race
description: It may be the ultimate political symbol for the coal fields of Appalachia: Just in time for the West Virginia governor's race, a slurry dam burst on the state's border with Kentucky, sending 250 million gallons of coal-dust sludge oozing down toward riverfront towns as a reminder of the environmental legacy of King Coal.

title: A Guy Thing: Strutting Past Trouble
description: SO what do you want to know first? Do they really take off all their clothes? Yes. Can you see, you know, everything? No, at least not from where I was sitting. And -- oops, almost forgot -- is it any good? Well, put it this way: the Eugene O'Neill Theater won't have to look for a new tenant for a long, long time.

title: The Mets Lose Series, But Their Pride Is Intact
description: It said ''National League Champs'' on the board posted in the hallway of the clubhouse. It was blank underneath. For the Mets, there are no more games or workouts on the schedule. They lost the World Series last night, falling by 4-2 to the Yankees in Game 5.

title: DaimlerChrysler's Profit Falls 78%, and Relief Is Not in Sight
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G. said today that its third-quarter profit fell by 78 percent, and its executives said that the bad times might continue well into next year.

title: A New Skill for Clemens
description: To the Editor:

title: Both a Social Pointillist and a Cultural Partisan
description: HOOKING UP

title: A Pernicious Secrecy Bill
description: Congress has delivered to President Clinton a misguided bill that would deny the American people access to information that is vital to maintaining an open, democratic society. The bill, which is attached to the intelligence authorization bill and was approved by the House and Senate with little debate and no open hearings, would make it a crime for officials to disclose any information that is ''properly classified.'' If Mr. Clinton signs this measure he will undermine his effort to reduce government secrecy, a signal achievement of his presidency.

title: Women's Soccer Hires Amster Yard
description: The Women's United Soccer Association in New York has named Amster Yard in New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle the introduction of the league, which is scheduled to begin play in April 2001. Billings were estimated at more than $5 million.

title: Pandora's Box of Prayers
description: To the Editor:

title: Yet Another Draw, and Time Grows Short for Kasparov
description: Time is running out for Garry Kasparov, but he conducted Game 11 against Vladimir Kramnik, the challenger for the world championship, as though he were taking a rest stop.

title: Dearth of Ads Makes Race in Kansas a Snooze
description: Seldom is heard a discouraging word about the presidential candidates in these parts. Then again, not much of anything is said about them at all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ROSE ZORNBERG
description: GOLDBERG-Rose Zornberg. On Oct. 26, 2000. Beloved mother of Marcia L. Greenbaum and her companion Dale Bairstow, David J. and Sharon Goldberg. Loving grandmother of Fara R. Greenbaum. Dear sister of Dr. Edward and Florence Zornberg. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Service Monday 10AM. Plaza Memorial 91st St at Amsterdam

title: An Election Equation: Nader and the X Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Rivals Raise Little Besides Rage
description: Conservatives for Effective Leadership was set up last year with an urgent mission: to rain the fury of the right wing -- $10 million worth of fury, its founders promised -- on Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign in New York. The group would expose her record, condemn her agenda and impugn her ethics. Hound her back to Arkansas.

title: New Video Releases
description: Frequency

title: LIGHTBRIDGE TO BUY CORSAIR IN $165 MILLION STOCK DEAL
description: Lightbridge, whose software permits companies to manage customer accounts, agreed to buy Corsair Communications for about $165 million in stock to help it offer more products and gain customers outside the United States. Lightbridge, based in Burlington, Mass., will exchange 0.5978 share for each share of Corsair, which makes prepaid billing systems for wireless companies. That values Corsair at about $9.34 a share, 35 percent more than its closing price on Wednesday. Corsair shareholders will own about 36.5 percent of the combined companies. Corsair's products permit consumers to pay for cellular telephone time in advance, track how much is used and ask the customer to pay more when the amount runs low. Lightbridge shares fell $2.50 to close at $13.13. Shares of Corsair, based in Palo Alto, Calif., rose 25 cents, to close at $7.19.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR PLUMMETS. Sugar plunged almost 9 percent on speculation that demand will weaken enough to leave a global surplus. In New York, sugar for March delivery fell 0.91 cent, or 8.9 percent, to 9.36 cents a pound.

title: Nervous and Paranoid? Well, You Should Be
description: The scariest thing about ''Level 9,'' a slick new cybercop series that has its premiere tonight on UPN, is that it gives no clue which of the dazzling technologies in its stories actually exist and which are made up.

title: Lieberman Sees Issues in News as Ammunition

title: Where Men Strut Like Gods and Devotion Takes All Forms
description: The album-size paintings often referred to as ''Indian miniatures'' have the look of deluxe collectibles. Produced for rich clients who demanded the very best in workmanship, they were enjoyed in private, then shut away like high-security gems, so that their suave forms and brilliant colors retained their expensive bloom.

title: LASER CONCERN DROPS ONLINE VENTURE
description: North America's largest laser vision correction company, TLC Laser Eye Centers of Toronto, has abandoned its e-commerce distribution venture and will take a one-time charge of up to $8 million in the current quarter. EyeVantage.com, was set last year to encourage 12,500 TLC-affiliated doctors in the United States to order ophthalmology products electronically. A $100 million investment in eyeVantage.com by a group of investment funds collapsed along with e-commerce share prices in the spring, and TLC could not find another buyer. The company also said that it had lost $2 million in the first quarter. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Barnstorming Nader Turf, Gore Draws 30,000
description: Vice President Al Gore strode into Ralph Nader territory in this liberal college town today and promoted his own ''progressive values'' to more than 30,000 people, the biggest crowd he has drawn so far in his campaign and perhaps one of the most important.

title: City Never Sleeps, But Wishes It Could
description: On the subway, their heads hung forward like so many wilted flowers, bobbing with the movement of the train. Around the office, their eyes were red and their coffee cups were filled to the rim. When the alarm goes off, many will still have smacked the snooze button a few extra times this morning.

title: The Injury-Depleted Flyers Hand the Rangers Their Third Consecutive Defeat
description: ''Nothing's written in stone,'' Mark Messier said after the Rangers were beaten, 3-0, by the Philadelphia Flyers tonight. ''Nothing says anybody has to play anywhere.''

title: Differing Sides on Abortion Issue See Stark Contrast in Candidates

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNELL, NATHAN
description: SCHNELL-Nathan. On October 24, 2000 in Paris. Beloved husband of Bernice. Loving father of Lloyd Schnell, Stuart Schnell and Laurie Blake. Father-in-law of Ellie, Diane and Paul. Cherished grandfather to Ron & Staci, Amy, Jody, Arielle, Camille, and great-grandfather to Jeremy. Services Sunday 11:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours Saturday, 7-9PM.

title: In 5 Games, a Third Straight World Series Trophy
description: The Yankees maintained their pre-eminence in New York last night, finishing off the Mets in the Subway Series by rallying in the ninth inning of Game 5, and established their place among the greatest baseball dynasties by winning their third consecutive title.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, GARY R.
description: PRATT-Gary R. Formerly of New Preston Hill, New Milford, CT. Died in Palm Springs, CA on October 18, 2000. Born in Greensburg, PA, on June 20, 1950. Gary Pratt was an officer in Bob Randall Productions, helping his life partner with many creative projects, including the long-running TV series Kate & Allie. Mr. Randall preceded him in death in 1995. He is survived by two stepchildren, Julia and Edward Randall of New York City, whom he helped rear; his mother, Anne Adams of North Port, FL; his father, Robert, of Sarasota, FL; his twin brothers, Scott of San Diego and Mark of Sarasota; his sister, Jamie Buskey, of Herminie, Pennsylvania; and two nieces. He also leaves behind a multitude of friends throughout the country. A memorial service will be held in Washington, CT, at the First Congregational Church on the Washington Green, at 3:00 P.M. Saturday, October 28, 2000.

title: Report Calls Officials to Task For Having Misled the Public : U.K. Understated 'Mad Cow' Threat
description: LONDON  An official investigation of Britain's "mad cow" crisis criticized government officials Thursday for misleading the public with a "campaign of reassurance," saying they played down potential risks to human health for years in order to prevent consumer panic and protect the country's beef industry.

title: The American Painter Who Conquered a Queen
description: One of the more amply documented episodes in the history of 19th-century American art arises from the determination with which Thomas Sully, a portrait painter solidly established in Philadelphia, set out for London in November 1837. He had one object: to paint a portrait of the very young Queen Victoria.

title: Book Chain Takes Steps To Coordinate Online Sales
description: In a long-awaited effort to coordinate support for its online spinoff, Barnes & Noble is installing barnes andnoble.com terminals in its 550 superstores and starting a joint membership discount program to encourage its biggest customers to shop at its online store.

title: A Guy in Love With Love Keeps Seeking Ms. Right
description: It's hard to dislike a romantic comedy that's infatuated with the concept of love, even if its hero is a guy who can't help pulling his pants down at the wrong time. In ''Loving Jezebel,'' that guy is Theodorus (Hill Harper), who has spent his whole life chasing currently attached women and starts the picture running from a jealous husband. Though ''Jezebel'' begins with Roy Ayers's song ''Love Will Bring Us Back Together'' -- part of a well-used score of old songs and new music that never becomes heavy-handed -- we should be hearing Joy Division's ''Love Will Tear Us Apart.''

title: Julian Schnabel Re Opus No. 2
description: ''It is very important to me to know that the viewer is not just watching something, but is participating,'' said Julian Schnabel, the painter-turned-award-winning film director.

title: John Abbott, 52, an Art Dealer And Contemporary Art Curator
description: John Abbott, an art dealer and curator, died on Saturday at Cabrini Medical Center in New York. He was 53 and lived in Manhattan.

title: BUDGET THREATENS CANDIDATES' PLANS TO SPEND SURPLUS
description: Congress and the Clinton administration are still wrangling over the final pieces of this year's federal budget, but by the time they are finished they could spend more than 40 percent of the surplus that the two presidential candidates are counting on to pay for their own proposals, analysts from both parties said today.

title: Dot-Com Fever Followed by Bout Of Dot-Com Chill; What a Long, Strange Trip: Pseudo.Com to Dot.Nowhere
description: He still wears the uniform: leather boots, leather jacket and a dark T-shirt. He is twitchy, he grooms his sideburns and he smokes a lot.

title: Anti-U.S. Fever: Arab Bitterness and Boycott Talk
description: Officially, on their state-controlled television stations and in their newspapers, many Arab governments have turned down the volume this week on the Palestinian-Israeli conflict.

title: To Our Readers
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, as well as information about errors that call for correction. Starting this week, an editor will respond to messages e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left at this toll-free number: 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397).

title: It's Kick-Up-Your-Heels Time With a Mexican Flourish
description: The Ballet Folklorico de Mexico put on a very good show on Saturday night at the New Jersey Center for the Performing Arts in Newark. Dance purists might have wished for something more than skirt-swirling from the company's women and quick-footed cantering from the men. But the massed, stamping dancers, gliding formations and spectacularly beautiful costumes rightly drew cheers throughout the evening.

title: Leo Nomellini, 76, 49er Star And an N.F.L. Hall of Famer
description: Leo Nomellini, the Hall of Fame tackle of the San Francisco 49ers who was renowned for strength and endurance in a National Football League career spanning 14 seasons and 174 consecutive games, died Oct. 17 in Stanford, Calif. He was 76.

title: Corrections
description: The New Economy column in Business Day on Oct. 9 about the views of John Seely Brown, former director of the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center and the author of ''The Social Life of Information,'' misstated his role at the investment firm Twelve Entrepreneuring. He joined the firm after it was created by Eric Greenberg, Halsey Minor and Benchmark Capital; he did not create it with them. The article also misspelled the surname of the firm's chief strategy officer. He is John A. Hagel III, not Hegel.

title: Both Sides on Abortion Issue Step Up Fight
description: Kate Michelman, president of the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League, says she is fighting a myth as much as anything else in this presidential campaign.

title: Malibaka Journal; Shattered Lives in Timor: Now, to Try to Rebuild
description: ''Ready?'' said the Australian officer in the pale blue United Nations cap, surveying the small crowd waiting on the far side of the shallow Malibaka River. ''Give the signal!''

title: 'The Little Vampire'
description: Directed by Uli Edel

title: For Muslim Americans, Influence In Politics Still Hard to Come By
description: When Salam Al-Marayati read yesterday that Hillary Rodham Clinton would return $50,000 in political contributions from members of the American Muslim Alliance, he got a sinking feeling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINGER, ISAAC
description: KLINGER-Isaac. Beloved brother, father, grandfather, and above all, friend, died peacefully October 19, surrounded by his children. A quiet and genuine man who loved to laugh, Isaac always gave generously of himself. He had a rare and special soul, and he will be missed dearly by all who knew him. The family respectfully requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: At the Home of Beauty, Vanity Is Hardly Skin-Deep
description: Angele (Nathalie Baye) is a woman of around 40 -- maybe a little older, but younger looking, as she coyly tells a date -- who works at the Paris skin-care and manicure salon for which ''Venus Beauty Institute'' is named. Because of a bad experience, which resulted in the scarring of a former boyfriend's face, Angele has sworn off love, instead pursuing a series of one-night stands with an unsettling mixture of callousness and neediness.

title: A Comeback For Jordache Spot
description: The 1970's nostalgia trend is claiming another convert as Jordache Enterprises said it would bring back the original television commercial that introduced the Jordache brand of designer jeans.

title: New Lawyers At a Big Firm Get Bonuses Of $35,000
description: A leading Wall Street firm, Sullivan & Cromwell, opened the season of annual bonuses this week, announcing on Wednesday that its first-year lawyers, most of whom began practicing law last fall at an annual salary of $125,000, would receive a year-end bonus of $35,000 this year. That is more than double the $15,000 that first-year associates received last year.

title: ALCOA TO LAY OFF WORKERS BECAUSE OF SLOW SALES
description: Alcoa, the producer of aluminum, will lay off as many as 90 workers at a Pennsylvania plant because of slowing sales to truck makers and other customers. The workers are among 1,162 employees at the plant in Cressona, which makes parts for trucks and tractor-trailers. The layoffs will begin in November and last three months, a company spokeswoman, Joyce Saltzman, said. On Tuesday, Alcoa fired 77 workers at a plant in Mississippi.

title: Vern Wolfe, a Track Coach And Innovator, Is Dead at 78
description: Vern Wolfe, a celebrated track coach for a third of a century and an early exponent of weight training in his sport, died on Wednesday in a hospice in Vista, Calif. He was 78.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE AD CAMPAIGN

title: Mrs. Clintons Archfoes Raise Little but Fury
