title: Leaving No X's or O's Unturned
description: Peer down the list of job titles and responsibilities for pro football coaches and the glory jobs rank this way: first and foremost, head coach, followed by offensive and defensive coordinator. Among the rest, quarterbacks coach has a nice ring to it. Even special-teams coaches have gained the spotlight in recent years.

title: Chavez Extends a Hero's Welcome to Castro in Caracas
description: Offering a hero's welcome and pledging to use his country's vast oil wealth as a political weapon, President Hugo Chavez today greeted Fidel Castro, the international figure whom he regards as his main mentor, ally and friend, at the start of the Cuban leader's first official state visit to Venezuela in more than 40 years.

title: W.T.O. RULES AGAINST U.S.
description: The World Trade Organization has ruled in favor of Australia and New Zealand in their dispute with the United States over its restrictions on lamb imports, Radio New Zealand said. Radio New Zealand said a confidential interim finding by a panel of the trade organization was delivered to the Australian and New Zealand governments earlier this week, ahead of the public release next month of the adjudicating panel's decision.

title: NEC REPORTS A PROFIT
description: The NEC Corporation of Japan returned to profitability in the six months ended Sept. 30, posting a net group profit of 20.5 billion yen ($190 million). That compared with a net loss of 51.1 billion yen ($472.5 million) in the comparable period last year. The chip manufacturer enjoyed robust orders from cellular phone and personal computer makers struggling to meet demand. The company expects strong sales of chips and PC's to continue and forecast a full-year net profit of 90 billion yen ($832.3 million). Shares of NEC fell 120 yen ($1.11), to 2,115 yen ($19.56). Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: CITY GUIDE SERVICE CALLS IT QUITS
description: Scout Electromedia, which introduced the Modo wireless hand-held device and the Modo.net city guide service in early September, shut down after running out of money. The Modo wireless devices, which were sold for $99, provided event and restaurant listings and articles over Modo.net. Investors in Scout Electromedia included Idealab, Chase Capital Partners and Flatiron Partners. The service had several thousand users, according to Ken Miller, an editor at Modo.net. Catherine Greenman (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSHING, HARRY COOKE IV
description: CUSHING - Harry Cooke IV. Passed away on October 24, 2000 suddenly after a short illness at age 76. Vanderbilt scion, accomplished polo player and world traveler, he will be remembered by all who came in contact with him for his strength of character, penetrating wit, voluminous historical recall and an aristocratic lifestyle long forgotten. He is survived by a son, Harry Cooke Cushing V, a daughter-in-law Laure, and two granddaughters Cathleen and Kyra. There will be a memorial service on Wednesday, November 1, 2000 at 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: A Halloween Of Holy Smoke
description: In many old legends, a church is a perfect refuge from goblins and ghouls. That sense of sanctuary, however, does not apply to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Enter the smoke-filled nave tomorrow evening, and the space will look less like a church than like a convention center for crypt dwellers.

title: WHOLE FOODS WEIGHS OPTIONS FOR AMRION UNIT
description: Whole Foods Market, the natural-foods grocer, said yesterday that it had hired investment banker Dain Rauscher Wessels to advise it on options for its unprofitable Amrion nutritional-supplement unit. Whole Foods said the Amrion preferred stock it holds represents a majority interest. The company also will take a pretax charge of $10 million in its fourth quarter to write off its preferred stock investment in closely held American WholeHealth, John Mackey, chief executive of Whole Foods, said during a conference call. Whole Foods is based in Austin, Tex. The shares of Whole Foods fell $5.25 to close at $47.

title: Medical School Applications Dip Sharply; Minorities' Rise Slightly
description: The number of students applying to medical schools has shrunk by a fifth in the last four years, reflecting what health professionals described as a growing disenchantment with life under managed care, coupled with blossoming opportunities in other fields.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN PEACE
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. Malvin dear, your birthday, and, wherever we may be, our memories of you are forever. Your love, wisdom, and inspiration is the force of our strength. Love always. Audrey, Irik and Jaar-me

title: Burma's New Export / Methamphetamine Menace : Pills Follow a Path Into Thailand Blazed by Heroin
description: BANGKOK  When the Thai police arrested a housewife the other day for selling banned methamphetamine stimulant pills outside a provincial hospital not far from Bangkok, they made further inquiries.

title: Yoko Ono: Painter, Sculptor, Musician, Muse
description: FORTY years ago, before people started thinking of her as that woman, Yoko Ono was 27, living in New York and an admirer of John Cage, creating conceptual art: she made up haiku-like instructions to be performed or just imagined. ''Light a match and watch till it goes out.''

title: American General Posts 11% Increase
description: The American General Corporation, the large publicly traded life insurer, said today that its third-quarter operating earnings rose 11 percent, driven by strong growth in retirement savings products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESS, HENRY N.
description: ESS-Henry N. October 25, 2000. Born 1921 in Kansas City, MO. He graduated from The Hill School in Pottstown, PA, in 1938, Princeton University in 1942 and Harvard Law School in 1944. He was a Trust and Estates Partner at Sullivan and Cromwell. Memorial service will be held Tuesday, October 31, at 10 AM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, NYC. The family requests a contribution to the New York Public Library in lieu of flowers.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Kissinger on Mend After Heart Attack

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLAIMAN, DONALD
description: SLAIMAN-Donald. We mourn the loss of a dear friend and a colleague in the battle for human rights, civil rights, organized labor and social democracy. Miriam and Manny Muravchik

title: Shaken NASA Offers New Plan For Mars Exploration Missions
description: Shaken by two failed Mars missions last year, NASA spent most of this year trying to restore morale, reform management and formulate a new strategy for exploring the planet over the next 15 years, culminating in flights to bring back soil and rock samples from Mars.

title: Queen's Bentley (No Money Down)
description: VOLKSWAGEN A.G. and more than a dozen of its suppliers are planning a gift to Queen Elizabeth II: a Bentley. The car -- her first Bentley -- is due in 2002, to mark her 50th year as monarch. Although the car will be one of a kind, it will set the style for Bentleys as they take a separate path from Rolls-Royce on Jan. 1, 2003.

title: Conflicting Loyalties in a Gritty Street Drama
description: ''Once in the Life'' begins with a flurry of fast cuts and quick, pungent scenes that effectively introduce its characters and milieu. On an as yet ungentrified Lower Manhattan street, a skinny fellow, dapper in black leather, does a solo break dance next to a sleek sedan, as the orange, graffiti-style credits pop onto the screen.

title: Foster-Child Advocates Gain Allies in Injury Lawyers
description: The girls were 2 and 4 when their mother abandoned them near a city park in Miami in 1986. Under federal law, the Florida Department of Children and Family Services was supposed to place them for adoption or return them home within 18 months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, ROSEMARIE
description: SCHINDLER - Rosemarie. Our heartfelt condolences to Charles, Diana and Carl Giuseppone as well as her most cherished grandchildren, Katie and David. Take comfort in the fact she is at peace. Carol and Richard Kalikow

title: A Race That Isn't What Was Expected
description: This was going to be one of the war zones in the battle for control of Congress, where the Republican-turned-Democrat was expected to battle a powerful local Republican. But that was before the Sept. 12 Democratic primary, when a pro-bono environmental lawyer who works out of her own kitchen unseated the incumbent, Michael P. Forbes, who switched parties last year.

title: An Election Equation: Nader and the X Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Twofold Mission Of Piety and Pop
description: At 9 p.m. on a recent Monday, cars were double-parked along Rogers Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. No action disturbed the street; the nearest bodega was quiet, and no one loitered on the corner at Martense Street. But behind the doors of the storefront Resurrection Temple of the Lord, a mighty noise ignited, lighted by the spirit of devotion.

title: Sojo Gets The Call And Again Delivers
description: Midway through the season, the Yankees were struggling and everyone knew something was missing. Derek Jeter and Bernie Williams approached Brian Cashman, the general manager, and were blunt. They wanted Luis Sojo back.

title: Woods Has a Hot Start And a Share of First
description: Before most of the players had even teed off today, Tiger Woods was at five under par.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/International; Letting the Good Times Roll: Fast Cars for the Truly Rich
description: GASOLINE prices may rise, and the bubble of dot-com wealth may wobble precariously, but European makers of powerful cars for the powerfully wealthy are proceeding as if only the smooth roads of conspicuous consumption lay ahead. They are planning a new wave of muscular, luxurious cars that eclipse their predecessors in size and power and often evoke the legends of automotive history.

title: Former Magellan Manager Is Closing His Hedge Fund
description: Jeffrey N. Vinik, manager of one of the nation's largest hedge funds, said yesterday that he would shut down his $4.2 billion Boston fund and return his investors' money by the end of the year.

title: Sports of The Times; A Not-So-Hostile Takeover at Shea
description: WHEN the brutal blare of the Shea Stadium loudspeakers let up for even a few miserable seconds, you could hear another sound, far more insidious.

title: An Election Equation: Nader and the X Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: It Sure Takes More Than a Dollar and a Dream
description: The blazing chartreuse early-1970's Buick Riviera that Russ Richards (John Travolta) drives in ''Lucky Numbers'' may be fashionable now, but it's a full-bore eyesore in Harrisburg, Pa., in 1988, when this picture takes place. Russ, a star weatherman on local television, is even more profligate with his money than he is with his smile. His livelihood is probably causing him more pain than pleasure, since he is reporting on the unseasonably warm weather that is causing the slow death of his sideline snowmobile business. He can see a family loading a swimming pool onto the roof of its station wagon through the window of the showroom where his Yamahas sit.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, DAVID
description: SAVAGE-David. Oct 27, 1989. Remembered with love by his family.

title: Delia Brown
description: 'What, Are You Jealous?'

title: The 'Winter' Before 'Lola'
description: Watch a movie by Tom Tykwer, the German director best known for ''Run Lola Run,'' and one wants to jog, sprint even. In a furious blast of energy, that film and its flamingly red-haired star, Franka Potente, represent the mad dash of young Germans from years of immobility under the administration of Helmut Kohl, Germany's former chancellor. Or such was the intent of Mr. Tykwer, who is 34. ''Go, Helmut, go,'' he reiterated this week on the telephone from Hamburg.

title: Nassau County Legislature Approves Plan Including 15 Percent Property Tax Increase
description: In a close vote along strict party lines, the Nassau County Legislature approved a four-year fiscal rescue plan tonight that includes a 15.4 percent increase in county property taxes next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARP, MARY ANNE
description: KARP-Mary Anne. The administration, staff and families of P.S. 226M mourn the passing of our beloved colleague and dear friend Mary Anne Karp. She will be deeply missed.

title: INSIDE
description: Gore Woos Progressives

title: Bucking History, Tossup States Increase, Forcing Candidates to Rethink Strategies
description: function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } The 2000 Election function displayDate(month) { if (month == "Jan") smon = "January"; else if (month == "Feb") smon = "February"; else if (month == "Mar") smon = "March"; else if (month == "Apr") smon = "April"; else if (month == "May") smon = "May"; else if (month == "Jun") smon = "June"; else if (month == "Jul") smon = "July"; else if (month == "Aug") smon = "August"; else if (month == "Sep") smon = "September"; else if (month == "Oct") smon = "October"; else if (month == "Nov") smon = "November"; else if (month == "Dec") smon = "December"; return (smon ); }

title: A Rare Trove From France
description: Some of the most extravagant furniture in 18th-century Paris was produced by marchands-merciers, merchants as entrepreneurial in their way as today's Wall Street speculators. These merchants combined the roles of dealer and decorator. They produced sumptuous objects that employed the skills of several masters in the separate guilds of cabinetmaking, bronze casting and porcelain manufacturing.

title: Undecided Voters Remain Skeptical On Soft Money Pact in Senate Race
description: The soft-money deal between the candidates for the United States Senate in New York has backfired, some undecided voters say, drawing more attention to the fund-raising activities of Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio than if they had quietly raised and spent millions and not made an issue of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, EDITH
description: GINSBERG-Edith. Approaching her 95th year. Wife of the late Louis Ginsberg, poet. Mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, friend and a woman of distinction to all who knew her.

title: Too Many Know Too Much About Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINE, ARTHUR
description: PINE-Arthur. On October 26, 2000. Of Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of Harriette. Dear father of David (Dale) and Richard (Nancy) Adored grandfather of Ross, Alec, Adam and Gideon. Brother of Martin. Services Sunday, 12 noon at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, LI. In lieu of flowers donations to The Service Guild of Long Island Jewish Hospital are appreciated.

title: Bush, Wooing Pennsylvania, Attacks Gore's Character
description: Stumping through the socially conservative western reaches of this important swing state, Gov. George W. Bush today questioned the integrity, courage and moral character of Vice President Al Gore and called the presidential race a matter of values.

title: Players Who Want to Be Nets Have Little Time Left to Impress
description: The Nets did not make any roster moves yesterday before leaving for Cincinnati for tonight's final exhibition game. They have until 6 p.m. Monday to set their final roster. That is the final time teams can set their 15-man roster with 12 active players. The Nets assumed a small financial burden, possibly up to $10,000, since it takes 48 business hours for players to clear waivers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'REILLY, BERNARD (BERNIE)
description: O'REILLY-Bernard (Bernie). Suddenly, on October 24, 2000. 62 years. Businessman and consultant to the computer industry. Beloved son of Catherine and the late Bernard. Loving brother of Patrick and Thomas. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends Friday, 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 St., Bronx. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at St. Margaret's of Cortona Church, Saturday, 11:00 AM.

title: Sports of The Times; Parade Needs the Mets to Be Participants Too
description: NOW that this World Series in New York, New York is over, the Mets -- not just the champion Yankees -- should also be in next week's parade up Lower Broadway to City Hall.

title: Difficulties Cloud the Debut Of Sony PlayStation 2 Console
description: Sony's PlayStation 2 video game console made its long-awaited and predictably frenzied North American debut yesterday. But what should have been a banner day for Sony was clouded by reminders of the difficulties it has had in bringing the device to market.

title: New Referee For the Tonys
description: Four months after the Tony Awards broadcast registered its lowest ratings, the show's overseers are close to hiring a new managing producer, presumably to add some zip.

title: Dot-Com Fever Followed by Bout Of Dot-Com Chill; Tech Stocks Down, But No Threat Is Seen To City's Economy
description: A year ago, BigStar Entertainment looked as if it was living up to its name.

title: 'None of Us Can Get Out' Kursk Sailor Wrote
description: Trapped in the rear of a breached and sunken submarine on the Arctic seabed, the electricity failing, facing all-but-certain death with 22 companions, Lt. Capt. Dimitri Kolesnikov, the commander of the turbine room on the Russian submarine Kursk, scrawled a message 10 weeks ago to what was then an unknowing outside world.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Five Myths
description: The U.S. ambassador to China, Joseph Prueher, was answering questions the other day after a lecture at Nanjing University, when an American student rose and asked him something like this: Why is it that whenever I'm back home Americans ask me what it's like to live in a Communist dictatorship that abuses its people, but when I'm here in China I feel that I'm living in a society that's becoming more open?

title: Tentative Pact Is Reached In 2-Day Strike By Teachers
description: Striking teachers in Neptune Township, N.J., ended a two-day strike yesterday morning, returning to work after reaching a tentative contract settlement with the district's school board.

title: House Passes Spending Bill, Ignoring a Threatened Veto
description: In the face of promised vetoes by President Clinton and with the election only 12 days away, the House today approved a $37.7 billion spending measure and a package of tax cuts and reimbursements to hospitals, nursing homes and health maintenance organizations.

title: There's No Stoppin' Mom's Cheatin' Heart
description: Nobody does adultery in the movies more knowingly than the French. And although ''The Bridge'' doesn't contribute anything new to the literature on the subject, it glides down a well-trodden path with hardly a misstep until the very end, when it suddenly bumps into a wall. The film's message is as unsettling as it is familiar: adulterous passion, once aroused, follows its own laws, cannot be reasoned with and often can't be stopped. That's just the way of the flesh.

title: A Star Is Borne Aloft To a Make-Believe Heaven
description: ''Stardom'' is another in the series of films -- collect 'em all -- that seem to use Andy Warhol's dictum that in the future everyone would be famous for 15 minutes. Would that ''Stardom'' lasted only 15 minutes. The writer and director Denys Arcand's social satire is torn from yesterday's screaming headlines, a fish-wrap comedy about the dangers of fame.

title: H. Cushing IV, Polo Player And Investor, 76
description: Harry Cooke Cushing IV, an investor and polo player, died on Tuesday at New York Weill Cornell Center in Manhattan. He was 76 and lived on the Upper East Side in his final years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, EDITH WOOD PERSHOUSE
description: STONE-Edith Wood Pershouse, October 6, 2000 at Goodwin House West, Falls Church, VA. Born NYC March 10, 1905. Daughter of Dr. Francis Carter Wood and Edith Sterling Wood. Wife of the late Aubrey Pershouse and the late Bradford W. Stone. She is survived by a brother, a sister, two children; three stepdaughters; seven grandchildren and eleven great grandchildren. A service and interment will be held in Englewood, NJ.

title: Article 2000102791733726295 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Coexistence Is the Only Choice
description: In Israel, despair and despondency have spread among those who really believed that the long-cherished end of the prolonged confrontation with the Arabs was within their grasp. The despair and rage of those in the ''peace camp'' have been directly proportional to the degree to which their illusions are shattered.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 15.

title: Kellogg Agrees to Buy Keebler Foods for $3.86 Billion
description: The Kellogg Company, the maker of Eggo waffles and Rice Krispies cereal, announced today that it would acquire the Keebler Foods Company for $3.86 billion in cash.

title: Deutsche Telekom Gains In Bid for VoiceStream
description: Deutsche Telekom won a major battle today in its effort to enter the United States when Congress abandoned legislation that would have blocked its proposed acquisition of VoiceStream Wireless.

title: Too Many Know Too Much About Us
description: To the Editor:

title: The Devolved AT&T: Are 4 Parts More Promising Than One?
description: Shortly after announcing on Wednesday that AT&T was going to split into four units, C. Michael Armstrong, the company's chairman, was asked in an interview if anything good would be lost as a result of the overhaul. He considered the question for at least 10 seconds, then responded, ''I can't think of anything.''

title: The agency that gave us a salvo of gerbils tries a more direct sell for Disney's Go.com unit.
description: AN agency responsible for perhaps the most notorious campaigns in the short, tempestuous history of Internet advertising, for the e-tailer Outpost.com, is taking on another high-risk, high-reward cyberassignment: promoting the substantial revamping of the Go.com Web site.

title: ANDERSEN CONSULTING TO CHANGE NAME
description: Andersen Consulting said yesterday that it would be known as Accenture beginning in January. The new corporate name was required by an arbitrator's decision, announced in August, separating the consulting company from its parent, the tax and auditing firm Arthur Andersen. According to Joe W. Forehand, the chief executive of Andersen Consulting, the company plans to consider a partial public offering of its shares. The new name is part of Andersen's effort to present itself as a professional services company that can carry out the business proposals it presents to clients. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: 'A Room for Romeo Brass'
description: Directed by Shane Meadows

title: Racial Profiling Used in His Arrest, Detective Says
description: A black New Jersey State Police detective has been suspended without pay after being arrested by white officers in Trenton in what he said was a case of racial profiling.

title: Trial on Clinton Disbarment Is Unlikely Before Term Ends
description: It now appears almost certain that a trial in Little Rock, Ark., over whether President Clinton should be disbarred will not take place until well after he leaves office, lawyers involved in the case say.

title: For Congress From New York
description: In most of New York's 31 Congressional races, the incumbents are heavily favored. But there is a hot contest for the Long Island seat held by Representative Rick Lazio before he left it to run for the Senate. Three other races for the House of Representatives also merit close attention.

title: Nike Sued Over Song in Ad
description: Nike Inc., the world's biggest maker of athletic shoes, and its advertising agency were sued by the singer Billy Paul for using his song ''Me and Mrs. Jones'' in a commercial. Mr. Paul seeks at least $1 million in lost licensing fees, according to the suit filed in Federal District Court in Los Angeles. Wieden & Kennedy, Nike's ad agency, was also named as a defendant. ''Me and Mrs. Jones'' was the No. 1 song on the Billboard Top 40 chart for three weeks in 1972. Mr. Paul says that Nike, without his consent, has run ads featuring his voice singing the song. The company could not be immediately reached for comment.

title: Dieting Dangers
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 9
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: Ad Campaign Seeks Votes For $3.8 Billion In Transit Aid
description: With less than two weeks to go until Election Day, supporters of a proposed $3.8 billion transportation bond act, by far the largest borrowing proposal in New York State history, have begun a television and radio advertising campaign to urge voters to approve the measure.

title: BB&T TO BUY BACK UP TO 20 MILLION SHARES
description: The BB&T Corporation, a banking company, said yesterday that it would buy back up to 20 million of its shares, worth about $600 million at current market prices. The buyback, which will take place over an unspecified period of time, represents about 5 percent of BB&T's shares outstanding. Companies use buybacks to increase earnings per share by reducing the number of shares outstanding. BB&T is based in Winston-Salem, N.C. The company's shares closed yesterday at $29.88, down 6 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Corrections
description: A contents entry in the Arts pages yesterday for a review of a performance of Bach and Brahms on Monday at Alice Tully Hall misstated the pianist's given name. As reported in the review, she is Anne-Marie McDermott, not Alice.

title: The Big City; On the Series, Who Exactly Is Provincial?
description: IT has become tragically obvious this week how provincial the rest of Americans are. They have not been paying attention to the Subway Series, and they have no excuse.

title: An Election Equation: Nader and the X Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about New Jersey voters' sparse interest in the Senate race, as shown in polls and in attendance at campaign events, misstated the contest's nationwide rank for spending. It is not the most expensive Senate race this year; the contest in New York is. The article also misstated the amount the Democratic candidate, Jon S. Corzine, has spent so far. It is about $56 million, not more than $60 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAHMS, KAREN ALLISON
description: BRAHMS-Karen Allison, daughter of Ronnie Brahms and the late Ruth Brahms. Sister to Claudia Brahms Mount and brother-in-law, Noel Mount. Karen was a successful research consultant. She conducted business seminars throughout the country. She was greatly respected by her clientele. Karen was the co-founder of the Research Roundtable. She was a devoted friend and a prolific poet. Karen was loved and loving and will be deeply missed. Memorial services at a later date. Donations in her memory for establishment of Melanoma Research Fund to Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Mars Rock Could Have Carried Life, Study Shows
description: WASHINGTON - It plunged through Earth's atmosphere in a brilliant fireball, but the inside of a chunk of Mars rock that fell to Earth 13,000 years ago stayed cool enough to sustain life, scientists reported Thursday.

title: EATING OUT
description: Mexican Class

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERFREUND, HELEN
description: PETERFREUND-Helen. On October 26, 2000. Of Rye, NY, age 86. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Loving mother of Sula Pearlman and son-in-law Robert. Cherished grandmother of Debbi, Amy and Philip Capell. Dear great-grandmother of Ian Capell. Graveside service today 11 AM, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens, NY.

title: Jeter, the M.V.P., Says This Title Is Most Gratifying
description: With a home run in each of the last two games and a .409 batting average, Yankee shortstop Derek Jeter was named the most valuable player of the Subway Series last night, but he deferred the honor.

title: Now (Still) Cleaning Up: Topps Company
description: IS there a New York kid of 50 who hears the name Topps and does not wistfully recall a baseball card of Mickey Mantle or Roger Maris, packed with a slice of gum?

title: It's Time for Big Oil to Step Up Its Efforts to Find More Oil
description: THE results are in on the first nine months of 2000 for Exxon Mobil, the oil behemoth created by the merger of two already huge companies. Profits are soaring, up 122 percent, to $12.5 billion, as high oil prices and rising profit margins for refineries create a torrent of cash.

title: Shortage of Technology Parts Is Still Dampening Results
description: I.B.M., Sun Microsystems, Ericsson -- the list of companies reporting that their recently completed quarter's sales and earnings were crimped by component shortages is not only broad but it is led by many of the biggest names in the global communications and information technology sectors.

title: An Election Equation: Nader and the X Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: PILKINGTON PROFIT RISES
description: The glassmaker Pilkington P.L.C. said first-half profit jumped 81 percent, to $:38 million ($66 million), from $:21 million ($30.1 million) a year earlier. Rising prices for glass offset higher energy costs. Results also benefited from a reorganization the last three years that cut costs and increased efficiencies. Sales for the six months to Sept. 30, remained flat at $:1.4 billion ($2 billion). Pilkington's shares rose 5 percent after the results were reported. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Candidates Pact Draws Attention to Soft Money

title: Bucking History, Tossup States Increase, Forcing Candidates to Rethink Strategies
description: The roster of states that are tossups in the general election is actually expanding in the closing days of the presidential campaign, a marked departure from previous elections and one that has forced Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore to hustle around the nation even more than past nominees.

title: Timberwolves Might Face Additional Punishment
description: Calling the actions of the Minnesota Timberwolves ''one of the most far-reaching frauds we've seen,'' David Stern, the National Basketball Association commissioner, yesterday did not rule out further punishment of the team and some of its officials for entering into a secret contract with forward Joe Smith.

title: Burkittsville Revisited, With More Mind Games
description: Whether or not it flies at the box office, ''Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2'' (the sequel to ''The Blair Witch Project'') can't be written off as a weak, half-hearted effort to eke out a few more dollars from last year's blockbuster cinematic jack-in-the-box. The $10 million follow-up to the Little $30,000 Movie That Could is a clever if muddled collection of riffs on the Blair Witch juggernaut, dressed up with intellectual pretensions by Joe Berlinger, who directed this film with a chortling zest.

title: Spessi
description: 'Bensin'

title: Rivera and Rest of Pen Did Job When Needed
description: For Mariano Rivera, who etched his name deeper into the World Series record book last night as perhaps the greatest relief pitcher in Series history, the key word was relief. It was relief that poured freely from him as he exhaled, screamed to the sky and raised his arms as Mike Piazza's long fly ball settled into the glove of Bernie Williams for the final out of the Series.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''13:15. All personnel from compartments six, seven and eight moved to the ninth. There are 23 of us here. We have made this decision as a result of the accident. None of us can get out.''

title: Labor Expenses for Businesses Climbed Slightly in September
description: Labor expenses for businesses showed the smallest gain in a year in the third quarter, government figures showed today, suggesting that the 30-year low unemployment rate was not stoking inflation.

title: Bid Made for Piece of Ailing Irish Phone Company
description: One year ago, 500,000 Irish retail shareholders in Eircom P.L.C., the former state telephone company, saw the 42-year-old entrepreneur Denis O'Brien as a persistent threat to their investment.

title: Lawren Stewart Harris
description: Americas Society

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUHN, LENORE
description: KUHN-Lenore. Our deepest sympathies to Leo, Jimmy and Bobby and their families on the passing of Sunnie, an exceptional lady we were privileged to know. The Steele Family

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Unexpectedly, Series Brought Fans Together
description: Strange that something so extraordinary and enchanted had such a familiar ending. For Yankee fans, that accustomed rush of self-satisfaction in their hearts; for Mets followers, that old sunken feeling in the pit of the stomach.

title: JOINT VENTURE TO SELL MOLSON BRANDS IN U.S.
description: Molson said yesterday that the Adolph Coors Company had agreed to pay $65 million for a 49.9 percent stake in a joint venture to sell Molson brands in the United States. Molson, Canada's largest brewer, will own the rest of the venture and retain ownership of its brands in the United States, Molson said in a statement. United States sales account for about 20 percent of Molson's revenue, the company has said. The venture is expected to be completed by the year's end. Coors, based in Golden, Colo., also agreed to use some of Molson's Canadian breweries to make its own beers, including Keystone Light.

title: Insider Is Chosen to Lead Lincoln Center in Rebirth
description: After a national search for its next president, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is poised to name one of its own, Gordon J. Davis, the chairman of Jazz at Lincoln Center and a former New York City parks commissioner, to lead the organization through the nation's biggest arts rebuilding project.

title: Johan Grimonprez
description: 'Inflight!'

title: An Election Equation: Nader and the X Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: SALES DOUBLE, PROFIT TRIPLES AT JDS
description: The world's largest manufacturer of fiber optic components, the JDS Uniphase Corporation, said its first-quarter sales more than doubled to $786.5 million, while net income excluding acquisition costs and amortization nearly tripled to $177 million. Including acquisition costs, JDS had a loss of $1.02 billion, compared with a $113.9 million loss in the year-earlier quarter. ''Acquisitions, just like product development, are part and parcel of our strategy,'' said Jozef Straus, the chief executive of JDS Uniphase. ''I expect us to continue acquiring as we grow.'' The results, which were closely watched after jitters over sales hurt the share prices of several fiber optic companies this week, fueled active after-hours trading in JDS Uniphase stock, which fluctuated between $70.56 and $77.63 after closing regular trading at $74.44, up $3.44. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: F.B.I. Investigates Letter Threatening Bombings in City
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik said yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating copies of a letter sent to two Midtown Manhattan hotels and The Washington Post that threatened Palestinian bombings of Times Square and other New York locations in early November.

title: Van Gundy Sees Little To Laugh About in Loss
description: An hour before game time, only a handful of Knicks were shooting baskets. Instead of warming up, most players were sitting casually in a locker room at Nassau Coliseum Wednesday night, smiling and laughing as they watched a videotape of their last meeting with the Washington Wizards.

title: British Wrongly Lulled People On 'Mad Cow,' Report Finds
description: For 10 years, British officials consistently misled the public by deliberately playing down the possibility that mad-cow disease could be transmitted to humans, an official report said today.

title: Jewish and Catholic Scholars Seek Pius XII's Files
description: Dissatisfied with published Vatican documents on the role of Pope Pius XII during World War II, a panel of Jewish and Catholic scholars asked today for access to closed Vatican archives.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: NEXTEL LOSS NARROWS
description: Shares of Nextel Communications fell more than 20 percent as investors, worried about growth in the wireless telephone company's subscriber base, ignored a smaller-than-anticipated loss. Nextel, as expected, added fewer subscribers in the third quarter than analysts had predicted, contributing to a sell-off of its shares. Nextel said its net loss narrowed to $236 million, or 31 cents a diluted share, from $361 million, or 55 cents, a year earlier. Analysts had forecast a loss of 37 cents a share. Nextel's revenue climbed 59 percent, to $1.4 billion, in the third quarter.

title: Residential Real Estate; Prices Cool a Little for Apartments in Manhattan
description: Market surveys by two major brokerage companies indicate that average sales prices for Manhattan apartments moderated a bit in this year's third quarter, with one report showing a 5 percent increase and the other -- coming off a record average price of almost $855,000 during the previous quarter -- indicating a 7.7 percent decline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ALEXANDER
description: WOLF-Alexander. Congregation Beth Sholom mourns the passing of Alexander Wolf, founding Member, Benefactor and Trustee. Beloved husband of Ruth, loving father and grandfather.

title: Visiting Rights Denied in Embryo Mix-Up Case
description: A white woman from Staten Island who gave birth to a black couple's baby after an embryo mix-up at a fertility clinic was denied visiting rights to the boy yesterday by an appeals court.

title: Championship Thoughts From O'Neill Turn to Dad
description: The sensitive question about how much Paul O'Neill has thought about his deceased father during the World Series was asked, and O'Neill instantly started fiddling with the index finger on his left hand. There were two wedding bands on his finger, one thick gold band and a much thinner gold band resting beneath it.

title: European Report Says Hong Kong Tycoon Is Too Influential
description: This is a city ruled by business, so it is little surprise that a businessman, Li Ka-shing, is widely thought to be Hong Kong's most powerful person. The question is whether Mr. Li has become too powerful even for a city that celebrates his kind of empire-building.

title: Public Interests; Full Nelson in Florida
description: History will look back and remember this as the presidential campaign in which candidates finally understood the importance of combining the very best characteristics of participatory democracy and professional wrestling.

title: CONSOLIDATED SERVICE BOUGHT BY ABN-AMRO UNIT
description: ABN-Amro Lease Holding, the leasing unit of the largest Dutch bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Consolidated Service Corporation, based in Chicago, for an undisclosed sum to become the world's largest auto-fleet management company. The purchase adds 400,000 vehicles to ABN-Amro's fleet at LeasePlan USA, making it the No. 2 manager of leased cars in the United States, with 527,000 cars. It increases ABN-Amro's global fleet to 1.2 million, just ahead of rival GE Capital Fleet Services', the company said. The acquisition is ABN-Amro Lease Holding's second this year. It bought Dial Group, the vehicle-leasing unit of Barclays P.L.C., with 115,000 cars, in April for $424 million. Consolidated Service's president will become a senior vice president of LeasePlan USA.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Gains in Investment Banking Bolster Performance of UBS
description: Continuing a pace set by United States banks, UBS of Switzerland, one of Europe's largest banks, reported results yesterday that exceeded analyst expectations as profits at UBS Warburg, its investment banking arm, more than doubled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, JONATHAN
description: ALTMAN-Jonathan. A resident of Scarborough, N.Y. On October 26, 2000. Age 51. Beloved husband of Cynthia B. Altman, father of Sara, brother of Carol Morganstern, son of Zelda Weintraub Altman and the late Milton Altman. title: An Escape From Words, Into a Sea of Teeming Energy
description: The Belgian-born French poet and writer Henri Michaux began to draw and paint in 1927, when he was 28. By then he was living in Paris, thrilled to have escaped Brussels, had been in print for five years and was becoming known for idiosyncratic writings full of invented words, fantasy narratives and stream-of-consciousness musings. In 1925, exposure to the work of Paul Klee and Max Ernst had alerted him to the possibility that Western painting might not be a dead end, condemned to simply repeat reality. (''As if there weren't already enough . . . of that awful reality,'' he later wrote.) He took up art in earnest in the mid-1930's, building on inspiration gained on a trip to Asia.

description: NEWBERGER-Jeanne Ellen. October 24th. Beloved daughter, sister, aunt. Services Friday 12 noon Gutterman's Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Metro Business Briefing; SPITZER OPPOSES UTILITY MERGER
description: New York's attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, said he opposed Consolidated Edison's proposed merger with Northeast Utilities under the state Public Service Commission's current agreement, which allows Con Ed to pass on increases in energy rates to its consumers. The commission has already approved the merger, but yesterday Mr. Spitzer called for changing its terms, saying that it would be bad for consumers unless the commission rejected Con Ed's request to extend its ability to pass on incremental costs. That ability was responsible for a 30 percent increase in residential electric bills this summer, Mr. Spitzer said in a written statement submitted to the commission yesterday. Con Ed wants the commission to extend its rate agreement until March 2005. Paul Zielbauer

title: AIRLINES AND SUPPLIERS TO MERGE INTERNET EXCHANGES
description: Nine airlines and three aerospace parts suppliers said yesterday that they would merge their Internet-based purchasing exchanges, AirNewco and MyAircraft, to create a single venture with wider participation. The combined site, which has not been named, is expected to start up by March. AirNewco was formed in April, while MyAircraft was formed in February. The site will be designed for use by buyers and sellers of goods including jet fuel, spare aircraft parts and catered meals. Combining the exchanges will cut operating costs, making the exchange more valuable for its backers, said one analyst.

title: W. H. SMITH SAYS EARNINGS GREW
description: W. H. Smith P.L.C. said its profit for the year grew 7 percent as the company reduced retail space and focused on selling higher-margin books, magazines and stationery at the expense of lower margin compact discs and videos. For the year ended Aug. 31, profits grew 7 percent, to $:90 million ($156 million), compared with $:84 million ($120.4 million ) a year earlier. Sales jumped 5 percent, to $:1.5 billion ($2.15 billion). Losses in the company's Internet division, including $:1 million ($1.4 million) of development costs, doubled to $:8 million ($11.5 million). The company's shares rose 5.7 percent after the results were announced. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Corrections

title: SBC MOVES ON LONG DISTANCE
description: SBC Communications Inc., which is known to most of its customers as Ameritech, Southwestern Bell or Pacific Bell, asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to sell long-distance service to its customers in Kansas and Oklahoma. The Telecommunications Act of 1996 allows local phone companies to enter the long-distance market on a state-by-state basis as they convince the F.C.C. that they have opened their local networks in those states. So far, Verizon Communications Inc. has been allowed to offer long distance in New York and SBC in Texas. SBC is known as an aggressive company, and yesterday's application was an aggressive regulatory move. There is less local phone competition in Kansas and Oklahoma than in either New York or Texas, so the commission's approval could set a new and potentially lower bar for the other Bells to clear. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: Putting Music Back Together Again
description: The conductor Kristjan Jarvi was 7 when his family left Estonia for the United States in 1979. But even before, as a young boy in his home town of Tallinn, he was transfixed by the rock and pop music being broadcast over the one television station from Finland that reached Estonia.

description: Three British players and a Frenchman topped the leader board at seven under par after the opening round yesterday at the Italian Open in Is Molas, Sardinia.

title: In Stirring Ritual Steps, Past and Present Unfold
description: We need theater that joins history to ritual, and not because ritual should transcend history, but because ritual can transform it. You can witness this transformation if you are lucky enough to see Ratan Thiyam's Chorus Repertory Theater of Manipur, India, performing Mr. Thiyam's ''Uttar-Priyadarshi'' (''The Final Beatitude'') at the Brooklyn Academy of Music through tomorrow. The history is ancient, set in the second century B.C. and based on the life of Ashoka, the third in a line of cruel, brilliant warriors who had conquered much of northern India. The history is modern, too, lived out with patriotic gore in every part of today's world. A ruler (an emperor then, a president or general now) must choose between tyranny at home and abroad and the kind of justice and compassion that is based on liberation.

title: Metro Business Briefing; WCBS-TV NEWS PARTNERSHIP
description: WCBS-TV in New York will introduce a partnership with television, radio and online media outlets on Monday that pools the organizations' resources to provide news coverage. WCBS-TV, channel 2, will broadcast reports from the news consortium, which will be called the CBS 2 Information Network. The WCBS-TV News 2 division, one of the partners, will be renamed CBS 2. Its news segments will use resources and content from other partners, including: CBS News, CNN, Court TV, The Daily News, Hollywood.com, Office.com and VH1 News. In addition, CBS 2 will televise VH1 News documentaries, Court TV crime reports and Office.com business stories. Many CBS 2 stories will be available at www.cbsnewyork.com.

title: Grafting an Autumnal Sound Onto Sondheim's Reflections
description: Just when it seemed as if Barbara Cook had achieved a plateau of vocal perfection reached by only a handful of cabaret performers, this great American singer, who turned 73 on Wednesday, has made another artistic leap forward. The conceptual seed of her new show, which plays through Nov. 25 at Feinstein's at the Regency, is a recent article in The New York Times Magazine in which Stephen Sondheim named songs he wished he had written.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRY, WALTER
description: BERRY-Walter. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of beloved artist and friend, Walter Berry. He made his Met debut in 1966 as an unforgettable Barak in the company premiere of Strauss' ''Die Frau ohne Schatten,'' and was subsequently heard at the Met in nine other roles, including three new productions: Don Pizarro in ''Fidelio,'' Telramund in ''Lohengrin,'' and Baron Ochs in ''Der Rosenkavalier.'' All of his portrayals were imbued with deep artistry and intelligence and an uncommon beauty of voice. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

Cendant, which franchises Coldwell Banker, Century 21 and ERA residential real estate brands, will end up with a 15 percent stake in Homestore.com. The purchase would give Homestore

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, DON
description: BROOKS-Don, 53. Musician, died October 25 of Acute Myelogenous Leukemia. A world-class harmonica player, he was known for his distinctive tone and lyrical style. Don moved to New York from Dallas in 1968. He worked with such notables as Harry Belafonte, Judy Collins, Waylon Jennings, Willie Nelson, Carly Simon, Bette Midler and David Byrne. He appeared on Broadway in ''Big River'' and ''Gospel at Colonus''. He will be remembered as a wonderful husband, exemplary step-father and loving brother. A private gathering for family and friends will be held at home on Sunday from 4-8 PM.

At Weill Recital Hall on Monday, Young Concert Artists presented one of its recent audition winners, Mimi Stillman, in a program devoted mostly to 20th-century works. Ten blocks uptown, at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening, the new music ensemble Sequitur presented its flutist, Patti Monson, in a recital that largely duplicated the program of ''Conspirare,'' her just-released debut recording for CRI Records.

Inside, a handful of Yankees showered off the acrid scent of dried Champagne, dirt and sweat, dressing quickly to join the championship celebrations across the city. Rushing out were Derek Jeter, Jorge Posada and Mariano Rivera.

As a Democrat seeking her fourth two-year term in the Arizona Senate, where Republicans have a two-seat majority, Ms. Hartley is one of several incumbents that state Republican leaders have singled out in their fight to maintain control of the chamber.

title: The Subway Series Ride
description: Somehow, this World Series has seemed too short. It probably would have seemed too short to New Yorkers even if it had gone to seven games, each one of them as long as the record-breaking first game. But if it had to end, it could hardly have ended in a finer, more emblematic manner than the contest that took place on Thursday night between the Yankees' pitcher, Andy Pettitte, and the Mets' pitcher, Al Leiter, who seemed, until his final moments on the mound, to be growing stronger and stronger. All of the Yankees' usual heroes -- Bernie Williams, Paul O'Neill, Mariano Rivera and Derek Jeter, who was named M.V.P. -- made it possible for the unusual hero, Luis Sojo, to win Game 5, and with it the 26th World Series in the history of this remarkable team.

title: Israeli Troops Shoot 4 Palestinians Dead in New Violence
description: Israeli soldiers shot four Palestinians dead today as violence flared across the West Bank and Gaza Strip after several days of relative calm.

title: AUCTION HOUSES SIGN PACT TO REPAY $512 MILLION
description: Sotheby's and Christie's completed an agreement yesterday to pay $512 million to settle claims that they cheated about 100,000 buyers and sellers in a price-fixing scheme dating back to 1992. The civil settlement, to which they agreed on Sept. 22, comes as prosecutors for the Justice Department stepped up efforts to conclude a three-year criminal investigation focusing on evidence that the world's largest auction houses stifled competition by colluding on a wide range of business practices. Last month, Sotheby's pleaded guilty to violating antitrust laws, as did Diana D. Brooks, Sotheby's former president and chief executive. Officials at Christie's turned over documents to the Justice Department in January and in return received conditional amnesty. Carol Vogel (NYT)

title: Student Is Charged With Killing 18-Year-Old Over Silver Chain
description: A student at a Manhattan special education high school has been charged with murder in the shooting death of an 18-year-old man who refused to turn over his silver neck chain, the police said yesterday.

title: On Each Side, Accusing Fingers Over Nasty Turn in Campaign

title: Senate Passes Spending Bill Clinton Has Vowed to Veto
description: Following the lead of the House, the Senate today approved a $37.7 billion spending bill that President Clinton has promised to veto. But even as they defied the president with the vote, the Senate's Republican leaders called for negotiations with the White House to iron out their differences on the legislation.

title: A Sharper Warning on Warming
description: The international panel of climate scientists considered the most authoritative voice on global warming has now concluded that mankind's contribution to the problem is greater than originally believed. In addition, the panel warns that warming over the next 100 years could increase even more than originally estimated. Its worst-case scenario calls for a truly unnerving rise of 11 degrees Fahrenheit over 1990 temperature levels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENBERG, FRIEDEL ROTH SCHILD
description: LICHTENBERG - Friedel Roth schild, on Oct. 26, 2000. Beloved widow of Al Lichtenberg. Mother of Judith and Frank Lichtenberg, grandmother of Andrew and Alexander Lichtenberg and Daniel and Rachel Luban, mother-in-law of David Luban & Michelle Sullivan. Memorial service at 12:30 P.M., Sunday, October 29, Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue White Plains, New York.

title: Playing Again, 2 Partners Find That Hearts Are Trump
description: The world of tournament bridge can be considered an enormous club, in which members come and go, perhaps resuming acquaintance after a lapse of many years.

title: In Rural China, a Steep Price Of Poverty: Dying of AIDS
description: To celebrate the Moon Festival last month, a frail retired doctor named Gao Yaojie scraped together money to hire a taxi, packed it full of medicines, brochures, sweet drinks and cakes -- and slipped off, once again, from this provincial capital to see patients in remote mud-brick villages where countless farmers are silently dying of AIDS.

description: To the Editor:

title: Alliance Profits Up 49%
description: Alliance Capital Management Holding, which acquired the money manager Sanford C. Bernstein earlier this year, said yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 49 percent, powered by new business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, FLORENCE (BOOK MAN)
description: BERNSTEIN - Florence (Book man), 89, Friday, Oct. 27. Beloved wife of the late Gad Bernstein. Devoted mother of Ellen Joy of Williamstown, MA,. & stepmother of David L. (Deborah Brudno) of Washington, DC. Loving aunt and friend. Memorial service Sunday October 29, 3 PM, The Riverside 180 West 76th St, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Simon Wiesenthal Center or Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Marceau, Stuck Inside a Hat, Says, '  '
description: There's pleasure in any show that depicts a panorama of gentleman's hats advancing ominously across a lovely blue sky. The image -- ridiculous, loaded and acutely entertaining -- is one of the climactic joys of ''The Bowler Hat,'' which completes its United States premiere run tomorrow at the Kaye Playhouse.

title: Chancellor Blocks Top Choice for Bronx Science
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has blocked a cherished homegrown administrator from heading the prestigious Bronx High School of Science and, according to an alumnus who has spoken with him, is hoping to recruit someone of the caliber of a Nobel Prize-winning scientist.

title: Franks Shows His Persona
description: This 30-second commercial, titled ''My Turn,'' was released by Representative Bob Franks, a Republican, in his campaign against Jon S. Corzine for the United States Senate seat from New Jersey.

title: The Devils Are Sloppy, But Rally 3 Times to Tie
description: The Stanley Cup is proving heavy for the Devils this season, but the champions appear to be up to the challenge.

title: A Pianist Plays American
description: Leon Bates devoted most of his Sunday evening recital at Carnegie Hall to American piano music composed in the first half of the 20th century, a part of the literature that has long been the backbone of his repertory. And as a programmatically puzzling side trip, perhaps meant to cleanse the palate between the angularity of Copland's Variations and the dreamy softness of Barber's Ballade, he glanced toward Japan for two brief, gently dissonant works by Takemitsu, ''Rain Tree Sketch'' (1982) and ''Rain Tree Sketch II'' (1992).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKMULLER, SIDNEY M.
description: ROCKMULLER-Sidney M. On October 26, 2000. Much loved husband of the late Rebecca; father of Ellen and Joel, Seth and Katharine, and Clifford and Doris; grandfather of Tahra, Ben, Anna, Emily and David; companion of Hannah Schub; and brother, brother-in-law, and uncle to a close and loving family too numerous to name. His love of family and solid presence throughout our lives enriched us all. Services Sunday 10:00 AM, October 29, at ''Gutterman's'' Funeral Home (Parkside Building), 98-60 Queens Boulevard, corner of 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, New York.

description: A runaway train is about to hit five men, and the only way to save them is by pushing the person next to you onto the tracks in front of it. Should you do it?

title: Corrections
description: An Oct. 19 Op-Ed article misidentified the newspaper where the headline ''Who's a Bum?'' appeared. It was The Daily News, not The Brooklyn Eagle.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Oct. 3 about ''Building Big,'' a five-part PBS documentary about feats of architecture and engineering, misstated the year in which an ill-fated bridge, then the world's longest, was built across the Firth of Tay in Scotland. It was completed in 1877, not 1890. A picture caption with the review misidentified the bridge shown and the date of the scene. It was a recent photograph of the Firth of Forth bridge, also discussed in the documentary, not an 1890 view of the Firth of Tay bridge. A correction prepared on Oct. 3 went astray at The Times.

title: With Ice in Their Veins, Yankees Took Charge
description: The monumental Subway Series had been over for about an hour when a soggy Joe Torre trudged through the third-base dugout runway holding the championship trophy as snugly as he would hold his 4-year-old daughter. Torre carried the trophy into the small manager's office at Shea Stadium, noticed that there were not enough family and friends with him and came back outside to wave more in. It was as if Torre were playing host to a party in his hotel room, again.

title: Valentine's Remarks Draw Bombers' Ire
description: The celebration in the Yankees' clubhouse spilled over into the players' lounge, with the Champagne flowing freely as players crowded into the room in the back of the locker room. But the joyous tone changed when the television flickered across an image of Mets Manager Bobby Valentine at his somber postgame news conference.

title: Sports of The Times; Torre Stands At Top Of Class
description: THE most brilliant manager in the history of the New York Yankees -- at least in this century -- sat behind his desk in his Yankee Stadium office yesterday afternoon, a day after guiding his team to its fourth World Series championship in five years. ''This one was the toughest,'' said Joe Torre, and perhaps the most improbable.

title: Giuliani Opens His War Chest, but Not Too Wide
description: The former manager of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's disbanded Senate campaign said yesterday that the campaign would transfer ''hundreds of thousands of dollars'' to state campaign committees for New York Republican candidates next week.

title: Brooklyn Man Arrested in Series Of Sex Attacks and Robberies
description: Detectives searching for a gunman who has sexually assaulted and robbed four women since September used a scrap of information from an apparently unrelated crime to trace a suspect to his home within a mile of where all the attacks occurred, the police said yesterday.

title: How a Mighty Power Was Humbled by a Little Skiff
description: It is called a houri, Arabic for a small workaday boat with an outboard motor that can be purchased for as little as $2,000 in almost any Yemeni port. But after what occurred here this month, the houri may never look the same again, at least to those who grieve for the 17 American sailors killed in the suicide bombing attack on the destroyer Cole.

title: Stifling the Source of the Surplus
description: As debate rages this season about how to spend the federal budget surplus, no one is discussing the real forces that generated it and how to keep them healthy. Many Americans understand that our unprecedented economic well-being comes from mining the extraordinary vein of basic knowledge laid down by our research universities over the last few decades.

title: Giuliani Seems to Back Hooky, Again
description: Everything he ever needed to know about figuring out the city's drop in crime he learned from baseball. Just ask.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Oct. 14 showing the biggest one-day gains in the Nasdaq composite index misstated the percentage change in the index one day after each such gain and five days after it. A corrected chart appears today, on Page C2.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LESHEFSKY, LEAH KLEIMAN
description: LESHEFSKY-Leah Kleiman. October 28, 1975. We miss you. All of us

title: That's Dr. Boss To You: A Dropout As B.M.O.C.
description: Bruce Springsteen is a community college dropout. His songs have barely touched on higher education since his first album, in 1973, when he sang ''some hazard from Harvard was skunked on beer.'' Yet he now has a campus presence that many a Ph.D. would envy.

title: HERCULES HIRES GOLDMAN, SACHS TO WEIGH POSSIBLE SALE
description: Hercules, a specialty-chemical maker that recently replaced its top executive after sagging share prices and declining profits, said yesterday that it had hired Goldman, Sachs to review options, including a sale of the company. Shares of Hercules, based in Wilmington, Del., have fallen as much as 58 percent this year. Hercules said third-quarter profit dropped 77 percent as costs rose and the dollar strengthened. Hercules has been trying to pay down heavy debt and stave off rising materials costs since its $3.1 billion acquisition of BetzDearborn in 1998. Its debt was about $3.5 billion as of June. Its market value was about $2 billion as of July 31.

title: Gas Station Attendant Dies In a Shooting in Brooklyn
description: A night attendant at a Brooklyn gas station died early yesterday, shortly after he was shot three times in the course of an attempted robbery, the authorities said.

title: The Mets Win! The Mets Win!
description: As a die-hard Mets fanatic, I'm disappointed that the team didn't accept Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's invitation to take part in Monday's ticker-tape parade down the Canyon of Heroes in lower Manhattan to honor the World Series champions.

title: Strong U.S. Demand Helps Volkswagen Profit
description: Volkswagen, Europe's largest carmaker, said today that third-quarter profit rose 50 percent because of the weakness of the euro and strong demand in the United States for Jetta sedans and Audi TT coupes.

title: MEXICO INVESTIGATES COKE
description: Mexico's antitrust commission said it began a formal proceeding against Coca-Cola to determine if it was guilty of monopolistic practices in Mexico. Coke, which had a 64.6 percent share of Mexico's $5 billion soft drink industry last year, has been accused by competitors of placing unfair exclusivity demands on stores that stock its products. The decision comes after representatives of the commission and Coke failed to negotiate an agreement. The affair has led to a dispute between Coke and PepsiCo Inc., the company that had accused Coke of violating fair trade practices. Coke said Pepsi refused to negotiate a settlement, but Pepsi said Coke refused to accept its latest offer. Graham Gori (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, MARY CECELIA GLEASON
description: SULLIVAN-Mary Cecelia Gleason, died October 26. Beloved wife of the late Joseph J. Sullivan. Devoted mother of Joseph J. Sullivan Jr. and Cecelia Sullivan Murray. Cherished grandmother of Joseph J. III, Sean P. & Shane P. Sullivan, Suzanne Sullivan Fraser, Megan and John F. Murray III, Michele Murray Sloan & Meredith Murray Landino. Loving great-grandmother of Aidan Fraser, Emily Cecelia, John Prentice, Peter and the late Robert Sloan III. Calling hours Sunday, 2-5 PM, Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, is at 10 AM, Monday, October 30th.

title: Read My Leadership Skills, Bush Emphasizes in Broadening Campaign Speeches
description: There are times on the campaign trail these days when what Gov. George W. Bush seems to be offering is less a package of proposed legislation than a seminar on leadership.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's plans to return some political contributions, including one from a board member of the American Muslim Council, gave a misspelled name in some copies for Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's wife, who was in a group that the council president told of having met. She is Hadassah Lieberman, not Haddasah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ROSE (ZORNBERG)
description: GOLDBERG - Rose (Zornberg). Shalom-Fannie Zornberg Group of Hadassah mourns the passing of Rose Zornberg Goldberg whose distance did not lessen her dedication to Hadassah, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the family. Sarah Neumark and Flo Zornberg Co-Presidents

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKMAN, DORIS
description: GLICKMAN-Doris. Convener of Congenial Souls, who seasoned her banquets with love. Irene and David Tiersten.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MICROCHIP TECHNOLOGY, Chandler, Ariz., has agreed to buy TelCom Semiconductor, Mountain View, Calif., for about $300 million in stock.

title: Charles Gussman, 87, Dies; Spinner of Soap Opera Webs
description: Charles J. Gussman, who brought delightfully tangled plots, addictively picturesque characters and heaping doses of steamy romance to soap operas he wrote for radio and television, died on Oct. 18. He was 87 and lived on a farm in Holland, Pa.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Iranduba Journal; Snakes and Scorpions vs. the Census
description: Counting the 170 million or so inhabitants of a country that is larger than the 48 contiguous United States is not easy. But taking the census in the Amazon jungle, some of the most inhospitable terrain on earth, is even harder, as France Maria de Souza discovered when she set off one morning to interview 22 families living on an isolated island near here.

title: Trial Judge Comments on Microsoft Ruling
description: Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson says he knows his rulings in the Microsoft antitrust case are controversial, but he has no regrets, even though, as he put it today, ''virtually everything I did may be vulnerable on appeal.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONGHIA, CARMELLA
description: DONGHIA-Carmella, mother of the late Angelo Donghia, passed away Friday, October 27, 2000. Born on October 3, 1913 in Tyler, Pennsylvania, Mrs. Donghia is survived by a brother, James Ferraccio and two sisters, Amelia Krotzer and Pompey Sciullo. She moved to NYC in 1968 to assist her son in his design endeavors and remained a mentor to Angelo Donghia throughout his career. Funeral services will take place at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church located at 869 Lexington Avenue on Monday, October 30, 2000 at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers the family has requested that donations be made to Saint Vincents Hospital Comprehensive Breast Center.

title: Corrections
description: A photography review in Weekend on Oct. 6 about ''Distant Voices IV: Images of the Other America,'' an exhibition that was at the Puffin Room in SoHo through Oct. 15, misstated the language of a photo book title, ''Creencias'' (''Beliefs''). It is Spanish, not Mayan.

title: UNITEDHEALTH SAYS 3RD-QUARTER PROFITS ROSE 26%
description: The UnitedHealth Group said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 26 percent as it added more than one million customers and premiums grew faster than costs. Net income rose to $182 million, or $1.08 a share, from $144 million, or 81 cents, a year earlier. The company had been expected to earn $1.04 a share, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Revenue rose to $5.37 billion from $4.90 billion, as UnitedHealth raised rates about 10 percent. Shares of UnitedHealth, based in Minnetonka, Minn., rose $2.25, to close at $109.69.

title: At Finest Hour, Torre Doesn't Forget
description: As he accepted the World Series trophy yesterday morning, Yankees Manager Joe Torre paused to thank others.

title: NONSTOP FLIGHTS TO LINK BERLIN AND WASHINGTON
description: Deutsche Lufthansa, Europe's second-largest airline, said yesterday that it would begin nonstop flights in March between Berlin and Washington. It would be the German city's first direct air connection to the United States since 1998. The airline will begin six flights a week between Berlin Tegel and Washington Dulles airports on March 25 using, Airbus Industrie A340's, which seat 247 passengers. The airline is starting the service ''because the critical mass for such an intercontinental connection is beginning to emerge, following the move to Berlin by the government and a host of institutions,'' its chief executive, Jurgen Weber, said in a written statement. Germany's capital was moved to Berlin from Bonn last year.

title: Cooling Chicago, Starting With a Garden on the Roof of City Hall
description: Here amid the steel and concrete canyons, green grass grows. A naked cockspur hawthorn tree stands in new soil, and freshly dug plants bend in the wind.

title: Prudential Securities to Stop Bond Trading for Institutions
description: Three weeks after a shake-up of its top management, Prudential Securities is preparing to stop trading bonds for institutional clients and to lay off a few hundred traders and other employees, people close to the firm said yesterday.

title: Yanks Know How to Get The Job Done
description: As close as the Mets came to the Yankees in each game of the World Series, the feeling remains that the teams were really not playing in the same ballpark (and that doesn't mean Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium). The scores indicated two almost evenly matched teams, but the real story was told by the outcomes of the games, not the scores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, BARRY M.
description: ROSEN-Barry M. Died on Friday, October 27, 2000. He is survived by his beloved wife, Jane. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, October 29, 2000 at 1:00 PM. For further information please call the Hellman Memorial Chapels at 845356-8600.

title: In Heavily Democratic West Virginia, Apathy (or Worse) Toward Gore
description: With time running out, here is how things stand for Al Gore in heavily Democratic West Virginia: Even among a crowd that had

title: Media Giants in Joint Deal for Harcourt
description: The media giants Reed Elsevier and the Thomson Corporation are buying Harcourt General for $4.4 billion in cash and the assumption of $1.2 billion of debt, a lower-than-expected price for one of the largest acquisitions in the publishing business.

title: A Warning on Abortion Rights
description: This 30-second commercial, titled ''Divided,'' was released yesterday by Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for Senate from New Jersey, in his campaign against Representative Bob Franks. It is running on television stations in New York and Philadelphia.

title: Polling Attack Against Clinton Is Reported
description: The New York Republican State Committee is conducting a telephone campaign attacking Hillary Rodham Clinton's record on issues of importance to Jewish voters, and a Manhattan man who received such a call yesterday described it as push-polling -- a technique disavowed by reputable pollsters in which a caller claims to be doing a survey but asks loaded questions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, JONATHAN
description: ALTMAN-Jonathan. A resident of Scarborough, N.Y. On October 26, 2000. Age 51. Beloved husband of Cynthia B. Altman, father of Sara, brother of Carol Morganstern, son of Zelda Weintraub Altman and the late Milton Altman. Funeral service on Sunday, 12 Noon, at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Donaldson Securities Sale
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. is putting the finishing touches on its last sale of commercial mortgage securities ever. The $1.3 billion effort is the last sale before the pending acquisition of the firm by Credit Suisse First Boston is completed. The firm was No. 4 in commercial mortgage sales in 1999.

title: Insecurity Once More Casts a Pall in Kosovo
description: As the West rushed to embrace Vojislav Kostunica's recent emergence as president of Yugoslavia, Kosovo's Albanians -- suppressed for years by the Serbs until NATO intervened last year -- felt threatened once more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, ROSEMARIE
description: SCHINDLER - Rosemarie. Our heartfelt condolences to Charles, Diana and Carl Giuseppone as well as her most cherished grandchildren, Katie and David. Take comfort in the fact she is at peace. Carol and Richard Kalikow

title: Miriam M. Salpeter, 71, Expert On Neuromuscular Disorders
description: Dr. Miriam M. Salpeter, a neurobiologist whose research contributed to the understanding and treatment of neuromuscular disorders like myasthenia gravis, died on Tuesday at Cayuga Medical Center in Ithaca, N.Y. A resident of Ithaca, she was 71.

title: In the Idioms of Ballet and Not-Ballet
description: There was plenty to think about in the program presented by American Ballet Theater on Thursday night at City Center. Three of the four works made distinctive statements about the art of classical ballet. The fourth had nothing to do, at least superficially, with ballet.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the campaign for governor in West Virginia misstated the surname of the incumbent in some references. He is Cecil H. Underwood, not Underhill.

title: New 'Labels' for Diamonds Sold by Sierra Leone
description: Sierra Leone has resumed exporting diamonds under a new plan approved by the United Nations, which imposed an embargo three months ago on selling the country's gemstones to keep the revenues from fueling an intensive civil war, industry executives and traders said today.

title: A Fan's Unanswered Prayers
description: I'm starting to question the relationship my priest has with the Maker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, JEROME
description: EDELMAN-Jerome. Age 87 of Boca Raton, FL., formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y. Died October 26, 2000. Beloved husband of Lillian. Loving father of Martin (Carmen) Edelman of N.Y.C., and Lynn Edelman of Playa del Rey, Calif. Dear brother of Esther Levine, N.Y.C., and Isidore Edelman, N.Y.C. Cherished grandfather of Dana and Gabrielle Edelman. He was a member of the International Academy of Trial Lawyers, The Association of Trial Lawyers of America, and the NY State Trial Lawyers Association. For information Shalom Memorial Chapels, Margate, FL 1-877-554-7878

title: Moms and Dads, at Work and at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrest Made in '95 Killing of Retired Teacher Who Clung to Purse
description: A convicted robber has been arrested in the 1995 killing of a retired schoolteacher who was savagely beaten on a residential street in Queens when she refused to let go of her purse, the police said yesterday.

title: THE REAL REALITY TV
description: It's the age of the media thon, a relentless hybrid of media circus, soap opera and tabloid journalism. Some stars -- Monica Lewinsky, O. J. Simpson and Woody Allen -- talk about being at the center of the storm, and the line where journalism may have teetered into fictionalized entertainment. A report by Frank Rich in The Times Magazine.

title: Lincoln Center Chief Dusts Off Welcome Mat
description: ''I can assure you I will not hit the ground running,'' said Gordon J. Davis, who was formally named yesterday as the next president of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. ''I will walk in and take careful steps.''

title: Lazio and First Lady Quarrel On Ethics, Israel and Schools
description: Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton engaged in a quarrelsome hour of bickering and badgering in their final debate yesterday, as they attacked each other's ethics, commitment to Israel and proposals to improve the nation's education system.

title: Excerpts From the 3rd and Last Debate Between Clinton and Lazio
