title: Sports of The Times; For Mets and Yankees, There Is, in the End, a Sense of Closure
description: INSIDE the Mets' clubhouse early yesterday morning, there was a library hush to the room. The Mets had just lost to the Yankees in the fifth and final game of the World Series. Players spoke in muted tones, but unlike after previous disappointments against the Atlanta Braves, there was no sense of devastation. They played great against a great team, and lost.

title: A Big Fantasy Camp Suddenly Evaporates
description: The people of New York knew that it would have to end, the way they know that the winds of November will soon be blustering up Broadway. Still, this thing of theirs, this World Series, seemed to end all too soon.

title: Valentine Is Hoping to Stay, But He Has Some Options
description: Twelve hours after the end of the World Series, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine sat comfortably in a seat that had once seemed so hot. Valentine, wearing khakis and a Mets golf shirt, sat in his office at Shea Stadium and spoke with ease and candor about the World Series and his uncertain future.

title: INSIDE
description: Ivory Coast Foes Meet

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL WINS $400 MILLION PARTS CONTRACT
description: Federal-Mogul said it won an engine-parts contract valued at about $400 million from an undisclosed North American automaker. The contract is for designing and building a system, starting in 2002 the company said. Federal-Mogul, which is based in Southfield, Mich., has struggled with falling demand for replacement parts and lower-than-expected savings from a series of 1998 acquisitions. Its shares have fallen 87 percent in the last year.

title: Similar Views In a Campaign For Congress
description: The race for Congress in New York's Second District has plenty of ingredients for great political drama. One of 35 open spots in the close battle for control of the House, the seat is held by Rick A. Lazio, who is giving it up to run for the Senate. And the Republican candidate, if successful, could be the first black woman from her party elected to Congress.

title: Yankees Parade Set for Monday
description: The ticker-tape parade in honor of the Yankees' World Series victory was scheduled by City Hall yesterday to start at noon on Monday.

title: After His Jersey Is Retired, Nets' Martin Takes Charge
description: At first, Kenyon Martin seemed unfazed about having his No. 4 jersey retired at the University of Cincinnati's Shoemaker Center, as if hanging with the Hall of Famers Oscar Robertson and Jack Twyman were an everyday experience.

title: Gore Offers and Seeks Assurance in Pennsylvania

title: Ramirez, Mussina Among Free Agents
description: Manny Ramirez and Mike Mussina, two of the most talented players eligible for free agency, were among the first 10 players to file yesterday, the first day of the filing period. Also on the list was Mike Bordick, the Mets' shortstop, who was the first World Series player to file for free agency.

title: Lazio Labors To Become Heavy Hitter
description: BEFORE baseball finally loosens its fierce grip on the autumnal city, please indulge one more image from that sport. Think of Representative Rick A. Lazio as the Babe Dahlgren of New York politics.

title: Start Spreading the News: All New York Won
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Puts Limit On Politicking By the President
description: The Gore campaign has told President Clinton to steer clear of battleground states like Michigan and Pennsylvania in the closing days of the presidential race to avoid alienating the swing voters who will play a crucial role in choosing his successor, Democratic officials say.

title: Suspect in Candy Store Shooting Is Killed in Police Raid
description: A New Jersey man suspected in the shooting deaths of a candy store patron in Union, N.J., on Monday and a Boy Scout in Virginia last month was himself shot to death early yesterday morning, officials said, by police officers who raided his mother's house about eight blocks from the store.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, TIMOTHY J.
description: SHEA-Timothy J. Of Kipps Bay. On October 25, 2000. Beloved husband of Frances. Loving father of David Brooks. Cherished grandfather of Victoria Brooks. Funeral from Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28th St on Monday, 9:30 AM. Mass of Christian Burial at Epiphany Church, 10 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Friends may call Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEICHNER, THEODORE W.
description: ZEICHNER-Theodore W. October 26, 2000. Longtime attorney with MFY Legal Services. Beloved husband of Gwen. Devoted father of Steve and Rachel. Loving grandfather of Sarah and Elizabeth. Dear brother of Leo Zeichner and Dorothy Geller. Service Sunday 11:30 AM, Plaza Memorial, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Memorial service on Wednesday, November 1, 3:00 PM, New York County Lawyers' Assoc., 14 Vesey Street, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONSAL, JEAN C. (CAVEN)
description: BONSAL-Jean C. (Caven). Of Upper Montclair, on October 25, 2000. Beloved wife of Richard I. Bonsal. Loving mother of Julia L. Bonsal Esq., Mrs. Sarah Bonsal Miller, Mrs. Martha Bonsal Day. Sister of Sara Caven Boland. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at the St. James Episcopal Church, 581 Valley Road, Upper Montclair, today, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Montclair Public Library, 50 S. Fullerton Ave., Montclair, NJ 07042, in Mrs. Bonsal's memory would be appreciated.

title: Safety Note
description: Fire prevention authorities recommend that smoke alarm batteries be changed twice yearly, at the start and the end of daylight time. The change occurs tomorrow morning.

title: Lazio Shifts Campaign Focus to Women's Issues
description: As independent polls show Hillary Rodham Clinton gaining ground among women, her opponent, Rick A. Lazio -- and his wife and other surrogates -- have embarked on a flurry of events focusing on women, including breakfasts, luncheons and tours of breast cancer treatment centers.

title: Hartford to Cancel Contract For Auto Safety Inspections
description: Gov. John G. Rowland said today that he planned to end Connecticut's $2.2 million annual contract for auto safety inspections with the company that performs them, after seven of the employees were charged this week with taking bribes from drivers in return for clearing vehicles with safety defects.

title: Excerpts From the 3rd and Last Debate Between Clinton and Lazio
description: Following are excerpts from the debate yesterday between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio, as recorded by The New York Times. The moderator was Gabe Pressman of WNBC-TV in New York:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Higher Interest Rates Slowed Economic Growth

title: Unfair Car Loans
description: Black plaintiffs have sued automobile finance companies because, they say, the companies charged them more for their loans than they charged comparable white borrowers. The lenders reject the accusation that their loans are racially discriminatory, pointing out that they never knew the race of the borrowers. That might seem like an ironclad defense. But the Department of Justice does not think so, and it has properly weighed in on the side of the plaintiffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDERMAN, YETTA
description: SCHNEIDERMAN-Yetta. On October 26, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Will. Loving mother of Brenda and Ely Lurin, Michael and Paula, and Lois Glickson. Dear sister of Mac Goldin. Cherished grandmother of Marcia, Scott, Eileen, Brian, Joe, Jay, and Julie. Adoring great-grandmother of Lily. She will be missed and remembered. Service Sunday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th & Amsterdam Ave

title: Selling Evolution in Ways Darwin Never Imagined; If You Can Build a Better Gene, Investors May Come
description: Novo Nordisk is designing better enzymes for detergents. Dow Chemical is trying to cut the cost of food processing. Pioneer Hi-Bred is aiming for better crops, and MedImmune a stronger version of its main drug.

title: To Our Readers
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, as well as information about errors that call for correction. Messages may be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left at this toll-free number: 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). For comments on an editorial: letters@nytimes.com.

title: TRINITY MIRROR BUYS SOUTHNEWS
description: As British newspaper groups consolidate to cut costs and broaden advertising revenues, Trinity Mirror, the country's biggest regional publisher, said it agreed to buy Southnews, based in wealthy southeastern England, for $409 million. Trinity Mirror, the acquisitive creation of Trinity's purchase of Mirror Group last year, said the price of 1,200 pence ($17.40) a share represented a 57 percent premium over Southnews's closing price yesterday. Trinity Mirror shares slumped by as much as 2.9 percent, to 452 pence ($6.55), while Southnews stock soared by 54 percent, to 1,175 pence ($17.03). Alan Cowell (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Johnson and Tindall Collect Ivy Titles
description: Enda Johnson of Brown, a junior from Ireland who broke his right foot last March during the indoor season, captured the Heptagonal Games Association men's cross-country title, covering the five-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx in 24 minutes 56.3 seconds yesterday.

title: As Turandot, Jane Eaglen Is Less Steely Than Soaring
description: Last season the soprano Jane Eaglen was a major presence at the Metropolitan Opera, singing in the new production of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' and the revival of Wagner's ''Ring,'' and doing her best work in New York to date. This season Ms. Eaglen appears only in the title role of Puccini's ''Turandot,'' a run of nine performances that began on Tuesday night.

description: ANTIOCO-Paul W. Devoted husband of the late Angelina (nee Aliotta). Beloved father of Anne ''Millie'' Madden, Rosalie Arnao, Peter, Esq., Marie Baldizzi and Paul Anthony. Cherished by 13 grandchildren and 13 great grandchildren. Dear brother of Vincent, Stella Iside, the late Fred, Victor, Nancy Damiata, and Julia Palmieri. Mass at St. Paul's 9:30 Monday. In repose Raccuglia & Son, 321-323 Court St, Brooklyn. 718-855-7737

title: At 6-0, Sooners Regain Old Glory
description: It is the little things, like the oranges that are showing up on campus again. It is the big things, like Barry Switzer, the favorite son and former coach, showing up on the sideline. It is the familiar things, like talk-radio programs buzzing with all things Sooners. It is the forgotten things, like a big game in October against a bitter rival.

title: Sanyo Will Replace Refrigerator Parts
description: The Sanyo Electric Company, one of Japan's largest home electronics companies, said today that it was providing replacement parts for 180,000 refrigerators because the doors might fall off.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Big officials tell small officials to deny it's here, and so people don't get help.''

title: Hillary Clinton's Slap at Muslims
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Writers Receive Whiting Awards
description: Ten writers deemed to show exceptional talent and promise have been named winners of this year's Whiting Writers' Awards, carrying a prize of $35,000 each. Among the recipients named by the Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation, acting on nominations by a selection committee of writers, literary scholars and editors, were five fiction writers, three poets, one nonfiction writer and one playwright.

title: Got the Glue Sticks?
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y.  Halloween is upon us, but I'm still recovering from the quest for every last item on my kids' school- supply shopping lists. Even as educators around the country pledge to put a laptop in every backpack, they're demanding that parents provide everything from unglamorous essentials like crayons and tissues to little luxuries like Post-It notes, blank computer disks and film for the class camera. Isn't that what taxes are for?

title: SEAGRAM SELLS RUM BRAND
description: Allied Domecq P.L.C. has secured the rights to the Captain Morgan rum brand, which is part of the Seagram wine and beverage business that is up for auction. Seagram is selling the unit, valued at about $7 billion, as part of its planned merger with Vivendi of France. Allied Domecq secured the rights through an alliance with with Destileria Serralles, a Puerto Rican rum supplier that has the right of first refusal should the Captain Morgan brand change hands. Likewise, Vin & Sprit of Sweden is expected to exercise similar authority over its Absolut vodka brand, which is also part of the Seagram portfolio. Vin & Sprit is bidding for the entire drinks division jointly with Bacardi and Brown-Forman, although that agreement does not include the rights to Absolut. Diageo P.L.C. has also submitted a bid jointly with Pernod Ricard S.A. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, ALICE L.
description: GOLDSMITH-Alice L. On October 26, 2000. Beloved wife of the late John J. Loving mother of John C. & Peter B. Devoted grandmother and great grandmother. Funeral services are private.

title: The Challenge at Chevron Texaco: Taking the Necessary Risks
description: David J. O'Reilly, those who know him contend, is an exceedingly nice man. Considerate, they say, down to earth, a good listener. He is also chairman of Chevron, which last week agreed to take over Texaco to create the world's fifth-largest oil company. Is a nice guy up to the task?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESSLER, IRA RICHARD
description: RESSLER-Ira Richard. Died on October 27, 2000 in New York City at the age of 78. Beloved husband for 50 years of Dorothy, devoted father and father-in-law of Bruce & Ellen Ressler, Jonathan Ressler, Debra and Leon Black, Richard and Alison Ressler, and Antony Ressler and Jami Gertz, loving brother of Gladys Nachamkin and the late William Ressler, and adored grandfather of Benjamin, Joshua, Alex, Victoria, Matthew, Michael, Samantha, Jillian, Andrew, Rebecca, Oliver, Nicholas & Theo. Ira Ressler was a decorated veteran of the United States Army Air Corps in World War II where he served with distinction, receiving the Air Medal for Bravery and the American Defense Service Medal with Star. He was a respected member of the New York Bar & a highly regarded trial attorney with his own firm, Ressler and Ressler, for 52 years. His proudest achievement was his family-his wife and children, their spouses and grandchildren-around whom his life truly centered. Funeral at 10 A.M., on Sunday, October 29, 2000 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street.

title: 4 Killed by Israelis As Violence Flares
description: Israeli soldiers shot and killed four Palestinians as violence ignited across the West Bank and Gaza Strip after several days of relative calm.

title: Uneasy Peace Takes Hold in Ivory Coast as Cabinet Is Formed
description: An uneasy calm returned to the Ivory Coast today as the new president and his opponents held meetings suggesting a truce in the political crisis that has shaken this corner of West Africa for a week.

Cherished grandfather of 13. Dear brother of George, Joyce Clements, Laura Bry, Nicholas and Carol Kane. Proud member of Steamfitters Union Local 638. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St. Garden City Sat. 7-9PM and Sun 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday 10AM St. Josephs R.C. Church, Garden City. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery, Locust Valley, New York.

title: In Michigan, a Swing State, Bush Picks Words Carefully
description: At a private Christian high school in this conservative region of southwest Michigan, Gov. George W. Bush brought an overflow crowd of faithful Republicans to their feet today -- though he often sounded like a Democrat.

title: Religion Journal; With Texas Group's Proposal, Struggle Among Baptists Enters a New Phase
description: A week ago, former President Jimmy Carter made the unexpected announcement that he was severing his lifelong ties to the Southern Baptist Convention. He would remain active in his church in Plains, Ga., he said, but he would no longer consider himself a member of the denomination itself, which he said had become ''increasingly rigid'' theologically under a conservative leadership.

title: Defending Lincoln's Legacy From a Confederacy of Culture Warriors
description: ''Who are we, anyhow?'' asks the intellectual historian John Patrick Diggins about Americans in this quirky, plucky and agitated book. One possible answer may be this: We are those who have to ask.

title: Blacks Stick With Gore Despite Differing Views
description: If he were headed to the polls today, Curt Farrison, a real estate broker in the predominantly black neighborhood of South Norwalk, would gladly pull the lever for Al Gore. But Mr. Farrison, whose three children are all grown, said he disagreed with the vice president's opposition to vouchers, which would let poor parents use tax dollars to send their children to private schools.

title: Don't Scare the Voter
description: To the Editor:

title: Hillary Clinton's Slap at Muslims
description: To the Editor:

title: TOSHIBA IS PROFITABLE AGAIN
description: Toshiba said it earned 53.9 billion yen ($498 million) on revenue of 2.8 trillion yen ($25.8 billion) for the six months that ended Sept. 30. Toshiba said that rising sales in chips, PC's and other information devices helped it turn around from a group net loss of 48.5 billion yen ($448 million) for the first half of last year. The manufacturer said it expected to report a full-year profit of 137 billion ($1.3 billion) yen on sales of 6.2 trillion yen ($57.3 billion). Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Abroad at Home; Why It Matters
description: If George W. Bush is elected, one probable result will be to put meaningful campaign finance reform off indefinitely. That is not only because Governor Bush is opposed to serious change in the system. It is because of the appointments he is likely to make to the Supreme Court, which has the last word on whether and how campaign spending can be limited.

title: Article 2000102890617060353 -- No Title
description: IOWA CITY, Oct. 27  Hoping to siphon votes from Vice President Al Gore, Republicans in three closely contested states prepared to broadcast a television commercial featuring Ralph Nader, as the candidate himself campaigned here tonight and continued to aim his sharpest barbs at the Democratic ticket.

title: In a Pastiche of Movements, Fussing Mixes With Flirting
description: Garth Fagan likes to build works out of scraps of movement, which he combines as it suits his fancy. This choreographic disjointedness can sometimes be refreshing, for the dances are unpredictable. At other times sequences become hodgepodges.

title: Article 2000102890276660515 -- No Title
description: From inflammatory telephone calls to voters by allies of Vice President Al Gore, to incendiary new television spots by supporters of Gov. George W. Bush, the presidential race reached a new level of mean- spiritedness yesterday. And each side sought to portray the other as the one dragging the campaign into the mud.

title: SULZER DROPS BID FOR MEDICA
description: The Swiss engineering conglomerate Sulzer has dropped its plan to merge with Sulzer Medica, one of Europe's biggest medical device companies, after investor criticism led to a decline in both companies' share prices since the deal was announced last month. The proposed merger could not overcome the market's preference for companies that deal only in a single field, Sulzer said. The company will retain its 74 percent stake in Sulzer Medica, which is listed in Zurich and New York, but indicated it was considering a bid for Zimmer, a medical unit of Bristol-Myers Squibb. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, ROBERT M.
description: CARROLL - Robert M. The Trustees and Staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn with deep sadness the passing of their respected colleague and friend, Bob Carroll, who was Armorer in the Department of Arms and Armor. At the Museum for the past 31 years, he was responsible for the conservation and installation of one of the largest and most important collections of arms and armor in the world. Always in good humor and with a sharing spirit, he worked in an unbroken tradition that had been passed down since the Middle Ages from one master craftsman to the next, using a combination of centuries-old tools with modern techniques. We extend our condolences to his entire family. He was an exceptional man. He will be greatly missed. Philippe de Montebello, Director

title: Rangers Are No Match For Jagr and Penguins
description: The best hockey player in the world and the worst team money can buy collided at Madison Square Garden last night. The result was all too predictable.

title: Saving Literary Gems
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Own Words
description: AL GORE

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sept. 23 about intervention by the world's major central banks to support Europe's unified currency, the euro, misstated the record high of the dollar against the German mark. The 1985 figure, above 3 marks, was not the record; the dollar was as high as 4.2 marks in April 1956. A reader's e-mail message in late September about the error was initially mis directed at The Times, and this correction was further delayed by efforts to verify past price data.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNSTONE, MINA
description: BROWNSTONE-Mina. Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, mourns the passing of Mina Brownstone Abramowitz, National Promotion Director, 1938-1981. Her unique, creative talents in print and film enabled us to reach untold numbers of new members and donors. Bonnie Lipton, National President

title: Giants Are Forced to Adjust on Defense Again
description: The Giants have been the second-best team defending the run in the National Football League this season. They rank 27th in pass defense.

title: PSION WARNS ON PROFIT
description: Psion P.L.C. said its full-year profit will be well below analysts' estimates because of a weaker euro and higher component prices, and its stock fell 29 percent. Psion's chief executive, David Levin, said the company's profit would be well below the $:6 million to $:11 million expected by analysts. He declined to provide further details. Psion, a pioneer of hand-held computers, is facing competition from the market leader Palm Inc. and others such as Compaq Computer and Hewlett-Packard. Psion was hurt by a strengthening dollar, which it uses to pay for components, and a weakening euro, which it receives for about half its sales, said Craig Breheny, a Psion spokesman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZER, HAROLD
description: SALZER-Harold. Beloved husband of Sally, devoted father of Peggy, Michael and Debi. Adoring grandfather of Jessica & Charlie. A celebration of Harold's life will be held at 5PM Monday, October 30 at Beekman Tower, 3 Mitchell Place (49th St & 1st Avenue). In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Windward School, Windward Ave., White Plains, NY 10605.

title: CONGRESS BACKING PROJECTS AT HOME AT A RECORD PACE
description: A few years back, the people of Toledo, Ohio, began building a new four-lane boulevard linking the northern edge of town to Interstate 280. But the money ran out before they could put on the finishing touches.

title: Sorry, Lads, Now Men Are From Venus
description: WHO does the American man -- specifically the American man somewhere between 25 and 39 with enough money to come home with a single-batch bourbon and $36 tub of Geo F. Trumper's sandalwood shaving cream every now and then -- really want to be? If one were to use the GQ Men of the Year Awards as a measure, the American male doesn't yearn to be staggeringly tall or unkempt or in possession of an affect suggesting he could get Vendela to go to Caracas with him for the weekend if he wanted. The American male looks up to those generally short in stature, hard-working, self-effacing and devoted to children and wives on whom they presumably don't cheat.

title: Marya Gwadz, Nicholas Viorst
description: Dr. Marya Gwadz and Nicholas Nathan Viorst were married yesterday by Dr. Khoren Arisian, a senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, at the Metropolitan Building, a converted factory that is now a space for social functions, in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Raised in a Barn?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRITSCH, STEVEN
description: TRITSCH-Steven. The Board of Governors and Members of Elberon Bathing Club mourn the untimely death of our longtime friend and member, Steven Tritsch. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Robert Fagenson, President Jane Guadagno, Secretary

title: Exploring History's Closet: They Were What They Wore
description: THE word costumes brings to mind slender mannequins dressed in fashionable period clothes -- ball gowns, perhaps, or outstanding examples of what ladies and gentlemen once wore to a wedding or a coronation. Yet the holdings of the costume and textile collection of the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford were not chosen for their aesthetic appeal -- although some of them are handsome indeed -- but for their historical associations, for what they bring to our understanding of the past.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-29-00: Economics of Frequent Flying; Heavy Mileage
description: HIGH-FLIERThis week, the frequent-flier mile takes its next step into hard currencyhood. MilePoint.com will enable the loyal customers of six of the biggest U.S. airlines to exchange their miles for up to 20 percent off goods from 140 retailers, including Amazon.com and the Sharper Image. This comes on the heels of American Airlines's new venture with America Online, AOL AAdvantage, which earns miles for those who subscribe to Time and lets consumers spend them on a George Foreman grill, for example. The mile, says Randy Petersen, publisher of InsideFlyer, ''is not just a currency for the airlines anymore. It's a currency for everybody else.'' He should hope so; he has a stake in the new venture.

title: New York to Albany Faster, via France
description: The rail trip between New York City and Albany will be cut by 30 minutes, to about two hours, as rebuilt high-speed French-designed turboliners are put into service and tracks and signals are upgraded to accommodate them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADGER, MARY ELIZABETH ''LIZ''
description: BADGER-Mary Elizabeth ''Liz'' passed away unexpectedly on October 21, 2000, at the age of 68. Liz was born in New York City, the daughter of James and Alicia Owens Boeri. Liz was a graduate of Middlebury College and received her Doctorate in Educational Psychology at the University of London. After the death of her husband Sherwin in 1968, Liz and her three young sons moved to England. Liz worked as an Associate Professor at Central London Polytechnic and as a Senior Research officer for the National Foundation for Educational Research in England and Wales. When she returned to the United States in 1982, Liz worked first for the Massachusetts Department of Education as Assessment Director, and then for the College Board as Director of Instructional Assessment. Liz retired two years ago and spent time traveling, visiting with her family, enthusiastically improving her photography skills, and volunteering for Doctors Without Borders. Liz is survived by her sons, Campbell and Matthew Badger, her daughters-in-law Joanna Badger, Juliet HolmesSmith and Madonna Badger, her sister Alicia McGinely, and her grandchildren, Sam, Alice, Thomas and Mary Elizabeth. Predeceasing Liz was her oldest son Mark Badger. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mary Elizabeth Badger Fund, Doctors without Borders P.O. Box 2247, New York, NY 10116-2247.

title: Why This Nostalgia For Fruits of Chaos?
description: THE Communist Party of China is like the bright sun,'' sang Granny Sha, her face glowing through wrinkles of sorrow as she told of abuse at the hands of a ''poisonous snake, bloodsucker'' landlord in Kuomintang-ruled China. Her words, soaring and elongated in the lyrical gymnastics of Beijing opera, were punctuated by a roar of applause from the audience in the Yifu Theater here. ''Without the party, my whole family would have been wiped out long ago,'' she concluded, joined by many audience members, spontaneously singing along.

description: The Girl in the Picture

title: Clueless in Virginia

title: Ideas & Trends; There'll Be a Quiz On This Tomorrow
description: Using materials found in your home, design assignments that will allow schools in the United States to keep up with those in other countries, allow parents to keep up with the Joneses, but will not keep students up at night. In your answer, you should consider the influence of the Horatio Alger narratives on American society and the impact of longer working hours on the average American family. Parents should be involved, but not too involved. Remember to factor in time for soccer, piano lessons, family togetherness, and a healthy dose of childhood exploration and fun (your answer should define healthy). Those who do not ultimately secure a good job will receive a failing mark. Extra credit for those who gain admission to a college in the U.S. News and World Report Top 20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ROSE ZORNBERG
description: GOLDBERG-Rose Zornberg. On Oct. 26, 2000. Beloved mother of Marcia L. Greenbaum and her companion Dale Bairstow, David J. and Sharon Goldberg. Loving grandmother of Fara R. Greenbaum. Dear sister of Dr. Edward and Florence Zornberg. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Service Monday 10AM. Plaza Memorial 91st St at Amsterdam

description: LOOKING for the perfect Christmas gift? How about a personal submarine for $20 million? Or a family of decorative robots, at $6,000 to $14,000 each? (Barko, the robot dog, barks and wags his tail; one has been sold.)

description: In 1626, in a purchase that would become legendary, a Dutch settler named Peter Minuit bought the island of Manhattan from American Indians for $24.

title: Running Backs Thriving as Reclamation Projects
description: The oddity of his situation is never lost on Oakland Raiders running back Tyrone Wheatley. When he was with the Giants, Wheatley used to joke that he was the most expensive scout-team player in history. He was as maligned a draft pick as the organization had ever seen. Two years later, few running backs are playing better or running harder. Some opponents have actually said that his punishing style is intimidating.

title: Subway Elevators Whose Troubles Never Seem to End
description: It has been two months since the reopening of the Clark Street subway station, and the middle elevator is out of service. Again.

description: To: My Successor

title: Uncharted (Hot) Waters at a Korean Spa
description: ALL the road signs and billboards in Sokch'o, a small city on Korea's east coast, were a mystery to me, since I don't read Hangul, the Korean alphabet. But I imagined that one of them proclaimed: ''Sokch'o: Exfoliation Capital of the World.'' Only two days after my arrival in this region, where rocky mountains tumble to a wide, sandy seacoast, my skin had turned a shade of hot pink, thanks to vigorous scrubbings, followed by repeated plunges into water hot enough to leave me feeling lightly poached.

description: Fifth Quarter

title: Shifting Rules Add Luster to Trusts
description: THE long bull market has left some people with more wealth than they -- and their children -- will ever need. But barring some extreme act of profligacy by their immediate heirs, the super-rich face the prospect of having that money whittled away again and again by estate taxes with each passing generation.

title: Presidents Find They Must Share Limelight
description: Fidel Castro and Hugo Chavez, the charismatic president of Venezuela, are accustomed to the spotlight and gravitate toward it almost instinctively. But today they found themselves competing for attention with an unexpected interloper: the Yankees reserve infielder Luis Sojo.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-29-00; Pro Pharma
description: Here's an unfashionable romance: I love America's pharmaceutical companies. As a slogan, ''Better Living Through Pharmaceuticals'' still has a campy, futuristic ring to it, but for me, at least, there's nothing sci-fi about it. Because I have H.I.V., I swallow around 800 pills of prescription drugs a month and around 400 extra pills -- vitamins, antidiarrheic, antinausea pills and the like -- to contain the side effects of the first 800. That's close to 15,000 pills a year. When I first tested positive, I had a dream that I was walking down the street shaking like a baby's rattle because there were so many pills inside me. Eight years later, that shaking has become white noise. I asked my pharmacist the other day to tote up the annual bill (which my insurance mercifully pays): $15,600, easily more than I pay separately for housing, food, travel or clothes.

title: A Hunt for the Gems in Genomics
description: CAMILO MARTINEZ remembers the joke circulating around Wall Street not that long ago: If you want to cause a buying stampede among investors, just insert the prefix ''gen'' into a company's name.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm a fool. I knew it wasn't going to work.''

title: Farmingville Organization Shows Ugly Side
description: So the Sachem Quality of Life Organization is surprised that so many Long Islanders view them as anti-immigrant extremists [''Border Warriors,'' Oct. 22]? What do they expect when one of their spokesmen said in published reports that the Army should be sent to Farmingville? When asked what the Army would do there, he responded that they would tell the immigrants to move on, if not, they would be shot. This same spokesman, Ray Wysolmierski, has publicly called Americans who have spoken up against the harassment of Latinos in Farmingville ''traitors'' and suggested that justice for such individuals would include hanging.

title: ATTACK ON COLE IS RAISED AS ISSUE IN NEW YORK RACE
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton denounced Representative Rick A. Lazio yesterday over a telephone campaign by the New York Republican Party in which callers were told that she took money from ''a Mideast terrorism group -- the same kind of terrorism that killed our sailors on the U.S.S. Cole.''

Kopinski, the other manager, speaks fluent Japanese. Collectively, the 14 American Century international analysts speak 13 languages, including Ukrainian, Cantonese and Afrikaans.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bon Voyage
description: To the Editor: My grandmother used to go to Germany every year for the mud baths in Bad Nauheim. During Prohibition, she was approached by the ship's captain the night before the ship docked in New York. He told her he had a bottle of Champagne for her if she could get it through Customs. Grandma tied the bottle to a string around her waist so it dangled between her legs, which she covered with a long skirt. As she walked down the gangplank the next morning the captain rushed up and said that he hoped she had not put the bottle in a warm place as it might explode.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, MARILYN
description: SAVAGE-Marilyn. 10/29/45-2/9/94. I can imagine you at 55-looking 35. Still wonderful, still impossible. Miss you every single day. Love, Vicki

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about Lee Radziwill misspelled the surname of the landscape architect who designed the gardens at Hammersmith Farm, a family home. He was Frederick Law Olmsted, not Olmstead.

title: Giants Might Want to Find Better Middle Management
description: This being an election year, it might be worthwhile for the Giants to move a little toward the center.

title: Campaigns Soft-Pedal On Children and the Poor
description: The question of government services for poor families and children has largely been absent from the United States Senate campaign trail in New York. And yet it is among the most vexing issues that the next senator will have to face.

title: The World; Is Serbia's Victory Kosovo's Loss?
description: THE fall of Slobodan Milosevic is a disaster at least for Kosovo's hopes for independence. The election in Belgrade of the apparently reasonable, legally minded Serb, Vojislav Kostunica, has spoiled that dream, and consequently, Kosovo has become a more explosive place, providing a further test for Western troops and diplomacy.

title: Reckonings; Drawn And Quartered
description: Devotees of good bad movies fondly recall that very 60's spy spoof ''The President's Analyst.'' The protagonist was pursued by various powerful, sinister organizations, including the government of Canada. But the most powerful of all was T.P.C. -- The Phone Company.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Page 6 last Sunday with the Frugal Traveler column, about Seoul, misidentified a palace in the city. It was Changdeokgung Palace, not Deoksugung.

title: The Nation; It's Even Worse Than You Thought
description: A report published by the Henry L. Stimson Center, a public policy institute, concluded that the threat of terrorist chemical and germ attacks had been overstated, but described surprising details of the probable aftermath of such attacks.

title: Jackson: The Net Out Of Nowhere
description: Four weeks ago, Stephen Jackson was just a name on the Nets' training camp list, one not even Coach Byron Scott recognized.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTENSEN, MARTIN R.
description: MORTENSEN-Martin R. On October 25, 2000. Formerly of Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of Anne and the late June. Loving father of Bradley, Scott, John, Tracy Murray and Kate. Cherished grandfather of 13. Dear brother of George, Joyce Clements, Laura Bry, Nicholas and Carol Kane. Proud member of Steamfitters Union Local 638. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St. Garden City Sat. 7-9PM and Sun 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday 10AM St. Josephs R.C. Church, Garden City. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery, Locust Valley, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, NORMAN E.
description: GLUCK-Norman E. On October 20, at age 86, in Rio Rancho, New Mexico, after a brief illness fought with courage, dignity and clarity of mind. Loving and devoted husband of the late Rose B. Dear friend, companion and golf partner of Katie Holzer. Devoted and caring brother of Helen, the late David and the late Etta Ungerfeld and brother-in-law of Shirley B. Krass. Much cherished and respected uncle of Joann Rollnick, Ellen Krass and Stephen and Sallie Krass; great-uncle of Kathy and Gerald Berenstein, Nancy and Lawrence Jacobson, Stephanie and William Hepner, Caroline and Adam Levy and Jamie Krass; and great great-uncle of Samantha, Chelsea, Jamie, Benjamin, Jennifer and Jason. Norman, a consummate gentleman, touched the lives of many people, each of whom is privileged to have known him and to have benefited from his guidance, intelligence and wisdom. He was a very special person and will be greatly missed. Contributions in Norman's memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: A Nonbeliever's Plaint: Who Let the Fans Out?
description: IN ''Bright Lights, Big City,'' Jay McInerney's narrator ducks into a New York bar where there's a basketball game on TV. A barfly offers some obscene commentary.

title: Dust Off Those Fishnets, Fellas
description: Was it really 25 years ago that we first met that ''Sweet Transvestite'' Dr. Frank N Furter? Talk about a Time Warp. To celebrate the silver (lame) anniversary of ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show,'' Fox Home Entertainment has released it on DVD. An accompanying ''Absolute Pleasure'' marketing campaign features more than 100 licensed tie-in products, including action figures of the mod doctor (right), Riff Raff and the tap-dancing groupie Columbia. To see them, you can click on www.rockyhorrorat25.com.

title: Fujimori Fires 3 Top Aides In Military
description: President Alberto K. Fujimori replaced the commanders of the Peruvian army, navy and air force today as the manhunt for his former spy chief failed for the fourth day in a row.

title: Free Ride at Heathrow
description: The Heathrow Express, a train that links Paddington Station in London with Heathrow Airport, is offering free trips to United States citizens Nov. 18 through 23 as a Thanksgiving gift; just show a United States passport at Heathrow Express ticket offices at the airport or Paddington. The train takes 15 to 22 minutes between London and Heathrow's four terminals. One-way fares are typically $17.70, or $29.50 first class, with a $1.48 discount for online or telephone orders (at $1.48 to a pound). Information: (44-845) 600 1515 or at www .heathrowexpress.co.uk.

title: Halloween? Boo! Humbug!
description: WHEN I was growing up, Halloween was a one-day affair. We dressed up in costumes and went trick-or-treating. The most we expected, other than candy, was permission to stay up late to watch the Peanuts Great Pumpkin special.

title: For the Adventurous, New Possibilities in Latin America
description: CARLOS ASILIS, emerging-markets equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, is seeing the kind of small changes in the correlations between markets that help analysts change their minds.

title: Yemen Restricting F.B.I. Access to Suspects in Cole Bombing
description: With the investigation of the Cole bombing at a crucial stage, Yemen's government is refusing to allow the F.B.I. to question suspects or witnesses, attend interviews with them or move at will around Aden to follow clues, raising fears that evidence-gathering may be delayed or even suppressed, sources within the American investigation said today.

title: Ah, the Good Old Bad Old 70's
description: ONE of my clearest memories of adolescence is of a T-shirt, worn by a fellow eighth-grader whose name I don't remember, but on whom I seem to recall having a crush. It was black, with hot-pink French-cut sleeves, and across the front was a precis of recent American history: ''50's were grease/60's were grass/70's are gross.'' At the time, this account seemed irrefutable. By nearly universal agreement, there had never been a worse time to be alive, and to be young was especially miserable. We were growing up in the aftermath of a vaguely heroic, splendidly tumultuous age -- ''the Sixties, man'' -- whose life-changing intensity we could never hope to know. The landscape around us was dull, ugly and decadent, and we seemed condemned to drag into adulthood the crippling sense of having been born too late.

title: The Stiff Guy Vs. the Dumb Guy
description: I was left with the impression that Marshall Sella (Sept. 24) favored Jay Leno's brand of political potshotting over David Letterman's. He seemed to find nobility in Leno's Jay-walks, citing them as a ''gentle reprimand to a big, dumb, lazy democracy.'' Gentle? Big laughs at the expense of the dim bulbs Leno illuminates and nationally humiliates? I like Jay, but I often cringe at his sophomoric style. Letterman rather likens himself to the befuddled Everyperson trying to make sense of all this political ''theater.'' Your writer was critical of the way he laid off Hillary after her visit to his show. She happens to be the First Lady, and after a very appropriate -- and very brief -- interval, her head was firmly back on Dave's comedy block.

title: Catching Football on Film
description: Steve Sabol like many of his contemporaries in Haverford, outside Philadelphia, in the 1950's -- would rush home from school to turn on his favorite television show.

title: After 34 Years, Unable to Let Go Of 'The Prisoner'
description: FOR the last 23 years, with the intensity of Newton contemplating the apple, the Prisoner Appreciation Society has pondered, debated and speculated on the properties of certain integers:

title: Nixon's Contradictions
description: To the Editor:

title: Landlord Displacing A Tenant
description: Q. My landlord has just notified me of his ''intention to recover housing accommodation based upon owner's use.'' I have lived in my rent-stabilized apartment for 13 years. I don't believe that the landlord's intentions are in good faith since there has been a turnover of units in the building over the last several months and the landlord didn't move into any of those apartments when they became empty. Also, I am paying one of the lowest rents in the building. What should I do? Do I have a good chance of winning this case? . . . Paul Veneziano, Manhattan.

description: THE HOUSE

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 15 about the Adams family of Massachusetts and its roots in Quincy referred incorrectly to Thomas Jefferson's longevity among signers of the Declaration of Independence. He was not the last survivor of the group; on the day in 1826 that both he and Adams died, Charles Carroll of Maryland became the last.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, DAVID SAUL
description: LEVITT-David Saul. Loving companion of Herb Klein, died October 22 in Miami, FL. Formerly of N.Y. City, this beloved man touched us all with kindness, support and generosity. He left us all better for having known and loved him. Anne Lawrence, Shirley Ringer

title: Local Boards Enter Cyberspace: Call Them Dot.Comms
description: Community boards are trickling into cyberspace. Last month, Board 7 in Manhattan unveiled a Web site for residents of the Upper West Side, and Board 5 in Midtown plans to launch its site this month.

title: Treacherous Stretch For a Busing Leader
description: NO company buses more people around North America than Laidlaw Inc. Its 40,000 school buses transport more than two million students in cities like Rochester, and its 3,800 Greyhound coaches form by far the largest network in the United States. Laidlaw also operates 240 municipal transit services -- including those carrying commuters in Orange County, Calif., and the disabled in Boston -- as well as ambulance services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DU BOIS, ELVA MURIEL
description: DU BOIS-Elva Muriel. October 24, 2000 in Venice, FL. Loving wife of Edwin du Bois for 64 years. Mother of Diane du Bois and Roger du Bois.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GUTTERMAN, IRVING R.
description: GUTTERMAN-Irving R. Passed away fifteen years ago this week and fondly remembered. Meryl is getting married today and the Yankees won it in five. Steve and Henry

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAHMS, KAREN ALLISON
description: BRAHMS-Karen Allison. Karen was a special loving friend to Michael Netski, and daughter of Ronnie Brahms. Karen gave us wisdom and happiness. Her love & wonderful words will be with us always. Donations in her memory for establishment of Melonoma Research Fund, Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: October 22-28; Now It's Time To Play Geography
description: Put aside, for the moment, thorny subjects like economic policy and national security. The 2000 presidential campaign is down to a question of geography. Eighteen states are in play, political strategists say, and in a startling reversal of received political wisdom, the number of tossup states is actually growing as the days to election day dwindle down to a few.

title: When Italy Feels Like Home, or Is
description: FOR the more than 130,000 county residents with roots in Italy or for those who are simply lovers of things Italian -- the Festa Italiana today at Westchester Community College here may be the ideal way to spend a Sunday afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACHLIN, LUCILLE SHYEV
description: RACHLIN-Lucille Shyev. On October 14, 2000, age 96. Beloved wife of the late H.L. Rachlin, M.D., a longtime member of the New York Psychoanalytic Society. Smith College alumna, class of 1925. Attended University of Chicago, took an MSS at Smith, law degree at NYU. Worked for the N.Y. Police Department and the Jewish Board of Guardians. Survived by cousins Ovid Rose and Ray Morrison, nephew Richard Ullman, niece Beverly S. Goldberg.

title: Article 2000102992467981488 -- No Title
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Oct. 28  At every mention of the word "spoiler," the crowd groaned.

title: Fighting an Overpowering Urge To Have It Out With the Referee
description: ADMITTEDLY I was already in a paranoid frame of mind when the referee blew the opening whistle for my team's soccer game against Yonkers. Two starters on the team I coach -- a team of 11-year-old boys from Pelham -- arrived just 30 seconds before the game, and they were late for a maddening reason: the directions our opponents gave us had a serious error.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZER, HAROLD
description: SALZER-Harold. Beloved husband of Sally, devoted father of Peggy, Michael and Debi. Adoring grandfather of Jessica & Charlie. A celebration of Harold's life will be held at 5PM Monday, October 30 at Beekman Tower, 3 Mitchell Place (49th St & 1st Avenue). In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Windward School, Windward Ave., White Plains, NY 10605.

description: A rival baseball executive called Brian Cashman in the middle of June, and he could tell by the hurried pace of Cashman's voice that the Yankees' general manager was very, very busy. ''He's got a lot of stuff going on,'' the executive said.

description: Meredith Anne Hudes and Jorge Alberto Zamudio were married on Friday at Temple Emanu-El in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony.

description: RICHMOND, Texas -- A construction trench collapsed Saturday, killing three workers who were buried in 14 feet of dirt, authorities said.

title: MUSIC; Tastier Programs at the Bottom of the Food Chain
description: IT was a typical George Steel moment. Mr. Steel, the intrepid impresario of the Miller Theater at Columbia University, was scrolling through a list of potential concert possibilities he keeps in a computer file. ''I'd like to reorchestrate 'The Rite of Spring' for rock band,'' he said. ''And I'd like to do a piano series combining jazz transcriptions with hard-core modernism. You know, Bill Evans and Elliott Carter.''

title: Shades of Halloween: Mummy White and Bat-Wing Black
description: It's that time of year when creepy crawlers everywhere forsake their dark lairs for the telelvision screen's bright lights. What child doesn't appreciate a good Halloween scarefest - from tales of magic and mischief to fright-night features that send teenagers and their parents running for cover? Here is a selection of programming for young ghouls of all shapes and sites.

title: Rallying the Troops
description: KEN COWING had always been proud to wear his scoutmaster uniform, but after a Supreme Court decision in June confirmed the Boy Scouts of America's policy excluding homosexuals, he thought about putting it away.

title: Pregame Fare Served With a Lack of Taste
description: Last year, ''NFL This Morning'' was a promising Sunday studio show on Fox Sports Net from 11 a.m. to noon, Eastern time, starring Chris Myers, Marv Levy, Jackie Slater and Chris Spielman. Levy, the brainy former Buffalo Bills coach, and Slater, the insightful former Rams offensive lineman, were the emerging stars.

description: RAPHAEL-Aaron. Oct. 29, 1912Nov. 7, 1995. Happy Birthday, dear Papa. We love you. Your Family

description: The nation's largest public pension system has given up tobacco.
