description: IN the movie ''Dancer in the Dark,'' the factory worker played by Bjork daydreams her black-and-white life into a Technicolor musical, where, to the music of machinery, her co-workers become so many Fred and Gingers.

title: A Boomerang?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUNK, CYLA BAAR
description: TRUNK-Cyla Baar. Born 1915 in Boryslaw, Galicia. Died before Rosh Hashana in sheltering Manhattan. An avatar of the Jewishnational - home and justice. ''...virtue and absolution kissed.'' (Psalms). ''Light of the world of life's treasure/Lights prevail summoned from mist.'' (Mahzor). Jobian life, quintessential love, Holocaust survivor, Peretzian mentor, lucent heroine, both in war and as refugee in a vale of vanity. Pioneer lace designer in pre-war Poland, indefatigable toiler in the legacy of genocide, predeceased by her loving paradigms, Khantshe, Abish, Herman, Shayeh. Bereaves beloved Gabi by the grace of her martyred firstborn, Khunele.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFINKEL, SARAH (''SID'')
description: GARFINKEL-Sarah (''Sid''). Age 91, on October 28. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin, devoted mother of Alan Garfinkel (Ellie), and Janet Quinn (Thomas). Cherished grandmother of Ann Goodlow (Bob), Cassie Kelly (Chris), Michael Quinn (Karen), Stephen Quinn, Jim Garfinkel (Jill), Andy Garfinkel (Christine) and 12 greatgrandchildren. Graveside service. She will be missed.

title: Back and Forth Across the Borders of Gender
description: THE countertenor David Daniels hates the term ''falsetto.'' He understands that there is no other term to describe his technique. The dictionary definition of ''countertenor'' is a high male falsetto voice, meaning that it is achieved through an artificial method of voice production involving only partial vibration of the vocal chords. But the nomenclature drives him crazy: ''falsetto'' (from the Latin word for ''false''), ''artificial.''

title: Nets Coach Born to Be A Champion
description: Byron Scott calls his shot, his eyes dancing and his mouth forming an ''I got you now'' grin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODLINGER, JACK
description: MODLINGER-Jack. Our extraordinary uncle died on October 26. A beloved husband, father, brother, and brother-in-law. Larger than life, the loss of his presence will always be felt, eased only by our loving memories. We know your journey to heaven will be sure and swift. Jack, Wagons Ho! Contributions in Jack's memory may be made to the Jack Modlinger Scholarship Fund of the Kinneret Hebrew Day School, Riverdale, NY. Steven and Joel Yohay

title: When 'Just Sit Tight' Is the Wrong Advice
description: AT first it sounds like a grimly humorous way to describe what you suffered on your last airline flight, when you were wedged for hours in a tight seat and the tray table slammed into your belly like a karate chop after the passenger in front of you decided to recline for a snooze.

title: Behind Colombia's Election Hoopla, Rebels Wield Power
description: For weeks, this village of 3,000 on a verdant mountainside in central Colombia has been gripped by election fever, with candidates scouring for voters and colorful banners hanging across narrow streets. In a scene being repeated across Colombia in preparation for nationwide municipal elections on Sunday, noisy political rallies are staged in the village plaza, topped off with free barbecued beef and weepy vallenato music.

title: Mets to Have 2 Ceremonies
description: The Mets, having declined a mayoral invitation to take part in the ticker-tape parade for the Yankees tomorrow, will be honored in two, more modest, City Hall ceremonies, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Army Corps of Engineers Has Long and Storied Past
description: Even before there was a Declaration of Independence, there was the United States Army Corps of Engineers -- though that was not what it was called. It had no name.

title: The Art of Books
description: The term ''Book Arts'' can mean fine papers, calligraphy, bindings and prints. It can also mean works of art that play with the book form.

title: Madden and McKay Score 4 Goals Each
description: The Devils accomplished something tonight that had not happened in a National Hockey League game in 78 years: two of their players, Randy McKay and John Madden, scored four goals each in a 9-0 trouncing of the Pittsburgh Penguins at Mellon Arena.

title: Revisionist or Terrorist?
description: ''Vulgar'' and ''terrorist'' are not words that spring to mind in depicting early music. But Andrew Manze, the British violinist and director of the Academy of Ancient Music, has seen both printed in otherwise sober articles about his style and transcriptions. In Princeton tomorrow, when the much-recorded 17-member string ensemble performs pieces from the Baroque era, listeners will have a chance to judge for themselves.

title: Grand Entrances For Big-City Visitors
description: NEW YORK'S chronic shortage of hotel space seems especially severe in the fall, when the city is at its busiest and most alluring. But this year, a collection of new hotels -- with several more poised to open soon -- has, theoretically at least, improved the odds that visitors will be able to find a room.

title: Second in Command in D.A.'s Office Retires
description: IF anyone can speak authoritatively about the history of crime in Westchester, it is Francis T. Donohue.

title: Great Depression
description: I LIKE BEING KILLED

title: No Arcade, No Games (At Least Near School)
description: An application to build a video arcade opposite Booker T. Washington Junior High School, on West 107th Street, is not scoring points with local residents, who would like to zap the arcade as a major distraction and neighborhood nuisance. A committee of Community Board 7 has already voted against the application by Mireybi Vega Game Room to the Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Rachel Stern, Derek Davis
description: Rachel Laura Stern, a stage manager at the New York City Opera, and Derek James Davis, the company's manager, are to be married today. The Rev. Edward Kacerguis, a Roman Catholic priest, will officiate with Rabbi Joel S. Goor at Studio 450 in New York.

title: Vanessa Kroll, Roger Bennett
description: Vanessa Mara Kroll, a daughter of Lynn Korda Kroll and Jules B. Kroll of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday evening at her parents' house to Roger James Bennett, a son of Valerie Bennett and Judge Ivor Bennett of Liverpool, England. Rabbi Alfredo Borodowski officiated.

title: Persecution Charged in Ex-Soviet Republic
description: Beneath the silk head scarf, her eyes were filled with thought and prayer, grief and anger. Her voice was soft and urgent, as if spilling out the story of her husband might somehow bring him home.

title: The World: Why Things Fall Apart; A Slow, Preventable March Into Crisis
description: WITH its running tableau of disasters, both man-made and natural, Africa in the 1990's has shown an unerring knack for inspiring hand-wringing in the outside world and increasing self-doubt among Africans themselves about the waste and futility of half a century of independence.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIMONA, JOE
description: DiMONA-Joe. We commemorate the life of a great man, Joe DiMona. Joe was an exuberant New Yorker with a luminous wit. He was a writer of towering vision, prescience and existential cool. Chris O'Neil Martin Nirschel

title: Easter Island's Lures: Statues and Rock Art
description: Known locally as Rapa Nui, Easter Island in the South Pacific is famous for its hieroglyphiclike tablets and colossal figures carved from volcanic rock. The 64-square-mile island, about 2,300 miles west of Santiago, Chile, has nearly a thousand immense stone statues and hundreds of petroglyphs, line drawings carved into rock.

title: Kosovo's Albanians Flock to Polls as Serbs Stay at Home
description: Under the protection of the NATO peacekeepers who in effect freed them from Serbian rule, jubilant Kosovo Albanians swarmed around polling places today to take part in what they saw as the first genuinely free vote they had ever enjoyed.

title: Sports of The Times; The One Who Got Away, And the One Who Stayed
description: IN this unwavering New York story, this

title: The Right to Bargain
description: To the Editor:

title: Fraudulent Marketers Capitalize On Demand for Sweat-Free Diets
description: Slimming soaps that slough off fat in the shower. Miracle pills that get rid of excess pounds without dieting or exercise. Plastic earplugs that curb the appetite. Even a glittering ring called Fat-Be-Gone that when slipped on a finger trims hips, buttocks and thighs. After her second baby was born, April Mankowsky got to know all the latest weight loss gimmicks -- and tried her fair share of them, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUREL, AIMEE
description: LAUREL-Aimee. Of Bronxville, NY, on October 28, 2000. Mother of Paolo and Nicole; sister of Regina, Rico and Rafael Laurel. Calling hours Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 1-5 PM, Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Monday, October 30, at 11 AM.

title: All in the Neighborhood: Best Buy Eyes Yonkers Site
description: Best Buy Company -- the nation's largest electronics retailer -- is considering a site in Yonkers that could pave the way for a four-way confrontation between other national chains that sell televisions, stereos and camcorders.

title: INFORMATIONAL PAMPHLETS FOR VOTERS
description: Westchester County is distributing pamphlets to voters about the Nov. 7 referendum on the $59.5 million bond issue to replace the 85-year-old penitentiary in Valhalla. The pamphlet, in a question-and-answer format, outlines the proposal and gives reasons why a new county jail is needed. The county, which is distributing the pamphlets to community groups and placing them in libraries and other public buildings, wants to build a four-story, 58,700-square-foot prison made up of dormitories and invididual cells. Elsa Brenner

title: Sad Return for a Lucent Executive
description: WITH the exception of Richard A. McGinn, who was ousted last week as chairman and chief executive of Lucent Technologies, perhaps no one was more distressed by that corporate upheaval than Henry B. Schacht. Mr. Schacht, 66, who was Lucent's chief executive for two years after the company was spun off from AT&T in 1996, was called back to replace Mr. McGinn, his protege, whom he had helped groom for the job.

title: Dismay From a Populist Outpost on Iowa's Plains
description: The final disorder of Alzheimer's was casting away the memories of his life's twin endeavors, farming and politicking. But John D. Stegemann could still delight his family by suddenly retrieving a vivid scrap of something seen and felt back in his heyday as a prairie liberal politician.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 3 about the history of cultural programs in New York City public housing misspelled the surname of a violinist who lives in the Amalgamated Houses in the Bronx. A letter from his son, dated Sept. 25, pointed out that the violinist is Herman Liebman, not Leibman. This correction was delayed by an editing oversight.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Last on the Skids
description: ''It's just like I'm dead,'' says a former heroin addict who has been living at the paradoxically named Sunshine Hotel on the Bowery for eight years. ''Every day is the same.'' His is one of the 50 haunting voices and faces in four Bowery dives found in FLOPHOUSE: Life on the Bowery (Random House, $24.95), written by David Isay and Stacy Abramson, two radio producers, with photographs by Harvey Wang. Skid Row emerged at the end of the Civil War, which created homelessness on a vast scale. The area's 16 blocks held 25,000 to 75,000 men at its height, at the end of the 19th century through the middle of the 20th; the population today teeters around 1,000. The photographs are poignant black-and-white shots, wholly unsentimental. ''Got a short life left,'' says Mike Slokevace, who lives at the Andrews Hotel, which has the cheapest rooms -- cubicles really -- at $4.50 a night. ''As far as convenience goes, this is all I need -- a nice little bed, a place to sleep.'' The men have landed here in the expected ways: alcoholism, drug addiction, gambling, mental illness and plain old bad luck. Ted Edwards sums up his life as ''a failure within a failure within a failure.'' Oddly, despite what all the men have told them, the authors insist on their own romantic view of the Bowery bum and his habitat, calling the flophouses ''fascinating places, inhabited by the last residents of a world soon to vanish.'' Andrea Higbie

title: Indonesias Relations With U.S. Sour Over Charge of Meddling
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 29 -- Relations between the United States and Indonesia have deteriorated rapidly following a series of high-profile disputes between the American Ambassador here and Indonesian officials and lawmakers, who have accused the United States of meddling.

title: Style; Posh Spice
description: We may be living in modern times, but most people's idea of luxurious living is stuck in another century: when we think of a grand New York apartment, visions of robber-baron-style rooms, with red damask curtains and old master paintings, dance in our heads.

title: The Age Of the Mediathon
description: Birth of a Genre

title: Out of the Loop, Art From Chicago
description: ALTHOUGH it's now really the third city, Chicago has long been called the second city. But the sometimes coarse yet imaginative art that has been produced there hardly makes the charts, in terms of its general familiarity. As a corrective and introduction, the Whitney Museum of American Art's branch in Stamford is presenting ''Chicago Loop: Imagist Art 1949-1979.''

title: Janitors in Stamford Use Hunger Strike as Organizing Tool
description: Six janitors who clean the gleaming office towers of this small city are in the fifth day of a hunger strike that is part of an ambitious organizing effort by the labor movement.

title: The Fossil Frenzy
description: At sunset, the fossil quarry of Mirzan is a forlorn place. The diggers have gone home exhausted, and only the foreman, Amar Taghlaoui, and his five tiny daughters watch the sun go down over jumbled slabs of granite. The desert here is reg, or loose stone, and its boulders are packed tight with thousands of fossilized sea creatures. Taghlaoui picks his way over them with gingerly care, smoothing away dark orange dust to reveal what look like ghostly snails and monstrous shrimps. He is a haggard man in his 40's with blackened, brutalized hands, an illiterate Berber living off the only riches that the Sahara now offers: fossils. Mirzan is his livelihood, and it lies in what was once the floor of a vast prehistoric ocean. ''It was a sea,'' he says. ''But God has willed it dry.''

title: The Dow Industrials Rise Above the Fray
description: Last week was a tale of two markets. There was the Dow Jones industrial average. And then there was everything else.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DOGRUN

title: Better Times at Lincoln High
description: THE truth about a school is not necessarily found in test scores, budgets or championship trophies. To get a sense of how teachers, administrators and students really feel about one another, check the bathrooms.

title: Allowing the Chinese to Look Chinese
description: WHEN far-off lands were new and hard to comprehend, 19th-century photographers sometimes recreated them, making them look more familiar, more like home. So British photograhers in India found angles that made the Indian landscape look like British picturesque painting; European photographers portrayed Chinese in poses that looked at home in the West; Europeans in Africa made group portraits of tribes that mimicked Western pictures of business or social organizations and nudes that resembled erotic tropes in painting and illustration. The tendency to convert an unknown experience into an artistic echo of safe cultural practices was a corollary of colonialism and in itself a kind of appropriation of the territory.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 29, 2000
description: Weeks

title: A NEW CITIZEN AND A NEW RECORD
description: Khalid Khannouchi of Ossining became a United States citizen on May 2, too late to recover from an injury and compete for his new country in the Olympics. But he entered its record books last Sunday, winning the Chicago Marathon in 2 hours 7 minutes 1 second, an American record. His wife, Sandra, draped him in an American flag at the finish line. ''This one is for America, not for me,'' said Khannouchi, a native of Morocco. The previous year in Chicago, Khannouchi set the world marathon record of 2:05.42. Chuck Slater

title: Wag the Human
description: The Truth

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Flying Philosophers
description: This unorthodox satire by Nicholas Mosley, who won Britain's Whitbread Book of the Year Award in 1990 for his novel ''Hopeful Monsters,'' confirms his delicate, slightly peculiar talent for extracting moving insights from heady fictional terrain. The action in SERPENT (Dalkey Archive, paper, $11.95) mostly takes place in the first-class compartment of a jet bound for Tel Aviv, where a screenwriter named Jason is struggling to persuade a bilious producer to buy his far-fetched script about Masada, the fortress where a thousand Jews killed themselves in A.D. 73 rather than be taken prisoner by the Romans. As this pair and their venal entourage sip Champagne and, absurdly, talk ethics, Jason's wife, Lilia, and their young son are consigned to economy, where they contend with spilled orange juice and a possible terrorist. From the start, Jason's glum philosophizing on Masada and his postmodern impulse to undercut the art of acting stirs up conflict. The producer wants a crowd-pleasing ''flesh and blood'' flick; Lilia merely wants a husband with vitality and directness. As the jet approaches Israel and disasters threaten, Mosley astutely weaves in excerpts of the script, which reads like some madcap amalgam of Sartre and Seneca. ''Serpent'' aims to crack a deadly serious joke about the human toll of noble ideas, and our inability to escape or fully apprehend them, and it mainly hits the mark. That Mosley -- who is the son of Sir Oswald Mosley, who led the fascist party in Britain in the 1930's -- can successfully compare an airliner to Plato's cave is just one measure of his droll appreciation of the peril of fanatical high-mindedness. Yet Mosley suggests that it is in the conserving actions of ordinary characters such as Lilia that we can ultimately find hope. Bill Broun

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the choreographer Christian Holder and his new ballet, set to the music of Cole Porter, misstated his relationship to the dancers and choreographers Geoffrey Holder and Carmen de Lavallade. He is Geoffrey's Holder's nephew, not the couple's son.

title: Black and White Together in History's Trap
description: ARE everyday interactions between races in the city, particularly blacks and whites, too often tainted by hostility and stereotyping on both sides?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSHING, HARRY COOKE IV.
description: CUSHING - Harry Cooke IV. Passed away on October 24, 2000 suddenly after a short illness at age 76. Vanderbilt scion, accomplished polo player and world traveler, he will be remembered by all who came in contact with him for his strength of character, penetrating wit, voluminous historical recall and an aristocratic lifestyle long forgotten. He is survived by a son, Harry Cooke Cushing V, a daughter-in-law Laure, and two granddaughters Cathleen and Kyra. There will be a memorial service on Wednesday, November 1, 2000 at 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Mystery Island

title: Winding Down On Essaouira's Shore
description: IT was deep twilight as we drove, exhausted, across the summit of the coastal ridge and made a switchback as the last light was fading over the western horizon of the Atlantic. In the distance, the lights were just coming on in the walled city of Essaouira, but it was still bright enough to make out the silhouettes of the ruined buildings on the prison island of Mogador in the harbor; indigo phantoms on a sapphire sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, HY (HONEY)
description: KLEIN-Hy (Honey). 90. Of White Plains, NY. On October 27, 2000. Beloved husband of Anne. Dear father of Nancy (Ned) and Ken (Jessie). Adored grandfather of Eileen, Benjamin, Abigail and Stephanie. Loving brother of Ida Frost and Morris Klein. Graveside services will be today, October 29, 11:30 AM, Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, NJ.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: 'The Witch of Staten Island'
description: AT first glance, there is nothing remarkable about the house on Richmond Avenue. Encased in gray vinyl siding and surrounded by the kind of suburban sprawl that covers much of Staten Island these days -- a Perkins restaurant and a Wendy's across the street, the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Expressway a stone's throw away -- it could easily pass as just another 20th-century addition to this north shore neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, ROBERT I., M.D.
description: LEVY-Robert I., M.D. 63, of Morristown, NJ, on October 28. Beloved husband and best friend of Ellen (Feis). Proud father of Andrew and Nina, Joanne, Karen and Michael Gooen, Patricia and Stuart Zuckerman, devoted son of Sarah and the late George, dear brother of the late Harold. Loving grandfather of Naphtali, Esther, Tsvi, Tova and Shoshana Levy and Elizabeth and Sandy Gooen. He will be remembered by numerous friends and colleagues, all of whose lives are blessed to have been touched by his warm friendship, wise counsel, and good humor. Service today at 2:15 PM at Menorah Chapel, 2950 Vaux Hall Rd., Union, NJ, 908-964-1500. Interment at B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, NJ. A memorial service is planned at 11 AM on November 28 at Caspary Auditorium, Rockefeller University, York Ave. at 66th St., NYC. For further information please call 973-660-5021. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Robert I. Levy Endowment Fund at Yale University School of Medicine, 333 Cedar St., New Haven, CT 06510 to fund a professorship in preventive cardiology in his name or The Robert I. Levy Endowment at The American Heart Association, 7272 Greenville Ave., Dallas, TX 75231 for an annual lecture in his name at scientific sessions.

title: Saving the Shore
description: MARC MILLER'S ocean view from the dining room of his modest Cape just footsteps from the beach -- is a painter's dream. On summer days, beachgoers make their way across the several hundred yards of sand that separate the Atlantic Ocean from his floor-to-ceiling windows. The scene is often frenetic, not serene, but that's the way Mr. Miller likes it.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about facade work on the Gorham Building, at Fifth Avenue and 36th Street, misstated the professional qualifications of Eric Cohler, who is involved. He is a historic preservation consultant, not an architect.

title: Public Spaces, Private Property
description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwans Opposition Challenges Presidents Nuclear Plant Decision
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan -- Taiwan's opposition parties will challenge a presidential order to scrap a partially completed nuclear plant, threatening to set off a constitutional and financial crisis for the island's five-month old government.

title: Irregular New Accounts Alerted Microsoft to Network Intruder
description: Howard A. Schmidt's staff called with troubling news late in the day on Tuesday, Oct. 17. ''Some accounts were being created that did not match our normal audit logs,'' Mr. Schmidt, the corporate security officer for the Microsoft Corporation, said yesterday.

title: Haughty or Curious?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REEVES, ROBERT A.
description: REEVES-Robert A. 78, of New York City. Passed away October 20, while vacationing in Arizona. His charm, wit and philanthropy will be missed by all, especially his cousin, Ines Warner and her children, Lois and Peter of Miami.

title: Treat Lightly On These Mats
description: Leave it to Martha Stewart to create Halloween welcome mats so attractive you would be too scared to step on them. The coir doormats are available in witch or owl designs, $24 each, from www.marthabymail .com.

title: Easing the Path To Good Citizenship
description: Time-starved workers complain that voting on Election Day is much easier said than done.

title: Rare Tornado Blasts English Seaside Town
description: BOGNOR REGIS, England -- Four people were hurt and hundreds of homes damaged when a rare tornado struck an English seaside town.

title: Fiber Optics? That Bear May Be Just A Shadow
description: HERE'S a puzzler: If you see bear tracks in what has long been a very friendly part of the forest, what do you do?

title: Mount Vernon May Limit All-Night Retailers
description: The Mount Vernon police commissioner, Gertrude Laforgia, has asked the City Council to pass a law requiring retail businesses that are now open all night to close between midnight and 5 a.m.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Sexual Liberation

title: Struggling Nassau Republicans Bench Elephant in State Senate Races
description: In the solidly Republican precincts of Nassau County, G.O.P. candidates have literally shed their political colors, a visible sign of their rush to abandon the county's once vaunted Republican machine.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: AN AFFAIR OF STATE: The Investigation, Impeachment, and Trial of President Clinton, by Richard A. Posner. (Harvard University, $16.95.) There are no heroes in this penetrating analysis of the Lewinsky scandal by the chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. His narrative, which assails the political posturing on both sides of the aisle, was chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 1999. ''In a way only good judges can do, he manages both to portray the ambiguity of constitutional law . . . and yet not shy from judgment about what actually happened and what to make of it,'' Andrew Sullivan wrote here. In Edward M. Kennedy: A biography, by Adam Clymer (Perennial/HarperCollins, $16), the Washington correspondent of The New York Times tracks the long, productive career of the Massachusetts senator, who overcame an unpromising start to earn the respect of his peers. The result is a ''thorough, careful account of a passionately interesting man and politician,'' Godfrey Hodgson said here last year. Dutch: A Memoir of Ronald Reagan, by Edmund Morris (Modern Library, $16.95), blends scholarship with imaginary scenes involving a phantom narrator who wanders in and out of the former president's life. It's a daunting leap of faith, but ''a reader who surrenders . . . will be led through a riveting story to a transcendent conclusion with a surprise twist,'' Steven R. Weisman wrote in these pages in 1999.

title: Candy Bars of Soap
description: Having your mouth washed out was never this much fun. Bath & Body Works, the cosmetics chain, features clear glycerin bars with candy corn-colored soap kernels floating inside. They're $5 each from a selection of Halloween-theme soaps.

title: A Variety of Rooms as Vignettes
description: ROOMS With a View'' at the Southport Congregational Church are just that. They're vignettes of rooms with a perspective -- a view of a garden, another room or a way of life.

title: Family Bakery Expansion Will Add 200 Workers
description: Neri's Bakery Products, the 90-year-old family business, plans to add 200 workers when it completes work on its two-story building in Port Chester. The company obtained $4.9 million in financing from Port Chester's Industrial Development Agency.

title: Track Down Pests
description: Monitor for pests: without the distraction of leaves, you can inspect twigs, branches and trunks of trees and shrubs for egg masses, scale and borer holes. Use binoculars to check treetops. Piles of sawdust may indicate feeding borer larvae; look for pencil-diameter holes in the bark, and prune out infested branches where possible.

title: Commercial Property; Turning Brownfields Into Fairways and Greens
description: THE view is terrific, even if it's from the top of a massive trash heap. The wide swath of the Hudson River and the breathtaking skyline of Manhattan are to the east, and the rolling hills of northern New Jersey march north and west.

title: New Day Dawns for Jets, Who Wake Up to Flutie
description: The Jets spent the week rehashing and recovering, reveling in Monday night's magnificent comeback victory while rubbing the emotional and physical exhaustion away. But like a fly buzzing about their heads, eluding their attempts to swat him away, comes Doug Flutie, the Buffalo quarterback who figures to pester the Jets in their game today, just enough to ensure that the Jets have fully forgotten the Miami Dolphins.

title: Emotion at Rites for 4 Arabs Spills Again Into Violence
description: The emotional funerals of four Palestinians who were shot dead on Friday proved the flashpoint for renewed clashes today between Palestinians and Israeli troops in the West Bank and Gaza, leaving at least 29 Palestinians injured in Gaza, including a 14-year-old boy who was in critical condition after being shot in the head.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Hyundai Santa Fe; Aspiring Scion of Immigrants
description: ITS first-born was a problem child, but the Hyundai family's subsequent offspring have been better behaved and more presentable. It's a good thing, too, since the clan is getting so big.

description: MARTHA PEAKE

title: Crippled Cole Begins Journey Home
description: ADEN, Yemen, Oct. 29 -- With her battle ensign flying, her crew saluting and her sound system booming the "Star-Spangled Banner" across the sun-dappled waters of Aden harbor, the U.S.S. Cole limped away with a show of heads-up pride today from the moorings where 17 of her crewmen were killed by two suicide bombers in a fiberglass skiff.

title: Treasure's Late Scores Light Up Baldwin's Fans
description: Baldwin trailed Lawrence by 13-0 yesterday, and the Bruins' homecoming crowd had little to cheer. But two fourth-quarter plays got Baldwin and its fans back in the game.

title: Bon Voyage
description: To the Editor: Alice Furlaud's recollections of festive departures by boat from New York to Europe, ''Bon Voyage Doesn't Mean What It Used To'' (Oct. 1), recall the the thrill of yet another celebrated sailing, of the gleaming white liner Lurline from San Francisco to Honolulu.

title: Heeding the Call of Cape Town
description: IN the final analysis, it came down to goose bumps.

title: Corrections

title: Heather French, Stephen Henry
description: Heather Renee French, Miss America 2000, and Dr. Stephen L. Henry, the lieutenant governor of Kentucky, were married on Friday at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Assumption in Louisville. The Rev. Dave Stone, an evangelical Christian minister, performed the ceremony with the Rev. Byron Z. Mills, a nondenominational Christian minister.

description: CANNON to right of them, cannon to left of them: that's how executives of Hyundai Motor America must feel as they ride into battle in the XG300, a new sedan at the top end of the midsize segment -- the bloodiest battlefield of the car wars.

description: THE NIGHT LISTENER

title: A Free Trip and the Free Press
description: Jeff Shireman, editor of The Indiana Daily Student, circulation 17,000, found himself the center of attention in his journalism classes after he published a fellow student's report about Goldman Sachs -- after Goldman paid for the writer's trip to its New York offices.

title: Skipping Check-In
description: The Cliffs at Princeville, a condominium resort on the North Shore of Kauai, has combined two of the more tedious tasks of a vacation into one. A resort representative greets guests at the airport baggage claim area with the keys to their condo, a map and directions to the resort and the traditional lei. There is no need to stop at the Cliffs check-in desk. Information: (808) 245-8864.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: The A-List; Sitting Pretty at Shea
description: THURSDAY night at Shea Stadium, it wasn't which team won or lost, it was who scored the best seats at the game. Celebrities get seats commensurate with their star clout. Billy Crystal sat in the Commissioner's Box. Jack Nicholson and Helen Hunt had the juice to get those choice seats that spill onto the field toward home plate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, NORA
description: FRIEDLANDER-Nora. Beloved friend. Died the morning of October 26, 2000. We will greatly miss her vitality, warmth and musicmaking, but her gentle spirit will always be with us. Rebecca Osborn

title: First Family's Arrival Changes the Focus Of Secret Service Office
description: IN 1992, Larry Saez, a Secret Service agent since 1980, was assigned to the protective detail for Bill Clinton, presidential candidate. Several years later, he was assigned to the White House.

title: Floating Power Plants? 'Pack and Go Home,' Residents Say

But at a heated hearing earlier this month, more than 100 Sunset Park residents came together to keep an electricity-generating barge, one of 15 barge projects envisioned for the city, from docking nearby.

title: Constance Young, Warren Lewis
description: Constance Young and Warren Judah Lewis were married yesterday. Judge Arthur D. Spatt of Federal District Court in Central Islip, N.Y., officiated at the Down Town Association, a club in Manhattan.

title: Don Brooks, 53, Harmonica Player Suited to Blues and Bee Gees
description: Don Brooks, a harmonica player who recorded widely as a studio musician in New York City, died of leukemia Wednesday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan, said his widow, Anne. He was 53 and lived in Greenwich Village.

description: ''The Nightmare Before Christmas,'' the 1993 Tim Burton film that cross-pollinated Oct. 31 and Dec. 25, turned out to be prophetic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, TIMOTHY J.
description: SHEA-Timothy J. Of Kipps Bay. On October 25, 2000. Beloved husband of Frances. Loving father of David Brooks. Cherished grandfather of Victoria Brooks. Funeral from Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28th St on Monday, 9:30 AM. Mass of Christian Burial at Epiphany Church, 10 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Friends may call Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Barak Nears Sharon Union, Arafat Defiant
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 29 -- Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak met hawkish Likud party chief Ariel Sharon on Sunday to try to forge an emergency coalition to cope with a Palestinian uprising which President Yasir Arafat vowed would continue.

title: Boors or Just Novices?
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Push Starts To Lift Turnout Of Black Vote
description: On black radio stations and in newspapers, from pulpits to mailboxes to answering machines, Democrats and civil rights organizations have begun an effort of unprecedented size to increase the turnout of black voters in next month's presidential election. In several close states, Vice President Al Gore's chances may hinge on the effort's effectiveness.

title: Crime May Be Down, But Not in Novels
description: NEW YORKERS are often accused of being addicted to the adrenaline rush. If that is true, here are four recent mystery novels with New York locales that might rev up the heartbeats of readers hereabouts.

title: Into Berber Country
description: A BROILING sun cooked the melange of cars, buses, trucks, donkey carts, mopeds and taxis as our minivan maneuvered its way out of Fez. We were headed south on Highway P-24 toward the Middle Atlas Mountains and the desert beyond. Having pampered ourselves in Fez at the luxurious Palais Jamai and tasted the exotic centuries-old flavor of the labyrinthine medina, we were off to the countryside in search of new adventures.

title: Allison Lautenbach, Christopher Reiling
description: Allison Ann Lautenbach, a daughter of Cynthia and Ned C. Lautenbach of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher Thomas Reiling, the son of Mary Reiling of Wilton, Conn., and the late Glenn Reiling. The Rev. Charles Allen performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Naples, Fla.

title: High School Confidential: A Great Neck Eye-Opener
description: BY most measures, Great Neck's high school students are in great shape academically, socially and economically. But for those in this wealthy enclave who might have thought their schools were immune from the problems facing schools nationwide, a student survey made public this fall has burst the balloon.

title: What's That Buzz, in Italian?
description: Vespas are back, and they are leading the pack. Of marathon runners, that is.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the political prospects of Connecticut's attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, characterized his job incorrectly. He is the state's top lawyer, not a prosecutor.

title: Images That Speak A Language Of Art
description: THIS week, you can see the most important show of Chinese calligraphy ever mounted in the West; you can buy the first book ever to digitize the old Vietnamese calligraphic system; and you can visit a modern show in which a Japanese artist uses the calligraphic tradition as the basis for works of conceptual art.

title: GUILTY PLEA IN VIDEO PIRACY
description: Bernard Scheman, 48, of Fort Montgomery, has pleaded guilty in Westchester County Court in White Plains to criminal possession of forgery devices in operating a lab in the basement of a video store in Mount Kisco that produced counterfeit videotapes of major movies. More than 4,900 counterfeit videotapes were seized from the store in March. Mr. Scheman and Frank Adrissone, 52, of Mount Kisco, were accused of operating the lab in the basement of Crossroads Video, which Mr. Ardrissone owns. Elsa Brenner

title: The Networks Barely Hear the Latin Boom Outside
description: WITH singers like Ricky Martin and Marc Anthony leading a Latin music explosion, and with Jennifer Lopez able to open one of the summer's biggest movies (''The Cell''), can a Hispanic wave on network television be far behind?

title: October 22-28; A Voice From the Deep
description: Waiting to die in the sunken submarine Kursk last August, a young Russian sailor scrawled a note describing how he and 22 others had rushed to a rear escape hatch only to find there was no way out. Divers found the note, written by Lt. Capt. Dimitri Kolesnikov, after recovering his body.

title: Fiacconi and Catuna To Run in New York
description: Franca Fiacconi of Italy, who won the New York City Marathon in 1998, and Anuta Catuna of Romania, the 1996 winner, will compete in the race next Sunday, marathon officials said.

title: The Other Legend of Sleepy Hollow
description: THE year is 1916. A little girl, 6 or 7, wanders into Sleepy Hollow Cemetery at night on a Halloween dare. She creeps among tombstones and mausoleums until she is stopped by an unsettling sound. It is a woman crying, softly, bitterly.

title: Streetscapes/Former Kings County Savings Bank on Broadway in Brooklyn; From a Bank to an Art Center, Via an Artist's Vision
description: STIFLED by the emphasis on traditional art in 1960's Japan, Yuko Nii decided to move to the United States. Three decades later, in 1996, she founded the Williamsburg Art & Historical Center in the magnificently preserved Kings County Savings Bank building at 135 Broadway in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, a block from the Peter Luger Steakhouse. Now she is battling the deterioration of the 1868 building, a task she considers a way of repaying those who have helped her.

title: All About Evil
description: HUMANITY

title: A Droll Dramatist Who's Also a Diva Moves Up a Notch
description: FOR Charles Busch, it was the shock of a lifetime. In 1984, he and some friends put on a campy show to entertain themselves for a weekend at a nightclub on Avenue C in the East Village. With Mr. Busch doing a star turn in drag, ''Vampire Lesbians of Sodom'' won a cult following, moved to the Provincetown Playhouse and ran for five years.

title: Lorin Latarro, Howard Lev
description: Lorin Latarro, a dancer in the Broadway musical ''Swing,'' and Howard Samuel Lev, a marketing executive, were married last night by Rabbi Stanley Asekoff at the Pleasantdale Chateau in West Orange, N.J.

title: Testing Bonds in Midst of Jerusalem's Clashes
description: With crowns of leaves encircling their heads, Shmuel Mantinband and Imam Tibi tried to decide on which vacant couch to settle their toga-clad bodies. Lute music echoed forlornly through their cavernous Roman-themed banquet hall in an Old City devoid of tourists.

title: Political Perspective
description: Just in time for Election Day, the Friends of the Irvington Public Library will present a panel discussion today at 4 p.m. titled ''The Presidency, Politics and the Press: Informing or Influencing Voters?'' featuring some of Irvington's most high-profile media types.

title: More Bodies Lifted from Kursk as Russia Bids Farewell
description: MURMANSK, Russia, Oct. 29 -- Russians bid farewell at last to the 118 sailors lost aboard the submarine Kursk on Sunday, uniting again in sorrow more than two months after the vessel sank in the Arctic Barents Sea.

description: Fire prevention authorities recommend that smoke alarm batteries be changed twice yearly, at the start and the end of daylight time. The change occurred this morning.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Broadway Boyhood
description: I very much enjoyed Frank Rich's theater reminiscence (Oct. 8). His article evoked, for me, my own early memories of Broadway. As a native New Yorker, I was fortunate to be able to see a show every weekend. In 1963, my uncle, Bill Ross, was a Broadway stage manager (he was then working on ''110 in the Shade''), who later became a producer and director. Every weekend, my cousin Anita and I would go to acting school in a building across from the Dakota. After class, my uncle would call one of his theater buddies, and we would slip in to see a show that might have some extra seats. Or we would pay the $2 or $3 that tickets cost then to sit in the balcony. We saw everything -- musicals, dramas, brilliant shows and lemons. I immersed myself in a world that, at the time, I so much wanted to be a part of.

title: POSTINGS: $4,800 to $18,000 a Month; In Village, Living Above The Store
description: A walkup over a grocery for $216,000 a year?

description: China's president, enraged by journalists' aggressive questions, lashed out at the Hong Kong news media on Friday, calling it naive.

title: October 22-28; G.E. Snaps Up Honeywell
description: In the largest industrial acquisition ever, General Electric acquired Honeywell International for $45 billion following a whirlwind of dealmaking that was concluded in less than 24 hours. G.E.'s deal with Honeywell broke up an impending merger between Honeywell and United Technologies that was abandoned just as Honeywell's board was planning to vote on that deal.

title: Crippled Cole Begins Journey Home
description: ADEN, Yemen -- As a recording of the American national anthem played Sunday, the crippled USS Cole was towed out of the Aden port that had been a death trap for 17 of its sailors.

title: Some New Wrinkles In Rand McNally Atlas
description: The question in the minds of the makers of the Rand McNally Road Atlas for the United States, Canada and Mexico seems to have been: What more can we provide than maps? The answer appears in the 2001 edition, which has, in addition to 5,500 updates and map changes, these new features: lists of road-construction projects; sources for tourist information for states and Canadian provinces, with a few major events for each; temperatures and precipitation in 90-plus cities, and charges on toll roads.

description: BASKETBALL

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: A STAR-STUDDED revival of Gore Vidal's 1960 stage comedy aobut a presidential convention opened at the Virginia Theater last month to some lovely reviews. The movie version of THE BEST MAN (1964), directed by Franklin Schaffner, has won its share of praise, too. Henry Fonda is the good guy, an intellectual liberal with integrity. Cliff Robertson is the bad guy, an ultraconservative Communist-hunting ''man of the people'' who will sink to any depth for votes and endorsements. One of these men is going to win the nomination. Mr. Vidal's screenplay is witty, literate and deadly, which is no surprise. But it is a little jolting to see how the game of politics was so completely a man's world 40 years ago. The actresses in the film (Margaret Leighton, Ann Sothern, Edie Adams) are fine, but their characters are memorable mostly for their hairstyles. A lot of French twists - Friday at 10 p.m. on TCM.

title: Word for Word/Kosovo Police Blotter; The War Is Over. Now, Violence Is the Daily Routine
description: POLICE blotters anywhere can be a grim but fascinating read. But those from the United Nations police force in Kosovo are even more so. Tucked in among the routine domestic disputes and traffic flare-ups are signs that the ethnic war between Albanians and Serbs in the province is still going on, underground, in individual murders, bombings and acts of arson. Sadly, the province has always been heavily armed and has had a high crime rate: robberies and beatings are common, as are abductions of women, and the assumption is that some of those kidnapped will be smuggled to western Europe and sold into prostitution. Attacks on gypsies, or Roma, are also frequent.

title: Star-Crossed
description: BACK at school after the third-grade trip to the Hayden Planetarium, every Flopsy, Mopsy and Cottontail among us sat with bended head neatly copying Miss Shoemaker's master letter from the blackboard: ''Dear Miss Birch, thank you for allowing our class to visit the star show.''

title: Everyone's Landmark Finally Joins the Landmark Club
description: More than 70 years after it was built, one of New York's most familiar landmarks has become an official landmark. Last Tuesday, the Landmarks Preservation Commission voted to confer the status on the New York Life Building, the 40-story structure famous for a golden pinnacle that glimmers at sunset and dawn.

In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Nicolai Malko Foundation, Inc., 36 West 84th Street, New York, NY 10024.

description: ROTHFELD-Freda. On October 21, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. Loving and devoted mother of Susan Rothfeld and Dr. Ira Rothfeld. Dear mother-in-law of Angela Silva Rothfeld. Services private.

title: Where a Strip Mall Is Cherished
description: BEFORE most of the tenants left and the place fell into disrepair, the shopping center on Hungry Harbor Road here was the unofficial center of the neighborhood, a place not just for groceries but also for a greeting, maybe a bit of gossip. Now residents are being asked to support a redevelopment of the property as an assisted-living center.

title: Still Aloft, for Now
description: It has been business as usual for the 102-foot-long, 24,000-pound model of a British Airways Concorde overlooking Times Square, even though British and French aviation officials grounded the Concorde fleet after an Air France Concorde crashed in July. But in April, the model Concorde may be grounded, too, when the four-story Times Square Brewery, atop which it is perched, makes way for a 47-story tower.

title: A Dreamer's Vision vs. Reality on Road and Rail
description: LITTLE in life is more exasperating than sitting in traffic, beginning and ending each workday with a frustrating crawl. It's expensive, too, costing billions a year in lost productivity. Nassau and Suffolk employers regularly rate transportation delays as one of the big problems of doing business on Long Island, and employees tend to feel likewise.

title: Tucson
description: This month American Heritage magazine features Tucson as its Great American Place for the year 2000. It's a tribute to the way the city uses aspects of its past to give visitors a ''historically significant travel experience.'' But just as significant -- to visitors and residents -- is Tucson's attitude toward the pres ent, the way it lives every day con gusto.

title: A Food-Friendly Hybrid
description: Muller-Thurgau, a hybrid grape that the eminent British critic Hugh Johnson wants banned from top vineyards in Germany because of its wimpy wines there, has found a new identity, respect and pizazz in Oregon.

title: Don't Judge Knicks' Front Court By Ewing's Absence in the Middle
description: They are regarded throughout the National Basketball Association as the Knicks' weakness. Hardly anyone expects the team to rebound, to score, to stay healthy or to defend adequately in Patrick Ewing's absence.

title: Poised to Take Merrill by the Horns
description: OPENING his mail several months ago, E. Stanley O'Neal got a real blast from his past. An instructor from graduate school had sent him a card that Harvard Business School professors had used to track Mr. O'Neal's class participation. Affixed to it was a picture of him in full mid-70's flower, with a bushy Afro, long mustache and dark-tinted glasses.

title: A Team That Held Tough When Faced With Disaster
description: The greatness of the Yankees could be found in their World Series performance, in their surge in August, or in their three-game sweep in Boston in September. But for Reggie Jackson, the Yankees of 2000 could be defined by how they responded to the late-season collapse that nearly wrecked the dynasty.

title: William Hurtz, 'Actor With a Pencil' Who Changed Face of Animation, Is Dead at 81
description: William T. Hurtz, a founder of the trendsetting United Productions of America animation studio, whose career stretched from Walt Disney in the 1930's to ''Rugrats'' in the 1990's, with stops in between for Mr. Magoo, George of the Jungle and Cap'n Crunch, died Oct. 14 at his home in Van Nuys, Calif. He was 81.

title: October 22-28; Arrests in Cole Attack
description: An unspecified number of Arabs were detained in Yemen in the Oct. 12 attack on the destroyer Cole, and Yemen's president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, said local and American investigators had tentatively concluded that they belonged to the Islamic Jihad.

title: TROOPER CHARGE DROPPED
description: The witnesses came forward nearly two years after two state troopers shot at unarmed minority men in a van on the turnpike, but their accounts led state prosecutors to drop a charge of attempted murder against one of the troopers last week. Two drivers for United Parcel Service said the men's van was moving toward state trooper John Hogan, as he had claimed, when he fired at it in April 1998, wounding three of the passengers. Prosecutors had said the shots were fired as the vehicle rolled away. Mr. Hogan is still charged with aggravated assault, and his partner, James Kenna, still faces charges of attempted murder and aggravated assault. David Kocieniewski

title: Compris? Coperto? Confused.
description: IN 1521 on a trip from Bruges to Cologne, the German artist Albrecht Durer handled transactions in 18 different currencies that included stuivers, anglots, orrts, and weisspfennigs. His pockets bulging with masses of mismatched coins, he probably never knew how much he was really paying for his rooms at the inn.

They were named for the late Ms. Rose, who was the president of the board of trustees from 1989 to 1996. The evening was also the opening of the main exhibition, ''Reflections in a Glass Eye,'' of works from the center's permanent collection.

He will be remembered as a motivated, hard working associate whose presence contributed to the overall success of our company. His willingness to contribute and commitment to our endeavors will be forever remembered. Those of us at CoreMarkets greatly miss him and extend our sincere sympathies to his family.
