description: @expectations

title: ANCHOR AWAY
description: State Senator Diane Allen (Republican, Burlington) ended her return to the television news anchor seat early after the Democratic Senate leadership accused her of going on the air to advance her political career. The Comcast channel CN8 had invited her to substitute during an anchor's two-week vacation. Senator Allen, who had a long career as a news anchor in Philadelphia before entering New Jersey politics five years ago, agreed to do so as long as she did not read any political news. After a week, Ms. Allen asked CN8 to pull out. Robert Strauss

title: Trying to Tame the Mishmash That Is East 86th Street
description: For years, much of East 86th Street has been a noisy tangle of traffic, pedestrians, shoppers and street vendors. Recently, upscale businesses patronized by residents of neighboring town houses and high-rises have joined the mishmash of banks, clothing stores, pizza parlors -- not to mention piles of garbage -- that have characterized the area. Heavy crosstown traffic clogs the street and the subway stop at Lexington Avenue adds to congestion.

title: Fish in a Flash: Brief Marinating for Fillets
description: THE more delicate the ingredient, the less marinating it takes. And nothing illustrates the point better than fish.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Whoever Wins, the Arts Can't Lose

title: The Ghouls Of Gotham Strutting Their Stuff
description: AMERICANS love a parade. We cheer the soldiers in their old uniforms marching down Main Street on Memorial Day, and we scream with delight when Bart Simpson soars overhead in Macy's Thanksgiving Day Extravaganza. That's nice. But is American ready for a bevy of drag queens flipping their curls as Charlie's Angels or gangs of half-naked gladiators tossing severed ears into the crowd? Because those are a few of the tamer sights that the national television audience is likely to see on Tuesday night at 7 when the Greenwich Village Halloween Parade is shown live on USA and the Sci Fi channel.

title: New Home for Maritime Art
description: AFTER seven years and an outlay $3.4 million, the maritime art of John A. Noble (1913-1983) has a new home. The Noble Maritime Collection will open to the public next Sunday in a former residence for retired mariners that was built in 1844 at Sailors' Snug Harbor. It now has gallery and studio space, a library and archives. Mr. Noble was a lithographer who chronicled the last chapter of the Age of Sail. Shown above is ''Cape Horner,'' a rendering of the Occidental, built in Bath, Me., in 1874. Mr. Noble drew the ship in 1950, after it was abandoned off Bayonne, N.J., where he kept his studio. ''She has preserved her shape perfectly,'' Mr. Noble wrote in 1955.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBIN, MORRIS
description: SOBIN-Morris. Passed away on Friday, October 27, 2000. Of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Roslyn Heights, NY. Loving husband of Doris and the late Ruth. Devoted & cherished father of Louise Sobin Hersh (Bob). Adored grandfather of Philip (Lara) and Joshua Sivin. Beloved brother of Rose Simon and Edward Sobin. Past president of Fresh Meadows Country Club. Former president of Olympia Radio and TV and Pilot Radio-TV. Former COO of Regent Sheffield Inc. Former director of Lear Siegler Inc. and Suburbia Federal Bank. He set an example of hard work, responsibility, sense of humor, zest for life, and fierce love of his family. His legacy will continue for generations to come. Services Florida, Sunday October 29, 11 AM, ''Gutterman Warheit'' 7240 N. Federal Highway, Boca Raton. Interment Tuesday, October 31, at 3 P.M., at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. Memorial contributions, Sass Foundation for Medical Research, 1025 Northern Blvd. Suite 302, Roslyn, N.Y. 11576.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNELL, NATHAN
description: SCHNELL-Nathan. On October 24, 2000 in Paris. Beloved husband of Bernice. Loving father of Lloyd Schnell, Stuart Schnell and Laurie Blake. Father-in-law of Ellie, Diane and Paul. Cherished grandfather to Ron & Staci, Amy, Jody, Arielle, Camille, and great-grandfather to Jeremy. Services Sunday 11:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours Saturday, 7-9PM.

title: Leaving His Home of 45 Years, An 89-Year-Old Starts Anew
description: LARRY STEVENS just made a major move, and Ralphie came with him. Ralphie is an affectionate brown tabby cat; Mr. Stevens is an 89-year-old retired accountant who last week left his New Rochelle home of 45 years and moved to a one-bedroom unit in Meadowview, an assisted-living complex that is part of the Wartburg Adult Care Community here.

title: Street Art Web Site, Courtesy of a Texan
description: When Cecilia Lynch sells her paintings on a West Broadway street corner in SoHo, she hands out a 3-by-5 flier with a black and white reproduction of one of her pieces, accompanied by the words, ''You can see more of Cecilia's work at NYCStreetArtist.com.''

title: SOAPBOX; A Old Haunt in Newark
description: A GHOST once lived in Newark. Not the shade of departed person, this ghost was a tavern. It once occupied the southwest corner of Commerce and Mulberry Streets, two blocks from Pennsylvania Railroad Station and several yards from the present-day Gateway III office building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONGHIA, CARMELLA
description: DONGHIA-Carmella, mother of the late Angelo Donghia, passed away Friday, October 27, 2000. Born on October 3, 1913 in Tyler, Pennsylvania, Mrs. Donghia is survived by a brother, James Ferraccio and two sisters, Amelia Krotzer and Pompey Sciullo. She moved to NYC in 1968 to assist her son in his design endeavors and remained a mentor to Angelo Donghia throughout his career. Funeral services will take place at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church located at 869 Lexington Avenue on Monday, October 30, 2000 at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers the family has requested that donations be made to Saint Vincents Hospital Comprehensive Breast Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, S. ROBERT (BUD)
description: SCHINDLER-S. Robert (Bud), 82, of Aventura, Florida, formerly of Merrick, New York passed away October 25, 2000. Beloved husband of Margy, loving father of Penny, son-in-law Wade Williams and cherished grandfather of Sarah. Donations to the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICH, BERNARD
description: REICH-Bernard. On October 25, 2000, of Lambertville, NJ, formerly of New York City. Beloved companion of Barbara Grigg Moses. Loving father of Lauran Vieland and Mr. and Mrs. Randal (Karen) Reich. Dear grandfather of Sonia, Rose, Julia and Justin; also extended family Kimberly, Kevin, Will and Annie Parham and Christopher Russak. Memorial services Monday, October 30, 10:30 AM, at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 98 Sky Manor Rd., Box 348, Pittstown, N.J. 08867. Memorial donations may be made to the church.

title: Al Gore for President
description: Despite all the complaints about the difficulty of falling in love with either Al Gore or George W. Bush, these two very different men have delivered a clean, well-argued campaign that offers a choice between two sharply contrasting visions of the future. Even though Vice President Gore is a centrist Democrat and Governor Bush has presented himself as the most moderate Republican nominee in a generation, they have sketched very different pictures of the role of government and how actively the president should help families secure adequate education, health care and retirement. This is also the first presidential campaign in recent history centered on an argument over how best to use real, bird-in-the-hand resources to address age-old domestic problems while also defining the United States' role in a world evermore dependent on it for farsighted international leadership.

title: SHOPPING WITH: Ian Thorpe; Teenage Olympian Learns to Wear Fame
description: IT takes forever to walk the couple of blocks from Ian Thorpe's hotel to Barneys. People keep stopping to congratulate him on the three Olympic gold medals he won swimming for Australia (and to peek at his size 17 feet). They keep reaching out to shake the hand that tagged the pool wall repeatedly in world-record time.

title: 'Taxpayer Advocates' Can Drain Resources
description: To the Editor:

title: Lazio, Aiming at His Political Base, Denounces Government
description: With a series of rallies from Babylon to Plattsburgh, Representative Rick A. Lazio sought to stir his base of supporters today with fiery reminders of his New York roots and calls not to trust the government.

title: October 22-28; New Strategy Offered For Surviving Cardiac Arrest
description: Thousands of lives a year could be saved if ordinary people were trained to use portable defibrillators to treat cardiac arrest and if the devices were made available in public places, researchers reported. The portable machines, like the paddles used in emergency rooms, deliver electrical shocks to restore a normal heart rhythm in people suffering from ventricular fibrillation, a condition that occurs without warning and causes sudden death in more than 200,000 Americans a year. Denise Grady

title: Ohio a 'Lock,' Yet Bush Tests the Door
description: Less than two weeks left in the presidential campaign. Three men sit at a bar, half-watching Game 5 of the World Series, from which the local heroes, the Cleveland Indians, are conspicuously absent.

title: Q & A
description: Christmas in London

title: U.S. Plan Would Sacrifice Baby Eagles to Hopi Ritual
description: The Department of the Interior has decided that Hopi Indians should be allowed to use golden eagle hatchlings collected at a national monument in Arizona in an annual, ancient rite in which the birds are smothered.

title: Cooperstown Series Displays
description: Memorabilia to help bring to life the first all-New York World Series since 1956 will be displayed at a Subway Series exhibit, beginning Nov. 17 at the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: A Rite of Passage Through Baseball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A 1909 Greeting
description: To the Editor: If the ''costumed role player'' who portrays the 1909 Russian-Jewish immigrant Mrs. Shapiro at Strawbery Banke in New Hampshire indeed greeted Sherry Marker, author of ''All the Town's a Stage'' (Sept. 24) with a ''Shalom,'' she was speaking anachronistically. The real Mrs. Shapiro would presumably have spoken Yiddish, not Hebrew, and therefore have greeted a visitor with a ''Sholem aleykhem,'' (literally, ''Peace be with you'') or, even more likely, responded ''Aleykhem sholem'' to the visitor's ''Sholem aleykhem.''

title: Kathleen Devers, Arthur Sawyer
description: Kathleen Anne Devers, the daughter of Mary O'Hanlon Devers and Peter Dix Devers of New York, was married yesterday to Arthur Lee Sawyer, a son of Barbara Allen Sawyer and Dr. H. G. Sawyer Jr. of Mystic, Conn. The Rev. Robert Michael Dunn, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Keep Your Costume Under Wraps
description: For men who hate costumes but want to get in the Halloween spirit, Old Navy has created boxer shorts that are appropriately creepy. The best, $7.50, come in an understated black and white skull print that looks more Day of the Dead than trick-or-treat. Pair them with an orange skeleton-print long sleeve T-shirt, $14.50.

title: Hold the Persian Pistachios, But the Carpets Are Flying In
description: It has been half a year since the United States relaxed the 1987 embargo on Iranian carpets, caviar and pistachio nuts in what it called a goodwill gesture toward improved relations with Iran. But so far, only the carpets have had a renaissance in the American market -- which is good news for some people, bad for others.

title: IONA SPEECH LAB RECEIVES GRANT
description: The speech language pathology department at Iona College has received a $10,000 grant that will enable it to become a center for detecting hearing loss in infants and toddlers. The grant, from the Marjorie C. Adams Charitable Trust, will provide Iona with equipment so it can teach up to 70 students how to test infants for hearing losses. The college offers a bachelor's degree in speech-language pathology and audiology. Elsa Brenner

title: A Note From the Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: A Saturday Tradition
description: SUSAN SMITHLINE is the ringleader of a tightly knit band of tag sale aficionados that roves around the county every Saturday. Joan Gerard, a member of the band, describes Mrs. Smithline with playful reverence as, ''the one who has been going to tag sales since before there were tag sales.'' Mrs. Smithline accepts the mantle with a smile, adding that people used to laugh at her for how many tag sales she went to.

title: Anxious Oscillation
description: To the Editor:

title: Portrait of a Failed Marriage
description: Katy Grannan's photographs precisely captured the pain of a failed marriage. And Emily Nussbaum's vignettes complemented the photos but only scratched the surface of this emotionally charged topic (The Way We Live Now, Oct. 8). Divorce defies the senses. It is not the singular event -- the unceremonious court order -- that severs the relationship; rather, it is the horror of the prelude and the pain of the aftermath. Divorce is disillusionment and the death of hopes and dreams. It is the destruction of the family. Today, more than half of all first marriages end in divorce. As a survivor of the loss of a 26-year marriage, I congratulate your efforts in focusing on this most important topic.

title: In His Own Words
description: AL GORE

title: On the Run With Wolf B36
description: This is the story of B36, a female wolf. She is lithe, with an almost pure white chest and a dusting of brown across her powerful shoulders. Her eyes, like those of most wolves, are a haunting, opalescent yellow. Once upon a time, B36 roamed northern British Columbia, a nameless wild animal in a frigid and empty landscape, but then one day five years ago, she was darted, sedated and put through customs at Great Falls, Mont. At which point, for better or worse, B36 became an American.

title: Islamic Revival Wears Many Faces in a Secular Asian Land
description: Said Umar Husseinzoda has large, luminous eyes that never seem to blink, eyes that lock on with the force of tractor beams from the brow of a onetime warrior for God who has turned politician -- and missionary -- for the Islamic Revival Party of Tajikistan.

title: Mayor Teases Chancellor Over Hooky Dust-Up
description: Hooky? Who said it was hooky?

title: Putting the Fun in Funeral
description: Playmates Toys has added a Springfield Cemetery play set, complete with ''Eat My Dust'' tombstones, to its line of talking ''Simpsons'' action figures and environments. A Toys ''R'' Us exclusive, the $30 set features Homer in costume as King Kong, Bart as the Fly, Mr. Burns as a very Gary Oldmanish Dracula, and the holier-than-thou Ned Flanders as the Devil. Push a button on the diabolical diorama and it's a scream. Literally. To go along, there's a $24.98 set of six ghoulish ''Simpsons'' episodes.

title: Turning to the Former Chief For Help in Troubled Times
description: RETIREMENT was the chance to get away: After leaving Campbell Soup, David W. Johnson had been enjoying life by climbing Mount Kilimanjaro. Thomas L. Gossage, who had left Hercules Inc., was living in Atlanta and serving on a few corporate boards. And Henry B. Schacht had traded his responsibilities as chief executive of the gigantic Lucent Technologies for a post as chairman of a much smaller maker of office communications equipment spun off from Lucent.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; The Librarian's Image, Unrevised
description: I AM a librarian, a part of a feminized profession with a median starting salary that recently topped $30,000. Despite a growing demand for our services, major areas of the country are unable to keep or attract employees for their public libraries. This must change if librarianship is to survive.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 15 about hyperrealistic painting misspelled the name of the gallery that represents the artist Alexis Rockman. It is Gorney, Bravin & Lee, not Braven.

title: In the Region/Westchester; White Plains Getting Retail Stores Near Big Mall
description: WHEN The Westchester, a million-square-foot mall, opened in 1995, expectations were high that complementary retail would soon spring up around it.

title: Meta-Midler
description: Lynn Hirschberg highlights the contradictions inherent in Bette Midler's righteous indignation over indecent billboards and Bill Clinton's behavior. But she leaves unchallenged Midler's casual assertion that she was upset because she had to cross a picket line to get to her ''upfront'' at Carnegie Hall. What happened to Midler's high-minded moralizing on that occasion?

title: A Floating Police Station
description: Book him has a new meaning these days in this upscale Bergen County town.

title: Hyde Park Resists Group's Plan to Buy Land
description: TO many residents of Hyde Park, the future of the town -- and even of the Hudson Valley -- comes down to two disputed parcels of land across from the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Home on Route 9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGA, OSSIAN KARE
description: BERGA-Ossian Kare. Beloved husband of Heather Cohane, born in Sweden 1919, passed away peacefully in his sleep, October 25th. Stepfather to Candida Burnap of Sun Valley and Palm Beach, Alexander Winder Cohane of London, Candida Cohane Stille of Monte-Carlo, and Ondine Kelpia Cohane, New York. A Viking Funeral will be held on Georgica Beach, Wainscott, Long Island. Date to be announced

title: Like the U.S.S.R., a Longtime Ukrainian Diner Is Defunct
description: Kiev, a Ukrainian coffee shop frequented by morning churchgoers and late-night bar hoppers alike for 22 years, served its final bowl of borscht last weekend.

title: FILM; They Were Young, Angry and Flourishing
description: THE shouts and yells that resound throughout the Film Forum's ''British New Wave'' series remind me that the novelist and critic Penelope Gilliatt used to insist that the tirade is an English form. You can trace it back to Shakespeare, to the soliloquies that need lung power: ''Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks!'' and ''O what a rogue and peasant slave am I!'' Modern shouters are mostly male, articulate but without much education, apt to ridicule the upper crust. They're not poor, but their salaries are only adequate, and their girlfriends tend to be too proper or pregnant. Their adventures and aggravations in England in the early 60's can be witnessed in films like ''The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner'' and ''This Sporting Life,'' now through Nov. 30. The fiery discontent of the under-30 generation was personal rather than political: They derided upper- and middle-class culture, and also criticized the stoicism of their seniors, who hadn't challenged ''things as they are.'' They were indignant because little seemed to be changing in postwar Britain -- they were wrong about that, but wouldn't know it for a couple of years -- and because they thought there were few opportunities for the young.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-29-00: On Language; Livid
description: 'One longtime friend of the president,'' wrote Neil A. Lewis of The New York Times, ''said Mr. Clinton was 'livid, off-the-wall angry' about the disbarment proceedings.''

title: INSIDE
description: As Albanians Vote, Serbians Lie Low

title: Unbought and Unbossed, Or 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell'?
description: Of all the tens of millions of dollars Jon S. Corzine has showered over New Jersey during his run for the Senate, one of the most audacious expenditures is his recent television commercial entitled ''In Debt.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in the A la Carte column last Sunday about La Bella Palermo, a restaurant scheduled to open in Glen Head, referred imprecisely to Pappagallo, a previous tenant at the location, 127 Glen Head Road. Pappagallo remains at 716 Glen Cove Avenue, where it moved two decades ago.

title: Bookend; Follow These Simple Instructions
description: I read recently that the fashion designer Elie Tahari (a k a King of the Jacket) was in court battling six lawyers from the Chase Manhattan Bank over real estate. He was so frustrated, he said, that at times he couldn't even find solace from the books of his favorite self-help guru, Eric Butterworth, author of ''Discover the Power Within You.''

title: Morocco's Veiled Charm
description: IT may be the prettiest restaurant I've ever seen; certainly it's in the top five. Yacout, behind high walls in Marrakesh's ancient medina, is set in a ravishing small 17th- and 18th-century palace, its various rooms in early January glowing with crackling fires in the fireplaces, lighted by ornate filigree and colored-glass fixtures, its walls miracles of colorful tilework. Waiters in long white caftans moved silently about, and from the roof terrace one could look out over the old quarter, or back to the inner courtyard and its pool.

title: Closing Thoughts: Rivera Remains the Infallible One
description: It has happened to Mariano Rivera for three straight years and he still cannot explain precisely how it feels to be on the pitcher's mound to collect the final out in a World Series game. There is something that explodes inside your body when you realize that eight months of sacrificing is being rewarded, he said, something that is indescribably blissful.

title: Lullaby of Broadway
description: GHOST LIGHT

title: Where Are They Now? 2 Administrators Who Left
description: HIS nine months leading Lincoln High School were among the most tumultuous in recent memory, but Horace Williams is unrepentant. Actually, he looks back at his work there with satisfaction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, JUDITH O.
description: MATTHEWS-Judith O. Beloved wife of Stephen. Loving mother of Sandra and Howard. Adored daughter of Ruth and the late Eli. Cherished sister of Marion. Services Tuesday, 12 PM, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ, 201843-9090. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Jewish Women International.

title: A Perfect Assist
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Blown Save
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Governor Names New Head of Parole Board
description: Mario A. Paparozzi, who served 25 years in the state Division of Parole, has been asked by Governor Whitman to return to state service as chairman of the beleagured New Jersey Parole Board.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLOCK, CHARLES
description: BLOCK-Charles. 10/29/'08 to 9/3/'96. He dared to dream, then made his dreams come true. His loving memory lives on in our dreams and our lives. His Family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESSLER, IRA RICHARD
description: RESSLER-Ira Richard. Died on October 27, 2000 in New York City at the age of 78. Beloved husband for 50 years of Dorothy, devoted father and father-in-law of Bruce & Ellen Ressler, Jonathan Ressler, Debra and Leon Black, Richard and Alison Ressler, and Antony Ressler and Jami Gertz, loving brother of Gladys Nachamkin and the late William Ressler, and adored grandfather of Benjamin, Joshua, Alex, Victoria, Matthew, Michael, Samantha, Jillian, Andrew, Rebecca, Oliver, Nicholas & Theo. Ira Ressler was a decorated veteran of the United States Army Air Corps in World War II where he served with distinction, receiving the Air Medal for Bravery and the American Defense Service Medal with Star. He was a respected member of the New York Bar & a highly regarded trial attorney with his own firm, Ressler and Ressler, for 52 years. His proudest achievement was his family-his wife and children, their spouses and grandchildren-around whom his life truly centered. Funeral at 10 A.M., on Sunday, October 29, 2000 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street.

title: After a Firing, Parents Get an Education in Politics
description: Pupils at Public School 3, a highly rated progressive elementary school in the West Village, received a lesson on grown-up politics last week as parents and teachers demanded answers about the sudden firing of the interim principal.

title: Palestinian Children
description: To the Editor:

title: For Mets' Co-Owners, Shea Itself Is a Battle
description: For their next act, the Mets will stage a public duel, cap pistols at 10 paces, between Fred Wilpon and Nelson Doubleday. Theirs is the worst relationship in professional sports ownership, and Doubleday's recently expressed views about Shea Stadium are only the most recent manifestation of the severity of their split. It is only growing worse.

title: Legislators Rated on Environment
description: ALL seven State Assembly members from Westchester received perfect scores on the annual Voter's Guide issued by EPL/Environmental Advocates, a lobbying group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYRICH, GERALDINE CAROLINE (NEE EHRMAN)
description: MEYRICH - Geraldine Caroline (nee Ehrman). Dearest adored wife of Fred for 60 years. Devoted mother of Gerry, Nancy, Ann and Steven. Beloved grandmother of Erik, Joanna, Julie, Jennifer, Caitlin and Ariana and great-grandmother of Carolyn. Dearest mother-in-law of Leopold Hahn, Richard Krasnow, Peter Blomquist, Mary Ann Shea. Grandmother-inlaw of Clark French. Cherished by all who ever knew her. Services Monday, 10 AM, at BoulevardRiverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be appreciated to your favorite charity.

title: VEHICLES, BUT NO FUEL
description: Meeting state and federal requirements to buy vehicles that do not burn gasoline, New Jersey has bought 1,100 vehicles that can be fueled with compressed natural gas. But most of them have never been run on anything other than gasoline, said Richard L. Fair, the state auditor, in a report released last week. Alternative-fuel vehicles cost more than gasoline-powered ones, so the state has spent $3.6 million extra so far without any environmental benefit. The state treasurer's office, which procures the vehicles, said there were only two places, Trenton and Hackensack, to get compressed natural gas. Karen DeMasters

title: Hard Work (and Luck) of the Irish
description: SEAMUS DOYLE, 42, a vice president of the Bridgehampton National Bank, came to the United States for the summer in 1986, when he was 26. But instead of returning home to Dublin, he rolled up his sleeves and decided to stay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, JON
description: ALTMAN-Jon. We have lost a loyal friend with a most generous heart. We will miss your countless entertaining stories shared with us on so many occasions. Our love goes out to Cyndy and Sara, Zelda and Carol. Sweet dreams, dear Jon. Mary, Bill, Pam and Alex

title: New Music, Please, but Not in a Ghetto
description: RECENTLY, while speaking to students in the ''Writing About Music'' class at the Manhattan School of Music, I offered some thoughts on the role critics could play in encouraging performances of new music. After emphasizing the positive, I got into my standard rap about the dismaying timidity of programming by many major American orchestras and ensembles.

title: Another Alice's Wonderland, As Susan Sontag Found It
description: ALICE IN BED'' is Susan Sontag's riff on Alice James, the brilliant, depressed sister of the novelist Henry James and the psychologist William James. Now in previews at New York Theater Workshop in the East Village, the play opens next Sunday. It is directed by Ivo van Hove, the resident director of the Het Zuidelijk Toneel, a prominent repertory company in the Netherlands.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Substantial Office Space Being Added to the Market
description: ALTHOUGH the the first building at the 33-acre Reckson Executive Park under construction along the Long Island Expressway just west of Route 110 in Melville will have its official opening in December, no tenants have yet signed leases for its 277,000 square feet of space.

title: African Connection
description: THE ATLANTIC SOUND

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Six people were identified in the picture, yet we heard the thoughts of only three. Was it just an accident that the three without thoughts were women? Your choice spoke volumes.

title: Fishing Maven Adopts an Artificial Reef
description: LANDLUBBERS might adopt a highway or a park. But Rich Johnson is a fishing philanthropist. He spends his days plying the waters around Long Island, searching for the best spots to cast a line. To create a habitat for sea bass, fluke, blackfish and porgies, fish that like rocks and the bottom of the ocean, he recently adopted an artificial reef.

title: A Voice From the Other Side
description: NOT long ago, Sally Morrison, a senior vice president at Miramax Films, got a message that her husband, Paul, was ''very upset that you don't spend more time being in touch with his family.'' Some wives would have chafed at the scolding, delivered by proxy, no less. Not Ms. Morrison. ''I laughed. It was exactly the kind of thing Paul would say,'' she recalled. ''I found it comforting.'' Comforting? Well, yes. Her husband, she explained, had been dead for six months and his reprimand arrived through a spirit medium.

title: Anne Wiedemann, John Churchill
description: Anne Spencer Wiedemann, the daughter of Barbara Hazeltine Symmers Bancroft of Upper Brookville, N.Y., and George Stanhope Wiedemann of Palo Alto, Calif., was married last evening to John William Churchill, the son of Alix Churchill of South Brewham, England, and the late William Churchill. The Rev. Boniface Ramsey performed the Roman Catholic ceremony St. Dominic's Chapel in Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: Ruling Erodes A Crackdown By the Swiss
description: The trial nearly two years ago of an alleged Russian mobster, Sergei Mikhailov, was unprecedented by the standards of Swiss justice. In a country largely free of violent crime, the trial lasted eight days, with unusually tight security, down to bulletproof vests for police officers in the courtroom.

title: Make Terrorists Pay a Real Price
description: To the Editor:

title: That Was Close: Mets Thwarted by Yanks' Use of Inches and Seconds
description: The Mets now know how excruciating it is to be beaten by the Yankees in October. In the Yankees' 16 victories in their past four World Series, all but two games have been decided by three runs or fewer. They beat the Mets by one run three times, by two runs once.

title: Alexandra Freeman, Douglas Pyle
description: Dr. Alexandra Fell Freeman, a daughter of Lucile and Harry L. Freeman of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Douglas Hugh Mackay Pyle, the son of Elizabeth Pyle Whitney of Weston, Mass., and the late Dr. Hugh Mackay Pyle. The Rev. Dr. Theodore Rosche, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Strong Mansion, a historic house in Dickerson, Md.

title: Milanovich Picked First By Los Angeles in Draft
description: Scott Milanovich, a former Tampa Bay Buccaneers quarterback, was selected by the Los Angeles Xtreme yesterday with the first pick in the inaugural XFL player draft.

title: Houses of Worship
description: To the Editor:

title: On Stage, Not on the Web
description: Loudon Wainwright III has two main claims to fame: the satiric 1973 hit ''Dead Skunk'' and the topical songs about figures like Tonya Harding (''Tonya's Twirls'') and Jesse Helms (''Jesse Don't Like It'') that he has written for National Public Radio.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Times Magazine last Sunday with an article about women in professional football misidentified one. The player wearing the helmet was Raven Marshall, a running back -- not Laurel Beaty, a quarterback.

title: Schools Firming Up Links With Dominican Republic
description: The slogan of Community School District 6 is ''A community connected to the world,'' but it might as well be ''A community connected to the Dominican Republic.'' Most students are Dominican-American, and hundreds move each year between Quisqueya, as the Caribbean nation is informally known, and Quisqueya Heights, the Dominican nickname for Washington Heights.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, BERTRAM
description: SHAPIRO-Bertram. World War II navigator bombadier, cinematographer, teacher. Beloved brother, uncle and great uncle. We have all missed your wisdom and kindness these past 15 years. Anita Shofler and famil

title: These Political Button Men Are Relic Makers Now
description: THE button brothers are busy. That should come as no surprise, since the elections are only a few days away. One day last week Alan and Robert Slater tried to talk buttons between the calls and orders pouring into their sunny, wood-paneled offices in the city's only button factory, the N. G. Slater Corporation on West 19th Street at Seventh Avenue.

title: It's a Small World
description: THE GLOBAL ME

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, PHILIP
description: TUCKER-Philip. On October 22, 2000, at age 82. Loving husband of Leonor and her sons, Halbert and Juan Carlos, father of Jeffrey and Stephen (deceased), father-in-law of Cheryl & Melanie, grandfather of Lacey. A certified public accountant and former Chairman of the Accounting Department at Bronx Community College. We all mourn the loss of this highly moral, compassionate, humble man. Services were held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 ST, Tuesday, October 24, 11 am. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Westside Federation For Senior And Supportive Housing, 2345 Broadway, NY, NY 10024.

title: In Final Days, Rallying Supporters and Attempting to Sidestep a Volatile Issue
description: All but pleading, Vice President Al Gore and Senator Paul Wellstone appealed directly tonight to independents and Ralph Nader supporters not to throw this traditionally Democratic state to Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Offbeat Touches for a Melting-Pot Menu
description: AFTER little more than a year, White Oak Bistro in New Canaan is gone. In its place, in the former Veterans Hall with stately front columns, is 62 Main. It retains much of the decor, but differs in name, menu and front-of-house staff. Chef Robert Troilo was formerly at Habana in South Norwalk.

title: Kim France, Malik Armstead
description: Kim Marie France and Malik A. Armstead, the owners of the Five Spot Soul Food Restaurant in Brooklyn, were married at the restaurant yesterday by former Mayor David N. Dinkins.

title: Jane Cullen and Teddy Walkowicz
description: AMONG friends, Teddy Walkowicz is known for his long bachelorhood, which seemed as hard to break as a secret code; his imitation of Jack Nicholson; his heartfelt thank-you notes on beautiful stationery; his aversion to barber shops (he cuts his own hair); his beautiful clothes; his bizarre clothes; and his graciousness.

title: Julie Fergang, Steven Rosefsky
description: Julie Ann Fergang, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen S. Fergang of New York, is to be married this evening to Steven Matthew Rosefsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard S. Rosefsky of Atlanta. Rabbi Allan Schranz is to officiate at the University Club in New York.

title: The World; Working Nuclear Blackmail
description: WHY the difference between American policy toward Cuba, a renegade Communist backwater whose dictator is scorned by the United States, and toward North Korea, a renegade Communist backwater whose dictator was feted last week with Californian wines carried by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright?

title: Laura Snyder, Giovanni Giorgini
description: Dr. Laura Joy Snyder and Dr. Giovanni Giorgini, both professors, are to be married today by Rabbi Michael Feinberg at the Hudson River Club in Manhattan.

title: The Nation; What Makes Ralph (And Pat) Run?
description: THERE is no obvious ideological line that connects Ralph Nader to H. Ross Perot, Robert M. LaFollette, George C. Wallace, Theodore Roosevelt, John B. Anderson, Eugene V. Debs, Strom Thurmond and many of the other independent and third-party candidates who have mounted notable campaigns for the presidency in the course of American history. But comparing the issues these candidates ran on is not the only way to assess just what it is they were trying to appeal to in the electorate. And to many historians, there is at least one prism through which they appear remarkably similar.

title: Her Hoop Dreams
description: FOR 17-year-old Rebecca Richman and her boyfriend, Travis, this spring was their first spring in love, and like many New York lovers, they often wandered deep into Central Park, feeling as if they were alone in the world. Day after day, they held hands, spread out a blanket near a pond, had picnics and took pictures of each other. But on June 21, their idyll ended. That is the day the National Collegiate Athletic Association allows recruiters to begin calling the basketball players they want to woo.

title: Bon Voyage
description: To the Editor: I can recall, with much pleasure, the sailings I made with my family. The first was in the summer of 1934 when we left Hoboken, N.J., on the Holland America Line for Rotterdam. The departure was scheduled at midnight (which they often were at that date). Friends arrived in black tie, we ate gorgeous hors d'oeuvre, Champagne was served, and it was all a great gala party. Very formal and very classy!

title: Minivan Rentals: Roomy, Pricey
description: WHEN Mike and Pam Hilburn of Laguna Beach, Calif., arrived in Hawaii with their two sons, 11 and 7, in January for a 10-day vacation, the midsize Alamo rental car reserved for them looked uncomfortably small.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Living, Working and Playing Near the Train Station
description: A THREE-ACRE lot across Lafayette Avenue from the train station in Morristown that has long been used for parking has become an increasingly rare commodity: a buildable site at the edge of the community's reviving central business district.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. The dialogue between traditional and modern that characterizes the apartment's interior reflects a similar sensibility in its owners, according to the designer, Vicente Wolf. So it's no surprise that the owners were drawn to artists whose work reveals the same tension. Eric Fischl is known for art that addresses the psychological issues of modern life by figurative means, as in ''The Tire Store'' (a). Ross Bleckner, on the other hand, is known for his richly colored, densely patterned canvases in which the decorative and the abstract combine to evoke various moods, as in ''Covered Slide'' (b).

title: Raising the Neighborhood; A Few Years Into Its Ambitious Plan, Trinity College Sees Results
description: IT is a street parallel to the playing fields at Trinity College, a corner of the now handsome block that is home to the neighborhood's four newest schools, where Eddie Perez illustrates the progress of an ambitious plan to reinvent a poor neighborhood in the poorest city in the state.

title: The Serenity Of Meditation On the Move
description: THE usual jangled nerves and pre-performance chaos were noticeably absent backstage at the Maison de la Danse last month when the Cloud Gate Dance Theater of Taiwan meditated and practiced tai chi while waiting for the curtain to rise. Repeated chants of ''om'' could be heard in the music playing throughout the theater as the cast and crew prepared to present ''Songs of the Wanderers'' by the company's artistic director, Lin Hwai-Min.

title: A Portuguese Man of Letters Meets His Public
description: IT was a bright and beautiful afternoon on Ferry Street in the Ironbound last Saturday. People were out shopping, Halloween decorations were up in the store windows, and the television sets in the cafes were tuned to the soccer games from Lisbon.

title: Flesch's Putter Keeps Him Ahead of Woods
description: Nothing fazed Steve Flesch today, not the presence of Tiger Woods or the pressure of protecting a lead.

title: Holes Seen in Open-Space Ballot Proposal
description: ENVIRONMENTAL groups said last week that a ballot proposal in Suffolk County threatens to severely limit voter-approved acquisitions of open space and farm development rights at a time when the fate of many of these lands is about to be determined.

title: Katherine Applebaum, James Lowy
description: Katherine Lynne Applebaum, a daughter of Elizabeth and Harvey Applebaum of Washington, was married there last evening to James Franklin Lowy, a son of Jacqueline and Sherman Lowy of Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbi Joshua Haberman officiated at the Cosmos Club.

title: Newt at Rest
description: One peculiarity of this political season is that we don't have Newt Gingrich to kick around anymore. Wasn't it only two years ago that he was marshaling his armies like a silver-haired Napoleon? Newt -- he was one of those tabloid figures who needed only a first name -- traveled to 48 states that year and raised tens of millions of dollars in a campaign that was really a crusade against a prevaricating, adulterous, untrustworthy President.

title: All Gong Takes Breeders' Cup Race
description: All Gong stamped himself as a contender for steeplechaser of the year yesterday when he took the lead approaching the 12th fence and then galloped out to win the $250,000 guaranteed Breeders' Cup Steeplechase in Far Hills, N.J.

title: A Professor's Passions in Life and Death
description: THE greeting is standard-issue cheery (''Hi. How are you?), but the tone is caustic and the speaker is known to be forbidding.

title: Jo Hoffman, Joshua Friedman
description: Jo B. Hoffman and Joshua Harris Friedman were married last evening by Rabbi Sandy Bogin at the White Space, a loft in Manhattan.

title: Eyewitness Account
description: History of

title: Ideas & Trends: The Car Is King; Mass Transit Riders Are Pawns
description: IT lasted 32 days and left half a million people stranded without their usual means of transportation. Maids and nannies struggled to find new ways from East Los Angeles to Beverly Hills, office workers carpooled and were chronically late and the notoriously bad traffic on freeways and surface streets was, if anything, worse.

title: For AT&T, A Lesson In Ways of The Street
description: IN their decision to split the AT&T atom into four separate parts, C. Michael Armstrong and the company's directors were clearly trying to put some new-economy pizazz into their despondent stock. But the AT&T spinoff plan, announced last Wednesday, only resulted in further losses for beleaguered shareholders. The stock ended the week down 18.5 percent; it has lost more than half its value since May.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 15 about trends in design and the work of the graphics designer Bruce Mau with Zone Books misspelled the surname of one of the imprint's editors. He is Michel Feher, nor Fehrer. The article omitted the names of two other prominent editors at Zone who have worked with Mr. Mau; they are Hal Foster and Ramona Naddaff. The article also misspelled the surnames of two authors published by Zone. They are the art historian Erwin Panofsky, not Panovsky, and the philosopher Georges Bataille, not Batailles. And the article misspelled the surname of a former editor of I.D., a leading magazine in the field. She is Chee Pearlman, not Perlman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, SALLY
description: ROSENBAUM-Sally. September 15, 1917-October 24, 2000. Beloved wife of Herbert for 59 years, devoted mother of the late Adrienne Jonay, the late Jane Rosenbaum, and Linda Rosenbaum, adored grandmother of Tal and Daniel Jonay, cherished sister of Eleanor, and loving aunt of Jean, Nancy, Nora and Paul, passed away suddenly after a brief illness. Graveside services, 1:30 PM, Monday, October 30, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, LI. Finally reunited with her precious daughters and at peace.

title: The Nation; Calculating One Kind of Middle Class
description: COURTING the middle class, as presidential candidates are wont to do, requires no great political calculus: most Americans -- nearly 70 percent by one count -- reckon that the siren song is directed at them. And while it's true that some wealthier folk are comfortable with the label of upper-middle class, and a good quarter of industrious citizens will tag themselves working class, stark categories like ''upper class'' and ''lower class'' remain unpopular.

title: This Bird Has Flown, and Thereby Hangs a Tale of Mercy
description: ''Missing her,'' reads one of 200 fliers posted up and down the tree-lined streets of Park Slope. ''Have you seen her?''

title: Lewis's Ability to Scramble Is Put to the Test
description: His boat is not yet finished, the coffers are still not full, the crew list remains incomplete. It would be one thing if the goal were an entry in this January's Key West Race Week, but for Cam Lewis, the intent is a trifle more grand. In nine weeks, on Dec. 31, Lewis plans to point the twin bows of his as-yet-unnamed 110-foot catamaran south toward Antarctica to begin The Race, the nonstop sprint around the globe.

title: A Poor Example
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On an Arizona Ranch, History and Adobe
description: In its heyday in the late 1800's, Sahuaro Ranch in Glendale, Ariz., nine miles northwest of downtown Phoenix, produced figs, pears, oranges, peaches, apricots and olives. Its owner, William Henry Bartlett, a grain broker from Peoria, Ill., had constructed 15 buildings, mostly of red brick and some quite lavish. He eventually added a rose garden, a golf course and a lily pond with gazebo.

title: GREENWICH ACCESS ROAD TO REOPEN
description: A dispute between Westchester County and Greenwich over the closing of a Greenwich street, Gateway Lane, has been resolved. The road, which has been used as a route to the Westchester County airport, has been closed to Westchester-bound drivers since Jan. 19. Under an agreement, it is to reopen in a month, after restrictions to limit heavy trucks and reduce speeding are are put in place. Merri Rosenberg

title: SOAPBOX; Sharing Milia's Final Journey
description: ONCE Milia opened the door to her spic-and-span apartment, I was captivated.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Phoenix

title: Money Talks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAWISA, BERNARD J.
description: ZAWISA-Bernard J. Artist and Professor Emeritus, Department of Art, Southern Connecticut State University, on October 3, 2000, in Los Angeles County, California, of complications from a brain tumor. He was born in Middletown, Connecticut on May 12, 1925. After serving in the US Air Corps in WW II he received his BA in 1949 from Wesleyan University and his MFA in 1954 from the University of Iowa. He joined the SCSU faculty in 1958 and until his retirement in 1992 was an inspiring teacher of design, painting, color, the philosophy of art and independent study in painting and color. He organized and proposed courses in color, water based media in painting and the philosophy of art. His paintings, collages, and sculptures won major prizes and honors. He was influenced by the color and light of spring and autumn in the New England landscape and extensive travels in Egypt, China, the Middle East, Europe and California. Mr. Zawisa exhibited widely in New England, Los Angeles and NYC. Critics state that his use of color is luminous and intriguing and his abstract and thematic figurative canvases are fully controlled yet expressive and aesthetic rhapsodies of composition. Mr. Zawisa's work has been described as arresting, inventive, distinctive and intellectual in concept. His quiet and sincere manner, pleasant disposition and brilliant, but unpretentious, creativity is missed painfully by his family, friends, colleagues and former students. Burial was in Calvary Cemetery, Middletown, Connecticut.

title: Few Lobsters, and Now, Fewer Lobstermen
description: BOB SPONG, 60, has been a lobsterman on Long Island Sound all his life. But last March, when he thought the lobster population might never recover, he decided to get what he calls ''the first real job'' he's ever held. So now he drives a forklift at the Home Depot store in Commack on the lobster shift -- what else? -- from 10 p.m. to 6:30 a.m.

title: In a Paris Salon, Beauticians, Too, Have Private Lives
description: FRENCH women may not start out with innate advantages over the rest of womankind, but they certainly work harder at being beautiful than most. They eat little, dress well and cultivate aloofness. They also spend a great deal of time and money on cosmetics, creams, algae, mud packs, massages, winter tans and the like. Indeed, in almost every Paris neighborhood, the beauty spa is now a fixture. For many French women, it is their house of dreams.

title: Enveloped by Grass Rooms
description: EVERYONE knows the saying about people who live in glass houses and what they shouldn't do. But what about people who live in grass houses, or at least those who build grass rooms.

title: The Look, and Outlook, of a Gallery
description: Although Rosenthal Wine Merchant's reputation for selectivity flows from its French portfolio, its smaller Italian collection is equally discriminating.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Welcome Not Universal, But Neighbors Adjust

title: Peony: A Regal Tree That's Really a Shrub
description: THE first time I saw a tree peony, I was overwhelmed, thunderstruck, just plain awed. The flowers were pure magnificence, easily a foot across. They looked like polished satin in the most vivid shade of red. The plants themselves assumed an almost regal position with handsome foliage as the flowers' foil.

title: 15-Minute Clean-Up
description: The prospect of fall garden clean-up can be daunting, especially if you lack an army of helpers. Some people can't afford the time; others would rather soak their heads than spend precious leisure hours rooting up annuals after frost has turned them to black slime.

title: Out of Their Depth
description: THE LAST DIVE

title: Nassau Republicans Change Their Stripes
description: Nassau County Republicans have been forced to reinvent themselves. They have expunged nearly all mention of their county party affiliation from campaign material, aware that Nassau's near fiscal collapse helped propel Democrats to power for the first time in decades last year. Republicans are struggling to maintain control of the State Senate, and see the prospect of losing even a few races in Nassau as a grave threat.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Samsons

title: In Oakland, a Dynasty All but Restored
description: An exhibition of more than 350 objects from the imperial court of the Qing Dynasty in China is on display at the Oakland Museum of California through Jan. 24.

title: From Bronxville, Evidence That Artists Still Call It Home
description: BRONXVILLE, well known for its exceptional schools, upscale shops and restaurants, once had another reputation: as a burgeoning art colony. Going back as far as the 1850's, artists settled here because it was picturesque and a quick commute from New York City via the newly constructed railroad.

title: Bon Voyage, Dummy
description: Travel is said to broaden the mind, which is good for the purchasers of a new series of vacation guides. IDG Books Worldwide, publishers of the ''For Dummies'' series of instructional books, has come out with eight travel books, with seven more due by the end of the year. Now available are Walt Disney World and Orlando for Dummies, Cruise Vacations for Dummies and New York, California, San Francisco, the Caribbean, Europe and London for you-know-who. Many of the hotel and restaurant listings come from Frommer's guidebooks, which IDG also publishes. The Dummies guides cost $15.99 to $19.99; (800) 434-3422. JOSEPH SIANO

title: Rappers Turn Dialectic Into a Conversation
description: BEFORE funk was music, it was a smell: the earthy tang of hard labor or uninhibited lust, of the human body in all its physicality. OutKast, the Atlanta group that made Southern hip-hop competitive with anything from the East or West Coast, puts a funky Southern-accented ''stank'' at the core of its fourth album, ''Stankonia'' (LaFace/Arista 26072).

title: With a Rally Vs. Nebraska, Oklahoma Rises Again
description: Before each team meeting last week, Oklahoma Coach Bob Stoops showed his players a highlight reel from past showdowns with Nebraska, specifically snippets from the 12 victories Coach Barry Switzer recorded over the Cornhuskers, a couple of them in come-from-behind fashion. Stoops wanted to educate them in what is known around here as Sooner magic.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Habitats/43rd Street and Eighth Avenue; An Actor Moves Closer To Day Job and Auditions
description: LIKE many young actors new to New York, Jeannie Dalton got a place in Brooklyn, took a day job in Midtown Manhattan and started going to auditions.

title: Corrections
description: The front-page index in this section last Sunday misstated the number of years since the death of the organist Virgil Fox, who was the subject of an article in the music pages. He died 20 years ago, not 50.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 37 of Arts & Leisure today about an exhibition of photographs of China misspells the photographer's surname in some copies. (The error also appears in some copies in a picture caption and a subheading on Page 37, in a caption with the continuation on Page 40 and in a front-page contents entry.) The photographer is Lois Conner, not Connor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDENBAUM, SIDNEY L.
description: LINDENBAUM-Sidney L. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Loving son of the late Sadie and Morris. Devoted father of Marcy and Sandy. Cherished grandfather of Jessica, Dara, Amy and David. Services Sunday, 1:30 PM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: More Than a Lawn, It's Food
description: IN suburbia, grass is the consumate symbol of suburban life. But elsewhere in the world, grasses represent an important food source.

title: Elizabeth Mayer, Howard Rappaport
description: Elizabeth Mayer, the daughter of Joan and Harold C. Mayer Jr. of New York, was married last evening to Howard Steven Rappaport, a son of Frances Rappaport of Woodbridge, Conn., and the late Harvey Rappaport. Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, the senior rabbi at Congregation Emanu-El in New York, officiated at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Designers Get Perfect 10 From Coach
description: FROM a tiny basement in a Newington apartment complex, two Russian women, Natella Abdulaeva and Lena Danilova, have spent a frenzied two months creating the outfits worn by some of the world's most famous ice skaters.

title: For Two Young Mayors, It Was A Difficult Week
description: It was a New Jersey kind of week.

description: It may be that Vladimir Kramnik thinks that the best defense is a good offense.

description: VICTOR-Max. At age 82, retired executive, of New York City, died October 14th, in Delray Beach, FL, after a brief illness.

description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRAYER, DORIS
description: DRAYER-Doris. One year has passed since you left. Not a day goes by that you are not in my thoughts and tears. Rest Well, My Darling Sonny

title: Much for the Imagination In G.E.-Honeywell Deal
description: IS John F. Welch Jr. in over his head? The chairman of General Electric may be the most admired manager in the world, but his encore -- the planned $45 billion acquisition of Honeywell International -- could be his hardest job yet. For an executive who usually cares about the dowdiest of details, he has not figured out exactly how combining G.E. and Honeywell will work.

title: No Talking
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-29-00: Archive; Thanks for Sharing
description: If a surprisingly large -- and vocal -- portion of the population remains undecided about the coming presidential election, it's not for lack of advice. In addition to spin doctors and professional commentators, it seems that every fading celebrity, small-town bureaucrat and fringe-group spokesman has gone on record in recent months offering his or her opinion about who's best for America. Herewith, a sampling of some of the most egregiously unsolicited endorsements.

title: Corrections
description: The Book Value column last Sunday, about ''The Power of Gold,'' by Peter L. Bernstein, misstated the year of a statement attributed to Benjamin Disraeli about the gold standard used in Britain. It was 1873, not 1895.

title: Copland's Centenary, In Art and Music
description: HOW does an art museum celebrate Aaron Copland's 100th birthday? By tracing the influences that shaped him and his contemporary visual artists, exploring the milieu in which they created their different, but sometimes complementary, arts.

title: The World: Snapshot of Despair; The Deathly Glamour of Martyrdom
description: RABAH EL-LOH, 23, stood one afternoon in front of the shallow pit where the body of his brother, Raid, killed in clashes with Israeli soldiers, had just been set down. The funeral had taken all morning and thousands of angry mourners milled around the barren cemetery in Gaza.

title: A Ghoul Tour: Notable Graves on the Island
description: ROSENBERG is a common name among the thousands of headstones at Wellwood Cemetery, a big Jewish burial ground in Pinelawn. There are four Juliuses and three Ethels. But there is only one plot where a Julius Rosenberg is laid next to an Ethel.

title: Sports of The Times; Cone Is Given a Moment to Cherish
description: DAVID CONE had not just been hit hard; he had been hammered for four home runs, the last a three-run homer by the Orioles' ninth-place hitter, second baseman Mark Lewis. The Yankees lost that July 4 game, 7-6, and Cone's record was 1-7. As he left the mound in the sixth inning, boos thundered.

title: Guns, Here and There
description: To the Editor:

title: Refinishing Wood Floors
description: ONE of the most noticeable improvements a homeowner can make is to restore a dull, scratched or discolored wood floor to a like-new luster. And since the necessary tools can be rented at most home-improvement centers, the work can be cost effective if care is taken.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHAN, PHILIP J.
description: NATHAN-Philip J. On October 23, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia, loving father of Walter and Helen, dear brother of the late Daisy N. Fenton & the late Helen N. Goldberg, loving uncle, grand uncle and great-grand uncle. Services were private.

title: Rested and Ready to Take Off After a Flame-Out
description: HE'S 27, a biker, the son of a Lutheran minister turned prison warden. He lives in a small fourth-floor walkup on the Upper West Side of Manhattan; ''my penthouse,'' he calls it. In the bedroom, he keeps a top-of-the-line D.J. station so he can mix music, mostly reggae, in his down time. He doesn't touch caffeine, drinks alcohol only on special occasions and is a vegetarian ''because it makes me feel lighter, less aggressive.'' He loves his two Harley-Davidson motorcycles, but in town he generally moves around on foot or by subway, traveling light, ''with just my Metrocard and a little money,'' he says.

title: Suggestions Offered on Cutting Energy Costs
description: STRONGER conservation programs, aggressive use of alternative energy sources and public control of the electricity supply were among the ideas proposed last week at a forum here on rising energy prices.

title: In His Own Words
description: GEORGE W. BUSH

title: 70's Redux: Notes From the Jazz Underground
description: JAZZ is undergoing a quiet revival, only it's not where you would expect to find it. It's not in the clubs, though there is plenty of good live music. Nor is it at prestige-enhancing institutions like Lincoln Center, welcome as they are. The revival in jazz is to be found, rather, in the explosion of reissues, first-ever historic recordings and bootlegs.

title: Theater Struggles to Come Out of Dark
description: OPENED in 1955, the American Festival Theater in Stratford was for years a popular destination for school field trips and theater lovers, who enjoyed high-quality performances without having to travel to New York City. But the stage went dark for the last time in 1989, and attempts at an encore have, thus far, been unsuccessful.

title: Allison Oakes, Charles Smith
description: Allison Jane Oakes, the daughter of Bonnie Casper of Sewickley, Pa., and John S. Oakes of Minneapolis, was married yesterday to Charles Calkins Smith, a son of Carolyn Calkins and Charles Paul Smith of Doylestown, Pa. The Rev. Leslie Harry Cohen, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Puck Building in New York.

description: A picture last Sunday with a restaurant review of Martino's, in Somerville, was published in error. It showed Encore, in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: After pulling copies of the past few months' magazines off my shelf, I noted that most of the pictures in What They Were Thinking were of typical Americans caught in their daily activities -- over all, an absorbing portrait of American life in 2000. Imagine my puzzlement, then, when on Oct. 8, we were treated to a 1997 shot of Bill Clinton and several of his advisers in the Map Room. And lo, there are Al and Tipper, engaging in their now familiar conjugal kiss. Was this to ensure that no one is unaware of Al's acclaimed uxoriousness? I hope to see a similarly touching portrait of the Bushes in the coming weeks.

title: Encyclopedic Epicures
description: PARK AND ORCHARD is hardly undiscovered; in the waiting area there is a whole wall of reviews. But it had been some years since The Times last visited, and I was eager to learn for myself what has made this place so successful and maybe bring a fresh point of view to it.

title: The Korean War, Both Personal and Political
description: 'The Korean War'

title: A Jekyll-Hyde Kind of Place in Northport
description: THE Bayview Bistro is not what is used to be. Diners who go to this Northport spot may not realize they are in a new restaurant. The name and decor are the same, but in the last six months everything else has changed: owners, chefs, menu.

title: Dracula Is the Big Man on Campus
description: BERT GARSKOF remembers hunkering down beside the radio with his family as a boy growing up in New York. Sixty years later he feels the same excitement when he performs on radio.

title: H.M.O.'s Address Discontent of Doctors
description: A SURVEY released last week by the attorney general's office found that doctors don't like managed care. While many may not find that surprising, the discontent of doctors has gotten the attention of the state's health maintenance organizations, which said they are already taking steps to make their doctors happier.

title: Parkers Prefer Spots for Their Cars to a Patch of Green
description: Car owners in the West Village say they are being shortchanged by plans to convert acres of affordable parking at Pier 40 into acres of open park.

description: Fistfights broke out at a Friday night staff meeting at Excelsior, once Mexico's most prestigious daily newspaper, after its managers confessed that it is nearly bankrupt and for sale.

description: Samantha Lauren Lerman, the daughter of Laura E. Lerman and Kenneth Lerman of Newtown, Conn., is to be married today to Dr. David Bruce Bernstein, a son of Gertrude Bernstein and Dr. Ralph Bernstein of Suffern, N.Y. Rabbi Bernard Schecter will officiate at the Heritage Inn in Southbury, Conn.

title: Olympics Seeking $20 Million Benefactor
description: Don't count on your Merrill Lynch broker to get you into the opening ceremonies at the next Olympic Games.

title: For Bush, His Toughest Call Was the Choice to Run at All
description: Karen P. Hughes, one of Gov. George W. Bush's top aides, walked into the governor's office one day in the summer of 1997 and brandished a sheet of paper.

title: Supplies of Blood Fall as Demand Increases
description: ONE day earlier this month the supply of the state's most common blood type, O positive, dropped to less than a day's reserve. The ''safe level'' is considered three days' supply by hospitals and the American Red Cross.

description: To the Editor:

description: THE Ludlow Park neighborhood made perfect sense to Jane Campbell and Peter Whitely from the minute they stumbled on it three years ago.
