description: To the Editor:

title: Graying of the Arts And the Audience, Too
description: In your recent article ''Graying of the Arts: Who Will Take Over'' [Oct. 22], you neglected to discuss an even more serious problem, the graying of the audience. As the president of the Massapequa Philharmonic Orchestra and the keeper of our mailing list of approximately 2,000, I can tell you that the list is barely growing, maybe 20 a year, and the graying audience is dwindling rapidly, due to death and infirmity, and not being replaced by younger adults.

title: The Nation: Double Vision; How Bush and Gore View the Role of Government
description: TEDDY ROOSEVELT would have gotten an enormous kick out of the last days of this year's campaign for president.

title: Can Mexico's New Leader Really Work Wonders?
description: AS a new president prepares to take power in Mexico, the biggest economic news is what's not happening.

title: Some Intriguing Discoveries As Lily Tomlin Searches Again
description: IN the 14 years since Lily Tomlin won the Tony Award for her performance in ''The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe,'' we humans have done a lot of peering, both outward and inward. In 1989 we sent the Galileo spacecraft on its way to an orbit around Jupiter. In 1995, for the first time, we detected a planet circling a star other than our own sun. Just a few months ago we completed the mapping of our own genetic structure.

title: October 22-28; AT&T Decides to Split Into 4 Businesses
description: Hoping to buy all your communications services -- wireless, Internet, cable television, telephone -- from one company and pay one bill? Don't count on AT&T. The company announced it would break into four parts in AT&T's biggest overhaul since the Baby Bell local phone companies left the nest in 1984. Under C. Michael Armstrong, AT&T's chairman since 1997, the company had tried to build a ''one-stop shop'' for communications consumers. But investors failed to line up to buy into the strategy.

title: Spanish Voted Here
description: In the window of El Jardin Restaurante on Main Avenue, where the awning advertises Comida Tipica Mexicana, or authentic Mexican food, a poster for a Passaic County freeholder candidate includes a message that Spanish-speaking voters understand all too well:

title: Give Me Liberty, or Something Else!
description: Two Faces of Liberalism

title: Logan Levkoff, Louis Cortes
description: Logan Ross Levkoff and Louis Edward Cortes were married yesterday by Rabbi Jerome Davidson at the Plaza in Manhattan.

title: Oh, to Be an Alaskan in October
description: October may have been a tough month for the stock market, but it was profitable, as usual, for Alaskans.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Linda Chang, Daniel Kim
description: Linda Maicy Chang, the daughter of Lai Yee Chang and Dr. Chu Jiang Chang of Schenectady, N.Y., was married yesterday to Daniel Jungkoo Kim, a son of Jung-Ja Kim and Dr. Ki-Choon Kim of Potomac, Md. The Rev. Timothy Sullivan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul the Apostle Church in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARPE, DR. LAWRENCE
description: SHARPE-Dr. Lawrence. Died from cancer Thursday, October 19, 2000 at the McKeene Pavillion, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. Dr. Sharpe was born in London on December 25, 1930. He completed his medical training at University College Hospital, London, 1961. His first academic position in the United States was as an Instructor in Psychiatry at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, Maryland. He was an Assistant Professor of Psychiatry at State University New York & became an Associate Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at the University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1967. Dr. Sharpe joined the Biometrics Research Department of the New York State Institute in 1967. As a Research Psychiatrist he worked on the NIMH US/UK Diagnosis of Mental Disorders Project for many years. He joined the Department of Research Assessment and Training in 1980 and was involved in all of their projects until the last week of his life. He is survived by Robert Roy Nicholson, friend; his brother Robert Arden and wife Joy; his niece Suzy; his nephew Matthew and his wife Alex and their daughter, his great niece, Talullah. A memorial service will be held to celebrate his life on November 4 at 2:00 PM at the Church of Incarnation, 209 Madison Avenue, New York, New York 10016 (at 35th Street). In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy may be sent to the American Cancer Society.

title: At a New Theater, Boldly, a New Play
description: AN emerging theater company is putting its credibility on the line by taking a chance on an unproven, unsettling play.

title: Taking On the Corporate Goliaths
description: WHEN Mexico's antitrust agency decided to break up the nation's airline monopoly in early October, the move was seen as a bold show of aggressiveness. It also sent a strong signal that with the government about to change hands, Mexico might be prepared to guarantee competitors greater access to markets now dominated by single companies.

title: Adding an Arch to Decorate a Doorway
description: ONE way to transform an ordinary rectangular doorway into a dramatic entryway is by adding an arch. Creating an arch entails building a wooden frame, attaching it to the header and jambs, then covering it with drywall. Be aware that the arch will lower the top of the entryway by an inch or two.

title: The Defining Moments of a Dynasty
description: Ten moments that define the Yankees' current dynasty, ranked in order by The Times's Buster Olney.

title: Corrections
description: The Gazetteer chart last Sunday with an article about living in Upper Yorkville misstated the phone number and the admission fees for tours of Gracie Mansion. For both individual and group tours, the number is (212) 570-4751. Admission is $4 for adults and $3 for those 65 or over, not $3 and $2.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies last Sunday about development plans for a 40-acre site on the Stamford, Conn., waterfront misidentified the former owner. It was Northeast Utilities, not the United Illuminating Company.

title: Caught in Fashion's Mesh
description: Fashion's spotlight is always shifting -- hemlines, necklines, the waist. Last year, it was handbags. At the recent collections in Paris, fishnet stockings were the rage: guests often resembled a Folies Bergere chorus line. Some stockings mixed lacy patterns with the traditional fishnet. The look met its match, though, at the Dior show, where models wore fishnet cat suits under the scanty clothes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: An E-ZPass Into The System
description: All Christopher Reagoso needed to get access to a stranger's E-ZPass billing statement was a couple of clicks and key strokes. He didn't write code or hack or practice some other form of computer voodoo, he just added another digit to his account number in a Web page address and found himself looking at another person's account statement.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WARDEN, ALICE HEARD
description: WARDEN-Alice Heard. passed away suddenly but peacefully on September 2, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Dr. David E. Warden, mother of Alice Guida and David Todd Warden II, grandmother of Amanda Guida and Katherine and David Todd Warden III. A memorial service will be held Saturday, November 4 at 1:30PM at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, LI, NY

title: Liberties; Tex-Prep Haunting
description: I'm getting excited just thinking about it. I'm dreaming of that moment when the thrill returns.

title: The Queen of Dish
description: NATURAL BLONDE

title: In Bordeaux's Mold
description: The interesting Osprey's Dominion '98 pinot noir examined here two weeks ago energized my interest in immediately revisiting the work of both Peter Silverberg, formerly of the outstanding Golan Heights Winery in Israel, who came on board as winemaker in August 1999, and the winery itself.

title: A Merry if Pensive Old Soul at Just the Right Bar
description: It was the end of the business day and the bike messenger had one last package to deliver to the St. Regis Hotel.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: A Mirror of Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the health status of Vice President Al Gore misstated his blood pressure. It is 110/68, not 140/85.

title: Premier's Collapse
description: To the Editor: I cannot resist adding a postscript to the article about the collapse of Premier Cruises (''After Premier, Refund Routes'' (Practical Traveler, Oct. 1).

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Winter Range

title: Hidden Empire
description: To the Editor: The article about Ani, ''A Hidden Empire in Turkey'' (Oct. 8), took me back to 1965, when, as a Peace Corps volunteer, I was assigned to teach English in Kars. One of the highlights of that year was my first trip to Ani. Part of the closed military zone since World War II, it had been reopened in 1964. Then a permit was a bit more difficult to get, and there was little mention of Ani's Armenian origin. On our trip, we were accompanied by a plainclothes policeman. We rode out in an old bus with Turkish villagers and three sheep.

title: Ideas & Trends; Just What Politicians Needed: A Patron Saint
description: ON Tuesday, John Paul II will formally proclaim Sir Thomas More the patron saint of politicians, a professional class that nowadays is not especially known for unbending principle.

title: Police Officer Shoots and Kills Actor at Halloween Party
description: LOS ANGELES -- A police officer at a Halloween costume party shot and killed an actor Saturday after the man pointed a fake gun at him, police said.

title: Macie Finkelstein, Robert Himmel
description: Dr. Macie Ellen Finkelstein, a daughter of Bette Finkelstein and Dr. Elliot Finkelstein of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married last evening to Robert Mark Himmel, the son of Maida and Donald Himmel of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rabbi Donald Pollock officiated at the Pine Brook Country Club in Weston, Mass.

title: Meta-Midler
description: Until now, you could truly experience the Divine Miss M. only at a concert performance (Lynn Hirschberg, Oct. 8). The character she created as her stage persona was so much more engaging than many of her movie roles. With this new television venture, Bette Midler will be able to bring her unique combination of self-deprecating humor, ribaldry and musical talent to a much larger audience. I am betting that there are lots of unsuspecting future fans out there who will be amazed to find out what they have been missing.

title: A New Thorn in Divorces: Who Gets the Miles?
description: IT'S not just the house, cars and investment portfolios that are being contested in divorce settlements and inheritance disputes these days. In a growing number of families, the fights also involve airline frequent-flier miles.

title: BRIEFING: LAW ENFORCEMENT; BLOOD ALCOHOL LIMIT
description: Governor Whitman said last week that she would support lowering the state's threshold for drunken driving from the current 0.10 percent blood level to 0.08 percent. Her statement followed President Clinton's signing a law sponsored by Senator Frank Lautenberg that would withhold federal highway funding for states that do not adopt the more stringent 0.08 standard. The governor had opposed the federal legislation. According to Laura Otterbourg, the Governor's spokesperson, Mrs. Whitman ''would not do anything to jeopardize the federal funding.'' John Holl

title: October 22-28; Dark Christmas Tidings
description: Millions of books recounting ''The Night Before Christmas'' may be up for revision. In a new book, ''Author Unknown'' (Henry Holt & Company), Don Foster, a literary scholar known for establishing the authorship of an anonymous text by analyzing its style and vocabulary, argues that the wealthy Manhattan biblical scholar Clement Clarke Moore stole credit for writing the poem.

title: Gayle Gruber, Thomas Tizzio
description: Gayle Nealy Gruber, the daughter of Diane and Ronald Gruber of Holmdel, N.J., was married on Friday to Thomas Patrick Tizzio, a son of Mary Ann and Thomas Tizzio of Middletown, N.J. The Rev. Anthony Carotenuto performed the ceremony at St. Anthony of Padua Roman Catholic Church in Red Bank, N.J.

title: Food; Jumping Juniper
description: The scent of crushed or powdered juniper berries delivers a suggestion of shelter -- the heady camphor and resin of a pine grove, the spice of humus underfoot, the lemony warmth of a pale sun filtering through branches. It has the flavor of something warm and earthy in the midst of a cold, wild world.

title: Ulster Protestant Leader Wins a Key Vote
description: The Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, faced down a severe challenge from within his badly divided Protestant party and narrowly held on to the leadership today, in a vote seen as crucial to the survival of the Northern Ireland peace settlement.

title: At an Iowa Rally, Nader's Supporters Stand Their Ground
description: At every mention of the word ''spoiler,'' the crowd groaned.

title: Jamaica Journal; An Old-Fashioned Country Doctor Finishes His Last Rounds in the Big City
description: In the early 1960's, when Dr. Gerald W. Deas was an intern in the obstetrics clinic at Kings County Hospital, he discovered that many black women he treated ate an unusual snack: cubes of laundry starch. The practice was believed to be a holdover from women who ate clay in Africa, but Dr. Deas quickly found that the ingested starch often caused anemia because it interfered with the body's ability to produce iron.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Stanhope House music club in Stanhope misspelled the surname of a blues musician who has played there. He was Stevie Ray Vaughan, not Vaughn.

title: Theft of a Quaker Tombstone Provokes Scholarly Sleuthing
description: Graves dating as far back as the 1600's long lay undisturbed behind the landmarked Flushing Quaker Meeting House at 137-16 Northern Boulevard. Until three weeks ago, that is, when one tombstone was stolen.

title: The View From/Hamden; Is There One Final Lap Left For the Ghost Parking Lot?
description: A WELL-KNOWN piece of public art in Hamden faces an uncertain future.

title: The Way We Live Now: 10-29-00: The Ethicist; Pushing the E-Envelope
description: I discovered that my supervisor routinely reads employee e-mail. Legal issues aside, is this ethical? I can understand doing so if a crime is suspected, but not as a matter of routine. It feels like a violation of my privacy. What do you think? -- Anonymous, New York

title: Make It 'The Betrayer'
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE CHTEAU DE ReSENLIEU

title: Lives; The Deer Hunter
description: Deep in the woods, with friends and quarry.

title: October 22-28; Nasty Habit or Creative Boost? A Nail-Biting Issue
description: There is much information about the presidential candidates available to American voters, if they choose to use it. For instance, last week came news that Vice President Al Gore has a habit of chewing his fingernails to the quick. This was reported in an article in The New York Times about the vice president's health, which is quite good, except for some concern about his cholesterol level.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Brothers in Art as Well as Life
description: DECADES from now it will be said that in the late 20th century the world saw an odd and wonderful artistic phenomenon. It will be added in wistful tones that it was a pity it didn't last, but not a surprise. Historians will be speaking of Chinese brother artist teams, two pairs and a trio who lived either in mainland China or in the United States and spent their lifetimes living and working together as if they were one person, putting their collective energies into the creation of (what was then) very contemporary art.

title: Skits and Toys, but No Child's Play, as Young Victims Learn Courtroom Survival
description: In a few weeks Michael, a bright-eyed 8-year-old with apple-red cheeks, will face one of the most traumatic days of his young life. He will sit on a witness stand and try to tell a judge how his 15-year-old baby sitter, a boy whom he trusted, had sodomized him repeatedly this summer.

title: OPINION; Reassessing Nassau Reassessment
description: AT executive dinners and political fund-raisers, at Little League dinners and autumn parades, the political jockeying that will put the next Nassau County executive in office is now well under way.

title: Restaurants Online: Not Yet Today's Special
description: FOR Santo Romano, whose restaurant, Red Rose, has been serving linguine and veal in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, for 17 years, the computer age has officially arrived. Since late summer, customers have been able to reserve tables at his establishment over the Internet by way of www .foodline.com, an online reservation system with restaurants in 25 metropolitan areas around the country.

title: Yale Records Rout While Reese Sets Columbia Rushing Records
description: Yale quarterback Peter Lee threw four scoring passes and safety Ryan LoProto returned two interceptions for touchdowns today as the Elis routed Columbia, 41-0.

title: A Seat for Every Student? A Bus for Every Driver?
description: A new city law requires yellow school buses to provide a seat for every public school student. Now, Amalgamated Transit Local 726, a union of about 100 Staten Island city bus drivers, is calling on the Transit Authority to guarantee seats for public and private school students who ride regular city buses.

title: Murder in the Neighborhood
description: Joseph Colicchio's novel 'High Gate Health and Beauty,'' is a murder mystery: a strangler kills a dog, and then a man, in a gritty precinct of Jersey City called High Gate, a white working-class neighborhood where ones of race and especially class are firmly enforced. But Joey Scadutto, the novel's 15-year-old hero and a High Gate resident, needs to know much more than the identity of the killer. He's looking to the answer of a question anyone ever born to a dead-end neighborhood asks: how can you leave without losing who you are? The question is familiar to Mr. Colicchio, a Cranford resident who grew up in Jersey City Heights, where views of the New York skyline are equal parts promise and threat. As a professor of English at Hudson County Community College in Jersey City, he now watches many of his students grapple with the same dilemma, balancing community loyalty with future ambition. ''High Gate Health and Beauty'' (Creative Arts) is $14.95 in paperback. ANGELA STARITA

title: A Yankee Hero From the Past Stays as Big and Complicated as His Legend
description: The graceful dark shadow that haunted my Subway Series was the real and imagined memory of our most glamorous and mysterious ballplayer, Joe DiMaggio. Back when the outfield was our frontier, the Yankee Clipper was our gunfighter, a quick and wary gazelle of a man who drifted so smoothly over the stadium grass and through the neon nights that he seemed the quintessence of competency and cool. Mickey Mantle never replaced DiMaggio for me -- alas, I got to know the Mick -- and Reggie Jackson was no enigma, and David Justice, Bernie Williams and Paul O'Neill seem like superb ballplayers and fine men, which is not the fantasy I have in mind.

title: Shake, Rattle and Toll
description: Vintage Halloween items from the 1930's to the 60's -- cardboard cutout decorations, papier-mache candy baskets and party favors -- today command top dollar at collectibles shows.

title: Man Held in Killing Of East Side Woman
description: A woman was stabbed to death yesterday afternoon by a man she had been living with in Midtown, the police said.

title: Old-Fashioned Italian and 60's Ambience
description: IT'S Queens circa 1960 every night at Stella, a time warp ristorante in Floral Park on the Nassau-New York City line. The songs of Frank Sinatra and Italian opera divas fill the air, the celebrity pictures of past patrons (everyone from Mayor W. Rudolph Giuliani to Joe Pepitone of the Yankees) hang on the bar-room walls, tuxedoed waiters, some of whom have been at Stella for 20, 25 or 30 years, scurry about and the menu lists every known mainstream Italian dish.

title: Mary Roethel, Michael Turnbull
description: Mary Frances Roethel, a daughter of Gail and Harold Roethel of Fayetteville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Michael Edwin Turnbull, a son of Dr. Desna Turnbull of Buffalo and Lyndley Turnbull of Lewisdale, Md. The Rev. Gregory C. LeStrange performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception.

title: An Old-School Sandwich Shop
description: At midnight the town of Princeton is almost completely dead -- except at a sandwich shop a few blocks from the center, where the lights are on and the line is long. With foot-and-a-half hoagies, old photographs of university students that double as decor and a griddle that never stops sputtering, Hoagie Haven is indeed a late-night haven. It is a noontime haven too, judging from the business suits alongside the backpacks at the counter, where hoagies are the order of the day, every day. Words like ''with everything'' and ''whole'' are common here; it is one of the few places left where a $3 sandwich can contain the calories equivalent to a five-course meal. Cheese steaks, Italian hoagies (both $2.45 half, $4 whole) and the chicken and eggplant Parmigianias ($2.65 half, 4.50 whole) are favorites, the owners say. Also popular are omelet hoagies, which come in cheese, bacon, sausage or Western varieties. A faded sign vouches that they ''serve the best hamburgers on Earth or anyplace else.'' Owned by a pair of distantly related Greek immigrants, George Angeletopoulos and Gus Lyras, the Haven, as it is known to students, has been a staple of Nassau Street for 30 years. The two men have owned the shop for the past 13 or 14 years, by Mr. Lyras's calculation, and serve sandwiches with a staff of six, including his wife, Georgia, who helps with the lunch rush. For a smallish storefront with no seating, the shop does a serious business, each day slicing open 300 to 500 loaves of bread (bought fresh from the Italian Peoples' Bakery in Trenton each morning). Although the Haven will make hoagies to order, the menu hasn't changed in years and according to Mr. Lyras, isn't going to anytime soon. The customers, in business suits or with backpacks, aren't complaining, according to Mr. Lyras. ''They want the same thing all the time.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 15 about the Hapsburg dynasty's furniture collection in Vienna misstated the relationship of the last Austro-Hungarian ruler, Emperor Charles I, to Emperor Francis Joseph. He was a grandnephew, not a son.

title: They Could Play It Safe, But Then That's No Fun
description: GROWING up in Lawrenceville, Jim Vincent danced with companies in Mercer and Burlington Counties, capping his early career with the role of the little prince in American Repertory Ballet's ''Nutcracker.'' Now, having danced in the Netherlands and led a corporate life at Disneyland Paris, this big prince, 42, is returning to his home state as newly appointed director of his own troupe, Hubbard Street Dance Chicago.

title: NEW LIFE FOR OLD COMPUTERS
description: Rather than discarding old computers, residents can now recycle them. Old computers in working condition are available at no charge to those who need them. To get rid of equipment that no longer works, residents should call the county's Recycling Office at (914) 637-3049. To give away working equipment, residents can list it on the County's Web site at westchestergov.com. Those interested can look up the ''Used But Usable Clearinghouse'' section on the Web site, or call (914) 637-3011. The program was developed with the help of an Ardsley High School senior, Michael Herman, who was a county intern this summer Elsa Brenner

title: Roni Neff, John McGready
description: Roni Ann Neff, a daughter of Dr. Joanna Neff and Dr. Martin Neff of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married last evening to John Brecht McGready, the son of Mary and Thomas McGready of Ambler, Pa. Rabbi Elizabeth Bolton officiated at Port Discovery, a children's museum in Baltimore. Cantor Sally Neff, a sister of the bride, took part in the ceremony.

title: TRACK 26
description: The Yankees defeated the Mets in the Subway Series to capture their third consecutive World Series championship, but in midsummer that outcome hardly seemed ordained. The struggling Yankees were remade, and the newly acquired players aided the team's veterans. They eventually joined the Mets in a Series that captivated a city. Section 8A.

title: ROAD CONDITIONS
description: Nearly half of New Jersey's roads are in poor or fair condition and need improvements or repairs, and 38 percent of its bridges are either structurally deficient or functionally obsolete, according to a study made for the New Jersey Alliance for Action and released last week. The report, made by the Road Information Program, a research group based in Washington, said three of the roads most in need of repair were Route 4 in Bergen County, Route 21 in Newark and Routes 1 and 9 in Middlesex County. Karen DeMasters

title: October 22-28; The Yankees (Yawn) Win Again
description: The New York Yankees could really have let someone else have a turn. After all, they've been the dominant team of the past century. And they nearly did; all five games were close. But when the jumping and hugging and screaming stopped (or have they stopped?), they had again won three straight World Series -- the first such streak since the early 1970's. Even as the glum Mets defiantly vowed ''Next year,'' though, New Yorkers had the true prize: an instantly mythic Subway Series to tell their grandchildren about. Hubert B. Herring

title: Honor of an Olympics Designation Is Lost on Some Angry Residents
description: Ben Haber was hot. You could tell because his face turned red as he criticized the plan that he was hearing to bring the 2012 Summer Olympic Games to New York. And you could certainly tell when he said, ''You're going to have to walk over a lot of dead bodies.''

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Did you believe that your message was subtle? Yes, you documented that Al Gore has kissed his wife in public on another occasion. It's not surprising what the photo archives will uncover. It's even less surprising that Bill Clinton took full advantage of this opportunity to skewer the Republican Party, to assert his ''close personal'' relationship with a foreign leader and to tout his economic agenda. Samuel Berger fell into line, too, by suggesting that the Gores will warm our nation with their devotion. For years the news media have informed us that Bill Clinton's marital infidelity (in the office, with an employee, while on the job) was unrelated to his performance as our president. Now you want us to believe that Al Gore's loving marriage (which I admire) will be an asset to his performance as president. You can't have it both ways.

title: Some Newspapers Endorse Gore's Experience; Others Back Bush's Conciliatory Tone
description: Nine days before Election Day, a number of newspapers announced presidential endorsements today on their editorial pages.

title: Art of Listening
description: TALK TO ME

title: Here Comes 'Johnnie B. Goode'
description: Chuck Berry, who helped invent rock 'n' roll, wrote one of his most famous songs, ''Johnny B. Goode'' about his piano player Johnnie Johnson, who has also backed such performers as Keith Richards, Eric Clapton and John Lee Hooker.

title: Coming to Work in Jeans In a March of Dimes Drive
description: Starting Friday, some businesses will look more laid back, thanks to the March of Dimes Blue Jeans for Babies drive.

title: In Port Chester, Dishes From All Over Asia
description: AFTER minor redecoration, Tamarind has moved into the moody space last occupied by Grill FX. If the departure of Grill FX and its menu of South African specialties has left a void in international offerings supplied by the many ethnic restaurants lining Main Street here, Tamarind has picked up the slack with an unusual collection of dishes covering all corners of Asia.

title: Poised to Raise Real Jersey Tomatoes, Year Round
description: Just as home gardeners are putting away the tomato cages, those at the experimental agriculture station greenhouse in Bordentown operated by Cook College of Rutgers University are preparing to harvest their first tomatoes of the season. The workers there not only hope to produce a steady stream of tomatoes to be sold to King's Supermarkets in northern New Jersey throughout the winter, but they also hope the tomatoes will be as good as any that are picked in the Jersey fields at the peak of summer. The greenhouse, next to the landfill at the Burlington County Resource Center, is in the middle of its third year of operation. Dr. Harry Janes, a research professor and director of the greenhouse, which is next to the landfill at the Burlington Country Resource Center, talked recently about the operation.

title: Trading on Hollywood's Future
description: MICHAEL R. BURNS, an investment banker turned Internet entrepreneur and studio executive, was talking about his role as vice chairman at Lions Gate Entertainment -- specifically, the company's desire to become a major player in independent films -- when his thoughts suddenly switched gears.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 29, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, ANNE PESHKIN
description: BRODSKY-Anne Peshkin. October 23, 2000. Cherished wife of the late Abraham Brodsky, beloved mother of Judith Schneider and Joan Aaronson, adored ''Nana'' to six grandchildren and nine great grandchildren. Co-founder of the Brooklyn Psychiatric Centers, active in Hadassah, UJA Speakers Bureau. Her love and devotion to her family and the joy and light she brought to all who knew her will be deeply missed and remembered always.

title: BENEFITS
description: A Prince and the Academy

title: Into 'The Light of Day'
description: Bruce Springsteen, who brought worldwide fame to the Stone Pony in Asbury Park, wrote a song called ''The Light of Day,'' which was used in a Joan Jett-Michael J. Fox movie of the same name.

title: A Matter of Certification
description: To the Editor:

title: Beth Jacobson, Brett Sher
description: Beth Ellen Jacobson, a daughter of Gilda and George Jacobson of New City, N.Y., was married last evening to Brett Cory Sher, a son of Marsha and Irwin Sher of Melville, N.Y. Rabbi Henry Sosland performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, N.Y.

title: THEATER; How Reality Can Be 'Realer' on the Stage Than Raw
description: NOT long ago, an entertainment opened Off Broadway called ''Lifegame,'' created by Keith Johnstone and performed by the Improbable Theater, in which real people (portrayed by actors) present their life stories directly to the audience.

title: Make Terrorists Pay a Real Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Testy Congress Acts to Keep Agencies Going
description: While negotiations over the final touches on the federal budget languished, a cranky Congress approved a temporary spending measure today that will keep many government agencies operating for at least another day.

title: Students Return to Israel With No Qualms
description: As Dov Scheinerman prepared for the trans-Atlantic journey he began last night, it became clear that he viewed the trip as one of the more mundane excursions of his young life.

title: Barak Fails to Forge an Emergency Unity Government
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 29  Prime Minister Ehud Barak failed today to forge an emergency unity government with the right wing, but he is nonetheless unlikely to face immediate dismissal when Parliament reconvenes on Monday after a three-month recess.

title: Denver Journal; What's in a Stadium Name -- Tradition or Money?
description: ''Not everything should be for sale,'' Mayor Wellington E. Webb said this week -- raising more than a few eyebrows, because what he does not want to sell could mean as much as $89 million for Denver and the surrounding five counties.

title: Corrections
description: Because of broadcasters' changes and the early end of the World Series, some Sunday and Monday listings in the Television section today have become outdated. Updated entries may be found in this section, on Page 41.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POST, SEYMOUR C. MD.
description: POST-Seymour C. MD. October 26. Survived by his wife, Judith, children Michael, Deborah Radovsky, Nancy Schecter and Susan Lichtenstein and eight grandchildren. Services private. Receiving family and friends at home on Sunday, October 29, 3-6PM.

title: Coming of Age, but Going Nowhere
description: TOMMY, a 12-year-old Indian boy, born in Canada, searches for a father, rejecting the one he has.

title: POSTINGS: Appointment at Cooper Union; Chanin School's Acting Dean
description: No one ever before succeeded to the deanship of Cooper Union's architecture school, because John Hejduk was the first and -- for 25 years -- the only dean.

title: Women's Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, MORTIMER A.
description: SHAPIRO-Mortimer A. At 84, died peacefully at his home. A life well led. Beloved husband of Mimi. Father of Sylvia and David. Grandfather of Luke, Nathan, Lily and Hazel. Dearest friend, colleague and drinking partner of many. Code-breaker and veteran of the Aleutian Campaign in his youth. Practiced the art of law in New York for over 60 years. Mentor and partner of Sylvia for over 20 years. His memory will be cherished by all who knew him. Morty, order yourself a martini with a side of ice. There's plenty tonight.

title: How Reality Can Be 'Realer' on the Stage Than Raw
description: LAST year, one of the major television networks engaged me to develop an hourlong dramatic series. It hired me and flew me to Los Angeles, I was told, because my plays are ''real.'' I got to work and obliged my bosses with a script so real, so topical, so without concession to tired television tropes, that it looked as if my first time out I might garner that elusive prize: a produced pilot.

title: North Korea & Company
description: While Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright was talking missiles and Oscars last week with North Korea's eccentric leader, Kim Jong Il, a less-ballyhooed delegation from one of Asia's early economic miracles, Singapore, was in North Korea to talk business.

title: Sounds of Gravity
description: Einstein's Unfinished Symphony Listening to the Sounds of Space-Time. By Marcia Bartusiak. Illustrated. 249 pp. Washington: Joseph Henry Press. $24.95.

title: Questions for Bono
description: Studying the Charter of the United Nations, relating to Harvard professors, quoting from Leviticus and chilling with the Pope may not seem ''inherently sexy'' to some, but so what (The Way We Live Now: Susan Dominus, Oct. 8)? This man, Bono, adored, even idolized by many, is putting his very sexy brain and energy toward selfless goals, making even the ''Big Guy'' proud, no doubt. Amen, brother!

title: It's O.K. to Listen; Just Don't Label
description: THE Jersey City-based band Better Off Dead mightily resists efforts to label its down-and-dirty mix of musical styles.

title: Article 2000103092122645839 -- No Title
description: DUBUQUE, Iowa, Oct. 30  Striking back against a Democratic offensive that questioned whether Gov. George W. Bush was ready to be president, Dick Cheney countered today that it is the Democratic ticket which lacks experience and said that Vice President Al Gore "is not up to the task" of being the nation's commander in chief.

title: Barak Gets a Breather as He Tries to Form a Unity Government
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak failed today to forge an emergency unity government with the right wing, but he is nonetheless unlikely to face immediate dismissal when Parliament reconvenes Monday after a three-month recess.

title: Congress and White House Remain Stymied on Budget
description: Congressional and administration negotiators made little progress for much of today toward agreement on the final spending and tax bills in the federal budget. The stalemate ensures that Congress, which has already set a post-World War II record for the latest adjournment date in an election year, will remain in session at least one day longer.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Article 2000103092028332476 -- No Title
description: PlayStation 2 as Trojan Horse

title: Investigation of Attack on U.S. Destroyer Moving Slowly
description: Despite a trail of clues suggesting that the destroyer Cole was bombed by Islamic militants, possibly associated with Osama bin Laden, American investigators lack the concrete evidence to prove anything, administration and government officials say. Washington is wary of inflaming political turmoil in the Middle East by making unsubstantiated accusations, the officials say.

title: In New Jersey, Voters Shifting Priorities Change a Senate Contest

title: Italy's New Politics: The Beauty Contest
description: Italians are known for their sense of style, so it is perhaps fitting that the campaign for 2001 parliamentary elections, which will determine whether Italy stays center-left or veers center-right, is fixated on looks. Italians will choose between two candidates for prime minister who could easily pass for rivals on ''The Dating Game.''

title: 3 Executives Form A Global-Minded Shop
description: Three top agency executives in Europe are leaving their posts to open a shop specializing in international clients.

title: Banned in Boston? Not Mike Keenan
description: Early this month, Mike Keenan returned to Madison Square Garden wearing a Rangers jacket and looking for a new fit. An unemployed hockey coach, Keenan heard cheers in a ceremony honoring 75 seasons of franchise history.

title: Congress and White House End Stalemate on Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  Congressional and administration negotiators made little progress for much of today toward agreement on the final spending and tax bills in the federal budget. The stalemate ensures that Congress, which has already set a post-World War II record for the latest adjournment date in an election year, will remain in session at least one day longer.

title: U.S. Braces for Trouble in Indonesia as Relations Rupture
description: Relations between the United States and Indonesia have deteriorated rapidly after a series of high-profile disputes between the American ambassador here and Indonesian officials and lawmakers, who have accused the United States of meddling.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 20 about Connecticut regulators' approval of the proposed acquisition of Northeast Utilities by Consolidated Edison included an erroneous name, supplied by the regulators, for the company that would result. (The error was repeated in an article on Wednesday.) It would be Consolidated Edison, not New Consolidated Edison.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, DAVID S.
description: ADAMS-David S. Passed away peacefully October 21, aged 90, in Washington, DC. Born in Edinburgh, Scotland, he joined Boosey & Hawkes Ltd., music publishers, in the 1930's, eventually heading the Toronto office, the New York office, and becoming Managing Director of the London head office in 1964 until his retirement in 1974. He was a Fellow of the Royal College of Organists, a Licentiate of the Royal Academy of Music, and a member of the Performing Rights Society, CAPAC and ASCAP. Predeceased by his wife, Doris, he is survived by two daughters, Judith Chalukoff of Virginia and Hilary Zwicky of New York City and two granddaughters, Francesca Dean and Alexandra Zwicky. Donations, if desired, to the PRS. Memorial to be announced at a later date.

title: Offending Muslim Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Fixed-Income Issues Scheduled for Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of 50-day cash management bills on Tuesday.

title: Article 2000103092633792867 -- No Title
description: DUBUQUE, Iowa, Oct. 30  Striking back against a Democratic offensive that questioned whether Gov. George W. Bush was ready to be president, Dick Cheney countered today that it is the Democratic ticket which lacks experience and said that Vice President Al Gore "is not up to the task" of being the nation's commander in chief.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's denunciations of the New York Republican Party for telephoning New Yorkers and telling them that she had received donations from a Muslim group quoted incompletely from the script used in the calls. It said she had accepted contributions from an organization that ''openly brags about its support for a Mideast terrorism group -- the same kind of terrorism that killed our sailors on the U.S.S. Cole.'' The script did not speak of accepting money from an actual terror group.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Media Talk column of Business Day last Monday about efforts by The Miami Herald to put its name on the Broward County convention center misstated the former name of a competitor. The paper, now The South Florida Sun-Sentinel, was until recently The Sun-Sentinel, not The Fort Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, FRANCES M.
description: MEYER-Frances M. Of Forest Hills, NY, on October 28, 2000. Beloved wife of Christian C. Loving mother of Francesca DeLasho and mother-in-law of Robert L. Friends may call on Monday, from 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM, at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, Hicksville Chapel, 47 Jerusalem Ave. (3 blocks north of Old Country Rd.). Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:45 AM, St. Ignatius R.C. Church, Hicksville. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUBY, MILTON
description: KUBY-Milton. Chief of Human Factors, Life Sciences and Space Environment, retired, at Fairchild Hiller Corporation, he was a pioneer in the field of aeronautical human safety engineering. His varied career accomplishments include designing a bauxite processing factory in Jamaica, West Indies, that produced significant economic benefits for the local community. In addition, he designed advanced cockpit technology for U.S. defense aircraft and, at a later time, led the biomedical engineering team that developed the lifesupport system for Apollo astronauts. After a long, courageouslyfought illness, he died on October 26, 2000, at age 81. He will be remembered for his love of family, generosity of spirit, endless intellectual curiosity, and passion for learning. Beloved husband of Selma and brother of Natalie Naishuler; adored father of Stevan (deceased), Stuart, Beth, and Laurel; devoted grandfather of Eric, Daniel, David, Kimberly, Tina, Evan, and Brian; inspiring father-in-law of Charles Levinthal and Paul Sclafani.

title: INSIDE
description: Fresh Start for the N.B.A.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWSON, SANFORD H. (SANDY)
description: DAWSON-Sanford H. (Sandy). On October 28. Husband of Helen. Father of Victoria. Brother of Harriet. Reposing Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave., NYC, on Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 10 AM, Wednesday, Church of the Epiphany.

title: Against Giants, Eagles Always Seem at a Loss
description: When the Giants see the Eagles, they see green and white, which, of course, also happens to be the color of money. Like instant cash, the Eagles have provided the Giants an anchor for their season twice in each of the last four years. It is now eight straight Giants victories in this series and counting, the latest a 24-7 mauling yesterday at Giants Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARSEL, ADAM
description: BARSEL-Adam. We mourn the death of Adam and extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Temple Sinai of Long Island Paula Winnig, Rabbi Dr. Richard Storm, President

title: Equity and Debt Offerings for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Congress and White House End Stalemate on Spending
description: White House and Congressional negotiators, working into the wee hours of the morning, reached a tentative agreement early today on a spending measure of roughly $112 billion to finance the Labor, Health and Human Services and Education Departments.

title: Sports of The Times; A Rookie Gives Groh Reason to Reconsider
description: THIS fall has been good to the Jets.

title: West Side Story, the Sequel
description: The Lakers of Shaq and Kobe, the Trail Blazers of Rasheed and Smitty, the Spurs of Duncan and Robinson. And now, the Seattle SuperSonics and the Utah Jazz, too. Never in the modern pro game has one side of the Continental Divide had so many dominant teams as the Western Conference. That leaves the Eastern Conference essentially wide open as the National Basketball Association season begins tomorrow night. The West is, indeed, best. Portland has retooled to compete with the Lakers, and Tim Duncan is healthy enough to help David Robinson. In the end, the Lakers still have too much heat. The 29 teams in predicted order of finish. MIKE WISE

title: Tall Order for a Tall Player at a Tournament
description: One of the Italian players who won the world team title last month at Maastricht, in the Netherlands, was Norberto Bocchi, who was easy to recognize. At 6 foot 6 he was the tallest player in the tournament.

title: Jeff Green Joins Brother in Record Book
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn. -- Jeff Green has turned the Busch Grand National series into the ultimate brother act.

title: As Subway Doors Close, A Last Glance Backward
description: GAME 5

title: Article 2000103091720564396 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Accounts
description: * Howiwork, Boston, a new online business service, to Frankfurt Balkind Partners, New York, to handle its first account. Spending was estimated at $15 million to $20 million. Howiwork is part of the Internet group unit of CMP Media, part of the Miller Freeman division of United News and Media; it can be found at CMP's Web sites like www. informationweek.com.

title: When the First Stop Is the E.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paterson House Fires Leave 55 Homeless
description: Whipping winds turned a house fire in Paterson, N.J., into a neighborhood conflagration yesterday, destroying three homes, damaging six others and leaving 55 people homeless.

title: Better Judicial Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, MEYER (MIKE)
description: DIAMOND-Meyer (Mike). Of Howard Beach, NY, on October 28, 2000. Beloved husband of Esther, father of Maxene Spindell and Jeffrey Diamond, father-in-law of Michael Spindell, grandfather of Alyson, Leah and David, brother of Leo Diamond. He was much loved and will be sorely missed. Funeral at 12 noon, Monday, October 30, at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, NY.

title: Zagat Chooses Branding Iron
description: Zagat Survey in New York, the purveyor of information about restaurants and night life, has named Branding Iron in Irvington, N.Y., as its first agency of record. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: As Subway Doors Close, A Last Glance Backward
description: GAME 4

title: Now That the Thrill Is Gone, Investors Turn Back to Basics
description: Spencer Nauman has changed his mind on technology, but don't think it was easy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORFOGEN, JAMES
description: MORFOGEN-James. Age 53, of Fort Lee, NJ, formerly of NYC, passed away at his sister's home in Glen Rock, NJ, on Saturday, October 28, 2000. Beloved and cherished son of Christine (nee Christakos) and the late James G. Morfogen. Cherished brother of Elaine and George Morfogen. Loving uncle of Kristine and Alexander John Morfogen. Adored by his aunts, uncles, cousins and friends. James was an assistant manager at Colony Records, Inc, NYC, from 1993 to present. Prior to that he was employed by Capital Cities/ ABC, Inc, as the supervisor at ABC Music Library in NYC from 1986 to 1993. All funeral services private. Interment George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ. For information contact Vander Plaat Colonial Home, Inc, Fair Lawn, NJ.

title: A Loss for Texas Students
description: A few years ago I had a job teaching creative writing at a Houston elementary school. One day my best writer -- a quiet boy in fourth grade who produced astonishingly vivid, imaginative stories -- failed to appear in class. His classroom teacher told me his family, beset with financial problems, had moved yet again, perhaps to another motel room. And she sighed, ''I was counting on him for my TAAS scores.''

title: Hard Times in the Hatchery; After Dot-Com Flameout, 'Incubator' Is a Despised Word
description: Call them instigators. Or catalysts or accelerators. Just please don't call a company that hatches Internet companies an ''incubator'' anymore.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an Arts Abroad article on Oct. 11 about the return of the stadium rock concert to Beijing misstated the type of series that is being sponsored at a popular club there by VH-1's regional music channel. It is an independent music concert series, not a film series.

title: Sun Microsystems Sets Wireless Strategy
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., whose computers power Web sites and corporate networks, said today that it had created a business unit, a $100 million investment fund and software applications for wireless equipment.

title: Improving Bilingual Education
description: Bilingual education as practiced in New York City is a historically troubled program that traps foreign-born students in substandard schooling instead of teaching them English and passing them into the mainstream. The city is required by state law and a longstanding court decree to offer some help to youngsters who do not speak English as they enter the public schools. But a program that was intended to be optional is often compulsory in practice because administrators dragoon children into foreign-language ghettoes as a way of preserving the bilingual program.

title: A Self-Appointed Lawyer for the Nation's Condemned
description: ON Elisabeth Semel's bulletin board is a New Yorker cartoon that shows a man with a thick briefcase walking into an empty prison cell: ''Hi, I'm your court-appointed lawyer,'' he announces. ''Whoa! Don't tell me you've been executed already.''

title: Egan Delivers Blunt Message For Elections
description: Interjecting the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese directly into next week's elections, Archbishop Edward M. Egan yesterday bluntly urged its 2.4 million parishioners to cast votes for candidates in local, state and national races who ''share our commitment to fundamental rights for the unborn.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESSLER, IRA
description: RESSLER-Ira. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire Ressler family on the loss of their beloved Ira. Warmly, Michael, Carol, Brett, and Jed Weisman

title: MediaTalk; It's a Small World: Jennings in Book Deal
description: The ABC News anchor Peter Jennings is moonlighting again as an author. But this time ABC's parent, the Walt Disney Company, is keeping the book at its Hyperion publishing division, to the envy of Mr. Jennings's previous publisher.

title: Venezuelan Leader Finds a Teammate in Castro
description: Fidel Castro has been known to make speeches that last up to eight hours, and Hugo Chavez, the president of Venezuela, can be nearly as garrulous. So there was no telling what would happen when Mr. Chavez invited Mr. Castro, who is making a five-day state visit here, to join him today as the only guest on his weekly radio program, ''Alo Presidente.''

title: Nader's Wrong on Gore
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE SENATE

title: Georgia Unable to End Jinx Against Florida
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 29  A season full of promise for Georgia came to an ugly end at the hands of its most despised rival.

title: 5-State Tour Seeks to Shift Nader Voters To Gore Camp
description: Joined by rock stars and flanked by signs proclaiming ''Remember the Supreme Court,'' a group of advocates of the environment, gay rights and abortion rights today kicked off a five-state tour aimed at people thinking of voting for Ralph Nader. Their message: Don't do it. Vote for Al Gore.

title: Russia, EU Seek Political Solution in Chechnya
description: PARIS -- Russian President Vladimir Putin and European leaders agreed Monday on the urgent need to find a political solution in the breakaway region of Chechnya, but insisted that Russian sovereignty must not be compromised.

title: Still Searching for a Safety
description: Coach Al Groh of the Jets expressed concern about the play of his safeties last week, and today he made a change in his lineup by giving Scott Frost, a former quarterback, his first start at safety after a three-year conversion process.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Philharmonic Relaxes With a Visitor
description: Candidates to head the New York Philharmonic, be they real or imagined, have been passing through town with regularity. Sir Colin Davis's appearance on Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall reminded us of the one who got away. How much warmer and more elegant musical life in either Boston or New York might have been during the last 25 years had he once made decisions that he didn't.

title: My 'Daisy' Ad, And the G.O.P.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: A Drug Law Overhaul
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheney Loosens Up as G.O.P. Confidence Grows
description: Dick Cheney is pumped. How can you tell? During a rally at the Mississippi Valley Fairgrounds here today, he underscored a point in his stump speech by raising his arm in the air. When someone in the crowd shouted encouragement, he smiled and ad-libbed a line, ''I'm going to take you with me.''

title: A State Grant Could Help Save Graham Studio
description: The ailing Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance, which closed its Manhattan school in May for lack of funds, is poised to reopen in temporary quarters as soon as January with a fresh infusion of private contributions and a promise of a $750,000 capital grant from the state senator from its home district.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend. JOE DRAPE

title: When the First Stop Is the E.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: Spanish Supreme Court Judge Among Three Killed in Madrid Car Bombing
description: MADRID, Spain -- A car bomb exploded in a busy residential area during rush hour Monday, killing a Supreme Court judge, his bodyguard and driver in the deadliest attack blamed on the Basque separatist group ETA since it ended a 14-month cease-fire last December.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBERSMAN, SELMA
description: EBERSMAN-Selma. Of New York and Bristol, RI, died October 29 in Baltimore at the age of 90. She was the daughter of the late Edward and Frances Rosenthal of New York. A retired librarian at the Rhode Island School of Design, she is survived by her son, Neil Hertz, her grandchildren, Ellen and Tom Hertz, and her greatgrandchildren, Anouk Werro, Julien Werro and Benjamin Browning. A memorial service will be held in Baltimore on Sunday, November 19.

title: A Showcase Opening For a Flawed Product
description: To open the National Basketball Association season, a doubleheader on TNT tomorrow night has been advertised hard by the cable network: Knicks-Sixers in an Eastern Conference donnybrook followed by Lakers-Blazers in a rematch of the Western Conference finals.

title: Sports of The Times; Toomer's Stature Rewritten on the Wind
description: THE warmth of the Subway Series had vanished. Pro football weather had arrived at Giants Stadium as it always does, on a wind that whips out of a slate-gray sky and flaps the flags atop the upper deck.

title: The Devils Find Goals In Strange Uniforms
description: The Devils defeated the Penguins in Pittsburgh by 9-0 on Saturday night and were in a joking mood. They were reacting to the efforts of Randy McKay and John Madden, who combined to do something that had eluded such fearsome twosomes as Mario Lemieux and Jaromir Jagr, Mike Bossy and Bryan Trottier, and Wayne Gretzky and Mark Messier.

title: U.S. Bid to Execute Mexican Draws Fire
description: Reflecting an increasing intervention by foreign governments in American death penalty cases, Mexico has sent a formal protest to the State Department in an effort to prevent the execution of a Mexican citizen scheduled to be put to death in two weeks.

title: 50 Centuries (Phew!) Of That Blessed Plot
description: When it's over, your mind will be filled with grotesque images: of a man's brains being scooped out of his skull with a sword and smeared across a church floor; of another man being disemboweled while he's still alive; of yet another killed by a hot iron shoved up his rectum. This may sound like a Halloween special conceived by Quentin Tarantino, but it's part of an extraordinary academic exercise called ''A History of Britain,'' which begins tonight on the History Channel.

title: Giants and the Winds Bring Down McNabb
description: As Donovan McNabb made the walk through the tunnel from the locker room to the interview room at Giants Stadium today, well-wishers passed by, offering mumbled greetings and prodding him to keep his head up. But he needed more than kind words.

title: Van Gundy Sets Down Guidelines for Knicks
description: With a season of uncertainty two days away, Coach Jeff Van Gundy gathered his team together this morning for a 30-minute state-of-the-Knicks address. He spoke of the necessity for mental toughness and professionalism, unveiled the team's rotation and let his players know that, despite their lack of size, his expectations were as high as ever.

title: Youths Use Varied Strategies to Feel Their Way to Choices
description: Asked for his views on the election, Bern Moorehead began with a little background: as a child, he spent a lot of time at a shooting range his mother owned, and he heard a lot of right-wing politics.

title: Good Conduct Potentates Spend 'Scholar Dollars'
description: The blond wig sold for $110, the skeleton mask, $155. The top price of the afternoon was $190, for a witch hat with orange locks attached. Even a tacky construction worker's costume was the subject of a silent bidding war, a fifth and sixth grader staring each other down from opposite sides of the cafeteria, before the triumphant child marched up to hand over $100.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Science Times on Tuesday about bird migration misstated the type of crane that humans were leading on a flight from Wisconsin to Florida. As reported in the article, they are sandhill cranes, not sandbill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBIN, MORRIS
description: SOBIN-Morris. Passed away on Friday, October 27, 2000. Of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Roslyn Heights, NY. Loving husband of Doris and the late Ruth. Devoted & cherished father of Louise Sobin Hersh (Bob). Adored grandfather of Philip (Lara) and Joshua Sivin. Beloved brother of Rose Simon and Edward Sobin. Past president of Fresh Meadow Country Club. Former president of Olympic Radio and TV and Pilot Radio-TV. Former COO of Regent Sheffield Inc. Former director of Lear Siegler Inc. and Suburbia Federal Bank. He set an example of hard work, responsibility, sense of humor, zest for life, and fierce love of his family. His legacy will continue for generations to come. Interment Tuesday, October 31, at 3 PM, at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. Memorial contributions, Sass Foundation for Medical Research, 1025 Northern Blvd. Suite 302, Roslyn, N.Y. 11576.

title: Fixing a Vulnerable 'Millionaire'
description: Less than a year after it changed the face of network prime-time competition, the ABC game show, ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' is coming back to earth, moving down in status from phenomenon to solid performer, and its producer is already contemplating a facelift.

title: School Days Are Rule Days In Bronx Charter Classrooms
description: Nearly every hour of every day at Bronx Preparatory Charter School begins with a recitation of rules.

title: Advertisers Select Their New Agencies
description: Several advertisers have made decisions on accounts.

title: Barak Gains Time, But Not a Unity Pact
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel failed to forge an emergency unity government with the right wing. But the party that had pulled out of the government in July said that it would grant the prime minister a temporary ''safety net'' while violence continues. At least three more Palestinians died in new confrontations with Israeli troops.

title: A Visit to North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokyo Journal; The City Isn't Quaking, but Maybe It Should Be
description: Once every few weeks this city is shaken by a tremor so powerful that it becomes Topic A of conversation in the gleaming high-rises that tower above Tokyo and aboard the packed subways that course underground. And then, just as swiftly, conversations shift back to Japan's economic performance, the latest political scandal or, these days, Japan's baseball championship series.

title: Kasparov on Verge of Losing Title After a 14-Move Draw
description: Garry Kasparov extended his hand with a draw offer after only 14 moves of Game 13 of his Brain Games Network World Chess Championship match in London yesterday and Vladimir Kramnik shook it. That made the score Kramnik 7 1/2, Kasparov 5 1/2, and it reduced the champion's chance to retain his title to zilch.

title: Clinton Says Return of Money Was Politics, Not Ethnic Slight
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that she respected Islam and did not intend to offend Muslim Americans when her campaign decided last week to return political contributions from members of a Muslim American organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLIN, DAVID C.
description: MULLIN-David C. Founder, Chairman and CEO of Mullin & Associates/Lincolnshire International, an established premium global consulting company, died October 28, 2000 at the age of 70. David was a respected leader, as well as pioneer in establishing the Outplacement Industry as a valued resource to Fortune 1000 companies, with many of his innovative practices becoming standard for the industry. Mr. Mullin, a catalyst and champion of ethical practices for the industry, previously held progressive leadership positions with other premier international consulting firms as well as the Johnson & Johnson family of companies. A longtime resident of East Norwich, NY, for 35 years, he is survived by his wife Rose Marie of East Norwich; daughter Shawn Rezek of East Worcester, NY; daughter Faine Christie of Hicksville, NY; son Keith of Rye, NY; and son-in-law Robert Romanelli of Oyster Bay, NY. He is pre-deceased by his five children: Donna, Timothy, Mary, David and Kelly. In addition to his three children, his seven grandchildren remember him. Visiting at the Francis P. DeVine Funeral Home, Inc., Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Thursday, 9:30 AM, St. Dominic's R.C. Chapel. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: A Dark Childhood Warmed by Footlights
description: GHOST LIGHT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELDMAN, PHYLLIS SYLVIA (GROSS)
description: ZELDMAN-Phyllis Sylvia (Gross). Age 74, of Mt. Lebanon, PA, on Wednesday, October 25, 2000. Beloved wife of Maurice Zeldman. Loving mother of Jeffrey Zeldman of NYC, and Peter Zeldman of London, England. Sister of George E. Gross of NYC. Aunt of Nina, Rebekah and Anna Gross, all of NYC. The people in her life were her life. For information call Beinhauer Mortuary, 412-531-4000.

title: For Congress From New Jersey
description: Congressional candidates in New Jersey this year are campaigning at the ''fighting center'' of the nation's important issues, as Woodrow Wilson once described the state's political tendencies. In at least two close and bitter races -- in the 7th and 12th Districts -- candidates battle over who best represents New Jersey's generally moderate politics. Here are our endorsements in important races.

title: Article 2000103091175764082 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Poll Finds Little Voter Movement In Race for Senate in New York
description: Despite three televised debates and a barrage of television advertisements and attacks, voter opinions about Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick A. Lazio appear largely static as the candidates enter the final week of their contest, with Mrs. Clinton's prospects now very much dependent on the extent to which her supporters turn out to vote, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Metro Matters; In Campaigns, Spin Cycle Never Ends
description: JUST minutes after the Senate debate on WNBC-TV last Friday, an assortment of political advisers, pollsters and politicians appeared, like puddles after a rain, in the large studio that is ordinarily the home of -- why did this seem so appropriate? -- ''Saturday Night Live.''

title: As Subway Doors Close, A Last Glance Backward
description: GAME 3

title: Japan Makes a Statement Against Saudi Arabia
description: Ateam from the Far East traveled West to the Middle East and yesterday won its second Asian Cup championship.

title: Democrats Remind Gore of the Economy
description: Frustrated and worried that their candidate has failed to capitalize on what they see as his best selling point, prominent Democrats say Vice President Al Gore needs to devote the closing week of the campaign to delivering an urgent pitch about his role in the administration's economic successes.

title: Copyright Office Backs Ban on Code-Breaking Software
description: In a decision giving copyright holders greater control over the way people use books, movies and music that are distributed in digital form, the United States Copyright Office on Friday endorsed a new federal law making it illegal to break the technological safeguards for such works.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, PHYLLISS UTZ
description: MORGAN-Phylliss Utz. Expired on October 27, 2000. A graduate of the Harlem School of Nursing. Mrs. Morgan directed the LPN Nursing Program at the Harlem YMCA. She was a longtime resident of St. Albans and Howard Beach. She will be funeralized Thursday morning, November 2, 2000, at St. Catherine's of Sienna in St. Albans.

title: MediaTalk; News Anchor Going To Reality Show
description: Taking a page from the CBS programming playbook, ABC has hired one of its attractive young news correspondents to be the host of a prime-time, entertainment reality show.

title: Push to Portray an Aura of Strength for Bush
description: As Gov. George W. Bush spent his last full day in Texas before Election Day, his aides today outlined the dimensions and details of an aggressive final push to reach undecided voters and Republican stalwarts through telephone calls, mail and the use of surrogates.

title: Divers Recover Eight Bodies from Sunken Submarine
description: MURMANSK, Russia -- Fighting harsh weather in the Barents Sea, Norwegian and Russian divers recovered eight more bodies from the sunken nuclear submarine Kursk, a navy spokesman said Monday.

title: Compressed Data; Lessons in Spam: A Nordstrom E-Mail Goes Astray
description: Nordstrom is a prestigious retailer that prides itself on customer service. But an e-mail marketing campaign last week for its Web site, Nordstrom.com, illustrates the pitfalls of relaxing standards on protecting customer information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZER, HAROLD
description: SALZER-Harold. Beloved husband of Sally, devoted father of Peggy, Michael and Debi. Adoring grandfather of Jessica & Charlie. A celebration of Harold's life will be held at 5PM Monday, October 30 at Beekman Tower, 3 Mitchell Place (49th St & 1st Avenue). In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Windward School, Windward Ave., White Plains, NY 10605.

title: Unexpected Names Emerge on a Wild Weekend
description: Two days ago, Virginia Tech's Dave Meyer was Michael Vick's fishing buddy and invisible backup, Georgia Tech's George Godsey was better known as the brother of Gary, who started two games early in the season at quarterback for Notre Dame, and ''victory right'' was a desperation play that Northwestern practiced often but had hoped never to use. Oh yeah, and Nebraska was the top-ranked team in the nation.

title: Third Suspect in Air India Bombing Arrested
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia -- Canadian authorities have arrested a third suspect in the 1985 bombing of an Air India jet, the deadliest-ever bombing of an airplane, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIER, CAROLA S.
description: TRIER-Carola S. 87, on Saturday, October 28. Wife of the late Edgar. Aunt of Pat and Paul Weiler. Devoted and generous friend of many. Service Tuesday, October 31, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St. For time: 212-362-6600.

description: To the Editor:

title: Don Brooks, 53, Harmonica Player Suited to Blues and Bee Gees
description: Don Brooks, a harmonica player who recorded widely as a studio musician in New York City, died of leukemia Wednesday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan, said his widow, Anne. He was 53 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Ship Attack Suspects Seemed Out of Place
description: ADEN, Yemen, Oct. 30  Neighbors of the two Arab strangers who came quietly in June to the cinder-block apartment at 9, Jabal al Sakhra, high above Aden's harbor, now say there were quite a few things that made them stand out, even among the disparate group of people who have settled in the cascade of ramshackle homes that tumbles chaotically down the hillside.

title: Toiling in Kindergarten
description: To the Editor:

title: In New Jersey, Voters' Shifting Priorities Set Tone of Senate Contest
description: New Jersey, where three of five voters are unaffiliated with a major party, has long been seen as an island of moderation in the liberal Northeast. But Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for Senate, has built his candidacy on the belief that liberalism is back.

title: MediaTalk; W-h-e-r-re's Johnny? In The New Yorker
description: One great thing about being the host of a late-night TV talk show is that all your jokes can be shared with millions and millions of people. It cannot be very easy to lose that after having it for decades.

title: New Economy; Airborne and grass roots. By popular acclaim, a wireless format with a name only a geek could love is taking hold.
description: AT the recent Agenda 2001 computer conference in Phoenix earlier this month, there was validation and a touch of irony for the conference organizer, Robert Metcalfe, co-inventor of the Ethernet office networking standard.

title: Question of Who's Ahead Also Applies to Surveys
description: Three polls on the New York Senate race conducted last week had widely differing results, from Hillary Rodham Clinton leading Rick A. Lazio by as much as eight percentage points to the first lady trailing Mr. Lazio by two points. When the results of these statewide polls are averaged, Mrs. Clinton leads by four points -- 48 percent to 44 percent.

title: Slowly and Saucily, Internet Animations Nibble at TV's Turf
description: Will ''Zombie College'' be as funny now that Scott, the protagonist, has joined the ranks of the living dead? Harper Langston is just not sure. But he is among 2,000 fans to leave an e-mail address at Icebox.com, which shows this animated series, to ensure that they are notified of the next ''webisode.''

title: Albanian Moderates Claim Kosovo Victory
description: The moderate Kosovo Albanian leader, Ibrahim Rugova, claimed victory for his party today in Kosovo's first postwar elections, saying that unofficial results from the election on Saturday showed that the party had won more than 60 percent of the vote in municipalities across the province.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTEN, GERALD BARRY
description: GERSTEN-Gerald Barry. 82, died October 26, in Lake Worth, FL. Mr. Gersten, an Army lieutenant in World War II, later founded Liberty Industries, a manufacturing company in Brooklyn, NY. He married Rita Achiron and they moved to Great Neck, LI, where they raised their children, Ben, Louise and Kenneth. Mr. Gersten received his Bachelor's degree at CCNY, where he was a marathon runner. He later obtained his Master's degree and was working on his Ph.D. in languages. Fluent in Spanish, he was an instructor at Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City. He later remarried, had two daughters and retired to Florida. His intelligence and motivation inspired many.

title: The Rural Life; Chaste Weather
description: When snow began falling on Sunday, I realized that a line from Keats -- ''until they think warm days will never cease'' -- had been running through my head for weeks. The line is from his ode ''To Autumn,'' one of the loveliest poems in the language, and ''they'' are the bees, whose clammy cells, as Keats calls their comb, have been ''o'erbrimm'd'' by summer. Jonathan Bate, author of a new book called ''The Song of the Earth,'' observes that the late summer of 1819, the season leading up to the completion of Keats's ode on Sept. 19, ''was clear and sunny on thirty-eight out of the forty-seven days from 7 August to 22 September 1819'' and that temperatures were milder in the final week of that period than they had been in three years.

title: Copyright Office Backs Digital Law
description: In a decision giving copyright holders greater control over the way people use books, movies and music that are distributed in digital form, the United States Copyright Office on Friday endorsed a new federal law making it illegal to break the technological safeguards for such works.

title: A computer company again asks a filmmaker for a fresh creative slant.
description: FOR the second time in two years, Gateway, which proclaims it eliminates the middleman by selling computers directly to consumers, has done the same with its advertising, turning to a documentary filmmaker for commercials rather than to its giant Madison Avenue agency.

title: Officer Kills Actor Aiming Fake Weapon
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29  A Los Angeles police officer responding to a noisy Halloween party in the Hollywood Hills shot and killed an actor who was pointing a fake gun, the police said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GASS, RUCHAMA
description: GASS-Ruchama. The National Jewish Outreach Program (NJOP) mourns the untimely passing of Ruchama Gass, beloved daughter of Esther Judy Manischewitz, a special friend and supporter of NJOP, who has played a crucial role in NJOP's efforts to assure a jewish future for American Jewry. Condolences to the entire family. Yehi Zichrah Baruch Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: Valentine Begins Contract Talks
description: The Mets have begun negotiations with Manager Bobby Valentine on a new contract, Valentine's agent, Tony Attanasio, said yesterday.

description: P.& G. Plays Role in Merger Between Minority Suppliers

title: GORE TEAM RENEWS CRITICISM OF BUSH AS INEXPERIENCED
description: Vice President Al Gore portrayed the presidential election today as a chance for people to reject special interests, while his wife and running mate pronounced Gov. George W. Bush too inexperienced to be president.

title: Revisions; Tuning In Seems the Same as Turning Back the Clock
description: I discovered a new expression (new to me, anyway) last week when I heard Internet entrepreneurs describe attracting an audience as ''generating eyeballs.'' This notion had a winning sci-fi ghoulishness. I instantly saw detached orbs whirling through space, reproducing madly as they went.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about comments by President Clinton on the violence between Israelis and Palestinians misstated the month in which peace talks were held at Camp David this summer. It was July, not August.

title: Reversal of Fortune at Jets' Expense
description: The Jets have reached deep into their stash of magic dust this season. They sprinkled it liberally over four fourth-quarter comeback victories and buried the Dolphins with it last Monday night.

title: A New Life Re-examined; After Murder Verdict, Town Questions Doctor
description: If you wanted to start a new life, free of reproach or inquiry, this remote prairie town of 35,500 might be the place. Its open wheat fields, quiet ways and uncritical embrace of strangers drew two such outsiders here in 1996, a doctor couple from New York and California who had both practiced medicine in Las Vegas.

title: Kind of Day Giants Like, And It Shows
description: The gusting wind sent snow flurries from sideline to sideline, and Kerry Collins, awaiting the opening kickoff, stood next to the Giants' bench with his helmet on and a smile peeking through his face mask.

title: Colombia Holds Elections, For the Most Part Peaceably
description: Colombians voted under heavy military security today in municipal and provincial elections that were seen as a test of the government's ability to carry out a crucial democratic exercise in a country racked by conflict.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: WORLD VIEWS/A special report.; Rivals Differ On U.S. Role In the World
description: If elected president, Al Gore says he will use America's military power to halt Bosnia-style massacres, its economic influence to press failing states to adopt democracy, and the carrot of trade accords to encourage adoption of Western-style labor and environmental standards.
