title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONGHIA, CARMELLA
description: DONGHIA-Carmella, mother of the late Angelo Donghia, passed away Friday, October 27, 2000. Born on October 3, 1913 in Tyler, Pennsylvania, Mrs. Donghia is survived by a brother, James Ferraccio and two sisters, Amelia Krotzer and Pompey Sciullo. She moved to NYC in 1968 to assist her son in his design endeavors and remained a mentor to Angelo Donghia throughout his career. Funeral services will take place at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church located at 869 Lexington Avenue on Monday, October 30, 2000 at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers the family has requested that donations be made to Saint Vincents Hospital Comprehensive Breast Center.

title: Article 2000103093257775541 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, DAVID
description: FRIEDMAN-David. Formerly of Mt. Vernon, NY, died after a long illness in Pembroke Pines, FL, on October 24, 2000, a few weeks short of his 70th birthday. He is survived by his loving wife Connie, brother Jay and his wife Maxine. Brother-in-law to Joe and Fran. Uncle to Beth, Stefanie, Mark, Joe Jr. and Peter. Donations in his memory to Vitas Hospice Care, 5420 NW 33rd Ave., Suite 100, Ft. Lauderdale, FL 33309.

title: Hingis Takes Title Over Kournikova
description: Top-ranked Martina Hingis beat Anna Kournikova, her doubles partner, 6-3, 6-1, to capture the women's Kremlin Cup in Moscow.

title: Bricks-and-Clicks World Needs Commercial Space
description: Unlike most retailers, the Kohl's Corporation, the fast-growing department store chain, is not yet selling anything on the Web, though it intends to. The bottleneck is not in bandwidth or server capacity -- the warehouse simply isn't ready yet.

title: Critic's Notebook; Behind Sealed Doors, Opening Up the Past
description: To the surprise of almost everyone, including its organizers, Vienna's Holocaust memorial is finally done. It was unveiled on Wednesday before several hundred people who crowded together for a solemn ceremony that included the president of Austria, the city's mayor, its chief rabbi and its Roman Catholic archbishop. The memorial, a large concrete box, is in the midst of the Judenplatz, a small Baroque square where a synagogue was burned during a medieval pogrom.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Latest Battleground In Latin Drug War: Brazilian Amazon
description: Until recently, this town on the corner of the frontiers of Brazil, Peru and Colombia was one of the most sleepy, remote and overlooked parts of the Amazon. But that was before the fighting upriver by army troops, guerrillas and paramilitary forces on Colombia's side of the 1,021-mile border started to intensify.

title: Microsoft Seeks to Block AOL and Others in Antitrust Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  The Microsoft Corporation asked a federal appeals court today to forbid nine organizations and individuals who support the government antitrust suit against the company, including America Online, to file friend-of-the-court briefs in the case.

title: In America; Warm And Warmer
description: One of these days, probably after some catastrophe in which hundreds of people are killed, we'll start to take global warming seriously.

title: An Early Birthday Party for a 'Guys and Dolls' Guy
description: The producer Cy Feuer comes rambling out of a back room of his Park Avenue apartment with a phony grimace on his face and a resolution in mind. ''I don't want to tell the same old stories all over again,'' he says, sounding every bit the Brooklyn-bred wise guy he is, ''because nobody wants to hear them anymore.''

title: Essay; The Protest Vote
description: The Desperation Index, a reliable election indicator, shows the Gore campaign rocketing up the desperation charts.

title: A Maimed Destroyer Cole Starts for Home
description: With battle ensign flying, crew on deck saluting and cheering and sound system booming songs ranging from ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' to an irreverent hit by the Detroit rapper Kid Rock, the patched-up destroyer Cole limped away from Aden harbor today with a show of unbowed pride as it cleared the moorings where 17 sailors were killed in a suicide bombing attack.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Where the Justices Are Unpredictable
description: The composition of the Supreme Court is a hot issue in the presidential campaign, with both parties warning of evil days if the other side gets to name the next several justices. But it's not so easy to predict the positions of Democratic or Republican court appointees -- and this is especially true of free-speech opinions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMAN, THEODORE O.
description: BERGMAN-Theodore O. On Saturday, October 28, 2000, of Ft. Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Harriet. Devoted husband of Irene. Loving father of David Bergman, Janet Buchholz, Laura Zucker. Stepfather of Daniel, Julia and Max Goldensohn. Also survived by six grandchildren and six step-grandchildren. Brother of Dorothy. Services will be held at Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. Friends and relatives are invited to attend. Call Schwartz Brothers (718) 263-7600 for more information.

title: Critics Say a Focus on Test Scores Is Overshadowing Education in Texas
description: For every administrator, teacher, parent and student in Texas public schools, the Texas Assessment of Academic Skills is the sun around which education orbits. Nothing else is as important as the state's standardized test.

title: PRO BASKETBALL
description: THE HEALTH AND EFFECTIVENESS OF MARCUS CAMBY -- One of the league's best offensive rebounders, Camby can almost single-handedly improve the Knicks in their greatest area of need: offensive rebounding. But only, of course, if he is healthy. Camby, a fifth-year veteran has never played more than 63 games in a season, and it may be wishful thinking to believe he will top that this season, especially because he is already experiencing soreness in his lower back and right knee and will spend most of his time on the court banging against bulkier centers.

title: Apparent E.T.A. Blast Kills Judge in Spain
description: MADRID, Oct. 30  A Spanish Supreme Court justice, his driver and body-guard were killed this morning in Madrid when a car-bomb exploded as the judge's car drove along a quiet residential street during the morning rush-hour.

title: John E. Ultmann, 75, Expert On the Treatment of Cancer
description: Dr. John E. Ultmann, a cancer expert who advanced doctors' understanding of how treatment should vary with the stage of the disease, died Oct. 23 at his home in Hyde Park, Ill. He was 75.

title: Without Ewing, Knicks Change How They Look
description: Gone is the weary, worn 7-footer with the kneepads and the lumbering gait, the brooding face of the Knicks for the past 15 years and, most recently, his former teammates' scapegoat. The success of Patrick Ewing's former team now revolves around three All-Stars on the perimeter, his frail, unpretentious and at times spectacular replacement, and an undersize post player whose battles with bigger men have turned his body into one aching mass of muscle.

title: Edith Ginsberg, an Anchor For Poet Stepson, Dies at 94
description: Edith Ginsberg, the poet Allen Ginsberg's stepmother, who brought a sense of harmony into a family that had been disrupted by mental illness, died on Tuesday in Ridgewood, N.J. She was 94 and lived in Elmwood Park, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COLE, CHARLES JACK
description: COLE-Charles Jack. Physically you've been gone from us for eight years but your incredible spirit, love and devotion are with us every day. We miss you. Your family

title: E-Commerce Report; To make online shopping easier and quicker, many Web sites are redesigning their home pages.
description: BUSINESS-MINDED archaeologists who pick through the rubble of the e-tailing fiasco will have little trouble piecing together what went wrong. With every new rollout of a Web store in 1998 and 1999 came declarations that the shop in question would revolutionize the buying experience by making it so much easier than shopping the traditional way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, NORA
description: FRIEDLANDER-Nora. Beloved friend. Died the morning of October 26, 2000. We will greatly miss her vitality, warmth and musicmaking, but her gentle spirit will always be with us. Rebecca Osborn

title: Anti-Fujimori Soldiers Rebel, Take Five Hostages in Peru
description: LIMA, Peru -- Just when President Alberto Fujimori appeared to be wresting control of Peru's military from his ex-spy chief and stabilizing weeks of political turmoil, a group of 51 soldiers staged a daring revolt -- demanding Fujimori resign and the shadowy spymaster be put behind bars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEGER, TONI G. (RIESENBERG)
description: KRIEGER-Toni G. (Riesenberg). The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to her husband Harry Krieger, and the family, our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Sr. Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd. Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: People
description: * Andie Fox was named managing director at a new Atlanta office of MindShare North America, the media services joint venture of two units of the WPP Group, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and J. Walter Thompson. She had been senior partner and media director at the Thompson Atlanta office.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENBERG, HERBERT
description: GREENBERG-Herbert. October 30, 1989. Love always and forever. Sylvia, Susan, Gwe

title: Rangers Win at Home After Sather Has Say
description: Glen Sather, the Rangers' president and general manager, chose an odd way to send a message to his struggling team. From the media capital of the world, Sather decided to use a Canadian reporter as his conduit, one whose newspaper is printed in Edmonton, Alberta, where Sather used to ply his trade.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of a Web site in the special E-Commerce section on Wednesday, with an article about buying medicine over the Internet, was published in error. The site, for the Franklin Drug Center in Philadelphia, lists prices. Prescriptions must be faxed or mailed to the company, which arranges payment off line. The company does not sell drugs online.

title: FIVE KEYS FOR THE NETS' SUCCESS
description: STAY AFLOAT -- Without forward Keith Van Horn, who is recovering from a broken leg for at least the first month of the season, the Nets have to be extra sharp to make sure they are not eliminated from the playoffs in November. They need to continue to play the stingy defense the new coach Byron Scott has installed, and find their offensive chemistry in a hurry, even if it is makeshift, until Van Horn and the backup shooting guard Lucious Harris return. Considering the Nets do not have a dominating center and will rely heavily on young players, anything near .500 could be enough to prevent them from gasping for air the first month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYE, DAVID LINCOLN
description: TYE-David Lincoln. Of Westport, CT, age 72, on October 28. Husband of Jean F. Tye (nee O'Niell), father of Gerald Tye, stepfather of Wendy Carr Froggatt, grandfather of Alecia and Joel Tye and Alexander Froggatt, brother of A. Raymond Tye and the late Dr. Mauray Tye. Services at Stanetsky Memorial Chapels, 1668 Beacon St., Brookline, MA, Tuesday, October 31, at 10 AM. Shiva at home of Ray Tye Tuesday and Wednesday, October 31 and November 1, and at his late residence November 2 in Westport. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to SUNY Health Science Center, Syracuse, NY, or Cardiology Department, New England Medical Center, 750 Washington St., Boston, MA 02111.

title: Reserves Help Out
description: The rookie Ron Dayne had run the football on six of the last nine plays, lugging the football to the Philadelphia Eagles' 4-yard line as the Giants sought the clinching, fourth-quarter touchdown today in a game they already led by 17 points.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's not 'The Dating Game.' You don't have to fall in love with Al Gore -- I did that.''

title: Magazines Mining Web For Readers
description: Robert W. Pittman, the president of America Online, caused a frisson at the conference here run by the Magazine Publishers of America when he announced that in the last five months, AOL had sold 500,000 subscriptions to Time Inc. magazines.

title: Patents; A few frightful ideas, but some safe ones, too, all in the spirit of Halloween.
description: GHOSTS and goblins, as well as Pokemon creatures and presidential candidates, will traipse the streets tomorrow night -- the culmination of weeks of preparation for Halloween. Hundreds of millions of dollars are spent on those efforts every year, and many of the costumes, decorations, candy and even pumpkins are patented.

title: Bloomberg Radio Station to Go to General News From Finance
description: Bloomberg, the financial information company, will announce that its New York City radio station, WBBR-AM (1130), will shift its format today from business to general news, company officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSHING, HARRY COOKE IV.
description: CUSHING - Harry Cooke IV. Passed away on October 24, 2000 suddenly after a short illness at age 76. Vanderbilt scion, accomplished polo player and world traveler, he will be remembered by all who came in contact with him for his strength of character, penetrating wit, voluminous historical recall and an aristocratic lifestyle long forgotten. He is survived by a son, Harry Cooke Cushing V, a daughter-in-law Laure, and two granddaughters Cathleen and Kyra. There will be a memorial service on Wednesday, November 1, 2000 at 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: Russian and U.S. Crew Ready To Blast Off to Space Station
description: A patient crew of astronauts is ready to blast off to the International Space Station to begin what could be more than 15 years when humans will continually occupy the orbiting outpost.

title: Everybody Loves Somebody Sometime, but Rarely Forever
description: A loves B, who loves C, who loves D, although C once claimed to love B, who eventually decides that A is not so bad after all.

description: Talks between the Philadelphia teachers' union and the school district continued late tonight without a settlement as the city prepared for a shutdown of its public schools on Monday.

title: P.& G. Helps Minority-Run Companies
description: Procter & Gamble is expected to announce today that it helped orchestrate the merger of two minority-owned companies from which it buys supplies and awarded a $100 million contract to them for going through with the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUOCO, ERNEST L.
description: CUOCO-Ernest L. On October 27, 2000. Devoted and beloved husband of Mary P. (nee Scandale). Cherished father of Dr. and Mrs. Louis F. Cuoco and Angela M. Cuoco. Unforgettable and special Papa of Dominique. Funeral Tuesday, 8:30 AM, from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd., Brooklyn, NY. Mass of Christian Burial 9:30 AM at Resurrection R.C. Church. title: Sapp Pushes, and Vikings Plunge From Unbeaten Ranks
description: There are few plays where Tampa Bay defensive lineman Warren Sapp does not make his presence known. His large frame, square and unwieldy, can overwhelm blockers, and his quickness is surprising.

title: A Platoon-Size Mutiny in Peru, Hoping to Force Fujimori Out
description: An army lieutenant colonel in command of 60 soldiers declared a mutiny today in an effort to press President Alberto K. Fujimori to resign. The dissident group briefly took control of a mining center, took a general hostage and then traveled in a truck and bus toward the remote highlands of Puno province.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAR, MURRAY SIDNEY
description: HAAR-Murray Sidney. Age 83, of Jersey City, NJ, died October 28. Beloved husband of Shirley J. Haar. Devoted father of Lynn and Michael Reichgott, Matthew and Betsie Haar, Diane Haar and Jack Lyons. Doting grandfather of nine. Brother of Frances Yeston. He was Vice President of Temple Beth-El in Jersey City, where contributions may be sent.

title: A Shareholder Sues Coca-Cola, Saying It Misled Investors
description: The Coca-Cola Company has been sued by a shareholder who says the company misled investors and artificially inflated its stock price, according to a statement released by the plaintiff's law firm, Chitwood & Harley.

description: Accusations of racism have divided a law school faculty here in recent weeks, opening an unusually public debate about the role of diversity in legal education here and across the country.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES

title: Familiar Faces in New Places And an Emptiness in the East
description: Tim Duncan has always been an iconoclast, spurning convention and perception. He pierces his tongue like a 20-something East Village hipster yet shoots bank shots as if he were playing for John Wooden, circa 1959. He has an old-school mind, sometimes nurturing, sometimes clashing with his Generation X peers.

title: Article 2000103091768608654 -- No Title
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29  Frustrated and worried that their candidate has failed to capitalize on what they see as his best selling point, prominent Democrats say Vice President Al Gore needs to devote the closing week of the campaign to delivering an urgent pitch about his role in the administration's economic successes.

title: Article 2000103090035196903 -- No Title
description: October 30, 2000

title: Nets' Attitude Still Positive Despite Rash of Injuries
description: The day before training camp began, the Nets were all in their uniforms, mugging for the cameras.

title: Where the Justices Are Unpredictable
description: LOS ANGELES -- The composition of the Supreme Court is a hot issue in the presidential campaign, with both parties warning of evil days if the other side gets to name the next several justices. But it's not so easy to predict the positions of Democratic or Republican court appointees  and this is especially true of free-speech opinions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REEVES, ROBERT
description: REEVES-Robert died October 20, 2000. He was a friend to many and a man of integrity, compassion, decent instinct, and keen perception. He was an avowed loner, but enjoyed the luxury of solitude. Politically, he was an independent; socially, a civil libertarian but for law and order, hopefully always with justice. He was a secular humanist and he decried hypocrisy. He was forever grateful to his esteemed parents, Minna and Benjamin Reeves, for their lifelong devotion to him, as well as for their generosity to him and to others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONKLIN, AUBREY ROBERT
description: CONKLIN-Aubrey Robert. A longtime Scarsdale, East Hampton and Vero Beach, FL, resident, died of a sudden heart attack early Saturday, October 28, while in New York City. He was 60 years old. Mr Conklin was born June 13, 1940, and raised in Goshen, NY. He was the son of Frances and Aubrey V. Conklin. He earned a Business degree from Pace University. In 1970, he co-founded Aubrey Thomas Personnel with offices in the tri-state area. Under Mr. Conklin's leadership, Aubrey Thomas, Inc., was later sold to the British firm Hestair. Mr. Conklin co-founded Accountec, Inc., in 1999, of which he was CEO. Aubrey served on the boards of Iona Preparatory School in New Rochelle, Bayberry Close in East Hampton and the John's Island Club in Vero Beach. As an active fund raiser, he was responsible for saving the McKee Botanical Gardens, a National Trust in Vero Beach. He was also a member of Our Lady of Fatima Church, the Scarsdale Golf Club and Windsor Club in Vero Beach. He is survived by his three sons, Thomas, Gregory and Paul; his daughters-in-law, Christine and Jennifer; a new grandson, Aubrey James; his fiancee, Linda Musilli and her son and daughter-in-law; and a sister, Patricia Eckerson of Goshen, NY. His wife of 30 years, Joan F. Conklin, died in January 1992. For information, contact Bennett Funeral Home in Scarsdale. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his loving memory may be made to the McKee Botanical Gardens in Vero Beach, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, ADOLPH
description: GROSSMAN-Adolph. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of its beloved member, Paulette Papilsky. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Family Doctors In Netherlands Stage a Protest
description: Politicians heading for the Dutch Parliament the other day came across a novel sight: a large gathering of family doctors setting off on a protest march.

title: Chicago News Experiment Is Calling It Quits
description: When it made its debut in February, the new late-evening newscast on Chicago's CBS station, WBBM-TV, was met with words that are rarely, if ever, applied to local news. It was called bold, serious, substantial.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a typographical error, a letter yesterday about the ''Daisy'' political advertisements misspelled the writer's surname. He is Tony Schwartz, not Schwarz.

title: In His Own Words
description: AL GORE

title: Dollar Makes the Good Life A Tourist Bargain in Europe
description: Like other European capitals, Rome is enjoying a record year for foreign tourism, with 24 percent more American visitors this year than last. Some may be religious pilgrims coming for the Jubilee, a Holy Year of the Roman Catholic Church. But most are not here to do penance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMERS, MOLLIE
description: SOMERS-Mollie. On October 29, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Judy and Michael. Cherished grandmother of Julie, David & Sabrina. Sister of Irving, Rose, Morris, Leah & Charlie Spector. Services Today, 11 A.M., from Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TENNECO AUTOMOTIVE INC., -- Lake Forest, Ill., the largest maker of exhaust systems in the world, said it had agreed to work with the Futaba Industrial Co. of Japan, to produce mufflers and related parts for automakers in Japan.

title: 6 Dead After Italian Military Helicopter Crashes
description: LEGHORN, Italy -- An Italian military police helicopter crashed off a Tuscan island overnight, killing at least six officers. The search was resuming Tuesday morning for the other two people aboard.

title: Verizon's Profit Is Nearly Flat After an Increase in Spending
description: Verizon Communications said yesterday that its third-quarter profit was almost unchanged as it spent more money on new services like long distance and high-speed Internet access.

title: It May Be Small, but Reykjavik Rocks Big Time
description: Backstage at a concert at the Laugardalsholl gymnasium here, Arni Matthiasson fretted about a battle of the bands he planned to judge later in the year in which 50 or so Icelandic groups would compete to win free studio time. ''I'm waiting to see if every band is going to show up playing their guitars with violin bows and making really long songs,'' said Mr. Matthiasson, a music journalist at the daily newspaper Morgunbladid. In his 15 years of covering music, he says, he has never seen the local rock scene take such a turn to the avant-garde as it has recently.

title: Mets Fans Lost in the Heart of Darkness
description: The canyons of finance were thronged with gloating Yankee fans. Their wretched confetti drifted through the air. Their hateful toilet paper was everywhere -- in the trees, on the asphalt, wrapped around their heads. It was their day, all day. Their beer cans were pressed to smug and smiling lips.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of All Saints' Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: An Even Closer Encounter With Eros
description: The tiny asteroid Eros was photographed from a distance of only 3.7 miles last week by the NEAR Shoemaker spacecraft, which arrived at the asteroid for a yearlong study last February. Eros, the largest of the near-Earth asteroids, is the smallest body ever orbited by a spacecraft. The pictures, showing rocks as small as a bathtub, reveal a primitive body, its chemistry apparently unchanged since the birth of the solar system, but whose surface has been battered and crumbled to deep dust by billions of years of bombardment.

title: The Desperate Risk Death in a Desert
description: Wire fences are all that mark the border here between the United States and Mexico. Still, Juan Flores, a 31-year-old Mexican farmer tired of living on $5 a day, said that sneaking north would be anything but easy.

title: A Report Card on Attack Politics
description: The final week of any hard-fought campaign brings out the best and worst in candidates and their campaign strategists and advertising experts. The presidential contenders are in full cry and have gotten down to the basics of their pitches to the voters, with Vice President Al Gore portraying Gov. George W. Bush as lacking experience and Mr. Bush asserting that Mr. Gore lacks integrity. Much is being made of their negative tone and the ever tougher messages delivered by telephone. But our view is that while there have been some unfortunate excesses, there is also nothing inherently wrong with sharp exchanges and rhetorical attacks about character and stands on issues in a campaign. Indeed they are a vital part of the process and a standard feature of the last week of most campaigns.

title: In the Lab: A Glimmer of Hope in Treating West Nile
description: Ribavirin, an antiviral agent used to treat hepatitis C, was effective against West Nile virus in laboratory experiments, an article in the October issue of The Journal of Infectious Diseases reported.

title: Other Congregants Gather
description: As thousands of people poured into Lower Manhattan for the parade, a smaller group weaved past the fans and barricades to enter the Shrine of Elizabeth Ann Seton for the 12:15 Mass.

description: To the Editor:

description: For some years drinkers of Smirnoff vodka have been seeing double, depending on which side of the Atlantic Ocean they are standing on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARO, ESTHER
description: FARO-Esther. Of West New York, N.J. Beloved wife of Michael, devoted mother of Melinda Presnal, loving grandmother of Samantha and Matthew. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, N.J. Wednedsay, 9:45 AM. Visitation Tuesday, 7-9PM. 1-800-378-1892.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEABODY, JOSEPH HAVEN
description: PEABODY-Joseph Haven. Died peacefully and unexpectedly at his home in Naples, Florida on Saturday October 28, 2000. Born March 31, 1921, son of the late George and Ruth Peabody of fairfield, Conn. Survived by his wife Lois, daughters Cornelia (Anthony Sroka) and Melissa, beloved grandfather to Kyley and Christopher Sroka. Joe served with the Americna Field Service in North Africa and later with the Marine Corps. He was educated at St. Paul's School in New Hamphire, Trinity College in Hartford, CT, and the University of Virginia. For most of his work life, he was employed by Texaco and Petrofina Canada, retiring to Naples, Florida in 1979. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. There will be a memorial service at Saint John's Episcopal Church, 500 Park Shore Drive, Naples, on Thursday November 2nd at 4 PM. with burial in the family plot in Southhampton, Long Island at a later date. ''Weeping may endure for a night, but joy cometh in the morning'' Psalm 30:5

title: Pepsico Buys a 90% Stake in South Beach Beverage
description: At the end of September, as the Coca-Cola Company wavered over purchasing a stake in the South Beach Beverage Company, the small but fast-growing manufacturer that makes SoBe juice and tea drinks, Wall Street analysts started getting a bit impatient with the cola giant's prolonged indecision.

title: Ship Attack Suspects Seemed Out of Place
description: Neighbors of the two Arab strangers who came quietly in June to the cinder-block apartment at 9, Jabal al Sakhra, high above Aden's harbor, now say there were quite a few things that made them stand out, even among the disparate group of people who have settled in the cascade of ramshackle homes that tumbles chaotically down the hillside.

description: More than a year after its owners put the Carlyle Hotel up for sale, a potential deal to buy the high-end Manhattan property has stalled, and negotiations with dozens of would-be suitors have yet to find a buyer.

description: O'SULLIVAN-Rev. John J. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the retired pastor of St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Brooklyn, on October 29. Reposing at Frederick J. Chapey & Son Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Highway, West Islip, NY, Tuesday, October 31, from 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM. Mass of All Saints with Funeral Commendation of the Dead on Wednesday, November 1, at 11:00 AM at St. Joseph's Church, 39 N. Carll Ave., Babylon, New York. All priests are invited to concelebrate. Loving and devoted husband of Anne for 58 years; beloved father of Paulette and Samuel Papilsky, Steve and Adrienne Grossman; cherished grandfather of Gary, Elissa, Nicole, Michael, Kenny, and Lauren; dear brother-in-law of Pauline Frisch. Shiva will be observed at the Papilsky home through Friday.

title: Blue Chips Stage Strong Rally While the Nasdaq Slides
description: The Dow Jones industrial average registered its biggest one-day gain in six months yesterday, as investors plowed money into blue-chip issues and sold highly priced technology shares.

title: MICROVISION UNIT TO HANDLE NEW SWITCHES
description: Microvision, a developer of display and scanning devices, has transferred its effort to develop organic optical switches and light processing materials to a new subsidiary named Lumera. Microvision, based in Bothell, Wash., said Lumera will shortly complete a $25 million to $30 million private round of fund-raising. Lumera's technology, based on research at the University of Washington first made public in April, relies on light-sensitive organic molecules embedded in plastic instead of metallic crystals to convert light into electrical signals. The novel materials reportedly combine extremely high switching speeds with low power requirements.

title: ABITIBI EARNINGS UP
description: Cost-cutting and higher prices for pulp and paper more than doubled third-quarter earnings at Abitibi-Consolidated, the world's biggest newsprint maker. Profit from operations was 118 million Canadian dollars ($77 million), or 27 cents a share, compared with net income of 48 million Canadian dollars ($31.3 million), or 19 cents, in the period a year earlier. Sales climbed 15 percent to 1.74 billion dollars from 1.51 billion dollars. Abitibi is integrating the operations of a smaller Quebec rival Donohue Inc., which it bought for 7.1 billion Canadian dollars ($4.6 billion) in February. Abitibi said it now expects to save 250 million dollars a year as a result of the acquisition -- ''much greater than anyone anticipated,'' said Sam Magid, an analyst with Salman Partners in Vancouver. Almost two-thirds of the savings achieved so far, have come from manufacturing, Abibiti said.

description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman is in excellent health and has no medical condition that would interfere with his serving as vice president, he and his two doctors said.

description: CLARKE-Doris White, on Sat. Oct. 28, 2000 in Greenwich, CT. Wife of the late Lewis A. Clarke, mother of Pete Clarke of Hingham, MA, Vicky Linville of Rowayton, CT & Debbie Moderow of Anchorage, AK, grandmother of six, Outstanding Woman Flyfisher, dedicated gardener. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the Atlantic Salmon Federation, Box 429 St. Andrews, New Brunswick, Canada EOG2XO, or The Alaska Conservation Foundation, 441 W. Fifth Avenue, Anchorage, AK. 99501.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, SILVIA ALBERT
description: FUCHS-Silvia Albert. Age 95, Passed away October 28, 2000. Daughter of the late Gussie and Isaac Albert. Loving wife of the late Dr. Theodore Fuchs. Mother of Dorothy (Henry) Fuchs Fox, grandmother of Jane Fox and Nancy (Dr. Tony) Webber, great grandmother of Teddie and Paige Yohay, Tracy, Jamie and Andy Webber, sister of Harriet Albert Bookheim and the late Fay Albert Greenbaum, Jack, Sidney and Charles Albert. A loved and spirited family elder, Mrs. Fuchs was the President of Camp Lou Emma and an Officer of the Queens College Speech and Hearing Center. Contributions to Camp Lou Emma, 214-45 42 Ave, Bayside, NY11361. Funeral services private, ''Gutterman's'', Rockville Centre.

title: Taiwan Jet Crash Leaves Dozens Unaccounted For
description: ALos Angeles-bound Singapore Airlines 747 jet with 179 people aboard reportedly struck an object on the runway while taking off in Taiwan during a storm Tuesday night and crashed in flames on the tarmac. More than 60 people were reported dead, at least 68 hospitalized, and the remainder unaccounted for hours after the incident.

title: USA Today Widens Its Lead In Daily Circulation Figures
description: USA Today continued to widen its circulation lead among daily newspapers in the last six months, reaching 1,777,500, about 1.1 percent above its level in the fall of 1999 and 15,000 more than its longtime circulation rival, The Wall Street Journal, according to figures reported yesterday by the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

title: Giants Have What It Takes to Be First
description: Jim Fassel knows his Giants are not the only 6-2 football team in town. He also knows his Giants have ascended to this midseason perch quietly, while the 6-2 Jets have been the high-wire attraction, forever a step from disaster or distinction.

description: MEYN-Donald H. Devoted husband of Catherine (nee Smith). Beloved father of Christopher. Funeral Thursday, 9:15 AM, from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd., Brooklyn, NY. Mass Our Lady Help of Christians RC Church, 10:15 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting hours Tuesday 7-10:00 PM, Wednesday 2-5:00 and 7-10:00 PM.

description: New Jersey's younger residents are running out of unregulated ways to ride.

title: Major Medical Mystery: Why People Avoid Doctors
description: Janet Grillo eats organic food, does not smoke or drink and keeps abreast of the latest health news. Yet Ms. Grillo, a 41-year-old independent film producer in Los Angeles, cannot remember the last time she had a complete physical exam, probably when her mother took her to a pediatrician.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESSLER, IRA RICHARD
description: RESSLER-Ira Richard. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of NY mourn the passing of Ira Richard Ressler, beloved father and father-in-law of Debra and Leon David Black. Debra and Leon are admired and respected within the UJA-Federation family for their extraordinary leadership, commitment, and philanthropy. To Debra and Leon, and to the entire family, we extend our sincerest condolences. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: BELL & HOWELL WILL SELL IMAGING UNIT TO EASTMAN KODAK
description: The Bell & Howell Company of Skokie, Ill., said it had agreed to sell its imaging unit to the Eastman Kodak Company for around $150 million in cash, which Bell & Howell plans to use to pay down debt. The unit makes high-volume document scanners and related products. Bell & Howell's other businesses include mailing and data storage products and an electronic and microfilm database of periodicals and other information. The deal is expected to close by year-end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELDER, ROBERT J.
description: ELDER-Robert J. Passed away peacefully on October 29, 2000 at the Long Island State Veterans Home in Stony Brook, N.Y. Husband of the late Billee D. Elder, father of Mark J. Elder, father-inlaw of Stephanie C. Brand, brother of Elizabeth Nickell of Muskegon, Mich and the late Irvin Elder of Wauwetosa, Wi. Also survived by many nephews, nieces and their progeny. Born in Cement City, Mich on April 27, 1906, he received a B.S. from the University of Chicago. He moved to New York in the 1930's and served honorably in World War II in the Normandy Campaign. He was married in 1940 and widowed in 1966. All his life he worked in the financial and insurance industries. At his request, there were no services. The family will receive visitors at their home at 521 Long Beach Road, Nissequogue, N.Y. on Thursday November 2 and Friday, November 3. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to Victims Information Bureau of Suffolk.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  The Supreme Court's great ongoing debate over the balance of power between state and federal government came to rest today in an unlikely place: the site of an abandoned strip mine in northeastern Illinois.

title: Italian Tanker Carrying Chemicals Sinks Off Coast of France
description: RENNES, France, Oct. 31 -- An Italian tanker carrying 6,000 tonnes of toxic chemicals sank in the Channel on Tuesday as it was being towed to France, maritime authorities said. The Ievoli Sun, whose crew had been helicoptered to safety on Monday, sank some 60 km (40 miles) west of the French port of Cherbourg, a spokesman for the Cherbourg maritime command said. The stricken tanker was carrying 6,000 tonnes of chemicals, including 4,000 tonnes of styrene, a hydrocarbon used for making synthetic plastics. It reported a hole in its double hull in heavy weather on Monday and radioed for help. The shipwreck happened 10 months after the tanker Erika sank off western France, spilling thousands of tonnes of heavy fuel onto the coast and causing an environmental disaster.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Saturday with an article about elections for state legislatures misstated the party breakdown of the New York State Senate. It includes 36 Republicans, not 35, and 25 Democrats, not 26.

title: ECUADOR PRICES MODERATE AFTER FREEZE
description: Ecuador's inflation accelerated 2.7 percent in October after the end of a five-month price-fixing agreement between the government and industry heads on 123 consumer items. Consumer prices rose 2.7 percent compared with 3.7 percent in September, the National Statistics Institute said. Inflation accelerated to 82.5 percent in the first 10 months and 104.9 percent in the last 12 months, the institute said. Ecuador's economy shrank by 7.3 percent last year after a pounding by the El Nino weather pattern, the near collapse of its banking system and the demise of the sucre currency, which was abandoned this year in favor of the United States dollar.

title: Divas Struck By Illness? Galloping to The Rescue
description: Everybody at the Metropolitan Opera involved with the annual gala pension fund benefit concert on late Sunday afternoon must have been terribly glad to have an extra hour to rehearse that day, thanks to daylight saving time. The program, with James Levine conducting the Met Orchestra, was to have featured the mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli in her only appearance with the company this season, along with the bass-baritone Bryn Terfel.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURK, DOROTHY, (NEE ZIFF)
description: TURK-Dorothy, (nee Ziff). of New York City and Putnam Valley, died on Oct. 29, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Everett. Devoted mother of Melissa and her husband Lee Rosenwasser. Adoring grandmother of Kate and Eliza. Funeral srvices Wednesday, November 1, 2000 at 11:30 am at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave. (corner of East 10 Street), NYC.

title: Radio Hosts Say Bush and Gore Pale Next to Clinton as a Talk Show Topic
description: As the candidate locally dubbed Dubya flew off from home base here today on his final sprint for the presidency, Mark and Ed, the talk-show team on KLBJ-AM's dawn patrol were already sensing fresh material in the air.

title: Read Gore's Lips: Many New Kisses
description: The Kiss is back.

title: Cheney Strikes Back, Calling Gore-Lieberman Team Unqualified
description: Dick Cheney struck back today at Democrats who questioned whether his running mate, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, was ready to be president, saying it is the Democratic ticket that lacked experience and asserting that Vice President Al Gore was ''not up to the task'' of being the nation's commander in chief.

title: Mets and Valentine Near Deal on New Contract
description: Bobby Valentine was hurt last winter when the Mets refused to discuss a new contract after he had managed the team to the playoffs. Now, after Valentine led the Mets to the World Series, the wait is about to pay off for him.

title: Early Pharaohs' Ghostly Fleet; Archaeologists Excavate Boats That Carried Kings to the Afterlife
description: Archaeologists have excavated the hull of a boat fit for an ancient Egyptian king's eternal journey in the afterlife.

title: CHAIRMAN WITHDRAWS OFFER TO ACQUIRE USED-CAR CHAIN
description: The Ugly Duckling Corporation said late on Friday that its chairman and largest shareholder, Ernest C. Garcia II, had withdrawn his offer to purchase the rest of the company for $8.50 a share. No reason was cited in the announcement, although the company, which owns a chain of used-car dealerships, never appeared interested in the offer. Mr. Garcia had offered $2.50 in cash and $6 in subordinated indebtedness of the acquiring company for each share of Ugly Duckling, a 50 percent premium on the stock's closing price last Friday. Mr. Garcia beneficially owns 36.5 percent, or 4.52 million, of the shares.

title: Rising Woes Cast Doubt on Globalstar Survival
description: The odds against Globalstar avoiding the path to bankruptcy court taken last year by two other companies that sought to provide satellite phone service -- Iridium L.L.C. and ICO Global Communications -- got a little steeper yesterday.

title: From Intimate To Showstopper
description: New York Chamber Symphony

title: Article 2000103190840351768 -- No Title
description: FOND DU LAC, Wis., Oct. 30  Power to the people was Al Gore's cry today as he trundled across the fading emerald farmland of Wisconsin in his ongoing struggle to blunt the appeal of Ralph Nader and keep traditionally Democratic states in his column.

title: SOME CONCORDES WILL FLY, BUT WHEN?
description: British Airways wants to resume service with its fleet of Concorde supersonic jets, but the airline and the Civil Aviation Authority of Britain said they could not set a date until investigators determine why an Air France Concorde crashed outside Paris on July 25. Aircraft manufacturers have put forward proposals to reinforce the fuel tank and undercarriage of Concorde planes, but ''we don't know exactly what we are trying to stop happening again,'' said Jonathan Nicholson, a spokesman for the aviation agency, adding, ''until we get information from the French investigators, the Concordes won't be going anywhere.'' The Sunday Telegraph, citing an unnamed British Airways official, said the airline was confident the plane could fly as early as March or April. But British aviation officials said French crash investigators were not moving fast enough to make that possible. A British Airways spokeswoman, Louise Hatch, said the airline was ''determined to resume services safely,'' though a date has not been set. Air France has said it does not expect service to resume before May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLIN, NATHAN
description: CARLIN-Nathan. On October 29. Beloved husband of the late Kitty. Devoted father of Fred Carlin and Abby and Howard Rosenblum. Cherished grandfather of Marni and Julia. Brother of Frank. He was a proud graduate of St. John's University (BBA 1935), a CPA and a World War II Army veteran. Service Wednesday 10:00 AM, Parkside, 2576 Flatbush Avenue (near Avenue V), Brooklyn, New York.

title: Few in No. 2 Spot Have Been As Involved in Policy as Gore
description: A case can be made that Al Gore has been the most active and influential vice president in American history.

title: Guilty Verdict Is Overturned In Fatal Blaze
description: A judge yesterday set aside the 1996 conviction of a homeless parolee who was found guilty of arson and murder in an apparently accidental fire that killed a firefighter, in a highly emotional case that rallied both the Fire Department and critics of the state's parole system.

title: Front Row
description: Steichen on Steichen

title: Vick's News Is Hopeful, but Passer Is Cautious
description: The Virginia Tech trainer is saying that Michael Vick, the country's most versatile quarterback, may be able to play against Miami on Saturday despite a sprained right ankle.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO RISES. The euro continued to rise on expectations that United States economic growth will slow to be more in line with that of the euro zone. In New York, the euro settled at 84.14 cents, up from 84.03 cents on Friday.

title: Car Bomb Kills 3 in Madrid, Including Judge
description: A Supreme Court justice, his driver and bodyguard were killed here this morning when a car bomb exploded as the judge's automobile drove along a residential street in the rush hour.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES SPENDING MEASURE, CHALLENGING G.O.P.
description: President Clinton late tonight vetoed an $18.1 billion spending bill that finances the operations of the Treasury Department, the White House and Congress, setting up a confrontation that could very well lead to lawmakers' having to return after the election to complete work on a federal budget.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a decline in television ratings for sports events misstated the figure and the change for this year's National Basketball Association finals on NBC. The rating was 11.6, not 11.7; it was a 2.7 percent increase from last year's, not an 18 percent drop.

title: In His Own Words
description: GEORGE W. BUSH

title: Sports of The Times; Waiting For the Next Shoe to Drop
description: THERE is an unmistakable air of incompleteness as the Knicks begin their season, and we are not talking about Luc Longley's being out or Patrick Ewing's moving on. More than anything, this team is a work in progress, if not regress.

title: U.S. Presses for Access in Cole Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  The State Department sought today to subtly increase the pressure on Yemen for fuller cooperation in the investigation into the bombing of the American destroyer Cole.

title: Women's League Allocates Foreigners
description: A busy week for the Women's United Soccer Association began yesterday when the league, which is scheduled to begin play in April, doled out 16 international players to its eight charter franchises.

title: Details of Settlement by 2 Big Auction Houses
description: A $512 million formal settlement of the class-action lawsuit against Sotheby's and Christie's lays out for the first time how the proceeds are to be divided among the more than 100,000 customers who said they were cheated by price-fixing and other collusion by the auction houses, according to Sotheby's court papers.

title: It Must Have Been The Gypsy in Him
description: Minnesota Orchestra

title: Marriage Issue Splits Jews, Poll Finds
description: Most American Jews accept marriages between Jews and non-Jews, a national survey by a major Jewish organization has found.

title: These dot-coms may know about e-commerce, but what they don't know about marketing . . .
description: THEY can be seen everywhere, filling the pages of newspapers and magazines. Some are striking. But most -- overloaded with oh-so-clever copy, or replete with meaningless references -- are somewhat less than compelling. They are print ads for Internet businesses and, for the most part, they are not very good.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SYMPTOMS; A Lower Pressure and a Cleaner Aorta
description: Even a modest increase in systolic blood pressure can lead to significantly higher levels of the kind of deposits on aorta walls that can cause strokes, according to a new Mayo Clinic study.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWSON, SANFORD H. (SANDY)
description: DAWSON-Sanford H. (Sandy). On October 28. Husband of Helen. Father of Victoria. Brother of Harriet. Reposing Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave., NYC, on Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, 10 AM, Wednesday, Church of the Epiphany.

title: Metro Business Briefing; FURNITURE FACTORY TO GROW
description: An upstate New York furniture maker whose armoires, nightstands, desks and other pieces are sold in major stores and used in top-ranking hotels, plans to invest nearly $2 million to buy and enlarge its factory in Salamanca, in western New York. The manufacturer, Philadelphia Furniture Manufacturing Company, has been leasing its four-story, 150,000-square-foot plant since it was established in 1997 in a building previously used by the Fancher Furniture Company, from which Philadelphia will buy the site, Ron Gilbert, Philadelphia's controller, said yesterday. He said his company planned to add 45 workers to its force of 147; state officials said this made the company eligible for a $75,000 state grant. Philadelphia's pieces are sold in retail furniture outlets like Ethan Allen and used in hotels like the Plaza in Manhattan. Joseph P. Fried

title: Sports of The Times; Boredom Is Absent; Students Are Present
description: NEITHER snow (blizzards of confetti), nor heat (a sanitation truck caught fire), nor chill (mid-40's with a stinging wind), nor inconveniences (a paucity of portable toilets), nor school (thousands of truants roamed lower Broadway after the mayor virtually sanctioned the unlocking of classrooms) nor yet another victory parade for the New York Yankees could stay these throngs of fans from the sweet contemplation of their appointed heroes.

title: A Plea to the Vatican: Open the Holocaust Files
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Is Divided Over Measure to Tighten Security on Government Information
description: A bill that would greatly tighten the lid of secrecy on government information has been sent to President Clinton, and administration officials said today that there was sharp division over whether he should sign or veto it.

title: Foreign Affairs; Ritual Sacrifice
description: Here's a day in the life of Israel and Palestine: I arrive in Jerusalem from Hong Kong at 5 a.m. The taxi drops me at the door of the King David Hotel. I walk in. The lobby is completely dark and empty. Not a soul, not a bellhop, is stirring, not even a mouse. ''Hello,'' I shout into the dark, wondering if my travel agent has made a mistake and the hotel has been closed. ''Is anybody home? Hello!'' Finally a desk clerk emerges from a dark corner, where he has been sleeping on a couch. The hotel has laid off most of its employees, because tourism is dead. ''Am I the only one staying here?'' I ask. The clerk just chuckles.

description: Even a modest increase in systolic blood pressure can lead to significantly higher levels of the kind of deposits on aorta walls that can cause strokes, according to a new Mayo Clinic study.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENN, FANNIE
description: GENN-Fannie. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the passing of Fannie Genn, beloved mother of Emanuel Genn, our Associate Dean for Business Affairs and a friend and colleague for more than 25 years. We extend our deepest and most heartfelt sympathy to Manny and to the entire Genn family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

title: North Korea Is All Smiles, And Bewildered by It All
description: It is impossible for any outsider to know exactly why North Korea has changed its tack so dramatically in recent months, inviting old enemies from South Korea and the United States to the capital, Pyongyang, and toasting them lavishly.

description: It is late in the evening. I am standing on the observation platform of the warm up pool at the Olympic Natatorium in Sydney. I am with eight other people, family members of Gary Hall Jr.

title: For Some, a Day Off Is the Mayor's Call, Not the Chancellor's
description: In the annual test of wills between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the schools chancellor over whether to skip school for the Yankee parade, it appears the mayor has won once again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPCHIK, RABBI ABRAHAM
description: KUPCHIK-Rabbi Abraham. The Histadruth Ivrith of America mourns the death of its past Executive Vice President, Rabbi Abraham Kupchik. His lifelong commitment to the advancement of Hebrew language and culture, and the strengthening of Jewish education as the lifeblood of a vibrant American Jewish community, inspired all those he served. We extend our deepest sympathy to his bereaved wife and children. Miriam Ostow, President

title: Sprewell & Co., for Better or Worse, Get the Ball Rolling
description: In today's National Basketball Association, where individualism rules, almost every club is associated with one player. The Philadelphia 76ers, who visit the Knicks at Madison Square Garden for Tuesday's season opener, belong to Allen Iverson. The Los Angeles Lakers, despite Kobe Bryant's brilliance, are led by Shaquille O'Neal. And for the last 15 years that were spent in heart-wrenching pursuit of a championship, the face of the Knicks has been Patrick Ewing.

title: Fancy Footwork From the Guys
description: Bulgari

title: News Corp. Delays Spinoff of Part of Sky Global Networks
description: The News Corporation, which had planned to sell part of its global satellite businesses to the public next month, has postponed the sale because of market conditions, a person close to the company said yesterday.

title: MATSUSHITA'S PROFIT UP
description: Matsushita Electric Industrial, maker of the Panasonic brand of electronics, reported a half-year consolidated net profit of 51.4 billion yen ($473 million), up 51 percent from a year earlier. Matsushita, Japan's largest home electronics manufacturer, posted better-than-expected results for the April-September period because sales of PC's, cellular phones, electric components and other electronic products grew faster over the last six months than anticipated, the company said. The company expects to record a full-year net profit of 102 billion yen on sales of 7.63 trillion yen for the year ending March 2001. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: QUALCOMM SHARES TAKE A DIVE
description: Shares of the wireless technology company Qualcomm tumbled sharply yesterday after one of its primary customers, Globalstar Communications, missed estimates for third-quarter earnings. Globalstar's losses widened unexpectedly during the quarter. On a day that technology stocks dropped across the board in Nasdaq trading, shares of Qualcomm fell 9 percent, or $6.75, to $68.13, after falling as low as $66.31. Trading was heavy, with volume at 14 million shares. The company's shares have dropped from a high of $179.31 at the start of the year. Qualcomm develops digital wireless communication products and services. In addition to providing handsets to Globalstar, which produces global satellite-based personal telecommunications, Qualcomm was one of the company's five founding partners.

title: The Determined Troupe You Don't See; The Creators of 'The Full Monty,' Like Its Heroes, Had Something to Prove
description: It was the final audition for ''The Full Monty.'' After 72 men had been reviewed for the roles of the 6 out-of-work, out-of-shape steelworkers who decide to strip as a desperate financial gambit, the show's choreographer asked each of the dozen finalists to take off his clothes.

title: PEOPLEPC EXPANDS TO EUROPE
description: PeoplePC said yesterday that it was opening a European subsidiary in hopes that corporations and governments there would sign up to offer their employees low-cost home computers and Internet access. The subsidiary also wants to increase the number of homes connected to the Internet throughout Europe, where PC use is much lower than in the United States. The subsidiary will start operations with offices in London, Munich and Paris. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

Mr. Kinney was retired Vice President of Ordinary Underwriting Division of Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. for 47 years. Allen Funeral Home, Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Tracks Rebelling Against League
description: Just when horse racing was building to its most important event of the year, the Breeders' Cup next Saturday, 22 tracks threatened to withdraw from the National Thoroughbred Racing Association, which was established three years ago to unify the business.

title: Thomas King, 79, Who Opened Way to Cloning of Mammals
description: Thomas King, whose early research in frog embryos foreshadowed the cloning of sheep and other mammals decades later, died last Wednesday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 79 and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: Europe's Last Tyrant
description: The fall of Slobodan Milosevic has left Europe with a single dictator, Aleksandr Lukashenko of Belarus. He was legitimately elected president of the former Soviet republic in 1994, running as a 39-year-old anti-corruption crusader. But, with support from Russia, Mr. Lukashenko has since amassed near absolute powers, permitting little dissent or private enterprise. He openly admires Hitler and has said that Belarussians want him to bring back a Stalinist state.

title: Even at 6-2, Groh Seems A Most Unhappy Fella
description: Jets Coach Al Groh looked like the unhappiest 6-2 coach imaginable today. Midway through the season, the Jets are tied atop their division. But the problems that pockmarked their successful first half, only to be briefly concealed when the Jets produced a string of comeback victories, were on display in all their ugliness in their loss to Buffalo Sunday.

description: BAIKONUR, Kazakstan -- A Russian rocket carrying the first residents of the international space station blasted off on Tuesday on a mission that NASA hopes will lead to the permanent occupancy of space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, ROBERT I., M.D.
description: LEVY-Robert I., M.D. The boards, faculty and staff of Columbia University Health Sciences, The New York-Presbyterian Hospital, and The Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College of Cornell University mourn the loss of our colleague, Dr. Robert I. Levy. Dr. Levy served as Vice President for Health Sciences at Columbia University from 1983 to 1984, and as Senior Assistant Vice President for Health Sciences from 1984 to 1987. During that time, Dr. Levy was a Professor of Medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and continued as an Adjunct Professor until his death. Before coming to Columbia, Dr. Levy served as Vice President for Health Sciences, Professor of Medicine and Dean of the School of Medicine at Tufts University. Earlier, he spent six years as Director of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute of the National Institutes of Health. Dr. Levy was a respected physician, educator and researcher. He received several prestigious awards throughout his career, including the Albert Lasker Special Public Health Award for his work in promoting high blood pressure detection and control. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARL, ETHEL C.
description: PEARL-Ethel C. On October 30. Beloved and devoted aunt of Jane and Allan Rosenberg. Great aunt of Leslie and Stuart Berman; Rick and Robyn Rosenberg, and Doug Rosenberg. Great great aunt of Evan and Natalie Berman. Lovingly remembered by nephews Leonard Jacobs; Alan and Barry Pearl and families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENKINS, LEIGH RAND
description: JENKINS-Leigh Rand. Teacher and friend. Her light will continue to shine within the hearts and minds of her colleagues, students and friends. The Department of Design for Stage and Film Tisch School of the Arts New York University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZECA, LINCOLN J, SR., ''LINK''
description: HERZECA-Lincoln J, Sr., ''Link'', passed away peacefully in the early morning of October 28, 2000 at the age of 85. Link, a professional engineer, was a proud graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and served during World War II as a Captain in the Army Corps of Engineers in Alaska and the European theater. Link's motto, ''if you are going to do something, do it right'', was pursued avidly whether in the design and construction of various types of aircraft and buildings, sailboat racing or vegetable gardening. Link will be lovingly remembered by Josette, his wife of 54 years, sons Lincoln Jr. and Christian & their wives, Luz Angela and Lois, his two grandchildren, Jane and Nicholas, and additional family and friends.

title: COMPANY TO SPLIT REGULATED FROM UNREGULATED UTILITIES
description: The American Electric Power Company, which owns utilities in 11 states and in Europe, said it would split its regulated utilities from its less-regulated businesses, creating two wholly owned companies. The separation resembles plans the company has already filed for units in Ohio and Texas as part of efforts to open the power market in those states to competition, the company said. It also said it had ruled out merging Seeboard, a natural gas and power distributor it owns in England, with Yorkshire Electricity, a British utility it partly owns. American Electric is based in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, ZACHARY
description: SCHNEIDER-Zachary. Of Springfield, NJ. Beloved husband of Marylin. Devoted father of Mark, Mindy, Jay and David. Cherished father-in-law of Elisa Leib. Dear brother of Eddie and Morris. Services Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, NJ, Tuesday, 11 AM. Donations to Congregation Israel of Springfield or the Leukemia Society of America would be appreciated.

title: Seeking Wisconsin Votes, Gore Sounds Populist Note
description: Power to the people was Al Gore's cry today as he trundled across the fading emerald farmland of Wisconsin in his ongoing struggle to blunt the appeal of Ralph Nader and keep traditionally Democratic states in his column.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARSON, SIEGEL, YEMIMA
description: KARSON-SIEGEL-Yemima. Beloved wife of Benjamin Siegel and the late Leon Karson. Loving mother to Esti and her husband Eli, Gil and his wife Lisa, and the late Ronnie. Cherished grandmother of Karen, Noa, Ari, Zachary, Laura & Jeremy. Dear sister to Drora, Esther and the late Aaron. Caring stepmother to Leslie and Seth and his wife Rachel. Devoted step-grandmother to Jason, Samantha, Alana, Sam and Talia. She was greatly admired for her indomitable spirit and her commitment to her family, Israel and Jewish education and culture. She was a great teacher and friend who touched the lives of many and was loved by all who knew her.

title: Up-Close Look at a Potato-Shaped Space Rock
description: Scientists have taken their closest look yet at the asteroid 433 Eros, maneuvering a robot spacecraft to within three miles of its rocky surface to see details of its battered origins.

title: Venezuela Will Sell Cuba Low-Priced Oil
description: Capping a five-day state visit by President Fidel Castro, the governments of Cuba and Venezuela sealed a de facto economic and political alliance today, signing an agreement for Venezuela to supply one-third of Cuba's oil needs at cut-rate prices.

title: Lazio Sought to Make a Legislative Mark in Housing
description: Nothing in Representative Rick A. Lazio's career gives him greater pride than his record on housing.

title: Democrats Ask Nader to Back Gore in Swing States
description: Liberal Democrats have begun an aggressive campaign to urge Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate for president, to endorse Vice President Al Gore in important swing states. At the same time, many of those liberals have ratcheted up their criticism of Mr. Nader, saying he is not interested in abortion, gay or civil rights.

title: G.E. and the PCB's
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, TAMAR
description: WEBER-Tamar. July 3, 1910-October 30, 2000. We celebrate the life of a remarkable woman. Mother of Jessica and Mark. Mother-inlaw of Alan Peckolick and Karen. Grandmother of Jordana and Valerie. Widow of Wally Weber. Graduate of Wellesley/'31. Tam traveled the world in her later years with an insatiable curiosity and love of adventure that will be her legacy. She was smart, inquisitive, and loved to share her knowledge and experiences with those who were privileged enough to have known and loved her. Memorial servies will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 65 Street and Fifth Ave. at noon on Thursday, November 2. Contributions in her memory may be made to Temple Emanu-El or the Wellesley College Fund, Wellesley, MA. She was truly an original.

title: For Congress From Connecticut
description: Senator Joseph Lieberman dominates political discussion in Connecticut. His name appears twice on this year's ballots -- as a candidate for re-election to the Senate and as the Democratic vice-presidential candidate. Mr. Lieberman's unwise decision to take up two ballot lines should not, however, be allowed to overshadow other important races that deserve equal attention from voters. Here are our endorsements for three especially crucial Congressional races in the state.

title: At Risk: A Drug Warning for Black Patients
description: The National Institutes of Health is advising blacks who take calcium channel blockers for hypertension to consult their doctors about a study that found that the medicine increases the risk of kidney failure for some patients.

title: Bush Has Advertised More in California Than in Swing States
description: Gov. George W. Bush spent more money on television advertising in California last week than in any of the swing states, where he is believed to stand a better chance of winning on Election Day, a new study shows.

title: Creative Executives Switching Agencies
description: Two leading creative executives are taking new posts.

title: In Missouri, Campaign Flourishes After the Death of the Candidate
description: For the moment, at least, it appears Missouri may elect Mel Carnahan as its next senator, even though Mr. Carnahan, the state's popular governor, died in a plane crash two weeks ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARSEL, ADAM BRETT
description: BARSEL-Adam Brett. On October 28, 2000. Beloved son of Richard and Rhonda Barsel. Brother of Allison and Lori Barsel. Cherished grandson of Jean and Harvey Good, and Ely and Janet Barsel. Beloved grandson of the late Adele Barsel. Adored nephew of Jeffrey and Pam Good, Bonnie and Barry Ivler, Debbie Barsel and Barbara Good Aal. Loving cousin of Nikki, Jason and Melissa Good, and Ilysa Ivler. Contributions in memory of Adam may be made to the Adam Brett Barsel Memorial Fund, Hewlett School District, or to the Lawrence School District Scholarship Fund.

title: Metro Business Briefing; ZAGAT'S CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Zagat Survey in New York, the purveyor of information about restaurants and night life, said yesterday that it had named Amy B. McIntosh as its first chief executive since the company was founded by Tim and Nina Zagat in 1979. Ms. McIntosh, who had been group president at Verizon's Internet and data services division, has five years of Internet, technology and marketing experience at Bell Atlantic and 11 years in senior marketing and operating roles at American Express.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNICK, HELEN LAST
description: CHERNICK-Helen Last. Formerly of Monticello, N.Y. Wife of the late Jack Chernick. Mother of Alice, Andrew, Miriam Israel and Bonnie Epstein. Grandmother of Adina, Rina, Ben, Gila, Hilah and Ariel. Died on October 29 in K'far Saba, Israel. For more information call 212-866-0386.

title: Welcome Back to the Latin Quarter (in 3-D)
description: Like it or hate it, it is impossible not to marvel, at least for a moment, at the obsessive detail of the production of ''La Boheme'' that Franco Zeffirelli mounted at the Metropolitan Opera in 1981, and which returned for the first showing of the season on Saturday evening. The very first stage picture makes Mr. Zeffirelli's aims clear enough: the bohemians' cluttered garret sits on a line of weathered Parisian rooftops, many of them with bent chimneys pouring smoke into a slate sky.

title: Fiber Optic Agreement in Japan
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. outlined its plans today to build a nationwide fiber optic network in Japan and roll out high-speed Internet and data services to corporate clients.

title: Excuses, Excuses
description: Working in the Brooklyn South narcotics unit of the Police Department, Detective Edward Murphy has heard his share of lame excuses and bold lies. But few top the ones he took in at the Yankee parade as he manned a police barricade at Reade and Church Streets, where he and his co-workers kept latecomers from trying to cross over to Broadway to see the parade.

title: Charting Terrain on an Internal Landscape
description: THE UNABRIDGED JOURNALS OF SYLVIA PLATH: 1950-1962

title: Jeanne Lee, 61, Jazz Singer Who Embraced Avant-Garde
description: Jeanne Lee, one of the great jazz singers in the avant-garde tradition and a teacher of singing, composition and movement, died on Wednesday in Tijuana, Mexico. She was 61.

title: SHELL TO BUILD IN CHINA
description: After 12 years of waiting, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group signed a contract for a 50 percent stake in a $4 billion petrochemical complex to be built on China's southeast coast. China's state-run New China News Agency said that construction of the joint venture would begin in 2003. It will be the biggest foreign investment in China. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: NETZERO, Westlake Village, Calif., named Gerald Popek chief technology officer, succeeding Ronald T. Burr, who continues as president. Mr. Popek recently held the same post at CarsDirect.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, STEVEN ADAM, M.D.
description: COLE-Steven Adam, M.D. Dear colleague & friend. A heroic battle to the end. A model for us all. We will miss you. Rest in peace. Lynn Burkes, M.D. Marvin Leifer, M.D.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIER, CAROLA S.
description: TRIER-Carola S. 87, on Saturday, October 28. Wife of the late Edgar. Aunt of Pat and Paul Weiler. Devoted and generous friend of many. Service Tuesday, October 31, 11:15 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St.

title: LATIN COMPANIES MERGE MEDIA HOLDINGS
description: Ibero American Media Partners, a joint venture between the Venezuelan media giant Cisneros Group and the private equity firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, plans to merge with a Latin American Internet portal, El Sitio, to integrate the companies' media holdings. The resulting company, Claxson Interactive Group, will be composed of the pay television provider Cisneros Television Group; Ibero American's largely Chilean broadcast television and radio assets; and El Sitio, which has operations in the United States and six Latin American countries. Stockholders will receive one common share in CIG for each El Sitio share. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Support for a Moratorium In Executions Gets Stronger
description: Rod Autrey, a Republican city councilman here, is a supporter of the death penalty in a state where it has long been entrenched. But even in reiterating that support, Mr. Autrey urged the Council in September to approve a resolution favoring a moratorium on executions in North Carolina. The Council adopted the measure, which calls for a two-year halt while steps are taken to ensure that capital punishment is administered justly.

title: Martians Landing on Earth? If You Mean Bacteria, Maybe
description: Each year, scientists estimate, a ton of fist-size and larger rocks from Mars land on Earth, and of those, a few make the trip quite quickly, in as little as one year.

title: Spending Rise By Consumers In September
description: Spending by the nation's consumers surged last month and federal farm payments increased incomes, suggesting demand for goods will grow in the months ahead, government figures showed today.

title: From Backwater to Boom Town; Dublin Is a Magnet for Technology and Young People
description: Sitting at a computer crowned with a soft toy shaped like the Eiffel Tower, Olivier Barre spends the day counseling French customers, in their own language, on high-ticket purchases of I.B.M.'s wares to be delivered in France.

title: Vote Trading Via the Net A Twist for Democracy
description: In a case of grass roots meets back room, a handful of Web sites have sprung up in last few weeks promoting the notion that supporters of Vice President Al Gore and Ralph Nader barter votes and even giving them a forum to do so.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Ancient Morsels

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KORN, JACK
description: KORN-Jack. 6/18/10-10/31/94 Forever remembered and loved by his family

title: The Buccaneers' Victory Is Worth at Least a Thousand Words
description: Minutes before the Buccaneers met the Vikings on Sunday, Tampa Bay wide receiver Keyshawn Johnson found Minnesota cornerback Robert Tate. Johnson got right in Tate's face and without hesitation said, ''I'm going to hurt you today.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHENSON, WALTER
description: SHENSON-Walter. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Walter Shenson, and send condolences to his family.

title: Early Detection of Infant Deafness Is Vital
description: Deafness is the most common disability present at birth. Every year, 12,000 American babies are born with moderate to severe hearing impairment and another 12,000 are born with lesser degrees of hearing loss.

title: Profit Shows Sharp Rise At Pharmacia
description: The Pharmacia Corporation said today that its third-quarter profit rose 61 percent on increased sales of the painkiller Celebrex but that earnings growth would slow this year and next. Its shares fell 3.7 percent.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It would be a waste of my time. He's one of the most stubborn people in the United States.''

title: Amid All the Fondness, Perhaps a Few Farewells
description: Joe Torre might have been a Hollywood producer in a previous life, having demonstrated an appreciation for drama, a singular moment. After Torre summoned Derek Jeter and others to the microphone at the Yankees' parade yesterday, he closed by calling on Paul O'Neill and David Cone, together.

title: Decoding the Candidates
description: Next week voters will consider two major candidates for president who have spent many months talking to them. The voices and messages are familiar enough by now. But what has also become clear is that one of these two men has fought a long and losing battle with the English language.

title: Red Storm's New Point Guard Is Thinking Final 4
description: The freshman Omar Cook, who is expected to make plenty of headlines this season for St. John's, began making them yesterday.

title: Rent-Way Irregularities May Affect Results
description: Rent-Way, which operates a chain of rent-to-own stores, said it had suspended its controller, Matthew Marini, and had begun an investigation into accounting irregularities that could hurt fourth-quarter earnings and lead to the restatement of its fiscal 2000 results. The company's president and chief operating officer, Jeffrey Conway, has relinquished his duties to assist in the investigation, which is being conducted by the audit committee of the company's board, outside lawyers and PricewaterhouseCoopers, the company said.

title: WINN-DIXIE TO PURCHASE 106 STORES FROM JITNEY-JUNGLE
description: Winn-Dixie Stores, the sixth-largest grocery chain, agreed to buy 106 stores from the bankrupt Jitney-Jungle Stores of America for about $85 million, expanding its reach in Mississippi, Alabama, Louisiana and Florida. Winn-Dixie, which is based in Jacksonville, Fla., said the purchase includes 72 grocery stores, 32 gas stations and 2 liquor stores. Separately, Winn-Dixie will buy the stores' inventory at prices to be negotiated, a company spokesman said. The 106 stores generate about $650 million in annual sales, and account for more than half of Jitney-Jungle's locations.

title: Perry Waived As the Nets Keep Ollie
description: After much agonizing, the Nets waived Elliot Perry yesterday. The ninth-year backup point guard has a $2.8 million guaranteed salary this year. Perry came to the Nets as part of the Stephon Marbury trade in March 1999.

title: Trapped In Subway, Missing The Parade
description: The triumphal parade was underway. Helicopters were hovering. Paper was pouring from the skies. And there was Yusra Awawdeh, standing practically in the middle of Broadway.

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINLES, MAX D.
description: WEINLES-Max D. Of Scarsdale, NY, on October 30th, 2000 at the age of 85. Beloved husband of Frances. Devoted father of Roslyn and Steven, and father-in-law of Elliot. Loving brother of Sylvia Jacobs and Rae Rendelstein. Service Tuesday, 2:30 PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ROSE
description: GOLDBERG-Rose. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Rose Goldberg, beloved sister of our dedicated Trustee, Dr. Edward and Sisterhood past President, Florence Zornberg. Deepest sympathy to them, children, Marcia Greenberg and David Goldberg, and the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Flurry of Ads and Speeches In Last Week of Senate Race
description: With just over a week before Election Day to attract voters in a tight race, the New York Senate candidates released a flurry of new advertisements as they traveled through parts of the state mining for votes among women, Catholics and the elderly.

title: Just Like the Mountains, Without the Heartburn
description: Surprise is not on the menu of ''Borscht Belt Buffet on Broadway.''

title: Patching Up Morale at the World Trade Organization
description: Nearly a year after violent demonstrations in Seattle disrupted the World Trade Organization's meeting of ministers and shredded its image, the group's leader, Mike Moore, is still trying to pick up the pieces.

title: Arafat Vows Defiance After Israeli Helicopter Strikes
description: GAZA, Oct. 31-- Palestinian President Yasser Arafat vowed defiance on Tuesday after Israeli helicopter missile attacks on three of his Fatah faction's headquarters and said he would go on fighting for an independent Palestinian state.
