title: GREIF AGREES TO ACQUIRE A FINNISH PACKAGING BUSINESS
description: The Greif Brothers Corporation agreed to buy the industrial packaging business of Huhtamaeki Van Leer Oyj, the world's biggest maker of plastic and paper containers, for $620 million in cash and assumed debt. The deal would double the size of Greif, a 123-year-old packaging company based in Delaware, Ohio. Greif has been buying packaging businesses in recent years to strengthen its North American business and its industrial shipping container and corrugated container operations. Huhtamaeki, based in Espoo, Finland, has been trying to sell the unit, which is the world's largest maker of steel drums, since it acquired the business last year as part of its $1.2 billion purchase of a Dutch rival, Royal Packaging Industries Van Leer N.V.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, EDITH K.
description: ANDERSON-Edith K. McCagg, widow of Richard N. Anderson, on October 29, 2000 after a long illness bravely borne. Service at Calvary Church, Stonington, CT, Friday, November 3, 2 PM.

title: Microsoft Tries to Keep 9 From Filing Briefs in Antitrust Case
description: The Microsoft Corporation asked a federal appeals court today to forbid nine organizations and individuals who support the government antitrust suit against the company, including America Online, to file court briefs in the case.

title: Safety: The Case for Trying Penicillin Again
description: Even if patients have had reactions to penicillin in the past, they may be able to take it again, safely, according to an article that calls for more widespread use of a skin test for the allergy.

title: Success in Diet and Exercise
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigation Leak Led to Mobsters' Plots to Murder, U.S. Says
description: Members of the DeCavalcante crime family in New Jersey learned last November about pending arrests through a leak from an investigation and plotted to kill mobsters they believed were cooperating with the investigators, according to a federal prosecutor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, JONATHAN P.
description: ALTMAN-Jonathan P. John, you were a one and only. We will miss you and will always think of you when we hear the ''Irish Tenors.'' Our condolences to your family, Cyndy, Sara, Zelda and Carol. You will not be forgotten. Lesley and Bill Collins

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIMPFHEIMER, JACQUES D.
description: WIMPFHEIMER-Jacques D. Of Stonington, CT, husband of Louise, father of Donald and James. Donations to Stonington Library, Stonington, CT, American Red Cross, Hospice of S.E. CT, or Jockey Club Foundation. For information, Dinoto FH, Mystic, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKMAN, IRVING
description: BECKMAN-Irving. Of Washington Twp, N.J. on October 29, 2000. Beloved husband of Valerie (nee Blumenthal). Devoted father of Jocelyn Murphy and the late Robert Beckman. Dear brother of the late Laurie Friedman. Cherished uncle of Leslie Li. Loving grandfather of Max, Josh and Sarah. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 402 Park St, Hackensack NJ, Wednesday, 1 PM. Should friends desire, contributions to the Leukemia Foundation or Mt. Sinai Medical Center N.Y., would be appreciated.

description: They tried to feign excitement, to wear the smiles of pride that scores of teenage truants and baseball nuts brought to the victory parade.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COULOUCOUNDIS, EMMANUEL J.
description: COULOUCOUNDIS-Emmanuel J. On October 30th, 2000 at age 74. Beloved husband of the late Cleopatra. Loving father of John and Sonya. Cherished grandfather of Emmanuel and Michael. Dear brother of Elias and Mary, Maria and Ulysses, Basil and Claudia, Nicholas and Maria. Devoted son-inlaw of Eleftheria. Friends may call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral services at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 319 East 74 Street, Friday 11 AM. Interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 120 Wall Street, 19th Floor, New York, NY 10005.

title: Letters: Extinctions as Old as Time
description: To the Editor:

title: BAA'S PROFIT RECOVERS
description: With retail sales growing for the first time in a year, BAA P.L.C., Britain's and the world's biggest airport operator, said second-quarter profit rose 27 percent. BAA's revenue from stores at airports like Heathrow and Gatwick, which once accounted for half its sales, were badly hit in the year-earlier period after the European Union outlawed duty-free shopping for travelers within the Union. The company said net income for the quarter that ended Sept. 20 increased to $201 million. BAA shares rose as much as 2.7 percent, to 579 pence. BAA runs 15 airports around the world and is trying to take over Kennedy International and La Guardia in New York. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, PAUL ''SONNY''
description: BERGER-Paul ''Sonny''. Died peacefully at home on October 29. World War II Navy veteran. He will be lovingly remembered by his children and their spouses, his grandchildren, brothers and sister, sister-in-law, aunt, former wife, nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. His family will receive visitors at his home on November 4, 2000, from 1:00 PM to 6:00 PM. His family has requested that those wishing to honor him make donations to the Lynbrook Lions Club or the Hospice Care Network.

title: VITAL SIGNS: AT RISK; For Black Patients, a Drug Warning
description: The National Institutes of Health is advising blacks who take calcium channel blockers for hypertension to consult their doctors about a study that found that the medicine increases the risk of kidney failure for some patients.

title: National News Briefs; F.D.A. Reconsiders Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration is re-evaluating the drug Lotronex because of serious side effects and five deaths among women taking it for irritable bowel syndrome, agency officials said yesterday.

title: Article 2000103191879578462 -- No Title
description: FOND DU LAC, Wis., Oct. 30  Power to the people was Al Gore's cry today as he trundled across the fading emerald farmland of Wisconsin in his ongoing struggle to blunt the appeal of Ralph Nader and function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } Both Candidates Turn Negative in the Race for New York Senate

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, VIVIEN
description: LEVINE - Vivien. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, N.J. mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Jeffrey R. Parker, President

title: Kosovo Voters Side With the Rebel Who Took the Path of Peace
description: Ibrahim Rugova, the Kosovo Albanian who led his people on a 10-year campaign of peaceful protest for independence from Serbia, was confirmed today as the winner of the elections held on Saturday. His party won 21 of 27 contested municipalities.

title: PROFIT UP AT SPANISH BANK
description: Profit at the leading Spanish bank, Banco Santander Central Hispano, grew 36 percent in the first nine months of the year, aided in part by increased earnings from Latin America, where economies are improving. The company said that income rose 1.64 billion euros, or $1.4 billion, and that profit from its Latin American operations was up 64 percent, to 721 million euros. Banco Santander has invested $12 billion in Latin America, where it is the No. 1 bank in assets and competes with a Spanish rival, B.B.V.A. Benjamin Jones (NYT)

title: Clinton Gets Secrecy Bill
description: A bill that would greatly tighten the secrecy of government information has been sent to President Clinton, and administration officials said there was division over it. Page A24.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE DROPS. Coffee dropped as rain fell in Brazil, easing drought concerns about the world's biggest crop. In New York, coffee for December delivery fell 2.1 cents, or 2.8 percent, to 73.5 cents a pound.

title: A CONFIDENT BUSH SAYS HE CAN WIN CALIFORNIA'S VOTE
description: Gov. George W. Bush hurtled today into the stretch run of the presidential race, making a high-profile visit to California instead of the more closely contested states in the Midwest and portraying his opponent as a man who practices the ''politics of division.''

title: BARNESANDNOBLE.COM LOSS GROWS
description: Barnesandnoble.com, the No. 2 Web-based bookseller in the United States, said its third-quarter loss more than doubled as it spent to improve service. Sales rose 58 percent on demand for Harry Potter books and college textbooks, but the loss widened to $48 million, or 33 cents a share, from $21.9 million, or 15 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose to $74.1 million from $47 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial put sales at $69.8 million. Barnesandnoble.com began selling videotapes and digital video discs in the quarter, and is also offering electronic books and Internet access to radio stations as it escalates competition with Amazon.com, the top Internet bookseller. Barnesandnoble.com also reached an agreement with Yahoo to be featured on its shopping pages. The Barnes & Noble book chain, and the German media company Bertelsmann each own about 40 percent of barnesandnoble.com.

title: State Legislative Candidates Strongly Support Reform of Court System, Survey Finds
description: Court reform advocates, hoping to nudge forward their campaign to repair New York's creaky court system, say they now have on record strong support from the state's legislative candidates.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN -- Denver, Chicago, Little Rock, Ark.

title: CIGARETTE SMUGGLING INQUIRY
description: British authorities said they would investigate claims in British and Brazilian newspapers that British American Tobacco P.L.C., the maker of Lucky Strike and other brands, had smuggled cigarettes. The Department of Trade and Industry said the inquiry was in response to a call by a parliamentary panel. B.A.T. said it was ''disappointed'' with the development but would cooperate with investigators. Investors shrugged off the inquiry as B.A.T. shares rose as much as 2.8 percent, to 495.5 pence, adding to its gains over the last year.

title: Ferreting Out the Legal Rights of the Poor
description: DON'T think of Douglas H. Lasdon, please, as a do-gooder lawyer.

title: A New Transplant Frontier: Intestines
description: More than a year ago, doctors told John S. Williams that they had run out of ways to help him.

title: PEP BOYS CLOSES 38 STORES AND 2 DISTRIBUTION CENTERS
description: Pep Boys-Manny, Moe & Jack, a major retailer of auto parts and service, closed 38 unprofitable stores, about 6 percent of its total, and 2 distribution centers as part of a restructuring plan to cut costs. About 1,500 jobs were eliminated, 1,200 at the closed stores and warehouses and 300 by reducing the number of supervisors and consolidating store-support centers. Pep Boys said it took a $60 million pretax charge in its fiscal third quarter for the reductions, which it expects will result in annual pretax savings of about $70 million.

title: Clinton Protests Early Release of Interview
description: President Clinton said today that Esquire magazine violated an agreement with the White House when it decided to publish a lengthy interview with him before the presidential election, including Mr. Clinton's contention that Republicans owe the country an apology for their failed effort to remove him from office.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 18 about ''France Moves,'' a festival of contemporary French dance to be presented at six New York theaters from April 23 to May 6, misspelled the surname of the artist whose work helped inspire one work. He was Marcel Duchamp, not Duchamps.

title: Walter Berry, 71, Opera Star Specializing in Mozart Roles
description: Walter Berry, an Austrian bass-baritone who was renowned for his lithe, richly toned interpretations of the German operatic and song repertory, died on Friday at his home in Vienna. He was 71.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGULIES, BEATRICE PRASHKER
description: MARGULIES-Beatrice Prashker. On October 29, 2000 in her 82nd year, peacefully at Calvary Hospital, Bronx, New York. Beloved and loving sister of Ruth Abes, Minnie Bass and the late Abraham Prashker. Adored aunt, great aunt and great-great aunt to many. She spent her life quietly seeking to help and comfort those in need. She will be dearly missed by everyone she touched. Graveside service Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York, Tuesday, 31st at 11 AM.

title: Decoding the Candidate
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Next week voters will consider two major candidates for president who have spent many months talking to them. The voices and messages are familiar enough by now. But what has also become clear is that one of these two men has fought a long and losing battle with the English language.

title: Court Backs I.R.S. on Credit Card Data
description: A federal judge ruled today that the Internal Revenue Service might force an American Express unit and MasterCard International to release information on their American customers who have accounts in three Caribbean countries.

title: Therapy Can Aid Weight Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Vision of CUNY As a Contender In Select Fields
description: For years, there has been talk about elevating one or two colleges of the City University of New York to flagship campuses with research capacity, prestige and drawing power like that of the Berkeley campus of the University of California.

title: Yanks' Parade of Numbers: Dollar Signs Followed by 0's
description: Now that their 26th World Series title is secure and another parade is over, the Yankees can look ahead to next season, and wonder who will televise their games.

title: Market Place; Nasdaq, Dow and New Principles of Physics for Wall Street
description: The stock market soared yesterday. It also plunged.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; When Counseling Makes Matters Worse
description: Counseling sessions known as debriefings, in which health professionals seek to lessen the effects of traumatic events by encouraging emotional expression, have been increasingly common.

title: Patterns: When Counseling Makes Matters Worse
description: Counseling sessions known as debriefings, in which health professionals seek to lessen the effects of traumatic events by encouraging emotional expression, have been increasingly common.

title: A Tough Day to Meet a Hero, Charm an Officer or Control a Kilt
description: Just like everybody else along the route of the Yankee victory parade yesterday, Gary Pavan used his lung power to try to get some attention from his favorite players.

title: Robert I. Levy Dies at 63; Studied Cholesterol
description: Dr. Robert I. Levy, a former director of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute whose research helped link cholesterol levels with heart disease, died of pancreatic cancer on Saturday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 63 and lived in Morristown, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day last Tuesday about the opening of Hotwire.com, an online airline ticket service, misstated the practices of Priceline.com, a competitor. Its users propose a price they are willing to pay for tickets and must buy them if Priceline can match that price. Priceline does not require users to bid for seats and accept the lowest fare offered.

title: Into the Final Week, as Political Passions Flare
description: To the Editor:

title: Blase About the Boom
description: Some Democrats and pundits can't figure out why Al Gore isn't getting a bigger bounce from the Clinton era's boom economy. The implication is that the vice president isn't politically deft enough to capitalize on this huge advantage.

title: Nissan Reports Solid Profit For Half-Year
description: The Nissan Motor Company reported a solid half-year profit today, the first evidence of a turnaround in the carmaker's fortunes since Renault of France rescued it from insolvency last year.

title: Prudential Closes a Unit
description: Prudential Securities confirmed yesterday that it was closing its institutional fixed-income business, but would keep its retail business intact, in a move expected to result in about 400 layoffs. The decision by Prudential followed market rumors and newspaper reports late last week that the company's Newark-based parent, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, would cut back its bond business and possibly sell its retail business to another firm.

title: Into the Final Week, as Political Passions Flare
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Host Steve Allen Dies at 78
description: Steve Allen, the versatile entertainer who created the "Tonight" show for NBC in 1953 and was widely regarded as a founding father of the late-night talk show, died Monday night at his son's home in Encino, Calif., his family said today. He was 78 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENLEAF, CRAWFORD ALDEN
description: GREENLEAF-Crawford Alden. Of Palm Beach, FL, died Saturday, October 28, 2000 after a sudden illness. Mr. Greenleaf was preceded in death by his wife, Ruth Mabee Greenleaf on March 16, 1990. He is survived by his daughter, Linda L. Mitchell; his son, Charles R. Lachman, Jr.; and three grandchildren, John Charles Mitchell, Christina and Georgina Lachman all of NY. Funeral Services will be held in Palm Beach, Tuesday, October 31, 2000. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the Elizabeth Glaser Pediatric AIDS Foundation, 2950 31st Street, #

title: Magazine Group Agrees to Buy About.com
description: Primedia, the magazine conglomerate controlled by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, agreed yesterday to buy About.com, one of New York City's largest Internet companies, for $690 million in stock.

title: Brain Folds
description: Q. What do brain wrinkles have to do with how smart you are?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKEL, HARRY
description: JACKEL-Harry. Of Glen Rock, NJ. On October 30, 2000. Husband of the late Shirley. Father of Joan S. Polk. Grandfather of Sylvia Woodman and Alexander Polk. He was a retired postal worker for the Grand Central Post Office in New York. He retired from Forbes Magazine as a mailroom employee. He was an editor for the New Renaissance Literary Magazine. Funeral services Wednesday 12PM at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West) Fair Lawn, NJ. Donations to the Parkinson Foundation.

title: BCE MAKES BID FOR TOP CANADIAN LONG-DISTANCE COMPANY
description: BCE Inc., the largest telecommunications company in Canada, said it would pay 35.71 Canadian dollars a share in cash and stock for Teleglobe Inc., the country's No. 1 international long-distance telephone company. BCE, once known as Bell Canada, will pay 10 Canadian cents and 0.907 shares for the remaining 77 percent of Teleglobe that it does not already own, it said. The final price of the offer is based upon the average trading price of BCE shares in the 10 days before Oct. 25. BCE is buying Teleglobe, which is based in Montreal, to expand its international telephone network for electronic commerce and data services. Teleglobe, which has lost money in four of the last five quarters, said in August that it would cut about 17 percent of its work force to save about $140 million a year.

title: The Week in Science: Evolution May Come Sooner Than Believed
description: One of the biggest unknowns in evolution is the rate of speciation, meaning the time it takes for one species to split into two.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday tracing major acquisitions and divestitutes by AT&T since its breakup in 1984 omitted two companies. In 1994 AT&T acquired McCaw Cellular, which became the basis for its wireless phone business. In 1998 it bought I.B.M.'s Global Network business, which has become an important part of its business services division.

title: Finding Order in Rainfall
description: To the Editor:

title: A Detour Into Naughty For Last Season's Nice Girls
description: Does naughty fashion need a spanking? That was the impression some people took away from the recent round of international collections for spring 2001, which concluded earlier this month. In the aftermath of runway shows in New York, London, Paris and Milan, much ink was spilled about a designer revival of punk, of ratty styles from the benighted 1980's, of ''Flashdance'' clothes and ruching -- as though, weary of imitating Upper East Side ladies, women were hankering for an opportunity to dress up as Jennifer Beals in a set of cafe curtains.

title: Flurry of Ads and Speeches in Last Week of Senate Race

title: WACHOVIA WILL BUY REPUBLIC SECURITY FOR $344 MILLION
description: The Wachovia Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Republic Security Financial Corporation for about $344 million in stock to expand in Florida. Wachovia plans to pay $7 in stock for each share of Republic Security, issuing 0.1245 to 0.1521 share for each, an 18 percent premium to the closing price on Friday. Wachovia, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., is the fourth-largest bank in the Southeast, with 700 branches and assets of $72 billion. Republic Security, the parent of Republic Security Bank, is based in West Palm Beach, Fla., and has 99 branches, all in Florida, and assets of $3.4 billion.

title: The Man That Almost Got Away
description: Even after three decades of autobiographical plays by gay writers, Brian Belovitch's ''Boys Don't Wear Lipstick'' stands out for the elegance of its writing -- not to mention the disciplined good humor that Mr. Belovitch and his director, Keith Greer, have developed for his performance of this one-man show. The challenge was to develop a character of sufficient strength and allure to divert an audience from imposing its own imagination and emotions on this unusual story, and Mr. Belovitch as a character in his own history keeps an admirable control over us for an hour and a half.

title: The Big City; Standing Fans Of the Opera Mourn Queen
description: FOR once, everybody had a seat when the music began at Lincoln Center. It was ''Entrance of the Gods Into Valhalla,'' the Wagnerian strain chosen to begin the memorial service for Helen Quinn, also known as the Mighty Quinn, or more often, the Queen of Standees at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Vital New Jersey Race for House Is Neck and Neck
description: Those who live amid the horse farms and fast-spreading subdivisions of central New Jersey could be forgiven for not knowing who represents them in the House of Representatives. Since 1996, voters in the 12th Congressional District have had to remember the names of three different men working on their behalf in Washington.

title: Telecommunications Giants Think Smaller
description: Just more than a year ago, British Telecommunications was under fire for, of all things, having too little debt. Analysts urged the former state-run monopoly to borrow money and make acquisitions to keep pace with its competitors. So it bought minority stakes in two mobile phone operators, SmarTone Telecommunications in Hong Kong and LG Telecom in South Korea. It also invested in Cegetel, the French telecommunications group, and in Airtel Movil of Spain.

title: Canadian Scientists Glower as U.S. Scientists Play in Frozen North
description: As Canadian soldiers hoist duffel bags from troop transports at a gravel airstrip here, a large red maple leaf signboard greets the new arrivals with the words, in English and French, ''Proudly Canadian.''

title: Marbury Hopes to Take Nets to the Next Level
description: When the Nets' practice ended in Continental Arena on Saturday, a technician, as if on cue, suddenly shut the lights off and warmed them up again as a test.

title: Article 2000103192082378257 -- No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  Liberal Democrats have begun an aggressive campaign to urge Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate for president, to endorse Vice President Al Gore in important swing states. At the same time, many of those liberals have ratcheted up their criticism of Mr. Nader, saying he is not interested in abortion, gay or civil rights.

title: Into the Final Week, as Political Passions Flare
description: To the Editor:

title: Tricky Liaisons Down the Garden Path
description: American Ballet Theater

title: STONE ENERGY TO BUY BASIN EXPLORATION FOR $458 MILLION
description: The Stone Energy Corporation, an independent oil and gas company based in Lafayette, La., agreed to buy Basin Exploration, a competitor, in a stock swap valued at $380 million based on closing prices yesterday. Stone will also assume about $48 million of Basin's debt. Both companies are active in the Gulf of Mexico. The deal will increase Stone's oil reserves by about 54 percent and its daily production by 50 percent. Basin stockholders will receive 0.3974 share of Stone for each share of Basin, and Basin's chief executive, Michael Smith, will join Stone Energy's board, Stone said.

title: Kamensky Has Bruised Kidney
description: While more than half the Rangers fanned out over the metropolitan area to visit primary schools yesterday, Valery Kamensky was at the doctor's office, where X-rays showed he has a bruised kidney.

title: A Chess Match Is Waged for a World Title Whose Authenticity Is Challenged
description: For chess enthusiasts the match being played in London between Garry Kasparov, the world's top-ranked player, and Vladimir Kramnik, the No. 2 player, is the most significant since Mr. Kasparov last put his world championship title on the line, in 1995.

title: Congressional Investigators Cite Safety Violations at Nursing Homes
description: Congressional investigators said today that they had found widespread violations of federal health and safety standards at nursing homes in Texas, New York, New Jersey, Illinois and California.

title: Goals Are Still Flowing for the Devils
description: Seven goals on the first 10 shots of a hockey game is a nightmare for goaltenders and coaches but a delight for fans. The Devils trailed the Florida Panthers, 4-3, tonight before their game was 11 minutes old, but things settled down after that and the Devils emerged with a 6-5 victory in overtime.

title: HONORING THE CHAMPIONS: A City's Rite of Autumn; Yankee Fans Paint the Town in Pinstripes Again
description: Once again, the city all but carried them on its shoulders up Broadway yesterday, as police officers parted the crush of their admirers and sanitation workers swept debris from their path. And once again, hundreds of thousands of people took off from work and school to jam Lower Manhattan, throw fists of confetti and holler themselves hoarse, all in their honor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBIN, MORRIS
description: SOBIN-Morris. Passed away on Friday, October 27, 2000. Of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Roslyn Heights, NY. Loving husband of Doris and the late Ruth. Devoted and cherished father of Louise Sobin Hersh (Bob). Adored grandfather of Philip (Lara) and Joshua Sivin. Beloved brother of Rose Simon and Edward Sobin. Past president of Fresh Meadow Country Club. Former president of Olympic Radio and TV and Pilot RadioTV. Former COO of Regent Sheffield Inc. Former director of Lear Siegler Inc. and Suburbia Federal Bank. He set an example of hard work, responsibility, sense of humor, zest for life, and fierce love of his family. His legacy will continue for generations to come. Interment Tuesday, October 31, at 3 PM, at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. Memorial contributions, Sass Foundation for Medical Research, 1025 Northern Blvd. Suite 302, Roslyn, N.Y. 11576.

title: ETOYS REPORTS LOSSES AHEAD OF HOLIDAYS
description: The Internet toy retailer eToys said yesterday that it had a net loss of $41.8 million, or 33 cents a share, for its second fiscal quarter, ended Sept. 30, compared with a loss of $32.1 million, or 27 cents a share, in the second quarter a year ago. The company lost $45.4 million, or 37 cents a share, in the first fiscal quarter. Net sales for the quarter were $26 million, a 95 percent increase over sales for the period a year earlier. The holiday season is expected to be crucial for the online toy industry, which has already suffered several casualties, as eToys squares off against a partnership between Toys 'R' Us and Amazon.com. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: In Need of Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Arabs See Brothers' Deaths as Israeli Escalation
description: For the Palestinian residents of this hardscrabble village, the shooting deaths here of two brothers in a confrontation with Israeli soldiers was proof that Israelis no longer hesitate to pull the trigger on unarmed civilians.

title: Playwright Takes Aim At Soulless Television
description: ''A Place at the Table,'' a new play imported from London, where it was first produced earlier this year, has the sophisticated gloss of British satires best exemplified by Tom Stoppard's ''Real Thing.'' The playwright, Simon Block, has provided rapid-fire dialogue that relishes wordplay, ambitious characters bent on self-justification in morally ambiguous circumstances, and a contemporary setting that stirs together the elements of art, the media and commerce into arch social critique.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRODE, MURRAY
description: GRODE-Murray. Great Neck Synagogue notes with sorrow the passing of its long time member and extends its condolences to his entire bereaved family. Dale Polakoff, Rabbi Dr. Ephraim Wolf, Rabbi Emeritus Howard Wolf, President

title: Barak Wins Support and Launches Strike Against Fatah
description: As violence again penetrated the heart of contested East Jerusalem, Prime Minister Ehud Barak stood at the helm of a crumbled government today and reopened Parliament after a three-month recess in which the Israeli-Palestinian reality underwent seismic change.

title: Supreme Court Accepts Case That Challenges Prison Law
description: There is no dispute in a new Supreme Court case that a four-year-old federal law ordinarily requires state and federal inmates to take their complaints about prison conditions through the prison system's grievance process before filing suit in federal court.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday listing the Yankees' 26 World Series championships misidentified the National League team that lost to them in 1996. It was the Atlanta Braves, not the San Diego Padres.

title: Both Bush and Gore Fight to Win the West

title: A Week to Go: Franks and Corzine in a Hotter Race
description: Jon S. Corzine opened his last full week of campaigning for the United States Senate today with a three-county swing through South Jersey that he described as part of a ''real chase'' for independent and undecided voters.

title: Corrections
description: The Religion Journal column on Saturday, about efforts by some Texas Baptists to end contributions to the Southern Baptist Convention because of its conservative policies, misstated the name of the denomination's Texas organization. It is the Baptist General Convention of Texas, not the General Baptist Convention.

title: Chebet Pulls Out of the Marathon
description: After losing two to three weeks of training time because of an illness, Joseph Chebet of Kenya will not defend his title in this year's New York City Marathon, withdrawing yesterday from Sunday's race.

title: The Flying Horse Is Seeking a Flying Finish
description: It was cold, the night temperature dipping into the 30's, and it was dark when Neil Drysdale led him from Barn 41 at Churchill Downs onto the almost empty stage where the colt reigns as the star of the Breeders' Cup.

title: MIKRON HOLDING TO ACQUIRE AXXICON
description: Mikron Holding A.G., a Swiss phone-parts maker, agreed to buy the Axxicon Group of the Netherlands for 91 million euros ($50.4 million) as well as an unidentified American company to form one of the top producers of plastic molds. Mikron will pay 26 euros in cash for each Axxicon share, 20 percent more than Friday's closing price, and assume 20 million euros in debt. Mikron, which earlier this year sold a milling-machine unit to focus on plastic parts, has said it aims to double sales within two years. Axxicon, which on Friday had a market value of 59 million euros, and the other acquisition would add 190 million Swiss francs ($106 million) to Mikron's annual sales of more than 500 million francs.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SAFETY; The Case for Trying Penicillin Again
description: Even if patients have had reactions to penicillin in the past, they may be able to take it again, safely, according to an article that calls for more widespread use of a skin test for the allergy.
